column2: The Timken-Detroit Axle Company, which announced on April 10 that it had adopted an "interim dividend" policy, issued yesterday a statement saying that while it intends to pay out as much of its earnings as the cash position will allow before the year ends, the directors believe it would be unwise to reduce the cash holdings until they are able to make a better estimate of the results for the full year.

With consumer buying at some stores reaching the largest proportions recorded this year, retail sales moved strongly upward this week in all of the leading cities, except in the strike-affected centers, the average gain being from 4 to 6 per cent over the figures for the previous week, according to the review issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

Governor Murphy today warned "irresponsible" leaders of the power strike which darkened almost every home in the Saginaw Valley Wednesday and paralyzed industry for more than seventeen hours that he was inquiring into means of singling them out for prosecution.

The Illinois Supreme Court laid it down as law today that a tunnel is non-taxable because it is intangible. The County Treasurer tried to collect taxes on the Chicago Railway Company's tunnels under the river.

Opposition to the use of ferryboats to supplement classroom instruction in the New York City high schools, authorized last Wednesday by the Board of Education, was expressed yesterday by members of the Board of Superintendents.

Olympic swimming pools which were open last Summer to all races and nations now are closed to Jews of any nationality. They had been opened with the coming of warm weather for the use of the general public. Over the main entrance, however, now is a large placard reading: "Entrance Prohibited to Jews."

Miss Lorraine Emerson Barlow, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Main Barlow of Greens Farms, was married here this afternoon in Trinity Church to George Emil Kirsten, son of Mrs. George E. Kirsten of Greenfield Hill and the late Mr. Kirsten.

Miss Ora Otis Worden, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Charles Beatty Worden of Princeton, was married here this afternoon to James Miles Hubball, son of Samuel William Hubball of Pasadena, Calif., and Vancouver, B. C., and the late Mrs. Hubball, at the home of the bride's parents.

Dr. Alfred E. Stearns, Headmaster Emeritus of Phillips AndoverAcademy, told the thirty-six members of the graduating class of the Pawling School today that habits of mind were more important than habits of work.

Amplifying a report made several days after the death on July 1 of Dr; John Wyckoff, dean of the New York University Bellevue Medical College, in which it was announced that he had succumbed to "coronary arteriosclerosis and general visceral congestion," that Medical Examiner's office yesterday said that Dr. Wyckoff's case had been established as a suicide.
About 125 members of the Bond Club of New Jersey gathered yesterday at the Yountakah Country Club, Nutley, N.J., for their annual Spring Outing.

American Labor party support for Mayor La Guardia was urged last night by Magistrate Charles Solomon at a meeting of the Centre Six Club, Bronx organization of the party, at its headquarters, 2,514 White Plains Avenue.

Ontario residents saw a strange sun today. It appeared in varied shapes and varied sizes across most of the central part of the Province, Some centers reported merely that there was a ring around the sun, but Peterborough citizens saw a rainbow, and for a time the center of the heavenly body was black.

Two old rivals, Yale and Princeton, will open the fifteenth annual intercollegiate outdoor polo championship this afternoon when their teams will ride against each other on Morris Memorial Field, Governors Island, starting at 2 o'clock.

WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP).--Vice President Garner named Senator Byrnes of South Carolina today to head a special committee to investigate unemployment and relief. The inquiry, proposed by Senator Hatch of New Mexico, was voted yesterday.

The Warner Brothers will become active as play producers in London this Fall, it was learned yesterday. The brothers will be associated in the new enterprise with O'Bryen, Linnit Dunfee, English agents and theatrical producers.

Dr. Samuel T. Arnold, dean of the undergraduates at Brown University, has been appointed dean of the college, effective July 1, President Wriston announced this morning. The change will give Dean Arnold more responsibility for academic matters in the undergraduate college for men.

Stocks declined gradually and closed lower in quiet trading; turnover, 722,121 shares. Bonds firm and mixed in dull session; transactions, $7,338,600. Curb Exchange Market fractionally lower; 208,420 shares traded.

Miss Joyce H. Bullard, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph H. Bullard of Brooklyn, was married last night to Daniel L. Merritt, son of Mrs. Wilbur Beach, also of Brooklyn, and the late Ralph Merritt. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Frank M. Townley in St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church, Brooklyn.

The Rev. Dr. G. Campbell Morgan, pastor of Westminster Congregational Church, Buckingham Gate, London, is passing a brief vacation in the United States. Dr. Morgan and his wife will sail for home on the Queen Mary on June 23.

Contracts with the Southern Kraft Corporation, a subsidiary of the International Paper and Power Company, were signed yesterday by Governor Richard W. Leche of Louisiana, covering a Kraft paper mill to be built at Spring Hill, La., at a minimum cost of $6,000,000.

Mr. and Mrs. Charles V. Bossert of the Hotel Bossert, Brooklyn, have announced the- engagement of their daughter, Miss Isabelle Taylor Bossert, to Edward Peter Ruddy, son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Ruddy of Forest Hills, Queens.

With the good wishes of even his political opponents, Premier Paul Van Zeeland set out from here this evening for the United States, where he will receive an honorary degree at Princeton and will visit the White House as "the messenger of Europe."

A general strike of 1,200 employes of all city departments was called for 5 o'clock tomorrow morning at a mass meeting of about 1,000 city workers here tonight, William Kane, chairman of the executive committee of the workers, said.

Confidential copies of the Governrment Reorganization Bill by Senator Robinson, the Democratic leader, disclosed today that it proposes several major modifications in the program recommended by President Roosevelt.

The Interstate Commerce Commission today authorized the Houston Belt and Terminal Railway Company to issue $3,600,000 of first mortgage 3 1/2 per cent bonds to be sold at par and the proceeds used for meeting the maturity on July 1 of a like amount of first mortgage thirtyyear 5 per cent gold bonds.

Sceneshifter, Brooklyn, Moonton and Melodist, leading local candidates for 3-year-old honors now that War Admiral and Pompoon are out of training, will meet this afternoon in the $8,000 Shevlin Stakes, mile feature at the Aqueduct course.

The Interstate Commerce Commission today authorized the Houston Belt and Terminal Railway Company to issue $3,600,000 of first mortgage 3 1/2 per cent bonds to be sold at par and the proceeds used for meeting the maturity on July 1 of a like amount of first mortgage thirtyyear 5 per cent gold bonds.

Sceneshifter, Brooklyn, Moonton and Melodist, leading local candidates for 3-year-old honors now that War Admiral and Pompoon are out of training, will meet this afternoon in the $8,000 Shevlin Stakes, mile feature at the Aqueduct course.

Stifling the protests of representatives of organized labor, the City Council, at a stormy special meeting tonight, voted six to one to grant to Mayor Lionel Evans broad powers for upholding law and order here during the present steel strike.

Paul Dawson Eddy, director in New York of the International Council of Religious Education and executive director of the Religious Education Foundation, has been elected president of Adelphi College, Garden City, L. I., to succeed Dr. Frank D. Blodgett, who will retire July 1 after more than twenty-two years of service.

Mrs. Hazel Martelle of Hartford won the twentieth annual Connecticut Women's Golf Association championship tournament on the Brooklawn Country Club links today, defeating Mrs. P. C. Barney of Farmington, 7 and 6, in the thirty-six-hole match for the title.

Despite Mayor La Guardia's opposition to salary restorations for appointive officials earning $5,000 a year or more, the Board of Estimate favors full restorations and some increases over the salaries paid before emergency cuts were made, it was learned at City Hall yesterday.

Nothing developed yesterday to lift the bond market out of its current state of lethargy, even the announcement of the basis of allotments of the new Treasury securities failing to cause a ripple of enthusiasm in the market for
The Tigers extended their winning streak to five games today by defeating the Red Sox, 6 to 5, although Bob Grove struck out eleven Detroit batters.

Newtown High School's stalwart band of athletes lived up to expectations last night by capturing the city team championship at the thirty-fourth annual Public Schools Athletic League's senior high outdoor track and field championships at Randalls Island Stadium.

The two-story building at 169-04 Hillside Avenue, Jamaica, Queens, was sold by Johanna and Anton Roefs to the Home Realty Corporation. It was held at $30,000 and was sold for cash over the first mortgage of $10,250. Brunswick, Praver Nassof were the brokers.
Elderly persons suffering fractures and other ills not absolutely requiring

The golfers in the open certainly had a fine day for it. There was just breeze enough to keep everybody cool under a bright sun. The Oakland Hills course was in grand shape. There were wild flowers blooming profusely in the lush growth between the fairways and native birds were singing merrily among the trees.
A truckload of angry farmers escorted three men described as C. I. O. organizers from picket lines at the Perry Knitting Company today and ordered them to "get out of town and stay out."
Two more WPA projects totaling $131,742 have been approved, to begin soon, in Atlantic County, according to George R. Swinton, district director.

SUNSHINE on gleaming sand and the boom of the sea as it marches up the shores of Long Island, New Jersey, Connecticut, and points even farther afield--therein lies the magic of Summer to the millions who spend their working hours cramped in our metropolitan area.
Fellowships and scholarships totaling $16,225 were awarded by Harvard University today to thirty-one students from all parts of the country. The recipients were:

EZIO," a three-act opera by Josef Myslivecek, the Eighteenth century Czech composer, whom Mozart called "the Divine Bohemian," was given its Czech premiere recently, under the direction of Professor P. Dedecek, by the opera department of the State Conservatory of Prague.
Extensive records of discussions concerning Russia in the Supreme Council at the Paris Peace Conference, including reports of a number of conversations among President Wilson, David Lloyd George,
W. B. Stratton of 522 Fifth Avenue, New York, filed today with the Interstate Commerce Commission a plan of reorganization for the St. Louis-San Francisco Railroad Company.
THE crusades, as we now look back upon them, were not many but one--one recurrent movement, one intermittent war dragging on for two centuries.

Dr. Paul R. Maloney, estate of Beatrix K. Robinson at Lloyd's Neck, L. I.; Harland W. Meistrell, broker. Robertson L. Cleveland, at 1 Iroquois St., in the Apawamis section of Rye, from Charles E. Reutter; Edward V. Siedle, broker.

The alien population, estimated at about 4,250,000 persons, is now the smallest since the early days of the Republic. It will become less, say officials, as aliens here become naturalized and new immirants are debarred.
The George E. Keith Company has declared a dividend of $1 on the preferred stock on account of arrears. On Nov. 5, last, a dividend of $1 was paid on this stock.

SALZBURG. DESPITE the uncertainty which has prevailed for several months regarding the likeliness and the feasibility of erecting a new festival theater in Salzburg as suggested by Toscanini or else partly reconstructing the present Festspielhaus, so as to improve the stage and other facilities, a plan for alterations of the existing house has been elaborated by Dr. Franz Rehrl, Landeshauptmann of Salzburg.

Miss Elizabeth Hubbard, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Crescens Hubbard of this city, was married to Clifford Lee Lord, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Clifford Lord of Mount Vernon, tonight in the Presbyterian Church here. The Rev. Hugh W. Hubbard of China, an uncle of the bride, performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Dr. Thomas F. Watkins. the pastor.

Mental ability does not deteriorate with age, Dr. Irving Lorge, Teachers College psychologist, declares in a report on adult learning appearing in the current issue of Educational Trends, official publication of the Northwestern University School of Education.
Circuit Judge Allen C. Southern borrowed a shotgun and stood guard today over a crew remodeling a home he owns in suburban Independence, his own protection against building strike sympathizers.

Still in the grip of a habit started in 1883, R. Masujima, 80-year-old lawyer of Tokyo, arrived at Pier 16, Brooklyn, yesterday on the Nippon Yusen Kaisha motor vessel Noshiro Maru for his thirty-seventh visit to the United States.

Resettlement of additional thousands of Puerto Rican families, including many small farmers whose homes and crops were destroyed by the hurricanes of 1928 and 1932, is the "next step" in the extensive program of economic improvement proposed by Governor Blanton Winship, the Interior Department announced today. It is estimated that 500,000 acres of farm land are available for the purpose.

Twenty students of Maryknoll Seminary here of the Catholic Foreign Mission Society of America, who have completed their courses, will be ordained at exercises in the seminary on Wednesday morning, it was announced today.

A nation-wide campaign to raise $12,500,000 for the University of Pennsylvania in entering upon its third century will be started on Oct. 18, with ceremonies in Philadelphia and more than 200 other cities.

Inscribed on the great white Postoffice Building in New York may be found this legend: "Neither Snow Nor Rain Nor Heat Nor Gloom of Night Stays These Couriers From the Swift Completion of Their Appointed Rounds."

The fifth Philadelphia Horse Show for Juniors took place today at Wissahickon Farms. Heading the committee which arranged the show were the Misses Julia Pemberton Morris, Louise Mellor and Anna W. Ingersoll.

Three organizers for the Amalgamated Garment Makers Union, a C. I. 0. affiliate, left Washington late yesterday upon the advice of Chief of Police Harry Opell after a crowd of about 300 men and women gathered in front of their downtown hotel.

NEW YORK has its "Black Watch" when Summer comes. Black becomes almost a uniform for the smart. One can fall into line in it in the early morning, for afternoon dress parade it's just the thing, and when it comes to full dress at night it's perfect.
WHEN Mr. Edward Shanks set out to write his critical biography, "Edgar Allan Poe," he must have had before him the well-known passage from Lowell's "A Fable for Critics":

AFFEN PINSCHERS Winners, Bitches and Best of Breed--Mrs. Henrietta Proctor Donnell Reilly's Lila v. Zwerglental. AIREDALE TERRIERS Winners, Dogs, and Best of Winners--Sid Perkins's Cotteridge Brigand. Winners. Bitches--Guy W. Walker Jr.'s Llanispa Princess Pam. Best of Breed--S. M. Stewart's Ch. Aislaby Joceline of Shelterock.
Gilbert Hunt of Washington and Bobby Harman of Berkeley, Calif., fought their way to the final round of the Pennsylvania lawn tennis championship today.
Governor Murphy sent troops ana State police to Monroe, Mich., to prevent any conflict at today's steel strike mass meeting, which he himself may attend. Page 1.

Wall Street has greeted the Lea bill with outspoken resentment mixed with no little ridicule. Bankers declare that the measure, which is the outgrowth of Securities and Exchange Commission investigations of reorganizations, is unworkable, will prevent qualified persons from engaging in protective committee activities, will pile up costs to shareholders and will substitute the judgment of Washington bureaucrats for individual initiative.

In the event that consumer resistance to higher clothing prices continues during the Fall, many retailers are planning to take smaller mark-ups if they cannot get price adjustments from manufacturers, according to comment by store executives here yesterday.
THERE is a notion in some quarters that painting portraits is a more "artistic" occupation than painting landscapes.

A two weeks' nation-wide strike by Mexico's industrial petroleum unions of the vertical C. I. O. type, carrying with it important political and economic complications, has just ended; but the vital problems that the walkout created remain to be solved.
Gold production of the Province of Quebec is running substantially higher than in the early part of last year, according to production reports issued by the government.
Flag Day will be celebrated here tomorrow with patriotic exercises and parades in parks and other public places. A few organizations will hold -their ceremonies today

Marshall Eldredge, winner of last month's outboard marathon down the Hudson from Albany to New York, is to join the group of American drivers going to Europe for the Spreckels race at Paris and other speed-boat regattas.

HOLLYWOOD. AN unlooked-for result of the restrictions and regulations placed on the industry by the agreement between studios and the Screen Actors Guild is the death of the short-money action films which are made for the Main Streets of America.
The second anniversary of the signing of the so-called peace pact between Bolivia and Paraguay finds peace more distant than on June 12 1935.

AS we watch the annual tide of American youth moving out of the colleges ready to take the places of the veterans who have fallen out of the older ranks, it is natural that we should ask ourselves what kind of boy and girl our melting pot is producing and whether the type is changing.
With a scared, wet man on his back, Clinton Pronto, husky, young farmer, climbed twenty-five feet up the inside of a well today, gripping wet stones with hands and feet, to save his farmhand.

Wholesale rug prices can be expected to rise at least 5 per cent and perhaps as much as 7 to 10 per cent when new lines are offered here early next month, mill sales executives and volume buyers agreed yesterday.

THE Federal Music Project's Composers Forum - Laboratory concluded its second season last week before ?? audience of record size and enthusiasm, and plans are under way for the third. While Ashley Pettis, the laboratory's director, hasn't settled everything as yet, he has settled one rather important bit of business:

Golf-Ralph Guldahl scored a three-under-par 69 on his last round to win the national open title with 281, the lowest total ever made in an open championship, here or abroad. Sam Snead finished second with 283 and Bobby Cruickshank third with 285.
Of great technical interest and far-reaching effects for the development of aviation in the Americas will be the Pan-American Aviation Conference to be held at Lima, Sept. 16 to 23.
Newton (Bucky) Jacobs, pitching ace who hurled three no-hit, no-run games for the University of Richmond this Spring, has signed a contract to join the Senators this season.

Howard Lindsay purchased from Miss Anne Sherman Hoyt the threestory house on a lot 21.8 by 94.10 feet at 50 West Eleventh Street through Frances Spencer, Inc., who also sold the three-story dwelling at 81 Charles Street, formerly known as 16 Van Nest Place, for Mrs. Sylvia Caviglia to Roger Briggs.

Considerable similarity exists between. the housing problem -in the United States and that of Great Britain, Captain Richard L. Reiss, British housing expert, points out in his book, "British and American Housing," which will be released June 21 by the National Public Housing Conference, the publishers.

The world's Gaelic football championship will be at stake this afternoon at the Yankee Stadium when Ireland's champion Mayomen take P on New York in the third and deciding game of their series. The battle is expected to draw a crowd of 50,000.

The possibility that the Lea bill to amend the Pure Foods and Drug Acts will be reported in the House of Representatives this week has encouraged the industries affected to hope that the legislation will be disposed of at this session.

Persons in need because money held in trust for them by the city was invested in mortgage certificates that now are worthless are to be assisted to the extent of some $40,000 a year under a plan worked out by Mayor La Guardia, it was explained yesterday. About $1,500,000 in trust fund money was invested in such mortgage certificates.

The Shell Transport and Trading Company, Ltd., in its report for 1936 issued yesterday, shows a net profit of [Pound]5,983,456 after expenses, directors' fees and other charges. This is equal to 21.5 per cent on the [Pound]24,121,361 of ordinary stock outstanding, after the 5 per cent first preferred and 7 per cent second preferred dividends.
Ted Bruce, veteran right-hander of Dartmouth, came back today after one day's rest to close his college career in brilliant fashion by defeating Maryland, 3-1, before a commencement throng.

Internal dissension has shaken the Townsend empire, and events during the next few weeks may determine whether the grandiose movement that emanated from the brain of a once obscure California physician is destined to perish or to survive.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates being June 11 unless specified: At New Haven: Badger, Tattnall. At San Diego: Kalmia, Marblehead. At San Francisco: Nitro, June 12; Tennessee. Acushnet, at Naval Operating Base, Norfolk, June 12. Brooks, Oakland to Puget Sound Yard.

Soon the American flag will be seen again on the Seven Seas, and 'in the hold of every vessel there will be American-produced commodities on the way to all parts of the world, if the promise of President Roosevelt and Joseph P. Kennedy, chairman of the United States Maritime Commission, is carried out.

The marriage of Miss Anita Friedman, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph Friedman of 53 West Seventythird Street, to Mark Apfel, son of Mrs. Rebecca Apfel, also of this city, took place on Tuesday at the house of the bride's parents. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Sidney Goldstein.
Charles D. Maginnis of Boston has been elected president for 19371938 of the American Institute of Architects, 386 Fourth Avenue, it was announced yesterday.

As its first step in the building of a merchant marine naval reserve of 5,000 officers and 35,000 men, the Navy Department will sponsor a two-week training cruise for 70 officers and 120 seamen from Atlantic ports next Fall, it was announced yesterday.

Bathing suits for little children are just as pretty this season as those designed for their mothers. For the first time shops are offering something very different from the clumsy suits hitherto made for youngsters.

A record that had withstood repeated onslaughts for more than a generation fell by the wayside yesterday in the Junior Metropolitan A. A. U. track and field championships at Castle Hill Park as the 22year-old standard for the javelin throw was shattered by the amazing performance of William Footrick of the New York Athletic Club.
The Rev. and Mrs. James Thornton Lodge of 59 Montclair Avenue have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Constance Lodge, to John Stanley Dey, son of Mr. and Mrs. William P. Dey of Newark.
Land which once was utilized by Asheville Barney, financier, as a country estate has become the site of four modern six-story apartment buildings.

Commencement processions winding across the campuses of a thousand colleges from coast to coast this month will follow academic traditions laid down in the seventeenth century in New England, when the college graduation was an event of the year for the whole community.

Backed up by the splendid pitching of its star southpaw, Joe Dooley, Jamaica High School's powerful nine regained the city championship yesterday when it blanked James Madison High, Brooklyn champion, by 6-0. The teams met in the final-round play-off in the annual P. S. A. L. tournament at Jamaica Stadium in Queens.
PROFESSOR BUCK'S book opens a new field of interest in the history of the United States since the Civil War. Most writers on the period,

Miss Natalie Tyng, daughter of Mrs. Francis Edmonds Tyng of 419 West 118th Street and the late Mr. Tyng, will be married to John William MacRae, also of New York, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Hugh Frazer MacRae, on the afternoon of June 26 in the chapel of St. George's Church, Stuyvesant Square, where the bride-elect's great-grandfather, the late Rev. Dr. Stephen H. Tyng, was rector for many years.

The firing of the New York State Rifle Association and the New York National Guard units was concluded at Camp Smith here today with the running off the final stage of the State match and the naval militia and naval reserve interstate match.
Although it is likely enough that the coming army and navy budgets will be larger than the current year's, those budgets have not yet been drafted.

Robert Moses, Commissioner of Parks, made public yesterday an exchange of correspondence with Colonel Brehon Somervell, Works Progress Administrator, in which the latter was criticized for refusing to approve eight hours' overtime payment for eight relief workers under the jurisdiction of the Department of Parks.

Faced with the prospect of a vast expansion in population and in building activity in their community, civic groups and citizens of the Riverdale section of New York have organized a movement to protect the residential character of the district.

Few classes of garden flowers show so many types, and bloom over so long a period, as the dianthus. Some are the hardiest of perennials while others are annuals, and the refined varieties are glorious greenhouse subjects.
Leon Trotsky, former Bolshevist leader now in exile, said tonight he saw in the execution of eight army leaders in Moscow "the beginning of the end for the Stalinist dictatorship."
IF Browning never saw his wife's "Sonnets From the Portuguese" before 1850 it is pertinent to ask how he could have arranged for their publication in 1847.
Electric washing machines and refrigerators went back into use today in Toecane, a mountain cornmunity in Mitchell County, after a consumer "strike" ended.

Without formal commencement exercises or degree, thirty young college graduates will complete a nine-month "interneship" in Federal Government departments this month, under the auspices of the National Institute of Public Affairs.
HISTORY OF BROOKLYN JEWRY. By Samuel P. Abelow. 8vo. Brooklyn. N. Y.: Scheba Publishing Company, 1,098 Park Place. $5. A history dealing largely with the past seventy years.

The Rev. Martin W. Stanton, assistant Newark diocesan director of the Society of the Propagation of the Faith, will preach the sermon at the baccalaureate mass of St. Peter's College tomorrow at 9 A. M. I in St. Peter's Church, Grand and Van Vorst Streets, here.

The steel strike is being waged over management's refusal to comply with labor's demand for a written and signed agreement between them. Below the surface of the dispute may lie other difficulties, but this is the asserted vital point at issue.

Federal and State income tax officials warned the public yesterday that failure to pay the second installment of taxes due next Tuesday would result in cancellation of installment privileges and .the imposition of fines.
BAKER-MORRIS-Mrs. Sophia E. Morris, 45 West 81st St., announces the engagement of her daughter, Muriel, to Mr. Murray Baker of New York.

ALAMEDA, Calif. THE roar of the untamed torrent, the clatter of a loosened rook, the hacking chug of the ice-axe-these are sound effects for a drama which, this year as last, is seeing many vacationists fight and puff their way to unnumbered summits in the West.

Athletes of five South American countries are due to arrive in New York on June 30 aboard the Munson liner Southern Cross. They will participate in the sports program of the Pan-American Exposition at Dallas.

To the three-century-old history of Gardiner's Island there was added another chapter a few days ago when Miss Sarah Diodati Gardiner purchased the island from Winthrop Gardiner Jr., thereby becoming the fifteenth consecutive proprietor by the surname Gardiner.

IT is time to go a-fishing. It is high time, in fact, and the best possible of times. The anglers who have already been out may have thought that they were getting the cream of the year's sport. Impetuous fellows, rushing the season, they were only, as it were, breaking the ice!

Miss Annabelle Forman Essary, daughter of J. Fred Essary, Washington correspondent of The Baltimore Sun, and Mrs. Essary, and niece of S. E. Forman, historian and author, was married this morning to Samuel Tilden Ansell Jr., son of Brig. Gen. and Mrs. Samuel Tilden Ansell of Washington.

Miss Mary Thompson Whipple, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Edward 1V G. Whipple, became the bride of o: Donald Richardson Clark, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Halford Clark t of Plymouth Avenue, this afternoon in the Third Presbyterian N Church. The Rev. Whitney Trousdale officiated.
Miss Phyllis Ames, daughter of Mrs. D. Abbott Ames of Wayland and Richard Ames, was married today to Archibald Cox, son of Mrs. Archibald Cox of Plainfield, N. J.

AS each new recording of a Mozart piano concerto sees the light one is amazed all over again at the rich resources of that inventive mind. A certain similarity of form encourages a feeling of familiarity and confidence, even in a first hearing, and yet what infinite variety there is in the detail.
Miss Edith Weed of Cathedral Avenu? gave a tea at her home today in honor of Miss Jaqueline Tompers and Dr. H. Easton McMahon, who will be married next Saturday.

OF Robert Ardrey and his "Casey Jones" the news this morning is that Herman Shumlin has bought that play about the all but legendary railroad engineer-a character which, as noted the other Sabbath, has stirred Richard Bennett to thoughts of acting again.

Joseph Stalin sent a wreath tied with red ribbon to the bier of his mother in Tiflis, it was disclosed today. It bore an inscription, in Georgian, "To my dear beloved mother, from her son, Joseph Djugashivili."

HARD BOILED as Hank Hyer appears to be, one suspects that he is merely putting on an act. He knows that it is sometimes necessary to be tough when dealing with such persons as criminals and policemen, and so he makes himself as tough as he knows how to be, but there are many occasions when he betrays a softness of heart that ill befits his hard exterior.

Yale downed Princeton, 9-2, today in the opening- of their annual baseball series, the oldest unbroken diamond rivalry among American universities. Ted Horton, veteran Eli pitcher, was highly effective, allowing the Tigers only seven hits, passing no batsman and in five innings turning back the visitors in order.

The proposed $50,000,000 new financing of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., is intended to provide for the natural expansion of the company which ordinarily would be financed out of earnings and for any contingencies that might call for greater working capital.

Miss Christine Grange, daughter of Mrs. George S. Grange and the late Rev. George S. Grange of Brooklyn, was married yesterday morning to the Rev. Charles T. Knapp, rector of Christ Episcopal Church, West Islip, L. I.
Two large new East Side apartment buildings designed for occupancy Oct. 1 or earlier are being erected by Syndicate Builders, Inc., to provide more small suites in this district.
Mrs. Edwin Binney of Binney Lake, Old Greenwich, was hostess to the Old Greenwich Garden Club yesterday afternoon, where an informal flower show took place.

With the two Hilpl brothers, Otto and Harry, turning in outstanding performances, the Crescent A. C. lacrosse team swept to a 12-0 verdict over the Montclair A. C. today, thereby revealing that it will provide considerable opposition for the All-American ten when they meet Wednesday night under the floodlights at Randalls Island.

Frank A. Rinaldi, 48-year-old druggist, was shot in the back and critically wounded shortly before midnight during a hold-up in his store at 8,002 Seventeenth Avenue, Brooklyn. He was taken to the Harbor Hospital.

George Lansbury, ardent pacifist and former leader of the British Labor party, who visited Chancellor Adolf Hitler in April and discussed ways and means of removing the causes of war, announced tonight that he was shortly visiting Premier Benito Mussolini.
Among early arrivals for the season at Saranac Inn, which opened today, were Mr. and Mrs. J. W. Moore Richardson of Ardsley-onHudson.

Adopting a number of resolutions designed to eliminate unfair trade practices and stabilize prices in the tobacco industry, the Retail Tobacco Dealers of America, Inc., at the closing session of their convention here yesterday, voted to present a memorial to President Roosevelt and other officials protesting against the "deplorable delay" in the enactment of the Miller-Tydings bill.

LONG honored as a symbol of the sea, the useful gull is under fire from officials of the Sea and Shore Fisheries Commission in Maine, who charge that sea gulls have been consuming myriads of young lobsters.

Miss Helen Quinton, daughter of Colonel and Mrs. Alfred Bixby Quinton Jr. of this city, was married to Robert Corbin Hallett of San Francisco, son of Mrs. Frank M. Taylor of Boston, this afternoon in Trinity Church. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Edward Sullivan.
Professor Stanley T. Williams of Yale University was the speaker at the Westminster School commencement exercises today on the east lawn, following the final chapel service at 11 o'clock.

For the second time in the fiftyfive years of its corporate existence, the New York Steam Corporation, originally known as the New York Steam Company, has in the last two weeks encountered a financial dilemma. This was caused by the refusal of the Public Service Commission to approve an exchange of stocks proposed by the Consolidated Edison Company.

The government has decreed that cork" can be stripped from trees only once in every nine years. The absence of restrictions heretofore had led cork growers to put an inferior quality on the market, and the decree was issued in the national interest to maintain the uniform quality of cork, the largest item in Portuguese exports.
MR. EMLYN WILLIAMS is an extremely good actor, and a playwright with imaginative Celtic blood in his veins, of whom much is to be expected.

Auction sales of art and literary property at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, Inc., during the 1936-37 season yielded a total of $2,970,997 in seventy sales, comprising 150 sessions, extending from late September to May 27.

Shipments of gold to the United States are continuing. The Deutschland sailed yesterday for New York with seventy-two cases of the metal weighing 3,600 kilograms and valued at 82,000,000 francs, and today the Europa embarked with seventyfour cases weighing 3,800 kilograms and valued at 90,000,000 francs.

With water pouring through a gaping hole in the side of the British steamer Royal Archer, 120 passengers groped their way to safety tonight aboard lifeboats and motor launches after a collision in a fog in the Thames estuary.
There is an old saying that all gardeners are divided into two groups: Those who swear by dahlias and those who swear at them.

By way of a pleasant prelude to the report of yesterday's doings at Ebbets Field it should be stated at once that Van Lingle Mungo is back at work and will pitch the first game of today's double-header, with Freddy Fitzsimmons, the new old Dodger, toeing the mound in the nightcap.

Stephen Van Culen Hopkins of 180 Maple Street, Englewood, N. J., died suddenly yesterday at his Summer home in Point-O'Woods, N. Y., of a heart attack which occurred when he became chilled after a swim.

WASHINGTON. A NEW and rigid motor vehicle A code covering 137 pages has just been made State law in Pennsylvania. Haulers of automobiles in these picturesque hay-rack affairs in which several automobiles in those picturesque hay-rack one feel the new regulations are particularly hard on them.

The engagement of Miss Louise Haxall Harris, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Morrison Harris of this city, to Richard Alvey Jamison, son of Mrs. Clifton J. Haden of Evanston, Ill., and John Vincent Jamison Jr. of Hagerstown, Md., has been announced by her parents.

The. list of prizes and scholarships for the current year at Hamilton College was announced today by President Frederick C. Ferry. The following men will be honored at the graduation exercises Monday:
Members of the Elizabeth Seton League, Inc., will give a bridge and games party on Tuesday evening at Schrafft's, 220 West Fiftyseventh Street.

Whatever may have been the hopes of British statesmen that coronation enthusiasm might be translated into practical arrangements at the Imperial Conference in London, it is now admitted, with this affair about to close, that none of them have been realized. IT is quite a job to get started when one is going on a pilgrimage to the very sacred cities of Najaf and Karbala, which rank next to Mecca in holiness.

While mystery still surrounds the exact object which Baron Constantin von Neurath, German Foreign Minister, is pursuing on his tour of Yugoslavia, Bulgaria and Hungary, its general lines can be estimated.

LUCREZIA BORI, former Metropolitan Opera soprano, will be the soloist of the fifth annual New Hampshire Seacoast Music Festival, to be held Saturday and Sunday. July 10 and 11, at Little Boar's Head, N. H.

Miss Constance Joan Butler, daughter of Mrs. William Brady of 950 Woodycrest Avenue, the Bronx, and the late Harry Butler, was married to John Gerald Fitzgerald, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Fitzgerald, also of the Bronx, yesterday morning in the Church of the Sacred Heart, 1,255 Shakespeare Avenue, the Bronx.

Miss Emily Castleman Strawn, daughter of Mrs. Emily Littlepage strawn of this place, was married this afternoon to Earle Wilson Bachman Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Earle W. Bachman of New Haven, Conn., in St. John's Episcopal Church here. The Rev. Francis Coffin, the rector performed the ceremony.

WASHINGTON. NEXT Wednesday the Public Works Administration, born in the depths of a depression and grown to prodigious magnitude in its short life of four years, will celebrate its fifth birthday. Secretary Ickes has described its job as "the largest construction program in history," and the job has been enlivened by one of the largest controversies of contemporary politics.
Creation of two Food Trade Vocational High Schools in this city is planned for the coming year, Dr. Alberto C. Bonaschl, member of the Board of Education, disclosed yesterday.
APFEL -- FRIEDMANN -- Dr. and Mrs. Joseph Friedmann, 53 West 73d St., announce the marriage of their daughter, Anita, to Mark Apfel, son of Mrs. Rebecca Apfel, on June 8.

TRACK EVENTS 120-Yard High Hurdles--Won by Paul Bunzell, New York A. C.; Leonard Eisindler, N. Y. U., second: Thomas Connell, St. Peter's College. third; John Miller. N. Y. Pioneer Club, fourth. Time-0:16.2.
The War Department released the following orders today, dated June 11: MAJOR GENERAL Reynolds, C. R., the Surgeon General two days' leave, June 16.

For two days this week groups of people here stood respectfully, silently, on the sidewalks before a mortuary. Along a Beverly Hills street a steady stream of cabs moved slowly, the occupants peering at numbers, and as one house was singled out an occasional voice could be heard above the traffic: "Look! there it is."

Miss Catherine Elizabeth Igoe, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Andrew Joseph Igoe of Brooklyn, has chosen June 30 for the date of her marriage to Dr. James Emerson Dailey, son of Mr. and Mrs. James Matthew Dailey of Olean, N. Y.

The navy submarine Salmon was launched today at the Groton shipyard of the Electric Boat Company. As the 298-foot submersible slid down the ways, Miss Hester Laning, daughter of Rear Admiral Harris Laning, shattered the traditional bottle of champagne over its bow.

An exhibit of an ideal city of 2000 A. D., with streets as utility channels running between parks formed by landscape treatment of lower terraces of buildings, is on display in the exhibition salon of the new building of the fourteen companies of the American Radiator and Standard Sanitary Corporation, 40 West Fortieth Street.

Joseph Stalin faces the gravest crisis of his rule in Soviet Russia since he succeeded Nikolai Lenin as the result of the arrest and secret trial of eight of the leading generals of the Red army and the suicide recently of Marshal I. B. Gamarnik, second in command to Defense Commissar Klementy E. Voroshiloff.

Mrs. John Boettiger of Seattie, Wash., will be matron of honor and Miss Aimee du Pont maid of honor at the marriage of her sister, Miss Ethel du Pont, to Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr., son of the President, on June 30. Mrs. Boettiger is a sister of the bridegroomto-be.

Miss Elizabeth Elliot Wilson, a daughter of Mrs. Gordon Wilson and the late Dr. Wilson, was married here this afternoon to Dr. Herbert Buddington Wilcox Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. H. B. Wilcox of New York, in Christ Protestant Episcopal Church by the rector, the Rev. Thorne Sparkman.

Miss Elizabeth Rogers Sage, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Merton W. Sage of this place, was married here this afternoon to Theron Batchelder, son of Mrs. Mabel C. Batchelder of Worcester, Mass. The ceremony was performed in Christ Church by the rector, the Rev. Harold F. Hohly.

Isadore Nagler, general manager of the joint board of the Cloakmakers Union, announced yesterday that the union's conference committee had been authorized to order a strike by 35,000 cloakmakers in this city whenever the committee deemed such a step advisable.
Mayor La Guardia last week accepted an honorary membership card in the Printing Pressmen's Union and took occasion to reiterate his sympathies for organized labor.

Miss Mary Louisa Vaillant Julier, daughter of Mrs. Arnett Vaillant Julier of New York, was married here at noon today in the chapel of the Kent School to Robert Howard Mattoon, son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Virgil Mattoon of East Orange, N. J., by the headmaster, the Rev. Dr. Frederick H. Sill, an uncle of the bride.
With preparations for completed Fall trade shows, the homefurnishings industry looks forward to its busiest season in years in the next few months.

Allegations that the executed Red Army leaders had attempted to murder leaders of the Communist party and of the government are made in a special message to the Red Army just issued by Defense Commissar Klementy E. Voroshiloff.
France turned out a full array of her chiefs of state today to wish Premier Paul Van Zeeland of Belgium success in his visit to the United States and his talks with President Roosevelt.

AMERICANS are going to stick three-cent stamps on out-of town letters for some time to come in spite of the general improvement in the operations of the Postoffice Department, according to present prospects.
Harlem River Houses, constructed at a cost of $4,500,000, will be turned over to the City Housing Authority on Wednesday by the Federal Public Works Administration.

ARNOLD Bax, the English composer, was awarded a knight hood in the recent coronation honor list. Since the announcement of this distinction a new string quartet by Bax has been broadcast in London by the Griller Quartet to whom it is dedicated.

The marriage of Miss Kate Davison Rice, daughter of Schuyler Neilson Rice of Highland Park, this place, and the late Mrs. Rice, to Roger Williams, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Whitmore Williams of New York, took place this afternoon in Christ Church here.

Eight Russian Army leaders, all in high repute until only a few days ago, have been shot for treason, the government announced early today. A terse communique issued just after midnight said only that the eight, who were sentenced Friday, had been executed yesterday.

The Misses Cornelia Schwab, Priscilla Lamb and Ida Bumstead of this city, with Miss Alica Howa of Hampton, Va., sailed yesterday on the Fort Amherst for the Labrador and Northern Newfoundland coasts, where they will pass the Summer as volunteer helpers in the work conducted in those regions by Sir Wilfred Grenfell.
Miss Catherine Beebe. daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Beebe of Rahway, was married to Raymond Michel, son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Michel, also of this city, at Hightstown today.

Only two of the seeded players, Frank Kovacs of Berkeley, Calif., and Thane Halstead of Chicago showed up for the opening of the twenty-seventh national clay courts singles tennis championship tournament today, and furnished what little excitement there was by winning their first tests.

Two Dollar liners sailed today for opposite sides of the world, the President Cleveland for Manila via Honolulu, Yokohama, Kobe, Shanghai and Hongkong, and her sister ship, the President Lincoln, for New York and Boston, via Los Angeles, the Panama Canal and Havana.
The light French cruiser D'Entrecasteaux arrived at 9 A. M. yesterday from Fort de France, Martinique, and will remain ten days at Pier 88, West Forty-eighth Street and the Hudson River.
Bennington College's second graduation took place today when fortyseven seniors received the Bachelor of Arts degree. The ceremony was marked by extreme simplicity, lasting less than half an hour.

Mrs. Felix M. Warburg will open Woodlands, her place here, on Monday for a meeting of members of the committee of the Westchester Chapter of the Women's Division of the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies of New York.

Complaining that the light under the Oakland Hills club house porch was too poor to make good pictures, photographers and newsreel men went on a "stay away strike" and refused tonight to photograph the ceremony in which the victor's cup was presented to the new open golf champion, Ralph Guldahl.
Some important dividend meetings this week by companies listed on the New York Stock Exchange follow: Tomorrow United Fruit Co, 'com. Tuesday Public Service Corp. of New Jersey, 6% pf.
MOUNT DESERT ISLAND, a Summer resort region of unique character and extraordinary history, continues to be different from any other place in the United States.

As the result of Tuesday's referendum Georgia remains legally dry but actually soaking wet. Wes Ferrell, repeatedly pounded by the White Sox when with Boston, made his debut in a Washington uniform today and held the Chicagoans to four hits for a 6-2 victory.

Miss M. Virginia Hunter, daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. John Merritt Hunter of this place, was married to Charles Wesley Jenkins, son of Mr. and Mrs. Earle E. Jenkins of Margaretville, N. Y., here this afternoon in All Saints Episcopal toN Church, of which the bride's father un is rector.
Fourteen tugs, aided by flood tide, pulled the battleship Tennessee from a San Francisco Bay mudbank late today and the vessel ancholer in her proper position thirty-one hours behind schedule.

One of the letter men on Governors Island (he had a large P, which stands for prison, on his blue denim shirt) made an unsuccessful attempt yesterday morning to escape from the Atlantic branch of the United States disciplinary barracks on the island, where he was serving a 21/2-year sentence.

Miss Joan Elizabeth Annan Rose, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Manley Rose of this place, was married this afternoon to Upton Beall Thomas Jr., son of the Rev. and Mrs. Upton Beall Thomas of Troy, Ohio.

No sufferer from false pride, the British Government is getting back some of the money it spent on coronation finery by selling off everything from the chairs the peers occupied in Westminster Abbey to the crowns that ornamented street decorations.

The Bronx Federal Savings and Loan Association, a locally organized home finance institution operating under private management but under Federal charter and supervision, will open on June 26 at 1,375 Jerome Avenue, Bronx, announces Gardner W. Taylor, president.

A long-standing feud between Westchester and State officials over the payment of Westchester Parkway costs began to flare anew this week with the submission to the county Board of Supervisors of a report stating that the county is completely at the mercy of State officials, who thus far have refused to budge an inch.

Cornell University's poloists invaded the Monmouth County Country Club today as they prepared for the intercollegiate championship and scored victories over the Monmouth County Country Club and Elberon in a fast round-robin.

IN its exhibition entitled "One Hundred Prints of the Past Hundred Years," in Room $21, the Prints Division of the New York Public Library has again afforded us a treat in black-and-whites, with occasional touches of color to heighten the variety.

NATIONAL coverage has been the main topic of recent discussions on television. It is possible that the engineers, having learned many lessons in local telecasting, are now beginning to study on a national scale. Or they may be bringing the nation-wide problem into the public forum to reveal the magnitude of the task that confronts the radio and telephone industries in building a transcontinental tele-see-system. It is no overnight job.
Lon Warneke, Cardinals' right-hander who has been blasted twice this season by the Bees, gained some slight satisfaction today by holding Boston to five hits as his mates scored a 4-1 victory.

The seventh annual Economics Conference for Engineers, which will be attended by seventy-five engineering graduates and professors of economics from thirty colleges and universities, will open Friday at the Stevens Institute Engineering camp here and will continue through June 26.

Mr. and Mrs. Herbert H. Hawkins of Hamilton have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Patricia Appleton Hawkins, to Dr. John Trolan Sill of Hamilton, son of Mr. and Mrs. Fred Sill of Watertown, N. Y.

Real estate transactions in Brooklyn announced yesterday included sales of houses by banks. The Citizens Savings Bank sold to St. John's Equities, Inc.
There was a rush of visitors such as this exclusive Summer resort seldom has seen today, drawn by the hope of witnessing some activity in the search for Mrs. William H. Parsons.

A team representing New York Naval Militia units in New York City, New Rochelle, Rochester and Buffalo today won the Interstate Naval Reserve Rifle Trophy match, closing event of match week on small arms ranges at Camp Smith.

Arrangements were made this week by the Westchester County School of Current Affairs and affiliated organizations to assign trained lecturers to inform the Westchester public regarding provisions of the Westchester County Government Act, which will come to a referendum in the Autumn.

VACATION passengers on coastwise steamships, guests on cruising yachts and holiday visitors along the seacoast often gaze wistfully at lighthouses. It seems to them that it would be idyllic to live in one;

Public sentiment, not gas bombs alone, broke the C. I. O. picket line around the Newton Steel Company's plant and ended the strike so far as the little city of Monroe, Mich., was concerned. What hapopened there on Thursday night is what the independent steel companies are bending every effort to bring to pass elsewhere in the vast region of idle men and idle facstories affected by the strike.

Sale of the Orpheum Circuit, Inc., to the Stadium Theatres Corporation, both subsidiaries of RadioKeith-Orpheum, which was approved by Oscar W. Ehrhorn, referee in bankruptcy, on Feb. 10, was upheld yesterday by Federal Judge Robert P. Patterson.

ACOUPLE of seasons ago, and in "Petticoat Fever," Mark Reed was shooting in reverse English at the White Man's Burden of a lonely wireless station in Labrador. Now he is eyeing the distaff young in "Yes, My Darling Daughter," and is doing so quite as successfully.

VARIOUS 'radio industrial and merchandising conventions, especially the meeting of the Radio Manufacturers Association during the past week in Chicago, have officially opened the 1937-38 season. The new sets are now being put on display by dealers throughout the country.

Sandwiches were substituted for picket signs yesterday afternoon as union members of Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians and their sympathizers started an all-night sit-in demonstration at the R.-K.-O. Palace Theatre in Times Square at Forty-seventh Street.

Miss Dorothy Krall, a Yale graduate school student, asserts in her studies for Ph. D. degree in sociology, that the second generation of immigrants contribute an unusually high proportion of this country's juvenile delinquents, youthful offenders and adult criminals.

IN my last article I spoke of some revivals. There are now two more; but the staging of one has such vitality and originality as almost to entitle the man who is responsible for it to rank as the author, or at least the part author, of a new work.

In answer to a question in the House of Commons last week as to whether the Spanish non-intervention negotiations were making satisfactory progress, Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden said: "I fear there is seldom anything altogether satisfactory in Spanish affairs."

Drivers of trucks carrying explosives or inflammables should come to a full stop and shift gears to neutral before crossing railway tracks, it is asserted by the bureau of safety of the Interstate Commerce Commission.

Class Day was held at Dartmouth College today, with throngs of alumni on hand. The 492 seniors wore their caps and gowns for the first time when they congregated on the campus to hear the address to the college by Cambridge G. Beckel of Huntingdon, Pa., and the class oration by William C. Clay of Mount Sterling, Ky.

The marriage of Miss Eunice Poulson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert S. Poulson of Upper Montclair, to Stanley Morton Parsil, son of Mr. and Mrs. C. Roy Parsil of Short Hills, took place this evening at a candlelight servicee in the First Congregational Church, Montclair.
RELAYED to America by Dutch stations for the past two months, Station YUA at Belgrade now employs two powerful German waves to drive its signal over the North Atlantic.

While C. I. O. leaders demanded investigation of a pitchfork attack on two of their number yesterday, eight C. I. O. women organizers headed by Miss Kathleen McInerney, said to be the daughter of a judge at South Bend, Ind., continued attempts to sign up women workers of the 1,100 employed in the Perry Knitting Mills here.
The first day of the C. I. O. strike at the huge Cambria plant here of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation passed quietly.

General Water, Gas and Electric Company and Subsidiaries-Twelve months ended April 30: Net income after interest, depreciation, amortization, Federal income taxes and other charges, $502,042, equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to $1.26 a common share, comparing with net of $376,226 or 61 cents a common share, in the twelve months ended April 30, 1936.

Four horsemen from Princeton avenged an early-season setback yesterday, defeating Yale's quartet by 7 to 3, as play in the fifteenth annual intercollegiate outdoor polo championship opened at Morris Memorial Field on Governors Island.

HOLLYWOOD. BOULDER DAM again. You marvel at the wide approaches, the perfectly banked highways that lead you to it. You stand at the top of the dam, look down more than 700 feet and the mighty spread of it leaves you dizzy.

With the exception of weakness in most of the industrial convertibles, which could be traced to the easier tone in their respective stocks, the bond market displayed a fairly steady undertone during the twohour trading period yesterday.

In one of the largest deals in re cent years involving property in the downtown financial district, the City Investing Company, of which Robert E. Dowling is president again has become the owner of the well-known Exchange Court Build ing at 52 Broadway.

KINGS Gross assets, $5,084; net, $4,602. To wife, Mary A. Bindhardt. Chief assets, mortgages, notes, cash and insurance, $3,448; miscellaneous property, $1,636. Samuel Kaufman, attorney, 51 Chambers St.. Manhattan.
Miss Eunice Dean of San Antonio, Texas, and Miss Cecilia Riegel, Philadelphia, today advanced to the finals of the women's Pennsylvania and Eastern States grass courts tennis championship.

THIS is Robert McAlmon's first book in several years. In 1920 he was one of the group of American writers in Paris. He founded the Three Mountains Press and published the now historic Contact Editions--Hemingway's first book, Miss Stein's "Making of Americans," and his own "A Hasty Bunch," "Village," "Postadolescence."

A card party will be given by the women's auxiliary of the 165th Infantry, formerly the Sixty-ninth, on Tuesday evening at the 165th Infantry Regiment Armory, Twentysixth Street and Lexington Avenue. Proceeds will go toward a fund which provides veterans in the hospitals with cigarettes, toilet articles and small gifts of cash, especially during the holiday seasons.
STARS, the moon, comets and interstellar spaces have always attracted H. G. Wells, as his scientific romances have shown.
Curtis High captured the honors in the Wagner College interschoplastic track and field meet for the second successive year yesterday at Wagner Field, Grymes Hill, S. I.

The Railway Labor law of 1926, as amended by Congress in 1934, in recent years has proved not to be the model for statutes regulating relations between employers and employes which it was expected to be, and therefore should be revised, according to views expressed in railway management circles: Numerous awards made to members of labor unions under the terms of the law are cited as inequitable by the managements in support of their contentions.

The marriage of Miss Camilla Wilson Hayward, daughter of Mrs. James Waldemar Hayward of Plainfield and the late Lieut. Commander Hayward, to Charles Julian Melville, son of Mr. and Mrs. H. S. Melville of New York and Jamaica, B. W. I., took place this afternoon in Grace Episcopal Church.

LONDON. ROM the Plymouth Hoe, where Drake, who "was a Devon man," contemplated his kingdom of blue water, a visitor can see the smoking chimneys and the stark ways of one of England's largest dockyards, busier now-like other shipyards of Englandthan at any peacetime period in its history.
MORE than one week of the season just ending would have been enriched by some of the newly opened exhibitions of early June.

Professor Albert Einstein, renowned scientist and instructor at the Institute for Advanced Study in Princeton, N. J., has leased an attractive country home of Mrs. C. A. Klots on Huntington Bay for the Summer season.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Julia Ann Reid Hutchinson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Warren Ball Hutchinson of Cherry Hall, this place, to Francis Viele Lowden Jr., son of Colonel and Mrs. Francis V. Lowden of Roselle, N. J.

James F. McLean, city cashier of Yonkers, who was suspended from duty last Thursday because of an alleged shortage of about $17,000 in his accounts, today was arrested and charged with suspicion of a PAS felony, according to the police.
HANDSHAKING: Among the changes at the White House under the Roosevelt regime is the elimination of New Year's Day handshaking and handshaking with long lines of visitors in the President's office.

A class of twenty-six will be graduated from the Hackley School here at exervices at 11:30 A. M. on Monday. The Rev. Dr. H. Adye Prichard will preach the baccalaureate sermon tomorrow afternoon. The commencement speaker will be Dr. Alfred E. Stearns, former headmaster of the Andover Academy.

IN the course of the sixty-odd round trips which the Pan American flying boats have now completed between the United States and the Philippines, a definite routine has been developed for passengers as well as crew. Yet there is so much leeway within the bounds of that routine that one might almost say the individuals' daily experiences vary as much as do the individuals themselves.

To the Editor of The New York TIMES: When I went to school, the home and school were unrelated entities. When I taught school, twenty-five years ago, the only time we saw a parent was when the father or mother of an incorrigible boy was summoned to discuss the problem,

Life insurance policies on office buildings, factories and other property are on the way, according to The Associated Press. Following the enactment of legislation in Albany in May, the Property-Life Insurance Company of America is being organized in this city.

Indiana University's medley distance relay team clipped more than four seconds off the world record for the two-and-a-half-mile event in a dual meet with Ohio State University today but the Buckeyes won, 73 to 58.

The Transport Workers Union, a C. I. O. affiliate, announced yesterday further progress in its drive to organize all of the 35,000 taxicab drivers in the city. The Atlas and Liberty Fleet Owners Association, according to Harry Sacher, counsel for the union, has agreed to hold a collective bargaining referendum among its 4,000 employes, operating some 2,000 taxicabs.

Smokeless chimneys against the late Spring sky and pickets moving outside the closed gates of silent plants symbolized last week the labor strife that has swept across the Great Lakes industrial area. Not all mills were silent, nor were all chimneys smokeless, but nearly 100,000 men were idle as life in many communities moved at half speed.

Gratifying progress in the reorganization and improvement of the prison industry systems and allied prison activities in more than twenty States was reported by the Prison Industries Reorganization Administration in a summary of its activities recently submitted to President Roosevelt and made public today.

Hanging up two new track records, Frankie Beeder, driving a Cragar Special, captured the fifty-lap feature event at the second annual Nassau County police auto racing show at the Fair Grounds track today. Close to 30,000 persons witnessed the event.

The forthcoming visit of the American battleships Arkansas, New York and Wyoming to Kiel is hailed with satisfaction. In point of tonnage it is the largest American squadron to visit the German naval port since the World War.

In one of the biggest upsets of the metropolitan season to date, Sceneshifter went down to defeat before 15,000 persons at Aqueduct yesterday as Rudie captured the $7,750 Shevlin Stakes by three-quarters of a length and paid 12 to 1.

VIENNA. STEPS are being taken here to correct what is considered the abuse of so-called "Viennese tuning" and to restore by legal means the system of international pitch which, for a number of years, has been supplanted in Vienna by a higher tuning.

Weather clear, track fast. It looked like a big heavyweight battle as the field went off in the national open championship over the Oakland Hills course today. Four big fellows were leading the parade as the third round started:

Frank B. Berry, former president of the American Type Founders Association, died here today in his eighty-fourth year. He was born in Akron, Ohio, and was a former manager of the Cleveland (Ohio) office of the American Type Founders Company.

Miss Helen G. Lindewurth, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Chester A. Lindewurth of Valhalla, N. Y., was married yesterday morning to Paul J. McCarren, son of Mrs. James McCarren of Brooklyn and the late Mr. McCarren. The ceremony was performed in St. Ignatius Church, Brooklyn, by the Rev. Joseph Murray of Philadelphia, formerly an instructor at Brooklyn Prep, of which Mr. McCarren is a graduate.
The twenty-ninth- annual conference of the Special Libraries Association will be held from Wednesday through Saturday, June 19, at the Hotel Roosevelt.

MORE than 10,000,000 persons this year will "sight-see" the cities and country of North America. Nearly 3,000,000 will ride in streamlined sight-seeing buses, and spend upward of $6.000.000.

This town boasts of a man who is believed to be the only living son of a soldier who fought in the Revolutionary War. He is William Constant Wheeler, a Civil War veteran. He is still in good health and spirits at 89.

The Chamberlain government won its second by-election today when Major J. P. Whiteley, Conservative, was elected to the House of Commons for Buckingham. Two days ago it retained the Hillhead division of Glasgow.

Six-year-old Charles J. B. Christian sailed for tiny Pitcairn Island today to claim the inheritance established more than a century and a half ago by his great-great-grandfather, Fletcher Christian, who led the crew of the British ship Bounty in mutiny.

UNTIL a few months ago there was not an experienced statesman or politician or business man or financier in Europe, and for that matter not an impartial observer of any kind, who did not believe that war, a big general war, was both inevitable and imminent.

Miss. Cecelia Marie Oelkers, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Oelkers of Newark, was married this morning in St. Peter's Church here to James Francis Brennan, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Brennan of Bloomfield. The pastor, the Rev. Matthew Thimmes, performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass.
Robert D. Coe, United States Vice Consul at Calcutta, will arrive tomorrow to join his father and stepmother, Mr. and Mrs. William Robertson Coe, at Planting Fields, Oyster Bay.

Commemorating its establishment in Ann Arbor 100 years ago, the University of Michigan is to hold a six-day celebration beginning tomorrow. Taking the title "Michigan Between Two Centuries," the program will place its main emphasis on the university's responsibility in relation to coming developments in society, government and industry.

Miss Ann Quigley, daughter of Judge and Mrs. Michael J. Quigley of this city, was married to Gordon Richard Noble, son of Mr. and Mrs. James Noble of Alexandria, Va., this afternoon in the rectory of Sacred Heart Church, Vailsburg.

LOS ANGELES. TRAVELERS with whom it is a point of pride to know the place names and aspects of resort lands like the Riviera, Switzerland, Florida and California, are going to have to hurry back to this section and re-educate themselves.

Reaping Reward, odds-on favorite of the Milky Way Stable, won the fifty-fifth running of the $15,000 added Latonia Derby today, going ahead in the last furlong of the mile and a quarter event. The victor pulled up slightly lame.
NO Sunday article today, No The lights just went out. All afternoon haze has been deepening over the mountains and sultry skies have been grumbling.
Western Union's main office and all nineteen branches in Seattle were closed today as a result of a four-day-old strike of 116 messenger boys. The messengers demand, higher wages.
Miss Jane Hare, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Russell I. Hare of Paris, was married yesterday to Delbert Johnson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Johnson of Cleveland.

A BY-PRODUCT of the motor age and of the travel urge of the American people, tourist camps have become a sizable industry, the Census Bureau reports in making public recently the results of a field canvass throughout all the forty-eight States.
When Williams College alumni return to Williamstown next week for the 143d commencement they will find closed the historic four-story, 165-room Greylock Hotel.

Gladstone Square, named for the late Benjamin Gladstone, Assemblyman from the Bronx, was dedicated yesterday afternoon. More than 1,200 persons attended the services in the square, which is at Westchester Avenue and Southern Boulevard. the Bronx.

Funeral services for Major Francis Burdett Warring, former National Guard officer and educator, who died Thursday night, were held today at his home here. The Rev. Harold B. Kerschner of the First Presbyterian Church, officiated. Burial was in Poughkeepsie Rural Cemetery.

The full Senate Appropriatibns Committee overrode the recommendations of Harry L. Hopkins, Works Progress Administrator, today and voted 13 to 10 for the Byrnes amendment to the Relief Bill which forces local governmental entities to pay at least 40 per cent of the cost of all new WPA projects.
MISS TURNER is well known for her verses on small animals, on children, on all the little things of life which amuse and please her for their essential rightness and for their self-contained lives.

Texas greeted nineteen Latin-American nations today with a Pan-American exposition to cement the goodneighbor policy. Dressed in hew splendor since last year's centennial celebration, the exposition grounds provided a vast pattern of historical commemoration, dedicated to the "amigos" south of the Rio Grande.

We print on this page today a letter from H. R. TOLLEY, the Agricultural Adjustment Administrator, concerning the Administration's farm policy and the editorial attitude of this newspaper regarding it.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Harry Howard Clutia of this place and Woodbury, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Virginia Dickinson Clutia, to H. Hugh McConnell, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Nealon McConnell of Montclair, N. J.
Secretary Hull said today the State Department has been assured by the Japanese Foreign Office that no Japanese fishing boats have been granted licenses for salmon fishing in Alaskan waters.
Business calls for college graduates this year have run well above last year, a survey of leading local colleges showed yesterday. While placement bureaus

As they set off on their homeward journeys after the adjournment of the Imperial Conference on Tuesday, the representatives of the British dominions will take with them information which has been hardly more than hinted at by the press, whose reticence has been almost like that of a Foreign Minister facing the House of Commons at question time with vague reassurances.

IN the Protestant Episcopal Cathedral of St. Anne in Belfast there is a recent tomb. It preserves what is left of one whose name in Ulster, at any rate, will not soon be forgotten. About this localized celebrity Mr. Colvin has written a three-volume biography.

Hearst Radio, Inc., operator of Station WINS, New York, has applied to the Federal Communications Commission for authority to install a new transmitter, increase power from one kilowatt to five kilowatts, change hours of operation from limited to unlimited time, erect a new directional antenna for day and night use, and move its transmitter from Paterson Plank Road, Carlstadt, N. J., to a point one mile east of Kearny, N. J.

Mr. and Mrs. John Baldwin of Norfolk, Va., have announced the engagement and approaching marriage of their daughter, Miss Cary Barton Baldwin of Washington and Norfolk, to Allen Philip Blade of Washington, son of Major I. Philip Blade, U. S. A., retired, and Mrs. Blade of San Diego, Calif.
The subject of control of electrical transcriptions and other recordings will be discussed at the annual convention of the American Federation of Musicians opening here Monday.

Stevens Institute of Technology awarded honorary doctorates in engineering and science to five men and conferred academic degrees on ninety-six graduates at the sixtyfifth annual commencement exercises of the college this afternoon at the William Hall Walker Gymnasium on the campus at Castle Point.

As leaders of 35,000 organized maritime workers of the Pacific Coast prepare to take their unions in a body over to the Committee for Industrial Organization, an increasingly bitter battle rages for control of the long-established and traditionally powerful labor movement of San Francisco.
BUT FOR THE GRACE OF GOD. By Leopold Atlas. 151 pages. New York: Samuel French. $1.50. Text of a three-act play put on by the Theatre Guild last season.
The sixth set of twins in little more than a decade was born to Mr. and Mrs. Harry Fifield of East Thompson in a hospital here today.

Leonard S. Leavy, Controller of the city and county of San Francisco, who had been a city official for thirty-eight years, died suddenly early today while walking toward his home. He was 61 years old. His widow, Frances, and a daughter survive.

The wedding of Miss Flora Belle Barclay of this city, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert F. Barclay of Malagash, N. S., to Clifford C. Beebe, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert F. Beebe of this city, took place in Plymouth Church this afternoon.
STROUDSBURG, Pa. -- Thousands are expected to arrive in the Poconos this week for the annual laurel - blossom time. From all indications, it will be one of the county's greatest celebrations.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Alfred R. Meyer of Greenwich, Conn., and Plymouth, Mass., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Janet Meyer, to Frederick Parsons Lowrey, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick D. Lowrey of Honolulu.
THE following letter bearing on the controversial subject of purchases of contemporary work by museums has been received from Milton Horn.

Fire of undetermined origin started after 11 o'clock tonight in the basement of Maurice Steisel's threestory furniture and hardware store on Glen Street, in the business district here, spread to two adjacent stores and some garages at the rear and caused damage estimated at more than $200,000.

THE trouble with the ordinary budget is that it doesn't pay enough attention to "Miscellaneous." And it is "Miscellaneous," of course, that must supply the amenities which are well symbolized as orchids. Marjorie Hillis is all for orchids, in the name of sound and sophisticated economy itself.

THERE is nothing half-way on apologetic, faint-hearted on cringing about the villainy of C. Henry Gordon--nothing venomous and Rathbonish, or pathlogical and Laughtonish, or horrendous and Karloffian, or haggard and Carridinish;
Robert Emmet Dolan has leased a nine-room Colonial house on Stanwich Lane, Greenwich, Conn., from Donald Lauder, who will spend the Summer on his maplesvru?? farm in Vermont.
State Senator Levi Lattomus Maloney, former president of the Security Trust Company of Wilmington, died today at his home at Townsend, Del., following a stroke suffered last Sunday.

Sole bargaining powers for their C. I. O. affiliated union were demanded tonight in a resolution passed by American Locomotive Company workers, who threatened to go on strike if the demand is not met by Thursday.

SALAD greens, fresh and crisp, are coming to market from near-by gardens, and those who take pride in concocting salad dressings are eagerly practicing their art, hoping always to produce the perfect combination of ingredients.

All local attendance records were broken today at the opening of the second division of judging at the flower show of the Rockland County Garden Clubs being held at the Ramapo Riding Academy.

Partly erased savings bank book numbers on the inside cover of a book entitled "The Structure of Life" led to the discovery yesterday by H. Wells Kilbourne, an attorney, that Mrs. Anna Dawson Smith, who died as a city patient at House of Mercy Hospital April 28, had deposits of $12,812 in two Pittsfield banks.

THE railroads have found a new way to figure on passenger safety. A statistician has figured out, on the record of the last seven years, that a passenger could have ridden continuously for nearly 5,000 years without meeting death from a train accident.

The oldest Christian chapel known to archaeologists, uncovered by the Yale expedition to Syria, transported- to the Yale Gallery of Fine Arts and reconstructed by Herbert Gute, a Yale art school graduate, will be shown to Yale graduates whe rurn next week for the 236th Coms-wcement.
The Soviet scientists in establishing a meteorological base in the Arctic Ocean near the North Pole show that they are as advance-minded in economic science as the U. S. S. R. is politically.

The theory that the "solution of the unemployment problem lies in the progressive shortening of hours," forcefully enunciated by John L. Lewis this week before the Joint Senate and House Labor Committee which is conducting hearings on President Roosevelt's hours and wages bill, is fundamentally wrong, in the opinion of Dr. Harold G. Moulton, president of the Brookings Institution.
