Mel Porter, veteran runner for the Millrose A. A. of New York, pounded to victory in the championship national A. A. U. marathon today.
The Securities and Exchange Commission made public today odd-lot transactions in stocks, rights and warrants on the New York Stock Exchange on June 10. The preliminary figures follow:

To the Drama Editor: As one who attended most of the sessions of the recent American Theatre Council convention, it seems to me that Brock Pemberton's somewhat explosive proposal that the producers be allowed to play. London Bridge Is Falling Down with the critics was only one of several amusing propositions placed before that solemnly self-conscious assembly.

A warning that there is no choice but to continue the policy of "protective spending" by the Federal Government unless the nation wants to risk future disastrous slumps, was given by Harry L. Hopkins, Works Progress Administrator, in an address read at commencement exercises of the Babson Institute, here today.
SOME slowing down of the retail trade spurt was noted last week in various sections of the country.

President Roosevelt will pay a visit to the 30,000 Boy Scouts who will encamp here and in Virginia from June 29 to July 10, and will probably talk with the boys from Dutchess County, N. Y., his home community.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Elizabeth Huntington Blake, daughter of Mrs. James E. Blake of 58 Gould Place, Caldwell, and the late Dr. Blake, to William H. Vogel Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Vogel of Hillcrest Road, West Caldwell.

Beating Philadelphia by 8-7 after taking a 13-2 victory over the defending Boston team on Friday, New York regained possession of the Griscom Cup, symbol of women's golf supremacy among the three cities, at the Plainfield Country Club today.
IN the field of finance the present period is characterized by what is called "easy money." This has come about as a result of government intervention to save business from the ruin of deflation.

The effects of the World War and the depression upon the occupations and outlook of Princeton University's class of 1912 are set forth in its "Twenty-five Year Record," a 300-page volume published in connection with the twenty-fifth reunion of the class which will take place next week-end.
BACHNER--To Mr. and Mrs. Max Bachner, a son. on June 12, 1937, at Park East Hospital. BATTERMAN--To Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Batterman, a daughter, on June 6, 1937, at Park East Hospital.

SOON crack rail fliers heading for Manhattan across the marshy, reed-covered Hacken sack Meadows will make no passenger stops after they leave Newark. And therein lies a story. Manhattan Transfer, where millions of incoming travelers have thrilled to the conductor's "All aboard; next stop Pennsylvania Station, New York," will pass into the limbo of forgotten landmarks.
Miss Elizabeth Wentworth Sawyer of Boston and Beaver Pond, Beverly, was married to Charles Galloupe Mixter, son of Dr. and Mrs. Charles G. Mixter of Boston, in Christ Episcopal Church this afternoon.
William House is experimenting with a "mechanical mule" which he hopes will make the no-horse farm and the one-horse town better places in which to live.

The United States pavilion at the Paris exposition will be opened the afternoon of July 4. During the opening ceremonies Ambassador William C. Bullitt will present the Commissioner General, ThomasJ. Watson, and Commissioner Frederick A. Sterling to high French Government authorities who will attend.

Miss Margery Frances Mitchell, daughter of Colonel and Mrs. William A. Mitchell of West Point, has chosen the afternoon of June 26 for her marriage to Lieutenant James B. Lampert, Corps of Engineers, U. S. A., son of Mrs. Lloyd R. Brigham of Sheyboygan, Wis., and the late Colonel J. G. B. Lampert, Corps of Engineers, U. S. A.

Two young brothers without experience in major tournament competition distinguished themselves in the invitation turf court tennis doubles fixture at the Piping Rock Club today as the starting field was cut down to the four semi-final pairs.

Acting upon instructions received from Washington, Postmaster Thomas L. Kelley of this city refused today to deliver 1,500 plain postal cards addressed to customers of the Little Falls Laundry Company of Little Falls by C. I. O. union members who are conducting a strike at the plant.

RADIO again proved its ability to flash with lightning speed away from remote places to civilization far across the horizon. From the North Pole by wireless the Russian campers on top of the world reported on how they had made soundings into the skull of the earth. Their line struck bottom at 14,070 feet. A bucket dragged along the ocean bed brought up greenish-gray silt.

New York State National Guard units will begin the Summer training season here at Camp Smith tomorrow with the arrival of the 102d Engineers of Manhattan, commanded by Colonel Frederic E. Humphreys, and the 102d Medical Regiment of Manhattan, White Plains, Rochester, Albany, Syracuse, Corning and Ticonderoga, commanded, by Colonel Lucius A. Salisbury.

Miss Lucille Hall, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Ford Hall of Merrywood, this place, was married to Burrall Barnum of New York here this afternoon in Christ Church by the rector, the Rev. Albert J. M. Wilson.

A concerted interfaith movement to boycott Germany would rout Hitler, and application of the boycott technique to Poland would curb that government's tendency to overlook the plight of minorities, Samuel Untermyer declared last night at the opening session of the twentyninth annual convention of the Federation of Polish Jews in America at the Hotel Astor.
Of the 137 sorts of fresh fruits and vegetables listed by the Department of Agriculture as available in New York some time in the course of the year, 111 are now displayed in the city's markets.

An aggressive campaign to convince the public that this country's foreign commerce not only improves domestic business but acts as insurance against war, will be launched by foreign traders this Fall, according to plans discussed informally here in the last few weeks.
The last dance of the season took place last evening at Grasslands, when Mr. and Mrs. Henry Leonard entertained for their son and daughterin-law, Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Thoron.

Contributions by employers to the State Unemployment Compensation Fund on wages paid in May are due on or before June 30, James G. Robinson, executive director of the Unemployment Compensation Commission, announced today.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Margaret Manson Weir, daughter of Mrs. David Manson Weir of this city and Steubenville, Ohio, and the late Mr. Weir, to William Prescott Bonbright, son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Bonbright of Grosse Point, Mich.

Plinio Salgado, leader of the integralista [Brazilian Fascist] party and its candidate for the Presidency, declared today that his movement was growing stronger daily, although it has been subjected to many attacks in Congress and banned by the States of Bahia and Parana.

A report submitted yesterday by Lieutenant Richard Aldworth, superintendent of Newark airport, to Mayor Meyer C. Ellenstein showed Newark had shattered all its records for commercial passengers, air mail and express in the first four months of 1937.
Americans, as usual, are doing the unusual in Spain-an impertinent flower garden sets off the hill-top entrenchments of the Abraham Lincoln Battalion fighting for the Spanish Government.

The third national organizers institute of the Young Circle League, labor fraternal youth organization and youth section of the Workmen's Circle will be held in the league center at 22 East FifteenthStreet for a two-week period beginning today.

The marriage of Miss Avis van Dyke, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Lowry van Dyke of 22 East Twenty-ninth Street, New York, to Edwin George Clemence of 2 East Eighty-sixth Street, New York, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Edwin George Clemence, took place here this afternoon in the garden of the home of the bride's aunt, Miss col Louise Townsend Nicholl.

SYDNEY, AUSTRALIA. THE stretch of telegraph line between Alice Springs and Birdum, Central Australia, has been in the news again because the husband of a woman who was desperately ill cut it to bring aid and thus saved the life of his wife.

The Ascot race meeting will open next week and the traditional royal spectacle connected with it is expected to surpass those of recent years. The King and Queen will drive in state from Windsor Castle each day. r There will be a larger number of house parties than for many years.
Amelia Earhart completed the third transAfrican hop of her round-the-world flight today, landing here after a 900-mile journey from Fort Lamy, French West Africa.

All records for new work placed with the Clyde shipyards since the war were broken in May by contracts totaling more than $90,000,000, according to a report from the American Consulate made public today by the Department of Commerce.

Mrs. Arthur Robertson Fergusson of Bryn Mayr, Pa., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Flora Fergusson, to Henry Dawson Furniss Jr. of Haverford, son of Dr. and Mrs. H. Dawson Furniss of New York and Pelham, N. Y.
President Roosevelt found opportunity tonight for a quiet chat with two Cabinet members while his yacht lay at anchor off a Chesapeake Bay island.

Belief, amounting almost to certainty, that Senator Robert F. Wagner will not permit himself to be drafted for the Democratic nomination for Mayor has caused a revival of the boom for former Supreme Court Justice Jeremiah T. Mahoney, it was learned yesterday.

Dr. Francis E. Townsend told members of his old-age pension movement today that "we are going ahead stronger than ever" despite the recent resignations of twelve executives of his national organization.

WHEREVER chess is played--and that means almost anywhere between the two Poles and perhaps on Mars-lovers of the ancient game are preparing to honor the memory of Paul Morphy, who was born a century ago, June 22, 1837.

Miss Margaret Laurie, London dressmaker, has withdrawn her slander action against General Evangeline Booth and other officers of the Salvation Army following appeals from her brother in the United States and others not to do anything likely to injure the Army.

Discussing the problem of rising labor and material costs, Myron L. Matthews of the Dow Service declares that new and more efficient construction methods seem to be the only avenue of approach to stabilize or reduce building costs. He indicates that the increases being granted to labor form the root of the problem.

Ann Wentworth Park, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Gray Park of Washington and this city, was married to Percy Smedley Darling-. ton Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Percy Smedley Darlington of West Chester, this afternoon.
The Montreal Royals won a free-hitting contest from Baltimore today, defeating the Orioles, 12 to 9, and evening the series at 1-all.
Celebration of the hundredth birthday of Mystical Seven, oldest of Wesleyan University's secret societies, will be, held on Friday, the opening day of Wesleyan's commencement.

The Dutch East Indies was the biggest purchaser of arms, ammunition and implements of war from the United States last month, its purchases totaling $2,514,194, nearly all for military aircraft, according to a report on export licenses issued by th State Department.

LATE Monday afternoon a TIMES reporter stopped off at one of those small cafeterias on Eighth Avenue (the presumption is that he hadn't been able to cash his pay check) and was interrupted in his contemplation of prunes, strawberries and fruit salads by the sight of the counterman with tears streaming down his cheeks.

Vice President Garner packed his fishing tackle today for a Texas vacation. The man who calls himself "the spare tire of the government" said that "the boss," President Roosevelt, had consented to his taking five weeks off.

Trustees of the New York Title and Mortgage Company Series B-K mortgage certificates disclosed yesterday that they were laying the groundwork for liquidation of 70 per cent of $9,000,000 underlying real estate they control.
Breaking camp here tonight to end their forty-seventh annual reunion, soldiers of the Confederacy already were looking ahead to a joint reunion with the "Yankees" at Gettysburg next June.

Mr. and Mrs. Charles J. Callan of Mount Vernon, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Anne Callan, to Charles Russell O'Brien, son of Mr. and Mrs. James F. O'Brien of Montclair, N. J.
Miss Margaret Clare Reimer, daughter of Rudolph Reimer and the late Mrs. Reimer of Brooklyn and Northport, was married here this afternoon to Charles Francis Petit of Los Angeles, Calif.

The marriage of Miss Arley Pistor, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George E. J. Pistor of Upper Montclair, to Olin Henry Timm, son of Mrs. Henry Timm of Dixon, Calif., took place tonight at the Montclair Heights Reformed Church. The Rev. Elwood Erickson officiated.

Philip Ricci, 28 years old, was being held in Middlesex County workhouse today as a "suspicious person" while agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation were investigating him as a possible suspect in the kidnapping of Charles Mattson of Tacoma, Wash, on Dec. 27. last.

When the three generations bearing the name of Charles Evans Hughes are together at Brown University next week-end for the commencement exercises they will share another of a series of college experiences which have been so much alike for grandfather, father and son.

MINNEAPOLIS MNNESOTA'S legislators have adopted a far-reaching State traffic code in an effort to make the State's highways safe for motorists and pedestrians alike. The bill was the most voluminous of the recent session. It is a traffic code setting up new speed limits, requirements s to lights, brakes and other equipment, and machinery designed to be life saving in its features.

The official attitude of the Polish Government toward the Ukrainian minority and its national movement for unification and independence was outlined to this correspondent by Dr. Alfred Bilyk, Governor of the Province of Lwow.

THE new thirty-ton Douglas DC4 monoplanes, now under construction for five of the major airlines of the United States, will be equipped with four fourteencylinder Pratt Whitney enginesof 1,400 horsepower each, it was announced last. week- by-George S.' Wheat, vice president of the United Aircraft Corporation.

WASHINGTON-Government tea tasters, meat chewers and softdrink samplers were pleased to learn recently that in determining flavors in food and drink there is no mechanical substitute for the human palate.

Mr. and Mrs. Clyde Scott Stilwell of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Esther Stilwell, to Emmons Bryant Jr., also of New York.
A SUMMER show of work by members has been put on in the well lighted and redecorated Lounge Gallery of the American Woman's Association.
The United Automobile Workers of America announced today settlement of strikes in the Packard Motor Car Company and Champion Spark Plug Company plants.
Activity increased in the wholesale markets last week, according to a special report prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell, Inc., resident buyers.

Browning E. Marean of 277 Park Avenue collapsed yesterday afternoon while at the wheel of his car at Broadway and 196th Street, but was able to halt the machine before he lost consciousness. A patrolman who saw the incident found Mr. Marean slumped over the wheel.

Miss Josephine D. Whitaker, daughter of Mrs. Ezra D. Whitaker of North Adams, Mass., and Sunset Hill Farm, this place, and of the late Mr. Whitaker, was married here this afternoon to Hans Meissner of Syracuse, N. Y., at her mother's home.
Robert L. Riggs, 19, maintained his perfect average for the tennis season today by trouncing Joe R. Hunt, 6--3, 6--4, 7--5, in the allCalifornia final of the Southern amateur tournament.

The marriage of Miss Barbara G. Kane, second daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John P. Kane of this community, to Samuel Wynne Mills, son of Mr, and Mrs. Paul Denkla Mills of Glen Head and Georgetown, S. C., took place this afternoon at the Episcopal Church of St. John's of Lattingtown.

Van A. Bittner, regional director for the Steel Workers Organizing Committee, asserted today that President Roosevelt would be asked on Monday to intervene in the union strike in effect in the plants of the major independent steel producers.

In the first hearing ever given to an outside organization, the Yale Corporation's executive committee listene today to-the request of a committee of five representing the American Federation of Teachers that Professor Jerome Davis be restore d to the faculty of the Yale Divinity School and receive a threeyear contract.

One labor crisis after another has kept Michigan in a constant stew of excitement the past week. At. the beginning of the week vigilantes brought an end to a nasty strike situation among the lumberjacks of the upper peninsula, concentrated at Munsing and Newberry.
FLAG DAY, tomorrow, has a special significance to stamp collectors this year, for various American republics are planning postal honor to our banner.

The wedding of Miss Jane Harris, daughter of Mrs. Selah Matthews e: Harris, and Phillip Mumford, son of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Mumford of Upton Park, took place this afternoon in the garden at Moreton Farms, home of the bride's mother. Dr. Andrew Gillies of the Third L Presbyterian Church officiated.

SCHROON LAKE, N. Y.--Among the new features at Scaroon Manor here are the ten-mile bridle path around the lake and over the mountain trails, and the changes in the nine-hole gilf course on the premises. Baseball, tennis, handball and volley ball courts are ready, and speedboat, sea-sled, outboard and surf-board races are to be conducted during the season.
YACHTSMEN whose Summer base ports are located anywhere between New London, Conn., and Delaware Bay are watching proceedings in Congress sharply these days.

IN their efforts to decrease vibrations that bring discomfort to a airline passengers aircraft designers face problems linked to the eons of time that have accommodated the human body to certain frequencies as encountered in walking, it was suggested at a recent t meeting sponsored by the Society of Automotive Engineers.
Last week the United States Treasury went to the market and borrowed another $800,000,000. One of the principal reasons why the Treasury needed this money was to buy gold which it doesn't want.
The formation of a new battalion of Americans, fighting on the Loyalist side in Spain, was announced yesterday by the Friends of the Abraham Lincoln Battalion, 125 West Forty-fifth Street.

The International Hydro-Electric System of Boston has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission an application for approval of its acquisition of 1,500,000 common shares of the Gatineau Power Company of Quebec, the commission announced today.

Daniel Willard, president of the Baltimore Ohio Railroad, ended here tonight the longest non-stop railroad run ever made east of the Mississippi River. He stepped from his special train at 8:15 to announce that the 569 mile trip from Cincinnati to Washington was made in exactly twelve hours, with no attempt at a speed record.

Announcement was been made by Dr. and Mrs. Eugene Lindsay Opie of 157 East Sixty-second Street of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Gertrude Eugenie Opie, to Henry Harreld Dinkins Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry H. Dinkins of New Orleans.

Four men, who traveled in two automobiles, are now thought to be responsible for the double murder Wednesday of Carlo and Nello Rosselli, Italian exiles, whose bodies were found in woods near Bagnoles-de l'Orne.

Miss Leila Ingersoll Jones, a greatgranddaughter of Governor Charles R. Ingersoll of New Haven, Conn.. and of George Griswold Haven, for many years president of the Metropolitan Opera and Real Estate Company, was married to Niels Kampmann of Aarhus, Denmark, this afternoon in St. Peter's Church here.

Women members of the Ausable Club and their friends who have met with excellent luck at trout fishing are at Edgewood Lodge, new headquarters, which will be used until the main clubhouse opens. Following its instantaneous success at a recent Sunday night tryout, Jules Eckert Goodman's "The Great Romancer," a biographical study of Alexander Dumas, will be presented at the New Theatre on Tuesday.
Mr. and Mrs. A. Pierce Gregg of HoltWilson, Edgewater Park, N. J., introduced their daughter, Miss Charlotte Louise Gregg, to society at a tea which they gave this afternoon at Holt-Wilson.

The seven-week strike of 300 employes of the General Optical Company here was settled this morning with an agreement recognizing the union. Negotiations were conducted at the Manhattan office of the National Labor Relations Board. The union has decided to apply for membership in the C. I. O.
For the last few weeks the Summer section of Newport has been gradually unfolding, shutters have come down and houses are being opened preparatory to what is expected to be a very busy season.

Maria Ilyinisha Ulianova, last living sister of Nikolai Lenin, died here today after a stroke. Her age was 59. Tomorrow her body will lie in state in the imposing hall of columns where Russians paid tribute to her brother after his death in 1924.

The marriage of Miss Louise McGill, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David James McGill of this city, to Norman E. Gullans, son of the Rev. and Mrs. D. John Gullans of East Orange, took place this evening in the First Lutheran Church of East Orange.

Pharis Tire and Rubber, Company capital stock, $1 par value, has been admitted to listing by the New York Curb Exchange. International Radio Corporation rights have been admitted to "when issued" dealings on the Exchange.

A Pittsburgh detective, Lawrence Kline, waited outside the women's wash room in the Pennsylvania Station yesterday while his prisoner walked out of another exit and escaped. He was returning Mrs. Frances Collins, 52 years old, to Pittsburgh to face charges of grand larceny and shoplifting.

KINGSTON, N. Y.--Femiliar sights in this gateway to the Catskills are the hiker with laden pack and the fisherman with a carload of equipment. With the advent of vacations this flow of naturalists and sportsmen increases until by the end of Summer thousands have paced the trails, enjoyed the numerous public campsites and whipped the trout streams.

Five thousand members and guests attended the annual carnival of the New York Athletic Club tonight at their quarters on Travers Island. Freaks, fortune tellers, "gambling" games with paper money--these and other features provided the proper atmosphere.

DATA on a new 12-eylinder Vee-type Diesel engine, under development in St. Louis for a number of years, has just been made available. This Deschamps motor develops 1,200 horsepower at 1,600 revolutions a minute and is built on the twocycle principle, which, though held impractical in spark ignition engines, has been found successful in Diesel construction.
A grant of $100,000 by the General Education Board to Sarah Lawrence College was announced today at commencement exercises on the college campus.
THE Summer sun has brought forth bevies of outdoor artists who pursue their hobby with pencils and paints while they absorb actinic rays.

Showing their all around superiority in every phase of the subject, New York City school girls outpointed the boys yesterday, winning eight of nine prizes offered in the semi-annual Latin vocabulary contest, conducted at the Washington Irving High School.

Lou G. Siegel, restaurateur, was the guest of honor last night at a dinner in his own restaurant at 209 West Thirty-eighth Street. The dinner was extended to him by business men of the garment section, of which he is popularly known as the "Mayor." About 300 attended.

Construction will start this week on the initial group of homes on the tract of more than 2,000 building lots recently purchased by United Associates Homes, Inc., in Jamaica facing the Grand Central Parkway. William Paul La Vallee
Big Ben Cantwell, although nicked for ten hits by the Toronto Leafs today, was effective in the pinches and hurled the Jersey City Giants to a 3 to 2 victory.
James J. Braddock pummeled five sparring partners again today in another long drill for his bout in Chicago with Joe Louis.

The Robinson-Patman law, which is one year old this week, has cut down quantity discounts, reduced direct and indirect diversion of brokerage, slashed the total volume of advertising allowances but increased the number of companies engaged in cooperative advertising, changed advertising practices and forced a clarification of distributive channels, according to opinions expressed here yesterday.

Big, droop-shouldered Ralph Guldahl, perhaps the only famous golf professional of Norwegian extraction, today won the,United States open championship, a title that eluded his grasp tragically four years ago.

Baron Constantin von Neurath, German Foreign Minister, conferred this morning and this afternoon with Premier Koloman Daranyi and Foreign Minister Koloman de Kanya. Tomorrow, accompanied by the Premier, he will be the guest of Regent Nicholas Horthy at the latter's Summer residence.

Citing several recent crimes of violence on Indian reservations in New York State, United States District Attorney George L. Grobe has advocated assignment of resident police to remedy a situation which, he said, is "bad and may grow worse."

The Spring meeting of the United Hunts Association on the race course of Boxwood, estate of Mr. and Mrs. Charles V. Hickox, drew several hundred persons this afternoon to the ringside. No meeting in the last few years has been so well attended.

The University of California defeated the University of Wisconsin in varsity and freshmen crew races on Lake Mendota today. The Golden Bears finished two and a half lengths ahead of the Badger varsity, covering two miles in 10 minutes 50 seconds. The losers finished 11 seconds behind.

The wedding of Miss Betty Gertrude Saacke, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert F. Saacke of this place, to Herbert F. Hinners, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick J. Hinners, took place this evening in the Community Baptist Church. The Rev. Russell F. Auman of the Lutheran Church of the Redeemer officiated.
Stocks closed steady and dull at lower levels; turnover, 387,220 shares. All classes of bonds firm and mixed in smallest turnover since last August; transactions, $3,759,500.

The new City College in Queens, which will open its gates this Fall, will give "serious and sympathetic thought" to students who are destined not only for professional but also for "sub-professional" careers, such as laboratory technicians, specialized nurses, newspaper writers and workers in the typographical arts, according to Dr. Paul Klapper, its newly appointed president.
Mount Holyoke alumnae gave expression today to their affection for the retiring president of the college, Dr. Mary E. Woolley, by presenting to her as a personal gift about $3,500.

The marriage of Miss Charlotte P. Diehl, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Diehl of Maplewood, and Andrew Paul Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Andrew Paul of Irvington, took place this evening in North Reformed Church. Newark. The ceremony was performed by the pastor, the Rev. T. Porter Drum.

MsssRhea Anne Robinson, daughter of Mrs. Irving E. Robinson of this city, and Ensign Bladen Du laney Claggett, U.S.N., were mar- Th tried at the Pine Street Presbyterian Alta Church here today. The ceremony E. I was performed by the Rev. Dr. C. Lint Waldo Cherry. Mr.

Mrs. Edith Minturn Stokes, wife of I. N. Phelps Stokes, president of the Municipal Art Commission, died yesterday morning at her residence, 953 Fifth Avenue, after a long illness, in her sixty-ninth year.

Miss Cynthia Smith, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Arnold Smith of 39-14 Bayside Boulevard, Bayside, Queens, was married yesterday afternoon to Robert Edward Holmes, son of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Joseph Holmes of Newton, Mass.

Miss Margaret Pillsbury of San Francisco and Montecito, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Horace Pillsbury, was married here this afternoon to Lieutenant Frederick William Coleman 3d, son of Major Gen. and Mrs. Coleman of Washington, at AllSanta-by-the-Sea Episcopal Church.
Robert Gair Company, Inc., $3 cumulative preferred stock, $10 par value, and common stock, $1 par value, have been admitted to the New York Stock Exchange list.

A ten-year recreational development program for New Hampshire, to embody recommended policies and be presented to the 1939 Legislature, is proposed in the biennial report of the State Planning and Development. Commission just transmitted to Governor Murphy and the Legislature.
WELLINGTON, New Zealand. KINGMAN REEF, the spot where the Pan American Clipper planes break their 2,6000mile flight between Hawaii and Pago Pago on the way to New Zealand, is a much-discovered place.

The 500-acre domain of the MacDowell Colony for creative workers here will be opened to visitors on the afternoon of June 26. Invitations have been sent out by Mrs. Edward MacDowell, widow of the composer and guiding spirit of the colony, to Summer residents in the vicinity to enable them to meet resident members of the colony and to visit their studio workshops in the woods.
The Mary K. Browne tennis tournament will be held at Lake Erie College, Painesville, Ohio, starting on Wednesday.

Following a two-day covering movement, prices on the 'Cotton Exchange eased again yesterday until contracts for near months went below 12 cents a pound at one time. Week-end evening-up of accounts furnished buying power on recessions, but the list ended with net losses of 13 to 15 points.

The cornerstone of the new parochial school of the Roman Catholic Church of St. Francis Xavier, 1,658 Lurting Avenue, the Bronx, will be laid today at 3 P. M. The ceremony will close the celebration of the silver jubilee of the Rev. John M. J. Quinn, the pastor.
THE scene of this adventure story of the sixteenth century alternates between Florence and Rome. It is in the first named city that Carlo Brunelli. the hero, spends his early boyhood.

The bitter and costly fight between the C. I. O. and American Federation of Labor marine affiliates for control in New York Harbor is expected to reach its crucial point within the next two weeks when the National Labor Relations Board conducts a secret election on the ships of three New York lines to determine which ground has the most adherents.

KATHARINE DUPRE LUMPKIN and Dorothy Wolff Douglas have written a book on the problem of child labor that should be disturbing both to those who have sought to abolish it and those who oppose regulatory legislation.

A definite program for working out future "gentlemen's agreements" between Japanese and American producers, and for solving numerous other trade problems, is expected to result from conferences tomorrow and Tuesday between the Japanese Economic Mission and a committee of American exporters and importers.

Finance Minister Arthur de Souza Costa, who will fly for the United States Monday, said he felt confident of the success of his trip. He said Brazilian-United States amity had not only an economic basis but also a political basis. He said Brazil must at all times work in harmony with the United States.

The marriage of Miss Margaret D. Evans, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William A. D. Evans of this place, to J. Stiger Ferry, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles D. Ferry, also of Summit, took place here today in Calvary Church. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. W. Ovid Kinsolving.

Spokesmen for the Nazi regime's labor policies today promised Far Eastern tours to the 1940 Olympic Games for thousands of deserving workers and concentration camps for employers that "rate machines higher than men."

In what police described as the pettiest thievery they could remember, Gordon Foster, 18 years old, of 544 Central Avenue, Brooklyn, was arrested shortly after 10 o'clock last night on charges of stealing 2 cents from George Warbass, 81-year-old war veteran, in the hallway of his home at 411 Evergreen Avenue.

One of the four New England Rhodes scholars and a French exchange student are among the 145 who will receive degrees from Bates College Monday. Of the degrees, 6 will be honorary, 20 for post-graduate work and 119 of bachelor rank.

Many patrons of music who are identified with society in this city and the Berkshires have subscribed to boxes for the Berkshire Symphonic Festival to be presented in August by the Boston Symphony Orchestra under the direction of Serge Koussevitzky.
SANDWICH, Mass. NO formal birthday party is planned, but a record-breaking procession of visitors is expected this Summer and Autumn in the oldest town on Cape Cod.

Taking off within half an hour of each other, the two big flying boats, one British and the other American, which will operate the scheduled five-and-a-half-hour service between New York and Bermuda, beginning next week, left this port this morning for Hamilton Harbor.
The Westchester Drama Association, at its annual meeting here a few days ago, elected Andrew Cameron of Yonkers as president, and Mrs. Pearl L. Hanna of Mamaroneck as vice president.

Capturing three of the four singles matches, Newtown High School's tennis team vanquished the Erasmus Hall netmen, 3 to 2, at the Mammoth courts in Brooklyn yesterday to take the city P. S. A. L. title.
Eugene F. Ellis, head of the rotogravure department of THE NEW YORK TIMES for the last twentythree years, died at his home here at 11:30 o'clock tonight after a year's illness. His age was 60.

Miss Janet Barr McKittrick, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis A. McKittrick of this city, was married at noon today to Lieutenant John Laurence Ewing, U. S. N., son of Mrs. John L. Ewing of Boston, in the Holy Rosary Church here.
The Red Sox lost the first game of a doubleheader today, 3 to 2, but overcame Detroit's four-run lead to win the ten-inning nightcap, 5 to 4, before 40,250 fans.

WHEN Governor Lehman recently signed a bill requiring that bicycles be equipped with brakes, horn or bell, head lamp and front and rear reflectors the lowly twowheeler was advanced officially to the status of a passenger vehiclea status sought for fifty years.

PARIS. CHARLES BAUDELAIRE, who was sued and condemned in 1857 for the publication of his book of poems, "Les Fleurs du Mal," is recognized today as one of the 'greatest poets of the nineteenth century, who not only carried on the work of the romantic Pleiad, but ushered in new forms of poetry and prepared the lyric revival of the Nineties.
President Getulio Vargas inaugurated this afternoon the largest and finest of Pan American Airways South American airports.
HENRY COLLINS BROWN, founder of the Museum of the City of New York, was well known, prior to 1928, not only for that notable achievement but as an important social historian of the city.
To the Radio Editor: It has been mentioned frequently by pseudo-educators that the youth of the country should listen in at the radio to obtain correct pronunciation of English words.

Daily average sales of general merchandise in small towns and rural areas for May were about 11 per cent higher in dollar volume than for May, 1936, Commerce Department preliminary figures indicated today.

Miss Elizabeth Halsey, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Robert H. Halsey of 17 East Eighty-ninth Street and The Cottage, Derby Vt., was married in the chapel of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church yesterday noon to Andrew Carnegie Whitfield, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry D. Whitfield of this city and Southampton, namesake of the late Andrew Carnegie and nephew of Mrs. Carnegie.

Details of a discussion of .plans for concerted action to enforce the new law making the practice of law by unauthorized persons and corporations a contempt of the Supreme Court were revealed today by Edwin M.

Dr. Randolph G. Adams, director of the William L. Clements Library of American History at the University of Michigan, has been appointed the Rosenbach fellow in bibliography at the University of Pennsylvania for the academic year 1937-38.

SEATTLM. A FTER a third of a century of sharp bickering and intermit tent quarrels over the matter, the loftiest peak in the Pacific Northwest and the second loftiest in the United States is still known as Mount Rainier.

MAX GORDON'S plans for a cinema career are beginning to look like something more than a mere reverie. Before sailing down the harbor Wednesday on the Queen Mary for a holiday abroad, the impresario of Broadway dropped word that the Max...

A strike of about 1,000 city employes began'at 5 o'clock this morning and several hours later hired trucks and crews, escorted by police, left the incinerator at Field's Point and began the collection of garbage.

The wedding of Miss Mildred I. Baum, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John F. Baum of this place, and Lieutenant Hamilton W. Fish, son of the Rev. Arthur E. Fish and Mrs. Fish of Eldora, Iowa, took place tonight in Morrow Memorial Church here. The bridegroom's father performed the ceremony.
Formation of a new labor union, the Workers Council for Social Justice, Inc., was announced here tonight by officers who said it solicits Ford Motor Company employes and other automobile workers.

Miss Patricia Fox, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Patrick Fox of West Orange, was married this afternoon in the home of her parents to Alexander J. Arbuckle, son of Mrs. George Arbuckle of Westfield. Mgr. Paul T. Carew of St. John's Catholic Church, Orange, performed the ceremony.
LIKE Sam Base, ballad hero of an earlier but no more legendary American pioneer epoch, Louise Fazenda was born in Indiana. The exact spot was Lafayette. The right time was 1895.

Miss Mary Yorke McCawley, daughter of Lieut. Commander and Mrs. Edmund S. McCawley of Clouden, Ithan, was married this afternoon to Robert Bowne Minturn, son of Mrs. J. Hampden Robb of Beverly, Mass., and the late Hugh Minturn of New York.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt will receive the honorary degree of Doctor of Laws from the John Marshall College of Law at its commencement exercises on Wednesday afternoon in the auditorium of the State Normal School, it was announced today.

Four residences each Containing seven rooms with three bathrooms are nearing completion and will soon be opened for inspection in the Murray Hill section of Scarsdale, White Plains, by the- Murray HillScarsdale Corporation. The development is on the White Plains Road, 200 feet south of Murray Hill.

(Figures in parentheses indicate par) Cherry Valley (72)--Match play handicap against par, Class A: A. L. Adamson, 2 down;' W. C. Douglas, 4 down. Class B: T. T. McWilliam, all even: R. T. Townaend, 1 down; C. W. Randall, 1 down.
THE steadily rising cost of steamship operation is said to be one of the main reasons for the 5 per cent increase in North Atlantic steamship fares announced for July 26.

Alex Gerard Jr. of Southampton, New York State junior champion and son of the professional at the National Golf Links of America, yesterday became a finalist in the Long Island Golf Association's sixteenth annual amateur championship tournament with a victory over John E. Scheffmeyer at the Pomonok Country Club in Flushing.

Alumni and friends will gather at the Loomis School today to honor Nathaniel H. Batchelder at the celebration of his twenty-fifth year as headmaster and to join in the remaining festivities of the commencement week-end.

More than 100 of New York State's third and fourth class postmasters closed the thirtieth annual convention of the New York State Branch of the National League of District Postmasters in the Hotel New Yorker yesterday with the selection of Utica, N. Y., as their 1938 convention city.

Deposits of $14,135,372.84 in the unemployment compensation trust fund of the Federation Government were reported this week by James G. Robinson, executive director of the State Unemployment Compensation Commission. Included are earnings of $10,372.84 credited to New Jersey's account as of March 31.

A Federal Government gift tax claim of $1,413,333 against Mrs. Helena Woolworth McCann, eldest daughter of the late Frank W. Woolworth, five-and-ten-cent store owner, has been -settled for $1,082,889.36.

Mayor La Guardia was asked yesterday by Alderman Joseph E. Kinsley of the Bronx to issue a proclamation calling public attention to the city ordinance adopted last year forbidding the sale or discharge of fireworks in the city.

The following Foreign Service changes since June 5 were announced today by the State Department: Merrit N. Cootes of Ft. Meyer, Va., assigned as Vice Consul, Montreal, Canada; orders to Havana canceled. F. Ridgway Lineaweaver, Philadelphia, Pa., Vice Consul at Montreal, to Havana, Cuba; as Vice Consul.

The United States Davis Cup team arrived on the liner Columbus today with Walter Pate, non-playing captain, confident his boys have at least an "even chance" of winning the coveted tennis trophy, now in possession of England.
A special anti-submarine flotilla has been formed by the Valencia Defense Ministry, according to a semi-official Valencia message broadcast here.
Celebrities in foreign lands have been buying Chris-Crafts this Spring, according to the orders piling up on the desk of Jay Cothran of New York, the Eastern manager.
President Lazaro Cardenas today ordered a nation-wide campaign to improve public morals throughout Mexico. Sharp orders were sent to State Governors, the Department of Propaganda reports.
LONDON. PRODUCTS of any kind that bear the official stamp are commonly exposed to a more severe criticism than is directed against the fruits of private and independent enterprise.

The eight-day celebration of the 300th anniversary of the purchase of Governors Island from the Indians will begin at 11 A. M. today, with a military church parade. Outdoor religious exercises will be held at the reservation. Bishop William T. Manning will give the principal address.

Rutgers University will hold its 171st commencement here tomorrow afternoon. Dr. Robert C. Clothier, the president, will confer forty-one advanced degrees and 260 Bachelor degrees. Honors and prizes will also be conferred.
Miss Elizabeth Barber, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. H. Barber of this place, was married tonight to Thomas A. Browne Jr. in the Hempstead Methodist Episcopal Church.

ALIGHT program of bridge tournaments is offered to A New York players for the remainder of the Summer. While they are waiting for the annual tournament at Asbury Park, N. J., beginning on Aug. 2, which is usually their favorite event, they have available tournaments at Coney Island and at Hanover, N. H., this month and at New London, Conn., in July.

Mr. and Mrs. James J. Kennedy of White Plains, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Helen Kennedy, to Bernard Spelman, son of Mrs. Bernard Spelman of Morristown, N. J., and the late Mr. Spelman.

A series of open-air concerts in Westchester County will be inaugurated Tuesday afternoon, when the Westchester Philharmonic Orchestra, a unit of the Federal Music Project, plays at Glen Island, New Rochelle.

Although retail trade showed marked improvement last week in most of the Federal Reserve districts throughout the country, in some sections labor disturbances, as well as inclement weather, retarded the movement of business in general.
Amid a thunderstorm which broke as the funeral cortege was making its way to Beechwood Cemetery, the body of Sir Robert Borden was borne to the grave late this afternoon.
A biographical drama, "Eternal Progress," based on the life of Dwight L. Moody, famed evangelist and founder of the Northfield Schools, opened the school's commencement program here tonight.
JUST in case it is needed, here is a list of the foreign equiv alents of "Here's how," to paste in your hat before leavingg for the Summer holiday abroad:
Jacques Van Brunt, member of a pioneer Brooklyn family that dates to the original Dutch settlers, died on Friday at his home, 8,001 Shore Road, at the age of 74.

NEVER in the happiest dreams of airplane designers and manufacturers did they envision a time like the present, when all the world is clamoring for planes and more planes. Ships for overland transportation, for war purposes, for overseas service are in demand-bigger, heavier, faster planes.

The Federal Home Loan Bank of New York has declared a semi-annual dividend on its capital stock at the rate of 2 per cent a year for the six months ending on June 30, it was announced yesterday by George MacDonald, chairman of the board.

CHATEAU THIERRY and Belleau wood, names to thrillevery American in the Summer of 1918, present a very different appearance today than when soldiers of the A. E. F. were fighting in the Marne salient in a decisive phase of the World War.

KRAUSHAAR--Mr. and Mrs. Philip R. Kraushaar of 305 Atlantic Ave., Cedarhurst, announce the bar mitzvah of their son, Leonard, at Temple Beth-E1, Broadway, Cedarhurst, on Saturday, June 19. at 10:30 A. M. Reception at Genadeen Hotel, Far Rockaway, after 9 P. M.

A city-wide labor holiday, or miniature "general strike," was threatened here tonight by extremist elements in labor circles as a protest against the action of city and county authorities in swearing in extra police and sheriff's deputies in the C. I. O. strike against independent steel companies.

MR. O'CASEY is a fighting Irish playwright with a righteous anger against the critics, but with little skill and less experience in answering them. In this slim volume of twenty slight pieces he turns against the theatre journalists-chiefly Agate and St. John Ervine-and the playwrights whom they admire, from Pinero to Coward.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Dorothy Werrenrath, daughter of Mrs. Ada Werrenrath of this city and Reinald Werrenrath, the baritone, to Carleton Brown Hutchins Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Carleton Brown Hutchins of Chicago.

Bonds called last week for redemption prior to maturity were in somewhat smaller volume than in the preceding period. Except for a few small amounts of foreign and municipal bonds which were called for retirement this month, the new refundings announced last week were for payment in future months.
THE twentieth season of the Daniel Guggenheim Memorial Concerts by the Goldman Band, under the direction of Edwin Franko Goldman, will be inaugurated on the Mall in Central Park Wednesday evening.

Miss Adele Virginia Bacon, daughter of Judge and Mrs. Curtiss S. Bacon of this city, was married to William Walter Hatfield, son of Mr. and Mrs. W. W. Hatfield of Bridgeport in the Church of the Holy Trinity this afternoon by the Rev. Frank Flood German.
Residential selling is shoving considerable activity in the Oranges and Maplewood this month reports the Board of Realtors of the Oranges and Maplewood.

Mary A. Shanley, third-grade detective of the pickpocket squad who, early this week, arrested two suspects after firing shots in the air to halt them, was promoted to second grade in the Police Department orders yesterday.
EVEN maps change with the seasons. Normally one thinks of a nation in terms of large cities, agricultural belts, mining regions and great rivers and harbors.

Mr. and Mrs. Albert Cox Leggett of 402 Washington Avenue, Brooklyn, and Craig Bield, Redding Ridge, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara MacGay Leggett, to Dr. Otto Emile Billo of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Otto Billo of Glen Ridge, N. J.

Miss Edith Emma Van Dorn, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Louis Van Dorn of Bronxville, was married to Edward Joseph Wreden, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Wreden of Mount Vernon, tonight in the Reformed Church here, by the Rev. John Henderson Powell Jr.
The famous Old Man of the Mountain, who from high over Profile Lake in the White Mountains, is familiar to thousands of Summer visitors, is in need of repair.

Congress having decided to take charge of the administration's investigation of alleged tax avoidance or evasion by possessors of large incomes, hearings will be started next week before a joint committee of six Senators and six members of the House of Representatives.
MORE than 700 of the nation's 20,000 Sea Scouts will soon come together from every section of America to hold what will be a unique "sea camp."

A FESTIVAL OF Pan-American chamber music sponsored by Elizabeth Sprague Coolidge, will be held in Mexico, D. F., July 13-24. Although works by contemporary composers of North and South America and the West Indies form the majority of the offerings listed, compositions by Bach, Mozart, Haydn, Beethoven, Debussy and De Falla will find a place on the elaborate schedule arranged for the six concerts of the series.
Machine tool buyers can look for an increase in prices on the majority of staple and special lines of equipment in the near future, according -to information in the wholesale market here yesterday.

A HOAX on the radio is defined as a fake broadcast. Since the microphone plays to an unseen audience, sleight-ofhand with sound is easy trickery, but the broadcast showmen, aware of their responsibilities, have been extremely careful to guard against fooling the listeners, lest they might never believe what they heard on the air.

VIEINNA. ONE thing, at least, Vittorio Giannini's new "Requiem," composed in memory of his mother, has in common with Verdi's--it is pervaded with a strong flavor of the theatre. Mr. Giannini was born in Philadelphia, but his Italian ancestry speaks persuasively to him, and just as little as Verdi does he seem to fear the reproach of having written an "ecclesiastical opera."
Howard Maurer, defending titleholder from the Trinity Club, defeated George V. Besratz, unattached, 21-4, 21-9, in a first-round match in the Queens County A. A. U.
It was announced yesterday that the Penn Central Power and Light Company, which serves electricity in communities in Central Pennsylvania, has changed its name to the Pennsylvania Edison Company.
William Beadley Jr., 37 years old, son of a Boardwalk candy merchant here, was arraigned today before Recorder Thomas D. Taggart Jr. in Police Court here on a charge of embracery.

Investors and dealers in investment securities have found a marked change in the character of the investment market in the last few months. The early part of the change in the period of readjustment of security values in March and early April was easily understood by them,

Girls from four New York boroughs skipped through the intricacies of folk dances of many countries under yesterday's bright skies on the Mall in Central Park in the final elimination tournament of the Department of Parks' second annual contest for playgrounds.

An agreement which will bring Germany and Italy back to the International Non-Intervention Committee was signed in London this afternoon by them and by Britain and France, but its pledges need acceptance by both sides in Spain before it becomes effective.

Dull trading and declining prices characterized last week's stock market. THE NEW YORK TIMES index of fifty stocks was off 4.16 points on the week, the widest decline since the week ended on May 15, as industrial strike news exerted a depressing influence.

Ralph Guldahl of Chicago, open champion; Sam Snead of White Sulphur Springs, W. Va.; Ed Dudley of Philadelphia and Byron Nelson of Reading, Pa., shot their way into American Ryder Cup team berths today in the final round of the forty-first national open championship.

Debits to individual accounts, as reported by banks in leading cities for the week ended June 9, aggregated $8,256,000,000, or 1 per cent below the total reported for the preceding week, which included five business days in most of the reporting centers, and 2 per cent above the total for the corresponding week of last year.

Division 5 of the Interstate Commerce Commission has decided in a test case involving railroad company pick-up and delivery service in New York that a railroad-owned trucking company performing such Services is not to be regarded, as far as regulation is concerned, in the same category as the railroad itself.

State and local police officials, apparently convinced that the mysteriously missing Mrs. William H. Parsons is dead, laid plans today for a thorough search for the body, but then held their plans in abeyance after a conference with Federal investigators.

Miss Edith Quier, golfer and daughter of E. A. Quier, publisher of The Reading Eagle, was married today to Dr. Harrison Fitzgerald Flippin of Philadelphia, son of Dr. and Mrs. James C. Flippin of Charlottesville, Va.
THE Brazilian commemorative series of coins of 1936 has but recently appeared on the local market. This series comprises seven coins, from the 100 reis to the five milreis.
Unemployment has now become so small that the Reich Labor Office announces it is beginning to worry about the labor supply for agriculture and the major industries.

The second annual series of Review-of-the-News Conferences to be conducted by THE NEW YORK TIMES this Autumn in cooperation with the leading women's organizations of Westchester, New Jersey and Long Island was scheduled last week as follows:
Hunter College will hold its commencement exercises on Wednesday morning at 10:30 in Carnegie Hall. Vilhjalmur Steafansson, scientist and Arctic explorer, will deliver the baccalaureate address.
The story of the Postmaster General and the horsd'oeuvres has been told before this, but only in fragmentary and distorted fashion.

H. C. McGehee's Fair Knightess today won the Bostonian Handicap at Suffolk Downs for the second successive year, beating A. J. Sackett's Tabitha by five lengths. She was clocked in 1:45 2-5 for the mile and one-sixteenth.
The Bears made it five in a row today as they trounced the Buffalo Bisons, 10 to 5. Newark has scored twelve victories in its last thirteen games.
Dr. Robert Wahl, head of the Wahl Institute of Brewing Technology, died late yesterday at the Alexian Brothers Hospital after an illness of three months. He was 79 years old.

THE Great Western Railway has added twenty-five sheepdogs to its staff in Wales. They assist roadmen along certain lines in the valleys, where sheep slip through fences and wander upon railway embankments in search of grazing, thereby endangering their lives and delaying trains.

Navy's eights today put on some pressure as the men settled down in their training camp above the city. All three Annapolis crews, plebe, junior and varsity, rowed down stream over their full courses tonight.

Eleven hundred artists, writers, musicians and archivists on WPA projects in this city will be dropped under the terms of an order received from Washington yesterday by Harold Stein, administrative officer of the four Federal art projects.

The expected ratification by the Senate of the Buenos Aires treaties looking to the maintenance of the peace of the Americas will fall short of the complete "good neighbor" effect that was hoped for them, as regards Latin America, because of the failure of that body to take any action on the sanitary convention signed more than two years ago by plenipotentiaries representing Argentina and the United- States.

The six ranking members of the Finance Committee were named today by Vice President Garner as the Senate representatives on the joint committee to investigate tax avoidance and evasion, created as a result of the President's recent message on this subject.
More than 125 couples attended the commencement dance held last night by the graduating class of Hunter College in the Continental ballroom at the Hotel St. Moritz.
Liquidation by longs featured today the markets for wheat and other grains on the Board of Trade here. Sharp declines were registered, with December corn sinking into new low ground for the crop.
Most of the objections to the proposed Federal Wages-and-Hours Act which have been delivered this week at a Congressional committee hearing are based either on historical or economic grounds.
EHRLICH--Mr. and Mrs. Peter Ehrlich of Flushing, L. I., will celebrate their-golden wedding anniversary at a reception Saturday evening, June 19, at 9 o'clock, at Hotel New Yorker. No cards.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Within the last few weeks you have published in THE NEW YORK TIMES several editorials which, in effect, oppose any further organized effort by agriculture with the aid of the Federal Government to adjust itself to presentday economic conditions.
The Arende Building Corporation announces the opening of the Windsor House apartment, containing seventy-eight suites.
A complete travel wardrobe of fabrics processed or woven to resist the rumpling effect of crushing can be assembled today by the prospective voyager.

Governors Island tercentenary celebration begins this morning at 10:30 o'clock and continues to next Sunday, on Governors Island. Rally of the West Side Manhattan division of the Holy Name Society begins with' a parade from 116th Street and Morningside Avenue to the grounds of the Convent of the Sacred Heart, 133d Street and Convent Avenue, 2:30 P. M. Speakers:
A ninth-inning drive by Tufts fell short by a single run as Harvard's varsity scored a 5-4 victory over the Jumbos in the annual Alumni Day battle at Tufts Oval today before 2,500 spectators.

Miss Elizabeth Barrett, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Francis Barrett of Fanwood, was married to Eugene Albert Otto, son of Mrs. A. F. G. Otto of Westfield, this afternoon in All Saints Episcopal Church, Scotch Plains. The Rev. William Bassill officiated.

The Serial Federal Savings and Loan Association of this city will be represented by George E. Palmer, secretary-manager; Charles Jacobson, vice president; William J. Considine, treasurer, and Morris Salpeter, counsel, at the fiftieth annual convention of the New York State League of Savings and Loan Associations at Saranac Inn, N. Y., beginning on Wednesday.
Waite Hoyt, in his nineteenth year as a major league pitcher, yesterday was purchased by the Dodgers from the Pirates for an unannounced sum.

The National Socialist party's bar association announces that under no circumstances may Jewish or foreign lawyers hostile to the Reich represent Germans in litigation abroad. The local juridical weekly prints a list of "reliable lawyers" outside Germany.
Mrs. Harry Frank Jr.'s Clifton's Beau fulfilled expectations today by being judged champion hunter of the fortyfourth annual Westchester County Horse Show.
THE Summer cruise season, accelerated by the closing of colleges and schools, is swinging into full schedule.

Phlox drummondii is one of those good old annuals that will provide masses of bloom during the Summer months. It is often a welcome change from the petunia, calendula, zinnia or other vigorous annuals which may have been planted year after year in nine out of ten gardens in the community.
Although the Meadow Brook Club fields were too wet for polo today on account of the rains of yesterday, two members' matches were held on the J. S. Phipps estate.
TO stop wanton destruction and theft of plants set out for roadside beautification, State Highway Commissioner E. Donald Sterner has directed that summary
Two Chicago stables won first and second prizes in the day's opening event of Chicago's Charter Jubilee Horse Show at Soldier Field today.

Miss Helen Grannis, daughter of Mrs. w Grosvenr Grannis of this place E and the late Mr. Grannis, was married this afternoon to Roy Erik Oman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Otto L. Oman, also of this place, in West Side Presbyterian Church in Englewood by the Rev. Frank Harl Huff man, the pastor.

Clinton H. Crane's new international 12-meter yacht Gleam today won her first race in the Long Island Sound championship series. She had shown the way before in special racing but had been beaten three straight times in the title events by Van S. Merle-Smith's Seven Seas.

LAKE PLACID, N. Y.--Ice skating will be added to the Summer sports of golf, tennis, swimming and riding this season. Ice will be put down on the floor of the arena on July 3, to remain there until Aug. 15.

WASHINGTON. WHILE strikes shake new areas of American industry and truces are made along old labor battle lines. Uncle Sam's efforts to bring about a new relationship between employer and employee center. in Washington. in a set of offices as homely and informal as an old shoe.

The Rutgers baseball team concluded its season today, dropping a 9-to-6 decision to Indiana's nine before 2,000 old grads. A five-run attack in the fifth by the visitors let the fighting Hoosiers come from behind to win. Clark and Kubic hit homers during the rally.
Tom Haynie, University of Michigan aquatic star, held the limelight in the Eastern intercollegiate and Eastern interscholastic outdoor swimming championships in Zach's Bay today.

ANNOUNCEMENT is made by the American Federation of Arts that there is to be a change in the method of publishing The American Art Annual. The Annual has regularly appeared soon after the opening of each year.

Miss Helen J. Goodwin, blind Radcliffe junior, who was the first New England girl to take a Seeing-Eye dog to college, was' married here today to Carl E. Hopkins, instructor and graduate student at Harvard.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Valle Ewing, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederic Ewing of this place, to Norman Keith, son of Mr. and Mrs. Clarence Lynwood Keith of Rutland, Vt. The announcement was made tonight at a dinner given by the bride-elect's parents at their home.

NOT only did a great man and a brave gentleman depart when William J. Henderson met his sudden end eight days ago, but a whole brilliant and indeed historic period in American music criticism was completed. He was the dean and considerably the longest in service of a remarkable group of writers on music who made history in the practice of their profession and who profoundly influenced the development of music throughout the land.

A ninth-inning rally produced only one run for the Indians today as the Athletics scored their second straight victory of the series, 3 to 2. The rally was made up of three bases on balls, a hit and an error.

Appeal of a Municipal Court order for his execution saved Ranger, giant police dog, from a firing squad today. Municipal Judge J. A. Gallaher condemned him to death after several persons reported they had been attacked and bitten.
The acuteness of the country's shortage of meat, particularly pork, continues to grow, according to expert observers, with no immediate relief in sight for consumers.
The estate of the late Ross M. Turner on Palmers Hill, Greenwich, Conn., one of the "show" places of the community, has been purchased by a client of George Howe.

Mrs. Fred- dor erick W. Harvey 2d of Wilmette, Ill., has announced the engagement and approaching marriage of her daughter, Miss Wilma Harvey, to Guenther Brandes, son of Carl Hermann Brandes of Rosebank, Staten Island, and the late Mrs. Brandes.

THE season of operettas which will be presented this Summer at the Jones Beach Stadium by Fortune Gallo opens Saturday night, June 26, with Jerome Kern's "Roberta." By theend-of the week the entire organization comprising 250 persons, including principals, chorus, orchestra, ballet and supernumeraries, will be in final training for this event.

Revision of the New York State laws affecting sex offenders will be sought by the Westchester County Society for Prevention of Cruelty to Children, it was decided this week following a conference on sex crimes involving children.

OPTIMISM of leading automobile company executives over the trade outlook was clearly demonstrated at Detroit recently at the annual meeting and show drawing of the Automobile Manufacturers Association when applications for exhibit space at the next National Automobile Show exceeded the amount available by several thousand square feet.

Jobs are seeking the girl graduate once more in the Eastern women's colleges. But the girl, looking them over, is not invariably eager to work, appointment bureau directors on seven campuses report to THE NEW YORK TIMES.
The New York State Labor Department said today a mediator would be assigned immediately to investigate alleged interference with pickets at the plant of the Perry Knitting Company.
HIGH spots of the American Medical Association's annual meeting, held last week at Atlantic City for the benefit of the thousands of medicos from all parts of the country:
Siam, odds-on favorite owned by the Bomar Stable, won the $5,000 added Pontchartrain Stakes today by more than three lengths before a cheering crowd of 10,000 at the Fair Grounds.

The commencement program at Wells College opened today with the arrival of alumnae for class reunions, the annual meeting of the Wells College Alumnae Association, presided over by Mrs. David Bellamy of Rochester, the alumnae banquet and the presentation of "Oedipus Rex."
Brig. Gen. Aaron S. Daggett, retired, oldest living army officer and veteran of three wars and two campaigns, will celebrated tomorrow his 100th birthday, a day before the anniversary.
Appointments The following probationary patrolmen are appointed patrolmen, effective June 12, their conduct and capacity while on probation having been satisfactory:

Miss Jadwiga Jedrzejowska, hard-hitting girl from Poland, has developed into a true menace for America's tennis stars. Already holding one decision over Miss Helen Jacobs in the French hard-court championships, Miss Jedrzejowska today scored her second victory in as many weeks over Miss Alice Marble, American singles titlcholder.

Miss Alice Whitney, 18 years old, daughter of Richard Whitney, former president of the New York Stock Exchange, was one of four persons injured today in a collision of two automobiles near here. Miss Whitney was taken to a Washington hospital where attendants said that she received cuts on the face.

The Cubs pounded out a 10-to-5 victory over the Phillies today to remain a half game behind the league-leading Giants. Chicago knocked Wayne LaMaster out of the box with a sevenhit attack in two innings, then went on to win easily behind Larry French's southpaw pitching.

Miss Jane Davies Bryant, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles S. Bryant of East Orange, was married to Alwin Kleinfeldt, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Kleinfeldt of Bloomfield, this evening in St. Paul's Episcopal Church, East Orange. The rector, the Rev. Edwin P. Wright, officiated.

Civic organizations in the northeastern section of the Bronx have been invited to attend a mass meeting Wednesday night in Public School 78, Needham and Fish Avenues, to protest against the route mapped out by the Board of Transportation for the extension of the Bronx division of the city's Independent subway.

MANHATTAN HEDLEY. THOMAS ALBERT (June 8). Estate, $2,814. To Ellen Hedley Reynolds, Phyllis Hedley Bailey. Hilda Hedley Perry, daughters, 139 E. 66th St., equal shares in residue. LOUDOUN, WOOD D. (June 1). Estate, more than $10,000. To Imogene Maude Loudoun, widow, Hotel Empire, Broadway and 63d St., life estate in residue; Harry Hammond Loudoun, son, petitioner, Atlanta, Ga., remainder interest.

The Westchester Drama Association, at its annual meeting here this week, elected Andrew Cameron of Yonkers as president for the coming year. Mrs. Pearl L. Hanna of Mamaroneck was elected vice president.

The Bureau of Fisheries took quick refuge behind a screen of piscatorial Latin today from the question, What is a lobster? Maine lobstermen have asked Congress to declare that a lobster is not a lobster unless he has formidable claws.
THE June issue of the magazine Story contains the announcement of the awards in the fourth annual short story contest held jointly by the colleges of the United States and the magazine.

A movement has been started by the advisory board of the' Salvation Army here, at the suggestion of Mayor Benjamin F. Turner, to provide an activity similar to the Boys Club for the underprivileged girls of Passaic. The nature of the undertaking has not been decided.
Federal Judge Samuel H. West overruled today a C. I. O. steel union motion to dismiss a suit brought by three railroads to enjoin pickets from interfering with shipments to picketed steel plants.

The German Davis Cup team advanced to the final round of the European Zone Competition today when Baron Gottfried von Cramm and Heinrich Henkel defeated Andre La Croix and L. De Borman of Belgium, 6--4, 6--3, 6--4, in doubles. The Germans won the first two singles matches yesterday. les matches yesterday.

SEVILLE.--That part of Spain held by the Insurgents has three capitals. The political and administrative center is Burgos, where cramped governmental quarters are steeped in traditions of Castilian centralism.

The new government's vigorous campaign to disarm civilians is proving exceptionally fruitful in Madrid. Within the last twenty-four hours 576 rifles, 863 hand grenades, 63 pistols and a large quantity of ammunition and dynamite have been collected and sequestrated.

The forlorn Reds, for whom nothing ever seems to break except around the axles, wheeled themselves to the Polo Grounds yesterday and forthwith put up the sort of performance that keeps them tremendously popular everywhere around the National League save in their home city of Cincinnati.

Mrs. Merrill MacNeille's gray gelding. St. Francis, a veteran juniper that was raced successfully at Belmont Park, captured the featured Bowman Steeplechase Handicap at the Spring meeting of the United Hunts Racing Association today before a socihty gathering of 5,000.

S. N. Harrison, publisher of The Bellingham Evening News, suspended by an American Newspaper Guild strike June 3, announced today the plant was "closed indefinitely" after negotiations with Miss Ellen-McGrath, international representative of the Guild, came to a halt.
Out of yesterday's revolt in the Senate against Premier Leon Blum's manner of governing, it is not likely that any great change will come immediately.

Three sales including a wide variety of foreign and United States coins will be held this month. The first is being conducted by Thomas L. Elder at 8 West Thirty-seventh Street. It will start Tuesday and close Friday.

The marriage of Miss Dorothy Lillian Fitzpatrick, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John C. Fitzpatrick of this city, to W. Everett Parsons Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. W. E. Parsons of Newark, took place this afternoon in the rectory of All Souls' Church here. The assistant pastor, the Rev. Maurice McManus, performed the ceremony.
Mr. and Mrs. Reuben S. Lind of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elaine Lind, to Maurice Levy, son of Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Levy of Merrick, L. I.

Diplomas were handed to 298 graduates of the military academy today by General Malin Craig, Chief of Staff of the United States Army. At the same time, 293 of the graduates were commissioned as second lieutenants.

While not a menace to real estate at the present time, the trend toward automobile trailers deserves to be watched and carefully considered by all real estate men, states Joseph P. Day. He points out that several important lessons to realtors can be learned from this type of structure.
Ralph Heyward Isham, New York financier, today married Christine Viscountess Churchill at the Paddington Register Office. Mrs. Isham is the widow of First Viscount Churchill, who died in 1934.

Pausing tomorrow to note the fourth anniversary of the Federal Government's first major home-saving offort, officials of the Home Owners Loan Corporation will look forward to the next two years as the most crucial period in this particular phase of the New Deal.
Announcement has been made of the approaching marriage of Mrs. Herman Snelling of Paris, daughter of Mrs. W. Colchester Mann of Newton, Mass., to Harvey A. Nichols of Boston and Newport.
Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine called the commanding officers of the Police Department to headquarters yesterday morning for what he termed a "caustic" lecture on the spread of gambling.
That Draper Hall, destroyed by fire this Spring, would be replaced by a modern dormitory of increased capacity was announced at New Hampton School's commencement here today.

Leonard Hartman, defending champion, entered the final round of the Brooklyn tennis championship yesterday when he defeated George Seewagen in straight sets, 6--2, 6--3, 11--9, on the courts of the Terrace Club of Flatbush. Frank Bowden also gained the last bracket, beating William Lurie, 6--2, 2--6, 6--8, 6--2.
TWO HUNDRED years ago this June the famed censorship of the English stage by the Lord Chamberlain came into official being, and, like many English institutions, it has endured long.
The sixth annual Westchester County Flower Show closed tonight at the county center here with an attendance of more than 4,500.
A sharp increase in dress linage featured the advertising by local department stores in New York and Brooklyn newspapers during May, according to the breakdown issued yesterday by Media Records, Inc.

The Corona Brewing Corporation of Puerto Rico argued today in a petition filed with the Supreme Court that the repeal amendment gave Puerto Rico the right to exempt the new company from local taxation.

CHIEF MOUNTAIN INTERNATIONAL HIGHWAY" instead of "New Kennedy Creek Road" hereafter will designate the eleven-mile stretch of scenic highway extending from the eastern boundary line of Glacier National Park, Mont., to the International Boundary Line between the United States and Canada, according to announcement made recently by the National Park Service. Chief Mountain Peak, 9,056 feet high, was given its designation by the Indians of the region, because of its resemblance to an old warrior.

Front St, 196-98, s w cor Fulton St, 56x57.1 x56.53.4; Wm. D. Seibert and another, executors of Jacob Seibert, to Oquossoc Realty Corp, 61 Bway; mtg $75,000 ($16). 19th St, 354 E. 20x92; Rosa Solomovici to Rose Orban. 335 2d Ave: mtg $7.700 ($1).

Further acute weakness in the French franc, particularly. in forward quotations, appeared in the foreign exchange market yesterday. The spot quotation for the franc fell 3/8 point to 4.447/8/s cents, retracing the advance which had been induced on the previous day by the operations of the official control.

The great grasshopper war of 1937 is being fought furiously in the Corn Belt. It began with scattered skirmishing two or - three weeks ago and reached a degree of maximum intensity during the past week. It will- probably continue for a week or two or as long as the ammunition holds out.

Decision as to whether the Communist party is still a "party" within the meaning of the New York Election Law as amended by the Legislature in 1935 was reserved today by Justice Gilbert V. Schenck of the Supreme Court.

There was a small booklet in the top drawer of a desk containing a list of lake and stream-fishing waters. But what caught our eye particularly were the words, "New York State, the State that has everything."
James F. Latimer, in 40 Fifth Ave; S. Joseph Marazzi, in 17 E 89th St; Miss Frances Mangun, Miss Muriel Tompkins, in 400 E 59th St; Douglas L. Elliman Co, brokers.

Governor George H. Earle promised labor in a speech last year that if the Democrats controlled both the Senate and House during the 1937 regular session of the Legislature, "we will write upon Pennsylvania's statute books more real liberal and social legislation than this State has seen in the last hundred years."

Miss. Elizabeth Swift, daughter of William Henry Smith Jr. of Verona and the late Mrs. Swift, was married this afternoon to Thomas William Goas, son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard L. Goas of Orange, in the Central Presbyterian Church of Montclair. The ceremony was performed by the pastor, the Rev. Morgan Phillips Noyes.
LONDON. VISITORS to Britain during this year of festivity have an opportunity of sharing the enthusiasm of the people for every kind of recreation.
Surgeons at Mercy Hospital announced that Carol Lynn Rowe, 3-year-old- "potential genius," underwent an operation to restore her sight today.
Carl Brumbaugh, veteran quarterback, was sold today by the Chicago Bears of the National Football League to the Cleveland- Rams, the circuit's newest member.

Judge John P. McGoorty, acting head of the law division of the Superior Court, ruled today that he would retain jurisdiction of the $225,000 damage suit brought by three organizers for the Committee for Industrial Organization against Edsel Ford and the Ford Motor Company.

Miss Carol Manwaring, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Addison Manwaring, and Bruce Hall Atwater, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Hall Atwater, all of this city, were married this afternoon at the home of the bride's parents. The Rev.
TRAVEL and education are to be combined-in numerous vacation tours scheduled for the coming Summer.
Police revealed tonight that a teargas grenade was found in a door at the downtown grocery store operated by Mayor Daniel A. Knaggs.
Fordham University's ninety-second annual commencement week will begin this morning with baccalaureate services in the university chapel on the campus.

Residents of this borough are being urged to buy stamps at the local postoffice "as a matter of civic pride," following a complaint by Postmaster Joseph A. Poole that the Deal Postoffice was in danger of losing its second-class rating because of dwindling patronage.

A hearing will be held before the Board of Estimate in the City Hall next Friday morning at 10:30 o'clock on the rezoning of Johnson Avenue from a residence to a business section at a point 100 feet north of West 235th Street to the intersection of West 236th Street, Riverdale.
The only activity today among the s America's Cup sloops was confined to the two Endeavours. Both of the English yachts were out on sail stretching spins, for it was a perfect sailing day.

Union College today announced to more than 1,000 alumni who attended the 142d annual commencement luncheon that it had received a total of $240,865 in gifts, the largest sum since 1929. The announcement was made by Dr. Frank Bailey of New York City and Locust Valley, L. I. Of the total, $54,617 is for current purposes and $186,248 for endowment uses.
Chinatown chose a king and a queen yesterday. They were crowned at 4:11 P. M. while the sun blazed down on Columbus Park, between Mulberry and Baxter Streets, and a noisy throng paid homage.
Violence flared briefly in the lumber strike today when strikers and employes of the Connor Land and Lumber Company clashed on a road at Thomaston.

The week-end finds many Summer residents occupying their homes here for the season. Among them are Mr. and Mrs. Martin Egan, Mr. and Mrs. Henry L. Beers, Mr. and Mrs. B. Herbert Smith, Mr. and Mrs. C. Burr Goodrich. Mr. and Mrs. Charles G. Black, Mr. and Mrs. Albert Rothwell, Mrs. Ranald H. Macdonald, Mr. and Mrs. William M. Ailing, Mrs. Clarence L. Altemus with Miss Charlotte Altemus and John Altemus;

The will of Sylvester Z. Poll, filed for probate here today, creates a trust fund of the bulk of his estate for the benefit of his widow and four daughters. The value of the estate left by the theatre operator was not indicated in the document, but court attaches estimated that it would reach $4,000,000.
