While both the Harvard and Controllers' Congress reports, issued during the last few days, showed that retailers fared well last year from the standpoint of earnings, the profit ratio for many retailers this Spring has not been equally as favorable, with the net derived from the increased sales volume being cut into sharply or even outstripped by added costs, according to views in retail circles here last week.

Miss Mary Pennock Horn, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Castar Horn Jr. of Orange, was married this afternoon to Eugene A. Williamson, son of Mrs. Charles Williamson of West Orange. The ceremony was performed in Christ Episcopal Church, East Orange, by the rector, the Rev. Charles Hutchison.
Five prominent members of the Wellesley College teaching and administrative staff, all of whom have served as chairmen of their departments, will retire this month.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated June 10: LIEUTENANT COMMANDER Updegraff, W. N., Seattle, Wash., to command Squadron 11-S, June 1; on July 1 to command VCS Squadron 6, and additional duty the Minneapolis; orders May 8 revoked.

George Washington Albright, 91year-old Negro who was born a slave, who became a member of the Mississippi "Black Legislature" during early Reconstruction days, was a pioneer Negro school teacher, farmer, oil operator, school board official, rancher and hotel owner, has come East "to shake the hand of President Roosevelt."

Manufacturer of dresses in new price lines, to meet demands of customers and permit both producer and retailer to institute a "legitimate markup to allow a fair margin of profit" will be considered at a conference early this week between representatives of the Popular Priced Dress Manufacturers Group and members of the National Association of Apparel Chains.

COLLECTING the original logbooks of old sailing ships, records of life on the high seas, intrigues many hobbyists, as is shown by the reports of the auction marts. In recent months the demand for these journals of voyages has been especially active.
AN effort to revive medieval church ritual will be made at the fourth annual Mountain Choir Festival, to be held next Sunday at Mountain Lake Park, Md., in the Blue Ridge Mountains. Dr.

Low, black clouds took heavy tll of last night's attendance in Randalls Island Stadium at the first open-air "pop" concert given by the combined chorus of 600 voices presented by the Associated Glee Clubs of America. The stands for the chorus were set in the field to face a portion of the bottom of the stadium U holding about 8.000, but the audience, scattered thinly about the bleachers, scarcely equaled the number in the chorus.

SCHOLAR'S Facsimiles and Reprints (106 Seventh Avenue, New York), is a new organization accomplishing a most useful work in a practical manner. They intend to reproduce in facsimile rare books and pamphlets beyond the reach of scholars.
HERE is a history of Virginia which covers a span of 330 years and strives to keep in perspective a period 110 years longer.

Professor Dewitt Clinton Poole, director of the School of Public and International Affairs of Princeton University, delivered the commencement address at the Gunnery School here today, marking the eighty-seventh anniversary of the founding of the school.

PARIS. THE season of opera-bouffes given under the auspices of the International Exposition of Art and Technique has Just opened at the Comedie des Champs Elysees. "L'Ecossais de Chatou," with music by Leo Delibes, opened the program of four one-act operettas.

THE Soviet Union's third Five Year Plan, announced at Moscow last week as a measure "to overtake and surpass America" industrially, is expected to be advertised to the world after it goes into effect next January with stamps presenting designs illustrating the project.

Frank Crosetti hit his third and fourth home runs of the season at Sportsman's Park today and Lou Gehrig drove his tenth of the campaign in a Yankee fireworks display that helped celebrate American Legion Day here.
A contribution of $50,000 to Columbia University from the Josiah Macy Jr. Foundation for development of research and instruction in the medical sciences was announced yesterday by the university.
Tufts College today opened its commencement season by celebrating Alumni Day with the members of the fifty-year class of '87 and their families honor guests.
MAN OF STEEL: In Transcaucasia, near the city of Tiflis, was born more than fifty-seven years ago Joseph Djugashvili, the son of a shoemaker.

Dandora, chestnut mare owned and ridden by Lieutenant George Van A. Kaufman of Hampton, N. J., found the outside course of the third annual Rock Spring Horse Show to her liking today and three times circled the brush and rail barriers to win blues.
The National Confessional Synod has issued to all Protestant pastors a warning that the National Socialist regime is systematically undertaking to deChristianize the coming generation.
New faces will appear in the pavilions, clinics and laboratories of New York Hospital, at Sixty-eighth Street and the East River, with the closing of the women's colleges for the Summer.
Nick Masters, Far Rockaway light heavyweight, will oppose Al Coccozza of South Brooklyn in the main event of six rounds at the Rockaway Arena on Friday night.

Degrees, diplomas and commissions will be conferred by City College on a record graduating class of more than 2,100 men and women at the ninety-first commencement exercises in the City College Stadium Wednesday evening.

MEXICO, D. F. THE influx of tourists that has swamped not only Mexico City but the minor towns of the country as well, has bowed in shame a proud old headthat of Mount Popocatepetl, which rises nearly 18,000 feet above sea level and some 10,000 above the national capital.

Dr. HARRY EMERSON FOSDICK, in his commencement address at Johns Hopkins University, caught into his own clarion call a phrase from THOREAU: that we have been engrossed in the invention of "improved means to an unimproved end."

At Rumson, New Jersey, Edward F., formerly of New York City, beloved brother of Julia G. Anderson, Mrs. Helena McLaughlin, Mrs. Gertrude Willoughby. Services at Church of Holy Cross, Rumson, Monday, 9 A. M. Interment Calvary Cemetery, Brooklyn.
Government forces struck back on the Cordoba front today, more than regaining the ground they lost Tuesday, and once again asserting their domination in that sector.

THERE were only two men," writes Mr. Fulop-Miller of the closing period of the nineteenth century, "who perceived in all its significance the terrible and fateful reverse side of the great picture of industrial progress"--Pope Leo XIII and Karl Marx.

A concert in memory of Jeno Hubay, the famous Hungarian violinist, composer and pedagogue, was held recently in the Budapest Academy of Music under the auspices of the Landesband Ungarischer Kulturvereinigungen.

Shooting birdies like a quail hunter on the loose, Willie Turnesa blasted Howard Bergman off the course at the Century Country Club today and, with a dazzling exhibition of sub-par golf, marched off with his second successive Westchester amateur championship.
Fascisti paid tribute today to General Alberto Liuzzi, the first high-ranking Italian officer officially announced as dead in the Spanish civil war.

THE CAT AND THE CANARY-Tomorrow evening at the Majestic Theatre. The Dollar Top Theatre is reviving the Willard Parker melodrama with these people in the cast: Howard Miller, Helen Claire, Hermann Lieb, Matthew Smith, Robert Ober, Eric Kalkhurst, Richard Barrows and Jeanne Temple.

Union Square, home of the soapbox and usually resounding on Saturday afternoon with oratory directed against Fascists and Nazis, came in for a surprise yesterday when Representative Emanuel Celler of Brooklyn, addressing a mass meeting of 500 members of labor organizations, referred to Stalin, along with Hitler and Mussolini, as conducting "governments of treachery."

AMONG professional decorators there seems to be, judging from the interiors which they design, a tendency to treat period motifs in a freer manner, either by combining furniture of different though allied styles or introducing contemporary pieces.

A major dog show problem once more has come to the front, and while its solution is simple, it would appear probable that considerable attention will be required. This is the time of the closing of entries for all-breed exhibitions, which, under the present rules, is 6 P. M. seven days before the opening of the show.
Three persons were killed and fifteen others injured in a crash of two school buses at near-by Scott Hill tonight. They were on the way to a school play.

While the special deputies 'and vigilantes who helped smash the picket line around the local steel plant last Thursday will lay down their arms tomorrow in a Sabbath truce, many of them will put on uniforms and join a battalion of the Michigan National Guard in policing tomorrow's union meeting.

Alumni Day at Lehigh University provide no fewer today than eleven class reunion banquets, as well as the annual alumni business meeting, an alumni parade to Taylor stadium and the baseball game between the Lehigh Varsity and the alumni.

IN A L. THURSBY of this city has given $125,000 for a music building at the Moravian Seminary and College for Women, Bethlehem, Pa., in memory of her music sister, Emma Cecilia Thursby, the celebrated soprano.
Political uncertainty in Paris was responsible for renewed nervousness here concerning the forward franc today and the discount for three-month delivery increased sharply, from 3 5/8 to 4 3/4 francs.
Diving into the Charles River from the River Street bridge, two Harvard students swam to the rescue early this morning of William J. White, 38, a suspended Cambridge fireman.

THE amount of research in the British Museum and the Bodleian Library which this compilation entailed should make even those pause who may say at the end that the dust of oblivion was more kind to the seventeenth - century poetasters than was Dr. Marshall.
Settlement of the strike of employes of the Pechter Bakery Company, which operates four plants in Harlem and the Bronx, was announced last night by Henry Mayer, attorney for the company.

The 200th anniversary of the birth of Christopher Colles, engineer, scientist and conceiver of the Erie Canal, was observed yesterday by the American Irish Historical Society at a luncheon at the Claremont Inn on Riverside Drive.
Another socalled crisis over Spain has come and gone and has been settled with so little difficulty that one almost forgets the scare headlines it produced less than a fortnight ago.
In the presence of a large gathering of fanciers, the final award in the annual all-breed dog show of the North Westchester Kennel Club today was made by John G. Bates of New York City.

NOT long ago a student wrote to the superintendent of the reading room at the Library of Congress at Washington to say that he wanted to come to the library and use it for two or three weeks going over material which he needed in connection with his writing and lecturing.

Two new bathing beaches and recreational areas within the city limits-the development of Orchard Beach, Pelham Bay Park, the Bronx, planned by the Department of Parks as a municipal rival of Jones Beach, at Wantagh, L. I., and Jacob Riis Park, on the Rockaway Peninsula in Queens-will be opened to the public at 9 o'clock next Saturday morning.

The time has arrived for us to take further action to extend the frantiers of social progress. With those words President Roosevelt three weeks ago opened his mes'sage to Congress requesting maximum hour-minimum wage legislation.
Nine errors in two games cost the Rochester Red Wings, both ends of a double-header today, the Syracuse Chiefs taking the first by a wide margin, 3 to 8, and the second, 5 to 4.
Tom Bolles, Harvara's new rowing coach, lost no time after the squad's arrival at Gales Ferry this afternoon to test his varsity crew over the full four-mile Thames River course.

The savings, building and loan associations of the country advanced during the month of April to-members for various uses, a total of $125,386,000, which, according to Morton Bodfish, executive vice president of the United States Building and Loan League, is the largest amount loaned by those organizations during the recovery period.

Plans for a University of Michigan semi-monthly magazine, Panorama, to be modeled after the picture periodical Life, have been approved by the Board in Control of Student Publications. The new publication will appear next year and will be edited by Joan V. Hanson, '40.

A NEW device, described for the layman as "a ghost engineer," but in the parlance of the technician as an "automatic peak volume limiter," is to be installed at Station WABC and eight affiliates of the network.
Dr. James E. West, Chief Scout Executive of the Boy Scouts of America, announced yesterday a new record membership registration of 1,075,423 Cubs, Scouts and adult leaders as of April 30.

Miss Virginia Waugh, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Morton Waugh Jr. of this place, was married here tonight to William Amos Grier, son of Mrs. Lily Scheer Grier of Baldwin, L. I. The ceremony was performed in the Hitchcock Memorial Church by the pastor, the Rev. George Hugh Smyth.

Mr. and Mrs. Helmuth von Moltlke Kiesewetter of South Orange, N. J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Hope Tyler Kiesewetter, to Standish Forde Medina, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold R. Medina of 14 East Seventy-fifth Street.
Guided tours of New York school libraries are to be offered delegates to the convention of the American Library Association here during the week of June 20.
Dr. Earle Fenton Palmer, Professor of Rhetoric at City College and a teacher of English, retired yesterday under the age limit. Dr. Palmer will celebrate his seventieth birthday on July 2.

The piling up of "sterilized" gold in the Treasury's general fund to a total of approximately $900,000,000 has served, among other things, to attract the attention of some members of the old "inflationary" bloc in Congress,

The haze above the Pacific location of the Princeton University, Franklin Institute and Cook Observatory eclipse expedition on Tuesday must have formed a thin layer well up in the stratosphere at a height of at least fifteen miles.

Philip Murray, union leader, said tonight that the steel companies affected by strikes in Ohio have agreed to maintain "present conditions" in their mills during negotiations at the Governor's office in Columbus.

THIS life of Henry Purcell by J. A. Westrup is a new member of the excellent "Master Musicians Series," there having been no volume devoted to its subject in the original collection, published some thirty years ago. It is a valuable and important contribution to our knowledge of one who is regarded as the foremost of English musicians since the great days of the Elizabethan period.

Miss Shirley Gardiner White, daughter of Charles P. White of Glen Brook, and Edwin Francis Kittle, son of Mr. and Mrs. G. Kent Kittle, also of Glen Brook, will be married next Saturday afternoon in Union Memorial Church.
Kibitzers will be in their glory when bridge teams from nearly a score of countries meet in a sevenday tournament beginning here tomorrow.

Year-long efforts of SpanishAmerican war veterans to reach an agreement on a design for a memorial to be erected in Summerfield Park terminated this week when Major William A. Darcey, chairman of the veterans' art committee, was notified that the Works Progress Administration had accepted the latest design submitted by Karl Illava of Greenwich, Conn.

A TOTAL eclipse of the sun is such a magnificent spectacle in the lifetime of a radio announcer that for once he finds himself at a loss for adjectives. The broadcast description is simple, almost as if an excited schoolboy was at the microphone. Words fail;

A strike of employes of Ludwig Baumann Co., which operates five stores in New York City and one in Newark, was settled yesterday at City Hall when the company accepted a group of American Federation of Labor unions as the representatives of its 1,500 employes and agreed to negotiate a one-year contract.

THIS reporter burst in on Alexander Korda, one of the two remaining United Artists, the night before he sailed for England and his vast London Films plant at Denham last week, and asked quite bluntly what has been wrong with British film production.

Miss Dorothea Patricia Reardon, daughter of Mrs. Edwin A. Weis, was married to Joseph Mario Vitelli, son of Mr. and Mrs. Giuseppe Vitelli, this morning in St. Raymond's Church here. The bridegroom's uncle, Mgr. FrancisVitelli, performed the ceremony and also celebrated the nuptial mass. He was assisted by the Rev. James O'Laughlen.

Treasury narcotic agents believed they had cut off yesterday an important source of narcotics supply to the underworld in Southern cities with the arraignment of two men and two women in Brooklyn, seized in a raid Friday night in an apartment house at 6,413 Twenty-fourth Avenue.

Post master General Farley today asked the Interstate Commerce Commission to make an audit of the books of the Chicago Southern Air Lines in connection with the application of the company to the commission for the fixing of reasonable rates in relation to its air-mail contract on Route 8.
By the narrow margin of two votes the French Chamber of Deputies passed this week the bill to suppress tipping as a means of livelihood. That does not mean that it suppressed tipping.

Members of the Westchester County Taxpayers Association were urged this week by E. M. Allen of Port Chester, their president, to conduct a campaign "to arouse citizens to the seriousness of the continual spending spree by the government, which has saddled the people of the nation with an unparalleled debt burden."
FIVE hundred million people are today submitting to British rule. This immense and varied population is governed with reasonable ease.

Ruth Page, premiere danseuse and ballet mistress of the Chicago Opera Ballet, has recently returned from a series of solo appearances in the Scandinavian countries, said to be the first such venture to be undertaken by an American dancer.

Mr. and Mrs. Frederic Fuller are returning, to occupy the G. Whiting Hollister house on Lily Pond Lane. Mr. and Mrs. John M. Budinger of Bronxville, N. Y., have taken the Neilson house on Pantigo Lane.

With a new coat of light gray paint, the 1,500-ton destroyer U. S. S. Dunlap was commissioned yesterday morning in the New York Navy Yard, Brooklyn. Captain Roe R. Adams, captain of the yard, read orders from Washington placing the ship in commission with Commander Albert E. Schrader as captain.
Six members of the German Air Force were killed when their military plane, caught in a squall, crashed near Detmold, it was disclosed today.
The International Labor Conference's plenary meeting heard an employer delegate justify the forty-hour week today for the first time at this conference.

BILBAO FRONT--Rebel headquarters announced the Basque "iron ring" in front of Bilbao had been pierced in two places. There was heavy aerial bombardment of Bilbao and its suburbs, and a powerful artillery barrage was laid on the defenses. Paris heard the Basque government had fled to Santander and evacuation of the city had begun. Page 1.

GIAN DAULI--enterprising editor of literary reviews, assiduous translator of foreign works into Italian and prolific novelist, now in his fifties, and who, by the way, bears a strong physical resemblance to Beethoven-has sometimes been compared to Zola and Dostoievsky and spoken of as the Italian Galsworthy.

Mr. and Mrs. Randolph C. Grew of Marlboro Street have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Eugenie H. Grew, to Alexander Cochrane, son of Mr. and Mrs. F. Douglas Cochrane, also of this city.

The marriage of Miss Dorothy Randolph Fell, daughter of Mrs. Ogden Livingston Mills of 2 East Sixty-ninth Street, New York, and this place, to Howell van Gerbig of 11 East Sixty-ninth Street, New York, took place here this morning at the country home of Mr. and Mrs. Mills.
Most regattagoers, confirmed addicts of rowing spectacles, make a week of it. They shuttle between Poughkeepsie and New London.

New York Botanical Gardens, Bronx Park, announces that its roses have never been in finer flower than now. Besides many species, they include exceptional collections of various types; that of hybrid teas and hybrid perpetuals is said to constitute the finest collection of the sort in the country.

THE mountains, the sea, the; valleys and lakes of New England are calling to America's vacationists. Transportation companies are out with Summer schedules; hotels and Summer camps are distributing vacation leaflets and folders; State agencies have organized for publication the country over of the attractions of the Land of the Pilgrims.

The marriage of Miss Leila M. Schenck, daughter of Mrs. Benjamin Robinson Schenck of this city and the late Dr. Schenck of Baltimore and Detroit, to Stuart Parson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stuart H. Parson of Bronxville, N. Y., took place yesterday afternoon in the Chapel of the Church of the Heavenly Rest.

Miss Florence Hilda Carpenter, daughter of Mr and Mrs. William L. Carpenter of 150 East Ninety first Street and South Norwalk, Conn., was married to Conrad A. Andersen, oldest son of Emil Andersen of Stamford, Conn., and the late Mrs. Andersen, yesterday afternoon in the chantry of St. Thomas Church.

Horation Alger, in his most imaginative days, never wrote a more thrilling success' story than the one Ralph Guldahl has scribbled in bold capital letters over the fairways and greens of the nation's golf. courses.

For the first time in eight weeks THE NEW YORK TIMES weekly index of business activity has declined. It lost two points for the week ended June 5, falling to 107.9 from 109.7 (revised) in the previous week and comparing with 97.9 a year ago.

R. W. V. Robins, popular Middlesex amateur, has been chosen to captain England in the opening cricket test match against New Zealand, it was announced today. The match, first of a series of three, is scheduled for Lord's June 26.

Rapidly increasing population throughout Westchester County is gradually absorbing all available rental space and materially strengthening rental conditions, states Albert W. Lockyer, president of the Westchester County Realty Board.
Freckels, a 3-year-old trotter owned by C. D. Robbins and driven by Carl Recor, won the Class A event, feature performance of the matinee held at Weequahic Park today.

Detectives of the safe and loft squad who had been trailing two suspected clothing thieves for several weeks captured their men yesterday afternoon in front of a loft building at 21 East Eighth Street after a short battle during which one of the suspects was shot in the left elbow.
Miss. Harriet Corning, daughter of Mrs. Edwin Corning and the late Lieut. Gov. Edwin Corning of Kenwood was married this afternoon in All Saints Cathedral to Wharton Sinkler Jr. of Elkins Park, Pa.

Governor Lehman announced today that he would hold a clemency hearing June 24 in the executive chamber for four men convicted of murdering Ike Shain during the hold-up of a Kings County bar and grill.
The Spanish Republican Government today rewarded the "savior of Madrid," General Jose Miaja, with the highest military decoration within its power.

Mrs. Scott Clark of Spring House, Wynnewood, has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Betty Clark, to John Wesley Cullen, son of Mrs. Edward E. Cullen Jr. of this city and the late Mr. Cullen.

WASHINGTON. THE question as to where the control of the nation's air transport system is to be lodged has at last reached the floors of Congress. Last week two measures introduced in the Senate by Senator Pat McCarran of Nevada were reported upon favorably by the Senate Committee on Interstate Commerce.

John Hay Whitney's Eastern, champion, Inhale, went to the post a 3-to-5 favorite for the $20,000 Princess Pat Stakes for 2-year-old fillies at Washington Park today, but when the numbers went up after a photo finish the winner was a Western juvenile, Well Rewarded, running with Manie O'Hara as the entry of Mrs. Ethel V. Mars of Chicago, owner of the famed Milky Way Farm Stables.

STARTING with a limited schedule, the steamers cruising the 1,000 miles between Niagara Falls and the Gulf of St. Lawrence and Saguenay River will be on a daily schedule both east and west by the end of the month.

Twenty-eight scholarships, covering a year's tuition, have been granted by the Training School for Secretaries, 117 West Forty-eighth Street, Miss Claire Bloomfield, registrar, announced yesterday. These scholarships are valued at $250 each.

Workmen, using a bo'sun's chair, rescued two painters from inside a afxly-foot smokestack of the steamslip Manhattan of the United States Lines yesterday, after the two had been overcome by fumes. The painters, Louis Rivas, 48 years old, of 419 West Nineteenth Street, ani Joseph Olsemer, 39, of 441 West Seventeenth Street, were applying a coat of aluminum paint to the inside of the stack.

Uneasiness over the labor situation in the United States is increasing here, especially because of the apparent indifference of President Roosevelt to this serious development in the country's economic life.

Delivering the valedictory address today to the senior class at Dartmouth College, President Hopkins challenged the attitude of some who believe that the present college generation has a right t pity itself because of the difficulties that must be overcome in the present-day world.
The fourpower accord reached in London over the resumption of naval control in Spanish waters is accepted here as having theoretical value, and that only for the time being.

The Senate is to receive tomorrow the unfavorable report of the Judiciary Committee on the President's courtreorganization plan. The report is 12,000 words in length. Just when the court measure will be called up for debate is uncertain.
Dr. Frank D. Fackenthal, secretary of Columbia University, announced yesterday the award of eight fellowships and seventeen scholarships for 1937-38.

Before a crowd of 7,000, one of the largest to witness a polo contest at Governors Island, the Governors Island quartet subdued a team composed of Monmouth County Country Club players yesterday at Morris Memorial Field.
We still hear a good deal about technological unemployment and the number of people thrown out of work by improved

Hoping to repeat the success it had with Maurice Chevalier, Paramount has signed Georges Rinaud as Marlene Dietrich's leading man in "Midnight," which is scheduled to enter production in the Fall. Rinaud is well known in the theatre of the Argentine as well as of France. He has made several French films. The script of "Midnight" is in the hands of Franz Schulz and Edwin Justus Maver.

The Cubs held the National League lead for a short time today after defeating the Phillies in the first game of a twin bill, 16 to 8, but quickly dropped out of the top berth when Philadelphia won the nightcap, 4 to 3, before 10.000.

The gold scare which had the financial market here so strongly in its grip over the last fortnight has subsided, thanks to the simple reassurance given by President Roosevelt at the end of last week and the more elaborate statement by the British Chancellor of the Exchequer on Tuesday of this week.
The Indians took both- games of a double-header, 2 to 1 and 2 to 0, from the Athletics today, evening the series at two games each.

Exactly two years after the cessation of the Chaco war the Paraguayan Army has revolted to overthrow the regime of Provisional President Rafael Franco and prevent the Chaco peace agreements from being put into effect, according to private advices received this afternoon from Asuncion.
Robert Forbes Brown, a New York contractor who built many fine city and country homes and public buildings, died today at his home here of a heart ailment at the age of 68.
At least fifteen men were injured as rioting marked the strike at the Cambria Works of the Bethlehem Steel Company plant here today.

Paine, Webber Co. and F. S. Moseley Co. will offer to the public today 120,000 common shares of the National Cylinder Gas Company at $17.50 a share. Of the proceeds, about $550,000 will be used for the retirement of the entire 6 per cent preferred stock, whereupon the common stock will become the sole capital issue. The company has no funded debt.
KENNEBEC, CRADLE OF AMERICANS, by Robert P. Tristram Coffin. (Farrar Rinehart, $2.50.) The story of Maine's great river.

Amelia Earhart paused only briefly here today on her flight around the world. She arrived at 7:28 A. M. Greenwich time [3:28 A. M.. New York time], after a 500-mile flight from El Fasher, in Western Sudan. An hour and fourteen minutes later she was flying toward Asia.

Next to depart from Broadway's thinning list of entertainments will be "The Show Is On," which closes next Saturday night at the Winter Garden after a run of twenty-five weeks and two days It is a not unexpected decision, for Lee Shubert some time ago announced its "last weeks," though he later withdrew that warning and instead reduced the prices (on June 1). "Pos-.
Twelve students in the graduate schools of Harvard University have been named marshals for the various graduating classes at the commencement exercises, a week from next Thursday.

Invitations have been extended to nine of this country's leading women tennis players to join the Wightman Cup squad in preparing for the international matches against England's representatives set for Forest Hills on Friday and Saturday, Aug. 20 and 21. Two of the players asked to participate in the practice sessions are now in England.

Howard A. Gray, director of housing of the Public Works Administration, reported today to Secretary Ickes, PWA Administrator, that the rejection as exorbitant of bids for the construction of seven housing projects had resulted in getting the work done during the past three months for $2,056,470 less than the original estimates.

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $4,152,796,600. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and non-interestbearing discount bills. The list follows:
Led by Merrill Fink, who scored six goals, a Blind Brook polo quartet overwhelmed a New York Athletic Club combination, 12 to 4, in an exhibition contest at the Blind Brook Turf and Polo Club today.

' The two Houghton Mifflin Literary Fellowships for 1937 have been awarded to David Cornel DeJong of 218 East Thirty-sixth Street, New York City, and to Dorothy Baker of El Cerrito, Calif., it was announced yesterday. Each of the winners will receive $1,000 in addition to usual advances and royalties. The prizes are awarded annually to assist writers to complete projected works. Both winners this year are at work on novels.

There are some fishermen who might readily be termed pioneers. They like to discover new fields to conquer and new places to fish. When a veteran Massachusetts angler like Frederic L. Smith of Nantucket goes half way around the globe and fishes for trout in New Zealand, that's news.

Family Outboards, Three and One-Third Miles, Open-Won by Frank Luquish, Bronx; C. Ward Frauenthal, Freeport, L. I., second; Arthur Baldwin, Freeport, L. I., third; Wesley Carman. Freeport, fourth; Eugene Wilks, New York, fifth. Time-5:43 4-5. Speed-34.903 M. P. H.

In the last fortnight Insurgent airmen have shot down forty-three Loyalist planes on the Guadarrama, Aragon and Basque fronts and chased four machines from Bilbae Into France, where they have been interned at the Biarritz-Parme airdrome by order of non-intervention control officials.

The four-story American basement dwelling at 510 East Eightyseventh Street, in the Yorkville section, was sold by Raymond Dillon to Samuel M. S. Lanham, who intends to occupy it after alterations, which will include air-conditioning. It has a frontage of eighteen feet and was sold through Warren L. Marks, Daniel Brener, Inc.
The official report on the condition of leading crops for June 1 shows slight improvements in wheat and rye. Winter wheat is 2.9, on the index basis of 2 equal to good and 3 equal to mediocre.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Kingsland Spencer of Tarrytown, N. Y., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Cynthia-Mary Spencer, to John Van Voorhis Cockcroft, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward T. Cockcroft of 137 East Sixty-sixth Street.
Dr. Mary E. Woolley, retiring president of Mount Holyoke College, laid the cornerstone for a new chapel, soon to replace Mary Lyon Chapel, at the close of the baccalaureate service this morning.

With a record crowd of 20,000 attending the fifteenth annual pilgrimage to .St. Anthony's International Shrine here today, all highways through the southern part of Rockland County were jammed with traffic. The normal population of this village is only 3,000, but the throng of visitors attracted hundreds of people from near-by villages to witness the spectacle.
Degrees were presented to nine students of the Hudson College of Commerce and Finance, the evening division of St. Peter's College here, at exercises this evening.

Theodore D. Staats, 73 years old, has been promised by Pennsylvania Railroad officials that he will have the privilege of buying the first ticket for the initial Newark-toNew York tube trip scheduled to start from the new Market Street station here next Sunday at 4:01 A. M.
The problem of how to go about removing a family of robins from the pocket of his coat is perplexing Morris Brenner, concert violinist and head of the music department of Deal Conservatoire, today.

Dr. Neil Carothers, director of the College of Business Administration, Lehigh University, will deliver the address at the Blair Academy commencement exercises here tomorrow morning at 11 o'clock. Dr.

Czechoslovakia won its place in the European zone Davis Cup final round today by taking the doubles match, which was halted by rain yesterday. The victors forfeited the last two singles matches to emerge with a 3-to-2 decision over Yugoslavia.

France's first statue of Father Jacques Marquette, the seventeenth century Jesuit missionary who explored the upper valley of the Mississippi, was unveiled here today on the 300th anniversary of his birth in the presence of high French and American officials.

New York State National Guard units, made up of more than 21,000 men, opened the Summer training season here today at Camp Smith and Pine Camp with about 1,700 medical troops, cavalrymen and engineers taking the field.

Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Edward Faithfull of this city have announced the marriage of Mrs. Faithfull's daughter, Miss Elizabeth Tucker Wyman, to Edward Anthony Hancock, son of Mrs. Antoinette K. Hancock of Chicago and Raymond G. Hancock

Joe Louis, preparing for his bout with James J. Braddock, world heavyweight champion, went eight rounds against four spar mates this afternoon before a crowd of 2,500 fans at Lake Front Stadium, but showed little improvement with his right.

Stockholders of the General Tire and Rubber Company of record next Friday will receive rights to buy 64,697 additional common shares on the basis of one new share for each seven shares held, at $20 a share until July 2.

Nothing is so uncertain today as conceptions of right and wrong, said Dr. A. Edwin Keigwin, pastor of the West End Presbyterian Church, Amsterdam Avenue and 105th Street, in a children's day sermon based on the shepherd of the Twenty-third Psalm.

Despite a thirty-day extension of time from May 31, .90 per cent of the 750,000 chauffeurs in the State of New York have failed to renew their licenses, which expire at midnight June 30, Charles A. Harnett, Commissioner of Motor Vehicles, revealed yesterday.

Miss Marie Folger, 50 years old, of 459 East Forty-ninth Street, Brooklyn, jumped or fell to her death yesterday morning from the roof of the Pierrepont Hotel, an eighteen- story structure, at 51 Pierrepont Street, Brooklyn.

Clairvoyant, racing for the Argentine-owned stable of Eduardo Martinez de Hoz, won the rich Prix du Jockey Club at Chantilly today by a length and a half ahead of Princesse de Faueigny-Lucinge's Actor. Simon Guthmann's Galloway, a 25-10 shot, was third.
Ernest Michael Fuller, a retired lawyer, who was descended from the first physician in America, died yesterday morning at his home in South Orange, N. J., at the age of 57

British steel production in May was 1,047,300 tons, compared with 1,080,400 in the preceding month, 696,300 in May, 1936, and a high record of 1,109,500 in March, 1937. Production exceeded official expectations, tempered by the Coronation and other holidays which slackened business.

Twenty-two second lieutenants of the United States Army, just commissioned, took brides today in the United States Military Academy's cadet chapel and Holy Trinity Chapel. Most of the ceremonies were by Chaplain Roscoe E. Foust of the academy, who officiated in the cadet chapel, and the Rev. George G. Murdock, who officiated in Holy Trinity Chapel.
From whatever quarter news of the steel strike comes-from Monroe, Youngstown, South Chicago or other affected areas-one point stands out significantly. Everywhere the C. I. O.
The Most Rev. Moses E. Kiley, Bishop of the Catholic Diocese of Trenton, will preside at the fourteenth annual commencement exercises of St. Joseph's College here tomorrow morning.

A thirty-foot cabin skiff, in which Captain F. H. Kelley of Belleville and Charles Shellfont of Trenton were returning from a fishing trip, sank to its gunwales a mile off Point Pleasant this afternoon, but remained afloat, due to air tanks in the hold.

The Whites, with two woman stars in their line-up, furnished stubborn opposition to a Brown polo team, led by Fred Miller, before bowing by 6-4 today at Bethpage State Park. Mrs. Frances Wood and Miss Marjorie Le Boutillier, who will play on the Eastern women's quartet that will meet a California four next month, featured the game with excellent defensive work for the losers.
Mrs. Jennie Avtzime Haft, wife of Max Haft of 465 Crown Street, Brooklyn, retired merchant, died yesterday in the Jewish Hospital, Brooklyn, at the age of 72. She was the mother of Morris W. Haft

Brooklyn police announced yesterday that John O'Connor, 31 years old, of 384 Hicks Street, had confessed that he had lighted several early morning fires in baby carriages that had terrified crowded tenements.

J. B. Gillett, author of "Six Years a Texas Ranger," died Friday night. He was 80 years old. Captain (Jim) Gillett served in the frontier battalion of the Texas Rangers in the Seventies and was Marshal of El Paso -in the early Eighties.

More than 400 excursionists inspected the plant of the Baldwin Locomotive Works at Eddystone, Pa., yesterday under the auspices of the New York chapter of the Railway and Locomotive Historical Society.

Retail prices on June 1 showed a gain of four-tenths of 1 per cent over May 1 and were at the highest level since March 1, 1931, according to the Fairchild Index. Figures were 8.5 per cent higher than on June 1 a year ago and 8.8 per cent above the 1936 low.

Kalinga Boli, the wild head-hunter credited with killing at least thirteen persons the past three weeks, was captured single-handed by a Philippine constabularyman, reports from Abalung have disclosed.

Richard E. Boiler, formerly with the Kempner Realty Corporation, is with Porter Co., Real Estate, Inc. A mortgage of $65,000 at 4 1/2 per cent for five years has been placed on 101 East Eighty-seventh Street by Robert E. Hill, Inc., as broker, for the Brownhill Realty Corporation.

The index for French wholesale prices on June 5 stood at 530, against 529 on May 29 and 532 on May 22. The gold index for world prices of raw materials stood at 54.7, compared with 55 on May 29 and 55.5 on May 22.

Lady Astor, member of Parliament, the Maharaja and Maharani of Winkomer, Rutherford Stuyvesant and Mrs. Lewis Clark are among the passengers due to arrive today from Europe on the French liner Normandie.
The votes by the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls in Congress last week are given in the following tabulation:

William F. Burnner, president of the Board of Aldermen, was the principal speaker yesterday at the annual convention of the Long Island region of the Union of Orthodox Jewish Congregations of America.

Cardinal von Faulhaber caused announcements from all Catholic pulpits today that he had protested to Hanns Kerrl, Church Minister, against the arrest of the Rev. Rupert Mayr. Father Mayr, who is a one-legged war veteran and perhaps the most popular Bavarian priest, was arrested June 5 and is still in prison.
A coming revival of religion that "will stir the world to its very foundation" was forecast by the Rev. R. A. D. Beaty in a sermon yesterday afternoon at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

Edward Knolhoff, Trinity Club ace, met little difficulty in eliminating Eugene Fox of the Ostend A. C., 21-4, 21--5, in one of the second-round matches of the Queens County A. A. U. one-wall handball singles championship yesterday at the Broad Channel Bathing Park.

Six men were arrested tonight several hours after nine non-union automobile workers had been wounded here by shotgun fire in a clash between members of the United Automobile Workers of America and non-union employes.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Edith M. Sanders, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. August Sanders of this city, to Dr. Harold M. Faigenbaum of Troy, N. Y. Miss Sanders was graduated from the New York State College for Teachers, and attended the New York School of Social Work. Dr.

More than 5,000 Roman Catholics heard a denunciation of State tyranny yesterday afternoon at the annual Holy Name Society rally of the West Side section of the Manhattan Division of the New York Archdiocesan Union.

In 1936 the Department of Purchasemade substantial advances in efficiency and. in saving money for the city, Commissioner Russell Forbes informed Mayor La Guardia yesterday in his. departmental report for last year.

Confirmation of reports of the sharp increase in all kinds of resort and travel advertising this season was given yesterday and Saturday when local newspapers brought out their special vacation and resort sections. One Sunday newspaper reported its largest section on record, with linage about 10 per cent ahead of last year, with others registering slightly smaller or similar gains.

Jersey City and Toronto divided a double-header today, the Jerseys winning the first, 2 to 1, but dropping the second, 5 to 0. Rollie Stiles turned the Leafs back with six hits in the opener and bested Earl Caldwell in a pitchers' battle.
No Japanese boats are fishing for salmon in the Bristol Bay region off Alaska, a Foreign Office spokesman said today.

The engagement of Miss Catherine Aker, daughter of Joseph H. Aker of this place, to Robert P. O'Loughlin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael T. O'Loughlin, also of Nutley, has been announced. The wedding will take place in September.

Commencement exercises of Alma White College will be held here tomorrow afternoon, with the Rev. Dr.Arthur K. White, Junior Bishop of the Pillar of Fire Church and president of the college, as the speaker. Zarephath Bible Seminary and Alma Preparatory School are associated with the college.
Elden Auker, Detroit's right-handed "submarine ball" pitcher, held the Red Sox to five scattered hits today as the Tigers won, 3 to 1, their third victory of the four-game series.
Two Spaniards were hit by stones in the plaza in front of the Church of Santo Domingo this morning after services in honor of General Emilio Mola, Spanish Rebel leader.

The cooperation of science and religion is essential for the salvation of the world today, Dr. Douglas Clyde Macintosh of the Yale Divinity School told the graduating class of Connecticut College in the baccalaureate sermon delivered tonight at St. James Church here.

Flag Day, which was begun by President Wilson in 1916, will be observed in the city today. The exercises will mark the 160th anniversary of the adoption of the Stars and Stripes as the national emblem.

Mary Pickford and Charles (Buddy) Rogers will be married Saturday, June 26, in a simple outdoor ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Louis D. Lighton in Los Angeles. Miss Pickford today set the date and said she and the orchestra leader-movie actor would honeymoon in Honolulu.

The behavior of "radical students" at City College was denounced as an "insult to the taxpayers who are supporting that school" in an address in the Hotel Astor yesterday by Colonel Alexander E. Anderson of the 165th Infantry at a communion breakfast of the New York Alumni Chapter of Theta Kappa Phi, a fraternity that brings together Roman Catholic students at non-Catholic institutions throughout the country.

The C. I. O. was denounced yesterday from the pulpit of the Marble Collegiate Reformed Church, Fifth Avenue and Twenty-ninth Street, by Dr. Norman Vincent Peale, as "an amazing and shocking perversion of the labor movement which will ultimately set back the cause of labor by turning all decent and lawabiding citizens against all working men."

In view of the disquieting labor controversies, the mounting taxes on industry, the recurrent uneasiness over political and financial developments at Washington, and the stock market's springtime reaction, the course of trade and industry has been reassuring. A good deal has occurred, thus far in 1937, which was not clearly foreshadowed during the hopefulness of six months ago.

Seventy-one economists, constituting the Economists' National Committee on Monetary Policy, have five signed a statement, which was made public yesterday, urging the abandonment of the government's silverpurchase program.

The Senate Appropriations Committee has taken a significant step in voting for the Byrnes amendment to the Relief Bill, which forces local governmental entities to pay at least 40 per cent of the cost of all new WPA projects.

One thousand barbers, members of the Journeymen Barbers International Union, Local 217, met yesterday at the Brooklyn Labor Lyceum, 949 Willoughby Avenue, and voted to call a strike in 1,500 Brooklyn shops this morning and one in Queens later.

Two persons were injured fatally and one other is in the Peekskill Hospital in a serious condition as the result of a head-on collision of two automobiles on the Bronx River Parkway Extension, one mile north of the Croton Lake Bridge, shortly before midnight last night.
Clinton P. Case, retired vice president of the . W. Woolworth Company, died here this afternoon after a brief illness at his home, Braeview. He would have been 82 years old on June 21.

After leading the Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League for most of the season, Dartmouth was defeated twice by Harvard on Thursday and dropped to third place in the standings. Yale became the pace-setter and, after improving its position with a victory over Princeton on Saturday, is now the favorite to take the title.
Further casualty lists published today shocked all Italians by revealing the losses suffered by Italians fighting in Spain had been much greater than any one imagined.
Displaying the agility of a middleaged woman, Mrs. Doris Mattis, believed to be New Jersey's oldest living resident, walked up the long hill from her Mechanic Street home to the Sts.

The Transport Workers Union of America, holder of an international charter from the Committee for Industrial Organization, announced yesterday the creation of an Office Workers Division to organize all clerical and general office workers employed by transit companies within the union's jurisdiction.
The need in this city for "more recognition of the innate unity that is here" was expounded yesterday in a sermon at Riverside Church by the Rev. Eugene C. Carder, associate pastor.
Several correspondents have written to comment on what was printed in this column last week on the strange and sinister happenings in the Soviet Union.

Lard futures were under pressure here last week as United States cold storage stocks were unusually heavy, and prices declined in the last few days. July lard closed at $11.85 a hundredweight, September at $12.121/2 and October at $12.171/2, at net declines of 55, 521/2 and 50 cents, respectively.

The Bank of France's return for June 3 showed a decline of 869,000,000 francs in the portfolio owing to bill collections at the month-end, but advances on collateral and treasury notes rose 486,000,000 francs.
President Dixon Ryan Fox, in delivering the baccalaureate address at Union College today, defined for the graduating class "the American scholar in 1937."

Miss Pearl Hill, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Hill of Hartford, Conn., was married to Laurence Wray of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Wray of Winchester, Mass., Saturday in the Church of the Ascension here.

The wife of the head of a trucking company was mysteriously shot and killed shortly after 10 o'clock last night as she left a motion picture theatre in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn with her husband and sister.

The task and function of the Christian church is to make God the center in the life experience of all men and women, and thus transform the world, the Rev. Lauriston L. Scaife said yesterday in a sermon at St. Peter's Episcopal Church, 344 West Twentieth Street.

That the bitter hatreds and the desire for revenge engendered during the quarter of a century of the dictatorship of General J. V. Gomez in Venezuela still live was shown in the attack on General Jorge Garcia by Manuel Oyon at Colon last night.

Police armed with riot guns tonight maintained their lines in the sand flats surrounding this city's incinerator, where thirty-five non-striking employes have "dug in," with cots and food supplies, to assure operation of the incinerator and sewage-disposal plant in the face of a general strike of public works employes.

The wedding of Miss Angelyn Stuart Hoffman, daughter of Mrs. William Gilmore Hoffman and the late Mr. Hoffman, to Richard L. Rianhard, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas McMahon Rianhard, took place yesterday afternoon at Brown Memorial Presbyterian Church and was followed by a reception at the home of the bride's mother.
Sentiment here has been perturbed further by the gold-price problem, although it is considered that the private dehoarding of recent weeks has deprived the crisis of its acuteness.

Sentiment in the grain trade has changed from moderately bullish to bearish as the result of recent rains over the greater part of the Northwestern United States and in Saskatchewan, one of the largest wheat-producing districts of Canada. Montana, has had plenty of rain.

America's star ten-goal poloists, Thomas Hitchcock Jr. and Stewart B. Iglehart, played on the losing side today as a smooth-functioning Old Westbury quartet downed Greentree, 14 to 6, in the season's initial exhibition match on the Meadow Brook Club's International Field.
The first furniture strike here in twenty-six years, which kept 1,000 employes of three factories idle for thirty-four days, was settled today.

Invitations have been sent out fo the marriage of Miss Selma Ruth Zeiger, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Zeiger of Columbus, Ohio, to Emanuel Lewis of this city, which will take place here the afternoon of June 24 at the Pierre.
Maude, at her residence, 1,279 East 28th St., Brooklyn, beloved mother of Roxanne Romaine and J. Gordon Mitchell. Service at the Fairchild Chapel, 86 Lefferts Place, Brooklyn, on Tuesday, at 8 P. M.

Secretary Perkins and Arthur J. Altmeyer, chairman of the Social Security Board, announced today the appointment of- a coordinating committee to assist the States in administering job-finding services in cooperation with State unemployment compensation systems.

The National Labor Relations Board stepped into the Midwest steel strike situation today by announcing that a complaint had been lodged with it against the Inland Steel Company charging violation of the section of the Labor Relations Act that requires recognition of the organization chosen by a majority of workers for collective bargaining.

Offering will be made today by a banking group headed by Stein Brothers Boyce, by means of a prospectus, of a new issue of $1,000,000 of five and ten-year 4 per cent notes of the Finance Company of America. The five-year notes, due on March 1, 1942, will be priced at 993/4, and the ten-year series, due on March 1, 1947, at 96, with accrued interest in each case.

The Maritime Association of the Port of New York has written a letter to the Senators from New York and New Jersey and the Representatives from New York City protesting against the towing of laid-up ships from New York Harbor to James River, Va., and also against the removal of these ships from New York Harbor.
Ira Haupt Co. have prepared a survey of the tobacco industry, with special reference to Philip Morris Co., Ltd.
Mrs. Isaac Evans of this place has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Marjorie Evans, to Lieutenant Dabney Corum, son of Dr. and Mrs. George T. Corum of Corbin, Ky.

Howard Bergman, thwarted in his quest of the Westchester amateur championship yesterday, returned to the Century Country Club today in the second annual interclub golf tournament for the Arthur Lehman Memorial Trophy to top a field of 104.

On the regatta course on the Hackensack River, where he first learned how to drive a speed boat and where his father builds them, America's national scoring champion, Fred Jacoby Jr., had another phenomenal afternoon today,

Prices on the Stock Exchange went last week to the year's lowest; in fact, to the lowest since last July. But the decline occurred on very small transactions. It is now more than three weeks since a full day's business has reached a million shares; it has often been barely half that sum.
News from the Flatbush front is well-nigh breath-taking, and but for the supporting evidence of 30,109 eye-witnesses at Ebbets Field yesterday might be regarded as incredible.

Commencement exercises for nine members of the graduating class of the Church Army Training Center were held yesterday morning at the All Angels' Episcopal Church, West End Avenue and Eighty-first Street.

Bespectacled Irving Cantor, former Cornell University captain, who never before won a major fencing championship with any weapon, yesterday accounted for the biggest upset of the season when he captured the national outdoor saber crown on the New York Athletic Club's strips at ravers Island.

Stricken while attending services at the Second Church of Christ Science, Sixty-eighth Street and Central Park West, yesterday, Henry Zetosch, 56 years old, a clothing manufacturer, of 124 West Seventy-ninth Street, died before the arrival of Dr. A. M. Liebstein of 1 West Sixty-eighth Street, who was summoned from his home. Dr.

Richard Ciuci of Fresh Meadow won the Long Island Golf Association's sixteenth annual amateur championship tournament yesterday by defeating Alex Gerard Jr. of Southampton, 1 up on the thirtyeighth hole, at the Pomonok Country Club in Flushing. The final was packed with all the thrills and golfing drama imaginable in a title tournament.

EulogizingAristide Briand at the unveiling of the publicly subscribed monument to France's "peace apostle" in front of the Foreign Office, Premier Leon Blum delivered this afternoon a speech in which he was highly optimistic regarding the chances forpreserving European peace.

The largest and most complete exhibition in recent years of locomotives, freight and passenger cars and other railroad equipment will be held in Atlantic City for a week beginning on Wednesday in connection with the annual conventions of the Railway Supply Manufacturers Association and the mechanical division and the purchases and stores division of the Association of American Railroads.

Retail purchasers in the United States in 1936 bought more goods on credit, particularly on the increasingly popular installment credit now available, and on the whole paid for their purchases more promptly, according to the annual retail credit survey for the nation made public today by Alexander V. Dye, director of the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce of the Department of Commerce.
Dr. Barret P. Tyler, an alumnus, preaching the baccalaureate sermon to graduates of Randolph Macon College, spoke on "Living Above the Necessary."

The second conference on Canadian-American Affairs, designed to promote more intelligent understanding between the two countries on current problems and long-range trends, will open here tomorrow at Queen's University.

Manager Joe Cronin of the rich Red Sox was found in this area barricaded behind a marble-topped table and sipping an ice-cream soda. Professor Moe Berg, the Fenway philologist, was with him. Professor Berg was explaining the political situation in Mittel-Europa, as he called it. Manager Cronin was doing the best he could to protect himself, but he was taking frightful punishment in the clinches.

The five-story private dwelling at 148 East Thirty-eighth Street, one of three residences comprising one of the most interesting groups in the old Murray Hill district of Manhattan, has been sold by Russell A. Pettingill to Julius S. Lowenthal in a deal negotiated by Lorelle O'Hara, broker.

Dr. Jose Baxeres de Alzugaray, metallurgical chemist who pioneered in the development of vanadiumsteel, died of a heart ailment on Saturday night at his home, 101 West Eighty-first Street. He was 71 years old.
The Rev. Francis P. Cassidy, dean of men at the Catholic University, gave the baccalaureate address today to the members of the class that will be graduated Wednesday.
Pricefixing in the sale of uniform caps, such as those worn by police, military and naval personnel of the local and Federal Governments, was today ordered terminated by the Federal Trade Commission.

John E. Friedman, theatrical manager who was one of the first to introduce Chinese actors in the United States, died yesterday in the Kings County Hospital after a two years' illness. He was 57 years old. He also took one of the first groups of Negro actors to Europe.

George W. Seam, In 150 W 79th St; Philip M. Grennan, in 45 Christopher St; Andrew P. Traber, in 302 W 12th St; Harry L. Hilton, in 39 5th Ave; Wesley C. and Lucy Sprague Mitchell, in 2 Horatio St; Joseph H. Bursch, Ivy L. Lee, in 230 E 73d St; Theodore Y. Hobby, in 235 E 73d St; through Bing Bing, Inc.

The gold price question is a puzzle here. Although the statements of President Roosevelt and the British Chancellor of the Exchequer were considered reassuring in financial circles, it was impossible to dispel doubts which certain persons carefully entertain.

Sir. William Turner, Lord Mayor of Belfast from 1923 to 1928, died today. He was 65 years old. Sir William,. who received his knighthood in 1924, was High Sheriff of Belfast in 1920, chairman of the local tramways committee, 1918-23. He was made an Irish Privy Councillor in 1927.
The Geneva Canton voted today, 18,278 to 12,076, to outlaw the Communist party and authorized the government to outlaw other parties affiliated with international or foreign organizations.

The Rev. Dr. William P. Schell of the Presbyterian Board of Foreign Missions, New York City, told the seniors at Hamilton College this morning that graduation was an achievement, but reminded them that they had not yet attained their goal or finished their course.

John L. Lewis called 'out 9,500 workers in seventeen mines owned by Bethlehem Steel and Youngstown Sheet and Tube. He denounced steel executives. Page 1. While the presence of troops kept peace in Monroe, Mich., about 10,000 C. I. O. adherents met in a park outside the city and cheered a pledge to restore the broken steel picket line. Page 1.

Miss Eleanor Hooper Eastman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Franklin Eastman of 96 Columbia Heights, Brooklyn, and Walpole, was married this afternoon to Lieutenant Jay Alan Abercrombie, United States Army, son of Mr. and Mrs. Earl Abercrombie of Denver, Colo.

A group of Berkshire colonists motored to Music Mountain, Falls Village, Conn., this afternoon to attend the first of a series of sixteen Sunday chamber music concerts by the Jacques Gordon String Quartet. Miss Muriel Kerr, pianist, assisted.

The Brookings Institution reported today that the Federal Government paid "more than half a million dollars" in the 1936 fiscal year to persons engaged in full time or allocated part-time publicity work.

Congress has been the chief obstacle to extension of civil service rules, not only to the new agencies created in recent years, but to the older agencies of the government, according to the annual report of the National Civil Service Reform League, made Public today.
Eight shots were fired this morning at R. G. B. Spicer, commander of the Palestine police,
About 3,500,000 Jews in Poland are facing mass starvation, speakers said yesterday at the twentyninth annual convention of the Federation of Polish Jews in the Hotel Astor.

Secretary Ickes today issued a statement on the accomplishments of the Public Works Administration of which he is head. The statement came a few weeks after the President declared the program had to be stopped because heavy industries had received sufficient impetus and within a few days after Congress decided to limit PWA's activities to winding up its outstanding business.

In the erection of the average American home more than SO per cent of the cost goes into carpentry, brickwork and concrete work, material and labor, while concrete work, brickwork, structural steel and elevator equipment, material and labor costs comprise more than 50 per cent of the total expenditure for non-residential buildings, according to Myron L. Matthews of the Dow Service.

Sheer dresses were in active demand in the wholesale markets here last week. Nets, marquisettes, floral and printed chiffons, and sheer cottons were bought heavily, and sports wear numbers, especially in washable silks and synthetics, were in demand.

A sixteenth-century tapestry portraying the crucifixion, which never before has been placed on public exhibition, is among the invaluable items of Belgian medieval art that have been lent by the Belgian Government to Princeton University for display over the university's 190th commencement week, starting Thursday.
To the Edtor of The New York Times: The letter from the executive committee of the Citizens Budget Commission is a cogent statement of the situation with respect to blighted areas.

The last of a group of sit-in demonstrators, members of Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians and their sympathizers, who took seats in the R.-K.-O. Palace Theatre in Times Square at Fortyseventh Street Saturday evening with the announced intention of staying all night, left the theatre at 3:30 A. M. yesterday.

The danger that widespread college education may be developing "that saddest and most dangerous of elements, namely, disillusioned youth," was examined yesterday in a sermon by the Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman, pastor of Christ Methodist Episcopal Church, Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street.

The great American tragedy is the increase of hate among the people, for we seem to have been "baptized with prussic acid rather than with the love of God," the Rev. Dr. Joseph R. Sizoo said in a sermon yesterday morning at the Collegiate Reformed Church of St. Nicholas, Fifth Avenue and Forty-eighth Street.

Although the Berkshire Symphonic Festival to be held at Stockbridge, Mass., in August will be devoted entirely to programs by the Boston Symphony Orchestra, it is probable that next season choral works and even operas may be presented. Operatic performances, however, will not be attempted unless money enough can be raised to give them in a finished manner.
Cardinal Hayes presided at a pontifical mass yesterday in honor of the 100th anniversary of St. Joseph's Church, Sixth Avenue and Washington Place. The Most Rev.

With John Wallace dominating the contest, the First Division four conquered the Bethpage Polo Club representatives, 9-6, yesterday at the Fort Hamilton Army Reservation as both teams launched their Eastern Polo Association campaigns. The alert No. 2 scored more than half of the local quartet's goals, getting five in all. A crowd of 4,000 saw the First Division unit score thrice in the last session for its margin of victory.

By way of a light tune-up for his mile race at Princeton on Saturday, Glenn Cunningham took his first whirl at winning a metropolitan senior A. A. U. championship today. And since record-breaking seems to have become a habit of his, the Kansas powerhouse thrilled a gathering of 10,000 at Glen Park by cracking the meet figures with very workmanlike 4:14.1.

Miss Virginia Goodrich, daughter of Mrs. Alfred Goodrich and the late Mr. Goodrich, was married to Anthony G. Rytina Jr. of New York, son of Dr. and Mrs. A. G. Rytina of Homeland, Baltimore, last evening in the Archbishop's house at the cathedral. The ceremony was followed by a reception at the Woman's Club of Roland Park.

Darkness engulfed this little Fountain County town of 312 inhabitants tonight, hampering rescue work of State police and hundreds of volunteers after a tornado had left at least sixteen persons injured.

Clinton H. Crane's twelve-meter Gleam, Fred T. Bedford's six-meter Lucie and Lester Brion's S Class sloop Allons were victorious in the special regatta conducted on Long Island Sound by the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club today.

Supply contracts numbering 100 under the terms of the Public Contracts Act were awarded by fourteen Federal agencies in the week ended in June 10 for a total of $6,410,762, the Department of Labor announced yesterday.

Interruption of steel deliveries From blockaded mills is causing only a minimum of inconvenience to steel consumers, according to the magazine Steel. The publication says that in a few instances tonsage has been booked by other proiucers to supply urgent needs of users, but it adds that this has been of small proportions.

An eight-day tercentenary celebration of the purchase of Governors Island from the Indians opened yesterday with a religious service, at which Bishop William T. Manning condemned the extreme pacifist position as "neither sound sense nor sound religion.

Miss Grace Joy Adams, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Fairchild Adams of this place, has chosen the afternoon of June 29 for her marriage to Henry Elliot Mallinckrodt, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Mallinckrodt Jr. of St. Louis.

Qualifying round for President's Trophy: Tie for medal between Earl W. Doebler. 80-11-69. and W. F. Johnson, 78-9-69. Qualifying Found for Vice President's Trophy: Tie for medal among Ernest Wildfoerster, 86-14-72: John W. Gordon Sr., 94-22-72; and R. W. Northrop, 89-17-72.

After delivering a truck load of food to the picket-besieged plant of the Hoffman Beverage Company this evening, Robert Cavanaugh, driver of the vehicle, was beaten by eight or- nine men at Broad and Hill Streets, two miles from the plant and a block from police headquarters.

The second installment of the State income tax is due Tuesday, Mark Graves, Commissioner of Taxation and Finance, announced today in citing the fact that at the close of business Saturday remittances had been received from fewer than one-fifth of the total number of taxpayers required to make this payment.

Net income of the Continental Can Company, Inc., and its wholly owned subsidiaries for the year to April 30 amounted to $9,084,927 after charges including income taxes and the surtax on undistributed profits, according to a report made by the company to the New York Stock Exchange.

Sixty Thousand workers will determine the question of affiliation in ninety elections this month. They will be held under the supervision of the regional office of the National Labor Relations Board, Mrs. Elinore M. Herrick, regional director of the board, said yesterday in making public a report to Washington.

The marriage or Miss nose Bampton, Metropolitan Opera soprano, to Wilfred Pelletier, a conductor at the Metropolitan, on May 24 in Elkton, Md., was revealed here yesterday. Mr. Pelletier and his bride sailed on Saturday on the Champlain on their wedding trip.

A forty-three-acre parking field for trailer tourists and a thirty-acre community interests zone portraying a world of tomorrow in the home and in the varied activities of man as a social being are the latest innovations planned for the New York World's Fair of 1939, it was revealed yesterday.

Grain future purchases on the Chicago Board of Trade last week greatly exceeded those of the previous week and a year ago, the total aggregating 424,393,000 bushels, compared with 278,039,000 the preceding week and 91,190,000 a year ago.

The continued decline in many commodity prices is discouraging and uneasiness over gold here has not been allayed entirely. With no stimulus coming from Wall Street or other foreign markets, the uneasiness evident on the Stock Exchange here persists.

Kresge Department Stores, Inc., has declared the regular dividend of $1 a share for the quarter to June 30 on the new 4 per cent cumulative convertible first preferred stock. The dividend is payable on July 10 to stockholders of record of July 1.

Letters congratulating Brig. Gen. Aaron S. Daggett, retired, the oldest officer of the United States Army, on his 100th birthday, Which he will observe tomorrow at his home in West Roxbury, Mass., were sent to him today by President Roosevelt, Secretary Woodring and General Malin Craig, Chief of Staff. The letters were to be delivered by an officer of the First Corps Area headquarters, Boston.

A collision between an automobile and a Fifth Avenue bus at Sixtieth Street injured five persons slightly last night. John Bellomo, 20 years old, of 264 Elizabeth Street, driver of the automobile, and Joseph Scorzese, 17, of 241 Elizabeth Street, who was riding with him, were treated at the scene by an ambulance surgeon from Metropolitan Hospital.

The trial of Mrs. Helen Tiernan of Manhattan on the charge of murder, first degree, for slaying her 7-year-old daughter, Helen, in the woods at Brookhaven May 15, will open in the Suffolk County Supreme Court here tomorrow morning at 11 o'clock. Justice James T. Hallinan will preside.

Professor Irving Fisher's index number of average commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, was 92, which compares with 92.6 the week before, 93.3 two weeks before, 93.5 three weeks before and 92.7 four weeks before.
Hungary is becoming popular in the chancelleries of Europe. Witness the presence in Budapest during this weekend of Baron CONSTANTIN
Following is the text of the resolution adopted at the C. I. O. rally this afternoon:

National income produced in the United States increased in 1936 by nearly $9,000,000,000. or about 16 per cent over that of 1935, the largest increase, both absolutely and relatively, for any year of the recovery period, the Department of Commerce announced today.
John Leofric Stocks, who was appointed vice chancellor of Liverpool University last year, died at Swansea today at the age of 54. He was a capable administrator as well as a philosopher.

5th St, 642 E. Samuel Zwerdeing to Anna Lieber, 176 E 3d St; mtg $2,000. 71st St, 118 W: James H. Cruikshank to Bloomfield Bank Trust Co, Bloomfield, N. J.? mtg $10,000. 2d Ave, 1,613; United States Trust Co to Marie A. Frey, 1 So Brookwood Dr, Montclair, N. J.; mtg $10,000. 85th St, 201 W: State Mortgage Commission to William E. Russell Jr., 149 Bway, trustee; mtg $800,000.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. Pett of this city that their daughter, Miss Lois F. Pett, has become engaged to Wesley J. Yordon of Westfield, son of Harlow C. Yordon and the late Mrs. Jennie Scott Yordon of Syracuse,
In Connecticut, where politics is thick, borough, city, police and town judges, deputy and associate judges are appointed by the General Assembly in separate resolutions to the number of about 130.
Sir W. F. Lloyd, former Coalition Prime Minister of Newfoundland, died in St. John's today of a stroke at the age of 73. He was Premier of the island in 1918.
DAVIS-FEIN-Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Fein of Brooklyn announce the marriage of their daughter, Belle Claire, to Mr. Jerome Davis, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Davis, also of Brooklyn, on June 12.
Judge Thomas F. Moran, 69, who has granted divorces to thousands, was on a honeymoon today with the former Mrs.. Jessie M. Smith, longtime clerk of his court.
Despite overcast skies all day, the beaches in the metropolitan area were jammed yesterday. Coney Island and the Rockaways reported record crowds for the season.

Owing to the keen competition between 4,000 members of the New York State Fife and Drum Corps Association for cups and other prizes at the annual State field music contests held here last night, under the auspices of Post 596, Veterans of Foreign Wars, the awards were not made until today.
The Veterans Administration has made a new rule for selection of veterans in the Civilian Conservation Corps, General Frank T. Hines, administrator. announced today.

Police of this State, New York and Pennsylvania were on the lookout today for two unidentified men who on Friday evening kidnapped Dr. Irwin Markowitz, local neurologist, as he was entering the home of a patient, and drove him aimlessly around in his automobile for more than an hour and a half before leaving him stranded in Belleville, N. J.

Awards of seventy-seven major and minor letters and freshman numerals have been approved for New York University athletes by the board of athletic control and the undergraduate athletic board, it was announced yesterday by Graduate Manager Albert B. Nixon.

The German wholesale price index on June 2 stood at 106.1, against 105.9 a week before. In the first five months of 1937 Germany's wholesale price index ranged between 106.2 on March 17 and 105.2 in the first week of January.

A program largely of Russian music was presented by the Festival Symphony Orchestra of the Federal Music Project at the WPA Theatre of Music last night before an appreciative audience of good size. Eugene Plotnikoff conducted and Grace Castagnetta, a talented young pianist, heard here earlier in the season in recital, was the soloist.

Alfred J. Talley, former judge of the Court of General Sessions, will receive from Cardinal Hayes at 6:30 o'clock this evening the DeSmet medal, which has been awarded to him by Gonzaga University, Spokane, Wash., in recognition of his work as president of the Marquette League for Catholic Indian Missione. The presentation will take place at the residence of Cardinal Hayes, 452 Madison Avenue.

Henry Ford, pioneer of mass production, will enter the thirty-fifth year of his industrial history next Wednesday. The year ahead may mot decide the question of mass unionization of some 120,000 Ford workers.

The reciprocal trade treaty with the United States apparently is becoming a political football of the opposition to the Government, led by former Foreign Minister M. F. Jimenez, who resigned because of objections to the treaty. The opposition is attempting to place responsibility for the treaty on Harold M. Collins, Charge d'Affaires of the United States Legation.

Boasting a lighter faced, more legible type-the first change in its type design in twenty-two yearsthe Summer 1937 issue of the Man hattan telephone directory will be distributed today and for the next five working days to 587,000 sub scribers in the borough.

H. B. Boland Co. will offer today an issue of $180,000 of Monmouth County, N. J., 3.25 per cent bonds, dated April 1, 1937, and maturing on April 1, 1941 to 1945, at prices to yield from 2.35 to 3 per cent, according to maturity. The bonds are legal investments in the opinion of the bankers, for savings banks and trust funds in New York and New Jersey.

The State's Attorney's office is making rapid strides toward prosecution of those alleged to have inflamed strikers before the Memorial Day violence at the Republic Steel Corporation plant in South Chicago.

Under the pressure of bearish factors which had accumulated in recent weeks, the cotton market declined rather sharply last week. On the New York Cotton Exchange cotton futures showed for the week net losses of 66 to 76 points.
Frank X. Bernhardt, former member of the State Legislature and known as the father of New York's old age pension system, died today of a heart ailment at his home here at the age of 79.

The use of gold in dental work is decreasing yearly, the American Dental Society stated. today. About $25,000,000 worth of gold is used in fillings annually, together with about $5,000,000 worth of silver- and Platinum.

Silver Jubilee of the American Electro-Platers Society begins at the Hotel Pennsylvania this morning at 9 o'clock and continues to Thursday. Triennial meeting of the General Society of the Sons of the Revolution begins at the Waldorf-Astoria this morning at 10 o'clock and continues Tuesday and Wednesday.

Mr. and Mrs. John Woodman Higgins will give a dinner at the Pierre Roof tomorrow night for Miss Katharine Huntington Bigelow, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Mason Huntington Bigelow, who will be married the next day to their son, Carter Chapin Higgins.

The reason for the apparent toleration of Christianity is that Christians are not living their faith, according to Bishop William Culbertson of the Philadelphia-New York Synod of the Reformed Episcopal Church.

Miss Dorothy Gilman Clark, daughter of Judge and Mrs. Walter Haven Clark, and William Olaf Thomson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Thomson, were married yesterday at the South Congregational Church. The Rev. Warren S. Archibald officiated.

Police Chief Carl Olson swore in fifty special policemen today under the emergency authority granted to Mayor Lionel Evans by the City Council Friday night to strengthen the police force against the possibility of further trouble in the C. I. O. steel strike against independent companies, now in its third week.
The Rev. James Lester Shipley, a retired minister of the Methodist Episcopal Church, South, died on Friday at Bedford, Va. He would have been 99 years old on June 21.

The Rev. R. Anderson Jardine, North Country parson who defied the Church of England by officiating at the marriage of the Duke of Windsor just ten days ago, resigned tonight his "living" of St. Paul's Church in Darlington, Durham County. The news was immediately telephoned to the Duke of Windsor at his Austrian retreat.

Roswell Magill, Under-Secretary of the Treasury, whose report to Secretary Morgenthau provided the basis for Mr. Morgenthau's tax-revision letter to the President, suggested himself in a recent publication some of the identical tax-saving methods that were condemned by President Roosevelt as "immoral," the Tax Research Institute charged yesterday.
Five young men were killed in two airplane accidents in this area today. A third ship was forced down in a busy street.
