More than 200 vigilantes specially sworn in as deputy sheriffs and emergency police guarded the single causeway that leads across a swamp to the Newton plant of the Republic Steel Company here today while leaders of the Steel Workers Organizing Committee and the United Automobile Workers of America at a meeting in Monroe State Park denounced them as thugs and hoodlums.

Miss Shirley Grace Putnam, daughter of Mrs. Raymond Carrick of Ardmore and Earl B. Putnam of Chestnut Hill, has completed plans for her wedding on June 28 to Edgar Felton Rulon-Miller, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sumner Rulon-Miller of Ardmore.
Italy's fight against "British propaganda" extended today to American motion pictures.

Catholics were urged to study the papal encyclicals on labor to understand the Catholic viewpoint on the present crisis between labor and capitalism in an address by Raymond Leddy of the Center Club at the twenty-first annual communion breakfast of the Children of Mary sodality at the Hotel Astor yesterday morning. "Through the ages since the dawn of Christianity,"

Oats and barley were planted late and have suffered from drought in some areas, so both are expected to have rather light crops, according to the government's crop report, roughly midway between last year's short crops and the average production in the 1928-32 period.

With Frank Fee limiting the losers to three singles the New York Athletic Club shut out the New York Police Department nine, 4-0, yesterday, at Travers Island. The southpaw ace fanned five and never was in danger of yielding a run.
The Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York made public yesterday a list of fourteen special committees appointed by Winthrop W. Chase, chamber president, to serve for the fiscal year 1937-38.
Sir James Barrie, who celebrated-his seventyseventh birthday last month, is seriously ill in a London hospital. Relatives have been at his bedside since Friday and one said tonight:
More than five hours of baseball ended at Sportsman's Park today with the Yankees gaining a decision over the Browns in one end of a doubleheader and getting a tie in the other.

Showing a passing attack that ws almost dazzling in its perfection, the Gaelic football team from County Mayo, champions of Ireland, easily outscored the selected New York team to carry off the world's title at the Yankee Stadium yesterday. The visiting Irishmen left little doubt as to their superiority over the home contingent, beating the New Yorkers by the score of 18 to 2.
Frederick A. Rueckel, an accountant and long active in Catholic fraternal affairs in Brooklyn, died on Saturday at his home, 392 Third Street, at the age of 50.
William E. Dodd, American Ambassador to Germany, continues his studies in history. He will have a new book entitled "Struggles for Democracy: The. Old South" published by Macmillan late in August.

With a light westerly breeze to fan them along, eighty-three craft competed today in the Larchmont Yacht Club's opening regatta, a special one on the Summer schedule arranged by Commodore R. J. Schaefer and Race Chairman John S. Dickerson Jr. Checked out of a bulging lot of sails at the end were H. T. von Frankenburg's twelvemeter one-design sloop Zio and Commodore Schaefer's yawl Edlu,

Among seven honorary degrees awarded by Rutgers University at its 171st anniversary commencement exercises in the gymnasium this afternoon Dr. James R. Angell, president of Yale, received the Doctor of Laws. Judge Clarence E.

The attention of the markets here this week was concentrated chiefly upon the financial situation of the government. The Treasury's difficulties are now an open secret, and the government has said it was about to propose in Parliament various measures tending to increase the budgetary receipts.

The college graduate of this day must have "the courage of conviction, of endurance and endeavor" if she is to lead a happy and useful life, President William E. Weld told the fifty-one young women members in the graduating class at Wells College in his baccalaureate sermon today in the Aurora Presbyterian Church.

Most young couples still approach marriage as one of the most sacred and significant of all our social covenants, Dr. Claude Allen McKay, minister of the First Congregations Church of Binghamton, N. Y., said in his baccalaureate sermon.

The enrollment of voters yesterday, first of Philadelphia's three registration days, was relatively light, and incomplete, unofficial figures showed comparatively little change in the standing of the two major parties "on paper."

The business outlook here is considered to be good. Commenting on the world trade prospect, the Reich Bureau of Statistics remarks that the trade treaties made by the United States in 1936 conduced little to a free flow of international commerce, because they really were based only upon the interests of American industry.
Brooklyn College will open its first Fall semester in the new Flatbush buildings one month later than the usual term beginning, it was announced yesterday by Dr. William A. Boylan, president.

One great trouble with the world, in which there are so many strikes, is a lack of concern for the welfare of other individuals, the Rev. C. Everett Wagner declared yesterday morning in his sermon at the Union Methodist Episcopal Church, 229 West Forty-eighth Street.

Reports from thirty district offices. of the Emergency Relief Bureau indicate that more than 95 per cent of the unionized members of the ERB administrative staff favor affiliation with the Committee for Industrial Organization, according to an announcement in the current issue of The ERB Staff Reporter, official organ of the Association of Workers in Public Relief Agencies.

A committee claiming that it represented 98 per cent of the 3,200 workers at the Republic Steel Corporation's South Buffalo plant today asked the City Council to intervene in a C. I. O. strike which has hampered mill operations for more than three weeks.

A threat to kidnap his wife unless a strike at a trailer construction plant of which he is head is settled is under investigation by Department of Justice agents, C. H. Kingham revealed tonight. The threatening note, sent through the mails, was received Friday. It said Mrs.

Stocks lower in the slowest trading since the week ended on March 30, 1935; turnover. 3,483,801 shares. United States Government issues down; other bonds steady in quiet trading; transactions, $39,678,300.
Chevrolet foundry employes rejected tonight a proposal that they return to work tomorrow pending a discussion of differences which precipitated a strike Thursday.

Senator Robert F. Wagner in a radio address last night defended his Housing Bill as the only one that could solve the nation-wide housing problem and at the same time sharply criticized, by implication, the plan of financing advanced by Henry -Morgenthau Jr., Secretary of the Treasury.

The Church of Christ and its members "have a great lesson to learn from the Communists," the Rev. Dr. William Pierson Merrill declared in his sermon yesterday at the Brick Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Thirty-seventh Street.

Leonard Hartman turned back the veteran Frank Bowden, 7-5, 2-6, 6-8, 6-2, 6-4, in a bristling fiveset final yesterday to repeat his 1936 triumph in the Brooklyn tennis championship at the Terrace Club of Flatbush. A gallery of more than 2,000 watched the former Columbia captain wear down his more experienced opponent by hard hitting and remarkable recoveries.

Fred D. Dickens and Javan A. Steele, Negro candidates for the Tammany leadership of the Nineteenth Assembly District, have agreed to join forces to bring about the election of a Negro leader to succeed Harry C. Perry, it was announced yesterday.

In the Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute baccalaureate sermon, delivered this evening in St. John's Episcopal Church by the Rev. Nelson M. Burroughs, the rector, the graduating students were urged not to be satisfied with "minimum requirements."

A payment of $80,000, equal to 3 per centof the face amount of the certificates held by investors in Series F, the $2,665,000 mortgage issue of the New York Title and Mortgage Company, will be made on June 30, according to an announcement by William J. Pedrick, William J. Schmitt and Alexander Pfeiffer, the trustees.

Flags of America, ranging from early Colonial banners to the design adopted by Congress in 1818, were displayed yesterday in a "Flag Day pageant," presented by thirty-nine posts of the Queens County American Legion at Fort Totten, Bayside, Queens.

Miss Jean Wirt Myers, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Ross Myers, and W. B. F. Hax, son of Mrs. George Hax and the late Mr. Hax, were married last evening at the Roland Park Presbyterian Church. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. John W. Douglas.

William M. Young's sloop Venturon, Harold C. McNulty's yawl Vigilance and W. L. Dommerich's sloop Clebe headed their divisions in the Norwalk Yacht Club's third annual Duck Island race, the second and final leg of which was completed tonight.

Yale's rowing squad, including coaches, managers and trainers, arrived at the Gales Ferry quarters late this afternoon after a sail down Long Island Sound from New Haven aboard Carll Tucker's auxiliary schooner Migrant.

The possibility that the mysteriously missing Mrs. William H. Parsons, 38-year-old Long Island society matron, was in New York City alone at 5 P. M. Wednesday, more than six hours after she left her Long Island farm, was investigated today by the police.

Noreen, 5-year-old brown mare owned by Edmund P. Stout of Port Washington, was adjudged the hunter champion in one of the feature classes of the fourth annual Sands Point Horse Show today. The event, held for the benefit of the Village Welfare Society of Port Washington, was staged on the estate of Edgar F. Luckenbach.

The Archbishop of Canterbury was defended for his stand in connection with the Duke of Windsor's marriage by the Rev. Dr. D. Wilmot Gateson, rector of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Saviour, in a baccalaureate sermon today before the graduating class of Drexel Institute of Technology.

Spanish Government commanders, seeking to help their hard-plessed Basque allies in the north by exerting pressure on the Insurgents elsewhere, threw large forces into action today on the Aragon front, in Northeastern Spain, and above Cordoba, in the South.
The secret of a happy life is to live a day at a time, according to Dr. William Ward Ayer, in a sermon yesterday as pastor of Calvary Baptist Church, 123 West Fiftyseventh Street.

Tucked away in the new Buckley law permitting the taxing of utilities to financeunemployment relief is a "surprise" package of woe for several businesses, State Tax Commissioner Graves indicated today.

Langdon W. Post, chairman of the New York City Housing Authority, will address a mass meeting at 8:30 tonight at the Educational Alliance, East Broadway and Jefferson Street, at which the Lower East Side Public Housing Conference will hold a send-off for fifty slum dwellers leaving by bus for Washington, D. C., where they will press for passage of the Wagner-Steagall Housing Bill.

The atmosphere generated by a "good" college is the most valuable attribute that it passes on to its students, Dr. Charles W. Gilkey, dean of the chapel at the University of Chicago, declared today in the baccalaureate address to the graduating class of Knox College.

If all pending city pay increases now before Mayor La Guardia or the Board ofAldermen were adopted, they would, together with pay rises already authorized, add $28,000,000 to the city budget for 1938 and force a 17-point rise in the real estate tax rate, the Citizens Budget Commission declared yesterday.

As an important step in reducing the large number of substitutes, the addition of 3,500 regular teachers to the New York City school system was recommended yesterday by James Marshall, vice president of the Board of Education.
Two men known to many Americans were included today in a warning from the Committee of Soviet Control giving them ten days to reorganize the automobile, tractor and combine industry or face trial.

As the celebrant of a solemn high mass of thanksgiving, Mgr. Paul T. Carew, rector of St. John's Roman Catholic Church here, today observed the fiftieth anniversary of his ordination to the priesthood.

Newark swept both ends of a double-header with Buffalo today, winning the first game by 7 to 1 and taking the nightcap 4 to 3, while Atley Donald, young right-hander, chalked up his ninth straight victory of the season. He has yet to be defeated.
The Zion Evangelical Lutheran Church today paid its annual rental fee-a red rose-to a descendant of Baron Von Stiegel, Colonial ironmaster and glassmaker.

Dick Floyd, brilliant No. 3, gave a superb all-around exhibition in leading the South Shore Polo Club quartet to a hard-earned 8-7 triumph over Fort Hamilton of Brooklyn in the inaugural Eastern Polo Association contest for both today at Hazard Field. Floyd accounted for six of the home squad's goals, his final tally in the last minute of play breaking a 7-all tie.

Miss Adelaide Newman, 27, of North Wales, a graduate of Wellesley College in 1931, plunged sixty feet to her death today from the fourth floor of Presbyterian Hospital. She was admitted to the hospital on May 4, suffering from a nervous breakdown.
Mrs. James H. Hackett, wife of one of Milwaukee's leading physicians and one of the first lay workers in the Catholic Church of America, died at her home yesterday at. the age of 67.

The most determined campaign conducted against any national minorities within the conglomeration of races and nationalities that constitutes Eastern Europe is being waged, strange as that may seem, against the German minorities.

Great clouds of gas, called "promnences," which shoot up from or across the sun's surface, are now being studied with motion pictures. Some of these prominences travel at the explosive speed of 180 miles a second and one shot out 490,000 miles from the sun's surface.

Ernst Rosenfeld, 59 years old, a retired foreign exchange broker, shot and killed himself while seated in a chair in the library of his duplex apartment at 820 Park Avenue yesterday morning. Mr. Rosenfeld was a neighbor of Governor Herbert H. Lehman, who lives in a similar apartment above.

Members of the Japanese economic mission, of which Chokyuro Kadono is president, and their wives, with Kaname Wakasugi, Japan's Consul General in New York, were entertained here at a luncheon today by Mr. and Mrs. William Robertson Coe at Planting Fields, their 750acre estate on Chicken Valley Road, which is one of the show places of Long Island.

James H. R. Cromwell, co-author of the recently published economic study, "In Defense of Capitalism," was arrested this afternoon and detained for one and a half hours in the National Hotel lobby for taking photographs in the street in front of the hotel and in front of the United States Embassy next door.
St Paul's Episcopal Church here was taxed to its capacity this afternoon at the first massing of the colors service ever held in this city.

Six-Mile Run-Won by J. Errol Vaughn, New York A. C.; Eino Penttl, Millrose A. A., second; Victor Drygall, Millrose A. A., third; Jean Berthelot, Millrose A. A.. fourth. Time-32:02.5. Three-Mile Walk-Won by Morris Fleischer, St. Anselm's A. C.; Otto Kotraba, Ninetysecond Street Y. M. H. A., second; Nat Jaeger, Ninety-second Street Y. M. H. A. third; Irving Horowitz. Ninety-second Street Y. M. H. A., fourth. Time-23:44.

The General Chapter of the Paulists Fathers, which assembles every three years to deliberate on policies and activities of this domestic miss sionary society of the Roman Catholic Church, was opened here yesterday in the Church of St. Paul the Apostle, Columbus Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street.

A brick Colonial home of ten rooms and three baths on a large plot at 200 Forest Avenue, Forest HIeights, New Rochelle, has been purchased by James W. McLaughlin, an executive of the Union Carbide and Carbon Company, from the Gilbank Securities Corporation. The property was reported held at $35,000. See Sullivan, Inc., negotiated the deal.

Despite new dividend increases, the stock market is behaving uncertainly and rather weakly. This week's lull in the Spanish complications failed to reassure business, which predicts that dangerous incidents will recur so long as the civil war continues and which cherishes no hope that the struggle can be terminated by a truce within any calculable time.

Sweeping a double-header for the third consecutive time, the rampant White Sox defeated Washington, 9 to 4 and 3 to 2, before 35,000 today to end their successful home stay with twelve victories in fourteen starts.

Both three-gaited and five-gaited saddle-horse honors went to the S-K-R, Farm during the second and final day of the third annual Rock Spring horse show today. The lone championship of the exhibition for three-gaited mounts was taken by Dixiana Moon, whom Mrs. Burt Ressler of East Orange has been showing for several years.
J. Gilbert Hall of South Orange and Arthur W. MacPherson of New York won the invitation tennis doubles tournament at the Piping Rock Club today.
A seven-day bridge tournament opened here today in the large hall of the Metropolitan Redoubt Building with the initial matches of the world championship for open teams of four.

Former Supreme Court Justice Jeremiah T. Mahoney leads for the Democratic nomination for Mayor in the poll of the magazine New York Politics. Of Republicans canvassed 5,524 favor renomination of Mayor La Guardia with 2,065 opposed.

More than 400 graduates of Fordham University were urged by the Rev. Francis X. Shea, '17, to maintain a "conquering faith" in God as a means of overcoming the obstacles of life in the ninety-second baccalaureate service of the university conducted yesterday morning in the campus chapel.

SOUTHERN DISTRICT Petitions Filed-Against PAUL TORRICE, doing business as Paul's Restaurant, 90 Lafayette St., by Hunter Printing Co., Inc., for $66; Premier Oyster Co., Inc., $30; Jacob Ruppert, $547. Petitions Filed-By SEYMOUR M. BLAUFARB, unemployed salesman, 370 Central Park West-Liabilitles $22,222. no assets.
A new society in which "people who work at machines may not only raise prize potatoes, they may even write verse," is indicated as the outcome of the current world-wide "portentous conflict,"

More than 400 graduates of Fordham University were urged by the Rev. Francis X. Shea, '17, to maintain a "conquering faith" in God as a means of overcoming the obstacles of life in the ninety-second baccalaureate service of the university conducted yesterday morning in the campus chapel.

SOUTHERN DISTRICT Petitions Filed-Against PAUL TORRICE, doing business as Paul's Restaurant, 90 Lafayette St., by Hunter Printing Co., Inc., for $66; Premier Oyster Co., Inc., $30; Jacob Ruppert, $547. Petitions Filed-By SEYMOUR M. BLAUFARB, unemployed salesman, 370 Central Park West-Liabilitles $22,222. no assets.
A new society in which "people who work at machines may not only raise prize potatoes, they may even write verse," is indicated as the outcome of the current world-wide "portentous conflict,"
The Monmouth County Country Club had little trouble defeating the Ramapo Valley Polo Club of Tallman, N. Y., in the opening match of the Eastern Polo Association season today. The score was 16 to 3.
The United States World War allies today prepared once more to give "regretful" notice they will default the installments due Tuesday on the obligations they incurred two decades ago.
A nationwide drive by the Postal Inspection Service against "fake" mutual life protection organizations, which have been working through the mails, was announced today by Postmaster General Farley.

The marriage of Miss Josephine Horsfall Champlin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Bates Champlin of West Hartford, to Robert Bacon English Jr., son of Mrs. Robert B. English. also of this place, and the late Mr. English, took place yesterday afternoon in St. John's Episcopal Church. The Rev. William T. Hooper officiated.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Nancy Du Noyer Jones, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Theodore Jones of Great Neck, L. I., to John Frederick Doble, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles French Doble, also of Great Neck.

The dangers of lawlessness that might result if practice of individualism were to get out of hand were emphasized in a baccalaureate sermon yesterday afternoon by the Rev. Dr. Alfred Grant Walton of the Tompkins Avenue Congregational Church at McDonough Street, Brooklyn, preached at Packer Collegiate Institute, 170 Joralemon Street, Brooklyn.

BILBAO FRONT - Insurgents made further advances through the "iron ring" of defenses with the heaviest artillery fire in the civil war and with continued aerial attacks. Some Basque forces were reputed cut off.

PUBLICATION of Farrar Rinehart's Rivers of America series starts today with a Niagara-almost a Victoria Falls-of lore and- history and humor and poetic phrase turned loose by that sturdy laureate of Maine masculinity, femininity, snow, apples, air, woods and lobsters, Robert P. Tristram Coffin. He writes of "Kennebec: Cradle of Americans" ($2.50).

Dizzy Dean pitched a five-hit shut-out victory today before the biggest crowd of the year in Boston-the paid attendance being 41,079-- as the Cardinals swept both ends of a doubleheader from the Bees.

The Ajax Tire and Rubber Corporation, 601 West Twenty-sixth Street, New York, has entered into a stipulation with the Federal Trade Commission to stop representing that it was founded in 1904, when it was actually founded in 1934, and that it manufactures tires and tubes when, according to the commission, it is merely a distributer and does not own or operate a factory.

Seven jurors were chosen in Suffolk County Supreme Court here today for the trial of Mrs. Helen Tiernan, 25-year-old blond widow who is accused of slaying her 7-year-old daughter, Helen, in the woods near Brookhaven on May 17. Justice James T. Hallinan is presiding.
Public offering is being made by the Carlton M. Higbie Corporation, by means of a prospectus, of 50,000 shares of common stock of the Silex Company at $9.871/2 a share.

United States PRINCIPAL EXPERIMENT STATION ADMINISTRATOR, $5,600 a Year-Office of Experiment Stations, Department of Agriculture. Applications must be on file not later than July 12 if received from States other than those named below; July 15 if received from the following States: Arizona, California, Colorado, Idaho, Montana.

Viscountess Astor, Member of Parliament, the former Nancy Langhorne of Virginia, arrived from London yesterday to visit her brother, Colonel William Langhorne, who is ill in Virginia. Her visit made it impossible for her to be in London to receive formally the title of "Companion of Honor," conferred upon her by King George VI.

Chief Pilot F. B. Fahrig, experienced Soviet Arctic aviator, returned to Moscow tonight, completing the first Winter flight over the entire transarctic route. The flight extended almost to Alaska. He left Moscow on Feb. 9 with a crew of five and three passengers in the huge plane U. S. S. R.-N120.

Lawrence Collette Million, 18year-old grocery store clerk, was arrested last night and charged with the fatal shooting of Mrs. Dorothy Carfucci as she emerged from a motion-picture theatre in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn Sunday night.

The New York Security Dealers Association will hold its fourth annual outing at the Westchester Country Club, Rye, N. Y., on June 25, when the President's Cup will be put into competition for the first time and the Governors Cup for the third year in a handicap golf tournament. R. C. Rice of J. K. Rice Jr. Co. has won the Governors' Cup for two years.

The Pan American Airways flying boat Bermuda Clipper landed here this afternoon at 4:20 o'clock after a flight from Hamilton, Bermuda, in 6 hours 21 minutes. Captain R. O. D. Sullivan, the pilot and commander. said the journev had been "routine."

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated June 11: COMMANDERS Gray, A. H., the Colorado, to Naval War College, Newport, R. I. Reeves, J. W. Jr., the Langley to Fleet Air Base, Pearl Harbor, T. H., as Executive Officer.

The public will have a rare opportunity, beginning this morning, to see some of the world's great books in a special exhibition arranged by the New York Public Library in its main exhibition room at Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street. The exhibition will continue through the Summer.

Lewisfield Plantation, consisting of about 1,000 acres on the west branch of the Cooper River near Charleston, S. C., has been sold by the Lewisfield Club to Robert R. M. Carpenter, vice president of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. Elliman Mullally, Inc., negotiated the deal.

Unlike the Walrus and the Carpenter, the average New Yorker does not weep like anything to see large quantities of sand. He is willing to go to a great deal of trouble to see them, especially if they are bordered by a presentable stretch of salt water and the weather is hot.
Mrs. Louis S. Epes today announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Julia Bagley Epes, to Allen Watts Staples, son of Abram P. Staples, Attorney General of Virginia, and Mrs. Staples.

In an atmosphere of secrecy conforming to the procedure adopted in connection with treason trials, the case against leaders of the former Nationalist Youth Movement came up for hearing before a special court here today.

The text of Bernard M. Baruch's address today at the commencement exercises of Union College was as follows: This is the month of marriages and commencement addresses, of gaiety and of elderly admonition.

Walter G. Warman, village clerk, tax collector and registrar of vital statistics since 1929, resigned the three eoffices tonight after investigators from the New York State Department of Audit and Control had announced to the Village Board that his accounts had been juggled to an extent of $2,196.

President Roosevelt and Premier Paul Van Zeeland of Belgium will discuss world economic problems on the Presidential yacht Potomac as well as in the White House, according to a program for Mr. Van Zeeland's visit issued by the Belgian Embassy today.
Our picture yesterday of the C. I. O. mass meeting of the day before at Monroe, Mich., might easily have been

About 4,000 workers in sixteen shipyards in Brooklyn and two in Hoboken went on strike yesterday for increased wages, shorter hours and a closed shop in response to the call of the International Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America, C. I. O. affiliate.
Dr. Richard C. Norris, an obstetrician, teacher and writer, died at the home of his son, Edward Norris, in Los Angeles, on Thursday, it was announced here today. He was 73 years old.

The evacuation of 20,000 women and children and men over the military age to Santander was ordered tonight. They will be transported both on trucks and aboard a fleet of minesweepers, trawlers and fishing boats.

Lawrence, Blake Jewell; Inc, has arranged a building loan of $600,000 for the Chelsea Land Corp, J. M. Felson, president, on the six-story apartment buildings under construction at 245-263 W 23d St and 238-56 W 24th St. The buildings will contain 188 apartments.
Sister Cecilia Teresa, a teacher in Saint Vincent's Academy here for more than twenty years, died yesterday at the academy after a lone illness.

An audience of more than 2,500 persons at the Hippodrome contributed approximately $5,000 last night to buy medical supplies and send three ambulances to the Spanish Government forces. The meeting was held under the auspices of the Medical Bureau to Aid Spanish Democracy.

The prolonged strike of mechanical and editorial employes of The North Shore Journal in Flushing, Queens, has been settled, it was announced yesterday by T. Harold Forbes, publisher of the newspaper. The mechanical employes went on strike on Nov. 23 and on Dec. 27 they were joined by editorial employes affiliated with, the Newspaper Guild.

Charles Lathrop Pack, forest conservationist, president of the American Tree Association and retired banker, died yesterday at Doctors Hospital after a brief illness. Mr. Pack, who lived at 250 Forest Avenue, Lakewood, N. J., was 80 years old.
A syndicate headed by Edward B. Smith Co. won yesterday the award of $4,700,000 refunding bonds of Buffalo, N. Y., on a bid of 100.799 for 3.10s. The next highest bid,

Dr. John L. Newcomb, president of the University of Virginia, told alumni and graduates this afternoon of plans to make the new $950,000 library building, now under construction, a memorial to the first president of the university, Edwin A. Alderman.

F. Eberstadt Co., Inc., will offer today $1,000,000 of ten-year sinking-fund 5 per cent notes and 34,750 shares of $25 par value 6 per cent cumulative preferred stock of the Avery Sons Company, manufacturer of farm implements.

Five governments defaulted on their war debt payments due tomorrow, in notes to the State Department today. They were Italy, which has $81,978,163 due, of which. $16,341,593 is a new installment and the rest arrears; Lithuania with $1,231,760 due,

Twenty houses in the group of thirty homes completed this season by the Rockaway Operating Company at Rockaway Point have been sold. They are of Cape Cod design, containing four to five rooms. Among the buyers were: Mary C.

A near-perfect round of golf by George Dunlap of Pomonok and Henry Ciuci of Fresh Meadow earned for the pair the top honors in the Long Island Golf Association amateur-pro tournament over the exacting Oakland course today as they set the pace for fifty-one other combinations, the last few finishing in a terrific rainstorm.

After an interval of fifteen years, John Willard's "The Cat and the Canary" was revived at the Majestic last evening. This is the second in a series of mystery melodramas that are being offered at one dollar an orchestra seat jitter during the usual swelter season.

The Adjutant General released the following orders today; COMMISSIONS Ross, Col. Ogden J. Hastings, qualified, is placed on duty. He is to report commanding general 53d Brigade for assignment to command 105th Infantry. Doll, Capt. Raymond J., Dental Corps, assigned to 174th Infantry.

Commercial and industrial failures in the United States dropped to the lowest total for any full week this year in the week ended Thursday, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday. The total for the six days was 161, compared with 146 for the five-day week preceding and 172 for the corresponding week last year.

In conjunction with the new incinerator which the city is about to complete on the West Side there will be a garage at Fifty-seventh Street and Twelfth Avenue to house the Department of Sanitation trucks. Three large freight elevators with platforms, 12.6 by 32 feet, with a capacity of 25,000 pounds,

Strong criticism of the Supreme Court was expressed by two speakers at tonight's dinner meeting of the four-day annual Institute of Labor, which began its seventh annual meeting this afternoon under the sponsorship of Rutgers University, in cooperation with the New Jersey Federation of Labor and the Workers Education Bureau of America.

William Woodward's Omaha, great 5-yearold son of Gallant Fox, apparently has run his last race. Lameness developing from a slight injury to a tendon in his left foreleg led to Omaha's withdrawal today from the Ascot Gold Cup race Thursday and Woodward declared

The crews of California, Wisconsin and Syracuse arrived on the Hudson today and were welcomed to the regatta city by a delegation from the Chamber of Commerce. Coach Ky Ebright of the Golden Bears brought his varsity and freshmen and the 86-year-old Jim Ten Eyck, coach of Syracuse, has his varsity and freshman eights here. Coach Ralph Hunn

Abbe Ernest Dimnet has written his publishers, Simon Schuster, that he will sail from France late in October to begin his annual lecture tour here. The second volume of his autobiography, "My New World," has gone to press and will be published just prior to his arrival.

Automobile production increased last week but, due to the holiday in the previous week, the daily average declined more than seasonally and the adjusted index dropped to 121.8 from 127.1 (revised). For the week ended June 13, 1936, the index was 101.1.
A financial and political crisis in France is developing at a fast tempo. Many political observers believe that the days of the Blum Cabinet are numbered.

Mrs. Roosevelt today denied at a press conference a report that she was going abroad, asserted that she had paid all her taxes in full and announced a schedule that will keep her actively engaged until she goes "off the record" July 8 for six weeks' vacation.

Another semi-annual installment day has rolled around for the war debts, but once more the only payment will come from little Finland. Twelve other war debtors are now in default to a total of more than $1,500,000,000, and the suspension of payments has now run for a period of five years.

The election of Clifford M. Baker Jr., '38, of Plainfield, N. J., to the captaincy of Princeton University's varsity tennis team for the 1938 season was announced today by the offices of the University Athletic Association. The New Jersey athlete succeeds William S. Rawls, '37, of Baltimore, Md.

CLASS A Mrs. Wright D. Goss Jr. Baltusrol, defeated Miss Grace Amory, Women's National, 4 and 3, and Mrs. Richard P. Limburg, Century, 7 and 5. Miss Gail Wild, Baltusrol, defeated Mrs. Van Devanter Crisp, Women's National, 3 and 2, and Mrs. David H. Sulzberger, Century, 3 and 2.

The two-story business building at 169-08 Hillside Avenue, Jamaica, Queens, has been sold by John Marmus and Anton Roefs to the Home Realty Corporation of Jamaica. The property is said to have been held at $30,000 and the buyer paid cash above the first mortgage of $15,000. Brunswick, Praver Nassof, Inc., was the broker.

Funds have been received by J. P. Morgan Co., fiscal agents, for the payment of the June 15 coupons of all bonds of the Imperial Chinese Government 5 per cent Hukuang Railways Loan of 1911, including those bonds that have been drawn for redemption for the sinking fund but not yet paid.

Dr. W. T. Mather, Professor of Physics at the University of Texas, died suddenly today of a heart attack at the age of 76. He came to the university forty years ago and had been a member of the faculty since.

Gaetano Manna, 47 years old, and Sylvia Trosola, 37, who twelve years ago fled from Newark while out on bail awaiting an appeal from their conviction on a kidnapping charge, were apprehended yesterday in an apartment at 37-31 Twelfth Street, Astoria, Queens.
Mount Holyoke College paid tribute to its retiring president and honored one of its most distinguished graduates at the 100th commencement exercises held here this morning.

Five players from Baltusrol made their way yesterday to the Fresh Meadow Country Club, Flushing, L. I., and walked off with the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's annual interclub tournament as neatly as any New Jerseyite could wish.

Dr. Joseph Goebbels, German Propaganda Minister, announced here today that old-age pensions for all deserving German artists were now being instituted by the National Socialist government. To begin with, he said, 2,000,000 marks has been set aside for this purpose for members of the theatrical profession.
Assignments Following probationary patrolmen having completed their course of training in the Recruits Training School, Police Academy, are transferred and assigned to precincts indicated:

Proposals for closing of cotton textile mills during the week of July 4 were being considered by mills and commission houses yesterday, but some selling agents said they had checked with large customers as to whether it would be permissible to defer deliveries due during July and found that a number of them were insistent upon shipment according to contracts.

Play in the Meadow Brook polo championship, with an entry list of thirteen teams, including many leading British and American internationalists, is scheduled to get under way Saturday at the Meadow Brook Club in Westbury, L. I.
Mrs. William F. Dowling, wife of the State Supreme Court Justice, was forced to choose between three commencements today.

Here and there: The joint resolution by members of the East End Surf Fishing Club at Riverhead, L. I., and representatives of commercial fishermen urging an extension of shrimping regulations at Peconic Bay until May 29 will be discussed at the club's next gathering, the second Thursday in July.... It has also

Cannon St, 104, 25x100: Merlet, Inc. Mathew G. Condon, president, to Lucien D. Bloch, trustee to Adolphus Ottenberg, 1,016 5th Ave. Same property; Lucien D. Bloch, trustee, Adolphus Ottenberg, to Sondra Real Estate Corp, 42 Catherine St ($32). Goerck St, 4, 25x100; Mary F. Penny to Margt. M. Dreyer, 216 Pemberton Ave, Plainfield, N. J.; mtge, $5,000 (50c).

The Municipal Civil Service Commission is restricting examinations for clerical positions to persons under 25 years of age because it wants flexibility in city employes and because it wants employes who will grow up with their departments, according to Assistant Corporation Counsel Jeremiah Evarts.

MANHATTAN ALEY, NELLIE (Feb. 14, 1934). Gross assets, $5,630; net, $5,630. To Maxwell Aley, son. Chief assets, jointly owned property, $5,630. H. H. Holbert, attorney, 205 E. 85th St. ALEY, ROBERT J. (Nov. 17, 1935). Gross assets, $20,198; net, $17,511. To Maxwell Aley, son. Chief assets, stocks and bonds,

First Lieut. Maurice Sherman, C. A.-Res. 114-03 127th St., South Ozone Park, N. Y., 533d Coast Artillery, is ordered to active duty June 20, at Fort Hancock, N. J., for duty as assistant instructor. Lieutenant Sherman will rank from May 22, 1937. He will be relieved from active duty July 3.

Stocks of refined copper at domestic refineries at the end of May amounted to 108,585 tons, compared with 99,576 at the close of April, a gain of 9,009 tons, according to the Copper Institute. Blister stocks,

Still in possession of the league lead, the Yankees will return to the Stadium today for a home stand against the Western clubs. Half a game in front of the White Sox, the Ruppert Rifles will attempt to strengthen that advantage at the expense of the Indians in a threegame series that will start this afternoon.

Two Democratic Senators, Edward R. Burke of Nebraska and Rush D. Holt of West Virginia, joined last night in denouncing President Roosevelt's Supreme Court proposal at a Flag Day dinner of the American Defense Society at the Hotel Commodore.

Mrs. Parmely W. Herrick entertained at luncheon yesterday in the outdoor Japanese Garden of the Ritz-Carlton for Mrs. J. Gordon Douglas and Mrs. William Fitz Hugh Whitehouse. Another luncheon hostess there was Mrs. Stuart G. Gibboney, whose guests were Mrs. Stuart McNamara, Mrs. F.

The writing of new life insurance last month was 7.4 per cent more than in May a year ago, while the total in the first five months wqs 9.2 per cent higher than in the same period in 1936, according to the Association of Life Insurance Presidents in a report to the United States Department of Commerce.
The infant mortality rate for the United States rose from 55.7 per 1,000 in 1935 to 56.9 in 1936, according to statistics made public today by the Bureau of the Census.

Brokers with foreign connections, under an order issued yesterday by the committee on foreign business of the New York Stock Exchange, are forbidden to make firm bids or firm offers in listed securities, where such action gives the foreign customer an undue advantage. An order which has the effect of making a firm bid or firm offer is considered to be one.

The long-awaited report of the Senate Judiciary Committee on President Roosevelt's bill to reorganize the courts reached the Senate today, and denounced the measure as "a needless, futile, and utterly dangerous abandonment of constitutional principle."

A 13-year-old boy received severe burns on the right arm here today in a prelude to the Fourth of July when an abandoned gasoline tank into which he had put a penny firecracker burst with a violence that hurled it 150 feet in the air and shattered windows in the neighborhood.

Bernard M. Baruch warned here today against over-regulation by the government in the economic field. Declaring that the world had two constant problems, to develop its understanding of natural laws and develop its ability to apply these laws judiciously, he said that

Headed by Miss Norma Taubele of New York and Miss Eunice Dean of San Antonio, Texas, a field of forty-four players started out in the women's New York State championship yesterday at the Jackson Heights Tennis Club, Queens.

Harry H. Woodring, Secretary of War, announced today that he had approved the spending of $26,000 by the Engineers Corps for completion of dredging in the Connecticut River to provide a channel 15 feet deep at mean low water from the mouth of the river to Hartford.

With Mayor La Guardia objecting in vain to salary restorations for appointive city officials earning $5,000 a year or more, the Democratic majority in the Board of Estimate proceeded yesterday with its task of restoring all salaries to the levels that prevailed before pay cuts were made.

War Minstrel, claimed only a short time ago by Mrs. Emil Denemark, cartried the Chicago sportswoman's colors to victory in the Kensington Purse at Washington Park today. It marked the second straight triumph for War Minstrel in the Denemark silks, the second of the afternoon for that stable, and the third during the day for Jockey Charlie Kurtsinger.
Former Governor Alfred E. Smith of New York said today his impressions of Europe led him to believe the American system of government was better than any kind of "ism."

Something of a triumph of illogic, not to say of Class B melodramas, is the Rialto's latest divertissement, a glib little crime-without-punishment film called "When Thief Meets Thief," produced by Douglas

The wedding of Miss Barbara Elizabeth Hawley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George S. Hawley, to Harcourt Frederick Schutz, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Walter Stanley Schutz of Hartford, will take place June 29 in the Hawley home. The Rev. Watson L. Phillips of New Haven will perform the ceremony.

New York City Negroes paid their annual tribute yesterday to Harriet Beecher Stowe, author of "Uncle Tom's Cabin," on the 126th anniversary of her birth, at exercises in New York University's Hall of Fame on the University Heights campus.

Every factor which existed in 1917 and caused a subsequent doubling of real estate prices is existent today-only to a greater extent--and will result in an early upturn in the realty market, Roy Wenzlick of St. Louis told 1,800 persons tonight at a meeting in the County Center here.

Although actual figures are not available, there is a well defined feeling in certain Wall Street circles that much of the pressure on prices evident yesterday was due to liquidation of "old margin accounts." It will be recalled that
Plans to introduce a group life insurance system and a retirement income plan for employes of the Todd Shipyards Corporation will be discussed at the annual meeting here on June 30.

Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, the German Economics Minister, is expected to arrive here on Friday on a visit ascribed to his desire to persuade the Austrian Government to change its somewhat lukewarm attitude toward economic cooperation with Germany.
Dartmouth's largest graduating class, numbering 493, received diplomas today and saw President Hopkins confer thirteen honorary degrees.
The A. G. Joyce Jr. Company has been formed to transact a general investment business at 115 Broadway.

The British Government "must reserve the right to consider" the expulsion of Italian missionaries from Malta, Nigeria and other parts of the British Empire, Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden told the House of Commons today.

Rex Mays, one of the outstanding drivers of the Pacific Coast, will participate in the 300-mile test for the George Vanderbilt Cup at the Roosevelt Raceway on July 3, it was announced yesterday. He will drive an Alfa Romeo.

The United States Steel Corporation announced yesterday that a total of 594 graduates of ninety-one colleges and universities located in forty-eight States had accepted bids to enter the training courses of the corporation this Summer, marking the definite return of big industry to the college campus in its search for trained men.

Scoring his first victory of the year over a racing strip fetlock deep in mud, Mrs. A. M. Creech's Sound Advice won the Falmouth Claiming Handicap, six-furlong feature of today's program at Suffolk Downs.
Declines were numerous and severe in the bond market on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday as prices fell in sympathy with the weakness in stocks.

The National Labor Relations Board has ordered hearings here starting next Monday to determine whether elections shall be held by the crews of seventy-four ship lines operating from ports on the Atlantic and Gulf of Mexico at which their bargaining agencies for wage contracts may be chosen, it was announced yesterday.

The necessity for dealing with reputable resources as the only certain guarantee that fabrics made from any fiber are posessed of quality and serviceability was stressed by several speakers at a meeting of executives of various departments of Bloomingdale's, following a dinner at the store last night.
Five members of the United States Davis Cup squad moved into the second round of the Queens Club tennis tournament today along with three of their compatriots.
James H. R. Cromwell and his wife, the former Doris Duke, departed today for Leningrad, taking with them films of the Kremlin walls which led to his arrest and detention for an hour and a half.

The Newark Bears temporarily were halted in their drive toward the International League pennant today as they bowed to the Toronto Maple Leafs, 7 to 4. The defeat ended the Bears' seven-game winning streak.
Magistrate Overton Harris, who is sensitive to the backfire of patrolmen's motor cycles and has other little difficulties from time to time, has lost a pistol. He reported as
Joseph Costinori, maestro of the hurdy-gurdy, said farewell to his art yesterday from the podium-the witness's platform, rather-in the Harlem Magistrate's Court.

Representatives of twenty-one Central and South American republics joined here today in a Flag Day observance at which Josephus Daniels, Ambassador to Mexico, declared that "in a decade of 'isms' we turn with confidence to the only hope of mankind-government by the consent of the governed."

Inactive gold in the Treasury's sterilization fund was increased by $16,012,549.80 from Thursday to Friday, raising the fund above the $900,000,000 mark for the first time, the Treasury's daily report showed today. The sterilized gold, as it stood on Friday, was $912,122,582.08, compared with $896,110,032.28 on the previous day.

An investing client of Edwards Co. has purchased the building containing eight stores on a plot 123 by 100 feet at 603 Central Avenue, East Orange, N. J. Purchase was for cash above a first mort- gage of $100,000 held by the Prudential Insurance Company of America.
R. W. Gwaltney, in 173 E 74th St; Katherine Ahrens, in 9 E 54th St; A. H. Jaeger, through Joseph Milner Co, in The Dover 687 Lexington Ave; Burgoyne Hamilton Co, Inc, broker.
Prices of wheat on the Board of Trade here fluctuated in a most erratic manner today within a fair range.

The Rev. Dr. Gustav A. Carstensen, who is 86 years old today, spent last evening reading birthday greetings through wreaths of smoke from cigars sent by friends and former parishioners. He lives at 142-02 Franklin Avenue, Flushing, Queens. He spent part of the day visiting Pilgrim State Hospital at Brentwood, L. I.

Thirty-three graduates of the Brooklyn Law School were inducted last night into the Philonomic Council, honorary scholastic society of the school. Professor Robert R. Sugarman, faculty member of the society, officiated at the ceremonies in the school auditorium, 375 Pearl Street. Dean William Payson Richardson presented the council keys.
Revolver shots echoed through the huge Capitol tonight when Representatives Manuel Penabaz and Narcisco Moran resorted to gunplay during a secret session of the lower chamber.
Turpentine firm, 34 1/4c; sales, 225 barrels; receipts, 474 barrels; shipments, 2,439 barrels; stock, 27,137 barrels.

The Interstate Commerce Commission's valuations for the five railroads contesting as excessive the taxes levied against them by New Jersey for 1934, 1935 and 1936 were read into the record in the United States District Court here today as trial of the carriers' suit for a permanent injunction was resumed before Judge Phillip Forman.

The Army and the Navy will compete in a new field of sport-crosscountry--next year. The addition of cross-country brings to eight the number of sports in which the Army and Navy compete annually. Several years ago they began competing in gymnasium and fencing.

A dinner for a group of visiting French and Belgian physicians and other notables was given last night at the Hotel Pierre by American members of the International Congress on Hepatic Insufficiencies and the International Society of Gastroenterology.

Delivery of copies of The Evening Bulletin was obstructed today by what the newspaper described as "a dispute between two rival groups of chauffeurs, one group representing the American Federation of Labor and another representing adherents of the C. I. O."
The desperately pleading and grimly threatening O'Connell kidnapping ransom correspondence was read here today to a Federal court jury trying eight men.

The Rev. Dr. Henry H. Tweedy, who retires from the Yale Divinity School faculty this Summer after holding the professorship of practical theology twenty-eight years, told the members of the class of 1937 in giving the annual commencement address today that they had received just the kind of education "with which to go places and by the right methods to the right places."

Colonel John Reed Kilpatrick, president of the Madison Square Garden Corporation, presented to Police Commissioner Valentine yesterday afternoon at police headquarters a check for $13,886.13, representing 50 per cent of the receipts from the police show "Around the Clock With New York's Finest," which was presented at the Garden on June 2, 3 and 4.

Steel operations for the current week are scheduled at 76.6 per cent of steel ingot capacity, compared to 76.2 per cent last week, a gain of .4 point, or .5 per cent, the American Iron Steel Institute reports. A month ago the

Every factor which existed in 1917 and caused a subsequent doubling of real estate prices is existent today-only to a greater extent--and will result in an early upturn in the realty market, Roy Wenzlick of St. Louis told 1,800 persons tonight at a meeting in the County Center here.
The Cabinet will be asked today to recognize that its primary problems are economic by adopting principles that later would be employed to control the budget.

With Associate Justice Martin Travieso of the Supreme Court presiding, the Federal Bar Association, besides condemning the attempted assassination of United States Judge Robert A. Cooper, offered a $1,000 reward for information leading to the arrest and conviction of the assailants.

Winners of the thirteenth annual scholarship competition of the Holy Name Society of the Police Department were announced yesterday by the Rev. Joseph A. McCaffrey, Catholic chaplain of the department. Four scholarships valued at $1,200 were awarded.
Charles Poletti became a Supreme Court Justice officially yesterday when he took the oath of office in a crowded court room in the county Court House in Foley Square.

Twenty-eight more executives and employes of the Amur section of the Transsiberian Railway have been shot as spies and saboteurs allegedly working in behalf of Japan at Svobodnie, important railway junction in the highly strategic area between Chita and Khabarovsk.

Meeting with American foreign traders at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday, the Japanese Economic Mission, which will conclude its two months' tour of the United States tomorrow, began compiling the results of its numerous conversations with business interests here.

Two years of struggling against illness while carrying on the double duty of coaching basketball and taking a full schedule of class-room work ended today for Johnny Galloway when he marched to the rostrum to receive a Bachelor of Arts degree at. the Colgate University com-. mencement.

Chalmers L. Pancoast was elected Grand Commander of the Knights Templar of New York State today to succeed Chauncey T. Thayer of Gloversville. Others elected as the Grand Commandery began its annual conclave were: Jackson R.
Speaking Maine as "a State of grace," Robert P. Tristram Coffin paid tribute today at commencement exercises of the University of Maine to the State's spirit of independence.

An appeal in behalf of non-striking workers in the Youngstown district or Ohio was made at the joint Congressional committee hearing on the Black-Connery Wage and Hour Bill today by Bernard Wittenauer, employee of the Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company, now out of work because of the strike.

Charges that Bilbao's desperate plight was the result of the treachery of a high Basque army officer and that border control was a "comedy" were made by Alfredo Espinosa Orive, Minister of Health of the Basque Republic, tonight in an interview at the Spanish Embassy here.

Miss Helen Pershing Healey, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William John Healey of Bradford, Pa., was married to Lebert Lombardo, son of Mr. and Mrs. Guy Lombardo of Stamford, Conn., yesterday morning in the Lady Chapel of St. Patrick's Cathedral by the Rev. Thomas L. Graham.

Mrs. Roosevelt, wife of the President, described today the costume she will wear at the wedding of their son, Franklin D. Jr., and Miss Ethel du Pont on June 30. On that occasion, Mrs. Roosevelt said, she will wear an "old ladyish" dress of white chiffon flowered in "mixy colors," and a large white hat trimmed with flowers of the same varicolored shades.

Miss Mary Hegeler Cole, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Rufus Cole of Cohomong Wood, this place, and 730 Park Avenue, New York, was married to Alton Quentin Childs of Princeton, N. J., this afternoon in St. Matthew's Episcopal Church in Bedford by the rector, the Rev. Arthur Ketcham.
National League teams came out on top today in both ends of a double-header exhibition for charity played before a crowd officials estimated at more than 6,000.

The Agrarian Department has sent a group of engineers to survey the big estate extending from Atlixco in the State of Puebla southwest to the border of the State of Morelos that is owned by William O. Jenkins, former United States Consul.

About 4,000 Boy Scouts observed Flag Day last night as they marched down Broadway from 110th Street, turned east on Seventy-seventh Street and entered the American Museum of Natural History, where the annual Manhattan Council Court of Honor was held.

After two hours of argument in the Circuit Court of Appeals here today the Federal Government won appointment of a special three-judge "expediting court" to decide on the government's prosecution of the Aluminum Company of America under the Sherman Anti-Trust Law.

Former Police Judge Oscar Schultz died today at his home here of a heart attack at the age of 71. Judge Schultz, who completed his six-year term as police judge of this town ten years ago, was a native of Long Island. He was active in politics

The Cornell University poloists showed power today as they downed Monmouth County Country Club, 6 to 3, in their final workout for the intercollegiate championship match with Princeton on Wednesday. The winners displayed excellent teamwork.

The Securities Dealers Associations of New York, New England and Maine, and the Investment Bankers Association, representing overthe-counter interests, are expected to intervene tomorrow when the Securities and Exchange Commission takes evidence on applications by the New York Curb Exchange for unlisted trading privileges in twenty-two bond or debenture issues now traded only over the counter. The Curb has applied also

K. T. Keller, president of the Chrysler Corporation, announced yesterday that J. E. Fields, vice president and director of the corporation, will resign as president of the Chrysler Division, effective today, and will assume more important duties in the executive management of the corporation as a whole. He will make his
Floral Garden Homes, Inc., 'has purchased from the estate of John Kiefer 109 lots in the village of Elmont, Hempstead, L. I., with an option to purchase an additional 107.

The national income produced in the United States in 1936 was $63,800,000,000, according to the estimates of the Department of Commerce, an increase of nearly $9,000,000,000, or about 16 per cent, over that of 1935, and an increase of $25,000,000,000 over that of 1932.
Mrs. Georgiana Montgomery Hamilton, wife of former Secretary of New York State James A. Hamilton, died last night at her residence, 2,090 Washington Avenue, the Bronx.
Investigation of a shooting in the Avenue Junot today led the French police to the discovery of what is believed to be one of the biggest underground systems of supplying arms to Spain.
The National Duckpin Bowling Congress said today Miss Ida Simmons of Norfolk, Va., had been selected as the leading woman duckpin bowler of the United States for the 1936-37 season. Her average,

Americans, banded together in patriotic societies, were joined by civic and military organizations and uniformed representatives of American youth in parades and patriotic exercises yesterday to celebrate Flag Day, which marked the 160th anniversary of the adoption of the Stars and Stripes as the national emblem by the Continental Congress.
Catalan troops on whom the Spanish Government pins hopes for a strong offensive to draw Insurgents from tottering Bilbao struck hard today at Huesca, on the Aragon front in the northeast of Spain.

The National Association of Sheet Music Dealers, Inc., yesterday started consideration of a plan of procedure whereby the legitimate music dealer will be protected from competition of "fly-by-night" concerns at the opening of the twentyfourth annual convention at the Hotel Roosevelt.

Estimates of the world's gold production, which has a necessary bearing on the present problem of absorbing the new supplies without undue inflation of bank reserves, vary considerably, but all agree that the last few years have been marked by an exceptionally rapid increase.
A premature announcement of a surprise visit by Chancellor Adolf Hitler to meet the "Old Guard" of the Nazis at Marienwerder in East Prussia may result in cancellation of his trip.

The Federal Government brought Governor Harold G. Hoffman's name into the Parker conspiracy case again today, but in a connection apparently designed to eliminate him as a figure in the secret, preliminary investigation that resulted in the surrender of Paul H. Wendel as the "confessed" kidnapper of the Lindbergh baby.

Standard Brands, Inc., New York, failed today to obtain dismissal a Federal Trade Commission complaint charging violation of the Robinson-Patman Anti-Price Discrimination Law. The commission complaint alleged that the company had discriminated in favor of large bakers on yeast prices.

The economic barriers which separate nations must be relaxed if the world is ever to come to a rational understanding and peace, Newton D. Baker said tonight at the opening session of the second conference on Canadian-American affairs.
For the first time in twenty-three years the Knights of the Garter, England's most ancient order of chivalry, held a service today in their bannerhung chapel of St. George, at Windsor.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It has pleased me to note the comments on my feeble revision of the oftcriticized line in Kipling's "Recessional"-"The tumult and the shouting dies." I had not dreamed that so much

Soon after Commissioner of Public Works Charles A. Maguire announced the end of the strike of 1,000 Providence city employes, an estimated 900 at a mass meeting tonight voted unanimously to stay out until their demands were met.

The average profit on $1,000 of municipal bonds bought and resold by the Public Works Administration increased from $26.14 on Aug. 31, 1936, to $29.55 on March 31 this year, the PWA's division of accounts reported today to Secretary Ickes.

Reflecting general business improvement in the rubber industry, earnings of the Firstone Tire and Rubber Company in the first half of its fiscal year increased 37 per cent over those of the corresponding period of the previous year, according. to an announcement made yesterday.

The pairings and starting times for the thirty-seventh metropolitan amateur championship tourney under the auspices of the Metropolitan Golf Association were announced yesterday. The competition will start tomorrow over the course of the Metropolis Country Club at White Plains.
George Mailler, a merchant and bank official of Cornwall, who had held public offices, died yesterday in Cornwall Hospital. His age was 71. He was in the meat business here for about a half century.

While admitting that over-exploitation and mistakes characterized the cooperative apartment house development during the years prior to the depression, Herbert U. Nelson, secretary of the National Association of Real Estate Boards, predicts that the cooperative apartment house idea but with certain modifications, will come back.

The Securities and Exchange Commission received testimony today that New Jersey was chosen as the site for a stock trade between an investment trust and a holding company so that payment of the New York transfer tax on securities might be avoided.

Harvard, the defending champion, and West Point will meet today on the Morris Memorial Field at Governors Island in the first semifinal game of the intercollegiate polo championship. The contest will start at 4:30 P. M.

The Senate will begin consideration tomorrow of the $1,500,000,000 Relief Appropriation Bill, reported today by Senator Byrnes for the Committee on Appropriations. The indications are that it will pass without any important changes.

Following are the coal mines affected by the C. I. O. call to shut down subsidiary diggings of strike-affected steel companies, or by previous company orders closing the mines because of the steel strike: ...

Peaceful picketing by strikers is generally permitted under the laws of the various political subdivisions in this country, and violence and coercion are illegal. But organized labor has found that peaceful picketing does not help to win strikes unless a community is overwhelmingly on the side of the strikers.

Miss Dorothy Wightman of Boston, daughter of Mrs. George W. Wightman, former national singles champion and donor of the Wightman Cup, advanced to the third round of the Middle States girls' tennis championship today.

170th St (11-2896), n w cor of Brook Ave, 90x50; Bale Holding Corp to Lesdor Realty Corp, 233 Broadway. 170th St (11-2910), s w cor of 3d Ave, 117x52; Friedboro Realty Corp to Albert W Pross, trustee, 20 Claremont Rd, Scarsdale, N. Y.; mtg $22,500. 168th St (9-2515), s e cor of Nelson Ave, 150x68; I. R. B. Realty Co, Inc, to Isidore Freeman, 2,734 Claflin Ave; mtg $77,500.

Mrs. Monaei Lindley Groves received an uncontested divorce from Wallace Groves, New York financier, at Carson City Saturday, it was learned here today. She charged cruelty. The couple were married Dec. 21, 1934, and have a year-old-son, Wallace Jr. Custody of the child was fixed in a sealed property settlement.

Magistrate Curran served notice in Yorkville Court yesterday on 100 unlicensed peddlers of candies, peanuts, ice cream and other foodstuffs that they would not be permitted to sell their wares in Central Park unless they obtained special permits from the Park Department.
By a proclamation issued under the hand of Speaker Francis Fahy, the Dail Eireann was dissolved tonight and the Free State's most momentous general election campaign was begun.

Hotel facilities in this tranquil New England community were all but exhausted tonight by Democratic women from ten States, flocking in for a two-day conference with their national leaders, opening tomorrow. An imposing coterie of party celebrities were among the early arrivals.

Operating revenues of eighty-eight Class I railroads reporting to the Association of American Railroads for May, 1937, were estimated at $284,140,831, or 8.3 per cent above such receipts for the same month last year, but still 24.9 per cent below May, 1930.
BADER--Louis, beloved husband of Emma (nee Ober), brother of the late Rose Morris. Service at the Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave., Wednesday, June 16. at 11 A. M.

Michael LaRocco, 33 years old, a granite salesman, pleaded guilty yesterday to a bigamy indictment that developed from the recently withdrawn breach of promise suit of Peggy Garcia, night club hatcheck girl, against David Rubinoff, the violinist.

Mrs. Norman M. Lack of Wilmington, Del., with an 82, six over par, captured medal honors in the qualifying round of the fifth annual Pennsylvania women's golf championship today over the Berkshire Country Club course. Mrs. Lack was out in 39 and back in 43.

In the ten years through 1933 E. L. Phillips Co. bought about $35,000,000 of materials for the Long Island Lighting Company, receiving a 3 per cent allowance for overhead and a 5 per cent allowance for profit, according to evidence submitted yesterday to Supreme Court Justice Aaron J. Levy.
Market closed steadier after 1-to-8-point declines in leading industrial issues; turnover, 1,300,169 shares. All classes of bonds lower, second-grade issues weakest; transactions, $7,871,900.

Baron Constantin von Neurath, Germany's Foreign Minister, flew this morning to Berlin. Afterward a communique was issued containing the usual phrases of "complete understanding" and "identity of views" and adding that both countries were for peace and the promotion of mutual understanding and cooperation but against the formation of political blocs.

Weekly figures on traffic accidents under the safety campaign of the Police Department were announced yesterday by First Deputy Commissioner Harold Fowler. For the week the number of accidents and deaths rose, although a separate table covering the week-end period showed declines in all items.

Sir Percival and Lady Meadow, Mr. and Mrs. Robert B. Cumming, Miss Muriel Crocker, Carle C. Conway, Mr. and Mrs. K. A. Mapp, Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Brownell and Mr. and Mrs. George E. Milne are among the passengers due from Europe today on the Cunard White Star liner Aquitania. Others include Mr. and Mrs. J. F. M. Taylor. Dr.

Two hundred and seven graduates of the University of Vermont received academic degrees at commencement exercises today. Twenty-four Masters degrees were given, including thirteen Master of Arts degrees and eleven Master of Science degrees. Fifty received Doctor of Medicine degrees.Six honorary degrees were conferred.

Peter J. Cleary, former Assistant Postmaster of Brooklyn and a member of the department for forty-four years until his retirement on Sept. 30, 1932, died Sunday at his home, 1,714 East Seventeenth Street, Brooklyn, after a brief illness. He was 74 years old.
Diplomas were awarded yesterday to a class of fifty at the ninety-sixth commencement of Williston Academy.

President Roosevelt and Secretary of State Hull are asked to intercede with Poland against "pogroms and ostracism of Jewry there" in a resolution by the Independent Order Brith Sholom, Jewish fraternal order with 18,000 members in twentytwo States.

The number of retail chains operating in 1935 increased 9.6 per cent in the United States over those in 1933, while the number of stores decreased by 8.2 per cent and sales volume increased 25 per cent, according to new data issued yesterday by the Bureau of the Census as part of its United States Summary of Retail Distribution.
If anybody thought that Saturday night had seen the last of the original production of "Dead End" he I reckoned without Louis F. Werba and Jules J. Leventhal.

Professor Charles H. Farnham and Mrs. Farnham have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Frances Farnham, to John H. Mitchell, son of Professor Sydney K. Mitchell of Yale University and Mrs. Mitchell.
The stock market here was quiet today, with price changes few and irregular. Gilt-edge issues were steady, while foreign loans were dull.
Mr. and Mrs. Francis James Cox announced yesterday the engagement of their daughter, Miss Alice Cox, to Joseph Garvin Shields of Dublin, Irish Free State.

A general strike of 5,000 river dock workers, boat crews and shipyard men was called this morning by the National Transport Federation. All inland navigation and port work was stopped except for the handling of mails and foodstuffs.
Municipal Court Justice Charles H. Haubert of Brooklyn died yesterday in Newfoundland, Pa., according to an announcement made here last night by his secretary, Martin H. A. Zinner. His age was 64.
Representative Paul W. Shafer of Battle Creek, Mich., proposed today collection of taxes on large consignments of liquor for private consumption in the District of Columbia.
A series of attacks by strikers on Cambria steel workers at Johnstown culminated in an early morning battle won by police with gas and pistols.
The Syracuse Chiefs of the International League defeated the Red Sox in an exhibition game tonight, scoring a run in the eighth to break a 2-2 tie.
Graduation exercises for fiftynine cadets of the Bordentown Military Institute will end the fifty-second commencement of the academy here tomorrow afternoon.

Mrs. Burt Weil of Cincinnati, who has monopolized the Ohio State championship for the last three years, bowed herself into the women's Western open golf tournament by rattling off a par-cracking 39, 39-78 for medal honors today at the Beverly Country Club.

Declaring that it is difficult to administer the Newark Department of Public Safety because of interference by politicians, City Commissioner Michael Duffy announced today his intention of resigning before May 1. 1938.

A plan to file an application next Fall with the Secretary of State for incorporation of a group to be known as the New York Presbyterian Foundation, Inc., for the purpose of administering bequests and similar gifts for the work in this city, was approved yesterday afternoon by the Presbytery of New York.

A delegation of American business men will sail Wednesday from New York aboard the Manhattan to attend the ninth biennial Congress of the International Chamber of Commerce at Berlin, the Chamber of Commerce of the United States announced today.

Government officials with special interest in air travel had an opportunity over the week-end to follow the newest strand of the airway web which has been woven out of vision and technical skill to join the United States and the Islands of the Bermudas.
Ely Culbertson spurned his doctor's orders to abandon play today and executed a squeeze on a six no-trump bid to keep his team in the running in the international bridge tournament here.

Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, local Works Progress Administrator, asked yesterday that Ralph M. Easley, chairman of the executive committee of the National Civic Federation, produce evidence to support -his charge that political considerations operate in the assignment and treatment of WPA employes.

Gifts to Connecticut State College totaling $686,000 for the college year were reported by President Katharine Blunt in her annual statement at commencement exercises this morning. The sum includes the bequest of $500,000 by Miss Virginia Palmer of New London for the Frank Loomis Palmer Auditorium.

Hamilton College, through its president Dr. Frederick C. Ferry, bestowed honorary degrees today upon four men distinguished in the fields of religion, law and education after the seventy-six members of the senior class had received degrees of Bachelor of Arts or Bachelor of Science.

Mr. and Mrs. Leslie Leland Locke of 950 St. Johns Place, Brooklyn, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Dorothy Brown Locke, to Edwin C. Bertsche, son of Mr. and Mrs. Carl Bertsche of Richmond Hill, Queens.

The unfavorable report of the Senate Judiciary Committee on the President's plan to reorganize the Federal courts comes at a time when Administration leaders in the Senate, abandoning hope of enacting that plan in its original form, are talking of the possibility of a compromise.

Movements of livestock on the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts, 11,000, including 4,000 directs. Market mostly 10c higher than Friday's average; closing with part of advance hundredweight; top $11.60; bulk good and
The Madison Square Garden Corporation of New York continued its legal battle today to prevent James J. Braddock, world heavyweight champion, from fighting Joe Louis in Chicago on June 22.
A proposal to amalgamate Zimmerknit Hosiery, Ltd., and York Knitting Mills will be considered by Zimmerknit's shareholders on June 23. The success of the plan hinges

Keystone Custodian Funds, Inc., Philadelphia, an investment trust, has filed a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering 74,516 Keystone Custodian certificates of participation, Series K 1, and 219,942 Series S 4, to be offered at the market.

The Daily Telegraph correspondent at Aden reports today that he is reliably informed that Miss Amelia Earhart, who is en route to Karachi, will be required to spend nine days in quarantine in India because she landed in a yellow fever area in Africa.

Manhattan BRENNAN, MARY (May 29). Estate, more than $10,000. To William G. Brennan, son, 278 Main St., Kingston, N. Y.; Agnes G. McCarthy, daughter, 35-28 153d St., Flushing; Gertrude C. McGloin, daughter, 258-19 Kensington Pl., Great Neck, L. I.; Margaret B. Ryan, daughter, 899 E. 39th St., Brooklyn, and John

As he scanned the luncheon menu the stout Mr. Bill Brandt of the National League Service Bureau remarked that it was a great day in history, a very great day, and it should be celebrated properly. He would speak to the waiter about it. A great day. Well, these are all great days, according to economists and historians who are surveying strikes and wars and political changes and the trend of the times.

Only two weeks out of a wheel chair, Mrs. Martin Johnson, widow of the explorer and photographer, was preparing yesterday to leave tomorrow on the Normandie en route to Nairobi in British East Africa, where she will lead her first expedition.

Leaves Battalion Chief James McBride, 45th Battalion, for 15 hours. Captain John T. Judge, Engine 226, for 9 hours. Firemen William J. Thompson (2), Engine 207, for 15 hours; Michael Policastro, H. L. 142, for 9 hours; John J. Davin, H. L. 113, for 9 hours: James Mullapy

Amplifying the statement made yesterday by John L. Lewis, C. I. O. chairman and head of the United Mine Workers, in ordering a strike of miners employed in the captive coal mines of the independent steel operators, Van A. Bittner, a regional S. W. O. C. director, declared today that 600,000 bituminous miners would be called on strike by Saturday if the mine owners furnished "aid and comfort" to the independent steel corporations.

" Representative government is a good idea that might be retrieved from the past and made to work," Dr. J. Edgar Park, president of Wheaton, told the graduating class of 131 at Middlebury College this morning in his commencement address.

Mayor Daniel A. Knaggs declared today that he would not try to prevent "peaceful picketing" of the Newton Steel Company plant by striking members of the C. I. O. But he asserted that he had no intention of demobilizing his army of special deputies or removing them from the entrance to the plant.

James J. Braddock today celebrated the second anniversary of his first day as the world's heavyweight champion by taking a rest at the Grand Beach, Mich., training camp where he is preparing for his first defense of the crown against Joe Louis here June 22.

Five hundred of the 1,500 barbers on strike on the Upper West Side since last week; returned to work yesterday following an agreement between the Journeymen Barbers' International Union and the United Master Barbers' Association, according to Ralph Allocca, president of Local 10 of the union.

Walter O. Briggs Jr., treasurer of the Detroit Baseball Club, said today the Tigers had discussed with the Browns a deal for Rollie Hemsley, star St. Louis catcher, but St. Louis asked too much for him. Briggs said:

Repudiation of the "gospel of force being preached in the world today by both the Right and the Left," was urged upon the graduating class of Drexel Institute of Technology today by James G. McDonald of THE NEW YORK TIMES editorial staff.
Sixteen Spanish diplomats, coming from posts as widely separated as Moscow and Washington, converged today on Valencia for a conference beginning tomorrow.
The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities shows the following changes for the week ended June 9:
The Securities and Exchange Commission today made public statistics on odd-lot purchases and sales of stocks, rights and warrants on the New York Stock Exchange for June 11 as follows:

Josephine Williams, a character actress who had appeared in many important Broadway productions, died yesterday in the Lenox Hill Hospital at the age of 82. For the last twenty-five years she had lived at the Hotel Langwell, 123 West Forty-fourth Street.

Winthrop W. Aldrich, chairman of the board of the Chase National Bank of New York City, told the Colgate graduating class today that "a free society such as ours must have. individual responsibility developed to the highest degree."

Despite the heat and humidity which made concert-going a burden, Artur Rodzinski, conductor of the Cleveland Orchestra, had a sensational success here yesterday when he appeared for the first time in leading a special concert of the Vienna Philharmonic.

Secretary Morgenthau tonight announced the sale today of $50,000,000 of 273-day Treasuly bills, to retire a like amount. The average interest rate was 0.572, a slight rise from the rate of 0.545 on the issue sold on June 7.

Miss Geraldine Lee, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Wideman Lee Jr. of 129 East Sixty-ninth Street and Port Chester, will be married to Marcallo Girosi of New York, son of Mrs. Beatrice Girosi of Naples, Italy, and the late Rear Admiral Edward Girosi, on July 3 at her parents' Summer home.

Funeral services for Mrs. Edith Minturn Stokes, wife of I. N. Phelps Stokes, president of the Municipal Art Commission, who died Saturday at her residence, 953 Fifth Avenue, were held yesterday afternoon in St. Paul's Chapel, Columbia University.

A heavy shower in which he played part of his round did not prevent Willie Turnesa of Briar Hills, recently crowned Westchester amateur champion, from setting a new course record for the Winged Foot Golf Club today in the amateur-pro tournament conducted by the Westchester division of the Metropolitan P. G. A.
