The most serious obstacle to a more rapid solution of the street and highway traffic problem is
More than 400 American companies with upward of $7,000,000 frozen in Spain, have filed reports of their holdings with the National Foreign Trade Council, it was announced yesterday.

Detective Elmer W. Hedrick and Euplio Di Marco of the Newark police force and Anthony Robbins, an agent of the State Alcoholic Beverage Control Board, were suspended from their duties here today on charges of accepting bribes from operators of unlicensed stills and allowing them to market illicit alcohol.

Trading in lamb slow; other classes generally fair. Steer beef sold strong to sharply higher. Fresh pork cuts were slightly uneven, but mostly steady to higher; other classes steady. Kosher beef opened about 50 cents higher and other kosher meats were steady with Friday's close, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.
Harry Balsamo will encounter Jimmy Belmont of Pittsburgh in the feature ten-rounder at the Queensboro Arena tonight. Tony Vaccarelli is to engage Frankie Barnwell in the six-round semi-final.

A need for greater emphasis on personal and economic freedom, rather than on political liberty alone, was set forth today by Dr. Alan C. Valentine, president of the University of Rochester, at the Alfred University commencement when 110 degrees in course were awarded.
Payment of the second quarter of the Federal income tax for 1936 is due today. Today is also the last day for payment of the second onequarter installment of State tax.

Activity in Manhattan and Bronx real estate as reported yesterday by brokers reflected an interest in business properties. A scattering of various types of dwelling units also were reported as changing hands.

BILBAO FRONT - The Rebels paused before the gates of the city while making an encircling movement north and south. Their staff believed two or three days would be taken up in such operations before they entered the city.

The Merchants Association announced its backing yesterday for legislation pending in the Board of Aldermen which would tax produce trucks from out-of-town which are used to compete with merchants established in this city.

Directors of the American Thermos Bottle Company declared yesterday an extra dividend of 75 cents and a payment of 25 cents on the common stock. On May 1 the company paid 25 cents to common shareholders.
A two-year factual study of big business has convinced the Twentieth Century Fund that mere size is not synonymous with immense profits, the fund announced yesterday.

Sales of three New England estates were reported by Previews, Inc. In New Hampshire the 250-acre estate known as Foxstand, with a ten-room house, near Springfield, was sold to a client of N. H. Sargent Co., co-broker in the deal.

Announcement was made today that H. A. Hobson, superintendent of the Buffalo division of the Pennsylvania Railroad, will become assistant to the general superintendent of the lake division with headquarters at Cleveland, effective on June 16.

A survey being carried out on the Tehuantepec Isthmus, with a group of American engineers reported cooperating, apparently supports the persistent assertion that some defense works in the Canal Zone might require deviation of part of the traffic or even the temporary closing of the canal, with no other

Lord Glenravel, better known to hundreds of his American friends as Sir Arthur Shirley Benn, who, throughout his business and political career, worked for increased Anglo-American understanding, died yesterday at the age of 78.

Brig. Gen. George E. Leach, Republican, held nearly a 7,000-vote margin over Kenneth Haycraft, his Farmer-Labor endorsed opponents, in the Minneapolis Mayorality campaign as returns from 204 of the city's 354 precincts were counted tonight. The vote was: Leach, 50,089; Haycraft, 43,220.

Representative Clare Hoffman of Michigan proposed today to organize a "well-armed" guard of a hundred men to prevent union organizers from re-entering the city of Monroe. On returning from a week-end tour of the strike-ridden sections of his State he made his offer in a telegram to Mayor Daniel A. Knaggs of Monroe.

Emphasizing the testimony of American, French and New Zealand delegates regarding the forty-hour laws in their countries, Harold Butler, International Labor Organization director, told its conference today that they had "made a prima facie case in favor of the shorter working week." He was replying to seventythree delegates, who had spoken during last week in discussion of his annual report.

Benjamin Butters Bryan, a stock and commodity broker in New York and Chicago for many years, died on Saturday in the New York Hospital after a brief illness. He was 76 years old and lived at 116 East Sixty-eighth Street.

Dr. Neil Carothers, Professor of Economics and director of the College of Business Administration at Lehigh University, delivered the address today at the annual Blair Academy commencement at which two of the school's prizes were won by his son, Neil Carothers 3d.

Yale's oarsmen had their initial workout on the Thames River this morning, but they were handicapped by intermittent rain and choppy water. Head Coach Ed Leader decided conditions were unfavorable for practice on the measured course, so he had the two varsity crews row about three miles above quarters. The freshman and combination boats also drilled, north of the boat house.

In a gesture for international friendliness Bates College conferred the honorary degree of Doctor of Humane Letters on Hirosi Saito, Japaness Ambassador to the United States, at the commencement exercises held in the chapel here this morning.

Benedict Van Voorhis of the plastics department of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. was elected president of the Purchasing Agents Association of New York at its annual meeting at the Builders Exchange Club last night.

A categorical denial was made late tonight of reports that the Viennese heart specialist, Professor Hans Eppinger, had been in Moscow to examine Joseph Stalin. Professor Eppinger, who had been in Rumania to see Dowager Queen Marie, learned of the reports on his return from that country and forthwith spoke to his lawyer, who issued the following statement:

Reuben A. Lewis Jr., now second vice president of the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company, has been elected executive vice president of the Metropolitan Trust Company, 11 South La Salle Street, Chicago.

Dr. Samuel G. Inman of Washington, special adviser to the United States delegation at the Buenos Aires Peace Conference, said here today that President Roosevelt's good-neighbor policy would turn to the radio waves next Fall.

Holders of 6 1/2 per cent notes of the McCallum Hosiery Company due in 1941 have been advised by the independent noteholders' protective committee, comprising Edward Groth, Robert N. Crow and Luigi Criscuolo, that the court has adjourned to July 1 the formal hearing on the reorganization plan called for June 1. The letter asks noteholders to sign forms of consent to the plan.

Miss Janet Van Ranken Stone, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Dwight G. Stone of this place, has chosen June 25 for her marriage to Bertram N. Carvalho Jr. of Philadelphia, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bertram N. Carvalho, also of West Hartford. The ceremony will take place in the Washington Memorial Chapel, Valley Forge, Pa., in the presence of near relatives.
The highest consumption rate for apparel wools for any April since 1923 was reported yesterday for April by the National Association of Wool Manufacturers.

A new home development on the North Shore of Long Island is being started in Roslyn in the vicinity of Willis Avenue and Northern State Parkway by the North Park Realty Corporation, of which James Farnham is president. It will be known as North Park.

Forty-three members of the graduating class of the Fordham University College of Pharmacy heard Dr. George Denton Beal, president of the American Pharmaceutical Association, attack the "cut-rate" pharmacy in the principal address delivered at the twenty-fifth commencement of the college last night in the university gymnasium.

Katharine Cornell, Helen Hayes and Carl Carmer received the honorary degree of Doctor of Letters at the commencement exercises of Elmira College this afternoon. Miss Hayes and Mr. Carmer, who gave the commencement address, received their degrees in person.

Reorders on Summer merchandise continued numerous yesterday, reflecting the active retail trade in most sections of the country last week. The business, however, was largely of the fill-in type, a demand that is now at its peak and may taper off shortly. Dresses, Summer coats, millinery and sports and beach wear were the goods in most active request.

Elmer and Delmer Brown, twin runners from North Texas State Teachers College, were among six contestants slated to perform in the fourth annual Princeton invitation track meet who took their initial workouts on the Palmer Stadium oval today.

Tufts College at commencement today awarded 502 degrees to students in its eight departments and conferred honorary degrees on seven men and one woman. An audience of 3,000, driven indoors by the inclement weather, attended the exercises in the Tufts Gymnasium.
Formation of a new old-age pension plan, to be known as the All-America, Inc., was announced today by R. E. Clements, co-founder with Dr. Francis E. Townsend of the Townsend pension movement.

The failure of attempts to organize the world through force and through "nationbuilding," Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, told international Geneva at a dinner in his honor tonight, has brought mankind to the point where the only path left to the twentieth century world is the application of the federal principle."
Two city subway employes who worked out a way of making the turnstiles register fewer rather than more fares were dismissed yesterday by the Board of Transportation.

A first mortgage of $225,000 for ten years at 5 per cent has been placed on the new store and office structure at the northwest corner of Montgomery Street and Bergen Avenue, Jersey City, N. J., by the A. F. Roe Company, Inc., for the Bergen Center Holding Corporation, A. Glickman, president.

Presentation of a Serfor Torah (Holy Scroll) by Young Israel to Borough President Samuel Levy, Municipal Building, noon. Luncheon of the Lions Club of New York, Hotel Astor, 12:30 P. M. "The Capital Gain and Loss Tax," Controller Morris S. Tremaine.
Outside influences and labor disturbances found reflection in the price movements of commodity futures in the local markets yesterday. In sympathy with other

The seventy-five-year sentence imposed in January, 1936, by the Morgan County Circuit Court on Heyward Patterson, one of the nine Negro defendants in the Scottsboro case, was affirmed today by the Alabama Supreme Court.

After obtaining a proffer from President Roosevelt of the services of taxation experts, the heads of the Joint Congressional Committee announced today that the tax evasion inquiry would get under way Wednesday or Thursday, with Secretary Morgenthau as the first witness.

High Fleet, champion 3-year-old filly of last year who runs in the colors of George D. Widener, came back to the races for the first time this season at Aqueduct yesterday and showed that she has all of her speed. This daughter of Jack High and Armada scored handily in the featured Genie Purse and ran the fastest mile of the meeting, covering the distance in i:372-5.

The Manufacturers Trust Company will observe today the 125th anniversary of the founding of the oldest bank in its "family tree." In connection with the event the bank has prepared a booklet giving the history of the thirty-nine independent banks which, through mergers and absorptions, have gone to make up the present institution.

Miss Louisa Bryan Price. daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Marshall Price of Coconut Grove, was married to Roger Sherman Robinson, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Henry Hollister Robinson of New Haven, Conn., this afternoon in Trinity Episcopal Church by the Rev. G. I. Hiller.
Reaffirmation of the American principle of civil and religious freedom was voiced throughout the nation yesterday by leading Protestant, Catholic and Jewish clergymen.

Mr. and Mrs. Harold Laycock of this city announced today the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Anna Laycock, to H. Lee Scott of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. H. Lee Scott of Dallas, Texas. The wedding will take place at Glen Summit in September.

Hailstones the size of marbles pelted homeward-bound New Yorkers yesterday as a miniature tornado, whirling on a 42-mile-an-hour wind with thunder and lightning and a drenching rain, cut a narrow path across mid-town Manhattan.
Movements of vessels follow; all dates are June 12, unless specified: Port Townsend to Bremerton, June 14; Brooks, Fox. At Boston Yard: Case, Conyngham, Tillman, June 13; Selfridge.

The Kings County- grand jury, which has been investigating the charge by County Judge Franklin Taylor that Brooklyn has the dirtiest streets in the city, handed up a presentment yesterday declaring the morale and efficiency of the Department of Sanitation "are seriously impaired" by intimacy between the officials of the department and the presidents of the employe groups within the department.

Albert Erdman, a lawyer, with offices at 475 Fifth Avenue, died suddenly yesterday of a heart attack at his residence, 23 East Seventy-fourth Street, in his sixtyninth year. His widow is Blanche G. Erdman. Their daughter, Jane Erdman Bergman, died several years ago.
CAPITAL KALEIDOSCOPE, by Frances Parkinson Keyes. (Harper, $3.50.) Reminiscences of a Washington hostess. SERVE IT FORTH, by M. F. K. Foster. (Harpers, $2.50.) A book about food.
Virtual civil war is witnessed today "in certain sections of the country," Dr. Edmund A. Walsh, vice president of Georgetown University, told seniors at Massachusetts State College here today.

With Mrs. William H. Parsons still mysteriously missing from her Long Island farm and no clues as to her whereabouts after five days of investigation, Federal, State and local police yesterday began a systematic search of the eastern end of Long Island.

When Max Schmeling touches German soil Wednesday he will be welcomed as world heavyweight champion, a statement issued by The Association of German Boxers said today. The statement said Schmeling had fulfilled everything that could be asked of a contender for the title.

Probable joint action by the British dominions in subsidizing ocean commerce to meet the competition of the United States and other countries was foreshadowed tonight on the eve of the adjournment of the Imperial Conference in a report made public by the shipping subcommittee.
Coloonel C. O. Sherrill, Cincinnati's first City Manager, received from the City Council today an invitation to return to that position and he immediately commented that he was homesick to do so.

The General Electric Company is the latest entry into the rapidly growing inter-communications field, which in the space of about a year has jumped into the $5,000,000 retail class. The new General Electric set will be called the Handy-Phone, and for the time being, advertising plans are incomplete.

The Securities and Exchange Commission has called a hearing for June 30 on an application by the Granite State Electric Company, Lebanon, N. H., for exemption from the requirements of filing a declaration for the issuance of 3,610 shares of $100 par value capital stock.

Mrs. Henry P. Fletcher, wife of the former Ambassador to Italy and recently chairman of the Republican National Committee, has leased her residence in the Onteora Club community, near Tannersville in the Catskill Mountains, to Peter C. Wright-Clark of this city.

As no word has been received from the patrol boat Larrakia, which reported the detention of the mother ship of a Japanese pearling fleet found Foxx fishing in territorial waters, Dr. Fenton of the Flying Service left Saturday on an aerial search. He located the Larrakia with two Japanese luggers 300 miles off Darwin.

Ten seniors received diplomas and honors were awarded at the commencement exercises of Mount St. Mary's Academy in North Plainfield High School today. The Rev. Thomas U. Reilley, Chancellor of the Trenton Diocese, presided.

Cannon St, 104, 25x100; Sondra Real Estate Corp (Reuben Berman, pres) to Lucien D. Bloch, trustee, Adolphus Ottenberg, 1,016 5th Ave, purchase-money mortgage due May 25, 1947; 4 1/2 years 5 per cent; $22,000. 22d St, 228 W. 20x98.9; Giambatista Sassarini to Domenico Sassarini, 228 W 22d St; prior mortgage $8,000; 3 years 6 per cent; $3,500.

Among university professors it has long been a cherished belief that science should not concern itself with the obviously useful. Hence the polite disdain with which industrial research is still treated. Latterly the professors have begun to wonder.

Bequests aggregating $350,000 were left to public institutions in New York and vicinity by R. Bleecker Rathbone of Red Oak Lane, Harrison, according to papers on file today in the Westchester County Surrogate's office. Mr. Rathbone retired seven years ago from the presidency of the Northern Insurance Company, New York, a concern his father had founded. He died April 22.
A sharp decline in prices abroad, favorable weather over the weekend and weakness in the stock market unsettled prices on the Cotton Exchange here yesterday.

James J. Bambrick, president of Local 32B of the Building Service Employes Union, announced yesterday, that the 53,000 members of the organization would not contribute one cent to the fund being raised by the American Federation of Labor for an organization drive in competition with the C. I. O.
President Roosevelt sent to the Senate today the name of Louis A. Johnson of Clarksburg, W. Va., former national commander of the American Legion, for confirmation as Assistant Secretary of War.

Dr. Frederick B. Robinson, president of City College, announced today the names of seventy graduates and students of the college who will receive medals, scholarships, honors and prizes at the ninetyfirst commencement exercises in Lewisohn Stadium tomorrow evening. The names of other prize winners will be released tomorrow.

A temporary restraint forbidding the scheduled auction sale tomorrow of collateral from the closed ChelseaSecond National Bank, now held by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, was obtained today by depositors of the institution.
Several leases for large quarters on Fifth and Fourth Avenues featured the contracts for commercial space reported by brokers yesterday.
" Freedom is less loved than at any time since the French Revolution," Miss Dorothy Thompson, wife of Sinclair Lewis, told the 138 graduates of St. Lawrence University today.

The Childs Company, large chain restaurant operators, will open a new chain known as '"he Host, Incorporated," in the lower price field, George R. Strohmeyer, president of the company, announced yesterday. The first unit of the new chain will be opened in September at 32 East Twenty-third Street. It is hoped that the new chain will become nation-wide, as is the parent company.

A "voluntary platform" calling for State regulation of maximum hours and minimum wages in retail stores, condemning the sweatshop and child labor and setting forth steps to improve advertising and tc foster better relations with the consumer, the manufacturer and the government, has been unanimously approved by the board of directors of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, it was announced yesterday by Channing E. Sweitzer, managing director.

A letter from General Washington to his nephew, announcing his intention to retire after the signing of a peace treaty with England or the evacuation of New York, sold for [Pound]210 to Dr. Gabriel Wells, a collector, at Sotheby's auction galleries today.

Representative John J. Delaney announced yesterday after an inspection of the Naval Reserve air base at Floyd Bennett Airport that he would introduce a bill in Congress providing for an appropriation of $250,000 to establish a permanent naval air base at the airport.

Almost all the seeded stars saw action in the national clay courts tennis tournament at River Forest Tennis Club today and five of them, including the defending champion, Bobby Riggs of Los Angeles, advanced to the third round by playing two matches.

The twenty-fourth commencement exercises of St. John's School, a private non-sectarian' institution, will be held tomorrow morning at 9:30 o'clock in the Wilson Mmorial Wing. Mrs. Henry B. Wilson, headmistress, will deliver the address and award diplomas.

Dr. Lewis Perry, principal of Phillips Exeter Academy, made the commencement address at Abbot Academy here today. Graduation exercises were held in the South Church, and other events of the day were the tree and ivy planting and commencement luncheon.

Suggested minimum recall prices under the Feld-Crawford Fair Trade Act have been established by two leading radio manufacturers, according to notifications reported by leading retail stores here yesterday. The concerns also set limits on "trade-in" allowances.

Cotton consumed during May was reported by the Census Bureau today to have totaled 669,460 bales of lint and 70,480 of linters, compared with 718,947 and 72,795 during April, this year, and 530,894 and 64,302 during May last year.

A General Sessions jury acquitted the Rev. Robert Lee Hector, 44 years old, pastor of the Spiritualist Church of the Universal Brotherhood, and Edgar Allen, 59, a former theatrical agent, yesterday on the charge of a former patrolman that they had defrauded him of $300 under pretext to have him reinstated to the force.

Mayor La Guardia was accused last night of having made a pledge to Republican leaders in 1933, before he was nominated for Mayor, that he would not lend himself to the building up of another party here, and that he would not support President Roosevelt for re-election, and then of having "directly violated that pledge."

Efforts to form a combination of members of the Tammany executive committee to oust James J. Dooling as leader, which have been in progress during the past week, have failed, it was learned yesterday.

The debt of the forty-eight States continues to climb, showing an increase of 21 per cent from 1931 to 1936, a rate three times greater than that for local borrowings, according to figures published in the June issue of the National Municipal Review.

Dr. Wilfred H. Osgood, chief curator of zoology at the Field Museum of Natural History, returned yesterday on the French liner Normandie after spending four months in Indo-China collecting birds and mammals.

The first bulletins issued on Sir James Barrie today diagnosed his illness as bronchial pneumonia, but noted some improvement in his condition. Lord Horder, a close friend of the 77-year-old playwright, after consultation with two specialists in the morning, acknowledged that his patient's condition was "causing considerable anxiety."

Five fires of suspicious origin, one of which destroyed irreplaceable records and notes compiled by two professors, were discovered yesterday afternoon and evening in the administration building of City College at 137th Street and Convent Avenue.

YOU may have noticed in yesterday's TIMES, down at the bottom of the financial page, an. interesting little wireless dispatch from Berlin. People in German business circles, said this dispatch, were becoming increasingly uneasy over the labor unrest in this country. They could not understand the "apparent indifference of President Roosevelt" to latest

Yorkshire retained first place in the English county cricket championship today, defeating Kent by an innings and 51 runs. In other matches concluded a day ahead of schedule, Worcestershire trounced Northamptonshir by an innings and 141 runs, Gloucestershire downed Essex by eight wickets and Nottinghamshire had a sevenwickets margin over Leicestershire.

The day of great fortunes is rapidly passing away and the goal of men should be to live sensibly and usefully rather than to seek riches, Homer L. Ferguson, industrialist, of Newport News, Va., told 255 graduates at the Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute commencement today.
Queen Wilhelmina, Princess Juliana and Prince Bernhard returned to The Hague today after passing a week at the Amsterdam royal palace.

The marriage of Miss Claire Josephine Lewis, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Lewis of 45 Gramercy Park, to Martin Fuld Ehrenberg, son of Mrs. Sydney P. Ehrenberg, also of New York, and the late Mr. Ehrenberg, took place last night at the Pierre. Dr. John Lovejoy Elliott of the Ethical Culture Society performed the ceremony.

Mrs. Rita A. Hyman of 19 East Eighty-eighth Street, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Abrahams of this city, was married to George Kleinert Guinzburg of New York and Chappaqua, son of Mrs. Victor Guinzburg and the late Mr. Guinzburg, yesterday morning at her home by the Rev. Dr. Jonah B. Wise. The bride dispensed with

Two Manhattan realty organizations yesterday reported additions to their membership rolls. The Real Estate Board of New York listed nine new members and six firms taking additional division memberships. The New York chapter of the National Association of Real Estate Boards announced fifteen new names.

President Roosevelt signed today a bill extending for two years the Connally "Hot Oil" Act. The act bans shipments in interstate commerce of oil produced in excess of quotas fixed by State laws. The two-year extension,

Mr. and Mrs. Frank Bellwood Carland of 137 East Thirty-eighth Street and Warren, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Matilda Carland, to Lieutenant Whiteford Carlisle Mauldin, U.S.A., son of Mrs. Whiteford Carlisle Mauldin of Lockesburg, Ark., and the late Mr. Mauldin.

Only slight changes in factory employment and payrolls in the State were noted from the middle of April to the middle of May, Elmer F. Andrews, Industrial Commissioner reported today. The 2,117 factories reporting to the State Department of Labor showed an increase of 0.1 per cent in employment and 0.1 in payrolls.

The United Artists Distributing Corporation will release thirty-six feature productions, ten of which will be filmed in Technicolor, during the 1937-38 season, it was announced yesterday by George J. Schaefer, vice president and

Jack Donovan, Dartmouth's great hurdling champion, was elected captain of the track team at a meeting of the lettermen today. At the same time the Athletic Council announced varsity letter awards in baseball, track and tennis.
The War Department released the following orders today, dated June 12: LIEUTENANT COLONEL Young, M. J., Engrs., 1 month and 5 days leave, Aug. 5. MAJORS
The Essex County Symphony Society will give the second concert of its series at the stadium in Newark tonight. Percy Grainger will be piano soloist and Erno Rapee conductor.

The uncertainty of the weather today kept the America's Cup sloops that are overboard here at their moorings in Brenton's Cove. Mr. and Mrs. T. O. M. Sopwith and the members of their party spent most of the day ashore, returning to Viva II late in the day after a round of tennis at the Casino.

The dwelling containing eight rooms and two baths at 110 Pelham Avenue, in Pelham, Westchester County, has been purchased by Robert L. Bosworth through the firm of Chauncey B. Griffen. The latter also sold in Pelham the house at 16 Mitchell Place for the Bowery Savings Bank to a client for occupancy.

After hearings which started two years ago and which included court actions by several railroads to enjoin the Interstate Commerce Commission from issuing the order, the commission today ruled that all steam locomotives built after Sept. 1 must be equipped with power-operated reverse gear.
William L. Foley of Tuckahoe, organizer of boys' centers in West chester County, died at the Lawrence Hospital, Bronxville, Saturday night. He was 35 years old.

Because of strong opposition by both Arabs and Jews, the plan to partition Palestine has been definitely abandoned, according to Emir Abdullah ibn Hussein of Trans-Jordan, who has just returned from London, where he was in close touch with authorities on the Palestine problem.
Following is the text of the adverse report of the Senate's Committee on the Judiciary on the proposal to reorganize the Federal judiciary:

The joint Congressional committee to investigate income tax evasions organized today and heard from Senator Harrison an assertion that President Roosevelt's recent message on the subject already had been responsible for collections of taxes previously avoided.
The administration's legislative farm program was abandoned for this session after a conference today between Secretary Wallace and several members of the Senate Agriculture Committee.

Business in the local foreign exchange market was at almost a standstill yesterday as world markets awaited the outcome of the French Government's efforts to strengthen its financial structure and halt the flight of gold.

Although selling pressure was lifted from most sections of the corporate bond list yesterday, the market exhibited little, if any, tendency to rally from the low levels reached on the preceding day. Except for moderate recoveries among the convertible and more sensitive loans, price movements throughout the list were narrow and the price averages of the various corporate groups showed little net change on the day.

The Salvation Army's tribulations as foster mother of the Basque refugee children in England became acute today when at the early morning roll-call it was found that fifty were missing from Congress Hall, Clapton, North London, where 400 were in quarantine following the discovery of a case of typhoid.

Kid Chocolate, 126 1/2, former featherweight champion of the world, pounded out an eight-round victory over Young Chappie, 132 1/2, Albany, N. Y., in a bout that featured the inaugural show at the Canarsie Stadium last night.

Derbyshire, county cricket champion last season, defeated Sussex today by 281 runs, the first real jolt the southern county has suffered this Summer. The loser takes second place in the championship table behind the strong Yorkshire eleven, while Derbyshire retains third place.

Huge sections of several of the enormous marble pillars inside St. Peter's, the world's largest cathedral, crashed to the pavement today. The falling blocks of marble did not endanger tourists. But Cardinal Pacelli, the Vatican Secretary of State, and Mgr. Luigi Pellizzo, secretary of the cathedral building committee, took immediate steps to insure the safety of visitors.
Eighty-eight students will receive degrees tomorrow morning at the annual commencement exercises of Adelphi College here. Dr. Paul Dawson Eddy, president-elect of the college, will be the speaker.

A picture of confusion was brought tonight from Bilbao, Spain, by Jean Casteran, the French consul there, who arrived here on the French dispatch vessel Audacieuse. He had left Bilbao on the orders of the French Government.

Income tax receipts in the Third Internal Revenue District, Manhattan, from June 1 to June 15, totaled $31,035,499, or about $12,000,000 more than those for the entire month of June last year, it was revealed yesterday.

The 37-year-old Waite Hoyt essayed a second comeback as a Dodger today and pitched well enough to win but the decision went to the 22year-old Johnny Vander Meer when the Reds barely skimmed out of a ninth-inning jam to win, 4--3.

AT ALL, trim chap, he was. Light brown hair, clean-cut features, cool gray suit, gray-green tie, tan shoes and a friendly way about him. That was Denis Victor Shore of Johannesburg, South Africa, as he popped by on his way to Princeton, where he is going to run a quarter-mile in the Princeton invitation track meet this Saturday.

Ed Wynn, comedian, who was divorced by his wife a month ago in Reno, Nev., was married yesterday in the chapel of the Marriage License Bureau in the Municipal Building to Miss Frieda Mierse of 277 Park Avenue. The ceremony was performed by Deputy City Clerk Philip E. Hines, long a friend of Mr. Wynn.

Announcement has been made by Mrs. William Greenwood Bearman of First Cliff, this place, of the engagement of her daughter, Miss Anna Neilson Bearman, to Joseph Keen Rulon, son of Mr. and Mrs. Watson Birdsall Rulon of Philadelphia.

Of total advertising expenditures in 1936 by 394 companies who spent at least $50,000 each in newspapers, 58.7 per cent went to newspapers, according to a study released yesterday by the Bureau of Advertising, American Newspaper Publishers Association.

Dr. Herbert F. Harms of Pearl River, N. Y., veterinarian of the Orangeburg Kennel Club's greyhound racing track and active in Rockland County politics at various times for the Democratic as well as the Republican party, was indicted by the Federal grand jury yesterday with Edward Straub, former cashier of the Nanuet National Bank, for alleged misapplication of the bank's funds and conspiracy.

Registrations of out-of town buyers in the market during the week ended yesterday numbered well below the preceding week but were only slightly under the corresponding week a year ago, according to the lists published in THE TIMES.

Both fighting for their lives in "iron lung" respirators against infantile paralysis, a Winnipeg girl of 22 and a young American of 26 are corresponding. They are Miss Inez Woollam, in a respirator here, and Fred Snite, en route in a respirator from Peiping to his home in Chicago.

Regardless of the measures to be adopted by the French Government to repair its financial structure and halt the speculative raids on the troubled franc, bankers in Wall Street feel certain that the present crisis will bring about some modification of the tri-partite monetary agreement.

Col. C. O. Sherrill, president of the American Retail Federation, accepted today an appointment as city manager of Cincinnati, a post he held once before. He will succeed C. A. Dykstra, who resigned to become president of the University of Wisconsin.

Health Commissioner John L. Rice will address the graduating class of the Cornell University Medical College at the thirty-ninth commencement exercises this afternoon in the auditorium, 1,300 York Avenue.

Charged with manslaughter in connection with the fatal shooting of Mrs. Dorothy Carlucci as she emerged from a motion-picture theatre in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, on Sunday night, Lawrence Collette Million, 18-year-old grocery store clerk, of 6,809 Third Avenue, Brooklyn, was held in $10,000 bail for furtheir hearing next Tuesday

Gas and electric rate reductions representing savings of nearly $20,000 annually for consumers in five counties in New York and an "indeterminate amount in a sixth had the approval today of the Public Service Commission.

The Rev. Gerhard Jacobi, pastor of the Kaiser Wilhelm Memorial Church, was placed under arrest today and charged with "incitement to disobedience of law" in the Nazi controversy with the German Protestant Church.

In a stormy meeting of the International Seamen's Union last night, David E. Grange, president of the Marine Cooks and Stewards Union and for thirty years a vice president of the I. S. U., tendered his resignation to both posts and left

A general price advance of 8 to 10 per cent on Fall rugs and carpets was foreshadowed here yesterday by the announcement of the Charles P. Cochrane Company, Philadelphia, that quotations on all lines, except contract goods, will be advanced to that extent on July 19.

Milk dealers are meeting behind closed doors scheming to get their milk cheaply, Senator Rhoda Fox Graves declared today in addressing the New York State Milk Committee. The price of milk continues to be controlled by the dealers, she told 125 independent dairymen from various parts of the State.

Twenty-five East Side youngsters comprising the Junior City Government were slightly abashed at City Hall yesterday when one of their number identified Special Rackets Prosecutor Thomas E. Dewey as the District Attorney of New York County.

George W. Burpee of the New York engineering concern of Coverdale Colpitts testified before Judge Phillip Forman in the United States District Court here today that transportation properties of the Central Railroad of New Jersey in this State were worth, in his opinion, nearly $30,000,000 less than the valuation set by New Jersey for taxing purposes.

The Parker defense caused a surprise in the Federal Court here today by resting its case without calling as a witness Ellis H. Parker Jr., who was accused by government witnesses of having personally supervised the alleged kidnapping and torture of Paul H. Wendel in February, 1936.

The "father" of the National Retail Credit Association predicted today the future will bring smaller retail profits and shorter credit terms. Addressing the twenty-fifth annual convention of the organization which he headed at its inception here in 1912,

Miss Ellen Wait Lord, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederic Wait Lord, was married to Robert Gordon Pierce, son of Mr. and Mrs. H. Gordon Pierce of this city, yesterday afternoon in the chapel of St. George's Church, Stuyvesant Square.

Imperial Conference, as its closing act today, said it was the unanimous opinion of the heads of the governments of the British Commonwealth that the League of Nations Covenant should be divorced from peace treaties.
Tommy Farr, British Empire heavyweight champion, knocked out Walter Neusel of Germany in the third round of their twelve-round bout at Harringay Stadium tonight.

President Roosevelt today presented the Henry L. Doherty Prize medal in the eighth annual Gorgas Essay Contest to William Lord Drake Jr. of Milwaukee, one of nearly 20,000 high school students competing throughout the country.

Bowery, 266, 16.6x98.9; Gold Electric Sign Co. Alex Gold, pres, to Pioneer Exchange Corp, 156 Montague St, Brooklyn; prior mtg, $10,000; 1 year, 6 per cent. .$2,612.50 Christopher St, 107-109, 44.9x91.6; Matteo Perrotty to Montgomery Properties, Inc, 565 5th Ave: prior mtg, $39,500; due April 14, 1938;

H. W. Warley, president of the New York Maritime Association, opposed today legislation to put water carriers under the Interstate Commerce Commission. Testifying before the House Merchant Marine Committee, he said that shipping was adequately regulated by the Maritime Commission.
Behind the conference of Danish, Finnish, Norwegian and Swedish Government delegates in Copenhagen over the last week-end is seen a movement for Scandinavian cooperation in the event of war.
Frank E. Gannett, president of the National Committee to Uphold Constitutional Government, expressed satisfaction over the Senate Judiciary Committee report on the court bill.

The motion picture status of "Room Service" grows daily more confusing. It seems now that Warners didn't buy the rights after all, that RKO came along from behind and picked them up for a sum reported to be $255,000 or more. According to the stories going around Broadway, Warners was prepared to pay $250,000, and that sum would have been agreeable to George Abbott.

Mrs. Audrey McMahon, regional director of the WPA Federal Art Project for New York and New Jersey, outlined plans for the Flushing Art Center, which will open next month, at a luncheon yesterday at the Town Hall Club to members of the new citizens' committee.

With strike pickets growing uglier as non-union men continued to work in the Bethlehem Steel plant here, and with citizen groups threatening "vigilante" action to restore order in the city, Governor Earle from Harrisburg today put State Police in charge of the picket lines and obtained assurances from union leaders that they would try to restrain the strikers from further violence.
The 1939 world bridge championships were awarded to the United States tonight at a meeting of the superior councils of the International Bridge League for Europe.

In a letter to shareholders, the management of the Wheeling Steel Corporation has announced a recapitalization plan that is intended to wipe out $9,157,128 of accumulated dividends on the 6 per cent cumulative preferred stock. There are now 381,547 shares of this issue and 388,091 shares of common stock outstanding.

John P. McCormick, secretary for the last eight years to Municipal Court Justice Murray Hearn, was elected a member of the Board of Aldermen yesterday to succeed Joseph Whitty of Brooklyn, who resigned to become chief clerk of the Appellate Term of the Supreme Court.
The 1937 Pulitzer Prize for epigram, backhand style, is already won. The lucky man is Emir ABDULLAH of Trans-Jordan.

Abandonment of any policies that "unnecessarily restrict the freedom of sound business relations, especially in view of the largely comelementary nature of American and Japanese trade" was recommended by a subcommittee of the Japanese Economic Mission,
After twenty hours of crisis, constant surprises and ever-changing situations, Premier Leon Blum's Popular Front majority in the Chamber of Deputies emerged almost intact near 6 o'clock this morning.

At the moment when France is in the throes of a Cabinet crisis and when Russia is temporarily paralyzed by her own internal troubles, it was announced tonight that Baron Constantin von Neurath, the German Foreign Minister, would pay an official visit to London on Wednesday of next week.

Working without his usual catcher, Earle Brucker, who split a finger in the eighth, George Caster, the Athletics' knuckleball pitcher, stumbled in the ninth today and the Browns scored four runs to win, 5 to 1.
Mr. and Mrs. C. Lyston Jones of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Doris Lyston Jones, to Robert Clark Rogers, son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Williams Rogers of Baltimore.

Forty-one members of the 1937 graduating class of City College were admitted to the Gamma Chapter of Phi Beta Kappa, the national honorary scholastic fraternity, at a meeting last night in the building of the Society for Ethical Culture, 2 West Sixty-fourth Street. Dr.Jesse G. M. Bullowa, '99, was elected to the fraternity as an alumnus member.

Testimony that the Long Island Lighting Company paid E. L. PhilUps ,'Co. about 40 per cent more to lay gas pipes than it would have cost it to use its own force was presented yesterday to Supreme Court Justice Aaron J. Levy in the trial of a stockholder's action to recover about $20,000,000 alleged to have been wasted by officers and directors of the power company.

President Roosevelt said today that if sugar lobbyists would leave Washington, he felt that Congress would pass at this session legislation to extend the provisions of the Costigan-Jones bill after next January.

Retired Lieutenant Mortimer x. Sullivan, formerly a member of H. L. 41, residing at 187-14 Linden Blvd., St. Albans, Queens, died June 11. Retired Fireman Bartholomew P. Sheridan, formerly a member of Engine 61, residing at 4 West St., Goshen, N. Y., died June 3. Retired Fireman William J. Harrigan, formerly a member of H. L. 28, residing at 342 E. 140th St.. Bronx, died June 11.
Baroness Dorothy Knight de Sibert has sued in Carson City to divorce Baron de Sibert of Paris on grounds of extreme cruelty.

Business failures were lower in both the manufacturing and retail groups in the week ended June 10 in comparison with the corresponding period last year, while the wholesale division showed no change, aocording to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.
Premier Milan Hodza of Czechoslovakia arrived here today from Prague for an official visit to the Rumanian capital. Crowds cheered him at all the railway stations from the frontier to the capital.

The wedding of Miss Natalie Ryan, youngest daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Barry Ryan of New York, to Thomas Ludlow Clarke, son of Mrs. Thomas Ludlow Clarke and the late Mr. Clarke, took place this afternoon in the drawing room at the Old Place,

Esquire Coronet, Inc., Chicago, has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering 150,000 shares of $1 par value capital stock for the account of certain stockholders, 75,000 shares of which are to be offered through underwriters and 75,000 optioned to underwriters for resale.

A. G. K. Brown, Cambridge University track star and Britain's outstanding runner in the Olympics last Summer in Berlin, will captain the joint Oxford-Cambridge team, which will leave soon to compete in America and Canada.

Dr. Mitchell P. Warmuth, an X-ray specialist who was chief surgeon to the Eastern Penitentiary, died at his home here today at the age of 66. He received a skull fracture and other injuries in an automobile accident two months ago.
About 250 teachers and students picketed a meeting of the Board of Higher Education, held last night in the City College School of Business, Twenty-third Street and Lexington Avenue.

Net profit of the South American Gold and Platinum Company and subsidiaries in the first quarter of 1937 amounted to $217,416 after depreciation, depletion, United States and Colombian income taxes, minority interest and other charges. This is equal to 12 cents each on 1,760,000 shares of $1-par capital stock and compares with $153,096, or 8 cents a share, earned in the March quarter of 1936.

Soviet agents entered the building housing the United States Embassy offices and staff quarters in the center of Moscow late last Friday night and spent considerable time in the apartment of a Russian Who had been living there.

For more than a year, with extraordinary skill, M. LEON BLUM has performed a feat of political legerdemain which entitles him to first prize in the art of government. The dilemma of the French New Deal is entirely different from that of the American.

Administration forces overwhelmed the strict-economy group in the first round of Senate debate on the Relief Appropriation Bill today, voting down amendments designed to restrict or curtail funds for the works program for the year beginning July 1.

When Justice James T. Hallinan declared a recess this afternoon until tomorrow morning eleven jurors had been selected in the Suffolk County Supreme Court here for the trial of Mrs. Helen Tiernan of Manhattan for the murder of her 7-year-old daughter, Helen, in the woods at Brookhaven, on May 15.

Organized business men of this city pledged full support yesterday to the Citizens Committee on the Control of Crime in New York, Harry F. Guggenheim, president, in its drive against racketeering. In a letter to Mr. Guggenheim, Louis K. Comstock, president of the Merchants Association of New York, pointed out that the practical way to meet organized crime was by "counter-organization."

Another sign that the big-game fishermen annually awaits-the taking of the first swordfish at Montauk. It happened on Saturday, when a 200-pounder was harpooned by Ed and Willie Parsons of Montauk, fishing from the Comanche II.

Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., headed the group that won yesterday the award of $60,000,000 of Commonwealth of Pennsylvania 11/22 per cent, Series C, tax-anticipation notes. They offered 100.3862 for the notes, dated June 1, 1937, and maturing on May 31, 1938.

With all the talk of a crippled pitching staff causing no end of worry for Manager Joe McCarthy in particular and Yankee followers in general, it was encouraging to all concerned that Charley (Red) Ruffing yesterday launched the home stand at the Stadium with a great performance on the mound.

In an eleventh-hour move, aimed to bolster the Giants' waning batting strength, Manager Bill Terry tonight acquired Wally Berger, longdistance hitting outfielder of the Bees. In exchange the New York club gave up Frank Gabler, young right-handed pitcher, and cash.

The ninety-second commencement exercises of Fordham University will end this afternoon when degrees will be awarded on the campus to 673 graduates of Fordham College; Fordham College, Manhattan Division; the School of Business Administration; Graduate School; Teachers College and the School of Social Service.

Charges of unfair labor practices against Louis Hornick Co., Inc., 22 West Twenty-first Street, New York City, were upheld today by the National Labor Relations Board today, which ordered the company to reinstate workers who struck Dec. 10, 1935, and who have not since received regular and substantially equivalent employment elsewhere.

In sympathy with a recovery in the outside markets, prices on the Cotton Exchange rallied $1 a bale at one time yesterday to end unchanged to 4 points higher than on Monday. Scattered showers where dry weather is needed and with more rain predicted, stimulated short covering and lifted the October above 12 cents a pound in the last hour.

The marriage of Miss Dorothy Holton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George C. Holton of this place, to Charles A. Brooks, son of Mrs. Charles A. Brooks of Richmond, Va., and the late Mr. Brooks, took place this afternoon in the garden of the Holton home.

Amelia Earhart stepped out of her flying laboratory on a fourth continent tonight in her flight around the middle of the world. She landed here at 7:05 P. M. (10:05 A. M. Eastern daylight time) after a 1,400-mile hop from Assab, Eritrea, across the Red Sea, the wide Arabian Desert and a part of the Arabian Sea.

Hope for the safety of the 110-foot motor ship Maloa with nine persons aboard has been abandoned here. The craft, bound from Tampa for Belize, British Honduras, gave a position report by radio on June 4 and has not been heard from since. A search by the Coast Guard was fruitless.

Purchasing executives are getting steel deliveries without difficulty at present and anticipate no trouble in shipments unless current strikes extend over a period of sixty days or more, according to comment offered here yesterday.
Mrs. Lucile Robinson Mann of Milwaukee, a title-winner a few years ago, ousted the defending champion, Mrs. Opal Hill of Kansas City, from the women's Western open golf championship today.
Ambrose Swasey of Cleveland, noted as a manufacturer of telescopes and turret lathes, died tonight at his Summer home here. He was 90 years old.

Brazil will re-enter tomorrow the de factor constitutional regime that she suspended in December, 1935. President Getulio Vargas will notify Congress that the state of war, a kind of modified martial law, has ceased.

Mrs. Champ Clark, widow of the former Speaker of the House of Representatives and mother of United States Senator Bennett Clark of Missouri, died this morning at the home here of her son-in-law and daughter, Colonel and Mrs. James M. Thomson.

Major Gen. Adelbert Cronkhite, U. S. A.,retired, died at a hospital here today after an illness of a week. He was 76 years old. Funeral services will be held Saturday at West Point, N. Y., where the retired officer will be buried.

Reuben H. Gulvin, former Mayor of Geneva and a former Sheriff of Ontario County, was found dead today in his car at Clark's Point. Dr. Frank H. Snyder, coroner, said he believed death was due to a heart condition and announced he would conduct an autopsy.

Nine seniors will be graduated from St. Bernard's School, an Episcopal institution of the diocese of New Jersey, at commencement exercises tomorrow afternoon at 4 o'clock in the school gymnasium. Walter H.

The first illustrated edition of 210-year-old "The Beggar's Opera" is being distributed to the members of the Limited Editions Club this month. The illustrations are by the Parisian artist, Mariette Lydis; they are lithographs printed by hand.

The Senate Judiciary Committee's report condemning President Roosevelt's bill to reorganize the courts was praised in a resolution unanimously adopted by the General Society of the Sons of the Revolution yesterday as "one of the outstanding state papers of America."

Automobile manufacturers denied today they were considering a general shutdown until peace was definitely restored among their workers. but declined to discuss the possibility of a refusal of United Automobile Workers members to work with steel purchased from plants now strike-bound.

General Jose Miaja, defense chief and Civil Governor, ordered today a drive against food profiteers and those who illegally hold food cards for rations. Thirty-three thousand illegally held cards were confiscated.

President and Mrs. Harold Willis Dodds heads the list of patrons and patronesses for Princeton University's annual senior promenade, which will climax the Spring social activities next Monday evening in the university gymnasium.

With extremist leaders who conducted the recent unsuccessful London bus strike barred from negotiations, the executive council of the Transport and General Workers Union today signed a new wage agreement providing some improvements in the busmen's working conditions.

Mayor La Guardia's dispute with Park Commissioner Robert Moses over the withdrawal of 2,000 WPA workers from the city parks. came to an end yesterday when the Mayor signed an Aldermanic resolution providing $587,054 in special revenue bonds to finance park and playground maintenance from July 1 to the end of the year.

Frederic G. Donner, assistant treasurer of the General Motors Corporation, was appointed general assistant treasurer yesterday. After his graduation from the University of Michigan in 1923 Mr. Donner joined the firm of Reckitt, Benington LeClear, public accountants, of Chicago.

Relations between Germany and Poland, normalized by the ten-year non-aggression pact concluded in 1934, will undergo one of their severest tests after July 14, the expiration date of the German-Polish convention signed at Geneva in 1922 to provide a special regime in Upper Silesia.

White Horse Eagle, Osage Indian, who said he was 115 years old, died at his home here yesterday. Chief White Horse lived here in 1927 and cast his first New York vote that Fall, supporting the entire Democratic ticket.

The Bears recovered their batting eyes tonight and drilled out fifteen hits while trouncing Toronto, 13 to 7. Eight runs in the opening frame on four walks and five blows, climaxed by Joe Gordon's tenth home run of the season with two mates aboard, sewed up the contest.

Twelve balloons representing five countries will take off here June 20 in the race for the fifth Gordon Bennett Cup. The Belgian Royal Aero Club received notice from William Eynhart, secretary of the contest board of the National Aeronautic Association at Washington, D. C.,

Russell J. Byington, an officer of several of the Henry L. Doherty subsidiaries, at a hearing before Special Master J. Rhodes O'Reilly yesterday corrected a misstatement which he acknowledged having made at a prior hearing. The hearings are being conducted to ascertain the votes cast by Henry L. Doherty, president, in the settlement of a stockholders' suit against his company, the Cities Service Company.

The Treasury reported today that its net market purchases of Federal securities for government investment 'accounts in May totaled $3,853,550. These accounts include Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation reserve funds and the government life insurance fund.
The Congregation of the Holy Office today instructed Bishops over the world to correct abuses in the forms of Catholic worship and to stop the development of such abuses in the future.

Colonel and Mrs. Edward B. Clark were honored today by the French Government with the Cross of the Legion of Honor for their World War service to France. The ceremony took place at the French Embassy.

With the annual Spring tournament at the Meadow Brook Club scheduled to get under ..-ay on Saturday, polo activity on Long Island reached a high point today, fortyfour players taking part in matches on the various fields in this sector.
The excoriating document signed by a majority of the Senate Judiciary Committee, composed of seven Democrats and three Republicans, was specifically addressed to the President's Federal Courts Bill.

The broad outline of a new administration policy for coordination of all Federal benefit programs with a view to raising the national income so that all forms of relief ultimately will be abolished was revealed by President Roosevelt at his press conference today. The plan, the President said, is still in the study stage and not ready to be brought definitely before the public.

Movements of livestock on the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts, 17,000, including 4,500 direct; market mostly 15c-25c lower than yesterday's average; packing sows fully 25c lower; top $11.40; most late sales on good and choice 200-300 pounds, $11.25 down to $11; 150-190 pounds, $10.25-$11.25; most 350-450 pound sows, $9.75-$10.25; bigweight sows down to $9 or under.

The government issued today a decree imposing a 5 per cent tax on sales of jewelry, domestic as well as imported. The tax applies also to watches of gold, silver or platinum. It affects only retail sales.

Newman St (14-3476), e s, 200 ft n of 150th St, 50x125; Maria A. Di Renna to Clementina Corbo, 52-30 62d St., Maspeth, L. I. Fteley Ave (15-3891), w s, 91 ft s of 177th St, 125x100; Herbert Shapiro to Max D. Diamond, 28 Neptune Ave, Woodmere, L. I. 172d St (11-2832). s w cor of Sheridan Ave, 122x191; Elliott Building Corp to 1,475 Sheridan Realty Corp, 1,475 Sheridan Ave; mtg, $377.000.

The Rivoli, which has been closed since Sunday night, will reopen tonight at 7:30 for the world premiere of Twentieth Century Fox's "Slave Ship," a drama of the days of the slave trade from Africa to the South, directed by Tay Garnett. Chief among the players are Warner Baxter, Wallace Beery, Elizabeth Allan, Mickey Rooney, Joseph Schildkraut, George Sanders and Jane Darwell.

A committee representing Mutual Life Insurance companies which own securities of the Denver Rio Grande Western Railroad submitted today to the Interstate Commerce Commission a plan for reorganization of the road. A reorganization proceeding is now before the commission.

Dr. Frederick Fuller Russell of Boston was elected yesterday a member of the board of managers of Memorial Hospital for the Treatment of Cancer and Allied Diseases, 2 West 106th Street. He succeeded Dr. Robert B. Greenough, who, at the time of his death,

The American public is in the mood for good times and harmony and it is time to cut out all wrangling and get down to business, Colby M. Chester, chairman of the National Association of Manufacturers and chairman of the board of the General Foods Corporation, told the Boston Chamber of Commerce today.

The Republic Steel Corporation went into the United States District Court here today and asked for a mandamus writ to compel Postmaster General Farley to order postoffices in Warren and Niles, Ohio, to deliver to people in its struck plants "all matter properly mailable."

The conference of Spanish diplomats that was to have commenced today was postponed until tomorrow at the last minute, because several of the Ambassadors were unable to reach here on time. The last of them are due tomorrow.

The first session of the tenth annual championship of the Intercollegiate Yacht Racing Association, being held on Long Island Sound under the auspices of the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club, ended tonight without any progress having been made toward the title, for which six colleges are contending with twelve crews.

Skipping all reference to the report of the Senate Judiciary Committee, a trio of Democratic women from New York State registered the hit of the program before a ten-State gathering of women of their party here today with an analysis of President Roosevelt's plan for reorganizing the Federal judiciary.

Bids ranging from a few mills a dead weight ton to $1.50 were opened today by the Maritime Commission for the charter of six governmentowned steamship lines for one year. The lines operate thirty-seven vessels, totaling about 310,000 tons.
Births in the city this year increased and maternity deaths are fewer than recorded last year, according to statistics released yesterday by Dr. John L. Rice, Commissioner of Health.

Paced by Don Budge, American representatives in the Queens Club tennis tournament fared well today, losing only two members in the advance to the third round of the singles and in the opening doubles tests.

Mr. and Mrs. Francis H. Bigelow of this city and Worcester, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Nancy Ames Bigelow, to Raymond Russell Camp, son of Mr. and Mrs. Oliver Southwick Camp of Spring Lake, N. J.

An amended plan of reorganization of the Panhandle Producing and Refining Company was filed yesterday in Federal Court in Delaware, it was announced here. A hearing has been set for July 19 in Wilmington.

The stock market here, reflecting yesterday's weakness in Wall Street and the unsettled financial situation in France, suffered an all around setback today. Although there was no great selling in evidence, buying power was almost entirely absent.

The strike of more than 8,000 shipyard and ship-repair workers in the New York-New Jersey area was extended yesterday to a dozen small repair shops in Staten Island and Hoboken, employing several hundred men,

Miss Lola Jane Maloney, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Elwood L. Maloney of this place, was married this evening to Theodore Bradley Pugh, son of Mr. and Mrs. Nevitt J. Pugh of Beckley, W. Va., in Prospect Presbyterian Church here by the Rev. Dr. Arthur Nelson Butz, the pastor.

An offering of $35,000,000 of 23/4 per cent debentures, due in 1942, of the Commercial Credit Company at 997/8 to yield 2.777 per cent will be made today by a group of fortythree houses headed by Kidder, Peabody Co. and the First Boston Corporation.
Harry Bennett, personnel director of the Ford Motor Company, said today that the Ford Brotherhood of America, Inc., an independent association of Ford employes, had agreed to disband.
The estate of Mr. and Mrs. H. Edward Manville was opened here this afternoon for a garden party under the auspices of the International Garden Club.

Appointment of Nathan R. Sobel as assistant counsel to the Governor was announced today by Governor Lehmen. Mr. Sobel for five years has been counsel to Irwin Steingut, minority leader of the Assembly. He is a graduate of the Brooklyn Law School, class of '27, and has engaged in private practice for the past ten years. The salary is $5,000.

William Haley has purchased a vacant plot on the southeast corner of Sixty-second Drive and Ninetysixth Street, Rego Park, Queens. The Hajada Realty Corporation was the seller. The property has frontages of 72 feet on Sixty-second Drive and 92 feet on Ninety-sixth Street.

Officials of the Treasury and the Federal Reserve met Secretary Morgenthau today. It was assumed that they discussed possible effects of financial developments in France upon the policies of this country, but information on the session was withheld.
An active demand for industrial properties was indicated by the Brooklyn realty deals reported by brokers yesterday. Included in the transactions were two involving large industrial space.
Scoring repeatedly with hard rights to the body, Petey Scalzo, 122 3/4, of the West Side, outpointed

The Treasury today announced the allotment by Federal Reserve districts of subscriptions received on the offering of $800,000,000 of intermediate term notes made on June 7. Subscriptions received amounted to slightly more than six times the total asked and $852,754,300 were accepted.

John A. Brown, director, president and chairman of the executive committee of the Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, Inc., last year received $120,000 for his services, according to a report by the company to the Securities and Exchange Commission which the New York Stock Exchange made public yesterday.

El Universo; one of the principal newspapers of the Guayquil, has been closed by the government and its director and subdirector. have been jailed, according to reports in Ecuadorian newspapers received here.

Freight claims paid in 1936 by Canadian and United States railroads increased 16.6 per cent over the previous year, according to a report presented today by the committee on prevention of loss and damage to the forty-sixth annual convention of the Freight Claim Division of the Association of American Railroads.
Miss Mary Gill of New York, daughter of John Gill of Montreal, Que., and the late Mrs. Gill, was married at noon here today to Noel Fairchild Busch of New York, an associate editor of Time magazine.

The American Institute of Architects, through Walter R. McCornack, chairman of its committee on housing, has appealed to its sixtyeight chapters to support the Wagner-Steagall Housing Bill as "essential to the continuation of the government's efforts to provide adequate shelter to a larger proportion of the American people."

Arrival of the British flying boat Cavalier of Imperial Airways at Port Washington, L. I., this afternoon will mark the first commercial airplane operation of a foreign airline into the United States. The Cavalier, taking off from Bermuda at 10 A. M. with sixteen passengers, under command of Captain

Realizing that the chief problems before Japan are economic and realizing also that increased taxation or a substantial reduction in the fighting services' requirements are impracticable, the Cabinet announced today its intention to embark on a five-year plan for the expansion of Japan's productive power.

Miss Norma F. Shapiro, a member of the graduating class of Fordham University School of Law, won four of the five prizes at the commencement exercises of the school, held yesterday afternoon in the university gymnasium on the Bronx campus.

Initial steps toward standardization of sizes in infants' and children's apparel in cooperation with manufacturers were taken yesterday by the newly organized infants' and children's wear buyers' group of the merchandising division of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, meeting at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

The National Republican Club at a meeting last night adopted a report of its National Affairs Committee, condemning the Roosevelt administration's gold-purchase policy, which was declared to have benefited foreign countries at the expense of the United States.

Reflecting a further decline on the London Metal Exchange, copper quotations abroad yesterday dropped to 13.45 cents a pound, c. i. f., European base ports, the lowest level for the current movement. The price was virtually nominal since buyers expect a further decline and producers refused to lower their quotations. On Monday the foreign price was 13.65 cents.

Mr. and Mrs. Hellmuth Gutmann of South Orange have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Alice King Gutmann, to Norman Kirkness Hackland, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Norman Hackland, also of South Orange.

Miss Hope Knowles of Philadelphia, the defending champion, advanced to the quarter-finals in the Middle States girls' tennis championship today, beating Miss Barbara Newhall of Philadelphia, 6--1, 6--0.

Harry J. Taylor, twelve rooms, in 817 Fifth Ave; John Lowry Roe Jr., through Brett Wyckoff, Inc., in 10 E. 85th St; Herman Agar, in 440 W. 34th St; Albert B. Ashforth, Inc., broker. Juan T. Trippe, seventeen rooms, in 117 E. 72d St; Mrs. Lionel Stahl. through Tishman Realty and Construction Corp., in 1,125 Park Ave; Mrs. Charles N. Edge, in 1,200 Fifth Ave; Douglas ,. Elliman Co., Inc., broker.
For purposes avowedly most pacific, more than 1,500 young Seattle truck drivers, chauffeurs and other members of the Teamsters' Brotherhood will take lessons in boxing, wrestling and jujitsu.

Buffalo got the jump on Jersey City today in the opening game of a three-game series when Bill Harris, veteran right-hander, turned the Jersey Giants back with six hits to give the Bisons a 5-to-1 victory.

Mrs. Madeline Brandeis, 39, a New York writer, and her 16-year-old daughter Marie were seriously injured today when their automobile overturned near here. Mrs. Brandeis, author of a series of children's books, was brought to a hospital suffering from concussion of the brain.

The Securities and Exchange Commission has called a hearing for July 6 on a declaration by the Middle West Utilities Company of Canada, Ltd., of Sault Ste. Marie, Ont., a subsidiary of the Middle West Corporation, covering the reduction of its paid-up share capital in the amount of $3,600,000.

The traditional red-coated Royal Canadian Mounted Police, viewed by social credit legislators of this province as a "semi-military" force, are not wanted and will be replaced by a provincial force just as soon as the present agreement with the federal government can be terminated, it has been decided.

BENJAMIN, MABEL HOLMES (Nov. 13, 1935). Gross assets, $28,574; net, $25,539. To William H. Holmes, brother, specific property and residuary estate; six bequests of personalty. Chief assets, mortgages, notes, cash and insurance, $21,789. Duer, Strong Whitehead, attorneys, 15 Broad St.
Fifty-nine senior cadets at the Bordentown Military Institute received diplomas here today, as the colorful four-day commencement period was brought to a close.

The Seabury Memorial Home for aged women at Mount Vernon, N. Y., will receive about $422,391 from the estate of Albert Hill Seabury upon the death of J. Alton Newman, a friend, according to a transfer tax appraisal filed yesterday. Mr. Seabury, who died Oct. 22, 1936, made the home his principal legatee.

John Frank Stevens, civil engineer, and Vladimir Karapetoff, electrical engineer, will receive honorary degrees tonight at the commencement exercises of Brooklyn Polytechnic Institute, to be held in the Brooklyn Academy of Music. Mr. Stevens will receive the degree

The marriage of Miss Marian L. Burgen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David H. Burgen of Brooklyn and Ramsey, N. J., to Matthew J. Schiebel, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. William Schiebel, will take place on July 1.

Mrs. Clara Hawkins Barnhart, who, with the late Miss Annie Milne, opposed the destruction of their old home. the Sprague Mansion, to make way for the new Brooklyn Bridge Plaza, died on Monday at her home, 99 Pineapple Street, Brooklyn, in her ninety-sixth year.

Harrison Prescott Eddy, Boston engineer, who was in Montreal to attend the semi-centennial meeting of the Engineering Institute of Canada, died in a hotel here from a heart ailment today, five hours before he was to be awarded an honorary membership in the institute. His age was 67.

Board of Trade figures for May are as follows: Total imports, [Pound]83,130,000; exports of British products, f42,730,000; re-exports, [Pound]7,390,000; total exports, f50,120,000; excess of imports, f33,010,000.

Representatives of 204 private welfare agencies, including settlement houses, day nurseries, Scout groups and boys' clubs, were notified yesterday that the local Works Progress Administration planned to withdraw 1,200 WPA recreation workers from the private agencies by July 15.

Our merchant navy, once in the days of the windjammers the pride of blue water, has run a fitful fever since those years when a forest of bowsprits spreading over South Street gladdened the eye of the seaman.
Tom M. Girdler, chairman of the Republic Steel Corporation, sent this letter today to the company employes, explaining his views in the present strike controversy: "To our employes: ...

The $4,219,000 Federal housing project for Negroes, known as Harlem River Houses, will be turned over to New York City today, with ceremonies. Within another month the structure will be open for occupancy by the 574 families selected out of 13,000 applicants who satisfy the New York City Housing Authority that they need better housing and at the same time have sufficient dependable income to be able to pay the rent.

Renewal of conflict between rival maritime unions tonight prevented sailing of the Eastern Steamship Lines steamer New York for New York and left ten crew members barricaded in the engine room of the vessel.

Sixty-four men and women who completed three-year courses in law at the John Marshall College of Law here will receive LL. B. degrees tomorrow afternoon at commencement exercises to be held in the State Normal School, at Hudson Boulevard and Audubon Avenue.

In the metropolitan interscholastic tennis singles tournament, which got under way yesterday at Fordham University, William Strange, Scarborough, defeated Thomas Madigan, Regis High, 6-0, 6-0, and Robert Musil, also of Scarborough, eliminated John Riely, Fordham Prep. 9-7. 6-0. William Schwartz.

The vestry of the Episcopal Church of St. Mark's-in-the-Bouwerie confirmed a report yesterday that they were now looking for a successor to the Rev. Dr. William Norman Guthrie, the rector, who has announced his intention to resign before September.

The Giants' famous "meal ticket," which for so long seemed utterly inexhaustible, had the boys on another starvation diet today, and, while the situation may not yet be critical, it certainly does not seem to be improving.

Operations at the J onn B. son Company, hat manufacturters, were virtually at a standstill today as a result of what the company termed a "sit-around strike." George W. MacKinnon, president of the company, said the majority of the 3,500 workers reported for work, took their usual places in the plant but refused to work, for the second day in succession.

Three liners will sail today for Europe with 4,021 passengers. The French liner Normandie has 1,500, the Cunard White Star liner Aquitania has 1,400 and the Manhattan of the United States Lines 1,121.

Asserting that the culmination of education is the capacity of the individual to accept responsibility to abstract ideals, Dr. Francis P. Gaines, president of Washington and Lee University, urged Lehigh University's graduating class this morning to "pour out, not only your brain but your heart as well in the high and holy causes that require your services today."

President Roosevelt said that employers willing to make oral agreements. with unions should be willing to put them in writing. Page 1. Senator Wagner, author of the labor law, accused the steel companies of bad faith, although admitting that the law did not compel them to sign a contract. [In above story.] Page 1.
The new women's metropolitan golf champion, Mrs. Marion Turpie, found no difficulty in winning the association's one-day tournament over her home links at the Plandome Golf Club today.

Miss Darling and Miss Moore are among the prospective brides whose engagements were announced earlier this month. Miss Darling, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. C. Coburn Darling of Providence, is engaged to F. Wilder Bellamy Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. F. Wilder Bellamy of Katonah, N. Y.
Dr. Samuel Downing, Newport News physician and former city health officer there, died yesterday in a hospital here after a long illness. He was 44 years old.

The Middle West Corporation, successor to the Middle West Utilities Company reported today for the first quarter of 1937 a consolidated net income of $185,703, or 5.6 cents a share, against $193,613, or 5.85 cents a share, in the first quarter of 1936. Both figures, according to D. C. Green, president, were after charging unearned preferred dividend requirements of subsidiaries against the consolidated account.

Trading in black pepper for future delivery will start this morning on the New York Produce Exchange under the auspices of the Spice Trade. An over-the-counter futures market has been in operation for some time and developed to the extent that the trade fills a need for a larger organized market of official status.

Presldent Roosevelt and Secretary of State Cordell Hull were asked today to use their good offices with Great Britain for the purpose of a maintaining Palestine as a refuge and a home for Jews by a delegation of the Pro-Palestine Federation of America.

Annual convention of the Special Libraries Association begins at the Hotel Roosevelt this morning at 10 A. M. and continues all week. Progressive City Committee luncheon, the Town Hall Club, 12:30 P. M. "Unfinished Civil Service Business," James E. Finegan.

Major Arthur McKeogh, World War hero and managing editor of Good Housekeeping Magazine, died yesterday at Mount Sinai Hospital of pneumonia after a week's illness. Gassed in the war, he had since fought against ill health. He lived at 125 East Fifty-sixth Street. His age was 47.

Payments on Cuba's public works bonds, which have been in default since 1933, will not, in all probability, be resumed in the coming fiscal year, beginning on July 1. Representative Marcelino Garriga, chairman of the Finance Committee of the House, told newspaper men today upon leaving the palace.

The Cubs moved today into first place in the National League for the first time this season when they halted the Bees, 5 to 4. More than 8,000 fans saw Chicago come from behind to assume a lead that Clay Bryant protected by allowing only one hit in five innings after Tex Carleton had cracked up in the fourth.

The first of a proposed national chain of French Bootery shops will have as its location a store in the Michigan Square Building, 544 North Michigan Boulevard, Chicago, according to an announcement by Culver, Hollyday Co., Inc., who, with Hooker Slosson of Chicago, was the broker who handled the negotiations for the shoe concern.

Frederick J. H. Kracke, Commissioner of Plant and Structures, defended freedom of speech as it is practiced over WNYC, the city radio station, when he was called before the Board of Aldermen in City Hall yesterday to answer for a broadcast on June 5 which some of the members considered antiJewish.

John Costello, 29 years old, of 98 Ninth Avenue, a longshoreman, was shot dead at about 10 o'clock last night by two gunmen as he sat on the steps of a Salvation Army social service center at Seventeenth Street and Ninth Avenue. The police said they believed Costello had ben involved in a waterfront racket.

Joseph P. Day, Inc,, had the asdistance yesterday of about 500 persons, including several municipal and Federal officials, in formally opening the firm's new Queens branch office in the World's Fair section, on Horace Harding Boulevard and Main Street, Flushing. John J. Halleran, Queens. Commissioner of Public Works;

Stockholders of the Liquid Carbonic Corporation approved yesterday in Chicago an increase in the corporation's authorized capital from 400,000 to 1,200,000 shares and the issuance of one additional share for each of the 350,000 shares now outstanding.
The death of General Matei Jalka Lukacs, Hungarian Communist and one of the important leaders among the international volunteers fighting for the Loyalists, was announced today.

An ovation was accorded tonight's presentation of "The Great Romancer" by the American, Jules Eckert Goodman, at the New Theatre, and it marked a personal triumph for Robert Morley. With his portrayal of Alexandre Dumas, he finds himself overnight in the front rank of actors.

Led by First Baseman Johnny Mize, who drove in four runs with two singles, a triple and an infield out, the St. Louis Cardinals lambasted the offerings of three Philadelphia pitchers today to win easily, 13 to 4. It was the Cardinals' ninth victory in their last ten games.

Continuing its policy of recognizing the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, an A.
