F. of L. affiliate, as the collective bargaining agency for its 40,000 employes and those of its affiliates, the Consolidated Edison Company announced yesterday that contracts giving pay increases have been signed between the company and locals of the union for employes in Manhattan, the Bronx and Queens.

Alexander U. Zinke, attorney, has accepted the post of vice chairman on the National Committee for Religion and Welfare Recovery, 60 East Forty-second Street, it was announced yesterday by Charles V. Vickrey, secretary of the committee.

Henry Ward Beer of Brooklyn, former Assistant Attorney General of the United States, was re-elected president for the fifth consecutive term of the Federal Bar Association of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, here this evening at the Newark Athletic Culb. More than 200 members attended.

Early disposition in the Senate of the administration's judiciary reorganization program, either by a vote on passage or action for indefinite postponement, was predicted here today as President Roosevelt joined forces with the bill's most hostile foes to bring the issue to a test.

Miss Hope Jackson, daughter of Robert Jackson of Concord, N. H., and Washington, has chosen her bridal attendants for her marriage to Francis Patrick Garvan Jr., which will take place on Saturday at Green Court, the country place in Brookville, L. I.,

J. H. Logan's Hunterdon scored his fourth victory of the year today, beating O. H. Rowe's Moralist by a length in the mile and a sixteenth of the Old South Claiming Purse at Suffolk Downs to pay $11.40 for $2 in the mutuels.

The second Annual National Exhibition of American Art, arranged by the Municipal Art Committee, was opened by Mayor La Guardia at a pre-view last evening in the Galleries of the American Fine Arts Building, 215 West Fifty-seventh Street.

The Savage School for Physical Education will hold its thirty-ninth annual commencement tonight at the Town Hall, 113 West Fortythird Street. Dr. Albert Sheppard of New York University will be the speaker.

MANHATTAN CASAL. JOE (March 17). Estate. $2,000. To Nellie Casal, widow, executrix, 1,668 Park Ave. FRIEDMANN, PAUL GEORGE (June 8). Estate, more than $10,000. To Muriel Leonard Friedmann, widow, 404 E. 55th St., residue; Maurice C. Reinecke, cousin, executor, 404 E. 55th St., membership on New York Curb Exchange.

Formation of the Westchester County Civil Service Employes Association was announced today by Leonard Mecca of Port Chester, temporary chairman of the organization and an employee in the County Controller's office.

Louis Finton will speak at the meeting of the Associated Music Teachers League this morning in Steinway Hall. Clarence Watters, organist, will give a recital tomorrow at 8:45 P. M. in St. Stephen's Church, Port Washington, L. I.

The sale of a private house in Yorkville and the leasing of a blockfront taxpayer were the highlights in yesterday's reports of Manhattan real estate deals. Dr. Frank B. Orr, in the first transfer of the property in thirtynine years, has bought the threestory private dwelling at 127 East Seventieth Street from W. L. Edgar.

President Roosevelt indicated at his press conference his belief that independent steel companies should sign contracts with their employes, broadly outlining a plan for coordination of Federal benefits agencies so that national income could be raised and relief eliminated and criticized the activities of lobbyists against the Jones-Costigan Sugar Bill.

Josiah T. Allinson, former Assemblyman from Mercer County, died today in the Mercer Hospital here. He was 79 years old. Mr. Allinson served in the Assembly from 1916 to 1918, and was Assessor in Hamilton township previously.

Charles F. Lester, John J. Gibbons and Vincent C. A. Bitter have been elected executive vice presidents of Peck Peck, 585 Fifth Avenue, it was announced yesterday by A. Wells Peck, president. Mr. Lester is director of operation for the New England group of stores as well as manager of the Boston store.

More than 500 men and women clashed today in a hand-to-hand fighting between followers of John L. Lewis and adherents of the American Federation of Labor, who attempted to reopen a strike-closed plant.

Several large properties in Manhattan changed hands yesterday at auction sales in the Vesey Street salesrooms. Two of the parcels were bought by the New York Life Insurance Company, the plaintiff, for $50,000 each.

The address of BERNARD M. BARUCH at the commencement exercises of Union College combined practical wisdom with historic perspective. He began by recalling the guild and "mercantile" systems which prevailed up to the end of the seventeenth century,

Absorption of the functions of the State Temporary Emergency Relief Administration by the State Department of Social Welfare will save between $450,000 and $500,000 a year in personnel costs, David C. Adie, State Commissioner of Social Welfare, announced yesterday.

To the Editor of The New York Times: After a public hearing held in the office of the Transit Commission on May 26 as to the necessity for at least one escalator in the Grand Central Terminal, a conference was held in Commissioner Haskell's office with representatives of the railroad company on June 7.
The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated June 12: CAPTAIN McBride, L. B., Naval Academy to Bureau of Construction and Repair, Navy Dept., Washington, D. C.

WHILE even on a modern map the community of Galesburg, Ill., doesn't seem to be very important, those who read Earnest Elmo Calkins's "They Broke the Prairie" (Scribner, $2.50) will discover that a century ago it was even less so. It was, as a matter of fact, not Galesburg at all, merely a spot on the lone prairie, minus trees and hills and all signs of human life.

The adjutant general released the following orders today: COMMISSIONS Gillett, Major Gen. Ransom H., having qualified, is placed on duty. He is to report to commanding general N. Y. N. G. for instructions. Kearney, Brig. Gen. Bernard W., of the line, will report to commanding general N. Y. N. G. for assignment to command 53d Brigade.

Harry Richard Zander of 30 North Bayles Avenue, a writer and newspaper man, died today at Doctors Sanitarium here after an illness of a week. He was 46 years old. For the last two years he had been preparing radio scripts and shows for Blackett-Sample Hummert, Inc., an advertising agency of 247 Park Avenue.

ABKOWITZ--Sarah, of 465 Central Park West, beloved mother of William, Max. Leo, Gussie Kroll, Evelyn Rosenberg and Pearl Bercu. Funeral Wednesday, 2 P. M., from Glassman's Memorial Home, 200 Broome St. Interment Washington Cemetery. ADAMS--Mabel C., wife of Albert J., mother of Quincy, suddenly, at Norwich, Conn. Services Woodlawn Chapel, noon, Wednesday, June 16.

As a sequel to the rioting here last month, Welwel Szcezerbowski, a young Jew, went on trial today here on a charge of murdering policeman, Stafan Kedziora. Kedziora confiscated 200 pounds of uninspected meat found in the shop of the defendant's father, leging that it came from a secret Jewish slaughterhouse in violating the restriction in ritual slaughter.

Manhattan 153d St, 508-10 W, 50x61.2, for 4-story' school; Church of St. Catherine of Genoa, 560 W 153d St, owner; Jules Lewis,. architect;- cost $45,000. Broome St, 514, 19.10x31. for- 2-family dwelling; Giacomo Cocozziello, premises, owner; F. Savignano, architect; cost, $8,000.

A large crowd, headed by the King and Queen, today saw Sir Abe Bailey's Valerian win the Ascot Stakes, opening-day feature of the 226th annual race meeting at this fashionable turf center. The race was at two miles.
Harlem River Houses will be turned over to the city today, and this ceremony will expose to public view another fragment of that low-rental Utopia so long and as yet so vainly sought.

The Tigers defeated the Senators, 9 to 8, in fifteen innings today after an error by Buddy Myer helped them score the winning run. Washington had put on a seven-run rally to tie the score in the ninth.

The huge investment of American funds in Canada, given as $4,000,000,000, was stressed by Canadian speakers today at the second conference on Canadian-American affairs as a compelling reason for a United States tariff policy that would be helpful to Canada in any revision of the reciprocal trade agreement.

Baron Robert Silvercruys, Belgian Minister to Canada, is expected to arrive tomorrow from Ottawa. He will be at the Ambassador. Mrs. William Fitz Hugh Whitehouse and Miss Adelaide Whitehouse are visiting Mrs. Parmely W. Herrick at Carlton House.

Daily average gross production of crude oil in the United States last week was 3,515,900 barrels, compared with 3,538,150 in the preceding week, a decline of 22,250, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday.

Under the protection of State police, striking steel workers re-formed their picket lines on the road leading to the plant of the Newton Steel Company here today after Mayor Daniel A. Knaggs's army of special deputies and vigilantes had been moved back out of hooting distance.

In recommending the rejection of Mr. ROOSEVELT'S bill to reorganize the Federal judiciary, the Senate committee has properly put its major emphasis on the proposed increase in the membership of the Supreme Court.

THE FRONT-The Rebel wings advanced further in the encircling movement on Bilbao. The right struck on a wider front toward the Nervion Estuary, but the left was delayed by destruction of an important bridge. Franco will wait for their advance before attacking the city. Madrid suffered its worst night shelling. Page 1.

Forty coal companies complained today to the Interstate Commerce Commission that railroad rates for hauling anthracite from mines in Pennsylvania to New York harbor for transshipment to New England were "unjust and unreasonable." The complaint was directed against thirteen carriers.

Miss Virginia Clark, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert B. Clark of North Adams, was married to Richard Horace Daniels, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank R. Daniels of Williamstown, at the First Baptist Church tonight.

The employers' and employes' organizations in Italy have just concluded the annual collective agreements, one of whose functions is to make strikes unnecessary in all industries. The process by which grievances are adjusted, first by arbitration l and, failing that, by special tribunals, is well known.

Renewed interest in housing properties featured the trading in Bronx properties reported yesterday. Among the largest was a 225-room house, with accommodations for sixty-five families, purchased by David S. Meister.

Stockholders of Paramount Pictures, Inc., approved yesterday a profit-sharing agreement with Adolph Zukor running from Aug. 1, 1936, to Dec. 31, 1937, and authorized the board to renew the agreement or to make a new one for the ensuing three years, by a vote of 3,558,061 shares to 12,188. This represented the approval of nearly 60 per cent of the 5,935,708 votes of record for the meeting.

Nicholas J. Demas, 43 years old, a former collector for the Consolidated Gas Company, who killed a man seven years ago with a pistol for which he had a permit, was sentenced yesterday by Judge Behan in General Sessions to two and a halt to five years in Sing Sing on his recent conviction of first-degree manslaughter.

The Red Sox gave Bob Grove, their veteran southpaw ace, plenty of hitting and almost perfect support today and he gained his fourth victory of the season at the expense of the White Sox by a 5-1 margin. The setback dropped Chicago to third place, Detroit moving into the second berth.

The League of Nations Economic Committee in its annual survey of the state and prospects of world recovery given out today finds that economic conditions favor a renewed effort at international agreement but do not suffice.

Upward of $10,000,000 of Federal aid to provide schools for more than 250,000 children now deprived of the opportunity for public instruction was forecast by Dr. Juan M. Gallardo, new Commissioner of Education, in a statement today.

The body of George F. Baker, chairman of the board of the First National Bank of New York, who died on May 30 at Honolulu, during a cruise on his yacht Viking, arrived this afternoon at Viking's Cove, his country home at Peacock Point on Long Island Sound, having been brought to New York in the morning by special train from San Francisco.

British experience has proved that the yearly subsidy plan for a lowincome housing program is much more satisfactory than the lumpsum grant, Sir Raymond Unwin, British architect, town planning and housing expert, said yesterday.

Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Chester Warren of 157 East Seventy-second Street have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Pauline Winslow Warren, to Potter d'Orsay Palmer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Honore Palmer of 435 East Fifty-second Street and Chicago.

David Fawlowitz, who will celebrate his fiftieth wedding anniversary Sunday at his home, 1,937 Sixty-first Street, Brooklyn, yesterday notified all tenants who have lived in his property on the lower East Side for twenty-five years or more that in commemoration of the happy event they could forget about their July rent.

One-fifth of the nation-wide program of the Federal Public Works Administration has been carried on in this State, with 490 permanent public improvements valued at $435,077,953 completed, or nearing completion, Arthur S. Tuttle, State PWA director, is reporting to Administrator Harold L. Ickes on the occasion today of the fourth anniversary of the establishment of PWA.

Awards of Keene Fitzpatrick medals to fifteen members of Princeton varsity and freshman track squads for proficiency and the greatest improvement and effort in their respective events during the Spring were announced today by Coach Matthew T. Gels.

An election in which employes of the Alexander Smith Sons Carpet Company took part today-to decide on union recognition for collective bargaining purposes was won by the Textile Workers Organizing Committee, a C. I. O. affiliate, by a margin of 315 votes.
Cleveland at New York -- Galehouse vs. Gomez. Detroit at Washington--Wade vs. Ferrell. Chicago at Boston--Whitehead vs. Newsom. St. Louis at Philadelphia--Knott vs. Kelley.
The House approved today a $194,328,000 appropriation for flood control, river and harbor improvements and related public works amid sharp criticism of administration floodcontrol policies.

Private funeral services will be held at 11 A. M. today in the Riverside Chapel, Seventy-sixth Street and Amsterdam Avenue, for Philip Liberman, retired New York merchant, who died suddenly Saturday in Miami Beach, Fla., after an operation. He was 60 years old.
Princess Juliana indicated in a radio broadcast today that she was to become a mother. Probably this was the first time such news had been given on the radio by the expectant mother herself.

The Goldman Band, Edwin Franko Goldman, director, will open the twentieth season of the Daniel Guggenheim Memorial Concerts tonight on the Central Park Mall. Mrs. Daniel Guggenheim, donor of the concerts, and her family, as well as Mayor La Guardia, are expected to attend.

Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden told the House of Commons today that he had forwarded an appeal to the Spanish Rebel authorities asking them not to destroy the center of Bilbao while refugees continue to be evacuated from the city.

Paulie Walker, Trenton (N. J.) welterweight, scored a technical knockout over Eddie Carroll of Ottawa in 2:02 of the fourth round of their eight-round bout at the Coney Island Velodrome last night, The Associated Press reported.

Nine-ton tanks armed with 'four machine guns and capable of standard road speeds of thirty-five miles an hour, a Northrop attack plane which cruises at 190 miles an hour and is armed with four guns in the wings and two in the rear cockpit, land other of the army's modern

George J. Trivers, a Negro, tonight awaited the results of a physical examination which will decide whether he can enter the Naval Academy. Trivers, who lives at 380 South Parkway, Chicago, was appointed by Representative Arthur W. Mitchell, Negro.

Charles A. McCarthy, retired shoe manufacturer, one of the founders of the Dunn McCarthy firm in Auburn, died early tonight at his home here. He was 84 years old. Mr. McCarthy was born in Newport, N. Y., the son of the Rev. William and Ruth E. Allen McCarthy. His father was a graduate of Edinburgh University, Scotland.

Initial reaction yesterday to the publication of the text of the "voluntary platform," adopted as a statement of policy for its 5,800 member stores by the National Retail Dwy Goods Association, was favorable, comment here indicated.

The fifty-four pupils of the Walter Scott Free Industrial School for Crippled Children, Inc., with their teachers, friends of the graduates and officials, attended the thirtysecond commencement exercises at the school, 55 West Sixty-eighth Street, yesterday.
A buying organization for group purchasing was formed at a special meeting yesterday of the Credit Retailers Association of America at its headquarters at 101 West Thirty-first Street.
James J. Dooling, leader of Tammany, said yesterday he had in mind a Mayoralty candidate upon whom, he believed, all factions of the Democratic party could unite, but declined to reveal his name.

The District Attorney's campaign against money lenders accused of victimizing city employes continued yesterday with the conviction of two men in Special Sessions and the arrest of a Harlem butcher accused of conducting a money-lending business from his shop.

The Board of Examiners reports that there have been placed. as of June 12. 1937, upon the eligible list of holders of license as shop maintenance man in day high schools, the names of the following applicants, who have been granted said license:
Lieutenant Norman Fereday of Southern Rhodesia, an expert rifleman who twice reached the final stage of the King's Prize at Bisley, died today at the age of 45.

Officials of the Second International -- the Labor and Socialist International--informed Georgi Dimitroff, secretary general of the Third (Communist) International, today, of their willingness to meet a delegation from the latter organization to discuss joint action to aid the Spanish Government against the Fascist Insurgents.
The Kosciuszko Foundation, 149 East Sixty-seventh Street, of which Dr. Henry Noble MacCracken is president, announced yesterday the award of eighteen scholarships for study in Poland this Summer.

Thomas W. Lamont, speaking in behalf of the American Council of St. Luke's International Medical Center of Tokyo, advocated the establishment of peace through the study of economic resources yesterday in an address to members of the visiting Japanese Economic Mission at a luncheon in India House, 1 Hanover Square.
Steel ingot production last week was unchanged when a seasonal decline was usual and the adjusted index has advanced to 105.4 from 102.3. For the week ended June 13, 1936, the index was 98.3.
Dr. William H. Allen, secretary of the Municipal Civil Service Commission at $5,000 a year since Aug. 9, 1934, submitted his resignation yesterday to James E. Finegan, president of the commission.

The Bishop of Durham accepted tonight the resignation of the Rev. R. Anderson Jardine, who performed the religious ceremony at the wedding of the Duke and Duchess of Windsor as vicar of St. Paul's Church, Darlington.
A. Sigmund Kanengieser of Newark was unanimously re-elected GrandMaster by the Independent Order B'rith Sholom, closing its thirtysecond annual convention in the Ritz-Carlton Hotel today.

Barnett Faroll, vice president of the Chicago Board of Trade, announced today that $1,218,000 had been paid on the first mortgage of the 'Board of Trade Building to the Northwestern Mutual Life Insurance Company, Milwaukee, reducing the debt to $9,000,000.

Democratic members of the Board of Estimate who have been overriding Mayor La Guardia's opposition to pay restorations for the higher city officials were checked yesterday by the discovery that, if the higher officials got more pay, there would be no budget funds left for increases to the thousands of per diem laborers in various city departments.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are June 14, unless specified: New Haven to Boston Yard: Badger, Tattnail. At Boston Yard: Baxcn, Schenok, Moffett. At Seattle: Brooks, Fox. At Mare Island Yard, MacLeish, McCormick, Simpson, Truxtun, Wright.

A six-day investigation of the mysterious disappearance of Mrs. William H. Parsons from her Long Island farm has "developed nothing new" Inspector Earl J. Connelly of the Federal Bureau of Investigation said today as he ordered a systematic search of the countryside continued.

Mrs. August Zinsser entertained with a tea yesterday at her home, 6 West Ninth Street, for Miss Luoille B. Sargeant and Gsorge L. de Peyster, who will be married on Friday. Other guests included Mr. and Mrs. Richard S. Reynolds, ...

Madrid trembled early today under the worst night shelling the capital has experienced in its seven-month siege. The casualties were believed to be heavy. The whole city was in an uproar with Insurgent shells exploding at the rate of twenty to thirty a minute and government artillery replying with almost as heavy fire.

Light-heavyweight Champion John Henry Lewis, Phoenix, Ariz., punched out a decisivefifteen-round decision over Al Ettore of Philadelphia in a non-title bout before 15,000 fans at the Phillies' Ball Park tonight. Lewis weighed 178 and Ettore 192.

Sidney Hillman, president of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America, urged the joint Senate and House Labor Committee today to retain Section 5, dealing with wages and hours, in the Black-Connery Labor Standards Bill.

Some fifty Wall Street men engaged in "investment counseling" in respect to railroad securities learned something yesterday about the field of transport through a trip of inspection ashore and afloat provided by the Pennsylvania Railroad.

At least seven, and probably eight, members of a fishing party of- eleven Pennsylvanians were drowned in Delaware Bay last night after leaping from the thirty-fivefoot cabin cruiser Teal, which ripped out part of her hull on submerged driftwood six miles offshore and settled upon a shoal.

Offering will be made today of a new issue of $1,100,000 of North American Car Corporation 4 1/2 per cent equipment trust certificates, Series P, by a group composed of Freeman Co., the Central Republic Company, Stroud Co., Inc., and Chandler Co., Inc.

Headed by the New York Security Dealers Association and the Investment Bankers Association of America, representatives of the over-thecounter brokers and dealers turned out in force today at a public hearing before an examiner of the Securities and Exchange Commission to oppose applications by the New York Curb Exchange for unlisted trading in twenty-two bonds or debenture issues now traded only over-the-counter.

The American Chamber of Commerce of Cuba has presented a protest to President Federico Laredo Bru and Congress against the enactment of taxes proposed by the Chief Executive in a recent budget message, according to a communication made public last night.
Following are the honors, degrees and diplomas that will be awarded at City College. Special graduation honors for having completed nine credits in honor courses with Grade A will go to:

Advance interest in the opening concert of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra's twentieth season at Lewisohn Stadium next Wednesday evening has been such that all table seats have been sold, it was announced yesterday. Five hundred extra seats within the enclosure facing the stage are still obtainable.

Prices of wheat and rye advanced sharply today on general scattered buying induced by reports of drought from parts of the Canadian Northwest. Both grains in Minneapolis and Winnipeg soared 5 cents a bushel, the permissible limit for one day, while July rye on the Board of Trade here also was up 5 cents.

Faced with a two-goal deficit late in the fifth period, Army's wellbalanced quartet rallied brilliantly to shade Harvard, 10 to 9, in their intercollegiate polo semi-final encpunter at Governors Island yesterday.

Three of the fifteen seeded stars met defeat today in the third round of the twenty-seventh national clay court tennis tournament at River Forest. Billy Kiley of Kansas City, Mo., was .first to go out, losing, 6--0, 6--4, to Bill Talbert of Cincinnati,

Contracts for space for three exhibit buildings at the 1939 New York World's Fair were announced yesterday by Grover A. Whalen, president of the Fair Corporation. The agreements were with the American Gas Association, the Consolidated Edison Company and the JohnsManville Corporation.

Miss Norma Taubele of New York and Miss Eunice Dean of San Antonio, Texas, the two top favorites in the New York State championship, found themselves quarely on their mettle yesterday at the Jackson Heights Tennis Club.

Representative William P. Connery Jr. of Massachusetts, who as chairman of the House Labor Committee piloted most of the New Deal labor legislation through the House, died in Homeopathic Hospital here at 5:10 o'clock this afternoon after a short illness caused by food poisoning.

Eamon de Valera, President of the Irish Free State, in a radio address in Dublin last night, defended his proposed new constitution, which has been approved by the retiring Dail Eireann, and which soon will be submitted to the people in a national plebiscite.

A hot Summer sun looked down today on the four miles of the Hudson that stretch from Krum Elbow on the North down to this city and glinted on the blades of sixteen eight-oared crews and three or four four-oared ones. With the arrival this morning of Washington and Cornell, each with three crews and substitutes, the flotilla for the intercollegiate regatta of a week hence was complete.

Dr. and Mrs. George S. Ogden of Brooklyn and Douglas Hill, Me., have announced the engagement and approaching marriage of their daughter, Miss Jean Ogden, to Dayton McCue Kohler, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin D. Kohler of Harrisburg, Pa. The wedding will take place on August 7 at the Ogden Summer home in Maine.

Hunter College will hold cornmencement exercises for about 830 graduates at 10:30 o'clock this morning in Carnegie Hall. Dr. Eugene A. Colligan, president of the college, will confer about 812 Bachelor of Arts degrees, nine degrees of Master of Arts,

City College will confer a total of 1,962 degrees, diplomas and commissions at its ninety-first commencement exercises tonight in the City College Stadium, 137th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. About 17,000 friends, relatives and guests of the graduates are expected to witness the ceremonies.

On police surgeon's certificate: PATROLMAN-Francis M. Kelly, Emeragency Service Squad 3. at $2.250 per annum. Appointed Oct. 6, 1920. Pensioned On police surgeon's certificate: PATROLMEN-Nicholas J. Berry, 70th Precinct, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed June 25, 1913. Thomas F. Ryan, office of the chle clerk, old record room, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed June 25. 1913.

Mrs. Sally Lewis Wood Nixon, wife of Lewis Nixon, shipbuilder, now president of the Nixon Nitration Works, died at 10 o'clock last night at her residence, 16 East Seventy-ninth Street, after an illness of ten months.

The Bankamerica Agricultural Credit Corporation, a subsidiary of the Transamerica Corporation, yesterday declared a dividend of $25,000, payable on June 29 to stock of record of June 25. W. W. Hopper, president, said the improving price and market conditions in the livestock industry throughout the West had resulted in the dividend.

Many prominent New York business and professional leaders voted yesterday in elections for Mayor, trustees and other town offices in the villages of Nassau and Suffolk Counties. Except for Great Neck, where two incumbent trustees were opposed, there was not a single contest in any of the elections.

Total sales of fur skins by members of the American Fur Merchants Association in May were $3,886,883, a decline under the aggregate of $4,814,097 in April, but slightly above the figure of $3,858,662 in May a year ago, according to figures issued yesterday by the association.

The Public Service Commission has authorized the Buffalo-Niagara Electric Corportion, formed by consolidation of the Buffalo General Electric Company, the Niagara Electric Service Corporation and the Tonawanda Power Company, to issue not to exceed $17,029,000 of general and refunding mortgage bonds, 31/2 per cent, Series C, for refunding purposes.

A banking group headed by Merrill, Lynch Co. and Cassett Co., Inc., will offer today a new issue of $15,000,000 of ten-year 4 per cent sinking fund debentures of Safeway Stores, Inc., at 991/2 and interest. The debentures are dated June 1, 1937, and will mature on June 1, 1947. The underwriting group includes Blyth Co., Inc.; Brown Harriman Co., Inc., and Dean Witter Co.

Harry Balsamo, hard-hitting subway brakeman, scored a quick victory at the new Queensboro Arena last night. He knocked out Jimmy Belmont of Pittsburgh in 39 seconds of the first round in the feature bout scheduled for ten rounds.

Committees representing the country's leading railroads and unions of rail employes with a membership of nearly 800,000 met here today to try to reach an agreement on the demands of the employes for a wage increase of 20 cents an hour.

Women owners captured both divisions of the Charade Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday as Orient Express and Drudgery triumphed for Mrs. C. Oliver Iselin and Mrs. Dodge Sloane, who maintain two of the best known stables in the East.

Edward R. Stettinius Jr., chairman of the finance committee of the United States Steel Corporation, told the 382 graduates of the University of Virginia this afternoon that enlightened business was thoroughly in accord with the new concept

Following a breach between the Resettlement Administration and the colonists at Jersey Homesteads, near here, private capital and the support of consumer cooperatives in the East and Midwest had been enlisted to enable the colony to continue operation of its governmentbuilt garment factory, Benjamin Brown, executive secretary and spokesman for the colonists, announced today.

The international chess-masters tournament which, for nearly four weeks, will hold the attention of chess followers throughout the world, and especially those of the United States, represented by two outstanding grand-masters,

Frank Fischer, who has already admitted his participation in the 1933 kidnapping of John J. O'Connell Jr., unhesitatingly identified today in Federal court seven men as having plotted and executed the crime.

James J. Braddock is in excellent physical condition, but not much can be said of his fighting form. This impression was gained here this afternoon as the man who is to defend the world's heavyweight title on June 22 against Joe Louis in Comiskey Park went through a six-round workout that featured four rounds of sparring.

Secretary Swanson has told the House Naval Committee that the Navy Department felt it would "serve no useful purpose" to permit all navy yards to bid on the new battleship to be built in a navy yard next year.

The United States received only one payment, $163,143 from Finland, today when war debt installments became due from thirteen governments which owe a total of $1,520,159,863 in new amounts and arrears.

Eugene Gamble of the Gamble Hinged Music Company, Chicago, was yesterday elected president of the National Association of Sheet Music Dealers at the group's twenty-fourth annual convention at the Hotel Roosevelt. He succeeded E. P. Hangen of Reading, Pa., who was named to the board of directors.

Brig. Gen. George E. Leach, World War hero and veteran Republican, was elected Mayor of Minneapolis in yesterday's elections, defeating Kenneth Haycraft, former Minnesota football star who had the endorsement of the Farmer-Labor party.

After twenty months of delay, the Public Works Administration has advanced $1,000,000 to this city to start work on the $4,250,000 New York Bay port terminal development, which is to be constructed under a onethird grant, two-thirds loan agreement, it was made known today.

Castle Hill Ave, e s, 76.1 ft s of Ellis Ave, 76x80; Mortgage Commission of New York against Emelen Holding Corp; due, $50,700: taxes, , $5,870; to plaintiff for $1,000. Bryant Ave, 1,464, 2-story dwelling, 25x100; Dollar Savings Bank of New York against Fannie Birnbach; due, $11,741; taxes, , $451; to plaintiff for $10,000.

Governor Martin L. Davey's latest attempt to effect a peace agreement between independent steel companies and the Steel Workers Organizing Committee failed this afternoon. Collapse of the movement came on the companies' announcement that they had not changed their decision against signing any agreement with a labor organization.

Stockholders of the Baldwin Locomotive Works approved today changes in the capital structure of the corporation that are required under the plan of reorganization now before the United States District Court.

Barney Ross, welterweight champion of the world, felt the wrath of the New York State Athletic Commission yesterday when he was suspended indefinitely for his failure to meet Ceferino Garcia of California in a title bout.

Old Main, center of Knox College life for eighty years and which holds stones on which Lincoln trod in 1858, was rededicated today as the chief feature of the Knox-Galesburg Centenary celebration. rg Centenary celebration.

The artilleryman who cuts his finger peeling potatoes while doing "kitchen police" is officially injured in the line of duty, but any member of the Sixty-second Coast Artillery Regiment at Fort Totten, in Queens, who becomes infected as a result of tattooing will receive no pay until he assumes a "fit-forduty" status, it was learned yesterday.

Officials of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., are formulating a new plan for the acquisition of the preferred shares of its affiliate, the New York Steam Corporation, to replace the proposal recently rejected by the Public Service Commission.

A trend of civilization to the Arctic and the need to "unlearn" some of the teachings about northern weather conditions and habits of living were pointed out yesterday by Vilhjalmur Stefansson, explorer, scientist and author, at the commencement exercises of Hunter College in Carnegie Hall.

At a continuation of the hearings before an examiner of the Securities and Exchange Commission today on the applications of the New York Curb Exchange for unlisted trading privileges in twenty-two issues of bonds or debentures now dealt in only overthe-counter, Abner Goldstone, counsel for the commission, sought to develop where the over-the-counter interests believed the line should be drawn in granting such requests.

In the first five months of this year, the Caterpillar Tractor Company showed a net profit of $5,093,825 after deducting expenses, depreciation, interest and Federal taxes, but before provision for surtax on undistributed earnings.

About the time "The Show Is On" was being born-last December-there ran a whispered threat that the Shubert office would do no more revues for a long, long time. Charge that off to the frayed nerves of the moment.

Mrs. Helen Baldwin has asked the police to institute a search for her husband, Richard D. Baldwin, 41 years old, of New York, who, she says, disappeared from their home on Monday with their 4-year-old daughter, Charlene.

A somewhat better tone in United States Government obligations featured yesterday an otherwise dull market for bonds on the New York Stock Exchange. While most of the higher-grade corporate loans held steady to firm, considerable selling pressure persisted throughout a broad list of secondary issues, particularly in the railroad group.

Humbert A. Vanozzi, assistant manager of the branch of the East River Savings Bank recently opened in Rockefeller Center, died yesterday at his home, 417 Ocean Avenue, Brooklyn. He was formerly assistant secretary of the Italian Savings Bank, with which he was nssniaterl for twenty-five years.

The opening game of the Brook League in the Meadow Brook Club's annual Spring championship tournament will pit the Santa Barbara team from California against the Gulf Stream quartet, headed by Michael G. Phipps, on Saturday at 4:30 o'clock on the Meadow Brook Club's famous International Field.

Supreme Court Justice William T. Collins was told yesterday that he would ruin the business of C. Ludwig Baumann Co. of Brooklyn if he ordered it to drop the "Ludwig" from its name temporarily pending trial of a suit for a permanent injunction as requested by Ludwig Baumann of 500 Eighth Avenue. Justice Collins reserved decision.

Reports from apparently reliable sources across the border state that a huge clean-up within the Phalangistas or Spanish Fascist party has resulted in the imposition of death sentences on Manuel Hedilla, nominal chief of the party, and fourteen other leaders by an Insurgent court-martial.

A little thing like a blister on the middle finger of his pitching hand couldn't stop Vernon (Lefty) Gomez yesterday at the Stadium. Neither could the Indians, who for the second straight afternoon took second money behind the league-leading Yankees.

The engagement of Miss Rose Patricia Johnston, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert B. Johnston of this city, to Earl George Dana, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence George Dana of Derrick City, Pa., was announced at a luncheon given today at the Bradford Country Club by her sisters-inlaw, Mrs. Al Smart Johnston and Mrs. Robert B. Johnston Jr., both of Bradford.

Trading in black pepper futures on the New York Produce Exchange was inaugurated yesterday, with considerable activity and interest evident throughout the trading session. The first sale was for one September contract at 5.78 cents a pound. Prices advanced to close at

A sound and effective plan of rapid transit unification can be worked out after the next city election, but only if the rigid five-cent fare is discarded and a flexible fare basis adopted, Harold Riegelman, counsel for the Citizens Budget Commission, predicted yesterday.

Sweden nosed out Minneapolis by 10 points early today in their bridge match in the "knock-out" round of the championship for open teams of four as Len Reiter of Minneapolis suffered a severe attack of nervous indigestion.
Astonished householders of this little mining town, ten miles north of Pottsville, went out with brooms and swept bullfrogs off their open - porches after a thunderstorm today.

Michael Zenko, alias DeMarr, 34 years old, a "fortune teller," who swindled two women out of $5,000 in a bogus stock investment scheme, was sentenced to Sing Sing yesterday by Judge Koenig in General Sessions for three to six years on his conviction on the testimony of two of his victims.
Panama Canal officials disclosed tonight that preliminary plans are being drafted to enlarge the canal to handle expected increases in traffic. The cost is estimated at $150,000,000.

Twenty students at the Maryknoll Seminary of the Catholic Foreign Mission Society of America were ordained to the priesthood today by the Most Rev. James E. Walsh, Superior General of the society. They will leave July 25 for stations in the Far East.
The Yale library has received from Thornton Wilder, '20, as a gift through the Library Associates, the autographed manuscripts of the first and second versions of his novel, "The Woman of Andros."

The present steel strike has raised the question whether a signed agreement is required by the Wagner act. Proceedings now in progress in regional offices of the National Labor Relations Board will eventually provide an answer, but in the meantime the extent of popular misconception of the problem calls for some clarification of the issues involved.

Operators were active yesterday in the purchase of housing properties in the Bronx. Henry Goelet bought the five-anda-half-story building for sixty-three families at 2,121-25 Harrison Avenue, adjoining the corner of 181st Street. which was held at $200,000.

International mining interests have agreed to provide the financing to equip and bring into production the copper properties owned by the O'Kiep Copper Company, Ltd., in Namaqualand, Union of South Africa, it was announced here yesterday.
The death of Emile Digneffe, Belgian banker, industrialist, politician and former Speaker of the Senate, was announced tonight. He was 78 years old.

President Roosevelt will be the starting pitcher in baseball's allstar game here July 7. Owner Clark Griffith of the Washington Senators said he had made a "deal" with President Roosevelt to pitch the first ball.

With what is claimed to be the first use of comic strip technique on twenty-four sheet posters, the Richfield Oil Corporation of New York, through Fletcher Ellis, Inc., will feature wordless cartoons by O. Soglow in its outdoor advertising this Summer.

Arthur W. Milburn, president of the Borden Company, announced yesterday that the company was retiring from the butter, egg and poultry businesses, but that other activities of the produce division would be continued.

Superior horsemanship, more accurate stroking and better team work carried Cornell to a 9-to-7 triumph over Princeton on Morris Memorial Field, Governors Island, yesterday in the concluding semifinal match of the intercollegiate outdoor polo championship.

Miss Rita A. McKenna, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James McKenna of Pelham, N. Y., will be married ,n June 22 to Egbert R. Ferguson Jr. of Birmingham, Ala.. son of Mr. and Mrs. Egbert R. Ferguson Df Lakewood, Ohio.

Al McCoy, 182, Boston, won a split ten-round decision over Natie Brown, 199, Washington, tonight at Fenway Park. Brown's body attack was impressive, but officials penalized him for several low punches.

Mrs. Leona Hertz, in Hotel Wyndham, Warren L. Marks, Daniel Brener, inc, broker. William B. Strong, in the Beverly, 125 E 50th St. Dr. Leon L. Watters, twelve rooms and five baths, through Fred F. French Co, in 1,010 Fifth Ave; Sidney R. Rosenau. in 912 Fifth Ave; Mrs. C. Swenson, in 417 Park Ave; Selected Apartments Service, broker.

Treasury reports disclosed today that about one-fourth of the veterans who received bonus bonds a year ago still are holding them. It was on June 16, 1936, that postmen, greeted by smiling veterans, started handing out the bonds.

The John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company sold for cash over a first mortgage of $22,500 the twelve-family house at 352-4 East Forty-fifth Street, Brooklyn, to the Marnet Management Corporation. Harry G. Gebhard, Inc., was the broker.
Jules Wareck, former sales manager of the cutting division of the Susquehanna Silk Mills, will join Marshall Field Co. on July 1 to assist in the development of the rayon and silk departments.
The fourth annual exhibit of students' work presented by the Art Division of the WPA-Adult Education Program of the Board of Education is on view at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

Miss Leah Henriette Messenger, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Manning Messenger of Mountainside, N. J., was married here tonight in the Westfield Presbyterian Church to Wilbur Melvin Crook, son of Mr. and Mrs. Wilbur F. Crook of Montclair, N. J. The ceremony was performed by the rector, the Rev. Dr. William McKinney.

Transfers and Assignments LIEUTENANTS-John T. Keudell, Grand Central Parkway Pct., designated as acting captain. Assignment to desk duty discontinued. Albert Douglas, from Juvenile Aid Bureau to Grand Central Parkway Pct., assigned to desk duty.

Arthur Calnan, reporter for The Associated Press in New York, was killed instantly early this morning when the automobile he was driving crashed into a stone wall after leaving the highway near here. He was about 35 years old.
The marriage of Miss Helen Douglas Love to William Dowd Scranton of New Haven, Conn., took place yesterday afternoon at her home here. Dr. Malcolm Dana of the Yale Divinity School officiated.

The Resettlement Administration said today it was gratified at the ability of the Workers Aim Cooperative Association to obtain private funds for financing the industrial program of Jersey Homesteads.

From well-informed circles this correspondent has learned the nature of the disease affecting the Dowager Queen Marie. In March of this year, after a medical examination, it was suggested that she suffered from an ulcer, but no definite diagnosis resulted. X-ray examinations also were inconclusive.

The ten-second count in boxing, as old as the game itself, will be swept out the window for the first time in heavyweight championship competition when James J. Braddock defends his title against Joe Louis in Comiskey Park here next Tuesday night.

A three-day conference between President Roosevelt and almost all Democratic members of Congress, designed to heal party wounds, will be held on an island in Chesapeake Bay over the week-end of June 27, the White House announced today.

Chances of. passage of. Governor Murphy's labor relations measure were lessened today when Senator Thomas Burke of the Labor Committee said the committee would not send the bill to the floor before Friday or Monday. Next week is the final week of the session, and the Senate appears certain to make changes that will send the bill back to the House.

The marriage of Miss Margaret Copeland, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. James Copeland of Cloverdale Farm, Peebles, Ohio, to James Crawford Bower Jr., son of Mrs. James Bower of Columbus, Ohio, and the late Mr. Bower, took place here yesterday at noon in the Church of the Transfiguration.

The Pennsylvania Game Commission submits its final report on the amount of game killed in that State in 1935, with some figures on the 1936 season. These supersede a report announced earlier in the year.

Electric power production increased last week, but the daily average declined more than seasonally, so that the adjusted index receded to 107.2 from 108.0. It was 101.0 for the week ended June 13, 1936.

Mr. and Mrs. Charles S. Sutherland of Roland Park have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Edith Marion Sutherland, to Dr. Leonard Chapman Drake, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter C. Drake of Georgia.

Philip Murray, head of the Steel Workers Organizing Committee, arrived here tonight from Pittsburgh and revealed that he had an appointment for tomorrow with Secretary Perkins to discuss the steel strike situation.

Resuming the stand in the United States District Court here today as an expert witness for five railroads in their suit for a permanent injunction restructing New Jersey from allegdly excessive taxes,

Possible stoppage of production in the coat and suit industry, due to the failure of manufacturers and jobbers and the union to agree on a new labor contract, has not caused heavy advance buying for August sales or initial Fall delivery, it was reported here yesterday.
Frank Pearce and Harry Smythe, veteran twirlers, hooked up in a mound duel tonight, Smythe of Montreal giving Syracuse only three hits, but losing, 1 to 0.

Leading from flagfall to finish, Yancey Christmas's Rough Time scored his third victory of the year in the six furlongs of the Commonwealth Handicap, feature at Suffolk Downs today. He was well supported and paid $6.40 for $2 in the mutuels.
A sudden rain storm, preceded by a strong wind, deprived the Dodgers of the doubtful pleasure of tangling with the Reds tonight in their one scheduled arclight game of the season.

Original listing applications have been approved by the New York Curb Exchange for 43,002 shares of Cosden Petroleum Corporation 5 per cent convertible preferred stock, $50 par value; 306,657 shares of Cosden Petroleum Corporation common stock, $1 par value, with permission to list 860,649 additional common shares on official notice of issuance;
Miss Helen Hicks and Miss Babe Didrikson kept alive their scheme to meet in the final of the women's Western open golf title tournament today at the Beverly Country Club.

The race not always going to the swift, nor the knockout to the fellow landing the most blows, it remained for the Giants to perform with rare efficiency today as they polished off an exceedingly muscular but inept Pirate band in the second game of the series, to win by 5 to 4.

Miss Janet Haines, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. S. Earle Haines of Earlsie, Merion, was married this afternoon to J. M. Russel Wilson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Fred J. Wilson, also of Merion. The Rev. C. E. Snowden performed the ceremony in the Memorial Church of St. Paul, Overbrook.
Dr. Carl Fischer of Woodbury, N. J., national intercollegiate champion fifteen years ago, reached the quarter-final round of the Delaware State tennis championship today.

The Yale. Dramatic Association tonight presented three one-act plays in the University Theatre, departing from tradition, which accords the undergraduate actors a single play given once or twice during commencement week.

Jockey Jimmy Stout brought off a triple at Aqueduct yesterday, including both of the features, for his most successful day of the meeting. J. D. Norris's Danger Point was strongly handled by Stout to take the Cynosure Handicap without trouble, and the blond lad also had the leg up on the Arden Farms' Quel Jeu to be best in the secondary event..

Although business continued small, the stock market here made a good recovery today and most sections were firm. Gilt-edge issues were better and among the foreign loans, German bonds advanced. International issues made headway;...

Trial of a stockholders' suit to recover $34,284,710 from the Atlas Corporation and several former officers and directors of the Securities Allied Corporation was started yesterday before Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook without a jury. The Atlas Corporation is now the principal stockholder of Securities Allied.
Governor Murphy told a University of Michigan centennial observance audience today that industrial peace "can and will be achieved" in Michigan.

The first of a series of dinners to advance the $10,000,000 ten-year development program of the American Museum of. Natural History was given at the museum last night by 'F. Trubee Davison, president, and the trustees.

Charles F. Gill, son of Charles Otis Gill, who was captain of the Yale football team in 1889, has been appointed instructor in English and history and assistant in athletics at the Milford School for next year, Dr. Paul D. Shafer, the headmaster, said today.
Mrs. Lynford M. Dickinson of this city and Noroton, Conn., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Lynda L. Dickinson, to Richard L. Linkroum.

The hope that "not too many dishonest" taxpayers would be revealed by the tax-evasion inquiry was expressed today by Chairman Doughton as the joint Congressional committee prepared to hear Secretary Morgenthau tomorrow morning at its first hearing.

The marriage of Miss Virginia Warder, daughter of Frank H. Warder of 370 Riverside Drive and the late Mrs. Warder, to Frank R. Jackie of this city and Spring Lake, N. J., took place here yesterday morning in the Church of Notre Dame.

Mrs. Norman Lack of Wilmington, Del., failed today in her quest for a second women's golf championship of Pennsylvania. The former Miss Frances Williams, medalist in the tournament, was defeated in the second round by Mrs. W. G. Boggs, Western Pennsylvania district champion from the Pittsburgh Field Club. 4 and 2.

Representatives of the three districts comprising the metropolitan golf area tied for the medal in today's qualifying round of the thirtyseventh annual amateur championship of the area at the Metropolis Country Club, stamping ground of Paul Runyan.

Charles Partridge will speak on "Appraising for Condemnation and Certiorari Proceedings and Court Testimony" at the meeting of the Brooklyn Real Estate Board tonight at the Brooklyn Club, 131 Remsen Street.

General Sessions Judge Freschi, on the recommendation of Robert S. Rubin, Special Assistant District Attorney in the 1934 investigation of defunct title mortgage companies, dismissed yesterday bail of $2,500 each on which eight former directors and members of the executive committee of the defunct New York Title and Mortgage Company were awaiting trial on a misdemeanor indictment.

Announcement was made here last night of the death yesterday, after a long illness, in St. Vincent's Hospital, Los Angeles, of Paul F. Burger of the writing staff of Twentieth Century-Fox Films. He was 46 years old. Before writing for the films he had been sales production manager for Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, and assistant to the president of United Artists.

Paul Leslie, author of "Satyr," presented at the Shaftesbury Theatre tonight by Martin Jones and William Mollison, handles as discreetly as British stage laws will allow, but with undeniable power, his grim theme of sexual and homicidal mania.

Madison Square Garden will open its doors to Summer boxing tonight, with a program headed by Bobby Pacho of Los Angeles and Baby Salvy Saban of Greenwich Village. These welterweight rivals, who battled to a draw two months ago in what was one of the best fights of the Winter season, will travel over the ten-round route.

THE FRONT--Rebel shells terrorized Bilbao and many persons were buried in the wreckage of their homes. Street barriers were raised as the Insurgents tightened their net about the city. The Santander road, the main exit to the west, was cut. A Basque counter-attack was repulsed. Page 1.

After hearing objections from representatives of the Socialist and Communist parties, Mayor La Guardia signed yesterday the four tax bills comprising the city's $71,000,000 emergency relief taxing program and thereby extended them for another year from July 1.
Developments on the Ohio front in the steel strike situation today assumed a critical character as leading company officials declined to confer with Governor Martin L. Davey tomorrow.
The Browns came from behind today to win their second straight game from the Athletics, 3 to 2, and advance to within one game of the seventh place Mackmen.

A bus loaded with workers from Long Island plants of the Hoffman Beverage Company and six delivery trucks ran the gauntlet of strikers and sympathizers surrounding the company's plant here this afternoon, resulting in the injury of five of the bus occupants and the damaging of several of the trucks in a score of collisions with other vehicles.
Mr. and Mrs. Willard B. Eddy of Rochester have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Carolyn Eddy, to Rene Constantin of New York and Geneva, Switzerland.

The United States is about to enter into an era of prosperity compared to which the boom days of early 1929 will seem like hard times, Dr. Ralph E. Flanders, engineer, declared last night in an address to the 166 members of the graduating class of the Brooklyn Polytechnic Institute at the college commencement held at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. More than 2,000 persons attended.
Out of the turmoil of last night's debate in the Chamber of Deputies Premier Leon Blum's government emerged at 6:15 this morning victorious but indubitably battered.

Princeton University's 190th commencement week will begin informally tomorrow afternoon with the arrival of the advance guard of some 3,000 alumni, including representatives of nearly sixty Princeton classes, for the annual alumni week-end.
A steeplechase race, to be known as the Noel Laing Memorial, will be run for the first time at the Montpelier, Va., meeting late in November, it was announced yesterday. The event is the
Yeshiva College will award forty- Ye seven degrees at its sixth annual commencement exercises this afternoon in the auditorium of the college at Amsterdam Avenue and 186th Street.

Willard Sands, beloved husband of Madie and devoted son of Moses S. and the late Theresa Sands Appel and loving nephew of Anna Sands Phillips. Funeral service at Universal Funeral Chapel, 597 Lexington Ave., on Thursday, June 17, at 2:30 P. M. Internient private. Denver (Col.) papers please copy.

Four million hoboes "bumming" their way on freight trains in the United States last year stole $1,700,000 of railroad property, T. F. Pratt, chief of police of the Chicago, Burlington Quincy Railroad, said today at the convention of maintenance and freight men's division of the Association of American Railroads.

Figures showing a declining birth rate and a rising death rate in the United States were made public today by Secretary Roper, who stated that for the second consecutive year the birth rate dropped, the record for 1936 being only one-tenth of a point above the all-time low of 16.5 a thousand of population in 1933.
The Interstate Commerce Commission decided late today to discontinue until Sept. 20 its hearing on a proposed reorganization of the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific Railway.

Miss Helen Clayton Mathews, daughter of Mrs. William Gordon Mathews, was married here today to Taylor Langston Palmer, son of Mrs. T. O. Palmer of Suffolk, Va. The ceremony was performed at Kanawha Presbyterian Church by the Rev. Dr. R. H. Merrill.

Fairplay, an 18-to-1 chance owned by R. Middlemas, responded to the whip in a strong stretch drive today to snatch victory in the Royal Hunt Cup, feature of the second day of racing at Ascot. by a neck from H. G. Blagrave's Couvert.
The field in the women's New York State championship narrowed down to eight survivors yesterday at the Jackson Heights Tennis Club with the favorites coming through in every instance.

Paul T. Cherington, partner in Cherington Roper, was elected president of the Society for the Advancement of Management at its meeting at the Metals and Plastics Bureau, 45 Rockefeller Plaza, last night. Mrs. B. R. McClaskey,
Change in Telephone Number The number of the direct line telephone in the quarters of the 9th Battalton, has been changed from Longacre 5-5544 to Circle 6-6737.

Manhattan Alterations 29th St, 253 to 257 W: to three 1-story stores; Mountco Realty Corp. premises, owner; Samuel Roth, architect; cost, $25,000. 121st St, 235 E; to 4-story tenement and stores; Alberto Nicoletti, 288 Mulberry St, owner; Emil Koeppel, architect; cost, $7,000.

Edward H. T. Robinson, 39 years old, a newspaper man who fought with T. E. Lawrence in Arabia, today was sentenced to three months at hard labor for converting to his own use manuscripts and photographs he had borrowed from Colonel Lawrence's brother in writing the biography of the World War leader.

Another day of favorable weather permitted long workouts for the crews preparing for Tuesday's intercollegiate regatta. The only time trial was that of California's varsity, clocked in the announced time of 21:20 by Coach Ky Ebright. Other crews went through routine workouts with speed tests, scheduled for tomorrow or Friday.

Consumption of crude rubber by manufacturers in the United States in May amounted to 51,733 long tons, compared with 51,797 in April and 50,612 in May, 1936, according to the Rubber Manufacturers Assooiation, Inc.

The Third Avenue Railway Company announced yesterday that it had deposited with the City Bank Farmers Trust Company the interest due on July 1 on the first mortgage 5 per cent fifty-year bonds of the Third Avenue Railroad Company, due July 1, 1937.

President Roosevelt vetoed today a Senate bill to give to the Court of Claims authority to hear and decide a claim of more than $700,000 damages sought by Robert A. Watson of New York as a result of importation in 1920 of 3,500 tons of sugar from Argentina.

A man who identified himself as a Federal agent investigating the disappearance of Mrs. William H. Parsons yesterday questioned a salesgirl at the stationery counter in the F. W. Woolworth Store, Patchogue, it was learned today, indicating that the paper on which a $25,000 ransom note was written may have been traced to the 5-and-10 chain.

Charles J. Ferber was elected Grand Chief Ranger of the State Division of the Foresters of America yesterday at the close of the annual Grand Court convention, attended by 300 delegates, at the Hotel Half Moon, Coney Island.

In a report filed yesterday by three appraisers before John E. Joyce, Federal referee, the 239 gasoline service stations of the WarnerQuinlan Company, which is in reorganization proceedings, were valued at $3,479,015.

Ernest T. Weir, chairman of the board of the National Steel Corporation, last year was paid $200,120 by that corporation, according to its annual report to the Securities and Exchange Commission. George R. Fink, president, drew $200,100 and Thomas E. Millsop, president of subsidiaries, was paid $60,000.

Mrs. Emma Guffey Miller, national committeewoman of Pennsylvania, in an address at the final session of the two-day regional conference of Democratic women here this afternoon, praised administration leaders for their attitude toward women on patronage, criticized the Supreme Court as discriminatory and endorsed the equal rights amendment.

Miss Marjorie Conklin, daughter of Mrs. John Percy Conklin of Brooklyn and the late Mr. Conklin, was married yesterday to Willis Mott Moore Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Willis Mott Moore, also of Brooklyn.

The National Orchestral Association and the National Association for American Composers and Condoctors will collaborate next season in a plan to present fifteen new compositions by American composers, it was announced yesterday.

Mayor Daniel A. Knaggs tonight recalled the special policemen who broke up a picket line of the Steel Workers Organizing Committee at the Newton Steel Company plant here. They were ordered to City Hall and laid down their arms.

The First National Bank of Boston yesterday purchased a new issue of $300,000 of revenue notes of the City of Worcester, Mass., on a 0.57 per cent interest basis. The notes will be dated June 18, 1937, and become payable on April 20 and June 10, 1938.

Five of the largest shipyards affected by the strike of the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipyard Workers in Brooklyn, Staten Island and Hoboken were ordered closed temporarily by their managements yesterday. Twelve other shipyards

Canada will own 24 per cent of the transatlantic air service on which experimental flying will begin after June 24, C. D. Howe, Minister of Transport, told the Engineering Institute of Canada here today.

Forging to the front with a one-two sweep in the second of the four races sailed today, Yale gained the lead in the tenth annual championships of the Intercollegiate Yacht Racing Association and held on with true bulldog tenacity through a long day on Long Island Sound.
George J. Trivers of Chicago became today the second Negro midship man at the Naval Academy in more than fifty years.

King Gustaf V, Europe's oldest reigning sovereign, celebrated his seventy-ninth birthday today with a game of tennis. He observed the anniversary quietly at Tullgarn Palace, his Summer residence, while guns boomed salutes in Sweden's beflagged capital.

Preservation of the democratic ideal, birthright of every American, is the special obligation and privilege of the men and women of this generation, Senator Joseph C. O'Mahoney of Wyoming told the graduating class of the Catholic University today.

The Free State's electorate battle opened in earnest tonight when Eamon de Valera, President of the Executive Council, faced an immense gathering in O'Connell Street, Dublin, while William T. Cosgrave, Opposition leader, addressed a big meeting at Kilkenny, his old constituency.

The strikes which have affected four major independent steel companies are having a "minimum" of influence on the steel markets, according to The Iron Age. Production of steel i??gots, however, is slightly lower this week, being estimated at 77 per cent, against 78 last week.

Passenger revenues of the Baltimore Ohio Railroad continue to show about the same percentage of gain realized since a short time after the reduction of passenger fares in the East a year ago, Daniel Willard, president, said yesterday.

Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, Minister of Economics and president of the Reichsbank, addressing a group of Austrian industrialists here today, said that despite the enormous handicaps imposed by the treaties of Versailles and St. Germain Germany
The best known of our popular-priced restaurant companies has gone into a still lower price field with a chain of self-service cafes where
Nathan Andrews, a right-hander obtained from the Cardinals, turned in a five-hit shut-out performance against Baltimore tonight, and enabled the Rochester Red Wings to take a 3-to-0 decision.

Luigi Criscuolo, chairman of the committee of common stockholders of the Panhandle Producing and Refining Company, yesterday sent a letter to important holders informing them the committee opposed the reorganization plan filed by the company on June 15.

Bryant Ave (11-2999), e s. 300 ft s of Jennings St, 50x100; New York Trust Co, trustee, to Herver Realty Corp, 364 E 149th St; mtg $40,000. Colden Ave (16-4446), w s, 250 ft s of Allerton Ave, 50x100; Theresa Caprogrosso to Migjos Realty Corp, 2,565 Radcliff Ave.

A proposal is being pushed for the erection of a radio broadcasting station to be owned and operated by the government and to be devoted for the most part to broadcasting shortwave programs from this country to Central and South America.
Buffalo scored a clean sweep in its two-game series with the Jersey City Giants today, winning behind with the seven-hit pitching of Truett Sewell, 3 to 2.
Jeanette MacDonald and Gene Raymond were married tonight in the most spectacular wedding in Hollywood history, attended by more than 1,000 motion picture notables. She is 30 ears old. He is 29.

In reply to a question concerning the position taken by the independent steel producers in the present strike, President ROOSEVELT has expressed the opinion that companies which are willing to make oral agreements with trade unions should put these agreements in writing. There is nothing in

BERLIN, June 16.--Dr. Wilhelm Frick, the Minister of the Interior, has issued a decree making it a crime to contribute money to the Confessional Synods or any other organization within the Protestant Church not specifically approved by Hanns Kerrl, the Minister for Church Affairs.

The Internal Revenue Bureau estimated today that $469,841,709 in income taxes had been received by Internal Revenue collectors from June 1 to 15, as part of the second quarterly installment due this month.
Fifteen creditors to whom Samuel Insull had owed $19,089,000 received $750,000 today under an order entered by Judge Cornelius J. Harrington of the Cook County Circuit Court.

Funeral services for George F. Baker, chairman of the board of the First National Bank of New York, held this afternoon at Viking's Cove, his home at Peacock Point, were attended by more than 500 relatives, friends and business associates.

Morgan J. O'Brien, former Preiding Justice of the Appellate Di?ision of the Supreme Court, and ?prominent Catholic layman, died ?t 10:30 o'clock last night at his evidence, 555 Park Avenue, of Pneumonia, after a two weeks' illless. He was 85 years old.

Wheat made a strong start and a tame finish today. Continued drought in parts of the Canadian Northwest and unexpected strength in Liverpool was responsible for an upturn of around 1 cent a bushel in the early trading. The outside trade, however,
Diplomas will be awarded to nineteen members of the senior class at the 171st annual commencement exercises of the Rutgers Preparatory School in Kirkpatrick Chapel here tomorrow.

Rug buyers visiting the wholesale market. here yesterday said they were resigned to the fact that Fall floor coverings prices will advance about 8 to 10 per cent as indicated by the Charles P. Cochrane Company's announcement on Tuesday. Although they concede

Machinery will be set in motion to change the name of the John F. Ahearn School at 293 East Broadway because a political club of the same name, with headquarters directly opposite, has attempted to "annex" the school, James Marshall, vice president of the Board of Education, disclosed yesterday.

Announcement has been made by Mrs. Oscar E. Miles of Columbus, Ohio, of the engagement of her daughter, Miss Elizabeth Adair Miles, to Edward Edgerton Hart, son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Purple Hart-of this city.
Tear gas was used by police early today, in the seventeenth day of the hotel strike, to disperse about 2,000 strikers and sympathizers after windows had been broken in downtown hotels.

Committees representing the railroads and fourteen unions and brotherhoods adjourned their wage conference shortly after noon today without reaching an agreement. The unions are seeking an hourly increase of 20 cents, which the roads assert will mean an annual cost to them of $400.000.000.

Raymond M. Hicks, treasurer of the International Mercantile Marine Company, was elected a director of the company yesterday, P. A. S. Franklin, chairman of the board, announced. Mr. Hicks has been associated with American shipping since 1919.

Ray J. Reigeluth, president of the board of trustees of the Hopkins Grammar School, which is fortyone years older than Yale University, will award diplomas in Latin at the commencement tomorrow. The diplomas will be received by the twenty-six candidates with a formal "tibi gratias ago."
Maxie Berger, Montreal lightweight, received the decision over Johnny Morro, the Bronx, in the feature bout of ten rounds at Dyckman Oval last night.

THE Giants now have Wally Berger, who should and probably will add some punch to the team. As he shed his Boston uniform Wally was hitting a mild .274, but there is no need for Horace Stoneham, his new employer, to worry about that. Berger always gets better as the season goes along.

The Internal Revenue rule to day that unemployment compensation taxes paid by employers for 1936 under State Social Security laws which had not been approved by the Social Security Board by Dec. 31, 1936, could be credited against Federal unemployment taxes.

A first mortgage loan of $320,000 has been placed with a life insurance company by Brooks, Harvey Co. for the 231 East Seventy-sixth Corporation, Sidney J. Bernstein, president, on the eight-story apartment house being erected at 231-3 East Seventy-sixth Street.

Paint shipments from continental United States in April exceeded 500,000 gallons, valued at nearly $1,000,000, the Chemical Division of the Department of Commerce announced today. Only nine countries in the

Activity in Westchester real estate was featured yesterday by the sale of an entire blockfront for business use in White Plains. The Bark Realty Corporation, operators, purchased the triangular plot fronting 220.5 feet on Mamaroneck Avenue, between Schuyler Place and South Broadway, from Stuart D. Platt.

Police were assigned tonight to guard the home of Walter-J. Mooney, president of the picketed Ballston-Stillwater Knitting Company, after he reported receipt of two anonymous telephone calls threatening his life.

Temple's aggressive baseball team brought its season to a successful close today on University Field by halting the Princeton nine, 2-1. The victory was the sixth straight for the Owls and their thirteenth of the campaign.
W. C. Engel, vice president and general manager of the Farmers National Grain Corporation, announced today that operations of the corporation in the Pacific Northwest would cease on June 30.
Colonel John J. Grimley, Deputy Markets Commissioner, was appointed yesterday as a Deputy Commissioner in the Hospitals Department at a $1,000 increase in salary. Colonel Grimley fills the

Testimony in the Parker conspiracy trial was finished today and the case was adjourned until next Tuesday when attorneys will make their addresses to the jury. The case will be given to the jury of eight women and four men on Wednesday, in the ninth week of the trial.

Details of a campaign in the Dersim region, one of the most secret military operations in history, in which 30,000 Turkish troops and a fleet of airplanes were required to subdue an insurrection in an almost inaccessible region, were disclosed today.

The combination of a sharp recovery in Liverpool and unwanted rains over a large area west of the Mississippi River offset the influence of easier outside markets, and as a result prices on the Cotton Exchange gained 4 to 10 points yesterday. At one time, foreign buying

The marriage of Miss Jean Graves, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene S. Graves of this city, to Lieutenant Andrew Jackson Lynch, U. S. A., son of Judge and Mrs. Frank L. Lynch of Winchester, Tenn., took place here tonight in the Central Congregational Church. The Rev. Dr. Arthur Howe Bradford performed the ceremony.

Fordham University conferred three honorary degrees and degrees in course on 673 students yesterday at its ninety-second commencement at the quadrangle on the campus. More than 6,000 persons attended the exercises, at which Cardinal Hayes presided.

Miss Harriet Goff Jackson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. S. Eugene Jackson of Providence, R. I., was married yesterday afternoon to Bernard E. Pollak Jr., son of Mrs. Frances M. Pollak and Bernard E. Pollak of New York, in Trinity Church, Broadway at Wall Street, by the Rev. Frederick S. Fleming.

The Fall season will show retail sales running about 8 per cent gait ahead of last Fall and, while some communities will make a better or worse showing, the New York area will equal this average, B. Earl Puckett, president of Allied Stores Corporation, predicted last night at a dinner meeting of the Metropolitan Controllers Association at the Roger Smith Restaurant, 40 East Forty-first Street.

104TH ST, 138 W. s s, 32.8X100.11X irreg; Genradel Corp., Jehiel R. Elyachar, President, to New York Savings Bank: pm mtg. $20.000. SAME PROPERTY, same to same; building loan, $29,000. 145TH ST. 506 W, 29x99.11; Len Green to Central Hanover Bank Trust Co.: p m mtg, 5 years 31/2-41/2 percent, $22,000.

Miss Helene Lillian Solomon, daughter of Mrs. Myer Solomon of 353 Park Avenue, was married to William E. Arnstein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leo Arnstein of New York and Dobbs Ferry, yesterday afternoon at the Ambassador by Judge Irving Lehman of the Court of Appeals.

Arthur Williams, 38-year-old. assistant steward on the FurnessBermuda liner. Monarch of Bermuda was shot and critically wounded about 11 o'clock last night in Fifty-fifth Street ne ar Tenth Avenue when he fought two men who attempted to rob him.

The New Jersey Title Guarantee and Trust Company has sold the Sunshine Apartments, a five-story brick building at 795 Park Avenue, on the corner of Twenty-third Street, West New York, N. J., to Sunshine Holding Company, which will hold the parcel for investment.

In the ruins of the Indian village, of Awatovi, in Northern Arizona, once a mighty pueblo of the Hopi tribe, Harvard archaeologists have found vital links for reconstructing the obscure story of the rise of America's greatest aboriginal civi-lization and the effects of the first impact with the white man.

Improved conditions in the lowerprice dress field are fairly well sustained, and volume manufacturers reported yesterday that orders are running slightly ahead of last year. Dark sheers and washable pastel or white synthetics in prints or solid colors account for the bulk of business.
The Rev. Henry Macbeth, rector emeritus of St. Paul's Episcopal Church, Tivoli, N. '., died yesterday at his home in Bethel, Conn., at the age of 78, according to word received here last night.

The Foreign Bondholders Protective Council, Inc., announced yesterday the receipt of a letter dated May 18, 1937, from the Mayor of Carlsbad, Czechoslovakia, stating that the municipality would send to its fiscal agents here sufficient funds to cover the balance due on the January, 1935, coupons.

Mrs. Helen Tiernan, 25-year-old blonde widow of New York, who is on trial in the Suffolk County Supreme Court here before Justice James T. Hallinan on the charge of murdering her 7-year-old daughter, Helen, in the Brookhaven wooden on May 15, was visibly affected this afternoon when her father, George Smith, 63, also of New York, was brought into the court room.

A garden party and fashion show were held yesterday afternoon in the Skyline Cafe of the Hotel Gramercy Park as a benefit for the Vacation Fund of the Charity Organization Society. The event was the formal opening of the cafe for the season.

The French liner Normandie sailed yesterday for Southampton and Havre with nearly 1,600 passengers, including 731 in tourist class, the largest number ever carried by the Normandie in this class, according to officials.

The third major gift of real property by wealthy persons to the Long Island State Park system in recent years was announced yesterday When the Long Island State Park Commission made public an offer by William K. Vanderbilt to give the right of way of the Motor Parkway to five public agencies involved.

Max Ams, Inc., manufacturer of t preserves, has acquired the business of the Pittsburgh Importing and Manufacturing Company, Pittsburg, manufacturer of "Simon Fischer" Levkar and Povidla, it was announced yesterday.

Indiana, undefeated in its brief tour of the Eastern college fields, conquered Harvard by 5-3 at Soldiers Field today. Ed Ingalls pitched brilliantly at times, but his mates faltered at critical moments, fielding faults accounting for three runs.
The annual flower show of the Garden Club of Larchmont opened today at the Larchmont Avenue Church House here. The Colonial theme predominated in the artistic arrangement classes.
The All-America lacrosse team, which will sail for England tomorrow, triumphed over the Crescent Athletic Club, 10 to 6, under the floodlights at Randalls Island Stadium last night.

Doubt as to the wisdom of removing tonsils and adenoids in most cases was expressed at the ninety-third convention of the American Institute of Homeopathy today by Dr. Wilfred Earle Allyn of Cleveland.

SLAVE SHIP, from a story by William Faulkner based on the novel, "The Last Slaver," by George S. King; screen play by Sam Hellman, Lamar Trotti and Gladys Lehman; directed by Tay Garnett; produced by Nunnally Johnson for Twentieth Century-Fox. At the Rivoli.

Members of the United States Ryder Cup team, hoping that an American ship would prove a good omen, sailed yesterday for England aboard the United States liner Manhattan to defend the laurels in the international golf matches to be played June 29 and 30.

The Bowery Savings Bank sold to an operator the five-story tenement house for ten families at 71 East 114th Street, assessed at $18,500 and occupying a lot 25 by 100 feet. The deal was arranged for cash by Samuel Hurwitz, broker, who also sold for the Church of the Crucifixion the two five-story tenements at 205207 West 142d Street to David Mendelsohn of Brookline, Mass.

Emory Morse of Laurence M. Marks Co., Phillip Brown of C. D. Barney Co. and Gustave Levy of Goldman Sachs Co. have been chosen to represent the Corporation Bond Traders Club of New York against teams of the Philadelphia and Boston bond clubs at the Westchester Country Club on Friday.

Headed by John J. McHugh, the country's premier track starter whose little red cap has been a familiar sight at IC4A meets for three decades, a list of thirty-three officials for the Princeton track meet Saturday was announced today by Asa S. Bushnell, director of the meet.
