Miss Helen Shoemaker Price, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thornton W. Price of Plainfield, was married to Anthony A. Belser Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony A. Belser, also of this place, this afternoon at the Friends' Meeting House here.

The conduct of week-end visitors to Camp Siegfried, Nazi colony at Yaphank, was assailed today before the Brookhaven Town Board by Justice of the Peace Gustave Neuss of Yaphank, who urged that drastic methods be used to curb the activities which be termed "disordely."

The Bureau of Internal Revenue decided today to appeal from a Board of Tax Appeals ruling that the General Motors Corporation was not deficient by $15,342,369 in its 1926 income, and urged the Department of Justice to file a plea in the District of Columbia Court of Appeals.

Judge Griffith ordered the Republic Steel Company today to bring into court any records showing how much had been spent for machine guns, tear gas, "labor spies, private detective. agencies and company unions." He ruled at the start of

Vladimir Golschmann, conductor of the St. Louis Symphony Orchestra, who will direct the first fortnight of the Philharmonic-Symphony concerts at the Lewisohn Stadium beginning next Wednesday night, will arrive today from Paris.

A 101gun salute this morning told Sofia of the long awaited birth of an heir to the throne-Queen Joanna gave birth to a son at 5:45 o'clock. Provincial garrisons received the news by telephone and soon guns were booming throughout the land. Mother and son are doing well.

Preliminary figures on deliveries of sugar for consumption by refiners, beet sugar companies and importers of direct-consumption sugar during May were made public today by the Sugar Section of the Agricultural Adjustment Administration.

Miss Louise Jenkins Hall, daughter of Mrs. Gilbert Weld Goodridge, was married to Robert Phillips Ellis, son of Harry B. Ellis of Springfield, Mass., at her home here today. The Rev. Fred Hoskins of the United Congregational Church officiated.

The revised Barkley bill to regulate trust indentures was endorsed as "workable, practical and livable" by representatives of the nation's banks in testimony before the Senate Banking and Currency Committee in Washington on Tuesday.

A Spanish Government plan for a major aerial counter-offensive was disclosed today by General Jose Miaja, Madrid defense chief, in an interview with the Madrid correspondent of the Perpignan newspaper Independent.

Patrolman Charles Schubert, 39 years old, of the Carnarsie precinct, Brooklyn, committed suicide at 10:30 A. M. yesterday, according to the police, by firing a bullet from his service revolver into his right temple in a bedroom in his home, 215 St. Nicholas Avenue, Brooklyn.

Miss Helen Carter, daughter of Mrs. Henry Clinton Carter of this city and the late Mr. Carter, was married yesterday afternoon to Lionel Alexander Mohnkern of Pittsburgh, son of M. MacAllister Mohnkern of Oswego, N. Y., and the late Mrs. Mohnkern.

The marriage of Miss Pauline Winslow Warren, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Chester Warren of 157 East Fifty-seventh Street, and Potter d'Orsay Palmer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Honore Palmer of Chicago, whose engagement was announced on Tuesday, took place yesterday afternoon in Mamaroneck, N. Y.

Supreme Court Justice James C. Cropsey died at 7:30 o'clock last night in the Brooklyn Hospital, where he had been a patient for a fortnight and was twice operated on for a glandular ailment. His condition had been critical for several days and yesterday morning a serum brought from Johns Hopkils Hospital, Baltimore, by airplane, was administered to him. He was 64 years old.

Yale has begun the application of modern linguistic methods to Chinese and related languages by the appointment of Dr. Fang-Kuei Li, of the Academia Sinica, Nanking, China, as visiting Professor of Chinese Linguistics. It was announced today that he will become a member of the Department of Oriental Studies in the Yale Graduate School, which trains the scholars

An honorary degree of Doctor of Laws was conferred upon Mrs. Eleanor Roosevelt, wife of the President, by the John Marshall College of Law here this afternoon at the fifth annual commencement exercises held in the State Normal School Auditorium.
Close-of-play scores in first-class English cricket matches started today follow: Middlesex, 188 (Robins 51, Voce six for 41): Nottinghamshire, six for no wickets; at Lord's.

Few $20,000-a-year business executives ever read a worthwhile book, Paul T. Cherington, former Professor of Marketing at Harvard University, declared at 'the Special Libraries Association's twenty-ninth annual conference: yesterday at the Hotel Roosevelt.
The four planes of the Soviet North Pole Expedition that installed four explorers on a drifting ice floe for a planes of the Soviet North Pole exseas landed at Amderma today enroute to Moscow.

Funeral services for Philip Liberman, Miami Beach banker and retired New York merchant, were held yesterday in the Riverside Chapel, Amsterdam Avenue and Seventy-sixth Street. Dr. Leo Jung of the Jewish Center officiated.

Eight hundred C. I. O. members held the Buffalo plant of the Fisher Body Company today despite the fact that company officials had declared a sit-down strike settled. The strike was called yesterday in protest against the discharge of a woman employee.
A sentence of death having been passed on Welwel Sczezerbowski, 18 years old, who was found guilty today of the murder of a policeman, the defense took an appeal. A milder penalty had been expected.

Germany and Italy have returned to the NonIntervention Committee and have resumed their former duties in the naval patrol of the Spanish coast. This is the first result of the fourpower naval agreement and has been effected without waiting for the acceptance of its conditions by the rival Spanish governments.

A protest against the death sentences imposed in Germany on Adolf Rembt and Robert Stamm, former labor leaders, and the life sentence of Max Maddalena was cabled today to Chancellor Adolf Hitler by William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor.

Luncheon of the Rotary Club of New York, Hotel. Commodore, 12:15 P. M. "Pioneering," John G. Jones. Luncheon meeting of the New York Young Republican Club, the Lawyers Club, 115 Broadway, 12:45 P. M. "Burlesque and Licenses," Commissioner Paul Moss.

Mrs. Helen Maloney Butler of Rye, wife of William M. Butler; son of the late James Butler, founder of the chain of grocery stores, died today in Mount Kisco Hospital after a month's illness. She was 35 years old.
President Roosevelt announced he would be host over the week-end of June 27 to Democratic members of Congress and other officials and party leaders, on Jefferson Island in Chesapeake Bay.

A complaint against Montgomery Ward Co. was issued today by the National Labor Relations Board, charging that the mail-order house sought to coerce its employes by threatening to cease operations unless they joined a company-sponsored union.

Walter Kidde, president of the New Jersey State Chamber of Commerce, will be the speaker tonight at the seventy-seventh annual commencement exercises of 'Stevens Hoboken Academy, Hoboken, N. J. Robert J. Haggstrom will give the salutatory and Rudolf W. Zillmann the valedictory. Kelley Graham,

Frank C. Hughes, Summer resident here, who sent by parcel post seven loaves and two fishes to nonstriking employes in the Republic Steel Corporation's plant at Warren, Ohio, said today he had received notice that his package had been delivered.

The United States Industrial Alcohol Company of 60 East Fortysecond Street sued the Federal Government yesterday in the United States District Court for recovery of $625,113 additional internal revenue tax, plus interest, charging that it had been "erroneously and illegally assessed and collected" for 1918.
The twentieth anniversary season of the Goldman Band, Dr. Edwin Franko Goldman, director, was started last night at the Central Park Mall before an audience estimated at more than 20,000.

Failure of the Public Service Commission to act upon $7,000,000 of serial debentures of the Buffalo Niagara Electric Corporation at the time that it gave approval to the issue of $17,029,000 of general and refunding mortgage 2 1/2 per cent bonds due in 1967 of the company caused the postponement of the public offering, scheduled for today, of both issues, it was disclosed yesterday.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Ruth Yeaton Power O'Malley of 4 East Ninety-fifth Street, daughter of the Irish landscape painter, Michael Power O'Malley of this city and Dublin, and of Mrs. Ruth Wise Stuart of Alexandria, Va., to James Warner Bellah, also of New York.

Profanity got a dishonorable discharge from the Italian Army today. General Alberto Pariani, UnderSecretary of War, issued a decree squelching cursing in the ranks and started measures to enforce his orders.

Atract comprising 100 lots in the Post Boulevard section has been acquired by the Post Boulevard Realty Company from Jerry and Elsie Bartow for immediate development. The purchasers plan to erect fifty one-family dwellings, each house to occupy two lots.

Mrs. Beulah Woolard Nash, 18-year-old wife of Ensign Charles A. Nash Jr., whose commission was revoked today because he married her prior to his graduation from the Naval Academy on June 3, announced tonight she plans to have the marriage annulled or sue for divorce. Mrs. Nash is prominent in Norfolk, Va., society. Mr. Nash, who is 22,

Seizing on the occasion of the annual tournament of the New York Retail Dry Goods Association for the best brand of golf he has unfurled all season, Sidney Reisman won low net honors at the Century Country Club today and gave to Bloomingdale Brothers possession of the S. F. Rothschild Memorial Trophy.
A Colonial-style house on Gerrish Lane, New Canaan, Conn., has been sold by George N. McKendry to Wells Murphy, a member of C. H. Murphy Co., New York stock brokers, through Ray E. Jarvis.

Bernard Jacoby and Emmet Steele, first and second seeded players respectively, advanced to the semifinal round of the first annual metropolitan interscholastic tennis tournament by scoring quarter-final victories on the clay courts of Fordham University yesterday.

Paul Smith, 45 years old, of 105 West Ninety-fifth Street, Manhattan, who pleaded guilty in Federal court, Brooklyn, to passing counterfeit $10 Federal Reserve notes in Nassau County, was sentenced yesterday by Judge Robert A. Inch to five years in prison and fined $600.
The Panama-Colombia Border Commission reported today it had discovered the ruins of the lost city of Santa Maria la Antigua del Darien, believed to be the oldest city in the New World.

A sweeping tax of 5 per cent on business profits over ??2,000 a year was submitted to the House of Commons tonight by Sir John Simon, Chancellor of the Exchequer, in an effort to meet the gigantic cost of Great Britain's rearmament program.
Mayor of Johnstown called on Roosevelt to "remove the murderous element" from the city while S. W. O. C. head demanded a vote of 80,000 Bethlehem workers. Page 1.
Harvard's crews held the spotlight today in the training on the Thames for the renewal of the ancient Harvard-Yale regatta on Friday, June 25. Early this evening, in the face
A mutiny has broken out aboard the Spanish Loyalist destroyer Ciscar, which is one of a group of Spanish Government ships now anchored here after having brought refugees from Bilbao.
Jesse (Pop) Haines, the "grand old man of baseball," who will be 44 years old next month, relieved the harassed Lon Warneke and pitched the Cardinals to a 7-to-6 victory today over the Phillies.

91st St, 73 E, 18x96.5; Jean Ferry to Corportion of the Brick Presbyterian Church, 412 5th Ave ($70), 91st St, 77 E, 20x67; 1,140 Park Ave Corp (David L. Holzman, president), to Jean Ferry, 62 E 92d St (50c). 92d St, 68 E, 15.11x100.8; Bronson Winthrop and another, trustee of Sara G. Iselin, to Jean Ferry 12 E 92d St ($26).

KINGS CROSLEY, MARIA L. (July 18, 1936). Gross assets $100,721; ??et, $98,841. To daughter, Grace C. Tredwell. Chief assets, real estate, $124; miscellaneous property, $752: transfers, $99,844. Stewart Marice, attorney, 159 Broadway, Manhattan.

Five hundred delegates from all parts of the State attended today the opening of the golden jubilee convention of the New York State League of Savings and Loan Associations, which will continue through Friday at Saranac Inn.
Samuel Reshevsky of New York, chess champion of the United States, made an auspicious debut today in the first round of the international masters tournament at the Kurhaus. The American was opposed

While the principal delegates to the Imperial Conference prepared today to depart for their homes or planned brief holidays, government officials studied the two acts of the conference which lay the groundwork for two sweeping changes in the field of foreign policy.

Several sales in the Larchmont section of Westchester County are reported by Cornelius Van Buren, broker. Among the properties involved was the Colonial house of nine rooms and four baths in Larchmont Manor, formerly owned by the estate of John F. McCooey.

Continued declines in the automotive and financial classifications and smaller advances in other divisions reduced the May advance in total newspaper advertising linage to 2.9 per cent over the corresponding month of last year, according to Media Records figures for fiftytwo cities.

The Chase National Bank and the American Holding Corporation, former security affiliate of the bank, will receive a net profit of about $2,000,000 from their General Theatres Equipment and Fox Film financing, former Supreme Court Justice Jeremiah T. Mahoney reported yesterday to Supreme Court Justice Ernest E. L. Hammer.

Senator La Follette told the Senate today he had been informed that Federal relief rolls would be cut 427,359 by July 15 if the proposed relief appropriation of $1,500,000,000 was approved by Congress.

United States DRAGTENDER, $1,380 per annum (less $420 a year for quarters and subsistence), Engineer Department at Large, New York, N. Y. Applications must be on file with the secretary, Board United States Civil Service Examiners, Engineer Department at Large, 39 Whitehall Street, New York, N. Y., not later than June 30.

The movements of population of the past and present between Canada and the United States, and the literature and art of the two countries were cited at the second conference on Canadian-American affairs today to show that the two peoples have a great wealth of common interests and characteristics and few differences.
The dominant aviation companies of France and Germany concluded an accord today for cooperation in the
Investigators for the La Follette Civil Liberties Committee of the Senate today examined a mass of affidavits and received testimony from both sides on the Memorial Day steel strike riot.

Charles E. Howard has joined the staff of H. M. Byllesby Co. in Chicago as statistician and market analyst. The Guaranty Trust Company has been appointed co-transfer agent of 2,000,000 shares of no-par common stock of the Dow Chemical Company.

A warning from British capitalism on the costs of tardy labor recognition was expressed yesterday- by Sir Josiah Stamp, British economist, who sailed for home on the French liner Normandie after a tour of the United States with Lady Stamp.

Alderman John J. Mahoney, Tammany leader of the northern third of the Fifth Assembly District, died yesterday in French Hospital after a brief illness. Mr. Mahoney, who lived at 345 West Fifty-fifth Street, was in his fifty-third year.
The Procurement Division of the Treasury Department announced today that it had purchased 5,970,500 yards of cloth of various types for a total of $649,718 for use in WPA projects, as follows:

Miss Katharine Huntington Bigelow, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Mason Huntington Bigelow of 130 East Sixty-seventh Street, was married yesterday afternoon to Carter Chapin Higgins, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Woodman Higgins of Worcester, Mass., in St. James Church, Madison Avenue and Seventy-first Street. The Rev. Horace Donegan, the rector, performed the ceremony.

Miss Bernadette Marie Whelan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph F. Whelan of this place, was married here this morning in the Church of the Epiphany to Lieutenant John Edward Watters, U. S. A., son of Mr. and Mrs. William Watters of Belleville.

Several hours after three incendiary fires, set simultaneously, had forced 1,800 school children to leave Public School 43, at Brown Place, between 135th and 136th Streets, the Bronx, yesterday morning, the police charged an 11-year-old Negro pupil with juvenile delinquency.

A Lane Critcher, representing the merchandise division of the American Warehousemen's Association, told the Maritime Commission today it had full power to control the free storage of import property and urged enforcement of a ten-day limit at New York piers.

A sparkling 37, 37-74, four over men's par, gave Miss Grace Amory of Women's National and Miss Louise Piping Rock the low gross award in a Long Island one-day best-ball golf tournament at the Nassau Country Club today.

The Book of the Month Club judges have selected "The Life and Death of a Spanish Town," by Elliot Paul, for August distribution, Random House announces, so the trade edition has been postponed until Aug. 2. The book is the story

The proposed equal rights amendment to the Constitution, providing that "men and women shall have equal rights throughout the United States and every place subject to its jurisdiction," was reported favorably today by the subcommittee of the House Judiciary Committee.

The recent executions of high Soviet Army officers for treason were "unpleasant but just" and as such are completely understood by the rank and file of the Russian people, Alexander A. Troyanovsky, Soviet Ambassador to the United States, said here today.

The "competition of 'subsidized' American ships plying between America and the westernmost [British] dominions" has been lately represented in London dispatches as a disturbing matter which a subcommittee of the Imperial Con- will ference has been carefully weighing, with a view to retaliatory action.
Tommy Gorman, manager of the Montreal Maroons of the National Hockey League, today announced that he, Leo Dandurand and Joe Cattarinich had purchased the Connaught Park race track at Ottawa.
Stocks closed generally lower in quiet trading, motor shares weakest; turnover, 698,730 shares. United States Government bonds higher, other issues irregular; transactions, $7,781,600.

Kemp Wicker's four-game victory Neill, national streak was broken today as the Toronto Leafs conquered the leagueleading Newark Bears, 6 to 2, behind fine pitching by Woodrow Wilson (Babe) Davis, who yielded only six hits.

The Advisory Committee on Medicine and Public Health of the New York World's Fair of 1939 approved yesterday a $1,000,000 medical and health project in which "man will be able to see himself as never before, to view the operation of the organs that animate him, and all that science is doing for his bodily welfare."

MANHATTAN BOHNE, ANNA KERR (June 3). Estate, less than $10,000. To the Dominican Sisters, 342 E. 69th St., $300; residue equally to seven nieces and nephews; Katherine McCarthy, executrix, 201 E. 66th St., $100. Theodore Chan, 54-32 152d St., Flushing. executor.

Harry H. Bennett, personnel director of the Ford Motor Company, said today that the company would suspend production during the Summer inventory period, but maintain its employment level at about 40 per cent of normal.

The marriage of Miss Jane Maxine Young, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Max L. Young of 1,130 Park Avenue, to George Ottinger Baer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Baer of 941 Park Avenue, took place last night in the main ballroom of the Plaza. The Rev. Dr. Nathan A. Perilman performed the ceremony.
Directors of Affiliated Fund, Inc., declared yesterday a dividend of 25 cents a share on the common stock. On April 15, last, the company paid 15 cents a share.

Ironically enough, almost the last words written by the late Marshal TUKHACHEVSKY before his recent degradation and execution were in terse and offhand praise of a system in which he did not believe, and the triumph of which helped to lead to his own downfall:

An amended petition of the Consolidated Edison Company, Inc., of New York was filed today with the Public Service Commission. It seeks authority to issue 92,134 shares of its $5 cumulative preferred stock to be offered in exchange for the preferred stock of the New York Steam Corporation upon revised ratios.

The suicide of the President of the White Russian Soviet Socialist Republic, hundreds of arrests and the removal of thousands from Communist party rolls were announced by the government today as the greatest political purge in Soviet Russia's history went forward.

The Merchants Association asked the Maritime Commission yesterday to retain in this port ships of the laid-up Shipping Board fleet, which are now tied up off Staten Island. The commission recently announced plans to remove many of the ships to James River where they would be offered for sale.

The Senate Committee on Appropriations voted today to combine and report in a single bill appropriations for military and non-military activities of the War Department for the fiscal year 1938. The combined bill allots $633,322,495, a net increase of $247,570,964 above the amount approved by the House.

Just how much of an impression Don Budge has made on English tennis observers since arriving with the American Davis Cup squad was demonstrated today when the topranking United States player was seeded at the head of the men's singles draw for the all-England championships, which begin Monday.

The stockholders' committee for the 7 per cent cumulative preferred stock of Huyler's of Delaware, Inc., advised stockholders yesterday that it has filed a petition for a hearing to determine the amount of their claims against the Schulte Retail Stores Corporation and that Peter B. Olney, special master, has issued an order to show cause why such a hearing should not be held, returnable on July 2.

Chancellor Adolf Hitler reviewed before the chancellery today 1,300 Italian Balillas, Fascist boys of 10 to 14 years now visiting Germany. Wilhelmstrasse and the square before the Chancellery were lined with the solid ranks of Hitler youth organizations in their brown-shirted uniforms. The Balillas, marching eight

Miss Anita Victoria Linke, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Victor Francis Linke of Bellaire, L. I., was married yesterday afternoon to Arthur Eric Konig Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Eric Konig of St. Albans, L. I., in St. Pascal Baylon Church, Hollis.

Jacques Salmon and Joseph . Weber, president and treasurer, respectively, of the newly formed Millinery Manufacturers Representatives, Inc., 65 West Thirtyninth Street, have informed 0. W. Pearson, secretary of the Millinery Stabilization Commission,

Reports in the financial section yesterday that customers of the independent steel companies affected by the strikes are switching to the larger producers brought no confirmation from officials of the major corporations.
Buck Newsom muffled the White Sox with five hits today to pitch the Red Sox to a 3-to-2 victory, their second straight over the Chicagoans.

Gerard B. Lambert's cup sloop Yankee is sporting a new boom, which will permit the carrying of the mainsail better, and it is the hope of the owner that it will increase the speed of the craft, which made a good showing in the first series of preliminary races among the three American boats.
Five pictures are scheduled to open today along Broadway. Universal's adaptation of Erich Maria Remarque's "The Road Back" will have its world premiere tonight at the Globe Theatre.

As the Veterans of Foreign Wars gathered here for their State convention today, pensions immediately became an issue. Comrade Post of Brooklyn backed a resolution calling for payments by the government from funds to be raised by taxing industry.

Announcement was made today by the United States Metals Refining Company here of an increase in wages affecting 2,000 workers. Employes working on an hourly wage basis will receive an increase of 8 cents an hour, with time and a half for all overtime in excess of forty hours a week.
The weights for the historic Brooklyn Handicap, major feature of the Aqueduct meeting, were announced yesterday and show that Rosemont is at the top of the list with 127 pounds.

Vast new fields in community health are opening up to medicine, creating opportunities as well as dangers to all members of the medical profession, Health Commissioner John L. Rice and Dr. Livingston Farrand, president of Cornell University, declared yesterday at the thirty-ninth commencement exercises of the Cornell University Medical College.

Six hundred persons who gathered outside the Maxine Elliott Theatre last night for a scheduled preview by the WPA Federal Theatre Project of "The Cradle Will Rock," Marc Blitzstein's opera about a steel strike, were informed that the performance would not be given until July 1.

The Securities and Exchange Commission has called a hearing for July 2 on an application by the Detroit City Gas Company of Detroit, a subsidiary of the American Light and Traction Company, for exemption of the issuance of $5,000,000 in bank loans.

The first of the ten Wednesday night concerts constituting the Federal Music Project's Brahms festival was given last night at the WPA Theatre of Music. Not so many years since, a program consisting entirely of music by the Hamburg master would have been a hazardous undertaking, especially on a warm night with a half-moon luring those on pleasure bent to spend it in the open.

Violation of the Clayton act, through purchase of the capital stock of the Bernheim Distilling Company of Louisville, was charged against Schenley Distillers Corporation of New York by the Federal Trade Commission in a formal complaint announced today.

New York City leased from the United States Government yesterday, for an experimental year at $69,062 rental, the four square blocks of model dwellings known as Harlem River Houses, now nearing completion as a Federal Public Works project.
Several deals in Queens real estate reported yesterday involved the transfer of residential plottage in communities in the vicinity of the World's Fair grounds.
Patrolman Isadore Astel, who has been critically ill since he "shot it out" with a Negro hold-up man last December, will receive today a promotion that he had long desired.

Byron M. Hawks, an estate superintendent for the Rockefeller family for fifty-two years, died at his home here last night at the age of 86. He was born in Springfield Center, N. Y.,the son of the late Foster and Ann Lovejoy Hawks.

Readers of Mr. MARQUAND'S latest tries novel, and anthropologists keen to study the manners and customs of strange tribes, will welcome any new information about the Boston Beaconians. Mr. ROBERT M. WASHBURN, a newspaper correspondent, has just given a little.

James E. Finegan, president of the Civil Service Commission, made a plea yesterday for a higher standard of wages for civil service employes and defended the political status of civil service commissioners before members of the Committee on Civil Service of the Progressive City Committee.

Chancellor Adolf Hitler's "old guard," 600 veterans of the Nazi movement, paraded today in Danzig's streets as guests of the Free City and the feature of a great show the Danzig Nazis staged in celebrating their attainment of forty-eight seats in the Diet, giving them the twothirds majority necessary to change the Constitution.

Testimony that the Long Island Lighting Company's depreciation reserves were seriously inadequate at the time when it was declaring substantial dividends on common stock in 1930 and 1931 was given yesterday at the trial of a stockholders' suit to recover $20,000,000 from present and former officials.

The Senate wrangled for more than five hours today in an effort to reach a vote on the Byrnes amendment to the administration's $1,500,000,000 relief bill for the fiscal year 1938, which would require sponsors of Works Progress Administration projects to contribute 40 per cent of the cost of those projects.
Chairman Mansfield of the House Rivers and Harbors Committee said today that a bill seeking to authorize completion of the Florida Ship Canal would be shelved for this session.

More than 440 residents of the northeast section of the Bronx, ineluding many tenants of the Hillside development, rejected last night a proposal of the city to extend the Eighth Avenue subway to the area by using the tracks of the New York, Westchester Boston Railroad, which has ceased operation.
All Loyalist Spain went on Summer time at 11 P. M. today, when clocks were moved forward one hour. The Insurgent territory has been using the daylight saving schedule for weeks.

J. M. Symes of Washington, vice president of the operations and maintenance department of the Association of American Railroads, said today that more real progress had been made in the last ten years in Improving transportation than in any previous period of twice that length.

The part played by the Communist Deputies of the Popular Front in the latest victory of the Blum Government raises some interesting questions. Twice during the all-night debate on the resolution giving the Cabinet emergency powers to protect the franc and raise new revenue, the Communists in caucus decided to abstain from voting.
The remnants of the more than 80,000 men from New Jersey who fought for the Union forces during the Civil War opened the annual State encampment of the G. A. R. today.
Joseph Stalin had his first meeting today with a foreign diplomat in more than two years when he attended a luncheon in honor of William Munters, Foreign Minister of Latvia.
A jury tonight convicted Tommy Smith, 19-year-old newsboy, of the slaying in February of Mary Ellen Babcock. Life imprisonment was recommended.

W. C. Fields, screen comedian, must pay Dr. Jesse Citron, small town physician, $12,000 for medical services, Superior Court Judge O. K. Morton ruled today. Judge Morton held that Dr. Citron's fee of $12,000 for twenty-five days' treatment when Mr. Fields was critically ill in a hospital last year was reasonable.

More than 350 persons attended a funeral service this morning at the First Presbyterian Church here for Charles Lathrop Pack, forest conservationist, president of the American Tree Association and retired banker. Mr. Pack, who lived here, died Monday in New York at the age of 80.

FRANCES PARKINSON KEYES was a-mem ber of Washington's official society for a dozen years. In that time she was snubbed by experts, told enough scandal to fill a set of volumes the size of the Encyclopaedia Britannica, and given the details on a sufficient number of romances to keep her busy as a fiction writer for some time to come. She tells something about

The victory of the cabinet of Premier Leon Blum in obtaining from the French Chamber of Deputies additional powers to meet the financial crisis brought prompt improvement to the franc in the foreign exchange market yesterday.
Mrs. Marie Antoinette Connery, widow of Representative William P. Connery Jr., today received a message of condolence from President Franklin .D Roosevelt.

An increase of 51 per cent in the volume of residential mortgages accepted for insurance by the FHA during the first five months of this year, as compared with similar months of 1936, is reported by Federal Housing Administrator Stewart McDonald.
Mrs. Flora Gresham Louer, mother of Bobby Franks, who was killed in 1924 by Richard Loeb and Nathan Leopold, died last night in her apartment at the Drake Hotel at the age of 60. She had been ill

Negotiations between the Consolidated Water Company of Utica, N. Y., controlled by the General Water, Gas and Electric Company, and the Citizens Committee of Utica have resulted in a price being fixed for the purchase of the water property by the municipality.

The appointment of F. H. Baird as assistant passenger traffic manager of the New York Central Railroad, with jurisdiction over lines west of Buffalo, was announced yesterday by L. W. Landman, general passenger traffic manager.

Miss Jean MacLean Krell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Krell of this place and Naugatuck, Conn., was married tonight to Lloyd Chipman Carpenter, son of Mr. and Mrs. William N. Carpenter, also of Scarsdale, in the Hitchcock Memorial Church here. The Rev. Charles B.

Studies conducted by economists of the Twentieth Century Fund, Inc., have revealed that in depression years large corporations are able to pay a greater percentage of their net earnings in dividends than the smaller organizations. This, according to the survey, is owing to the fact that the big companies have heavier percentages of assets in surplus and undivided profits.

Following receipt of a letter from the New York State Tax Commission, the New York Stock Exchange committee on securities prescribed yesterday a form of affidavit to be used in cases when share certificates which have been transferred to brokers for purposes of sale have not been sold and have been transferred back to the customer.

Three men and a woman, who had pleaded guilty in the Court of Special Sessions in Brooklyn to a charge of conspiracy to defraud by using fictitious names to sell tickets by telephone for a non-existent charitable affair, were sentenced yesterday.

Lessthan two hours after the four-week strike of the 900 employes of the Radio Condensor Company here had been called off tonight, some one hurled a bomb into one of the buildings of the plant where four employes were at work and within 100 yards of where a number of police were on duty.

A Brazilian general was put under arrest today and another was named in an alleged conspiracy of generals against the government. The two in turn accused General Pedro Aurelio Goes Monteiro, Chief of Staff, of slander.
Amsterdam Ave, 711; 5-story brick tenement and stores, 25x82; Franklin Savings Bank in the City of N. Y. against John J. Schwartz; due, $27,066; taxes, , $1,820; to plaintiff for $30,000.

The annual senior ball, closing Senior Week activities at Fordham College, will be held tonight in the grand ballroom of the Hotel Astor. For the first time the Manhattan division of the college will join the uptown branch on a formal occasion of this kind.
Jake Wake, young Tiger hurler, wild-pitched his way to defeat in a twelve-inning hurling duel with Wes Ferrell of the Senators today. The bases were full at the time. The score was 2-1.

In his first appearance in a Paramount film since 1932, Lionel Barrymore has been borrowed from Metro for the leading character role in Frank Lloyd's "Wells Fargo," which is scheduled to go before the cameras on July 6.

Rand, McNally Co, publishers, store Palazzo d'Italia; Beverage Service Co, bottied beverages, store in concourse of International Building; Rockefeller Center leases. Nathan Landau, floor in 31-3 W. 31st St; Apparel Products Corp, store in 10 E. 33d St; Hyman Mendelsohn, in 42 W. 33d St; Julius Lukacs, in 37-9 W. 28th St: Anthony Scherbaum, in 110 W. 27th St; Kastorians of Society Omonolo, Inc. in 804 6th Ave; Williams Co, Inc, broker.

ABRAM'S WAYSIDE FURNITURE SHOP, INC., Paulding and N. Division St., Peekskill-By 457 Fourth Avenue Furniture Co., Inc., for $163; I. Greenspan Sons, Inc;, $1,500: Rose Greenspan, $45. SAMUEL COHEN HARDWARE CO., INC., 2,398 Amsterdam Ave.--By Consolldated Tank and Seat Co., for $715: American Soap Powder Works, Inc., $270; Stevens soap corp $400.

About 100 members and guests of the West of Central Park Association made a "preview" tour of part of the West Side improvement and Riverside Park project yesterday and then endorsed the pending request of Park Commissioner Robert Moses for an additional city appropriation of $2,600,000 with which to complete the job by next Fall.

Degrees, diplomas, certificates and commissions totaling 1,962 in number were conferred by City College last night at its ninety-first commencement exercises before 17,000 spectators in the City College Stadium- at 137th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.
Mrs. Mary A. C. Lewisohn appealed yesterday to Daniel F. Cohalan, official referee in Supreme Court, for a divorce from Ludwig Lewisohn, the writer, to whom she was married in 1906. She said her

Lady Haig, widow of Earl Haig, war-time Commander-in-Chief of British forces in France, announced today she would refuse to attend the unveiling of the nation's memorial to him in Whitehall later this year.

Officials of the National Maritime Union and the National Labor Relations Board acted yesterday in an effort to prevent a spread of labor difficulties in the shipping industry while arrangements were being made for a general election among all Atlantic and Gulf crews to determine a bargaining agency for the men.

The discussion of the world situation by the European consultative committee of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, its president, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, said today before leaving for Paris and London, had served to confirm its decision to concentrate its efforts on "the appalling monetary and economic war ravaging the world" as still the most urgent problem and the least difficult approach to peace.

Mrs. Winthrop W. Aldrich, the Misses Mary and Harriet Aldrich, Dr. and Mrs. Logan Clendening, Mr. and Mrs. Sheldon Whitehouse, Paul M. Dutko, United States Consul at Riga; Baron Georg von Sedlitz, Mr. and Mrs. William T. Aldrich, Major J. Heard, Military Attache at the United States Embassy in London;
America placed four men in the quarterfinals of the Queens Club tennis tournament today and furnished an almost certain finalist in redheaded Don Budge of Oakland, Calif.

The report of the Public Service Corporation of New Jersey and subsidiaries for the twelve months ended on May 31, issued yesterday, shows a net income of $25,215,852, after interest, depreciation, amortization, Federal income taxes and other expenses and charges.
The Literary Digest, which for many years'-was the most popular news weekly in this country, was sold yesterday to the publishers of The Review of Reviews, a monthly interpretive publication.

Justice Schenck denied the petition of J. J. Little Ives Company of New York today for an order directing Charles B. Smith, head of the Division of Standards and Purchases, to accept a bid for printing.

Mrs. Elizabeth 'Veronica McTaminey Griffin, mother of William Griffin, publisher and editor of The New York Sunday Enquirer, died of a heart attack on Tuesday night at her home, 800 Riverside Drive, after a brief illness. Her age was 65.

Robert Sweeny, young American-born resident of England who last month won the British amateur golf championship, today broke the amateur course mark at the West Herts Club with successive rounds of 69 and 68 to win the Golf Illustrated Vase with a record aggregate score of 137.

William S. Menden, president of the B. M. T. system, wrote yesterday to the Transport. Workers Union, a C. I. O. affiliate, agreeing to a referendum among the 12,000 employes on the question of which organization should represent the employes as a collective bargaining agency. The B. M. T. president met with C. I. O. officials last Friday and promised an early adjudication of the issue.

Sentences of seven and a half to fifteen years each in Sing Sing were imposed by Judge Koenig in General Sessions yesterday on three youths who had pleaded guilty to first-degree manslaughter in the strangling of Otto Schwecke, 58 years old, a steamship engineer, in his room at 352 West Twenty-third Street last March 17.

Miss Ruth Virginia Birck, daughter of Mrs. Leon A. Birck of this place, became the bride of Lieutenant Frederick Pierce Campbell, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry P. Campbell of Catawissa, Pa., this evening in the garden of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Bradford's home in Scarsdale.

At a dinner tonight at St. Amour, the home here of Mr. and Mrs. Lammot du Pont, announcement was made of the engagement of Mr. du Pont's daughter, Miss Alexandrine de M. duPont, to Howard Alfred Perkins Jr. of this city, son of Mrs. Robert K. McCall of Strafford, Pa., and the late Howard Alfred Perkins.
Freedom of opinion, "the most precious privilege of life," is menaced today and its continuance is not guaranteed, declared President Cowling of Carleton College today in an address at Knox College.

Official composite annual statements of the eighty mutual fire insurance companies in the American Mutual Alliance reveal many alltime financial records achieved in 1936. The companies returned $15,918,573 to their policy holders, declaring the money was unneeded.

The President at his press conference this week indicated the broad outlines of a policy for coordinating all Federal benefit programs with a view to raising the national income. If such a program is carried out, he believes that the budget can be balanced automatically without raising the present taxload in proportion to national income, while all forms of relief could ultimately be abolished.
The Bureau of Mines reported today that in 1936 the United States imported 210,440 ounces of platinum metals valued at $5,996,034, against 164,149 ounces valued at $3,228,022 in 1935.

While the college fraternity system is under severe criticism in many institutions, President James L. McConaughy in his report to the trustees of Wesleyan University finds that no crisis faces the fraternities here. He says:

The youth of democratic lands must adopt the fervor of Fascist and Communist youth and apply it to rebuilding the foundations of freedom, Dr. Paul Dawson Eddy, president-elect of Adelphi College, declared here today at the annual commencement exercises of the college.

Fiftyfive golfers turned out for the Long Island Association's annual oldtimers' tournament at the Inwood Country Club today. This was by far the largest number of players 50 years and over ever to enter this event.

Beginning regular commercial air service between New York and Bermuda, the Cavalier, flying boat of Imperial Airways, arrived here at 4:15 this afternoon, 5 hours 35 minutes after the departure from Bermuda.
The long-dormant new Building Code was reported favorably yesterday by the buildings committee of the Board of Aldermen and may be acted upon when the Aldermen meet a week from next Tuesday.

The 1937 Pacific Coast Convention of the American Association of Advertising Agencies will be held at the Hotel Del Monte, Del Monte, Calif., Oct. 21 and 22. Edmund M. Pitts, J. Walter Thompson Company, San Francisco, has been appointed chairman of the committee on program.

The purge of Communists from the British trade union movement is being vigorously pursued. Tonight it was announced that Harry Pollitt, British Communist leader, had been reejected as a delegate to the Trades Union Ccngress by his own union, the Boilermakers Society.

The Citizens Union and the City Affairs Committee joined yesterday in an appeal to the Board of Estimate for establishment of a $500,000 revolving fund to finance the rehabilitation of old law tenements.

Mayor La Guardia was assured yesterday in a friendly letter from Joseph P. Ryan, president of the International Longshoremens Union, that the Sanitation Department's disposal services would not be halted if tugboat men and scow laborers join in the shipyard strike.
The Red Sox swept the four-game series with the White Sox today by taking both ends of the Bunker Hill Day double-header, 5-2 and 3-2, the latter in ten innings.

Announcement was made today of the appointment of Colonel Bernard W. Kearney of Gloversville, N. Y., as a brigadier general to command the Fifty-third Infantry Brigade, comprising the 105th Regiment of Troy and the 106th of Brooklyn, New York National Guard.
The citizens who constitute the government board which is to attempt mediation of the steel strike will begin under an unusual handicap, perhaps a unique one in a task of this sort.
The Newark Bears won a ten-inning battle from the Rochester Red Wings today, 4 to 3, after the visitors scored twice in the ninth to knot the score.

The New York Telephone Company has filed an amendment to its registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering $25,000,000 of refunding-mortgage 3 1/4 per cent bonds, Series B, revealing underwriters and allotments as follows:

Keen price competition, more emphasis on "armchair" models and quite a few million-dollar advertising budgets are the major elements in the merchandising campaigns for the 1938 radio lines, practically all of which have now been shown to dealers, according to comment in the industry yesterday.

Turpentine firm, 34 cents; sales, 177 barrels; receipts, 468 barrels; shipments, 197 barrels; stock, 28.203 barrels. Resin firm; sales, 767: receipts, 2,020; shipments, 1,205; stock, 56,520. Quote: B to M, $7.82 1/2; N, $7.85; WG, $7.90; WW, X, $8.90.
The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes in pounds sterling:

General Owen O'Duffy's Irish brigade, numbering 633 men who fought for the Spanish Insurgents, sailed for Dublin at midnight aboard the Portuguese liner Mozambique only a few hours after it had arrived here from Caceres.

The refusal of the Paraguayan Army to obey orders to retire from its positions in the Chaco not only has created a critical internal situation in Paraguay but has caused a serious international problem.
Government trade specialists said today that Brazil soon may produce 1,000,000 bales of cotton annually for export and increase the threat to the United States staple in world markets.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are June 16 unless specified: At Boston Yard: Badger, Tattnall. At San Diego, June 17: Boggs, Lamberton. Acushnet, Norfolk to Dahlgren, June 17. Avocet, at Pearl Harbor. Charleston, Charleston Yard to sea, June 17.
The Reichsbank's statement as of June 15 shows the following changes from the preceding week, in thousands of marks:

Hopes for Sir James M. Barrie's recovery were virtually abandoned tonight after Lord Horder and attending specialists announced that "there has been an extension of the pneumonia process during the past twenty-four hours and his condition has become much more serious."
Commencement exercises at the Don Bosco Institute, a Roman Catholic preparatory school for Polish boys, will be held in the school auditorium here tomorrow afternoon at 3 o'clock.

The deadline for the selection of a Democratic Mayoralty nominee is Aug. 10, one week earlier than had been generally supposed, it was learned yesterday. That midnight will be the last possible hour for the filing of designations for all offices, including the Mayoralty, for the September primaries.
The pressure upon the French franc relaxed somewhat further yesterday as further details were awaited of the measures Premier Blum intends to take to meet the fiscal crisis facing his government.

Mrs. Muriel Vanderbilt Phelps's fourin-hand, Brewster-made, all-sport coach was sold at auction today to Mrs. A. D. French of Beverly, Mass. The coach, which is in fine condition, was knocked down at $400 after bidding had started at $200.
As a result of mid-month settlements, bank clearings increased over the preceding week, but declined 4.4 per cent below the same period last year, owing largely to the loss reported in this city.

The Rutgers University award "for high attainment in secondary education" was presented to Philip M. B. Boocock, retiring headmaster of the Rutgers Preparatory School, at the 171st commencement of the Rutgers Preparatory School in Kirkpatrick Chapel here this morning.

Expressing hope that the status quo would be maintained in the steel strike, Charles P. Taft, chairman of the Federal mediation board appointed today by Secretary Perkins, said the board would try to expedite its business "most rapidly."
Dr. Henry Marion Neale, tuberculosis authority, died at his home in Upper Lehigh today of pneumonia. He was 79 years old.

More than 2,000 persons, including 800 Reserve Officers, witnessed a battalion parade of the Sixteenth Infantry on Governors Island yesterday and a demonstration of a detachment of mechanized forces from the First United States Cavalry.

Despite the plea of Mrs. Elinore M. Herrick, regional director of the National Labor Relations Board, for restraint on the part of the maritime unions, the crews of two Eastern Steamship freighters continued a sit-down strike yesterday and strikes were called on several ships in Baltimore.

Mrs. William H. Moore of New York City has given to the Yale Gallery of Fine Arts, in memory of her son, Hobart Moore, a collection of textiles which contains examples from the days of early Christianity in Egypt to seventeenth and eighteenth century Persia.
Authorities today blamed Japan's increasing suicide and crime rate on the growth of insanity in the empire. Statisticians announced that 86,278 persons went mad in Japan last year.
The general executive board of the United Automobile Workers of America today considered disciplinary measures to curb "outlaw" strikes.

Interrupted by a strong wind, hail and rain, the thirty-fifth annual Southern amateur golf tournament was thrown into overtime play today in the midst of the second round. Seven of the eight second-round matches were washed out.

The Tuna Club reported today that 11-year-old Douglas Bombard had broken the world light-tackle white seabass record by catching a sixty-pounder half an inch longer than the boy is tall on light tackle with a breaking strength of twenty-six pounds.
Wearing the red sash of generalissimo over his khaki uniform, General Francisco Franco told your correspondent today:

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Howard Stephen Thayer of Shaker Heights, Cleveland, of the engagement of their elder daughter, Miss Jane Thayer, to Norman John MacGaffin Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Norman J. MacGaffin of this city.

Support for the Rogers-Allen law, which "returned the milk industry to the producers," and determination to fight "chiseling" distributors were voiced before more than 3,000 members of the Dairymen's League Cooperative Association, Inc., at its annual meeting here today.
A sitdown strike at the Fisher Body Company's plant here was ended soon after 6 o'clock tonight when approximately 750 employes left the building.

Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Paris Seelman of Brooklyn have announced the engagement and approaching marriage of their daughter, Miss Constance Van Wicklen Seelman, to George Ludwig Ahrens of London, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry A. Ahrens of Grymes Hill, S. I. Miss Seelman will sail today for England and will be married there on June 28.

Two married women, each with two young daughters, were among the graduates of Hunter College on Wednesday when they marched down the aisle of Carnegie Hall to receive a B. A. degree, which had taken more than seven years of attendance in the college evening session to earn.

With excellent rowing conditions again prevailing today, the Yale and Harvard crews went through good workouts in both the morning and afternoon. Yale's varsity, whichplans a time row tomorrow night over the full four miles, took things a little easier than Harvard.
The Seventeenth International Agricultural Congress, which opened here today, was attended by Prince Bernhard and Premier Hendryk Colijn.

The final phase of the Little Entente conference was held today when Premier George Tatarescu of Rumania and Foreign Minister Victor Antonescu accompanied by Premier Milan Hodza of Czechoslovakia and Premier Milan Stoyadinovitch of Yugoslavia took a trip up the Danube on the steamer King Carol.

Andrew W. Mellon, Secretary of the Treasury under Presidents Coolidge and Hoover; the Aluminum Company of America, which he and relatives are accused of dominating, and forty-two other defendants named here last April in an antitrust action denied yesterday in Federal court that they had violated the Sherman Act.

Mark Graves, Tax Commissioner, predicted today that on June 30 the estimate of $92,000,000 for the State from income tax receipts, as made in Governor Lehman's budget statement, will be exceeded by $12,000,000.

Now, if one lived in Binghamton, it wouldn't, according to the latest bulletin from the New York State Conservation Department, be a strange sight to see "deer running wild." Perhaps if you were alert you might also notice one invade a second-hand furniture shop, wreck the interior, scramble out across the street and leap through a store window.

Imitation being the sincerest form of flattery, the Yankees imitated the Indians out of a ball game at the Stadium yesterday. Cleveland hit some home runs, and so did the Yanks. The lakeshore combination pounded out base hits, and so did the New Yorkers.

The B. M. T. management has definitely agreed to an early collective bargaining referendum among its 12,000 employes on rapid transit, street car and bus lines, Harry Sacher, counsel for the Transport Workers Union, announced yesterday.

Roman Catholic efforts to assist the spiritual and material welfare of the American Negro will be intensified as a result of the formation last night of a group for this purpose by delegates from ten Catholic college alumni and alumnae associations.

Chased indoors by a rainstorm that\ drenched this part of the country today, Joe Louis went through what might be termed a final hard workout at Moose Hall for the bid he will make Tuesday night in Chicago to lift the world heavyweight title from the furrowed brow of James J. Braddock.

Submitting its annual report for 1936 to the Securities and Exchange Commission, the American Rolling Mill Company has refused to give the names of one domestic subsidiary and nine foreign subsiddiaries, although answering all other questions put by the commission.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Walter C. Flanders of this city and Cooperstown, N. Y., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Sampson Flanders, to Oscar Edward Boline, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward N. Boline of Lindsborg, Kan.

The rural police of the town of Eisleben, Saxony, are investigating what appears to be the attempted murder of a German-American, William Edward Baker of New Orleans. Mr. Baker was found unconscious in his automobile.

Cool police heads in Harlem last night averted what might have developed into a major disturbance as four persons, three Negroes and one white, were injured in street battles outside Father Divine's Heaven, 20 West 115th Street.
Lady Zia Wernher's Precipitation, the 2 to 1 favorite, won the historic Ascot Gold Cup today, covering the two and a half miles in near record time.

Canada Dry Ginger Ale, Inc., distributors of Holloway's gin, yesterday announced a revision in suggested resale prices under the FeldCrawford law. The gin will be marketed at $1.39 a fifth instead of $1.44. In an earlier revision, a price of $1.32 a fifth had been announced but this was corrected in yesterday's schedule.
Often in the past the Federal Government has intervened in major labor disputes, sometimes by injunction or force of arms, sometimes by mediation or arbitration.
AMERICAN DREAM, by Michael Foster. (Morrow, $3.) A chronicle of three generations in America. NAPOLEON AND TALLEYRAND, by Emil Dard. (Appleton-Century, $6.) Containing considerable new material.

Simultaneously with the opening by the Navy Department today of private bids for the construction of one of its two new 35,000-ton battleships, State Department officials disclosed that the United States had appreached the principal naval powers with a suggestion that the guns on new battleships be restricted to 14-inch caliber instead of the present 16-inch maximum.

The Basques' support of the Loyalist government in Spain, as a consequence of which they now are bearing the brunt of the Nationalist offensive, was prompted more by racial aspiration for autonomy than by sympathy with Madrid's multi-party administration.

Mrs. Beryl Markham, British flier, arrived yesterday on the French liner Ile de France to buy an American airplane. It was the first time she had come here by steamship. Last Fall she made a solo flight of the Atlantic which terminated in a forced landing in Nova Scotia.

It was in 1908 that Mr. WILLIAM K. VANDERBILT built the Long Island Motor Parkway for automobile drivers who wanted to step on the gas and burn up the road without fear of arrest. Those were the days of high-seated tonneaus, linen dusters and goggles.

The four-story residence of the late John D. Rockefeller at 4 West Fifty-fourth Street and the ninestory residence of Mr. and Mrs. John D. Rockefeller Jr. at 10 West Fifty-fourth Street are to be demolished and a part of the plot is to be used by the Museum of Modern Art as a garden for the display of sculpture.

A $15,000 suit brought as a result of a golfing accident by Dr. J. Grady Booe, a physician and surgeon, of 111 Arcadia Avenue, against Dr. J. A. MacLennan, a dentist, of 155 Grovers Avenue, was compromised by an insurance company for $2,500 in court today.

The engagement of Miss Laura Eugenie La Fond, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest La Fond of this place, to Seward Wright Livermore, son of Mrs. Seward Bucknam Livermore of Cambridge, Mass., has been announced by her parents.

Bernard Jacoby of Evander Childs entered the final round of the first annual metropolitan interscholastic tennis tourney yesterday when he defeated William Schwartz, a teammate, 6--2, 6--2, on the clay courts of Fordham University.

Mrs. Tokuko Nakano, former champion of Japan, was eliminated from the women's New York State championship at the Jackson Heights Tennis Club yesterday as Miss Norma Taubele, the defending titleholder, and Miss Eunice Dean of San Antonio gained the semifinal round.

Paul Van Zeeland, Premier of Belgium, will arrive today on the Cunard White Star liner Berengaria to accept an honorary degree at Princeton University and discuss Belgian-American relations with President Roosevelt.

Seven years after she left Broadway for the films, Sylvia Sidney will return next Fall in the leading feminine role of "To Quito and Back," the Ben Hecht play with which the Theatre Guild will begin its twentieth subscription season.

Mr. and Mrs. Harris Fahnestock left yesterday for Eastover, their place in Lenox, Mass. They will sail July 9 on the Ile de France. Mrs. Peyton C. March of Washington is at the Vanderbilt. Chief Justice and Mrs. Charles Evans Hughes left the Plaza yesterday for Littleton, N. H.

Continuing the unionization drive, 450 barbers in 200 shops went on strike yesterday on the East Side from Twenty-third Street to Fiftyninth Street for increased wages and better working conditions, it was announced by Adolph Rosenbaum, secretary-treasurer of Local 1 of the Journeymen Barbers International Union. Strike headquarters were established in Hibernian Hall, 200 East Forty-fourth Street.

Monopoly and price discrimination were charged today in a Federal Trade Commission complaint against a group of manufacturers and distributors of window glass and their trade associations, the Window Glass Manufacturers Association, 19 West Forty-fourth Street, New York, and the National Glass Distributors Association of Chicago.

Retail credit men were urged today to liberalize credit in hard times and demand prompt payment in boom periods. R. E. Baylis of Toronto, Canada, before the annual convention of the National Retail Credit Association asked:

During the week ended June 16 member bank reserve balances decreased $121,000,000. The reduction in member bank reserves resulted from an increase of $165,000,000 in Treasury deposits with the Federal
The Treasury procurement division today announced the following invitations to bid on textiles, the material to be delivered by-July 20, 1937:
As lost wages of idle steel workers soared into millions of dollars, the Steel Workers Organizing Committee laid plans today to provide for dependants of employes seeking bargaining contracts.

Mrs. Marie Hambright Cramer of this city, daughter of Mrs. Herbert L. Bartlett of Asbury Park, N. J., and of the late Harry Coleman Hambright of Lancaster, Pa., was married to Philip Bradford Niles last night at the home of Mrs. Sidney Sewall Boardman, 142 East Seventy-first Street. The Rev. Dr.
Montreal took both ends of a double-header with the Jersey City Giants today, winning the first, 2 to 1, in thirteen innings and taking the second, which was halted in the fifth by rain. 4 to 2.

Following the resignation of two partners from Abbott, Proctor Paine and two partners from Baker, Weeks Harden, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that it had issued orders suspending the proceedings brought against the partnerships and the four partners as individuals on May 22, alleging manipulative activities in the common capital stock of the Root Petroleum Company, a security registered on the New York Curb Exchange.

President William E. Weld has announced the election to the board of trustees of Wells College of Henry R. Stebbins Jr. of Rochester; Mrs. David Bellamy of Rochester, president of the Wells College Alumnae Association, and Mrs. J. R. Kimberly, '26, of Neenah, Wis., daughter of Joseph W. Essick of Reading, Pa., also a trustee of the college.

MANHATTAN ADELSDORFER. LIZZIE (Nov. 26. 1936). Gross assets. $79,422; net, $74,774. To Jerome Adelsdorfer. son, and Sydelle Adelsdorfer, daughter-in-law, one-half residue each; Natalie and Gloria Adelsdorfer, grandchildren, $1,000 each; ten other bequests ranging from $100 to $250 each. Chief assets, stocks and bonds, S61,231. Goldsmith Rosenthal, attorneys. 1,501 Broadway.
It is Universal's "The Road Back," not Erich Maria Remarque's, that they presented last night at the Globe.

The thirty-one sailors killed in the bombing of the warship Deutschland off Ibiza, Balaric Islands, were buried in the naval cemetery here today in the presence of Chancellor Adolf Hitler, Admiral General Erich Raeder and Field Marshal Werner-von Blomberg, War Minister.
The two Endeavours went out for another trial spin today and they had the closest to a real race of any day since they began to prepare for the coming America's Cup series.
Laurel wreaths and great bouquets will brighten Queen Victoria's statues next Sunday, the 100th anniversary of the day an 18-year-old Princess was awakened to learn that she was a Queen.
The mere prospect of a mediation of the steel strikes was taken bullishly in stock trading circles yesterday, but in industrial circles the attitude was to wait and see how things develop.

Fire laid waste most of a lumber yard occupying a ten-acre tract on the waterfront here early tonight, causing damage estimated at $100,000. A dozen firemen and employes of the yard were cut and bruised in fighting the blaze, but only one required hospital treatment.

IN his street clothes the 18-year-old Bob Feller looks even younger than that. He was talking with a well-dressed stranger of middle age, and Wally Schang, the old Yankee catcher who is now a coach with the Cleveland club, identified the stranger.
Albert L. Wolfson, electrical equipment manufacturer and former real estate operator, died yesterday of a heart attack at his home, 75 Central Park West. His age was 60.

Newspaper ?? sections throughout the country will be included in the Fall advertising schedule for Artistic Foundations, Inc., manufacturers of Flexees, according to Arthur Hirshon, president of Hirshon-Garfield, Inc., agency in charge. Copy will use 200-line space, starting late in September.

Any doubt regarding the probability of a general rug and carpet price advance for Fall was dissolved in the wholesale market yesterday when the Bigelow-Sanford Carpet Company announced it will increase its quotations for the new season 8 to 10 per cent.

The Cuban Government will abandon the project to impose new taxes to balance the 1937-38 budget, President Federico Laredo Bru asserted this morning. "The government is abandoning for the present the idea of soliciting new taxes," said the Chief Executive, who recently sent his budget message to Congress, asking that a series of new taxes be imposed to make up the estimated $9,000,000 deficit, proposed in the $79,000,000 budget.

Doubleday, Doran have just signed contracts for the publication of "Life of Christ," by the late Sir Thomas Henry Hall Caine. It is expected that the book will be published both here and in England in the Spring of next year.

Houses on the East Side formed the bulk of the realty turnover in Manhattan yesterday. An investor paid cash for the three five-story brick tenements at 230-234 East Ninety-sixth Street, sold by the Charles F. Noyes Company for the trustees of Jerome Adrian Frank. The property is assessed at $58,500 and will be altered into modern apartments of two and one-half rooms. The plot is 76.7 by 100.8 feet.

The 1938 open championship of the United States Golf Association will be played at the Cherry Hills Club, Englewood, Col., near Denver, the U. S. G. A. announced yesterday through The Associated Press.

The majority of the thirty-eight entrants in Princeton University's fourth annual invitation track meet, to be held in Palmer Stadium Saturday afternoon, applied the finishing touches to their conditioning today. Five new arrivals raised the number of competitors now in town to thirty-one.

Samuel Reshevsky and Reuben Fine, the two Americans competing in the international chess masters' tournament at the Kurhaus, acquitted themselves well in the second round today, but both figured in adjournments. The chances of their being successful on resumption tomorrow are excellent.

For two weeks Joseph Tuzil, 22 years old, of 1,766 Seward Avenue, the Bronx, slept on the floor of his father's cleaning store at 1,457 Madison Avenue, with a 22-caliber rifle at his side to prevent a repetition of a robbery committed there the day before he began his vigil.

Monroe Jubitz, second-string pitcher, today limited Indiana University to four scattered singles, giving Yale a 7-5 victory and Indiana the first defeat of its Eastern trip after triumphs over Harvard, Brown and Rutgers.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total gold holdings for the system as a whole to be at the lowest point of the year to date. The ratio of reserve for the New York bank also reached a new low figure for the Year.

A surprise Plea of guilty to murder in the second degree brought to an abrupt end tonight the trial of Mrs. Helen Tiernan, 26-year-old widow, in a special session in Suffolk County Supreme Court here.

Benjamin W. Bunker, 59 years old, a former financial writer, who had pleaded guilty to operating a bucket shop at 79 Wall Street last year, escaped with a suspended sentence and was placed on five years' probation yesterday by General Sessions Judge Collins, with a warning not to engage in the bucketing business in the future.
Mr. and Mrs. John Kerr of Queens Village have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Veronica Teresa Kerr, to Denis B. Sullivan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Timothy Sullivan of Hollis.

The Cardinal Hayes Literature Committee issued yesterday a "white list" of 105 books approved for Summer reading for Roman Catholics. The list, which is issued every three months from headquarters of the committee at 23 East Fifty-first Street, contains twentytwo titles of books recommended for children. The complete list follows:

The fortyhour convention in the textile industry was adopted in committee at the International Labor Conference today by a vote of 73 to 40. The danger of its failing to get a two-thirds majority when it reaches a plenary meeting next week has increased, however.

Essex proved far too strong for Cambridge University, winning by an innings and 31 runs in a first class cricket match completed in two days. Against the county team's total of 346, the varsity players were dismissed for 112 and 201.

Mary A. Shanley was commended by Mayor La Guardia at City Hall yesterday following her promotion Wednesday from third to second grade detective for having arrested two men about to commit a holdup on April 11.

Democracy as understood in the American form of government is a precious gift which every citizen of the United States will die to preserve in the face of the growing dictatorships, National Commander Bernard P. Learney of Gloversville told the annual State encampment of the Veterans of Foreign Wars this afternoon.

An explosion due to a fire occurred at 8:25 o'clock yesterday afternoon aboard the Battleship Jaime Primero, now undergoing repairs at Cartagena, according to a communique issued by the Ministry of Defense.
The Republic Steel Corporation furnished the Steel Workers' Organizing Committee today with an inventory of munitions which the corporation said were in its Warren and Niles plants.
Leaking badly as a result of an aerial bomb attack and with her decks scored by hundreds of machinegun bullets, the Italian steamer Madda, 5,181 tons, came into Gibraltar today for repairs.

Given a rousing ride by Ira Hanford, C. V. Whitney's Piccolo gained a nose decision over Mrs. C. E. Allen's Trouper in the photo finish that decided the $5,000 added Bunker Hill Handicap, mile and one-eighth feature today at Suffolk Downs. Piccolo paid $11.20 for $2 in the mutuels.

An agreement covering 3,000 retail meat markets in Brooklyn was signed yesterday between the Association of Retail Meat Dealers and the Amalgamated Meat Cutters and Butcher Workers Union, Local 233, an A. F. of L. organization.
Fortyfive Stateville Prison convicts got their eighth grade diplomas today, neatly signed by Joseph E. Ragen, warden, and looked forward to a Summer vacation on which they are not going anywhere.

A new drive for $250,000 was announced yesterday by the Trade Union Relief for Spain from its offices at 3 West Sixteenth Street. The funds are to be used for medical aid and relief for the Loyalist forces.

Frederick O'Byrne, Commissioner of Jurors in New York County since 1916 and an attache of that office since 1882, died yesterday at his Summer home, 228 Beach 129th Street, Rockaway Park, of coroary thrombosis at the age of 75.
A well-trained and supremely confident James J. Braddock sent out the word today that he'll knock out Joe Louis in eight rounds or less when they clash in Comiskey Park, Chicago, next Tuesday night.

Members of the judiciary and close friends will serve as honorary pallbearers at the funeral services today for Supreme Court Justice James C. Cropsey at the Classon Avenue Presbyterian Church, 1 Monroe Street, at 2:30 P. M.
Eight of the ten living members of the fifty-year class are expected to attend the alumni reunion of the Cook Academy on Saturday.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Dr. Margaret Bevans, daughter of Mrs. martin J. Bevans of Flushing, Queens, and the late Mr. Bevans, to Dr. David Lyall, son of Mrs. William L. Lyall of Ridgewood, N. J., and the late Mr. Lyall.

Champions and near-greats of college track and field open a twoday assault on time and distance tomorrow in one of the biggest athletic carnivals of the year, the annual National Collegiate A. A. meet.
Thousands today filed past the flag-draped, flower-banked coffin of Representative William P. Connery Jr., chairman of the House Labor Committee.

Librarians were advised not to wear a "top hat" but to be "humble" in their attitude toward their work at yesterday's sessions of the Special Libraries Association's twenty-ninth annual conference at the Hotel Roosevelt.
Henry W. Morgan, founder of the Morgan Machine Company and former head of the Rochester Boy Scouts, died at his home today after a long illness. His age was 74.

Bowery, 215, n e cor Rivington St., 21.6x 95.6x26.10x91.9; Manufacturers Trust Corp to 215 Bowery Corp, 134 Bowery; p mtg, $22,500 ($27.50). Stanton St, 177. 25x100; Evelyn NiarktvitZ to Baron De Hirsch Fund, 220 5th Ave. 59th St, 539 W, n s, 25x100.5; Emma N. Hartung to John A. Hartung, 168 South Ave. Poughkeepsie, N. Y.

THERE are more than 500 pages to Michael Foster's novel called "American Dream" (Morrow, $3), the Literary Guild selection for July. Many of these have the romantic enthusiasm of, let us say, a historical novel foaled in 1910. The others could well be represented in a blend of "Drums Along the Mohawk," "Anthony Adverse" and Norris's angry "Octopus."

Charles L. Campbell, vice president and treasurer of the Connecticut Light and Power Company since Oct. 15, 1929, was elected president at a meeting of the directors yesterday, succeeding the late J. Henry Roraback as head of the $112,000,000 corporation.
An agent for the Metropolitan Museum of New York bought today the Fragonard canvas entitled "Portrait Presume de Rosalie Fragonard," for $64,740.

Louis Lowe Jenkins, member of an old Maryland family, died yesterday at his home; Hunting Ridge, at the age of 58. He was a son of the late E. Austin Jenkins and a brother of the late Spalding Lowe Jenkins, former president of the Maryland Jockey Club.

The City Affairs Committee, through F. L. Guggenheimer, executive director, announced yesterday that it had sent a letter to all members of the Board of Estimate urging approval by that body of a resolution to establish a revolving fund to be used by the city in repairing tenements under the Murray "prior lien" bill.

James E. Hughes, from W. H. Pitner, at 17 Blackthorn Lane; H. J. Southmayd, from L. Darlington, at 4 Vermount Ave, Prospect Park; Murray Mayer, from W. E. Larned, at 28 Reynal Ave; H. Smith, from R.R. Zipprodt, at 36 Midchester Ave: R.F. Smith, from M. C. Brown, at 59 Ralph Ave; White Plains rentals by Chauncey B. Griffen, broker.
Three sit-in demonstrations staged by 200 WPA arts projects employes and 1,500 sympathizers ended yesterday morning when the WPA employes called off the demonstrations and returned to their posts.

Republicans commenting today upon the three - day harmony conference which President Roosevelt will hold next week with Democratic members of Congress at Jefferson Island asserted that Mr. Roosevelt's "oneman" power is vanishing and that his party cannot be controlled by him upon the Supreme Court issue.
Democratic ranks in the Senate split today over a proposal by Senator Robinson, majority leader, that more of the Federal relief load be shifted to State and local governments.
The La Follette School of Music will give its tenth semi-annual students' recital tonight in Carnegie Chamber Music Hall, the proceeds to go to the school's scholarship fund.

Paul Moss, Commissioner of Licenses, criticized recent burlesque productions for their "bad effect" upon the theatre generally, in addressing members of the New York Young Republican Club yesterday in Lawyers Club, 115 Broadway.

The presidents of ten large associations of newspaper editors and publishers, which include a majority of the nation's 1,900 newspapers, issued a call today for a special convention June 29 to discuss demands of the American Newspaper Guild for a closed shop.
The Caravan Theatre's open-air performances will be given at the following municipal grounds tonight: Manhattan, a ten-act vaudeville bill at Washington Square Park; Brooklyn, "The Show Off"

Although John Fales of Princeton won the two final races, Yale's yachtsmen today captured the McMillan Cup for the first time in the tenth annual intercollegiate championship regatta on the waters of Long Island Sound and Manhasset Bay.

Division Five of the Interstate Commerce Commission, by a two-to-one vote today granted a certificate as a common carrier of coal to Lyle H. Carpenter of Delhi, N. Y., owner of a one and one-half ton truck, despite the objections of the New York, Ontario Western Railway Company.

The Board of Tax Appeals ruled today that the North American Company of New York City was $390,282 deficient in income taxes. The Bureau of Internal Revenue had assessed the utilities holding company for $967,973.

After allowance for the usual seasonal changes, there was a slight increase in the volume of business in the Pittsburgh district last week, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh. The bureau's index stood at 119.1 per cent of the 1923-25 average.

A general strike of Paris hotel, cafe and restaurant workers which would paralyze the Paris Exposition is the prospect for next Wednesday if the employers do not meet the labor demand for a forty-hour, five-day week, as well as other demands inspired by the government's social legislation.

The Official Gazette announced today that a sum totaling 5,717,749 marks, constituting unpaid taxes, flight tax and property value, had been assessed against Hans LachmannMosse, his wife and two other members of his family. Mr. LachmannMosse, a son-in-law of the late Rudolf Mosse, founder of the Berlin Tageblatt, is an emigre living in Paris.

Irving Rudow, president of the B. R. Clothing Company, Inc., at 162 Fifth Avenue, went on trial before Justices Bayes, Kozicke and Salomon in Special Sessions yesterday for alleged State income tax violations in 1933 and 1934, developed by Thomas E. Dewey, special prosecutor, in his investigation of alleged racketeering in the clothing industry here.

Miss Dorothy Sutherland Turno, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter G. W. Turno of this place, was married this evening to Nathaniel Purdy Gardner Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Nathaniel P. Gardner of Maplewood. The ceremony was performed in the Arlington Avenue Presbyterian Church by the pastor, the Rev. William E. Kroll.

The Armstrong Cork Company, Lancaster, Pa., has filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission under the Securities Act of 1933 covering an unstated number of shares of nopar value common stock to be offered to stockholders through transferable subscription warrants.
For the second successive year Joseph Fishback, St. John's University freshman, won the junior Long Island Center championship yesterday at the Jackson Heights Tennis Club.

The Fairfield division of the Westchester-Fairfield Women's Golf Association, captained by Mrs. Russell Holman of Innis Arden, won the annual intra-association team match at the Woodway Country Club today, 8 1/2 to 6 1/2.

A "suspension of service" staged by postal employee yesterday morning as a protest against an alleged anti-union attitude by Postmaster General Alfonso Gomez Morentin was termed a complete failure today by postal authorities.

Elton Ave. 758 (9-2378); Miriam Schulman to 5th Ave Bank; 5 years, 4 per cent; $14,000. Williamsbridge Rd (15-4087), s w side, at n w side of Sacket Ave, 287x86; B. C. Estates, Inc, to Rose Breithart, 714 E 4th St, Brooklyn: 6 per cent; $12,000.

One of the most interesting and important moves that have been undertaken on the European chessboard with peace or war as the ultimate stake was made today when General Ludwig Beck, chief of the German General Staff, paid a "courtesy call" on General Marie Gustave Gamelin, his opposite number in France.
Leon Trotsky, former Bolshevist leader now in exile, today offered to the Central Executive Committee of the Soviet Union his "complete support" to save Russia from "complete collapse."
The Hun School of Princeton will hold its annual commencement tomorrow afternoon at the school. The Rev. Walter E. Lowrie, canon of Trinity Cathedral at Trenton, will give the address.
