Bobby Pacho, Mexican welterweight from Los Angeles, outpointed Baby. Salvy Saban, Greenwich Village idol, in the feature bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden last night.

The two-year survey of American business profits made by the Twentieth Century Fund discloses that big business survived the depression better than did the "little fellow," the organization announced yesterday. Sheer size, however, was not responsible for this, according to the findings reported.

The $100,000 damage suit by four cousins of the late Elizabeth Ann Ahearn, school principal and chairman of the Welfare Board of Danvers, Mass., against the Compagnie Generale Transatlantique over her burial at sea after her death on the Ile de France on Aug. 4, 1935, went to trial yesterday before Federal Judge John C. Knox and a jury.
The Manufacturers Trust Company is registrar for 750,000 shares of common stock, 100,000 of prior preferred and 181,135 of $3 convertible preferred stock of the Chicago Pneumatic Tool Company.

Barney Ross of Chicago, world welterweight champion, slugged his ..ay to a four-round knockout vietory over Chuck Woods of Detroit in a non-title bout before 6,000 fans tonight. Ross weighed 143 and Woods 148.

Charges that the nine victims of the Memorial Day steel strike riots here gave "their lives, and scores of others have had their bodies maimed, in one of the most brutal massacres in the history of the struggles of labor," were made by John L. Lewis in a telegram read tonight at a mass meeting of 12,000 strikers and sympathizers in the Chicago Stadium.

Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, German Economics Minister, arrived here from Berlin this morning on a visit that will last until tomorrow night. He was greeted at the airfield by Dr. Wilhelm Taucher, Minister of Commerce; Dr. Viktor Kienboeck, president of the National Bank, and the German Ambassador, Franz von Papen.

Twelve opereating electric and gas utility companies of the Niagara Hudson Power System are to be merged into a new Consolidated Corporation with the approval of the Public Service Commission, it was announced today.

Miss Frances Elizabeth Morris, daughter of Lewis Gouverneur Morris of New York and this city, will be married June 30 to Harold Whitfield Carhart, son of Mr. and Mrs. H. W. Carhart of New York, at St. Ann's Church there.

The arrival of thousands of refugees from besieged Bilbao confronted Santander today with a grave food problem. Authorities of the city said they feared they would be unable to cope with the situation unless foreign nations came to their aid.

Dr. and Mrs. Herbert B. Wilcox of 39 East Seventy-fifth Street have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Louise Geer Wilcox, to William Richardson Knowlton, son of Mr. and Mrs. Eben Beers Knowlton of this city.

While asserting that the industry was in favor of the enactment of laws against misbranding of merchandise, the National Knitted Outerwear Association, in a memorandum submitted to the Senate Interstate Commerce Committee today, disapproved passage of the Fabric Labeling Act of 1937, known as the Capper bill, in its present form. The memorandum was submitted by Harold R. Lhowe, executive director of the association.

The net profit of the General Finance Corporation and subsidiaries for the six months ended on May 31, after all charges, including provision for Federal income tax, but before provision for preferred dividends and surtax on undistributed profits, was reported yesterday as $347,094.

The marriage of Miss Edna Mae Dingman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Ernest Dingman of Mount Vernon, to Lieutenant Robert Besson, U. S. A., son of Lieut. Col. Frank Schaeffer Besson, U. S. A., and Mrs. Besson of Washington, took place here at noon today in the Cadet Chapel. The Rev. H. Fairfield Butt 3d performed the ceremony.

The Buckingham Hall Apartments, a property with accommodations for 159 families, was among the parcels in Brooklyn passing to new ownership in deals reported yesterday. The structure consists of four units of six stories each and covers an area of 40,000 square feet on New York and St. Mark's Avenues and Bergen Street.

Following the appointment by Secretary Perkins of a board to mediate current steel labor disputes, Sheriff Ralph Elser of Mahoning County announced tonight that he had asked all parties to the strike, the union, employers and back-towork spokesmen, to maintain the status quo.

Officials of the United States Lines will confer tomorrow in Washington with the Maritime Commission and, it is expected, will sign an agreement for a new subsidy to replace the present mail subsidy contract.
There were some startling surprises in the first two rounds of the metropolitan amateur golf championship at the Metropolis Club today, the chief one being the dethronement of George T. Dunlap Jr.

A decided sentiment in favor of a return to the two-cent postage rate was expressed today by members of a House Postoffice Subcommittee, who promised that "careful consideration" would be given proposals for a uniform postal rate for Greater New York.
Dictators and bigots of the present day were denounced by Borough President Samuel Levy at the sixth commencement exercises of Yeshiva College yesterday.
The State Department of Labor intervened in eighty-four strikes in May in an attempt to effect a peaceful settlement, Elmer F. Andrews, State Industrial Commissioner, reported yesterday.
Relatives here have received word of the death yesterday in San Francisco of Federico Mejia, Salvadorean Minister to Washington in 1907. His age was 76.

A fourth trial of the divorce suit brought by Joseph Kimball, Yonkers real estate operator, against Mrs. Gladys Kimball, Federal theatre project actress, was in prospect yesterday after the jury at the third trial failed to agree.

Edward W. Joyce, Boston business man and Catholic leader, addressing the graduates of St. Michael's College in the presence of hundreds of alumni and visitors, declared today that the prevailing disregard for law in America results from the rejection of belief in God.

Stocks recovered and closed irregular; steel shares rallied sharply on news of strike-mediation board; turnover, 1,259,000 shares. United States Government bonds irregular, corporate issues lower, foreign loans steady; transactions, $7,910,700.

Prices on the Cotton Exchange were irregular over a range of $1 a bale yesterday and closed 4 to 8 points higher. An early decline which followed a sharp break in Liverpool was halted by the news that a labor mediation board had been appointed by the President and an active covering movement more than recovered the early losses.

Despite appearances to the contrary, Germany's export drive for cash is still going strong and is moreover putting her foreign trade on a healthier basis which enables her to buy cheaper, sell dearer and stock up gold reserves to boot.

In announcing on Wednesday to the House of Commons a tax of 5 per cent per annum on all profits of British industry over [Pound]2,000, the Ministry has adroitly covered its recent retreat from the "profits tax plan" of April.

The marriage of Miss Phyllis Edwards Abbe, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James E. Abbe, to David O'Donnell Kennedy, son of Mrs. David E. Kennedy of this city, and the late Mr. Kennedy, took place yesterday at the home of the bride's parents in Hudson View Gardens.

The marriage of Miss Frances Crooke, daughter of Mrs. Julia Crooke of New York, to Frederick Sugden Murphy, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick D. Murphy of Montclair, N. J., took place here today at the home of her sister, Mrs. Willis H. Taylor Jr.

Deaths Announced Fireman Ist Grade James V. Dobbins of H. L. 130 died June 14. Funeral will take place from Simms Funeral Chapel, 37-12 104th St., Corona, Queens, at 9:30 A. M., Friday, June 18. Interment at Mount St. Mary's Cemetery, Flushing.

Evidence that the Long Island Lighting Company "wrote-up" the book values of subsidiaries after their purchase was submitted yesterday to Supreme Court Justice Aaron J. Levy in the trial of a stockholders' suit to compel various present and former officials

Three more buildings in the recreated home town of Abraham Lincoln were dedicated here today. Sixteen of the original twenty-five buildings in the pioneer village where Lincoln was reared have been reproduced in the park here. Nearly $450,000 has been spent in this memorial.

Mayor La Guardia, addressing 525 graduatess last night at the eleventh annual commencement exercises of the Central Needle Trades High School, in the Washington Irving High School, Irving Place and Seventeenth Street, asserted the United States is now entering upon a new and better age in which the working people of the nation will be able to obtain "the better things of life."

The differences between the American Federation of Labor and the Committee for Industrial Organization resulted in disorder last night at a meeting of the Central Trades and Labor Council in Beethoven Hall, 210 East Fifth Street.

Manhattan Alterations 7th St, 168-170; to 5-story tenement; Chafranc Corp, 45 Astor Pl, owner; Jacob Fisher. architect; cost, $12,000. Broad St, 24-28; to 16-story offices; New York Stock Exchange Building Co, 11 Wall St, owner; J. L. Cassidy, architect; cost, $10,000.

Prices of commodity futures were generally steady in moderate activity on the local markets yesterday. Rubber, cocoa and coffee futures were firmer. On the cash market, cocoa, cotton, rubber, rye, oats and flour advanced, but tin, wheat, corn and lard declined.

A neatly dressed, middle-aged woman went into a frenzy early this morning aboard an Erie train as it was entering the Pearl River station, breaking eighteen window panes in a coach and manhandling two members of the train crew and two policemen before she was subdued.

Declaring that New York City has men capable of filling all public offices, Supreme Court Justice William T. Collins, who was the guest of honor last night at the twentythird anniversary dinner of the New York Society for the City of New York, criticized Mayor La Guardia for appointing men not natives of the metropolitan area.

Eugene H. Amory, through Douglas L. Elliman Co, Inc, twelve rooms, in 30 E. 71st St; Carroll B. Alker, through Ralph Bloomer, ten rooms in 888 Park Ave; F. Huntington Babcock, through Douglas L. Elliman Co, Inc, ten rooms, in 885 Park Ave; Tishman Realty Construction Co, owner.

Fifty-six feature productions and 198 short subjects will be released by RKO-Radio Pictures during the 1937-38 season, it was announced yesterday by Ned E. Depinet, vice president, at the company's sales convention in Hollywood.

Confessional Synod pastors announced in thronged Berlin churches last night that half the members of the governing council of the Prussian Confessional Church had been arrested and the remainder were hiding from the secret police.

Cardinal Hayes will conduct funeral services for Morgan J. O'Brien, former presiding justice of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court, tomorrow at 11 A. M. at the Catholic Church of St. Vincent Ferrer, Sixty-sixth Street and Lexington Avenue.

The Transamerica Corporation will buy its own stock for retirement to "protect the interests of stockholders," John M. Grant, president of the holding company, announced today in a letter to stockholders. He said in part:
Secretary Perkins appointed a Federal Board of Mediation, upon President Roosevelt's instructions, to seek peace in the steel strike. C. P. Taft 2d will head the board. Page 1.
President Roosevelt conferred with Secretary Perkins on the steel strike situation, after which she announced the appointment of a Steel Mediation Board to attempt settlement of the controversy.

Miss May Louise Bodenheimer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leon M. Bodenheimer of this city, was married last night in the Empire Room of the Waldorf-Astoria to Thomas H. Loeb, son of Mrs. Anna Loeb of Chicago, by the Rev. Dr. Jonah B. Wise.
The stock market firmness which developed yesterday was well maintained today, but, with the approaching end of the account, business continued on a small scale.

About 200 porters, bellhops, painters, garage employes, electricians, engineers, carpenters, upholsterers and chambermaids, all members of the Building Service Employes Union, Local 65, an affiliate of the American Federation of Labor, went on strike at the Hotel Amhassador here at 5 P. M. today.

Movements of livestock on the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts, 9,000 including 3,500 direct; strong to 10 cents higher than yesterday's average; medium grade hogs mostly 25-50 cents lower than good and choice kinds;

A new contender for juvenile honors was uncovered yesterday at Aqueduct when Mrs. Parker Corning's Thanksgiving, a son of Bud Lerner, was turned loose down the chute in the Hornpipe Purse and made a procession of a race that was supposed to be between Endvmion and Transmitter.

Mr. and Mrs. John Lawler of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Kathryn Lawler, to Richard Nye Gulick, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles P. Gulick, also of East Orange. The announcement was made tonight at a buffet supper at the Lawler home.

With the assertion that "tax ethics generally today are where business ethics and trade practices were in the Nineties," Secretary of the Treasury Morgenthau today carried to Congress a request that it plug up loopholes in the present income tax structure through which hundreds of millions of dollars of revenue are said to be lost to the government each year.

Speculation over the possibility that the Duke and Duchess of Windsor may visit or even settle in the United States was revived today by the disclosure that the Duke's solicitor. A. G. Allen, had sailed on the Queen Mary last night for New York on a "business trip."

World business and industry showed further expansion in April, with trade reaching the highest mark since 1931, although the seasonally unadjusted figures for the latter were slightly lower, owing to the shorter month, according to the current issue of The Annalist.

Forced to adopt a missionary budget for 1938 that is $100,000 under the anticipated figure, the National Council of the Protestant Episcopal Church expressed alarm and dissatisfaction at the lack of interest among members of the church in missionary affairs, at the close of a two-day meeting yesterday at the Episcopal Church Mission House, 281 Fourth Avenue.

Reiterating his hope of balancing the budget next year, President Roosevelt today warned Congress that enactment of a bill to continue the present 3 1/2 per cent interest rate on Federal Land Bank loans and to lower rates on other loans would cost the government $40,000,000.
The men chosen by President Roosevelt to mediate the steel strike have all been impressed into previous service by him in the settlement of labor disputes.

The Warren County Board of Supervisors today adopted a resolution establishing a motor boat safety zone within 200 feet of the mainland or any island within Warren County as a means of curbing what was termed "reckless operation" of speed boats and to prevent accidents through collision of the faster boats with slower craft and with swimmers.

The marriage of Miss Beulah Hoffberg, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Hoffberg of this city, to Leslie Handler, son of Mrs. George Handler of New York and the late Mr. Handler, took place last night in the Waldorf-Astoria.

163d St (10-2714), n w cor of Fox St. 78x 76; Banner Estates, Inc, to Semons Products, Corp 1,989 Anthony Ave. Elton Ave, 758 (9-2378); Fifth Ave. Bank, agent, to Mariam Schulman, 1,720 University Ave. 156th St, 870 E (10-2687); Annie L. Deuel to Archie B. Morrison, 426 E 143d St. 241st St (17-5059), ?? s, 33 ft w of Seton Ave, 33x100; Cortlandt Savings Bank to Vincent Mastromarino, 9 South 10th Ave, Mount Vernon.

Mayor LaGuardia at noon yesterday officially opened for traffic an improved $1,000,000 five-lane roadway replacing old paving on the Queensboro Bridge. It was constructed in the face of unparalleled difficulties in eighteen months by WPA labor supervised by the- Department of Plant and Structures.

Active early buying for August sales and on merchandise for initial Fall delivery has been done on lower end furs which have not participated to any material extent in the rise of from 35 to 50 per cent on the more expensive skins.

Bayard W. Read, '26, of New York City, a member of Princeton's undefeated lightweight crew of 1926, has presented to the university an eight-oared shell as a tribute to Gordon G. Sikes, his former coach, now retiring as amateur head coach of Nassau crews, it was announced tonight by Professor Burnham N. Dell, chairman of the University Council on Athletics.
The following Coast Guard orders for the week ended June 16 were announced today: Wolff, Dist. Cmdr. W. M., promoted to Dist. Comdr., Lt. Comdr., with rank from Jan. 31, 1937.

Government investigators have been following for three months a trail of forgeries attributed to a $2,400 payroll clerk in the National Park Service arrested for cashing checks for more than $7,000 made out to non-existent persons whose names he had added to the rolls in various parts of the country.
The "key town" of Chimillas, just west of Huesca on the Aragon front in Northern Spain, was destroyed today by government artillery, government commanders reported.

Spanish diplomatic representatives to many countries met here today in a joint conference with members of the Loyalist government. It was the first time such a meeting had been held since the formation of the second republic and it was summoned at a critical period for the Loyalist cause.

The engagement of Miss Margot Loines, daughter of Mrs. Russell Hillard Loines of 232 East Fortyninth Street and Seven Gates Farm, Vineyard Haven, Mass., and the late Mr. Loines, to Dwight Whitney Morrow Jr., son of Mrs. Dwight Whitney Morrow of Englewood, N. J., and the late Senator Morrow, has been announced by her mother.
Ely Culbertson's New York team led Hungary by 730 points tonight at the half-way point in their match in the semi-finals of the contract bridge championship for open teams of four.

Present day building practices put a premium on economy at the expense of quality are producing faulty and deficient structural designs, Samuel Fassler, Manhattan Commissioner of Buildings, told forty engineers and steel men at a luncheon in the Building Trades Employers Association at 2 Park Avenue yesterday.

The wedding of Miss Hannah Louise Valentine, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Melvin Sheldon Valentine of this city, to Alexander Berthold Timm Jr., son of Dr. Alexander B. Timm of New York, took place in St. James's Episcopal Church this afternoon.

Miss Evelyn Buck Adriance, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert I. Adriance of this place, and Dr. E. Kenneth Miles, son of Mrs. Kirk Miles of Appleton, Wis., and the late Mr. Miles, were married this evening in the garden of the home of the bride's parents.

The wedding of Miss Ina Margaret Schmidt, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Henning Schmidt of this place, to William Newell Tilton Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. W. N. Tilton, also of Englewood, took place this evening in the First Methodist Episcopal Church here.
Because a single employee, a woman, refused to join their association, 165 employes of the Cooper Oven Thermometer and Horace R. Whittier Companies refused to work today.

The General Motors Corporation and General Motors Sales Corporation, were accused today by the Federal Trade Commission of trying to monopolize the sale of automobile parts, accessories and supplies by compelling dealers in General Motors cars to buy parts exclusively from General Motors or affiliates.
Cornell University looked forward today to entertaining more than 2,000 alumni in the three-day reunion opening tomorrow.

To those who regard the unity or tne American people as a priceless heritage of the past and who wish to preserve that unity in the face of influences which would readily destroy it, events of the past few months have been disturbing.

From her bed in Lincoln Hospital, where she lay in a critical condition yesterday, 10-year-old Mary Maglione of 796 East 161st Street, the Bronx, positively identified a 26-year-old Negro as the man who lured her into a Bronx theatre Wednesday morning, beat her into unconsciousness when she resisted him and locked her in a suborchestra tunnel.

Trading was active to fair. Prices showed little change on traefa meats. Thursday being an off kosher day, the slaughter of those classes dressed kosher was light. Kosher business was confined mostly to lamb at sharply higher prices, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.

Mr. and Mrs. Thomas I. Hare Powel, who are at their Summer home, Hopelands, entertained with a dinrier dance there tonight in honor of Miss Hope Linton Drury, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Holland Drury, and Robert H. I. Goddard Jr. of Providence, who tomorrow noon are to be married at Berkeley Memorial Church by Bishop James De Wolf Perry of the Episcopal Church.
Amelia Earhart took of from Dumdum airdrome near here at 6:42 A. M. today [8:49 P. M. Thursday, Eastern daylight time] for Bangkok, Siam, on the next leg of her flight around the middle of the earth.

Offering was made yesterday in Canada only of $31,000,000 of bonds of the Province of Quebec by a group headed by the Royal Bank of Canada and the Provincial Bank of Canada and including the Bank of Nova Scotia, the Canadian Bank of Commerce, W. C. Pitfield Co., Ltd.; Wood, Gundy Co., Ltd.;
Hundreds of men who were frightened away by strikers' attacks early this week returned to work today through dwindling picket lines at the huge Cambria plant of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In THE NEW YORK TIMES of June 16 there was printed a letter which I wrote to The New York Sun on Nov. 2, 1935, dealing with the question of whether employers were required by the National Labor Relations Act to negotiate and sign written agreements.

Because of what union officials characterized as an impasse in the negotiations for a new agreement with the four employer associations in the industry, the executive boards of the eight cloakmakers' unions in the city, representing a membership of about 40,000, met last night at the Center Hotel, 106 West Fortythird Street, to consider the situation, including possible strike action.

The police could produce no proof that Adolph Ackerman, 40 years old, of 2,323 Mermaid Avenue, Coney Island, and Harry Inberman, 36, of 8 St. Mark's Place had been engaged in anything unlawful last June 5, when detectives of the Safe and Loft Squad arrested them on burglary charges as they were leaving a loft building at 21 East Eighth Street.

Announcement was made yesterday of a proposal to form a "Senior Margin Clerks' Section" of the Association of Stock Exchange Firms with the main purpose of clarifying SEC and Federal Reserve margin rules and regulations.

Premier Paul van Zeeland of Belgium is taking with him to Washington an idea, if not a plan, for solving through the Bank for International Settlements the problem of foreign financing, according to reports here.

Miss Frances Hamilton Robertson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis H. Robertson of Westport and Path Valley, Pa., was married today to Irving McKee of Culver, Ind., in the Church of Holy Trinity, Westport. The Rev. Arthur H. Moffatt,

A special weather forecasting bureau has been installed in the administration building of Jones Beach to be used in conjunction with the season of Gallo-Shubert operetta productions, which starts Saturday night, June 26.

The wrath of the government-controlled press was turned today against Czechoslovakia for alleged insults and brutalities by police and customs officials. Two separate incidents furnished the material for the protests.

Full constitutional guaranatees were restored to Brazil's 47,000,000 people today after a nineteen-month "state of war." The move was interpreted by observers as an effort to weaken the campaign arguments of a Presidential candidate.

Motion picture extras and bit players in the few active studios left in the East will receive the full Hollywood wage scale and all benefits guaranteed under the contract of the Screen Actors Guild with producers after Aug. 1, it was announced here yesterday by Kenneth Thompson, secretary of the Guild.
Luncheon of the Circus Saints and Sinners. Hotel Commodore, noon. David Sarnoff, guest of honor. Pageant of the United Scottish Clans of New York and New Jersey, Randalls Island, 8:30 P. M.
BAYONNE--Basque representatives announced that the government had left Bilbao to set up the capital at an unrevealed sent place. A junta of four has taken over defense of the city.
Moro Chieftain Amai Millon hoisted the red flag of rebellion in the Mindanao Island jungles and promptly received an ultimatum tonight to surrender or take the consequences.
The body of Charles Lathrop Pack, founder of the American Tree Association, was buried today in the Pack Demonstration Forest he had given to the State.
Continued weakness of farm prices sent wholesale price levels still lower in the week ended on June 12, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today.
Robert Rankins Brown, a leader in the casualty insurance business, died yesterday morning at his home in Englewood, N. J., after a long illness. He was 67 years old.
The thirtieth annual commencement exercises of Concordia Collegiate Institute will be held tomorrow night in the Schoenfeld Gymnasium on the campus here.

Cardinal Hayes has appointed the Rev. Dr. Edward Roberts Moore, sociologist, as the new pastor of St. Peter's Church, Barclay and Church Streets, the oldest Catholic parish in the Archdiocese of New York. The church was founded in 1785.

Twenty-five hundred children, winners of awards in the city-wide contests conducted this season by the Music Education League, took part in a concert and presentation of prizes last night at Carnegie Hall in celebration of the league's fourteenth anniversary.
Not to be outdone by the steam railroads and the ship lines, the Independent Subway has a "mystery trip" of its own these days for night riders on its Washington Heights line.

About 800 persons attended a mass meeting last night at Hunts Point Palace, 163d Street and Southern Boulevard, the Bronx, held by the Friends of Social Justice and the American Association Against Communism.

Professor Milton P. Kleintop, who had been Associate Professor of English at Wagner Memorial Lutheran College, Grymes Hill. S. I., since last year, has been appointed dean of the college by the board of trustees, Dr. Clarence C. Stoughton, president, announced yesterday.
America qualified two men for the semifinals of the Queens Club tennis tournament today and temporarily lost the services of the "Atlanta atom," Bryan (Bitsy) Grant.

The time has come to reveal certain facts, ignorance of which explains the confusion prevailing among the public in regard to the true meaning of the latest developments in the international situation-for example, the coming visit to London of Baron Constantin von Neurath, German Foreign Minister.

Charges that the Chicago police were guilty of "cold-blooded and deliberate murder" in the riot at the Republic Steel Company's plant on Memorial Day, in which nine persons were killed, and that they were "notoriously corrupt and in complete alliance with the steel corporation," were made today by Philip Murray, chairman of the C. I. O. Steel Workers Organizing Committee, before the Senate Postoffice and Post Roads Committee.

MANHATTAN CARLISLE, EMILY S. (May 4). Estate, more than $10,000. To Georgia A. Fanning, friend, Hotel Seville, life estate in residue; Florence Mary Carlisle, sister, Surrey, England, succeeding estate in residue; Anna C. King, Osgashope, Longlelore, England; George Carlisle, Richmond, England, and William Carlisle, Alberta, Canada. equal remainders in residue. Charles P. Rogers, 300 W. 108th St., executor.

Grand National Films, Inc., in a report to shareholders, has disclosed an agreement to hire A. Pam Blumenthal for three years starting on Aug. 1 at $1,000 a week, plus options on 10,000 shares of common stock at $3 a share in August, 1938, a similar amount at $4 a share in August, 1939, and a similar amount at $5 a share in August, 1940.
The annual commencement program of the Lawrenceville School here will open tomorrow morning with class day exercises on the front campus of the school. William G. Larsen of Lima, Ohio, will preside.
The text of Secretary Morgenthau's statement on tax dodging, submitted today to the Joint Congressional Committee of Inquiry, was as follows:

Mrs. Louise Mengel McCuteheon of Garth Road, Scarsdale, widow of James M. McCutcheon, president of the Fifth Avenue Linen Company, died today in St. Agnes Hospital here. She was 68 years old. Mr. McCutcheon died seven years ago.

The Securities and Exchange Commission today issued a summary of the daily figures on odd-lot transactions of odd-lot dealers and specialists in stocks, rights and warrants on the New York Stock Exchange for the week ended on June 12, intended to show purchases and sales in lots of less than 100 shares which it is believed reflect transactions by the public.

W. H. Winterrowd of New York, vice president of the Franklin Railway Supply Company, today told the mechanical division of the Association of American Railroads, which is in convention here, that the steam locomotive was the backbone of American railway transportation.

Miss Alyse Matthews Hunneman, a Philadelphia debutante who was to have been a bridesmaid at the wedding of Miss Ethel du Pont and Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr., died tonight in the Women's Hospital, Baltimore. She was 20.
The General Assembly of Spiritualists opened its annual session with a dinner last night at Pythian Temple, 135 West Seventieth Street. More than 300 attended.

A banking syndicate headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., submitted yesterday the highest bid for a new issue of $10,066,000 of consolidated bonds of the State of Tennessee, offering a price of 100.405 for $5,867,000 of refunding bonds as 3 1/2s and $4,199,000 of county-reimbursement bonds as 3 1/4s. Both issues are to be dated June 1, 1937, and to mature on Dec. 1, 1944 to 1949.
Deposits in the Bank of Canada declined about $5,000,000 in the week ended yesterday, the weekly statement disclosed today, and holdings of gold coin and bullion were down about $500,000.

Isidore Astel, patrolman wounded in December, 1936, while exchanging shots with a hold-up man whom he killed, received yesterday from Mayor La Guardia the badge of a third-grade detective, the rank to which he was promoted for his bravery.

Further selling in a broad list of secondary corporate issues featured another dull trading session in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. Trading was given over largely to a general readjustment of values of issues which had not sold recently.

For the first time in the country's history, the national debt on June 15 passed the $36,000,000,000 mark, reaching $36,633,907,803, according to the latest daily statement of the Treasury Department.
" Oh, Daedalus, my father, I will fly To those Olympic regions of the sun, That toiling farmers leave their plows to run And follow my curved flight through morning sky;

The War Department released the following orders today, dated June 16: COLONELS Barnes. J. F.. F.A., three months and seven days' leave, June 23. Smith, F. H.. C.A.C.. three months' leave, July 12, with permission to visit foreign countries.

A total of 110 teachers in the public and parochial schools of New York City have completed the Spring course in physical and moral training of children given under the auspices of the Police Academy, it was announced yesterday by Deputy Chief Inspector John J. O'Connell, dean of the academy.

The all-day Westchester fete held today at the Century Country Club in Purchase under the auspices of the Westchester Chapter of the Women's Division of the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies of New York, attracted more than 1,500 persons.

Increased output of durable goods and heavier freight movement, after allowance for seasonal fluctuations, raised The Annalist index of business activity for May to only slightly below the high level for last December.
A survey by the Bureau of Labor Statistics disclosed today that all except three of the Latin-American republics have enacted general legislation affecting the working day for industrial workers.

The Mifflin Chemical Company of this city, a large-scale manufacturer of rubbing alcohol, three other concerns and thirteen persons have been indicted in an alleged conspiracy to convert denatured alcohol into beverage liquors in "recapturing plants" in this area.
Chicago at New York--T. Lee vs. Makosky. St. Louis at Washington--Bonetti vs. De Shong. Cleveland at Boston--Allen vs. Ostermueller. (Only games scheduled.)

Professor Joannes Dusser de Barenne of Yale University and .Mrs. Dusser de Barenne have announced the marriage of their daughter, Miss Charlotte Dusser de Barenne, to D. Crosby Greene Jr., which took place yesterday at the home of the bride.

A shift from the effort on the part of plant hybridizers to produce ever bigger and more colorful blooms to the development of strains biologically immune to various diseases has been revealed in discussions by experts connected with the AllAmerica Council for Plant Selections, a body sponsored by the American Seed Trade Association, which opened its annual convention here Tuesday.

Miss Helen Hicks did her part again today, but Miss Dorothy Foster, 23-yearold music teacher from Springfield, Ill., wrecked prospects for an all "business woman" final in the Women's Western open tournament by conquering Miss Mildred (Babe) Didrikson in a 19-hole struggle at the Beverly Country Club.

Mayor La Guardia declared that higher education is as much of a responsibility to a community as primary and high school education, in a speech last night at a dinner in honor of Dr. Paul Klapper, president of Queens College, which will be opened on Kissena Boulevard, Flushing, next Fall with a freshman-class enrollment.

Of MORGAN O'BRIEN, the lawyer and the judge, it is superfluous to speak. The elder titans of the bar, Mr. ROOT and Mr. CHOATE, wrote his fame far higher than any layman's praise can reach when, with the approval of their fellow-lawyers in New York, they asked that he be appointed an associate justice of the Supreme Court of the United States.
The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:...

Dowager Queen Marie at Sinaia today received a three-hour visit from King Carol, who had just returned from Transylvania. Former Queen Elizabeth of Greece arrived at Sinaia to remain with her mother, Queen Mother Marie of Yugoslavia, Princess Hohenlohe, the Rumanian Dowager Queen's elder sister, having left.
The administrative order of Secretary Perkins setting up a mediation board to attempt a settlement of the Midwest steel strike, read as follows:

Canada's domestic exports for May totaled $99,497,000, an increase of $15,677,000, or 18 per cent, over May, 1936. The rise in exports to the United States alone was $15,409,000, that country taking Canadian goods to the value of $43,956,000, compared to $28,547,000 a year before, an increase of 54 per cent.
Morris S. Tremaine, State Controller, urge today immediate repeal of the Federal law taxing capital gains as income. In an address prepared for delivery

Dizzy Dean remarked he didn't feel very well when he took the mound for the Cardinals against the Phillies today, and the ace hurler felt worse when the game ended. Philadelphia won, 13 to 7, and Dean didn't last through the contest.

Radio progress in all branches of the science, including television, will be exhibited and demonstrated in a "temple of magic" to be erected at the World's Fair by the Radio Corporation of America, it was announced yesterday by David Sarnoff, president of RCA.

Five members of the class which was graduated from Hunter College on Wednesday have received scholarships from the Hebrew Technical School for Girls for advanced study, it was announced yesterday by Dean Hannah M. Egan. The students are:

Ninety women visited James McGurrin, Deputy Commissioner of Jurors, in the Hall of Records yesterday to declare themselves ready for jury service. Their names, the commissioner said, would be placed on the same jury panels as men.

Unless some "accident" happens it is expected that the Senate tomorrow will reluctantly and by a small majority give its assent to the government's request for full powers to deal with the financial situation.

King Boris decreed an amnesty this evening to mark the birth of a Bulgarian Crown Prince. Of 15,000 political and common-law prisoners, 5,000 serving sentences up to three years will be released tomorrow.

Another group under Harvard's new scholarship plan was announced today as President Conant gave out a list of thirty-two high school and private school students, chosen for the highest awards given entering freshmen, and of thirtyseven others, to whom were granted other scholarships.
Members of Kansas Chapter, Delta Upsilon fraternity, at Lawrence, Kan., want a photograph of Stephen Crane, the author, who was a member of the fraternity at Syracuse University.
Improved conditions in the industrial realty market are reported by members of the Industrial Real Estate Brokers Association, comprising those active in this field in the metropolitan area.

Further complications arose in the postponed WPA Theatre production of Marc Blitzstein's opera, "The Cradle Will Rock," last night when more than. 100 persons appeared at the box office of the Maxine Elliott Theatre, on West Thirty-ninth Street, and demanded a refund on their tickets.
Sir Squire Sprigge, editor of The Lancet, the world's best known medical publication, died today. He would have been 77 years old on Tuesday.
Pierre Cot, French Air Minister, dedicating the new Herignac airport, said today that France's air force would number 1,680 planes by the end of the year.

The Federal Trade Commission today ordered the National Kream Company, Inc., and its distributing subsidiary, National Foods, Inc., both of 360 Furman Street, Brooklyn, to stop representing certain of their products as "pure preserves" or "pure jam" when it fails to abide by the accepted housewife's formula of one cup of sugar to one cup of fruit in the making of these products.

Secretary Morgenthau today announced that tenders will be received at 2 P. M. on next Monday at Federal Reserve Banks or their branches on an issue of $50,000,000 of Treasury 273-day bills to be sold on a discount basis to the highest bidders.

Miss Kate Cary gave a tea this afternoon at Meadow Place, the Lenox branch of the Berkshire County Home for Aged Women, which she founded. At the tea tables were Miss Louisa G. Ludlow, Miss Nancy T. Patten, daughter of Mrs. Thomas Frederick Davies, and Mrs. James Dwight Francis.
Sales of houses for cash featured real estate trading on the West Side yesterday. Two of the deals involved brownstones which the buyers plan to alter.

A new plant is to be erected by the General Motors Corporation in Trenton, N. J., in a $15,000,000 construction program, E. F. Fisher, general manager of the Fisher Body Division, announced yesterday.

A four-day search of thickly underbrushed land adjoining the farm of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Parsons has brought no clues to Mrs. Parsons's mysterious disappearance eight days ago, Inspector Earl J. Connelly of the Federal Bureau of Investigation said tonight, and will be discontinued after two more days.

The announcement by Franz Machnik, Minister of War, in the Chamber today of a far-reaching and drastic measure for the defense of the republic might suggest that the leaders of this country are prey to anxieties regarding the military situation.
With 175 of the country's best show horses entered, the eighteenth annual Troy exhibition opened today on the grounds of the Troy Riding Club before a crowd of 2,000.
According to reports from Innsbruck, many shipments of war material have been crossing Austrian territory from Germany to Italy during the last few weeks.

The Roxy's new tenant this morning is "Sing and Be Happy," a musical comedy from the Twentieth Century-Fox studios featuring Tony Martin, Leah Ray, Joan Davis, Dixie Dunbar, Helen Westley and Chick Chandler.
The Rev. Hugh Joseph McManus, one of the oldest Dominican priests in point of service in the United States, died yesterday in St. Michael's Hospital after a brief illness at the age of 82.

The peace and freedom of the world depend on a close understanding between the British Commonwealth and the United States, Lord Tweedsmuir, Governor General of Canada, today told the second conference on Canadian- American Affairs, meeting here at Queen's University.
More than 500 degrees will be awarded at the commencement of the New York State College for Teachers on Monday. Of these, 402 will be undergraduate degrees, with 100 getting master's degrees.

With a score of shipyards and repair plants employing some 12,000 workers remaining closed in the New York-New Jersey area because of the strike of International Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America, C. I. O. affiliate, the National Labor Relations Board intervened yesterday in an effort to pave the way for a settlement.

Routine drills marked the activities of the Poughkeepsie regatta crews today, with the evening workouts cut short by rough water and the threat of showers. A rumor that the Washington jayvee crew may be substituted for the present varsity is largely discounted at other crew quarters.

A decline of $180,000,000 in the excess reserves of member banks, resuiting from subscriptions to the $852,754,300 of Treasury financing on Tuesday, was reported in the weekly statement of the Federal Reserve System, issued yesterday.
A strike of 450 hotel workers ended today when operators of seven hotels signed a contract guaranteeing virtually a closed shop to seven unions. A forty-eight-hour week

Scacchettt Siegel have been appointed architects for the first unit in the Childs Company's new low-priced restaurant chain, which will be known as the Host, Inc. The restaurant will be located at 32 East Twenty-third Street and alterations will cost about $30,000.
Ten man may not be too widely darkNew York State boys were among the class graduated today from St. George's School at the annual prize day exercises.
Mayor S. Davis Wilson told representatives of both sides in the truck drivers' strike at The Evening Bulletin today that they must "settle the trouble in twenty-four hours."

Sherman Foote Denton, 80-year-old naturalist, died today at his home. For many years he mounted fish specimens for Smithsonian Institution, the Field Museum in Chicago, Agassiz Museum at Harvard University and many other institutions here and abroad.

Howard R. Stiles of 144-70 Roosevelt Avenue, Flushing, a wholesale furniture dealer, died on Wednesday in Flushing Hospital after a brief illness. He was 49 years old. His offices were at 1 Park Avenue, Manhattan.

Lumber production increased last week, but the daily average was not much higher than in the previous holiday week, so that the adjusted index was only slightly higher at 95.9, which compared with 95.8 in the preceding week and 80.7 for the week ended June 13, 1936.

Julia Ann Wilkinson of Des Moines, Iowa, has won a scholarship for foreign study awarded by the trustees of the Frank Huntingdon Beebe Fund for Musicians, it was announced yesterday. The scholarship is for one year, beginning Sept. 1.

The twenty-story Hotel Taft, in the east blockfront of Seventh Avenue between Fiftieth and Fiftyfirst Streets, was among the five Manhattan properties sold at auction yesterday in the Vesey Street salesrooms.
Istanbul, which used to be Constantinople, announces in matterof-fact tones the liquidation of a Kurdish
Figures on changes in holdings of reacquired stock, made public yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange and the New York Curb Exchange, contained few movements which could be considered significant.

With the opening of the annual Meadow Brook Club Cups polo tournament only two days off, ten of the thirteen teams entered took part in practice matches today. Four of the five games were decided by one-goal margins.

Employment on Federal work relief projects dropped to 1,980,236 in the week ending June 5, a decline of 19,033 in a week. In the preceding week the number employed fell below 2,000,000 for the first time since November, 1935.

Dr. and Mrs. Le Roy L. Scott of this place and Ocean Grove, N. J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Clara Elizabeth Scott, to Harry Parberry Green, son of Mrs. Harry Green of East Orange and the late Mr. Green.

Two Pittsburgh women reached the final of the State golf championship today. Miss Betty Abernethy of the Oakmont Club defeated Miss Virginia Fox of Harrisburg, three-time Central Pennsylvania title-holder, 2 up.

Actual payment of the first 5 per cent dividend on the deposits frozen early in 1933 by the closing of the Atlantic City National Bank, will begin Monday. It will spread out over about a ten-day period and will total. about $500,000.

Miss Denise du Pont, adopted daughter of Mrs. Alfred I. du Pont, was married on May 22 to Carl Zapffe, a Harvard graduate student, Mrs. du Pont announced today. The wedding took place at Christ Episcopal Church in Cambridge, Mass.

The Board of Examiners reports that there have been placed upon the eligible list of holders of licenses for service in day high schools the names of the following applicants, who have been granted licenses, as indicated:

The establishment of a storm corps for the Patriotic Front-a sort of Austrian Elite Guard- is now under consideration. The plan has progressed so far that steps are being taken to enroll in Vienna the former members of the Heimwehr and Sturmascharen.
Charles A. Nash Jr., 22-year-old Saginaw (Mich.) Naval Academy graduate who lost his ensign's commission because he married while still a midshipman, may also lose his bride.

Sixteen college students interested in careers in city service were assigned to various city departments by Mayor La Guardia at City Hall yesterday and received scholarships of $50 a month during July and August to aid their education.

Dwight School will hold its fiftyseventh annual commencement exercises tonight at the school at 72 Park Avenue. Dr. Charles Gordon Post, Assistant Professor of Political Science at Vassar College and a graduate of Dwight, will give the commencement address.

Weidlich Bros. Mfg. Co., silversmiths, in 362 5th Ave; through James Felt Co. United Cigar-Whelan Stores Corp., two stores in 20-22 University P1, from the trustees of Sailor's Snug Harbor; Cushman's Sons, Inc., two stores in 390 3d Ave, from Ottmann estate; Bl??nat, Inc., dresses, additional store space in 783 Madison Ave; J. B. Feuerstein, tailor, store at 136 E 61st St; Beatrice Polan, dresses, store at 825 Lexington Ave; John A. Ward, broker.
British business -accepted the new profits tax so philosophically today that the government's proposals are fairly certain to have smooth passage when they come before the House of Commons Monday.

The program of campus activities leading up to Princeton University's 190th commencement exercises on Tuesday began today and the vanguard of some 4,000 alumni who are expected to attend was busy establishing class headquarters for reunions.
The Securities and Exchange Commission has called hearings on applications for the delisting of twelve security issues from National Securities Exchanges.

Charles M. Schwab, veteran chairman of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, returned yesterday on the North German Lloyd liner Europa to face the worst labor troubles known to the steel industry since the Homestead riot in 1892.

Judge John R. McLane of Manchester was the speaker at the "Last Night" exercises at St. Paul's School tonight and diplomas were awarded to seventy-three graduates by Reeve Schley. Bishop Dallas of the diocese of New Hampshire gave the benediction.

Wesleyan defeated Williams, 5 to 4, in an eleven-inning game today after coming from behind in the ninth to tie the score. The triumph placed the Cardinals in a tie with Amherst for the Little Three lead, and the title will be decided when Wesleyan plays at Amherst tomorrow.
The Twig Realty Corporation, S. J. Kaplan, president, purchased from Herbert M. Palmer the twostory business building at 171 Mamaroneck Avenue, White Plains, N. Y.

A jury before Federal Judge Vincent L. Leibell brought. in a verdict of guilty yesterday against the Yvette Company, which operates a chain of beauty shops, and David Oppenheim, its vice president and general manager, on a charge of failing to report $51,924 in income taxes due for 1927 and 1928.

Three Soviet airmen were passing over Arctic wastes late last night in an attempt to fly from Moscow to Oakland, Calif., non-stop, over the perilous 6,000-mile North Pole route. Battling unfavorable weather and apparently making only about 100 miles an hour, the airmen had taken their Soviet-built monoplane about halfway between Franz Josef Land and the Pole by 10:10 o'clock last night, Eastern daylight time.
Building projects submitted in the city yesterday included plans for several new houses in Queens and a garage in Manhattan to cost $100,000.

Mayor J. P. Nanney said that a number of employes of Reed Brothers Manufacturing Company "invited" Miss Ida Sledge and another woman, organizers for the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, to leave town early today. "They went to the hotel in which the women were staying and invited them to leave," Mayor Nanney said.

A promise made by I. Gainsburg, the lawyer, to contribute $5,000 to Beth Israel Hospital was declared binding and enforceable by the Appellate Division in a four-to-one decision yesterday. Previously Supreme Court Justice

A nervous ailment, apparently brought on by failure to win a place on the eligible list for sergeant, caused Patrolman Anthony Bardio, 37 years old, of 115-22 222d Street, St. Albans, Queens, to shoot himself at his home yesterday.
Continuing a trend established in reports previously issued, lower net returns in May were recorded by the two railroads which reported yesterday. Their statements follow:

After examination by the police at Eisleben, Saxony, and investigation by the American Consul at Leipzig, a man calling himself Willi Edward Baker, a German-American from New Orleans, admitted today that he is a German. His real name is Elvers and he absconded from Hamburg with a large sum belonging to his employer.
Mayor S. Davis Wilson announced tonight that a five-day strike of The Bulletin circulation truck drivers, which interfered with local distribution of the newspaper, had been settled.

The difficulties of reorganization for the Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul Pacific Railroad are "insuperable" at the present time, in the opinion of Fairman R. Dick, financial adviser of the Association of American Railroads, given in testimony on June 16 before the Interstate Commerce Commission in Washington.

New State and municipal financing scheduled for next week totals $49,842,870, to be represented by three States and fifty-eight municipalities, compared with the revised total of $93,607,361 this week. The weekly average of new offerings for the year to date now stands at $31,991,298.
The Weyerhaeuser timber and shipping interests today filed with the Interstate Commerce Commission exceptions to the report of Examiner Paul O. Carter which recommended

Al Boasberg, who for more than twenty-five years wrote jokes for leading comedians, died today while chuckling over one of his "laughs." He was stricken with a heart attack as he recounted the startled look friends gave him last night when he told them he was going to the opening of one of Hollywood's "colossal" film epics "to get some sleep."

There was a short-lived flurry in the investigation of the mysterious disappearance of Mrs. William H. Parsons from her Long Island farm nine days ago when a report was circulated that $24,000 in small bills had been withdrawn from the New York Trust Company, 100 Broadway, New York City.

The daily average of cotton-mill activity was unchanged last week when a seasonal rise was usual and the adjusted index receded to 144.8 from 147.8 (revised). It was 116.7 for the week ended June 13, 1938.

The answer to Washington's question as to whether Japan is willing to restrict capital ships' gun-caliber to fourteen inches was a polite but decided negative. Foreign Minister Koki Hirota was received by Emperor Hirohito this

At 5 o'clock this morning few Soviet people knew of it yet-so completely can the Soviet Government conceal any of its enterprises-but a Soviet airplane bound to San Francisco took off from the military airport at Sholkovo, twenty miles from Moscow, at 4:05 yesterday morning.

Sheriff Michael Boyle of Cambria County telegraphed to Governor Earle in Harrisburg early this morning asking him to send troops here under a declaration of martial law. The Sheriff told the Governor that the local authorities could not guarantee the maintenance of law and order in view of a threatened invasion of this city by 40,000 coal miners today and tomorrow.

Children of the North Shore colonies showed their ponies and horses and exhibited their horsemanship today in the opening sessions of the three-day benefit CedarValley Horse Show for Hope Farm. The show is being held in the show ring of the Townsend F. Bailey estate.

Judge Eugene O'Dunne in Circuit Court here today authorized settlement, for an aggregate of $225,000, of receiver's suits against twenty former directors of the old Baltimore Trust Company. The settlement was accepted by the receiver.

Thomas G. Grace, State director of the Federal Housing Administration, said today that the Federal Government's system of insured mortgages was "borrowed" from the savings and loan association. He spoke at the fiftieth annual convention of the State League of Savings and Loan Associations.

Miss Louise Converse Morgan, eldest daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Junius Spencer Morgan of this city and Salutation, Glen Cove, L. I., will be married to Raymond Skinner Clark, son of Mrs. Raymond S. Clark of New York and Fishers Island, N. Y., and the late Mr. Clark, at noon on Wednesday in the Protestant Episcopal Church of St. John's of Lattingtown, Locust Valley, L. I.
A week from today members of the Wa-Wa-Yanda Fishing Club of Great South Bay will inaugurate another season with a weak-fishing trip and clambake.

Twenty-one laborers working out of the Pennsylvania Railroad camp on Newark Turnpike and the Hackensack River here suffered ptomaine poisoning this afternoon after eating lunches that had been left in the sun most of the morning.

In pursuance of their efforts to dispose of the court bill controversy quickly by compromise or indefinite postponement, the administration leadership in the Senate had virtually decided today not to draft a minority report answering the Judiciary Committee majority's denunciation of the measure as filed on Monday.

James F. McLean, city cashier of Yonkers until his suspension eight days ago, was indicted by the Westchester County grand jury today on charges involving the falsifying of public accounts and misappropriation of funds.

The sounds to which young John J. O'Connell Jr. said he listened as he lay shackled to a bed in a Hoboken, N. J., kindappers' hideout, were described today by witnesses at the trial of eight men for the 1933 abduction.

Although they were booed, hissed and cursed by protesting property owners, the members of the Board of Estimate adopted a resolution yesterday setting up a $500,000 revolving fund to bring old law tenement into compliance with the Multiple Dwelling Law.

Business in the stock markets was extremely small today, the last day of the account, but the tendency was to steadiness and most of the sections had a better tone. Gilt-edge issues were little changed; among the foreign loans, German bonds declined.

An assault upon Democratic financial and social policies was made in the House today by Representative Snell, the minority leader, who quoted from the Treasury statement showing that the national debt rose to $36,633,907,802 on June
More than 200 persons attended funeral services yesterday for Major Arthur McKeogh, World War hero and managing editor of Good Housekeeping Magazine.

Miss. Jean Mulford Buckley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albion Chester Buckley of 15 Badeau Avenue, this place, and Jacob Rapallyea Van Water Lefferts Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. J. R. Van Water Lefferts of Matawan, N. J., were married here this evening in Central Presbyterian Church. The Rev. Rockwell S. Blank, the pastor, performed the ceremony.

With the government standing firm in its demand for full powers to deal with the financial situation in terms of the bill voted Tuesday night by the chamberr of Deputies and with the Senate Finance Commission equally firm in its refusal to give other
The St. Augustine's Diocesan High School nine gained the city C. H. S. A. A. final yesterday by blanking St. John's Prep, 4-0, at Boys High Field, in a play-off for the Brooklyn championship.

The Reconstruction Finance Corporation has called for bids to be opened on July 8 on seventy-four issues of securities of municipalities, counties and school districts, with a face value of $5,501,150, which the corporation bought from the Public Works Administration to be resold in the investment market.

Oral Hildebrand, veteran righthander, shut out the Senators for the Browns today, 6 to 0, in a game marked by fisticuffs between Al Simmons and Bill Knickerbocker. Hildebrand was touched for only two hits, a single to left field by Simmons and a scratch through shortstop by Buddy Lewis.
The League of Nations Financial Committee announced today the resignations of two of its most prominent members, Sir Otto Niemeyer and Sir Henry Strakosch.

Real financial stability will not exist until definite gold pars are fixed, Ralph D. Baker of Winnipeg said today in his presidential address here at the convention of the Canadian Investment Dealers Association.
Fred H. Bruckel, proprietor of the Montross Art Gallery at 785 Fifth Avenue, died yesterday at his home, 286 Milburn Avenue, Baldwin, L. I., after an illness of some months. He was 50 years old.
John Birch, 114 years old, whose last three years of life were happier because the Dionne quintuplets were "almost my neighbors," died today at his Nipissing Junction home.

Arrangements have been made for the Manufacturers Trust Company to acquire three banking offices now operated as branches of the Chase National Bank, it was announced yesterday. One office is at Second Avenue and Fourteenth Street,

Mr. and Mrs. Roger Strout came into port yesterday in the course of their first sea trip, which they made alone in a 37-foot auxiliary ketch. They tied up to the Hudson River Day Line dock at West 125th Street. Mr. Strout admitted that they had gone so far about 35,000 miles. The trip was uneventful.
Chicago at New York--Lee vs. Ruffing. St. Louis at Washington--Bonetti vs. Weaver. Detroit at Philadelphia-Bridges vs. Ross.

Mrs. Julia M. Ely, affectionately known as "the mother of the United States Army," died early today at her home here at the age of 100. Widow of a Civil War captain who helped organize the Republican party in Wisconsin, she was the mother of a general and two colonels of the United States Army and was grandmother to five men who also hold army records.

Oliver Sweet, director of the Finance Bureau of the Interstate Commerce Commission, has asked H. H. Larimore, general counsel of the Missouri Pacific Railroad Company, why the commission has not been informed of certain corporation positions held by L. Warrington Baldwin, chief executive of the Missouri Pacific, it was learned today.

Members of the bar and the bench were among the hundreds who attended the funeral services of Supreme Court Justice James C. Cropsey yesterday afternoon in the Classon Avenue Presbyterian Church, 1 Monroe Street. The jurist died last Wednesday after a brief illness.

Disagreement with the notion that labor would soon be completely out of hand unless there was more aggressive police action was expressed tonight by Otto S. Beyer, member of the National Mediation Board, in a speech at the opening session of the seventh annual economics conference for engineers, sponsored by Stevens Institute of Technology and the Society for Promotion of Engineering Education.

The Far West, paced by the University of Southern California, held the advantage tonight at the end of qualifying events for the starstudded National Collegiate Athletic Association track and field championships.

Action by the Board of Estimate yesterday formally launched plans for acquiring the land needed for the approaches and parkway connections in Queens and the Bronx for the suspension bridge which the Triborough Bridge Authority is about to construct between
A. O'Rourke, one of the original Irish Players at the Abbey Theatre, Dublin, died in London today at the age of 55.

According to "The Testament of Beauty," the "soul's nobility" consists not in the riches of imagination or intellect, but in "harmony of essences" which have full power where "a few fundamentals in purity" attain their "self-coordination." So, it is added, we may see--" and 'tis pleasant to see"--how simple characters have such extreme beauty.

The Textile Workers Organization Cdmmittee, affiliate of the C. I. O., announced yesterday through its chairman, Sidney Hillman, that to date it has signed contracts with 360 companies emplaying an aggregate of 130,000 workers. The latest group brought into the C. I. O., through T. W. 0. C., are the 1,700 employes of Boott Mills, Lowell, Mass. Mr.

Michael Cashel, first vice president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, Chauffeurs, Stablemen and Helpers, affiliate of the American Federation of Labor, announced yesterday the adoption of a resolution endorsing Mayor F. H.

Miss Eisabeth Reynolds Lieb, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Clarence William Lieb of this place, was married here this afternoon to G. Douglas Lawrence, son of Mr. and Mrs. Dudley Bates Lawrence of Mount Kisco, in St. Matthew's Church.
The Treasury Department named to Congressional investigators today seven men, who, it asserted, employed devices such as foreign corporations to avoid or reduce their income taxes.

Thomas W. Lamont, partner in J. P. Morgan Co., expressed his keen sense of loss last evening when informed of Mr. Gammack's death. He said he considered Mr. Gammack one of the most promising men of the younger generation in business circles. He added he had known Mr. Gammack for many years and that in his successive posts, he had always shown unusual capacity and integrity.

The Securities and Exchange Commission has approved an application by the Middle West Corporation, a registered holding company, for permission to acquire from its wholly owned subsidiary, the Middle West Utilities Company of Canada, Ltd., 4,248 1/2 shares of common stock, $1 par value,

The seventy-second prize day exercises of St. Mark's School were held here today. The service in the chapel was followed by speaking in the Elkins Field House. The distribution of prizes and the awarding of diplomas to the thirty-five members of the graduating class concluded the exercises.

The Non-Intervention Committee at its first meeting since Germany and Italy returned to its deliberations adopted this afternoon this moving appeal for the humanization of warfare in Spain to be sent immediately through British diplomatic channels to both warring factions:

Miss Dorothy Foster Symes, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Gifford Symes of Pittsfield, Mass., was married here yesterday at noon in the Church of St. Vincent Ferrer to Donald Francis Lange, son of H. Wade Lange of Northport, L. I., and the late Mrs. Lange. The Rev.

Charles E. Reed, resident partner of Kean, Taylor Co. in Newark, was elected yesterday president the Bond Club of New Jersey for the ensuing year at the annual meeting held at the Down Town Club, Newark. He was vice president of the club for the last year. He succeeds Foy W. Porter of Herrick, Berg Co.

Miss Millicent Hirsh of New York, runner-up for the national indoor crown, and Miss Helen Germaine of Brooklyn gained the two remaining semi-final brackets in the women's New York State championship yesterday at the Jackson Heights Tennis Club.

Miss Helen Hicks. New York's "business woman" golfer, ,will make the big try tomorrow for the only title within her reach. the Western women's open crown, against sturdy Miss. Bea. Barrett of Minneapolis.

A vast espionage plot against the Loyalist government has been uncovered in Madrid and Barcelona with the arrest of 200, among whom are some army officers, Falangists and leaders of the POUM [left wing Communist group].

The volume of new bond financing last week was the largest in more than four months for a similar period, aggregating $143,577,511, compared with $9,155,000 in new bonds placed last week, and with a total of $89,255,500 new issues marketed during this week a year ago.

President Roosevelt has virtually agreed to a compromise proposal for the financing of the proposed slum clearance and low-cost housing program and action on a bill putting it into effect may be expected soon, Senator Wagner, its author, said today after talking with the President.
With three stakes down for decision, the Queens County Jockey Club this after-noon will stage its most important program of the meeting to date.
Just what would HEYWOOD BROUN have Chief Justice TANEY and his associate justices do in the Dred Scott decision?

Meteorological service for the army, which has been under the Signal Corps, on July 1 will be transferred to the using arms and services, namely, the Air Corps, Field Artillery, Coast Artillery Corps, Ordnance and Chemical Warfare Service, it was announced today.

The Venezuelan workers' reaction after their quarter of a century of subservience to the late General Juan Vicente Gomez, Dictator President, was seen today in the announcement by government offices throughout the country that the word "peon"

A former Los Angeles judge charged today that a rigid censorship by the German Government was keeping from him information that would establish two of his clients as legal heirs to the $20,000,000 Henrietta E. Garrett estate.

The Cards bunched their hits and triumphed over the Bees today, 5 to 2. The Bees, who held a 2-to-0 lead after batting in the sixth, had men on base in every inning and outhit the Cards, 13 to 10, but left eleven men stranded.

Federal Judge William Clark denied today motions for directed verdicts of acquittal in behalf of Ellis H. Parker Sr. and his son, Ellis Jr., who are on trial here for conspiracy in connection with the kidnapping of Paul H. Wendel.

Ward's Automotive Reports estimated to. day that this week's output of the nation's automobile plants would amount to 111,620 units, compared with 118,798 last week and 100,161 cars and trucks in the corresponding week a year ago.

Miss Muriel Boelsen, 13-yearold daughter of Mr. and Mrs. F. William Boelsen of Elmhurst, continued her acquisition of laurels by winning the equitation championship as the Cedar Valley horse show opened today with a program devoted to youngsters.

A warning against "stuffing the ballot box" in elections which may be ordered to determine collective bargaining agencies for employes of steamship lines on the Atlantic and Gulf routes was issued tonight by the National Labor Relations Board.

Outstanding today among reports of alleged "Trotskyist wreckers" flooding Moscow from every part of the Soviet Union is an announcement of the trial and condemnation of seven officials of the locomotive shop in Tashkent, Russian Turkestan.

With the arrival in New York of the Premier of Belgium there are landed on these shores in a special and very literal sense the problems of Europe. Mr. Van Zeeland's visit is interesting for many reasons besides his return to Princeton, although it was in that university that he completed the economic and financial studies which are largely responsible for his rapid rise from the banking world into national and international prominence.
Judge H. J. Johnson of Grainger County died in a hospital here late today from three bullet wounds. He was shot while in his office at the court house at Rutledge, soon after noon.

Miss Hope Linton Drury, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Holland Drury of Middletown, was married at noon to day to Robert H. I. Goddard Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert H. I. Goddard of Providence, at the Berkeley Memorial Church in Middletown.

Miss Juanita Decker of this city, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Owen Decker of Elizabethtown, Ill., will be married tomorrow to Blair Duffy of Tucson and New York, in the Church of SS. Peter and Paul. The Rev. John L. Howard will perform the ceremony, which will be followed by a nuptial mass.

Judge Raul Machado of the National Security Tribunal today signed releases for 345 political prisoners against whom no charges had been made, bringing the total freed to about 700 since June 3, when Dr. Jose Carlos de Macedo Soares became Justice Minister.
Peter G. Ten Eyck, Commissioner of Farms and Markets, resigned his position today in a letter to Governor Lehman. Mr. Ten Eyck was the first Democratic commissioner in twenty years.

Appointment of the personnel of the temporary salary standardization board created by Chaper 859 of the laws of this year, providing career opportunities In the public service, was announced tonight by Governor Lehman. The board is to submit its findings to him by Oct. 1.

Father's Day will be observed in the city's churches tomorrow. There will be much more general commemoration of this day than in any previous year. In some churches doors to usher their fathers to pews. There will be sermons about fatherhood.

CHRISTIANITY AND COMMUNISM, edited by H. Wilson Harris. (Marshall Jones Company, $1.50.) In this volume seven able writers express their views on a subject that is arousing increasing interest. As the editor notes, no one can fail to be conscious of an actual, and much more a potential, rivalry between Christianity as a faith and communism as a creed.

Atley Donald, brilliant young righthander, chalked up his tenth straight victory of the season tonight, blanking Rochester with three hits as Newark won, 2 to 0. It was his second shutout achievement of the season.

Supreme Court Justice William T. Collins refused yesterday to issue a temporary injunction restraining the Associated Gas and Electric Company from paying $875,000 in costs incurred in reorganization proceedings in Federal court.
Dean Carl W. Ackerman of the Graduate School of Journalism at Columbia University sailed last night on the Grace liner Santa Lucia to conduct a survey of news dissemination in South American nations.

Miss Elizabeth Rankin Irwin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Burke Irwin of this city, became the bride this afternoon of James Crane Kellogg 3d, son of Mrs. J. C. Kellogg Jr. and the late Mr. Kellogg.

The interest of the late H. V. D. Moore in D. T. Moore Co. ceased on June 16 and Mary Sayles Moore was admitted as a limited partner on June 17. The G. R. Kinney Company, Inc., common stock. $1-par value,

Miss Anne French Earle, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Keese Earle of this city and Cold Spring Harbor, will be married to Roy R. Buxton Attride, son of Major and Mrs. Percy W. Attride of London, on June 26 in St. John's Church, Cold Spring Harbor.

BUSSELL, JOHN H. (April 4, 1936). Gross assets, $17,874; net, $15,756. To William Bussell, brother, life estate in residue. Chief assets, stocks and bonds, $11,459. C. Herbert Vonhof, attorney, 130 Clinton St., Brooklyn.

Federal Judge Vincent L. Leibell signed a consent decree yesterday whereby George Herbert Heyman, customer's man, was permanently enjoined from using the mails and other means of interstate commerce to make matched sales or engage in any transactions of Aluminum Industries, Inc., common stock that did not involve a change of beneficial ownership.

Passage by the House of Representatives of the chain store tax amendment to the regular District of Columbia appropriations measure evoked charges in chain store circles yesterday that the action was "grossly unfair to the chains" in that they were given no opportunity for a hearing.

THE FRONT--Rebels continued to drive up the Nervion estuary. cleaning out defenders to the east of Bilbao. The left wing pushed forward in the mountains to the south of the city and expected soon to cut the main interior road to the west.
Miss Maureen Orcutt made a runaway race of the Women's New Jersey Golf Association one-day tournament today at the Crestmont Country Club when she scored a 77, five over men's par.
Paul Van Zeeland, Premier of Belgium, arrived yesterday from Europe on the Berengaria, accompanied by Mrs. Van Zeeland. He said he had come for two purposes:
The Interstate Commerce Commission authorized today the Minneapolis St. Louis Railroad to issue $805,800 of receivers' certificates to bear interest at not more than 4 1/2 per cent.
A New York team of four defeated Hungary by 3,620 points and Austria downed a team from Minneapolis by 2,650 points today to enter the finals of the world contract bridge championship.
Mrs. G. B. Miller's Derby winner, Mid-Day Sun. captured the Hardwick Stakes of a mile and a half, last big event of the fashionable Ascot meeting, today.
Plans to reorganize the clerical staff of the New York City school system at a saving of $500,000 were presented yesterday by Theodore Fred Kuper, executive manager of the Board of Education.

Three hundred members of the Grand Street Boys' Association of New York City, which numbers Governor Lehman, ex-Governor Smith and ex-Mayor Walker on its roster, began a three-day outing today at Galen Hall, South Mountain.
Foreclosures of non-farm properties during April in New York and New Jersey were 16 per cent below those of April, 1936, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board reported today.

Pageantry, parades, mechanized cavalry manoeuvers, an anti-aircraft demonstration and a championship polo match will be the climax of Governors Islands celebration today of the tercentenary of its purchase from the Indians. The celebration, which started last Monday. will end tomorrow.

Total volume and volume of member trading in round lots on the New York Stock Exchange decreased in the week ended on May 22, but the percentage of member trading to total volume rose slightly, from 20.28 per cent in the preceding week to 20.48 per cent.

Two stipulations by New York drug manufacturing concerns that they would stop making false advertising claims for their products, and a complaint against a New York garment manufacturer were announced today by the Federal Trade Commission.

Miss Margaret Virginia Hughes, daughter of Mrs. Clarence H. Wilson of West Hartford, was married to Cable Ambrose Wirtz, son of Mr. and Mrs. A. J. Wirtz of Honolulu, yesterday afternoon at the bride's home.

The executive committee or McKesson Robbins, Inc., approved terms of a contract yesterday to acquire the assets of Milwaukee Drug Company, Milwaukee, Wis., which was founded in 1848 and is the oldest in the State.

While a score of shipyards and repair plants in the New YorkNew Jersey area remained closed by a strike of 12,000 employes who continued peaceful picketing yesterday, the National Labor Relations Board was unable to arrange the conference it had sought to negotiate a settlement.

About 1,500 delegates from all over the country are expected to attend the thirty-third annual convention of the Advertising Federation of America, which opens tomorrow with informal receptions at the Hotel Pennsylvania. Business sessions get under way on Monday, with nine affiliated groups scheduled to hold meetings.
About $1,450 in cash and book prizes were awarded tonight at the Phillips Exeter Academy's Prize Night exercises. Dr. Lewis Perry, principal, made the awards.

Unless otherwise stated, the resuits of operations of the following companies, announced yesterday, are after deductions for operating expenses, normal Federal income taxes, depreciation and other charges, but before provision for Federal surtax on undistributed earnings. Figures, in many cases, are subject to final adjustment.

Full payment for certificate holders on the largest issue of guaranteed mortgage certificates covering a single property in the hands of the State Mortgage Commission was assured yesterday through a loan of $3,615,000 made by the Equitable Life Assurance Society, through Ivor B. Clark, Inc., for Garment Center Capitol, Inc., of which Jesse Woolf is president.

Jefferson Seligman, New York banker, died at 4:20 o'clock yesterday afternoon at the Columbia Medical Center after a long illness. Mr.. Seligman, who was 78 years old, lived at 14 East Sixtieth Street. He was formerly senior partner in the firm of J. W. Seligman Co. of 54 Wall Street, with which he served for fifty years.

An agreement with the management of the Interborough Rapid Transit Company, under which the company may return about $2,000,000 from its pension fund to some 12,500 employes, was alleged yesterday by the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O. affiliate.

Van Lingle Mungo's four-game winning streak was broken today and the big fireball hurler's temper snapped with it. The Pirates won, 6-4, scoring two unearned runs in the eighth on errors by Joe Stripp and Jimmy Bucher and when the disastrous inning ended big Van walked off the field to the clubhouse without waiting to see what his teammates might do in their half of the ninth.
Government economists predicted today that there will be a minor slump in industrial activity during the next few months. They added, however, that the longer-range outlook is relatively favorable.
Mrs. Emma Belle Dougherty Pierson, wife of Delavan L. Pierson, editor of The Missionary Review of the World, died today at her home here at the age of 65.

Miss Evelyn Flower Morris, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold H. Morris of Shanghai, China, and niece of Miss Ellen Morris of Villanova, was married this afternoon to W. Richardson Blair Jr., son of Mrs. W. R. Blair of this city, in the garden Dundale, her aunt's home. The ceremony was performed by Dr. F. L. Hawks Pott, president of St.

The French franc weakened again yesterday on reports that Premier Leon Blum was facing defeat in the Senate on his demand for decree powers to levy taxes. Spot francs fell 1/4 point to 4.45% cents, while the discount on three-month forward francs, which had been decreasing in the previous two days, again widened. It increased 1% points to 17% points discount under the spot rate.
An American printer, Harry Shufeld, 25 years old, who stowed away on the liner Conte di Savoia, was landed at Gibraltar last night when the vessel arrived from New York.
