The Rev. Gerald Carl Treacy former vice president of Fordham University, began his duties yesterday as rector of Brooklyn Prep, a Jesuit school at Carroll Street near Rogers Avenue, Brooklyn, and pass tor of St. Ignatius Roman Catholio Church at the intersection of these two thoroughfares.

Winning his game adjourned from the second round with Paul Keres of Estonia, Samuel Reshevsky of New York, chess champion of the United States, tied for first place today with H. Berg of Latvia in the international masters' tournament at the Kurhaus.
Without hindrance from officials of Nassau County, the dog-racing season opened at the Nassau County dog track tonight. About 8,000 attended.
Stock Exchange Market irregularly higher in less active trading; turnover, 695,530 shares. Bonds firm in second slowest trading of month; transactions, $6,277,100.

" Northwest Passage," by Kenneth Roberts, is already in its large edition, Doubleday, Doran report. The novel will be published on July 1, and is the Book-of-theMonth Club choice for July. Mr. Roberts is now in Maine after a Winter in Italy.

The Waialua Agricultural Company, Ltd., Honolulu, H. T., has filed a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 for 121,875 shares of $20-par value capital stock to De offered first to stockholders at $20 a share, the unsubscribed shares then to be offered to the public.

The Rev. Dr. George A. Buttrick of the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, New York City, gave the commencement address here to ninety-two graduates of the Taft School this morning. After offering congratulations to the graduating class Dr. Buttrick said:

ONE might think that after forty years scientific romancing H. G. Wells would sick and tired of Other Worlds. But he isn't; can't be. His fantastic yarns about the solar system are part of what must be called, for lack of a better term, his faith. The most reent is also one of the best: "Star-Begotten" (Viking, $1.75).

The smaller members of the national banking system of the United States were described yesterday as "a weakening influence in the nation's commercial banking struccure" in the report of the two-year survey conducted by the Twentieth Century Fund, Inc.
If Premier Van Zeeland suggests that the United States open a substantial deposit account with the Bank for International Settlements, it will meet with an unfavorable reception.
The Senate wrangled for four hours today in an effort to determine what portion of the cost of projects financed by the Works Progress Administration should be paid by local communities.

Sales of General Motors cars and trucks to dealers in the overseas markets in May numbered 33,306, representing a gain of 7.4 per cent over a year ago. The figures include the products of the corporation's United States, Canadian, English and German factories sold outside of the United States and Canada.

The Fascist party's aspiration to make of Premier Benito Mussolini's personal newspaper, Milan's Popolo d'Italia, in organ of public opinion with the widest circulation in Europe was realized with a single penstroke by the party's secretary-general, General Achille Starace, who has secreed that all Fascisti must in the future figure on its list of subscribers.

The New York World-Telegram unit of the American Newspaper Guild went on record last night against what it termed the highhanded methods of the delegates to the recent national convention in St. Louis. It adopted by a 27-to-20 vote a resolution condemning the delegates for refusing to submit to a referendum the constitutional amendments adopted at the convention.

The City Industrial Relations Board will hold two hearings next Tuesday afternoon on proposed referenda to designate collective. bargaining agencies for employes on traction lines. The first will involve the 14,000 employes on the rapid transit, street car and bus lines controlled by the B. M. T. and
Four blues adorned the heads of two horses exhibited by Moses W. Faitoute of Short Hills at the conclusion of the first program of the sixth annual Plainfield horse show at Vinebrook Farm today.

The new- Premier, Prince KONOE, and his colleagues have given the first concrete indication of the way in which they hope to solve Japan's domestic and foreign problems. On Tuesday the " reformist " Cabinet declared its intention to adopt as its own the army's planned economy program-a five-year scheme to place Japan, Korea and Manchukuo on a semi-wartime basis.

Lewis Luckenbach, New York and San Francisco shipping man, obtained a divorce here today from Mrs. Gladys Luckenbach, on charges of cruelty. The case was transferred from the Carson City courts, where it had been pending since Dec. 18.

At the opening of the last session of Parliament yesterday before the general election in October the government submitted a report by G. H. Ince, chief insurance officer of the British Ministry of Labor, embodying a scheme of unemployment insurance.

The last apparent legal obstacle to the heavyweight championship fight between James Braddock and Joe Louis at Chicago next Tuesday was removed today by the United States Court of Appeals' refusal for the second time to grant the plea of Madison Square Garden for an injunction stopping the fight.

Shareholders of twelve Niagara Hudson System companies providing gas and electric service to a large area of Central and Northern New York State will meet on various dates next month to act on the proposal to consolidate into a single regional operating company, according to an announcement yesterday by Alfred H. Schoellkopf, president of the Niagara Hudson Power Corporation.
The Republic Steel Corporation indicated in a statement issued tonight that it was opposed to maintaining the "status quo" as to plant operations pending the outcome of the mediation board's inquiry.

Sales records in self-service grocery stores more than demonstrate that consumers prefer nationally known brands of merchandise when left free to make their own selections, Paul S. Willis, president of the Associated Grocery Manufacturers of America, Inc.,
The redhot Red Sox stretched their winning streak to five straight today and took over fourth place in the American League with a 5-to-4 victory over the Indians.

The National City Bank of New York will today observe the 125th anniversary of its founding. Originally organized as the City Bank of New York on June 19, 1812, the bank came into existence as an outcome of the enforced closing of the First Bank of the United States.
Lillian Tooker, 15 years old, of 529 West Scott Avenue, was found dead in the basement of her home here from illuminating gas shortly after noon today.
Sumerian boxers of 5,000 years ago bandaged their hands before starting a contest, just as modern prizefighters do, according to evidence found at Khafaje, near Baghdad,

The following is the text of a letter written by Lee Pressman, general counsel of the Steel Workers Organizing Committee, transmitting to the Natiunal Labor Relations Board charges against the Republic Steel Corporation, and the text of the charges:

Miss Elizabeth Mellick Smyth, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Nathan Ayer Smyth of 171 Linden Avenue, this place, was married in the garden of her parents' home this afternoon to Dr. Frederic Geake Hirsch, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanton Pike Hirsch of Toledo, Ohio.

Miss Janet Wilson Flanigan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Edward Flanigan of 51 Fifth Avenue, was married last night in the chantry of Grace Church to Henry Ernest Blagden, son of Mrs. Walter John Blagden of London and the late Mr. Blagden. The ceremoney was performed by the rector, the Rev. Dr. W. Russell Bowie.

An important development in international cooperation may be recorded shortly from the Near East and Middle East. Dr. Tewfik Rushdu Aras, the Turkish Foreign Minister, left Angora today for Baghdad, Iraq, and Teheran, Iran, where he hopes to clear the way for an

Expressing the belief that there was nothing to prevent a peaceful settlement of the seven-State steel strike in the near future, Edward F. McGrady, Assistant Secretary of Labor, returned from abroad yesterday and hurried to join the two other members of the Steel Mediation Board in Cleveland this morning.

The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company sold to the B. C. Estates Corporation the building containing 124 apartments at 1,54151 Williamsbridge Road, the Bronx. The property is 287 by 90 feet and was sold for $50,000 cash over a purchase money mortgage of $270,000 at 5 per cent for ten years. The All City Realty Corporation negotiated the transaction.

Authorization of loans totaling $1,068,000 from the National City Bank of New York for financing the purchase of eighty-nine super-coaches from the Yellow Truck and Coach Manufacturing Company was sought today from the Interstate Commerce Commission by three Greyhound bus companies.

Amelia Earhart took off from Akyab today for the third time in an effort to reach Bangkok, Siam, on her round-the-world flight. She and Captain Fred Noonan, her navigator, hopped at 3:42 A. M. Greenwich time [11:42 P. M. in New York] Friday,

All hope for continuance of the Westchester County Collegiate Center here and the Yonkers Collegiate Center at Yonkers, which have provided college courses for more than 1,000 students in the last three years, was abandoned by directors of the institutions today when-final
Malcolm Muir has resigned as president of the McGraw-Hill Pubfishing Company to accept the presidency of Weekly Publications, Inc., publishers of News-Week,

As Senator WAGNER pointed out yesterday, in a letter to THE TIMES, it was the primary purpose of Congress when it wrote the National Labor Relations Act to encourage the settlement of labor questions by the peaceful process of negotiation rather than through strife. It was with this end in view that Congress made it an " unfair labor practice" for any employer to refuse to bargain collectively with the chosen representatives of his employes.

Showers over a large part of the Cotton Belt where the crop is reported to be in need of warm, dry weather created more resistance to selling on the Cotton Exchange here yesterday and prices gained 2 to 9 points.

Rainy weather curbed somewhat the expansion of Summer retail trade here this week, but the comparative results with a year ago were still favorable. Department store executives estimated the increase for this week at from 8 to 10 per cent, where many of the stores had gains during the first half of the month ranging up to 15 and 20 per cent.

The three-story building containing seven stores and two large business floors at the southwest corner of Madison Avenue and Seventy-sixth Street has been leased by the Charles Frederick Hoffman estate to Maurice Epstein, treasurer of the Seventy-sixth Estate, Inc.
The strike of employes of the Hotel Ambassador here ended this evening, about twenty-four hours after members of the Building Service Employes Union walked out.

Professor Sherley Warner Morgan, director of the School of Architecture in Princeton University, will receive the class of '13 silver cup from his former classmates at Princeton University tomorrow in recognition of his "outstanding accomplishments" in education and architecture.

Attorney General John J. Benneft, Jr., sent today to Miss Doris I. Byrne, Deputy Secretary of State, eight answers to as many questions regarding tangles that have arisen in connection with the constitutional convention.
The Field Museum of Natural History exhibited today the skins and skulls of a dozen gibbon apes and a squirrel five feet long as evidence of one of its most successful zoological treasure hunts.

A lively debate on the merits of spiritualism and spirit mediums, backed by a challenge and an offer of $10,000 for the production of genuine proof, enlivened the fortyfirst annual convention of the General Assembly of Spiritualists at the Pythian Temple last night.

A debate on estimates for the Ministry of Health in the House of Commons today was enlivened by a speech in which Henry George Strauss, Conservative member for Norwich, pleaded for less building of by-passes around the villages and more effort to make them attractive to tourists.

Officers and men of the Sixteenth United States Infantry, 1,265 strong, paraded yesterday at Governors Island in a farewell review for their commanding officer, Colonel Albert S. Williams, who will retire on July 1 to become Professor of Military Science and Tactics at the University of Pennsylvania.
The House Rivers and Harbors Committee approved today a proposal for improvement of Flushing Bay and construction of a boat basin at the site of the New York Wold's Fair.

The Yakima Indian tribe went on the warpath today for $2 a day wages, free hamburgers three times a day, free tobacco and a 10 per cent "cut" on all souvenir postcard sales during Yakima's Pioneer Days celebration, July 3-5.
The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court, in Brooklyn, affirmed yesterday a decision of Surrogate Robert S. Pelletreau of Suffolk County which held that Mrs. Pauline V. Rogers,

Jose Yulo, Secretary of Justice of the Philippine Commonwealth, and Mrs. Yulo, Dean Lynn Harold Hough and Mrs. Hough, the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Charles Carroll Albertson, Dr. and Mrs. John Robert Gregg and Commander J. Harding and Mrs. Harding are among the passengers on the Cunard White Star liner Berengaria sailing today for Southampton via Cherbourg. Others on board are Mr. and Mrs. T. V. Harnett, Mr. and Mrs. Frank P. Henderson.

Still streaking with amazing consistency but in the wrong direction, Carl Owen Hubbell, who not so long ago was mowing down all opposition, was himself mowed down again today as an intrepid band of Reds tore the one-time invincible screwball maestro loose from his moorings inside of three rounds.

AS he demolished a club sandwich and gulped his iced coffee, Robert H. (Bob) Davis, the globe-girdling literary gent who is just back from India, said that he wasn't going to Chicago for the heavyweight championship fight. In fact, he was packing up to go to Alaska.

The House adopted the conference report today on the $957,738,963 Independent Offices Appropriation Bill and sent it to the White House with a proviso that experts on the Social Security Board be appointed by the President subject to confirmation by the Senate.

The Congressional committee appointed to investigate the tax question began its work yesterday by naming a half dozen individuals who now stand accused before the American public of "tax evasion" or "tax avoidance." It is difficult to see what is gained by this procedure.
Miss Margaret Bell Harvey, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick W. Harvey of Ardmore, was married this afternon to Edward A. Steele Jr., son of Mrs. Edward A. Steele of Chestnut Hill.

Postal investigators are seeking to identify striking pickets at Warren and Niles, Ohio, who are alleged to have interfered with delivery of mail to steel mills, the Postoffice Committee was told at its strike inquiry today by W. W. Howes, Assistant Postmaster General.

Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on June 12 amounted to 754,360 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 62,220 cars, or 9 per cent, more than for the preceding week, 67,717 cars, or 9.9 per cent, more than for the corresponding week last year and 102,249 cars, or 15.7 per cent, more than for the corresponding week two years ago.

Announcement yesterday that the nineteen-company injunction suit against the Tennessee Valley Authority would be tried in either Nashville or Chattanooga in the United States District Court on Oct. 12 sends the entire issue back to Judge Gore, who issued the original injunction against the TVA.

Common stockholders of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. adopted today by a vote of more than 75 per cent of the stock an amendment to the company's certificate of incorporation authorizing the creation of 500,000 shares of $4.50 cumulative preferred stock without par value.

Goble Pl (11-2859), n e cor of Inwood Ave, 130x95; 27th St Garage, Inc to Lenor Realty Corp, 74 W 176th St; mtg $60,400. Dyre Ave (17-4970). e s. 100 ft n of 233d St. 100x100; Marion K. Wohn to Ruth Schwartz, 30 Crary Ave, Mt Vernon. 3d Ave (9-236-3). e s, 280 ft n of 153d St. 34x177; 3,006 3d Ave Corp to City Bank Farmers Trust Co, trustee.

A trust of $5,000,000 created by former United States Senator Chauncey M. Depew, at his deatl on April 5, 1928, was worth $7,161,: 453 on Nov. 12, according to an in termediate accounting in his estate filed yesterday in Surrogate Court by the United States Trust Company.

The Committee for Industrial Organization is the main route for the formation of a true Farmer-Labor party in the United States, Norman Thomas, national chairman of the Socialist party and its Presidential nominee in 1936, asserted here tonight at the opening session of the annual June conference of the League for Industrial Democracy.

Nottinghamshire slipped into third place, ahead of Derbyshire, in the English county cricket championship table today by defeating Middlesex by three wickets. Sussex retained the runner-up position, behind the. idle Yorkshire eleven, getting first innings' points in the tilt with Warwickshire.

Wilson Workman Butler, president of the Canadian Car and Foundry Company and one of Canada's best-known industrialists, died suddenly tonight at the age of 75. He supervised construction of the first steel railway coach built in Canada.

Adrian Fredericks, dwelling. at 17 Butler St, Westbury, L I; Harland W. Melstrell, broker. Mrs. Rose Abrams. In 135 Davis Ave, White Plains, Westchester; Max. B. Pohs, in 235 Chatterton Parkway; Miss Louise A. Johnston, renewal in 2 Walworth Ave; George C. Rohrs, renewal in 25 Blackthorn Lane; Meuer Auerbach, Inc., broker.

William Ray, 26 years old, a porter of 894 Union Avenue, the Bronx, was arraigned yesterday before Magistrate Edgar Bromberger in the Bronx and charged with attacking 10-year-old Rose Maglione and attempting to assault her crimfinally in a Bronx theatre Wednesday morning.

A group of thirty-three West Point cadets and graduates sailed last night for Guayaquil, Ecuador, on the Grace liner Santa Lucia for a ten-day vacation in Quito. In the party are Cadets Eloy Alfaro and Jaime Alfaro, sons of Colon Eloy Alfaro, Ecuadoran Ambassador in the United States, who is a graduate of the military college.

Residents of the Sunset Park section of Brooklyn were awakened the early yesterday morning by regulated cries of "We Want Mother Home" and pulled aside curtains to behold a picket line consisting of front of 563 Forty-first Street.
Willie Turnesa, a senior at Holy Cross, and John E. Parker Jr., an old Yale Blue, are the two who are left to vie for the metropolitan amateur championship, vacated by George T. Dunlap Jr. yesterday.
Gaston Dou mergue, former President of France and a moderator in French political strife, died suddenly today of heart disease. He was 73 years old and in apparent good health.

Despite the political and economic disturbances in Europe, there is a definite recrudescence of art there, according to Homer Saint-Gaudens, director of fine arts, Carnegie Institute, Pittsburgh, who arrived yesterday on the Deutschland after selecting 300 paintings for this year's international art exhibition at Carnegie Institute.

The Public Service Commission announced last night that it had prescribed accounting systems to be followed by gas and steam corporations in New York State. The new procedure is to become effective on Jan. 1, 1938, for gas corporations with revenues of more than $250,000 a year and for steam corporations with revenues exceeding $100,000 a year.

The Rev. C. Everett Wagner has completed a decade as pastor of Union Methodist Church, 229 West Forty-eighth Street, just west of Broadway. The edifice, which is in the heart of the theatrical section, is known as "The Church Ninety-nine Steps From the Great White Way."
Chairman James M. Landis of the Securities and Exchange Commission, commenting upon the death of Mr. Gammack, said:
J. Edgar Leaycraft Co. has moved its offices to 300 Madison Avenue, where it will occupy the third floor. James Wright, until recently president of Wright-Rowe, Inc., is joining the Leaycraft firm.

Three West Coast stars and one from Florida reached the singles semi-finals of the national clay courts tennis tournament today. Bobby Riggs of Los Angeles, the defending champion, advanced through the quarter-finals by downing Elwood Cooke of Portland, Ore., 6--3, 6--4, while Walter Senior of San Francisco eliminated Frank Guernsey, Orlando, Fla., 4-6, 7-5, 6-2.

The American South African Steamship Company announced yesterday that it had completed negotiations with the Maritime Commission for an operating differential subsidy, effective July 1, covering its service between the Atlantic seaboard of the United States and ports of South Africa.
Bryan M. (Bitsy) Grant of Atlanta was reported recovering rapidly today from the shoulder ailment that forced him to withdraw from the Queens Club tennis tournament yesterday.
The dollar value of orders taken in May by the Baldwin Locomotive Works and subsidiary companies, including the Midvale Company, was announced today as $1,978,126, against $2,861,583 for May, 1936.

Movements of livestock on the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts, 4,000 including 1,500 direct; generally 10-20 higher than yesterday's average. Packing sows around 10 higher;
The War Department released the following orders today, dated June 17: COLONELS Tuttle, A. D., Med. Corps, 2 months leave, July 10. Burt, R. J., Inf., 4 months and 13 days leave, June 18.

Arthur Sidner, Nebraska attorney, told the Federal Communications Commission today that he could play an important role in battling the grasshopper plague if he and two other Nebraskans were authorized to build a radio station at Fremont.

The marriage of Miss Barbara Swift, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Wesley Swift, to Russell Clark Morley, son of Mr. and Mrs. Franklin A. Morley of West Hartford, Conn., took place this afternoon at the home here of the bride's parents.

Principal laurels in the fifth annual specialty show of the Labrador Retriever Club, staged amid delightful conditions on the sidelines of the Meadow Brook Club's famous International Field today, went to Ch. Banchory Trump of Wingan, owned by Jay F. Carlisle of East Islip.

The Watsessing Methodist Episcopal Church was the scene this afternoon of the marriage of Miss Dorothy Alice Balg, daughter of Louis Balg, to Adam Bell Smith, son of Mr. and Mrs. William D. Smith. The Rev. Howard Breisch, the pastor, performed the ceremony.

Friendly borderers in spite of the proverb, Canada and the United States have long had what Chief Justice HUGHES has called " the habit of peace." They also have the habit of democracy; as Lord TWEEDSMUIR has just said, they are "engaged in the same job." Politics in the Dominion has all the heat and fury and humor and humbugging of ours.

President Roosevelt has appointed Representative Frank Le Blond Kloeb of Celina, Ohio, an outspoken critic of his plan for reorganization of the Federal judiciary, to be a judge of the United States District Court for the western division of the Northern District of Ohio.

This is a petition to this court under the provisions of the Labor Board Act to enforce by its processes the findings of the board. The case would present no difficulties were it not for the unusual fact situation presented.
YESTERDAY'S RESULTS Boston 5, Cleveland 4. St. Louis 6. Washington 0. Chicago at New York, wet grounds. Other clubs not scheduled.

A number of contracts for space in the various units of Rockefeller Center featured the commercial lease reported yesterday. Jack Curley, the sports promoter, took quarters on the third floor of Nine Rockefeller Plaza, for occupancy early in July.

Price movements of commodity futures were generally higher yesterday in the local markets in moderate activity. Cocoa and coffeefutures were the exceptions, losing ground. In the cash markets, rubber, cotton, tins and corn advanced, but wheat, rye, oats, cocoa, butter and lard declined.
The Jersey City Giants ended their losing streak at five straight today when they defeated the Montreal Royals, 4 to 3, in the third of a scheduled five-game series.

In the account in yesterday's issue of the American Rolling Mill Company's refusal to disclose to the Securities and Exchange Commission the names of ten subsidiaries, there was no intention to imply that the company was not within its rights in so doing.
The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated June 16: LIEUTENANT COMMANDER Laird, O. C., orders of May 3 revoked to continue duty at Naval Academy.
The fifty-seventh annual commencement exercises of the Dwight School were held last night at the school, 72 Park Avenue. Prizes were awarded by Headmaster Ernest Greenwood.

Miss place this afternoon Josephine Drexel Henry, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Seton Henry of Pen Ryn, Andalusia, was married this afternoon to Joseph Wharton Lippincott Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Wharton Lippincott of Oak Hill, Bethayres. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. John LaFarge in St. Michael's Church at Torresdale.

Clergymen of the Reformed faith from many countries will attend the fifteenth quadrennial council of the Presbyterian and Reformed Churches in the Presbyterian Church of St. Andrew and St. Paul, Montreal, Canada, beginning Wednesday and continuing through June 29. The general theme will be "The Church in the Modern World."

GASTON DOUMERGUE, who died yesterday at the age of 73, is known to the world, not for his devoted public service during more than four decades or as the twelfth President of France, but for his courageous leadership as Premier in the critical weeks after the "Stavisky" riots of February, 1934, which splattered the Place de la Concorde with blood.
