President Roosevelt was the honor guest at a dinner given tonight by the members of the "Little Cabinet," made up of the Assistant Secretaries of the government departments, who entertained him at Oxon Hill, the Maryland country home of Sumner Welles, Under-Secretary of State.

Smith Mitchell, 7, missing twenty- six hours, was found unconscious in an apt infested hole near Juliette late yesterday by one of a searching party of 250 persons. The child's physicians said today the boy's condition was "acutely painful" but not dangerous.

So much of Paragraph 5, Special Orders 120, dated May 24, 1937, ordering 2d Lt. Edwin G. Sauers, Inf.-Res., to Headquarters Buffalo District, Buffalo, N. Y., effective June 13, 1937, and relieving him on June 26, 1937, is amended so as to relieve him on June 22, 1937.

The wedding of Miss Louisa Mercena Pickett, daughter of Judge and Mrs. Walter Mason Pickett of New Haven, Conn., to John Irville Waterman, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Irville Dennat Waterman of South Weymouth, Mass., took place in the Congregational church here tonight. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Tertius Van Dyke of Washington, Conn.

Representative Mary T. Norton, Democrat, of New Jersey, entitled by seniority to the Labor Committee chairmanship vacated by the death of Representative. William P. Connery of Massachusetts, today said she would accept the post, "when and if it is offered me."

The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that in its study of investment companies it would hold public hearings beginning on June 28 on the Atlas Corportion and its affiliated companies. Recent hearings dealt with some of the companies taken over by Atlas, the examination being generally restricted, however, to the time when they were absorbed.

The Standard Oil Company of New Jersey advanced yesterday the price of light heating oil at terminals 55 points at New York to 6.3 cents a gallon. When sold in barges to resellers, the company Will allow a discount of 1/8 cent a gallon from that level.
Fletcher H. Montgomery was elected president of the Hat Corporation of America at a directors' meeting here yesterday, succeeding John Cavanagh, who was named chairman of the board.

An official invitation to residents of Harlem to participate in the opportunities of the new East Harlem Health Center at 158-164 East 115th Street was extended yesterday by a corps of 150 Department of Health nurses.
A chainstore license tax for such establishments within the District of Columbia was voted today by the House in approving a new tax bill for Washington.

Arthur J. O'Neill has been appointed State Stores division manager of Seagram-Distillers Corporation it was announced yesterday by 4ice President L. B. Davis. Branch offices serving as headquarters of the Chicago sales division of Standard Oil Company or Indiana will be located at Suite 1000, 20 North Wacker Drive, Ohicago Civic Opera Building, on and after July 5.

Miss Lee Seldon McCabe, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lewis B. McCabe of New York and Garrison, was married to Richard Dana de Rham, son of Henry Casimir de Rham of Cold Spring, N. Y., and the late Mrs. de Rham, at noon here today in the Episcopal Church, St. Philips-in-the-Highlands. The Rev. Dr. E. Clowes Chorley,

A message of condolence from President Roosevelt was received yesterday by the widow of Morgan J. O'Brien, former presiding justice of the Appellate Division, First Deapartment, for whom a solemn high mass of requiem will be offered at 11 A. M. today at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Vincent Ferrer, Sixtysixth Street and Lexington Avenue.

Gene Williams, chief investigator for District Attorney Buron Fitts of Los Angeles, said today that "I know the man who killed William Desmond Taylor." The statement was made at the convention of the District Attorneys Association of California.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Paul Tunnell of this city of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Helen Louise Tunnell, to Elmer Robert Thomas Jr., son of Elmer R. Thomas of Troy, N. Y. Miss Tunnell, who is a niece of Mrs. Peyton J. Van Ransselaer of New York,

The Inland Steel Company made its first statement today on its reasons for not signing a contract with the Steel Workers Organizing Committee. The statement was contained in the company's answer to a complaint filed recently with the National Labor Relations Board by the S. W. O. C. and the Amalgamated Association of Iron, Steel and Tin Workers.

Dick Carew of Stanford University will compete in both the 100 and 220 yard dashes at the World Labor Athletic Carnival at Randalls Island Stadium on July 11, it was announced yesterday by Chairman Charles L. Ornstein.

24th St, 533-535 W, 57x98.9; Chelsea Operating Co, William R. Patterson, president to Broadway Savings Bank; mtg, $44,000 held by grantee ($56.50). 56th St, 10-12 E. 42.cx100.5; Cabin Holding Corp, Benjamin Bernstein, president, to Column Holding Corp, 565 5th Ave. 109th St, 249-251 W, 50x100.11; Citizens Savings Bank to 249-251 W 109th St Corp. 21 E 40th St ($80).

A bolt of lightning struck a water tower on the roof of a seventeenstory apartment building at 1,200 Fifth Avenue, on the northeast corner of Fifth Avenue and 101st Street, shortly before 10 o'clock last night, richocheted off the tower onto the corner of the roof and showered a half-ton of cement coping into the street below.
The one-family dwelling at 108 Weequahic Avenue, Newark, has been purchased by Benjamin Winter of Newark from Ben R. Glassner. Leslie Blau, Inc., negotiated the deal.

Estate, less than $1,000. To Gertruae Brett, widow, executrix, 250 W. 94th St. COWEN, DAVID (June 10). Estate, more than $10,000. To Cecile Samuels, daughter, 40 E. 83d St, and David Cowen Jr., son, 7 W. 81st St, 5 per cent of decedent's stock in A. Goodman Sons, Inc. each;

Labor unrest restricted retail trade activity this week, the average gain over the previous week's total being held down to 3 to 6 per cent, according to the review issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

Youngstown Sheet and Tube prepared to reopen its mills early next week despite mediation move. Page 1. Republic Steel assailed "anarchy" and opposed "status quo" keeping plants closed pending Federal board's inquiry. Page 1.

The value of the mortgages in which they have participation and not the value of the real estate underlying the mortgages should be used in computing claims of investors against defunct title companies, the Appellate Division of the

Max Zahn, president of the International Dress Company, Inc., died yesterday at his home at 300 Central Park West after a long illness. He was 47 years old. Mr. Zahn was treasurer of the Home of the Daughters of Israel and a director and founder of the Hunt's Point Jewish Center.

Three passengers bound from San Isidro to Panama were arrested by the police when their airplane landed here yesterday and they were found to be carrying a large quantity of gold ornaments recovered from Indian graves.

Over the opposition of the International Association of Theatrical and Stage Employes, A. F. of L. affiliate, radio technicians employed by the Columbia Broadcasting Company voted yesterday to join the American Radio Telegraphists Association, C. I. O. affiliate, it was announced by Mervys Rathbone, president of the radio telegraphists.

Miss Martha Tyson Manly Parker, daughter of Mrs. Louis McKim of Baltimore and of Myron Parker Jr. of Washington, was married to Edgar Mills Gemmell, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Gemmell Jr. of New York, yesterday afternoon in the Church of the Ascension. The ceremoney was performed by the Rev. Arthur Cooper.
Vice President Garner took occasion today to deny rumors from Washington about a break with President Roosevelt.

W. C. Langley, a director of the Long Island Lighting Company, was paid $50,000 by the company in 1932 for arranging with various banks for the extension of company notes for about $8,750,000, according to evidence presented yesterday to Supreme Court Justice Aaron J. Levy in the trial of a stockholders' suit to recover about $20,000,000 from present and former officials of the utility.
As of this morning, there is only one show which admits its imminent departure, although (darkly) there are a couple of others hanging on so slender a thread as today's business.

Twelve hours after the new outbreak Thursday night in front of Father Divine's "heaven" at 20 West 115th Street, in which three Negroes and a white woman were injured, the New York County grand jury opened yesterday an inquiry into the two-hour fracas.

The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow: "With shearing more general and accumulations heavier in the West, buying has been more general. Some fairly heavy transfers have been made in Texas at 33-35 cents on the basis of 93-95 cents, clean Boston, for good to choice twelve months wools, with short eight months types at 32 cents, or about 90-92 cents. clean basis, Boston.
The three-story building on the southeast corner of Main and Center Streets, Hempstead, L. I., has been sold by the Second National Bank of Hempstead to the Montcaul Realty Corporation.

The ruling body of the United Automobile Workers of America voted today to call upon local unions to discipline all members and officers responsible for "unauthorized stoppage of work by fine or suspension or both."
Murray W. Stand, former majority leader of the Board of Aldermen, was appointed chairman of the New York World's Fair Commission at a meeting yesterday in City Hall.

Removal of the last real threat of a legal blockade for the Jim Braddock-Joe Louis heavyweight title fight, set for next Tuesday night at Comiskey Park, coincided today with the disclosure of Co-promoter Mike Jacobs's plans to conduct two more championship matches this year, in London and New York.
The International Labor Organization Conference unanimously, adopted today two recommendations for national and international planning of public works in advance of depression.

Charges and counter-charges of simple assault involving seven persons who participated in a street brawl on May 27 outside Bill's Gay Nineties, 57 East Fifty-fourth Street, were withdrawn yesterday and the defendants were freed by Magistrate Henry Curran.

Thirty-eight outstanding track and field stars will endeavor to better both American and international standards tomorrow in one of the track classics of the East, the fourth annual Princeton invitation meet, which will start at 5 P. M. in Palmer Stadium.

The annual Gathering of the Clans was held at Randalls Island last night with about 3,500 persons in the stadium to watch exhibitions of bagpiping, Highland dancing and marching. The affair was sponsored by the United Scottish Clans of Greater New York and New Jersey.
Bernard James McGinn, vice president of the American Surety Company of New York, died yesterday at his home, 151-18 Eightyfourth Road, Jamaica, after a brief illness. He was 54 years old.

A story of Cinderella proportions was revealed at Metro today with the reported signing of Mary Dees, $55-a-week dancer at Warners, to complete "Saratoga" in the role left vacant by the death of Jean Harlow.
Paired tomorrow in the first of the observation series trials to select a defender of the America's Cup will be Harold S. Vanderbilt's new Ranger and Gerard B. Lambert's Yankee.

More moisture in parts of the dry area in Saskatchewan and favorable weather for harvesting in the Winter Wheat Belt in the Southwest led to general selling of wheat futures in North American markets early today,

Miss of Garrison, Miss Lucia Br Marjorie Estelle Gould, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Norman F. Gould of Somerton, was married this evening to Robert Ritter Eyerly, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul R. Eyerly of Bloomsburg. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Reginald G. Davis in the Church of Our Saviour, Jenkintown.

Seven men who were convicted of extortion and conspiracy in New York's restaurant racket lost a habeas corpus application for release from Sing Sing prison today when Supreme Court Justice Mortimer B. Patterson filed a 3,000word decision sustaining their conviction.

W. Stanton Barbour of the Morris County Country Club and his partner, W. A. Bartle Jr. of Deepdale, led the qualifiers in the annual Piping Rock Club invitation best-ball golf tournament today with a 4-under-par total of 67.

Assurance of the inviolability of social security records is provided in a regulation issued by the board and made public today. Embodying its previously announced policy that all information in its files pertaining to "any

The marriage of Miss Lucille Burnham Sargeant, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Franklin Sargeant of Charlottesville, Va., to George Livingston de Peyster of New York took place this afternoon in the Episcopal Church of St. John's of Lattingtown at Locust Valley. The Right Rev. Frank Du Moulin, rector of the parish, performed the ceremony.

The Cubs moved up to a game ahead of the Giants today when Augie Galan tripled with three men on in the ninth to give the Chicago team an 8-to-7 victory over the Phillies while the New Yorkers lost to Cincinnati.

Interest in bond trading fell off yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange as prices in the main body of both investment and secondary issues fluctuated irregularly within narrow limits in the second slowest trading session of this month. Transactions in all bonds amounted to $6,277,100, compared with $7,910,700 on Thursday.

Polo's principal attractions in the metropolitan district this afternoon will be the intercollegiate championship match between Army and Cornell at Governors Island and the opening game of the Meadow Brook tourney at Westbury, L. I.

The secret political police continued today to hunt for members of the Prussian Council of the Confessional Church charged with disobeying the decree against announcing from the pulpit the names of those leaving the church.

A graduating class of 131 received diplomas here today at the 127th annual commencement of the Lawrenceville School. Dr. Allan V. Heely, headmaster, presided at the exercises, which were held in the Edith Memorial Chapel.

Fakirs and "others commercializing the science of astrology" have been barred from the first world convention ot astrologers now being held here. The convention is being attended by some of France's biggest "names" in astrology and the

If you should happen, one of these nights, to drop into Leon and Eddie's familiar West Fifty-second Street rest-house and should suddenly discover yourself at a table in a jungle-ringed stockade, with a furious thunderstorm rumbling and flashing overhead and with "rain" beating heavily in a tin trough, don't run away in fright.

President Harold W. Dodds of Princeton, commencement speaker at Phillips Academy today, declared it was the obligation of every educated person to resist the "philosophy of doom" which says that social problems have become so acute that force alone will settle them, and that popular government will of necessity fall by the wayside. Diplomas were conferred on 180 graduates.
A meeting of shareholders of Imperial Airways, Ltd., today approved a resolution seeking a 400 per cent increases in the company's authorized capital.
Mutual but unofficial assurances of aid in the event of war were exchanged today at the closing session of the second Conference on Canadian-American Affairs.
Sorrel-topped Don Budge and Henry Wilfred (Bunny) Austin will offer British tennis fans a possible Davis Cup preview tomorrow.

Forty members of the Southern Municipal Association, dealers in bonds for the most part, attended an outing at the Rockville Country Club today. They played golf and tennis and attended a dinner in the evening.

Mr. and Mrs. Eugene S. Newbold of Glenrocky, St. Davids, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Virginia Bramble Newbold, to John Williams Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. John Williams of Narberth. The wedding will take place next Spring.

Charles E. Wyzanski Jr., special assistant to the Attorney General, who won praise for his arguments in New Deal cases for the government, will leave the Department of Justice Aug. 1 to return to the Boston law firm of Ropes, Gray, Boyden Perkins.
Mr. and Mrs. Charles Chipman of this city and New York gave a supper dance here tonight at the Northampton Country Club for their debutante daughter, Miss Elizabeth Fitz Randolph Chipman.

PATROLMEN-James J. O'Donnell, from Traffic Precinct E to Traffic Precinct N; David Rubin, from Traffic Precinct J to 63d Precinct. Temporary Assignments LIEUTENANT - Daniel L. Murtaugh, Traffic Precinct D, assigned in command, from 8 A. M., June 19, during absence of captain on sick report.

Miss Mary Elizabeth Stanwood, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William E. Stanwood of Wellesley Hills, was married this afternoon to Horace Guy Crockett Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. H. G. Crockett of Glen Ridge, N. J. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Philemon Storges in St. Andrew's Church, Wellesley.
Mrs. Salvena Shloss Grant, wife of Adolph Grant, retired president of the Grant Tile Company of New York, died today at her home, 131 Lockwood Avenue. Her age was 77.

Directors of the Certain-Teed Products Corporation yesterday omitted the dividend on the 6 per cent preferred stock which was due to be paid on July 1, in order to conserve working capital for anticipated business expansion, Walter G. Baumhogger, president, announced.

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: Last week Dizzy Dean was compared with Carl Hubbell, but no mention was made of Van Lingle Mungo, the Dodgers' speedball ace. So. let's take a look at the record.

The four-family flat at 43 Graham Avenue, Brooklyn, was sold by the Duo Contracting Company to Rose Beer for $16,500 over a first mortgage of $14,000, extended for five years at 3 to 5 per cent. The Midwood Trading Company was the broker.

Weekly cotton statistics are as follows: British stocks 913,000 bales, against 909,000 a week ago, 917,000 two weeks ago, 928,000 three weeks ago and 727,000 a year ago; of which American 360,000 bales, against 380,000 a week ago, 390,000 two weeks ago, 400,000 three weeks ago and 307,000 a year ago.

As a result of protests against the route of the proposed extension of the Independent City Subway into the Bronx-voiced yesterday at the Board of Estimate meeting in City Hall, the board voted to defer action for one week on that extension, as well as another planned
Movements Co: vessels follow, all dates are June 17 unless' specified: At Cardena Bay, Brooks, Fox. At San Diego, Nitro, June 18: Overton., June 4; Cincinnati.
Bobbie Kamrath of the University of Texas advanced today to the final of the Delaware State tennis championships, beating Richard Bennett of the University of California, 6-4, 7-5.

The policy of the government in declining to state its official interpretation of doubtful language in the Robinson-Patman act is "manifestly wrong," but the government is "undoubtedly right" in declining to express any official opinion on a given case of application, Charles Wesley Dunn,. counsel for numerous trade associations, declares in a statement issued for release today on the first anniversary of the date of effectiveness of the act.

Five signed examples of the work of Francois Boucher, eighteenth century French court painter, brought the unusually high price of [Pound]23,100 at a sale of collections of old masters at Christie's today.
John Cavanagh, formerly president, yesterday was elected chairman of the Hat Corporation of America, the company announced. He succeeds Maurice Wertheim, who had resigned.

Frustration seems to dog every step toward the re-establishment of peace between Paraguay and Bolivia. Fears lest the devastating conflict over the Chaco be resumed have again been aroused by the refusal of the Paraguayan Army to obey President RAFAEL FRANCO'S order.

The Johns-Manville Corporation has completed negotiations for the purchase of the Richmond (Ind.) plant of the Fibre Conduit Company, which is consolidating its manufacturing activities in its Orangeburg (N. Y.) factory.

William S. Knudsen, president of the General Motors Corporation, declared yesterday that the United Automobile Workers Union's inability to control its members was the cause for "outlaw" strikes in the company's plants.

Briarcliff Lodge, well-known resort hotel at Briarcliff Manor, N. Y., where persons prominent in New York's social life often were guests, has been purchased by a group of Westchester citizens interested in Edgewood Park School, of which Shannon C. Wallace is business manager.

Several dinner parties preceded the colorful cruise supper-dance given here by Auxiliary 8 of Stony Wold Sanitarium, Saranac, N. Y., tonight at the Indian Harbor Yacht Club. Among those who entertained guests for dinner at their homes before the dance were Mrs. Burton Jackson, Mrs. John W. Lewis, Mrs. Harma Brereton, Miss Esther Bird and Mrs. Gordon Thompson.

The State Committee of the American Labor party will meet today at the Hotel Edison and set up a permanent organization for the Fall campaign, its first as a legal political party. State Chairman Luigi Antonini will preside.
" The Cradle Will Rock," an opera by Marc Blitzstein, was presented last night at the Venice Theatre, Fifty-ninth Street and Seventh Avenue, as a concert and a commercial production.

Miss Carolyn Tyler Chase, daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. C. Thurston Chase of Hartford, Conn., and Monterey, Mass., was married to Dr. Reginald Charles Farrow of Newark, N. J., here this afternoon in the gardens of the Eaglebrook School.

A two-to-one decision by the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals, which would have the effect of curbing the power of the National Labor Relations Board to compel employers to deal with "collective bargaining agents," designated by it to handle disputes with employes, was handed down here today.
The British Government announced today it would send a commission to inquire into the results of the Scandinavian system of requiring compulsory reports on the treatment of venereal diseases.
Alfred Hahn, cotton converter, died Thursday at his home, 25 East Eighty-sixth Street, at the age of 73. Mr. Hahn was an organizer of Golding Hahn Company, a cotton corporation, in 1913.

Thomas Hubbard Gammack, stock broker and former official of the Securities and Exchange Commission, died at 5:30 P. M. yesterday of an embolism in New York Hospital at the age of 37. Mr. Gammack suffered an infection about two weeks ago. He lived at 840 Park Avenue.

Bishop James Welldon, former headmaster of Harrow School, died in Sevenoaks today at the age of 83. Although he left Harrow in 1898 after thirteen years' service, the school's graduates who are now middle-aged cherish anecdotes about their most prominent headmaster.

The Steel Workers Organizing Committee filed charges late today with the National Labor Relations Board against the Republic Steel Corporation, asking an investigation of alleged acts of discrimination, coercion and intimidation which, it said, frustrated the operation of collective bargaining in the corporation's plants.

The Hudson River tonight saw one of its greatest four-mile crew races, with oarsmen from one college participating. Washington's varsity eight, Olympic champions, came from behind in a time trial to catch the junior varsity in the last half mile and row a dead heat.
Premier Richard L. Butler of the State of South Australia today made himself the first of all the Dominion statesmen now in London to speak out boldly in favor of an AngloAmerican trade treaty.

Announcement has bean made of the engagement of Miss Amelie Sigourney, daughter of Henry L. Sigourney of this place and of Mrs. Alfred G. Kellogg of Boston, to Douglas Channing Scott, son of Donald Scott of Huntington, L. I., and Cambridge, Mass., and the late Mrs. Channing Eustis Scott.

Premier Leon Blum was twice defeated in the Senate this afternoon, but was as solidly supported in the Chamber of Deputies this evening a.s he was last Wednesday in his demand for full powers to straighten out France's complicated financial affairs.

Bold Turk, speedy 2-year-old from the Paragon Stable, outran his field to the first turn and won going away from seven other youngsters today in the third running of the $5,000-added Fanueil Hall Stakes. The sprint featured the closing program of Suffolk Downs 24-day Spring meet.

The Transport Workers Union of America, according to a statement issued yesterday by Austin J. Hogan, general secretary, has more than tripled its membership since it affiliated with the C. I. O. on May 10. Mr. Hogan declared that the union's membership in Greater New York had grown from 14,000 to about 43,000 in a little more than a month.

Over the breast of a cloud-blackened sea, Harold S. Vanderbilt's new Ranger was a clear-cut victor today in the first of the observation series of races to determine the defender of the America's Cup.

Miss Shirley Gardiner White, the daughter of Charles P. White, of Glenbrook, was married to Edwin Francis Kittle, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Kent Kittle of Glenbrook, this afternoon in the Union Memorial Church. The bride's uncle, the

ALL over the country interest is growing in the drivertesting clinic a laboratory for measuring, with the aid of scientific apparatus, the physical and psychological characteristics of driver and would-be drivers.

The School Art League, which presents art scholarships and medals to high school students at the end of each term, yesterday announced the winners of its awards for the January to June term. Eight scholarships and eighty-eight medals have been won.

City officials, political leaders and representatives of religious and fraternal organizations were among some 3,000 persons who attended the funeral service yesterday morning for Alderman John J. Mahoney at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Paul the Apostole, at Sixtieth Street and Columbus Avenue.

Frederick William Procter married Miss Ivis Ethel Helen Goulding today in a civil ceremony at the city hall here. Richard Barthelmess, the movie star, was best man. A reception was held for sixty guests.

Governor Earle said in a statement tonight that it was a "modified form of martial law" he had ordered for Johnstown, to preserve law and order in the face of an expected march of 40,000 miners tomorrow in support of strikers in the Bethlehem Steel Company plant.

The medical staff and trustees of the new Jewish Memorial Hospital at Broadway and 196th Street will make a preview tour of the building at 2 P. M. today under the direction of Isidor S. Schweitzer, president of the hospital.

Business executives do not think very highly of their librarians, placing them in the same class with typists or file clerks, Dr. Charles C. Williamson, dean of the School of Library Service and director of the Columbia University Libraries, declared yesterday.

SEVERAL years ago the outside and inside of the Metropolitan Opera House were extensively refurbished. Many things were done-new lights, paint, seats, air-conditioning were among the additions and operations performed on the old house.

A. K. Powell, chief of the New Jersey real estate section of the division of conservation, reports that substantial progress is being made in the management of real estate held for the account of banks, trust companies, building and loan associations in possession
Graduation exercises for six students of the Newark Apprentice Course in Museum Training will be held Monday evening with an informal supper in the garden of the Newark Museum.

Fifty-two advanced degrees were awarded by Brown University at the annual Graduate School convocation this afternoon when Dr. Abraham Flexner, director of the Institute for Advanced Study at Princeton, spoke on "The Prepared Mind."

Miss Margaret Frances Sheldon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clinton A. Sheldon of this place, was married to Earle Stuart Willoughby of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth E. Willoughby of Buffalo, N. Y., this afternoon in the Reformed Church here. The Rev.

A RADICALLY altered "Stage Door" is being photographed at RKO, where Ginger Rogers, Katharine Hepburn, Gail Patrick, Constance Collier and a varied assortment of young ladies are giving their version of what goes on in the minds and lives of the youngsters who speak of the theatre only with a capital T.

Miss Anne Elizabeth Downs, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Findley Downs of Chestnut Hill, was married this afternoon to William Rice Moseley, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Russell Moseley of Charles River, Mass.

FIGURES issued by the International Broadcasting Office at Geneva indicate that the United States is well in the lead in the number of radio receiving sets. In fact, this country probably has more radio sets than an of Europe, excluding the Union of Russian Soviet Republics, which was not included in the count. Nevertheless,

Four days before he is to enter the ring at Comiskey Park, Chicago, against Joe Louis in defense of his world heavyweight crown, James J. Braddock today impressed those who have been watching his training, and provided a distinct surprise for newcomers who expected to see a stiff-legged, old man of the ring.

Baron Constantin von Neurath, the German Foreign Minister, will arrive in London next Wednesday for an official visit to the new British Government. The invitation to the German statesman provided gratification as well as surprise in official circles who promptly read into it a complimentary gesture toward Chancellor Adolf Hitler as well as recognition that a frank, comprehensive exchange of views between Berlin and London is desirable at this time.

STAGING the recent American Bowling Congress championship matches in New York brought to the city about 22,000 keglers from every section of the country and made our citizens more generally bowling conscious.

Miss Margaret Gilmore Pendleton, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Nickels Pendleton of Portland, Ore., and this city, was married to Dr. Edward Fuller Stanton of this city, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Edwin Stanton of Hartford, Conn., yesterday afternoon in the Smith College Club of New York at the New Weston.
Mrs. William Pierce Evans announced today that her daughter, Mrs. Elizabeth Evans Graves. will be married late this month to Francis Bowes Sayre, Assistant Secretary of State.

Miss Margaret Reeve Boyd, daughter of Mrs. Robert E. Boyd and the late Mr. Boyd of this place, was married this afternoon to Charles Knoll, son of Mr. and Mrs. Max Knoll of Grantwood, N..J., at St. Paul's Episcopal Church here.

ONCE again the Danish dramatist Kjell Abell has scored a success, as "Eve Serves a Term of Childhood," following a triumph at Kongelige in Copenhagen, is beginning to turn up elsewhere in Scandinavia.
A CLASS in the staging of operettas and pageants and a class in creative music for the children's theatre have been added to of the music education department of the Juilliard Summer School. Mrs.
To a committee of fifteen, headed by John W. Davis of New York City, was assigned today the task of solving the problem of "overcrowding" in the State bar.

A series of sixteen afternoon concerts will be given at the Juilliard Concert Hall, 130 Claremont Avenue, during July and August. The first program will be played by Sascha Gorodnitzki, pianist, on July 13 at 4 o'clock.

Miss Mary Elizabeth Galligan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Joseph Galligan of South Orange, was married to Leo Laughlin of Girardville, Pa., this morning in Our Lady of Sorrows Church here. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Theodore Hemalt of Baltimore.

WILLIAM PENN'S life was at once noble and tragic. He could have lived in a world of fashion in the warmth of material success and pleasure, but he chose the colder spiritual realm of religious piety and devotion. More than once he was

Coroner William L. Seil gave a verdict of suicide today in the death of Edgar F. Bloch, 21-year-old Cornell University senior who was to graduate with his class on Monday. Bloch's body was found in Ithaca's Deep Fall Creek gorge early today under the "swinging bridge" near the campus.

The American Philosophical Society has made a grant of $2,000 for the cataloguing and study of the original Moravian musical manuscripts in Bethlehem, Pa., which number more than forty, the oldest dating from 1749.

(Figures in parentheses indicate par) Arrowbrook (70) -- First round for President's Trophy : Harry Parker defeated M. Bachemheimer. 3 and 2; Al Schanzor defeated Jack Goodman, 1 cup ; I Diamond defeated L. Stein, 2 up ; William Himlyn defeated M. Rattinger, 3 and 2 ; Mark Smith defeated Nat Lurie, 2 and 1.
Alumnae of St. Catherine's Academy will give their annual Spring dance on Friday evening at Ben Riley's Arrowhead Inn. Riverdale, for the benefit of the scholarship fund.

At least one man was killed and twelve persons were injured in a fiercely fought battle between police and striking workers of the Republic Steel Corporation plant. The dead man was John Bogovich, who carried a picket card of the Steel Workers Organizing Committee.
THIS is a book about food; but though food is univer sal, this book is unique. The first adjective for "Serve It Forth" must certainly be "different." And as one reads on the

A bill introduced into Congress by Senator Arthur Harry Moore of New Jersey and now in the hands of the Senate Committee on Banking and Currency provides that individuals as well as banks and other financial institutions may be approved as mortgagees in obtaining FHA insurance on mortgage loans made on homes.

Miss Dorothy Gilder Martin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry H. Martin of Rye, was married yesterday afternoon to John Bartol Dunning, son of Mr. and Mrs. M. Bartol Dunning of Upper Montclair, N. J. The ceremony, which took place in the Presbyterian Church here, was performed by the Rev. Charles G. Sewall of Tryon, N. C., formerly pastor of the church in Rye.

Lieutenant Michael J. Morreil, a World War veteran and past vice commander of Lafayette Post, American Legion, died at the United States Veterans Hospital at Castle Point, near Chelsea, N. Y., Friday. He organized the legion post at the veterans hospital some years ago. He served overseas as second lieutenant in the Seventy-sixth Field Artillery Regiment. He was wounded and gassed in the MeuseArgonne battles.

Many of Bilbao's 300,000 men, women and children hid in the railway tunnels and cellars of the stricken city today waiting for relief from one of the most terrible scenes of horror and privation since the height of the World War.
Ten directors and seven new members were elected this week by the Westchester County Council of Social Agencies, it was announced by C. Parker Lattin of Yonkers, chairman of the organization.

The Cuba Company reported yesterday for the three months ended on March 31, a consolidated net profit of $405,338 after taxes, interest and depreciation but before preferred dividends on subsidiary companies and minority interest.

Although Chile's nitrate production has not reached pre-depression levels, according to a report to the Department of Commerce, sales during the fiscal year up to June 30, 1937, are estimated to have been 40 per cent above those in 1933-34 in spite of the virtual loss of the Spanish market.

THE title of this book explains why so accomplished a West Pointer as Colonel Mott was not the commander of a regiment or a brigade in France in the World War. For nine years before 1914 he had been military attache to the American Embassy at Paris, and with the entrance of the United States into the war in 1917 he

Music Hall of the Air symphony orchestra, Mischa Violin conducting; soloists are Viola Philo, soprano; Edwina Eustis, contralto; David Novalis, violinist, and Gaston Dubois, 'cellist: WJZ, 12:301:30 P. M.

Fifteen hundred Wellesley alumnae defied the threats of leaden skies this afternoon to march in costume on Severance Green in the annual alumnae parade. A last-minute burst of sun brightened the serpentine parade winding past the massed spectators.

More sales in the Onteora Park section of the Catskills were reported yesterday by Potter, Hamilton Co., brokers. One of the deals involved The Studio, home of Dr. Edward Jones, which was purchased by Professor and Mrs. Harry Parr. Mr. Parr holds the

Miss Louise Wells Curtis, daughter of Mrs. Roderick Perry Curtis of this place and the late Mr. Curtis, was married to Austin Wheelock Roche, son of James Thomas Roche of Fairfield, Conn., and the late Mrs. Roche, here this afternoon in Trinity Church by the rector, the Rev. William Schroeder.

The City Industrial Relations Board, which has settled labor difficulties in 187 cases involving 75,000 workers since Its appointment by Mayor La Guardia last April 1, will cease activities July 1, when the New York State Board of Mediation, created by the Legislature, begins to function, it was announced yesterday by Mayor La Guardia.

Discussing some phases of. public housing and realty values in the recent issue of Real Estate News, published by the Greater New York Taxpayers Association, Tenement House Commissioner Langdon W. Post says that low-rent public housing will, to some extent, compete with existing old-law

Paul Van Zeeland. Premier of Belgium, paid a fifteen-minute visit to Mayor La Guardia at City Hall yesterday. The Belgian leader, who was accompanied by Count Robert Van Der Straten-Ponthoz, Belgian Ambassador, departed without being interviewed by the press.

Miss Barbara Chisholm, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hugh J. Chisholm of the Savoy-Plaza in New York, Strathglass Farm in Port Chester and Portland, Me., was married to Robert L. Scott this afternoon in Christ Church here. The Rev.
NEXT Saturday most New Yorkers who will visit the Metropolitan Amateur Athletic Union's sports carnival at Randalls Island will be treated to the sight of a game they have never seen before.
HOW have the world-shaking events of recent years affected American thought? The false prosperity of the Nineteen Twenties, the depression, the struggle for recovery, the liberal

Defeat of the State organization of the Farmer-Labor party in the Minneapolis city election last Monday is regarded as the first important straw in the political winds of Min- nesota since the November election.

Having crossed without misha the Arctic Circle, with its hazard of unexplored areas and unpredictable weather conditions and then the wilds of Northwestern Canada, three daring Soviet airmen were speeding down the Pacific Coast early today en route to Oakland, Calif., goal of their 6,000-mile nonstop flight from Moscow.

THE increasingly liberal attitude of the Soviets toward Russia's cultural past, the fact that citizens of Stalin's State are now encouraged in the knowledge that there was such a past prior to 1917, the new emphasis on human beings, rather than on members of "desirable" or "undesirable" social classes-such changes cannot be without effect on the country's literature.
William Elliott Sr. of 112 West Passaic Avenue, a director of the Rutherford National Bank and president of the Taxpayers Association, died today in Hackensack Hospital at the age of 62.

Miss Rose Walker Page, daughter of Mrs. Thomas Walker Page and the late Dr. Page who was for many years professor of economics at the University of Virginia and later a member of the Brookings Institution and the United States Tariff Commission, was married today to John B. Wilson, son of Mrs. Andrew T. Wilson of Boston and the late Mr. Wilson.

Miss Justine Arnold, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Harold Sears Arnold of this city and Woodbridge, Conn., was married here this afternoon in Christ Church to Edward Mortimer Linforth, student at the Yale School of Fine Arts and son of Professor and Mrs. Ivan M. Linforth of Berkeley, Calif. The ceremony was performed by the rector, the Rev. C. Clarke Kennedy.
Two of the world's rarest books, a first folio Shakespeare and a volume of the Gutenberg Bible, will be sold at Sotheby's Monday as the climax of some expected tall bidding.

IN an address before the pharmacology section of the American Medical Association convention at Atlantic City, Dr. Allan L. Barach of the Medical Center and Presbyterian Hospital in New York called the attention of

A. K. Powell, chief of the New Jersey real estate section of the division of conservation, reports that substantial progress is being made in the management of real estate held for the account of banks, trust companies, building and loan associations in possession

THE chief value of Mr. Huberman's book lies in the fact that retells for its own generation, in the vernacular and imagery of this generation, the result of the studies and passionate argument of the historical and social writers that have gone before us. It presents a picture, necessarily schematic

FOR over a year there has been talk of a forthcoming album set involving Kirsten Flagstad. Everything considered, it was inevitable, but it is hoped that "Flagstad in Song" (Victor M-342) is only a beginning, for as a set it falls far short of expectations, particularly after all that supposedly has been promised.
A shift in Soviet buying from Germany to England has occurred this year as credits established in Germany by Russia have begun to expire, foreign traders pointed out here yesterday. Purchasing in

The indications are for partly cloudy and slightly warmer weather today. There will be showers tomorrow with moderate temperatures, according to the map charted at the United States Weather Bureau at 7:30 o'clock (E. S. T.) last night.

Eugene G. Grace, president of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation. protested tonight in a telegram to Governor Earle that a forced closing of its Cambria mills at Johnstown would result in the loss of "millions of dollars in wages to workmen and great damage of property."

In a speech marked by thinly veiled references to the present struggle over the courts, Chief Justice Charles E. Hughes warned here today against "the often unwise fervor of crusaders which may carry a dominant majority over into oppression, destroying the basic values of democratic government."
An investigation of President Roosevelt's income tax returns by the Congressional committee studying tax evasion, was advocated today by Representative Fish, Republican, of New York.

Track-Archie San Romani won the Princeton invitation mile, defeating Don Lash in a close finish, with Glenn Cunningham third. San Romani and Lash both were timed in 4:07.2, this being the second fastest mile ever run. Southern California retained the National Collegiate A. A. title in the meet at Berkeley.

Cheerful, and apparently improved in health, Frederick B. Snite Jr., 28-year-old infantile paralysis victim, reached the United States today after traveling from China in an "iron lung" and left by train for his home city, Chicago.

Betsy and Betty Anderson, New Rochelle's "unrelated twins," celebrated their eighteenth birthdays Thursday and pledged themselves never to part for long periods, although after next Wednesday, when they will be graduated from the New Rochelle High School, they will enroll in different colleges.

The New York Curb Exchange has admitted new $1 par value common stock of the Taggart Corporation to unlisted trading in substitution for old common stock of no par value. The new stock is being exchanged share for share for the old.

A choppy sea and threatening weather held the fleet in the Yacht Racing Association's fifth championship event, the fifty-third Spring regatta of the Larchmont Yacht Club, down to eighty-six craft today. Only a scattered few

THE newest American race track, in a natural setting of trees and rolling hills, will be inaugurated here on Saturday amid unusual fanfare. The opening of Delaware Park will mean- that another State has ended its long ban on horse racing.

A chapel in memory of the Rev. Dr. George Alexander, for many years minister of the First Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Eleventh Street, is to be built in the church. Plans for the chapel are outlined in a printed letter sent to friends of Dr. Alexander by Mrs. Roger H. Williams, chairman of the committee of the George Alexander Memorial Chapel.

The ten-acre estate of John T. Adams, one of the "show" places of the Titicus district of Ridgefield, has been purchased by Mrs. Georgia S. Outwaite of New York and Florida. The buyer, who has just returned from a world cruise, will improve the homestead and occupy it as her permanent home.

The marriage of Miss Margaret Maynadier Hardcastle, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Yellott Fitzhugh Hardcastle of Haverford, Pa., to William Plummer Drake of Detroit, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick E. Drake of Bath, Me., took place here this afternoon in Christ Church.

Miss Mary Gertrude Lanigan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin A. Lanigan of this city, was married yesterday morning in St. Margaret's Church, Riverdale, to James Maxwell Charlton, son of Mr. and Mrs. D. E. A. Charlton of Scarsdale, N. Y. The Rev. Thomas Doyle performed the ceremony.

The Department of Agriculture reported today that United States exports of cotton had declined this season, although world trade in cotton had expanded sharply. Its survey, covering the period from August through April, showed 10,271,000 bales of cotton in international trade for the first nine months of this season, compared with 8,159,000 bales in the same period last season and 9,831,000 bales two seasons ago.

AN exhibition entitled "American Painting from 1860 until To day" will open on Wednesday at the Cleveland Museum of Art and continue through Oct. 3. The museum seeks to make the show a worthy sequel to that of last year for the many thousands of visitors who are expected to come to the city during the second Summer of the Great Lakes Exposition.

Liquor interests actually are far from worried about the spread of local option victories, spokesmen for distilling companies said here last week. The dry gains, they contend, have been made in towns and counties which normally were dry before prohibition and which went wet only in the landslide voting which brought repeal.

Political circles today expressed anxiety concerning the next moves by the different parties in view of the announced reshuffle of the Cabinet with the possibility of the Radicals figuring in the next coalition.
The pace of economic recovery in the United States has speeded up, if figures in the Department of Commerce report on 1936 national income, released this week, may be taken as a guide.

Paul V. McNutt, United States High Commissioner, has acted to halt Philippine violations of the London sugar agreement, instructing Commonwealth officials to suspend all further shipments to Hongkong.

The Spanish situation took another serious turn today when, in a denial of its own former denial, the German Government officially announced as another Saturday surprise for the world that "Spanish-Bolshevist submarine pirates" had made two unsuccessful attempts to torpedo the German cruiser Leipzig while she was on non-intervention duty in the Western Mediterranean.
The Friendly Town Association of this village is planning the establishing of a Chauncey M. Depew Alcove and Research Department here in the field library.

THIS clearly written and combative volume is not only--to use Mr. Elliott's word-dynamic. It is dynamite. Every paragraph is charged with economic explosive--and will be of provocative interest to some one financially affected by the theories advanced.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated June 17: COMMANDERS Schuirmann, R. E., naval operations, Washington, D. C., to command Destroyer Division 5. Moreell, B., Civil Engineer Corps, Navy Dept.. Washington, D. C., to Navy Yard, Pearl Harbor, T. H., as Public Works officer, about Sept. 1.

Miss Dorothy Rita Roy, daughter of Mrs. J. Harriett Roy of this place and the late John H. Roy, founder of the Roy Press of New York, was married to Robert Francis Blue, son of Mr and Mrs. Edward F. Blue of Jackson Heights, N. Y., yesterday in the home of the bride's brother and sister-in-law, Mr. and Mrs. Arthur R. Roy of Valley Road, Gillette, N. J.

The chief danger in the current rapid spread of all types of deferred payment and budget plans, particularly in the men's and women's apparel field, is that competition will force inadequately financed stores to adopt such schemes and result in a sharp increase in defaults, credit executives of manufacturing and wholesale companies agreed here yesterday.
JUNE is ever the season of abundance in nature's world about New York. Wild strawberries and other fruits are ripening in every field and woodland. Caterpillars, beetles and a

William J. Donohue of Binghamton was re-elected president of the Civil Service Association of the State of New York, and Albany was selected as the 1938 convention city at the association's twenty-ninth annual convention in this city today. The other officers re-elected were: vice president, Frank J. Prial of New York; treasurer, John D. Keleher

While a capacity audience of 5,400 persons was watching the show in the Capitol Theatre, Fiftyfirst Street and Broadway, last night, a small fire started in a storeroom on the lounge floor but it was put out with hand extinguishers before the arrival of three fire engines and two fire trucks, summoned on one alarm. The theatre audience was ignorant of the fire.
An increasing demand for apartments of eleven to fifteen rooms in the Park and Fifth Avenues section of Manhattan is seen by John F. Hamlin, renting manager of Douglas L. Elliman Co.

Amelia Earhart took off at 6:30 A. M. today on the next leg of her flight around the world. It was believed her destination was Bangkok, Siam, about 400 miles southeast of here. She arrived here yesterday after a flight through a Burmese monsoon which she described as the worst experience of her journey.
The Manufacturers Trust Company is agent under the plan of readjustment affecting the 6 per cent secured notes of the. Aeolian Company.

Mayor La Guardia yesterday designated June 26 as Junior Birdmen Day. The day will be marked by the fourth annual outdoor model plane championship contest, to be held in the sheep meadow in Central Park from 10 A. M. to 5 P. M.

The statement that he believes Mrs. William H. Parsons, missing from her Long Island farm for. ten days, to be still alive was made today by a high official engaged in the investigation of her mysterious disappearance.

Resumption of its biennial conventions by the mechanical division of the Association of American Railroads at Atlantic City last week provided graphic proof of the progress made in the improvement of railway equipment since 1930, the last year in which the meeting was held. The Railway Supply

The use of relief funds to help workers whose wages in private industry are insufficient to meet minimum living costs is "the most vexing of relief problems," because of the danger that such relief payments will operate as an indirect subsidy to employers who pay their workers so little that they cannot maintain themselves and their families without public aid, Mayor Le Guardia said yesterday.

Miss Dorothy Olcott Tumbridge, daughter of Stanley Spartan Tumbridge and the late Mrs. Tumbridge of 141 Willow Street, Brooklyn, was married yesterday afternoon to William McCarroll Mark, son of Mrs. Henry A. Mark and the late Mr. Mark of New York. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Theodore Cuyler Speers in the Church of the Holy Trinity in Brooklyn Heights.

The Long Island Real Estate Board will hold its annual outing the Patio, Westhampton Beach, on July 14. A new real estate organization, known as. the Fred Berger Company, has opened offices at 70 Street. The president is
A bridge party and tea for the benefit of the work of the Sisters of the Good Shepherd will be given on June 30 by Mrs. Timothy A. Leary at her home in White Plains.

Trading in the stock market last week continued quiet, although it did show on increase over the week before, and prices were lower. Bonds were easier in light trading but the new-issue market was the busiest in four months. Net changes in commodity prices on the week were small, but these markets showed a relatively higher degree of activity than did securities.
ALTHOUGH it has been a known disease for more than 3,000 years, cancer is still "the great darkness."

Cornell alumni today elected Miss Mary Honor Donlon, New York lawyer, and Alfred H. Hutchinson, Chicago business executive, as alumni members of the university's board of trustees. Results of a record mail ballot of 14,924 votes were announced at the annual meeting of the Cornell Alumni Corporation.

Miss Carolyn Roberts, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James J. Roberts of this city, was married to Francis X. Byrne, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles P. Byrne, also of New Rochelle, this afternoon in the chapel of the Holy Family Church here. The Rev. John J. Coffey

Willie Turnesa, youngest of the famous Turnesa clan, scored his second notable golf victory of the current season today when he defeated John E. Parker Jr., member of the Essex County Country Club, 6 and 5, in the final round for the metropolitan amateur crown.

Governor Davey tonight told Mayor James Seccombe of Canton that the reported seizure and detention at union headquarters of seven men seeking to return to work in Canton steel mills was "a clear violation of the State laws pertaining to kidnapping."

The management of Alexander's Department Stores, Fordham Road and Grand Concourse and Third Avenue and 152d Street, the Bronx, announced yesterday that the stores' employes had voted 2 to 1 against the Department Store Employes Union, Local 1,250, C. I. O. affiliate, as their collective bargaining agent. The election was held under the supervision of the City Industrial Relations Board and the stores side, were closed during the balloting.
One piece of cake was the "celebration" for Representative Edward T. Taylor of Colorado today on his seventyninth birthday anniversary. He is the oldest member of the House.

The Federal Circuit Court of Appeals granted today a temporary injunction holding up construction of the proposed Buzzard Roost hydroelectric plant in Greenwood County, S. C., but allowed PWA to grant an additional $150,000 to the $200,000 already given the county for preliminary legal expenses, administration and acquiring options on land involved.

Miss Alice Bartlett Fitch Smith, daughter of Wilson Fitch Smith of this place and New York, and the late Mrs. Smith, was married here today in the Second Congregational Church to Robert Miller Walker, son of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Walker of Flushing, L. I. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. William Burnham Stimson, rector of St. Mary's Church, Hamilton Village, Philadelphia.

Chet Laabs hit a home run and a triple today to drive in five runs and lead the Tigers to an 8-6 victory over the Athletics. With the Tigers two runs behind in the fifth, Laabs hit. his circuit blow with two aboard to put Detroit in front, 6-5. In the ninth, after Bill Werber's sixth-inning single had tied the score, Laabs tripled with two on base to decide the issue.
Father's Day promotions of men's wear items last week resulted in a gain of about 10 to 15 per cent in sales volume over the previous week, according to local store ex-' ecutives here yesterday.

Miss Charlotte Van Bibber, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Van Bibber of this place and Bronxville, N. Y., was married to Frank Rutledge Davis Jr., this afternoon in the gardens of Argyle House, Echo Valley Farms, the home of her parents here. The Rev. George H. Smyth of Scarsdale, N. Y., performed the ceremony.

KNOWN to many impartial authorities as the best gagplugger in the movies a girl who can take a poor author, and does nine cases out of ten, and make him sound like Noel Coward or the late Wilson Mizner, Patsy Kelly has, naturally, been borrowed more often, during her four years in pictures, than almost any other unique Hollywood property.

Bonds called last week for redemption before maturity were in smaller volume than during the preceding period and consisted principally of small parts of issues, not whole loans. Except for two calls of small municipal issues to be retired this month, the week's redemption notices were for future months.

St. Peter's College will confer degrees upon sixty-three graduates at its thirty-seventh commencement exercises here tomorrow afternoon. Mark A. Sullivan, former Judge of Common Pleas, and a graduate in the class of 1897, will give the principal address. Bishop Thomas J. Walsh of the Roman Catholic diocese of Newark will preside.

S. C. Treat's Alpha led home a fleet of eleven boats in the weekly series of Star Class races held off the Morris Yacht Club, City Island, yesterday under the auspices of the newly organized Eastchester Bay Y. R. A. George Dvorak's Juno II was runner-up, thirty-four seconds behind the victor.

Three persons were killed today in the collision of their automobile with a Baltimore Ohio passenger train on the outskirts of this town. They were Mrs. Ada Lape, 40; her daughter, Mary Jane Lape, 16, and Edward Stimmel, 23.

Mr. and Mrs. De Forest Grant have gone to Reverie Cove, their Summer home at Bar Harbor. Charles Betts Hillhouse and Miss Sylvia Remsen Hillhouse of the Westbury leave today for their place in Newport.

The Steel Workers Organizing Committee asked the Treasury Department today for an investigation of whether the Republic Steel Corporation and the Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company are violating the National Firearms Act by having in their possession unregistered machine guns.

Brazil, the world's largest coffee producer, proposes to burn in the course of the 1937-38 crop year, which will begin on July 1, almost 20,000,000 bags of coffee, or 7,000,000 bags more than experts estimate that the country will export in the same period.

Members of the Tabor Academy crew of Marion, Mass., sailed yesterday for England aboard the Cunard White Star liner Berengaria to defend the Thames Challenge Cup at Henley-on-Thames during the annual Henley regatta, which is to start on June 30.

THE distinction of being the first automobile company to present 1938 models to the public will fall this year to Hupmobile. In its comeback effort, after having suspended operations for fourteen months, it will announce its new lines probably late in August. Automobile editors in

There were harmonica players, violinists, fife players and drummers, but it remained for the pianists to carry off the major share of first prizes yesterday afternoon. The occasion was the second annual Opportunity Contest for Amateur Musicians, conducted on the Mall in Central Park by the Park Department.

Miss Adele Allison Wood, daughter of Mrs. Fred F. Wood of this place, was married this afternoon to William Alfred Hands, son of Mr. and Mrs. C. Alfred Hands, in Grace Episcopal Church. The Rev. Charles W. Popham performed the ceremony.

The remodeled Berkshire Museum will be formally opened on Friday with a preview for invited guests, followed by a dinner at the Berkshire Country Club and a reception in the evening. A special loan exhibition of landscape painting has been assembled and important works of art in the permanent collection will be on view.
TESTS made recently by transengineers for John brewers of London, Canada, proved that revolutionary style in truck design made for increased efficiency and lower cost operation per unit.
The Rev. Dr. C. Morton Murray, rector of the Church of the Holy Comforter here for twelve years, died today following an illness of several months.

With a light easterly breeze ruffling the waters of the Sound, twenty auxiliary cruising yachts started in the annual overnight race of the Riverside Yacht Club at 10:30 tonight. The race is the seventh in the series.

The marriage of Miss Eldora Enz of Montclair, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Enz of Red Wing, Minn., to Douglas Groff Cole, son of Mr. and Mrs. Mortimer S. Cole of Bloomfield, took place this afternoon in the Methodist Episcopal Church at Watsessing.
The great lift of relief and optimism felt all over China when news was received that the Hayashi Cabinet had fallen in Japan has given place to a spirit of cynical resignation.

Miss Florence Lambert Suydam, daughter of Mrs. William Farrington Suydam of this city and the late Mr. Suydam, was married to Lieutenant Joseph J. Kohout, son of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Kohout of Astoria, Queens, here at noon today at the home of her aunt, Mrs. E. B. Hardenbergh.

Danny Ahearn, 35 years old, of 64 Gouverneur Street, who said he was a writer of detective stories, was arrested last night and charged with extortion. The arrest was made on the complaint of Mrs. May Lehrer, of 9 Post Avenue, Inwood, who said that Ahearn demanded $200 on the pretext that he had abducted her husband, Harry.
Cupid upset the phone service at the Paris Exposition's German Pavilion late this week, because a 100 per cent Aryan switchboard girl, Hertha Rost, fell in love with a Swiss non-Aryan

The Joint Boycott Council of the American Jewish Congress and the Jewish Labor Committee yesterday asked the Brooklyn and Queens Transit Corporation to stop purchasing German steel for use on its surface car. system. The request was made in a letter to William S. Menden, president of the B. M. T. and its operating subsidiaries.

THE Summer exercise season is throwing a sunny spotlight on many new sports, but, thanks to new bridle paths and unchanged depression rates on riding horses, horseback riding promises to hold its own as an old favorite recreation.

Thomas F. Hanley, receiver of the Washington National Bank of New York, announced yesterday that a final interest dividend of 10.305 per cent would be paid immediately to all depositors and other creditors. This will bring to 110.305 per cent the total of payments to depositors and creditors on their claims since the bank went into receivership on June 10, 1932.

The Graf Zeppelin has made her last flight. After eight years of continuous service she flew to the hangar at Frankfort-on-the-Main last night to be deflated. She is not suited for helium, the gas which the government plans to use in dirigibles in the future.

Mauri Rose of Columbus, Ohio, won the feature fifty-mile automobile race at the Langhorne mile dirt track today, nosing out Billy Winn of Detroit before a crowd of 30,000. Rose's time was 33 minutes 6.42 seconds, setting a new record for the track.

House-trailer builders of the United States will produce a minimum of 112,500 factory-built trailers this year, according to their estimates as assembled in the House Trailer Redbook, published yesterday by the Carrier Press of Chicago.

Mr. and Mrs. Otto F. Sieder of this place gave a luncheon today at their home at which they announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marion Sieder, to Nils Oscar Ohlson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Oscar J. Ohlson of East Orange.

Mrs. W. Minor Osborn of West Orange, N. J., commander of the Girl Scout Hendrik Hudson Region, including New York and New Jersey, announced yesterday that the first of the Girl Scout Mariner cruises will leave Gloucester, Mass., on July 3. The mariners will sail

The International Labor Conference adopted today amendments raising from fourteen to fifteen the minimum age required by its conventions in industrial and non-industrial undertakings. With all four United States

City girls who have no flower garden at the back door to supply corsages for Summer dates will find a pretty good substitute in a florist shop that makes corsages of common varieties or Summer flowers. Thus a girl can wear, on

SUIYUAN, Inner Mongolia.Genghis Khan, the Mongolian warrior whose fearless, hardriding legions terrorized Europe seven centuries ago, was paid a new and unique tribute at a Chino-Mongolian mass meeting here. A Mongolian speaker credited Genghis Khan with popularizing the necktie among Occidental peoples.

Flying a new, secret Army Air orps pursuit plane, Lieutenant E. ??recht of the Base Force, Selfridge field , Mount Clemons, Mich., ended here at 12:10 o'clock this afternoon, having made the 520 ??iles in two hours. This was an average speed of 260 miles an hour
One angle of the new traffic code of New York City will be put to a test tomorrow in the Mott Street Court, although the test case may not become apparent. This factor

Mrs. Helen Comstock Van Gaasbeek, active in club and church work for the last fifty years, died yesterday at her home here at the age of 83. She was the widow of Amos C. Van Gaasbeek, an Oriental rug importer.

Miss Leona Virginia Pierce, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lewis 0. Pierce of Upper Montclair, was married this afternoon to Dr. Ralph Howard Edson of New York and Washington, son of Dr. and Mrs. Howard A. Edson of Washington. The ceremony, which took
More than 1,000 tenants bought farms from the Federal Land Banks during February, March and April, W. I. Myers, governor of the Farm Credit Administration, announced today. A survey made by the FCA

Miss Carol Ann Morehouse, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Brown Morehouse of this place and a descendant of Elder William Brewster, was married here tonight to William French Jones, son of Mrs. Frederick Henry Jones, also of Darien, and the late Mr. Jones.
The trans-polar flight of three Soviet airmen is "one of the most hazardous flights in the world," Jimmie Matter, who once tried to fly around the earth, said here today.

Nebraska's thirty-year record for being "in the black" was marred today by a $921 debt. The deficit was reported by the State Treasurer's office, custodian of funds totaling more than $21,000,000, but W. H. Smith, State Tax Commissioner, explained:

The New York A. C. lost to the Penn A. C. in a sensational eleven-inning game at the Phillies' ball park today, 10-9. After the New Yorkers made four runs in the eleventh, aided by O'Connell's two-bagger with the bases full and Terry's single, Penn A. C. won in its half.

VERA BRITTAIN deserves the gratitude of her colleagues in the writing profession for an article in a widely circulated evening paper in which she dispels some popular illusions about authors. It is commonly believed, she says, that a single book, by some inexplicable stroke of luck, can carry a hitherto unpracticed writer with one leap to fame.

The British Navy retired Bobbie today with the full ceremonial honors usually reserved for an admiral disembarking from his flagship. Bobbie, a horse, was permitted to resign after twenty years' service in the naval forces.

Debits to individual accounts as reported by banks in leading cities for the week ended June 16 aggregated $9,636,000,000, or 17 per cent above the total reported for the preceding week and 3 per cent below the total for the corresponding week of last year.

EVERY year more Americans are using the inexpensive third-class accommodations on Atlantic and other ships. The odium of the classification may still irk, because unlike most other peoples Americans refuse to be stratified, but most of the inconveniences and all of the hardships have been removed.

Fred Schluter, president of the Thermoid Company, has written to stockholders to say that, to correct any misunderstanding which might have arisen in connection with its recent application to the Securities and Exchange Commission for registration of its securities, the company is not distributing securities and does not intend to issue any securities at present.

SCATTERED through New England and bearing records of the country's history, close to 200 old houses are open to the public--and well worth seeing and knowing about. Whether or not one can visit them, one may greatly enjoy this book. Mr. Chamberlain's

Joseph A. Moore, former president of The New York American and former owner of The Morning Telegraph, died suddenly last night while ascending the stairs to the Mascotte Restaurant, 19 East Sixtieth Street.

Increasing demand for reclaimed rubber, owing to high prices of new rubber, has resulted in the boosting of capacity of the United States rubber reclaiming industry from 209,800 long tons on Oct. 1, 1936, to 227,300 long tons on June 1, an increase of 8.4 per cent, the Department of Commerce announced today.

The Summer branch shop of the New York Exchange for Woman's Work will open for its third season on June 28. The shop is situated in the Clifford Block, Lenox, Mass. Mrs. Henry Hollister Pease, a vice president of the exchange and long a Summer resident of the Berkshires, will supervise the shop and will be assisted by Mrs. George K. Livermore, Mrs. Carl de Gersdorff and Mrs. Newbold Morris.

SIX and a half hours after leaving a desk in Times Square a New Yorker can be swim ming in Bermuda's blue waters, or one of those fortunate persons who reside on the midocean islands lying more than 550 miles from the nearest mainland can leave Hamilton after a leisurely breakfast,

Sir James M. Barrie lived in an eyrie above the scurrying life of London's Strand. Daniel Frohman, older almost by a decade than Sir James, who was his friend when both were younger, lives in an eyrie above the make-believe life of whatever play may be current on the stage of Forty-fifth Street's Lyceum Theatre. Yesterday

EIGHT round-trip demonstration flights over the North Atlantic from Germany will be made by Deutsche Lufthansa beginning early next month, it was revealed here last week. Two new Blohm and Voss monoplanes will be used for the flights. The course will be via the

Miss Dorothy Irene Peterson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank H. Peterson of this place, was married tonight to Jean Paul Deusinger, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry G. Deusinger, also of Nutley. The ceremony was performed at the Emanuel Baptist Church, Newark, by a former pastor of the church, the Rev. Donald

Miss Loreta Darling Barto, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. William Torrence Barto of West Hartford, was married to George Laurence Blauvelt, son of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin L. Blauvelt of White Plains, N. Y., this evening in the West Hartford Congregational Church, by the pastor, the Rev. Elden H. Mills.

Mr. and Mrs. Edward B. Colby of St. George, S. I., formerly of Montclair, N. J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Carolyn Colby, to John Mason, son of Mrs. William Mason of Strathaven, Scotland, and the late Dr. Mason.

Grouping their hits to the great est advantage, players from Brooklyn schools defeated representatives of Manhattan and the Bronx in the annual all-star college baseball game at Manhattan Beach yesterday.

Captain Francesco Tarabotto, commander of the Italian Line flagship Rex and the only master of an Italian vessel to take his ship across the Atlantic to win the modern commercial ship speed record, has retired from the sea, it was announced yesterday.

With the scheduled transfer here tomorrow of the Hudson and Manhattan tube-train terminal from Park Place to the Pennsylvania Railroad station, bus and street car transportation companies today were making last-minute changes in schedules. Coincident with

Trotting the mile in 2:07, Mr. Watt, owned and driven by Stacy Smith of Short Hills, set a new track record for 3-year-olds in the matinee sponsored by the Road Horse Association of New Jersey at Weequahic Park today.
The New York Society Library, the oldest free public library in this city, which has been located at 109 University Place since 1856, has moved into a new home at 53 East Seventy-ninth Street.

Wreckage found on the beach at Saida after residents told of an apparent burst of gunfire at sea baffled maritime officials today. Inhabitants along the coast reported hearing firing off shore and of seeing flashes of fire like that of a ship's gun Wednesday night.

Octavia, bay mare owned by Captain James M. Callicutt, scored a splendid triumph today in the second session of the Cedar Valley Horse Show. This mare, one of the most consistent performers in the show ring last year captured the blue in the lightweight hunter class.

Mrs. Frothingham Manning of New Canaan, Conn., was married here this afternoon to Warren Shepard Matthews, New York architect, at the home of the bride's brother and sister-in-law, Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Frothingham.

The marriage of Miss Alferia Hall, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Bourke Hall of this city, to Charles Everett Garrett. son of Mrs. Elizabeth Garrett of Orange and the late Mr. Garrett, took place here this morning in the Church of the Holy Name. The Rev. Edward J. Stanley

So far as market supply is concerned, "a chicken in every pot" might well be a consumer expectation this Summer. Cold storage poultry holdings total 40,000,000 pounds, about 50 per cent more than they amounted to last year at this time. Besides, the price of chicken in season is about 25 per cent less than then, whereas meat, a direct competitor of poultry, is priced high.

The sale of sixteen houses in the Manor Homes community at 166th Street and Twenty-fifth Drive, Flushing, is reported by John E. McHugh Jr., sales manager. The buyers were Timothy J. Sullivan, John P. Gerrity, John Francis McLernon, Roy L. McCannaughy, Willard F. Read, Frank Neft,

The Treasury plans no change in its present gold-sterilization program, a high Treasury official declared today. Commenting on a published report that the Treasury was giving serious consideration to modifying its present procedure of sterilizing gold purchases, officials said that the Treasury was carefully

The marriage of Miss Grace Marie Ayers, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Valleau Gordon Ayers of this place, to James Matthew Connolly, son of Mr. and Mrs. James Connolly of Brooklyn, took place this morning in St. Augustine's Church here. The Rev. Dr. Thomas J. Deegan, the rector, performed the ceremony.

Mayor La Guardia was threatened with a suit for $250,000 yesterday by Joseph Goldsmith, president of the Taxpayers Union, for denouncing a group of tenement owners as "filthy" and exploiters of the poor at a hearing before the Board of Estimate on Friday at which a $500,000 slum-repair fund was authorized.

The siege of Bilbao has been another bloody epic of the Spanish civil war. Bitterly assaulted and as bitterly defended, attacked from sea, land and air, the capital of the Basques held out for more than nine months against the enveloping movement of the Insurgent forces.

A hard wind that brought cool weather but unwelcome rough water kept nearly all the crews in training here off the river this morning. California had a short paddle and Columbia was out for a brief stretch but the others stayed in their boathouses. A shift in tide, however, brought a burst of last-minute time trials and activity in the evening.

Austria led Ely Culbertson's New York team by 1,720 points early today after sixty hands in their match in the finals of the world contract bridge championship for open teams of four. Play of the remaining thirtysix hands will begin this afternoon.

James E. Musgrove, a young steel-mill worker, of Warren, Ohio, told the Senate Postoffice Committee today that he was stripped of his clothing, covered with grease and paraded before C. I. O. pickets near the Republic Steel Company plant because he was trying to get into the plant and go to work "to protect my home."

The committee report recomending the acceptance of a United States-Costa Rica trade treaty was approved in Congress today by a vote of thirty to ten, paving the way for ratification in the final debates next week.

Between 2,000 and 2,500 department, dry goods and specialty store executives from all sections of the country are expected to attend the midyear convention of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, which begins tomorrow in the Palmer House, Chicago, and continues through Thursday.

Peddie closed its baseball season today by dropping a hard-fought game to the New York Stock Exchange nine, 3 to 1. Jack Cronin, youthful Peddie right-hander, went the route for the losers. Hough starred on the mound for the victors.

The marriage of Miss Rachel Marjorie Hixson, only daughter of Dr. Arthur Warren Hixson, Professor of Chemical Engineering at Columbia University, and Mrs. Hixson, to Dr. Richard Herman Wilhelm, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Richard Wilhelm of Richmond Hill, L. I., took place this afternoon in the Presbyterian Church of Leonia. The Rev. John W. Voorhis, the pastor, performed the ceremony.

Employes of the Diamond T. Motor Car Company of Chicago, which claims sixth place among truck manufacturers of the country, have voluntarily and independently organized the Automotive Workers Industrial Union, representing 99 per cent of their number, and signed with the company an agreement covering wages, hours and working conditions, it was announced here yesterday by C. A. Tilt, president of the company.
Captain Shanty Fuchs led Williams to a 5 to 1 upset victory over Boston College to close the baseball season before an alumni crowd of 1,500 on Weston Field today.

From a study of the sanguinary battles in Spain and the guerrilla warfare in Ethiopia, and through frequent manoeuvres and experimentation, the general staffs of the world are trying to solve the equation of tomorrow's conflict.

The demand of the government of Premier Leon Blum and Finance Minister Vincent Auriol for full power "to assure the restoration of the public finance of France and to protect the franc, the savings of the people and public credit against speculative attack," has brought an amazing week of argument and intrigue.

POETS who turn to the novel face a problem that rarely troubles other members of the guild. There is such a thing as poetic insight. Most of us hover around it like sleepwalkers, respond to it with some common appreciation of its suggestiveness.

Miss Pam Barton, holder of both the 1936 United States and British women's golf championships, was threatened with the loss of her amateur standing today if she receives remuneration from the sale of a book to be published next week.

Bilbao's fall closes one chapter in the Spanish Civil War but opens a new and probably even more dramatic and important chapter in what every one realizes now is a long, long story.

Dr. Andor B. Paul, noted allergist and internist, of Budapest, Hungary, arrived Friday on the Cunard White Star liner Berengaria to spend six months doing research work and to lecture at Columbia University.

The tournament polo season got under way at the Meadow Brook Club today, with the Gulf Stream quartet running up an astounding 14-to-5 victory over Santa Barbara on the historic turf of International Field.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Candace Carstens, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Christian Carl Carstens of Forest Hills, Queens, to Dane Farnsworth Smith of Albuquerque, N. M., and Mount Pleasant, Tenn.

Drastic reorganization of operations in the low-end "hand-made" industry is anticipated if the recently re-invoked Puerto Rican $1a-day Minimum Wage Law is upheld, but manufacturers in the various fields employing Puerto Rican labor stated yesterday that they foresee some compromise, particularly as concerns home-work.

The American banking structure is in a "healthy condition," J. F. T. O'Connor, controller of the currency, said here today in an address prepared for delivery at the convention of the Colorado Bankers Association.
