Mrs. Ralph Kearney, a 14-year-old pupil of the sixth grade in Groveton school, is mother of a six-pound girl born yesterday. Mrs. Kearney is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Cox of Groveton, and Mrs. Cox, who is 33 years old, is acclaimed as New Hampshire's youngest grandmother.

The marriage of Miss Virginia Chapin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gerard Chapin of Lyman, S. C., formerly of this place, to Arnold Mills Combrinck-Graham Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Arnold Mills Combrinck-Graham of Brooklyn, took place here this morning in Christ Episcopal Church. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Arthur Taft.

Japan produced 239 babies an hour in 1936, the government disclosed today. Taking the death rate into consideration, that meant an enlargement of the empire's population at the rate of ninety-nine persons an hour. Even so, the birth rate was the lowest in twenty years29.92 per thousand.

Miss Ruth Gwendolyn Moore, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Merritt Moore of Sidney, N. Y., was married here this afternoon to John Hall Blackburn of this city, son of Mrs. John T. D. Blackburn and the late Mr. Blackburn, in the Fellowship House of the First Presbyterian Church.

Miss Emelia Theresa Hageman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Adolph Augustus Hageman of this city and Babylon, L. I., was married to Frederic John Schroeder, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederic Charles Schroeder of Norwood, N. J., last night at the home of her parents in Babylon. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Charles Knapp.

THE modern automobile, marvelous in its ease of control, is not a complete mechanism in itself. - It is the driver who must control the car and always react in the time and space available. The brief interval between the happening of something in one's environs and the making of a certain response is called "reaction time"; for example, the time interval between the policeman's signal and the pressing of the brake pedal.

President Roosevelt has been advised by an unofficial but close counselor who, it is understood, made a survey of the situation on Capitol Hill at his request, to trim his legislative program to an absolute minimum and end the present session of Congress at the earliest possible date.

Miss Caroline Alden Sayles, daughter of Mrs. Frederic Clark Sayles and the late Mr. Sayles, was married here this afternoon at Aldwill, the home of her mother, to Ward Rathbun Clark, son of Mrs. S. Allen Clark of Oneida, N. Y., and the late Mr. Clark. The Rev. Dr. Daniel Russell performed the ceremony.

Committees were named last week by the National Sweepstakes Regatta Association for its important speedboat fixture on the North Shrewsbury River, Aug. 14-15. Assemblyman Joseph C. Irwin has been named president and chairman, and headquarters have been established in the Chamber of Commerce office, 60 Broad Street, Red Bank.

Gratification expressed last week at the public inspection of the new Harlem River Houses, 153d Street at Seventh Avenue, was somewhat tempered by realization that this low-rent housing project, costing $4,219,000, would serve more as a model than as an answer to the acute housing needs of the quartermillion Negroes who live in Harlem, the world's largest Negro community.

If there is one place where the system of minority protection under the supervision of the League of Nations should have worked out according to the ideals of its founders it is Upper Silesia, the tiny strip of territory that, partitioned by the Allies between Germany and Poland, gave Poland her richest province and the industrial basis for the new Polish State.

The marriage of Miss Mercedes Molyneux Cullinan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Cullinan of this place, to Robert Morton Adams, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. Adams of Saddle River, N. J., took place at noon today in Our Lady of Mount Carmel Church, Ridgewood, N. J.

Under overhanging skies, with an occasional shaft of sunlight lending even more color to the pageant of costumes, nearly 4,000 Princeton alumni, one of the largest number ever to return for a reunion week-end, marched, danced and sang through Princeton's ordinarily quiet streets this afternoon in the parade to the Yale baseball game.

Carlos Alberto Acevedo, vice president of the Bank of the Nation, was appointed Minister of Finance today to succeed Roberto ?? Ortiz, who is retiring on Monday to run for the presidency on the Government party's ticket.

STROUDSBURG, Pa. - The mountain laurel of the Poconos is now in full bloom and during the past week thousands have motored along the mountain highways and trails to see the sight. The blooms will continue for another week or ten days and it is expected that thousands more will see them.

An exchange of good-will greetings between President Roosevelt and Lord Tweedsmuir, Governor General of Canada, will be a feature of a Dominion Day program which is being arranged by the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation for July 1, seventieth anniversary of the confederation of Canada.

Congressman Arthur Bernardes, former President of Brazil, addressing Congress today, brought serious charges against the European-controlled Itadira Iron Company, which he said was seeking an iron-mine monopoly here. He stated the Itabira interest sought a concession by any device, aiming to dispossess Brazil of her iron mines.

Announcement has been made by Fisher Ames Buell of 485 Park Avenue of the engagement of his daughter, Miss Nancy Dickinson Buell, to James H. Brewster 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. James H. Brewster Jr. of Hartford, Conn.

Republicans of Philadelphia, who have just reorganized their party here with a new chairman, sought an alliance with leaders of the party in Allegheny County today in an effort to control the selection of a new Republican State Chairman to succeed M. Harvey Taylor, who resigned yesterday.

Miss Ethel Baker Drumm, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Milton Drumm of this place, was married in the Mercersburg Academy Chapel this afternoon to Albert William Butterfield, son of Albert C. Butterfield of Pana, Ill.

Alberta is to do away with its redcoated counties. In the very province wherein they first won enduring fame as incorruptible guardians of law and order in a wide and wicked land, they are to be replaced by an ordinary everyday blue-coated unmounted provincial police force.

Style has invaded the field of camp clothing and has transformed the olive drab contingent of young Summer campers into a picturesquely costumed tribe. The girl who goes to camp takes with her plenty of neatly fitting shorts, a few polo shirts and anklets.

The German Government tonight ordered a sweeping redistribution of agricultural lands by pooling large numbers of small farms into collective enterprises. A twenty-page decree, effective next Jan. 1, provides that each participant shall hold rights corresponding to the amount of land contributed.

Led by the heavy-hitting Joe Medwick, who drove in five runs, the Cardinals snatched a 7-to-5 victory from the Bees today with a dramatic ninthinning finish. Medwick was the hero of the rally. After two were out in the ninth, Jimmy Brown and Don Padgett singled. The Cards' leftfielder then smashed a homer against the scoreboard in left field for three runs and the game.

Gobind Bihari Lal, Indian-born science editor of the New York American and co-winner with four other journalists of a 1937 Pulitzer prize, was guest of honor last night at a dinner given by the India Community of New York at the Town Hall Club, 123 West Fortythird Street. William Laurence and John J. O'Neill, who shared in the prize, were present.

Interesting competition was provided in the third day events at the eighteenth annual Troy Horse Show today. Entries from the Audrey's Choice Stable of Providence, R. I., placed first in the saddle, fine harness horse and five-gaited classes.

The engagement of Miss Mary Frances Hill, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas B. Hill of this city, to Dr. John William Smith, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Smith of Little Rock, Ark., has been announced by her parents.

Colonel A. S. Janeway, military commander of the strike area under the state of martial law proclaimed yesterday by Governor Earle, announced at 2 o'clock (Eastern daylight time) this morning that he had ordered State troopers to close all mills of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation here with a blockade through which neither workers, food nor other supplies would be allowed to pass.

A state funeral will be held at Nimes Tuesday for Gaston Doumergue, 73-year-old former President and Premier of France, who died Friday. Originally authorities planned to hold the ceremonies at Aiguesvives, his birthplace, but a government architect decided the streets were too narrow for the cortege.

Lawrence, also of New York, and the late Mr. Lawrence, yesterday afternoon in St. Agnes Chapel of Trinity Parish on West Ninety-second Street. The Rev. Dr. William W. Bellinger performed the ceremony.

Dividend payments by the Canadian mining industry may reach $100,000,000 in 1937, setting a new high record, according to a survey made this week. So far this year Canadian mines have paid $48,215,804. In any event, it is expected that the declarations will exceed $90,000,000.

The Federal Trade Commission today announced scheduling of six hearings at New York City during the coming week. All will be held at 45 Broadway and are timed to start at 9 A. M.
Ian B. MacCallum, New Jersey State amateur golf champion, again failed in his club's championship today
Representative Vinson, Democrat of Kentucky, said today that the incorporators of more than 100 foreign companies might be subpoenaed to testify in the Congressional tax-dodging inquiry.

At the opening of the last session of Parliament before the general election, which is expected to take place in October, the government submitted a report by G. H. Ince, chief insurance officer of the British Ministry of Labor, embodying a scheme of unemployment insurance.

Collections in the men's clothing industry, which had been causing serious concern since the start of April, have definitely turned upward, with the total in the first two weeks of June equal to the entire payments for May, credit executives reported here yesterday. Even in those sections affected by strikes, stores have shown a definite improvement in payments, it was said.

The Rev. Wilhelm Caroli, the priest in charge of the Catholic parish in Rhein-Goenheim, near Ludwigshafen, was sentenced here today to eight months' imprisonment for not flying a Swastika flag on his church on National Socialist holidays.
Rumors regarding the disposition of the late King George V's valuable stamp collection have been set at rest, King George VI will keep the collection and add to it.

Every employer covered by the Social Security Act will have to make certain by June 30 that his employes have social security account numbers, Mrs. Anna M. Rosenberg, regional director of the Social Security Board, warned yesterday. A record of these numbers is required in connection with the first periodic report on wages paid by employers to their workers between Jan. 1 and June 30.

The twenty-five-story Hotel McAlpin, at Broadway and Thirtyfourth Street, is undergoing extensive renovations. To date more than seven floors, with the bar and cafe, have been redecorated and refurnished. New lighting fixtures, wallpaper, furniture, hardware and draperies have been installed by Myers, Minott Co., Inc., and W. J. Sloane.

BristolMyers Company, Rockefeller Center, New York, has stipulated with the Federal Trade Commission to stop representing that its product, Vitalis, retards falling hair, unless limited to excessive falling hair, that combined with massage treatment it brings new life and looks to the hair, and that it contains oils that the hair requires for health, the commission announced today.

STATING at the outset that his book is "a biographical criticism rather than a critical biography," Claude Lee Finney at once places his study of the evolution of the poetry of John Keats in its proper relation to the many other important surveys of the poet. The Derby Gas and Electric Corporation, a holding company registered with the SEC, filed today an amendment to its plan of reorganization under which the Utilities Power and Light Corporation, also a registered holding company, of which the first registrant is a subsidiary, will increase its contribution to the equity behind the preferred stock of the Derby Corporation.

The Foreign Office was informed by the Egyptian Minister in Rome today that the Abuna Cyril, Coptic Bishop of Ethiopia, is being held a virtual prisoner in Venice because of differences with Premier Benito Mussolini.

The Czechoslovak Press Bureau has issued a flat denial of the report that Bruno Weigel, a German, had been tortured by the Prague police. The German Official News Bureau, after publishing this statement, expresses skepticism of the denial.

In the three weeks since Netherlanders clearly showed at a general election their loyalty to democratic institutions and demonstrated confidence in Premier Hendryk Colijn's government by crushing extremist movements, party leaders, by their narrow particularism, have been bringing the unity expressed at the polls into derision.

Mrs. Sophia Rittenhouse Shelley of 15 West Fifty-fifth Street, a member of the National Society of Colonial Dames and the Daughters of the American Revolution, died yesterday in Roosevelt Hospital.

After an afternoon of almost continuous telephone communications, the Federal Steel Mediation Board arranged to begin its attempt to conciliate the steel strike, involving nearly 100,000 employes in seven States, by conferring with spokesmen for both sides on Monday.

Miss Louise Barnes, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Roderic Barbour Barnes, was married to Jess Angell Hall, son of Mrs. Louise Twitchell Hall of this town, at the Congregational Church on the Green this afternoon. The Rev. Tertius Van Dyke of the Gunnery School and the pastor, the Rev. Wilbur Deming, performed the ceremony.

A cleaning woman who thought it looked "sissified" to have a doll's house around a man's college sent a beautiful model of a stage setting for "Twelfth Night" to Schenectady's incinerator and thereby almost wrecked the play schedule of the Mohawk Drama Festival, which opens a six-week season on July 6.

With the capture of Bilbao, a new phase in the Spanish civil war is about to begin. Everybody on the government side hoped it would begin before this, and everybody was trying to relieve the pressure on Bilbao. But the task proved too formidable.

Men in bearskin busbies and with gleaming sabers, men in scarlet jackets with gilt facings, men in the Summer khaki of the army and the blue of the navy marched across the green parade ground of Governors Island yesterday as the army celebrated the 300th anniversary of the purchase of the island from the Indians.

A real estate sale requiring fifteen months to close and in which $400 was the gross amount involved from which the broker obtained a commission of $30 and $30 was paid for clearing up the title is called by Henry E. Reed, a broker of Portland, Oregon, "his most unusual sale."

So much of Paragraph 12, Special Orders 138, dated June 15, 1937, as relates to 1st Lt. Harry A. Martin, Engr-Res., is revoked. 1st Lt. Joseph A. Kwint, Med-Res., 18 Willow Ave., North Plainfield, N. J., unassigned, is ordered to active duty for six months, effective July 1 at Headquarters Pocatello District, CCC, Pocatello, Idaho, for assignment. and duty in connection with CCC activities.

The German building industry, while brisk, appears to be suffering from the use of materials "depreciated in quality," according to a report to the Department of Commerce. This is attributed to the demand for raw products for Germany's armament program.

Miss Elizabeth Burt Brewer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Josiah Brewer of this place, was married to Gerard Henry Dericks, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerard C. Dericks of Tuckahoe, this morning in St. John's Episcopal Church here. The Rev. Francis J. H. Coffin performed the ceremony, which was followed by a small reception at the Brewer home.

THE conspicuous, and essential, quality of this book is its matter-of-factness, its lack of emotion. And that, when you come to think of it, is an unusual characteristic in a book on India. Most people who write of experience and observation and meditation in India are not dispassionate.

Governor Hoffman is expected to be the principal speaker on Thursday, July 1, at cornerstone execises for the permanent Ediso?? Tower, which is being constructed here on the site where the inventor developed the first incandescent lamp.
Senator Wheeler, Democrat, of Montana, said today that President Roosevelt's Court Bill should be withdrawn because to press it would only be for the purpose of reprisal.

VACATIONING motorists must pay the tax collector 10 cents an hour on the gasoline they use, according to the American Petroleum Industries Committee. If you travel 100 miles a day for twelve days, the tax collector will get $4.32.

Britain is having her troubles with tax-dodgers, even as the United States. Sir John Simon, the new Chancellor of the Exchequer, recently told the House of Commons that the revenue authorities were "in the position of gamekeepers having to tax poachers."

RETAIL trade activity improved through the country last week but not by impressive margins. The average gain seemed to run over the May rate, with the increases again marked in the South, Southwest and parts of the Middle West.

The marriage of Miss Candace Lamberton Loud, daughter of Mrs. Herbert Richardson Loud of this city and Bangor, Me., and the late Mr. Loud, to Charles Haven Sawyer, son of Mrs. Charles J. Sawyer of Bangor and the late Mr. Sawyer, took place here yesterday at noon in the chapel of the Riverside Church. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Eugene C. Carder.

Miss Ida Baldwin Lynch, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Moore Lynch of Garden City, L. I., and New York, was married here this afternoon in Trinity Episcopal Church to Robert Norman Murdoch, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Robert Murdoch of Manchester, N. H. The Rev. Leicester F. Kent performed the ceremony.

Meadow Brook championship polo matches, which started this afternoon on International Field at the Meadowbrook Club, drew a large contingent of polo enthusiasts.

There is no reason for concern in the present period of business and financial recession, Edward B. Smith Co., investment bankers, say, in an analysis of current conditions. Fundamentals of cheap money, abundant credit, rising national income and unsatisfied consumer needs should reassert themselves in due course, as the recovery cycle still has a considerable distance to run. they add.

Dr. Edward S. Godfrey Jr., Commissioner of the New York State Health Department, has agreed to permit shipments of New Jersey fresh milk into New York to econtinue after July 1 under existing permits so that recent New York legislation will not work a hardship on shippers of milk from this State, William B. Duryee, Secretary of Agriculture in New Jersey, has announced.

Business and financial institutions in the United States continued last year to lose stockholders at a rate about the same as in 1935, according to a survey of 180 companies compiled by Frazier Jelke Co.

Recognizing the motion picture as an important art form and as a growing social force, Columbia University announced yesterday the establishment of a new academic division, to be known as Film Study, which will begin in the Fall a twenty-week course in motion picture appreciation.

Home building continues to show substantial progress in practically all of the metropolitan suburban centers of New Jersey, and brokers in many of the choice residential areas report that the demand for new homes is virtually keeping pace with the supply.

Andrew, chief statistician of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, declared tonight.

Isaac Katz of 325 West 112th Street, a lawyer associated with the firm of Bernstein, Geist Netter, died yesterday in Beth Israel Hospital of meningitis after ten days' illness, at the age of 24. An exceptional scholar, he graduated from City College at the age of 17, later receiving his LL. B. from the Columbia Law School.

Judge Charles Klein of Orphans Court awarded today the $4,218,000 estate of J. Dundas Lippincott to his grandniece, Mrs. James Herbert Boone of New York City. The league leading Newark Bears and Rochester Red Wings divided a double-header today. Rochester won the first game. 5-4, by scoring two runs in the ninth, and Newark walked away with the nightcap, 11-2.

Well-informed political circles here understand that both Czechoslovakia and Rumania are pleased with the binding assurances of loyalty to the Little Entente that Premier Milan Stoyadinovitch made in behalf of Yugoslavia at yesterday's conference.

THREE "firsts" are scheduled this season for Chile: the first occasion on which a LatinAmerican country will play host to American crack skiers, the first international Winter sport event to be played south of the Equator and, inaugurated there, the first PanAmerican downhill skiing championships.

The labor situation now facing the country has developed a feeling of uncertainty not unlike that which faced the banks early in 1933, Henry H. Heimann, executive manager of the National Association of Credit Men, declared in a business review released yesterday to 3,000 delegates to the forty-second annual convention of the association, which opens in Chicago tomorrow.

Six new houses in the Wyngate development at Great Neck, L. I., have been sold, according to Patrick J. Callen, president of Callen Brothers, owners and developers. Four new houses in the section will be opened today, and also a new street which will be known as Wyngate Place.

Washington. LIKE Janus, the Republican party today sits, two-faced, looking forward and backward. Having ridden high and ridden low through more than fourscore years of American history, it is now confronted with the necessity for a momentous decision, and already the forces of change and chance may have rendered that decision and rendered it irrevocably.

Military funeral services were held here today for Major Gen. Adelbert Cronkhite, commanding officer of the Eightieth Division during the World War. He died Tuesday in St. Petersburg, Fla., at the age of 76.

Miss Gretchen Weiland, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Adelbert Weiland of this place, was married in the Church of the Ascension here this afternoon to Abbott Quincy Hastings, son of the Rev. and Mrs. A. Abbott Hastings of Troy, N. Y. The bridegroom's father, rector of St. Paul's Church, Troy, performed the ceremony.

Blake of Portland, Me. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Joseph A. Vance of Detroit.

DRAWING rapidly to a close is the day of the gas stations that offered free bunks to truck drivers between New York and points South. For the Interstate Commerce Commission has placed restrictions upon the "gypsy" truckers who were their chief customers.

The marriage of Miss Gladys Alexia Hoage, daughter of Mrs. Benjamin Joseph Hoage of this city, to John Patrick Brady, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward F. Brady of East Orange, took place this morning in Our Lady of Good Counsel Church here.

Opening the first Commencement Week of Harvard's fourth century, President James B. Conant will give the baccalaureate sermon tomorrow afternoon before nearly 800 seniors of Harvard College and their families and friends gathered in the Memorial Church, Harvard Yard, at 4 o'clock.

Miss Anne Delano Piersol, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. George Morris Piersol of Oak Ridge Farm, Huntingdon Valley, was married this afternoon to Edward A. Collins Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward A. Collins of this city.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I believe that the anxiety of Prime Minister Lyons of Australia, and that of many other people, about peace in the Pacific will be allayed if President Roosevelt takes action now to enter into negotiations with other powers interested in the Western Pacific in order to conclude a treaty neutralizing the Republic of the Philippines when established.

Members of the North Shore colonies of Oyster Bay, the Brookvilles, Westbury, Glen Cove and Roslyn were on hand early today, the second day of the benefit Cedar Valley Horse Show on the estate of Townsend Bailey, to see the large classes of jumpers ridden by society owners.

The engagement of Miss Jean Wells, daughter of Mrs. Ernest Alden Wells of Ithaca, formerly of Hartford, Conn., and the late Dr. Wells, to Joseph Bentley Hollinshead, son of Augustus Livingston Hollinshead of West Englewood, N. J., has been announced by her mother.

Exports of automotive parts from the United States in April were valued at $31,892,296, compared with $29,942,375 in the preceding month and $23,947,444 in April, 1936.

Miss Sara Blair Huntington, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert W. Huntington, was married this afternoon to Martin H. Johnson, son of Dr. and Mrs. E. B. Johnson of Lakeville, by the Rev. Raymond Cunningham, rector of Trinity Church, who was assisted by the Right Rev. Chauncey B. Brewster, retired Protestant Bishop of Connecticut.

Mrs. Kenneth Moller of Milton has announced the engagement of her step-daughter, Miss Nancy Moller, to David Howland of New York. Miss Moller is the daughter of the late Kenneth Moller and Mrs. Elizabeth Sweetser Moller.

A total of 382 children were being cared for at the Children's Village, Dobbs Ferry, N. Y., on Dec. 31, 1936, and an additional 310 children were being supervised, according to the eighty-fifth annual report of the institution, made public yesterday. Of those living at the institution, 347 were boys and thirty-five were girls.

BOGNER - THIERFIELD--Mr. and Mrs. David Thierfield of 320 Riverside Drive announce the engagement of their daughter, Roslyn, to Mr. Carl Bogner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Isidore Bogner of Monticello, N. Y.

The government won today the right to retain for the purpose of evidence in the Binghamton O'Connell kidnapping trial some of the articles seized from two of the eight defendants when they were arrested.

THE picnic season is here and the outdoor cook has greased the frying pan and taken the portable charcoal grate and broiler out of the attic. Smoke is curling from the backyard fireplace, and the demand for cooking places in State parks and reservations is often greater than the supply.

Joe Burk, former University of Pennsylvania sweep oarsman, won the Schuylkill Navy senior single sculls championship in the eighty-fourth annual regatta today. Representing the College Boat Club, the Beverly, N. J., sculler finished a length and a half ahead of C. S. Wurts Bissell of University Barge in 7 minutes 29 seconds over the mile and a quarter course.

Mayor La Guardia and Health Commissioner Rice will be among the speakers tomorrow at exercises dedicating the East Harlem Health and Teaching Center at 158-164 East 115th Street. The ceremonies will open the city's ten-year district health center development program, which provides for the establishment of thirty health centers.
MOTOR tourists journeying through central and south western New Mexico and southern Arizona from now on will find a new historical interest in that rugged and romantic region.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In a letter printed in THE NEW YORK TIMES of May 9, George 0. May commented critically on the recommendations for the taxation of capital gains in the report of the Twentieth Century Fund's Special Committee on Taxation.

Reports on a national survey of unemployed older women will be made at the eighteenth annual convention of Quota Club International, opening on Thursday at the Hotel Traymore, Atlantic City, with more than 400 business women attending from the United States and Canada.

Mrs. Annie D. Wurster, widow of Frederick W. Wurster, last Mayor of the old city of Brooklyn, died on Friday at her home, 145 East Fiftyfourth Street, after a three weeks' illness. She was 75 years old.
THE pastime of pitching darts is coming back into prominence, and many new games have been conceived to give this old offshoot of archery more color and make it more fascinating than ever.

James Dorment and Robert L. Goetz, builders, who last week announced the purchase of 350 homesites for their Parklawn and Park Manor communities near the Marine Park, Brooklyn, are beginning construction on their fourth unit of new dwellings.

The wedding of Miss Margaret Winifred Compton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Compton of Hamden, to Clyde Overton Orr, son of Mrs. Earl J. Bailey of West Haven, took place in Dwight Memorial Chapel, Yale University, this afternoon.

Mr. and Mrs. Theodore A. Wick of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marion Wick, to Lieutenant Colin P. Kelly, U. S. A., son of Mr. and Mrs. Colin P. Kelly of Madison, Fla.

Joseph P. Kennedy, chairman of the Maritime Commission, today told leaders in the shipping industry that "much progress has been made in the negotiations between the commission and the steamship lines."

Resisting deportation upon his return to this country after fighting for Italy in Ethiopia, Augusto Silvestri, 34 years old, an Italian citizen, obtained a writ of habeas corpus yesterday from Federal Judge Vincent L. Leibell. He will have a hearing on Tuesday.

Thirty-five hundred students are expected at the Summer session of Hunter College, it was announced yesterday by Professor Broderick Cohen, director of the evening and extension division of the college. The Summer semester will begin on July 12 and end on Aug. 20.

Unable to rise to the occasion or the traditional alumni parade, Princeton University's baseball forces went down to a 13-4 defeat at the hands of a heavy-hitting Yale nine today on University Field, thereby giving the Blue a sweep of the annual Princeton series.

Robert J. Kleburg, Texas'rancher, sent his star filly, Dawn Play, out at Washington Park today to win the $25,000 added American derby. While 28,000 spectators cheered, the 3-year-old daughter of Clock Tower-Gun Play, a granddaughter of Man o' War, conquered the best 3-year-old colts in this section.

One strike, had Charley (Red) Ruffing been able to toss it, would have brought victory to the Yankees yesterday in their struggle with the White Sox at the Stadium. But the right arm of the burly hurler, which in the past has thrown thousands of strikes, failed to turn the trick and the world champions lost, 5-2.

Mrs. Samuel Emlen of Awbury, Germantown, has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Elizabeth Hartshorne Emlen, to Lewis Gordon Walker Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Lewis Gordon Walker of Richmond, Va.

After opening around the high figures of the week, prices on the Cotton Exchange eased yesterday under July liquidation and unsettling labor developments. Although Liverpool had improved sharply, selling pressure in the last hour here canceled the early improvement and left the list with losses of 8 to 12 points. July ended 6 to 7 points under October, showing a loss of 4 points from the previous Saturday, compared with a 2-point loss on October.
Brandishing sticks and hurling stones, 300 hysterical Basque refugee children at North Stoneham fled their camp last night when the news of the fall of Bilbao was broadcast from a mobile radio van.

Yarrow of Redding Ridge, Conn., and of Wilson Foss Jr. of New York and Concourse Farms, Centerville, Md. Miss Chandlee is the granddaughter of Mrs. William S. Blakeley of Chester, Pa.

Trading in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange was the slowest in almost seven years. The two-hour turnover of $3,008,300 compared with $3,759,500 on the previous Saturday and was the smallest since Aug. 2, 1930, a Saturday when sales amounted to only $2,954,000.

James Francis Fargo of 1,148 Fifth Avenue, financier and an originator of the modern express travelers check system, died on Friday in the Harkness Pavilion after a short illness. He was 80 years old.

The marriage of Miss Constance M. Elmendorf, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Reed D. Elmendorf of this place, to Robert Gwynne Bray, son of Mrs. Elizabeth K. Bray, also of Chatham, took place today in Chatham Methodist Church.

Miss Helen Hicks of Hewlett, L. I., won the eighth annual women's Western open golf championship today by defeating Miss Beatrice Barrett of Minneapolis, 6 and 5, in the thirtysix-hole final match at the Beverly Country Club.

Another important outdoor fixture that appeals widely to both exhibitors and spectators heads the list of dog shows for the week. This is the ninth annual Monmouth County event on the estate of Charles B. Harding at Rumson, N. J., Saturday.

Major Gen. and Mrs. John S. Thompson entertained officers of the 108th Infantry and their wives at his home here this afternoon, following the general's retirement after forty years of active service in the New York National Guard.

The International Longshoremen's Union tonight took steps which their spokesman declared were intended to "cripple completely" the Boston wool market, largest in the nation. Bales of wool are piled high on Boston docks.

Because of the limitations both in the number of faculty members and the size of the physical plant, a large number of persons who apply for admission to the next freshman class of the Pennsylvania State College will be disappointed, President Ralph D. Hetzel said today.
New York Athletic Club members led a group of metropolitan athletes to first place in nearly all events today on the program of the New Haven County Sheriffs Association second annual field day.

Before a large Commencement Day crowd the Amherst College baseball team defeated Wesleyan, 8-8, today to take the Little Three championship. Big Bill Mitchell, Amherst righthander, held the Cardinals to three runs and seven hits, while his mates concentrated nine of their twelve safeties in two big innings to tally eight times.
President Manuel L. Quezon of the Philippines and his party arrived in Havana this morning on the steamship Florida from Miami for a two-day visit as guests of the Cuban Government.

A. L. Ferguson's Shining Heels, black daughter of Flying HeelsGlimmer, added her name to the register of Clipsetta Stakes victors by accounting for its fifty-fifth renewal here today. The elite of Kentucky's 2-year-old filly division competed for the $2,500 added purse, with Shining Heels among the outsiders.
Miss Norma Taubele of New York will defend her New York State championship against Miss Eunice Dean of San Antonio this afternoon in the final round at the Jackson Heights Tennis Club.

The New Jersey State Cricket League championship fixture at Wattsessing Park today was taken by the Hudson County eleven of the Brooklyn C. C. The Newark C. C. was downed by a margin of 10 runs, with 5 wickets to spare. Newark batted first, scoring 108. The winners tallied 118.

Williams of New York and Saugatuck, Conn., took place here this afternoon in the Church of St. James the Less. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Alan R. Chalmers, the rector, assisted by the Rev. Harry Price.

Donner of Philadelphia and the late Mr. Donner, here this afternoon at Fernwood, the home of her parents. The Rev. William S. Murphy of Philadelphia performed the ceremony.

Freddie Haas of New Orleans won the Southern amateur golf championship for the second time today, defeating Charlie Yates of Atlanta, 1 up, in the thirty-six-hole final. The slender Haas, winner of the crown in 1934 and runner-up to Jack Munger of Dallas, Texas, in the tournament a year ago, caught up with Yates to win after being 1 down through eighteen holes.

IT was with melancholy musings on ingratitude and the low estate to which appreciation of poesy has slumped that this department learned of the characterization of the appended verses as "horrors of iambic pentameter" by certain callous and unobserving Warner publicists.

One hundred and thirty-five relatives of American men fighting on the Loyalist side in Spain in the Abraham Lincoln Battalion were entertained at luncheon yesterday by the Friends of the Abraham Lincoln Battalion in Rossoff's Restaurant, 147 West Forty-third Street.
Class Day exercises were held this morning at Wesleyan University, with Warren L. Klinger of Pottstown, Pa., president of the senior class, presiding. The history was read by Thomas R. Bodine of
With the completion of its current Business Census, the Bureau of the Census has closed its temporary branch in Philadelphia and is moving records to the Commerce Building here.
About 2,000 career women are expected to attend the week-long biennial convention of the National Federation of Business and Pro-fessional Women, opening July 19 in Atlantic City, N. J.

Dr. A. Burton Eckerdt, superintendent of the Territorial Hospital in Honolulu for sixteen years, and a former resident of Baltimore, died in Honolulu yesterday after a long illness, according to a cablegram received by relatives here.

The study of community planning in connection with large-scale programs for low-rental housing is engaging national attention. The opportunity for orderly and unified development of new districts within and surrounding the sites of these housing projects was emphasized by several speakers at the convention of the American Institute of Architects a few days ago in Boston.

Miss Frances and Kathryn McLaughlin, twin daughters of Mrs. Kathryn M. McLaughlin and the late Frank McLaughlin, formerly of Brooklyn, will be graduated Wednesday from Lyman Hall High School with unusual honors.

While the medalists, W. S. Barbour of Morris County and W. A Bartle Jr. of Deepdale, were making a quick bow from the first round of the Piping Rock invitation best-ball tournament today, the favorites, Jess Sweetser of Siwanoy and J. T. Trippe of the home club,
For the second time in his long career Americus Polli entered baseball's hall of fame today with a no-hit, no-run pitching performance.

Dr. Erastus G. Smith, former Mayor, banker and teacher at Beloit College, died today of a heart ailment at Holyoke, Mass., while attending his sixtieth anniversary reunion at Amherst College. His age was 82.

Miss Catherine Luella Owen, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Maynard Smith Owen of this city, was married yesterday to Stephen McNutt, son of Mr. and Mrs. William McNutt of Cincinnati, by the Rev. Arthur F. Mabon at the Carlyle. The bride, who was given in marriage by her father, was attended by Miss Elizabeth Adams of Washington. Carl Heyel was best man.

THE broadcasters, without any fear of conflict with the copy right owners, have turned to Shakespeare, and have invited noted actors to stalk upon the air this Summer to play the Bard's famous characters.

Few changes occurred in the standing of the leaders in the international chess masters' tournament as a result of play in the third round at the Kurhaus today. The two with clean scores-Samuel Reshevsky, the United States champion, and H. Berg of Latvia-both adjourned their games.

The marriage of Miss Helen M. Salerno, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Vitor Salerno of this city, to James J. Rose Jr., son of James J. Rose of Paterson and the late Mrs. Rose, took place this afternoon at the home of the bride's parents. The Rev. Remigio Borghesi, pastor of our Lady of Mt. Carmel Church here, performed the ceremony.

WASHINGTON. - In its drive against tax evaders the Treasury pays good money as rewards for information leading to recoveries of taxes which would otherwise be uncollected. Last year it paid nearly $44,000 in rewards. The largest amount paid in 1936-resulting in the recovery of $290,491--was $18,699. The smallest reward

ONE would be hard put to it to find a better contemporary novel than this for the girl in her middle teens. There is a depth and beauty in this book, coupled with an evocative, sense-stirring prose which places it easily among the few first-rate books in this category. Readers of that age are all

Making a brilliant recovery after losing the first two sets, Bobby Riggs of Los Angeles, the defending titleholder, reached the final of the national clay courts tennis championships today by defeating Art Hendrix of Lakeland, Fla., 6-8, 6-8, 6-1, 6-4, 6-4.
Mrs. Gordon Wright's highly regarded aged bay gelding Sonny carried off the jumper championship at the eighth annual one-day horse show staged by the Bronxville Riding Club on the club grounds today.
Figures given out today revealed that contracts had already been closed abroad for the export of 80,000 tons of Chilean sulphur, which is the most important deal for this product ever attempted here.

John M. Franklin, president of the United States Lines, announced yesterday that the line had signed a contract in Washington with the United States Maritime Commission replacing the old mail subsidy contract which has been abolished as a government policy.

Whatever may have been the evils of the wholesale liquidation of Russian Army and civilian leaders, and whatever may be the internal effects, the actions of the Soviet have had a beneficial effect on the general situation in Europe. For the time being, at least, while Russia settles her problems, she is being disregarded as a main factor in the interplay of statesmanship. The other great powers, ignoring her, are hastening to

Dr. Harry C. Storrs, superintendent of the Wassaic State School, has been appointed superintendent of Letchworth Village, where he was for eighteen years first assistant physician. He succeeds the late Dr. Charles S. Little.

While many owners of business structures still have a long way to go to achieve a profitable level of occupancy for their space, they find cause for optimism in the mid-year reports indicating a gradual but steady lowering of vacancies throughout the nation.

Tamiris, director and premiere danseuse of the Federal Theatre dance drama, "How Long, Brethren?" received the Dance Magazine's annual award of excellence in a formal presentation last night at the Nora Bayes Theatre, where the production is now running. Her direction of the group choreography in "How Long, Brethren?" was termed the "most brilliant for the year 1936-37."

SOME rivers are to be canoed for themselves, for exciting navigation and rapids and rocks; some for what is to be seen on their banks; a very few (Rhone and Danube are the outstanding examples) for both navigation and sightseeing.

One of the encouraging signs In the improvement of real estate at the present time is the steadily increasing volume of sales of small homes and other structures for modernization, points out Arthur J. Horton, vice-president of Bulkley Horton, Brooklyn and Queens brokers. This tendency, he holds,

MORE than routine interest attached to the Spring symphonic cycle that wound up the Scala season this year. The chief attraction was the first performance in Italy in an Italian version of Cesar Franck's "Beatitudes." It was also Milan's

With a substantial increase in registration for the four-week Summer intersession term which began last week, New York University is now preparing for a heavy advance in the regular Summer session, which will open on July 6, it was reported by enry G. Arnsdorff, registrar.

General Hugh S. Johnson and New York Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora will be among the speakers at a dinner to be given exhibitors and buyers by the management of the New York Furniture Exchange, Inc., at the Hotel Pennsylvania on Tuesday night.

The dwelling at 549 Mount Prospect Avenue, Newark, N. J., has been purchased by Leon L. Horstmann from the Howard Savings Institution and the house.. at 1,081 Nicholas Avenue, Union, was purchased by Frank Sedlock from the Branch Brook Building and Loan Association. Sargent Dumper, Inc.,

Not often in the long history of the United States Senate has a document been produced which possesses the clarity and the force of the report which was filed last week by a majority of the Judiciary Committee, recommending rejection of the President's plan to reorganize the Supreme Court.

Sir Hugh Gwynne Levick, a former partner in Lee Higginson Co. at Boston, died today. He was 67 years old. A native of England, he went to the United States in 1886 and worked for the Bank of Montreal. He joined the Lee Higginson firm in 1902 and was admitted to partnership in 1906.

Baroness Maude B. Von Leidersdorff of Harrison, N. Y., faces a six-month term in Westchester County jail at East View for contempt of court unless she promptly pays at least $900 on account of a $5,736.87 bill for gowns.

A Vienna court yesterday heard action by Archduke Leopold Hapsburg against his mother the Archduchess Blanca requesting that she be ordered to increase his $150 monthly allowance to $400 complaining that it was impossible for an Archduke to live on $150.
"Make merry while you may," Sir James Matthew Barrie once told the students of St. Andrews of Scotland. "Yet," he quickly added, "lightheartedness is not forever and a day. 'You seize the flower

ASHEVILLE, N. C.-Hiking club representatives of States from Maine to Georgia will gather at Gatlinburg, Tenn., in the Great Smoky Mountains National Park, on June 26, 27 and 28 for the biennial Appalachian Trail conference.

Price softening in some sections of the men's furnishings market last week brought an improved volume of business to manufacturers, and this influence, combined with favorable weather, which helped to clear retail stocks, resulted in larger sales at wholesale than had been seen for several weeks.

SEVERAL hundred Scouts from twenty-four foreign countries are planning to attend the National Jamboree of the Boy Scouts of America, which will be held from June 30 to July 9 at Washington, D. C. They will be guests of their
ASSEMBLED by the American Federation of Arts under the grant from the Rockefeller Foundation, the American Arts and Crafts Exhibition has been installed at the Paris Exposition.

An organized campaign is under way in Congress so to amend the Wagner act as to render it useless for collective bargaining, Abraham Isserman, counsel for the C. I. O. in North New Jersey., charged heretoday at the June conference of the League for Industrial Democracy.

Dr. Amos P. Hutchins, chairman of the board of visitors and governors, announced today the unanimous election of Stringfellow Barr, 40year old former University of Virginia History Professor, as president of St. John's College at Annapolis.
There is nothing to indicate at present that the Corn Belt farmer will be much concerned over the decision to postpone action on the Farm Parity Bill at the present session of Congress.

Another controversy raged today over the merits of the works of the New York-born sculptor, Jacob Epstein, following the announcement that six of his statues are to be removed from the front of Rhodesia House in the Strand.

More than 100,000 people along the Pacific seaboard earn their living from the salmon industry. These people are now bombarding Washington with protests against the alleged invasion of the North Pacific salmon banks by Japanese fishing boats.

Principals-James J. Braddock, North Bergen, N. J., champion, vs. Joe Louis, Detroit, challenger. Title at Stake-World heavyweight championship. Number of Rounds-Fifteen to a decision, with "no foul" rule in effect.
SEVEN score and ten years ago our forefathers, in convention assembled in Phila delphia, consummated the folk begun a decade earlier by the Continental Congress.

Dry goods wholesalers are prepared for an increase in total sales of Fall merchandise and are well covered on most lines, although their initial sales for Fall to date were described yesterday as "at best, moderate," or unsatisfactory.

The Garrison Inn, landmark on the Albany Post Road in Putnam County, N. Y., has been leased for a long term by Gustave von Lowenfeld, manager of the Hotel Concord in New York. The old inn dates back to about 1820, but additions have been made to the older portion and the building now has facilities for about 100 guests.
CLEVELAND, Ohio. Adam is at last going to wear the trousers-or at least the overallsin that modern substitute for Eden, the home garden. That, at any
At a meeting of stockholders of the Kimberly-Clark Corporation today, ratification was voted of the recent action of the directors in authorizing a $20,000,000 bond issue.

Mild sentences were passed today by a Vienna court on thirty-one leaders of the illegal Lower Austrian Nazis who had organized for civil war. Supreme Leader Baumgartner was sentenced to seven months in prison. The others got terms of two to five months.

Large European investment trusts and other professional investors abroad continue to favor investment in American securities, according to Arthur Wiesenberger of Distributors Group, Inc., who has just completed a ten-week survey of European financial centers.

In finishes as close and thrilling as any that have been seen here this season, Strabo won the $14,250 Dwyer Stakes and Aneroid the $11,425 Carter Handicap yesterday before 20,000 persons, a near-record crowd at Aqueduct.

The toll in the Memorial Day strike battle at the Republic Steel Corporation's South Chicago plant rose to ten today with the death from gunshot wounds of Lee Tisdale, Negro furnace man employed by the Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company. He leaves a widow and four stepchildren.

R. P. BLACKMUR is one of the best of our American critics. But perhaps it is the long study of the most obscure and interesting of our poets that has caused him to rewrite too critically his own poetry. The best poems in this book are the least labored at and spun.

Richard Llewelyn Lloyd of Sycamore Drive, Great Neck, L. I., vice president of the Dwight Lloyd Metallurgical Company and of the Dwight Lloyd Sintering Company, with offices at 19 Rector Street, died yesterday in St. Luke's Hospital of an embolism after a short illness.

Charging down the homestretch like a team of horses harnessed together, Archie San Romani and Don Lash burst through the tape at Palmer Stadium this bleak afternoon in a near dead-heat finish that furnished the second fastest mile that man has ever unfolded,
Hector McInnes, president of the board of governors of Dalhousie University and vice president of the Bank of Nova Scotia, died at his home today. He was 73 years old.

A new home community is about to be opened in the vicinity of Harrison and Mamaroneck, comprising a tract of sixty acres between the Hutchinson River Parkway on the west and Kenilworth Road on the east. Prince Ripley, managing

ONE glowering afternoon not so long ago this occasional wayfarer stood watching the sun- trying its best, despite interference from gathering thunderheads, to bring out the full splendor of what was by far the most striking bonnet we had observed in this mad-season.

Announcement has been made here of the marriage in Shanghai, China, on May 1 of Miss Gertrude Margaretta Peppard, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Marcus R. Peppard of 390 West End Avenue, this city, to Lieutenant (junior grade) Joseph Hunt Bourland, U.S.N., son of William M. Bourland of Clarendon, Texas, and the late Mrs. Bourland.

Hathaway Watson, an investment broker, died yesterday in St. Luke's Hospital of a streptococcus infection in his jaw which developed a month ago when a bristle from a tooth brush became lodged in his gum.

Sixteen students in the School of Business and Civic Administration of the City College were elected to Beta Gamma Sigma, the national scholarship honor society of business, upon the conclusion of the Spring semester. The sixteen students were elected unanimously.

Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. David D. Pratt of Rochester, N. Y., and New Bedford, Mass., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jean 0. Pratt, to Kenneth C. Ogden Jr., son of Kenneth C. Ogden of 50 East Seventysecond Street and the late Mrs. Ogden.
Humphrey Mellish, former Justice of the Supreme Court of Nova Scotia, died at his home today. He was 75 years old. Two months ago he resigned from the bench on account of ill health.

The University of Southern California successfully defended its team championship today in the National Collegiate A. A. track and field championships with a total of 62 points. Stanford took second place with 50. Ohio State finished with 28 points and Columbia with 21.

SMOOTH operation of today's popular sports and hobby trains-rail fan trains, fold boat, fishing, bicycle, sightseeing trains and the like-challenges the resourcefulness of rail officials and employes.

A program of courses on the education of physically, socially and mentally handicapped children will be offered at Teachers College, Columbia University, as part of the Summer session work, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Merle E. Frampton, principal

The eighth annual horse show of the Bronxville Riding Club was held today on the grounds of the club in Tuckahoe. Officers of the club are William Guthrie Packard, president; Robcliff V. Jones, Harry D. Nims and Roger A. Young, vice presidents; A. Robert Baumann Jr.,
Mrs. Rebecca Hooper Eastman of 96 Columbia Heights, Brooklyn, author and playwright, political worker and Brooklyn social leader, died yesterday in Brooklyn Hospital of a heart ailment.

Six Greyhound bus companies asked the Interstate Commerce Commission today to authorize loans totaling $1,212,000 from the National City Bank of New York to finance the purchase of 101 super-coaches from the Yellow Truck and Coach Manufacturing Company.

"The Cradle Will Rock," an opera by Marc Blitzstein, which was originally intended for a WPA production and was taken over on Friday by a private management when the WPA ruled against the opening of any new productions until after July 1, will continue at the Venice Theatre "so long as the public supports it," John Houseman, managing producer, said yesterday.

Supreme Court Justice Joseph Perskie announced today that, unless the bondholder groups and Asbury Park came to some agreement, he would dictate on July 8 terms for refinancing the $10,735,000 bonded debt of Asbury Park.

The experiences of the patrol boat Larrakia, which broke down after arresting a group of Japanese pearlers and could not bring the valuable prize to the mother ship in her New Guinea port, are expected to convince the government of the need for a modern patrol in North Australian waters, either of the aerial type or a larger vessel.

The list of the North German Lloyd liner Berlin, due today from the Channel ports, includes Miss Elsie Smith, Anton Donner, Mrs. Klara Mayer, Heinrich Stoffel, Wilhelm Koehler, Mrs. Anna Wahl, Mrs. Grete Wagner and Mrs. Sophia Kenely.
Miss Martha Rogerson, daughter of Charles M. Rogerson and the late Mrs. Rogerson, became the bride today of Mr. James Mansfield Estabrook, son of Mr. Mansfield Estabrook and the late Mrs. Estabrook.

The arrangement of flowers in vases is a constantly recurring topic at garden clubs. By general vote of members of the Federated Garden Clubs of New York State it has been chosen as the subject of a series of lectures to be given before different organizations by Mrs. Fleurette Withers, teacher of painting and art appreciation at Hunter and Adelphi Colleges.

The Brown Rubber Company, Inc., of LaFayette, Ind., has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission under the Securities Act of 1933 a registration statement for S735,000 of common stock, $1 par. A total of 140,000 shares is to be offered at $5.25, and 25,000 shares are to be optioned to the underwriter for resale at the market, if offered, the terms to be set by a post-effective amendment.
The General Fireproofing Company declared a 30 cent dividend on the common stock. On April 1, 25 cents a share was disbursed.

AFTER sweeping high over Angola, the Ivory Coast and the Cape Verde Islands, a signal from Mozambique found its way to America's shores late one afternoon recently, bearing with it songs and dances from Portugal's southernmost colony on the East African Coast.

$210,000 Binghamton Building Plans for the construction of a our-story building to be used for Administration offices and research laboratories have been completed oy the Agfa Ansco Corporation of Binghamton, N. Y.

Miss Emily Harrison Todd, daughter of Captain and Mrs. Forde A. Todd of Annapolis, Md., and Washington, D. C., and granddaughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Hampton Barnes of West Acres, Devon, was introduced this afternoon at a tea given at their home by her grandparents.

Resignation of Arnold C. Sorenson as Scout executive of the Pomperaug Boy Scout Council after ten years' service was announced today by Arthur M. Comley, council president. "Chief" Sorenson, as he has been known to 20,000 men and boys in this area, will leave Bridgeport about Aug. 1 to become executive of the Newark (N. J.) Council.

The marriage of Miss Helen Clark North, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Henry Briggs North of this city, to Fred Clifford Fay, son of Mr. and Mrs. W. Clifford Fay of Brooklyn, took place here this afternoon in St. John's Episcopal Church. The ceremony was performed by Canon Paul S. Atkins.
Bowdoin College graduated 109 seniors and conferred six honorary degrees today at its 132d commencement. The recipients of honorary degrees were:

The speediness with which the Joint Congressional Committee on Tax Evasion and Avoidance was organized, and started to function, augurs well for at least an intensive inquiry. The President's message on the subject was issued on June 1 and on the same day the Senate passed the bill.

Rapid expansion in Southern kraft paperboard output, with its threat of potential overcapacity, has caused the industry to seek a tariff reduction by England in the hope of broadening exports to that country, it was learned here yesterday. At present the duty is 15 per cent and if it can be cut to 10 per cent paper executives here believe there would be a considerable rise in exports.

Two new champions, an intercollegiate and an interscholastic, will be crowned in the sport of speedboat racing this week-end. The eighth annual outboard regatta also may produce a new team champion to succeed Dartmouth when the college men and prep schoolboys finish their racing on Saratoga Lake, just out of Saratoga Springs, N. Y., on Saturday and Sunday.

Mrs. Robert McKim of Old Westbury proved the leading pilot today at the races of the Nassau Driving Club over the Mineola Fair Grounds half-mile track In the 2:25 trot, Mrs. McKim drove Clarinda Hanover, owned by the Bostwick-Whitney Stable, to a two straight-heat victory over Prosita, the property of and directed by Howard Cornwell, Mineola, and Calumet Ewing, driven by William Wiswall of Hempstead.

The Progressive City Committee announced yesterday that it plans to ask the Public Service Commission to stop the New York Telephone Company's practice of charging more than five cents for communications between parts of the different boroughs.

MORE than a score of living artists have been called upon for their impressions in fluent water-colors of New York's upstanding concrete and steel in the attractive exhibition now current at the Museum of the City of New York. "A City Standing Up" is the title which has been bestowed on the show, the phrase being taken from Louis-Ferdinand Celine's "Journey to the End of Night."

The Rev. J. Harding Fisher, former Associate Editor of America, has been named rector of the College of St. Ignatius at Inisfada, estate of the former Mrs. Nicholas F. Brady at Manhasset, L. I., that she recently gave to the Society of Jesus, it was announced yesterday by the Very Rev. Joseph A. Murphy, Provincial of the MarylandNew York Province of the Society of Jesus.

Before visiting Bilbao this afternoon, at noon I entered Arzgoitl, where I was yesterday, and learned from the commander of the Insurgent Second Brigade that they had heard a series of explosions this morning, beginning at 3 o'clock, which they assumed meant the blowing up of the bridges over the Nervion River.

The following from New York City are members of the newly formed FiftyYear Club of Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, an organization of scientists and engineers who attended the institute fifty years or more ago.

The Broadway Association announced yesterday the receipt of a letter from President Roosevelt disclosing that he had referred to Harold L. Ickes, Public Works Administrator, the association's request that the Federal government contribute the major part of the money needed to construct a vehicular tunnel under midtown Manhattan.
The third annual Westchester County Summer recreation training institute will be held on Monday and Tuesday from 9:15 A. M to 2:30 P. M. at the County Center here. Community recreational needs

The centenary celebration of the University of Michigan ended tonight with President Alexander Ruthven exhorting 2,000 men and women graduates to remember that they were going into a troubled world and must put to work the culture which the university had given them.

THE 4 and 5 cent Army and Navy Stamps recently issued by this country are going to be more valuable than many United States commemoratives released in the past few years, according to present indications. Only 30,000,000 each

Sir James M. Barrie, creator of the immortal Peter Pan, died in a London nursing home this afternoon at the age of 77. Peter Davies, the author's adopted son who as a child inspired Sir James to write "Peter Pan," had been at the bedside since 8 A. M. when the playwright, suffering from bronchial pneumonia and a weak heart, lapsed into unconsciousness.

Dr. and Mrs. Harry L. Rosenbaum of Brooklyn have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marion Shaley Rosenbaum, to Robert Ira Edelson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Emanuel M. Edelson, also of Brooklyn.
Representatives of the coal, paper and textile industries asked the Interstate Commerce Commission today to turn down the petition of Class I railroads for a general increase in freight rates.

Influenced by the prospective activity in and around the World's Fair site, another home community is about to be opened in the Flushing area of Queens by P. J. Duffy, president of the Queensboro Estates Corporation. Mr. Duffy announces

Another season in the long history of intercollegiate rowing comes to its climax this week. On Tuesday afternoon the thirty-ninth regatta of the Intercollegiate Rowing Association will be held at Poughkeepsie and on Friday, at New London Yale and Harvard will pick up the thread of their ancient rivalry on the water which started in 1852 with the first intercollegiate event in the United States.

Pierre A. Duquesne, buyer of toilet articles and cosmetics for Lord Taylor, has resigned, effective as soon as a successor is appointed. A. B. Buckeridge of this city has been elected president of the Silver Jubilee Club of the national Retail Credit Association, which held its convention last week in Spokane, Wash.

UNMATCHED along any of our great rivers of the Eastern coast is the rugged beauty of the landscape in which the Hudson is cradled, its bold headlands transforming to the eye a great tidal estuary into a chain of lakes embosomed in swelling green hills and forest-clad mountains.

A TOUR of New York State may well be developed into a sightseeing trip for sportsmen. In a three-day motor trip that swings as far north as the Adirondacks and back to the city again, one may get a good idea of what the State is doing to conserve its forests and wild life.

New York City public schools will close for the Summer on Wednesday, June 30, according to an announcement by Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools. Free Summer classes are being offered at Public School 39, 235 East 125th Street, under the supervision of the Adult Education Program of the WPA-Board of Education.

Dr. Arthur De Souza Costa, Brazilian Finance Minister, said today that he had arranged to confer on Monday with Secretary Morgenthau of the Treasury. Previously he had visited the State Department. He said his mission had started with a display of "great good-will" by authorities here.

Miss Sarah Vick Jones, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Van Dyke Hill Jones of this place, was married this afternoon at a military wedding at Christ Episcopal Church to Lieutenant Samuel Charles Gurney Jr., son of Lieut. Col. and Mrs. Samuel Charles Gurney of San Antonio, Texas. The Rev. Edwin S. Carson, rector of the church, performed the ceremony.

STRETCHED at ease in the same hotel suite that Mickey Cochrane had occupied the last time he was in New York, Manager James J. Dykes of the Chicago White Sox was puffing on an expensive cigar. Yes, James is smoking again. He looks natural that way.
Representative William P. Connery Jr. described by President Roosevelt as the "champion of the underprivileged," was buried today with full military rites in St. Mary's Cemetery.

Freddy Fitzsimmons, the old Giant knuckleballer who let the Pirates down with five hits last Sunday in Brooklyn, chalked up a perfect score as a Dodger by beating Pittsburgh again today when the Kelly Greens won for him in the ninth, 4-3.

The older a man grows the younger he wants his first bride to be in comparison with his own age, whereas the later a woman marries the more nearly like her own age, on an average, will be the age of her first husband, according to a report yesterday by statisticians of the Metropolian Life Insurance Company, who completed a study of first marriages in New York States, exclusive of New York City.

BIG BEN atop the House of Parliament has become the world's most stentorian voice of Time as it strikes away the hours in London. Out of the daylight in Australia and out of the darkness of nighttime in New York the thunderousboom of the giant timepiece is plucked from space on short waves.

A GROUP of Elinor Wylie's friends and admirers recently formed a committee whose purpose is to establish a memorial in the form of a poetry fellowship which will keep her memory alive among lovers of poetry and at the same time be an encouragement and help to future poets. The committee,
THE Goldman Band resumes its Summer march across the wave lengths tomorrow night. Station WNYC is scheduled to broadcast from 8:30 to 10 and WJZ from 8:30 to 9:30 o'clock.

Headquarters for thirty returning alumni classes from 1872 to 1934 were opened at Yale University today in anticipation of the 236th commencement next week. Presentation of "--and for Yale" shared reunion honors with informal dinners at historic college rendezvous clubs.

The Rev. J. Harding Fisher, former Associate Editor of America, has been named rector of the College of St. Ignatius at Inisfada, estate of the former Mrs. Nicholas F. Brady at Manhasset, L. I., that she recently gave to the Society of Jesus, it was announced yesterday by the Very Rev. Joseph A. Murphy, Provincial of the MarylandNew York Province of the Society of Jesus.

Another season in the long history of intercollegiate rowing comes to its climax this week. On Tuesday afternoon the thirty-ninth regatta of the Intercollegiate Rowing Association will be held at Poughkeepsie and on Friday, at New London Yale and Harvard will pick up the thread of their ancient rivalry on the water which started in 1852 with the first intercollegiate event in the United States.

Pierre A. Duquesne, buyer of toilet articles and cosmetics for Lord Taylor, has resigned, effective as soon as a successor is appointed. A. B. Buckeridge of this city has been elected president of the Silver Jubilee Club of the national Retail Credit Association, which held its convention last week in Spokane, Wash.

UNMATCHED along any of our great rivers of the Eastern coast is the rugged beauty of the landscape in which the Hudson is cradled, its bold headlands transforming to the eye a great tidal estuary into a chain of lakes embosomed in swelling green hills and forest-clad mountains.

Headquarters for thirty returning alumni classes from 1872 to 1934 were opened at Yale University today in anticipation of the 236th commencement next week. Presentation of "--and for Yale" shared reunion honors with informal dinners at historic college rendezvous clubs.

Premier Paul van Zeeland of Belgium is an economist as well as one of the most enlightened European statesmen; consequently, he has no illusions regarding an early solution of the problem of trade barriers which he will discuss with President Roosevelt and Secretary Hull in Washington.

The Treasury's daily statement shows that, as a result of the Government's $851,000,000 Treasury note issue of Tuesday, the gross public debt has passed the $36,000,000,000 mark. The exact figure reported at the close of business June 15 was $36,633,907,803. Since $300,000,000 of last week's new borrowing was designed to take up other Government obligations maturing later, the increase in the public debt should be somewhat less than the June 15 statement indicates;

In culmination of thirty years of effort by the Smith College Alumnae Association the cornerstone of the $250,000 Alumnae House at Elm Street and Bedford Terrace was laid this afternoon before hundreds of spectators, including alumnae, seniors and guests of the college.

The need for organization of unlisted brokers and dealers, long urged by the Securities and Exchange Commission, is at last seriously considered by the dealers themselves. Primary attempts of several unlisted dealers in this city have been made in the direction of setting up an organization which would provide uniform quotations on unlisted

The proceedings of a series of regional banking conferences held in the early months of this year by the American Bankers Association have been compiled in a volume called "Present Day Banking," published by Banking, the official journal of the association. The work is described by Tom K. Smith, president of the association, as a cooperative effort.

For the past vo years New Hampshire has been ?? its soil, measuring its water, hunting its people, and, in general, ?? account of its stock in trade. he immediate result is the publication of the State Planning and development Commission's first report, an illustrated volume which ?? the Maxfield Parrish cover on ?? front to the index in the back provides a mountain-top view of an american State.

The War Department released the following orders today dated June 18: COLONELS Miles. S., F. A., General Staff Corps, 11 days leave, June 18. Kaempfer, A. B., Inf., Ft. Wadsworth, N. Y., to Syracuse University, Syracuse, N.Y. James, L. R., Inf.. Ft. Hayes, Ohio, to home and await retirement. Howard, J. H., Air Corps, San Antonio, Texas, to Omaha, Neb., Air Corps Headquarters.

NOT toward communism. Not toward fascism. Rather toward old-fashioned democracy. For "France, after three years of internal conflicts, is still the stronghold of freedom on the Continent, and the defender of those human values which are precious to both the French and the British peoples:"

In a statement issued today by George H. Davis, president of the United States Chamber of Commerce, the organization was put on record as standing "for outlawing every form of force and coercion and intimidation in labor relations, for outlawing strikes when brought to coerce the public or public authorities, and for public registration of all labor organizations and of those who seek to form them."
Persons who have a week-end or an all-Summer residence in the country and want quickly the greatest possible beauty in a garden for the least expense and care must first do a little planning.

Whopper, big bay horse of Hal Price Headley, galloped in front of ten other horses at the halfway mark and won the $5,000 added Wolverine Handicap today by three lengths, despite a heavy impost of 130 pounds. Tempestuous was second and Carl S. third, a neck farther back.

Miss Patricia Dale McCarthy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. McCarthy of this place, was married to Harold Coffin Syrett, son of Mr. and Mrs. F. Harold Syrett, also of Nutley, this afternoon in Grace Episcopal Church here. The Rev. Clifford Stanley of New York performed the ceremony, which was followed by a reception at the Nutley Field Club.

THE problem of night flying on the international air routes is rapidly being solved. Many innovations have had to be adopted in place of the elaborate facilities enjoyed by pilots and passengers at the airports and on the airways of this country, where the
Mrs. Wallis Warfield's marriage to the Duke of Windsor on June 3 at Monts, France, is recorded in the Summer Social Register for 1937, which is now being distributed to subscribers.

A WAY out in the Hawaiian Islands Hon Chew Hee has painted the unholy splendor of color in Waimea Canyon. In West Virginia William Estler has loaded the trestle tables for his "Home Coming, Bethesda Church," with some of the most indigestible appearing fried chicken ever put on canvas.

Calling for an increased use of mass production methods in the construction of houses, Preston Delano,- governor of the Federal Home Loan Bank System, advises prospective purchasers of homes to buy such structures at a price within their means.
The American Labor party, at a meeting of its State committee at the Hotel Edison yesterday, went all the way in support of Mayor La Guardia for re-election except to nominate him formally.

Miss Anne Catherine Thompson, daughter of Mrs. Franklin Clark Thompson of Forest Hills and the late Mr. Thompson, was married yesterday to Matthew Robert Thompson Jr., son of Matthew Robert Thompson of Kew Gardens and the late Mrs. Thompson. The ceremany was performed by the Rev. Cranston Breton in St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Forest Hills.
The President's court reorganization measure having been tagged with a stinging adverse report from the Senate Judiciary Committee, the question now arises: What will happen to it next?

Officers of the Seventy-seventh Division Association will be installed on Wednesday evening at a meeting in the Seventy-seventh Division Memorial Building, 28 East Thirty-ninth Street. Pelham St. George Bissell, president justice of the Municipal Court, will preside.

New Haven. DR. JAMES ROWLAND ANGELL, about to retire from the presidency of Yale University, discussed, the other day, some of the conclusions he has reached after his long service as a leader of education. His sixteen years at the head of Yale have been the period of swiftest expansion in the history of that university and of the college world in general.

Pledges for the proposed Roberts Memorial Union at Colby College have reached $274,000, the alumni were told today. The program for raising funds is still incomplete in Maine and several other areas, and confidence was expressed that the coal of $300,000 would be reached within five weeks.

The governments of six American nations took steps this week to try to prevent a renewal of the Chaco war, threatened in consequence of the refusal of the Paraguayan Army to obey orders to withdraw from its present positions.
President Roosevelt today cabled congratulations to King Boris of Bulgaria on the birth of a son and heir to the throne. The President's message follows:

Fraternity was forgotten completely for several hours at the Polo Grounds yesterday afternoon as the Police Department baseball team battled the Fire Department nine for the championship of the Municipal Departments League.

The Cubs clung tenaciously to the National League lead today when Larry French pitched them to a 2-to-1 victory over the Phillies. More than 11,000 fans saw French best Wayne LaMaster in a pitchers' duel, with each allowing four hits.

Miss Louise Des Jardins, daughter of the Rev. Wesley H. Des Jardins, rector of St. Alban's Episcopal Church here, and Mrs. Des Jardins, was married this afternoon to Paul Harmon Worcester, son of Mr. and Mrs. John A. Worcester of Brooklyn. The ceremony was performed

Well-mounted and coordinating splendidly, Army's undefeated poloists scored in every period to conquer Cornell, 10 to 6, and capture the intercollegiate outdoor championship in the sports feature of yesterday's celebration program at Governors Island.

IT began with the dream of a placid old age on a lonely is land farm in a Norwegian fiord. It resolved itself speedily into a Summer program of active farming that was anything but placid, and that had about it no suggestion of old age.

One hundred years after Queen Victoria's accession to the throne the Lord Chamberlain licensed with royal consent the first public performance. of Laurence Housman's "Victoria Regina." The play had already

Miss Catharine Farley Osgood, daughter of Mrs. George Laurie Osgood Jr. of New York and Boston and the late Mr. Osgood, was married here this afternoon to Thomas Henry Foster Jr., son of Mrs. Thomas H. Foster of Old Bennington, Vt., and the late Mr. Foster, at the Summer home of her aunt, Mrs. Charles L. Rogers of St, Louis.

The American Library Association is holding its annual convention in New York this week for the first time in sixty years. It is a dramatic reminder of the growth of the public library as a democratic institution.

THIRTY-ODD years ago a sandyhaired, freckle-faced boy, with a basket of candy under his arm, ascended the gangplank of an excursion steamer plying in Boston Harbor. As he walked the decks calling out his wares, his eyes wandered across the water and he saw the masts and funnels of ships made fast to their docks or pulling out to sea.

Slim Monte Weaver today hung up his sixth pitching triumph of the year when the Senators defeated the Browns, 2-1. Weaver gave only seven hits. With two out and two on in the ninth, he was replaced by Carl Fischer, who retired the side without scoring.
Two men were killed and two were injured today in the collapse of the Montgomery River Bridge, west of Williamsport.

After being shot in the right arm while picking cherries in the orchard of Valentine Hansen at 376 Brehaut Avenue, Tottenville, S. I., Valentine Farri, 14 years old, was resting comfortably at his residence, the Mount Loretta Home, Tottenville, last night.

The slaying of a Christian railroad worker in an argument with a Jewish colleague raised new fears among Jews today of another anti-Semitic outburst. Jews immediately began throwing up barricades in front of their shops. Police were quickly

UNDAUNTED by the calendar and its implications, new exhibitions continue to arrive in numbers and variety. The largest of those recently opened is the group show with which the Studio Guild starts its. novel Summer schedule of "Revolving Exhibitions," in which nearly two hundred works are displayed by approximately fifty artists, most of them well known to gallery-goers.
The Richmond County men's singles started yesterday at the Clifton Tennis Club, Arrochar, S. I., with five of the seeded players in action, while a sixth, Paul Haber, defaulted.

The cornerstone of the $1,000,000 Frances Schervier Hospital and Home for the Aged at West 227th Street and Independence Avenue, the Bronx, will be placed at exercises this afternoon at 3 o'clock. The institution is conducted by the Sisters of the Poor of St. Francis.

While business conditions were irregular in many industrial sections of the country last week, due to labor disturbances, reports from agricultural districts showed an improvement in trade as the result of the promising outlook for heavy crops this season.

Southampton. THE 3,800 Basque children who have been evacuated from Bilbao and brought to England under the auspices of the National Joint Committee for Spanish Relief seem to have made a remarkable recovery.
