Japanese military might was paraded yesterday before the awed gaze of the Peiping populace but the demonstration was markedly restrained compared with a similar show a year ago when foreign onlookers were treated high-handedly.

The engagement of Miss Emily Joy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Sumner Joy of this place, to Harold Warren Cobb, son of Mrs. Sumner W. Cobb of Great Neck, L. I., and the late Mr. Cobb, has been announced by her parents.

The Pan-American Medical Associtation announced yesterday the liner Queen of Bermuda has been chartered for the inter-American medical congress to be held in Havana, Cuba, from Jan. 18 to Jan. 23. More than 1,500 physicians from

The government issued a statement today concerning the alleged ill treatment of the German Bruno Weigel in a Prague prison last November. The statement follows: "The campaign waged by the German press against the Czechoslovak Government in connection with the Weigel incident has become a subject of diplomatic negotiations in both Berlin and Prague.

Fifteen hundred persons marched through the streets of Harlem yesterday afternoon in protest against impending reductions in WPA personnel. Under the auspices of the Workers Alliance, the City Projects Council and Local 453 of the Teachers Union, the paraders gathered at 2 P. M. at 126th Street and Lenox Avenue.

THE NEW YORK TIMES weekly index of business activity eased farther in the week ended June 12, the number falling to 107.1 from 107.8 (revised) in the previous week. The index was 97.8 for the week ended June 13, 1936.

Gifts to Williams College totaling $2,799,777.14 in the past year were announced today by Charles D. Makepeace, treasurer, in his annual report to the Alumni Association. More than $2,600,000 was given by the late Samuel Hopkins, New York cotton merchant, for endowment purposes.

To the Radio Editor: In today's radio section of THE NEW YORK TIMES Elisha Flagg criticizes the pronunciation given to thirteen words by radio announcers and commentators, presenting what he alleges to be the correct and the incorrect pronunciation of each word. According to the Century
Mr. and Mrs. Truman Parker Handy gave a garden party yesterday afternoon at their home in Riverdale-on-Hudson at which they introduced to society their daughter, Miss Reid Handy.

The Cunard White Star liner Berengaria sailed yesterday for Cherbourg and Southampton with 1,700 passengers. Of these sixtyfive had been transferred here from the liner City of Newport News which had been held in Baltimore for two days by striking longshoremen. The strike was settled
FRIEDMAN--Mr. and Mrs. Edward I., 315 Central Park West, announce the bar mitzvah of their son, Herbert, on Saturday, June 26, at Temple Shaare Zedek, 212 West 93d St. At home Saturday from 3-6.

MANHATTAN ERDMAN, ALBERT (June 14). Estate, more than $10,000. To Blanche J. Erdman, widow, executrix. 23 E. 74th St., life estate in residue; Herbert J. Erdman, nephew, 22 E. 88th St., $5,000: Willard L, Bergman, 141-25 Northern Blvd.. Queens, $3.000: t. Sinai Hospital, Montefiore Hospital for Chronic Diseases. Gun Hill Road, Bronx, Beth-Israel Hospital, E. 17th St.. Columbia University and Hebrew Union College. Cincinnati, remainder interest. Lawyers Trust Co., 160 Broadway, executors.

Bilbao's fall was hailed throughout Italy as a victory for Italian Fascist arms because it was thought the deciding factor in the battles that have raged on the northern front for the last two months was the Italian volunteer unit. the Black Arrows.

Support of President William Green of the American Federation of Labor, in his fight with John L. Lewis and C. I. O. was pledged today by the New Jersey State Council of Carpenters in a resolution adopted at the closing session of its threeday thirty-second annual convention. The resolution crystallized a

HOLLYWOOD can be defenseless at times, helpless before the ribald jeers of those who accuse it of doing a cast, bungling job. It is not enough at such times to argue that the cinema, elastic a medium as it is, dare only be stretched so far; that politteal and economic pressure limit it.
Engagements of $5,058,000 gold abroad for shipment here-$2,549,000 in England and $2,509,000 in Canada-were reported yesterday to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. These purchases brought to
9:05 P. M.-Russian-built monoplane bearing three "Soviet heroes" hopped from Moscow on projected 6,000-mile flight to San Francisco Bay.

Miss Polly Horsey, daughter of Mrs. Outerbridge Horsey of 151 East Sixty-first Street, New York, and Shinnecock Hills, near here, was married at noon today in St. Rosalie's Church, Hampton Bays, to Charles Frederick Moulton, son of Mrs. Donatian Moulton of Dinard, France, and the late Mr. Moulton. The Rev. John La Farge performed the ceremony.
Six ships of the Eastern Steamship Lines were held at piers along the Atlantic seaboard yesterday by the impasse in the struggle
While Sir James M. Barrie of Scotland and London wrote plays that were great in their time, it was a daughter of Salt Lake City who lifted them into their greatest popularity.

THE fortnight between now and the Fourth of July witnesses one of the biggest seasonal upheavals in the broadcasting schedules of the entire year. With more than a score of programs signing off for the Summer within the next two weeks, many others plan to un dergo changes in talent, time and style. The finale dates are:

People go to the tattooer for divers reasons. The old Maoris of New Zealand chiseled patterns on their faces and bodies to enhance personal charm. Tars of the sailing-ship era considered tattoos good omens, painful proof of he-manhood and identification for bodies in shipwreck.

Japan's unfavorable trade balance since the beginning of 1937 today had reached such proportions as to cause the Cabinet to adopt early balancing of international payments as one of the major planks of its platform.

The fourth siege of Bilbao in 102 years ended today with the capture of the city. Three general officers of the staff of General Francisco Franco accepted the city's surrender from militiamen who had remained in it. All superior officers of the defending forces had left, presumably going to Santander.

Mrs. Barbara Vandenberg Knight, daughter of Senator Vandenberg, and her former husband, John Knight of Detroit, were remarried this afternoon in the Park Congregational Church here in the presence of intimate friends.

THE "Jeune France" gave its second important orchestral concert in the Salle Gaveau. The talented young conductor Roger Desormiere led the Orchestre des Concerts du Conservatoire in a program composed largely of new works. The members of this

The following Foreign Service changes since June 11 were announced today by the State Department: Warden McK. Wilson of Indianapolls, Ind., First Secretary of Legation, at The Hague, to Genoa, Italy, as Consul General. John R. Putnam of Hood River, Ore., Consul General at Genoa, to Florence as Consul General. Laurence W. Taylor of Bakersfield, Calif., Vice Consul at Copenhagen, to Strasbourg, France, as Vice Consul.

The marriage of Miss Florence C. Spitzmiller, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John L. Spitzmiller of this town, to Jacob Dickerson Snyder, son of Mr. and Mrs. A. E. Snyder of Glen Ridge, took place this afternoon in Advent Lutheran Church, East Orange. The Rev. George C. Loos, the pastor, performed the ceremony.

F. E. Williamson, president of the New York Central Railroad, is to be the principal guest at the final Spring meeting of the New York Division, Railroad Enthulasts, Inc., which wil be held in the Grand Central Terminal on Friday at 7:45 P. M. J. M. Fitzgerald, vice chairman Eastern Railroads Public Relations Committee, will address the meeting.

Miss Constance Wilder Lyman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis Edward Lyman of Glen Ridge, was married to A. Stewart Hegeman Jr., son of A. Stewart Hegeman, also of this place, this evening in the Glen Ridge Congregational Church. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. William Leath of Little Falls and Montclair.

The marriage of Miss Arlene Newton Thomson of this city, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Robert Mortimer Thomson, to Wesley Alsgood Kornder, son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip J. Kornder of Brooklyn, took place yesterday afternoon in the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Church. The Rev. Dr. George Paull T. Sargent performed the ceremony.

Expressing "great satisfaction in the progress that has been made against racketeering since my appointment of Mr. Thomas E. Dewey as special prosecutor," Governor Herbert H. Lehman has just sent a personal contribution of $250 to the Citizens Committee on the Control of Crime in New York, the committee announced yesterday.

Premier Leon Blum's difficulties caused the offering here today of forward francs on a virtually non-existent Saturday morning market. One-month francs weakened to a discount of 2 3/4 per cent and three-month francs to one of 4 3/4 per cent on spot which, after operations by the exchange equalization fund, showed slight improvement at 110 7/8 francs to the pound. The dollar was steady at $4.93 29-32 to the pound.

A field of more than 60 golfers will participate in the annual Women's Westchester and Fairfield County Golf Association tournament, which gets under way tomorrow at the Westchester Hills Golf Club. The tournament will

Miss Bernice Porter Grater, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley H. Grater of this city, was married to John William Grieve, son of Mrs. William Gray Grieve of New York and the late Mr. Grieve, this afternoon at the chapel of the Second Congregational Church. The Rev.

R. H. Helsel won the High Scratch Cup at the Jamaica Bay traps of the Bergen Beach Gun Club yesterday, leading a field of thirteen gunners with a perfect score of 50. In the handicap event, five tied with full scores of 50, and in the shootoff the victor was H. W. Watts.

Misfortune from a fresh and unexpected quarter cracked down on the Giants today when Clydell Castleman, the dud of the 1936 campaign but who recently became the bulwark of the pitching staff, failed for the first time in four starts to offset one of those even more amazing Carl Hubbell collapses.

NANTUCKET. Mass.-Strangers in Nantucket this season may see the arms go around on a-historic windmill. But the operation of the primitive grinding plant atop Mill Hill is not designed primarily as a tourist attraction. Nantucket is putting

A Summer dwelling is being erected by the Arthur D. Crane Company on the west shore of Lake Mohawk, Sparta, N. J., for Ralph J. Reck, manager of the Hotel Olcott, New York City. It will be completed for occupancy this season. The house will contain a large

Don Budge, America's Red Terror of the courts, handed Henry Wilfred (Bunny) Austin, England's greatest presentday amateur a 6-1, 6-2 beating in the Queens Club tennis tournament final today and immediately was installed an odds-on favorite for the all-England championship starting at Wimbledon Monday.

EACH new line of radios introduced for the 1937-38 season indicates that 1937 will be remembered as the ."robot year" for radio. With six push-buttons to do the tuning of favorite stations and an electric clock to turn the set onor off for preselected programs, the new Sparton line introduced during the past week by the Sparks Withington Company, includes a set that utilizes neither dial nor pointer for tuning.

Miss Aline Davis of this city, daughter of Mrs. Albert Milton Davis of Boston and the late Mr. Davis, was married here last night in the chapel of Riverside Church to David Wallace Danforth of Austin, Texas, son of Mrs. Mary E. Danforth of San Marcos, Texas, by the Rev. Eugene C. Carder.

Much progress on special-type routes of the regional highway system, to facilitate through traffic in the metropolitan area, was disclosed yesterday by the Regional Plan Association. Development of express

Many Democrats in Congress are restive over the President's program and the President's personal tactics in furthering it. Some Democrats who have long been loyal are in open rebellion. The hope behind the plan to bring as many of these as will come into friendly contact with Mr. Roosevelt at Jefferson Island next week-end is that good-fellowship will smooth a multitude of ruffled feathers.

A certain amount of activity was fostered in the wholesale markets here last week by improvement in retail business, according to a special report prepared for THE NEW YORE TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., resident buyers. The establishment

Bismark, a German shepherd owned by Robert E. Cook of 239 New Main Street, Yonkers, is in trouble again and this time he appears doomed. Several weeks ago Bismark was ordered destroyed because he had bitten a 12-year-old boy.

ALT-MULLER--Helen K., youngest daughter of the late Dr. george Alt-Muller and Charlotte Veitch, at her residence. Funeral from late residence, 118 Park Place, Brooklyn, at 2 P. M., Monday, June 21. Interment St. Paul's Churchyard, Glen Cove, at 4 P. M. BAKOFEN--Bertha. Services Park West Memorial Chapel, 79th St. and Columbus Ave., today, 2 P. M.

Appointment of a commission to draft changes in existing laws to effect "a constructive reorganization of our criminal courts and prosecuting agencies" was recommended in a letter, made public yesterday, which has been sent to Mayor La Guardia by the City Affairs Committee.

The League for Industrial Democracy today called for a national conference of farm, labor, cooperative and labor educational groups to block the creation of "antagonisms" among them "by the forces of reaction."

OFF for Chicago, still in a thick fog. The 'Shufflin' Joe Louis who bounced Baer and Carnera on the canvas should be a cinch to batter Braddock all around the White Sox ball park. But is this the same Shufflin' Joe Louis?. If not, why not?

Reports that Baron Constantin Von Neurath, the German Foreign Minister, intends on his visit to London to try to satisfy Downing Street by reassuring declarations regarding Germany's disinterestedness in the activities of Konrad Henlein and his Sudeten German party here and her willingness to respect

Declaring the Christian church "must have a part in the affairs of industry," without sanctioning violence "by strikers, police or company employes," the Rev. Phillips Packer Elliott of the First Presbyterian Church,

THE stories Cora Jarrett tells in "I Asked No Other Thing" (Farrar Rinehart, $2.50), contain the material for a fairly revealing handbook on woman's weapons. They exploit a field of conflict that, until recently, has been barely acknowledged in fiction.
The common assertion that luck is an important factor in men's lives was challenged by President Tyler Dennett of Williams College in his baccalaureate sermon to the graduating class today.

Samuel Liehtenstein, 46-year-old veteran of the World War, was drowned yesterday morning when lameness resulting from wounds received in the war prevented him from escaping when his automobile plunged into Wallabout Canal, in Brooklyn.

Extension of the basic principles of Harvard's national scholarship system to include New England private schools which regularly send men to Harvard was announced here tonight with the award of seventeen scholarships.

Two mortgages aggregating $17,500. held by Daniel M. McKeon of Ridgefield, Conn., from the Hood Memorial African Methodist Episcopal Zion Church on 229 Lenox Ave were extended to June 2, 1947, at 4 to 5 per cent. Grace 0. Chapman and others extended to April 12. 1942. at 4 1/2 per cent, a mortgage for $31,500 on 235-37 W 145th St, held from the 437 Lenox Ave Corp, Beatrice Block, president.

Premier Beni to Mussolini today received from the Spanish Insurgent leader, General Francisco Franco, a telegram announcing the capture of Bilbao and expressing pride that his Insurgent army had justified the confidence placed in it by Italy.

The world is divided in a death struggle between two ideologiesthe belief that men are controlled by impulsion from within, and the theory that men are driven only by compulsion from without, the Rev. Dr. Albert W. Beaven, president of Colgate-Rochester Baptist Divinity School, declared in a sermon yesterday morning at the Marble Collegiate Reformed Church, Fifth Avenue at Twenty-ninth Street.
A replica of a jail cell in which sits a paper mache convict labeled "1618" went on display today as the National Association of Credit Men opened its forty-second annual convention.

Alexander A. Troyanovsky, Soviet Ambassador to the United States, served as interpreter last night in a radio interview with the three Soviet airmen, broadcast from the home of Brig. Gen. George C. Marshall, United States Army, commandant at Vancouver, Wash.

King George and Queen Elizabeth today telegraphed condolences on the death of. Sir James M. Barrie to the playwright's adopted son, Peter Davies. The message read: "The Queen and I are so grieved by the death of our old friend Sir James Barrie.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Nancy Carrington Williams, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Peter Williams Jr. of this city, to George Tener Oliver 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Sturges Oliver. also of Pittsburgh.

Behind the hurling of Elden Auker and Tommy Bridges, the Tigers took both ends of a double-header from the Athletics today, 6 to 3 and 8 to 1. While Bridges held the Mackmen to six hits to hand them their seventh straight defeat in the nightcap, his mates put on a five-run attack in the sixth inning against Hary kelley.

Seguin II, owned by Duane Stoneleigh of Towson, Md., sailing under the burgee of the Harlem Yacht Club, won the seventh annual Riverside-Stratford Shoal overnight race of the Riverside Yacht Club, which ended today.

The report on Germany's foreign trade in May, although in part seasonally explicable, must be regarded as unfavorable because, for the first time since deterioration of the balance ceased, the export surplus was smaller than in the same month in the preceding year.
Fighting with great desperation and no small amount of perspiration as well, the Giants finally managed to quell the rebellious Reds today while 21,000 groaned with the heat.

A combined marine amphitheatre with island stage and exhibit building, costing $1,600,000, will be erected at the World's Fair for the State of New York, the State Fair Commission announced yesterday.
Friends of "Uncle Dan" Beard, National Boy Scout Commissioner, will gather at his home here tomorrow afternoon to celebrate his eighty-seventh birthday.
Investment of one's talents to their best use was advised today by Professor Chauncey B. Tinker of Yale in the baccalaureate address at the University of Rochester.
Seven of the nine members of the German expedition that was seeking to scale Nanga Parbat, towering 26,629 feet in the great Himalayan range, and nine Gurka porters have been killed by an avalanche.

Protesting that his power had been usurped and that even his "right to talk" had been taken away, Mayor Daniel J. Shields nevertheless held the first Sunday session of the Johnstown Police Court in the city's history this afternoon, sitting as magistrate in the cases of twelve strikers or sympathizers charged with various offenses.

The cornerstone of the new million-dollar Frances Schervier Home and Hospital overlooking the Hudson River at 227th Street and Independence Avenue, the Bronx, was laid yesterday with a service of benediction presided over by Mgr. John F. Brady,

" Current happenings in Europe are finally convincing the world that the enemies of democracy are the foes of all men," Rabbi William Margolis said yesterday, preaching before Congregation Ohab Zadek, 118 West Ninety-fifth Street.

Miss Bertha Manning, daughter of Mrs. Ida Manning of this place, and Arthur Crane, son of Mrs. John Heimmel of Elizabeth, were married in the Caldwell Presbyterian Church this afternoon by the pastor, the Rev. Edwin I. Stearns.

Miss Anne French Earle, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Keese Earle of this city and Cold Spring Harbor, L. I., will have her sister, Miss Margaret Earle, and Miss Katharine Smull of New York as maids of honor at her marriage on Saturday afternoon to Roy R. Buxton Attride, son of Major and Mrs. Percy W.Attride of London, England, and Quetta, Inda.

John McDiarmid of Princeton University and Gene McCauliff of Chicago captured the doubles championship of the twenty-seventh annual national clay courts tennis tournament today, but rain washed out the singles battle between Bobby Riggs and Joe Hunt of Los Angeles.

A father and his two children were drowned yesterday while on a canoe ride on the Hackensack River. They were identified early today as Jack Blyth, 38 years old, of Hohokus, N. J.; his daughter, Jean, 11, and his son, John, 9, of 31 Vanderbeck Place, Hackensack.
Mr. and Mrs. Newton W. Larkum of West Hartford have announced the betrothal of their daughter, Miss Virginia Larkum, to Arthur Paul Bencks Jr., son of A. P. Bencks of Brookline, Mass.

Recent reports from Washington indicate that we are not likely to have housing legislation at this session of Congress unless the difference of opinion which has grown up between Senator WAGNER and Secretary MORGENTHAU can be ironed out.

An intimation that further Soviet treason trials are in preparation is contained in Prosecutor A. J. Vyshinsky's declaration today that the secret court-martial that resulted in the shooting of Mikhail Tukhachevsky and seven other Red army generals brought to light new facts concerning criminal acts of "enemies of the people."

The United States Employment Service during May found the largest number of jobs in private industry for unemployed persons of any month in its history and listed the lowest number of job seekers on its rolls, Secretary Perkins reported today.

Advertising men and women gathered from all parts of the country yesterday to register for the thirtythird annual convention of the Advertising Federation of America, which opens today in the Hotel Pennsylvania. A total of 1,600 persons connected with various phases of the business are expected to attend the three-day meeting.

James J. Braddock. keyed to a razor's edge for the defense of his title against Joe Louis in Chicago Tuesday night, didn't strike a lick of real work today. But he ran three miles early this morning and shook hands with a big delegation of New Jersey admirers who poured into camp this afternoon by train and auto hoping to see the champion in his last dress rehearsal.

George Harrison, president of the Brotherhood of Railway Clerks, said tonight that he would call a strike of 40,000 employee of Railway Express, Inc., unless the company met union demands for higher hourly wages and vacations.
Assistant Corporation Counsel Mark S. Mathews has been elected a national director of the United States Junior Chamber of Commerce, in charge of the Eastern States, it was announced yesterday.

The action of the oats and rye markets here last week was a reflection of that of the other grains. While there was some talk of a delayed oats harvest this year, the buying of futures was not aggressive,

" High-salaried" executives were advised to leave their "ornately furnished offices and go down into the grease and din of the plant and mix with their workers" in a talk today by C. E. Stiles, production superintendent in the Arlington plastics department of I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc.

Catholic and Protestant members of the Paterson Police Department attended today what is believed to be the first Police Department communion breakfast to be held in any New Jersey Protestant church. They were urged to form a St. George Association and heard pleas for the cooperation of the two faiths in spreading righteousness.

Palmer Wilson, florist. store in 1.329 LexIngton Ave., through Douglas Gibbons Co., Inc. Old Town Ribbon and Carbon Co., typewriter supplies, additional loft in 176 Johnson St.; Globe-Weine Plumbing Supply Co., in 70 Commercial St.; Beckerman Shoe Co., in 35 Meadow St.; Brooklyn rentals by Baffa Dixon, brokers.

George W. Crane, assistant director of the State Department of Taxation and Finance and a Past Grand Master of the I. O. O. F., died at his home here today of a heart ailment at the age of 72. His widow and three children, G. Lionel, Myra and J. Russell Crane, all of Buffalo, survive.

Figures in parentheses indicate par) Arrowbrook (70)-First round for Presldent's Trophy: Phil Scharf defeated I. Greene, 1 up: Harry Feldman defeated George Wedeen, 2 and 1; Harry Gray defeated William Levinson, 1 up (21 holes); Lou Korn defeated D. Knapp, 1 up.

Last-half rallies carried the Foxhunters and Bostwick Field quartets to victories, while Aknusti galloped to a one-sided success over Roslyn in today's games in the Meadow Brook Club Cups polo tourney.

The engagement of Miss Dorothy Alyse Unger, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William F. Unger of this city and Woodmere, L. I., to Lieutenant Maurice Arthur Preston, U.S.A., son of Mrs. James Preston of Tulare, Calif., and the late Mr. Preston, has been announced by her parents.

In a letter read yesterday afternoon at the Finnish Folk Festival in Central Park Mayor La Guardia praised the building of co-operative apartment houses as one way of solving the city's housing problem.

The Metropolitan Museum of Art has acquired and placed on exhibition in its room of recent accessions a painting by the eighteenth-centurn French artist Jean Baptiste Joseph Pater. The picture, called "Concert Champetre," is one of Pater's typical portrayals of the gay and artificial life of the beau monde of his day.

Before an attendance of 3,000, the largest in the sport's history at the Blind Brook Turf and Polo Club, the First Division four conquered the Blind Brook Esquires, 13 to 9, today in an Eastern League clash.

A likeness between the brother of the prodigal son, who stayed calmly at home working while his younger brother wandered about squandering his money, and the thousands of people who today are "slaves to their work,"- looking forward only to their pay checks, was drawn yesterday morning by the Rev. Albert L. Neibacher.

Asserting that citizens used to weighing their words feel that this nation faces a crisis comparable in its gravity with the Civil War, President James Rowland Angell said today in his last baccalaureate as executive head of Yale University,

A recount of votes cast in the recent run-off election for president of Typographical Union No. 6 was authorized yesterday by the general assembly of the union at a stormy meeting in Stuyvesant High School, Fifteenth Street and First Avenue, when a report of the election was heard by the delegates.

After a century of preaching the sentimental gospel of optimism and progress, the church is once more returning to realism, because it is realizing that there is nothing sentimental about the gospel, the Rev. Dr. John S. Whale, president of Cheshunt College, Cambridge, England, said in a sermon yesterday morning at the Fifth Avenue Pres-. byterian Church, at Fifty-fifth Street.

Daniel Joseph Boyle, 21 years old, of Bayonne, who hopes to make writing his career although he is blind, was one of sixty-four students who received degrees today at the thirtyseventh commencement of St. Peter's College. The exercises were conducted on the campus by Bishop Thomas J. Walsh of the Catholic diocese of Newark.

Unexpected encouraging features are developing in the steel market, in the opinion of the magazine Steel. Buying, while less than a few weeks ago, is said to show an increase over a fortnight ago, to the extent that deliveries in some instances are falling back.

Miss Margaret Elizabeth Herrick, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard C. Herrick of this place, was married to Philip Staedler, son of Mrs. Emma Staedler of Verona, this afternoon in Our Lady of All Souls Church, East Orange, by the Rev. John McManus.

Those two attractions reported on Saturday as hanging by a thread were "Abie's Irish Rose," at the Little, and the Lundy-Kamsler program of mystery show revivals at the Majestic. The thread broke and both houses will be dark tonight.

Professor Irving Fisher's index number of average commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, was 91.9, which compares with 92 the week before, 92.6 two weeks before, 93.3 three weeks before and 93.5 four weeks before.

Miss Louise Clement Carter of this city, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herman M. Carter of Memphis, Tenn., was married here yesterday afternoon to Lieutenant Richard Gates Williams, U.S.A., son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul D. Williams of Citronelle, Ala., in the West End Presbyterian Church.
A commercial airplane, piloted by Chick Stanton, a Californian, with five passengers, has been missing since 9 o'clock this morning, when it left El Pozo, near the Panama border, bound for SaN Jose.
Although the importation of gold in May, as in April, was insignificant, the Reich, it is computed, holds 120,000,000 marks more gold than it did at the beginning of the year.
Controller Morris S. Tremaine reported today a net reduction of $200,000,000 in the State's temporary debt in the last two months.

With the first vote on the forty-hour-week convention for the textile industry expected tomorrow in the International Labor Organization Conference, the American delegation, which has been leading the fight for the measure, was hopeful tenight of obtaining the necessary two-thirds by one or two votes.
PARIS, Monday, June 21.-Premier Leon Blum's Cabinet resigned early today after the Senate had rejected for the second time in two days a measure giving the government extensive fiscal powers.

The Rev. Dr. James J. Henry, pastor of the Park Avenue Methodist Episcopal Church, Eightysixth Street, East of Park Avenue, yesterday prophesied "a famine of the word of God" if the pastors throughout the city silenced their pulpits through a preaching moratorium.

Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 75 per cent of capacity, unchanged from either of the two preceding weeks. The high level maintained before strikes started averaged about 91 per cent. The Pittsburgh district has not been affected by the strikes and has been going at about 94 per cent.

The fifteenth anniversary of the occupation of Upper Silesia by Polish troops after the allocation of the eastern counties of that disputed territory to Poland by the Council of Ambassadors was celebrated here today by the dedication of a

A prediction that eventually the United States may attempt to solve its gold problem "within the tripartite understanding" is made by Herbert M. Bratter, former financial specialist of the Commerce and Treasury Departments, in the June 15 issue of the Foreign Policy Association's "Foreign Policy Reports," made public today.

The Douglas estate leased to Arthur Charn the five-and-a-half-story English basement dwelling at 57 Park Avenue through Pease Elliman, Inc. The house has a frontage of twenty-five feet and has a large penthouse with terrace and elevator.

The Rev. Walter J. Duffy of St. Edward's Catholic Church, Eighth and York Streets, died on Friday after an illness of eight weeks. His age was 69. He had been rector of St. Edward's for the last two years.
Mr. and Mrs. John J. Schumann Jr. of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Caroline Fairchild Schumann, to Gardner Abbott Jr. of Cleveland, Ohio.

President Federico Paez issued a decree today adding a 50 per Cent surcharge to the regular customs duties on imports from thirty-five countries with which Ecuador has an unfavorable trade balance of more than 30 per cent.

With James J. Dooling, leader of Tammany, committed to a "hands off" policy in contests for Assembly district leaderships, primary fights in at least nine of the twenty-three Manhattan districts are in prospect. This number undoubtedly will be greater if the Democratic county leaders in the city fail to agree on a Mayoralty candidate.

After declining at the beginning of last week, the cotton market later showed a strengthening tendency, although prices moved irregularly; Net changes for the week were small. On the New York Cotton Exchange active future contracts at the close on Saturday were 4 points down to 4 points up.

Dr. Wilbour E. Saunders, headmaster of the Peddie School here, presented prizes and awards to freshmen, sophomore and junior students for scholastic excellence and outstanding work in extra-curricular activities at the final concert of the school's musical clubs this afternoon. Senior awards will be made at the commencement June 28.

In thirty-nine States and the District of Columbia the legal minimum marriage age for children has been raised above the "common-law" age, that is 14 years for boys and 12 for girls, according to a table made public today by the Children's Bureau of the Labor Department.

Rochester got off to a flying start in its four-game series with Jersey City today by capturing both ends of a double-header, winning the first. 3 to 2, in eleven innings and the second in seven frames, 6 to 1.

A military mass, attended by the garrison of Fort Jay, the 165th Infantry (the old Sixty-ninth) of the National Guard, and more than 500 visitors, opened yesterday morning the final day of a week's celebration of the tercentenary of the purchase of Governors Island. Mgr.

Wes Ferrell scored his third straight pitching victory since he joined Washington by defeating St. Louis today, 5 to 3. The Browns took an ealy lead, tallying a run in the first or a walk and an infield out, and adding two more in the second on three hits and an error.
The French minesweeper Granit, on non-intervention patrol off Port Vendres, France, today took off a Spanish sailboat twentyone men whom officers described as volunteers for the Spanish civil war.
As the result of an appeal by President Arthur Howe, a gift of $100,000 for the trade school of Hampton Institute has just been received from Edward S. Harkness of New York City.

Most of this city's clergymen mentioned the strike situation in sermons this morning and, while in general they urged that a peaceable settlement was the paramount problem, a few, at least, criticized Governor Earle for the policy which he instituted yesterday.

Former Supreme Court Justice Jeremiah T. Mahoney continued to lead for the Democratic nomination for Mayor in the fifth week of the poll of the magazine New York Politics, Jerry Finkelstein, its publisher, announced yesterday. Justice William T. Collins gained second place, displacing Senator Royal S. Copeland, who dropped to fourth.

Although receiving a one-goal advantage, a team composed of Bethpage Polo Club players found no use for it as it routed the South Shore Blues, 11 to 6, today at Hazard Field. After the home unit wrested the lead at 3-2 in the second session, the invaders pushed across four tallies in the third period and stayed in front thereafter.

Westchester Ave, 586 (10-2616): Apartment Estates, Inc, to Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank; $31,358. Matthew Ave, 2,944 (16-4551): Robert Bisceglia. to Fannie L. Harrison, 1,085 Park Ave, 5 per cent; $10,500.
A two-round workout, instead of the four he had scheduled, today ended Joe Louis's training campaign for his world title fight with Champion James J. Braddock Tuesday night in Comiskey Park, Chicago.

New freight cars on order on June 1 for Class I railroads were larger than for any corresponding date since 1924, according to the Associtation of American Railroads. More steam locomotives were on order than for any June since 1930.
Albert Kahn of New York and Detroit, and head of the architectural firm of Albert Kahn, Inc., was honored by France tonight for his services to that country, especially in World War days.

Dr. Stricker Coles, Philadelphia physician widely known in the field of obstetrics, died this morning of a cerebral hemorrhage at his home, Alscot, Fisher's Road, Bryn Mawr, at the age of 70. He was born in Virginia, the son of Peyton Skipworth Coles and Julia Isaetta Coles.

The Austrian team of four tonight captured the world contract bridge championship by defeating the New York team by 4,740 points In the final 96-hand match. The Austrians finished with a spurt, increasing their margin from 250 to 4,740 points in the last twelve hands.
Continuing heartily and humorously on the second century of her life, Mrs. Henriette Wimpfheimer of 175 West Seventy-ninth Street, will celebrate her 101st birthday today.
Addressing the 105th commencement of Wesleyan University- tonight, Dr. Edwin W. Kemmerer, '99,
No influences such as international restiveness, tariff barriers or lower commodity prices prevented a further expansion in British foreign trade in May.

Six hundred and three degrees will be conferred tonight on Brooklyn College graduates at the Academy of Music at the tenth commencement exercises of the institution. Five hundred and ninety-one will receive baccalaureate degrees and twelve will get master degrees.

Dr. James B. Conant, president of Harvard University, in the annual baccalaureate sermon before 800 Harvard seniors in the Memorial Church today, drew a parallel between the American scene into which the present seniors are graduating and the one into which he graduated in the Spring of 1914.
Landing short of their goal by re some 600 miles, the three Russian h fliers on their flight over the North Pole came close to the world's nonstop airline distance record.

Cornell seniors were asked today to consider the "condition of your religion" in the baccalaureate sermon preached in Bailey Hall today by the Rev. Dr. Rockwell Harmon Potter, dean of the Hartford Theological Seminary.

With the gradual approach of the bass season another popular phase of fresh-water fishing will be opened. to thousands of anglers in this State. Those who spend their vacations near lakes or ponds are usually anxious to leave the city in July because they want to try a hand at some patch of water where they suspect the bass are lurking.
Summer officially begins this afternoon at 3:12 o'clock, although yesterday's coolness made it hard to believe. The average temperature yesterday was 68 degrees, two below normal.

Justice Fred H. Davis of the Florida Supreme Court died suddenly here today at the age of 43 of angina pectoris. He served in the Florida House of Representatives for several terms and was Speaker in 1927.

Newark stretched its lead. in the International League today by sweeping both ends of a doubleheader-with Montreal, winning the first game by 7-6 and the nightcap by 3-2. Charlie Keller's 420-foot home run into the center-field bleachers in the sixth tied the score in the second tilt, and Bob Seeds's triple and an outfield fly by Pinky Hargrave produced the deciding marker immediately afterward.

VATICAN CITY, June 20.--Pope Pius presided at a special meeting of the Congregation for Extraordinary Ecclesiastical Affairs which met at Castel Gandolfo, the Pope's Summer home, this morning to discuss the religious situation in Germany and the turn for the worse
The general wholesale price index on June 12 was 530, unchanged from a week before. The world gold price index for twenty-two raw materials was 53.7, against 54.7.

The number of persons dependent on public relief in this State has declined by more than 650,000 in the last fourteen months, according to figures made available yesterday by the State Temporary Emergency Relief Administration.
All day today Insurgent troops poured into Bilbao, many moving on toward Santander, forty-five miles to the west, which they hope to capture within a short time.

Captain Robert A. (Bob) Bartlett, veteran explorer and lecturer, sailed yesterday afternoon on his 43-yearold Gloucester fishing schooner, the Effie M. Morrissey, for his eleventh Summer trip to arctic regions.

Circe, sailed by Logan Munroe, defeated Bob Kat III, Robert Meyer's six-meter yacht, over a course off the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club today. Circe, one of a fleet of eleven boats, came from third place on the last leg to gain the triumph.

While spokesmen for the company declared they would take no action pending further developments in the sit-down strikes that have tied up six ships of the Eastern Steamship Lines, leaders of the National Maritime Union said Yesterday that plans to extend the walk out today were being considered.
An uneasy peace settled down on this city today after last night's pitched battle between C. I. O. pickets and police guarding the Republic Steel plant.

Prank Hamilton Davis, eleven rooms comprising entire floor in 952 5th Ave; Raymond L. French, in 111 E 80th St; David W. Hulbord Jr., in 450 E 52 St; Douglas L. Elliman Co, Inc. brokers. Robert J. Earle, in 1,133 Park Ave th??ough Douglas L. Elliman Co. Inc; Arthur H. Van Brunt, in 31 E 79th St; Mrs. G. P.

Vaulting over the top of the world, the three Russian fliers, VALERI CHKALOFF, GEORGI BAIDUKOFF and ALEXANDER BELIAKOFF, each already crowned with the title "Hero of the Soviet Union," earned new and rich laurels by their non-step flight from Moscow which ended yesterday afternoon at Vancouver Barracks, near Portland, Ore.

Franklin W. Fort, former Representative in Congress from New Jersey, died today in a Mayo Clinic Hospital. He was 57 years old. He had been ill since May 1, when he came here for an operation. At the bedside were his wife, Mrs. Emita Ryan Fort of East Orange, N. J.; a daughter, Mrs. A. R. Crawford of Pleasantville, N. Y., and a son, William S. Fort.

The former Benedictine abbot, the Rev. Albanus Schachleiter, a stanch supporter of Nazism and friend of Adolf Hitler, died today at Feilnbach in Upper Bavaria. He was 76. Chancellor Hitler always visited his friend when near his home. He ordered a state funeral for him when told of his death.

The usual quiet of Sunday in the rowing camps along the Hudson was broken today; for this was not an ordinary Sunday; In two more days the regatta toward which all these oarsmen and their handlers have been aiming all year comes, and there was work on the river today for some of the crews.

Except for the fact that the sterling price for gold continues to rule at below United States parity, normal coneditions have been restored to the bullion market. The quantity coming out of hoards has declined and sales in the last week amounted to [Pound]2,269,000, compared with [Pound]4,017,000 in the previous week and [Pound]12,845,000 a fortnight ago, when panic conditions prevailed.

The Economist's index of British commodity prices, based on the average of 1927 as 100, stood on June 16 at 84.2, compared with 86.2 a fortnight before, 86 a month ago and 60.4 on Sept. 19, 1931, just before suspension of gold payments by Great Britain.

The busiest week of the Summer on the North Shore, sometimes referred to as the "little season," will start on Wednesday with the wedding of Miss Louise Converse Morgan and Raymond Skinner Clark and continue through the July 4 week-end.

The Census Bureau figured out today that more than a fourth of the nation's employes and payrolls are concentrated in twenty-three counties. An analysis of the 1935 business census, just completed, showed that New York County had 4.31 per cent of the employes and 9.27 per cent of the payrolls in the country.

Honore Mercier, a Quebec Cabinet Minister for twenty-two years under two Premiers and a member of the Provincial Legislature for almost twentynine years, died last night at the age of 62. The retired Liberal politician, son of former Quebec Premier Honore Mercier, died after a heart attack at his home in this village thirty miles south of Montreal.

Women's polo was staged at the Burnt Mills Polo Club's Schley Field today, with the East scoring a 7-6 decision over the West. Miss Marjorie Le Boutillier, back for the Eastern team, was the outstanding player. She tallied five goals and paced her team's attack with hard riding and strong hitting. The Western combination was led by- Mrs. C. H. Jackson Jr., who scored four tallies.

The yachting season on Barnegat Bay began in a cold, drizzly, fresh northeasterly breeze yesterday as the International Star Class sloops sailed the first race of the elimination series off the Seaside Park Yacht Club.

The Fedaral Steel Mediation Board deternined today on its policy for negoiations with principals on both ides in its attempt to end the sevan-State. steel strike before further riots and bloodshed develop.

Fred C. Tanner Jr. and Martin Victor gained a well-earned, consistently played triumph today in the final round of the annual Piping Rock invitation best-ball golf tournament. By dint of a 2 and 1 sub-par semlfinal morning victory over the established favorites, Jess W. Sweetser and J. T. Trippe,. Tanner and Victor were the afternoon favorites over the other finalists, William G. Curran and George Hepburn.
Frederick J. Bruce, 50 years old, of 36 Montgomery Place, Brooklyn, president of the Frederick J. Bruce Lumber Company, died yesterday in the Greenpoint Hospital from a bullet wound in the chest. Mr.

The order for the discontinuance June 30 of Camp Forster, the only CCC camp of any material service to New York City, will be protested by every means, according to Herman Forster, Deputy Commissioner of the New York City Department of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity.
The Phll lies whittled the Cubs' rational League lead to one game today when they captured the final game of the series, 6-5, before More than 23,000 spectators.

A stained piece of blue polka-dot cloth was found today by the police at Sound Beach and tonight was being examined to see if the stains were blood and if the cloth might have come from the blue dress worn by Mrs. William H. Parsons

Calendar congestion is being steadily and notably reduced, Mr. LEONARD SAXE, executive secretary of the Judicial Council, shows in his report published today. Four years ago the Municipal Court and the City Court seemed hopelessly submerged under their volume of business.

The Police Academy graduated its largest class in ten years at exercises yesterday afternoon at Ebbets Field, Brooklyn. Mayor La Guardia told the new policemen that on them depended the future of a new policy of honesty, efficiency and courtesy established by the present city administration.

Alleging that stockholders in leased lines are treated unfairly, a protective committee of the Old Colony Railroad has asked shareholders to join them in a formal protest to the United States District Court against the reorganization plan submitted recently by the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad.

The strike against the three independent steel companies already has cost 85,000 steel workers more than $10,000,000 in wages, and the total is mounting at the rate of about $500,000 a day. The average steel worker gets $35 a week and the strike is now in its fourth week.
The Monmouth County C.C. quartet displayed its characteristic powerful offensive in overwhelming the Bethpage Polo Club team, 14 to 6, today for its second victory in as many Eastern League clashes.

The marriage of Miss Yvette Lorraine Kopelov, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Max I. Kopelov of 920 Riverside Drive, to Samuel Rosenthal, son of Max Rosenthal of this city and the late Mrs. Rosenthal, took place last night at the Commodore. The Rev. David Putterman of the Park Avenue Temple, cousin of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony.

Newark took in its stride today the start of complete service in the Pennsylvania Railroad's $40,000,000 transportation development which now links main-line trains, Hudson and Manhattan trains, city subway, trolley cars, buses and taxicabs.

Pitted against a formidable seventeen-goal combination, the elevengoal Governors Island quartet turned in superb performance by holding the Rumson County Club team to a 8-8 tie yesterday at Morris Memorial Field, Governors Island.

Setting the pace from start to finish, Peter Fick, the New York Athletic Club's national indoor and outdoor free-style sprint champion and American Olympian, encountered no difficulty in retaining his metropolitan A. A. U. senior 100meter swimming title yesterday at Manhattan Beach.

A new day is dawning in the education of the handicapped and the deaf, Dr. Merle E. Frampton, general adviser on education of the handicapped at Teachers College, Columbia University, declared last night at the opening of the thirtieth annual meeting of the American Instructors of the Deaf in the Horace Mann Auditorium, 120th Street and Broadway.

The election of John J. Cavanagh, restaurateur, as president of the Twenty-third Street Association was announced yesterday. He succeeds the late Dr. Paul H. Fairchild, who headed the organization for eight years.
Alvin Untermyer stated yesterday that the scratching of his race horse, Jungle Chase, at Aqueduct on Saturday. had been ordered by his stable foreman four and a half hours before the race.

Now that Westchester County is said to have the finest parkways, recreation centers, bridle paths for horseback -riding and public golf courses in the country, the County Park Commission may go one step farther and build bicycle trails.

A campaign to induce the Board of Aldermen to repeal the 50 per cent increase in water rates has been started by civic, taxpayer and trade associations throughout the city, Clarke G. Dailey, president of the Real Estate Board of New York, announced yesterday.

Harold Whitford, 35 years old, of 235 East Fiftieth Street, field commissioner in charge of nature study for the Manhattan Council of the Boy Scouts of America, captured a three-foot rattlesnake in Harriman State Park yesterday afternoon after remaining perfectly still for thirty-five minutes before the coiled rattler decided not to strike.
The drive for the compulsory incorporation of labor unions "is contrived to embarrass and block unionization," it is charged in a bulletin published yesterday by

The Evergreen Farms quartet got off to a good start in the defense of its Eastern Palo League championship by conquering the South Shore Polo Club of Cedarhurst, L. I., 7 to 6,.today at the Monmouth County Country Club.

Dr. H. H. Kung, Chinese Minister of Finance and other members of the Chinese delegation to the Coronation in London in May are among the passengers due today on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary. Others coming on the ship from Southampton via Cherbourg are Sir Alexander George Wales, Lord Mayor of Melbourne; Mr.

Being master showmen well versed in the art of staging a major production at the proper time, the Yankees entertained baseball's largest crowd of the season at the Stadium yesterday by trampling over the White Sox in both ends of a double-header.

BOROFF--Mr. and Mrs. Harry Boroff (Julia Blaker) announce arrival of Alan's sister, Carol Linda, Jewish Hospital, Brooklyn. KONIGSBERG--Mr. and Mrs. Frank (nee Erma Baruch), announce the arrival of their daughter, Lynn, on June 19, at Doctors Hospital.

For the second successive year, Miss Norma Taubele won the New York State tennis championship yesterday. In a beautifully fought final staged before the largest crowd to turn out at the Jackson Heights Tennis Club in recent years, the left-handed New York girl defeated Miss Eunice Dean of San Antonio, Texas, 6-2, 6-4.

" There can be only one justification "for the modified form of martial law "which I have ordered to be put into "immediate effect. That is the main"tenance of law and order." With this theory of Governor EARLE none can fail to agree.

If the siege and fall of Bilbao ever finds its Homer, and he seeks a scene to convey all the terror and pity of the Spanish tragedy, no episode will serve his purpose better than what happened when the exiled Basque children in England heard the news of the capture of their city.

The Bethlehem Steel Corporation formally. "submitted" today to the order of Governor Earle to close its $50,000,000 Cambria plant and atop production therein, but stipulated that it did so "under duress" and reserved its rights to sue the State

James Louis Orton, British writer on the treatment of stammering, discussed the method yesterday on his arrival aboard the American Merchant of the United States Lines by which King George VI of England has largely overcome the speech impediment noticed in some of his addresses while Duke of York.

Officials, after viewing moving pictures of finishes in yesterday's National Collegiate A. A. track events, changed two results. Both were in the 120-yard high hurdles. Roy Staley, University of Southern California, was awarded second over Allan Tolmich, Wayne University.

More than 152,000 individually owned retail grocery stores in all parts of the country have just completed a major promotion in the industry and have succeeded in moving??a major agricultural surplus into consumptive channels, Charles E. Smith, president of the National Association of Retail Grocers, told members of the board of that association here at the Statler Hotel today.

Important legislation and hearings of more than local interest will contribute to a busy week for both houses of Congress. The Senate when it convenes at noon tomorrow is scheduled to take up the $1,500,000,000 relief measure and hopes to dispose of it promptly.

Lard futures here declined to a new low level for the season last week as the result of liquidation induced by the disappointing demand for the cash product and the slow reduction in local stocks. In the first half of June,

Roswell P. Rosengren of Buffalo, N. Y., has been elected president of the United States Junior Chamber of Commerce at the annual convention here. Ten regional vice presidents and ten directors were elected..

Dr. Francis E. Townsend, who believes elderly persons are entitled to retire on $200 a month, may get such a pension himself. A group of House members terming itself "the General Welfare Steering Committee," recommended today that Dr. Townsend and his wife each be retired "with honor" at that figure because he was the "original sponsor of the popular national old age pension movement."

Diplomatic inquiries made here over the week end have brought the disclosure that about 30,000 refugees, all non-combatants, have been taken from Bilbao during the last few weeks under the protection of British ships, supervised by the British Consul.

Corn planting has been completed over the main producing areas and reports indicate that the new crop is generally in good condition except in parts of Northern Iowa, where there has been considerable loss in acreage as the result of recent

A plea for greater cooperation among the Christian denominations was made yesterday by the Rev. Paul Keen in the first sermon preached in English at the Russian Cathedral of St. Nicholas, 15 East Ninety-seventh Street.
The capital outflow, already considerable, took on still larger proportions last week and on Monday the Bank of France raised its official discount rate 2 per cent, making it now 6 per cent.
The American delegation to the International Labor Conference defeated the Japanese delegation in a baseball game here today, 18 to 15.
Dr. Harry Woodburn Chase, chancellor of New York University, announced yesterday that the university had adopted a balanced budget for the eighth successive year.

So Irish Free State's general election campaign has been devoid Of any great enthusiasm or thrills. Both President de Valera and William Cosgrave, his opponent, have been facing audiences which are more critical than demonstrative.

Registration statements that became effective in May under the Securities Act of 1933 were for new securities with estimated gross proceeds of $238,068,000, compared with $288,076,000 in April, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today.
Chief WHITE HORSE EAGLE, who said he was 115 years old, is dead. He was one of several Indians who boasted
A 28-year-old man was shot dead accidentally in a shooting gallery at Rockaway Beach last night while chatting with a friend with whom he had engaged in a game of target practice.

The Rev. Arthur M. Elliott, former member of the New York Presbytery, died suddenly of a heart ailment in Chicago Saturday morning, it was learned here when Miss Gertrude Elliott, the minister's daughter, telephoned his home in Chicago yesterday to extend "Father's Day" greetings.

The marriage of Miss Mary Hartness Beardsley, daughter of Mrs. Anna Hartness Beardsley and the late Dr. William H. Beardsley of this place, to Francis T. Fenn Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis T. Fenn of Sunset Farms, West Hartford, Conn., took place here yesterday afternoon at Hartness House, the home of the bride's mother.
Billy Belden of Bedford Hills and Miss Mildred Rohrig of Yonkers annexed two blues apiece at the second annual one-day amateur Lawrence Farms Horse Show, held on the club grounds today.

With information indicating that approximately half of the woolen and worsted yard goods entering into the manufacture of women's and children's apparel is not preshrunk, the National Better Business Bureau announced yesterday

The Federal Government, through the Veterans Bureau, expects to care for 400,000 cases of cancer in the next twenty-five years, according to Dr. James Ewing of New York, pathologist and authority on cancer.

Both a crowd of 23,222 paying fans and the Pirates had to be content with an even break in today's double-header with the Dodgers. After Waite Hoyt. making his second start for Burleigh Grimes, had lost the opening decision to Joe Bowinan, 4-2, the Kelly Geehs bounced back to take the nightcap by the same' score.

A bitter denunciation of the non-intervention policy and the part Germany and Italy played in the attack on Bilbao was made by Julio Alvarez del Vayo, former Foreign Minister, in an interview today with THE NEW YORK TIMES correspondent and a few other journalists.

The contents of Samuel Insull's luxurious penthouse atop the Civic Opera Building will be sold at auction on Thursday and Friday. Admittance will cost $1. To get to the sale persons must go to the forty-first floor of the opera building, then transfer to what was once Mr. Insull's private elevator,

Dr. Thomas Parran, the Surgeon General, has dedicated his new book, "Shadow on the Land: Syphilis," to Governor Herbert H. Lehman, under whom he served three years as Commissioner of Health for New York State, and to whom he gives great credit for the spread of the control movement that he himself is now leading.

Although the ultimate desire of every Christian is to be able to see Jesus Christ everywhere, such an event would hold many dangers, for the world would undergo complete revolution, the Rev. Thomas Ayres Sparks said yesterday in a sermon at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

Imports of gold to Great Britain in May amounted to [pound]11,725,575, making the total for the first five months of this year [pound]135,914,859, against [pound]74,652,592 for the same period in 1936. Exports of the metal in May were [pound]21,658,848, bringing the total for the five months to [pound]108,915,488, against [pound]20,823,269 in the same part of last year.
Premier Mussolini today summoned 6,000 Fascist women to new tasks, which he said he hoped would be tasks of peace.
Fifteen government agencies awarded 154 supply contracts valued at $8,209,511 under the Public Contracts Act in the week ended on June 15, the Department of Labor announced today.

The Rev. Dr. A. Edwin Keigwin predicted in his sermon yesterday morning that a stronger and bettercoordinated church front would grow out of the World Conference on Faith and Order to be held in Edinburgh, Scotland, late this Summer.

Miss Mary Elizabeth Harris, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Charles W. Harris of this city, was married to Richard Booker Brandt, son of Mrs. Henry Brandt of Troy, Ohio, and the late Mr. Brandt, yesterday afternoon in Colton Memorial Chapel at Lafayette College.
Amelia Earhart set her silver monoplane down here in Central Java today at 10:17 A. M. 11:37 P. M. Sunday, Eastern daylight-saving time], completing a flight from Singapore on her globegirdling trip.

Mrs. Katheryn Marshall, wife of Brig. Gen. George C. Marshall, commanding officer at the Vancouver barracks, played hostessa little unexpectedly-today to the three fliers from Moscow who had dropped out of the skies on Pearson Field.

Annual conference of American Library Association begins at the Wald??rf-Astoria at 10 A. M. and continues all week. First general session tonight at 8:30; speakers, Mayor La Guardia, Frederick A. Stokes.

Government officials and stamp collectors begin a two-day conference here tomorrow to consider possible changes in the design and production of postage stamps. Under the auspices of the Washington Philatelic Society the conference will bring together collectors from all parts of the country to meet with representatives of Postmaster General Farley and Secretary Morgenthau.

The New York City Housing Authority announced yesterday that it would begin mailing today application blanks for apartments in Williamsburg houses. The blanks will go to more than 15,000 families that have requested them.

Having disposed of Princeton by an impressive 13-to-4 victory last Saturday, Yale will attempt to hurdie its last obstacle for the Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League championship when it meets the second-place Harvard nine in a two-game series this week.

The Blind Brook-Knights of Port Chester ushered in their Eastern Polo League campaign by conquering the Fort Hamilton quartet yesterday at the Fort Hamilton army reservation in Brooklyn. A crowd of 4,000 saw the visitors mark up eight goals in the latter half of the

That last week's financial markets should again have moved hesitantly, with stock market averages at one time reaching the lowest in twelve months, was a perfectly natural result of the very unpleasant turn which the labor war has taken, and of the somewhat more general doubt as to whether continuance of the siege of manufacturing plants may not cause more of recession in business than had heretofore been expected.

In the year since the Robinson-Patman act became law the Federal Trade Commission has conducted 291 investigations requiring field work and has issued twenty-two formal complaints in the 152 cases in which inquiries have been completed, the commission announced today in an anniversary statement.
Interest in Summer merchandise was sustained in the wholesale market here last week, although manufacturers in a number of lines directed their attention to midseason and early Fall items.

The necessity of reaffirming a "more heroic doctrine" than security as the goal of life was emphasized this morning by President Harold Willis Dodds of Princeton University, in delivering the baccalaureate address of Princeton's 190th commencement week in the university chapel before more than 2,000 seniors, alumni, faculty members and parents.

A certain amount of light on the causes of the fall of Bilbao is furnished by an article in The New Statesman which an editorial note explains comes from a special correspondent who left there last week after being in the city three weeks.

147th St, 205 W, 37.6x100; Adolph Friedmann and wife to Epoch Realty Corp, 215 W 145th St ($9). Broome St, 112, 25x87.6: Fayhan Realty Corp to Clifford-Davidson Corp, 21 E 40th St (50 cents). Hudson St, 116, 22x75: Caroline M. Etzel to Edward S. McSweeney, 829 Park Ave, mtg $19,000.

The Indians overcame a five-run lead today to beat the Red Sox, 8 to 7, in the second game of a twin bill after Boston had captured the opener, 5 to 2, for its sixth consecutive victory in the longest winning streak of the team since Joe Cronin became manager in 1935.
Market closed lower on week, after brief rally on steel mediation news; turnover, 5,102,942 shares. All classes of bonds lower; transactions, $42,722,700.

The National Labor Relations Board will conduct a hearing itarting today at 10 A. M. at the State Office Building, 80 Center Street, on an application of the International Seamen's Union for an election by the crews of seventy-five ship lines operated from Atlantic and Gulf ports to determine their labor bargaining agency.
Groups of Basque child refugees, grief-stricken and fearful of their parents' fate in Bilbao, continued to break away from their camp here. today.

Governor Earle will fly to Johnstown at 9 o'clock tomorrow morning "to look over" the steel strike situation. Mr. Earle said that he intended to stay in Johnstown for only an hour and return immediately to the capitol.

Weather markets in wheat are notoriously erratic affairs and price fluctuations last week were unusually rapid without the price level getting very far in either direction. An early bulge based on reports of drought damage in the southern half of the Province of Saskatchewan was followed by a rapid dedine when parts of the dry territory received beneficial rains.

Ashton C. Lawrence, formerly for many years a member of the New York Stock Exchange, died yesterday at his residence, 197 Clinton Avenue, New Brighton, S. I., after a fortnight's illness at the age of 76. He was a son of the late Charles Edward Lawrence and Leila Homeyard Lawrence.

Halsted H. Wainwright, dean of the Monmouth County bar, died this morning in a Philadelphia hospital following a six weeks' illness. His age was 82. He had practiced law at his offices here since 1878, when the borough was known as Squan village.

To encourage tourist travel to Alaska the Federal Government will start by July 15 construction in Mount McKinley National Park of a hotel affording a view of the continent's highest mountain peak, the Department of the Interior announced today.

An appraisal conference will be held by New Jersey Chapter 1, American Institute of Real Estate Appraisers, on Friday and Saturday at the Berkeley-Carteret Hotel, Asbury Park, N. J. E. J. Maier is president of the chapter.
Dizzy Dean and Lon Warneke held the Boston Bees to nine hits in a twin bill today, and by winning both games the Cardinals took over second place, four points ahead of the New York Giants.

Tension increased in Trinidad's oil fields tonight as sit-down strikes spread to embrace workers in almost every oil area. Heavily armed police and deputized volunteers patrolled Fyzabad, where an English police inspector and a native corporal were killed last night.

Encouraging reports for the foreign trade of the United States in the first quarter of the current year caused the Chamber of Commerce of the United States today to issue a statement pointing to these gains as-emphasizing "the remarkable recovery that has taken place since the low point of the depression."
Twelve balloons soared into the dusk tonight in the twenty-fifth Gordon Bennett Race. Nearly 100,000 persons cheered the competitors on their way.

A suplemental summary of additional transactions in equity securities by officers, directors and principal stockholders in April, with some deplayed reports for earlier months, was issued today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A year ago we were told to vote for Roosevelt because he "kept us out of chaos." Back in 1932-so the 1936 propaganda went-the country would have dissolved in a series of riots, had it not been for his "leadership."

Declaring that world conditions are "a reflection of the individual souls- that make up the world," the Rev. Robert E. Woods, preaching yesterday at high mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral, warned against "the common vices of pride and anger" as the basic causes of war.

Prince Charming II, aged bay son of Teddy, sire of Gallant Fox, owned by Edwin V. Quinn of Shrewsbury, N. J., and the outstanding champion of the show ring two years ago, scored another triumph today in his successful comeback.

Invitations have been sent out by officers of the Belgian League of Honor in the United States, and several affiliated organizations for a tea and reception for the Prime Minister of Belgium and Mrs. Paul van Zeeland to be held on June 29 in the Embassy suite of the Ambassador.

Counsel for the Radio Corporation of America will appear before the Federal Communications Commission tomorrow to oppose an appli- re cation by the Mackay interests for approval of an agreement with the Italian Government to provide radio service from the United States by way of Italy-to Central Europe and the Mediterranean area.

Fanned along by a light southeasterly breeze over an almost smooth sea, Harold S. Vanderbilt's Ranger continued her unbroken string of victories today in the observation trials to choose the America's Cup defender.

Robert G. Goodman, personnel and financial secretary of the Y. M. C. A. in New York since 1931, died here today at his home, 121 Midland Avenue, at the age of 54. A native of Toledo, Ohio, Mr. Goodman was graduated in 1910. from Wesleyan University, where he was elected to Delta Epsilon and Phi Mi Theta.

The Rev. William L. Whalen and the Rev. Henry P. Cunningham of the Roman Catholic Order of Preachers, celebrated a silver jubilee mass in commemoration of their twenty-fifth anniversary of ordination, at the Church of St. and Lexington Avenue, yesterday morning. A 200-girl choir of St. Vincent's School sang the mass.

Miss Polly Goodrich, daughter of Mrs. Frank Edward Cone of North Steele Road, West Hartford, has announced the plans for her wedding on July 9 to Arthur W. Gregory Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur W. Gregory of Hartford. The Rev. William T. Hooper will perform the ceremony in St. John's Church here.

A plot 200 by 152 feet at the southwest corner of Franklin and Stewart Avenues, opposite Best Co., in Garden City, L. I., has been purchased by Stephen Properties, Inc., Marcel Weiss, president, from the Royal Indemnity Insurance Company.

Ralph M. Easley, chairman of the executive council of the National Civic Federation, who has written to President Roosevelt, charging Communist and other political. influences in the Federal relief program, turned yesterday to charges of wasteful practices in the WPA.

The large residence containing eleven rooms owned by George I. Tyson at Riverside, Conn., has been purchased by Marquard H. Lund, associated with the Waring Central Company, stationers and printers of this city.

The Social Security Board today made public a progress report as of June 1, which took account of its approval on that date of the New York plan for aid to dependent children, estimated to benefit 65,500 children, and the State's aid to needy blind, estimated at 3,700 persons.

Miss Mary A. Cashin, sister of Mgr. William E. Cashin, rector of St. Andrew's Church, 27 Duane Street, this city, and former chapplain of Sing Sing prison, died yesterday at Maryknoll, N. Y. She was an aunt of Sister Mary Helen, Foreign Mission Sister of the Order of St. Dominic.

Officers of the Soviet Embassy today expressed their thanks to various agencies of the United States and Canadian Governments for their cooperation and help, especially in providing weather reports which were essential to the success 'of the Moscow-Vancouver flight.

" The man who has power and uses it only for himself is a mean man," said the Rev. Dr. Frederick W. Norwood, former minster of City Temple, London, and present special evangelist of the -National Free Church Council of Great Britain, in his sermon yesterday morning at the Riverside Church, Riverside Drive and 122d Street.
Salo Flohr of Czechoslovakia today took the lead in the international chess masters' tournament here by defeating the Latvian player, H. Berg, in the fourth round. It was Berg's first setback.

Princeton University's annual senior promenade, the final social event here for the class of '37, will be held tomorrow evening in the university gymnasium. The program will climax a full program of Class Day exercises. The list of 125 feminine guests follows:

" No thinking person Will deny that in many sections Ameraca has gone stark pagan," the Rev Dr. William Ward Ayer, pastor of Calvary Baptist Church, 123 West Fifty-seventh Street, declared in his sermon last evening.

The third resident session of the Graduate SChool of Banking, under sponsorship of the American Bankers Association, will begin tomorrow at Rutgers University and continue until July 2. An enrollment of 593 bank executives from forty-six States, the District of Columbia and Puerto Rico will attend.
In contrast to yesterday's blustery going, Long Island Sound turned around today and offered nothing much to speak of in the way of wind for the special regatta of the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club.

John J. Miller, a partner in the forty-year-old New York firm of Maddock Miller, 129 Fifth Avenue, importers of English china and chinaware, died here yesterday at his home, 161 Park Street, after a long illness, at the age of 73.

At baccalaureate services at Smith College today, President Neilson addressed the 437 students who will receive degrees tomorrow. In keeping with Smith traditions, the service was for the seniors only. The Smith College Symphony Orchestra gave a concert in the

Representatives of the poultry industry asked Commissioner of Public Markets William Fellowes Morgan yesterday to advocate city-constructed union terminal stockyards for poultry. The municipal yards would end overcharges and abuses, the spokesmen said.
The annual commencement exercises of the Ardsley School for Girls were held this afternoon at Masonic Temple at Dobbs Ferry, with the valedictory address being delivered by Miss Gloria A. Tamor.

George Kenyon, 35 years old, of 88 Gilden Street, New Brunswick, and Henry Buengener, also 35, of 65 Munn Avenue, Newark, signal men employed by the Pennsylvania Railroad, were struck by an incoming passenger train in the Newark station tonight and killed instantly.

An important investment deal on the West Side has just been closed in the purchase by the Vanderbilt Estates, of which Louis Schleifer is president, of the nine-story elevator apartment house at 120 West Seventieth Street, between Columbus Avenue and Broadway.

Methods of reproducing music, music library personnel and music cataloguing will be discussed at a two-day meeting of the Music Library Association at Columbia University tomorrow and Wednesday. There will be a joint session with the American Library Association
A success such as that of the three Russian aviators who flew across the North Pole to the American Pacific Coast is possible only under socialism, declared the Moscow press tonight.

The tactical exercises of the 303d Chemical Regiment with the officers of the Seventy-eighth Division, the First Chemical Regiment and the camouflage battalion of the Fortieth Engineers were held here today.

In the week's markets here, sentiment improved and stocks were firmer for the most part. The announcement of Foreign Minister von Neurath's impending visit to London had a soothing effect, which the Moscow executions, so far from weakening, rather strengthened, inasmuch as optimists imagine that the prospect of detaching Western Europe from its Soviet associations has been enhanced.
Manuel L. Quezon, President of the Philippines, who arrived here yesterday, left Havana with his party tonight by steamship for Miami, where he will entrain tomorrow to go to Washington.

The German wholesale price index on June 9 was 106.1, unchanged from a week before. In the first five months of 1937 Germany's wholesale price index ranged between 106.2 on March 17 and 105.2 in the first week of January.

Although in its earlier stages the fortnightly Stock Exchange account just conCluded was thoroughly gloomy, it ended on a much brighter note. One by one the obstacles to recover seem to be fading slowly into the background.
Soviet Russia's three transpolar fliers brought their huge monoplane to earth at 8:22 A. M., Pacific time, today [12:22 P. M. Eastern daylight-saving time] at the army airport at Vancouver, Wash.

Adam Metz, president of the Bakers Mutual Insurance Company of New York and chairman of the bondholders' reorganization committee for Prudence-Bonds Corporation twelfth series, announced yesterday that a 7 per cent cash distribution would be made to bondholders.

Mr. and Mrs. Albert Spalding and their guests at Aston Magna, Mr. and Mrs. Hudson Stroe and Miss Marion H. Beckett, were the honor guests at a dinner party given tonight by Mr. and Mrs. Adolf A. Berle Jr. at Konkapot.

For the second time in her screen career Joan Blondell will venture fror the Warner fold, this time to assume the dual roles of star and stand-in in Clarence Budington Kelland's "Stand-In," scheduled to face the Walter Wanger cameras on June 28.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. John Fulton Folinsbee of this place of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Joan Baldwin Folinsbee, to Peter G. Cook, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas G. Cook of Heathcote Farm, Kingston, N. J. The announcement was made this afternoon at a tea at the Folinsbee home.

The Wimbledon championships, which will decide the succession to the tennis throne made vacant by the abdication of Fred Perry, will open tomorrow. Donald Budge of the United States and Baron Gottfried von Cramm of Germany, it is generally believed, will decide it between themselves, just as it is taken for granted that the Davis Cup will be taken from a sadly weakened British team by either the American or German side in July.

The fall of the Basque capital Saturday, after what, in effect, was a nine-month siege, to the forces of the Spanish Insurgents with their overwhelming supremacy in the air, is a staggering but not necessarily decisive blow to the Loyalist cause.

The Federal Symphony Orchestra, directed by Eugene Plotnikoff, presented a program of varied compositions at the WPA Theatre of Music last night. The soloist was Jean Schwiller, 'cellist, who was heard in Boellman's Symphonic Variations.

The Duke and Duchess of.Windsor unexpect.edly left Wasserleonburg at 3 P. M. today by automobile, arriving at the Hotel Bristol here at 9:15 o'clock. On their arrival it was stated that they had no program for the evening as they were tired after the journey.
Representative John W. McCormack of Boston urged the fishing industry of the United States, "particularly of New England," today to participate in New York's World Fair in 1939.

" Liberty is safe only when the Lord of Conscience is none lower than the just God of the universe," the Rev. Dr. Henry Sloane Coffin, president of Union Theological Seminary, told the graduating class of Wellesley College in his baccalaureate sermon in the Memorial Chapel this morning.

In an effort to tighten control over misleading advertising of linen, the Linen Trade Association has appealed to the Federal Trade Commission to call a trade practice conference, at which rules covering advertising violations will be laid down, according to Harry Radcliff, secretary of the trade group. A meeting with officials of the commission will be held this week to prepare the groundwork for the conference.

Three ministers formerly associated with the Park Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Eighty-fifth Street, assisted the Rev. Edmund M. Wylie yesterday in conducting a service which may be the congregation's last under its present name.

The National Socialist regime struck back at the papacy with all its might today, announcing through Adolf Wagner, the Minister of the Interior in Bavaria, the suppression of all Catholic public schools in that State--probably the most
