After three years of effort, delay has been "substantially eliminated in the courts of New York State," according to Frederick E. Crane, Chief Judge of the Court of Appeals and chairman of the Judicial Council of the State of New York.

The Rev. Otto George Gerbich, pastor of St. Peter's 'Lutheran Church, 439 East 140th Street, in his sermon yesterday warned the fathers of his congregation that they must not expect to be honored by their children unless they accepted the responsibilities of their position.
Mr. and Mrs. Austen Fox Riggs of The Knoll, Stockbridge, Mass., will come to the Carlyle today. Mr. and Mrs. Howard Brougham Major of Palm Beach will arrive today at the Pierre.

The "owner's stamp" of Jesus Christ is a mark of honor and should be in evidence in every Christian home, the Rev. John King Benedict said yesterday morning in a sermon at the Father's Day service held in the Centenary Methodist Church, Washington Avenue and 166th Street, the Bronx.

Twelve huge navy flying boats soared from fog-shrouded San Diego Bay today on a projected non-atop flight to the Coco Solo naval base in the Panama Canal Zono, 3,060 miles distant. Officers said the purpose was a routine delivery of equipment.

State librarianships as political perquisites have descended to a point where a beauty contest winner in one Southern Commonwealth captured the position with no additional qualifications, Dr. James I. Wyer of Albany, director of the New York State.Library, said yesterday in a sectional gathering held in conjunction with the .convention of the American Library Association here.
Deputy chiefs shall make final returns for tickets for the baseball game between the Police and Fire Departments, on Tuesday, June 29.

Because it is impossible to repair any of the seven bridges blown up between Bilbao and Portugalete, about seven miles north, rapidly enough to enable the Insurgents to press their pursuit of the. Basques toward Santander, two pontoon bridges were completed today and more are being constructed to transfer artillery and supply trucks to the western bank of the Nervion River.

Mr. and Mrs. Henry V. Matthews of this city announced today the engagement of their daughter, Miss Phyliss Eleanor Matthews, to Milton Harvey Clark, second lieutenant, U.S.A. The wedding will take place early in July.
Comparately few persons appeared today at the Atlantic City National Bank and the Chelsea Second National Bank, which began their first distributions of money to depositors since they closed in 1993.
Movements of vessels follow, all dates are June 19, unless specified: Pearl Harbor to San Diego: Breese, Gamble, Ramsay.

Announcement of the marriage of Miss Margaret Pierce to John Andrew Kenyon has been made by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Leolie M. Pierce of Philadelphia. The bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. J. T. P. Kenyon of Maplewood.
The Adjutant General issued the following orders today: COMMISSIONS Morris, 2d Lt. Daniel R., to the 107th Infantry for assignment to Headquarters Company. First Batt.

In order to overcome the usual apathy of employes to house organs, a livelier approach to organization news features the latest issue of the Seagram Spotlight, issued by Seagram Distillers, Inc., according to Walter M. Swertfager, director of advertising.

Labor difficulties in parts factories and in automobile shops hampered automobile production last week, and the adjusted index declined to 115.0 from 121.8. This compares with 102.6 for the week ended June 20, 1936.

The first of eight district health centers to be opened this year in the city's plan to establish thirty such units over a period of ten years was dedicated yesterday by Health Commissioner John L. Rice at 158-164 East 115th Street.

President J. Edgar Park conferred degrees on seventy-seven graduates at Wheaton College this morning, three of them magna cum laude, and five of them cum laude, and announced that the gifts to the college during the 'year totaled $66,000.
Tens of thousands of gayly garbed Shriners frolicked in Detroit today, awaiting the formal opening tomorrow of the imperial council of their mystic order.

WASHINGTON, June 21.--Administration forces in the Senate defeated today both efforts to restrict expenditure under the $1,500,000,000 Relief Bill, which will go to the President virtually in the form he requested.
A Japanese textile mission--which is considered generally as the first evidence of a desire for closer Anglo-Japanese cooperation-arrived in London today
The United Automobile Workers of Americs delivered to General Motors Corporation today a list of demands the union is seeking in a revision of its contract with the corporation.

The Rev. Joseph H. Dineen, president of St. Peter's College, this city, was transferred today to Wernersville, Pa., as rector of the Jesuit Novitiate of St. Jogues. He was succeeded at noon by the Very Rev. Dennis J. Comey, as president of St. Peter's College, the Hudson College of Commerce and Finance, the evening division of St. Peter's;

A trip to Europe was won yesterday by Carlo Leonetti, 53 West Forty-sixth Street, as first prize in the Tudor City tulip contest. Eighty-eight painters submitted oils and water-colors in the competition, which was judged by John Sloan, Walter Pach, and William >Glackens. All of the paintings portrayed the gardens at Tudor City.

St. Francis Preparatory, 41 Butler Street, Brooklyn, will hold its seventy-ninth commencement at 8 o'clock tonight at Bishop McDonnell Memorial High School, Classon Avenue and Eastern Parkway, Mgr. Patrick J. Cherry of St. Michael's Roman Catholic Church, will preside. The address will be by Leo J. Hickey, United States Attorney.

Since October, 1935, the Standard Gas and Electric Company group has eliminated 195 interlocking positions in an effort to decentralize the main holding company and place more responsibility on the operating units, Bernard W. Lynch, president, said today in connection with a statement on earnings.

Hypothetical flames swept Indedendence Hall today in a demonstration of fire'-fighting apparatus of a century and a half ago for delegates to the annual convention of the National Association of Insurance Commissioners.

President Roosevelt promulgated today a code of fair competition for the bituminous coal industry under the Guffey Act. All producers of bituminous coal in interstate commerce are subject to its provisions, which are designed to prevent price cutting and unfair competition.

Secretary Morgenthau announced tonight that the Treasury had accepted tenders for $50,120,000 for the 273-day Treasury bills offered on last Friday, and that the bids called for an average interest rate of about 0.578 per cent.

Earl Baldwin of Bewdley, who three weeks ago relinquished the post of Prime Minister, has undertaken a new task based on an unprecedented tribute to him-the administering of a [Pound]250,000 fund presented by an anonymous donor as a thank offering for the manner in which he handled the abdication crisis.

Princeton University will confer 527 advanced and baccalaureate degrees tomorrow morning at its 190th annual commencement exercises on the lawn in front of historic Nassau Hall, with more than 8,000 persons in -attendance. In event of rain the exercises will take place in the university chapel.

Turpentine firm, 33 1/2c: sales, 137 barrels; receipts. 530 barrels; shipments, 1,125 barrels; stock, 27.887 barrels. Resin firm: sales, 675: receipts, 1,789; shipments, 2,746; stock, 58,190. Quote: B. D, $7.65; E. F. G. H. 1. K, $7,75; M, $7.80; N, $7.85; WG, $7.90; ww, X, $8.85.

The trial of six men accused by Special Prosecutor Thomas E. Dewey of racketeering in the baking industry was postponed yesterday when it was called before Justices William R. Bayes, Max Solomon and Bernard A. Kozicke of the Court of Special Sessions.

An earthquake which, witnesses said, cracked strong walls and turned crosses on church belfries shook the coast of Peru today. Reports from villages 300 miles north of Lima described the quake as "very long."
Miss Mary Catherine Odium, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Thomas Odlum of Unionville, was married there this forenoon to Cornelius Francis O'Connell,

Prices on the Cotton Exchange advanced $1 a bale yesterday when a concentrated short interest covered a line estimated at between 40,000 and 50,000 bales and the list ended with gains of 11 to 15 points.
The Maritime Commission today rejected all bids for the charter for one year of six government-owned shipping lines operating thirtyseven vessels.

Sales of copper in the export market were made late yesterday as low as 13.3 cents a pound, c. i. f., European base ports. It was reported that offerings were comparatively heavy at the low price, which was established following a break in prices on the London Metal Exchange.

The Norris bill to create seven regional power and conservation authorities "makes power secondary to navigation and flood control all the time," Senator George W. Norris of Nebraska testified at the opening of hearings today before a Senate agriculture subcommittee.

Under blue skies and in the warm June sunshine the Portuguese liner Mocambique steamed up Dublin Bay today bringing back Generar Owen O'Duffy's Irish Brigade after its seven months of campaigning in Spain with General Francisco Franco's Insurgent army.

Manor Ave (14-3743), e s. 100 ft s of Westchester Ave, 66x101: Rodry Realty Corp to Alix Infeld, 1,506 Hoe Ave; mtg, $75,000. Fox St (10-2707), w s, 200 ft n of 156th St, 100x100; Geneve Courts, Inc, to Limited Equities, Inc, 349 E 149th St; mtg, $114,600. Beach Ave (15-3899), e s, 200 ft s of Archer St, 75x92; Gil-Sol Realty Corp to 1,460 Beach Ave Corp, 1,615 University Ave; mtg, $68,000.

A return to democracy was predicted by Charles P. Taft, chairman of the new Special Steel Mediation Board, in an address read to the graduation class of Rochester University in his absence, by President Alan Valentine.

Three Toronto men were killed instantly. today when their airplane plunged from 1,000 feet into a wheat field in Blanchord Township, seven miles west of here. Found dead by farmers were Arthur Leavens, 34, pilot and coowner of the plane; Charles Sockett, 28, and A. L.'Ogden, passengers. Leavens and his brother operated a taxiplane service out of Toronto.
The Cabinet, in extraordinary session and in communication with President Manuel Azafia, today considered the implication of the "evacuation" of Bilbao.

The Federal Steel Mediation Board's efforts to settle the month-old strike affecting about 100,000 steel workers in seven States collapsed tonight when the operators, led by Tom M. Girdler, chairman of the board of the Republic Steel Corporation,

Daniel Carter Beard, National Boy Scout Commissioner, celebrated his eighty-seventh birthday today with a buffet luncheon party on the porch of Brooklands, his home here. The elderly Scout leader, known to Scouting as "Uncle Dan," received hundreds of letters, telephone calls and telegrams congratulating him and wishing him well.
Governor Harry W. Nice literally watched his right eye removed today in an operation at the Johns Hopkins Hospital here.

In a letter to Representative John Luecke of Michigan, William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, expressed apprehension over "an evil influence which has caused groups of newly organized workers connected with the C. I. O. to follow a destructive policy."

The most striking thing about our life at the present time is its instability, Dr. Charles H. McIlwain, Harvard professor and retiring president of the American Historical Association, said today in the commencement address at Williams College.

To avoid repetition of last October's sanguinary rioting in the East End, when 100,000 anti-Fascists blocked a procession by 5,000 uniformed Black Shirts, the government decided today to prohibit all political processions for the next six weeks in eight of London's East End boroughs.

In compliance with a recent order of the Brooklyn Federal Court, Theodore Stitt, official bankruptcy receiver, announced yesterday that he had sent out checks for $34,821 to creditors of the defunct private banking firm of J. Lehrenkrauss Sons of Brooklyn.

This week will see two of the most spectacular events in college sport: the intercollegiate regatta at Poughkeepsie, scheduled for today, and the Yale-Harvard boat race on the Thames at New London on Friday.

Heroism displayed in rescuing a dog from a ledge overlooking a steep embankment has won a medal for Police Lieutenant James Boyle. The American Humane Society has granted the award, it was announced today by William Bevan, president of the Westchester County Animal Protective League.

New problems in the insurance field created by activities of the Federal Government were pictured to the convention of the National Association of Insurance Commissioners today by George W. Bowles, the Virginia commissioner.

BORLAND-On Sunday, June 20, Margaret Wynne, beloved aunt of Alexander M. Christie. Funeral service in the Chapel of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, 5th Ave. and 55th St., Tuesday, June 22, 2 P. M. Interment Greenwood Cemetery. BROWN--Robert Rankins. The Executive Committee of the New York Southern Society announces with deep regret the death on June 17 of Robert Rankins Brown, a member of the Society.

Deliveries of airplanes, engines and aircraft equipment in the first five months of 1937 reached a new high record for such a period, it was announced yesterday by Leighton W. Rogers, president of the Aeronautical Chamber of Commerce of America.

Dr. Clyde Lyndon King, for seventeen years Professor of Political Science in the Wharton School of the University of Pennyslvania, died unexpectedly today at his home in West Town at the age of 58. Although he had been suffering with heart disease for a year, his condition had improved to such an extent that he was going ahead with plans to teach at the university's Summer school.

General Francisco Franco's campaign against the Basques has run a somewhat different course to that of previous offensives in the Spanish civil war. In the progress achieved it may seem to contradict the evidence which these afforded of the continued superiority of defense over attack on land under modern conditions.

Marking another milestone the 2,500,000th cubic yard of concrete was .placed the other day in Grand Coulee Dam, being constructed by the Bureau of Reclamation on the Columbia River in Eastern Washington. This amount of concrete would build a four-foot sidewalk completely around the United States and is but one item in the building of the project, which is the biggest dam ever undertaken.- anywhere at any time by man; says the Interior D'epartment.

Sixty years ago the American Library Association held its first conference in New York. Sixty librarians were registered. Approximately sixty times sixty librarians will be in attendance upon the meetings being held

Under a gray, sullen sky that ocasionally spilled rain, the crews of even colleges "let her run" tolight, lifted their shells from the vater and racked them for the last ime this year-for the last time unil some of them come home with argoes of shirts and victory
John Charles Thomas, Metropolftan Opera baritone, will be the soloist at the third outdoor concert of the Essex County Symphony Society in the Newark Stadium tonight. Erno Rapee conducts the series.

Summer reorders, while numerous, did not increase appreciably in the wholesale markets here yesterday, with indications that the wholesale season has now passed its peak. At the same time, however, the number of buyers here for August sales merchandise increased.
Premier Benito Mussolini sent this telegram today to the Spanish Insurgent generalissimo, Francisco Franco, captor of Bilbao:

Harvard's tour crews had a twomile time-trial this evening. Head Coach Tom Bolles said it was the last time-trial for the eights before the regatta on Friday. The crews paddled to the twomile flags and were lined up evenly for the test upstream.

Faw W. Danford, Monroe County Republican leader and for four years Justice of the Peace of Brighton, died yesterday after an illness of several years. He was 59 years old. Mr. Danford underwent a lung operation on May 24.

One hundred years and one day since the accession of Queen Victoria, Lawrence Housman's "Victoria Regina" was allowed to be presented for the first time to the public tonight. Her great-grandson, the Duke of Kent, and the Duchess were present at the showing in the Lyric Theatre.

Still a game-and-a-half in front of the second-place Tigers, the Yankees will launch a three-game series with Rogers Hornsby's Browns at the Stadium today, preparatory to meeting the week-end invasion of the Detroit club.

The light-hearted Duke and Ducnessof Windsor returned tonight to the Viennese night clubs which they enjoyed last year on a vacation cruise before their marriage. The couple lunched at the British Legation, went shopping during the afternoon, and then went dancing. Chatting gaily, they swung around to old Viennese tunes and to American jazz during visits to restaurant and night clubs.

More than 350 persons attended the testimonial dinner last night in honor of William A. Clarke, principal of John Adams High School, Queens, at the Hotel Commodore. William F. Brunner, president of the Board of Aldermen; State Senator Joseph D. Nunan Jr., Assemblyman Maurice A. Fitzgerald,

Mrs. Marion Turpie started the defense of her Long Island golf title auspiciously today by ripping off a 78, one over women's par, at the Women's National Golf and Tennis Club to lead the field of fortyfive entrants.

Air and railroad lines operating between New York and Chicago found it necessary to supplement their regular service in order to accommodate the last-minute rush of fight fans planning to attend the heavyweight title contest between James J. Braddock and Joe Louis in Chicago tonight, according to announcements from passenger offices yesterday.

Hiram C., Samuel J. and Mrs. Rita G. Bloomingdale of New York'City asked the Board of Tax Appeals today to redetermine deficiencies in gift taxes for 1934, aggregating to $122,491, assessed on them by the Internal Revenue Bureau.

Monge, a black Newfoundland dog, and the twenty-three members of the crew of the fishing schooner Pauline E. Lohnes, which during a fog on the Grand Banks last Thursday was sunk by the Belgian steamship Jean Jadot, were landed yesterday morning when the steamship docked at the India Wharf at the foot of North Pier Street,
Ten attendants escorted Miss Beverly Ayers to the altar of the Episcopal Church of the Ascension tonight for her wedding to John Clement Van Orden, son of Mr. and Mrs. Clarence Van Orden of Union.

Miss Josephine Roche, Assistant Secretary of the Treasury, summoned the graduating class of 308 Wellesley seniors today to join the men and women who are pioneering on a new frontier, "the frontier of human relations."

The Reconstruction Finance Corporation has in its possession, as part of its collateral for a loan in 1932 to the Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railroad, $100,000 in first mortgage 5 per cent bonds of the Rock Island Dardanelle Railroad Company,

Labor makes a serious mistake when it assumes that it must resort to violation of law and high-handed methods to obtain its share of its product for hire, Henry H. Heimann, executive manager of the National Association of Credit Men, said today at the association's forty-second annual convention, which opened here and will continue through Thursday.
So much of paragraph 3, Special Orders 117. dated May 20, 1937, as relates to the following second lieutenants, Infantry Reserve, is revoked:
WASHINGTON, June 21.--John L. Lewis outlined today his plans for bringing more than 800,000 civilian government employes into "one big union," to be known as the United Federal Workers of America.

A new child labor amendment, authorizing Congress to forbid commercial employment of persons under 16 years of age, reached the Senate floor today. Offered by Senator Vandenberg of Michigan, it received the unanimous endorsement of the Senate Judiciary Committee.

Peter Bold, who celebrated his one hundredth birthday on Dec. 31, died last night at his home here. Mr. Bold fought in the Civil War and voted for Abraham Lincoln. He had been ill for eleven years with a heart ailment.

Mr. and Mrs. Hobart Hayes Putnam will give a tea on Saturday at their home on Center Island, Oyster Bay, to introduce to society their daughter, Miss Jeanne Putnam, a member of this year's graduating class at the Finch School.

A spokesman for the Association of American Railroads contended today that the recent imposition of pension and unemployment taxes was an added reason for allowing Class I carriers a general increase in freight rates.
Dr. Louis Kaufman of the Fifth Avenue Hospital, New York City, has purchased the residence formerly owned by Helen Lowell on Main Street, Norwalk, Conn., through the G. LeRoy Kemp Company, brokers.

Harry Frankel; secretary and treasurer of Local 167 of the Chicken Drivers Union, was found guilty of usury in the Court of Special Sessions yesterday. He was convicted on fourteen of sixteen counts in an information filed against him by Thomas E. Dewey, special racket prosecutor.

One of the most modern private dwellings on the East Side, the sixstory residence at 44 East Seventyfirst Street, between Madison and Park Avenues, has been sold for the estate of Katherine Stone Hoyt, of which Robert G. Stone is executor, to a syndicate known as the 44 East Seventy-first Street Corporation.

Gross assets, $12,210; net, $9,371. To Irving Krantz, $1,000; Lena M. Schwartz, residuary estate. Chief assets, stocks and bonds, $606; mortgages, notes, cash and insurance, $11,598. Furst, Schwartz, Schwager Landau, attorneys, 130 Clinton St.
Robert K. Beach, secretary, treasurer and general manager of The Jamestown Post, died in Buffalo General Hospital this afternoon after an illness of several months. His age was 71.
A woman was killed and two persons were critically injured about 11 o'clock last night on the Grand Central Parkway at Winchester Boulevard, Queens Village, in a head-on collision.
Market slightly lower in slowest trading since March, 1935; turnover, 423,950 shares. United States Government bonds fractionally lower, other issues firm ' and quiet; transactions, $5,430,900.
All was quiet here tonight on the steel strike front as the second day of martial law which closed the Cambria plant of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation drew to a close.

With dealings in the franc yesterday in the foreign exchange market so small as practically to preclude any radical change in price, the French currency was held steady by the official control, despite the resignation of Leon Blum and his Cabinet.
The Cabinet met this morning under Premier Benito Mussolini's chairmanship and approved three measures, which will result in a considerably added burden for the Treasury.

Rain today prevented Yale from taking its final practice for tomorrow's baseball game with Harvard, which will be played before a commencement day crowd of about 8,000. Coach Joe Wood of the Elis nominated Ted Horton to pitch the 178th contest of the series begun

The largest class in the history of Amherst College, numbering 189 candidates for the Bachelor of Arts degree, was graduated this morning at the 118th commencement exercises, with the usual pageantry and academic procession, formed at the Converse Memorial Library and marched across to College Hall, led by High Sheriff Beckman of Hampshire County and the commencement marshal, Russell L, Davenport, '12, of Holyoke.

Despite a sharp decline in the number 'of accidents and persons killed or injured over the week-end on the streets of the city, the accident and injured rate for the entire week rose as compared with figures of the corresponding week of 1936, First Deputy Police Commissioner Harold Fowler announced yesterday.

From the British point of view, b the short-term problem of "what to C do about gold" presents little diffi- p culty. On the contrary, here is a s strong case for making no early change in the present monetary policy of the British Government not to reduce the sterling price of gold, according to a leading article in The Economist of London for June 12.

Business failures in the United States totaled 166 for the week ended June 17, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday. The figure is five above the total for the week before but compares with 192 for the corresponding period a year ago.

The 3,767 electrical wholesalers in the United States in -1935 had net sales of $1,109,404,000 and total expenses, including payroll, of $142,879,000, according to announcement yesterday by William L. Austin, director of the Bureau of the Census, in connection with publication of the special trade report of the census of business on electrical wholesaling in 1935.

Declaring that the problem of "internal peace, like that of international peace, depends for solution on our ability to translate into practice the principles of democracy and social justice to which we all give lip service," Dr. James G.

When Alexander Dean's South Shore Players start their season on July 3 at Cohasset, Mass., it will be with Peter Arno, temporarily an actor, playing the leading role in John van Druten's "Most of the Game." John J. Wildberg, Mr.

A tentative draft of rules and regulations for the over-the-counter markets, intended as the first step in a program aimed at the use of manipulative, deceptive or other fraudulent devices by brokers or dealers, has been completed by the Securities and Exchange Commission, and probably will be sent to the industry this week for criticism and comment.

Federal army policing of the Rio Grande do Sul State Assembly was abrogated today by President Getulio Vargas. As the result of strife between Rio Grande do Sul political factions a month ago the State Assembly asked the Federal army to guard it. Brazil then was under the state of war or modified martial law.
Several manufacturers and sales representatives notified retailers here .yesterday of the establishment of retail prices on their products under the provisions of the FeldCrawford law.
Frank Purnell, president of the Youngs- Cor town Sheet and Tube Company, criticized Governor Davey for sending National Guardsmen to keep his company's plants closed.

President Roosevelt tonight appealed to Tom M. Girdler, president of the Republic Steel Corporation, and Frank Purnell, president of the Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company, not to open their Youngstown plants tomorrow morning. In identical telegrams he joined in the request previously made by the Steel Mediation Board that the plants be kept closed "in the interest of a reasonable and peaceful settlement."

The engagement of Miss Candace Baird Alig, daughter of Mrs. Otto Fidele Alig of 15 East Sixty-ninth Street and Des Moines and the late Mr. Alig of Des Moines and Indianapolis, to Kelvin Cox Vanderlip, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank A.
Marshaled by Donald Budge of Oakland, Calif., the American expeditionary tennis forces paraded through the opening day at Wimbledon with the loss of only one set.

For the first time in many years the challenger for the world heavyweight boxing championship is favored over the titleholder. Joe Louis will go into the ring at Comiskey Park in Chicago tonight a 1 to 3 choice against James J. Braddock, the New Jersey boxer who took the title from Max Baer.
Mr. and Mrs. C. Hyland Jones of South Orange have announced the marriage of their daughter, Miss Esther Annis Jones, to Robert Gaylor Morrison Jr., of Amarillo, Texas, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert G.

An urgent appeal to safeguard American democracy, "by honest thinking and exercising that judgment necessary for the preservation ?? our national and international integrity," was made today by Dr. Livingston Farrand, retiring presi dent of Cornell University, in an address to the 942 students on whom degrees were conferred at the sixty-ninth commencement exercises.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A fundamental reason behind the steadily mounting costs of government is the lack of public knowledge concerning the planned disbursements of public funds. It is practically impossible to gain an accurate knowledge of government costs until the funds are authorized for expenditure or perhaps even spent.

Plans for a housing development in Queens were announced yesterday in connection with the sale of a large property in Jackson Heights. The Superb Homes Corporation (Jacob Miller and Hyman Guterman) bought from the Tri-Bridge Building Corporation a tract of land on Thirty-first Avenue and Eighty- eighth and Eighty-ninth

The Citizens Budget Commission followed up the demand of ninetytwo civic organizations for reduced water rates yesterday with a letter to Aldermanic President William F. Brunner for a return to the rates that prevailed in 1932.
Six games in the fifth round and two adjourned matches were decided today in the international chess masters tournament.

A prize of $50 for the best poster executed by a high. school student in the city was awarded yesterday to Hal Kurnit of the Abraham Lincoin High School in the office of Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools.

Dr. Ralph E. Badger of Detroit, banker and investment counsel, testified today in Federal Court here as an expert witness in the suit of five railroad companies for a permanent injunction restraining New Jersey from collecting the entire amount of taxes levied for 1934, 1935 and 1936.

Miss Elizabeth Arnoux Eskridge, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Guy Webb Eskridge of 145 West Twelfth Street, New York, was married to Lieutenant William Perry Baldwin, U.S.A., son of Major Perry L. Baldwin, U.S.A., Plattsburg Barracks, Plattsburg,

NORTHHAMPTON, Mass., June 21.--The nearly 500 members of the graduating class of Smith College here today heard Walter Lippmann urge that they continue to think and form their own opinions about current happenings and to continue to search for the truth.

Fees of $47,500 for their work in connection with the reorganization of the $13,000,000 Series B-K mortgage certificate issue of the closed New York Title and Mortgage Company were allowed yesterday to attorneys and accountants by Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler.
Luncheon meeting of the New York Lions Club, Hotel Astor, 12:30 P. M. Address by Mayor La Guardia.

Two officials of the Nassau Kennel Club, which conducts greyhound races at the Mineola Fair Grounds, and six directors of the QueensNassau Agricultural Society, which owns the grounds, pleaded not guilty to violation of Section 986 of the Penal Code here tonight when they were arraigned before Police Justice Francis B. Hamlin. George M. Levy, counsel for the Kennel Club officials,
An airplane piloted by Charles Stanton of Los Angeles with five passengers which disappeared between the Panama.border and this city yesterday is believed to have crashed in the jungles.

The suggestion that Tammany Hall might nominate Mayor La Guardia and thus solve the Mayoralty problem for both political parties was made last night by Alderman Newbold Morris, Republican, speaking before a meeting of the Affiliated Young Democrats, at the Hotel Victoria.
The Appleton-Century Company points to the fact that it has three books on its list that have been kept continuously in print by the Appleton Company for ninety-onei years.

The Securities and Exchange Commission has dismissed an application by Teck-Hughes Gold Mines, Ltd., to withdraw its $1-par capital stock from listing and registration on the New York Curb Exchange because the company did not appear to offer evidence at a hearing on April 6.
The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated! June 18:

A new high monthly record was established in production of nickel during April with an output of 21,266,884 pounds, the Dominion Bureau of Statistics reported today. In April, 1936, the output was 11,018,947 pounds.

In the colorful setting of the Lowell House Quadrangle, members of the Harvard 1937 class tonight held the annual Senior Spread and dance, ushering in the round of entertainments in connection with Harvard graduation week.

Mrs. Francis K. Green entertained at luncheon yesterday in the Viennese Roof of the St. Regis for her sister-in-law, Miss Florence Bell Green, who will be married to William Taylor Turner of Washington on Saturday at Benton, the home of her aunt, Mrs. Daniel C.

Mr. and Mrs. Maurice B. Blumenthal of 1,088 Park Avenue celebrated their thirty-fifth wedding anniversary last night with a family party at the Waldorf-Astoria. Mrs. Blumenthal is the former Miss Minnie Blumenthal of Marion, Ind.
Lashing out at the "universal hypocrisy" pervading our life, at the "inferiority complex of the press" and the "defeatist attitude of business," Clayton Rand, publisher of The Guide. Gulfport, Miss.,

PHILADELPHIA, June 21.--In the first ruling by a Federal court on the sit-down strike issue, the Circuit Court of appeals here today ordered sit-downers to vacate the local mill of the Apex Hosiery Company and restore it to the company, "its rightful owner."

Playing through a heavy mist, Mrs. Henry H. Dietrich from neighboring Gedney Farm streaked over the Westchester Hills Golf Club today in one under women's par to win the medal in the fifteenth annual women's Westchester-Fairfield championship.

The Turnesa clan continued its triumphant march in tournament golf today. This time it was Mike who held the spotlight, topping the largest field of the season with Richard Chapman in the Westchester amateur-pro competition at Green Meadow.

In Liberia's first sit-down strike, native steamship workers of the Pru tribe demanded today that their wage of 36 cents a day be increased to 48 cents. The German and Netherland Steamship Lines, which employ thousands of the Pru tribesmen on their African coastal steamers, declined to recognize "the president of the labor union of Liberia" who presented the demands by letter.

Hartman; 4, E. Pfeifer; 5, J. Furman; 6, J. Rogers; 7, H. Beuttell; stroke. J. Dodge; coxswain, G. Holley.

Charles S. Voorhies, civil and sanitary engineer and developer of several prominent waterfront resorts, died on Sunday at his home, 662 St. Mark's Avenue, Brooklyn, after a brief illness. He was in his seventy-third year.

On July 1 a new air service will be opened on the London-Moscow line, covering the distance in one day. It will be operated by the Dutch Airlines, collaborating with the Swedish Lines on the London, Amsterdam,

LONDON-Baron von Neurath, German Foreign Minister, canceled his visit to London because other powers did not act against Loyalist Spain over the alleged submarine attack on the cruiser Leipzig. Adolf Hitler was reported to have been angry because Reich naval men were doubted. The British Government was sore over the rebuff. Page 1.
Adolphe J. Menjou, the. movie actor, asked the government today to consider his reputation for being among "the. best dressed men in the world."

An offer by James H. Harper to serve the State's prison sentence imposed in General Sessionson his wife, Helen K. Harper, 33 years old, on her plea of guilty in the theft of $54,000 from her former employers, the Hold-Meredith Lumber Company, was rejected yesterday by Judge George L. Donnellan as "impractical." Judge Donnellan pointed out that no evidence had been produced that Harper was connected with the crime.

The United States battleships Arkansas, New York and Wyoming were moored here late last night after passing through the Kiel Canal. Salutes between the American training squadron and a German warship were .postponed until this morning, when greetings from the three American ships were replied to by the "pocket battleship" Admiral Graf Spee.

The disappearance of a large black beard belonging to a Mexican politician was brought into the open in the political fight being waged for control of the North Central State of San Luis Potosi, where General Saturnino Cedillo, Secretary of Agriculture, maintains the last private army in Mexico.
At a garden party tomorrow in their home, Point House, Somerset, Mr. and Mrs. Carveth Wells of Washington, D. C., will announce the engagement of their daughter, Miss Frances V. Wells,
The first National Stamp Conference started at its opening session today a movement to "promote interest in more attractive and better printed" United States postal paper.
Wimbledon's luck held and weekend clouds had blown away when Competitors from twenty-seven nations drew racquets from scabbards to begin the greatest friendly war in the realm of sports today.

Strike pickets, ignoring a court injunction calling for them to lay down their arms and limit their number, patrolled the gates of Republic Steel's plant late tonight, most of them carrying clubs. The roadway leading to the plant remained barricaded.

The Westchester realty market was enlivened by several good transactions in the Scarsdale neighborhood. The largest deal involved the sale of the six-story garden apartment house known as the Northgate on Garth Road, Scarsdale, by the New York operator,
Miss Alice Frink, daughter of Lieut. Col. James L. Frink, Quartermaster Corps, and Mrs. Frink, was married today in the Washington Cathedral to Lieutenant
PATERSON, N.J., June 21.--Miss Alice Weidmann, daughter of Mrs. Frederick August Weidmann of this city, and the late Mr. Weidmann, was married to J. Robert Blair,...

The House adopted the conference report on the Railroad Retirement Bill today, but sent back the conference report on the Civilian Conservation Corps Bill because of a Senate amendment requiring that non-enrollee and civilian employes of the corps be hired under civil service regulations.

The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities shows the following changes for the week ended June 16: Increases of $94,000,000 in loans, $298,000,000 in holdings of United States Government direct obligations and $444,000,000 in government deposits; a decrease of $264,000,000 in demand deposits-adjusted;

George M. Harrison, president of the Brotherhood of Railway Clerks and the affiliated union of Express Workers, telegraphed to L. O. Head, president of the Railway Express Agency, tonight that he was prepared to call an immediate strike of 40,000 express employes unless the agency agreed to sign a new contract.

Fall furniture prices were up 5 to 10 per cent at the seasonal market opening here yesterday. In addition, the threat of a further advance of like proportions later in the Summer were conveyed to buyers by manufacturers exhibiting new goods.

Income tax collections through last Saturday surpassed by about $9,000,000 the President's revised estimate of such receipts for the entire fiscal year, the Bureau of Internal Revenue announced this afternoon.

As the big fight approaches, the mystery deepens. The "insiders" are picking Braddock. The "outsiders" are picking Louis. According to the parties of both parts it won't even be close. Jersey James Braddock will reduce Shufflin' Joe Louis to a jelly. Shufflin' Joe Louis will slaughter Plain James in short order.

Postmaster General James A. Farley conferred yesterday at luncheon with Frank V. Kelly, Brooklyn Democratic leader, and Secretary of State Edward J. Flynn, leader in the Bronx, but so far as could be learned no progress was made toward picking a candidate for Mayor.

Donald Budge. Oakland, Calif., defeated Norman Farquharson, South Africa, 6-2, 6-3, 6-1; Gene Mako, Los Angeles, defeated Jacques Jamain, France, 6-4, 5-7, 6-3, 6-3; Bryan M. Grant, Atlanta, defeated J. M. Hunt, England, 6-3. 6-4, .7-5; Wayne Sabin. Hollywood,
A cordon of troops was thrown around the Sinclair refinery at Arbol Grande, near here, after rioting today by workers who had attacked a company agent.

President Roosevelt today designated Raymond B. Stevens chairman of the United States Tariff Commission to succeed Robert Lincoln O'Brien, whose resignation, effective June 30, was announced; and designated Henry F. Grady vicechairman. The designations are -for one year.

Corporation Counsel Paul H. Windels was knocked down by an automobile yesterday on Chambers Street, in front of the. Municipal Building,, as he was on his way home at about 5:30 P. M. He was treated in his office in the Municinal Bulding for slight injuries to a

A five years' extension of the first mortgage of $200,000 has been made by Rostenberg Associates, brokers, for the Ragero Realty Corporation on the property at the s e cor of Main and Grove Streets, White Plains. The mortgage is held by the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank of New York City.

James Cronon, a resident in Tuxedo for more than fifty-one years, died at his home here yesterday at the age of 80. He had been town clerk of the town of Tuxedo for more than thirty years and served as justice of the peace for thirty-two years, starting in 1887. He also was connected with the school board for a similar period.

Announcement has been made of the marriage of Miss Elizabeth Cain of Pittsfield, Mass., to Maxwell Hall Elliott Jr. of this city on Friday in Washington, D. C. The ha ceremony was performed in the New York Avenue Presbyterian fo Church by the pastor, the Rev. Albert Evans.

The Wheeler Shipyard, Cropsey Avenue and Coney. Island Creek, Brooklyn, was added yesterday to the score of shipyards affected by the strike of the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers.
A State Planning Council report revealed tonight that 175,220 vacant parcels of land in New York City have been made ready for building use in advance of need.

Bertram Goldberg, presidenttreasurer of Bertram Goldberg, Inc., silk dressers of Johnstown, N. Y., died suddenly here yesterday of a heart attack in Memorial Hospital. He formerly operated the Triangle Trucking Company's fleet of trucks between Johnstown and New York. since discontinued.

Miss Alyse M. Hunneman, 20-yearold society girl who was to have been a bridesmaid at the Ethel du Pont-Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. wedding on June 30, was buried today. She died in a Baltimore hospital last Thursday of injuries suffeared by a fall from a horse during a recent show at her home at Malvern.

Representative Cox of Georgia made in the House today one of the sharpest attacks yet heard on the administration's attitude toward labor troubles in the lake States, particularly as related to the delivery of mails to the mills.

Miss Grace Surber of Jackson Heights, L. I., and Miss Olga Kallos of Tuckahoe, N. 'Y., advanced to the quarter-final round of the New Jersey tennis championships for women at the Oritani Field Club today to be one round in advance of the field when play was concluded after intermittent showers.

Interest in trading in bonds yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange was at an extremely low ebb and the turnover was the smallest for a full session to date this month. Sales volume was only $5,430,900, compared with $6,277,100 on last Friday. The lethargy was apparent in all classifications.

Plans for the marriage on July 22 of Miss Virginia Davis, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. E. Asbury Davis, to E. Gillet Boyce, son of Mr. and Mrs. W. Graham Boyce of Bacon Hall, near Baltimore, were announced today.

On the eve of his sixty-first birthday, Dr. Raymond L. Ditmars, curator of mammals and reptiles at the Bronx Zoo, revealed yesterday that he is conducting experiments in cooperation with medical men to determine the value of snake poisons in treating epilepsy, hemophilia and malignant growths.

The third annual Spring training course for Westchester County recreation leaders opened today in the Little Theatre of the County Center here. Instruction in methods of conducting Summer activities at camps and playgrounds was given to 250 persons.

The annual complaint days for taxpayers to protest against county, town and village assessments are being held throughout Westchester County. According to reports today there has been a decline in complaints by taxpayers over former years. In the town of Rye 229 protests were filed, involving more than $400,000 asked in reductions.

Those who find conditions in France unsatisfactory or unsettling should contrast them with those in Germany. When the present Nazi government came into power in January, 1933, it found German working men paid a scale of wages that marked the lowest point in the depression.

Officers of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation reported today that a survey had shown that between 2,000 and 3,000 of the 14,000 insured banks had less capital than that deemed desirable by the FDIC. They said this did not indicate that the banks were unsound, but nevertheless it probably would be desirable for the institutions to increase capital as insurance against possible adverse conditions.

Ranger, outstanding in the trials to select the defender of the America's Cup, is to have a parachute spinnaker of an area of nearly 18,000 square feet. It will be the largest sail ever made for any vessel of.any kind, and more than the total canvassed area of the great

Prices of wheat in North American markets advanced the permissible limit of five cents a bushel today as the result of numerous reports from Eastern Kansas and Nebraska and Western Missouri, indicating that severe damage might be done to the Winter wheat crop by black rust, and the confirmation by local experts of the presence of the infection over the greater part of the Spring wheat area in Eastern South Dakota.

Broome St. 112. 25x87.6; Clifford-Davidson Corp to 112 Broome St Realty Corp, 22 W 32d St (quitclaim), (50 cents). 51st St. 349, W, 20x100.5: Joseph L. Lyon to Bridget M. Kelly, 349 W 51st St, (50 cents). Columbus Ave. w s, block from 62d to 63d Sts, 125 deep, John C. Spallone to the Manhattan Company; consideration, $100,000; foreclosure.

The House decided after much horseplay today that it was all right for a member to exhibit a bottle of "government rum" to illustrate his remarks. Representative Rich, Republican of Pennsylvania, with a shoebox under one arm, arose to protest against measures that "put the government in business."
Sixto Escobar of Puerto Rico, world's bantamweight boxing champion, scored a technical knockout in the eighth round at Marigold Gardens Arena tonight over Pat Robertson of New York.

Sheriff Troy Carroll said today that Lester Brockelhurst tried unsuccessfully to hang himself in his jail cell "because he knows he is going to get the electric chair and is tired of waiting." He used his blanket to swing himself from the ceiling of his cell last night, but was cut down by officers before suffering any ill effects, the Sheriff said.

James Francis Kelly, a familiar figure around the Aqueduct race track, was found dead yesterday in his room at 109-48 109th Street, Richmond Hill, Queens. He was the trainer of Michael Sokol's Whizzaway, which ran second at the Aqueduct track on Saturday. A heart ailment caused his death.

The Herald says Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr., son of the President, will not receive an ensign's commission in the Naval Reserve upon his graduation, as will other members. of his class who have taken the four-year course in naval science at Harvard.

Principals-James J. Braddock, North Bergen, N. J., champion, vs. Joe Louis, Detroit, challenger. Title at Stake-World heavyweight championship. Number of Rounds-Fifteen to a decision, with "no foul" rule in effect.
Eva Le. Gallienne: appeared tonight in ".The Mistress of the Inn," Goldoni's comedy of eighteenth-century Italy, at the .opening of the eighth Summer. season of the Westchester Playhouse.

The demand of the Public Service Commission that municipally owned electric power plants reduce their rates was seen tonight behind announcements from the commission of reduced schedules by three municipal plants.

The plaintiffs in a $20,000,000 stockholders' suit against the Long Island Lighting Company were attacked sharply yesterday in Supreme Court as the trial entered its third week. The suit was denounced by former Supreme Court Justice Stephen Callaghan, counsel for Ellis L. Phillips, the principal defendant, as an attempt to "hold up" the lighting company's directors.

More than the customary variety in fishing news is contained in week-end dispatches. For instance: At Freeport, L. I.: The first tuna of the season was brought in by Wilburn Wensley, a Brooklyn angler aboard Captain Ray Eldred's boat, Betsy Anna.

Announcement has been made here of the marriage of Miss Frances Bradley Wheeler, daughter of Mrs. Orie Walter Fowler of Chula Vista, Calif., and the late Orville Gould Wheeler of New York, to Delbert Raymond Jeffers,

It was a source of some astonishment to observers to note a drop of less than 1 per cent in the rate of operations of the steel industry this week, despite the closing down of the Cambria plant of Bethlehem.

A competent political writer for The Daily Bulletin reports that President Manuel Quezon has already started a campaign for re-election to the Presidency either of the Philippine Commonwealth or of a Philippine republic, should his early independence plan succeed.

Mrs. Helen Tiernan received an indeterminate sentence of twenty years to life imprisonment today, in Suffolk County Supreme Court here for the murder of her 7-year-old daughter, Helen, in the woods near Brookhaven, May 15.

The Bethlehem Steel Company has received a contract for 2,900 tons of sheet piling for the East River Drive in this city. The American Bridge Company received the contract for the addition to the plant of the Electro-Motive Corporation at La Grange, Ill., involving 2,500 tons.

The District of Columbia grand jury today returned an indictment against Ted Creech, 35-year-old son of a Harlan County (Ky.) mine owner and superintendent of his father's mine, who was arrested after he testified before the Senate Civil Liberties Committee on April 16. Perjury was charged.

Not so many years have passed since eminent authorities testified before a commission appointed by President COOLIDGE that it would be folly to extend the air mail to Northern Alaska, to think that commercial flying could ever be a success in the Far North, to believe that any aerial military invader of the United States could survive the ice, snow and hail of the North.

Arriving today from Warsaw on the Pilsudski of the Gdynia America Line are twenty-three Polish Boy Scouts and eight Girl Scouts, bound for the jamboree of the Boy Scouts of America, to be held in Washington from June 30 to July 9.

The largest graduating class in the history of the Van Hornesvllle Central School heard Millard H. Jencks, president of the board of trustees of St. Lawrence University, describe the heritage of Herkimer County students, after being introduced by Owen D. Young today.

Net profit of the Distillers Corporation-Seagrams, Ltd., and all its subsidiaries for the quarter ended on April 30 was $1,467,865, Canadian currency, after deductions for depreciation, interest, income and profits taxes and other charges, according to a report issued
Amelia Earhart decided today to take a three-day rest and have her plane overhauled before taking off on the next leg of her flight around the world.

Six persons were dead and thirty-four known wounded tonight as authorities pushed the largest mobilization of police and volunteers on this island in thirty-four years to cope with a wave of sit-down strikes in Trinidad oil fields.

A son was born to Mr. and Mrs. Edwin L. Hotchkiss of this city on June 12. Mrs. Hotchkiss is the former Miss Christine Matheson Rouse, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Wells Rouse Jr. of New York and Baltimore.

An exhortation to educated men to safeguard the liberties of American democracy was delivered before the alumni of Brown University today by Chief Justice Charles Evans Hughes. An exhortation to educated men to safeguard the liberties of American democracy was delivered before the alumni of Brown University today by Chief Justice Charles Evans Hughes.

Sherrill M. Gray, president of the Gray Equipment Corporation of 305 West Seventy-ninth Street, died suddenly of a heart attack on Saturday at Bill Brown's Health Camp on the Hudson. Mr. Gray, who was born 42 years ago in Alabama, was a graduate of Vanderbilt University.

Rex Mays, Los Angeles speed demon, cranked up his high-powered Alfa Romeo today and gave the revamped Roosevelt Raceway its first test under speed in preparation for the second 300-mile Vanderbilt Cup race, which will be run over the course July 3.

Bail of $500 on which George T. Mortimer, former president and director of the New York Title and Mortgage Company, was released in General Sessions in July, 1934, on a misdemeanor indictment was canceled yesterday by Judge John J. Freschi.

The formation of Swart, Duntze Co., Inc., an affiliate of Swart, Brent Co., Inc., to take over the entire personnel of the bank and insurance stock trading department of G. M.-P. Murphy Co., was announced yesterday.

The following persons are appointed patrolmen on probation, at $2,000 per annum. effective June 20, 1937, their names appearing on certifications of eligible list of the Municipal Civil Service Commission, dated June 10 and 14, 1937.

The stock-market was sluggish today, with the unsettled state of the gilt-edged issues thrown into relief by the poor response to the new Australian loan. Traders, too, marked time in watching developments in France and Spain and the American labor outlook.

Oscar Philipp of 131 Kensington Avenue, Jersey City, died of a heart attack early yesterday shortly after arriving at his offices at 29 Broadway. His age was 53. He was head of the firm of Oscar Philipp Co., exporters of steel products, which was organized ten months ago.

Apparently the victim of hold-up men, Maurice Danzis, who has operated a drug store at 89 Orange Avenue for the last thirty-five years, was found critically beaten in the rear of the store at 8:30 o'clock tonight.

The main prop in the government's case against the Zinovieff-Kameneff conspirators a year ago and the Piatakov-Radek conspirators last January has been destroyed by no less a person than the government prosecutor himself.

IN March of this year a press dispatch from Albuquerque revealed that on Good Friday at least a dozen men, members of a secret religious brotherhood, had allowed themselves to be crucified in remote mountain regions of New Mexico.

A. C. Norris's Guy Fawkes defeated the Greentree Stable's Chicolorado by a head in the Lawrence Handicap, six-furlong inaugural feature at Rockingham Park today to pay $3.30 for $2. A crowd of 10;000 saw the bay son of Happy Time lead most of the way while being clocked in 1:123-5 over a muddy racing strip.
Both principals in tomorrow night's fight expressed the greatest confidence in themselves in statements made for THE NEW YORK TIMES today. The rival managers were also highly optimistic.

The Federal Steel Strike Mediation Board issued this statement tonight: We met Monday morning with the union representatives. We discussed with them the question of the terms of the Carnegie-Illinois agreement in an effort to determine just what the issues were, if any, between the union and the companies.

Samuel Rosenthal, a former New York newsboy who became the founder and head of the Technical Press, one of the largest printing plants in the city until its discontinuance in 1933, died Sunday in his apartment in the Hotel Marcy, 720 West End Avenue, at the age of 76. A brother, Harry, and a sister, Mrs. Jennie Kamsler, survive.
President Roosevelt remained in the living quarters of the White House today suffering from what officials described as a cold in the nose.

John Hernandez, 23-year-old inmate of Sing Sing prison, committed suicide by hanging himself with a sash cord in his cell tonight. Prison officials said he was grief-stricken over the death of his 9-months-old daughter, whose funeral was held in New York yesterday.

All healthy and hungry again, America's Ryder Cup golfers were preparing tonight to abandon shuffleboard sticks for golf clubs as the Manhattan slid through a placid sea two hundred miles from Cobh. The players will disembark at Plymouth tomorrow at 6:30 P. M. and leave immediately for London.
Obviously enjoying himself, former Governor Alfred E. Smith of New York spent his first day in London today in the role of a Summer tourist of the more unconventional type.

Everett Slocum, president of the Slocum Straw Works in Milwaukee, died here yesterday morning of a heart attack while visiting the offices of Gage Brothers Co. at 417 Fifth Avenue. He also was vice president of Gage Brothers. His age was 55.

Before the fortieth annual convention of the National Association of Retail Grocers here today, Governor Charles F. Hurley of Massachusetts demanded that the Federal Government take immediate action to release and liberalize the country's

A charge that President Roosevelt and Governor Earle were pursuing "clearly seditious" policies in the handling of the steel strike situation was made by the executive council of the Philadelphia Board of Trade in a resolution adopted today.

From inside the Niles plant of the Republic Steel Corporation 278 employes sent a letter today to Secretary Perkins declaring that they are being held prisoners in the plant "by a C. I. O. gang armed with clubs and blackjacks."
Personnel and credit problems were uppermost at the sessions opening the mid-year convention of the National Retail Dry Goods Association at the Palmer House today.

Building plans filed yesterday included a project for a six-story apartment building, to house fiftythree families, at 1,218-28 Ocean Avenue, Brooklyn, at an estimated cost of $175,000. Specifications for alterations to the interior of the Hotel Astor, at Broadway and Forty-fourth Street, Manhattan,

New Jersey Representatives in Congress paid tribute today to former Representative Franklin W. Fort of East Orange, N. J., who died yesterday at Rochester, Minn. Representative Edward L. O'Neill of Newark, who now represents the district which formerly elected Fort, said:

Diplomas will be awarded to forty-two graduates of the Manhattan College High School at the eighty-fourth commencement exercises tonight at 8:15 o'clock in Smith Auditorium on the college campus, 242d Street and Spuyten Duyvil Parkway, Riverdale.

More than a hundred members of the House had failed up to this morning to respond to invitations to the Democratic "love feast" scheduled for next week-end at the Jefferson Island Club in Chesapeake Bay.

Whisky produced in the United States during May totaled 17,986,080 tax galIons, of which 5,139,267 was withdrawn tax-paid, leaving stocks at the end of the month at 434,261,867 tax gallons, the Bureau of Internal Revenue reported today.
Gold bullion on the open London market, in terms of British currency, unchanged at 140s 61/2d per fine ounce. Price before British suspension of gold payments on Sept. 21, 1931, was 84s 93/4 d.

Two tennis players and a pair of boxers arrived yesterday aboard the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary. Ellsworth Vines and Fred Perry returned from their net exhibitions in England and Ireland. Also on board were Deacon Leo Kelly, Los Angeles Negro lightheavyweight, and Ben Foord, South African heavvweight.

The New York College of Music, 114 East Eighty-fifth Street, will close its fifty-ninth year tonight with a concert and commencement exercises in Town Hall, 123 West Forty-third Street. John H. Meyer, secretary, will address the graduates and Carl Hein, director, will present diplomas, certificates and testimonials to twenty-nine students. The list follows:

A strike of seamen of the Eastern Steamship Lines, which was called last Tuesday in Boston and had spread to three other ports, was ended late yesterday afternoon at an informal conference of union leaders and an agent of the National Labor Relations Board.
Foreign Minister Constantin von Neurath's official visit to the new British Cabinet scheduled for Wednesday and Thursday of this week has been postponed indefinitely by the Reich Government.
A deposition by Serge Koussevitzky, Boston Symphony Orchestra director, today helped Ernst Panenka of Brookline, Mass., a bassoon player in the orchestra, to win a divorce from his wife, Rosa.

Inspired by the success of the first flight from Moscow across the North Pole to the United States, Soviet aviation experts here revealed today their determination to build greater, faster and longer-range planes to make regular air communication between the U. S. S. R. and the U. S. A. entirely feasible.
" Memphis Bill" Terry slipped into town today for a brief visit and left behind him the prediction his Giants and the Cubs will do the battling for the National League pennant.

President Roosevelt wired appeals not to reopen their mills to officials of Republic Steel and Youngstown Sheet and Tube. Page 1. Governor Davey declared martial law in Youngstown and sent militia there to prevent the scheduled reopening of steel mills this morning. Page 1.

Miss Juanita Muriel Seabold, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George W. Seabold of this place, was married to Theodore Larned Eastmond, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Farnham Eastmond of Beverly Hills, Calif., this afternoon in the Reformed Church.

Ralph G. Coburn, 53 years old, formerly a vice president of the General Foods Corporation and a Harvard classmate of President Roosevelt, shot and killed himself at 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon in his room at the Murray Hill Hotel, 112 Park Avenue. He had been ill for ten months.

At a hearing before the Public Service Commission yesterday on the petition of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., for authority to issue 92,134 shares of its $5 preferred stock in exchange for the preferred stocks of its affiliate, the New York Steam Corporation, Randell J. Le Boeuf Jr., counsel for the company, maintained that savings of $166,847 annually in preferred dividend charges would be effected if the plan were approved.

A son was born to Don and Donna Luciano del Balzo di Caprigliano of Naples, Italy, on Sunday at the Doctors Hospital, this city. Donna del Balzo di Caprigliano is the former Miss Frances Miller, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Andrew Miller of this city.

Close of the picture-puzzle contest staged by Old Gold cigarettes offering $200,000 in prizes found 40,000 entrants, or 2 per cent of the 2,000,000 who competed, tied for the first prize of $100,000, according to a booklet issued yesterday by the Bureau of Advertising of the American Newspaper Publishers Associatio.
The War Deapartment released the following orders today, dated June 19:

Captain Brantz Mayer, Supply Corps, died yesterday at his home at Merion, Pa., the Navy Department was advised today. He was in his fifty-eighth year and is survived by his widow, Mrs. Mary Kelly Mayer. He will be buried at Annapolis.

Trading was rather slow on lamb and fair to good on other classes of traefa meats. Steel beef cuts sold strong to sharply higher, veal hindsaddles were sharply higher, lamb uneven, fresh pork steady to higher.

Sharply critical opinions of Governor Earle's action in ordering steel mills closed are expressed by editorials in the nation's press as gathered by THE NEW YORK TIMES yesterday and reproduced as follows:
Obesity was traced to the blood, and linked to a control of blood sugar by the pancreas, in a discovery reported today to the American Association for the Advancement of Science.

Bourbon King, Kentucky-bred juvenile from the stable of Hal Price Headley, served notice today at Washington Park that he is a big threat for the $40,000 Washington Park Futurity to be run Saturday. Bourbon King, making his first Middle West start, scored by five lengths over three other Futurity candidates and four who were not named in the featured juvenile dash.

Organizers for the C. I. O. accused the Hershey Chocolate Corporation today of engaging in unfair labor practices by discriminating against members of the United Chocolate Workers Industrial Union in the company's plant at Hershey.
William H. Parsons, whose wife disappeared mysteriously twelve days ago, -issued today a second public appeal to those he believes are holding her for $25,000 ransom. to communicate with him.

Mrs. Rosamund Dale Templeton, daughter of Robert Dale Owen, died at her home here today. Her age was 91. She had spent half her life fighting a legal battle in Palestine courts for rights to the site of the Haifa railroad station, which is on land purchased by her first husband, Laurence Oliphant.

Charles Frederick Sturdy, who survived sinking of the Lusitania in 1915, died suddenly tonight while bowling. His age was 61. He clung to an overturned lifeboat three hours and was rescued by a tug off the. Irish coast after the Lusitania was lost. John R. Sturdy marine editor of The Montreal ?? ?? son.

Mayor La Guardia wrote to Police Commissioner Valentine yesterday asking for stricter police supervision of traffic in the theatre zone and calling attention to several conditions which he said required correction.
Spectacular bidding for treasured books, in which Americans participated prominently, yielded [Pound]46,000 in an auction at Sotheby's today. The sale Blasted a little more than an hour.
In the U. S. Court of Customs and Patent Appeals today the following proceedings were had:

A severe lightning and wind storm, similar to the miniature tornado that struck Manhattan last week, tore through Coney Island last night, putting out lights in many homes, unroofing several houses, uprooting trees and flooding cellars and streets with rain.

It is not imrobable that Leon Blum will sueeed Leon as Premier of France. His resignation in the early ?urs of this morning was not the ?esult of a defeat on the bill giving him broad fiscal powers, for in the skirmish in the Senate that preceded the resignation he did not use his heavy artillery or the strengthh of his position.
Officials of the New York Stock Exchange took steps yesterday which were interpreted as being preliminary to formulation of rules to govern participation by members in investment trusts of all kinds.

Georges Bonnet, French Ambassador to the United States, visited Paul Van Zeeland, Prime Minister trip of Belgium, yesterday shortly before the latter left for Princeton where he will receive an honorary degree of Doctor of Laws at commencement exercises today.

Announcing his commitment to one feature-length picture a year, Walt Disney today made known the purchase of "Bamby," Felix Salten's popular seller of last season, as his full-length comedy for next year. Decision to advance beyond the short subject field came with the showing of a small portion of "Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs" to the R.-K.-O. sales convention last week which provoked unusual enthusiasm.
The House Naval Affairs Committee approved today a bill authorizing construction of six auxiliary naval craft at a cost of not more than $50,000,000.

Forty-hourweek conventions for the textile, chemical and printing industries survived their first test of strength in the International Labor Organization plenary conference today. The textile convention lacked only four votes of the two-thirds majority needed for adoption.

Judge Martin J. Cunningham, Democrat, was elected Mayor of Danbury today by a majority of 841 votes over the Republican holdover, Adam A. Roth. Judge Cunningham polled 4,403 votes to 3,562 for Mr. Roth in the special election necessitated by the death April 4 of Mayor-elect Byron W. Austin, who had also defeated Roth at the March 29 election.

Standing on a washtub in the cellar at 2,401 Westchester Avenue, the Bronx, a band of robbers sawed a hold through the floor above, early yesterday morning, entered the year room of a jewelry store, ripped open a safe in an adjoining
An allusion to interventionists in the Spanish civil war is contained in a cablegram of congratulations from Maxim M. Litvinoff, Soviet Foreign Commissar, to the Russian polar fliers.
Here is the statement made by T. M. Girdler;, chairman of the RepubliceSteel Corporation, before the Steel Mediation Board today:

The German Government has awarded three scholarships for military training to subaltern officers iii the Ecuadorean Army. Each award consists of three years' study in a German military academy and training with the German Army.
Estate, less than $3,000. To Katherine Tully, sister, 200 W. 93d St., and John J. Gibbs, brother, executor, 69 W. 93d St., $800 each;

Dr. Remsen B. Ogilby, president of Trinity College, conferred 110 degrees in course at the commencement exercises today. Wilbur M. Urban, Professor of Philosophy at Yale University, gave the baccalaureate address.

Mrs. Paul Purington of 36 Sherman Place, a bride of three weeks and a sister of the Rev. Henry P. Wackerbarth of Hackensack, died today in Christ Hospital here, after being ill of a kidney malady for four days.

Dr. Hugh Allison Greenwood, an authority on tropical diseases and an associate of General W. C. Gorgas during the construction of the Panama Canal, died here yesterday following a cerebral hemorrhage. His age was 58.

Judge Peter J. Brancato of Kings County sentenced two brothers yesterday to long terms in Sing Sing after their conviction on charges of first-degree robbery. Anthony Adomaitis, 31 years old, of 397 South Fifth Street, Brooklyn, received thirty to sixty years and his brother, John, 23, of the same address, got ten to twenty years.

Wheat marketing in the prairie provinces for the week ended on June 11 amounted to 891,268 bushels, a decrease of 503,857 from the previous week and a drop of 1,659,236 from the corresponding week last year, the Dominion Bureau of Statistics reported today.

Lawrence M. Helfgott assigned to Edward S. Waters a mortgage for $16,000 on 136 E 93d St. A new mortgage for $24.000 given to the Connecticut Mutual Life Insurance Co by the 54 W 14th St Corp. Beck Madow. president, has been consolidated with a prior mortgage to form one joint lien for $90,000 on 54 W 14th St, payable ten years hence at 4 3/4 per cent.
Black will probably account for 65 per cent of the volume in handbags for Fall, according to a survey issued yesterday by the National Authority for the Ladies Handbag Industry.
A short circuit was caused yesterday about 3 P. M. when a workman struck a cable of the Consolidated Edison Company at Thirtyfourth Street and Twelfth Avenue with his pneumatic drill.

Dismissal notices' were received yesterday by 1,709 WPA workers in the Federal Theatre Project and officials there estimated that the result would be to curtail next season's production activities by about 50 per cent.

John Davison Rockefeller 3d of New York City was elected a life trustee of Princeton University at the commencement meeting of the board here today. Mr. Rockefeller was graduated from Princeton in 1929 and was assigned by the board to membership on its committee on undergraduate life.

This city will benefit financially to the extent of $5,000,000. on the world's heavyweight championship fight between James J. Braddock and Joe Louis tomorrow night. .With fans pouring into town in a steady stream that shows little sign of abating before the rival warriors are called into action, Chicago merchants, hotel men, restaurateurs, inn keepers and the like are experiencing a turn of prosperity that is reminiscent of "the good old days."

Mischa Rosenbaum, 31 years old, who used the professional names Ross and Rosen in theatrical circles, collapsed yesterday in the ante-room of General Sessions after Judge Saul S. Streit had sentenced him to thirty-five years' to life imprisonment for slaying Julis Nussenbaum, 24, a violinist.
Bobby Riggs of Los Angeles retained his national clay court tennis championship today, defeating Joe Hunt, a fellow-townsman, 6-3, 4-6, 6-3, 6-4.

A sudden recrudescence of incidents along the Siberian-Manchukuo frontiers is believed by the Hsinking Japanese authorities to be due to the Soviet's efforts to restore the Far Eastern Red Army's morale. Three incidents occurred during the week-end, all of which are ascribed to Soviet aggression.

Bernie (Schoolboy) Friedkin of Brownsville and Jimmy Lancaster of Wilmington, Del., will clash in the eight-round feature at the boxing show at the Canarsie Stadium in Golden City Amusement Park tonight. Three sixes and as many fours also are on the card.

The Nazi regime announced tonight that new immorality trials of Catholics would show justification for its drastic action against Catholic schools in Bavaria. Adolf Wagner, Bavarian Minister of the Interior, who yesterday announced the closing of eleven private Catholic schools, declared that the public would know the reason for this "when the trials begin."

Despite a trio of bogies, the brother combination of Bob and Frank Stuhler of Idlewild crashed through with a remarkable 32, 30-62 at Hempstead to set a new record for amateur-pro best-ball competition as they led forty-five other teams in the Long Island P. G. A. tournament today.
Miss Kathleen Hays Guthrie, daughter New if Mrs. Francis Sellers Guthrie of his city and the late Mr. Guthrie, vas married this afternoon in Cal,ary Church to Allan Dean Conrerse Jr.,

In the financial section of last Sunday's TIMES, GODFREY N. NELSON presented two tables which throw a brilliant light not only on the present investigation into " tax avoidance " but the much larger and more important question whether existing income-tax rates are not already too high even from the standpoint of Government revenues.

Robert Woerner, hat-stamping dies, In 693-97 Broadway; M. Schwartzman; H. Rifkin and N. Kruger, furs, in 236-40 W 27th St; American Play Suit Co. floor in 125 Prince St; M. L. Hess, Inc, broker. Thomas G. Sabin radio consultant, In RCA Building; Parfums Schiaparelli, Inc, of Paris, in La Maison Francaise; Rockefeller Center leases.

Seven Maine-born men and women, including Edna St. Vincent Millay, poet, were among the recipients of honorary degrees from Colby College at commencement today. Governor Barrows termed the degree list "a Maine roll of honor" in speaking at a dinner following the exercises.

The City Labor Relations Board named a board of three members yesterday to supervise the referendum on collective bargaining to be held today for employes of the New York City Omnibus Corporation, principal bus-operating company in Manhattan.

New York's office skyscrapers have a higher percentage of occupancy than prevails in the country as a whole, committee on renting of the National Association of Building Own-ers and Managers reported to the annual convention of that body, which opened today.

Freddy Hopkins, who trained the mighty Equipoise during his 2 and 3-year-old years, saddled his first winner of the metropolitan season for the Sage Stable yesterday at Aqueduct when he sent out That One. This filly, by Whichonefrom Oval, was neglected in a field of ten that went to the post for the six furlongs of the featured Rosetint Handicap.

Gloucestershire trounced Surrey by 109 runs in an English county' cricket match concluded today, while Worcestershire's victory over Oxford University was even more decisive, the sauce county winning by an innings and 163. Other matches started Saturday were not completed.

Once again, Chicago is the world's fistic center. From all over the country and from distant lands, followers of boxing are arriving in steady streams for the first heavyweight championship battle in two years.

The announcement of several of the independent steel companies in the strike area that they will attempt today to expand their operations has brought from union leaders threats that this effort will be met with violence.

After an absence of two years, the national intercollegiate tennis championships returned to the turf courts of the Merion Cricket Club today with the largest field to gather for the tournament in its fiftythree-year history.

Mrs. Blanche L. Steele, president of the Easton Publishing Company, died at her home here tonight after a brief illness. She was born in Philadelphia, where her father, S. A. Leith, was a pioneer merchant.
ECONOMIC PLANNING AND INTERNATIONAL ORDER, by Lionel Robbins. (Macmillan, $2.50.) The author is Professor of Economics. University of London.

Arthur L. Howard, who has written New York dramatic criticism for The London Era for the last thirtyfive years, died suddenly this morning at his desk in his home, 145 Mountain Way, while writing reminiscences of Sir James M. Barrie, who died on Saturday. Both Mr. Howard and Sir James were 77 years old.

Leonrard .Hartman, defending champion and third ranking player in the East, swung into action yesterday in the third day of play in the Richmond County open men's singles tournament at the Clifton Tennis Club, Arrochar, Staten Island, by defeating Morgan D. Evans Jr. in the first round, 6-1, 6-2.

Are the Nazi leaders deliberately antagonizing all the religious elements in the Reich? This possibility is suggested by the Government's peremptory order closing last Saturday all the Catholic schools in Bavaria and by the continuance of Nazi assaults on the Protestant Confessional Synod.

Urging adoption of a bill by Representative Lea now pending before the House Committee on Foreign and Interstate Commerce, the Securities and Exchange Commission forwarded to Congress today another section of its general report on reorganizations and defaults, dealing this time with the activities of protective committees and alleged abuses attendant upon conflicts of interests where members and counsel of committees are involved.

CHIEF OF PROBATION AND PAROLE SERVICE, $5,600 a year; SUPERVISOR OF PROBATION, $4,600 a year; ASSISTANT SUPERVISOR OF PROBATION, $3,800 a year. Bureau of Prisons, Department of Justice. Applications must be on file not later than the following dates:

The Trust Company of Northern Westchester announced today that it would resign as a trustee in 270 mortgage series, aggregating more than $20,000,000. It was elected early this year as one of three trustees in each series.

Dr. Alfred Rosenberg, noted chiefly for his attacks on Christianity, volunteered some advice-yesterday to the United States. Praising its pioneers, he asserted it was time for the United States to abandon individualism and come around to something nearer the totalitarian idea of life.

Twenty bars of silver valued at about $3,000 were stolen here today from two employes of a New York concern by four armed men who waylaid their automobile on Chestnut Street, near State Highway 29. The victims were forced into the bandits' car and driven several blocks before being released.

Department store sales in the metropolitan area showed an increase of 9.0 per cent for the thirteen shopping days from June 1 to 15, over the comparative period last year, according to figures issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

John H. Nicholson, a former vice president of the National Tube Company, died yesterday at his home here at the age of 70. Mr. Nicholson was an authority on steel processing development and a pioneer in the development of seamless tubing.

President Roosevelt conferring with Secretaries Hull, Wallace, Morgenthau and other officials, appointed Raymond B. Stevens chairman and Henry F. Grady vice chairman of the Tariff Commission, and promulgated the Bituminous Coal Code.
