Harry Halbren. ten rooms and five baths In 944 Park Ave: Alfred Van Praag. in 340-50 Park Ave; Miss Ethel Innes, in 17 E 96th St; Douglas L. Elliman Co. Inc, broker.

Jacob (Gurrah) Shapiro, convicted racketeer, who was recently described by Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine as "public Enemy No. 2," was the object yesterday of a Federal inquiry. Shapiro, convicted of violating the anti-trust law in the city's $10,000,000-a-year rabbit skin industry, was under a three-year sentence for that offense.

Seven firemen were overcome by smoke and property damage estimated in excess of $50,000 was caused about 5:30 P. M. yesterday by a fire of undetermined origin that swept through a five-story loft building at 335-337 East Twenty- so sixth Street, about 100 yards from Bellevue Hospital.

Steel operations are scheduled at 75.9 per cent of capacity this week, compared with 76.6- per cent last week, a decrease of .7 point, or .9 per cent, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute. This is a new low rate for the year, and compares with 91 per cent a month ago.

The State of Minnesota will enter the market on July 20 with a new issue of $1,225,000 of certificates of indebtedness, for which bidders are asked to designate the rate of interest. The certificates will be dated July 30 and will mature on July 30, 1942.

Police here decided tonight to discontinue their investigation of the drowning yesterday of John Blythe, 38 years old, and his two children, Jean, 13, and John, 9, in the Hackensack River after County Physician Ralph Gilady said the tragedy was "accidental."

When the President seemingly ranged himself on the side of those counselors who have been advocating economy and a legislative truce as the best methods with which to stop the drift from Mr. Roosevelt, the star of Harry L. Hopkins visibly paled.

Oscar Lampland, president of the Lampland Lumber Company of St. Paul, Minn., and brother of Carl O. Lampland, the astronomer, died suddenly yesterday morning at 5 Prospect Place, where he was visiting his son and daughter, Arthur and Ruth Lampland.

The class of 1937 of Yale University today closed its undergraduate career with class exercises, the senior dance and glee club program, and the Law and Medical Schools held their annual luncheons and alumni reunions.

Arthur de Souza Costa, Finance Minister of Brazil, proposed today to officials of the United States that the Brazilian banking system be reorganized--possibly with the assistance of United States gold creditas the best possible means of improving mutually profitable trade between the two countries.

The banker of today must have a sense of responsibility to the economic order, Tom K. Smith, president of the American Bankers Association, said tonight at Rutgers University at the opening of the third resident session of the Graduate School of Banking. The school is under the auspices of-the association and the university.

Directors of the Brooklyn-Manhattan Transit Company halved the dividend on the common stock yesterday, authorizing a disbursement of 50 cents a share for the quarter, against $1 previously. The dividend is payable on July 15 to shareholders of record on July 1.

Charles Hodges, a Negro who weighs 218 pounds, stands 6 feet 3 inches tall, and who said he was chauffeur and bodyguard for Father Divine, was held without bail yesterday for arraignment in Special Sessions Court when he appeared before Magistrate William A. Farrell in Felony Court, charged with violation of the Sullivan Law.
Prominent members of the New Jersey bar will attend funeral services at the residence on Wednesday at 2 P. M. for Halsted H. Wainright, dean of the Monmouth County Bar Association.

The tangled mass of aluminum alloy that was once the airship Hindenburg, now lying on the field at the Lakehurst Naval Air Station, has attracted bids from several American companies. Bids range from $4,000 to $12.000 for the wreckage of the airship, which cost nearly $4,000,000 to build.

The last barrier to immediate action on the United Front movement to promote newspapers was removed yesterday, when the Newspaper Advertising Executives Association, meeting in the Hotel Pennsylvania,

Gold membership buttons and silver plaques, in recognition of their service, were presented last night to 254 members of the Quarter Century Club of the National City Bank, the City Bank Farmers' Trust Company and affiliated institutions who have worked more than twenty-five years in these financial organizations.

The engagement of Miss Lilla Price Renshaw, daughter of Mrs. Joseph G. Coleman Jr. of Santa Barbara and the late Howard P, Renshaw of New York and Hollister, Calif., to Phelps Stokes Hunter, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Hunter,

Dr. H. H. Kung, Minister of Finance of China, arrived yesterday from Europe aboard the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary after representing his country as a Special Ambassador at the coronation ceremonies in London.

The Bangor Aroostook Railroad reported yesterday a net income of $824,074 in the five months ended on May 31, or $5.25 a common share, against $602,380, or $3.53 a share, in the same period last year.
St. Louis at New York-Knott vs. Malone. Cleveland at Washington-Whitehill vs. Fischer. Detroit at Boston-Wade or Poffenberger vs. Wilson. Chicago at Philadelphia-Kennedy vs. Williams.
Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Morril B. Spaulding of 108 East Eighty-first Street of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Isabel Milliken Spaulding, to Laurance P. Roberts, son of Mr.

Former Emperor Wilhelm of Germany visited Crown Princess Juliana of the Netherlands today at her palace. He was received by Juliana and her consort, Prince Bernhard, and the latter's mother, Princess Armgard of Germany. He remained several hours before returning to Doorn.

Sir Eric Geddes, one of the leading British industrialists who proved a tower of strength to the British Government during the World War, died at his home, Albourne Place, Hassocks, Sussex, tonight, at the age of 61.

Miss Elizabeth Moore Lincoln, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alan M. Lincoln of Rye, has completed plans for her marriage to Ledyard Stevens Bowen, son of Mrs. J. Q. H. Smith of this city and of the late John de Koven Bowen of Chicago, which will take place Saturday afternoon in Christ Church, Rye.
It is no longer greatly doubted in Washington, where politics is the chief industry, that the elections for Congress in 1938 will reveal important group shifting from 1936.

The Monsanto Chemical Company of St. Louis has filed under the Securities Act of 1933 a registration statement covering 50,000 shares of no-par $4.50 cumulative Series A preferred stock. The offering price is to be given later in an amendment. Edward B. Smith Co., New York, are named as the principal underwriters.

Many metropolitan anglers are waiting for off-shore fishing to improve in near-by water. Along the New Jersey coast boatmen and sportsmen are patiently watching the week-ends slip by for the time when things will be humming.

Miss Phyllis Ruth Smith, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. A. Philip Smith of this place, was married here tonight in the Second Congregational Church to Montgomery Stevenson Blake, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert S. Blake of Glen Ridge, N. J., by the Rev. Dr. John Gordon.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Evidently convinced that no depression can be completely overcome without a moral renaissance, the lawyers have voted to set up a new code of ethics for the guidance of their profession while practicing the law in behalf of their clients.

The dollar volume of food sales this month through retail channels is running more than 10 per cent ahead of the totals for the corresponding period last year, the American Institute of Food Distribution, Inc.,

Commencement exercises for Hunter College High School will be held tomorrow night in the Wadsleigh High School auditorium, West 135th Street and St. Nicholas Terrace. Dr. Hannah M. Egan, dean of Hunter College, will give the address.

Crosby Ave, 1,749 (15-4169); 1,749 Crosby Avenue Realty Corp to City Safe Deposit Co of Albany, N. Y.; installments, 5 per cent, $12.000. Marion Ave, 2,644 (12-3282); estate of Martin Hoyne to Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank, extends mtg to April 21, 1942, at 5 to 5 1/2 per cent; $25,825. Grant Ave. 1,357 (11-2830); 1,357 Grant, Inc. to Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank, extends mtg to May 1, 1942, at 6 per cent: 556,000.

John Wilson Belches, former member of the Boston Stock Exchange, died here today at his home after a long illness. He was 91 years old. A familiar figure in Boston's financial circles for many years, Mr. Belches retained an active interest in political and current events up to his death.

Miss Julia Gilbert Post, the debutante daughter of Charles Morgan Post and the late Mrs. Post, who will be introduced on Saturday afternoon at a garden party to be given by her grandmother, Mrs. Cass Gilbert, at her Ridgefield, Conn., home, Cannon Ball House. Mrs. Gilbert, her daughter,

Mrs. Charles Eastman of Greenwich, winner of the competition two years ago, was the victim of an upset today as match play in the fifteenth annual women's Westchester and Fairfield championship began at the Westchester Hills Golf Club.

Nat Litfin, 124 1/4,- Pittsburgh, scored easily over Henry Hook, 123, Indianapolis, in the feature eightround bout at the New York Coliseum last night. The winner was off to a slow start, but gained speed as the engagement progressed.
Robert W. Lea of Chicago was elected president of the West Virginia Coal and Coke Company yesterday at a meeting of the directors held here. He will succeed John C. Cosgrove, who has resigned.

With threatening clouds occasionally obscuring the bright sunlight, Princeton University celebrated its 190th annual commencement exercises on the lawn in front of historic Nassau Hall this morning with all the pomp and pageantry of academic tradition.

Twelve giant navy patrol planes, which took off from San Diego Bay at 11:30 A. M., Pacific standard time, yesterday, arrived at Coco Solo, Canal Zone, at 3:28 P. M. today, completing the longest nonstop massed flight in United States naval history. The planes flew 3,085 miles and were in the air twentyseven hours and fifty-eight minutes.

Dr. Ralph E. Badger of Detroit, an investment counsel appearing as an expert witness in the United States District Court here for five railroads in their suit before Judge Phillip Forman for a permanent injunction restraining New Jersey from collecting tax levies in full for 1934, 1935 and 1936,
The veteran Ted Horton today pitched and batted Yale into its first Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League championship in five years.
Republicans of prominence are being solicited to sign a "round robin" urging Mayor La Guardia to be a candidate for renomination in the party primary, it was learned yesterday.

Acclaimed in the afternoon as winner of the John Newbery medal and f ted in the evening as the writer of the "most distinguished juvenile book" of the year, Ruth Sawyer, long time teller of children's tales, was the focal figure of yesterday's sessions of the American Library Association at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Newark increased its lead to thirteen and one-half games by routing Montreal, 15-1, tonight. Frankie Kelleher led a fifteen-hit attack with four safeties, one a home run with the bases filled in the seventh inning.

Bobby Britton, 138 1/2, West Side, son of the former welterweight champion, and Tony Marteliano, 139, East Side, battled six rounds to a draw in the feature bout before 1,500 persons at the Queensboro Arena last night. Marteliano finished strongly and the verdict was unpopular.

The body of former President Gaston Doumergue was placed in the family tomb here today with simple services following an impressive funeral at Nimes. Only the widow, members of his family and a few officials and intimate friends attended the rites at the village Protestant church.
Favorites continued their march through the women's New Jersey State tennis championship at the Oritani Field Club today as all but two brackets in the quarter-final round were filled.
There was little change yesterday in the character and course of the bond market from the preceding day, except a slight acceleration in the pace of the decline in many second-grade issues.

Marker B. Paloolian, Colombian animal dealer, arrived yesterday on the Grace liner Santa Inez with a cargo of animals that kept him busy on the way up from the Panama Canal, what with battles, deaths and a high birth rate among the boa constrictors.

The Port of New York Authority opened four bids yesterday for the contract to build a New Jersey approach to the new Lincoln Tunnel, which is under construction below the Hudson River between West Thirty-seventh Street, Manhattan, and Weehawken.
Camille Chautemps, who has formed a Cabinet in France, has had many years of Ministerial experience. Most recently he was Minister of State in the Cabinet of Leon Blum.

Charles V. Kimball, Civil War veteran, achieved today the goal he set for himself on his ninetieth birthday by reaching the age of 100. In honor of the event Mayor Arthur E. Kerwein, members of the Borough Council and delegates from

Marking time for the week-end invasion of the second-place Tigers, the league-leading Yankees engaged the last-place Browns in the first of a three-game series at the Stadium yesterday, with the McCarthymen recording an 8-to-5 decision.

Miss Jean Albin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leland D. Albin of this place, was married to John H. Griesel Rogers, son of Mr. and Mrs. Wilbur H. Rogers, also of Plainfield, this evening in the Crescent Avenue Presbyterian Church.

Two hundred and seventeen degrees will be awarded tomorrow morning by President Comstock at the Radcliffe College commencement exercises. Included in the number are 160 candidates for A. B., 47 candidates for A. M. and 10 candidates for Ph. D.

The course of President Roosevelt and the Governors of Pennsylvania and Michigan in regard to the current steel strikes was denounced today in both houses of Congress, with an intimation coming from Senator Bailey of North Carolina that Governor Earle's action in calling out the troops at Johnstown might have its repercussions in the 1940 Presidential race.

Seaman George Donaldson, second class, attached to the United States Coast Guard cutter Ponchartrain, flagship at the Poughkeepsie rowing races, was rescued from drowning in the Hudson River near the finish line of the varsity race today.

The marriage of Miss Maybelle V. Matthews, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William G. Matthews of Glen Cove, L. I., to William James Stewart Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Stewart of Amsterdam, N. Y., took place here today in the Old Stone Church. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. H. W. Sherwood.

Passengers carried in May on the entire Interborough Rapid Transit System, including both subway and elevated divisions, numbered 85,761,668, according to the monthly report of Thomas E. Murray Jr., receiver for the I. R. T., which was filed yesterday with Federal Circuit

The position of steel companies in expressing a willingness to agree to terms with unions but refusing to sign a paper to that effect is "preposterous," General Hugh S. Johnson said here last night. He spoke before 900 members of the Furniture Exchange and retail furniture buyers from nearly every State in the country.

Jim Braddock was a tired athlete when he returned to his dressing room at Comiskey Park tonight. He lay down immediately and remained that way for probably ten minutes before proceeding to dress. All that time he uttered not a word, preferring to leave such matters to his manager, Joe Gould.

Miss Rosemary Cecilia Belbey, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Eugene Belbey of this place, was married here this morning to Justin William Seymour, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Browne Seymour of East Orange, in St. Stephen's Church.

Ruling that the city was responsible for an eighteen months' delay in completing a part of the Lexington Avenue subway, Supreme Court Justice Louis A. Valente awarded yesterday the Rapid Transit Subway Construction Company $381,472 plus interest from May 16, 1921, in liquidated damage.
The Bronx Board of Trade has adopted a resolution to "encourage and support the Citizens Committee on the Control of Crime in New York," of which Colonel Harry F. Guggenheim is chairman.

The French Ministerial crisis early Monday morning, precipitated by the Senate's rejection of LEON BLUM'S demand for full powers to meet the financial situation, has been ended through a shift of personnel which preserves the Popular Front.

Reports of weevil infestation in some cotton fields east of the Mississippi River and an advance in wheat counteracted the influence of the best crop weather so far this season and, after irregular fluctuations over a 10 point range, prices on the Cotton Exchange ended unchanged to 1 point higher yesterday.

James B. Taylor, a civilian test pilot, began preliminary flights here today for a series of power dive tests of the Seversky navy fighter, a low-wing all-metal monoplane for aerial combat. The test will last several days. The plane has a seat for the pilot only and is equipped with machine-guns and bomb racks.

Edward Somers, 12 years old, looked with steady eyes from each side of the open cockpit of a Fleet biplane poised yesterday on the runway at Floyd Bennett Field. Then with the assurance of a Lindbergh, he "gave her the gun," and as the motor roared, he took off on his first solo flight over Long Island.

America's Ryder Cup golf team reached England tonight after a "birdie shooting" contest on the English Channel, and left immediately for London to begin practice for the international matches against British pros at Southport June 29-30.

The Italian liner Roma arrived late yesterday from Mediterranean ports under the command of Captain Alberto Ottino, who was staff commander of the Rex three years ago. Since then he has been in the Italian Naval Reserve and for two years commanded the transport Lombardy, carrying troops to and from Abyssinia.

Frank Merkert, 49 years old, of 170-20 Ninetieth Avenue, Jamaica, pleaded guilty yesterday in Federal court, in Brooklyn, to an indictment charging him with embezzlement of $410 of the funds of the Jamaica branch of the Title Guarantee and Trust Company, by which he was formerly employed as head bookkeeper.

New York State, through Controller Morris S. Tremaine, sold today $40,000,000 of unemployment relief and construction bonds to a syndicate headed by the Bank of the Manhattan Company, New York, at a net interest rate of 2.19037 per cent.
Sitdown strikers remained in possession of the Apex Hosiery Company's plant here tonight in spite of a Federal court injunction, signed this afternoon, ordering their ejection "forthwith."

An effort to settle the strike of workers at the plant of the Tietjen Lang Drydock Company in Hoboken, one of a score of shipyards in the New York-New Jersey area tied up by the walkout of the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipyard Workers, resulted in failure yesterday when the company turned down the demands of the union. These demands,

President Roosevelt today ordered that the two new 35,000-ton battleships be built in navy yards, one at New York and the other at Philadelphia. The action was taken, the President said at a press conference, because of the large differential in construction costs between bids by private builders, and the estimates of the Navy Construction Corps.

Sir Henry Strakosch, prominent banker and economist, was named today as the probable anonymous donor of the f250,000 fund given to Earl Baldwin, former Prime Minister, to cement relations between the dominions and the crown.

A "shake-up" that will result in the transfer of at least six police inspectors and the possible demotion of two of them was rumored at police headquarters yesterday. While Police Commissioner Valentine refused to discuss the matter he did not deny that changes among divisional commanders were imminent.
Mr. and Mrs. Harold Dwight Mack of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Dorothy Mack, to Eugene Fairchild Russell Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Eugene F. Russell of Tarrytown.
Credit managers of the National Retail Dry Goods Association elected seven new regional directors and three directors-at-large today at the association's mid-year convention.

Branding the type of competition that American exporters are meeting from Germany in the Brazilian market as "unscrupulous and unfair," the American Chamber of Commerce in Brazil in a special report to the National Foreign Trade Council here suggested yesterday that some sort of special import duty be levied by Brazil against subsidized German exports to that market.

Recognition of the vital role of retailer-manufacturer relations with consumers, steps to remedy labor unrest in retailing, a warning of the "menace" of rising taxes, and improved practices in handling the wave of credit purchasing throughout the country featured the sessions here today of the midyear convention of the National Retail Dry Goods Association in the Palmer House.
Three foreign racing cars, all owned by young New York sportsmen, today appeared on the redesigned Roosevelt Raceway in practice spins for the 300-mile George Vanderbilt Cup race on July 3.

Four oil workers were killed and four others wounded in a clash between strikers and the police today as British sailors and marines were landed in an attempt to bring peace to the strike-torn island.
Not even witty lines can hide the structural defects of Philip Leaver's new comedy, "Three Set Out," offered at the Embassy Theatre tonight, the critics say.

Eight one-year art scholarships and eighty - eight medals were awarded yesterday to students of the city's high schools by the School Art League at annual exercises held in the Brooklyn Museum for the close of the school term. The awards are made for work done at school.

James Barclay Co., Ltd., distillers, will launch an intensive newspaper advertising campaign in New Jersey early in July on Barclay's two-year-old Private Stock Rye and new Seven Cup Blended Whisky, according to Arthur M. Q. Syme, sales manager for the metropolitan New York and New Jersey area.
Except in one bracket, form held true in first round matches of the Women's Long Island Golf Association annual tournament at the Women's National Golf and Tennis Club today.

Mediation Board called new parley of steel heads today after cons ferring with both sides yester, day.-Page 1. State troops took over control of Youngstown and kept steel mills closed. They seized 150 "invaders" and many weapons.Page 1.

The United Automobile Workers will open negotiations tomorrow with General Motors Corporation on an amended agreement and at the same time will pass out union literature to Ford Motor Company employes.

The marriage of Miss Helen Marie Mordaunt, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. Mordaunt of Pelham, N. Y., to Joseph A. Young, son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel A. Young of Glen Ridge, N. J., and this place, took place at noon today in the country Church of St. Ann at Canadensis.

Sales of houses in the downtown, Harlem and Washington Heights sections of Manhattan were announced yesterday. The twenty-family apartment house at 49 Leroy Street, corner of Seventh Avenue South, was sold by the estate of Samuel Hirsh to a client of Plante, Edwards Abraham for rehabilitating. Walter Samuels, Inc., and Alberti Romano were the brokers.

In its new quarters at 14 West Forty-ninth Street, where it is to remain until its permanent home is completed, the Museum of Modern Art today will open its Summer show of painting and sculpture from the permanent collection, augmented by examples from private collections.

Steel ingot production increased last week against a downward seasonal trend, and the adjusted index advanced to 108.6 from 105.4. It was 104.5 for the week ended June 20, 1936. THE NEW YORK TIMES estimated output at 76 per cent of capacity, compared with 75 per cent for the previous week and 72 per cent for the corresponding week last year.
Dr. Ernst Lert will discuss plans for an English translation of Wagner's "Ring" cycle, to be sponsored by the Richard Wagner Society, in the Hotel Barbizon at 5 P. M. today.

Nearing the end of its evidence against eight men on trial in the O'Connell kidnapping case, the government submitted testimony today purporting to show the defendants were associated in the liquor traffic during prohibition years.

Ellis L. Phillips took the witness stand yesterday in Supreme Court and denied that his life insurance premiums, the taxes and interest payments on his home in Long Island and other personal expenditures had been charged indirectly to the Long Island Lighting Company, of which he is president.

The first ray of hope in many years for Jarrow, the symbol of all of Great Britain's distressed areas, with 30 per cent of its men still unemployed, came today with the announcement by Oliver Stanley, president of the Board of Trade, that arrangements had been made for the formation of a new company to build and operate a plant for the manufacture and rolling of steel at Jarrow.

Miss Alice Marble's debut on the center court was today's tid-bit. Women's matches at Wimbledon, since Suzanne Lenglen blazed the trail, are nearly as intriguing as men's, now that almost every country is throwing up colorful champions.
President Roosevelt indicated today that he had been keeping in close touch with the steel strike situation, having remained ear a telephone most of the past few days and nights to do so.

The Chantry of St. Paul's Episcopal Church was the scene of the wedding today of Miss Carolyn Lindsay, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jesse W. Lindsay of East Avenue, and Robert White, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph J. White of New York, Dr. George E. Norton, rector, officiated.
Weakness in the forward franc rate yesterday provided the only indication in the foreign exchange market of the pressure on the franc occasioned by the government crisis in France.
The bones of Henry the Fowler, first King of Germany, have been exhumed in the ancient town of Quedlinburg, it was announced here today.

The twentieth anniversary season of concerts at Lewisohn Stadium will open tonight with the orchestra of the Philharmonic-Symphony Society playing again. Vladimir Golschmann, conductor of the St. Louis Symphony Orchestra,

Four German warships-the cruiser Koeln and the destroyers Leopard, Luchs and Tiger-arrived at Algeciras this afternoon and with the battleship Admiral Scheer, the cruiser Leipzig and the destroyer Seeadler already off Ceuta, Spanish Morocco, there are insistent rumors at Gibraltar that they are concentrating in preparation for a naval demonstration at Valencia and other Spanish government ports.

Opposition to the amended plan of reorganization of the Standard Gas and Electric Company, now pending in the United States District Court of Delaware, developed yesterday with the announcement by a committee for the noteholders and bondholders,

Governer Davey issued an order to National Guardsmen tonight to "carry out the terms of the court order" of Judge Lynn Griffith of Warren, limiting steel plant picketing, and "granting the right of the workers of those mills to go to and from their homes without molestation."

Announcement has been made of the marriage of Mrs. Ruth Ronald Stevens of this city to Remington Korper, which took place on Monday at Dongan Hills, S. I. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. John J. Moment, pastor of the Crescent Avenue Presbyterian Church of Plainfield, N. J., in the future residence of Mr. and Mrs. Korper in Circle Road.

Georges Bonnet, when he returns from his Ambassadorship in Washington to become the new French Finance Minister, will face a task of restoration resembling in many ways that undertaken by the late Raymond Poincare in 1926.

Reflecting the revival in the railway equipment market, the American Car and Foundry Company reported yesterday that in the year ended April 30 it had net earnings of $1,210,676, which compared with a net loss of $582,515 in the preceding like period. Gross earnings, after a deduction of $198,000 for estinated Federal normal taxes, were $4,972,170 in the fiscal year just ended, against $2,197,202 in the preceding period.

The C. I. O. scored another victory in the transportation field here yesterday, when the Transport Workers Union won a referendum held for employes of the New York City Omnibus Corporation, operator of most of the new bus lines in Manhattan.

Miss Ruth Yeaton Power-O'Malley of 4 East Ninety-fifth Street and James Warner Bellah, a member of the faculty of Columbia University, were married on Monday in Alexandria, Va., by the Rev. Pierce Ellis. Mr. and Mrs. Bellah are at the Marguery, 270 Park Avenue.
The Mark Twain Junior High School, Neptune and West Twentyfourth Street, Brooklyn, which was opened for classes on June 1, was formally dedicated yesterday. About 500 persons attended the exercises.

Deals involving two Bronx properties valued at more than $500,000 were reported yesterday by Grudin Sawitch, brokers. For Rabreal Estates, Inc., the brokers sold to the Bemac Realty Corporation the six-story elevator apartment house on a plot 200 by 100 feet at 2,081 Cruger Avenue, in the Pelham Parkway section.

Papers to incorporate the Highway Security League as a membership organization were filed with the Secretary of State today. The league proposes to "promote highway security and bring about the greater comfort and conveni ence of the users of the highways. It would employ legislative action. publicity and other methods, it was stated.

The East was left with two survivors, one each from Princeton and Pittsburgh, today as the field in the national intercollegiate tennis championship was cut to sixteen, with two more of the favored group making their exits.

Arthur Loomis Harmon has been elected president of the New York Chapter of the American Institute of Architects, it was announced yesterday. He succeeded Hobart B. Upjohn. The other officers elected were Eric Kebbon, vice president; Frederick G. Frost, secretary; Cornelius J. White, treasurer, and Harvey Stevenson, recorder.

Italy accords Germany full solidarity in whatever action she may take to avenge the alleged affront suffered by the German cruiser Leipzig, which was reported to have been the target of two unsuccessful torpedo attacks by Spanish Loyalist submarines.

Joseph F. Collins, Deputy Superintendent of Insurance at the Albany office of the State Department of Insurance, has been appointed chief of the miscellaneous bureau at the office here in the State building, 80 Centre Street, Louis H. Pink, Superintendent of Insurance, announced yesterday.

Fees in excess of $600,000 were awarded by Supreme Court Justice Ernest E. L. Hammer yesterday to attorneys and accountants representing the plaintiffs in a stockholders' suit against Albert H. Wiggin and other former and present officials of Chase National Bank.

Twelve airplanes, including eight United States Army planes from the Panama Canal Zone, searched vainly all this morning for a plane with a pilot and five passengers which disappeared Sunday morning on a one-hour flight from the Panama border to this city.

The final concert and commencement of the fifty-ninth year of the New York College of Music took place last night at the Town Hall before an audience of good size. Awards of diplomas, certificates and testimonials were made by Carl Hein, director. John H. Meyer, secretary delivered a short address.

Dr. Joseph Van den Berg, an Xray specialist with an office and laboratory at 43 East Twenty-fifth Street, died yesterday at his residence, 270 Riverside Drive, of heart disease, after an illness of a few days. His widow, Mary, and a son, Alan, survive.

The Reconstruction Finance Corporation, in a report today to Congress for the first quarter of 1937, listed repayments on loans for the three months as $115,263,225 and loan disbursements as $73,223,118.
Sixty-three boyd who will enter Harvard next Fall as freshmen have been awarded scholarships totalling $20,425. Among the recipients are: John F. Ambrose of Ozone Park, N. Y.

Declaring that the city "cannot afford the luxury of a political government any more;" Mayor La Guardia appealed to business men yesterday to place candidates in the field for Councilmen to be elected under the new city charter, effective Jan. 1.
The members of the House of Commons voted themselves pay rises today. They will now receive [Pound]600 a year instead of [Pound]400. Seventeen votes were recorded against the increase.

The Department of Agriculture's preliminary estimate of the world's wheat production this year shows how strikingly what is called the "wheat position "has changed since 1932. During some years prior to 1928, production and consumption apparently balanced fairly, for the unsold surplus left at each season's end was normal.
The Mexican police, cooperating with United States and Cuban authorities, broke up today an international band of counterfeiters of United States $10 and $20 bills.
Frank H. Larned, formerly in the United States consular service and a former official of the United States Bureau of Immigration, died last night at his home here at the age of 76.

Edward De Gray joined Morris Adelsberg in the quarter-finals of the Richmond County men's singles at Clifton Tennis Club, Arrochar, S. I., yesterday when he defeated Robert Low, 6-3, 11-9. Joseph A. Sinclair entered the quarter-final round also when David Geller failed to appear for his match.

On Saturday the Bethlehem plants at Johnstown were closed by Governor EARLE for the stated purpose of avoiding violence. On Monday, for the same purpose, Governor DAVEY forbade two companies in Youngstown to open additional plants.

The War Department estimates $1,200,000 should be spent on the Merrimack River flood control program in the first year of a four-year construction program. The Merrimac was one of fifteen streams listed for immediate work in a priority list submitted by the department and made public recently by the House Appropriations Committee with testimony on the War Department functions appropriation.

The Public Service Commission announced yesterday that it had authorized the New York Telephone Company to issue $25,000,000 of refunding mortgage 3 1/4 per cent bonds. The issue is to be sold to underwriters at not less than 98 per cent of. principal amount to realize proceeds to the company of not less than $24,500,000.

Instead of being afraid of the "consumer movement" demanding facts on merchandise, advertisers should "welcome it as the greatest selling opportunity in their history, dumped literally on each advertising desk in this country," Mrs. Lois B. Hunter of the local office of N. W. Ayer Son told the Retail Advertising Conference held yesterday in conjunction with the thirty-third annual convention of the Advertising Federation of America at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

The last came first in the One-day amateur tournament of the Long Island Golf Association at the Sound View Golf Club today, when Celestin Durand Jr. of the Garden City Golf Club, in one of the last teams to start, came in with a card of 71.

" My troubles getting to the title are now over and my only regret is that I did not have Max Schmeling in the ring tonight instead of the man I knocked out," was the way Joe Louis quietly summed up his triumph upon arriving in his dressing room amid a babble of congratulations from all sides.

B. Altman Co., New York, has entered into a stipulation with the Federal Trade Commission to stop making certain "unfair misrepresentations" with respect to the sale of women's blouses, the commission announced today. The concern agreed,

Apparently abandoning plans to match Tommy Farr, British Empire champion, against the winner of tonight's Jimmy Braddock-Joe Louis fight, White City Stadium promoters announced today that Farr had signed to meet Max Schmeling in a 15round bout. The date for the fight, scheduled for White City, has not been set.
Governor Lehman named H. V. Noyes of Kenwood-as Commissioner of Agriculture and Markets today to take the place of Peter G. Ten Eyck of Albany, who resigned last week.

Through the use of microphotography, by which the smallest detail on a music manuscript can be reproduced, a wider knowledge and enjoyment of music can be afforded to the general public, R. H. Carruthers, who is in charge of experimental work on microphotography at the New York Public Library, declared yesterday.

Obviously happy as old friends and coaching colleagues pumped his hand in congratulation after the varsity finish, Al Ulbrickson was the first to admit candidly that he didn't expect the record-setting victory in the main race today. "To be frank, I am surprised," he explained.

Mark Graves, State Tax Commissioner, announced in a letter to comptroller Frank J. Taylor today that the Tax Commission had decided to administer collection of the 2 per cent utility tax on a State-wide basis. The law permitted New York City to collect the tax and pay it to the State.

For the first time in thirtynine years Poughkeepsie had a phantom boat race this afternoon. It was not carefully planned like the Braddock-Schmeling fight of recent memory, but was quite impromptu. That is what added so much to its appeal.

Investigation of the use of demonstrators of cosmetics and toilet preparations by certain manufacturers in this field as a violation of fair trade practice was begun yesterday by the Federal Trade Commission at its hearing rooms at 45 Broadway.

At the request of Thomas E. Dewey, special prosecutor of rackets, the sentencing of James Plumeri, alias Jimmy Doyle, and John Dioguardi, alias Johnny Dio, was postponed yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook until July 19.
Classroom reading of Shakespeare's "Merchant of Venice" was banned today in Boston public schools as a result of complaints that the character of "Shylock" was offensive to the Jewish race.

The Pirates defeated the Bees, 4 to 1, today for the Boston club's tenth consecutive defeat. Cy Blanton had pitched perfect ball until Di Maggio came up with two out in the fifth to hit the ball over the left-field wall.

Bursting with civic pride and enthusiasm in having achieved something which only a few months ago was deemed impossible of accomplishment, Chicago went all out tonight to make a rousing triumph of its second world heavyweight extravaganza in ten years.

Treasury officials told the joint Congressional committee investigating income tax avoidance and evasion today that the government had failed for four years to collect $549,501.97 due from six New Yorkers alleged to have bought "fictitious" insurance policies from a Bahamas company to escape taxes of that amount.

A reduction in the price of electricity used in excess of 200 kilowatt hours a month for the benefit of residential customers owning electric water heaters has been filed by two companies in Oswego County, the Publice Service Commission said today.

Notice that counsel for the operators of the dog-racing track at the Mineola Fair Grounds would seek to have the gambling charges pending against them referred to the Nassau County grand jury was served today on District Attorney Martin W. Littleton.

Samuel D. Riddle, owner of War Admiral, outstanding three-yearold race horse of 1937, will be the guest of honor at the annual dinner of the Thoroughbred Club of America this year, it was announced tonight.

Wheat prices in North American markets advanced today into new high ground for the current upturn on further reports of black-rust damage in Winter wheat fields in the Southwest and in Illinois, and drought reports from parts of the Canadian Northwest. The market, however,

One of the most brazen murders in the history of the city was committed yesterday afternoon by two men in an automobile while they a were being pursued by a policemanwho had heard cries of "help, police, murder!" coming from the car as it passed him.

The Northern Securities Company, said to be the oldest of railroad holding companies and one which evoked an epochal decision by the United States Supreme Court upholding the Sherman Anti-Trust Law, is to be dissolved, it was announced yesterday.

Twenty-seven cases against the Interborough Rapid Transit Company involving insanitary platforms and comfort stations. which have been pending since June. 1936 were virtually dropped by the Health Department yesterday in Municipal Term Court.

William Brunner, President of the New York City Board of Aldermen, said after a conference today with Senator Wagner that a $42,000,000 model housing project planned in Queens County probably would be eligible for Federal funds.

Reynolds Smith, chunky 4-year-old Walker Cup performer from Dallas, Texas, drove in at the fag end of a windwhipped field to capture the medal today in the thirty-seventh annual trans-Mississippi golf tournament.

Joseph Burstiner, pioneer builder of apartment houses here and a lover of trees, died today at his home in his sixty-sixth year. Mr. Burstiner was one of a group of real estate men instrumental in changing this city from a community of small homes to one with many apartment houses.

Washington wasted no time in starting its sweep on the Hudson today. Starting with almost the first stroke of the blades in the freshman race, the Huskies jumped out in the lead and stayed there over every foot of the course.

While business failures declined in the retail and commercial service groups in the week ended June 17, compared with the same period last year, increases were recorded in the manufacturing, wholesale and construction divisions, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

Although a member of the high command of the State forces here described Johnstown this evening as the "quietest city in the country," indications coming from Harrisburg were that the State of martial law declared by Governor Earle in connection with the strike at the Bethlehem Steel Corporation's Cambria plant would continue indefinitely.

The Rebecca Elsberg Memorial scholarship prizes have been awarded to Geraldine Gallagher of Public School 115, Manhattan, and to Demetrius Hadjinanos of Public School 30, Manhattan. it was announced yesterday.

The Relief Bill has now passed both the House and the Senate in the form desired by the Administration. It appropriates the full amount of $1,500,000,000 without restrictions on the discretion of the President or the WPA Administrator regarding its allocation.

Premier Paul van Zeeland of Belgium will be received by President Roosevelt' tomorrow for their much-discussed conversations on economic and peace questions and with Mrs. van Zeeland will be the guest overnight at the White House of the President and Mrs. Roosevelt.

52d St, 102 E, 38.4x79.4; 102 E. 52d St Corp to Union Dime Savings Bank; mtg $110,000 held by bank. 45th St, 251-57 W, 80x100.5; P. F. G. Realty Corp to Avreal Corp, 485 Madison Ave ($13). Columbia St; e s, 24.10 n of Stanton St, 21.8x75.4; Lillian Mittelman to Joseph H. and Mollie Mittelman, 116 Columbia St. 113th St, 81 E, 25x101; Anna Schnapper to Excelsior Savings Bank; mtg $12,000 held by bank.

Work was resumed today at the Chevrolet and Fisher body plants here, following a shutdown since Wednesday. Sufficient engines and other parts were received from the Middle West yesterday to permit the resumption of work, and 800 cars were produced today.

The Society of the New York Hospital, with its affiliated units, cared for more patients last year than in 1935 and the expenditure of approximately $3,725,000 in their behalf last year was greater than in 1935. the society's report revealed yesterday.

More than 800. workers on WPA art projects went on sit-down strikes yesterday, disrupted office work, picketed and caused the cancellation of three scheduled musical performances in protest against dismissal notices sent out from Washington to 2,848 of their number.

The administration forces in the Senate rejected all moves to reduce the $1,500,000,000 relief appropriation for the fiscal year 1938 today and passed the bill without a roll call in the form desired by the President.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are June 21 unless specified: At Humpback Bay: Brooks, Fox. Mare Island Yard to San Diego: Cuttlefish, Koka. New London to New York: Erie, Fairfax, Jacob Jones, Manley, Roper, J. F. Talbott.

Leo F. Fitzpatrick, manager of the uptown office of the Fidelity and Deposit Company of Maryland, at 11 West Forty-second Street, died during his sleep Monday night at his home, 40 East Eighty-eighth Street, of a heart attack.

The National Association of Insurance Commissioners, at its annual convention today, instructed its committee on unauthorized insurance to study a suggested form of Federal regulation of "irresponsible" companies defrauding policyholders through the sale of worthless contracts.

The marriage of Miss Mary A Ingraham, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry A. Ingraham of Brooklyn and this place to Dr. Henry Bunting, son of Dr. and Mrs. Charles Henry Bunting of Madison, Wis., took place here today at the Summer home of the bride's parents.

The experience of the men's clothing industry in the last four months should result in considerable changes in the merchandising and advertising of the 1938 lines by both manufacturers and retailers, according to comment expressed here yesterday by agency executives.

The five-week-old strike at the Norma - Hoffman Bearings Corporation plant was settled today with the signing of an agreement by the company and Local 219, United Electrical and Radio Workers of America.

Colonel Calvin Duval Cowles, one of the few remaining Indian campaigners, died here today at his home of pneumonia after a brief illness. He was 86 years old. His last active service was during the World War as military training director.

For the second successive year crews of the University of Washington won all three races of the Intercollegiate Rowing Association yesterday on the Hudson at Poughkeepsie. This was the first time in modern rowing annals that a two-year sweep had been accomplished.

Miss Patricia Godfrey, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William S. Godfrey, was introduced this afternoon at a tea which her parents gave at Woodforde, their home in Ardmore. The debutante received with her mother.

The New York Trade School, 304326 East Sixty-seventh Street, will complete its fifty-sixth year on Friday with the termination of classes in electrical work and plumbing, it was announced yesterday by the superintendent, H. V. Brill. The school is said to be the oldest trade school in the world.
Open-market discount rates on bankers' acceptance were reduced yesterday in response to an increase in the demand and a slackening in the supply of this type of paper.

The New York American, Hearst daily morning newspaper, as such will publish its last issue tomorrow. Beginning on Friday the daily issue will be consolidated with The New York Journal in the evening and with The New York Mirror in the morning field, it is disclosed in an announcement in today's New York American.

Dr. W. S. Lockhart, for forty years a minister of the Disciples of Christ, died in a hospital here yesterday. He had held pastorates in Houston, Texas; Youngstown, Ohio, and Huntington, Ind., before coming to the Highland Avenue Church here.

Invitations have been sent out by Mr. and Mrs. Albert Gallatin Glidden of this city for the marriage of their daughter, Miss Mary Dayton Glidden, to Arthur Wellesley Patterson 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. A. Wellesley Patterson of Roselle. The wedding will take place July 10 in St. Luke's Episcopal Church at Roselle.

Miss Roberta Read Lewis, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harmon Lewis of this place, was married this afternoon to Robert Thrun, son of Mrs. Ferdinand Thrun of Eagle River, Wis., in the garden of her parents' home here. The Rev. Charles Warren Baldwin, rector of St. Mary's Episcopal Church, performed the ceremony.

The Cornell board of trustees elected Dr. Livingston Farrand president emeritus at their annual meeting yesterday. His elevation to the post came on the sixteenth anniversary of the day when he was elected to the presidency of the board.

President Roosevelt said today that when he was away from his desk on Sunday he worked from 10 in the morning until after midnight and that yesterday, when a slight nasal infection kept him in the White House, his working day ran from 9:30 A. M Monday until 1 A. M. today.

Miss Constance Cutter Morrow, youngest daughter of Mrs. Dwight Whitney Morrow of Next Day Hill, Englewood, N. J., and the late Senator Morrow, was married here in the Morrow Summer home at Deacon Brown's Point today, to Aubrey Niel Morgan, youngest son of Mr. and Mrs. John Llewellyn Morgan of Llandaff. Wales.

Lee Grissom, 24-year- old southpaw rookie, pitched a 6-to-0 shutout over Philadelphia today to boost the Reds into sixth place in the National League, the highest spot they have enjoyed all season. It was Grissom's sixth victory against as many defeats.

Directors of the Federal Motor Truck Company have been compelled to postpone several times their meeting to consider dividend action because of the illness of two members of the board. They now hope to hold the meeting Friday afternoon or evening.

Emanuel Boasberg, tobacco merchant and philanthropist, died today, at the age of 71, while the body of his nephew, Al Boasberg, Hollywood humorist, was on its way home from California, where the nephew died last week.

Mullan Pl (18-5521), s s. 204 ft e of Pennyfield Ave, 50x100; Locust Point Estates, Inc, to Charles De Souter, 3,090 Mullan PI. Garfield St, 1,670-1,676, and Van Nest Ave, 600 (15-4027); Alfred Mann to Nicola Bianchi, 1,649 Taylor Ave. 167th St, 896 E (10-2716); Clara Petersel to Bowery Savings Bank, 110 E 42d St. Bronxwood Ave, 4,111 (17-4854); Anna Konzelman to Pasquale Di Georgia, 656 E 221st St.

Twelve thousand workers on WPA construction and white collar projects in this city will be dropped on June 30, with other thousands to follow by July 15, Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, Works Progress Administrator here, announced yesterday.

Making his move after the early leaders had retired, Ralph E. Fair's Abaddon, an obscure three-year-old son of Diavolo, closed fast on the outside in the stretch to snatch the mile Derry Purse by a neck at Rockingham Park today.

Dissolution of the sixty-year-old law firm of Hughes, Schurman Dwight became known here yesterday at the same time that the name of Richard E. Dwight, a member, was mentioned in testimony before the Congressional committee in Washington which is investigating methods of tax avoidance. Mr.

General chairmen of the five railway oprating brotherhoods decided today to authorize a strike vote of their 300,000 members to force a showdown with the railroads over demands for a 20 per cent wage increase.
Led by Mayor William E. Meiser, police today penetrated picket lines at the S. Kantor shirt factory here to permit nearly eighty non-striking workers to return to their jobs.

While draught beer sales in May were more than a quarter of a million barrels less than in May last year, packaged beer sales increased 378,000 barrels, according to figures announced yesterday by the Treasury Department.

James Wallace Tower, consulting engineer and architect, long associated with Hardy S. Ferguson Co., 200 Fifth Avenue, died during his sleep Sunday night at his residence, the Hotel Flanders, 137 West Forty-seventh Street.

Twelve hundred of the 2,600 barbers on strike on the upper West Side of Manhattan and in Brooklyn returned to work yesterday morning as a result of individual agreements signed with their employers, it was announced by John Tartamella, international representative of the Journeymen Barbers International Union.

Arlene Brunette, 25-year-old wife of Harry Brunette, who is serving a life sentence for the kidnapping of a New Jersey trooper, was sentenced here today to an indeterminate term in the Clinton Reformatory for Women after pleading guilty to a charge of carrying concealed weapons. Sentence was imposed by Judge Ralph J. Smalley in Somerset County Quarter Sessions Court.
The kidnap note which was found after the disappearance of Mrs. William H. Parsons on June 9, bore an identification symbol, L. Barron Hill, Suffolk County District Attorney, said yesterday.
Monty Stratton was in fine form today, limiting the faltering Athletics to three singles as he pitched the White Sox to a 2-to-O victory. It was his eighth triumph of the season against four defeats.

Abraham Bernstein of 47 Fort Washington Avenue, executive director of the Institutional Synagogue for the last twelve years, died on Monday night in Sydenham Hospital from injuries suffered in an automobile accident at 121st Street and Eighth Avenue. He was 57 years old.

Liberty in the United States is seriously threatened and the nation must be on its guard lest in curing the sins of industrial capitalism a "bastard democracy," communistic in essence and employing Fascist methods to gain its ends, be set up, Dr. James Rowland Angell, president of Yale University, asserted here today..

The general death rate for the city in the week ended last Saturday was the lowest recorded in any week since that ended Oct. 3, 1936, Dr. John L. Rice, Commissioner of Health, reported yesterday. The total of 1,251 deaths brought the rate to 8.8 per 1,000 population, as compared with a rate of 11.6 for the twenty-four weeks since the first of the year.

A movement to make President Roosevelt the Democratic nominee in 1940 is gaining headway in Pennsylvania, and those who are promoting it among organized labor and Democratic workers say that it has not been discouraged by James A. Farley, Democratic National Chairman.

Derbyshire, English county cricket champion, suffered its third defeat of the season today. The Midlanders lost to Yorkshire by an Innings and 95 runs. Sussex halted the fast slipping Hampshire eleven by 153 runs.

The Appellate Division, reversing a determination made by Controller Frank J. Taylor, ruled yesterday that New York University and the Y. M. C. A. are exempt from the city sales tax as charitable institutions.

Oliver Goldsmith Carter, president of C. W. H. Carter, Inc., manufacturers of lithographic varnishes and specialties for the manufacture of printing ink, died suddenly Monday night of a heart attack at the home of his sister-in-law, Miss Maude Connelly,109 Marlboro Road, Brooklyn.
The output of gold mines in Ontario in May was $7,315,799, a new high for the year, the Ontario Department of Mines reported today. Output in April was $6,979,588 and in May, 1936, $6,511,801.

The name of Jacob (Gurrah) Shapiro, industrial racketeer being sought as a bail jumper on his recent two-year sentence in the Federal court on a conviction in the fur racket, was brought into the Special Sessions trial of Irving Rudow yesterday on a State tax-evasion charge.

Thorkil Aschehoug of Mamaroneck has purchased, through Peter C. Doern Jr., Inc., the stone and shingle Colonial residence of Frank H. Giffing on the corner of Walton and Seney Avenues, Orienta Point, Westchester.

The annual report of the General Investment Corporation for the fiscal year ended May 31, 1937, shows gross income of $166,831, against $209,252 the year before, and net income after expenses and taxes of $52,541. against $122,935.

A three-year-old tragi-comic feud between a Bronx automobile sales agency and a self-styled "sucker" who utilized his "lemon" to advertise the alleged faults of his automobile came to a close yesterday afternoon in the Bronx Supreme Court before Justice Francis Bergan when the customer won a $200 verdict against one of the agency's salesmen.

Price movements of commodity futures were generally upward in moderate activity on the local markets yesterday. Crude rubber and pepper futures, exceptions, lost ground. In the cash markets, wheat, corn, tin and silk advanced, but rye, oats, butter and rubber fell.

Mrs. Owen Johnson had as guests this afternoon at Ingleside, Stockbridge, seventy members of the Lenox Garden Club, of which she is president. It was the first full club meeting this Summer and proposed activities were discussed. Miss Mabel Choate gave an illustrated talk on Mexican gardens she visited several weeks ago. Mrs. William Ellery Sedgewick assisted the hostess.

MARKS, ESTHER (June 10). Estate, less than $7,500. To Mrs. E. H. Long, niece, 186 2d St., Albany, and Mrs. J. La Cory, niece, 182 2d St., Albany, $675 and 20 per cent residue each; eleven bequests ranging from $25 to $225 each; Esther M. Weil, cousin, executrix, 45 Wadsworth Ave., $400 and 60 per cent residue.

When the diplomatic stage is as carefully set for the visit of a Foreign Minister of a Great Power as was that at London for the reception this week of Baron CONSTANTIN VON NEURATH only the most unexpected developments of grave importance are allowed to intervene to change his plans.

Harvey Gibson, president of the Manufacturers Trust Company of New York, told the Securities and Exchange Commission today that he disapproved of affiliations between commercial banks and investment trusts.

President Roosevelt announced at his press conference that the navy's two new battleships would be built in navy yards. The Senate passed the $1,500,000,000 Relief Bill and recessed at 5:25 P. M. until noon tomorrow. The Postoffice Committee announced that it had subpoenaed Tom M. Girdler, president of the Republic Steel Corporation, to appear at Thursday's session of its investigation into interference with the mails in the steel strike.
Frankie Frisch, manager of the St. Louis Cardinals, was asked today if he expected any pitching help this season from Paul Dean, who is recovering from an operation on his hurling arm.

Discovery that electricity, streaming out behind airliners in flight, caused the static which broke off radio signals just before some of last Winter's fatal air crashes, was announced today to the American Association for the Advancement of Science here.

A reduction of 5 per cent in employment and 30 per cent in wage disbursements in Pennsylvania anthracite mines from the middle of April to mid-May was reported today by the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia.

Because she recently inherited $3,000, an 80-year-old widow was ordered by Supreme Court Justice Sydney A. Syme today to repay to the State the $2,382 old-age pension she had received from January, 1931, through last December.

Ununiformed Fireman William J. Corry Jr. of Engine Co. 289, died June 21. Funeral will take place from the funeral parlors of Dennis T. Kennedy, 87-20 Woodhaven Boulevard, Woodhaven, Queens, at 9:30 A. M., Wednesday, June 23. Services will be held at Church of St. Thomas The Apostle. 87th St. and 88th Ave.. Woodhaven. Interment at St. John's Cemetery, Queens. No funeral escort desired.

The National Association of Dyers and Cleaners, representing 1,500 cleaning plants, is prepared to award its signet of serviceability to those manufacturers whose merchandise meets the association's laboratory tests, it was announced today by Christopher J. Wagnev, director of merchandise approval, at the convention of the American Home Economics Bureau at the Hotel Muehlebach here. Manufacturers, he pointed out, will be licensed to advertise the emblem.

Bob Burns and Martha Raye will make their debut as a starring comedy team today at the Paramount in "Mountain Music," featuring George Hayes, Terry Walker, a newcomer from the night clubs; Fuzzy Knight and Jan Duggan
Frederick B. Snite Jr., prisoner in an "iron lung" respirator for 450 days, concluded one of the most dramatic adventures in medical annals today a 12,000-mile journey by ship and train from China.

Despite the lively anticipations of early progress in the settlement of Chino-Japanese problems that were aroused in connection with the forthcoming return to China from Tokyo of Ambassador Shigeru Kawagoe, there does not appear to be the slightest chance of breaking the present deadlock.

MOST radio announcers (no need to mention names) write pretty frothy books when they write books at all. Not Thomas Woodrooffe. His "Yangtze Skipper" ($2.50), the first volume published by the new New York firm of Sheridan House, is light reading however one looks at it, but it is also good reading and highly entertaining.

Bilbao's defenders lost the city in battle in the open country. It is true that Nationalist [Rebel] aviation and heavy artillery made possible the fall of the city, but these means of warfare were used only to demolish the. "iron ring" fortifications thrown around Bilbao at distances seven to fifteen miles from the city.

The body of Mrs. Hazel Whelan, said to have been a former Mack Sennett bathing beauty, was found here tonight in her apartment at 11 Harrison Street. Dr. George p. Olcott Jr., Assistant Medical Examiner of Essex County, gave a tentative verdict of suicide by poisoning, based on several notes found near the body, but withheld a final verdict pending an autopsy which will be performed tomorrow morning.

Miss Ruth Miriam De Young, daughter of Mrs. Frederic R. De Young and the late Justice De Young, was married yesterday afternoon to Herbert V. Kohler of Kohler, Wis. The ceremony was performed here in St. Paul's Episcopal Church by the Rev.John C. Evans, religious editor of The Chicago Tribune, of which Miss De Young was women's page editor.

Speaking at the inauguration of the South African pavilion at the Paris Exposition this afternoon, N. C. Havenga, South African Finance Minister, discredited rumors of a reduction in the price of gold and expressed the belief that ultimately the world would return to gold.

Movements of livestock on the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts, 15,000, including 3,500 direct. Market generally steady with yesterday's average; top $11.65:

Failure of the four naval powers to agree on the procedure to be adopted in dealing with reported attacks on' the German cruiser Leipzig by Spain is destined to have an unfortunate effect on the prospects for a British diplomatic demarche for liquidation of the Spanish crisis.
Rifted Clouds, from the Woolford Farm of Kansas City, returned to the races today at Washington Park to score in the Turf and Field Club Handicap.

FRITSCHE, MADELEINE W. (April 21, 1936). Gross assets, $244,679; net, $225, 394. To Elizabeth M. Scheurer, daughter, $130,000, personal effects and life estate in residue; Adolf Schuerer, son-in-law, succeeding estate in residue; Society for the Relief of the Destitute Blind of the City of New York, St. John's Guild and New York Society for the Relief of Ruptured and Crippled,

Alderman Newbold Morris, Manhattan Republican, was smothered with opposition in the Board of Aldermen yesterday when he tried to have rescinded a resolution authorizing the purchase of $175,000 worth of Remington-Rand business machines, which is now before Mayor La Guardia for signature.

Trading was mostly fair. Steer hinds and ribs were moderately higher and some fresh pork cuts sharply higher. The veal market was steady and lamb uneven. Early trading in kosher meats indicated prices to be about in line with Monday's close as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.

Leaders of rival labor groups in the waterfront strikes of the last two years conferred yesterday on a program to maintain peace in Atlantic and Gulf shipping pending the outcome of an election which the National Labor Relations Board plans to conduct among the unlicensed personnel of ships.

The House, by a vote of 218 to 126, passed today the Sumners bill, creating an additional method of trying impeachment charges against Federal district judges accused of misbehavior. The measure was sent to the Senate.

The convention establishing the forty-hour week in the textile industry was adopted by the International LaborOrganization Conference today by a vote of 88 to 41, with 38 abstentions-three votes more than necessary for a two-thirds majority.

Delmar Brown, winner of the Princeton invitation quarter-mile race, and his twin brother Elmer, both of North Texas State Teachers College, will be seen in action in the 440-yard event at the World Labor Athletic Carnival on July 11 at Randalls Island, it was announced yesterday.

Making her way over 23.7 miles through two windless drifts and four rain squalls, Gerard B. Lambert's Yankee today won the third of the observation trial races toward selection of the America's Cup defender. Chandler Hovey's Rainbow, her opponent, did not finish.

The Browns have put their baseball games on a charge account basis. Eighteen hundred civic and business leaders of St. Louis have been given the privilege of seeing a game or sending a group of friends or visiting business men to Sportsman's Park and paying later.

The Brit ish political agent at Gilgit, Kashmir, now reports that Dr. Karl Wien, leader of the German Nanga Parbat expedition in the Himalayas, perished in the avalanche that took sixteen other lives.
The twentythird annual Tuberculosis Day game at Sportsman's Park today was a grand success for everybody except the Gas House Gang.
Mrs. Catharine Breyer Worrilow, daughter of Mrs. Henry W. Breyer and the late Mr. Breyer, was married at her mother's home here this afternoon to Leroy A. Van Bomel of New York.

The silver mace of the old Irish House of Commons, which used to muster the twelve tribes of Galway, was sold at auction here today for $15,500. L. C. Honham, acting, for a Dublin bank, was the successful bidder in the sale, held at Christie's.

A new automobile engine, said to eliminate normal maintenance and decarbonization expenses, has been developed by a research engineer at Bury, England, according to a report from the London Consulate to the Department of Commerce.

Confronted with an adverse trade balance of 625,000,000 yen (about $179,375,000), Japan prepared today to ship 200,000,000 yen (about $57,400,000) in gold bullion to the United States to settle international accounts and support the yen.

Members of The Jockey Club did well at Aqueduct yesterday, as the main prizes fell to men who have been leaders in American racing for years. The featured Diavolo Purse saw the filly Drawbridge win as she pleased by five lengths in a field of four at the end of the mile.

By THOMAS F. BURCHILL Amsterdam Ave 1,268, five-story tenement; Greenwich Savings Bank against Ray Schmitt Scheid; due, $21,568; taxes, $628; to plaintiff for $15,000. By EDWIN J. McDONALD Front St, 74, four-story loft; Margaret A Jamison against Financial District Real ty, Inc.; due, $57,304; taxes, , $350; to plaintiff for $3,500.

Although the net current operating earnings of the 13,956 commercial banks insured by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation in 1936 amounted to $481,000,000, a gain of 9 per cent over 1935, they were equivalent to 90 cents for each $100 of assets, compared to 92 cents in 1935, according to the annual report of the corporation, part of which was made public today.

In an article welcoming the ninth Congress of the International Chamber of Commerce, which is meeting here next week, Colonel General Hermann Goering, commissioner in charge of the Four-Year Plan, today emphasized anew that Germany had no intention of changing her economic policies but would pursue national independence through economic independence on the basis of the Four-Year Plan and controlled foreign trade.

Miss Betty Bryne of Pitman, N. J., upset one of the district's leading players, Miss Mary Louis Stafford of Philadelphia, 6 and 5 today to reach the quarter-final round of the fourteenth annual Philadelphia district girls' golf championship tournament.

Joseph Schroeder has been elected a vice president of Dwight, Voorhis Perry, Inc. The other officers are: President, Henry R. Dwight; vice presidents, Harry B. Helmsley and William T. Simonton; treasurer, George Hyde, and secretary, Frank Dietz.

Dr. Fritz Voitche, a Nazi who the police charged had been concerned in a somewhat fantastic plot to shoot Chancellor Kurt Schuschnigg at the side of his wife's grave in Hietzing cemetery and had plotted an equally fantastic scheme to bomb the Chancellery from a private airplane, was tried today and sentenced to twelve years' imprisonment.

With the graduation exercises today of the undergraduate schools of Yale University, half of the commencement program was completed. Tomorrow the annual festivities will be ended with the conferring of graduate and honorary degrees.

Residents of New York have to be twice as good as persons from other parts of the country because twice as much is expected of them, Mayor La Guardia told thirty-two Boy Scouts who visited City Hall yesterday.

Retail grocers from all parts of the country took part in a general forum on merchandising, advertising and sales promotion of groceries at the retail point, at the fortieth annual convention of the National Association of Retail Grocers in Mechanics Hall today.

Dr. Albert E. Payne of this village, one of the leading physicians in Suffolk County, died at the Southampton Hospital, Southampton, early this morning of diabetes and heart disease. He was 65 years old.
Stockton Beekman Colt, a retired New York architect, died here this afternoon at his home, 910 Salem Avenue, after a long illness. His age was 74.

Dr. Roger W. Burt of 36 Onondaga Street, Rye, a dentist with offices at 67 Park Avenue, New York, died tonight in the White Plains Hospital of injuries suffered this morning when his automobile struck a rock here.
Thirty-five members of Wellesley's graduating class this year were eligible for the traditional ceremonyrunning around the tables at the annual senior banquet-for those who are engaged to be married.

The indications are for fair weather with slowly rising temperatures today and tomorrow, according to the map charted at the United States Weather Bureau at 7:30 o'clock (E. S. T.) last night. The depression that was over the
Jersey City and Rochester divided a double-header today, the Little Giants coming back to take the nightcap, 4 to 1, after the Red Wings had won the opener, 4 to 3, in ten innings.
The New York Curb Exchange announced yesterday that the short position on all stocks on May 28 was 59,326 shares, compared with 72,275 shares on April 30, 1937, and 31,747 shares on May 29, 1936.

The report of the Brooklyn-Manhattan Transit System, including the Brooklyn and Queens Transit System, for the eleven months ended May 31, shows a net income, after interest, depreciation, Federal income taxes and other expenses and charges, of $4,277,247, equal, after preferred dividend charges, to $3.95 a common share.

The Japanese Cabinet decided today to restore the system of parliamentary Vice Ministers in the various government departments. Twenty-four will be chosen from the members of the House of Representatives in the move to gain political support for Prince Fumimaro Konove's Cabinet.

Experience with the problem of housing, gained in the last four years, has shown the need for a permanent policy fixed by law, Mrs. Mary K. Simkhovitch, president of the National Public Housing Conference, stated in a letter to President Roosevelt, dated June 18.
The House today put Representative Mary T. Norton of New Jersey at the head of its labor committee. She succeeds the late Representative Connery.

Forrest Shannon led the University of Southern California to the team title in the Middle Atlantic Intercollegiate Golf Tournament when he won the qualifying medal for himself with a score of 76-77--153 today at the Shawnee Country Club.

The Samo Holding Corporation sold to an investing client of Riker Co., Inc., the six-story apartment house for seventy-two families at 2,246 Ocean Avenue, in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn. Valued at $325,000, the property was sold subject to a first. mortgage of $235,000 held by the Manufacturers Trust Company, as trustees.

The marriage of Miss Clara Jaffray Reese, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Mesier Reese of Yonkers, N. Y., to Dr. John Ellis Knight of West Roxbury took place here this afternoon in the Cole Memorial Chapel, Wheaton College, where the bride was graduated yesterday.
The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today dated June 19: COMMANDER Sauer, E. P., the Farragut, to temporary duty 11th Naval District, San Diego, Calif.

Cleveland's Bob Feller shared the unhappy fate of three other Indian pitchers today when Washington won an 11-to-2 victory. After pounding Earl Whitehill out of the box in the fourth inning with a three-run rally, the Senators renewed the assault on Paul Andrews and then drubbed Feller for four runs during his two-inning turn.

Miss Sybill Houston Beck, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick C. Beck of St. Johnsbury, Vt., and Douglas Binney Kitchel, son of Mr. and Mrs. Allan F. Kitchel of Binney Lane, Old Greenwich, were married today in the North Greenwich Congregational Church, St. Johnsbury.

The Wesson Oil and Snowdrift Company, Inc., and subsidiaries reported yesterday for the nine months ended on May 31, a net profit of $3,716,031 after depreciation, amortization, interest, Federal and State income taxes and other charges.

Although the number of buyers registered in the market during the week ended yesterday was only slightly under the preceding week, the total was considerably below the corresponding week a year ago, according to the listings in THE TIMES.
At least a moderate amount of fireworks is to be expected at today's meeting of the International Paper and Power Company in Boston when the recapitalization plan comes up for a vote.

Mr. and Mrs. J. Macy Willets are at the Carlyle before going to Big Win Inn, Muskogee Lake, Canada. Mrs. Suzanne Silvercruys Farnam is arriving tomorrow on the Washington and will join at the Ambassador her brother, Baron Robert Silvercruys, the Belgian Minister to Canada.
Popular-price dress manufacturers are prepared to produce a new price line for this Fall, Luis Rubin, executive director of the Popular Priced Dress Manufacturers Group, announced last night.

H. F. Boe has been appointed commercial manager of the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company, it was announced yesterday by N. G. Symonds, vice president of the company, and will have headquarters both at 150 Broadway, this city, and in the Union Bank Building, Pittsburgh.

Louise Baum gave a mortgage for $2,500, due May 18, 1939, at 6 per cent, to the trustee of the will of Leon C. Weinstock on 79 Baxter St. A second mortgage for $21,390, due according to the bond, was given on 152-154 Second Ave., by Gramercy Memorial Chapel, Inc., to Structural Builders, Inc., subject to a first mortgage for $35,000.
Miss Carolyn Griswold, principal of Cleveland Grammar School here since 1928 and a teacher in the Englewood school system since 1898, died of heart disease at her home here this morning.

Winners in the 1937 Better Copy Contest of the Public Utilities Advertising Association were announced yesterday. In the newspaper advertising divisions they were: Electric load building, Northern States Power Company, Minneapolis; electric public relations, four were tied,

Governor Earle today granted a respite to Roy Lockard, Blair County slayer, who was to have died in the electric chair June 28. The execution was postponed to the week of Oct. 4. Lockard was convicted, with Mrs. Margaret Karmendi, of slaying her little son.
Three National Guard regiments; arriving here early today, brought peace to this strike ravaged city of 175,000 after possible bloodshed seemed imminent at the steel plants of the Mahoning Valley.

Postmaster General Farley contended in Federal District Court here today that the refusal of the postoffice to accept food and clothes in the mails for delivery to nonstriking steel workers in Ohio mills was "legal, proper and warranted."
Neither Yale nor Harvard's crews practiced below the two-mile flag off the submarine base today, a strong northwest breeze stirring up whitecaps on the lower half of the measured course.
Franklin Wilbur Heath, secretary emeritus of the Typothetae of Philadelphia and widely known in the printing trade throughout the country, died at the Strath Haven Inn, Swarthmore. He was 76.

White-tipped oar blades, standing out boldly in a slate-gray, rainy river, wrote one of the greatest pages of rowing history on the Hudson today. For the first time in modern rowing one college won all three races two consecutive years as Washington's freshman,
Mr. and Mrs. Charles G. Morris today announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Laura Wylie Morris, to John Shepard Burnett, son of Will Burnett of Brattleboro, Vt.

Four cousins of the late Elizabeth Ann Ahearn, devout Catholic and chairman of the Welfare Board of Danvers, Mass., lost their $100,000 damage suit yesterday against the Campagnie Generale Transatlantique for the burial of Miss Ahearn at sea after her death on the Ile de France on Aug. 4, 1935.
John C. Hoctor, a former captain of Company L, 165th Infantry, National Guard, died today of a heart ailment in his home here at the age of 38.

Alice Marble found her game today for the first time since she reached England and took a hard-fought contest from Miss Mary Hardwick by 9-11, 6-4, 6-3, as the women's singles got under way at Wimbledon.

Teachers and students who have jobs in camps and hotels this Summer come under taxing provisions of the Social Security Act, Peter Gagne, Collector of Internal Revenue for this district, reported today. "Ordinarily," he said,

John L. Lewis, generalissimo of the seven-State steel strike, told reporters today at the county airport, "We're going to win." The steel corporations, against which the C. I. O. is striking, would sign contracts with his committee "in the fullness of time," he asserts.

A sit-down strike of about 150 mailing-room employes forced the three Pittsburgh newspapers, The Press, The Sun-Telegraph and The Post-Gazette, to suspend publication "indefinitely" yesterday. Although the strikers left the plants last evening, suspension of publication was continued.

Featuring apartment leases reported yesterday was a contract for fourteen rooms and six baths, comprising an entire floor at 993 Fifth Avenue, taken by Mrs. Walter A. Schiffer of Mount Kisco through Douglas L. Elliman Co., Inc. The same broker leased a nine-room suite in 270 Park Avenue to Wade D. Holland and quarters in 290 Park Avenue to Thomas A. Robertson.

Fear that the Norris bill for creation of seven regional conservation authorities might take control of navigation on the Great Lakes from the Army Corps of Engineers was expressed to a Senate subcommittee on agriculture and forestry today by L. C. Sabin, vice president of the Lake Carriers Association, an organization- representing about 83 per cent of the tonnage operating on the Great Lakes.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated June 21: COLONELS Goldthwaite, R. H., Med. Corps, two months' leave, Dec. 8, with permission to visit foreign countries. MacDill, L. (Lieut. Col.), (Air Corps), General Staff Corps. 14 days' leave, June 21.
