Lulls Corp, novelties, lamps and shades, in 26 E 22d St; Harold Surgical Corp, electrical sun lamps, in 205 E 22d St; Henroe Co, giftware, in 225 5th Ave; De Luxe Embroidery Works, 263 W 40th St; Cross Brown Co, broker. Rosebro Fabrics, Inc, Mildred Shawn, millinery, and Nora Stanton Barney, in 509 Madison Av; Butler Baldwin, Inc, brokers.

Mrs. Hugh D. Auchincloss opened the gardens of her estate this afternoon to the public for the first garden day of Summer in behalf of the Civic League. Mrs. W. Harry Brown of New York and Pittsburgh is at Hopedene for the season.
John C. Hoctor, a former captain of Company L, 165th Infantry, National Guard, died today of a heart ailment in his home here at the age of 38.

Alice Marble found her game today for the first time since she reached England and took a hard-fought contest from Miss Mary Hardwick by 9-11, 6-4, 6-3, as the women's singles got under way at Wimbledon.

Teachers and students who have jobs in camps and hotels this Summer come under taxing provisions of the Social Security Act, Peter Gagne, Collector of Internal Revenue for this district, reported today. "Ordinarily," he said,

John L. Lewis, generalissimo of the seven-State steel strike, told reporters today at the county airport, "We're going to win." The steel corporations, against which the C. I. O. is striking, would sign contracts with his committee "in the fullness of time," he asserts.

A sit-down strike of about 150 mailing-room employes forced the three Pittsburgh newspapers, The Press, The Sun-Telegraph and The Post-Gazette, to suspend publication "indefinitely" yesterday. Although the strikers left the plants last evening, suspension of publication was continued.

Featuring apartment leases reported yesterday was a contract for fourteen rooms and six baths, comprising an entire floor at 993 Fifth Avenue, taken by Mrs. Walter A. Schiffer of Mount Kisco through Douglas L. Elliman Co., Inc. The same broker leased a nine-room suite in 270 Park Avenue to Wade D. Holland and quarters in 290 Park Avenue to Thomas A. Robertson.

The Independent Federation of Republic Employes, composed of nonunion workers for the Republic Steel Corporation, telegraphed this protest today to Governor Davey against the use of the National Guard to prevent those who want to work from returning to their jobs:
On June 14 the "iron ring" of forts around Bilbao had been broken and what by way of compliment had been called its second line, the ridge of Santa Marina, was occupied by Insurgents.
Alice looked up from her sewing and smiled at the Dormouse. "Must you rattle the newspaper like that,"
The Rev. Oliver J. Coby, a retired minister, died last night in the New Rochelle Hospital. Since his retirement five years ago he resided in Larchmont. His age was 77.

Mrs. J. Raynor Wells of this city has announced the marriage of her daughter, Miss Marie Storrs Wells, to Philip S. P. Randolph Jr. of New York. The ceremony was performed in Hudson, N. Y., on Sunday by the Rev. Dr. Johnson of Hudson.

Virtually the entire higher command of Osoaviakhim-the association allied to the Red Army, the principal tasks of which are to train millions of reserves for the Red Army and educate the civil population against airplane and gas attacks-has been discharged, some of its members by their own request.

The threatened general strike within the hotel and restaurant cafe industries has been deferred until Saturday. Mass meetings held today by union delegates and workers voted, after much discussion, to postpone the strike, because since the Cabinet crisis there has been no government to hear or to act to remedy their grievances.

The autobiography of Florence Finch Kelly is now announced for publication in 1938 by E. P. Dutton Co. Mrs. Kelly was a member of the staff of THE NEW YORK TIMES for thirty years, retiring a year ago. Previously she had spent twenty-six years working for newspapers in Boston, Los Angeles,
Joe Louis is the world's heavyweight champion, the first Negro boxer to hold the title in twenty-two years, or since the days of Jack Johnson.

Mrs. Mary E. Mahoney, widow of Alderman John J. Mahoney, was elected to the Board of Aldermen yesterday to represent the Fifth Aldermanic District in Manhattan and became the sole woman member in the Board of sixty-five members.

Announcement that the Treasury Department would hold a national competition to obtain designs for the next regular series of postage stamps was made here tonight by Edward Bruce, head of the Painting and Sculpture Branch of the department's Procurement Division. The competition will be open to all American professional and amateur artists.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 3,510,950 barrels, compared with 3,515,900 in the previous week, a decline of 4,950, according to the American Petroleum Institute. A decline of 8,600 barrels in the average daily output of Oklahoma was the most important change. Production was 144,950 barrels more than the calculation of 3,366,000 daily by the Bureau of Mines for June.

With Georges Bonnet as Minister of Finance, Yvon Delbos still at the Foreign Office and Leon Blum as Vice President of the Council of Ministers without portfolio, Camille Chautemps shortly after 11 o'clock tonight completed the formation of his Cabinet and presented it to President Albert Lebrun.

A golf tournament conducted at the Winged Foot Golf Club today by the Bankers Athletic League of New York was won by a team comprising John E. Parker, Albert Schomp, J. A. Holwill, William Horne and P. A. Williams, representing the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company.

A suggestion that railroads meet increasing competition from the automobile and motor truck with a double-deck train car to carry-on the upper deck-passengers' automobiles and luggage was offered here today by L. K. Sillcox, first vice president of the New York Air Brake Company.

Mrs. M. Buckner Royall of Fieldston Old House, Riverdale, gave a supper last night in the Starlight Roof Garden of the Waldorf-Astoria for Miss Reid Handy, debutante daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Truman Parker Handy. Miss Handy made her debut on Saturday afternoon at a garden party given by her parents at their home in Riverdale.

The marriage of Miss Margaret Mary McCloskey, daughter of Joseph McCloskey of this city and the late Mrs. McCloskey, to Raoul Jean Orceyre, son of Mrs. Jean Orceyre of St. Flour, France, and the late Mr. Orceyre, took place yesterday morning in the Church of Our Lady of Lourdes. West 142d Street.

The marriage of Miss Gretchen Mills, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward James Mills of this place, to Leroy Albert Howland Jr., son of Dean Leroy Albert Howland of Wesleyan University, Middletown, Conn., and Mrs. Howland, took place this evening in the North Avenue Presbyterian Church here.

Willard E. Bowman announced today his resignation as executive vice president and publicity director of L. Bamberger and Company to become executive editor of The Newark Star-Eagle. He will assume his new duties on Aug. 1.
The Duke of Windsor, who as king had ordered the ban on plays about British royalty lifted for "Victoria Regina," went unthanked, it was reported today, by government request.
Peter J. Barthel, cashier of the New York insurance firm of Talbot Bird Co., 111 John Street, died here today of a cerebral hemorrhage, after a two-day illness, at his home, 73 Abington Avenue.

John Barrymore and Elaine Barrie were reunited at a railroad station here today. "I'm going to set aside my divorce decree," Miss Barrie an- nounced. "I'm just a family man at heart," said Mr. Barrymore, who has been divorced four times.

The new Quebec law for collective wage agreements was praised by David Dubinsky, general president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, here to preside over executive board sessions of his union.

Immediate action from all social agencies to mitigate the adverse circumstances surrounding the Negro in Harlem, an "area of neglect," was urged by Arthur Huck, executive director of the Children's Aid Society in the organization's eighty-fourth annual report issued yesterday by William Church Osborn, president.

Play in the international chess masters' tournament at the Kurhaus today was not without a special significance. Exactly 100 years ago, Paul Morphy of New Orleans, who conquered the chess playing world just before the Civil War, was born.
Luncheon forum of the Committee on City Planning of the Progressive City Committee, Town Hall Club, 123 West Forty-third Street, 12:30 P. M. "City Planning and Good Government," Lawrence M. Orton.

With twenty-nine entrants on hand and more expected, the Ryeto - New London - overnight race under the sponsorship of the American Yacht Club, is scheduled to start at 7:30 this evening. Thirtytwo starters were in the race last year.

While office buildings in nearly all parts of the country have experienced a rise in occupancy and somewhat higher rentals this year, the resulting increases in gross income have been offset by unsettled labor conditions, wage increases and high payments for taxes and supplies, according to regional officers of the National Association of Building Owners and Managers.

The City Amateur Symphony Orchestra opened its seventh season last night with a concert on the Mall in Central Park. Mayor La Guardia, honorary chairman of the organization, was the guest of honor. About 2,500 persons were in the audience.

Old Annapolis saw something new today, a woman for Mayor, the first to seek that office in the 229 years of the city's incorporated history. Mrs. Mildred M. Clements, wife of Professor Guy Roland Clements of the Naval Academy and a native

The New York School for the Deaf at 930 Riverside Drive graduated thirty-eight young men yesterday afternoon. All the graduates received vocational certificates. Captain Victor O. Skyberg, school superintendent, said it was the largest class in twenty-five years.

Louis B. Glass, whose jewelry concern at 71 Nassau Street was revealed by Assistant District Attorney James J. Wilson to be actually his headquarters in an illegal money-lending enterprise, was sentenced to a three-month workhouse term yesterday on his recent conviction in Special Sessions on a usury charge.

Charles Lathrop Pack of Lakewood, a leader in the movement to conserve the nation's forests, left $57,000 of his estate, estimated at $1,000,000, to forestry organizations, it was disclosed here today after the filing of his will for probate at the office of Surrogate Clinton O. Fogg.

The Illinois Athletic Commission designated Tommy Thomas as referee of tonight's bout between Joe Louis and James J. Braddock for the world heavyweight championship. The judges were Ed Hintz and Ed Klein. Braddock weighed 197 pounds and the challenger 197 1/4. The round-by-round description of the fight follows:

LONDON-Britain and France refused to join Germany and Italy in a naval demonstration against Loyalist Spain in retaliation for the reported submarine attacks on the German cruiser Leipzig. The Reich was expected to take independent action but not to break with the Non-Intervention Committee. Page 1.

The subscription committee for Westchester and Greenwich of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Society, Mrs. Alva Benjamin See, chairman, will. have a tea next Tuesday afternoon at the Belle Haven Beach Club, Greenwich. Mrs. Vincent Astor, chairman of the society's auxiliary board, will preside.

Samuel G. Krivit, for nine years vice president of The Boot and Shoe Recorder and manager of the New York State territory, has formed the Samuel G. Krivit Company, Inc., advertising, with executive offices at 10 East Fortieth Street. An office will be opened in St. Louis.

Ethel Barrymore, who formally announced her retirement from the stage last August, will return to it next season in the Theatre Guild's production of Sidney Howard's new play, "The Ghost of Yankee Doodle."

Testifying today before a subcommittee of the Senate Banking and Currency Committee, Lonis S. Posner of the New York State Mortgage Commission endorsed important principles of the proposed Trust Indenture Act of 1937.

As shown at the Plaza Theatre here, the Paramount newsreel of the fight between strikers and police at the Republic Steel plant in Chicago gives the general effect of a string of snapshots and cannot be accepted as continuous record on which an opinion of the rights and wrongs of the combatants could be based.

The Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company has signed the first formal contract for exhibit space in a building to be constructed by the New York World's Fair 1939, it was announced yesterday by Grover A. Whalen, president of the fair.
The Parker conspiracy case will be given to the jury of eight New Jersey housewives and four men tomorrow morning in the ninth week of the trial before Federal Judge William Clark here.

The fortnightly statement of the Central Bank of Argentina for June 15 showed that the ratio of the gold reserve to notes in circulation had risen from 130.67 per cent on May 31 to 134.95. The reserve ratio of gold to notes and sight liabilities rose from 90.52 to 91.03 per cent.
Tazio Nuvolari, crack Italian racing driver, is pessimistic about again winning the Vanderbilt Cup race.

The Twenty-third Street Association at a meeting in the Aldine Club yesterday appointed a committee to map out a program for lower assessed valuations on real estate. The committee, consisting of Peter Forrest, chairman; Charles J. F.

The marriage of Miss Marjorie Anne McPherson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Scott McPherson of New York, to Braman Blanchard Adams 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. C. Robert Adams of Pelham Heights, N. Y., took place here this afternoon in the Noroton Presbyterian Church.

Between 1928 and 1936 Germany's total debt rose from 7,831,000,000 Reichsmarks to 14,439,000,000, according to a report on Germany issued by the League of Nations today as the latest number in its series analyzing public finance in each country.

Paul Sawyer, captain of Yale's outboard team. won two events, and Fred Nickell, Allentown (Pa.) professional, accounted for another today in an international outboard regatta labeled as for the "world championship."

Governor Earle indicated today, that he would not lift martial law in Johnstown until peace was negotiated in the steel strike. He continued to defend his action in the face of a flood of criticism at home and from beyond the borders of the State.

Yale announced establishment of. a $10,000,000 fund for cancer research, the gift of Starling W. Childs. Page 1. The will of George F. Baker, banker, created a $15,000,000 trust for charitable purposes. Page 8.

According to a Reuters dispatch from Berlin late tonight, civil flying has been forbidden between midnight Monday until the afternoon of July 2 over a district in West Germany extending roughly from the Dutch frontier to Oldenburg and Bremen, up the rivers Weser and Minden and then across to Ehrenbreitstein on the Rhine near Coblenz;
Under the most aggressive buying movement since March, prices on the Cotton Exchange advanced steadily yesterday, gaining about $1 a bale and ending 16 to 21 points higher.

Encouraged by evidences of community improvement and aroused by the fact that despite the civic betterment their district still remains one of the worst in the city, a group of residents of East Harlem formed yesterday The Neighborhood Youth Guidance Association to combat harmful influences and conditions in the area.

When the new Constitution was introduced into the Dail political prophets said that not constitutional but economic questions would be the prime issues in the campaign. This forecast seems to be justified so far, though Mr. DE VALERA is not forgetting the Constitution in his speeches;

Miss Elizabeth Ann Butterworth, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Warner Butterworth Jr. of Chestnut Hill, was presented to society by her parents this afternoon at a tea which they gave at the home of Mrs. Butterworth's brother and sister-in-law, Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Bromley Flood, 8035 Seminole Avenue, Chestnut Hill.

Peter Riedel, veteran soaring pilot, cut capers over Manhattan and the Bronx yesterday, flying the sailplane with which he will enter the international meet of the International Soaring Society of America, which will open in Elmira, N. Y., on Saturday.

"It's up to the women" to change an "extravagant" national system of distribution, to assure farm women a fair living standard, Mrs. Charles W. Sewell, administrative director of the American Farm Bureau Federation, declared here today at the convention of the National Association of Retail Grocers.
The Pirates made it two in a row over the Bees today, winning 8 to 5. It was Boston's eleventh consecutive loss. Russell Bauers, tall right-hander who worked the full game, held the Bees to six hits.

Ellis H. Parker Sr., the veteran Burlington County detective, and his 26year-old son, Ellis Jr., were convicted in the Federal court here tonight of conspiring to violate the Lindbergh Kidnapping Law.

Showing its second Warner Brothers production in as many weeks, the Radio City Music Hall today will present Marion Davies and Robert Montgomery in "Ever Since Eve," with a supporting cast of featured comedians, including Frank McHugh, Patsy Kelly, Allen Jenkins and Louise Fazenda.

Segregation of power generation and flood control functions in dam construction, on grounds of economy, was urged upon the Senate subcommittee on Agriculture and Forestry today by Alan N. Jordan, executive secretary of the Ohio Valley Conservation and Flood Control Congress.

Austin J. Cross, known to book collectors for his skill in the extra illustrating, inlaying and rebuilding of rare editions and centuries-old manuscripts, died today in the Lutheran Deaconess Hospital. Mr. cross, who lived at 2,246 North Sawyer Avenue, was 86 years old.
The National Association of Credit Men protested in a resolution today against "a growing tendency of some banks to make an exchange charge for clearing checks."

Hewing close to the line for two circuits of Quaker Ridge's tightly trapped layout, Frankie Strafaci of Shore View today carded a 73-73-146, six strokes over par for thirtysix holes, to win the fourth annual William Rice Hochster Memorial Golf Tournament from a notable field of local amateurs.

Countess Frieda Costantini of Paris, France, widow of Count David A. Costantini, was married to Baron Carl Gottlieb von Seidlitz of Germany this morning in Seidlitz of Germany this morning in the Church of the Good Shepherd. Dr. Malcolm Lockhart performed the double-ring ceremony.
The will of George F. Baker, chairman of the board of the First National Bank of New York until his death May 30, was filed for probate yesterday in the Surrogates' Court.

The Securities and Exchange Commission today made public the following applications from New York City for registration as brokers or dealers in the over-the-counter market: (Symbols: S. sole proprietor; P. partnership; C. corporation.)

A rising tide of protests from citizens developed today against Governor Davey's use of National Guard troops to prevent the closed plants of the Republic Steel Corporation and the Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company here and near by from reopening, and to prevent men who want to work after the month-old strike from returning to their jobs.

Gross assets $84,607, net $80,479. To wife, Yetta Finkelstein, life estate; children, Augusta, Jacob, Carol, Sadie and Jean Finkelstein, Mathilda Rich, one-sixth remainder interest in life estate each. Chief assets, cash, notes, stock and bonds, mortgages and real estate, $84,607.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Malcolm Greene Fleming of this city of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Janet B. Fleming, to Lance Ernest Booth Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Lance Ernest Booth of Roselle.

The opening of the twentieth season of concerts at the Lewisohn Stadium was accomplished last night under the most cheerful of auspices before an audience of about 15,000. The weather was perfect; nature contrived its own airconditioning.

The Board of Education has approved the following appointments 'of teachers in various branches of the school system to take effect Sept. 10, 1937 except where otherwise noted: HIGH SCHOOLS To Benjamin .Franklin--Edith G. Socolow, Miriam W. Rosenthal, *Bert F. Hoenigmann.
Mayor Scully called a meeting of striking mailers for 10 o'clock tomorrow morning in an attempt to end the strike which has stilled the presses of the city's three daily newspapers for two days.
A Class Day crowd today saw Harvard defeat Yale's nine, 10 to 7, after breaking down a five-run lead with an eight-run rally midway in the game.

Bear, Stearns Co. have formed an investment advisory department, to be directed by Leonard Dickson. Nugent Igoe have opened a Summer office in the New Monmouth Hotel, Spring Lake, N. J., under the management of James V. Igoe, resident partner.

St. Margaret Mary Church and Fred H. Dummeyer sold to the 156 East 178th Street Corporation a plot 75 by 94 feet at 154, 156 and 158 East 178th Street, the Bronx. The property was held at $35,000 and will be improved with a six-story elevator apartment house.

The Keystone Pipe Line Company, a subsidiary of the Atlantic Refining Company, yesterday awarded contracts involving about $1,700,000 for the extension of its gasoline pipe line from Williamsport, Pa., to Buffalo, N. Y., a distance of 213 miles.

Hope for settlement of the strike in a score of shipyards in the New York-New Jersey area was seen yesterday, when it was announced at the office of the National Labor Relations Board, 45 Broadway, that the Robins Drydock and Repair Company of Brooklyn, the largest plant affected by the strike, had consented to an election of its employes to determine their desire as to union affiliation.

Miss Elizabeth Kelly, 22 years old, of Nebraska City, Neb., has received the $1,000 Gilbert M. Hitchcock Scholarship of the Graduate School of Journalism of Columbia University for 1937-38, it was announced yesterday. She is the first woman to receive the honor, established in 1934 in memory of the late Senator Hitchcock, publisher of The Omaha World-Herald.

The Reynolds Metal Company yesterday announced that it plans to give common stockholders rights to subscribe fdr one additional share of common stock at $17 for each fifteen shares now-held. The purpose is to increase working capital.
A discovery made at the Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research that viruses which cause disease can be made to "fall apart" and become harmless was reported here today.
The new Popular Front government, with its gold defense fund almost gone, tonight trimmed its sails to the storm that drove out the Cabinet of Leon Blum.
The Senate Judiciary Committee has unanimously endorsed the new child labor amendment offered by Senator VANDENBERG.
The securities and commodity markets pointed higher yesterday, with the former dull and the latter active. Steel and mining issues led the improvement in the stock list.

First route survey flights across the North Atlantic, designed to establish regular air transport service between the United States and Europe, will get under way early in July, J. T. Trippe, president of Pan American Airways, announced last night.

The Insurgent tide rolled westward from Bilbao tonight toward Santander, last important city held by the Basques. Artillery thundered in the hills. Five columns of infantrymen moved out of the Bilbao region on roads leading toward Santander, fortyfive miles from Bilbao.

The threatened strike of 40,000 Railway Express Agency employes will not take place, George M. Harrison, president of their union, announced tonight. Mr. Harrison and L. R. Gwyn, vice president of the express agency, after several days of conferences, reached an agreement late this afternoon on all major points at issue.

Miss Virginia Welsh, daughter of Mrs. Joseph Wickes Welsh of 950 Park Avenue and Lawrence, L. I., and the late Mr. Welsh, was married here yesterday afternoon in St. James's Church to Mark Leavenworth Sperry 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leavenworth Porter Sperry of Waterbury, Conn.

Mayflower Associates, Inc., has informed its stockholders that its interest in certain leases and royalties on prospective oil acreage in Louisiana and Texas, which cost it $238,978, and the drilling obligations pertaining to the interest, have been discharged.
FEDERAL OFFICE FURNITURE CO., INC., 118 W. 23d, by Beaver Furniture Corp.. for $146; Wagemaker Co., $306; ijalmar A. Clemeteen, doing business as Office Furniture Warehouse Co., 41,202.

Led by Mayor Wilson and cheered by 20,000 sympathizers, 256 sit-down strikers this afternoon marched out of the Apex Hosiery Company's plant, which they had occupied since seizing, May 6, in an attempt to force a closed-shop agreement.

The sale of a thriteen-acre estate on the North Shore of Long Island was announced yesterday when J. Ralph Bloomer, broker, reported that he had disposed of the property of Edwin D. Morgan Jr. on Wheatley Hills Road, Old Westbury, to Randall J. Le Boeuf.

The protective committee for the 8 per cent cumulative preferred stock of the Schulte Retail Stores Corporation yesterday advisedstockholders that a plan of reorganization had been developed in cooperation with other interested parties and was under negotiation with representatives of creditors and security owners.

A bill carrying out the administration's program for executive reorganization was introduced in the Senate today by Majority Leader Robinson. It modified in certain respects the plan originally outlined by President Roosevelt, but granted him nonetheless broad authority to transfer, consolidate, regroup and abolish Federal agencies.

With great interest I have read THE TIMES editorial of June 18, "American Labor." What we have lived to see during the last few months regarding labor troubles and still shall live to see is in my opinion one of the most important events in the industrial and social evolution of this country.

The heads of the Uzbekistan Soviet Republic's government and numerous other officials have been removed from office in a new discovery of alleged anti-government opposition in Middle Asia, it was disclosed today.

The marriage of Miss Margaret Knox Gray, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Paisley Gray of this city and Paterson, N. J., to William Hutchins Turner Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Turner of Ridgewood, N. J., took place here yesterday afternoon at the home of the bride's parents, 1,160 Fifth Avenue.

Alfred Lunt and Lynn Fontanne appeared here tonight in Jean Giraudoux's "Amphitryon 38," using S. N. Behrman's English adaptation, which was presented before a capacity audience at the Curran Theatre for its first performance in this country.

York St, 8, 25.3..x117.21h, and 268 West Broadway, 25x66.4, contiguous; Helena Day McGlone to Busk Realty Co. Inc, 291 Broadway; mtg, $41,500 ($18.50). Grand St, s w cor Pitt St, 56.8x35.6, Bowery Savings Bank to Wilronphil Realty Corp, 214 east Broadway (S11).

Charles E. Hendrickson, one of Jersey City's oldest practicing lawyers and a former Assemblyman from Hudson County, died suddenly of a heart attack yesterday at his home here. Mr. Hendrickson, a son of the late New Jersey Supreme Court Justice Charles E. Hendrickson, was 64 years old and a member of the law -firm of Hendrickson, Greenberg Jacobs, 75 Montgomerv Street, Jersey City.

A race that was run almost exactly to form in practically every particular was the featured Gotham Purse at Aqueduct yesterday, wherein John Hay Whitney's Royal Feast, the favorite, led from start to finish to win by a length and a half at 11 to 10. Advocator, the second choice, came next past the judges, and Trickwick, the third choice, landed the show.

The election of Edmund R. Novak of Baltimore, regular third baseman this year, to the captaincy of the Princeton baseball team for the 1938 season was announced today by the University Athletic Association. Novak succeeds Dean Hill Jr. of New York City.

The Insular Court, with District Judges de Jesus, Berga and Llauger sitting, denied today an injunction to the Needlecraft Association against Commissioner of Labor Rivera Martinez to prevent the extension of the $1 daily minimum wage to women employed in homes and not working in factories.

Uncle Robert announced yesterday the opening of his Summer safety drive. The campaign is being launched this year more than a week in advance of the closing of school so that the slogan of the drive-SOS (Stay on Sidewalk)may be spread as widely as possible..

Miss Patricia Henry of Los Angeles and Occidental, defending champion, and the third-seeded Miss Louise Raymond of Smith gained the second round on byes today when the college girls' invitation tennis tournament opened at Longwood.

Wheat prices fluctuated in an erratic manner on the Board of Trade here today, breaking early in sympathy with Liverpool and on reports of scattered showers in parts of the Canadian Northwest but strengthening later when aggressive commission house buying developed on drought reports from the three Canadian Provinces, black rust reports from the Northwest and wild rumors regarding political developments in Europe.

Alex Smith, chief process server in the District Attorney's office, was selected last night as Tammany leader of the northern third of the Fifth Assembly district, succeeding the late Alderman John J. Mahoney.
D. Owen Stephens, noted American astronomical painter, died yesterday morning in the Gorgas Hospital, Balboa, Canal Zone, of a stroke of paralysis he suffered on board the S. S. Clara.

The Newspaper Guild of New York voted last night at a meeting at the Hotel Astor to open its membership rolls to employes of the "business, circulation, advertising, promotion and other allied groups on news publications" in the city, in accordance with the action of the recent American Newspaper Guild convention in St. Louis.

The marriage of Miss Renette Casebolt, daughter of Mrs. George H. Casebolt of this city. to Hugh Paterson Scott, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles R. Scott, also of Newark, took place tonight in Forest Hill Presbyterian Church here.
Ambassador Robert W. Bingham will find it necessary to travel almost the length of the United Kingdom on June 30 to receive two distinguished British honors-one in Scotland and the other in London.

The United States Embassy announced today the names of fourteen American women to be presented at court July 1. They are: Miss Frances W: Andrews of Washington, D. C.; Mrs. William A. Becker, Summit, N. J.; Miss Anna G. Butler,

The House Plan Association, a society of alumni and members of the teaching staff of the College of the City of New York, has purchased the house at 292 Convent Avenue, between 141st and 142d Streets, for a student center, it was learned yesterday.
Mayor James Seccombe, in a letter to Governor Davey today on steel strike violence, wrote: "Has the time not come when we who hold public office, major or minor, should be honest with the public?"
Women will play a part in determining Republican policies and carrying them out, William S. Murray, Republican State Chairman, declared in an address before the State Republican women here today.

Although general closing of cotton mills for the veek of July 4 has been found impossible, due to the inability of some mills to arrange delivery deferments on contracts due for shipment during the week of July 4, a substantial number of mills will shut down for that week, it was indicated in the goods market yesterday.

A group headed by Phelps, Fenn Co. has marketed a new issue of $434,000 of city of Chattanooga, Tenn., 4 and 4 1/2 per cent public improvement bonds, dated June 1, 1937, and due on June 1, 1953 to 1962.

Miss Margaret Louise Crane, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Ralph W. Crane, was married to Dr. Morgan Sargent, son of Dr. and Mrs. Walter Leslie Sargent of Quincy, Mass., tonight at her parents' home here. The Rev. Gerald A. Cunningham, rector of St. John's Episcopal Church, officiated.

Julius Wile Sons Co. priced Robertson dry tawny port under the provisions of the Feld-Crawford Fair Trade Act, and not McKesson Robbins, as was inadvertently reported in THE TIMES on Tuesday. The Wile Company is the importer of the liquor.

In a fluttering breeze over the sea off here today, Harold S. Vanderbilt's undefeated new Ranger won her seventh victory in the America's Cup defense trials and her third in the present observation series.

More than 4,000 Harvard alumni, plus the additional thousands made up of their families and friends, frolicked through the picturesque rites of the college Class Day here today, marching, singing, watching and acting in the full program held under the first blue skies of this Commencement Week.
The engagement of $3,389,000 gold abroad for shipment here, $1,682,000 in England and $1,707,000 in Canada, was reported yesterday to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
Tension increased on Capitol Hill tonight after Senator Robinson of Arkansas, Democratic leader, announced that debate on the Roosevelt court bill probably will begin next week.

The Athletics, the talk of the American League little more than a month ago, completed a plunge from first to last place today, losing 2 to 0 to the White Sox as St. Louis beat New York. The Sox made only three hits off Bud Thomas and Herman Fink, but two of them were homers by Mike Kreevich and Luke Appling.
Herbert A. Stutchbury, general superintendent of the New York State Electric and Gas Corporation, died last night at the company's plant of a heart attack His age was 70.

The Bank of England bought today bar gold valued at [pound]5,145,259. This was the first addition to its gold stock since the middle of May, when it bought [Pound]8,000,000 of gold to avert a fall in the banking department's reserve below the so-called danger point of

Withdrawing from the "neutral" patrol system around the Spanish coast, Germany and Italy yesterday jointly resumed freedom of action to "protect " their interests and ships " against the Bolshevik firebrands in Valencia."

Cornelius Crane, Florence H. Crane and Florence C. Robinson owned 29.34 per cent of the common stock of the Crane Company at the close of its last fiscal year, according to a report to the Securities and Exchange Commission

Governor Lehman told the annual conference of health officers and public health nurses today that New York has made "tremendous strides" in the reduction of death rates from certain causes, but asserted further improvement can be achieved.

In a day packed full of stirring matches and beautiful tennis, the East found itself shut out of the national intercollegiate singles championship today as the Pacific Coast qualified three quarter-finalists at the Merion Cricket Club.

Washington (Wash) Irvin, 33 years old, one of three Harlan County deputy sheriffs who resigned Tuesday in protest against the dismissal of Deputy Lee Fleenor and who was a witness -before the Senate Civil Liberties Committee, was found shot to death in his automobile today on Pine Mountain, near here.

The excitement of the big night and the big fight caused some slight mental confusion at the time but it all comes back now in orderly fashion. It was a grand night, clear and cool. Evidently the weather man had trained perfectly and was in the pink of perfection at twilight. The promoters couldn't have ordered a better evening if samples had been displayed in advance.
Commissioner William 0. Douglas of the Securities and Exchange Commission today spoke in defense of the Chandler bill at the annual convention of the National Association of Credit Men.

One of the factors which now handicap efforts to settle the steel strike is the insistence of the employers that the C. I. O. is not a responsible agency with which to deal. In support of this charge they cite its record in the automobile industry. Certainly that record is not auspicious. It is less than four months since the C. I. O. signed an agreement with the General Motors Corporation.

Emphasizing the world-wide need for religious freedom, Jeremiah T. Mahoney urged last night that this country make it a cardinal principle to enter no treaty with, the government of any nation that persecutes or refuses protection to minorities.

A syndicate of American and European diamond dealers, whose members are alleged to have had a secret code and to have hired housewives and school teachers to smuggle jewelry into the United States, was indicted yesterday in the most sweeping prosecution of its kind ever undertaken by the government.

Within ten years at least 5,000,000 persons living chiefly In the slums of America will be occupying modern government housing, Charles F. Palmer of Atlanta, Ga., former president of the National Association of Building Owners and Managers, predicted today at the annual convention of the association.

Dogs, said to be sufferers from confinement in city apartments and carriers of many diseases, will be permanently expelled from the metropolitan area within ten or twelve years if plans of a newly formed organization mature. The objective would be attained by State legislation.

Miss Ercil Howard Chapman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Kinkaide Chapman, was married to George Haywood Hawks Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. George H. Hawks, this afternoon in St. Luke's Episcopal Church. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Samuel Tyler of Rome and the Rev. Frederick M. Winnie.

The two leaders in the international chess masters' tournament in progress at the Kurhaus, Samuel Reshevsky, the United States champion, and A. Apscheneek of Latvia, first and second, respectively, met today in the seventh round but failed to reach a decision.
Governor Earle took himself out of the Presidential race today and announced his decision to support President Roosevelt for renomination, in 1940 unqualifiedlyy and finally."

Nevil Ford, vice president of the First Boston Corporation, was elected president of the Bond Club of New York yesterday at the annual meeting in the Bankers Club. He tinue are Frank F. Walker, Hearn man, Dillon Co.

Fees totaling $90,000 were awarded yesterday by Supreme Court Justice John E. McGeehan to the three appraisers he appointed to evaluate the assets of EitingonSchild Company, one of the world's largest dealers in fur skins.
The Chiefs spotted the International League-leading Newark Bears a 6-0 advantage in the first three innings tonight, got to Atley Donald in the late innings, but lost, 6-5.

Uniform reductions in working hours and the work week throughout the country, if necessary to reduce unemployment, were called for yesterday by Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia, in an address at the closing luncheon session of the Advertising Federation of America at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Retail package deliveries in the metropolitan area showed an increase of 11 per cent over 1936 for the week ended June 19, according to figures issued yesterday by the United Parcel Service. The increase is unchanged from the preceding week.

C. I. O. called a "labor holiday" in Warren and Niles, Ohio, bringing a total of 14,000 on strike, including steel workers, as a protest against enforcement of court injunction. Police and troops broke up a parade. Page 1.

Luncheon of the Rotary Club of New York, Hotel Commodore, 12:15 P. M. "The Public Library and Its Influence on American Life," Chalmers Hadley. Luncheon of the American Tin Trade Association at the Railroad Machinery Club of New York, 30 Church Street, 12:30 P. M. Speakers: J. van den Broek and Representative Sam D. McReynolds.

World production of tin in the first four months of this year amounted to 60,646 tons, an increase of about 5,600 from the corresponding period of 1936, according to the International Tin Research and Development Council.

Mrs. Carl B. Ely of his city and Greenwich has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Ruth Mary Ruxton, to Roy D. Chapin Jr., son of Mrs. Roy D. Chapin of Grosse Pointe, Mich., and the late Mr. Chapin.

Harvard will confer 2,062 degrees at commencement tomorrow. Of these degrees, 781 will go to seniors in Harvard College, of whom 615 will receive the degree of Bachelor of Arts and 166 the degree of Bachelors of Science.

Hugh Mulcahy pitched the Phillies back into sixth place in the National League race today with a four-hit 3-to-0 victory over the Reds, who dropped to seventh position after a one-day stand ahead of the Phils.
The Pennsylvania Bar Association opened its annual convention here today by voicing emphatic opposition to President Roosevelt's program for court change.

President Ada L. Comstock of Radcliffe College conferred Bachelor of Arts degrees upon 160 students, awarded forty-seven Master of Arts degrees and invested ten others with the academic hoods of Doctors of Philosophy at oommencement exercises today.

Installation of officers of the Seventy-seventh Division Association took place last night at the division's Memorial Building, 28 East Thirty-ninth Street. Fred A. Rupp, local heating engineer, was installed as president for his second term.

Illustreating the sharp decrease in activity on national securities Exchanges, the Securities and Exchange Commission published today a summary showing that sales in May amounted to $1,474,109,197, a decrease of 37.9 per cent compared to April. The figure was 2.9 per cent above the values of sales in May, 1936, however.
The Postoffice Department has completed a five-month job of delivering several billion dollars in gold to the new vaults at Fort Knox, Ky.

Three of the country's largest bus systems, all affiliates of the Greyhound Corporation, said frankly today in applications to the Interstate Commerce Commission for permission to issue stock to take care of obligations, that their plans were necessary in order that they might avoid "the penalties of the corporation surtax on undistributed profits."

The Public- Service Commission announced yesterday that it had prescribed a new accounting system to be followed by water-works corporations in this State. The system is to become effective on Jan. 1, 1938, for companies with gross revenues of more than $100,000 a year.

William F. Marsh of Pittsburgh was elected president of the National Association of Cost Accountants at the annual meeting held here today. He is resident partner of Lybrand, Ross Bros. Montgomery in Pittsburgh and has served as vice president for the last two years and as a member of the national board since 1932.

Advices from Paris that the French stabilization fund had virtually exhausted its ability to support the rate of exchange caused increased weakness in the franc yesterday. There were almost no bids for forward francs, and the discount on 90-day futures increased to 27 points, 4 1/2 points larger than on the previous day.

So much of paragraph 14, Special Orders 122, dated May 26, 1937, as relates to Captain Lewis S. Parody, QM-Res., is revoked. Leave of absence for four months and six days, effective on or about June 20, to terminate not later than Oct. 26, is granted Captain Lewis S. Parody, QM-Res.

President Lazaro Cardenas tonight announced that the government would expropriate the National Railways of Mexico. The railways, said a Presidential decree to be published tomorrow in the Official Gazette, will be administered by a new Federal department to be appointed.

Charles D. Jaffee of Charles D. Jaffee, Inc., was elected for his thirteenth term as president of the New York Clothing Manufacturers Exchange at its annual meeting yesterday. Julius H. Levy was reelected secretary. Other officers elected were: First vice president, Isidore Grossman, Grossman Clothing Company;

Mrs. Samuel Gilbert Colt will give a garden party Saturday afternoon at her Crofut Street home in compliment to visitors who will be in the Berkshires for the reopening of the Berkshire Museum and the dedication of the Ellen Kittredge Crane Memorial Auditorium, given to the museum by Mrs. Colt and her brother, the late Zenas Marshall Crane.

Miss Ruth Marilyn Van Hine, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Van Hine of this place, was married to the Rev. Andrew Donald Dennis tonight at the home of her parents by the Rev. George Mitnik of Newark. Mrs. Charles Katona of Bloomfield was matron of honor and Joseph St. King of New York was best man.

Logically, it could be presumed that, because of dissensions among the Democrats on Capitol Hill over the President's Judiciary Bill and labor policies, Congress will revise the Government Reorganization Bill introduced by Senator Robinson today, to assure against too great concentration of power in the Executive.

Twenty-nine graduates of high schools in Greater New York have received full or partial scholarships from Long Island University, Brooklyn, it was announced yesterday by Dean Tristram Walker Metcalfe..
Valencia received news today that a German squadron in a belligerent mood was headed this way.
The Red Sox wasted no time wiping out Hank Greenberg's first-inning homer with the bases full today, and, although outhit, 12-11, beat the Tigers, 6 to 5.
With his revue, "Floodlight," presented at the Saville tonight, Beverly Nichols joins that small group who can write an entire musical show-book, lyrics and music.
Chancellor Adolf Hitler demonstrated tonight his determination to maintain German naval forces in Spanish waters by ordering the battleship Admiral Graf Spee to proceed immediately to Spain.

A banking syndicate headed by Morgan Stanley Co., Inc., will offer today $25,000,000 of New York Telephone Company refunding mortgage 3 1/4 per cent bonds, Series B. The bonds will be priced at 100 and interest to yield 3 per cent and will be dated July 1, 1937, and mature on July 1, 1967.

Electric power production showed a small decrease last week when an increase was called for on both seasonal and long-term basis, and the adjusted index receded to 106.4 from 107.2. It was 101.7 for the week ended June 20, 1936.
The marriage of Miss Frances Gardner, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leslie Brekenridge Gardner, to James Hastings Snowden of New York took place in the mission of St. Francis here this morning.

1st Ave. 1,121-23; to two 5-story tenements and stores; Jolay Realty Corp, 44 Wall St, owner; Victor Bark Jr., architect: cost, $35,000. 2d Ave. 1,714: to 5-story tenement and stores; Bank for Savings, 280 4th Ave, owner Louis E. Ordwein, architect; cost, $20,000.

Valentim F. Boucas, debt consultant of the Brazilian Finance Ministry, said tonight that negotiations to revise annual payments on Brazil's foreign debt would be begun in New York City on Friday with J. Reuben Clark, head of the Foreign Bondholders Protective Council.

Mrs. Ida F. Craven, 49 years old, 'president and director of the Holmes-Western Consolidated Mines Inc., pleaded not guilty yesterday before General Sessions Judge William Allen on a charge of grand larceny arising out of alleged fraudulent transactions in the shares of the company she heads.

Public library reading rooms as sanctuary for underprivileged youth in American metropolises, and books as an important factor in crime prevention activities, were recommended yesterday to librarians at the fifty-ninth annual conference of the American Library Association at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
Pounding the offerings of three hurlers for 17 hits, the Senators overpowered the Cleveland Indians, 14-5, today. Joe Kuhel and Cecil Travis clouted homers for Washington.

The great Jerome Herman Dean, bested in a pitchers' battle with Van Lingle Mungo for seven innings, finally came up with his eleventh triumph of the esason today as the Gas House Gang pushed over two unearned runs in the eighth to win, 3 to 2.

Fighting the government suit in New York to dissolve the Aluminum Company of America as a vast monopoly, attorneys for the company argued before a special expediting court of three Federal circuit judges here today that the New York court lacked jurisdiction because all charges in the suit were covered by a. consent decree entered against the company in Pittsburgh in 1912.

America has been knocked out by Max Schmeling's contract to fight Tommy Farr in London this Summer and the world heavyweight championship has become a European affair in German eyes. At least, a united host of sport commentators took this view today.

Long shots had their innings at Agawam Park today as form players were handed a succession of rude jolts. Titanical, W. Cook up, provided the longest win payoff of the meeting, also the highest daily double, when he took the second race.

The Fifth Avenue Coach Company agreed yesterday to the demand of the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O. affiliate, for a collective bargaining referendum among the company's 1,200 employes. A conference between John A. Ritchie, president of the company, and Harry Sacher, counsel for the union, resulted in an agreement to ask the City Industrial Relations Board to supervise the election.

Behind a three-hit pitching performance by Tom Gorman, the Power Memorial Academy baseball team blanked St. Augustine's High of Brooklyn, 4 to 0, at the Polo Grounds yesterday to win the city Catholic High Schools Athletic Association championship.

Johnny Bonito, 134 3/4, Washington Heights lightweight, outpointed Phil Siriani, 133 1/4, the Bronx, in the feature eight-round bout before 2,000 persons at Dyckman Oval last night. Bonito's early advantage offset a strong closing bid by Siriani.

The first downtown section of the East River Drive will be opened for public use next Tuesday, at 4 P. M., it was announced yesterday by Borough President Samuel Levy, who will preside at the opening ceremonies. The East Side Chamber of Commerce and other local organizations will participate.

After more than forty years on the police force, Captain William H. Amann, 62 years old, filed an application yesterday for retirement at the end of this month. Captain Amann, who joined the force on Oct. 1, 1896, was appointed sergeant on May 29, 1911.

Problems of world economics, finance and peace were discussed by President Roosevelt and Paul Van Zeeland, Prime Minister of Belgium, during a cruise on the Presidential yacht Potomac on the Potomac River this afternoon.

A participle is a word that " partakes "of the nature of a verb and an ad"jective." As such it differs from an ordinary adjective in that it can take a substantive after it as its object and that it may signify a continued motion.
The Pennsylvania Railroad cited today improved equipment as an argument to support its suit in Dauphin County Court to restrain the State from enforcing the new Full-Crew Law.
Warrants were Issued today for six steel strike pickets charged with interfering with delivery of the United States mail in the Warren and Youngstown districts and service was imminent tonight.

With the sugar harvest still going on, the prospects today indicated that the crop would exceed 1,000,000 short tons and be the second largest on record if it does not surpass the output of 1,113,697 tons for 1934.

A temporary injunction restraining C. Ludwig Baumann Co., Brooklyn, from using the name "Baumann" pending trial of a suit brought by Ludwig Baumann Co., 500 Eighth Avenue, alleging unfair competition, was refused yesterday by Supreme Court Justice William T. Collins.

Sales of copper were made abroad late yesterday at 13.75 cents a pound, c. i. f., European base ports. Early in the day a large volume of business was transacted at 13.57 cents a pound, or around Tuesday's ruling level.

Elias Vander Horst, civil engineer and member of the firm of William H. Cole Sons, died today at his home here at the age of 68. Mr. Vander Horst was a native of Charleston, S. C., and a graduate of Lehigh University. He lived in New York for many years prior to coming to Baltimore.

H. W. Austin, Great Britain, defeated Wayne Sabin, United States, 6-2, 6-3, 6-0; Donald Budge, United States, defeated G. P. Hughes, Great Britain. 6-2, 6-2, 6-2; Bryan M. Grant, United States, defeated R. Morton. Great Britain, 6-2, 3-6, 6-3, 6--0; Gene Mako, United States, defeated H. C. Fisher, Switzerland, 6-1, 6-2. 6-1.

The estate of Henry O. Havemeyer, sugar manufacturer, which was valued at the time of his death on Dec. 4, 1907, at $18,500,551, had increased to $28,411,629 on Dec. 31, 1936, according to an accounting filed in Surrogate's Court yesterday by the executors and trustees.
LONDON-Germany and Italy withdrew from the four-power Spanish patrol as a result of the disagreement over the Leipzig incident. They assured Britain that nothing further was contemplated. Page 1.

The International Labor Conference adjourned its twenty-third session today, facing as its big issue in the coming year a proposal by the workers' bloc that next June's session be devoted to concluding one blanket convention establishing the fortyhour week in all economic activities.
The stock market here was quiet but steadier in most sections today as South African mining shares staged a fair recovery. Gilt-edge issues sagged, although prices rallied somewhat at the close.

More families of social prominence are living abroad this year as compared with last season, and all shore and inland resorts are showing increased patronage, according to the Summer Social Register for 1937, which is now being distributed to subscribers.

The transfer of Marshal Joseph Pilsudski's coffin from St. Leonard's crypt in the Wawel Cathedral --at Krakow to the adjoining "Silver Bell Tower" by the order of the Archbishop there, Prince Sapieha, against President Ignaz Moscicki's wishes today, provoked the Cabinet to offer its resignation.

Rowing shifted its center of interest today from the river town of Poughkeepsie to the deep-sea atmosphere of this one-time whaling port where, on Friday, Harvard and Yale bring this season's college racing to its close.
Grabbing the new season by the horns, as it were, Gilbert Miller comes forward this morning to make a definite announcement of the opening date for his first Fall production.

Commodore Reuben Oscar Bitler, retired naval officer, died yesterday at the home of his daughter, Mrs. John Zablisky, in Drexel Hill, after a long illness. He was 78 years old. Commodore Bitler's long career in the navy was decided by the flip of a coin.

Charges made by W. C. Langley Co. for marketing bonds and preferred stock of the Long Island Lighting Company were not excessive, Joseph W. Briggs, vice president of the investment banking house of H. M. Byllesby Co. of Chicago, testified yesterday in Supreme Court.

Receiving an honorary degree at Yale University today in recognition of his contribution to amity in the Western Hemisphere and for his reciprocal trade policy, Secretary of State Hull declared that personal freedom under the law was the American creed and way of life, and added that these principles were guiding the government today more strongly than for many years.

Four members of the University of Southern California golf team fought their way into the quarter-finals of the Middle Atlantic intercollegiate golf tournament today. Howard Hoon won on the eighteenth green from F. Souchek, Pitt, who missed a long putt by inches. The summaries:

Secretary Perkins said today that the Federal Mediation Board, headed by Charles P. Taft 2d, was making "definite headway" toward a solution of the steel strike. She said she had been in frequent touch with the board members and could say positively that progress was being made.

Miss Sarah Lee Perot, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward S. Perot of 2 Beekman Place, will be married to Harvey Branigar Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Harvey Branigar of Chicago, on Aug. 16 at the home of her parents.

The board of directors-of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company has become a "self-perpetuating body," investigators of the Federal Communications Commission t asserted today when the commission resumed its inquiry into the utility's capital structure.

President Roosevelt today received the honorary cross of the American Cross of Honor and accepted the honorary presidency of the order, which is made up of persons who have received medals for saving life.
Employes of the American Locomotive Company's plant here will be polled next Tuesday to select a bargaining agency, according to John Corey, organizer for the United Locomotive Workers Union. Mr.

C. I. O. union members in the local plant of the American Smelting and Refining Company went on a sit-down strike this afternoon, halting operations in the plant and refusing to permit any one to leave or enter the buildings.

The excellent all-around performance of the ten-goal Stewart Iglehart gave his Aiken Knights quartet a 9-3 victory over Robert E. Strawbridge's Ramblers in a practice match on the J. S. Phipps estate today.

A HISTORY OF PEACEFUL CHANGE IN THE MODERN WORLD, by C. R. M. F. Cruttwell. (Oxford University Press, $3.) Alteration of the status quo by peaceful means. ANATOLE FRANCE, by Edwin Preston Dargan. (Oxford University Press, $5.) A biography.

If Senators always vote in accordance with their own convictions, and if these convictions are based solely on the merits of the proposal before them and are without relation to their chances of re-election, then the following figures are without significance.

The United States should have an army and navy adequate "to defend ourselves not only from nations without, but from influences of other nations within our land," Senator William E. Borah asserted in a speech in the Senate today in support of the $663,000,000 War Department Appropriation Bill.

The contract for construction of the Bronx and Queens towers of the proposed Bronx- Whitestone bridge was awarded to the American Bridge Company yesterday by the Triborough Bridge Authority on a bid of $1,128,800. The only other bid was for $1,160,080, submitted by the Bethlehem Steel Company.

Elmer F. Andrews, State Industrial Commissioner, announced today an increase of 1.1 per cent from midApril to mid-May in the payrolls of New York's retail stores. Employment, he said, remained at practically the April level.
The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today dated June 21: CAPTAIN Shelden, L. Jr.. Med. Corps, to Norfolk Naval Hospital, Portsmouth, Va., Instead Chelsea. Mass.

Preparation of pay checks for 4,400 WPA artists, musicians, writers and archivists was halted yesterday by a sit-down strike of fifty relief workers, eight of whom had received dismissal notices, in the administrative offices of the four Federal art projects at 235 East Forty-second Street.

On the site of one of the nation's oldest courses, St. Andrew's, where the first national amateur was played in 1894, a small but select field of aspirants for the New York State junior crown set forth today.

Five parcels of residential. realty in Jersey City have been purchased by the P. S. Realty Company from two Jersey City savings banks through J. I. Kislak, Inc., broker. The Provident Institution for Savings sold the building at 182 Bay Street, containing six apartments and two stores:
In spite of the deadlock in the labor situation in the steel industry, a little more optimistic feeling toward security prices is becoming evident in the financial community.

The Giants gave an unexpected and uninvited touch to Chicago's Frank Chance Day today when, in an inspired effort to bring their own idolized Carl Owen Hubbell back on the victory trail once more, they crushed the Cubs, 8 to 4. The victory brought New York within one game of the league-leading Chicagoans.

Recapitalization of the International Paper and Power Company was approved by a "large majority" of stockholders who met here today for that purpose, according to Richard J; Cullen, president of the company.

Action of major interest to the men's clothing field was taken yesterday by two popular-price chains, when Crawford Clothes announced a temporary reduction in price and Howard Clothes introduced a tenpayment plan for customers in this area.

The forces which have opposed Governor Earle's policies in the strike at the Bethlehem Steel Corporation's Cambria plant combined here tonight and announced a drive on a nation-wide scale to raise funds to fight "the greatest invasion of workers' rights ever attempted in this country."
Dr. William Beebe made a quarter-mile walk under water from his experimental station at New Nonsuch Island to Longbird Island, acquiring much submarine data.

Mrs. Helen Tiernan, sentenced to twenty years to life for the murdertof her daughter, entered the State prison for women at the Westfield State Farm, near here, at 5:15 P. M. today. She arrived in an automobile and was accompanied by a matron.

Thomas Hancock Nunn, probably the most retiring and certainly one of the foremost voluntary social reformers of his generation, died in Shoreham, Sussex, today at the age of 78. It was largely due to his work on the Royal Commission investigating laws for administering relief to the poor that the efforts of voluntary and statutory bodies were coordinated.

A jury, after deliberating thirteen hours, returned verdict of guilty early yesterday against the National Home Builders Corporation and four individuals and disagreed as to two others who had been indicted under the mail fraud statute for allegedly misrepresenting that they were connected with the Federal Housing Administration.

The marriage of Miss Louise Converse Morgan, elder daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Junius Spencer Morgan of this community and New York, to Raymond Skinner Clark, son of Mrs. Raymond S. Clark of Fisher's Island and New York, and the late Mr. Clark, took place at noon today in the Episcopal Church of St. John's of Lattingtown, Locust Valley.

The wedding of Miss Ella von Boettisher Hedrick, daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. Charles Baker Hedrick of this city, to Robert Henry Footman, son of Henry Edward Footman of Kansas City, Mo., took place today in St. Paul's Church Chapel. The bride's father officiated.
St. Louis at New York-Hogsett vs. Hadley. Cleveland at Washington-Harder vs. Weaver. Detroit at Boston-Auker vs. Grove. Chicago at Philadelphia-Lee vs. Kelley.

Joe Louis promised today to be a fighting champion, and said he wants to fight at least four times a year. Following his knockout victory over James J. Braddock for the world heavyweight title, the Brown Bomber today signed a contract giving Promoter Mike Jacobs exclusive call on his services for five years.

Arthur G. Newmyer, publisher of The New York American, which is to be consolidated with The New York Journal and The Mirror, will become an assistant general manager of the Hearst chain of newspapers, it was announced last night.

The importance of film as a medium of musical research was emphasized yesterday by Roger Howson, librarian of Columbia University, at the closing session of the two-day meeting of the Music Library Association in the Journalism Building, Columbia University.

The forgotten men and women of Wimbledon fought hard today but the seeded players, including Donald Budge, Bryan M. (Bitsy) Grant, Frank Parker and Miss Helen Jacobs, of the United States, all advanced on schedule to the third round of men's and the third and fourth rounds of women's singles in the all-England tennis championships.

A review of the effect of its policies on domestic economic conditions and of developments in the foreign economic situation which had tended to induce a steady flow of capital to the United States from abroad was presented today by the board of governors of the Federal Reserve System in a report covering 1936 sent to Congress.

An appeal for settlement of the steel strike on the principle of an organized relationship between employers and employes, cemented by signed agreements, was made today by more than 100 clergymen of many denominations residing in various parts of the country.

An eighteen-inch putt that stubbornly skirted the right side of the fifteenth hole and a wasted niblick shot that refused to dislodge her ball from the trap below the nineteenth green furnished small but potent reasons today why Miss Grace Amory will not be playing for a finalist's bracket in the Women's Long Island Golf Association championship at the Women's National Golf and Tennis Club tomorrow.
Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum on June 12 totaled 307,199,000 barrels, according to the Bureau of Mines. This represented a decrease of 24,000 barrels in a week.
Mr. and Mrs. Augustus S. Blagden of Ambler have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Kemp Blagden, to Dr. Arthur Lee Kinsolving, rector of Trinity Church, Boston.

The Collins Aikman Corporation and subsidiaries reported yesterday for the quarter ended on May 29 a net profit of $1,236,709 after expenses, depreciation, Federal, State and Canadian income taxes and other charges.

Governor Lehman ordered vigorous enforcement of laws prohibiting gambling at dog racing tracks today, and within an hour had a pledge of "full cooperation" from District Attorney Martin W. Littleton of Nassau County.

Miss J. Emilie Young, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Harold E. W. Young of Brooklyn, was married yesterday afternoon to Dr. David Saville Muzzey, Graduate Professor of American History at Columbia University.

Forty yachts, the largest fleet in the history of the American Yacht Club's annual Rye-to-New London race, set sail from off Scotch Caps late this evening in a light northwest breeze expected to freshen enough during the night to carry them to their destination, some ninety miles eastward down the Sound, by midday tomorrow or thereabout.
Dr. Robert K. Lippmann of New York, a client of Kenneth Ives Co., has purchased the property of Mrs. Maria Muller on Weed Hill Avenue, Stamford, cnn.

The election of Republican delegates to the 1938 State Constitutional Convention "is more essential to the success of the Republican Party and to the future of the State" than the election of a Republican governor, William F. Bleakley, gubernatorial candidate last autumn, told 700 members of the Westchester County Republican Committee here today.
Former Premier Hendryk Colijn completed today, after almost four weeks' effort, a Cabinet of Catholic-Calvinist character. The list, which was approved by Queen Wilhelmina this afternoon, follows:

The lack of public interest continued -in evidence yesterday as bond prices were mixed with the utility issues declining. The trading pace quickened somewhat over the previous session on the New York Stock Exchange with sales $6,609,700, compared with $5,771,400.

For the first time in many years graduates of the Army War College were addressed in secret today, the speaker being Secretary Woodring. What he said was impressed upon the ninety-five graduates as "strictly confidential."

Sharp gains in membership and the distribution of merchandise among the consumers cooperatives in all the democratic countries in Europe in 1936 are shown in statistics compiled by the International Cooperative Alliance and issued yesterday by the Cooperative League News Service.

Pensioned On his own application: To take effect 12 midnight. June 25: PATROLnMAN - William P. McDermott, 41st Precinct, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed June 11, 1912. Transfers and Assignments: To take effect 8 A. M., June 24:
Activity in realty in Manhattan yesterday was marked by deals involving a variety of improvements, including houses. a loft building and a warehouse.

Former State Senator Albert Wald, chairman of the Jewish exhibit at the New York 1939 World's Fair, will be the speaker tonight at the nineteenth annual commencement of the Talmudical Academy, the high school department of Yeshiva College, Amsterdam Avenue at 186th Street.

Movements of livestock on the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts, 12,000, including 4,500 direct. Market fully 10c higher than yesterday's average; top $11.75 paid frequently;

JOHN DOS PASSOS, just home from Spain, France and England, writes a "Farewell to Europe!" in the current issue of Common Sense. The novelist found cause in Europe only for pessimism, but the Atlantic was a relief because it was so wide. Over there the hopes that dazzled for twenty years that a political movement' might tend to the betterment of the human lot, he says, are mostly buried.

A possibility that the week-end conference of Democrats with President Roosevelt at the Jefferson Islands Club might develop into a fight over adjournment of congress was suggested today by incidents on Capitol Hill.

Mrs. Mary Sprague Cook of 103 East Eighty-sixth Street died on Monday at her Summer home at Branford, Conn., in her eightysixth year. Mrs. Cook, long active in charitable enterprises here, was the widow of Edward Mitchell Cook, whom she married in 1876. He died in 1907.

Miss Mildred Mary Brereton, daughter of Edward Joseph Brereton of West Hartford, and Richard Daniel O'Connell, son of Dr. Thomas Smith O'Connell of East Hartford, were married today in St. Joseph's Cathedral. The Rev. John F. Callahan of St. Thomas the Apostle Church, West Hartford, officiated.

A recommendation for settlement of the Public Works bonds that have been in default since 1933 has been presented by the bondholders' committee for Republic of Cuba bonds, headed by Senator Gerald P. Nye of the United States, to the Cuban Government commission now studying resumption of payment on this issue, according to a statement made tonight to the press.

The Senate Committee on Foreign Relations voted today to recommend to the Senate ratification of a treaty to coordinate and bring up to date all Pan-American treaties affecting neutrality and related questions.

Johnny Bonito, 134 3/4, Washington Heights lightweight, outpointed Phil Siriani, 133 1/4, the Bronx, in the feature eight-round bout before 2,000 persons at Dyckman Oval last night. Bonito's early advantage offset a strong closing bid by Siriani.

Here are the recipients of honorary degrees as presented today by Professor William Lyon Phelps to President Angell at Yale University, together with the citations: James Gore King McClure Jr., M. A. PROFESSOR PHELPS - Farmer, Yale, B. A., 1906.
Estate, more than $20,000. To Edith Kane Baker, widow, executrix, 75 E. 93d St., household, personal effects, except cash and life interest in residue:

Worried over the probable effect on exports of a sharp increase in production and selling costs on manufactured goods this Fall, export executives will confer on the problem here in coming weeks. Foreign traders asserted yesterday that a sharp advance in selling prices will mean a setback to sales of American goods in practically all parts of the world.
"A policy of shedding blood is dangerous and contagious; one cuts off a head today, tomorrow another, and the day after tomorrow a third--then what remains of the party?"

Thomas F. Moore Sr., retired superintendent of officers of the New York Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children, died yesterday of a heart ailment at his home-at 32-21 167th Street, Flushing. His age was 75.

Passengers arriving today from the Channel ports on the Washington of the United States Lines are Dr. Robert Andrews Millikan, noted American physicist; Mrs. Millikan and their son, Dr. Glenn Millikan; Harry J. Anslinger, United States Commissioner of Narcotics; Mrs.

Production of coats and suits has continued without break this week and the indications yesterday were said to be that output would be maintained for another week at least, despite the fact that the union and the inside manufacturers and jobbers have been unable to get together on a new contract.
The Mackay Radio and Telegraph Company must be allowed to compete in the international field if it is to survive, Luke McNamee, president, yesterday told the Federal Communications Commission.
Mrs. Edmund Cluett, a member of one of Troy's leading families, died suddenly of a cerebral hemorrhage last night at her home, 50 Second Street. Her age was 90.

The Seventh International Management Congress; which delegates from forty countries are expected to attend, will be held in Washington from Sept. 19 to 23, 1938, it was announced last night at an organization dinner in the River Club, 447 East Fifty-second Street. Viscount Leverhulme will be president of the congress.

The twenty-first annual Summer session of City College will open today, when approximately 5,500 men and women students return to classes in the Main Center, 139th Street and Convent Avenue, and in the School of Business and Civic Administration, Twenty-third Street and Lexington Avenue.
Labor troubles, particularly in the Midwest, are definitely retarding advertising volume, delegates to the Advertising Federation convention here, which closed yesterday, agreed.
When a commercial fisherman brought in the first swordfish at Montauk less than two weeks ago, anglers had some inkling of the approaching season. Since then some thirty more have been harpooned.

Mrs. Henry H. Dietrich, medalist and favorite, led a select group into the semi-final round of the fifteenth annual women's Westchester-Fairfield championship today at the Westchester Hills Golf Club as only one minor upset marked the quarter-finals.

The United Automobile Workers carried their organizing campaign among Ford Motor Company workers to the Dearborn City limits today. Volunteers distributed a "Ford edition" of the union's publication, The United Automobile Worker, under instructions to remain on the Detroit side of the line.

In a statement telephoned to the New York offices of the company after the meeting Mr. Cullen said: "It has been gratifying to learn that the holders of such a large majority of our shares agree with us." The vote by classes was as follows:

The proposed equal rights amendment to the Constitution providing that "men and women shall have equal rights throughout the United States and every place subject to its jurisdiction" was reported favorably to the Senate Judiciary Committee today by unanimous vote of a subcommittee, of which Senator Burke is chairman.

Trading in lamb was slow in slaughter houses but fair in wholesale markets. Demand for other classes, fair to good. Lamb Prices were uneven, steer beef strong to higher, other prices fully steady. Early trading in kosher meat indicated beef and veal prices to be strong to higher, lamb steady, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.

A tea will be given tomorrow at Driftwood, the home of Mrs. Otto Marx in Mamaroneck, for members of the women's committee of the New York Guild for the Jewish Blind. At that time also a meeting will be held to formulate plans for the social welfare activities of the guild;

"Labor anarchy with a government guarantee places the strikeaffected steel companies in a position from which there appears to be no way out that will be satisfactory to either side in the controversy,"
Announcement has been made by Mrs. James T. Houghton of the engagement of her daughter, Miss Carol Prichitt, to Zeb Mayhew, son of Mrs. Allard Kaufmann of New Orleans and of the late Zeb Mayhew.

The practice of "many wealthy taxpayers" of splitting themselves into multiple personalities, "with the single purpose of avoiding the payment of taxes," was explained today by Guy T. Helvering, Commissioner of Internal Revenue, to the joint Congressional committee investigating the income-tax situation.
A return of 77,000 workers to private industry in May and an increase of nearly $5,200,000 in weekly payrolls over those of April were reported today by Secretary Perkins of the Department of Labor.

The German Aero Club, which as a coordinated body was presumably acting in conformity with government wishes, has telegraphed a request to the International Aeronautic Federation to annul this year's Gordon Bennett balloon race, just completed, and arrange a new start for all the participants.

Details were received here today to identify several Americans killed and wounded at the time of the shelling of Almeria by a German squadron on May 31. Three Americans were killed and two wounded. All had been engaged in army transport duty.

When Mayor LA GUARDIA said the other day that New York City " cannot " afford the luxury of a political govern" ment any more " he expressed a truth with which most of us must agree, but he also underlined the degradation of a noble word.
A strong feeling of disappointment arises out of the first half-dozen tax evaders, or tax deviators, or tax diversionists,

Simple funeral services attended by men prominent in New Jersey governmental, political and financial circles, were held here today for Franklin W. Fort, former Representative and adviser to ex-President Herbert Hoover. More than 400 persons attended the rites in the Fort residence.

A stock option plan for employes covering 25,000 shares of common stock was revealed in a statement filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission by the Simmons Company and made public by the New York Stock Exchange.

Areements by Bristol-Myers Company to stop representing that use of Ipana toothpaste with a gum massage will keep one from becoming a "dental cripple," and by the Charles H. Phillips Chemical Company to stop asserting that Phillips' Milk of Magnesia toothpaste as "the best way yet discovered or science's latest. discovery for cleaning teeth," were among a number. of stipulations entered into by New York firms made public today by the Federal Trade Commission.
One issue, "labor," crowded all others to the background today in the discussions of retail store executives attending the midyear convention of the National Retail Dry Goods Association here.

Two continuous rod mills of the American Steel and Wire Company, a subsidiary of the United States Steel Corporation, were dedicated yesterday at Joliet, Ill., as part of a $5,000,000 improvement program of the company in the Chicago district.

Phillips Chemical Company to stop asserting that Phillips' Milk of Magnesia toothpaste as "the best way yet discovered or science's latest. discovery for cleaning teeth," were among a number. of stipulations entered into by New York firms made public today by the Federal Trade Commission.

Amsco Book Company, Inc., in 373 Fourth Ave; Peter J. McLoughlin, textiles, in 377 Broadway; New Art Flower Co, in 165 W 26th St; Carl Heyman and Harry SegaL in 460 Fourth Ave; Bernard Castro, Inc, through Holmes Douglas, Inc, floor in 45-7 E 20th St: Carstens, Linnekin Wilson, Inc, broker.
The crisis precipitated by Italy's and Germany's withdrawal from international patrol duty off Spain took on special gravity today.

The A. A. Building Corporation of Quaker Ridge has purchased twenty-six building lots in New Rochelle, N. Y., through the G. LeRoy Kemp Company, Inc., and Boehm Co., co-brokers. The buyers propose to develop the tract, which is located on Oxford Road in Wykagyl Park, with a group of Colonial homes.
President Roosevelt spent most of the day in conference with Premier van Zeeland of Belgium, his overnight guest.

The Steel Mediation Board failed in another attempt today to arrange a joint conference between the spokesmen for the four independent steel companies and the Steel Workers Organizing Committee. But it will renew its efforts tomorrow.

Joseph C. Lang, retired treasurer of the Perrin Glove Company, Inc., 432 Fourth Avenue, manufacturers and importers of gloves, died on Tuesday of a heart ailment at his home, 923 Herkimer Street, Brooklyn, after a long illness.
