Mr. Lang was 58 years old and a native of Indiana. He served twenty-five years with the Perrin company.

The toll of Trinidad's strike riots mounted to fourteen dead and forty-four injured today as additional reports came from the interior of the island, crippled by a strike of more than 5,000 oil workers.

Two continuous rod mills of the American Steel and Wire Company, a subsidiary of the United States Steel Corporation, were dedicated yesterday at Joliet, Ill., as part of a $5,000,000 improvement program of the company in the Chicago district.

Substantial gains in the domestic production of practically all groups of coal-tar chemicals, including dyes and other synthetic organic chemicals; were shown last year, in comparison with the previous year, according to a report issued today by the Tariff Commission.

Mayor La Guardia called the Third Avenue Railway Company a "selfish and greedy" organization yesterday, and blocked the Sinking Fund Commission's plan to authorize removal of street car tracks in Park Row and in West Forty-second Street.

The first solo flight on Tuesday of 12-year-old Edward Somers of 1,982 East Thirty-seventh Street, Brooklyn, from Floyd Bennett Field, started an investigation yesterday by the officials of the Bureau of Air Commerce. Under the regulations no one under 16 years of age is qualified to fly as a student pilot.
The Duke of Windsor celebrated his forty-third birthday here in a hotel with his Duchess today. Congratulations came from all parts of the world. He received many gifts.

A contract whereby the Pittston Company, a coal mining and distributing agency controlled by the Chesapeake Ohio Railway and the Alleghany Corporation, paid $60,000 as fees to Pittston Coal, Inc., a subsidiary of the Pittston Company, was disclosed in a statement filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission by the Pittston Company and made public by the commission.

Miss Dorothy Matthew Olton, daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. Percy T. 01ton of this city, was married this afternoon to Richard Prescott Saunders of New York, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Charles A. Saunders of Somerville, Mass.

"Men, Women and Tenors" will be the title of Mme. Frances Alda's memoirs, Houghton Mifflin announces. Mme. Alda, a former member of the Metropolitan Opera Company and wife of its director, Gatti-Casazza, has just signed a contract. The book will appear in the Fall.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are June 23 unless specified: At San Juan, Badger, Decatur, Dickerson, Herbert. Leary, Tattnall, Tillman. At Juneau, June 22, Brooks, Fox. Acushnet, at Dahlgren. Cummings. New York Yard to sea, June 22. Cuyama, Pearl Harbor to San Pedro, June 22. towing Sanderling.

Close-of-play scores in English first-class cricket matches started today were: Yorkshire 428 for three wickets (Sutcliffe 189, Hutton 153, Leyland 55 not out); vs. Leicestershire; at Hull. Hampshire 341 (Pothecary 115, McCorkell 59, Arnold 55 not out); Derbysbire 47 for no wickets; at Chesterfield.
Miss Marsyl Stokes, eldest daughter of Mrs. Henry Drummond-Wolff of London, who is to be introduced this year, is to have three comingout parties.

Spurgeon Chandler's return to pitching duty for the Yankees was hardly a success yesterday. The Browns found the freshman righthander no puzzle as they routed the McCarthymen at the Stadium with a thirteen-hit attack and won, 6-3.

An active demand for East Side apartments featured the residential leasing reports yesterday. Many large suites were included in the list, which was one of the heaviest in recent months. The klay's reports follow:

Supreme Court Justice Louis A. Valente signed an order yesterday directing Richard J. Daly of New Rochelle, Margaret E. Daly, his wife, and a third person identified as Robert Oakley to appear at Special Term on July 1 with the books of the firm of Richard J. Daly Co., operating a securities investment service in White Plains.

Five hundred and fifty new elementary and high school teachers were added to the New York City school system by the Board of Education at its regular meeting at 500 Park Avenue yesterday afternoon. James Marshall, vice president of the board, presided.

Tne war Department released the following orders today dated June 22: BRIGADIER GENERAL Grant, W. S., one month leave, July 1. LIEUTENANT COLONELS Porter, W. N., Chemical Warfare Service, one month and ten days leave, July 6.
Members of the New York Stock Exchange are circulating on the floor a petition to have. the Exchange closed on Saturday, July 3. Yesterday there were 224 signatures.
Abandonment of the control system of the Spanish coast is being urged here as a result of the withdrawal of Germany and Italy.

The Chicago North Western Railway received yesterday the Harriman memorial gold medal for meritorious achievement in railroad safety in 1936. Silver and bronze medals were awarded to the Detroit, Toledo Ironton Railroad and the Lake Superior Ishpeming Railroad, respectively.

Several demonstrators and policemen were injured here today during a manifestation by war veterans against the amnesty extended by the government to "war traitors," the term applied by the demonstrators.

Dispatches from the ranch of Medellin reported today the slaying of nine persons, including the Villa Hermosa police chief, in a gun battle that followed an attempt by police to arrest a group of Catholics attending religious services in a private home.

The Chicago North Western Railway received yesterday the Harriman memorial gold medal for meritorious achievement in railroad safety in 1936. Silver and bronze medals were awarded to the Detroit, Toledo Ironton Railroad and the Lake Superior Ishpeming Railroad, respectively.

Several demonstrators and policemen were injured here today during a manifestation by war veterans against the amnesty extended by the government to "war traitors," the term applied by the demonstrators.

All semi-final brackets in the doubles competition and the two remaining places in the quarter-final round of the singles were filled today in the women's New Jersey State tennis championships on the courts of the Oritani Field Club.

The American Radio Telegraphisis Association has withdrawn from: negotiations by maritime labor unions for a peace settlement pending the outcome of an election by tie crews of eighty-eight Atlantio and Gulf steamship lines for a bargaining agency, it was learned yesterday.
Eleanor Nash McWilliam today received a divorce from Culver B. McWilliam of New York on the ground of cruelty. An agreement was signed for the custody of their three children.

The city was urged yesterday to purchase an acre of privately owned land overlooking Raritan Bay in order that the grounds of Conference House, a historical shrine located at the southernmost tip of the State at Tottenville, S. I., may be extended and improved.

Beck St. (10-2707), e s 75 s of Longwood Ave. 35x100; Bankers Trust Co., trumte, to Meyer Chinsky, 927 Faile St. Anderson Ave, (9-2504), e s 558 n of Jerome Ave, 31x154; George B. Raymond to Archie B. Morrison. 426 E 143d St, mort $21.000.

Mike Belloise, recognized here as the world's featherweight champion, will oppose Jimmy McLeod of Tacoma, Wash., in the feature tenround bout at Madison Square Garden tonight. Prices ranging from 40 cents to $2.20 will prevail again.

A dozen contestants took part in the annual team championship of the Long Island Golf Association at the Plandome Golf Club today. Quartets were present from only three clubs, Plandome, the Oceanside Country Club and the Peninsula Golf Club of Inwood, with the home forces coming through as - champions.
The Baltimore Orioles finally emerged from last place today at the expense of the Jersey City Giants, whom they defeated, 3 to 1,

Five persons were killed, twenty were seriously injured and ninety-eight were less severely hurt this morning when a suburban train of the Brazilian Central Railroad crowded with workers bound for the city was rammed by another train.

Young Men's Christian Associations as a group are not exempt under the State Unemployment Insurance act, it was ruled today at a hearing before W. Warren Barbour, chairman of the State Unemployment Compensation Commission, and George W. Griffiths, a member of the commission.

Hornet, the sloop owned by George Hubbard, was the winner in the racing division today in the Rye-toNew London contest. She defeated the scratch craft, George Lauder's Windward, which was first to finish, on corrected time.
The threelegged race, so dear to the hearts of American picnic directors, has become a fixture in the life of at least one village in war-torn Spain.

GOVERNORS ISLAND So much of paragraph 3, Special Orders 117, dated May 20, 1937, as relates to the following named Reserve officers, Is revoked: 2d Lt. John V. Greene. Inf-Res.; 2d Lt. Herbert Kirschner, Inf-Res.; 2d Lt. Frank J. Curran Jr., Inf-Res.

The Duchess of Leeds, accompanied by her sister, Mrs. Edward Latham Jones of Philadelphia, has returned to the Waldorf-Astoria. Mr. and Mrs. F. Hamilton McCormick-Goodheart of Washington, who had been at the Madison, left yesterday for their Summer home in Bar Harbor, Me.

Mrs. Henry H. Dietrich of Gedney Farm advanced a step nearer the women's Westchester-Fairfield golf championship today by triumphing over Mrs. Edward Stevens of Round Hill, 4 and 2, in the semifinal round at Westchester Hills.

Six days of agony, three of them spent in crawling a scant 200 yards to his cabin in the mountain fastness, preceded his telphone call for help, it became known here today after Warden Edward McDonald, badly injured, was brought to Jasper from his cabin forty miles away by a rescue party.

The New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad's trustees filed today a petition in Federal court for authority to pay interest on New York, New Haven Hartford Harlem Riverport Chester 4 per cent first-mortgage bonds and on Naugatuck Railroad Company 4 per cent first-mortgage bonds before Aug. 1, the date on which the period of grace for such payment expires. The interest fell due on May 1.

Harry Brown, importer, long a resident here, died suddenly yesterday at Nassau Hospital, Mineola, of an internal disorder. He was president of the Arthur Geoffrey Company, Inc., importers of upholstery fabrics, with offices at 874 Broadway in New York. Mr.

Retail credit collections in May showed an increase of 1.14 per cent, according to the index of twenty local key stores issued yesterday by the Credit Bureau of Greater New York. Fifteen stores showed increases. The average for the month was 49.05, compared with 47.91 for May, 1936.

IT is pretty hard to find a simple descriptive term for Maury Maverick's book. The book is called "A Maverick American" (Covici, Friede, $3), and hence might appear to be an autobiography. But at the very beginning the author declares that he has written no such thing. And an author may as well be taken at his word.

Violent differences of opinion on divorce shook the House of Lords today in a debate over Alan Patrick Herbert's hotly controversial, marriage bill, providing for reform of Great Britain's archaic divorce law and the end of what its author has called the "holy deadlock."

The American and European auto drivers who will try for the rich prize in the second 300-mile Vanderbilt Cup race at the Roosevelt Raceway Saturday, July 3, will start revealing their speed tomorrow in the first of the qualifying tests to determine the thirty cars and drivers that will start in the contest.

Special Prosecutor Thomas E. Dewey took personal charge yesterday of the prosecution in Special Sessions of Irving Rudow on a State tax-evasion charge growing out of an investigation of racketeering in the garment district.

Chick Hafey, former National League batting champion, now attempting a comeback after a twoyear layoff, wielded a powerful stick today to lead the Reds to a 6-4 victory over the Phillies, and the Reds thereby displaced their victims in sixth place in the National League race.

Miss Norma Taubele, New York State champion and No. 1 seeded player, was the victim of a sensational upset in the quarter-final round of the women's New Jersey State tennis championships at the Oritani Field Club today when she went down before the steady-stroking Mrs. Tokuko Nakano of Japan, 6-2. 6-2.

Magistrate David L. Malbin, sitting in the Bay Ridge Court, Brooklyn, yesterday dismissed complaints of illegal sale of contraceptives against fifteen druggists arrested May 19 in District Attorney William F. X. Geoghan's campaign in Brooklyn to safeguard morals.

A Circuit Court jury convicted today Lester Brockelhurst, 23 years old, of first degree murder and fixed his punishment at death in the electric chair for the hitch-hike slaying of Victor A. Gaines on May 6.

A move to rally all foreign traders, as well as investors in the Philippines, to protect their interests in the islands, will be launched here this week through the Philippine-American Advisory Committee, sponsored by the National Foreign Trade Council.

Business on the stock market took a better turn today, with the result that prices in most sections reflected an upward tendency. Gilt-edge issues were steadier and Germans, among foreign loans, improved.

Action to clean up Britain's theatres, motion pictures, music halls and cabarets was launched today at a secret conference in St. James's Palace. The idea for the conference came from the Earl of Cromer, the stage censor, who organized the meeting jointly with the London County Council, the licensing authority in the metropolitan area.

Short "air taxi" tours over the World's Fair grounds will be one of the most popular features of the coming exhibition, forty members of the women's advisory committee of the fair predicted yesterday afternoon after a twenty-five-minute trial flight from Newark Airport over the Flushing Meadows and back.

Despite the insistence of Emir Abdallah Ibn Hussein of Trans-Jordan that the idea of the partition of Palestine has been abandoned, this writer has learned authoritatively that the British Government's solution of this country's problem will be the already much- discussed partition scheme, based on the Royal Commission's report.

The Times or London has announced that its manager, William Lints Smith, will retire in the Autumn. He will be succeeded by C. S. Kent, now assistant manager. Mr. Lints Smith has been manager of The Times for seventeen years. Before that he was associated manager for six years.

Federal Judge Vincent L. signed yesterday a writ of corpus requiring immigration authorities to appear in court next Tuesday with a man who says he is Baron Rolf Reitzenstein, who will be executed, he insists, if an order calling for his deportation to Germany is carried out.
Mrs. Alfred B. Hallowell of Boston will serve as attendant to Miss Elthel du Pont, who will be married to Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. next Wednesday, it was announced today.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The serious consideration given by correspondents of THE TIMES to the steel companies' refusal to put their agreements into writing is but further evidence that the Labor Law is sui generis and that in industrial disputes reason waits patiently upon expedience.

Following Wednesday's sharp recovery, prices on the Cotton Exchange eased yesterday under favorable weather and July liquidation to end with losses of 10 to 18 points. Aggressive buying operations of the previous session were not repeated and at the same time, the rise in May contracts toward the 12 1/2-cent level brought out more cotton.

George Bernard Shaw believes that Congress deserves "drastic lynching" for forcing curtailment of the WPA Federal Arts Projects. In a cablegram yesterday to relief actors, musicians, artists, writers and archivists who are protesting against the distribution of dismissal notices-to 2,848 of their number, the Irish dramatist said:

42d St, n a, 557 ft w of 11th Ave, 43x100.5; Anna M. Schlosser to Henry Schlosser, 649 W 42d St ($40). Front St, 287-291, 43.4x61.7%, excrs .will of Walter Longman to Royale R. Longman and five others, 70 Park Ave, consideration $16,962. 10th St, n s, 293 f e of University P1, 44.6x 94.9; Meon Corp to 39 E 10th St Corp, 24 5th Ave.

The Orizaba of the New York Cuba Mail Steamship. Company was held at her East River pier more than three hours yesterday afternoon when a jurisdictional quarrel between two radio unions caused her crew to quit work.

Four more subsidiary operating companies of the Greyhound Corporation filed applications with the Interstate Commerce Commission for permission to issue stock with which to pay for advances for capital expenditure and equipment from the parent corporation.

The International Longshoremen's Association notified ship lines yesterday that consignments of -wool arriving in this port en route to New England mills where strikes are in effect would not be unloaded.

The National Hospital for Speech Disorders will be expanded and operated in a new home at 61-63 Irving. Place as a result of a gift from Lucius N. Littauer, manufacturer and philanthropist, it was announced yesterday.

Facing an acute labor situation, berry farmers of Burlington, Camden and Atlantic Counties express fears that 25 per cent of the crop in those counties would spoil on the ground unless a call for berry pickers, sent out yesterday, was answered within the next two weeks.

Because of research work sponsored by the nation's great industries, the science of optometry stands on the threshold of a new era in which the entire progress of the past 200 years may be exceeded in a decade, Dr. Richard M. Hall, of Cleveland, said as the annual meeting of the American Academy of Optometry opened today.

A residence and three and onehalf acres on El Retiro Lane, Irvington-on-Hudson, N. Y., have been purchased by Adolph Stern from Mrs. Donaldson Brown. The house contains ten rooms and four baths and will be occupied by the buyer. Prince Ripley were the brokers.

J. Harvey Williams, head of the Republican Committee Against La Guardia, charged yesterday that counterfeit ballots had been used to "stack" a poll being taken by him among members of the New York Young Republican Club.

A tentative draft of proposed rules for the regulation of the over-the-counter markets which define practices considered to be manipulative, deceptive or fraudulent within the meaning of Sections 15 (c) and 10 (b) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 has been sent to State Securities Commissions, organizations of brokers and dealers and the various Stock Exchanges for their comment prior to final adoption,

The Pennsylvania Railroad Company issued yesterday a statement for May showing a net railway oprating income of $6,066,111, a decrease of $793,281 from the same month of 1936. For the first five months of this year the net operating income was $28,765,731, compared with $28,320,802 in the similar period last year.
Public offering will be made today by a banking group headed by Morgan Stanley Co., Inc., of $20,449,000 of securities of the Buffalo Niagara Electric Corporation.

Governer Davey in Columbus early this morning issued orders to Major Gen. Gilson D. Light, military commander of the Youngstown strike area, to permit men who want to return to work in the mills of the Republic Steel Corporation and the Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company to do so under the protection of the 4,500 National Guard troops now in this city and vicinity.

The New York City public schools will close officially next Wednesday, when nearly 1,250,000 children and 36,000 teachers start a tenweek Summer vacation, Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools announced yesterday.

Plans for the establishment at Valley Forge of the experimental College of Liberal Arts, aimed to preserve "the intimate values of the small college in conjunction with the advantages of a great university," have been made public by the University of Pennsylvania Bicentennial Committee.

The following Coast Guard changes for the week ended June 23 were announced today: LIEUTENANT COMMANDERS Belford, H. G., the Nike, to command the Tallapoosa, about Oct. 15. Wood, R. E., the Galatea, to the Campbell as executive officer.
The duel is the only means by which a German student can uphold his honor, Gustav Scheel, Reich student leader, told his subleaders today.

A contract for construction of the Baker Homes development in Lackawanna, N. Y., the last project on the government's first slum clearance and low-rent housing program, was awarded today by Secretary Ickes to the Fleisher Engineering and Construction Company of Buf-, falo, low bidder at $1,329,000 for the complete job.

While there has been no sharp decline since February, business activity in May continued to remain below the recovery high point registered last December, according to the review issued yesterday by the National Industrial Conference Board.

Directors of Cluett, Peabody Co. declared yesterday an initial dividend of 25 cents a share on the common stock following the threefor-one split-up. The dividend prior to the split-up was 75 cents a share and was paid on May 1.

Hot weather has caused a rapid growth of grain crops in the Prairie Provinces of Canada where moisture reserves are adequate, but there are large areas in which rain is urgently needed, according to the current crop report of the Bank of Montreal. The bank adds that some insect damage has been reported.

Geprge Weems Williams, lawyer and member of a prominent Maryland family, died at his home last night at the age of 63. He earned his A. B. degree at Princeton in 1894 and his M. A. in 1897. He received his law degree from the University of Maryland in. 1896.

Mr. and Mrs. George S. Frank of 17 Monroe Place, Brooklyn, have announced the engagement of their ' daughter, Miss Adele Van Anden Frank, to John Baldwin Walker Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. John B. Walker of New York.

With only four dissenting votes, the congregation of Grace Presbyterian Church, Stuyvesant and Jefferson Avenues, Brooklyn, has consented to sell its edifice and merge with the congregation of the First Presbyterian Church of Forest Hills, Seminole Avenue and Gown Street, Queens, the Rev. H. Paul Guhse, pastor, announced yesterday.
Basque troops rallied today at a new defense position extending from Ortuella southward to Gordejuela, about ten miles west of fallen Bilbao.

J. David Stern, publisher, gave a dinner party last night in his New York Post penthouse attended by John L. Lewis, chairman of the C. I. O.; Governor George Earle of Pennsylvania, Senators Wagner and Guffey, Charles P. Howard, president of the Typographical Union, and six other men.

More than sixty sales representatives of Marshall Field Co., manufacturing division, arrived at Newark Airport early last night to attend a three-day sales convention here. Fourteen sales representatives, including Porter J. Case, Pacific Coast sales manager, arrived on an extra plane of the American Airlines from Los Angeles.

A plea for a universal scientific state of mind as the only hope of democracy at grips with despotism and ignorance was made yesterday by Dr. Robert A. Millikan, one of the leading physicists of the world, who returned here on the United States liner Washington. Dr. Millikan, accompanied by his family, lectured in Ireland and the Scandinavian countries.
There was a slight decline in business activity in the Pittsburgh district last week, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh.

Representatives of 465 soft-coal producers at a meeting here today established a board of seventeen members to aid the Bituminous Coal Commission, provided for in the Guffey-Vinson Coal Act, in regulating prices in Eastern Pennsylvania, Maryland and part of West Virginia.

Leasehold deals involving business and residential properties in scattered sections of Manhattan were announced yesterday. The Joseph P. Ryan Association took a lease on the three-story dwelling at 420 West Eighteenth Street in a transaction negotiated by the Duross Company.

With David Croll former Minister of Labor in the Ontario Cabinet, acting as defense counsel, two C. I. O. organizers from Detroit today started an action in the Supreme Court of Ontario seeking $25,000 damages for "false imprisonment" and "ma licious persecution,

James Earl Clauson, veteran newspaper man and for ten years assistant managing editor of the old New York World, died at his home here tonight after he had collapsed on the street. Since 1932 he had conducted a column, "These Plantations," in the Providence Evening Bulletin.

Eluding the grasp of a policeman, Philip Wydoff, 54 years old, a druggist, of 1,765 Southern Boulevard, the Bronx, leaped to his death yesterday afternoon from the third floor of Fordham Hospital, where he was a prisoner charged with felonious assault.

At the annual business meeting of the Municipal Art Society yesterday afternoon, Alfred Geiffert Jr. was elected president to succeed Electus D. Litchfield, who had served the full number of terms permitted under the by-laws of the society.

For the seventy-fifth time since that day in 1852 when Yale and Harvard inaugurated intercollegiate rowing competition in this country with their first race at Lake Winnipesaukee in New Hampshire, the varsities of these two old institutions will meet tomorrow in the feature event of their annual regatta.

The regional office of the National Labor Relations Board completed yesterday the presentation of its case against the Consolidated Edison Company and affiliated companies, and counsel for the utility concern announced that Floyd L. Carlisle, chairman of the board of directors of the Consolidated, would be the first witness for the companies when hearings are resumed on July 6.
Current confusion over the social security status of radio performers may eventually have a decided effect on broadcasting volume, opinions here yesterday indicated.

Customers' orders to buy in odd lots, or lots of fewer than 100 shares, on the New York Stock Exchange in the week ended on June 19 exceeded both in number and value customers' orders to sell, according to a summary made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Queen Mary of England will broadcast from Westminster Abbey tomorrow at 9:55 A. M. over WEAF'S network, while officiating at the laying of the cornerstone for the new church house in the Dean's Yard at the Abbey.

British Government factories already have turned out 9,000,000 gas masks for the civilian population in case of war, Geoffrey Lloyd, Under-Secretary for the Home Office,. told the House of Commons today.
His Boston team-mates gave Lou Fette eight runs in the first three innings today and the Bee hurler scattered thirteen Pirate hits to win, 9 to 6, and end Boston's chain of losses at eleven.

Movements of vessels follow. all dates are June 23, unless specified: San Diego to San Francisco, June 24: Barry, Borie, Childs, Dallas, Gilmer, Goff, Hopkins, Reuben James, Long, Marblehead, Melville, Memphis, Richmond, Trevor, Trenton, Williamson, Zane. williamson, Zane.
The French Government's attitude toward the "new situation" created by the German-Italian decision concerning Spain has hardened since yesterday.

Miss Doris Carver, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry E. Carver of Maplewood, was married this evening in Morrow Memorial Church here to Charles Fuller Fearon, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry D. Fearon of Oneida, N. Y. The Rev. Dr. John E. Charlton, the pastor, performed the ceremony.

The prepared statement of Tom M. Girdler, chairman of the Republic Steel Corporation, before the Senate Postoffice Committee today follows: I appreciate this opportunity to state the facts relating to the C. I. O. strike in the Republic Steel plants to the distinguished members of this committee.
Movements of livestock on the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture follow:

John Burke, Green Meadow defeated Brewster Parker Garden City G. C., 5 and 4: Fred C. Tanner, Piping Rock, defeated Steve Beaudry, Cortland, 4 and 3; W. B. George, Seven Oaks, defeated Richard Remnsen, Cherry Valley, 3 and 1; Richard Harris. Apawamis, defeated George Gilmore, Bellevue C. C., 2 up; Burr Horn Jr., Seven Oaks,

Red-headed Johnny Burke, Georgetown star, and Guy Berner, Buffalo boy who has just completed his freshman year at Duke, advanced two notches nearer one another as a result of their two victories in the opening match-play rounds of the New York State junior golf championship over the historic St. Andrew's course today.

The marriage of Miss Thelma Richmond, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Stanley Richmond of 14 East Sixtieth Street, to Lieutenant Carl Laverne Rickenbaugh, U.S.A., son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank S. Rickenbaugh of Hudson, Mich., took place yesterday afternoon in Christ Church, Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street.

A unanimity of views on the desirability of liberal trade policies as a means of encouraging world peace dominated discussions between Paul van Zeeland, Prime Minister of Belgium, and President Roosevelt and Secretary Hull, according to what was revealed in official circles tonight concerning the conversations of the last few days.

Presses rolled off thousands of ??apers and newspaper boys cried-their headlines in the downtown "golden triangle" again tonight after striking mailing room employes of Pittsburgh's three dailies had voted to return to work.
Appeals for peaceful settlement of differences between employers and employes were made here today by Secretary of Commerce Roper and the National Association of Credit Men in convention session.

Tom M. Girdler, chairman of the board of the Republic Steel Corporation, assured the Senate Postoffice Committee today that he would never sign a written contract with an "irresponsible, racketeering, violent, Communist body like the C. I. O.," unless forced to do so by law.

The marriage of Miss Esther Manning, daughter of Mr. and Mrs Hiram Terry Manning, to Ira Koenig, son of Mr. and Mrs Samuel S. Koenig of New York took place here at noon today at the home of her parents.

William Randolph Hearst Jr. announced yesterday that about 30 per cent of the editorial employes of The New York American and The New York Evening Journal were being dismissed as a result of the cessation of independent publication of The American. Mr. Hearst sent telegrams to the executives of all newspapers in the chain operated by his father, asking them to give preference to the dismissed workers in filling vacancies in their staffs.

In the days of our grandfathers " The Old Red Sandstone" and "Footprints of the Creator" were much read and highly prized in the United States. AGASSIZ wrote the preface for the latter book. The former was based on AGASSIZ'S studies of the Old Red fishes, but its most valuable part was the result of MILLER'S accurate observations.

The marriage of Miss Beatrice Gilbert, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Spofford Gilbert, to Joseph Benjamin Birdsell of Boston, son of Mrs. John Comley Birdsell of South Bend, Ind., and the late Mr. Birdsell, took place here this afternoon at the home of her parents The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Carl Hopkins Elmore.

Ellsworth B. Buck, Staten Island member of the Board of Education, dedicated two new high schools last night at Tottenville and New Dorp, S. I. Each of the schools was built by the WPA at a cost of $1,000,000 and opened for classes last September.
The heat wave and the Cardinals descended on the Dodgers at the same time today and it was a question which was hotter-the weather or the Gas House Gang.

The fury with which all Soviet organs of power and propagandathe political police, the Communist party leadership, and the controlled press-are prosecuting the hunt for "wreckers, spies and enemies of the people" is deeply puzzling to both Russians and foreigners.

Miss Mary Treat Nettleton, daughter of Dean George H. Nettleton of Yale College and Mrs. Nettleton, was married to Gordon Sherman Haight, son of Louis Pease Haight and the late Mrs. Haight of this city, in the Nettleton home here today by the Rev. Harry R. Miles of Stamford, uncle of the bride.

Dr. Edmund P. Lowe, retired physician, student, traveler and writer, died today at his residence, after a career which included service on the Southern Ute Indian reservation in Southwestern Colorado not long after an uprising and massacre, and in New Orleans during two yellow fever epidemics. His age was 77.

The marriage of Miss Helen Mathesius, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Mathesius of this place to James H. Colket Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Hamilton Colket of Brooklyn and Old Greenwich, took place today in the chapel of the Low-Heywood School. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Merrill Fowler Clarke of the New Canaan Congregational Church.
Representative Caroline O'Day became the second woman chairman of a Congressional committee when she was elected today to head the House Committee dn Election of the President.

The fact that of 48,000,000 persons employed for gain in the United States 11,000,000 are women, and that laws affecting this large number are advocated and adopted without consultation of women is commanding the attention of the annual convention of Zonta International in session here.
A heat wave, spreading from the plains of Texas to the Great Lakes, today accounted for at least fourteen deaths and established new June temperatures at many points.

Only one of the eighteen starters remained undefeated today after the eighth round of the international chess masters' tournament at the Kurhaus. He is Salo Flohr of Czechoslovakia, who, paired with V. Mikenas of Lithuania, drew for the sixth time. He won in the second and fourth rounds and has not been outplayed.

Massada, the youth section of the Zionist Organization of America, opened its fourth annual convention last night at the Roosevelt Hotel. Paul Safro, president of the New York region of the organization, presided. Isaac Imber, national president, spoke on the proposed activities for the next year.

Mrs. T. Arthur Ball was hostess this morning at a meeting of the Southampton Garden Club at her Summer home in Water Mill. Mrs. Adrian H. Larkin presided. Mrs. William Crawford arrived today to pass the season at the Meadow Club, and Mrs. Charles T. Barney will arrive tomorrow.

34th St, 48-54 E, one 5 and three 4-story stone tenements and stores, 72x98.9; Greenwich Savings Bank against Madison Realty Co; due, $437,943; to plaintiff for $350,000. By HENRY BRADY 68th St. 32 E, 5-story stone dwelling, 20x100.5; Chase National Bank against 32 E 68th St Corp; due, $83,668; taxes, ', $4,562; to plaintiff for $60,000. t

The Cast Iron Soil Pipe Association of Birmingham, Ala., today filed with the Federal Trade Commission an answer to the commission's complaint, denying that the association, in conjunction with thirty-five companies producing and selling 90 per cent of the country's output of this type of piping, had established a "Birmingham plus" system through which prices were controlled and competition lessened.

William Rollinson Whittingham, one of the oldest residents of this community and a civic leader and former official here, died today at Orange Memorial Hospital, Orange, N. J., in his seventy-eighth year after an illness of sixteen months.

For the first time in four weeks total bank clearings for the week ended on Wednesday increased over the corresponding week of 1936. The gain was due largely to the severe drop during the 1936 period rather than to any general rise in the current figures, it was explained in the report to Dun Bradstreet, Inc., issued yesterday.

An early increase in the size of the Austrian Army was announced semi-officially tonight. The Neuigkeits Weltblatt, which is close to the Chancellery, disclosed that measures had been prepared for incorporating the year-old militia into the regular army.

Arrangements have been made for the sale of a seat on the New York Curb Exchange for $19,800, down $2,200 from the previous transaction. Yesterday's price was the lowest since March 15, 1935, when a membership was transferred for $12,000.

The marriage of Miss Ruth Marian West, daughter of Mir. and Mrs. Arthur W. West, to Arthor Cartwright Sculley will take place tomorrow at Holy Trinity Church, Bailey's Bay. Mr. S alley is the son of Mrs. Genevieve Sculley of New York and John D. Sculley of Garden City.
Holton V. Noyes promised "the fairest of trials" for the new Rogers-Allen Milk Price-Fixing Law today as he assumed charge of New York's Deapartment of Agriculture and Markets.
Up to and including June 1, claims numbering 5,390, of which only 43 have been disallowed, were filed with the Bureau of Federal Old Age Benefits, according to the Social Security Board.

"The rawmaterial question can never be settled satisfactorily without an equitable redistribution of territory," Delegate Shudo of Japan today told the League of Nations committee dealing with the raw-material problem, originally raised by Germany.

Increased production and sales of rubber goods, other than automobile tires and tubes, are a major factor in the recovery being experienced by manufacturers of rubber products, according to The Index, a publication of the New York Trust Company.

Four Syracuse errors contributed to Newark's 6-to-2 victory over the Chiefs before 5,500 tonight. Vito Tamulis of the Bears and Jake Mooty of the Chiefs allowed eight hits each, but Newark bunched its blows to better advantage as it earned its second triumph in as many starts here.

The Municipal Civil Service Commission, it was announced yesterday, has unanimously adopted a resolution charging the World's Fair Corporation with "openly and flagrantly" violating its announced policy of hiring civil service eligibles for non-technical positions.

Governor Hoffman's Summer office here said today the Governor had "no comment whatsoever" on the conviction of Ellis H. Parker, Burlington County detective chief, and his son, Ellis Jr., for conspiracy in the Paul H. Wendel kidnapping case.

The present industrial unrest in the country will not abate until employers agree to deal with labor unions in the spirit of the nation's newly aroused social consciousness, Professor William Z. Ripley, Harvard economist, told the Tamiment Economic and Social Institute at the opening session of its annual conference tonight.

Business men's organizations and - other friends of a balanced budget should study tomorrow's Congressional Record with unusual care for guidance in their efforts to achieve a non-political taxation policy in this country.
The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated June 22: LIEUTENANT COMMeANDERS McVay, C. B. 3d, to additional duty as aide at the White House, Washington, D. C.

Government cotton experts predicted today that the new marketing season would open on Aug. 1 with about 4,400,000 bales of old American cotton in the United States, or 1,000,000 bales less than a year earlier and about half the peak carryover of 9,580,000 bales in 1932.
Unofficial reports today said that twenty-six German warships were expected to arrive soon at Lagoa, Southern Portugal. There was no indication of the direction from which the ships would come.
William S. Murray, Republican State chairman, tonight urged "patience" upon Young Republicans in their climb to party leadership.

Lifting his 27,000-pound ship gracefully off the waters of the bay here, Richard Archbold started the first transcontinental flight of a flying boat at 4:51 P. M. today. Mr. Archbold radioed his home here tonight he was over Gila Bend, Ariz., at 6:20 P. M. (9:30 P. M. Eastern standard time). The plane was averaging about 125 miles per hour..

George H. Bond, president of the New York State Bar Association, named Mayer C. Goldman of New York City chairman of the association's committee on public defenders tonight. Seven other members of the committee are from New York City.
Attempting to sail a race without wind, Ranger and Rainbow spent an idle afternoon out at sea today and the score in the observation trials to select the America's Cup defender remains unchanged.

America's Ryder Cup golfers limbered up on the Ainsdale course today, experimenting leisurely with the smaller 1.62 ball in preparation for the international series with Great Britain's picked professionals next Tuesday and Wednesday.

After making it abundantly clear yesterday that she had thrown all non-intervention obligations to the four winds and considered herself at liberty to intervene in Spain at whatever moment and in whatever way suited her best, Italy today was attempting to convince herself and the world that there was nothing alarming or dramatic in the attitude she had resumed.

Viscountess Astor, the former Nancy Langhorne of, Virginia, who is a member of the House of Commons, saw President Roosevelt for fifteen minutes today and then held court in the lobby of the Executive Offices, discussing world affairs with spontaneity and keenness.

Federal Judge J. Boyd Avis, following hearings here today, promised early decisions in two cases involving loans made by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to the closed Chelsea-Second National Bank and Trust Company of Atlantic City.

The Senate yesterday gave a perfect illustration of how not to legislate on taxes or on anything else. It was quietly considering the relatively routine question of extending the existing nuisance taxes, when Senator LA FOLLETTE broke in with an amendment to increase the surtax on personal incomes by 4 per cent.

The wheat market continued erratic today. Prices advanced over a cent a bushel early to the best levels in nearly a month on reports indicating drought had done heavy damage in the Canadian Northwest and strength in Liverpool, only to react later go heavy profit-taking.

Representative William B. Barry of Hollis, N. Y., urged in a statement today that people of Queens County on whose homes there are HOLC mortgages "scrutinize carefully any plan to help them that is going to cost them money."

The GAR final of the Women's Long Island Association tournament at the Women's National Golf and Tennis Club tomorrow will be a replica of the last-round match of the 1936 competition. In other words, Mrs.
The ripening into romance of a friendship of long years' standing between an elderly couple was revealed yesterday with the announcement that they intended to be married.

Police relieved a threatening sit-uation in the Phillips Packing Com pany strike late tonight by releasing a Negro striker to a cheering crowd of sympathizers who had marched to the jail to demand his freedom.
Very nearly 67,000 graduates will be launched by a single system of educational institutions in New York City alone. These are, of

Romping over the five furlongs in time that was one-fifth of a second off the track record, Mrs. Paul Shaw's Stage Beauty won the Lassie Stakes, $2,500 added feature for juveniles at Rockingham Park today. She paid $5 for $2 in the mutuels.

Thomas Williams Slocum, textile manufacturer and merchant, and for many years prominent in the affairs of Harvard University, died yesterday morning at the Neurological Institute of New York of pneumonia. He was 70 years old and lived at 19 West Forty-fourth Street.

Here are the ten who received honorary degrees at Harvard commencement exercises, today, and the citations: Charles Henry Taylor, Master of Arts--Manager and treasurer of The Boston Globe. "Among publishers of the daily news an acknowledged leader, to lovers of the printed book a valued conselor."

Colonel A. C. Downey, former president of the Fargo Motor Company, a division of the Chrysler Corporation which handles sales of cars and trucks to fleet users, has been appointed president of Airtemp, Inc., the Chrysler subsidiary which manufactures air-conditioning equipment, it was announced yesterday. R. L. Biggers, former vice president of Fargo, was promoted to the presidency.

Representative Ellwood J. Turner, speaking for the House Republican Steering Committee today, accused Governor Earle of responsibility for labor disturbances. "In using the power of the Commonwealth illegally to close mills against majority wishes," Mr. Turner said,

Professor Noel T. Dowling, Nash Professor of Law at Columbia University, came to the defense of the Supreme Court in a talk tonight at the seventh annual Economic Conference for Engineers at Camp Stevens here. Seventy engineers,

Norman Lila Estates, Inc., have resold to an investing client of Benjamin Alter the six-family apartment at 47-49 Forty-sixth Street, Sunnyside, Queens. The house is 25 by 100 feet, and contains three three-room and three four-room apartments.
Eugene Goossens' four-act opera in English, "Don Juan de Manara," with libretto by Arnold Bennett, had its world premiere at Covent Garden tonight with Lawrence Tibbett, baritone, heading the cast.

Charles A. Flammer, former police justice and magistrate who saw Abraham Lincoln in this city, fined boys for riding tandem bicycles at fourteen miles an hour, and was for more than sixty years known to residents of New York as Judge Flammer, died yesterday at his home, 309 West 105th Street, after an illness of many weeks. He was 91 years old and within four days of his ninety-second birthday.

Two new wholesale dress price lines were agreed upon yesterday afternoon at a meeting of representatives of the Popular Priced Dress Manufacturers Group, Inc., and the National Association of Apparel Chains.

Silas Mandeville Wheelock, agent of the Putnam Woolen Corporation and a member of the staff of former Governor Everett J. Lake, died suddenly yesterday at his home here following a heart attack at the age of 66.

The Italian liner Rex, crack vessel of the Italian merchant marine, came into port yesterday under command of Captain Attilio Frugone, former master of the liner Roma and now permanently in command of the larger vessel.

By a margin of more than four to one, workers in the local plant of the American Smelting and Refining Company voted tonight for representation in collective bargaining by the Perth Amboy Smelters and Refining Workers Union, which is affiliated with the C. I. O. through the International Union of Mine, Mill, Smelter and Refining Workers.

Judge John J. Freschi of General Sessions dismissed yesterday the $3,000 bail on which Frank M. Sherry was awaiting trial on a felony indictment growing out of the inquiry into mortgage company irregularities.

The marriage of Miss Eleanor J. Ortman, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Max J. Ortman, to Ralph H. Wiener, son of Mr. and Mrs. Max Wiener of New York, took place yesterday morning at the home of the bride's parents, 680 West End Avenue. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Sidney Goldstein.
A father killed three of his eight children and his wife, then took his own life today in this Western Pannsylvania village.

H. W. Snowden will manage the new branch office of Hendrickson Co. in the Essex and Sussex Hotel, Spring Lake, N. J. The Manufacturers Trust Company is transfer agent for the common stock, 8 per cent cumulative preferred stock and 4 per cent convertible first preferred stock of Kresge Department Stores, Inc.

The Pratt family, which owns about 2,000 acres in and near this city and has made several gifts of land for public buildings, has presented to the municipality an additional fifteen acres, it was announced today by Mayor Harold Mason.
The Senators ran their winning streak to five straight today, downing the Indians, 8 to 2, behind the steady pitching of Monte Weaver.

Thomas Mather, Emeritus Professor of Electrical Engineering at the Imperial College of Science and Technology, London, died today at the age of 81. The inventor of electrical measuring instruments widely adopted in industry, he contributed valuable scientific papers to the Royal Society of which he was elected a fellow in 1902.

The Rev. Ivan Kolesnikoff of the Old Russian Evangelical Christian Union, a New Yorker and a United States citizen, was arrested three days ago at the Polish-Latvian frontier charged with illegal traffic in foreign exchange. Twenty dollars in United States notes and $100 in American Express Company travelers' checks were found on him.

Orchard Beach Park in the Bronx and Jacob Riis Park in Queens the most modern bathing resorts in the city's park system, will be opened to the public today without ceremony, the Park Department announced yesterday.

The Holland-America liner Tolendam sails for Plymouth, Boulogne and Rotterdam tonight. Her passengers will include the Right Rev. Ashton Oldham. Mrs. Oldham, the Rev. and Mrs. William Adams Brown, the Rev. Fred Field Goodsell, Major T. Oakley Rhinelander, Helen Dean Fish, Carl T. Parsons,

Canal stain Freeman R. Boyce and Lieutenant George Caruso, scoring a total of 117 points, won the twoman company team match for Company A today, opening the annual rifle tournament of the Old Guard of New York, famous military organization which has held an annual Summer tournament here for many decades.

Even with income taxes at their highest known peak, the differential between estate taxes and levies against gifts makes "increasingly attractive" the donations of large sums for "charitable, literary and educational" purposes, Ralph E. Lum, attorney, advised the Library Gifts round-table participants yesterday at the convention of the American Library Association.

The five-story apartment at 2,108 Davidson Avenue, the Bronx, has been sold by Lord Estate, Inc., to the Warley Realty Corporation. The house stands on a plot 90 by 100 feet, contains 148 rooms, divided into forty-four apartments, and is twelve years old.

A group of twenty-four prominent dramatic artists from the Sofia National Theatre, as well as a technical personnel; will leave for the United States tomorrow. They will perform for the Bulgarian and Slav colonies of Indianapolis and Detroit Bulgarian and other dramas.

A resolution calling upon retail stores to require a down payment on every new installment account opened, limit the length of the installment contract to a maximum of twentyfour months and eliminate competition between stores on terms was adopted today by the credit management division of the National Retail Dry Goods Association as its midyear convention here came to a close.

Mrs. Frances S. Peters Holmes of the Pierre, daughter of Norman W. Peters of Miami Beach, Fla., and his first wife, the late Mrs. Anne Darby Peters, and Harry Cooke Cushing, banker, of 435 East Fiftysecond Street and Oyster Bay,L. I., obtained a marriage license yesterday at the Municipal Building.

It is a trying situation with which the Chautemps Ministry is confronted, on succeeding LEON BLUM. The reason for the demand of BLUM that the French Parliament give him plenary powers for applying certain drastic fiscal measures was the Premier's belief, shared by French financiers,

Miss Marjory Knight Logan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles P. Logan of Belle Haven, Greenwich, was married to Richard Duval Chapman, son of Mrs. John Duval Chapman and the late Mr. Chapman, in the Second Congregational Church, Greenwich, today.

Miss Mona Jerusha Cutler, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick John Cutler of Kensington and Yonkers, N. Y., was married here this afternoon to Gordon Ferrie Hull Jr. of Hanover, N. H., in the Dwight Memorial Chapel, Yale University, by the Rev. John U. Harris of Hanover.

Here is the statement issued tonight by the Federal Mediation Board: The strikes in the steel industry began May 26. Our board was appointed June 17 and held its first meeting in Cleveland Saturday, June 19.
An agreement was reached today between the Ontario Government and the Abitibi Power and Paper Company, now in process of reorganization.

Engineering construction contracts awarded in the week ended yesterday, totaling $115,530,000, represented the highest weekly dollar volume since March 19, 1931. This is a gain of 144 per cent over the same week last year.

Miss Louise Lee, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Franklin Lee, was married to Richard Floethe of New York and Middletown, N. Y., this morning at the home of her parents here. Supreme Court Justice George H. Taylor Jr. of the Appellate Division, long a close friend of the bride's father, performed the ceremony in the presence of immediate relatives of the couple.

Heath Ave (11-3240), e s, 795 ft e of Kingsbride Rd, 50x136; Bertha Shaw to Emma F. Fettretch, 155 E 93d St. Prospect Ave (10-2694), e s, 218 ft n of Home St, 37x100; 280 E 199th St Holding Corp. to Cream Realty Co., Inc., 369 E 149th St: mt-. 541.505.

With the exception of concentrated pressure against a few public utility bond issues, the market for domestic corporation issues exhibited a somewhat firmer undertone yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, wife of the President, was among those who entertained with dinner and supper parties last night in the Starlight Roof Garden of the Waldorf-Astoria. Her guests were hei son-in-law and daughter, Mr. and Mrs. John Boettiger, and Earl Miller.

Colonel Hugh L. Cooper, pioneer hydroelectric engineer who designed and supervised the construction of Wilson Dam at Muscle Shoals and the Dnieprostroy Dam and power station in Russia, died of arteriosclerosis at his home here tonight after an illness of three weeks. His age was 72.

MANHATTAN ALEXANDER, LENA (June 26). Estate, less than $10,000. To Sigmond Alexander, Hotel Savannah, Savannah, Ga., and Jacques Alexander, 436 Fort Washington Ave., brothers, executors, residue equally. COHN, JENNIE F. (June 9). Estate,

The stell mediation board tonight called on the four independent steel companies whose employes are on strike to meet jointly with the board and the Steel Workers Organizing Committee's representatives to discuss possible terms of settlement.

The value of retail sales of new passen-ger automobiles continued in May to keep ahead. of the 1929-31 average, the Department of Commerce's preliminary adjusted index figures being 103.5 in May, compared with 102.5 in April and 123.5' in March, according to an announcement today.
Superior Court Judge Joseph Walsh today found certain directors of the Beacon Participations, Inc., liable for a total of $240,991.75 in transactions of the concern.

The statement that flood control and navigation were brought into the Norris Power Bill 'to serve as a constitutional peg upon which to hang the legislation" was made before a Senate subcommittee today by Cleveland A. Newton, general counsel of the Mississippi Valley Association and former member of the House Rivers and Harbors Committee.

By nationalizing more than 13,000 miles of Mexican railroads owned and operated by the private National Railways of Mexico Company under the Expropriation Law, the Cardenas government has placed itself legally in a commanding position to dictate the terms of a settlement with the United States and British bondholders of the company, whose capital and accrued interest unpaid totals more than $300,000,000.

Announcement has been made by Mrs. F. Stokes Coleman of Chestnut Hill, Philadelphia, of the engagement of her daughter, Miss Eugenia Mange Coleman, td John Connable Bennett, son of Major and Mrs. J. Walter.F. Bennett of 1,105 Park Avenue.

With the thermometer soaring near the boil ing point, the Giants and Cubs went at it hammer and tongs today, but at the. finish the New Yorkers and all their implements wilted and the result was a smashing 10-to-5 triumph for the Chicagoans.
Baron Manfred von Killinger, former Premier of Saxony and prominent in National Socialist politics, has been appointed German Consul General in San Francisco, it has been announced officially.

Miss Anne Whaples, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Heywood H. Whaples of this place, was married in the Farmington Congregational Church this afternoon to John Sheldon McCook, son of Supreme Court Justice and Mrs. Philip J. McCook of New York.

The marriage of Miss Beatrice Callan, daughter of Mrs. Edward J. Callan of New York and the late Mr. Callan, to J. Ross Mimnaugh, son of James P. Mimnaugh of New Rochelle and the late Mrs. Mimnaugh, took place here this morning in St. Augustine's Church. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Leo Madden, who also celebrated the nuptial mass.

Evidence that liquor was distributed by unlicensed operators to the retail trade was given yesterday by a representative of Joseph E. Seagram and Sons Company at the hearing before the Federal Trade Commission on charges of price fixing and resale price maintenance against the Massachusetts branch of this corporation.
A banking group headed by the National City Bank obtained yesterday the award of a new issue of $3,000,000 of veterans' welfare bonds of the State of California on a bid of 102.833 for 3s.

Manhattan Alterations 26th St, 420-22 W; to five-story tenement; 420 W 26th St Corp, 580 5th Ave, owner; David S. Lang, architect; cost, $35,000. 87th St, 1 W; to twelve-story and penthouse tenement; estate of Henry Seidenberg, care of City Bank Farmers Trust Co, trustee, 22 William St, owner; Robert Teichman, architect; cost, $5,000.
Reports from Russia on industrial chaos are becoming increasingly alarming. The Daily Telegraph's correspondent in

This morning's addition to the ranks of ladies who produce shows would be A. Alexander, who has taken offices-at 234 West Fortyfourth Street-and has bought a script with music. Call it'"Right This Way," described as an intimate entertainment with book and lyrics by Marianne Brown Waters and tunes by Brad Greene.
Six members of a railroad section crew were killed today by a Montreal-bound train as they were preparing to work on the Central Vermont Railroad line three miles north of here.
A marriage which took place fiftyfive years ago and broke up twenty years later was officially severed in Superior Court today without either of the principals appearing in court.
The industrial expansion upon which the armaments program is compelling Japan to embark has become the principal source of news interest in the Japanese press.

Following its order on June 10 for 177 twin-engined bombing planes, at a cost in excess of $65,800 each-from the Douglas Aircraft Corporation, the army today announced award of a contract to the Wright Aeronautical Corporation of Paterson, N. J., for 531 single-row nine cylindered Cyclone engines of 1,000 horsepower each.

LONDON-Britain, learning seven German warships had passed into the Mediterranean, waited to see what the Reich and Italy would do. The British Ambassador at Berlin was assured Germany would confine her action to withdrawal from naval control off Spain. Page 1.

The Village Board has declared war on rhus toxicodendron (poison ivy), and after next Tuesday any one having the offending flora on his property or within twelve feet of the boundaries will be subject to a $10 fine.

The Navy Department today awarded a contract to the Electric Boat Company of Groton, Conn., for two submarines at a cost of $3,477,000 each. The craft are to be built in twentynine and thirty-one months, respectively.

Trading in lamb continued slow in most slaughter .houses. Demand for other classes was good. Steer beef cuts were sharply higher and fresh pork cuts strong to sharply higher. Veal cuts sold strong and the lamb market was mostly unchanged. The small amount of kosher business was confined largely to lamb at about steady prices, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.

The White Sox made it three straight over the Athletics .today, knocking the veteran Harry Kelley out of the box in the first inning to score a 7-to-2 victory. It was second time this season the Mackmen have lost ten straight.

An unranked and comparatively unknown player from the Southwest and an 18-year-old junior from the Pacific Coast fought their way into the semi-finals of the national intercollegiate tennis championship today on the turf courts of the Merion Cricket Club.

Benjamin Apthorp Gould, son of the late Dr. Benjamin Apthorp Gould, Harvard University astronomer who was instrumental in organizing a Harvard observatory in Argentina, died yesterday in Toronto, where he made his home.

During the week ended June 23 member bank reserve balances increased $46,000,000. Additions to member bank reserves arose from decreases of $21,000,000 in money in circulalation, $99,000,000 in Treasury

Although there may still be some uncertainty among certain members of the financial community over the investment market's appetite for new issues, the new loans placed this week have demonstrated that many smaller investors, as well as the large institutional buyers, are far from hesitant, and, in fact, are eager to obtain bonds of certain types at what they term "proper prices."

License Commissioner Paul Moss has refused to renew the licenses of about 400 public porters on the ground that they act as "steerers" for certain hotels and give visitors a bad impression of New York, it was disclosed yesterday when an action was started in Supreme Court to force him to make the renewals.

The deadline set by William H. Parsons for some communication with the persons he says he believes are holding his wife for $25,000 ransom passed at noon today, apparently with no contact established.
Earl Baldwin of Bewdley laid bare a page of unwritten history today when he revealed that he -would have retired from politics almost a quarter-century ago if his wife had not dissuaded him.

The War Department released the following orders today -dated June 23: COLONELS MacDill, L. (Lieut. Col.), Air Corps, General Staff Corps, three days extension of leave. Spurgin, H. F.. C.A.C., Fort Monroe, Va., to office of the Chief of Coast Artillery, Washington, Sept. 1.

The dismissal of two patrolmen on charges in connection with an early morning Greenwich Village shooting brawl last September which resulted in the death of Harold Sullivan, 42-year-old cabaret owner, was announced yesterday. The action was taken on Wednesday following departmental trials. The dismissals brought to a total of 170 the number dropped from the force since Commissioner Valentine took office in 1934.

A "typical New York welcome," hospitality "without reservation," and even "beautiful weather" await the American Legion at its convention here in September. The Legionnaires, in return, will temper their revelry with "every possible restraint."

The assistance of eight United States army airplanes in the search for an airplane and five passengers lost last Sunday is considered a practical demonstration of the goodneighbor policy by Costa Ricans. Former President Ricardo Jimenez said.
Early termination of the second largest American transpacific passenger service was disclosed today by the local office of the States Steamship Company.
Commissioner Fred Holtje, Director of Streets and Public Property,. died at North Hudson Hospital in Weehawken today. He suffered a paralytic stroke on Monday at his home here. He was 53 years old.

Advocates of higher surtaxes on incomes, led by Senator La Follette, won a short-lived victory in the Senate today when an amendment to the bill to extend the so-called nuisance taxes, whereby the net surtax on incomes would have been increased, was adopted by 35 to 31.

On the ground that "apparently the emergency has passed," Governor EARLE has announced the end of martial law at Johnstown. The emergency which led to the imposition of martial law was the proposed "march" on Johnstown by some 40,000 C. I. 0. sympathizers.

Commander Donald B. MacMillan's sixteenth Arctic expedition sailed today for the north land. The famous Gloucester fishing schooner Gertrude L. Thebaud left here for Portland, Me., on the first leg of a 6,000-mile voyage for scien tific and geographical exploration work in North Labrador and Baffin Bay.

The Parker Pen Company of Janesville, Wis., and the Lanston Monotype Machine Company of Philadelphia reported to the Securities and Exchange Commission today that they paid their chief officers higher compensation last year.

Death Announced Retired Fireman Timothy Sullivan (2), formerly a member of H. and L. 41, residing at 38 Stewart Place, Tuckahoe, N. Y., died June 22. To Report to Chief Medical Officer The following ununiformed firemen shall be directed to report to the Chief Medical Officer at these headquarters, at 10 A. M., Tuesday, June 29:

Proper timing of special sales events and methods of destroying the "wholesale-retail selling hoax" are the two chief problems to be attacked by retailers in en effort to improve retail trade, Ira A. Hirschmann, vice president in charge of sales and promotion of Saks-Fifth Avenue, told 600 members of the Fashion Group at a luncheon meeting at the Hotel Biltmore yesterday.

Aaron Kornbluth, 35 years old, a central figure in the garnishee. racket uncovered last year by Paul Blanshard, Commissioner of Accounts, on complaints of hundreds of policemen, firemen and other city employes, escaped with a suspended sentence yesterday in General Sessions. He had pleaded guilty on two indictments on Dec. 23, 1936.

The four-story and basement residence at 123 East Sixty-first Street has been sold by the estate of Maria E. Hampton to a buyer who intends to occupy it after extensive alterations. The house has a frontage of 19 feet and is assessed at $46,000. Pease Elliman, Inc., arranged the sale.

Taking all three heats, Dalehurst, chestnut colt owned by T. L. Gustin of Holcong, Pa., captured the 3year-old pace, the opening day's feature of the Penn-Jersey harness racing circuit meeting today. Driven by Walt Garrison, Dalehurst turned in the fastest time of the day,

A new industrial safety record for New York State has been made in the plant of the International Business Machines Corporation at Endicott, which has been operated 4,500,000 man-hours without an accident.
Sir James Barrie was buried today at Kirriemuir, his native village-which to readers of his books will always be "Thrums"--in the churchyard where Babbie met the Little Minister.

Turning the spotlight on New Jersey's salt water fishing for a few moments: Several members of the Beach Haven Tuna Club, including Max Schoenberg, Alec Parker, Watson Pharo and Henry Schoenberg, caught five tuna that weighed from twenty-five to thirty pounds each, eighteen bonito averaging four pounds apiece and five bluefish, all over seven pounds, on their trip to the off-shore grounds on Wednesday.

Sales of copper were negoutatea abroad yesterday at 13.80 to 14.10 cents a pound, c. i. f., European base ports. It is reported that a heavy volume of business was transacted around the lower level, while, in the afternoon, when the price was advanced above the 14cent level, there was only moderate activity.
Japan's trade in the larger Chinese cities is expected to show a marked decline after Sunday, when "the boycott against Japanese smuggled goods" becomes effective.

Dr. George Etling, a psychiatrist r on the staff of the Rockland State S Hospital for the Insane, has received two telephone messages and one telegram within the last ten days threatening him with death by next- Saturday, it was learned today.

Two girls were killed and their mother and two sisters injured, the mother critically, in a collision tonight between their sedan and a truck at Stockton Street and Route 25 here. The truck driver and his helper were also injured.

Demanrest Lloyd, sportsman, publisher and former foreign correspondent, died suddenly this morning at his country home at Pennyfield, Md. He was in his fifty-fifth year. He retired last night at his usual hour and was found this morning dead in bed by the caretaker of his estate.
Harvard scientists disclosed tonight a concerted drive to purify what they described as the last great medium of human infection, the air we breathe.

The contract between E. L. Phillips Co. and the Long Island Lighting Company, which stockholders of the latter have attacked in a $20,000,000 accounting action, was pronounced yesterday to be fair and equitable by Maxwell M. Upson, president of the Raymond Concrete Pile Company.

Like a lightweight fighter trying to outpunch a Joe Louis--it just can't be done. The Browns attempted to outslug the Yankees at the Stadium yesterday, swung hard enough to build up a four-run lead, then promptly were flattened on the canvas.

No one knows how much is spent annually on true cancer research in this country. There is reason to believe that the sum lies between $500,000 and $700,000-a pathetic showing when compared with the gate receipts of the Braddock-Louis fight and with the five, six and eight millions at the disposal of any one of half a dozen great industrial research laboratories.

The State Department announced today that the Treasury was making arrangements to transfer to the Philippine Commonwealth $50,000,000, representing net proceeds of processing taxes collected up to July 1, 1937, on Philippine coconut oil.

Bryan M. (Bitsy) Grant got up from one of the nastiest falls the "Atlanta tumble bug" ever has taken and ran out his match with E. R. Avory of Great Britain in short order to reach the fourth round of men's singles in the all-England tennis championships today.

Transfers and Assignments To take effect 8 A.'M. June 25: PATROLMEN-James A. Byers, from 62d Precinct to 18th Division, duty in Bureau of Information. Horace M. S. Matheson, from office of the property clerk to 18th Division, designated as third-grade detective.
Prime Minister W. L. Mackenzie King of Canada said today that he would hold a "man to man talk" with Chancellor Adolf Hitler in Berlin next week for a general exchange of views.

A sit-down strike in the Emergency Relief Bureau district office at 5,318 Fourth Avenue, Brooklyn, was called off at 5 P..M. yesterday, after the head of the office had promised to issue food vouchers to striking shipyard workers, pending investigation of their eligibility for temporary home relief.

As the Free State's election campaign proceeds, opinion here is swinging more and more to the viewpoint that President Eamon de Valera's party and the Cosgraveites will run a close race to return the biggest single group in the new Dail.
The Insurgent cruiser Baleares bombarded and sank the Spanish Government freighter Trinidad seven miles off the French coast today.

Gloucestershire scored only 279 runs in a county cricket championship match against Kent, but the total was sufficient to give the West of England players victory by an innings and 31 runs today. Kent replied feebly with 104 and 144.

Gold holdings of the Bank of Canada declined more than $2,000,000 in the week ended yesterday and holdings of sterling and United States currencies increased $6,000,000. The ratio of net reserve to notes and deposit liabilities rose from 61.5 per cent a week before to 61.95 per cent.
Here is the joint statement of the four struck steel companies as presented to the Steel Mediation Board today: To the Federal Steel Mediation Board:
Derending champion John Dawson of Chicago and two former title winners led the way into the quarter-finals of the Trans-Mississippi golf tournament today.

A MAVERCICK AMERICAN, by Maury Maverick. (Covici, Friede, $3.) The autobiography of a TexasCongressman. T. E. LAWRENCE, by His Friends, edited by A; W. Lawrence. (Doubleday, Doran, $4.) Views of Lawrence by men and women who knew him.

Mrs. Norma Gatto, 25 years old, of 96 Columbia Avenue, Huntington Station, L. I., was found guilty of assault on Joan Morvan, 4, at 11:20 o'clock last night by a jury in Queens County Court. She wept when the verdict was read.

The Council of the World Presbyterian Alliance found itself unable to agree today about the fundamental causes of economic distress and social ills. The Rev. Dr. Stuart Parker of Toronto was taken to task by a colleague for suggesting that one of the causes of distress was "more mouths coming into the world than the present social organization can feed."

Jacob A. Livingston, former Brooklyn Republican leader, who has been making a drive to prevent Mayor La Guardia from getting the Republican renomination, made public yesterday a letter to Samuel Seabury charging that the Mayor had "double-crossed"

Barney Balaban, president of Paramount Pictures, Inc., announced yesterday at the adjourned stockholders' meeting that plans for increasing the authorized common stock from 4,500,000 to 6,000,000 shares would be held in abeyance, although the management was of the opinion that the increase was in the interests of the corporation.

Governor Lehman announced today that he would not call a special election to fill the Congressional vacancy caused by the death of Philip A. Goodwin of Coxsackie, N. Y., Republican Representative from the Twenty-seventh District.

Five men arrested in the Youngstown area on charges of preventing mail carriers from making deliveries to Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company and Republic Steel Corporation plants pleaded innocent today before W. J. Laub, United States Commissioner.

A warning that "the battle on the Supreme Court question is not ye?? won" was voiced before the Pennsylvania Bar Association's convention here today by Sylvester Smith of Phillipsburg, N. J., chairman of the American Bar Association's committee on reorganization of the court.
The conference method of working out industrial legislation won a victory today, when President Roosevelt approved a new social security system for the nation's 1,150,000 railroad workers.

Mr. and Mrs. Dwight C. Wheeler 1 of this city and Fairnold, Easton, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Louise Wheeler, to Bishop Von Wettberg, son of Mr. and Mrs. E. F. Von Wettberg.

Wiffy Cox of Washington shot a sub-par 69 today to lead the field at the end of the first round in the seventy-two-hole True Temper open golf championship tournament at the Whitemarsh Valley Country Club. Cox was out in 35 strokes and returned in 34.

For the balance of the year, insensive competition, earlier new model announcements than ever before and the fact that few changes are contemplated in the 1938 ranges will bring about a barrage of automobile advertising, according to comments here yesterday.

Moe Steinbach, 22-year-old son of a furrier, was assaulted yesterday afternoon in his fathers' shop, where there is a minor labor dispute, by one of six men who invaded the premises on the fifteenth floor of 305 Seventh Avenue.
The tension that followed Germany's threat to stage a naval demonstration against Valencia died down today, but it has been followed by some bitter and serious reflection.

Both houses of Congress today postponed further legislative sessions until Monday, so that their majority members could enjoy with clear consciences the Democratic field day and outing which will take place tomorrow, Saturday and Sunday at the Jefferson Islands Club in Chesapeake Bay.

After recording a par 70 to lead the qualifiers, Ray Billows of the Dutchess Country Club of Poughkeepsie, former New York State amateur champion, today triumphed in the opening round of match play in the Hudson River Golf Association amateur title tourney at the Hudson River Country Club.

Frank Miyoshl, Japanese employment agency, in 101 W 45th St; Mary Hardy. beauty parlor, loft in 218-22 W 34th St; Tankoos, Smith Co, brokers. Herman Menasche, floor in 32 E 31st St; Gift Headquarters, Inc, floor in 39 W 23d St; Disman Stempel, floor in 19 W 38th St; Schneider Sunkin, floor in 135-7 W 27th St; Solotar Hershman, floor in 31 W 21st St; Williams Co, Inc, broker.

The total of loans and investments of reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in New York City fell $93,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, according to the condition report of these banks issued yesterday.

The dismissal of an information filed by Thomas E. Dewey, special prosecutor of rackets, against six men charged with conspiracy to dominate the bakery industry was asked in Special Sessions yesterday by Caesar Barra of the defense counsel, on the ground that the information contains no specific charges of unlawful acts.

If the Hollanders who reputedly spent twenty-four dollars to buy Manhattan Island from the Indians had appropriated-perhaps two dollars to keep the waterfront open in perpetuity for public uses, we should not now be rejoicing in the reclamation of a mile here and another mile there.

It was learned here that the trial of the Dutch flying officer Aalders, who was involved in a case of treason and spent more than twenty months in German prisons, ended today much less severely for the prisoner than might have been expected after reports of his molestation in jail and the extreme secrecy surrounding the case.

A long-term lease of a property in the Times Square area was announced yesterday when the Trebuhs Realty Company (Lee and J. J. Shubert) leased to the Silver Ballroom, Inc., the fivestory business building at 224 West Forty-sixth Street, near Broadway.

The East New York Savings Bank has sold the following Brooklyn properties: 1,325 East Ninety-sixth Street, to Mrs. Yetti Fenster; 2,046 East Thirty-fifth Street, to Joseph P. Gowan; 192 Stockton Street, to Angelina Gattano; 349 Chester Street, to Joseph Wilensky;

Raymond Loewy, industrial designer, has been retained by the W. T. Grant Company to assist in designing stores. Ned E. Saill, formerly sales manager here, has been appointed assistant general sales manager of A. K. Hamilton Co., Inc.,
One painter was killed and another was injured critically yesterday afternoon as a result of a fall from a scaffold on the eighth floor of an apartment house at 560 West 165th Street.

The Federal Trade commission today announced stipulations by a number of business concerns in the New York area that have agreed to discontinue certain practices held by the commission to constitute "unfair competition."

Generoso Pope, publisher of Italian newspapers in this country, returned yesterday on the Italian liner Rex from a visit to Italy in the course of which he talked with Premier Mussolini, King Victor Emmanuel, Pope Pius, Cardinal Pacelli and Count Galeazzo Ciano,Minister of Foreign Affairs and son-inlaw of II Duce.

The state of modified martial law which has prevailed here since Saturday will end at 8 A. M., New York time, tomorrow by decree of Governor Earle, but the Bethlehem Steel Corporation made plain tonight that it would be "physically impossible" to resume at once normal operations in the huge Cambria ??lant.
The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes in pounds sterling:

No efforts were made to open the dog track here tonight because of the presence of State troopers, deputy sheriffs and George V. Dorsey, Rockland County District Attorney. A crowd estimated at 12,000 was turned away.
Mayors of every Italian city received a government circular today asking for estimates on the amount of iron that could be realized by scrapping all municipal iron fences and gates.

The excess reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve Systern recovered $60,000,000 of the $180,000,000 decline they had shown a week ago, according to yesterday's Federal Reserve reports covering the week ended on Wednesday.
Congressional advocates of sugar legislation recommended by President Roosevelt offered "compromise" proposals today in an attempt to break a deadlock over division of the domestic market.
