The Board of Regents of the Smithsonian Institution formally accepted today Andrew W. Mellon's $50,000,-. 000 art collection. The board also appointed five trustees for the new National Gallery of Art.

Miss Barbara Krantz, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alpheus M. Krantz, was married here tonight, at the home of her parents, to Dr. James P. Morrill Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. James P. Morrill, also of this place.

Joe Louis's first actual cash offer to defend his world heavyweight crown arrived from London today as Mike Jacobs started jockeying to bring Max Schmeling in line for a bout with the Brown Bomber in the Fall.

Richard J. Daly, 42 years old, of 15 Watkins Place, New Rochelle, was arrested on a grand larceny charge yesterday as the result- of an investigation made by the office of Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. into reports that some forty-eight clients of the investment firm of Richard J. Daly Co. had lost about $150,000.

Happenings in three heavenly bodies which may cause trouble for the earth were reported to the American Association for the Advancement of Science today. They are: A huge, new spot on the planet Jupiter which is the beginning of a mysterious storm there; a remarkable change on the face of Mars, which looks like fine dust sweeping the planet, and record-breaking sunspot storms on the sun.

Latest treatment trends in modern medicine were discussed today by the national authorities at the annual meeting of the Lake Keuka Medical Association. More than 250 doctors from twenty-two western New York counties and four in tom Pennsylvania attended the session in Keuka College.
Saturday, July 3, will be bargain day for New Jersey motorists using the toll bridges over the Arthur Kill and Kill van Kull, the Port Authority announced yesterday.

The Lewisohn Stadium was dedicated in 1914 by the playing of "The Trojan Women." The text followed was that of GILBERT MURRAY'S translation in which the chorus sang of " a soft grey crown for a city beloved "-the city of Athena, a City of Light.

The severity with which adherents of the forbidden Social Democratic party are punished, contrasting with the leniency shown to Nazis, was strikingly exemplified today when Judge Cazafura sentenced five workingmen each to five years of penal servitude and two others to one year each for printing and distributi ing Socialist literature.

Manager Joe Cronin's long-distance hitting paced his Red Sox to a 9-0 victory over Detroit today, enabling Bob (Lefty) Grove to gain his sixth victory of the season and his first 1937 triumph over the Tigers.

The Food and Grocery Conference Committee, formed after the end of the NRA to work with the Federal Trade Commission and other governmental organizations for better conditions in the grocery industry, has elected J. Frank Grimes, Chicago, president of the Independent Grocers Alliance, chairman, it was announced here today.

Apartments in buildings on Park and Fifth Avenues continue to prove attractive to families seeking new living quarters in the city, according to lists of new tenancies reported yesterday by renting agents. Suites in houses along Riverside Drive and near-by thoroughfares also were rented.

Two thousand tense American fishermen, preparing to shove off tomorrow for the Far North's great salmon run, scanned Bristol Bay to-. day and counted twenty-six large foreign fishing boats and floating canneries.
Nine transatlantic liners, the heaviest concentration of passenger shipping in recent months, will leave here between noon and midnight tomorrow.
Amelia Earhart returned tonight to Bandoeng, Java, from Surabaya for repair of instruments in the plane she is flying around the world. It was uncertain when she would continue her flight.

The second concert in the series at the Lewisohn Stadium was given last night under Vladimir Golschmann's baton before about 3,000 persons. Perfect weather prevailed. Mr. Golschmann arranged a list centering around the Second symphony of Brahms.

Erskine Caldwell and Margaret Bourke-White have collaborated on a volume, "You Have Seen Their Faces," that Viking will publish in the Fall. The book deals with the South and the text is -by Mr. Caldwell, Miss Bourke-White contributing more than ninety photographs.

Secret political police have arrested the Rev. Friedrich Mueller, chairman of the temporary Reich church government set up by the Confessional synods to govern German Protestantism until State interference in church affairs could be eliminated.

Foreign Minister Halvdan Koht, in the Storthing emphasized today Norway's neutral attitude and said "the northern governments will not discuss nor have they discussed military questions with each other.

Resolutions calling upon government officials to "enforce the law rigidly" to protect property rights in strike-troubled districts and asking for relief from "excessive burdens" of heavy taxation and public spending were adopted today by the National Association of Building Owners and Managers at the closing sessions of its convention.

APPLETON-On Thursday, June 24, 1937, Alice A., after a brief illness, at her residence, 1 Pierrepont St., Brooklyn, wife of the late Herbert Appleton and beloved mother of Winlfred Appleton Ross and Frank Hawkins Appleton. Services at the Fairchild Chapel, 26 Lefferts Place, Brooklyn, on Saturday at 3 P. M.
Continued weakness of prices of farm products and foods drove wholesale prices still lower in the week ended in June 19, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today.

Six matches in the Meadow Brook Club Cups polo tournament were played today, with Aknusti, Old Westbury and the Aiken Knights registering Meadow League triumphs, while Gulf Stream, the Fox Hunters and Delhi were winning in Brook League engagements.
The Senate Labor Committee approved today legislation granting consent of Congress to a minimum wage compact between Northeastern States.
Professor Otto J. Schmidt, leader of the Soviet North Pole Expedition, disclosed tonight a proposal for a chain of "amphibian tank" bases for Moscow-United States flights across the polar wastelands.

The two Manhattan public school students who received the Rebecca Elsberg Memorial prizes yesterday heard Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, commend them on their scholastic records in a brief ceremony in his office.

Calling off the labor holiday which was declared yesterday, the C. I. O. today canceled plans for a general strike in Trumbull County in protest against the actions of Sheriff Roy Hardman and the National Guard commanders in allowing men to go to work in the Warren and Niles plants of the Republic Steel Corporation who had not been inside the mills during the four weeks of the strike.
Lumber production declined less than seasonally last week, and the adjusted index continued its forward movement, advancing to 96.6 from 95.9. It was 82.8 for the week ended June 20, 1936.

The marriage of Miss Helen Conant Hanford, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John Munn Hanford of 70 East Ninety-sixth Street and granddaughter of the late Rear Admiral Franklin Hanford, to William Benedict Johnson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis E. Johnson Jr. of Far Hills, N. J., took place yesterday in the Church of the Resurrection.

The Biddle Purchasing Company of New York filed with the Federal Trade Commission today the first final brief of a respondent concern under the Robinson-Patman act, in reply to the commission's complaint based on the "brokerage clause" of the law which makes it unlawful for a broker to pass on to a buyer a brokerage fee obtained from a seller.
The University of Goettingen will open its 200th anniversary jubilee here tomorrow in an ill-concealed atmosphere of discouragement.

Postmaster General Farley, in Boston today, en route to the New England postmasters' convention at Old Orchard, Me., declined to comment on the statement of Governor Earle of Pennsylvania that President Roosevelt should run for a third term. He said it was too early to talk about 1940.

The following Marine Corps changes for the .week ended June 24 were announced today: Inman, Major K. A.. Headquarters, Wash-ington, D. C., to Depot of Supplies, Marine Corps, Philadelphia, Pa. Monson, Major G. E., to Marine Corps Schools,. Quantico, Va.
Government plans for closing its case against eight men on trial for the O'Connell kidnapping were upset tonight when defense counsel announced it would recall the victim to the witness stand.

Announcement has been made by Mrs. Leopold Weiner of Woodmere, L. I., of the engagement of her granddaughter, Miss Muriel Ann Leopold, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Leopold, to Bernard Friedman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Isidor Friedman of this city.

Through Internal Revenue Commissioner Guy T. Helvering, the Treasury Department today placed in the record of the Congressional investigation into income-tax avoidance and evasion the names of sixty-seven "large, wealthy taxpayers who, by taking assets out of their personal boxes and transferring them to incorporated pocketbooks, have avoided paying their full share of taxes."
Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total gold holdings for the system as a whole to be at the lowest point of the year to date.

There was a gathering of thousands of workers in the Place de la Nation this evening, but at no time did they become unruly. Men cried, "We want Blum back in power," but the speakers tried to convince the crowd that Camille Chautemps's government was for the best and that the Popular Front program would continue.

Black will lead Fall colors for dressy coats and suits, silk dresses and shoes, while beige and brown tones are ahead for casual and sportswear, the color coordination committee of the National Retail Dry Goods Association said yesterday in "announcing that its basic ensemble color card for Fall will be issued in the next few days.

For the second time since United Automobile Workers' organizers were beaten and chased from the gates of the Ford Motor Company's Rouge plant May 26, Harry Bennett, Ford personnel director who supervises the company's service department, testified before a grand jury inquiry into the affair today.
A correctional court here has pronounced prison sentences against the author, illustrator and publisher of -a book of poems that won the municipality's annual prize for the best literary'work.

Department store stocks of merchandise on hand at the end of May continued heavy, with increases ranging up to 89 per cent over the corresponding period a year ago, according to figures for large stores in the Second Reserve District isSued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

Trading was spotty in the wool goods markets this week, with men's wear fabrics in light demand, according to the report issued yesterday by the New York Wool Top Exchange Service. Purchases of women's wear fabrics showed a moderate increase, with the demand confined mostly to cloakings.
The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:
It was officially admitted today that Prince Peter, King George's cousin, had quit the Greek Army and left for Paris some days ago. Peter is the son of Prince George and Princess Marie Bonaparte.
Stocks steady and generally higher; metal and steel shares again the feature; turnover, 553,390 shares. Bonds firm and mixed in narrow trading; transactions, $6,274,700.
The House passed today the so-called Municipal Bankruptcy Bill and sent it to the Senate. The vote was 123 to 16. No roll-call was demanded.
Governor Lehman announced tonight the membership of the State Labor Relations Board and the State Mediation Board, which will become operative July 1. Both were created by the Legislature.

Twenty-nine relatives, friends and employes of Alfred H. Sawyer of Concord, Mass., heating engineer who died June 14, today were assured they may "end their days in comparative comfort" under Mr. Sawyer's will, disposing of a fortune of more than $1,000,000.
Charles J. Merrell, assistant director and chief of the bureau of administration of the New Jersey State Department of Health, died at the Muhlenberg Hospital in Plainfield today.

The Securities and Exchange Commission has approved an application by the States Electric and Gas Corporation, which was organized recently under the laws of Delaware with a nominal capital and which has registered as a company purporting to become a holding company, for permission to acquire from the General Water, Gas and Electric Company and the American Equities Company certain se??urities, including those of public utility and other companies.

Lamar W. Hill, since 1924 vice president and general counsel of the Continental Insurance Company and its affiliated companies, and an officer of the American Expeditionary Force in the World War, died yesterday in St. Luke's Hospital after a short illness. He was 52 years old.

The new Joe E. Brown comedy, "Riding on Air," will go on view this morning at the Roxy. Assisting Mr. B. are Guy Kibbee, Florence Rice, Vinton Haworth and Harlan Briggs. .... The Rialto, which only last Monday brought in a logging melodrama, will have another new picture today, Columbia's "A Fight to the Finish," with Don Terry, Rosalind Keith, George MacKay and Ward Bond...

Miss Elizabeth Knowlton Walker, daughter of Commander Hugh MacLean Walker, U. S. N., and granddaughter of the late Colonel Harrison H. Dodge, custodian of Mount Vernon for fifty years, was married today to Joseph Maul Carey, son of the late Senator Robert D. Carey of Wyoming, in St. John's Church by the Rev. Oliver J. Hart, the rector.

Justice George E. Brower in the Supreme Court in Brooklyn yesterday conducted a hearing on a plan for the readjustment, modification or reorganization of the rights of holders of participation certificates in a mortgage of $700,000 on the Hotel Bossert, Montague and Hicks Streets, Brooklyn.
President Roosevelt conferred with Premier Van Zeeland and Secretary Hull on world economic conditions and departed at 8 o'clock tonight for the Jefferson Islands Club in Chesapeake-Bay.

Contingents of Boy Scouts from the West began trickling into New York yesterday for a few days of sight-seeing before going on to Washington for the national jamboree June 30 to July 9, which is expected to draw some 25,000 Scouts and Scoutmasters.
Although the final result of elections for the Icelandic Althing, the world's oldest democratic government, is not yet available, it is believed the position will be as follows:

Mike Belloise, the Bronx fighter whom the New York State Athletic Commission regards as the world featherweight champion, knocked out Jimmy McLeod, game Tacoma, Wash., lightweight, in the feature bout scheduled for ten rounds at Madison Square Garden last night.

Two New York pickpockets whose actions in St. Francis Church in Hoboken last Palm Sunday aroused suspicions of worshipers, who caused their arrest, were sentenced today to serve eighteen months in the County Penitentiary when they pleaded non vult to charges of pickpocket attempts before Judge Thomas F. Meaney in Common Pleas Court here.

The Metropolitan Golf Association held its annual senior tournament at the Garden City Golf Club today, with Bechtel Alcock of Oakland capturing the individual honors while his Long Island team-mates were winning the team competition from the Westchester and New Jersey continzents.

Harvard University received during the past year $11,534,056.38 in benefactions, including gifts and pledges to the 300th anniversary fund. President Conant announced this today during the commencement exercises at which 2,062 degrees were awarded.

Frank Brown, 28-year-old Bellevue Hospital X-ray technician of 519 Lincoln Place, Brooklyn, survived yesterday an electric current of 75,000 volts that passed through his body for several minutes. A1though his hands were burned severely, it was said at the hospital that he was not dangerously hurt.
Baltimore made it two in a raw and hammered the Jersey Giants deeper into last place today by defeating the locals, 4 to 1, in the second game of the series.
Almost left at the post, but a romping winner, nevertheless, the favored Quel Jeu from the Arden Farms yesterday captured the featured Gravesend Handicap at Aqueduct.

Closing here today, the fortieth annual convention of the National Association of Retail Grocers, represented by more than 2,000 delegates from nearly every State, voted to develop a standard legislative program by which the interests of the industry will be protected from the excesses of loss-leader selling and uneconomic practices.

In line with the President's drive to rout- out income tax dodgers, it was revealed yesterday that the United States Attorney's office is prepared to proceed with full speed against tax avoidance that is not within the law.

The pattern of yesterday's stock market was much like that of the day before. Steel and metal issues again led the list slightly higher, and the small trading volume of 553,000 shares on the Stock Exchange was almost identical with that recorded on Wednesday.

Charles J. Grant of C. B. Richard Co. was elected yesterday president of the newly organized Senior Margin Clerks Section of the Association of Stock Exchange Firms. It was stated that more than 200 firms were represented at the meeting, which was addressed by Charles R. Gay, president of the New York Stock Exchange, and Dr. Birl E. Schultz, dean of the Stock Exchange Institute.

Miss Elizabeth Marie Bartner, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry R. Bartner of Bay Shore, L. I., was married to Ward Henes Bolter, son of Mrs. Carl Eggers of 850 Park Avenue and the late Edward Bolter of 'Chicago, last night in the Lutheran Church of St. James, Madison Avenue and Seventy-third Street.

The conflict between the Archbishop of Cracow, Prince Saphieha and the Polish Government over the transfer of Marshal Josef Pilsudski's coffin will be settled by the Vatican. Foreign Minister Josef Beck received today the Papal Nuncio, Mgr. Cortesi,

Representative Jesse P. Wolcott of Port Huron, Mich., ranking Republican on the House Banking and Currency Committee, predicted today an adverse minority report on legislation which, he said, would commit the nation to continuation of the administration's gold policy.

Price movements of commodity futures were generally higher on the local markets yesterday. Trading activity was on a moderate scale. Cottonseed oil and pepper futures were the exceptions, losing ground. On the cash market rubber, tins, lard, oats and corn advanced, but cotton, wheat and rye declined.

Dr. Leopold Auer. world famous violinist who had Mischa Elman, Efrem Zimbalist, Jascha Heifetz and Ruth Breton as pupils, left a net estate of $50,658 when he died July 15, 1930, according to a transfer tax appraisal filed yesterday. His widow, Mrs, Wanda Auer, is sole beneficiary.

The Fusioneers, an organization which supported Mayor La Guardia for election in the 1933 campaign, adopted a resolution last night calling upon the Mayor "to continue his public service by standing for re-election as Mayor."

Net profit of the Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation and subsidiaries in the twelve months ended on April 30 was reported yesterday as $7,619,668 after depreciation, interest, Federal income taxes and other charges but before surtax on undistributed income.
Gifts of $50,000 or more to Harvard University made public by President Conant in announcing total receipts of $11,534,056.38, were as follows:

MANHATTAN AUER, LEOPOLD (July 15. 1930). Gross assets, $50,708: net, $50,658. To Wanda Auer, widow, $30,264; Nadine Sibor, Natalie MiklassheveskY and Marie Ounkovskoif, daughters, $6,798 each. Chief assets, stocks and bonds, $27,325. Arnold Gross, attorney, 1,440 Broadway.

Tsunemasa Niigaki, medical adviser to the Foreign Office, urged the government today to pick its diplomats by blood type-the "O" kind. Dr. Niigaki explained that there were four distinct types of human blood, "A," "B," "AB," and "O."

Stirred by Governor Earle's labor policy and the strikes here and in other parts of the State, Republicans of Philadelphia see issues appearing that may restore them to power in the county this year and insure victory in the State next year.

Some of the wonders of microphotography, by which entire books, telephone directories and other pieces of literature are reduced in size many hundreds of times and printed- on films, were displayed yesterday at the Hotel Waldorf Astoria in connection with the Fifty-ninth Conference of the American Library Association.

Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Landfair Rosenberry gave a dinner in the Garden of the Ambassador for her sister, Miss Nancy Kershaw, and Everett Parsons Tomlinson, whose marriage will take place tomorrow in Forest Hills, Queens.
Baltimore made it two in a raw and hammered the Jersey Giants deeper into last place today by defeating the locals, 4 to 1, in the second game of the series.
Almost left at the post, but a romping winner, nevertheless, the favored Quel Jeu from the Arden Farms yesterday captured the featured Gravesend Handicap at Aqueduct.

Review of Reviews Corp, additional floor in 229-33 4th Ave; Carstens, Linnekin Wilson, Inc. brokers. Cuban American Sugar Co, floor in 120 Wall St; New York Sugar Trade Laboratory, Inc, in 66 Beaver St: Philip Stein, attorney, in 29 Broadway; Merry Co, Inc, electric fans, in 95 Broad St; George H.

Total volume and trading by members in round lots for their own account on the New York Stock and Curb Exchanges in the week ended on May 29, in which there were five tradIng days, were lower than in the preceding week, but the percentage of total volume represented by member trading increased slightly, from 20.48 to 20.57 per cent, according to the weekly summary issued today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Chief Justice William M. Maltbie of the Connecticut Supreme Court addressed thirty-four members of Bacon Academy's senior class at graduation exercises today at the historic Congregational Church here. Dr. J. Almus Russell, principal of the academy, presided. About 500 persons thronged the church.

Gerard B. Lambert's Yankee scored over Chandler Hovey's Rainbow today by 12 minutes and 36 seconds in a race of 26.3 miles, which was the greatest margin recorded by one yacht over another in the America's Cup defense trials.

The State Banking Department has authorized the opening of three branch offices by the Manufacturers Trust Company, 55 Broad Street, New York City, the department's weekly bulle'tin announced tonight.

Plans for reopening the Republic Steel Corporation's four Cleveland mills employing 8,000 persons were discussed here today. Mayor Harold Burton assured Donald B. Gillies, Republic vice president, that "all the police protection necessary" would be furnished as soon as the mill gates were thrown open, probably early next week.

The United States District Court was asked yesterday to authorize settlement of a $6,800,000 suit against former directors of the defunct Harriman National Bank and Trust Company for $1,026,737. Judge Vincent L. Leibell signed a show cause order bringing on the proposal for a hearing on next Friday.

With the failure of the first effort at mediation in the steel strike, the situation reverts to the position of a week ago. The C. I. O. continues to demand an agreement with the independent companies modeled on the agreement it has made with the Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation, and the independent companies continue to insist that the C. I. O. is not a responsible agency with which to deal.

The marriage of Miss Elizabeth Neill Ford, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George H. Ford of Dallas, Texas, to John Joseph Lippoth, son of Mrs. Jonathan E. Lippoth of this city and the late Mr. Lippoth, took place yesterday afternoon in St. Paul's Chapel, Columbia University. The ceremony was performed by Dr. Charles B. Ackley of St. Mary's Protestant Episcopal Church.

Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora protested in a decision handed down yesterday against what he described as a growing tendency to put people into jail for non-payment of debts. Saying that the trend should be resisted he refused to issue a body attachment for a debtor who had failed to satisfy a $3,877 judgment.

Weekly cotton statistics are as follows: British stocks, 886,000 bales, against 913,000 a week ago, 909,000 two weeks ago, 917,000 three weeks ago and 721,000 a year ago; of which American 352,000 bales, against 360,000 a week ago, 380,000 two weeks ago, 390,000 three weeks ago and 292,000 a year ago.
Harry T. Van Camp, since 1911 editor of the weekly Wayne Democratic Press here, died today in Clifton Springs Sanitarium. His age was 77.

Two, of the finest crews that have ever rowed over the Thames River course reached the crest of a seventy-five-year rivalry of their universities this evening, when Harvard's varsity oarsmen climaxed the best Crimson season in years with a superbly wrought victory over a Yale crew good enough and game enough to wring every bit of the brilliance from them before conceding defeat by a length and a quarter.
More than 270 persons attended yesterday the fourth annual outing of the New York Security Dealers Association at the Westchester Country Club. Golf, as usual, was the principal activity of the day.

There was plenty of drama as the Yale-Harvard regatta opened today. Not in a long stretch of years has there been the unexpected excitement provided by the freshman race, which started Yale on its tworace sweep of the morning. The Harvard cubs collapsed suddenly and Yale went on to victory.

Mrs. William Revell Moody, daughter - in - law of Dwight L. Moody, evangelist and religious educator, will have charge of the third annual Women's Conference, July 31 to August 16, at East Northfield, Mass. The conference will be subsidiary to the fifty-seventh annual General Conference of Christian Workers there.

Several hundred demonstrators of cosmetics and toilet preparations were used by the Hudnut Sales Company, Inc., to meet the competition in this field, according to testimony given by its counsel yesterday at a hearing before the Federal Trade Commission at 45 Broadway.

Dr. Alberto Ulloa, legal adviser to the Peruvian Foreign Office, announced tonight that arrangements had been made to resume partial interest payments on $100,000,000 in Peruvian bonds held in this country, which have been in default since 1931.

President Roosevelt met the other guests at the Jefferson Islands Club today dressed in a pair of old linen slacks, no coat and no necktie and with his shirt opened at the neck, the returning guests reported.

Miss--Margaret Thurston Pickering, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Thurston Pickering of Pasadena, Calif., was married this afternoon to Samuel Zemurray Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Zemurray of New Orleans. The ceremony was performed in the Harvard Memorial Chapel in Cambridge by the Rev. C. Leslie Glenn.

The government completed today its case against eight men accused of the 1933 kidnapping of John J. O'Connell Jr., after climaxing the eighteen days of trial with testimony that O'Connell's father was originally the target of the abductors.

Joseph Stalin personally welcomed Professor Otto F. Schmidt and thirty-odd other members of the North Pole expedition this afternoon on their triumphant return from the Arctic into one of Moscow's surprising heat waves.

In the first of three week-end Democratic outings, planned for the purpose of sealing a growing subsurface breach between the White House and Congress, President Roosevelt spent six hours today with about 150 of his party associates at the Jefferson Islands Club near here.

Retail operating expense, as reported by the 1,653,961 stores operating in 1935, averaged $22.89 for each $100 of sales, of which $10.98 was payroll, it was announced today by William L. Austin, director of the Bureau of the Census, in a special report of the retail census.

Reduced rates for residential, general and power service in parts of Westchester, Putnam and Dutchess Counties have been filed by the New York State Electric and Gas Corporation, the Public Service Commission made known today.

The first non-stop trip across the continent by flying boat ended in Bowery Bay, at North Beach Airport, yesterday when Richard Archbold, research associate of the American Museum of Natural History, landed a 34,000-pound Consolidated PBY-1 which he had taken off at San Diego 17 hours 3 minutes 30 seconds before.

France today ratified the London Naval Treaty of 1936, hitherto accepted only by the United States. Italy and Japan refused to sign the treaty, which aimed to set the maximum caliber for big guns at 14 inches.

A plea of guilty to possessing a pistol in his shop at 215 East Thirtyfourth Street was entered yesterday in Special Sessions by Joseph Gedeon, 54 years old, the furniture repair man whose wife, daughter and a boarder were murdered in their home at 316 East Fiftieth Street last Easter Sunday morning.

The particular branch of engineering with which the late Colonel HUGH L. COOPER so closely identified himself, that of water-power development, long ago passed into the hands of the highly trained graduates of technical institutions. He stood apart. With no formal technical education, he gravitated as naturally to engineering as artists to painting and sculpture.

A gay crowd of picnickers, all Democrats, left a dock at the Naval Academy here early this morning and returned late tonight, having spent the day with the President of the United States. Many got thoroughly sunburned.

When the Jerlbll Holding Corp, Jerome H. Frank, president, sold to the 15 W 132d St Corp the dwelling at 234 W 130th St for a consideration indicated as $1,000 over the mortgage for $6.000 held by the MIetropolitan Savings Bank, which sold this house to Jeribil a couple of months ago, the buyer gave back a purchase money mortgage for $2,000, due according to the bond, at 5 per cent.

Plans of Commander Earl Winfield Spencer, first husband of the Duchess of Windsor, for another marriage were disclosed today when his fiancee, Mrs. Norma Reese Johnson, made application at the County Clerk's office for a marriage license.

Employes of the Bethlehem plant of the Bethlehem Steel Company sent a petition to Governor Earle today asking that he "maintain the Constitution of the United States and of the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania. "
Mrs. Rebecca S. Swallow, widow of the Prohibition party's Presidential candidate in 1904, died today. She was 93 years old. Her husband was Dr. Silas C. Swallow, Methodist Episcopal minister.

A warning was issued yesterday by Joseph T. Higgins, Collector of Internal Revenue for the Third District of New York, that those claiming refunds for processing taxes paid under the invalidated Agricultural Adjustment Act must file their claims on or before June 30. If the claim is not filed by that date, it will be outlawed, he said.

One hundred American public school pupils who arrived in Germany on the liner St. Louis, which also brought 100 German students returning from a visit to the United States, are now in Berlin, where they will remain for six weeks. They are quartered with private families.

Field Marshal Werner von Blomberg, the German War Minister, arrives Monday on what is officially described as a courtesy visit Undoubtedly, however, he will discuss an armament loan, as Germany is anxious to sell Hungary army planes and armored cars.

Mrs. Garfield Holden, the former Miss Aufilla P. Cutter, principal of the South Avenue Elementary School here, committed suicide yesterday by hanging herself in her home in Groton. She was 54 years old.

Completing the first route inspection flight in the North Atlantic area, preliminary to the establishment of air service for passengers, mail and goods to London, the Pan American Clipper 3d landed here at 5 o'clock this afternoon after a round-trip flight to Shediac,
Notices for fewer than 9,000 bales were issued yesterday on the Cotton Exchange, a smaller total than had been anticipated, and as a result covering in the spot month strengthened the list.

While ordinarily floor-coverings manufacturers would announce their advertising plans simultaneously with the opening of Fall lines, this season the situation is so unsettled that they will probably not complete advertising campaigns until September, executives said here yesterday.
A watch-and-clock factory, more than 100 years old, has been brought here piece by piece from its original location in Barnstable, to be erected later on the Sturbridge site of the Wells Museum.

Morris Glaser, 52 years old, of 326 West Hudson Street, Long Beach, L. I., and Philip Pearlman, 33, of 2,320 Bronx Parkway, the Bronx, money lenders, paid fines of- $500 each in Special Sessions yesterday. Both had admitted charging usurious rates on loans to city employes, including policemen and firemen.

Assets of the sixty Federal savings and loan associations in New York State jumped from $96,501,907 to $109,924,921 between June 1, 1936, and June 1, 1937, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board reported today. Home construction, likewise, is expending in keeping with the improved conditions of the savings and loan associations.
Miss Helen Scott Morris, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Caspar W. Morris of Haverford, Pa., was married this afternoon to Edwin Packard Halsey, son of Dr. and Mrs. John Taylor Halsey of New Orleans.

Officers of the B. M. T. division of the Transport Workers Union lead were authorized last night to call a strike of the 12,500 men employed on its rapid transit, street car and bus lines unless the company agrees unconditionally on Monday to an mea immediate collective bargaining referendum.

The marriage of Miss Doris Neilson Harvey, daughter of Mrs. Harold C. Harvey of this city, to Wayne Overn Stahler, son of Mr. and Mrs. Horace C. Stahler of Philadelphia, took place here this afternoon in the crypt of Trinity Protestant Episcopal Cathedral. The Rev. Walter H. Stowe, rector of Christ Church, New Brunswick, performed the ceremony.

An application by John T. Brook, former president of the Pelham National Bank, to pay $20,000 in settlement of a damage suit brought by the Federal receiver of the institution was granted today by Supreme Court Justice Graham Witschief.
The Interstate Commerce Commission dismissed today a complaint of the Pennsylvania Coal and Coke Corporation against rates on bituminous coal.

Sharp advances in wheat and corn and the livestock and meat group carried The Annalist weekly index of wholesale commodity prices 0.9 point higher in the last week. The index rose to 141.9 per cent of the 1913 average on Tuesday from 141.0 (revised) on the Tuesday previous.
Thomas F. Bundy bought a house and an acre of land at Polly Park Road and North Street in the Park Ridge section of Harrison, N. Y., from the Doehler Realty Corporation. E. V. Siedle was the broker.

Four real estate operators convicted last Wednesday of mail fraud growing out of their management of the National Home Builders Corporation received prison sentences yesterday from Federal Judge Alfred C. Coxe.

Mrs. Suzanne Carroll Hill of Baltimore and former United States Senator Hiram Bingham of Connecticut will be married on Monday at the Summer home of Mrs. Robert W. Chambers, widow of the author, in Broadalbin, N. Y.

Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain's declarations to the British House of Commons today on the withdrawal by Italy and Germany from the four-power patrol off the Spanish coast is considered so important here that Italian newspapers ignore the rule against publishing British news and print the speech under a London date line.

36th St, 356-60 W. 12-story brick loft and store building, 75x98.9; Frank L. Weil, trustee, against Meridian Securities Corp; due, $394,815; to plaintiff for $1,000. By WILLIAM KENNELLY 8th Ave. 952-4. one 4 and one 6-story brick apartment and store buildings, irreg;

With the President's signature, a new Railroad Pensio Act has now become law. It is the third such act within a period of three years. The Railway Pension Act of 1934 was declared unconstitutional by the Supreme Court. The act of 1935 was declared unconstitutional by the Supreme Court of the District of Columbia.

A biography of the late Marlen E. Pew, for many Years editor of Editor and Publisher, newspaper trade journal, is being prepared by Dr. DeForest O'Dell of New York, with the assistance of members of Mr. Pew's family. Dr. Odell would be grateful for the use of letters and papers on Mr. Pew that might aid him in his work.
Aug. 1 was proposed today in conversation at the Jefferson Islands Club as the possible and not improbable date for sine die adjournment of Congress.

Lieutenant Thomas Lee Turner died this morning in Naval Hospital, where he had been under treatment for about three weeks. His age was 36. He had been on duty in the office of the Judge Advocate General, while at the same time taking a post-graduate course in law at George Washington University.

Unless otherwise stated, the resilts of operations of the follow wing companies, - anlnolunced yesterday, are after deductionls for operating expenses, normal Federal income taxes, depreciation and other charges, but before provisions for Federal surtax on undistributed earnings. Figrt. es, in manly cases, are subject to final adjustment.

After months of fretting about the subject, the Council of the Dramatists Guild finally has awarded the Roi Cooper Megrue Prize to Arthur Kober's "Having Wonderful Time." The prize, carrying a purse of $500, is given for the best comedy of the year.

First Lieut. Mayer S. Kaplan, Med.-Res. 125 East 59th St., Brooklyn, New York, 3d Evacuation Hospital (R.A.I.), is ordered to active duty for six months, effective July 1, at headquarters Fort Lewis District, CCC. Fort Lewis. Wash., for assignment and duty in connection with CCC activities. Lt. KaDlan will rank from Dec. 1. 1936.
Mrs.Mabel Amelia Harper Gow, a granddaughter of John Harper, one of the brothers who founded the Harper Bros. publishing company, died on Wednesday atCamis Eskan, her home near Helensburgh, Scotland.

Queen Mary and her bother, the Earl of Athlone, announced today that a fund of [pound]250,000 would be raised for a memorial to Rudyard Kipling. The announcement said [pound]30,000 had been subscribed. The Earl is president of the council of the Kipling Memorial Fund.

Miss Charlotte Glutting, women's Eastern champion, added to her laurels today over the Rock Spring Club course when she scored a 78 to win the women's New Jersey Golf Association one-day tournament. Miss Glutting failed by four strokes to equal her home course record when she went out in 38 and came back in 40.

Lloyd (Whitey) Moore, sensational right-hander of the Chiefs, broke his own season's strikeout record as he fanned sixteen Newark batsmen tonight, but the Bears emerged with a 5-2 victory. In his debut with Syracuse Sunday Moore struck out fifteen Toronto batters, but lost that game also.

Crowds shouted "Down with Archbishop Sapieha!" "To the concentration camp at Bereza!" at a meeting in Pilsudski Square here tonight. A resolution was voted requesting the government to banish the Metropolitan, who had dared to disobey President Ignaz Moscicki and removed Marshal Pilsudski's coffin from its crypt in the Wawel Cathedral.

Ward's Reports, Inc., estimated today that the output of automobile plants for the current week would total 121, 032 cars and trucks, compared with 111,620 last week. For the comparable period of 1936 the production was 104,473 units.

Members of the New York City Charter Commission waded through the intricacies of proportional representation voting today with the Hamilton County Board of Elections and representatives of the Cincinnati Charter Committee.

Gerard S. Smith's polo mounts were highly successful in the first day's judging at the annual Ox Ridge Hunt Club horse show, held on the club grounds today. With ideal weather, the classes were run off speedily.

The Securities and Exchange Commission has set July 1 for a hearing on a registration statement filed under the Securities Act of 1933 by the Consolidated Funds Corporation Jersey'City, of which David M. Milton is president.

Miss Virginia Dickinson Clutia, daughter of Mr. and Hrs. Harry Howard Clutia of this place, was married tonight at the home of her parents to H. Hugh McConnell, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry McConnell of Montclair. Dr. George C. Vincent, pastor of the Union Congregational Church of Upper Montclair, officiated.
Miss Margaret M. Righter, daughter of Mrs. Thomas M. Righter of Princeton, has selected July 16 for her marriage to Albridge Clinton Smith 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Albridge C. Smith of South Orange.

Mrs. Anne Theobald Bailey Barstow of Gardiner, Me., widow of George B. Barstow, Boston banker, was married in the Appleton Chapel here today to Charles H. Strong, for many years secretary of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York. The Rev. Dr. Palfrey Perkins of King's Chapel Unitarian Church, Boston, performed the ceremony.

LONDON-Prime Minister Chamberlain told the House of Commons the European situation was "serious but not hopeless." He warned that "an incautious move, or even a sudden loud exclamation may start an avalanche."

Some 1,500 barbers on strike in 1,000 shops throughout Brooklyn will return to work on Monday under an agreement reached yesterday by the Journeymen Barbers International Union and the Kings County Master Barbers Association, it was announced yesterday by John Tartamella, international representative of the union.

Tomorrow will mark the close of the Winter season in the churches, and a week from Sunday will mark the opening of the Summer season. With a very few exceptions the churches will remain open for Sunday morning services throughout the vacation period.

Play in the second annual best-ball invitation golf tournament got under way at the Cherry Valley Club today, with Everett Hoyt of the Garden City Golf Club and his veteran partner from the home club, Leo Smith, tying the youthful combination of Edwin Butler of Hempstead and A. L. Adamson of Cherry Valley for the qualifying honors with a subpar 69.

Belmont Ave., 2,540 (12-3273): Adele Lambrose to Aaron Rabinowitz, trustee, 1,125 5th Ave.; extends mtg. to Oct. 1, 1939, at 4, per cent; $136.031. Davidson Ave., 2,185 (11-3195); Helen R. Roberts to president and directors of the Manhattan Co.; 5 per cent; $10,000.
On the eve of the coming of 27,000 Boy Scouts for their national jamboree, it was estimated that it would require 117 special trains to move them.

Miss Ann Rae, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Garfield Rae of this place, was married tonight to Frederick John Warren, son of Mrs. Walter Burgess Warren, also of West Newton, in the Second Church in Newton by the Rev. Boynton Merrill.

Presenting one of the country's most modern race tracks, Delaware Park brings the thoroughbreds to an old horse-loving community tomorrow when it opens. a twentyfive-day meeting with ten 3-yearolds named for the $10,000 Kent Handicap.

More than 200 American clergymen will attend the second World Conference on Church, State and Community in Oxford, England, July 12 to 26. Many will sail this week. A large percentage will remain in Europe to attend the second decennial World Conference on Faith and Order in Edinburgh, beginning Aug 3.
Miss Eunice Dean of San Antonio, Texas, defending champion, and Miss Millicent Hirsh of New York reached the final of the women's New Jersey State tennis championship today.

Protesting the decree for rigidly enforcing the forty-hour week in their industry, the French hotel, restaurant and cafe proprietors announced tonight a lockout for tomorrow throughout French territory.

Sir John Simon, recently appointed Chancellor of the Exchequer, surprised the House of Commons this afternoon with the announcement that Great Britain's huge exchange equalization fund, already amounting to ??350,000,000, was to be increased by another [Pound]200,000,000.

Arthur J. Marks, a partner in the New York Stock Exchange firm of Sartorius Smith and a Wall Street broker for many years, died suddenly of a heart attack today at his Summer home here. Mr. Marks, who lived at the Hotel Gladstone, New York, had an office at 1,422 St. Nicholas Avenue, New York. His age was 73.

Mrs. Amelia Goodyear Crim of this city and Oakland Farm, Somerville, N. J., widow of John W. H. Crime, was married yesterday to Roger Benton Hull of New York in her apartment at 130 East Seventyfifth Street. The Rev. Dr. Willard P. Soper of the Huguenot Memorial Church of Pelham Manor performed the ceremony, at which the couple dispensed with attendants.
The rising Red Sox continued their drive today by beating the Browns, 4 to 2, behind the four-hit pitching of Buck Newsom. It was Boston's third consecutive victory and ninth in the last ten games.

The business cycle was branded as the worst enemy of banking in this country by Colonel Leonard P. Ayres, chairman of the Economic Policy Commission of the American Bankers Association, in an address here tonight.

Marc Baldwin, formerly New York sales manager for Browne Vintners Co., Inc., distributors of Wilson whisky and of a variety of imported liquors, has been made Ohio State sales manager for the company.

Below are given nominal comparative quotations on standard constructions of gray printcloths, sheetings and pajamas checks in this market, as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:
Mr. and Mrs. Stewart C. Pratt of 1,107 Fifth Avenue will sail today on the Rex. They will return in September. Mr. and Mrs. William H. Downey of the Ambassador also are sailing on the Rex.

Yale won the annual baseball series with Harvard by defeating the Crimson, 13 to 3, before 2,000 regatta-day spectators today. The contest, scheduled between the morning and evening rowing events, was the odd game in the two-out-ofthree series.
The United States is helping the Brazilian Navy with plans and technical assistance in the construction of three destroyers, it was learned yesterday.

Ralph Guldahl, American open golf champion, and Big Ed Dudley took advantage of the record fourday drought by firing a pair of subpar 67s over the Southport and Ainsdale course today in practice for the Ryder Cup matches between United States and British professional teams.

The marriage of Miss Doris Isabelle Eddy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jay Edson Eddy of 1,158 Fifth Avenue, to James Raymond Boyce, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. James Raymond Boyce, took place yesterday morning in the Lady Chapel of St. Patrick's Cathedral. Mgr. James Brady performed the ceremony.

Despite two bomb explosions here early this morning, officials of the Republic Steel Corporation announced that the back-to-work movement under the protection of the National Guard was accelerated today.

New State and municipal financing scheduled for next week totals only $16,376,659, to be represented by one State and fifty-nine municipalities. This compares with the revised total of $50,942,870 for this week. The weekly average of new offerings for the year to date now stands at $32,749,360.

Grim-faced farmers, "armed with shotguns," entered today into the troubled labor situation at the big strike-closed Phillips canning plants where there has been one fatality--a picket killed by a truck.

The diplomatic tension relaxed today. The British Government accepted the Paris proposal that France and Great Britain take charge of the Mediterranean sectors of the Spanish naval control abandoned by Germany and Italy.
Colin Clive, English stage and screen actor, died here today from pulmonary and intestinal ailments. He was 37 years old.

Preparations for the expected arrival within the next few days of Miss Amelia Earhart and her globe-girdling plane got under way today on Howland Island, tiny coral Pacific Ocean isle 1,532 miles southwest of Honolulu.

Never down at any point, Mrs. Henry H. Dietrich today returned to the women's Westchester-Fairfield golf throne, which she last ascended in 1933, by defeating Mrs. James Robbins of Lawrence Farms, 8 and 6, in the final of the fifteenth annual championship tourney.

The millionth motor vehicle to be built this year by the General Motors Corporation, including both United States and Canadian factories, was produced on Thursday, according to reports received yesterday by William S. Knudsen, president.

Miss Mary Marshall Hyde, daughter of Mrs. Lewis Huntington Hyde of New York and Winchester, Va., and the late Mr. Hyde, was married here this afternoon in the Hitchcock Memorial Church to Allan Barbour Richardson of New York, formerly of Chicago. The ceremony was performed by the rector, the Rev. George H. Smyth, in the presence of the two families.

Six hundred WPA artists, writers and musicians imprisoned the executive head of their projects last night, after they had taken full control of the central offices of the Federal Arts Projects on the third floor of 235 East Forty-second Street.
Joe Gould, manager of James J. Braddock, dethroned world heavyweight boxing champion, arrived at the Grand Central Terminal yesterday on the Twentieth Century Limited from Chicago.
In an effort to effect a new collective agreement through "peaceful negotiation," representatives of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union and the Industrial Council of Cloak.

Manhattan Alterations 4th St., 66-68 E.; to 4-story catering hall; Burland Catering Corp., premises, owner; J. S. Schafran, architect; cost, $40,000. Lexington Ave., 798; to 1-story office and store; Bank for Savings, 280 4th Ave., owner; Louis E. Ordwein, architect; cost, $10,000.
The immediats effect stock-marketwise, of the announcement that the government is increasing the Exchange Equaliztion Fund was a general strengthening in all leading categories.

In fine weather today after forty-eight hours of rain Insurgent troops operating southwest of Bilbao continued to advance west toward Valmaseda. Those pushing along the coastal highway to Santander reached Somorrostro, about nine miles from this city. Somorrostro is very near the border of Vizcaya Province.

Dr. Peter W. Sothman, electrical engineer who was in charge of large power projects in many parts of the world, died yesterday in Ploen, Holstein, Germany, according to word received here. He had been ill for a year. Dr. Sothman, who had a home in Mount Tabor, N. J., was 67 years old.

Bo Lisman of California led a fiveman team to victory in a partideo, feature race of the fifth weekly English style motor cycle races last night at the Yankee Stadium before a crowd of 16,500, the largest of the season.

Striking members of the Max Fleischer Studio, where the animated cartoons, such as "Popeye" and "Betty Boop" are turned out, staged a raucous demonstration last night in the Paramount Theatre, where a "Popeye" picture was being shown. Outside the theatre about sixty pickets paraded.

For the second consecutive week the volume of new bond financing exceeded the $100,000,000 mark with this week's total of $101,843,000, comprising only eight individual issues, comparing with an aggregate of $143,577,511 in new bonds placed on the market last week.

Miss Katherine Arnstein, daughter of Mrs. Walter Arnstein of San Francisco and the late Mr. Arnstein, was married to Dr. Joseph L. Lilienthal Jr., son of Mrs. Joseph L. Lilienthal and the late Mr. Lilienthal, yesterday afternoon in the apartment of the bridegroom's mother at 911 Park Avenue by Dr. John Lovejoy Elliott of the Ethical Culture Society.

The word has gone out through the racing 'garages at Roosevelt Raceway that the American drivers who will start -their qualifying tests tomorrow for the 300-mile Vanderbilt cup race July 3 had better set some high marks for Bernd Rosemeyer, the German star, to shoot at with his Auto Union when he arrives Monday.

Miss Marian West, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Wellington West of Shelly Hall, Shelly Bay, Bermuda, was married today to Arthur Sculley, son of Mrs. Genevieve Sculley of New York and John Sculley of Garden City, L. I., in Holy Trinity Church, Baileys Bay, by the Rev. Archibald Ball. The ceremony was followed by a large reception at Shelly Hall.

Stocks eased and closed irregularly lower in quiet trading; turnover, 574,640 shares. United States Government issues and foreign bonds firm, corporate bonds fractionally lower; transactions. $6.840.600.

Officials of Quincy, Mass., awarded yesterday to the First Boston Corporation a new issue of $100,000 relief bonds on a bid of 100.486 for 1 3/4S. The bonds, dated July 1, are due July 1, 1938 to 1942.

Miss Helen de Russy Sloan, daughter of Colonel and Mrs. Thomas Donaldson Sloan of Lawrence, L. I., was quietly married yesterday to Martin Van Buren Morris, son of Mrs. Stuyvesant Fish Morris of Hewlett, L. I., and the late Mr. Morris, in the rectory of St. John's Protestant Episcopal Church, Far Rockaway, Queens, by the Rev. Francis G. Urban.

Venturing into the realm of prophecy, Lord Tweedsmuir, Canada's Governor General, told the World Presbyterian Alliance tonight that Presbyterianism might in the future become what the Germans called a "bridge kirch" between the churches rich in historic accretions and churches which lacked them.
The outlook for the railroad industry might be described as "favorable to mixed." Early returns for May show that in many cases larger expenses and disbursements absorbed the increases
Charles E. Baird, 82, of 395 Lexington Street, who was the model for Daniel Chester French's statue of "The Minute Man" at the Concord Bridge, died suddenly today.

Three amendments to the charter will be placed before shareholders of the Reynolds Metals Company at their meeting here July 6. They will be asked to authorize an increase in the common stock from 1,150,000 to 1,500,000 shares,

Two well-dressed thugs who robbed a broker's messenger of $700 in cash just before noon yesterday in the financial district invested a nickel and made certain of having plenty of time for their escape. After taking the money, they forced the victim to board a subway train.
William B. Williams Jr. of Montclair, N. J., who was injured yesterday in the collision of two automobiles near here, died today. His wife received minor injuries.

The New York Stock Exchange committee on quotations and commissions will consider on July 1 the proposal to form the new firm of Whaley, Potter Finucane. The partners are to be Frederick C. Whaley, Earl S. P6tter and William G. Finucane.

Jimmy Hines, metropolitan open champion from Garden City, L.I., came to the front of a fast field today in the True Temper golf tourney, carding a second par-shattering round of 36-34-70 for a total of 140, four strokes under par at the half-way mark.
Frank R. Kelly of West Orange, N. J., captured the 20-gauge event with a 97 as the ninth annual great Eastern skeet championships opened on the Remington Gun Club range at Lordship today.

The fortieth annual convention of the Zionis Organization of America will open this evening at the Hotel Roosevelt and will continue until Tuesday evening, when a mass meeting to discuss problems facing the future of Palestine will be held at Carnegie Hall.

Premier Benito Mussolini turned from Italian park fences to Austrian scrap heaps today in his campaign for more iron and steel for Italy's armaments. The Italian Cabinet approved a decree providing duty-free importation from Austria of 2,755,000 tons of scrap iron, pig iron and iron bars.

In an expansion policy under which films will be made in London and Hollywood, Walter Wanger will open a series of conferences Sunday with Charles B. Cochrane, British producer, who will arrive at that time.

Rather than permit the Committee for Industrial Organization to force the company to.break its contract with the American Federation of Labor, McKesson Robbins, Inc., one of the largest wholesale drug concerns in the country, closed its big warehouse at 3,674 Third Avenue, the Bronx, yesterday morning.

The Pittsburgh United Corporation has reported to the Securities and Exchange Commission that its chief parent company is Pennsylvania Industries, Inc., which held 130,900 shares of its common stock, or 33.1 per cent, at the end of last year, and had reduced its holdings to 101,000 shares, or 25.9 per cent, at the end of May.

The Tennessee Valley Authority today announced the conclusion of negotiations for a contract with the Arkansas Power and Light Company which will send its electricity west of the Mississippi for the first time. The contract is the second negotiated by the TVA with a private power company.
A decree calculated to put the entire Mexican agrarian system under strict State control was quietly issued in the Official Gazette today under the signature of President Lazaro Cardenas.

The marriage of Miss Marjorie Underhill, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Adna H. Underhill, to James Morton Christian Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. James M. Christian, took place here today in St. Paul's Episcopal Church.

It seems like a pretty far cry from the scenes of industrial discord to the local night club front, but some of the more solemn managers of New York's currently languishing resorts (of which there happen to be a few) are telling themselves sympathetically that the labor situation is to blame.
A less-than-seasonal decline was registered in cotton-mill activity last week and the adjusted index advanced three points to 147.8 from 144.8. It was 117.7 for the week ended June 20, 1936.

The price of milk to consumers in New York City will "inevitably" go up 1 cent a quart in July, it was reported yesterday following a producer - distributer agreement granting an increase to the farmers.
Heavy rains and melting glacial ice interrupted interior Alaska highway travel last night, caused flood conditions at Nenana and speeded progress of the famed Black Rapids Glacier.

Mayor La Guardia was angered yesterday by the imputation that he was the only member of the Board of Estimate who wanted a Summer recess, and retaliated by serving notice on the members that they would convene every Friday throughout the Summer at City Hall.

The fact that Tchaikovsky's "Pathetic" symphony figured on last night's program at the Lewisohn Stadium probably was largely responsible for the increase in attendance over that of the preceding event in the series.

The Rev. Edward Strong Worcester, Professor of Theology at New Brunswick Theological Seminary, died in the Middlesex General Hospital here today after an illness of three weeks. He was 61 year old. He collaborated in the translation of Zahn's Introduction to the New Testament, which was published in 1909.

Four block fronts containing 115 lots in Whitestone, L. I., have been purchased by Walter J. McCormick, president of the MacMurray Homes Company, from Edwin P. Roe. The lots are on Fourth to Seventh Avenues, 149th to 150th Streets, and were purchased some years ago by Mr. Roe, who is president of the College Point Savings Bank.

The Shoe Manufacturers' Board of Trade of New York, Inc., announced yesterday that its eighteen members had granted wage increases of 10 per cent, aggregating $720,000-annually, to 5,800 factory employes.

Misi Marguerite W. MacCoy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. W. Logan MacCoy of Overbrook, Pa., was married this afternoon to Arthur Merriam Rogers, son of Mr. and Mrs. William O. Rogers of Madison, N. J. The ceremony was performed b3 the Rev. Dr. Andrew Mutch, rector emeritus, and the Rev. Rex Clements at the Bryn Mawr Presby. terian Church.
The Reichsbank's statement as of June 24 shows the following changes fron the preceding week, in thousands of marks:

An effort to raise $500,000, which is "needed immediately" to aid homeless Spanish children of the Basque territory, will be started within a few days by the American Board of Guardians for Basque Refugee Children, it was announced yesterday by William E. Dodd Jr., acting secretary of the board.
Big Ten and Pacific Coast track stars tapered off training with light workouts today and were pronounced in shape for tomorrow's big meet.

130th St, 234 W. 15x100; Jeribil Holding Corp to 15 W 132d St Corp, 198 W 134th St; mtg $6,000 ($1). 148th St. 221 W, 25x100: Emanuel Libman to Selma Stern ($4.50). Same property; Selma Stern to Ardrich Realty Co, Inc, 48 W 125th St ($4.50). 8th Ave, 2.573, 25x100; Lillian Lubliner to

Death Announced Fireman first grade William Clancy of Engine 49 died June 24. Funeral will take place from his late residence, 520 West 139th St., Manhattan, at 9:30 A. M. Monday, June 28. Interment at Gate of Heaven Cemetery.
The Defense Minister is conferring with naval officials on plans to purchase two cruisers and other units which are considered indispensable for the navy and gradually to withdraw old vessels.

Goettingen University announced tonight that the widely known Neopagan and often violently antiChristian professor, Dr. Hans Heyse, would speak for the university faculty and deliver one of the two main addresses of the bicentennial anniversary ceremonies, which began today.

Mary Pickford changed her mind tonight about her entire costume for her marriage tomorrow to Charles (Buddy) Rogers in an informal garden. Instead of ice blue crepe she will wear ciel bleu (sky blue) crepe.

Marking the "century of peace" along the Canadian border, the international relations committee of the International Zonta Clubs in a report today urged appropriating funds to promote the peace program of the organization.
The strokes of the Harvard and Yale varsity eights were elected tonight to captain next year's crews at the traditional "breaking training" dinners at the two boathouses.
New York's school children are better off today than they were, say, twenty-five years ago, but not so well off as they will be
President Roosevelt recommended in a letter to Speaker Bankhead today that Congress appropriate $50,000 for expenses of the Senate-House committee investigating tax evasion and avoidance.

After an ownership by the same family dating from its construction in 1887, Elizabeth M. Miller of Bordeaux, France, has sold for cash to a client of Samuel Hurwitz the three-story brick and brownstone dwelling at 128 Halsey Street, Brooklyn.

The City Amateur Symphony Orchestra, under the direction of Municipal Court Justice Leopold Prince, will present the second concert in a Summer series on the Central Park Mall tonight. The orchestra will be heard tomorrow at 3 o'clock in the Music Grove of Prospect Park, Brooklyn.
The House of Commons seat traditionally held by the Baldwin family until former Prime Minister Stanley Baldwin was raised to the peerage stayed today on the Conservative side.

Dr. Charles E. Levin, a dentist, was found dead yesterday morning, apparently of a heart attack, in his office in the Medical Arts Building, 57 West Fifty-seventh Street. His body was discovered by his nurse, Miss Mary Ballou of 25 West Ninety-first Street, when she arrived for work.

All Southern and Eastern Chinese Turkestan, a territory larger than France, is in revolt against the Pro-Soviet administration of that region, according to authoritative advices reaching embassies here.

Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Snare Jr. of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Dorothy Stanwood Snare, to Beverly Walden Warner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Warner of Hackensack and Sachem's Head, Conn.

Retail trade here lagged somewhat this week and few stores were able to exceed last year's figures by any substantial amount. The business to be done today will determine the showing for the week, but up to last night some stores here had sales under last year ranging from 2 to 6 per cent.

The Baltimore Orioles made it three in a row over the Jersey City Giants today when they captured the third game of the series, 3 to 2, in eleven innings. The Orioles came from behind to tie the score with a two-run rally that knocked Don Brennan out of the box in the ninth and they produced the winning tally in the eleventh on Milt Gray's single and Bill Cissell's double.

More than 2,000 engineers drawn from all parts of the country will arrive here Monday to attend the five-day annual meeting of the American Society for Testing Materials at the Hotel Waldorf -Astoria.
Circuit Judge W. J. Waggoner sentenced Lester W. Brockelhurst, 23, Galesburg, Ill., today to death in the electric chair at Tucker Prison farm Aug. 27 for the hitch-hike slaying of Victor A. Gates.

Plans for the extension of the work of the Committee for Indus.trial Organization in the radio maritime industries were discussed yesterday by John. L. Lewis and Mervyn Rathborne, president of the American Radio Telegraphists Association in a two-hour conference at the St. Regis Iiotel.

World lead production, excluding Spain, amounted in May to 158,519 tons, compared with 153,981 in April and 148,659 in March, according to the American Bureau of Metal Statistics. For the first five months of this year, world lead output was 747,288 tons.

Chancellor Samuel P. Capen announced today the appointment of Clarence M. Pierce as Assistant Professor of Public Welfare and Public Administration in the School of Social Work of the University of Buffalo. Mr. Pierce was graduated from the University of Michigan in 1931.

Sales of real estate on the East Side yesterday included a deal for the five-story brick building at 423 East Seventeenth Street, in the Stuyvesant Square section, which was sold by Herman J. Kessler, operator, to a client of Brownstein Brownstein.

Sir George Beharrell, long prominent in transport and industry in the United Kingdom, was appointed today chairman of Imperial Airways to succeed Sir Eric Geddes, who died Tuesday. Sir George is 64 years old and has been managing director of the Dunlop Rubber Company and a director of Imperial Airways.

Harvard's varsity crew rowed to a triumph over Yale by a length and a quarter yesterday on the Thames at New London, Conn., in one of the greatest races their seventy-five-year rivalry on the water has witnessed.

George Kimball Sargent, vice president of the Mutual Life Insurance Company, who was active in the insurance field for more than fifty years, died of coronary thrombosis in his home, Lucas Point, here early tonight after an illness of several months. His age was 64.
A premature Fourth of July demonstration occurred when a fireworks vending stand operated by George White was destroyed by fire.

Discovery of electric currents which shoot out from bright spots on the sun in the form of ionized rays, and flow to the earth carrying enough electricity from a single spot to light the city of Chicago, was reported to the American Association for the Advancement of Science today.

Miss Helen Elizabeth Jones, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Lester Jones of this city, was married to Daniel Geary Lewis, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thornton Lewis, also of South Orange, here this afternoon in the Hillside Presbyterian Church by the pastor, the Rev. Dr. John A. MacSparran.

The Board of Aldermen recognized the growing demand for a fifty per cent reduction in water rates yesterday when its general welfare committee called a public hearing in City Hall for 10:30 o'clock Wednesday morning to fore action on the cut.
Officials of the Inland Steel Company joined today in refusing to accept the Federal- Strike Mediation Board's invitation to a "man-to-man" peace conference.

Irving G. Rudow of 420 Central Park West, president of the B. R. Clothing Company, was convicted yesterday of filing a false State income tax return and conspiracy to violate the tax laws by Justices Bayes, Salomon and Kozicke in Special Sessions Court.

Morgan J. O'Brien, former pre siding justice of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court and prominent Catholic layman, who died on June 16, left his estate in equal shares to his nine children after making bequests to eight charitable and religious institutions. He was 85 years old.

Miss Evelyn H. Wagner, niece of Senator Robert L. Wagner, was married here this afternoon to Kenneth Steinreich. The ceremony was performed in the living room of St. Timothy Farm, the home of former Mayor James J. Walker and Mrs. Walker. The Rev. George C. Moor, pastor of the Madison Avenue Baptist Church in New York, officiated. Seventy guests were present from Long Island and New York.

Paul van Zeeland, Prime Minister of Belgium, in his discussions here is seeking to inform himself thoroughly of the attitude and policies of the United States that he may equip himself the better for conducting his mission in Europe of exploring means of economic appeasement and thereby blazing paths to peace.

John Cacopardo, 27 years old, of 69 East Ninety-eighth Street, Manhattan, who was found guilty of second-degree murder by a jury in the Kings County Court Wednesday, was sentenced yesterday by Judge John J. Fitzgerald to a term of from thirty years to life in prison.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savingss banks in New York State, now offered by dealers:

THOUGH he has been dead hardly more than two years, T. E. Lawrence is already spoken of as a secular saint. People have learned to refer to his exploits in reverent tones. He has been the subject of at least four admiring biographies and at least one long poem (Selden Rodman's "Lawrence: The Last Crusade").

Washington Park's Summer race meeting closes tomorrow with the running of the richest 2-year-old stake of the year to date, the Washington Park Futurity, which will have a gross value of $38,730, provided all nine named in the overnight field go to the post.

Trading in traefa meats was fairly active. All classes were stronger with some steer and fresh pork cuts sharply higher. Early trading in kosher meats was slow with beef and veal prices stronger and lamb about steady, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.

Deputy Joao Mangabeira obtained his freedom from prison today under a habeas corpus petition, which was granted unanimously by the Supreme Military Tribunal. Sentenced two months ago to imprisonment of one year to three years and four months under the National Security Act for sedition, Deputy Mangabeira appealed and then appeared before the tribunal and pleaded that he had been sentenced illegally.

Local police and private guards of the Theurer Wagon Works used clubs to break up a picket line of more than 100 strikers early this morning after they attempted to overturn an automobile that started to enter the plant at Fifteenth Street and Hudson Boulevard. Fourteen of the strikers were injured, one seriously.

Despite reports that seven German warships, which steamed eastward through the Strait of Gibraltar yesterday, were moving on Valencia and that the British Mediterranean fleet had been ordered to Gibraltar, Valencia and Loyalist Spain generally ceased to worry about any developments in the international situation.

The Freeport (L. I.) Tuna Club has made a formal award to Dr. Luther H. Kice of Hempstead for having brought into Freeport the first tuna taken aboard a private boat this season. On Thursday, fishing from his craft, the Ecik, Dr. Kice landed a twenty-two-andone-half-pound tuna.
Felled once again by blistering heat and an even more torrid attack, the Giants began to feel today like something the chef had forgot to take out of the oven.

Seven ships of the Midshipmen's Coastal Cruising Detachment, with 210 second-class midshipmen from Annapolis aboard, stood into New York early yesterday and moored to Piers 72 and 73, North River, for a three-day visit.

Ed Leader, head rowing coach at Yale, complimented the Harvard oarsmen tonight for their fine victory over his varsity crew. "Harvard had a magnificent crew--they were just too good for us," he stated.

Directors of the National Independent Retail Grocers Association threw their support today behind a plan to link 152,000 retail store outlets in a. cooperative movement to help farmers sell bumper food crops.

The marriage of Miss Elizabeth Simpkins Cheney, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Austin Cheney, to Thomas Crowell Taylor Buckley, son of Mrs. Julian Gerard Buckley of Geneseo, N. Y., and the late Mr. Buckley, took place this afternoon at Wedgeway, the home here of the bride's parents. The Rev. Remsen B.
The Red Army by all indications has withstood the shock of the execution of its greatest strategist [Marshal Mikhail N. Tukhachevsky] and seven other generals.

Death penalty convictions were returned against Robert J. Suhay and Glen Applegate, paroled New York convicts, by a jury in Federal district court here tonight for the murder of Wimberly W. Baker, a Federal agent, in a gun battle on April 16.

After two months of trial the policy suggested by President Roosevelt of limiting PWA grants to 115 per cent of the amount paid to workers taken from relief rolls has proved impractical and has been revoked by a new order which restores the system of financing approved projects up to 45 per cent of their cost, with the recommendation, not stipulation, that relief labor be emplayed as and whenever "available."

It is, for many reasons, too bad that ALBERT BIGELOW PAINE has gone from earth, and especially so for the reason that he would have rejoiced to know that something on a large scale was being planned and endowed for the benefit of stutterers and others afflicted with speech and voice disorders. That Dr.

Challen It. Parker, in 160 E 48th St, through Sharp Nassoit; Mrs. M. K. Megargel, in 277 Park Ave, through Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens. Inc.; Robert Thayer, in 819 Madison Ave, through Payson McL. Merrill Co.; Douglas L. Elliman Co., Inc., brokers.

Yachting officials from Baltimore and Chesapeake Bay forming the committees of the Gibson Island ocean race, which starts here Sunday noon, arrived today and set up headquarters in the New London Y. C. on Burr's Dock to inspect the thirty-eight sailing cruises entered in the ocean-going 475 nautical mile fixture.

While a continued heavy flight capital from France pushed down yesterday the franc in the spot and forward markets, strong rumors that a fresh devaluation would be ordered early next week, when the new Finance Minister, Georges Bonnet arrives, caused speculative selling of the exchange for Wednesday delivery and drove it to a discount of 7 or 8 points below the spot rate.

Miss Maxine Bluhm, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Julius Bluhm of the Lombardy and Poland, Me., was married to Charles King, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leon King of this city, yesterday afternoon at Sherry's by the Rev. Dr. Jonah B. Wise.

Heavy rains and shifting winds broke the season's intense heat wave in the Middle West today. Relief came to most of the area from the Rockies to the Great Lakes after twenty-one deaths had been attributed to the sultry weather.

Ray Billows of the Dutchess Country Club, former New York State amateur titleholder, gained the semifinal bracket of the Hudson River Golf Association championship by winning his second and quarterfinal round tests at the Hudson River Country Club today.

Aneroid, winner of the Suburban, Queens County and the Carter Handicaps in the metropolitan area, following a successful campaign in Maryland, will be up against stiffer contention than ever this afternoon in the historic Brooklyn Handicap at Aqueduct.
The second season of operettas at Jones Beach under the aegis of Fortune Gallo and J. J. Shubert opens tonight with the production of "Roberta," which will continue nightly until next Saturday.

A hearing has been called for July 28 by the Securities and Exchange Commission at its Los Angeles offices on an application by the Crystalite Products Corporation, Glendale, Calif., to withdraw its $1-par-value common stock and $7 cumulative preferred stock from registration on the Los Angeles Stock Exchange.

Commodity futures prices moved upward yesterday in the local markets, with sentiment more optimistic than in recent sessions. Cocoa prices broke out of the trading rut and registered gains. In the cash market, wheat, corn, oats, flour, cocoa, lard, tin, rubber, hides and cotton moved ahead. Rye and silk declined.

The city's two newest bathing beaches, at Jacob Riis Park on the ocean in Queens and at Orchard Beach on Long Island Sound in the Bronx, were, opened for the season yesterday without ceremony. The lack of ceremony was due to the fact that both beaches, which have a joint capacity of 500,000 bathers, were in service last year, although without many of their present facilities.

A long step forward in the reorganization and modernizing of the Berkshire -Museum was formally celebrated today with the complete reopening of the institution, which has been partly closed during the last year.

Making amends for his only reverse, sustained yesterday, Samuel Reshevsky of New York, United States chess champion, today won his adjourned game from the seventh round of the international masters' tournament in progress at the Kurhaus. His opponent was A.

Interest was awakened in all circles here today by the publication of a front-page article in the newspaper Aurora, asserting that Argentina had ambitions to gain Chilean territory in the extreme south of the continent, principally Magallanes and Chilean Tierra del Fuego.

Deposits of $10,214,000 of Wisconsin Central Railway first general 4 per cent bonds of 1949, or 48 per cent of the amount outstanding, and $4,627,000 of Wisconsin Central, Superior Duluth division and terminal, first 4 per cent bonds,

General Sessions Judge John J. Freschi, after a hearing, set aside yesterday the conviction last February of Lawrence Scarlione, 31 years old, a waste paper dealer, of criminally receiving about $21,000 in furs, stolen from the Anglo-American Fur Merchants Association.

Mayor La Guardia said yesterday that the Emergency Relief Bureau would be able to take care of dismissed WPA workers if they could qualify for home relief, after the Board of Estimate had authorized $26,474,600 for home relief for the three months ending Sept. 30, 1937.
Of the eighteen Class 1 railroads that have reported for May, fifteen showed increased gross revenues but only six disclosed larger net operating incomes.

Official statistics prepared by the United States Engineers Department show that bulk freight shipments from the Duluth-Superior Harbor from the opening of the navigation season to June 1 of this year were approximately two and one-half times greater than during the corresponding period in 1936.

Sales of copper were made abroad yesterday at the equivalent of 14.125 cents a pound, c. i. f., European base ports, the highest level for the current movement. This compared with a ruling price of 13.80 to 13.90 cents on Thursday, although late that day a few sales of the metal were made at 14.10 cents.

Reports to the Department of Commerce, from representatives at The Hague, indicate that the Netherlands intends to extend to the United States the concessions granted to other "Oslo States" by a multilateral agreement signed May 28, and that the benefits might also be extended to Germany and the United Kingdom.

The recently constructed apartment consisting of two nineteenfamily units at 92-98 Highland Avenue, Jersey City, N. J., has been sold by the Suburban Building Corporation to an investing client of J. I. Kislak, Inc.
Steel mills in Youngstown area resumed operations. More troops and an aircraft force arrived to guard against rumored "invasion." Page 1.
