Frank Bowden, seeded second in the Richmond County open men's singles at the Clifton Tennis Club, Arrochar, Staten Island, was upset in the quarter-final round yesterday by Morris Adelsberg, seeded sixth 4-6. 10-8. 6-2.

Freckles, bay son of Guy Day from the stable of C. D. Robbins, Maplewood, N. J., captured the 3-yearold trot, second day feature of the Penn-Jersey circuit harness meeting today. Freckles provided the fastest heat of the day in taking the second brush in 2:08.

The text of Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain's speech before the House of Commons today follows: I only rise in order to say a few words about one aspect of the foreign policy. It is one which is uppermost in all minds.

Positions at the top of the Engish county cricket championship remain virtually unchanged as the result of the matches concluded yesterday and today. Glamorgan downed Worcestershire by nine wickets and Somerset was beaten by Essex by 161 runs. Lancashire finished with a sixwicket margin over Northamptonshire.

The British and French Governments' proposal to extend their non-intervention patrol of the Spanish coast to cover the gap left by the German-Italian withdrawal will necessitate considerable reinforcement of the British Mediterranean fleet with numbers of small craft from Great Britain.
The Baroness Eva von Blomberg, cousin of former Kaiser Wilhelm, died today after a brief illness at her home in Roxbury.

National Container Corporation $1-par common stock, will be admitted to dealings on the New York Curb Exchange on Tuesday. Simultaneously trading in the common stock of the old company, known as The Natcon Corporation, will be suspended.

An assertion that passage of the administration's Black-Connery Wages and Hours Bill was essential to the maintenance of recovery was made today by Leon Henderson, economic adviser to the WPA and a former director of the National Recovery Administration, before the labor leaders and economists assembled at the Tamiment Social and Economic Institute.

P. W. Litchfield, chairman and president of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, was paid last year $89,500 by that company and its subsidiaries, in addition to 1,000 shares of its common stock, according to a report to the Securities and Exchange Commission.

A nation-wide strike of 800,000 workers in the non-operating departments of the railroads was predicted tonight by George M. Harrison, chairman of the Railway Labor Executives Association, following what he called "a complete breakdown of negotiations" with railway managements over the employes' demand of a wage increase of 20 cents an hour.

Yachts from Miami, Washington, Philadelphia and Chesapeake Bay, from New York, Boston, Marblehead and as far north as Islesboro, Me., yachts from practically every cove and anchorage on the Atlantic and a dozen from such inland harbors as Detroit, Cleveland, Buffalo and Chicago lined the Thames today in the spectator fleet for the Yale-Harvard rowing regatta.

This city was quiet but uneasy tonight after an all-day "invasion" by thousands of miners who left the soft-coal pits of Cambria County to bolster the picket lines re-established this morning at the gates of the huge Bethlehem Steel plant.

Just to show that you never can tell in golf, especially where young devil-may-care juniors are involved, the two players whom everybody picked to meet in the final of the New York State junior championship at the St. Andrew's Golf Club won't be on hand tomorrow unless in the roles of spectators.

Miss Elizabeth McEntee, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George C. McEntee of Glen Ridge as married to Howard Burrell Matthews Jr. of East Orange tonight in the Church of the Incarnation, East Orange. The Rev. Harry L. Everett of Jersey City performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Carolus Webb, the rector.
Albert Tangora of New York defended his championship as the world's fastest typist tonight, but he had to break his own world's record to do so. It was his sixth annual winning of the title.

Defending Champion John Dawson of Chicago played over a rain-swept course today to gain the semi-finals of the trans-Mississippi golf tournament. He defeated a fellow-Chicagoan, Arthur L. Doering, 6 and 4, in a match held up for more than an hour by a downpour which sent players scampering to shelter.

A firm offer to pay at least $6,500,000 for a substantial part of the remaining assets held by the estate of the International Match Corporation has been made by International Match Realization Company, Ltd., of Hamilton, Bermuda, according to a letter addressed to the Irving Trust Company, trustee in bankruptcy for International Match, by John C. Bancroft, president of the Bermuda company.
Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on June 19 amounted to 756,289 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 1,929, or 0.3 per cent,

To Sports Editor of The New York Times: May I step into the box once more to say that I am sure many Giant fans are shocked over the Giants' recent deal with Brooklyn, the exchange of Fitzsimmons for--what?

Permission to appeal the decision granting to the Reconstruction Finance Corporation power to collect under stockholders' liability was granted today to shareholders of the Central Republic Trust Company.

The New York Sun in a statement on its first page yesterday explained that The New York Sun, Inc., identified before the Senate Committee in Washington as a holding company set up by William T. Dewart, publisher of the newspaper, to avoid taxation, was not organized for that purpose.

A complaint in a suit brought by Percy Campbell Reed, owner of the Nassau Kennels in Mineola, L. I., known as the Mineola Dog Track, to enjoin State authorities from interfering with betting at the dog track was filed yesterday in the office of the clerk of the United States District Court in Brooklyn.
The Phillies scored a 10-5 victory over the Pirates today in opening a three-game series, assailing their former teammate, Joe Bowman, for seven runs in the first three innings.
High in the picturesque Litchfield hills the eleventh annual Watertown horse show opened today with 816 entries, the largest number in the history of the exhibition.

Holders of Crane Company 7 per cent preferred stock are notified . that the company will retire all such shares on Sept. 15 at $110 per share and accrued dividends to that date, amounting to $7 per share.

Trapped by the Mackenzie River flood near Aklavik, William Douglas, Arctic trader, and his wife spent two weeks on the sloping roof of their flooded cabin, according to a story related by Pilot Con Farrell today when he returned to Edmonton, after an air mail flight to the Arctic post.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A certain moderation is an essential condition of liberty. This is a theme upon which we in America need to dwell. We live in a moral world. Moral in the sense that individually and in groups we must abide by the choices we make.

Contracts for new buildings in the metropolitan area awarded during the first five months of the year race sharply over those of the corresponding period in 1936, according to the F. W. Dodge Corporation, which attributes the gains chiefly to awards of residential contracts, which up to June 1 of this year advanced 85 per cent over the first five months of last year.

The White Sox ended Washington's five-game winning streak today by scoring a 7-to-6 victory in a long, hard-fought game before 15,000 fans. Wes Ferrell went the route for the Senators and lost his first game since coming from Boston. Chicago used Johnny Whitehead, Sugar Cain and Clint Brown, with Cain getting the victory.

Six persons were slightly injured and traffic was halted for fourteen minutes during the noon hour yesterday on the northbound local track of the Third Avenue elevated when the last two cars of a sevencar train became unhitched and bumped into the rear of the fifth car as the train pulled out of the Forty-seventh Street station.

Can't Nature take a joke? Although the farmers and gardeners last year were threatening to conduct a lie-downon-the-front-porch strike against Nature as a congenial protest against the lack of rain, they did not mean it seriously.

Government charts on the flow of dollars to the farmer's purse showed today an unseasonal decline. Usually the farmer obtains more money in May than in April, but this year cash farm income was $646,000,000 in April and $610,000,000 in May, the Bureau of Agricultural Economics reported.

Twenty-six organized vacation camps on Recreational Demonstration Areas in thirteen States will be ready for use this Summer, and leases on eleven of them have already been executed with organizations which will sponsor vacations in these areas for children of the lower-income groups, Arno B. Cammerer, director of the National Park Service, announced recently.

The Yankees wanted a victory over the Tigers yesterday as speedily and as decisively as possible. So they went out there before 13,788 fans at the Stadium, hit Tommy Bridges early, often and with great gusto, continued against George Gill and buried the Detroiters under an 8-1 score to widen their lead in the American League race to four games.

Fat Freddy Fitzsimmons's third turn as a Dodger starting pitcher today was far from charmed. The superheated Cubs, already envisioning a world series cut, ignored Fitz's two previous victories over the Pirates, knocking him out in the fourth inning. and won. 11-2.

Under the auspices of the Explorers Club and the American-Russian Institute for Cultural Relations, the three Soviet transpolar fliers, Valeri Chkaloff,.Georgi Baidukoff and Alexander Beliakoff, will be honored at. a dinner to be held next Wednesday evening at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Mary Maglione, 10-year-old schoolgirl, of 796 East 161st Street, the Bronx, who was attacked June 16 in a Bronx theatre and locked in a sub-orchestra tunnel for twenty hours, died early yesterday morning at Lincoln Hospital as a result of her injuries.
Three people were crushed and burned to death when a huge redwood tree toppled onto their automobile fifty-five miles south of Eureka last night.

The War Department released the following orders today dated June 24: BRIGADIER GENERAL De Witt, W., Assistant to the Surgeon General, 2 months leave, July 10. LIEUTENANT COLONELS Camp, T. J., Inf., General Staff Corps, 2 days leave, June 27.

Airplanes from the British cruisers Ajax and Exeter circled over Trinidad tonight, dropping copies of Governor Sir A. G. M. Fletcher's appeal to workers to end the strikes that have disrupted island business and caused fourteen deaths since Saturday.

Yesterday the Japanese Ambassador, SHIGERU KAWAGOE, left Tokyo for Nanking under instructions to try with a policy of "patience" to break the deadlock in Sino-Japanese relations. Unofficially, his Government has indicated that it is prepared to make many and important concessions if China will recognize Manchukuo.

Twenty-six organized vacation camps on Recreational Demonstration Areas in thirteen States will be ready for use this Summer, and leases on eleven of them have already been executed with organizations which will sponsor vacations in these areas for children of the lower-income groups, Arno B. Cammerer, director of the National Park Service, announced recently.

The Yankees wanted a victory over the Tigers yesterday as speedily and as decisively as possible. So they went out there before 13,788 fans at the Stadium, hit Tommy Bridges early, often and with great gusto, continued against George Gill and buried the Detroiters under an 8-1 score to widen their lead in the American League race to four games.

Fat Freddy Fitzsimmons's third turn as a Dodger starting pitcher today was far from charmed. The superheated Cubs, already envisioning a world series cut, ignored Fitz's two previous victories over the Pirates, knocking him out in the fourth inning. and won. 11-2.

The War Department released the following orders today dated June 24: BRIGADIER GENERAL De Witt, W., Assistant to the Surgeon General, 2 months leave, July 10. LIEUTENANT COLONELS Camp, T. J., Inf., General Staff Corps, 2 days leave, June 27.

Under the auspices of the Explorers Club and the American-Russian Institute for Cultural Relations, the three Soviet transpolar fliers, Valeri Chkaloff,.Georgi Baidukoff and Alexander Beliakoff, will be honored at. a dinner to be held next Wednesday evening at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Airplanes from the British cruisers Ajax and Exeter circled over Trinidad tonight, dropping copies of Governor Sir A. G. M. Fletcher's appeal to workers to end the strikes that have disrupted island business and caused fourteen deaths since Saturday.

Valentim F. Boucas, a member of the Brazilian Mission headed by Arthur Souza Costa, Minister of Finance of Brazil, began conversations here yesterday with J. Reuben Clark Jr., representing the Foreign Bondholders Protective Council, Inc., regarding the service upon Brazilian dollar bonds after the expiration next March of the Aranha Plan which is now in operation. Negotiations yesterday were merely preliminary.

Bonds resumed a downward course yesterday in trading on the New York Stock Exchange, but there was no material increase in turnover. High-grade investment issues, as well as secondary obligations, participated in the broad decline which was reflected in the combined price average for domestic corporation bonds by a drop of 0.34 point.

The spectacle of the Yale-Harvard regatta is one that never palls, a stirring picture of dazzling beauty which never fails to bring a catch to the throat of the oldest racegoer. And when the sleek white yachts are jammed on the river the way they were today the sight is absolutely breathtaking.

Hearings will begin next Wednesday by the grievance committee of the Popular Price Dress Manufacturers Group on charges filed against manufacturer members, alleging violations of the fair trade practice rules of the Dress Returns Control Bureau, it was announced yesterday by Louis Rubin, executive director of the group.

Mary Maglione, 10-year-old schoolgirl, of 796 East 161st Street, the Bronx, who was attacked June 16 in a Bronx theatre and locked in a sub-orchestra tunnel for twenty hours, died early yesterday morning at Lincoln Hospital as a result of her injuries.
Three people were crushed and burned to death when a huge redwood tree toppled onto their automobile fifty-five miles south of Eureka last night.

Playing at a whirlwind pace throughout, young Frank Strafaci, national public links ruler in 1935, came within two strokes of the course record to take medal honors today in the annual invitation golf tournament at the Briar Hills Golf and Country Club.

Chester C. Davis, a member of the Federal Reserve Board, gave to bankers today a broad hint that the public may demand government ownership and operation of banking in the event of another bank crisis.

The Republic Steel Corporation, in a demurrer filed in the Federal District Court for the District of Columbia, suggested today that the Postoffice Department was under the dictation of the Committee for Industrial Organization.

In two of the longest and most nerveracking semi-finals the tournament has witnessed in years, Ernest Sutter of Tulane, the defending titleholder, and Gerin Cameron of Tulsa University, a comparative unknown, gained the final round of the national intercollegiate tennis championship today at the Merion Cricket Club.

A reception for which 2,000 invitations were issued marked the reopening tonight of the Berkshire Museum. In the fifteen months the museum had been closed, there was added an auditorium and a room in memory of Mrs. Ellen J. Crane, the gift of her daughter, Mrs. Samuel Gilbert Colt of Pittsfield, and her son, the late Zenas Marshall Crane of Dalton.

Randalls Island Stadium will be the scene of an all-sports carnival today. The Metropolitan Association A. A. U. has arranged a program which will bring more than 800 athletes into competition in twelve different activities. The carnival embraces every spot on the local A. A. U. roster except swimming.

Movemente of vessels follow, all dates are June 24 uni less specified: San Juan to Guantanamo Bay, June 25: Badger, Decatur, Dickerson, Herbert, Leary, Tattnall, Tillman. San Pedro to San Francisco: California, Idaho, Nevada, New Mexico, Tennessee. At New York, June 25: Claxton, Erie, Fairfax. Manley. Roper, J. F. Talbott.

While civilian and navy aviation experts watched apprehensively from the ground, James B. (Jimmy) Taylor, ace test pilot, put a prospective fighting plane through a crucial power dive of 15,000 feet this afternoon at a speed estimated to have been between 500 and 600 miles an hour.

The New Jersey Municipal Finance Commission announced today completion of its refinancing plan for the Township of Chester, Burlington County. The municipality's affairs have been handled by the commission since March, 1933.

Fewer and better books in each year's literary harvest were advocated yesterday by Clarence W. Sherman of Providence, R. I., before the convention of the American Library Association, for an American audience designated by Charles W. Ferguson of The Reader's Digest in an earlier address as history's most numerous and most discerning reading public.
Miss Marta Cunningham, founder and secretary of the Not Forgotten Association, that cares for tens of thousands of British veterans wounded in the World War, died here today of a stroke.

169TH ST, (11-2961), n s, 157 ft e of Boston Rd, 108x98; Leader Property Corp to Melrose Central Corp, 260 E 161st St; mtg $40.000. PAINE ST, 2,956 (18-5336); Domenick Petta to Michelina Brancati, 150 Davis Ave. 172D ST (14-3771), s s, 52 ft w of Wheeler Ave. 29x109; William G. Ross, referee, to Williamson M. Vreeland, trustee, 180 Mercer St. Princeton. N TJ.

The Works Progress Administration in this city must cut 34,000 persons from its rolls by Oct. 15, but absorption of some workers by regular city departments and the normal departure of others into private industry will make unnecessary any considerable number of forced separations after dismissal notices are distributed to 11,800 WPA workers on Wednesday, Lieut. Col Brehon B. Somervell,

The National Socialist State took a new tack today in its drive to coordinate the Catholic Church when in open court it accused Dr. Ludwig Sebastian, Bishop of Speyer, of treason against the State and a continuous breach of the concordat because he transmitted reports about German domestic conditions to "a hostile foreign power"-the Vatican-and also sent his pastoral letters to friends in the United States.

The Reds, specializing in extra base blows, scored a 6-to-2 victory over the Bees today to register their sixth triumph in the nine games that the veteran Chick Hafey has patrolled center field as a regular.
Joseph Jerome, last surviving member ?? the G. A. R. of Coxsackie, died ?? his home in Coxsackie last night ?? his eighty-ninth year. He was a member of the G. A. R. there for sixty years.

Reports from the Canadian Northwest that the area suffering from drought was rapidly extending and less favorable comment on the European political situation combined today to send wheat futures soaring.

At the First Church in Chestnut Hill, Miss Ellen Edwards Kennedy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Edwards Kennedy of Chestnut Hill, was married today to Endicott Peabody Saltonstall, son of Mrs. Endicott Peabody Saltonstall. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Edwin Oliver Kennedy of Madison, Wis., a cousin of the bride.

A committee representing Cuban holders of the republic public works bond issue urged today that President Federico Laredo Bru of Cuba take steps to settle this obligation, in default since 1933, as a means of restoring the island's credit and furthering its economic development.

The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow: "There is hardly any wool or wool byproducts moving out of the Boston wool market in consequence of the strike of the wool handlers in the lofts, with whom the longshoremen's union is cooperating to the extent of tying up wool shipments at other ports, as well.

Weaknesses in many of the leading railway issues, and profit-taking in the steels and metal shares, sent the stock market to an irregularly lower closing. Prices were generally firm in the early trading.

The magic that lies-or does not lie-in a putter made all the difference to the finalists in the Women's Long Island Golf Association championship today. In both morning and afternoon rounds Mrs. Sylva Annenberg, the winner by a 4 and 3 margin, was holing short putts, medium ones and long ones while Mrs. Marion Turpie, the three-time victor and defeated champion, found the tricky greens of the Women's National course a putting nuzzle.

J. W. Eiss of 509 Fifth Avenue, New York, has agreed with the Federal Trade Commission to stop asserting that his "Crucifix Wondrous Luck Ring" is a jewel or set with a jewel and to cease claiming, by inference or otherwise, that the ring will bring to the wearer luck or happiness, the commission announced today.
Tom M. Girdler, chairman of the board of the Republic Corporation, reiterated today his declaration that he would not sign a contract with the C. I. O.
Two Americans who had been detained for questioning during an intensive espionage round-up in Catalonia were released today. Four others were held for further questioning.

Condemning a "very few large corporations" for "fighting labor and labor's right to organize" in the current industrial strife, United States Senator Robert F. Wagner, sponsor of the National Labor Relations Act, declared last night that the machinery of the act provided the means for restoring the combatants in the steel cities to "the ways of peace."

The Federal Bureau of Investigation today broadcast 50,000 circulars carrying five hazy snapshots of Mrs. William H. Parsons, mysteriously missing from her Long Island farm home for sixteen days, and asking for "information as to her whereabouts."

The real significance of the Roxy's "Riding on Air," quite apart from its modest contribution to mirth and laughter, is that it has given us hoof and mouth experts an opportunity to decide whether Joe E. Brown still holds the "biggest mouth" title or has lost it to challenger Martha Raye.

Richard J. Daly, an "investment counselor" whose clients allegedly have lost $160,000 since the first of the year, was held for the grand jury today by County Judge Gerald Nolan on a charge of first-degree grand larceny. He made no application for bail and was remanded to the Westchester County jail at Eastview. His home is in New Rochelle and his office here.

Arthur Curtiss James, chairman of the Western Pacific Railroad, is a passenger today on the Cunard White Star liner Franconia, sailing for the North Cape and Russia. Others on board are the Princess Miguel de Braganca, Philip Moeller, Dr. and Mrs. Nathan Beers, Mrs. Charles E. Coxe, Miss Katherine G. Davenport, Mr. and Mrs. Clinton S. Dow, Mrs. Ralph Morgan and Alexander Gordon.
A romance which began on University of Tennessee campus twentyone years ago culminated in an $80,000 award today in the State Court of Appeals.

Fighting one of the greatest uphill battles of his career, Bryan M. (Bitsy) Grant of Atlanta today dropped the first two sets of his match with Alan Stedman, young New Zealand Davis Cup star, then, by sheer determination, forced his injured ankle to carry him through the three additional sets required to bring him to victory and the quarter-finals of the Wimbledon singles. The score was 4-6, 6-8, 6-1. 6-4. 6-3.

THE Detroit Tigers aren't quite the same without G. Stanley (Mickey Himself) Cochrane leading the parade. Cy Perkins said: "They're going to let Mike sit up today. I just got word. Isn't that great?" No, it's pitiful. Black Mike, the perfect athlete, a live wire, a bundle of energy-and poor Cy, his pal, thought it was "great" that the medical caretakers were going to allow him to sit up.

Admiral Sir William Fisher--"Big Bill Fisher of Portsmouth' '-who was the last man to shake the Duke of Windsor's hand as the former King stepped aboard the destroyer Fury on the night of his abdication, is dead at the age of 62.

THE ever-widening network of international airlines, bringing with it the further need for long flights, non-stop over both land and water, has turned the attention of aircraft designers to the development of long range types.

His Elegance, owned by Mrs. Bernard F. Gimbel of Port Chester and ridden throughout the show by her daughter, Miss Hope, won the championship hunter trophy at the annual Ox Ridge Hunt Club show this afternoon, in the concluding class of the two days' judging.

An operating program providing for the immediate selection of 53,995 young men and veterans as replacements for the Civilian Conservation Corps next month was approved today by James J. McEntee, acting director, following approval by Congress of the plan to extend the life of the CCC for three years.
The Women's Press Club, sponsoring a movement to erect a Eugene Field memorial in Lever's Lane, has set up a special division for a drive in all universities and colleges to obtain funds.

Miss Catherine Boudinot Stimson Dominick, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Francis Dominick, was married this afternoon to Alexander Guthrie Walcott, son of former United States Senator Frederick C. Walcott of Norfolk, Conn., and the late Mrs. Walcott, at the home of the bride's parents in Stanwich Road here.

So far as Senator McNary of Oregon is concerned, President Roosevelt started a charm school this weekend at Jefferson Islands. That was what the Republican leader called the gathering of Democrats, adding that the President hoped "to wheedle out of Congress some more action of his personal brand."

After the metallic clangor of the city the countryside seems quiet. To many city people on vacation the silence of the country is distracting at first; it rings in their eardrums like a preternatural void at night and is disturbing to nerves accustomed to rumble.

The Treasury's "disclosures" during the past week made to the joint Congressional committee on tax evasion and avoidance were principally confined to so-called personal holding companies. From the record produced the cases "selected purely at random" were certainly not, as a whole, typical examples of corporations availed of for the purpose of tax avoidance.

The United Electrical and Radio Workers of America, C. I. O. affiliate, announced yesterday that it had begun negotiations, through its locals at Schenectady, Glens Falls and Gloversville, N. Y., with the New York Power and Light Company, subsidiary of the NiagaraHudson Power Company.
The University of Goettingen's 200th anniversary ceremonies have turned out to be an almost entirely National Socialist affair tinctured with neopaganism.

Mr. and Mrs. Gillespie Sadler of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ida Moore Sadler, to Daniel O'Day, son of Mrs. Daniel O'Day of Rye, N. Y., and Washington and the late Mr. O'Day.

Magistrate W. Overton Harris made a start yesterday toward improving conditions in the Department of Correction. He was particularly annoyed about the devious route taken by the driver of the prison van and about delays at Jefferson Market prison for women.

MARINE PARKWAY BRIDGE, spanning Rockaway Inlet at the mouth of Jamaica Bay, will be the lifeline of Jacob Riis Park, the first major oceanfront development in the City of New York designed primarily for the benefit of motorists. It is scheduled to open next Saturday at 2 P. M.

The Mediterranean situation is still viewed with some anxiety in London, not because any immediate danger is threatened, but by reason of the general uncertainty that leaves the ships of any naval power there at the mercy of an "incident."

Behind St. Matthew's Church at 215 West Sixty-eighth Street there is a small garden. Yesterday the Catholic Youth Organization revealed that gardening classes have been conducted there for the last four years.
Governor Davey told labor men Miss Perkins asked him to hold Girdler and Purnell till they signed with C. I. O. In Washington Miss Perkins denied urging such action. Page 1.

Smiling faces of company executives and returning workers, worried looks from C. I. O. leaders and ugly words from strikers told the story of the fast-growing back-to-work movement today at local mills of the Republic Steel Corporation and the Youngstown Sheet and. Tube Company.

GOING INTO JULY--The following is the list of attractions, both new and revived, which will be shown this week in the Summer theatres. Unless otherwise noted, first performances will be tomorrow evening: New York "Retreat From Folly" (American premiere), by Amy Kennedy Gould and Eileen Russell, with Margaret Anglin-Westchester Playhouse, Mount Kisco.

A SET of regulations that may be an opening wedge for the Federal regulation of all motor highway traffic goes into effect on Friday. Entitled "Rules and Regulations Governing Qualifications of Employes and Safety of Operation and Equipment of Common Carriers and Contract Carriers by Motor Vehicle," these rules, handed down by the Interstate Commerce Commission, make up the most comprehensive code governing traffic on our highways.

Miss Dorothy Morehouse, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lyman F. Morehouse of London, formerly of Montclair, was married to William C. Chrisman of New York, son of Robert H. Chrisman of Berea, Ky., and Mrs. Laura E. Chrisman

Akira Ariyoshi, former Japanese Ambassador to Brazil and to China, died here yesterday of a stomach disorder. He was 60 years old. Mr. Ariyoshi was the first Japanese envoy to China to hold the rank of Ambassador. While he was minister to the Nanking government in 1935, Japan raised the legation there to the status of an embassy as a gesture to win Chinese friendship.
CZECH FUEHRER: The Germans of Czechoslovakia--they number about 3,500,000 in a population of 15,000,000--form a minority which Konrad Henlein, a former bank

A timely easterly came to the aid of the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club's sixty-fifth annual regatta, sixth in the Yacht Racing Association championship series today, after light, variable airs punctuated by two periods of flat calm all but ruined it.

An innings of 102, not out, compiled by R. A. Wiles featured the Brooklyn Cricket Club's victory over Staten Island in the annual championship competition of the New York and Metropolitan District Association at Livingston yesterday. Brooklyn made 160 for the loss of five wickets in reply to Staten Island's 92.

THE University of Pennsylvania Press is preparing to publish 100 hitherto unpublished American plays edited by outstanding authorities in the dramatic field. Many of these plays have been regarded as lost, but diligent search has brought them to light.

THE Third Maggio Musicale Fiorentino, n?? closing the six weeks of its comprehensive program, may be rated an unqualified success. Tribute for this is due Mario Labroca and his collaborators, celebrated or obscure. This festival has, by common con sent, long outdistanced even the first "Maggio" of 1933.
What will be the end of the purge now being administered so violently in every department of Soviet life? Is this new order at last collapsing after twenty years of painful and sacrificial building?
The special trot of the Nassau Driving Club, in which Mr. and Mrs. C. N. Bliss and Mr. and Mrs. Dunbar Bostwick were the competing drivers, featured the racing today at the Fair Grounds.

Not to be outdone by the Borough of Queens, which recently put on civic celebrations to mark the opening of new sections of the city's Independent Subway, the Bronx will stage its own demonstration Wednesday, at 4 P. M., when the new escalator at the 205th Street station of the Bronx Concourse line is placed in operation.
Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Helen Dery, daughter of D. G. Dery of Catasauqua, Pa., to Carl Ferdinand Strauch of Allentown.

Richard Ganslen, Columbia University junior, stole the spotlight from Glenn Cunningham, world famous miler, at the New Jersey A. A. U. senior track and field championships today. Ganslen, defending his title in two events, came through handsomely in each to carry off the individual honors.

Miss Diantha Birdsall Schmid, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis G. Schmid, was married here this afternoon in Christ Church to George Northrop Melinette, son of Mr. and Mrs. John A. Melinette of Brooklyn.

LIEUTENANTS--From precincts indicated to 19th Division, office of the chief inspector, for 15 days, from 8 A. M., July 1: Thomas P. Browne, 46th Precinct; Daniel Gallagher, 62d Precinct. SERGEANTS--Richard R. Siegert Jr., from 1st Precinct to 6th Division, assigned to clerical duty, for 15 days, from 8 A. M., July 1.
Miss Dorsey Bruen was wed here today to John Courtney Ivey of New York, formerly of Americus. The Rev. Ernest Risley performed the ceremony in St. John's Episcopal Church.

Four contracts for part of a coal order totaling $835,000 which Philadelphia is placing for the coming year were signed today by Mayor S. Davis Wilson in the presence of a delegation of public officials, union and civic leaders from the anthracite region.
HAMLET the Dane, as played by H John Barrymore in the first of a Monday-night series of Shakespearean broadcasts, stalked a through an electrically infested air over the New York area.

Aircraft production in the United States during the first quarter of the current year increased 25 per cent over the corresponding period last year, with 571 units produced, compared to 456 in the same period last year, the Department of Commerce reported today.
Although the snow may be perilously poised, it has not yet begun to move. If we can all exercise caution, patience and self-restraint, we may yet be able to save the peace of the world.

Joseph A. Campagna, son of Anthony Campagna, the well-known New York builder, is completing in partnership wih his uncle, Anthony A. Paterno, two residences in the selling class just above the $20,000 class at Shippan Point, near Stamford, Conn.

The marriage of Miss Irene Geoghegan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. F. Geoghegan of this place, to Gerard A. Schultz, son of Mr. and Mrs. H. J. Schultz of Larchmont and Brooklyn, took place this morning in the Holy Family Church here.

The Senate Appropriations Committee raised to $125,518,729 today the amount Congress will be asked to vote for the use of the Interior Department in 1938, an increase of $2,517,425 over the total the House had written into the Supply Bill.

(Figures in parentheses indicate par) Arrowbrook (70)-Second round for President's Trophy: Harry Feldman defeated P. Scharf, 3 and 2; Harry Gray defeated H. Milchman, 3 and 1; Herman Yorks defeated Mark Snith. 2 and 1; Al Schanzer and I. Diamond finished all even.

THE yardstick by which radio stations are judged is the phrase in the law which stipulates that to qualify as broadcasters they must serve "public interest, convenience and necessity," Judge E. O. Sykes, Federal Communications Commissioner, told the National Association of Broadcasters in convention during the past week at Chicago. It is the criterion, he said, set up in the law for the issuance and renewal of licenses.

A sermon by the Rev. Arthur Howe, '08, president of Hampton Institute, will mark the beginning of the commencement program of the Hotchkiss School here tomorrow. In the evening, following supper in the school dining room, guests will be invited to the headmaster's house for coffee and music.

Asserting there is apparently no slackening in the steadily rising demand for petroleum products, The Lamp, official organ of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, in its current issue estimates that gasoline consumption this year will be nearly 10 per cent more than in 1936, when it rose more than 10 per cent over 1935.

The Federated Garden Clubs open their series of discussions and demonstrations of "The Arrangement of Flowers" tomorrow morning at 11 o'clock in the Woman's Club, 36 Old Mill Road, Great Neck, L. I. Questions of design and color organization will relate to the practices in different periods and countries, and the first lecture will be on "Inspiration from the Greeks."

All is quiet on the Huesca front, and from present appearances, barring an unexpected Rebel attack, it will remain so for the near future. The operation the Loyalists launched around Huesca last week is now over, and as always in this war it has been possible to get a clear idea of what happened only by visiting the scene of action.

MICHAEL FOSTER has written a warm and lovely and searching book about three generations of American life. In them he is looking for the American dream-that spirit. that way of life which evolved out of a land originally peopled by the discontented spiritual and political exiles of the world.

THE July 4 week-end will see in full swing the annual trek of campers to government owned recreation areas. The advance guard of Eastern city dwellers is already moving into State and Federal parks and forests from Maine to Virginia, pitching tents by picturesque lake
Miss Florence Bell Green, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Bell Green of New York, was married here this afternoon in the garden of Benton, the estate of her aunt, Mrs. David C. Sands,

BOLTON LANDING, N. Y.--At a recent meeting of the horse show committee for the fourth annual Sagamore horse show to be held on Aug. 6, 7 and 8 at the horse show ring on Green Island, Arthur H. Bradley was elected president, Karl P. Abbott vice president and David W. Roberts of Hartford, Conn., chairman. Mrs. Frank M. King Jr. is secretary and Harry Little treasurer.

As charges of reckless and irresponsible behavior are laid at the door of Committee for Industrial Organization affiliates, the leaders of the new unions in the basic industries find themselves compelled to take stock of their groups in order to bring about a necessary discipline that seems to be lacking during the present state of organization activity.

Police were searching through a maze of labor troubles today in an effort to find a clue to the murder of Robert A. Shields, 54 years old, financial secretary of Local 184 of the Painters Union, who was shot to death Friday night as he came in from an alley to a garage in the rear of his home on the Southwest Side here.

Miss ary Alicia Nickerson, daughter of Er. and Mrs. John Nickerson of lis place, was married here this Eternoon to Walton Campbell ment, son of James M. Ament of Tilmerding, Pa., and the late Mrs. ment, in St. Luke's Church.

A research scholarship for studying the spiritual and educational background of Franklin and Marshall College has been awarded to Professor Frederic S. Klein of the Department of History at F. and M., through the Nehry Janssen Foundation of Reading.

Refusal of Democratic leaders to accept Senator Robert F. Wagner's decision not to run for Mayor as final, stalling of the movement to oust James J. Dooling as leader of Tammany, and widening of the cleavage between Republicans who support Mayor La Guardia for renomination on their party ticket and those opposed to him have been the most marked developments in the local political situation during the past week.

The marriage of Miss Dorothy Barbara Monaghan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eugehe A. Monahan of New York, to James Francis Keleher, son of Mr. and Mrs. D. Keleher also of this city, took place yesterday morning in the Church of Our Lady of Lourdes.

Third-quarter freight carloadings this year are expected to be about 7.9 per cent above those for the same 1936 quarter, according to estimates of the thirteen shippers' regional advisory boards. Loadings of the twenty-nine principal commodities are set at 6,539,536 cars, against 6,058,269 actual cars in the third quarter of 1936.

AGAIN Superintendent Hanslet of Scotland Yard is puzzled and this time with good reason. Sir Andrew Wiggenhall, chairman of the board of Hardware, Ltd., is killed in his own home by an explosion which shakes the entire suburb in which he lived.

In a close finish, Stanley Ogilvy's Jay of the New Rochelle Yacht Club, today took the first of the International Star Class championship races here. Jay crossed the line one second ahead of Charles Rollins's Perseverance.

An American machine-loomed rug, claimed as an entirely new idea in floor decoration through combining the features of carpet and rug, has been produced by the A. M. Karagheusian, Inc., rug mills and shipped to France where it will be placed on display in the American Pavilion of the Paris Exposition.

Thousands of Bethlehem Steel employes went back to work at the Cambria plant today and the strike leadership of the Committee for Industrial Organization here, facing a crisis, called an outdoor rally for tomorrow afternoon which is expected to be attended by miners from all over the country.

Five Summer camps operated by the Young Women's Christian Association of this city for schoolgirls and young employed women will open this week. Quannacut junior camp for grade school girls and Quannacut senior camp for high school girls at Pine Brush, N. Y., will open Thursday.
A "cooperative industrial commonwealth" was predicted at today's session of the World Presbyterian Alliance as the fulfillment of the world's only hope for "the realization of human rights."

ROME.--When Italian workers recently received a wage increase of 10 to 12 per cent in recognition of the rise in the cost of living, the decision took the form of a resolution of the Central Corporative Committee.

Helen B. Storm and Cornelia V. Storm, twins, of Fishkill, celebrated their eighty-third birthday together yesterday at a family party, featured by three birthday cakes. Hale and hearty and very active despite their age, the twins admitted they had a "swell time."
Miss Beulah Bailey, chief of the research staff of the State Department of Taxation and Finance, was married here today to George E. Thull of Utica in the parish house of St.
THE round-up of actors to play in the Shakespearean cycle opening July 12 on WABC and more than ninety stations is almost complete, with Hollywood film lots the center of activity.

Duplicating the success of his brother, Clifford, Ernest Sutter of Tulane won the national intercollegiate tennis championship for the second time today. In a hopelessly one-sided match that was a disappointing conclusion to a week of exceptionally fine tennis, the stalwart defending titleholder scored a crushing victory over Gerin Cameron of Tulsa University, 6--2, 6--2, 6--2.

Judge John Wood Fishburne, member of the Seventy-second Congress, died yesterday at his home here. He was 70 years old. He was a native of Albemarle County, son of the late Daniel and Elizabeth Wood Fishburne. He obtained his preparatory education at Pantops School, near Monticello, and later attended Washington and Lee University and the University of Virginia, following which he taught at Fishburne Military School at Waynesboro.

In the daily records of various real estate activities, there occasionally appears the name of a partially forgotten thoroughfare, and which, perhaps, to a large proportion of the residents on Manhattan Island is wholly unknown.

AN exhibition entitled "The Art and Technique of Ceramics" has just been opened at the Brooklyn Museum. It is presented by the Rockefeller internes of the museum, who have also prepared a well-illustrated handbook, which is in effect a brief survey of the three major stages in the advancement of ceramic art.

Columbia University announced yesterday a gain of 60 per cent over last year in its Summer course enrollment. Thus far, 1,016 students have registered for these courses, given in June and July, compared with 632 a year ago.

Growing confidence in the stabilization of Chinese currency has brought new life to the Shanghai Stock Exchange. Money is returning in large volume from Europe and the United States, whither it was sped by the ruinous American silver purchase policy, and share transactions are climbing once more.

GOVERNORS ISLAND Each of the following reserve officers is ordered to active'duty, effective July 1, at Plattsburg Barracks, N. Y., for training with C.M.T.C. These officers are assigned or attached to the 392d Infantry. Each will revert to inactive status July 14: Col. Floyd D. McLean, Inf.-Res., 12 Millard Ave., Binghamton, N. Y.

THE greatest of biographies was written by an observer of intimacies who, day by day and year by year, trailed his man. The present volume, irresistible as the Life of Johnson, is synthetic Boswell, the composite vision of a great cloud of witnesses to the most wayward and complex genius of moderrr times.

The quadrennial convention of the Ladies Catholic Benevolent Association will open on July 13 at 10 A. M. with a high mass in St. Nicholas Church, here, according to plans completed at a recent meeting of the board of trustees, it was announced today.

Earl Baldwin has been joined in retirement on fashionable Eaton Square by Rene de Marees-van Swinderen, Netherland Minister to the Court of St. James, who is retiring after twenty-four years of service.

There may be only one "Battle of the Century," but the magic of another Dizzy Dean-Carl Hubbell duel will attract a near-record crowd to Sportsman's Park tomorrow, when the Cardinals and Giants close their three-game series.

The new international crisis growing out of the Spanish civil war finds Berlin and Rome coordinating their diplomacy and their naval strategy. In the following dispatches from the two capitals some of the political aspects of the common front are presented.

The failure of the National Guard teams of New Jersey and Delaware to appear at Camp Smith today to compete against the New York State National Guard in the annual interstate pistol match resulted in two New York quartets competing to determine the entries to shoot against the Organized Reserve team in the Thatcher P. Lugger match that followed.
Members of the New York State Labor Relations Board whose appointment was announced by Governor Lehman on Friday met yesterday at the home of the Governor, 820 Park Avenue, to discuss their duties.

Average daily sales of chain drug stores in May were 5.7 per cent higher than in May, 1936, including allowances for seasonal variation, according to preliminary reports made public today by the Department of Commerce.
A marked increase in Manhattan real estate sales activity for the first five months of the present year over the similar period of 1936 is reported by the Real Estate Board of New York.

After one of the hardest-fought finals in the four-year history of the tournament, slender Charley Pettijohn Jr. of the Green Meadow Club won the New York State junior crown by defeating Raymond Korndorfer of the near-by Scarsdale Club today.

MEN and women march back and forth before the gates of scores of mills dotting the country. Singly or in clusters, they argue with those seeking to enter upon cornpany property. Sometimes they sing and laugh and may appear to the casual observer to be a good-natured crowd out for a lark.

Charles A. Flanagan, retired circulation manager of THE NEW YORK TIMES, died of cirrhosis of the liver yesterday morning in the Eye Institute of the Presbyterian Hospital. His age was 63. He was circulation manager for twentyseven years and was with THE TIMES forty-four years.

Many smaller stores that have been conducting August sales of fur-trimmed coats in recent years are modifying their promotions or discarding the events entirely, according to a canvass made by the Industrial Council of Cloak, Suit and Skirt Manufacturers, Inc.

Proponents of municipal government reform in Philadelphia were cheered this week as the State Supreme Court opened the way for speedy consolidation of the city and county by means of a constitutional amendment.

Racing--Seabiscuit defeated the favored Aneroid by a nose in the $25,025 Brooklyn Handicap at Aqueduct as 18,000 looked on. Regal Lily won the Gazelle and Maetall the Great American Stakes at the same track.

The Audwill Stable's chestnut gelding Golden Brew climaxed two days of consistent jumping performances by winning the Professional Horseman's Association Challenge Cup at the eleventh annual Watertown horse show today. Ridden by Mickey Walsh, the Southborough, Mass., entry of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Kennedy ran his string of blues to six in taking the award over Mrs. Gordon Wright's bay gelding Sonny.

Miss Patricia Cumming of Westfield, defending champion, advanced a round ahead of the field into the fourth round of the Anne Cumming Memorial tennis tournament, the New Jersey State championship for girls, at the Westfield Tennis Club.

Rapid price fluctuations and a somewhat lower range of prices featured trading in wheat futures today. While there was little change in the general character of the news, with no rain reported in the dry sections in the Canadian Northwest, heavy profittaking appeared in the American markets and wheat closed on the Board of Trade here with net losses of 5/8 to 7/8 cent a bushel.

Under renewed selling pressure, the stock market closed lower yesterday in the third slowest trading session of the year. The turnover aggregated 288,000 shares, compared with 220,000 shares on the previous Saturday.
Missouri is infested with "one-arm bandits," and Attorney General McKittrick has declared open war on them.

The garden at the home of Mrs. Sidell Tilghman of Madison was the scene of the marriage this afternoon of Mrs. Tilghman's daughter, Miss Leonie Tilghman, to Horace Hutchins Work Jr., son of Mrs. Horace H. Work, also of this place. Mgr. John J. Dauenhauer, pastor of St. Vincent's Church, performed the ceremony.
Miss Ruth Frances Simon, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. R. Francis Taylor, was married this evening to William Howard Gluck of New York at the Bellevue-Stratford by Dr. Louis Woolsey.

Dr. H. H. Kung, Vice President of the Chinese Executive Yuan and Minister of Finance, seated in his suite in the Waldorf-Astoria, discussed yesterday the purpose of his visit to this country and the significance for the rest of the world of China's plans for industrial and economic development.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J. -- Summer cottages are being opened, hotels and boarding houses are refurbished, fishing boats are newly painted, golf courses are in shape, amusement places have elaborate billings and the full force of lifeguards is on duty-all is ready for the Fourth of July influx of visitors.

The Richard Wagner Society announces a contest for an English translation of a scene from Wagner's music- drama "Siegfried." Prizes of $150, $100 and $50 will be awarded for the best three manuscripts submitted before Dec. 31, 1937.

The successful flight of Soviet airmen from Moscow to Vancouver, Wash., although they made no stop on Canadian soil, was a matter of rejoicing to Canadian air officials and all others interested in the future of flying in this Dominion. It confirmed their opinion that Canada is the hub from which will radiate the principal international air routes of the world-north and south, east and west.

During 1936 the Finance Department's division of inspections rejected 2,443,567 pounds of foodstuffs bought for use in city institutions, that were found to be below standard, Controller Frank J. Taylor reported yesterday.

TRAVELERS in Manchukuo who gaze at the sights of the new State from the car windows of the streamlined Asia Limited are passengers of a historymaking organization, the South Manchurian Railway, ceded by Russia to Japan after the RussoJapanese War.

Frank A. Rexford awards were received by 298 high school students at recent commencements here, the Cooperation in Government, Inc., donors of the awards, announced yesterday. In each of the city high schools one medal and several diplomas were given.

Mrs. Agnes Deane Fry, 40 years old, of Riverside Avenue, Westport, Conn., widow of Commander George Gardiner Fry, United States Navy, retired, committed suicide last night by firing a revolver bullet into her head in Greenwood Union Cemetery on North Street here.
The "lawlessness" and "anarchy" of the current labor situation, Professor William G. Sutcliffe of Boston University said today, "hold in jeopardy the growth of economic well-being."

The Mexican Government prepared furtheir steps today to implement its new program for State control of public services and agriculture. Coincidentally, new difficulties developed as to the part labor is to play in the new system.
LONDON.--A new economic slump is foreseen by a group of English economists at Oxford, including Sir Arthur Salter and D. H. MacGregor.

The marriage of Miss Betty Ives, daughter of Mrs. Henry W. Ives of Hilton Hall and the late Mr. Ives, to Arthur H. Chadwick, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur R. Chadwick of Rockville Centre, L. I., took place today in the Cathedral of the Incarnation.
MORE than 2,800 dealers' service stations are listed in a booklet released throughout the country by the Buick division of General Motors in preparation for the Summer touring season.

W. P. Conway of Green Village, N. J., hit 151 targets in a row to defeat J. R. Anderson of Chicago in the Class A competition at the ninth annual Great Eastern skeet tournament on the Remington Gun Club range in Lordship today.

The Municipal Civil Service Commission reports that in 1936 it extended the competitive class of civil service. The commission transferred forty exempt positions to the competitive class, transferred 177 non-competitive positions and one labor position

The move for a third term for President Roosevelt, sponsored by organized labor in Pennsylvania, is viewed by some politicians as one strong enough to break the precedent against a President's having more than two terms.

The Mullins Manufacturing Corporation has declared a. stock dividend of 100 per cent on the Class B common stock. On April 27 last the stockholders authorized the directors to declare the dividend in a recapitalization plan.

OUR manner of celebrating July 4 has changed considerably with the years. It has come to be less formal, less ceremonious, less colorful. The town orator, garbed in the ruffles of 1776, no longer declaims the Declaration of Independence in the public square.

Judge Mahoney, pacing colt from the Newbrook Stables driven by Ed Mansfield of Hoboken, won the Class A event in straight heats at the matinee sponsored by the Road Horse Association of New Jersey at Weequahic Park today.

The marriage of Miss Anabel Morton, daughter of Mrs. Frederick James Morton of East Orange and Lhe late Captain Morton, formerly of Laurel, Del., to Dudley Minton Day, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Day of Chatham, took place today at Central Brick Presbyterian Church here.

The election of Mrs. William S. Paley, Eustace Seligman and William H. Baldwin to the board of trustees of the Graduate Faculty of Political and Social Science was announced yesterday by Ira A. Hirschmann, chairman.

One of the most consistent terrier winners in this country, the handsome Sealyham Ch. Wolvey Noel of Clairedale, owned by Mrs. W. O. Penney's Clairedale Kennels of Riverhead, L. I., carried off the top award in the ninth annual Monmouth County Kennel Club all-breed exhibition at the Harding estate today.
President Roosevelt again set the note of easy informality at the Jefferson Islands Club today, greeting the other guests without a coat or tie and with his shirt opened at the neck.

The Manufacturers Trust Company is transfer agent for the common and convertible preference stocks of Wil-Low Cafeterias, Inc. The T. I. S. Distributors Company of 60 State Street, Boston, has been appointed sole distributor for Trusteed Industry Shares to security dealers in the United States and Canada. Guy MacVicar is in charge of distributing these securities.

William L. Blanchard, banker, contractor and Masonic leader, died at his home here today after an illness of twelve days. He would have been 70 years old tomorrow. Entering the building field as a young man, after having conducted a factory for making bakers' ovens in his 'teens, Mr. Blanchard later won success as an industrial builder and real estate developer.

Miss Louise Gerdes, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John F. Gerdes of Mrs. Burlington, Iowa, was married to J. Robert Guy, son of Mrs. J. L. Guy of Milwaukee, Wis., yesterday morning in the Riverside Church by the Rev. Eugene C. Carder.
It seems there is not merely one but there are two Loch Ness monsters, and they have produced a litter of baby monsters.

Granted by Surrogate James A. Foley on the following estates: BEARNS, JOSEPH G: (Feb. 5). Estate, $10,000. To City Bank Farmers Trust Co., 22 William St. Heirs, widow, sister. BURKE, MICHAEL P. (April 21). tate, $3,200. To Bridget McBride, sister, 378 Cherry St. Other heirs, four nephews, niece.

The marriage of Miss Althea Marian McCammon, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Frederic James McCammon of 167 Hancock Street, Brooklyn, to Roland Offerman Rasch, son of Mr. and Mrs. G. William Rasch, also of Brooklyn, took place at noon yesterday at Sherry's.

The White Sox rallied in the ninth today to win their second straight game from Washington, 6 to 5. The Sox pushed across three runs in the final inning against Pete Appleton and Syd Cohen and made off with a nip-and-tuck battle that gave them their eighth victory over the Senators in eleven meetings this year.
BAR HARBOR, Me.--An active social and sports season is being planned at the various Summer retreats on Mount Desert Island, including Bar Harbor, Seal Harbor, Northeast Harbor and Southwest Harbor.
Ten men, one of whom can be identified as a high officer of the political police, received high decorations today on the order of the Soviet Central Executive Committee.

The City Bank Farmers Trust Co assigned to Walter E. Beer a mortgage for $80,000 on 67-7?? W 47th St. The Broadeagle Realty Corp, Herman Knobloch, president, bought 19 E 119th St from Helen Yanover on last April 9, and now gives a second mortgage thereon for $5,400, due next Dec. 9 at 5 per cent, to Herman, Wesley E. and David C. Knobloch, subject to a first mortgage for $3,000.
Miss Rosamond Bell, daughter of Professor J. Carleton Bell of City College and Mrs. Bell, was married yesterday to Carl Hoffgaard Jensen, son of Dr. and Mrs. Carl Jensen of Brooklyn.
A pilgrimage commemorating the 300th anniversary of the arrival of the first Lincoln in America ended here today at the Abraham Lincoln Shrine. It started in Boston Sunday.

Trading in bonds last week was at the slowest pace in almost fourteen years. Transactions on the New York Stock Exchange totaled only $35,628,200, the smallest weekly turnover for a full five and one-half week since Aug. 25, 1923, when dealings amounted to $35,591,400.

Two Germans, an Australian and Britain's lone seeded player today joined three Americans and another Australian in the quarter-finals of the men's singles at Wimbledon. If Gene Mako had drawn Jack Crawford, Heinrich Henkel or even H. W. (Bunny) Austin, three of those who advanced today, he might have had a chance to join Donald Budge,

THE Summer comes with flower and bee, as the poet sang, but none of the season's harbingers is more welcome than the prosaic hum of the mechanical refrigerator. Thanks to the refrigerator, ice cubes plop into long, refreshing drinks,

Riverdale Ave (13-3419). s w cor Spaulding Lane, 112x242; Acamp Realty Corp to Marie P. Campagna, Riverdale Ave and Spaulding Lane. Morris Ave, 2,023 (11-2829), Harlem Savings Bank to Abraham Dobrowitsky, 2,029 Morris Ave.
Twenty-eight yachts entered in the Eastern Yacht Club's New London to Marblehead Race of 171 nautical miles, had fisherman's luck today as a refreshing breeze out of the northeast favored the fleet.

Infantry, 9-2 shot from the Millsdale Stable, leading all the way, won the $10,000 added Frontier Handicap at the Fair Grounds today and established a new track record for the mile and three-sixteenths.

The National Labor Relations Board, charging the Ford Motor Company with responsibility for "malicious and brutal assaults" on United Automobile workers' organizers, issued a complaint against the company today and set July 6 for a hearing.

Stressing the action of twelve States in enacting standard license laws, of fifteen cities in installing accident prevention bureaus and of the schools in general for starting highway safety teaching, Paul G.

The fifty-ninth convention of the American Library Association closed yesterday morning with a speech in praise of reading. It was delivered by Alvin Johnson, director of the New School for Social Research, at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, where the association has had its headquarters since the convention opened last Monday.
Mr. and Mrs. Laurence V. Benet of Washington, D. C., and Paris, who are at the Plaza, will sail for France Wednesday. Mrs. Ronald Tree of London is expected to arrive tomorrow at the Savoy-Plaza.

ALTHOUGH he has acted Shakespearean roles for the greater part of an extremely active career (he is now 54 years old) Fritz Leiber humbly owns to a private conviction that he just isn't the Shakespearean type on the screen. But one thing he prides himself on, and that is having overcome what seems to be regarded in Hollywood as the tremendous artistic handicap of being experienced in the school of the Bard.

In a deal involving an exchange of properties an investing client of Previews, Inc., has purchased from Frederick Brown through George W. Levy the seven-story business building at 439 Madison Avenue, between the old and new sections of the New Weston Hotel.

PITTSFIELD, Mass.--Outstanding among sporting events of the week in the Berkshires will be the Western New England men's tennis championships in singles and doubles at Wyantenuck Country Club, Great Barrington, which start Wednesday and will continue through Independence Day. An informal party Friday evening will be followed by the tennis tournament ball Saturday night.

Miss Helen Gertude Bowling, daughter of Mrs. Abner Bowling of Verona and the late Rev. Mr. Bowling, was married this morning to the Rev. Norman Alexander Wilson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis Wilson of New York.

LIVINGSTON MANOR. --This village, for many years a haven of trout fishermen because of its location on the Willowemoc Creek, has an ambitious program calculated to increase its prestige, built up in recent years, as a Catskills resort. .
A group of independent steel workers appealed to Governor M. Clifford Townsend today to work out a "quick, peaceful settlement" of the steel strike controversy in Indiana's Calumet district.

Furniture buyers, coming into the market here last week, showed an eager interest in the possibilities of adapting the type of arrangement through which R. H. Macy Co., Inc., now sell furniture to consumers who finance their purchases by loans obtained through the Morris Plan Industrial Bank of New York. More than 200 inquiries by retailers' representatives were made during the first week of the annual Fall furniture market here last week.

About 1,500 night shift workers on rapid transit, surface car and bus lines of the B. M. T. system added their votes yesterday to the 7,000 which on Friday authorized officers of the B. M. T. division of the Transport Workers Union, a C. I. O. organization, to call a strike of the company's 12,500 employes unless it consented by tomorrow to an immediate collective bargaining referendum.

Establishment of a maritime school devoted exclusively to training students to become expert seamen has been approved for this city and will open in September, Morris E. Siegel, director of evening and continuation schools, disclosed yesterday.

Test operation of trains over the completed section of the Brooklyn crosstown line of the city's Independent Subway system began yesterday, in preparation for the formal opening of the new route at 1 P. M. Thursday.

T. M. Girdler, chairman of the Republic Steel Corporation, today said that newspaper dispatches from Washington yesterday credited him with remarks in criticism of members of the Steel Mediation Board which actually had been made by a former administration adviser.
President Roosevelt's Supreme Court plan must be withdrawn, there can be no compromise, United States Senator Burton K. Wheeler of Montana said today.
The idea of standardizing rates for space in office buildings and setting up uniform rental schedules to guide both tenants and landlords is gaining ground.

Conference of the Non-Sectarian Anti-Nazi League, Hotel Edison, 2 P. M. Samuel Untermyer, chairman. Fortieth annual convention of the Zionist Organization of America, Hotel Roosevelt, 2:30 P. M. Address by Dr. Stephen S. Wise. Continues tomorrow afternoon and evening.
Miss Lola Ruth McDonald, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Burt Austin McDonald of this place, was martried in Christ Church here this afternoon to Dr. George Edward Hall of Toronto, Ont.,

The natural gas business has become less speculative in the last few years, owing to the improvement of geologic technique and the discovery of enormous quantities of gas, in the opinion of financial and engineering authorities.
New defenses against fire today guarded the historic belfry of Old North Church, where lanterns signaled Paul Revere to start his famous ride toward Concord and Lexington.

If any Italians still wondered whether Italy intended to see through the Franco venture in Spain to the bitter end, regardless of consequences, their doubts were laid entirely at rest by the Popolo d'Italia this morning.

DESPITE the necessity of moving only a few days earlier, a task of no small proportions and beset with many complexities, the Museum of Modern Art opened on schedule last week its Summer exhibition of paintings, sculpture, architecture and other material from the permanent collections, supplemented by important loans from private collections.

Frank Strafaci of Shore View, medalist in the fourth annual Briar Hills Golf and Country Club invitation tournament, won two decisive matches today on his way toward acquiring the graceful silver bowl on which Willie Turnesa and Donald Hotaling already have their names inscribed.
Lee (Buck) Ross held the Indians to three hits today while the Athletics pounded Mel Harder to score a 7-to-0 victory, ending a losing streak of ten straight games.
Mrs. Martin H. Schrenkeisen of Third Street gave a tea at her home this afternoon for Mrs. Madison Haythe. Mrs. Sidney Nash and Mrs. Frederick Olmstead were at the tea table.

The re-election of Mayor La Guardia with the support of the American Labor party was predicted by Jacob Potofsky, vice chairman of the party, in an address before the Tamiment Economic and Social Institute here today.

The Spanish merchant vessel Cabo Palos, laden with foodstuffs, was reported tonight to have been sunk by a submarine off Point Ifach with the loss of five members of the crew. Forty-four survivors, including a woman who was aboard as a nurse, were taken to Alicante by another ship after they had drifted for six hours in lifeboats.

MR. GREGORY BIEN STOCK, author of books on economics, written in German, has now presented the English-speaking readers with a volume dealing with the Pacific problem and published in English, which, as this reviewer sees it,

ADD paradoxes of the week: A the Soviet film-makers turn out an adventure picture in which thirteen persons fight off 200 bandits in the desert until the arrival of the Russian equivalent of the Seventh Cavalry; Hollywood indulges itself with a spirited drama celebrating the social purpose, the heroism and the self-sacrifice of the working man.
Stocks closed lower in third slowest trading of the year; turnover, 288,240 shares. United States Government and corporate bonds lower; transactions, $4,700,900.

The Old Westbury quartet topped the Aknusti riders, 6 to 5, in an overtime thriller on International Field today in a match in which two well-known poloists and sportsmen narrowly escaped serious injury.

Harold Stein, administrative officer of the WPA Federal Arts Projects in this city, purchased his freedom yesterday from 600 sit-down strikers, who had held him captive in his own office for fifteen hours, by granting all of the strikers' demands to the limit of his authority.
OF its kind, "Lulu" is a masterpiece and in the history of atonality and the twelve-tone scale probably an epoch-making one. It is an immense pity

EXPANDING" his production activities beyond the Mickey Mouse and Silly Symphony field, Walt Disney is planning a second feature-length cartoon to follow "Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs" on which 500 people are working at present.
It may be that Soviet Russia's new democratic Constitution is chiefly responsible for STALIN'S new firing
Fortyeight boats competed today in the initial invitation regatta of the season of the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association, held under the auspices of the Babylon Yacht Club.

Miss Jean Louise Rockwell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Ensign Rockwell, was married this afternoon to Henry James Forsyth, son of Mr. and Mrs. James Forsyth of Buffalo, in the garden of the Rockwell home.
T. Suffern Tailer of the Meadow Brook Club, Westbury, L. I., has been selected to captain the Metropolitan Lesley Cup team, it has been announced by E. H. Driggs

This is a Summer for cruising to the east'rd. Pretty nearly everything that floats, from ten-foot outboard skiffs up through the superyachts such as Alfred P. Sloan's Mene, W. K. Vanderbilt's Alva and J. P. Morgan's Corsair, will spend a good many days this season cruising in the Shelter Island area between the two prongs on the eastern end of Long Island.

A RADIO hook-up described as "the most extensive assembled since the Roosevelt inaugural" is being assembled to broadcast the National Scout Jamboree from June 30 to July 9 in Washington, D. C. With short-wave stations supplementing the regular broadcasting stations, it is expected that the various programs will reach the twenty-four nations represented by the Scouts at the conclave.

TROUDSBURG, Pa.--All of the resorts here are now making plans for the Fourth of July ek-end and each one of them is ranging special attractions for three-day outing. Horseback riding through the any miles of bridle paths has bene one of the most popular orts; there are more horses in Poconos than ever before.
Wearing a gray suit and hat and with $20 in his pocket, Julius Lehrenkraus, 69 years old, former Brooklyn banker, left Sing Sing today on parole.

Surveys are under way to determine a route for a highway to make accessible to visitors the place where occurred the Great Swamp Fight, historic Rhode Island battleground at South Kingston, which has lain hidden for more than 250 years in an impenetrable bog.
Miss Julia Marie McCloskey, daughter of Mr. ar Mrs. John J. McCloskey of New York, was : arried yesterday morning to John Thomas Dolan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. Dolan of Brooklyn.

When the joint Congressional committee began its investigation into methods of income tax avoidance and evasion the announced intention was to learn how existing loopholes in the law could most effectively be plugged.

Authorities released today two Americans who had been detained for questioning during an intensive espionage investigation in Catalonia, but continued to hold four others. Mr. and Mrs. Charles Orr of North Branch, Mich., were those freed.

THE liveliest of theatrical trading centers, where two and two can add up to five (and frequently do), Times Square has just seen a new deal concluded: it will be Harold Arlen and E. Y. Harburg who supply the scoremusio and lyrics-of "Greek to You," for which Russel Crouse and Howard Lindsay are already known to be fashioning a book based on a story by Lowell Brentano and William Jourdan Rapp.

Stating that the estimated cost value of new buildings for which permits were filed throughout the country in May was 24 per cent higher than in the same month one year ago, Secretary of Labor Frances Perkins in her monthly statistical report says that it represented, nevertheless,

CHAMPIONSHIP FLIGHT First Round-Frank Strafaci, Shore View, defeated George Cotellis, South Bay, 3 and 2; George Buckingham, Briar Hills, defeated Leo Kaufmann, Green Meadow, 1 up (20 holes); Francis Critchley, Briar Hills, defeated Malcolm Hetzer, Green Meadow, 4 and 3; Jack Creavy, Hickory, defeated Arthur B. Jorkiund, Briar Hills. 2 and 1; Edward Searle defeated Donald Hotaling, Briar Hills, 1 up;

The following is the chart showing how the Washington Park Futurity was run at Washington Park today: SIXTH RACE--The Washington Park Futurity; 2-year-olds: $15,000 added: six furlongs. Start good from gate; won easily; place driving. Went to post 5:51, off 5:53. Winner, br. c., by Bull Dog--Starless Moment. Trainer, R. McGarvey. Time--1:11. Value to winner, $26,135; second, $4,000; third, $2,500; fourth, $1,500; Weather clear; track fast.
The auxiliary schooner Morrissey left this port today under command of Captain "Bob" Bartlett with a party of college students on a scientific expedition to the Arctic.

" NEUROSIS," according to Dr. Homey, "is the price paid for cultural development." Some people, he explains, are adequately equipped to withstand the conflicts around which a neurosis grows; still, many of the weaker members of our society may be mentally defeated by these same conflicts,

THE primitive Monterey coast country, little altered in the almost 400 years since the early Spanish explorers sailed their tiny ships along its forbidding granite shores, will this Summerbe more accessible to motorists.

DETAILED "life histories" of rainstorms are being recorded in Oklahoma by a series of rainfall measurements taken by the Soil Conservation Service of the United States Department of Agriculture in cooperation with the Weather Bureau in Western Oklahoma.

Again a new alarm over Spain has occurred and again-at this writing-it has seemingly passed, leaving Europe still at peace. Chancellor Adolf Hitler, exhausted, has retired to his Bavarian hilltop. Premier Benito Mussolini is again occupying himself with the real problem of how to raise enough money to make something out of his Ethiopian conquest.

Dismissing the idea that recent developments in Soviet Russia, ineluding the widely publicized purge of high military and other officials, has shaken the confidence of American business men in the Soviet, David A. Rosoff, chairman of the board and president of the Amtorg

THE hobby of collecting cigar bands, with their glowing colors and intricate designs, has not been widely publicized in the United States since the Nineties, when grandfather used to spend long hours making a pattern of the bands which he had collected during years of smoking. Now the hobby has revived and has become so popular that the Cigar Progress Board is about to establish an exchange mart for its followers.

CERTAINLY not more than once in a generation can one expect to find a young dancer so manifestly destined for a great career as Carma Lita Maracci. To a small section of the New York dance spectators her name already has a certain significance, for she made an informal appearance at the Y. M. H. . A. only last Spring, and there were immediate reverberations.
Austin, Nichols Co. and subsidiaries reported yesterday a net profit of $174,073 for the year to April 30, after deductions for depreciation, interest, Federal income taxes and other charges.

Royal Scarlet Grocery Store, in 1,231 6th Ave, through Tankoos, Smith Co. Sadie Torre, dresses, in 15 W 47th St; Frederick Fox Co., brokers. Superior Tire Co., retreading of tires, in 27-35 Verona Ave, Newark; Feist Feist, brokers.

IN the heavyweight drama the scene now shifts to London. Uncle Mike Jacobs, with a fiveyear contract with Shufflin' Joe Louis tucked away in his weskit, is looking toward England in search of a fit opponent for the Dark Destroyer in his London debut. Brig. Gen. A. C. Critchley, the British promoter, is already on the premises with a rival pugilistic show, the Schmeling-Farr bout.

KARL SCHNEIDER of Vienna, reported recently in this column as Austria's claimant to the title of "perfect player," appears to be justifying the views of his adherents. He and his favorite partner, Hans Jellinek, were half of the Austrian team that captured the world title at Budapest a week ago.

The marriage of Miss Nancy Allaire Titus, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Titus of this place, to Stanislas George Trembicki, son of Mrs. Marie Trembicki of Jackson Heights, Queens, and Harold L. Trembicki of Forest Hills,

Miss Mary Lawless, 23 years old, a student of 28-17 100th Avenue, Bellaire, L. I., was rescued and a companion, Anthony Sullivan, 29, of 244 Roosevelt Avenue, Newark, N. J., an insurance man, was drowned shortly before 11 o'clock last night when the backwash from an unidentified excursion steamer upset the rowboat in which they were returning to shore from an auxiliary sloop anchored in the Hudson River off 142d Street.

Results obtained through scientific appraisal methods should be carefully checked against the appraiser's own knowledge and experience if mistakes are to be avoided, according to M..C. O'Brien, president of the Brooklyn realty firm of M. C. O'Brien, Inc.

Miss Josephine Browning Doughten, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Isaac Doughten Jr. of Chestnut Hill was married this afternoon to George Frederick Tyler Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. George Frederick Tyler of Indian Council Rock, Newtown, in St. Paul's Church, Chestnut Hill.
Three bases on balls and an infield out pushed over the winning run for the Syracuse Chiefs in the last of the eighth as they ended Newark's seven-game winning streak tonight. The score was 5 to 4.

Chester Maines, 27 years old, of Tappen, N. Y., made a "pancake" landing in the middle of the Hudson River this afternoon after bringing his small biplane out of a nose dive, caused by a stalled motor.

Dr. Harry Woodburn Chase, chancellor of New York University, announced yesterday the appointment of Dr. Curt Sachs, European music authority, as visiting Professor of Music for the coming year in the Graduate School of Liberal Arts.

While Florida is divided over the Atlantic-Gulf Ship Canal and the north and south portions of the State battle for and against the project, the University of Florida is quietly building a unique extension school on a section of the abandoned site.

Frank B. Dorman has been appointed resident housing manager for the $13,500,000 PWA financed Williamsburg houses in Brooklyn covering the plot bounded by -Leonard Street and Bushwick Avenue, Maujer and Scholes Streets.

Although Leon Blum is no longer Premier, the Popular Front is still in charge in France. All that has happened in the past week is that it has shifted the burden of government from its left to its right shoulder.

Amelia Earhart landed her monoplane at 1:30 P. M. [12:30 A. M. New York time] here today after a flight from Bandoeng, Java, a distance of about 1,200 miles. The noted American flier, accompanied by her navigator, Captain Fred Noonan, completed a new leg on her around-the-world flight on a course over the Sunda Islands skirting the Flores Sea.

Miss Katharine Augusta Cregar, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Luther Cregar of 123 Leland Avenue, and Fosdick Whitney Ayer, son of Mrs. Helen F. Ayer, also of Plainfield, were married this afternoon in the First-Park Baptist Church by Rev. Henrv L. Bell.
