Still under the depressing influence of industrial labor strife, the security markets moved irresolutely in the week just completed. Trading continued extremely dull. Led by grains, the commodities markets were generally active and firm.

WHEN Thomas Jefferson proposed Charlottesville as the site for the University of Virginia he argued that its location in the geographical center of the State made it accessible to the young students who were to come by horseback and coach over miles of mud roads.

Charles J. Minsterer, who had served as assistant to Brooklyn Borough Presidents until 1933, died on Friday in Long Island College Hospital of pneumonia. He was 66 years old and resided at 2,901 Newkirk Avenue, Brooklyn.

The centennial celebration this year of the birth of Admiral Dewey has focused public interest on his birthplace, which is visited by a large number of tourists each week. The hero of Manila Bay was born in an unpretentious house almost across the street from the State Capitol, but the house was moved some years ago from its original site and now stands further west on State Street.
Dr. Hans Frank, Reich Commissioner for Justice and Minister Without Portfolio, has come forward with a new reason for antiSemitism in the new Germany.

Miss Isabella Lois Burnham, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander 0. Burnham of Bellerose, L. I., was married yesterday morning in St. Thomas' Church, Bellerose, to Benedict Frank Haberle 3d, son of Mrs. Kirk Haberle and of Benedict Frank Haberle of Syracuse. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. John L. Williams, rector of the church.

Mr. G. F. POWELL, ambassador of Major DOUGLAS, apostle of Social Credit, has arrived at Edmonton to study and report on the technical and political situation. The Major is not a politician but head of the Douglas Secretariat, an association of economists.
Director Victor Gelineau of the New Jersey State Board of Commerce and Navigation is receiving bids for several dredging operations on the lower stretches of the New Jersey Inland Waterway.

The Federal Steel Mediation. Board made today what was regarded as its last gesture before giving-up its efforts to mediate the seven-State steel strike. Edward F. McGrady, Assistant Secretary of Labor,

An earthquake caused the United States Army transport Saint Mihiel to shake violently between 7:10 and 7:12 o'clock Thursday morning, Captain C. A. McMullen declared today on the ship's arrival from California.

In the artistic colony at Woodstock, Ulster County, N. Y., a few miles from Kingston, Mrs. Norbert Heermann, who-is better known to her friends as Elizabeth Alexander, the playwright, has-purchased the fifty-three acre farm owned by Bernard F. Schulte, who bought the property in 1928 and- added a swimming pool and guest house.

How a collection of contemporary Spanish paintings, sculpture and craftwork, valued at more than $200,000 was captured on the high seas by Spanish rebels was told here by a group of Spanish artists that arrived in New York recently from Mexico on their way back to Spain.

ARRIVAL of the twenty-ton Royal Mail Aircraft Cavalier on the waters of Long Island Sound the other day-significant of a new, swift link between the United States and near-by but foreign Bermuda and the first air service actually gotten under way on the North Atlantic-marked also the first appearance of a foreign air line on the American mainland.

IN "The Katchinas Are Coming" the author presents sixteen myths and folktales of the Pueblo Indians, illustrating them by large color plates. This is a book of Indian folklore for readers of any age who are interested in the American Indian and already have some knowledge of the subject,

The engagement of Miss Constance rhayer, daughter of Mrs. Charles Martin Thayer of this city and the late Mr. Thayer, to David Cleveland Cory, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert H. Cory of Englewood, N. J., has been announced by her mother.

Engineers attending the final sessions of the economic conference here at the Stevens Institute of Technology camp were told today by Professor Edmund D. Ayres of the University of Wisconsin that they were the "logical" individuals to bring about a harmonious relationship between management and the worker.

Miss Elizabeth Spotswood Ralph, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stuart Harrison Ralph of this place, was married this afternoon in the Church of the Holy Trinity to Robinson Davis Bullard, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph William Camp Bullard of Southport, Conn. The ceremony was performed by the pastor, the Rev. Arthur A. Moffatt.

The right to work is sacred. The right to strike is equally valid. Governor Davey of Ohio. These two rights, guaranteed by law and tradition, were the basic factors in last week's chapter of the steel struggle as it entered its second month.

Miss Florence Emma Hopcraft, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John H. Hopcraft, was married here to George Robert Schenck, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Schenck, this afternoon in the Episcopal Church of St. James the Apostle.

While the men's clothing trade found that the average price rise of 12 per cent in the Spring evoked definite consumer resistance, business in Summer merchandise has been well maintained, reports last week indicated.

Citing some of the benefits conferred by the Home Owners Loan Corporation upon distressed owners, Herman A. Acker, president of the Real Estate Association of the State of New York, said in an address last week that some other projects might be-created by the government

To the Editor of The New York Times: We in the Works Progress Administration recognize the value of a freely critical press as a factor in the formulation of public policy. We should, however, like to take advantage of this freedom to place before your readers our position on certain questions of relief policy which are raised frequently on your editorial pages.

The great Kluchev volcano on the Kamchatka Peninsula in Eastern Siberia was reported today to have become violently active again. Reports from an observatory in the remote section said the volcano had hurled ashes about four and a half miles into the air while streams of molten lava had overflowed its sides.

With the technical aspects of advertising and selling pushed into the background at its convention here last week, the Advertising Federation of America for the coming year will have to devote more attention to the broader problems

Righthander Jim Walkup found today's chilly and misty weather conditions so ideal that he held the hard-hitting Red Sox to four hits while his St. Louis team-mates were pounding Johnny Marcum for a 7-1 triumph. It was Boston's second defeat in eleven games.

An Interstate Commerce Commission examiner recommends that the Boss Lines, Inc., Buffalo, N. Y., be authorized to continue operations as a common motor carrier between points in New York and Pennsylvania.

An ambitious three-ply program for training American youth to fly and meet what was termed an implied threat from abroad to this nation's air supremacy was announced today by the National Aeronautic Association.

Dr. John Randolph Winslow, for many years one of the leading eye, ear, nose and throat specialists in Baltimore, died today at his home here after a long illness. Dr. Winslow had been living in retirement for several years. He was 71 years old.

THE American Museum of Natural History is preparing to establish the first permanent microvivarium in the world. Microvivarium? You look in vain for the word in the dictionary. It is hybrid Greek and Latin. "Micro" obviously means "little." And the '"vivarium"? A place where animals are kept.

An Ohio National Guard unit was detailed tonight to aid workmen patrolling a railroad embankment which kept a huge lake formed by flood waters from pouring in upon this already partially inundated town of 6,000 where one person has been drowned.
County Judge Morris Saylor held Perry Noe and Allen Bowlin, former deputy sheriffs, to the grand jury without bond today in the "ride" murder Tuesday night of former Deputy Washington Irvin, 33.

Miss Georgia Kavanagh, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gardner Charles Kavanagh of Rochester, N. Y. was married yesterday to Robert Lenzen Schmitz, son of Dr. and Mrs. Henry Schmitz of Chicago, in the Lady Chapel of St. Patrick's Cathedral.

In St. John's Church here this afternoon Miss Anne French Earle, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Keese Earle, was married to Roy Ronold Buxton Attride, son of Major and Mrs. Percy William Attride of Quetta, India, and London. The ceremony was performed by the rector, the Rev. Lyman Cox Bleecker.
" I Will Never Lose a Minute" M A. B. desires the identity of this passage, supposed to have been made by Napoleon: "It may be that I will lose a battle, but I will never lose a minute."

Charles Poletti of New York, former counsel to Governor Lehman and now a State Supreme Court justice, to day called the United States Supreme Court's "checkered record" of opinions on social legislation "discouraging and disgusting."

The Retail Women's Apparel Sales People's Union, Local 1,125, was restrained from picketing May's Fur and Ready-to-Wear, Inc., 508 and 510 Fulton Street, Brooklyn, by a decision handed down yesterday by Justice Leander B. Faber in the Supreme Court.

In the British House of Commons on July 27, 1914, Sir Edward Grey, the Foreign Minister, spoke grave words. He was telling of negotiations with Berlin, Rome and Paris by which he had sought to keep the Serbian crisis from developing into the "greatest catastrophe" that could befall the European powers.

Full operation of the second major unit of the West Side improvement project will begin tomorrow, the New York Central Railroad announced yesterday. The unit consists of an open cut in a private right-of-way twenty-four blocks long, between Tenth and Eleventh

Burleigh Grimes's Dodgers used up eleven innings and an untold amount of energy today trying to knock out the Wrigley Field jinx, and success finally crowned their efforts when they beat Bill Lee and the Cubs, 2 to 1.

WASHINGTON.--Though the motorization program of the army has unhorsed many mounted units and in ten years reduced by 43 per cent the number of animals on the rolls, army picket lines still contain approximately 25,000 horses and mules.
Teams coached by A. J. Robertson at Bradley Tech won twenty-three games in a row during the season recently concluded. The football team closed its season with three straight victories.

Insurgents launched two heavy but unsuccessful attacks on the southern Madrid front today, apparently confirming reports that Insurgent General Francisco Franco was massing his men for a new campaign against the capital.

Yankee division veterans elected A. Raymond Doucette of Lynn, Mass., their national president today in the concluding business session of their convention. He succeeded Albert W. Herman of Norwalk, Conn. Mr. Doucette served with E Battery of the 101st Field Artillery in France as a private. He was gassed at St. Mihiel and Verdun.

The three-masted tern schooner General A. W. Greeley, fresh from the Newfoundland trade, will catch the tide out of Port Newark, N. J., on Wednesday or Thursday and bear a crew of twelve men, scientists, sailors and one Boy Scout to a stay of from eighteen months to three years in the Arctic Circle.

The Bituminous Coal Commission invited today coal producers and distributors to give their ideas on marketing rules. The commission announced the beginning of a series of hearings on July 19 on discount and trade practices of wholesalers.

The army authorities made public yesterday the list of seventy New York State business and professional men, commissioned officers of the Army Reserve, who will direct the training of the 1,703 New York and New Jersey youths at the Citizens' Military Training Camp at Plattsburg, N. Y., starting next week.

Fifteen boys and girls in their teens start work tomorrow at the camps of the Westchester County Recreation Commission at Croton, in what is thought to be the first practice course in camp leadership for their age group in this country.

The engagement of Miss Marjorie Jane Kendig of this place to Frederick Emerson Creamer of Fairfield, Conn., was announced this afternoon at a reception given by Miss Kendig's brother-in-law and sister, Mr. and Mrs. John Hiram McKee of Grace Church Street.

With legislation on hours and wages to the forefront, establishment of a national board of planning for the $800,000,000 men's clothing industry was advocated here yesterday by Charles D. Jaffee, head of the company bearing his name and last week re-elected president of the New York Clothing Manufacturers Exchange for the thirteenth year.

With Bilbao's capture eighty-one days after the late General Emilio Mola began his offensive on the northern front, General Francisco Franco has added valuable territory to that he already controlled.

The old saying that "one never misses the water 'till the well runs dry" is quite as applicable to the garden as to the well. In a season of abundant rainfall, such as we have enjoyed so far, it is very easy to forget that, according to the law of averages, prolonged periods of heat and drought are almost certain to lie ahead.

Zooming, soaring and riding the winds with much of the stability and speed of regular air transports, some 1,200 model planes dotted the sky over the Sheep Meadow in Central Park yesterday as the Junior Birdmen of America held their fourth annual city-wide contest of "stick" models, gliders and cabin-type aircraft.

Miss Sara Buena Brewer and Joseph John Wickham, son of Mrs. Edward J. Wickham, were married this afternoon at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Vincent C. Brewer of East Hartford. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Warren S. Archibald of South Congregational Church.

Mr. and Mrs. Clement S. Henry Jr. gave a dinner tonight before the first Seawanhaka Yacht Club dance at Larkswing, their country place here, for Miss Elizabeth Shelby Sinclair and Louis Wood Hoyle, whose marriage will take place on Tuesday in New York.

Middlebury College Language Schools will open this week with the largest total enrolment in the twenty-nine years of the existence of the Summer session.
Miss Florence Jensen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis F. Jensen of this city, was married to Herbert Seiser, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Seiser of Irvington, today in Sacred Heart Church, Elizabeth.

A vivid picture of mass air attacks of the future was given today by 260 bombers and fighters, which roared in perfect formation over Hendon Airport as a climax to the annual show by the Royal Air Force.

Announcement has been made of the engagement and approaching marriage of Miss Mina Kellner of 145 East Seventy-fourth Street, daughter of Mrs. Elmer R. Kellner of Chicago and San Antonio, Texas, and the late Mr. Kellner, to Herbert Sheldon Spencer of this city and Springfield, Mass.

THE industry is recognizing at last the value of colorful presentation to lift its product out of the prosaic rut that runs from main title to final fade-out. There are eleven productions now before the cameras that may be termed colorful, and twelve others are on the schedule for early shooting.

Scoring an ace with a No. 8 iron on the eighteenth hole at the Maplewood Country Club today, Jim Blanchard of Essex County took the lead with Frank M. Bowen at the end of the first round in the John F. Roche memorial golf tournament.

NEWPORT, R. I.--With the Fourth of July only a week away the Summer colonists are preparing for their first big week-end of the present season. As the holiday falls on a Sunday and will be observed on Monday many of the men in the city this week are preparing to return next week-end for a prolonged stay.
A woman tentatively identified by police as Mrs. Caroline Boldon, 40, of Detroit, and her dog were found shot to death in an automobile five miles north of Darien this afternoon.

IRELAND--or the best part of it, making up the Free State--is once more at the political crossroads. Dail Eireann has been dissolved and the country is in the ferment of a general election. The "sovereign people," as Eamon de Valera likes to call them, will go to the polls early next month not only to choose a government but to enact a new Constitution which will revolutionize the internal structure of the State.
Germans today regarded the approach of June 28, birthday of the Treaty of Versailles, with less sense of national humiliation than at any time since the World War.
Mr. and Mrs. Lewis F. Weber of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Dorothy Weber, to Richard H. Ludeman, son of Mrs. Edwin Ludeman of Brooklyn and the late Mr. Ludeman.
Legislation which would block some forms of tax evasion and at the same time discourage the flow of unwanted gold to this country is being considered in Treasury circles.

Busch's Kredit Jewelers, 35 West Fourteenth Street, New York, has stipulated with the Federal Trade Commission to stop representing in the sale of certain radio sets that they are capable of "all wave" reception when "the products are not capable of reception of the entire meter range of broadcasts and commercial transmission," the commission announced today.

Mr. and Mrs. Goldthwaite Higginson Dorr of 146 East Forty-seventh Street have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Kathmarine Goldthwaite Dorr, to Dr. Dean Alexander Clark, son of Mrs. Charles Alexander Clark of St. and the late Mr. Clark.

The Interstate Commerce Commission today denied petitions for reargument and reconsideration of its Division 5's definition of the commercial zones of New York, Chicago, St. Louis for purposes of exemptions under the Motor Carrier Act.

Miss Elizabeth Wilmot Gateson, daughter of the Rev. Dr. D. Wilmot Gateson and Mrs. Gateson of this city was married this afternoon to Gordon Howell Friend Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Gordon Howell Friend of Bryn Mawr.

Miss Natalie Beatrice Lisner, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. George Lisner of New York, became the bride here today of John Pescud Lynch of Boston, son of Mrs. Percy P. Lynch of Raleigh, N. C., and the late Mr. Lynch.

The twenty-eighth annual conference of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People will open Tuesday in Detroit and continue through Independence Day. The meeting will be featured by discussions of the economic, social and political problems confronting the American Negro.
Two army bombers, the first to fly to Puerto Rico, arrived from Miami and will make the return flight Monday, Lieutenant D. P. Laubach said today. The flying time from Miami was about eight hours.

Although Senator Robert F. Wagner, according to friends, still insists he will not run for Mayor, efforts to draft him for the Democratic nomination are being continued, it was learned yesterday, and some of teh party leaders profess hope that he will change his mind.

HYANNIS, Mass.--The Summer season on Cape Cod will open this coming week with a sport program featured by the Massachusetts State Open Golf Tournament at Oyster Harbors and with the opening of several of the yacht clubs.

The growing conflict between management and labor in this country, reaching a crisis in the strike in the steel industry, has caused to be raised the question whether the National Labor Relations (Wagner) Act is fully achieving the purpose for which it was enacted.

EVER-WIDENING possibilities of glass in the modern interior are being explored by many decorators. This does not mean merely that they are using more mirrors, but that they are working out varied effects, both in furnishings and in architectural setting.
A government commission today began the actual division of lands belonging to a United States citizen, William Jenkins, in the State of Puebla.
The secret rites of the Demagogue Club, into which President Roosevelt was inducted yesterday at the Jefferson Islands Club, were revealed today for the first time in the history of the club.

LAKE SUNAPEE, N. H.--In this lake, which is said to have risen twelve inches the first three weeks in May, fishing has been so good that anglers have caught the maximum allowance day after day.

Retirement is like heaven, Stanley Baldwin told his friends this week at the end of his first month as a private citizen. But it isn't the heaven he once pictured as his heart's desire.

A FUND of $2,500 has been raised by Mailamm assuring the 2,000 trees in the projected Mailamm-Gabrilowitsch Memorial Grove in Palestine and the continuation of the plan for a Gabrilowitsch Stadium in the grove.
REGATTA: On the Hudson at Poughkeepsie last week the University of Washington for the second time won all races of the Intercollegiate Rowing Association.
Mr. and Mrs. George S. Tompkins of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mabel Tompkins, to J. Wesley to Mapletoft, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert B. Mapletoft of Newark, N. J.
Members of the New York Yankees and the Detroit Tigers had a puzzler tossed to them -yesterday afternoon when they appeared at the Yankee Stadium for the second of a three-game series.

ALL Scout trails lead this week to the Jamboree, to the "city of A Tents' that has been laid out in the shadows of the Washington Monument and on the banks of the murduring Potomac. Twenty-five thousand lads in khaki are hurrying to ten days of fun and high endeavor, eager to let the country see what scouting can do and what it represents.

Miss Grace Langhorne Slater, daughter of Mrs. Horace Slater, and Nathaniel Coleman Brydon, son of Rev. and Mrs. George Maclaren Brydon, were married here this afternoon in Grace and Holy Trinity Episcopal Church.

While hundreds of spectators crowded about Belair in an effort to get a brief glimpse of the ceremony, Mary Pickford was married to Charles (Buddy) Rogers, former screen favorite and now an orchestra leader, at 3 P. M. today.

The temperature rose to 97 degrees following official announcement of Chicago's new tax rate--$9.52 per $100 of assessed valuation, the highest in the city's history. The leap of the mercury fairly represented the feelings of the people.

Students of economics must be impressed by the enormous extent to which the doctrines of KARL MARX now influence and permeate popular thought. It is true that in this country there are still only a comparatively minute number of conscious Communists or conscious Socialists, yet many of the persons who think they are violently opposed to Marxism tacitly accept some of its leading doctrines.

Calling attention to some of the changes which have occurred in the real estate world during the last twenty-five years, Harry Grant Atkinson told the members of the New York Chapter of the National Association of Real Estate Boards at their meeting yesterday that real estate today is definitely tied up with public welfare and progress.
The average gardener has clearly In mind the meaning of the terms annual and perennial; but what a biennial is and which plants are truly to be so labeled often seems to him uncertain.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Topics of The Times some time ago posed the question: "What country has produced the most famous engineers of the last 100 years?" The categorical answer is "France, with de Lesseps and Eiffel." The obvious comeback is to inquire who completed the job at Panama that was too much for de Lesseps.

The Fourth of an July is more than just Independence Day about Lake George this year. It is also the 180th anniversary of the campaign between the Marquis de Montcalm and Sir William Johnson, in July, 1757, toward the end of the French and Indian Wars, which ended so disastrously with the massacre of the English garrison at Fort William Henry in August.

Experiments with highly explosive chemicals preparatory to celebrating the Fourth of July in adequate fashion caused serious injuries to three Jamaica youths and painful burns to two others yesterday afternoon and early last night.
E. B. Curtis defeated Bill McCarthy, New York University baseball coach, and George Mulligan downed Dr. Roy Blackmon in two of the outstanding first-round matches

Earl Backe of Merrick, runner-up last year to Jack Morrison, beat Al Munro of Valley Stream, 6--1, 6--2, in a third-round match, only one played in the men's division of the Hempstead Lake State Park's fifth annual open tennis tournament today.
The Rev. Dr. E. McNeill Poteat, former president of Furman University, Greenville, S. C., and a leader in the Baptist Church, died at a hospital here today after a long illness. His age was 76.

Miss Mary Winslow Greene, daughter of Mrs. Marshall Winslow Greene of this place, was married to Henry Peirce Massey of -Montclair, son of the late Mrs. Mary P. Massey, this evening in the home of the bride's mother by the Rev. Morgan Phelps Noyes, pastor of the Central Presbyterian Church here.

House and Senate baseball teams played against each other during the second day of the Democratic harmony picnic at the Jefferson Islands Club, and the Senators, who are now struggling with the court plan, had eleven men on their team instead of the traditional nine.

Miss Mary Ellen Nicols, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Guy Hayward Nicols of Peekskill, N. Y., was married to Samuel Lawrence Callahan, son of the Rev. and Mrs. John Callahan, yesterday afternoon in the garden of his parents' home in Scarsdale. The ceremony was performed bv the bridegroom's father.
A year ago, on July 1, 1936, more than 400,000 Wisconsin workers began to accumulate a new rightthe right to benefit payments if they should lose their jobs through no fault of their own.

AT this time of writing there are strong possibilities of a great music festival of unprecedented scope and significance to be given during and in conjunction with the New York World's Fair of 1939 and 1940.

A crowd of more than 5,000 wildly cheering fans turned out at Dyckman Oval last night to witness the opening game of the Eastern Amateur Box Lacrosse Association between the Manhattan Shamrocks and the Bronx Indians.

THIS book is an intensely interesting performance. It is a useful performance, too, and one which ought to be repeated ever so often. For in it an English investigator has gathered opinions from six nations on public policy and foreign affairs and has presented them with clarity and brilliance in easy conversational form.

A colorful tent city rose today on a 350acre camp as some 5,000 Boy Scouts arrived for their ten-day jamboree, which begins on Wednesday. In all, 25,000 Scouts from every State and 400 from foreign countries are expected.

67th St, 207 W, 25x100.5, Midge Postal to Louis Gonzales and wife, 214 W 67th St. Amsterdam Ave. 1926-1928. 49.11x100; also 506-510 West 156th St, 50x100, contiguous, Harlem Savings Bank to Thomas Reilly Sons, 133 Bruce Ave, Yonkers ($166).

Mrs. Marianne Briggs Blanchard, daughter of Mrs. Charles H. Briggs of Worcester, Mass., and widow of Colonel Harold Blanchard of Boston and Nassau, B. W. I., was married to William 0. Keyes of this city Friday afternoon in the solarium of the Harkness Pavilion, Columbia Presbyterian MpAical Center.
The Department of Agriculture announced today that a public conference would be held in New York City on July 8 to consider proposed changes in official government standards on creamery butter.
Lee Grissom pitched three-hit ball today for his fourth shut-out of the season, giving the Reds a 2-to-0 triumph over Boston for the club's seventh victory in nine starts.
Russia's famed flying trio, the aviators who flew 5,420 miles non-stop from Moscow to Vancouver, Wash., were in Chicago this morning en route from San Francisco to Washington.

As fast as early cabbage, beets, peas and lettuce are cleared up other plantings can be made in the vegetable garden. It is a good plan to put in a second planting of sweet corn about the middle of June, using an early variety, such as the new Secena 60, and also a standard type such as the Golden Cross.

THE first National Stamp Conference held at Washington last Monday and Tuesday and attended by government officials, collectors and philatelic news writers was unprecedented in the hobby's history and gave Postoffice Department executives a new conception of collectors' desires and hopeful expectations.

High temperatures, prospects of bumper crops and a continuance of peak operating rates in industrial centers not affected by labor disturbances served to stimulate trade activity in many sections of the country last week.

Another day of fun and frolic and a good time with President Roosevelt was reported by more than 100 Senators and Representatives returning early tonight from the Democratic "harmony" outing at the Jefferson Islands Club, across Chesapeake Bay from here.

The bond market yesterday ended another exceedingly dull week with values at moderately lower levels. The two-hour turnover in all bonds amounted to $4,700,900, compared with. $3,008,300 on the previous Saturday.

A tract of 19,000 acres in the vicinity of Charleston, South Carolina, has been purchased by a syndicate headed by David K. E. Bruce, who married about ten years ago Ailsa Mellon, daughter of Andrew W. Mellon.

The marriage of Miss Anne Hilton Lord, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hartley Little Lord of Auburn and this place, to John Rogers, also of Kennebunk, took place this afternoon in the First Parish Unitarian Church here. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Augustus Mendum Lord of Providence, cousin of the bride, assisted by the Rev. Arthur Schoenfeldt, the pastor.

IN introducing a new line of 1937-38 radios in New York during the past week, James M. Skinner, president of the Philco Radio and Television Corporation, announced that the factories are geared to turn out 2,000,000 home and auto sets during 1937, an increase of 200,000 over 1936.

Stockholders of the New York Title and Mortgage Company announced yesterday that an appeal will be taken from the recent 3-to-2 decision of the Appellate Division that the value of the mortgages in which they have participation, and not the value of the real estate

The names of eleven high school seniors in New York and New Jersey who won prizes in the Fourth Annual Intercholastic Short-Story Contest, conducted by the Department of English at New York University's Washington Square College, were announced yesterday by Dean Milton E. Loomis of the Washington Square College.

FRESH-BLOWN cloud masses are playing tag with the setting sun these days, and New York camera men are well aware of the fact. Nightly, from the Battery to the Bronx, from East Side to West Side, hundreds of enthusiasts are leaving their homes, camera in hand, and returning with beautiful and dramatic pictures.

Employes of McKesson Robbins, Inc., wholesale drugs, extended their sympathetic strike to the company's warehouse at 464 Liberty Street, Brooklyn, yesterday while C. I. O. and A. F. of L. locals representing the strikers filed a joint complaint against the company at the local offices of the National Labor Relations Board, 45 Broadway.

-Mr. and Mrs. Malcolm S. Black of Upper Montclair entertained with a dinner here tonight at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club for Miss Amanda Grace Hayward and Standish Salisbury Rowe, who will be married Tuesday in St. Luke's Church, Montclair.

The marriage of Miss Ruth Wynne Hall, daughter of Mrs. Marlborough Hall of this city and Philadelphia, and the late Mr. Hall, to Reginald Theodore Weber of Brooklyn, son of the late Captain William R. Von Weber, formerly of the Imperial German Army, and Mrs. Weber, took place yesterday morning in St. Paul's Methodist Episcopal Church, Eighty-sixth Street and West End Avenue.

Miss Dorothy Margaret Schnapp, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John A. Schnapp of this city, was married to Lawrence J. Durkin, son of Mrs. John J. Durkin, also of this city, and the late Mr. Durkin, yesterday at noon in the Church of St. Margaret Mary, Tremont and Morris Avenues, the Bronx. The ceremony was performed by the pastor, the Rev. Michael J. Walsh.

COINCIDENT with the fall of Bilbao, the Basque capital, to the Spanish Insurgents, two coins of the Basque provinces have been received in New York. This independent coinage, 1 and 2 peseta pieces minted in Brussels, bears inscriptions in the Basque dialect.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are June 25 unless specified: At San Francisco-Barry, Borie, California, Childs, Dallas, Gilmer, Goff, Hopkins, Idaho, Reuben James, Long, Marblehead, Memphis. Melville, Nevada, New Mexico, Relief, Richmond, Tennessee, Trenton, Trever, Wasmuth, West Virginia, Williamson, Zane. Acushnet, Naval Operating Base, Norfolk to sea.

AN apartment house of unusual design and layout, planned by Andrew J. Thomas, architect, for Robert L. Hecht, New York tea merchant, is being erected at 908-15 Park Avenue, Plainfield, N. J. The house is going up on a triangular plot of 27,000 square feet, but the building itself will cover only 7,173 square feet of ground, or about 27 per cent of the total area.

Over 1,000 alumni and friends of Mount Hermon School took part in a full day's program of events today, which marked the fifty-sixth anniversary of the beginning of the school and the 100th since the birth of the founder, D. L. Moody.
The Inwood station postoffice will move on Tuesday from 3,860 Tenth Avenue, at 207th Street, to new quarters at 90 Vermilyea Avenue, corner of 204th Street.

Mike Jacobs, the man at the throttle of the heavyweight train, threw it wide open on his return to Broadway yesterday from Chicago. He definitely announced his newly crowned heavyweight champion, Joe Louis, will fight abroad this Summer, probably in the Wembley Arena, London, in August.

That there is a steady increase in interest in the pure-bred dog is attested by the greater number of shows and the larger entry lists. The trend is emphasized by an announcement by the American Kennel Club for May.

The Diprectoire ball given in the Palais Royal gardens was a brilliant spectacle. The smartest women wore creitions by leading dressmakers in modernized Directoire styles with authentic accessories; these were principally long scarfs, scoop bonnets, plumed turbans and ribbon-laced sandals. They will continue to wear these gowns on regular evening occasions, thus influencing the mode.

Hope sprang a little higher among the American contingent of race drivers at Roosevelt Raceway today when they learned that Wilbur Shaw, who won the last 500-mile race at Indianapolis, will probably be a starter in the 300-mile Vanderbilt Cup race Saturday.

Treasury officials disclosed today that they will ask the 1938 Congress for a thorough overhauling of the tax structure, designed to make further changes unnecessary for many years. Under the new system, they said, rates could be varied from year to year, depending on economic conditions and governmental needs, without changing the general tax laws.

A tentative decision to close hotels, cafes and restaurants throughout France next Saturday was taken by the Employers Association at a meeting here today. The lockout is to take place, it was stated, unless the government in the meantime modifies the decree published yesterday providing for the introduction of the forty-hour week in the callings inevolved.
THE Summer opera season at the Zoo Garden, Cincinnati, opens tonight with Verdi's opera "Aida." The cast includes Rosa Tentoni, Maru Castagna, Jose de Gaviria, Joseph Royern and Daniel Harris.

Speaking for the national affairs committee of the Socialist party, Norman Thomas in a statement yesterday denounced the refusal of the independent steel companies to negotiate with their striking employes.

Anthony Dvorniak, owner of a grocery store in the Ridgeway district of White Plains, walked into the Ridgeway station of the New York, Westchester Boston Railway late this morning to buy a ticket for New York City.

Announcement has been made by Mrs. Walter George Hooke of this city of the engagement of her daughter, Dr. Mary Stewart Hooke, to Dr. Thomas Campbell Goodwin of Baltimore, son of Mrs. Robert Archer Goodwin of Richmond, Va., and the late Rev. R. A. Goodwin.

A meeting followed by tea will be held for members of the subscription committee for Westchester and Greenwich of the Philharmonic-Symphony Society of New York by the committee chairman, Mrs. Alva Benjamin See on Tuesday at the Belle Haven Beach Club, Greenwich.

Miss Wardu Barbara Lucas, daughter of Mr. end Mrs. G. Brinton Lucas of Midstream Farm, Paoli, was presented to society tonight at a dinner dance which her aunt and uncle, Mr. and Mrs. A. Atwater Kent, gave at their home, West Hills, in Ardmore.

With five Olympic champions, world record holders by the score, more than thirty Olympians and at least sixteen defending champions leading the assault, the crack athletes of the country will assemble at Milwaukee on Friday and Saturday for the fiftieth annual track and field title games of the Amateur Athletic Union.

THIS book is precisely what it proclaims itself to be, that is to say, a chronicle. If, at the close of the tercentenary celebration, Harvard College had had occasion to lay a cornerstone, a copy of this chronicle would have been the one most important document to be included for the persual of future generations.

According to the monthly statistics of the Ontario Department of Mines, production of gold in the province in May reached $7,315,799, derived . from 699,316 tons milled, compared with $6,979,588 from 675,814 tons in the previous month.

ENTIRELY leaving aside the controversial point of Liszt's significance as a composer, there is such a vast amount of fascinating material connected with his public and private adventures, the humanness of his strivings, successes and failures, and, above all, the clashing of his dual personality. that any approach to it can scarcely fail to be of interest.

Miss Vera Warbasse, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. James P. Warbasse of 384 Washington Avenue, Brooklyn, and Charles Willett Spooner Jr., who had previously been married by a civil ceremony, today went through another ceremony, the service for which had been Specially written by the bride's father.

The army is building bird-baths, and hard-boiled sergeants on Governors Island are muttering, "things ain't what they used to be." Some time ago the army post on the island sprang to arms to repel an "invasion" of Japanese beetles; this year it is bird-baths.
HE Note-Books and Papers of Gerard Manley Hopkins" now reverently collected and edited by Humphrey House only confirm, if confirmation were needed, the very real originality of Hopkins's mind.
UNDER THE TENT OF THE SKY" is a delightful poetry collection that may well be added to a child's personal library when he is ready to move on from Mother Goose and nursery jingles.

Miss Mary Sadler, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George B. Sadler of Englewood, was married today in the chapel of St. Paul's Episcopal Church to Albert Timothy Day, also of Englewood. The Rev. James H. Lamb Jr., rector of Christ's Church at Upper Merion, Pa., an uncle of the bride, officiated.

Protesting against impending cuts in the WPA, 5,000 demonstrators, most of them women, picketed City Hall for more than an hour yesterday morning with the intent of obtaining Mayor La Guardia's intervention aid in preventing the staff cuts. It was the largest demonstration at City Hall in recent years and it was entirely orderly.

Mrs. Cecelia Brill, widow of Edward Brill, a founder and former vice president of the J. G. Brill Company, car builders in Philadelphia, died in West Jersey Homeopathic Hospital here today of injuries received in an automobile accident on June 10. She was 71 years old and was a native of Philadelphia.

Miss Honor Marjorie Paul, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Paul of this place, was married this evening in the Worthington Congregational Church to Allerton de Cormis Tompkins, son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Stuart Tompkins of New York and Little Compton, R. I. The Rev. J. Herbert Owen performed the ceremony.

It is extremely difficult to get dependable information on present labor conditions in Russia. In that so-called "paradise of the proletariat" no Russian workman dare openly protest against wage or work conditions, especially to foreign journalists.

The marriage of Miss Mary Eileen Schaefer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Wilber H. Schaefer of Plainfield to Thomas P. Lennon, son of Mrs. Mary E. Lennon of Elmhurst, L. I., and the late P. M. Lennon, took place this morning in St. Mary's Church. The Rev. George, C. P., of Jamaica, L. I., as classmate of the bridegroom, officiated at a nuptial mass.

The following Foreign Service changes since June 18 were announced today by the State Department: Harry L. Troutman of Macon, Ga., Consul at Alexandria, Egypt, assigned to the Department of State. Edward Page Jr., of West Newton. Mass., Consul and Third Secretary of Legation at Riga, to Moscow as Third Secretary of_Embasssy.

A new development is being started in Madison, N. J., by the Webb Estates, Inc., covering three large tracts of land which formerly were part of the estate of the late James A. Webb, head of the Webb Alcohol Company. A new street, known as Wyndehurst Drive, named for the old Webb homestead,

The State Mortgage Commission calls attention to the fact that the closing of three large transactions during the last two weeks, practically two-thirds of the financial task placed upon the commission at its organization, has been concluded. The three recent transactions included the turning over to trustees of the Buchanan apartment hotel

ANATOLE FRANCE was no natural genius, driven to the ardors of literary endeavor by some obscure ferment in his soul. No, to an extent unknown in America save, perhaps, in the close intellectual circles of Boston of a century gone, to an extent rarely equaled even in the centralized literary oligarchies of Paris itself, Anatole France was a made writer.
K. R. Dorries of North East won the free-for-all sailing race today as the North East River Yacht Club opened the Chesapeake Bay regatta season. The craft made good time around a three-mile course.

THE American Association for the Advancement of Science held its Summer meeting in Denver last week and ranged over the vast cosmos. It considered rats and men, stars and cattle, diseases and meteors. Here are some high spots:

Miss Helen Ann Konow, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louise Charles Konow of this city and Belmar, was married to Herman 0. Wey, son of Mr. and Mrs. Emil Wey of Maplewood, this afternoon in the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, Newark, by the pastor, the Rev. Norman McQueen.
The marriage of Miss Virginia S. Dobbins, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Carlton A. Dobbins of Morris Plains, N. J., to Herbert C. Van Ness,

RICHARD STRAUSS'S "Salome," with Erica Darbo in the title role and Alexander Smallens conducting will be the first of a series of opera productions at the Stadium this Summer. Soloists for the week at the Stadium are Lily Pons, soprano, and John Corigliano, violinist.
SUMMER group shows continue to open in the galleries with plentiful and highly diverse fare for the art lover who is undismayed by the season. Most of them will be current into next month or longer.

Assuring a new titleholder, Eddie Held of St. Louis beat the defending champion, John Dawson of Chicago, in the trans-Mississippi golf semi-finals today and will meet Don Schumacher, Dallas, tomorrow, for the title.

THE late Alfred Clark Chapin was for a time something of a mystery to the two booksellers he favored, James F. Drake and Lathrop C. Harper. He continually bought the choicest books but, instead of taking them along, allowed them to accumulate until they filled a large case at the dealer's whence they were sent into storage.

The marriage of Miss Muriel E. Robinson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sherman A. Robinson of Yonkers, to Graham H. Walworth, son of Mrs. Roland Beatty and the late Graham H. Walworth of New York, took place yesterday in St. Andrew's Memorial Church, Yonkers.

The House of Representatives this morning approved the 1937-38 budget of $78,513,778.60 by a vote of 86 to 22. Reducing the figure recommended by the President only $342,000, the lower chamber balanced the budget by the simple expedient of increasing revenue estimates and adding a new income item of $5,500,000 under the vague heading "revenue from special funds."

Progress toward the settlement of the four-day sit-down strike at the local plant of the American Smelting and Refining Company was reported by the management and C. I. O. leaders after a conference this morning,

A report today by the Seventh Federal Reserve Board District Bank disclosed that the production of packing houses had slumped counter-seasonally in May, while creamery butter manufacture rose to its highest level since June, 1936.

The fourth concert of the season at the Lewisohn Stadium was given last night, Victor Golschmann continuing as guest conductor of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra. For a Saturday night event which, furthermore, featured the ever popular Franck symphony, the attendance of 3,000 was relatively small.

Acute nervousness for the French franc characterized an otherwise quiet foreign-exchange market here today. A wave of selling overtook the market and one-month francs weakened to an 8 per cent discount and three-month francs to 10 per

MOST revolutions have been commemorated by postage stamps. In 1876, to mark the hundredth anniversary of American independence, two special envelopes were issued, picturing various means of communication, from the pony express to the telegraph. While not adhesives, they are of particular interest in that they form the earliest known commemorative issue.

The Spanish Government in a note published today firmly rejects the four-power proposal asking guarantees for the safety of naval vessels in the arms patrol off Spain. This caused profound satisfaction throughout Loyalist Spain, particularly since the attitude taken genuinely reflects popular disgust with the whole series of international complications following the bombing of the German battleship Deutschland.

Miss Doris Bartlett Draper of this place and Brooklyn was married to Charles Edgar Rogers 3d, also of Brooklyn, this afternoon in Hyannis Hospital, in the private room of the bridegroom, who thiteen hours before had been operateon for an attack of appendicitis.

A nose on the finishing post decided the $25,025 Brooklyn Handicap before 18,000 wildly excited spectators at Aqueduct yesterday to make the forty-ninth running of the race the most thrilling in its long history. Seabiscuit from California won from Aneroid of Maryland, as veterans who have seen every running of the Brooklyn pronounced it the most remarkable finish from the day Dry Monopole took the inaugural by a head in 1887.

Nineteen of the twenty houses in Forest Hills West, L. I., recently placed on the market by the Easy-to-Own Homes Organization Easy-to-Own Homes Organization through Frank O'Hara, Inc., Jack son Heights, broker, have been less sold, he reports. The houses are on Sixty-second and Alderton Streets, Sixty-second Drive and Sixty-third Avenue.

A conservative buying procedure for the present is recommended to industrial purchasing executives by the business survey committee of the National Association of Purchasing Agents in its report on June business.

PARIS.--The motion - picture profession will now build its own church in the Paris suburb Joinville-le-Pont, the French "Hollywood." Funds for the structure, which is to be called Notre Dame du Cinema, will be raised principally through the making of a film, "Paris, Light of the World," in which Archbishop Cardinal Verdier has promised to play the leading part.

The regulation banning sales below cost, and the calculation of prices according to standard cost sheets, becomes effective on July 6 for the manufacturers of millinery ranging in price from $10.50 to $15 per dozen, comprising Group C of the Eastern Women's Headwear Association, was stated yesterday by Maxwell E. Lopin, counsel for the organization.

Treaty Indians of the Great Slave Lake area, 600 miles north of Edmonton, are on strike against payment arrangements and have refused to accept treaty money from Dr. J. E. Amyot, Indian agent at Resolution, asserting that he has imposed too severe restrictions upon them.

Three and one-half miles from the finish of a hard struggle today, Yankee and Ranger dropped out of the last observation series race in the America's Cup eliminations. There was half an hour left of the time period in which it was stipulated the contest become completed and it seemed that they could get home in time.

The wedding of Miss Lois Louise Sturm, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William C. Sturm of 160 Fairmount Avenue, to Herbert Lees, son of Orville J. Lees of Brooklyn, took place this evening at the home of the bride.

IF it is in a people's songs that their hearts speak, it is in their tales that we may best understand their life and thought. A selection of native stories such as this, so skillfully retold by a rarely gifted storyteller, is perhaps, even for an adult, the best approach to the actual cultural background of the Hawaiian people as Captain Cook found them before contact was set up with Western civilization.

Postmaster Albert Goldman anounces that the Station B Postoffice will move into its new building at 128 East Broadway tomorrow. The office has been for several years at 45 Suffolk Street. The new site has a frontage of 50 feet on East Broadway running through to Division Street with 75 feet

It is nearly July and still there is no telling who is going to run for Mayor on what ticket. Nominations must be in by Aug. 10. Mayor Fiorello La Guardia is the strongest candidate yet in the field, but will he be the candidate of the Republicans or of the American Laborites, or of some Fusion combination?

IT wa an entirely new theory of the cause of rain and snow static, which-by blotting out the radio signals has been assigned as at least a contributory cause of a number of the latest accidents in air transport, that was announced last week by Herbert M. Hucke, chief of United Air Lines' communications laboratory, at the Summer meeting of the Institute of the Aeronautical Sciences.

A Presidential Palace spokesman announced today that the Cuban Government had agreed to the appointment of J. Butler Wright as United States Ambassador to Cuba to succeed the present envoy, Jefferson Caffery, who has been on leave from his post for three months.

A petition that Great Britain "fully and fairly fulfill the obligations" of her League of Nations mandate over Palestine was made public last night at the opening session of the convention of the Zionist Organization of America at the Hotel Roosevelt.

The Board of Tax Appeals today upheld a finding by the Commissioner of Internal Revenue that Lammot du Pont of Wilmington could not deduct from his 1930 income the sum of $46,392 which he had abandoned hope of collecting from R. O. Marsh, a fraternity brother at Massachusetts Institute of Technology, to whom he had advanced the money to finance a "white Indian" hunt in Panama.
Dr. R. Dadiani, Rumanian physician whose cabin-mate disappeared mysteriously while they were traveling from Brazil to France, started back to Brazil today to face questioning.
Robert S. Taplinger of 485 Madison Avenue has purchased Caresend, a sixteen-acre estate at Irvington-on-Hudson, in Westchester County, through Prince Ripley, brokers.

Movements involving 4,500 New York State National Guardsmen will take place tonight and tomorrow as units, mostly from the metropolitan area, move in and out of the State reservation, Camp Smith and Pine Camp here.

THIS country is spotted from coast to coast and from Lakes to Gulf with planned settlements, some alive, some dead and dying. They were born of compelling convictions, religious, political, social. Those who founded them saw the "good life" ahead--a sure thing.

Sales of lead and zinc pigments in 1936 increased 14 per cent over 1935 in both value and tonnage, according to the United States Bureau of Mines, reflecting the greater demand for paint, automobiles, pneumatic tires and storage batteries, all major pigment-consuming industries.

A large reception with dancing was given by Mr. and Mrs. Robert Hayes Putnam this afternoon at their home on Center Island to introduce their daughter, Miss JeAhne Putnam to society. Dancing took place in a marquee erected on the east lawn.

Indications that times a better for the nation's teachers were plentiful here today as hundreds of educators poured into Detroit ahead of schedule for the annual convention of the National Education Association, whose sessions start with a vesper service tomorrow afternoon.

While the rising costs of building are causing some cessation in the construction of low-cost housing, the effect of higher costs will probably show little if any diminution of new home building in the choice home centers of Westchester County, states R. Eugene Curry,

ALTHOUGH the country is troubled by serious labor strife and the motor industry has been hampered in its production schedules by sit-down strikes in its factories and by delays in securing materials from suppliers, retail demand for passenger cars has held up surprisingly well.
Detective Captain E. A. Hedman said tonight a middle-aged man, "seeking relief from family troubles," admitted he started thirtysix fires causing damage estimated "conservatively" at $2,000,000.

Craving heroin, of which he had been deprived during a night in jail, Joseph Resciniti of 234 East Thirteenth Street, an inveterate narcotic addict and ex-convict, said to be only 26 years old, made a desperate attempt to escape yesterday from the Federal courthouse in Foley Square.

Delaware Park, the $750,000 plant of William Du Pont Jr., and associates, opened its gates today and most of the near-capacity crowd of 18,000 went home well pleased, for Mrs. C. Oliver Iselin's Strabo, well backed second choice, took the featured $10,000 added Kent Handicap.
THEY come in thousands, grandfathers and grandmothers, honeymooners, little children and their bigger brothers and sisters, and they come every day except Sunday.

Harry Byrd Davis of Ridgewood, N. J., head of the H. B. Davis Printing Company, 44 Warren Street, this city, died here Friday in the Park West Hospital at the age of 62. He had been connected with The New York Commercial before establishing his printing business in 1922.

FOR the veteran radio listener the Braddock-Louis fight a few nights ago conjured up a parade of champions and challengers that goes back across the wave lengths to 1921. Marching along the waves that have long since flashed off into the infinite are the muscular figures of Jack Dempsey and Georges Carpentier, Luis Firpo and Harry Wells, Gene Tunney, Sharkey, Heeney, Stribling. Schmeling and Baer.

Mr. and Mrs. Max Auster of 114 East Ninetieth Street have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Edythe Kathryn Auster, to Alfred Greenfield Vigderman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Vigderman of Philadelphia.

Defeating V. Mikenas of Lithuania in the ninth round at the Kurhaus today, Samuel Reshevsky of New York, chess champion of the United States, maintained his winning streak and held first place in the international masters' tournament.

The stratosphere was suggested at the final meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science today as the place of manufacture of the new particle of matter discovered two months ago by scientists at Harvard and the California Institute of Technology.

Still determined to convert his estate on the end of Davenport Neck, facing Long Island Sound, into a beach club, Charles D. Beckwith made another application this week to the New Rochelle Board of Zoning Appeals for removal of residential restrictions on his property. Decision was reserved.

Stephen Ogilvy, New Rochelle, N. Y., reached the third round ofthe Mountain Lakes Club tennis tournament today by upsetting Stephen Brubans, Hoboken. Ogilvy downed the veteran in the second round, 6-3, 4-6, 6-3. John Kroel, Passaic, beat James MacFarland, local entrant.

Miss Mary Louise Weikert, daughter of Constantine Weikert of Englewood, N. J., and the late Mrs. Weikert, was married here yesterday morning to Laurence C. Tuttle, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur S. Tuttle of Brooklyn, in the Church of the Transfiguration, by the rector, the Rev. Dr. Randolph Ray.

" Our only hope for ultimate peace lies in everlasting work throug' understanding and toleration," said Miss Edith W. Fisher of Boston, chairman of the committee on international relations of Zonta International, during the discussion today on the adoption of the youth peace project.
In an interview which he gave on his arrival from Europe Dr. ROBERT A. MILLIKAN voiced the opinion that democracy's hope lies in the extension of the scientific approach to government.

QUEBEC, Que.--Americans resident in Quebec for the Summer will have an opportunity to celebrate national holidays of Canada and the United States next week. Dominion Day falls on Thursday and the following Sunday is Independence Day. Elaborate preparations are being made by the Summer colony here fittingly to honor both days.

The marriage of Miss Nancy Kershaw, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Kershaw of Forest Hills, Queens, to Everett Parsons Tomlinson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Roy E. Tomlinson of Montclair, N. J., and Chatham, Mass., took place yesterday afternoon in St. Luke's Protestant Episcopal Church, Forest Hills.

College publicity officers should not attempt to censor or color the news of their institutions which they release to the press, a special committee representing colleges in New York State reported to the American College Publicity Association at its annual convention in Louisville last Thursday.
Harry Cooper of Chicago won the 72-hole True Temper golf tourney today, posting a 38, 30-68 last-round score for an aggregate of 280.

IN the past five Summer seasons Day Tuttle and I have made about seventy-five productions in the Summer theatre, and of these seventy-five productions only six have been tryouts of new scripts. The rest have been revivals ranging from Shakespeare to Sidney Howard.

Miss Julia Sands Dickson this afternoon had the honor of being the first debutante of the season here., She was introduced at a reception given by her mother, Mrs. Sands Dickson, at her house on Rhode Island Avenue, though Mrs. Dickson makes her home with her mother, Mrs. Frederic P. Sands, and her sister, Mrs. Giraud Foster Elliott, at Greenough Place and Catherine Street.

With Leonard Hartman of New York, runner-up in last year's tournament, heading the draw, the annual New Jersey State men's tennis singles championship got under way today at the Montclair Athletic Club. A field of ninety-one, one of the largest in the history

The Summer children's camps of the Westchester County Recreation Commission at Croton Point, Harmon-on-Hudson, will open on Monday for the eleventh consecutive season, it was announced today by E. Dana Caulkins, Superintendent of Recreation.

King Carol and Crown Prince Michael of Rumania arrived here this afternoon to return President Ignaz Moscicki's State visit to Bucharest a fortnight ago. Warsaw's citizens gave them a rousing welcome, hundreds of thousands lining the route from the railroad station to the Lazienki Palace, where the royal guests will stay during their four-day visit.
The Yankee attack slipped into reverse yesterday at the Stadium and the world champions lost to the Tigers before an enthusiastic gathering of 21,148 fans. The count was 5 to 3.

Mrs. Mildred Clarke Kienbusch of New York City and Charles F. Chase of Sparta, N. J., were among those elected as honorary vice presidents of the Chase-Chace Family Association at its annual meeting here today. Many New Yorkers were among the 200 members present.

The hot Summer sun is having its effect on the fruit and vegetable market. Shoppers are beginning to notice the difference in the variety and quality of produce displayed. Though warm weather adds to the quality and the crop yield of some garden products, it affects others adversely.

Argentina is making ready to mass 100,000 powerful flamethrowers against an enemy within her borders-locusts. The National Board of Defense announced a broad program to be carried out within the coming year for battling the insects through every stage of life.

The Commonwealth Arbitration Court this week unanimously awarded to fifty-three unions, representing 600,000 workers, basil wages increases averaging 5s weekly over the whole Commonwealth. The estimated annual gain to the workers is [Pound]6,250,000.

Miss Margery Frances Mitchell, daughter of Colonel and Mrs. William A. Mitchell of West Point, was married here this afternoon in the Cadet Chapel of the United States Military Academy to Lieutenant James B. Lampert, Corps of Engineers, U.S.A., son of Mrs. Lloyd

Tragedy marred the closing day of the Penn-Jersey Harness Racing Association program at the Trenton Fair Grounds today as Elaine Hanover, owned by W. E. Miller of Washington dropped dead as she crossed the finish line in sixth place in the second heat of the third race.
Premier Paul van Zeeland of Belgium deferred his departure for New York from today until tomorrow in order to obtain rest.

Bainbridge Ave, 2,786, (12-3290); Halbridge Building Corp to Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank; extends mtge to June 23, 1947, at 41/2 to 5 per cent; $145,000. 156th St. (10-2736); n e cor Barry St, 194x 118; Gold Medal Farms, Inc. to Dickey Corp, $1,161 E 156th St, 5 1/2 per cent; $10,000.

Germany's rebellious Protestant pastors got down to fundamentals in their struggle with the National Socialist regime this week when the Prussian Brotherhood Council issued instructions not to obey two ordinances issued by the Reich Ministry of the Interior.

An encouraging picture of apartment house renting in Manhattan is contained in a report of a survey recently completed by the Mortgage Conference of New York. In an effort to supply the answer to the oft-repeated question about the effect of new construction on slightly older buildings, the conference compiled data on vacancies

Condemning the imposition of special tariffs disguised as excise taxes on imported goods, foreign traders said yesterday that the secondary results of such imposts are as serious as those arising from regular tariff duties.

Mr. and Mrs. Frederick C. Tanner of New York and this place gave a dance tonight at the Creek Club here for their debutante daughter, Miss Jane Ogden Tanner. The dance took place in an outdoor marquee lined with silver and white silk and connected with the clubhouse by a canopy.

A Summer program of training of youth for retail store work will start July 6 at the Central Commercial High School, 214 East 42nd Street, under the auspices of the Board of Education and the WPA. Courses will include Salesmanship, Store Management, Merchandising, and Window Display.

Independence Day will be celebrated here July 5. There will be a joint program for both residents of the Park and villagers. Gilbert W. Keech is chairman of the committee, which includes Eben Richards, treasurer; Griswold Lorillard, Crawford Blagden Jr., John W. Winters, David Nagle, Robert Bentley; Louis Euvrard and Vincent Macaluso.

Dr. Adolfo Alejandro Nouel, former President of the Dominican Republic and former Archbishop, died here today. He was 75 years old. Dr. Nouel, widely known orator, was elected Provisional President in 1912 and resigned in March, 1913. He presented his resignation as Archbishop of Santo Domingo (now Ciudad Trujillo) to Pope Pius in 1931.

Mr. and Mrs. Charles Goodwin Cushing, who are passing the season at Lloyds Neck, Huntington, gave a dinner dance tonight at the Piping Rock Club to introduce their elder daughter, Miss Elizabeth McK. Cushing, to North Shore society.

College professors, government experts, churchmen and labor secretaries will lead discussions at the sixth New England Institute of International Relations, which will open its eleven-day session Tuesday at Wellesley College.
Mrs. Myrtle F. Kerngood, 47, of this city, disappeared today from the Chesapeake Bay steamer City of Norfolk and is believed to have drowned in the bay.

The following is the chart showing how the Brooklyn Handicap was run at Aqueduct yesterday: 6324 FIFTH RACE--The Brooklyn Handicap; $20,000 added; 3-year olds and upward; one mile and a furlong. Start good; won driving; place easily. Went to post 4:13, off 4:15. Winner, b. c., 4, by Hard Tack--Swing On. Trainer, T. Smith. Value to winner, $18,025; second, $4,000; third, $2,000; fourth, $1,000. Time--1:501-5. Weather cloudy; track fast.

The marriage of Miss Marion Lurene Maybury, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Maybury Jr. of East Orange, to Lester Vorhis Jochem, son of Mr. and Mrs. Warren Jochem of East Rutherford, took place this afternoon at the First Presbyterian Church of Orange. The Rev. Raymond Irving Lindquist officiated.

Mr. and Mrs. Harold A. Reich of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Harriet Sylvia Reich, to Myron Heidingsfield, son of Mrs. Benjamin Heidingsfield, also of New York, and the late Mr. Heidingsfield.

Patrolmen Edward J. Callahan and Aloysius Nevins were dismissed from the Police Department yesterday following departmental trials. Their ousting brings the total of dismissals made by Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine to 174 during the two and one-half years he has headed the department.
The marriage of Miss Elizabeth Moore Lincoln, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alan M. Lincoln of this place, to Ledyard Stevens Bowen of New York took place this afternoon in Christ Church here.

Miss Mary Denise Hurley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Leo Hurley of Brooklyn, was married yesterday in St. Augustine's Roman Catholio Church, Brooklyn, to John Lynn McManus, son of Terence J. McManus of New York and the late Mrs. McManus. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. James Helpenstein.

The news of the triumphant flight of three Soviet aviators to the United States by way of the North Pole came as a breath of fresh air after the strain and tension of the Red Army executions and the nation-wide purge of "enemies."

IN anticipation of this week's heavy holiday traffic, highway officials in the metropolitan area are opening new links of roads which are expected to carry many motorists to and from resorts and parks in Long Island, New Jersey and Westchester.

Further relative strength in the spot month quotation counteracted the influence of continued favorable weather in the South, so prices on the Cotton Exchange here held within narrow limits yesterday to end 2 points higher to 1 point lower. From a discount of 13 points on Wednesday, the July rose to a 2-point premium over the October when price fixing by mills disclosed few contracts in the market.

The Military Order of the Purple Heart, which is holding its annual State and Eastern zone convention here, last-night held a dinner at the Park Central Hotel in honor of Howard J. Lepper, national adjutant and past commander of the order. Governor Hoffman of New Jersey was the principal speaker.

The Board of Education will open 386 supervised public school playgrounds and athletic fields next Thursday for the use of children until Aug. 30, Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, has announced.

The marriage of Miss Jean Marie O'Halloran, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. O'Halloran of this city, to Cornelius T. Blessing of East Orange took place this morning in the Immaculate Conception Chapel of Seton Hall College, South Orange.

LAKE PLACID -- Opening of scheduled activities here with an ice event on Saturday will serve to differentiate the Adirondack season from that at other centers in the country and will lend an unusual aspect to the celebration of the Fourth.

King George and Queen Elizabeth, the Archbishop of Canterbury and 500 distinguished visitors will go to the Tate Gallery Tuesday morning for the opening of the new wing of modern sculpture, designed by John Russell Pope of New York
Five hundred persons attended the first supper dance of the season at the Greenwich Country Club tonight. It was held on the outdoor terrace.

The decline in THE NEW YORK TIMES weekly index of business activity was checked in the week ended June 19 as five of its components moved higher. The index advanced to 107.2 from 107.1, and compared with 99.2 for the corresponding week last year.

THE bicentenary of the death of Antonio Stradivari is being elaborately celebrated this Summer in Cremona, his native city, whose name has been made illustrious above all by the great violin maker's art.

GILBERT WHITE'S "Natural History of Selborne" is sound enjoyment for the lover of nature. His goal was never beyond his compass, for he believed that "men that undertake only one district are much more likely to advance natural knowledge than those that grasp more than they can-possibly be acquainted with;

IT is a curious fact that, although every phase of Wagner's com plex life, psychology and labors have been and continue to be tirelessly explored, nobody seems to have occupied himself to any degree with the rather human question of what the creator of "Tristan" and "Meistersinger" liked to eat.

Miss Natalie Green, daughter of Mrs. Herbert Post Green of Forest Hills Gardens and the late Mr. Green, was married last night in the Church-in-the-Gardens, Forest Hills Gardens, to Lloyd Luther Maurer of New York, son of Dr. Irving Maurer, president of Beloit College, Beloit, Wis., and Mrs. Maurer. Dr. Maurer performed the ceremony.

Many New Yorkers will attend the wedding on Wednesday of Miss Ethel du Pont, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene du Pont of Owls Nest, Greenville, near Wilmington, Del., to Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr., son of the President and Mrs. Roosevelt.

SARATOGA SPRINGS. -- The recreation unit of Saratoga Springs has a busy calendar for next week, including the introduction of collective reducing exercises, designed by Edwin Ladue, director, for Saratogians and Summer visitors.

TRAVEL through the Panama Canal grows heavier as sightseers en route to Western South America, California and the Orient increase. Nor does Summer bring a let-up. Large numbers of school teachers, students and others select the Canal Zone among tour objectives. Interest in the waterway is now increased by the announcement of preliminary plans for enlargement of this channel connecting two oceans.

Mrs. Faye Larson, living on a farm three miles east of Ava, said today she had found while pulling weeds, a ring bearing the name of Zachary Lansdowne, commander of the dirigible Shenandoah, which crashed Sept. 3, 1925, near Ava.

FOUR years after the advent of Adolf Hitler, German Nazism, despite the predictions and the hopes of its foes, is more firmly entrenched than ever. Those who looked upon the events of Jan. 30, 1933, as a social and mass uprising are now able to look back and, in retrospect, realize how wrong they were. For, as Professor Brady points out, Germany went through no social revolution.

Robert Irwin, eccentric sculptor, who murdered Veronica (Ronnie) Gedeon, New York model; her mother and a roomer in the Gedeon apartment in New York City last Easter, surrendered in Chicago today and immediately afterward confessed the crimes.

Sir Charles Clegg, president of the football association which is in charge of British professional soccer, died today at Sheffield at the age of 87. Although millions of pounds are bet annually on soccer matches, Sir Charles never placed a bet of any kind.

The wedding of Miss Frances Long, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank V. Long of East Orange, to L. Cretney Bunnell, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred R. Bunnell of Orange, took place this afternoon in the chapel of the First Presbyterian Church of Orange. The pastor, the Rev. Raymond Lindquist, performed the ceremony.

There was a double wedding in the family of Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas J. Healy Jr. of this city yesterday morning in the Church of Our Lady of Lourdes, West 142d Street, when their daughters were married--Miss Rosemary Frances Healy to William Joseph Walsh Jr., and Miss Marjorie Cecilia Healy to Lester Dewis Borden.

Test pilots and inspectors of the Bureau of Air Commerce, it was revealed today, have about completed tests on a new all-metal, twin-engined commercial amphibian built by the Grumman Corporation at Bethpage, L. I.

Despite the near approach of the early Fall buying period, many merchants have yet definitely to shape their Fall buying budgets. Those retailers who have prepared their initial Fall program have done so on the conservative basis of a 5 to 8 per cent gain in sales and no increase in units, while others plan to watch economic developments during the next few weeks and frame their budgets accordingly.

Miss Lois Golder Cline, daughter of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Thomas S. Cline of this place, was married here this afternoon in Christ Church to Bernard Patton Ireland of New York, son of Mrs. Walter B. Sherwood and the late Walter A. Ireland. The ceremony was performed by the bride's father, who is rector of the church.

Miss Janet Debrot, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John Cornelis Frederik Debrot of New York and Mason Island, Conn., was married to Theodore Tholfsen, son of Mrs. Thorwald Tholfsen of Brooklyn and the late Mr. Tholfsen, yesterday in St. Stephen's Protestant Episcopal Church in West Sixty-ninth Street. The Rev. Dr. Nathan A. Seagle, rector of the church, performed the ceremony.

The Westchester County Park Commission's engineers are surveying between 200 and 300 acres of the Rockefeller estate at Pocantico Hills surrounding the reservoir that supplies the Tarrytowns with a view to the acquisition of the tract for a park and picnic grounds, it was announced here today by Arthur W. Lawrence of Mount Kisco, chairman of the commission.
The Lewiston Daily Sun reported today that its editions, issued on paper made experimentally by the Great Northern Paper Company from Southern slash pine pulp, printedd well."
Justice Lewis L. Fawcett in the Supreme Court in Brooklyn awarded yesterday a verdict of $67,500 to Dr. Lester J. Schultz of the Robert Fulton Hotel, West End Avenue
Achieving speed boat honors never before attained by a rival, Thomas Tyson today for the fourth consecutive year carried off the intercollegiate outboard championship in Class A.

New Jersey fishermen had a taste of tuna fishing during the last few days that presages well for the weeks to come. Hundreds of fish were taken by those who left Brielle, the tuna ranging in weight from thirty-five pounds to seventy pounds.

Ambassador and Mrs. Bingham gave a dance on Wednesday night at the United States Embassy for Lady Jean Ogilvy, debutante daughter of Lord and Lady Arlie. Among the hostesses who gave dinner parties before the dance were the Countess of Bessborough, Mrs. John BowesLyon, the Countess of Dahlhousie, Lady Marjorie Dalrymple-Hamilton, Lady de Trafford, Mrs. Gerard Leigh, Lady Morrison-Bell, the Marchioness of Titchfield, the Countess of Westmoreland and Lady Zia Wernher.

HOT weather provided a stimulant to retail trade in Summer goods during the week, but the distribution picture remained spotty. The range of results was from volume a little under a year ago in this area to gains of up to 25 per cent in the Southwest. The stores, of course, had to beat the higher figures of last year when the veterans' bonus was being distributed.

Construction of Wheeler Dam will be officially completed tomorrow with an almost complete lack of formal attention. Most officials seem surprised when they are reminded that no further funds for construction work will be available
LAST Summer Victor issued an album of eight Slavonic Dances from Dvorak's Op. 46 and 72, played by the Czech Philharmonic Orchestra under the direction of Vaclav Talich (Album M-310).

Announcemeflt has been made of the engagement of Miss Grace Elinor Groff, younger daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John D. Groff of this city, to C. Howard Van Atta, son of Mr. and Mrs. R. Howard Van Atta of Rye Beach, Ohio.

Miss Mary Virginia Hamilton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Browning Hamilton of this place, was married this evening in St. Luke's Episcopal Church here to Douglass G. Adair Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Douglass G. Adair of Mobile, Ala. The ceremony was performed by the rector, the Rev. Dr. Luke M. White.

Sailing in a fresh northeasterly breeze, the seven member yacht clubs of the Barnegat Bay Yacht Racing Association sent sixty-three yachts away today in the opening championship regatta of the season.
Mayor La Guardia issued a safe and sane Fourth of July proclamation yesterday in which he pointed out that the sale and discharge of fireworks in New York City on Independence Day has been outlawed.

By Adolf Hitler's order, an elaborate program for "German Cultural Week" has been arranged to be held at the Paris Exposition, Sept. 2-12. Germany's foremost artists, including Richard Strauss and Wilhelm Furtwaengler, will conduct Wagnerian and Strauss operas.

Miss Virginia Anne Martin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry J. Martin of this town, was married to Walter Dillon, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Dillon of Newark this morning in the Prospect Presbyterian Church here by the Rev. Arthur Nelson Butz, the pastor.

The sit-down habit reached the South Seas when members of the Fono of New Zealand Samoa sat down but refused to legislate. The Fono is a gathering of representatives of native tribes and consists of thirty-nine Faipules, chosen by native custom,

The marriage of Miss Heroise Weber, daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. Herman C. Weber of East Orange, to Kenneth L. Wilkinson Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. K. L. Wilkinson, also of East Orange, took place this evening in Central Brick Presbyterian Church here.

Striking employes of the Phillip?? Packing Company greeted a "save our-crops-and-homes" plea from farmers today with the slogan "I?? we get ours, you'll get yours." Russell P. Smith, Dorchester County Register of Wills, who operates a large farm, presented the farmers' plea to a meeting of 600 of the 2,000 strikers at the State armory.

A drama of the Northwest will be unfolded here August 5 to 8 when a cast of 400 characters will present, for the third year, a pageant extolling the life of Pere Jacques Marquette, whose exploration of the Mississippi River changed the maps of the seventeenth century.
James Dearborn Kent, for the last nine years assistant head master of St. Paul's School here, died of a heart ailment at his apartment in the school after a long illness. His age was 57.

The exposition, which has the approval and thorough cooperation of fashionable society, and the Grande Saison in Paris are attracting to this side of the Channel much of the mundane brilliance that characterized the coronation in London.

New York City's Summer education program, opening this week, will emphasize both in its instructional and recreational aspects the solution of maladjustment problems arising in school, in the home and in underprivileged neighborhoods.

Hawaii's newest invention will be used next week to harvest sugar cane on the strike-bound Puunene plantation on Maui Island, it was revealed today by John Waterhouse, president of the plantation company.
