Announcement has been made by Mrs. Walter George Hooke of this city of the engagement of her daughter, Dr. Mary Stewart Hooke, to Dr. Thomas Campbell Goodwin of Baltimore, son of Mrs. Robert Archer Goodwin of Richmond, Va., and the late Rev. R. A. Goodwin.
Miss Mary Senate Howes, daughter of the First Assistant Postmaster General and Mrs. William W. Howes, was married today to John Alexander Stewart, son of Mrs. Lawrence

Economics Minister Hjalmar Schacht, in a facetious mood, tonight told United States delegates to the International Chamber of Commerce Congress here: "There is little difference in theory between Secretary of State Cordell Hull and myself, although it is claimed we have a different weltanschauung [world outlook].

Miss Eunice Dean of San Antonio, Texas, won a thrilling match from Miss Millicent Hirsh of New York to take the New Jersey State women's title for the second consecutive year at the Oratani Field Club today. Miss Dean came from behind to win, 3-6, 7-5, 6-3.

The Charlton Athletic soccer team of England recorded an easy victory over the Pennsylvania stars at Northeast High Field today. The visitors scored by 7--0 for their tenth straight triumph after being held to a 1-1 tie in New York.

CONTINUING the policy embarked upon with its new for mat at the beginning of the year, the Magazine of Art for June contains a diversity of articles ranging from "Is Restoration Necessary?" by Sheldon Keck of the Brooklyn Museum, to "America Is Outgrowing Imitation Greek Architecture," by William Lescaze, which was the subject that exponent of modernism selected for his address before the American Federation of Arts at its recent annual convention.
A new teletypewriter linked the State Department of correction today with the extensive network of the State police.

For the first time since 1932 the United States this year will produce enough wheat for its own domestic needs and still have enough left over to help fill the emptied grain elevators of Europe. This despite probable damage to both Winter and Spring crops from black rust.

Formal opening of the new home community known as Fair Estates at Dry Harbor Road and Caldwell Avenue, Rego Park, Queens, is announced for this week by the owning syndicate, composed of Julius Land, David Meltzer and Samuel Butwinick.

John Farson, senior partner in the brokerage firm of Farson, Son Co., died of a heart attack Friday in his home at 830 Park Avenue. He was 55 years old. Mr. Farson, who was a former member of the New York Stock Exchange, had specialized in municipal bond business.
THROUGHOUT his book this veteran pulpwood editor uses the word "pulpwoods" as if he were thus designating some peculiar kind of forest. And the metaphor is as apt as it is easy.

The marriage of Miss Betty McCreery, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ira G. McCreery of this place, to John E. Hauser, son of Mrs. H. K. Null of Philadelphia and the late John E. Hauser, took place here this afternoon at the home of the bride's parents.
The Mott Haven Health Center, second of eight centers to be opened by the city this Summer and Fall, will be dedicated on Tuesday. The building, at 349 East 140th Street, the Bronx, cost $209,978.

Larry Kelley, Yale's football, baseball and basketball star, has definitely turned his back on a major league diamond career. Not even a high financial offer, said to be $5,000, from the Cardinals could induce the Eli All-America end to put his name to a big league contract.

The "K" Line, (Kawasaki Kisen Kaisha) will begin a new direct monthly service to North China from Los Angeles and San Francisco, effective with the sailing of the motorship Eidsuold from Los Angeles Sept. 23, and from San Francisco Sept. 28, followed at monthly intervals by the Nailsea Meadow in October and the motor ship Skagerak in November.
Mr. and Mrs. Harry Levine of Brooklyn have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Norma Levine, to Dr. Leo Stoll, son of Dr. and Mrs. Victor Stoll, also of Brooklyn.

The marriage of Dr. Marion Leone Cottrell, daughter of Mrs. Edgar Henry Cottrell of this city and Pawcatuck, Conn., and thelate Mr. Cottrell, to Charles Henry Birdsall, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles A. Birdsall, also of New York, took place yesterday

A STATEMENT in an article about Houston, Texas, published in the Travel Section of June 6 has stirred a dispute. In a paragraph devoted to conditions in Galveston it was said that "along its docks you come upon cotton sheds and warehouses virtually idle."

Baltimore made it four out of five in its series with Jersey City here today by taking the second game of a double-header, 4 to 2, after the Jerseys had won the first, 2 to 1. Ben Cantwell, stopping the Orioles with six hits,

AMERICAN soldiers somewhere in France--that was the news flashed to the millions at home in the United States twenty years ago. Sailors in our fighting ships had already gone to the war. Now both army and navy were represented overseas.
THREE HUNDRED AND FIFTY YEARS ago a little band of 121 men, women and children sailed from England and landed at Roanoke Island, in the coastal waters off North Carolina.

Plans for foot the marriage of Miss Louisa Thompson MacGill, daughter of Mrs. J. Charles MacGill and the late Dr. MacGill, to J. Wister Huey Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Wister Huey, have been announced.

Ryan, also of Haworth, took place here yesterday morning in the rectory of St. Patrick's Cathedral. The Rev. Joseph A. Tytheridge performed the ceremony.

The plant of the Philadelphia Wholesale Drug Company, a pharmacists's cooperative organization which furnishes bacteriological and medical supplies to about 1,500 retail druggists in this area, was tied up today by a strike of part of the 400 employes.
Major and Mrs. James R. Werth of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Polly Herndon Werth, to Cary Jacquelin Randolph of Martinsville, Va., youngest son of Winslow

THE West Side's eighty-yearold dream of busy streets freed from trains will be virtually realized tomorrow when the second stage of the $100,000,000 West Side improvement is completed and put into service.

Co-medalists yesterday with a subpar 69, E. W. Hoyt of the Garden City Golf Club and L. O. Smith of Cherry Valley recorded two close victories today and moved into the semi-finals of the second annual invitation best-ball tournament at Cherry Valley.

FRIEDMAN-SCHACHTER--Mr. and Mrs. Louis Schachter of 1,645 Grand Concourse, New York City, announce the engagement of their daughter, Eleanor Hortense, to Mr. Norman Friedman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Friedman. GUGGENHEIMER--QUINT--Mrs. Ethel F. Dlugo announces the engagement of her niece, Miss Miriam J. Quint, to Mr. Edward S. Guggenhelmer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Julius Guggenheimer.

Sharp improvement in the spot rate, but continued deterioration of the forward position, characterized the market for the French franc yesterday as financial centers here and abroad awaited developments tomorrow upon the arrival in France of Georges Bonnet, the new Finance Minister, who also will continue as Ambassador to the United States.

The growing unrest in Democratic ranks in Congress, which was noted in these columns in April and was confined then to cloakroom murmurings and private office fulminations, has in the vast two months developed to the point where no one, not even President Roosevelt, can ignore it.

The crew of the stricken British freighter Sandgate Castle, who abandoned the foundering and burning 7;634-ton ship less than two hours after the first S O S message was sent out yesterday morning, were picked up from life boats last night by the American passenger liner President Pierce.

French Cabinets tend to follow each other in rapid succession. There have been thirteen in the last five years and Leon Blum had therefore far exceeded the expected span when he stepped down last week after more than a year in office.

WATERFOWL of the United States, after having dropped to the lowest numbers in history during the drought years from 1931 to 1934, seem to be on the increase again, according to observations made during the current nesting season on the refuges maintained by the Bureau of Biological Survey of the Department of Agriculture.

Secretary Perkins denied tonight that she had made a proposal that Governor Davey summon Tom M. Girdler of Republic Steel and Frank Purnell of Youngstown Sheet and Tube and hold them until they signed with the C. I. O. A statement issued for her read:

Yacht racing on Moriches Bay started today under auspices of the Yacht Racing Squadron of the Country Club of Westhampton Beach. Thirty-four yachts went to the starting line off the club's station on the Speonk Shore.

Miss Helen Margaret Fitts, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Fitts of this city, and Thomas Hollinger of Lyndhurst, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Hollinger, were married this afternoon at the First Methodist Episconal Church here.

Captain Franklin Luckman encountered a new kind of strike today--in front of his own police station. Five boys paraded past carrying cards: "Strike! We want the use of fireplugs," "Unfair to children on Glenmore Avenue."

The continuing effort in the United States to find a solution for the pressing problem of relations between labor and employers has thrust into prominence the British Trade Disputes Act, which is often pointed to as a model solution for that type of problem.

Miss Agnes Driscoll, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Driscoll of Brooklyn, was married yesterday in the Holy Name of Jesus Church, Brooklyn, to John W. Kickham, son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Kickham of Granville, N. Y. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. John F. White, president and chaplain of the College of New Rochelle.
Miss Lucille Dimm, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lloyd Dimm of this city, was married this afternoon to Jules J. Devigne, son of Mrs. Jules J. Devigne of Hawthorne and the late Mr. Devigne.

Debits to individual accounts, as reported by banks in leading cities for the week ended June 23, aggregated $8,909,000,000, or 8 per cent below the total reported for the preceding week and 11 per cent above the total for the corresponding week of last year.

Buying activity was good in most departments of the wholesale market here last week, with interest more strongly focused on merchandise for Fall, according to a special report prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell, Inc. The report continues:

Some costumes that dated back to the Gay Nineties, when "Diamond Jim" Brady flourished along Broadway, and some others that were so modern they were the next best thing to nudists' finery were displayed yesterday afternoon by children participating in an uptown baby parade.

How a physician found a burglar in his apartment two weeks ago, knocked him unconscious with a hammer and then rendered first aid while waiting for the arrival of the police and an ambulance surgeon was described yesterday morning in the Felony Court.

State Representative Samuel Kircher of Kawkawlin was killed this morning in an automobile accident while driving from an all-night session of the Legislature at Lansing to attend the wedding of a daughter.

In a vain effort to win a [Pound]100 bet, J. H. Perkin, keen young Bognor Regis golfer, teed off at the Goodwill course at 3:55 A. M. today and finished at 10 P. M. after playing eight eighteen-hole rounds.

Stripped of most of its drastic provisions, Governor Frank Murphy's Labor Relations Bill was voted by the Legislature at the 'end of a twenty-one-hour continuous session ending at dawn today. Passage of the bill was a personal victory for the Governor.

John C. Robinson, 46-year-old World War veteran and former accountant in the Treasury Department, was arrested yesterday on a charge of criminal libel. Clarence L. Converse, intelligence agent for the Bureau of Internal Revenue, had spent eighteen months tracing Robinson and investigating a series of charges he said Robinson has made in letters to government officials.
H. C. McGehee's Fair Knightess; 4year-old daughter of Bright Knight, defeated nine rivals today in the fifth running of the Granite State Handicap before 15,000 spectators at Rockingham Park.

It looked last night as if an ani mal Ellis Island might have to be established here, with restrictive legislation covering the wholesale immigration of the denizens of the African and Malayan jungles. Here are some of the animals which are about to arrive:
American exhibitors tonight were announced as winners of many awards in the International Philatelic Exhibition that opened June 18 in the Grand Palais. The winners included:

New Zealand, gunning for its first cricket victory over England, faces a stern task. In - the first of the three tests scheduled this season England hit 370 runs for seven wickets on the opening day's play at Lord's today.
Mrs. Pliny Taylor Evans has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Anne Evans, to Charles Vines Brown Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Vines Brown of Philadelphia.
THE Stockholm Symphony Orchestra and its conductor, M. Nils Grevilius, gave two concerts in the Champs-Elysees ThAtre under the auspices of the Paris International Exposition.

In a statement urging every one to learn to swim, John L. Rice, Health Commissioner, made public yesterday a list of the uncontaminated bathing areas in the city as well as those areas in which swimming is prohibited.

A new German film company, Terra Filmkunst, was organized here today with 5,000,000 marks capital. The company has received a production allotment of twenty-five film plays for the season, while the allotments to the existing film companies, UFA and Tobis, since their recent reorganization, have been forty for each.

Two Radcliffe alumnae prominent in the work of the college have been elected alumnae trustees for six years. They are Miss Anna Holman, '14, of Cambridge, and Mrs. Henry W. Taeusch, '23, of Cleveland.

The Race -- Second annual George Vanderbilt Cup competition. Time--2:15 P. M., Saturday, July 3. Place -- Roosevelt Raceway, Westbury, L. I. Distance--300 miles; 90 laps around three and one-third mile course. Starters--Thirty fastest cars as determined by speed trials. Cars will get off in ten rows of three from standing start.

The Securities and Exchange Commission called today a hearing for July 15 on the reorganization plan of the International Paper and Power Company, whose stockholders approved the plan on last Wednesday.

The Postoffice Department announced today that new airmail schedules between the United States and the principal South American cities would reduce flying time to Buenos Aires and Rio de Janeiro by one day.

BURLINGTON, Vt.--Vermont is preparing for the biggest recreation season in its history. The coming week will bring the opening of most of the resorts throughout the State and reports indicate a heavier advance reservation of rooms, camps and cottages than in any previous season in recent years.

The Securities and Exchange Commission has received application for registration of $600,000 of $1-par common stock of the Sands o'Penn Corporation, Grand Valley, Pa..,an oil producer, to be offered at $2, or at the market "if any is established."

A brown streak of horseflesh named Tiger took the lead in the battle for the 2year-old championship of the American turf today by galloping to victory in the first running of the Washington Park Futurity.

TRACK AND FIELD 75-Yard Dash, Novice--Won by Fred Nichols, unattached; Howard Tannenbaum, unattached. second; Philip Segarra, St. Anselm's A. C., third. Time-0:08.2. 100-Yard Dash (Handicap)-Won by Thomas A. Carey, N. Y. Pioneer Club (6 yards); Ed O'Sullivan Curb Exchange (1/2 yard), second; Fred bummer, Glencoe A. C. (5 1/2 yards), third. Time-0:09.7.

Bonds called last week for redemption prior to maturity continued in relatively small volume, with municipal retirements leading the list. Most of the issues called will be paid in future months, only a few small amounts of miscellaneous bonds being slated for payment this month.

Ray Billows, former New York State amateur champion from the Dutchess Golf and Country Club, won the Hudson River Golf Association title by overwhelming Foster Nichols Sr. in the final today at the Hudson
Miss Diantha Birdsall Schmid, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis G. Schmid of Winnetka, Ill., was married today to George Northrop Melinette, son of Mr. and Mrs. John A. Melinette of New York.

A parade of passenger ships to and from the piers of the Holland America Line, which was started Friday morning and is scheduled to continue until Tuesday afternoon, will establish a new high record for the company's sixty-five years of operations in this port.

Thousands of little children from 2 to 10 years of age are setting out for Summer camps this week-end. This stream of camp-bound little folk signalizes the opening of double the number of private and organizational camps specially planned for them that were in existence a year ago.
The course of the strike upheavals in the United States is being closely watched here, and the fact that President Roosevelt's behavior is the same as former Premier Blum's is considered striking.

Meredith Newcomb Stiles, a close associate of the late George Eastman in his calendar reform work, died at the Monroe Golf Club this afternoon of a heart attack suffered on the course, which he was playing with his son, Meredith N.

The War Department released the following orders today dated June 25: COLONELS Avery, R. L., Chemical Warfare Service, one month and ten days leave, Aug. 1, with permission to visit foreign countries. Baird, H. W., Cav., Ft. Knox, Ky., detailed with the Organized Reserves, Baltimore, Md., about Sept 1.

Miss Elisabeth Carleton Hubbard, daughter of Mrs. William Brewster Hubbard of this place, was married to A. Ten Eyck Lansing 3d, son of Mrs. Stuart Douglas Lansing of Watertown, N. Y., here this afternoon in the First Church of Christ.

Italy's very decided attitude against Soviet Russia is a comparatively recent development, so recent, indeed, that it is doubtful whether it antedates the establishment of the RomeBerlin axis through the Berchtesgaden agreement of Oct. 24, 1936.
The Bronxvile Field Club here was the scene this evening of a dance for members of the younger set. Mrs. Robcliff V. Jones and Mrs. Frank A. Hutson were co-chairmen of the dance.

Miss Helen Hotchkiss, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clayton E. Hotchkiss of Stamford, was married today in Wellfleet-by-the Sea, Cape Cod, Mass., the Summer home of her parents, to Edmund Finley, on of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Finley of Stamfnord.

Mr. and Mrs. Lewis H. Brown gave an outdoor tea dance this afternoon at their home in Deer Park here to introduce to society their daughter, Miss Rosalind Brown. The dancing took place on two platforms on the lawn.
BROADCASTS of the Summer concerts of the Philharmonic Symphony Orchestra from Lewisohn Stadium will begin July 4 over the nation-wide network of WABC.

SCOUTS bound for the National Jamboree which opens this Wednesday in Washington, D. C., are planning to do as much sightseeing as possible on their trip to and from the capital. In this plan the nation's railroads

WASHINGTON.-Paper money costs more these days. To print a thousand sheets of Federal Reserve notes at the Government Printing Office now involves an expense of about $97. In June, 1935, the cost was $86.
Twelve-year-old Ann Hoffman shot her 5-year-old sister, Patricia, in the head today with a small-bore rifle she found in a park greenhouse. Physicians said that the child's condition was critical.

THE author of this amazing work, Canon Douglas of Denver, is too well known to need any commendation. In both sacred and secular music he is a recognized authority, although he would seem to have dedicated

Glenn Cunningham, the Kansas running machine, ground out another world record yesterday, slipping over the sleek Randalls Island Stadium track at the All-Sports Carnival In the fastest time for a mile and a half that man has ever unfurled.

Robert B. Whitaker of Kenosham Wis., vice president of the National Association of Real Estate Boards, and Herbert U. Nelson, Chicago, executive secretary, will represent the association at two international conferences, one on housing and town planning, and the other on real estate appraisal, to be held in Paris during July.

The Jersey City Field Club captured the Hudson County A. A. U. track and field championships for the third straight year at Pershing Field today with an overwhelming total of 61 points. The Pioneer Club of New York was second with 33 and St. Peter's A. C. and the Jersey Harriers tied for third with 19.
Mr. and Mrs. Radcliffe Cheston of Sandy Run, Oreland, gave a dance tonight at Sandy Run for their daughter, Miss Sydney E. Cheston, who was among the debutantes of last Winter.

SIR JOHN REITH, director general of the British Broadcasting Corporation, recently outlined the British viewpoint of the relationship of radio and the news when he addressed the Empire Press Conference in London.
NC--Not given. SL-Slight. ND--No damage. TF-Trifling. CS-Considerable. TL-Total loss. MANHATTAN

A new impetus has been lent to the efforts of the Federated Garden Clubs and other organizations interested in preserving the natural beauty of metropolitan roadsides by the construction of new highways and the remaking of old ones in connection with the coming New York World's Fair.

The North Pole is having a heat wave-not the kind that parches fields and crops, but one that melts houses. Radio messages from the Soviet North Pole base today described a crisis in the lives of the four men who volunteered to remain there a year.

Pacific Coast conference athletes defeated the Big Ten in a dual meet between picked squads before 20,000 spectators today. The score was 92 to 44. The winning four-man mile relay team of the Pacific Coast bettered the unofficial world record when it was timed at 3 minutes 11.8 seconds.

The first forty-two railroads to report for May showed a decrease of 3.5 per cent in combined net operating income compared with May, 1936. Gross revenues and net operating incomes of these companies in May are shown in the following table, with comparisons, the last three ciphers being omitted:

Arthur M. Hyde, former Secretary of Agriculture, said in an interview today that the hope of the Republican party lay in "drafting" Herbert Hoover for the special task of revitalizing and strengthening it for 1940.

This town of about 10,000 people, which is observing its sesquicentennial this year, has another distinction. It is blessed with just about the smallest debt of any town in Vermont. And that is saying a great deal.
Rube Benton, former pitcher for the Giants, will celebrate his fiftieth birthday tomorrow-on the mound. He will pitch for Erwin against Angier in the Tobacco State League.

Miss Marjorie Mansfield Snevily, daughter of Mr. and MlIrs. Henry iansfield Snevily, and John Charles Morrison, son of Mr. and William R. Morrison of Westfield, were married this afternoon in St. Paul's Episcopal Church, by the Rev. 0. O. F. O'Donnell. rector.

A Berkshire group attended at the Berkshire Industrial School, Canaan, N. Y.,, this- afternoon its fifty-first anniversary exercises, the feature of which was the laying of the cornerstone by Mrs. Henry White of a new trade school building to replace the one burned last year. Mrs. White gave the original building erected in 1922.

The Niagara Hudson System announced yesterday that due to the demand for a house costing less than $8,500, indicated by answers to a questionnaire sent out by that company to 250,000 of its customers, it was increasing the number of "Five-Star Homes" to be constructed in Albany, Buffalo and Syracuse from three to six.

Most business men do their job much as boys play baseball, R. G. Wilson, sales vice president of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, said today at the closing session of a conference of the American Marketing Association in the Hotel Statler.

NEW YORK CITY, in the period between 1880 and 1900, was a frenetic mass of construction activity. Madison Square Garden, located then with some degree of accuracy in Madison Square, was officially opened in 1890 with a concert conducted by Edouard Strauss, an adventitious relative of the famous Johann.

The Steel Workers Organizing Committee of the Committee for Industrial Organization celebrated its first anniversary by releasing for the first time substantiated statistics on the progress of the drive to organize the nation's steel workers in an industrial union.

Bounded by a graveyard and a terrifying range of sand dunes, and swept for the first time in a week by a stiff wind, the Southport and Ainsdale course frightened America's picked professional golfers today into full realization of the task they face if they are to retain the Ryder Cup against Great Britain Tuesday and Wednesday.

The League of Nations Raw Materials Committee has adjourned until Sept. 1, when it plans to complete its report in time for discussion by the League Assembly. Its failure to finish its report this session seems due partly to the political situation, making the British prefer the delay.
Administration strategists in the Senate, it is said, will make their first move on the Supreme Court bill on Wednesday by calling up the proposal and forcing a vote on a compromise amendment.

THIS could not be China, the young naval lieutenant thought, as the huge buildings loomed up into a sky all gaudy with advertising signs and the cars buzzed like fireflies and the trams clanged and groaned.

It is a safe bet that every New Yorker who can afford railroad fare will leave the city next weekend for the three-day holiday that the Fourth of 'July, falling on Sunday, affords. The shops have been preparing for this exodus.

A feature of this year's St. Johnland Annual Fair, to be held on Wednesday at Kings Park, will be a public auction of furniture, brica-brac, used cars and boats. The usual booths, beer garden and other divertissements will also be in operation during the afternoon and evening.

WE have definitely gone Hollywood. We've rented a new apartment for a second month, richer and more magnificent than the first, and are using it as a base for excursions into the gorgeous country all about. We're going to Palm Springs, Agua Caliente, San Diego and Monterey.

An all-star Manhattan nine routed an all-Brooklyn team in the first annual interborough game on the Manhattan Beach diamond yesterday. The invading array scored an easy 8-to-1 victory before an attendance of 6,500.

Joseph Fishback, runner-up for the national indoor junior singles title in 1936, but unranked as a senior and unseeded in the tourney, scored his second upset in as many matches to enter the final of the Richmond County men's

IN 1737 Anne de Montchanin and Samuel Dupont were married in Paris. She was "the daughter of an ancient and noble French house, now desperately impoverished because of long and stubborn adherence to the Huguenot faith." He was a watchmaker from Rouen, one of eleven children of a thrifty line.

It was still insufferably hot in the Mound City today, but for a change that was most refreshing, the Giants rose with the thermometer and presently became just about the hottest number in all this sun-baked metropolis.

Madison Square Garden, located then with some degree of accuracy in Madison Square, was officially opened in 1890 with a concert conducted by Edouard Strauss, an adventitious relative of the famous Johann.

The Steel Workers Organizing Committee of the Committee for Industrial Organization celebrated its first anniversary by releasing for the first time substantiated statistics on the progress of the drive to organize the nation's steel workers in an industrial union.

The League of Nations Raw Materials Committee has adjourned until Sept. 1, when it plans to complete its report in time for discussion by the League Assembly. Its failure to finish its report this session seems due partly to the political situation, making the British prefer the delay.
Administration strategists in the Senate, it is said, will make their first move on the Supreme Court bill on Wednesday by calling up the proposal and forcing a vote on a compromise amendment.

THIS could not be China, the young naval lieutenant thought, as the huge buildings loomed up into a sky all gaudy with advertising signs and the cars buzzed like fireflies and the trams clanged and groaned.

The Very Rev. Milo H. Gates, dean of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, declared in his sermon yesterday morning that confidence was "the last word in the world that anybody would think of using to describe today."

To the Editor of The New York Times: In the argument that the government is failing to assume its proper ro1e as an impartial arbiter between economic groups lies a hidden assumption which opponents of the New Deal's labor policies perhaps do not realized they logically must support.

With bold, dramatic strokes, President CARDENAS of Mexico within a few days has taken over 13,000 miles of Mexican railroads and has now placed the country's agriculture under the strictest governmental control. Further announcements are momentarily expected regarding a similar nationalization of important industries.

The spirit of Christ can heal the mentally sick individual and "halt the insane rush of civilization toward destruction today just as Christ drove the demons from the insane man during His life on earth," the Rev. Elmore McNeill McKee, rector of St. George's Protestant Episcopal Church, Stuyvesant Square and Sixteenth Street, declared in his sermon yesterday morning.
The University of Goettingen, despite the refusal of most universites and colleges in the United States to send delegates to its 200th anniversary ceremonies, honored today three American scholars.

Fossil remains discovered last Summer in Northeastern Utah have been identified as those of a duck that lived on this continent about 50,000,000 years ago, Dr. Glenn L. Jepsen, '27, curator of vertebrate paleontology in Princeton University, announced today.

Emil Mosbacher Jr. won the International One-Design Class race with Susan today in the Horseshoe Harbor Yacht Club's special regatta. The Internationals, like the rest of the fleet, were well below par in numbers, probably because of the forbidding weather.

Agents in Smyrna of the British Shell Company, the American Socony-Vacuum Oil Company and the Rumanian Steaua Romana were arrested yesterday because they had refused to sell gasoline and oil at prices fixed by the municipality, which are lower than those fixed by the companies.

Two five-story walk-up apartment houses, each 116 by 100 feet, at 3,031-41 Holland Avenue, the Bronx, were sold by Vogel Rotkin, operators, to a client of Isidore Tankus. They are fiftyfive-family buildings containing apartments of two, three and four rooms and were sold for cash above two first mortgages of $130,200. S. Ginsberg was the broker.

The New York Board of Trade, in a resolution made public yesterday, demanded that law and order be maintained in industrial disputes and condemned "the countenancing by public officials of breach of law, breakdown of authority and the subversion of government by organized forces within this country."

Continuing his victorious march in the international chess masters' tournament at the Kurhaus, Samuel Reshevsky, United States champion, today defeated S. Landau of The Netherlands in the tenth round, thereby keeping his lead of 1 1/2 points over the rest of the field.
Dr. Wilbour E. Saunders, headmaster of the Peddle School, gave the baccalaureate sermon to members of the school's graduating class this morning in the First Baptist Church here.

The Athletics divided a doubleheader with the Indians today, holding them scoreless in the first game, 10 to 0, to administer their second successive shutout. The Indians tallied their first run of the series in the first inning of the second game and went on to beat the Macks, 7 to 2.
De Witt L. Burnside, former executive director of the National Daylight Saving Association, died in Kings County Hospital on Saturday of an intestinal ailment. He was 58 years old.

Funeral services were held today for Aaron Dollinger, motion-picture theatre owner, who died yesterday at his home in his sixtieth year. Mr. Dollinger was the owner of the Plaza Theatre in Linden, N. J., and co-owner with Warner Brothers of the Ritz Theatre in Newark. Born in Austria, he came to this country thirty-nine years ago.

An old maestro for whom not so long ago they were expressing grave fears came back with one of his grand masterpieces today as Carl Owen Hubbell brought down the Cardinals, with Dizzy Dean on the firing line, in the final clash of a three-game series.
Manoeuvring his light glider into a landing at the Elmira Airport
"Life With Mother," by the late Clarence Day, will be published with a first printing of 50,000 copies by Alfred A. Knopf on Aug. 23.

The sum of $2,370,000 has been raised during the first six months of 1937 for overseas aid to Jews by the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee, Rabbi Jonah B. Wise reported yesterday at a meeting of the Campaign Plan and Scope Committee, held in the offices of William Rosenwald, 122 East Forty-second Street.

After kicking about the office buildings and corridors of Congress for nearly five months, President Roosevelt's bill for the reorganization of the Federal judiciary will reach its decisive parliamentary test on the floor of the Senate soon after the legislators return from their Fourth of July holidays.

President Roosevelt has asked an advisory committee of twenty-two laymen and educators to investigate the "whole subject of Federal relations to State and local conduct of education" and to give him their report by December, before the next session of Congress.

The Democratic members of Congress who, with President Roosevelt, enjoyed the hospitality of the Jefferson Islands Club today, in the third and final of the outings planned for their benefit, included the following:

With the whole labor situation in the United States evidently in a state of flux, the future in this respect appears obscure. Its seriousness is evident from President Roosevelt's reluctant and apparently half-hearted intervention. That more positive action will be needed to bring the warring parties into closer contact seems certain.

BERLIN-Cheers for King George VI were given by 150,000 German war veterans after two British speakers had asked for an understanding between the two countries. The leader of the veterans' union called for the cheers. Page 1.

Tne stocks market here this week was dull, with relatively few sellers but almost a complete suspension of speculative buying, in consequence of which there ensued an almost general decline. Exceptions were shipping stocks, especially Hamburg-America and North German Lloyd, which continued their preceding week's gains, and shares of the leading commercial banks, which maintained their quotations unchanged.

Ohio C. I. O. director charged "a campaign of terror against workers" as back-to-work movement grew at Youngstown steel mills. Page 1. Extremists of both the Right and Left seemed in control of Michigan labor war, with all factions arming. Page 1.

Miss Marie Louise Butts, daughter of Major and Mrs. George Whitfield Butts Jr. of Wynnewood and granddaughter of Mrs. George Whitfield Butts of New Haven, Conn., has completed plans for her wedding on July 20 to Herbert Forrest Stratton, son of Mr. and Mrs.
The Federal Government's income and outgo for the 1937 fiscal year appeared today likely to exceed the official estimates. The year will end on Wednesday at midnight.

With the opening of many cottages for the Summer and a full program of activities planned at the Westhampton Country Club and Yacht Squadron, the season is well under way. Mr. and Mrs. George P. Conard are among the arrivals for the Summer, having opened their Basket Neck Lane residence in Remsenburg.

The steamship President Pierce of the Dollar Line, which rescued forty-seven members of the crew of the 7,000-ton British freighter Sandgate Castle, which caught fire Saturday morning 650 miles southeast of New York and forced the men to take to the lifeboats, is expected to reach Quarantine late this afternoon.

Miss Mary Corinne Fentress, daughter of Mrs. Charles Harvey Fentress and the late Mr. Fentress, became the bride of Samuel Braley Gray Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. S. B. Gray, of Old Town, Me., last night in St. Stephen's Episcopal Church here.

Members of the 1917 classes of Columbia College and the School of Journalism, which number persons now prominent in various fields, have an average yearly income from all sources of $14,250 and an average yearly salary of $19,500, according to results made public yesterday of a questionnaire.

A public hearing to assure proper administration of the fund for assessing repairs in old-law tenement houses under the Multiple Dwelling Law was suggested yesterday in a statement by William S. Prince, president of the Association of Harlem and Bronx Property Owners, Inc.

Miss Joan Day Pattinson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Graham I. Pattinson of Bayberry Lane, Greenwich, has completed plans for her marriage to Oscar T. Lawler, son of Mr. and Mrs. Oscar Lawler of Beverly Hills, Calif., on July 27, at Christ Church, Greenwich.

The rise in the price of metals because of general arming has resuited in renewed interest in the manganese deposits on the Pacific Coast of Costa Rica. Although of comparatively low grade these deposits were worked profitably during the World War.
Collecting a total of twenty-eight hits, Boston swept both games of a double-header with the Reds, 8 to 2 and 10 to 5, today, before a crowd of 20,262.
Carl S. Schweinler of West Orange, N. J., captured the Great Eastern individual skeet championship today by shooting 99 of 100 targets on the Remington Gun Club range at Lordship.
Dr. James Rowland Angell, retiring president of Yale University, will become educational counselor of the National Broadcasting Company in September, it was announced in a statement here today.

Mr. and Mrs. Charles H. Jones gave a reception this afternoon at Jones Manor, their country place, to celebrate the twenty-fifth anniversary of their wedding. Their three daughters, Mrs. John B. Watkins and the Misses Elizabeth and Mary Jones, assisted in receiving. Many floral tributes and silver gifts were received by the hosts, some of which came from those who had attended their marriage.

The Spanish Government ordered a special vigilance fleet into service against submarines today, announcing that the Spanish merchantman Cabo Palos, laden with foodstuffs, had been sunk by a submarine Friday.

The action of the oats and rye markets here last week was largely a reflection of that in wheat and corn. Oats showed net gains of 314 to 3'A cents a bushel for the week, with the July closing at 424 cents, September at 38 cents and December at 39% cents.

Miss Natalie Beatrice Lisner of New York was married here yesterday to John P. Lynch of Boston at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Percy P. Lynch, brother and sister-in-law of the bridegroom. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. John James Kirkpatrick, rector of Christ Episcopal Church of Glen Ridge and Bloomfield.

With thanks to the Postoffice Department for the work of assigning more than 29,000,000 account numbers through June 26, the Social Security Board announced today that after Tuesday the work of assigning Social Security account numbers will be carried on through 147 field offices to be maintained by the board.

Mrs. Lizzie Baytop Baker, wife of the Rev. Dr. T. Nelson Baker and a leader among Western Massachusetts Negro women, died here last night at the age of 71. She was born in Gloucester County, Va., Aug. 10, 1865, four months after her parents, born in slavery, had been set free.

With travel agencies experiencing their greatest activity since the boom years, advertising volume placed by three of the most important companies has spurted considerably ahead of a year ago, a check-up has revealed. Steamship lines, also enjoying record bookings, have been using more space than in previous years.

Down near Les Halles in Paris is a smoky little bistro frequented by gourmets of the extreme Left. The patronne of the place may be called Mere Marianne, because she is so typical of her species, the inevitable and incomparable women who run the small businesses of France.
Fewer than half the 747,000 chauffeurs in the State have renewed their licenses, only three business days before the June 30 deadline, Charles A. Hartnett, Motor Vehicle Commissioner, said today.

Harry Noyes Pratt, director-manager of Crocker Art Gallery, said today he had uncovered evidence that a painting attributed to Carletto Veronese really was the work of his famous father, Paolo Veronese of the Venetian school.
Luncheon of the Foreign Policy Association in honor of Prime Minister Paul Van Zeeland, Hotel Astor, 12:45 P. M.

Mr. and Mrs. William Creighton Peet of Rye, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sara Brevoort Peet, to Leicester Sargent Lewis of Bryn Mawr, Pa., son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Wilfred Lewis of Philadelphia.
Because of an alleged error in geography the newspaper Dia has been ordered closed by a decree of President Federico Paez.

A revival in the new-capital market is definitely in progress here, based on confidence in financial quarters concerning the business outlook, and consequently industrial offerings figure largely in the list of actual and impending issues.
The statement of the Bank of France for June 17 shows an increase of 1,258,000,000 francs in bills discounted and almost 700,000,000 in advances on collateral and bonds.

Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 75 per cent of capacity, the same as for each of the three preceding weeks. For three weeks before strikes broke out production had been quite uniform at close to 91 per cent.

Bits of silk appeared and disappeared, ropes were cut and mysteriously made whole again and eggs were used only to mystify yesterday afternoon as a group of youngsters demonstrated that the arts of magic are still practiced in New York-especially Brownsville, Brooklyn.

A declaration that the Ontario Government would stop C. I. O. agitators "at the Detroit River" and a charge that President Roosevelt had been favorably influenced to the C. I. O. because John L. Lewis had contributed $500,000 to his Presidential campaign, were made here last night by Premier Mitchell Hepburn.
Amelia Earhart landed her round-the-world airplane at Port Darwin at 10:03 A. M. today [10:03 P. M., Sunday, New York time] after a 500-mile flight from Kupang, Timor, in the Dutch East Indies.

David B. Provan, managing director of the Adelphia Hotel, which he built twenty-three years ago, died today at the home of his sister, Mrs. Thomas Z. Lee, in Providence, R. I. He would have been 69 years old on Thursday.
The marriage of Miss Florence E. Wilson, daughter of Mrs. Louis E. Wilson of Ithaca, N. Y., and the late Homer E. Wilson, to Edwin F. Lawton took place this afternoon In Trinity College Chapel.

The unexplained absence of two prominent Russians from an official welcoming party for Dr. Otto J. Schmidt, who returned last Friday from the Russian North Pole air base, led to reports today that they had been arrested.

An offering of $80,000,000 first mortgage and collateral trust bonus, 33A per cent series due 1962, and $15,000,000 of 3 per cent notes due 1942, of Union Electric Company of Missouri will be made today by Dillon, Read Co. and a large group of underwriters.
The reaction in the City and financial markets generally to the government's decision to increase, the Exchange Equalization Fund by [Pound]200,000,000 has been wholly favorable.

Lily Pons, the Metropolitan coloratura soprano, made a trimphant first appearance at the Lewisohn Stadium last night. The participation of the popular artist on the program of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, under Vladimir Golschmann, attracted an audience of 11,000 persons, despite overcast skies.
A bullet wound in the head which he inflicted upon himself in a boardwalk shooting gallery Saturday night proved fatal today to Parker

Mayor La Guardia, Park Commissioner Moses and Borough President Ingersoll of Brooklyn are expected to attend exercises on Tuesday at 1 P. M. in Fort Greene Park, Brooklyn, marking the completion of restoration work on the Martyrs' Monument and improved landscaping of the thirty-acre plot.

Master performers from the British Isles gave a selected American team a lesson in soccer at the Polo Grounds yesterday as the superb Charlton Athletic unit vanquished a picked eleven from the United States Football Association, 4 to 0, before a crowd of 10,000.

Filling the creel: The annual team competition for the $3,000 Ocean City Casting Trophy is scheduled for Aug. 14 at Philadelphia, where the Dover Fishing Club, present holder of the cup, will act as host.

The week's markets again were unsettled, the feature being not only the reaction of stocks and uncertainty among bonds but a partial suspension of wholesalers' orders for consumption goods. Behind all this nervousness the main factor was the international unrest.

Short covering was largely responsible for a sharp upturn in soy bean futures here last week. The July delivery rallied 12 cents a bushel in three days, the rise being the maximum permitted under the regulations of the Exchange, and closed 51/2 cents higher at $1.311. The deferred futures, which represent the new crop, gained 7 1/4 cents to 8 1/4 cents for the week.

The month now closing has been an eventful one for the financial markets here. Another gold scare accompanied by record sales of dehoarded gold with attendant conditions approaching panic, and a rapid subsidence of the scare following denials, from Washington and London that a reduction in the price of the metal was contemplated were its princiDal feature.

A plaque in honor of Miss Lillian D. Wald, founder of the Henry Street Settlement, will be dedicated at 2:45 P. M. tomorrow at the playground at Cherry, Monroe and Gouverneur Streets, which will be named for her.

R. G. Casey, Finance Minister of Australia, and Mrs. Casey; Jose Lara, Cuban Charge d'Affaires at The Hague; James Mollison, Mr. and Mrs. Edmund Lowe, Paul Cavanagh, Carlos Seminario, Hal B. Wallis, Mr. and Mrs. William Wilkerson, Mr. and Mrs. Welles Bosworth, Charles Campbell, Baroness Garibaldi, the Rev. J. Hunter Guthrie and the Rev. Andre Bremond are among the passengers due today on the French liner Normandie.
Farmers facing the loss of a valuable bean crop because of the strike that closed the Phillips Packing Company accepted tonight the offer of farm organizations to help them market their product.

Formation of a $100,000 endowment for a poetry fellowship to be administered by the Academy of American Poets is under way, it was announced yesterday by Carl Van Doren, chairman of the sponsoring group which has selected the name of Elinor Wylie Poetry Fellowship Committee.

The Dutch, following closely labor developments in the United States, find it difficult to understand the situation because most of the objectives for which labor in America is fighting are long established in law and deeply rooted in custom in almost all European democratic countries.

Three underprivileged public school children who overcame their physical handicaps and other obstacles to get an education will be honored tomorrow morning when Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, presents to them the M. Samuel Stern Memorial awards.
A representative of Italy in El Salvador, Vitor Annichiarico, will supply to the government, free, sufficient quinine to combat malaria in the entire country, according to the Prensa of San Salvador.
What happened at Wrigley Field today should be recorded in the archives under the caption: "Among the Great Events in History."

The Long Island Aviation Country Club will conduct its seventh annual seaplane cruise from here from July 8 to 11. Commodore Rudolph Loening will head the fleet of eighteen planes carrying more than forty aviation enthusiasts.

Consideration of former Deputy Controller Frank J. Prial for the Democratic nomination for Mayor was urged yesterday by Sidney S. Levine, former Commissioner of Licenses, in letters to the five Democratic county leaders.

All creditors of the New York, Westchester Boston Railroad will file tomorrow in the United States District Court here claims against that subsidiary of the New York, Ne-- Haven Hartford System, which is in receivership.

Among those who gave luncheons today were Miss Julia A. Berwind and Mr. and Mrs. Roger W. Cutler. Mr. and Mrs. William F. Whitehouse had dinner guests tonight at Stone Villa, and Mr. and Mrs. Elisha Dyer entertained with a tea.

God's purpose in creating man is slowly revealed by growth of faith in Him, the Rev. Dr. Joseph P. McComas, vicar of St. Paul's Episcopal Church, Trinity parish, Broadway and Fulton Street, suggested in his sermon yesterday morning.

David Stewart Beyer, author, lecturer, industrial safety expert and vice president and chief engineer of the Liberty Mutual Insurance Company of Boston, died today at his home in Newton Centre after a brief illness. He was 57 years old.

Miss Ruth Lee Coughlin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Dennis J. Coughlin of Wethersfield, was married to Bruce McGray, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank McGray of Scarsdale, N. Y., yesterday afternoon in the garden of the bride's home. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Newton C. Fetter of Cambridge Mass.

Let the arguments now begin! For here, fans, is the hand-picked squad of twenty-three which will represent the American League against the National League's best in the fifth annual all-star game at Washington's Griffith Stadium, home of the Senators, Wednesday, July 7.
More than half of the operating expense of a modern retail store goes for salaries and wages, according to an analysis of census figures made public today by the American Retail Federation.
Jacob Riis Park in the Rockaways and Orchard Beach, Pelham, both of which were opened Friday, had more than 100,000 visitors over the week-end, the Park Department reported yesterday.

Representatives of 149 organizations opposing the Nazi regime in Germany voted yesterday to unify their efforts for a boycott of German-made goods and shipping and for other anti-Hitler activities in a national drive under the direction of the Non-Sectarian Anti-Nazi League. They also planned to seek the active support of Catholic and Protestant organizations "in the struggle against Hitler."

Financial clr. cles welcomed formation of Premier Camille Chautemps's government because the hope is that although the existing social laws will be maintained, at least they are not likely to be added to.

The outcome of the Spanish civil war is certain to have a powerful influence on the future of South America and indirectly will affect the United States, Fernando de los Rios, Spanish Ambassador to Washington. said today.

Miss Florence Lipstein, daughter of David Lipstein of 127 West Ninety-sixth Street, was married yesterday afternoon to Edgar L. Schlesinger, son of Mr. and Mrs. Max Schlesinger, also of this city, at the home of the bride's brother and sister-in-law, Mr. and Mrs. Adolph Lipstein, 336 Central Park West. The Rev. Dr. Gabriel Schulman performed the ceremony before members of both families.

Lard futures made advances of 621/2 to 87 1/2 cents for 100 pounds last week as the result of continued limited receipts of hogs. The latter were only sufficient to take care of the fresh-meat trade, according to reports, and a majority of brokers expect that the monthly report on stocks of lard will show a fairly liberal reduction this month despite the continued lack of an aggressive export demand.

The stock market's course last week appeared on its face to indicate an attitude of continued financial hesitancy, but of rather noteworthy composure. With daily transactions on the Stock Exchange barely exceeding half a million shares, prices edged slowly higher during most of the week;

A crowd of 24,372 braved leaden skies to see the Yanks close their home stand against the Tigers at the Stadium yesterday and the reward was an old-fashioned demonstration of Yankee slugging, which bruised three Detroit hurlers, wearied the Motor City pretenders to the American League throne and brought the McCarthymen victory, 9 to 5.

Miss Dorothy G. Russ, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Henry C. Russ, was married yesterday afternoon in the garden of her parents' home here to Norman A. Greist, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter C. Greist of North Haven. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. John H. Westbrook Jr.
Eddie Hedges of Atlantic City, N. J., sent his Class A inboard motor boat Mysterious Eagle roaring to a world record today in the closing events of the North East River Yacht Club's regatta.

As the Insurgent captors of Bilbao steadily pursue the retreating Basques toward Santander, large sections of the Basque army seem to have been demoralized, and desertion has been widespread. In more than one sector the Basque commander has arranged a truce with his opposite number to facilitate a change of allegiance.

Merchandise for pre-holiday and Summer selling occupied an important place on orders received last week in the wholesale market here, although an increasing volume of business was placed on Fall goods.

The general French wholesale price index on June 19 was unchanged at 530. Native products stood at 560, against 555, on June 12; imported products, 476, against 485; food products, 523, against 521, and industrial materials, 536, against 538. The world gold-price index was 22, with raw materials at 53, against 53.7.

William Hardin Caldwell, president of the Caldwell Travel Service, 545 Fifth Avenue, New York, and former president of the New York branch of Franco-Belgique Tours, Ltd., died at his residence here today, after a long illness, at the age of 58.

Earl Reed Silvers, Rutgers University director of alumni and public relations and Associate Professor of English, departed today with his family for their Summer home at South Casco, Me., as he began a year's leave of absence granted at the Spring meeting of the university trustees.

Corn futures here were affected last week to some extent by the strength In wheat, but a large part of the corn buying was induced by the lack of cash grain at leading terminal markets available for delivery on July contracts.

A plea for a continued fight for American patriotism among veteran groups was voiced today by Governor Hoffman in an address to the closing session of the eighteenth annual convention of the New Jersey Veterans of Foreign Wars here.
Hurrying from Havre, Georges Bonnet, new Minister of Finance and National Economy, will arrive in Paris tomorrow

Motorists will have paid an. average of $48 apiece in taxes, direct and indirect, contributing a total of $1,349,000,000, or 10.5 per cent, of the nation's entire tax revenues during the twelve months ended June 30, according to a study just released by Northwestern National Life Insurance Company.

The New York American and Journal units of the Newspaper Guild of New York voted last night by a margin of three to two to empower the guild to call a strike if their demands for the retention of those dropped as a result of the consolidation of The American are rejected.

We are in an era where change is essential and where the old idea that to stand still is to play safe is completely outmoded, Dr. Henry Hallam Tweedy, Professor of Pastoral Theology, Yale Divinity School, said yesterday morning in a sermon at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Seventy-third Street.

Nazi swastikas and Union Jacks hung over the platform as Prime Minister W. L. Mackenzie King of Canada left a through train from Paris early today at the Friedrichstrasse Station for his personal visit to Germany's leaders.
THE tributes paid Senator George W. Norris of Nebraska during his campaign last year for re-election to the Senate have gone to his biographers' heads. Setting out to write a biography, "Integrity:

The jockeying of small men into positions in which they assume the powers of the Deity is one of the evils of the present day, declared the Rev. Dr. Frederick W. Norwood, special evangelist of the National Free Church Council of Great Britain, in his sermon, "The Blank in Our Knowledge," yesterday morning at the Riverside Church, Riverside Drive and 122d Street.
Four persons were killed and twelve injured late tonight when a Southern Railway train crashed into a dead-end siding at Swanley Junction, Kent.

Miss Theodora Roosevelt, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Archibald B. Roosevelt and granddaughter of President Theodore Roosevelt, was introduced to society tonight at a dinner and entertainment at Turkey Lane House, the home of her parents in this colony.

Barney Ross, world's welterweight champion, today knocked out Jackie Burke of Ogden, Utah, in the fifth round of a scheduled tenround fight at Heinemann Baseball Park. A crowd of 4,000 paid $5,000 to see the battle under a sweltering sun.

William N. Matsner, an international trader in hides and skins, died on Friday in London, England, of a heart ailment, according to word received here. Mr. Matsner, who was 47 years old and had been living in London for several years, maintained offices here at 242 West Thirtieth Street.

The powerful First Division four continued its unbeaten pace in the Eastern Polo League by sweeping to a 15-9 verdict over the Governors Island Blues yesterday at the Fort Hamilton Army Reservation. The victory was the third in a row for the home outfit.

Building trades employes in urban areas from coast to coast have been successful in obtaining wage increases, according to reports from twenty-six representative cities in the current national construction cost survey conducted semi-annually bytheDowService.

Europe's financial outlook for the second half of 1937 would be considered hopeful if the situation were not obscured by the Spanish civil war, which continues to be a serious menace to European peace;

Behind the steady pitching of the veteran Ted Lyons, the White Sox swept a three-game series from the Senators today with a 5-to-3 triumph which moved them into second place in the American League standing. The game was called for forty minutes on account of rain in the eighth inning.
The B. M. T. and the Transport Workers Union, a C. I. O. affiliate, will adjust their differences without a strike, it was indicated last night.

After three days of Democratic harmony conferences at the Jefferson Islands Club, across Chesapeake Bay from here, President Roosevelt departed for Washington tonight to test the results of his first effort at mass wooing of Congress.

Announcement has been made by Dale B. Carson of this city of the engagement of his daughter, Miss Elizabeth Ellsworth Carson, to Horace Byron Fay Jr., son of Horace B. Fay of Shaker Heights, Cleveland, and the late Mrs. Fay.

The United States Government was asked by the Zionist Organization of America in annual convention in the Hotel Roosevelt yesterday to intercede with Great Britain against curtailment of Jewish rights in Palestine granted under the Balfour Declaration.

The second annual Cherry Valley best-ball invitation tournament was concluded today, with Neal Fulkerson, home club champion, and Tom McEntee of Hempstead registering a 2-and-1 triumph over the veteran Leo Smith of Cherry Valley and Everett Hoyt of the Garden City Golf Club in the final.

The main objectives of the Social Security Act are unquestionably praiseworthy and must command universal sympathy, the Guaranty Trust Company of New York says in the current issue of the Guaranty survey.

Expressing skepticism at the "quick and complete conversion to decency" of burlesque producers in the six weeks since their shows were closed, John S. Sumner, secretary of the New York Society for the Suppression of Vice, said yesterday that if the shows do come back they should be "as clean as the music halls of the Weber and Fields era."

Sir Hamnet Holditch Share, retired PaymasterRear Admiral, died yesterday after an operation. He was 73 years old. His long career in the Royal Navy ended in 1921 when he was placed on the retired list after serving as secretary to Admiral Lord Jellicoe during his naval mission to India and the dominions in 1919-20.
T. Newton Perry and N. S. Geruldsen have organized I. Newton Perry Co. to deal in municipal and corporation securities at 135 South La Salle Street, Chicago.

Caging a forty-foot putt on the seventeenth green for a birdie 2, Chester Birch of the home club turned back Jack Creavy of Hickory, 2 and 1, in the final of the fourth annual invitation golf tournament at Briar Hills today. The former Dartmouth captain, 1 down at the turn, squared the match on the tenth, gained the lead at the twelfth and thereafter remained in front.

J. C. Morris Jr.'s Arrow II, of the Corinthian Yacht Club of Philadelphia won the International Star Class contest today in the opening Sunday regatta of the Seaside Park Yacht Club. Eel, sailed by Mrs. Charles E. Lucke Jr., trailed by seven seconds. Stardust, with Wilson McNeeley as skipper, placed third.

At Friday's meeting of the Board of Estimate after the Mayor had moved to adjourn the regular weekly sessions till Sept. 24, the President of the Board of Aldermen snapped out that he didn't "want a vacation," and the President of the Borough of the Bronx hung a halo on himself and his diligent colleague and pointed a finger of scorn at lazier justice:

Walter Pollin, 21 years old, of 148 East 123d Street, and his fiance, Miss Eleanor Sexton, 18, of 161-63 East 123d Street were killed about 3 A. M. yesterday on the elevated express highway at Gansevoort Street when the car in which they were riding skidded, crashed into a parapet and overturned.

The Rev. Dr. Arthur Lee Kinsolving, 38-year-old rector of Trinity Church, Copley Square, with the announcement that "next Fall Trinity Church will have a new parishoner in the rector's pew," formally made known to his congregation this morning his engagement to Miss Mary Kent Blagden, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Augustus Silliman Blagden of Ambler, Pa.

All problems can be satisfactorily solved if God is placed at the center of human life, the Rev. Dr. Edgar Tilton Jr. declared in his last sermon yesterday before the congregation of the East Eighty-ninth Street Reformed Church.

Realization of the kingdom of God is the only cure for the ills of these times and of all times, Bishop William F. Anderson declared yesterday morning in a sermon at Christ Church, Methodist Episcopal, Park Avenue at Sixtieth Street.
The Rev. Dr. William Norman Guthrie, rector of the Episcopal Church of St. Mark's-in-theBouwerie, denied yesterday reports that he would retire before September.

Plans for modernizing a Bronx theatre for the showing of newsreels were announced yesterday in connection with a leasing of the 600-seat theatre in the twostory building at 209 East Fordham Road, northeast corner of the Grand Concourse.

Continuing to display an excellent brand of baseball, Yale finished at the head of the Eastern Intercollegiate League last week, with nine victories and three defeats, despite the desperate efforts of Harvard to turn back its traditional foe. In two games with the Crimson, on Tuesday and Wednesday, the Elis broke even, winning the opener, to clinch the title, and bowing in the second test.
Combines are roaring in the nation's "bread basket" as jubilant wheat farmers, the memory of five lean years forgotten, reap a money harvest equaled few times in history.

Ships of the combined Hamburg American and North German Lloyd lines started the movement Saturday of passenger traffic which will total 7,100 persons in five days and involve six liners. Officials of the lines said it was the largest concentration of passenger traffic on their piers in several years.

The bondholders' protective committee for the first-mortgage twenty-year 71/2 per cent bonds of the Manati Sugar Company announced yesterday that it had filed a revised plan of reorganization for the company and that a hearing on the plan would be held in the United States District Court House, Foley Square, on July 14.

No employee has worked in the Department of Justice longer than John Van Buren Merritt, chief clerk of the United States Attorney's office, who will complete fifty years' service tomorrow, when messenger boys and judges of the United States Circuit Court of Appeals will join in a celebration in his honor.
Being persistent, J. P. H. Brombach, manager of the safekeeping department of the First National Bank, has finally collected 4 cents the bank owed him for thirtynine years.

The Grand Council of the Six Nations of the Iroquois Confederacy is planning a ceremonial celebration at the St. Regis Reservation a week hence, the first of its kind since the American Revolution, more than 150 years ago.

Robert Irwin, 29-year-old sculptor and former theological student, arrived here by airplane from Chicago last night. He had voluntarily waived extradition and declared his willingness to face the penalty for the three Gedeon murders here on Easter Sunday.
The complaint against it by the National Labor Relations Board has put the Ford Motor Company in conflict with a government agency for the second time within a few years.

The Most Rev. Thomas J. Walsh, Bishop of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Newark, officiated here today at the dedication of the Gate of Heaven Cemetery, owned by the Newark diocese. The ceremony was attended by 2,000 persons, who inspected the new 120-acre grounds at the conclusion of the services.

Within the week we shall open a new chapter in our maritime history. The old system of ocean mail contracts (actually disguised Government subsidies) is to be replaced by the franker one of direct constructional and operating subsidies, "based upon provid" ng for American shipping Govern"ment aid to make up the differential "between American and foreign ship" ping costs."

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $3,852,530,600. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and non-interestbearing discount bills. The list follows:

The new synagogue of the Congregational Beth-El on Upper Bellevue Avenue was dedicated here this afternoon. Rabbi B. Reuben Weilerstein of the Community Synagogue of Atlantic City delivered the dedicatory sermon.

Mexico's nation-wide conservative regional Confederation of Labor, known as Crom, announced today that it opposed fascism and communism for Mexico, following President Lazaro Cardenas' moves toward State Socialism.

Former Supreme Court Justice Jeremiah T. Mahoney led in the poll of the magazine New York Politics for the Democratic nomination for Mayor, final results of which were announced yesterday. A canvass of Republicans showed 14,573 in favor of the renomination of Mayor LaGuardia and 5,068 against it.
Champions were judged in all classes as the eleventh annual Watertown Horse Show, most successful in point of entries, closed today with a large crowd in attendance.
Mr. and Mrs. John Calvin Thorne of the Ambassador will sail on the Kungsholm Wednesday. After a North Cape cruise they will go to Russia and Germany, returning to New York early in September.

Much confusion has been caused here by reports from the United States that that country is to aid Brazil in constructing destroyers under her new naval program. Columns upon columns have been printed in newspapers here but they have not made the situation clear.

Miss Helena Kohut, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene A. Kohut of 35-40 Eighty-second Street, Jackson Heights, was married yesterday morning to Edward J. Friedlander, son of the Rev. and Mrs. Marcus Friedlander of Brooklyn, at the home of Miss Kohut's parents. The bridegroom's father performed the ceremony.

Cotton prices strengthened moderately last week. On all days except Thursday, when net losses were recorded, prices held steady or showed net advances. At the close on Saturday active months on the New York Cotton Exchange were up 20 to 33 points.

The money market here is quiet. Day loans yesterday were quoted at 2%5 to 238 per cent. The balance sheets of Berlin banks for May 31 show an increase in deposits, a decline in loans and discounts and a large increase in holdings of Reich bonds.

Rock candy, that old-fashioned remedy, is not chiefly used for medicinal purposes and cannot be admitted through customs under a medical classification, the United States Court of Customs and Patent Appeals has determined, according to a decision made public today.
Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Suter of New York will give a dinner on July 5 at Whole Loaf, their estate here, in observance of the sixth anniversary of their marriage.

The Rev. Robert Anderson Jardine, the English clergyman who officiated at the marriage of the Duke of Windsor, will give the first address of his scheduled American speaking tour on Sunday evening, July 11, at the Broadway Temple Methodist Episcopal Church, 174th Street and Broadway.

The death of the Right Hon. Henry Hobhouse, for forty-six years Ecclesiastical Commissioner for England and Wales, was announced here tonight. He died Friday at the age of 83. He was Conservative Member of Parliament for Somerset East from 1885 to 1906; in 1902 he was appointed to the Privy Council.

After a week of strenuous competition in Wimbledon's great fortnight of tennis, the decks were really cleared for action today as net stars from all over the world rested in preparation for the second and hardest part of the program.
Clairvoyant, owned by the Argentine sportsman, Eduardo Martinez de Hoz, today won the Grand Prix de Paris, oldest and richest race of the French turf.
Extremists of the right and left have the upper hand in Michigan. Liberalism and tolerance appear to have vanished with the open shop in this strike-beset State.

Many persons are offended by religion just as many of Jesus's countrymen were disillusioned when He became King, the Rev. Dr. Joseph R. Sizoo said yesterday morning at the Collegiate Reformed Church of St. Nicholas, Fifth Avenue and Forty-eighth Street.

Professor Irving Fisher's index number of average commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, was 92, which compares with 91.9 the week before, 92 two weeks before, 92.6 three weeks before and 93.3 four weeks before.

Coordination and decentralization of city relief activities, as part of the permanent welfare program that will follow adsorption of the Emergency Relief Bureau by the Department of Public Welfare, were urged by Welfare Commissioner William Hodson in his annual report to Mayor La Guardia, made public yesterday.

The seventeenth annual "medal concert of the New York Schools of Music, Arthur Cremin, director, was given yesterday afternoon at Washington Irving High School. Lawrence Arthur, 12-year-old pianist, 1,095 Park Avenue, was awarded the gold medal for his playing of the "Impromptu" in A flat, Op. 90, No. 4, by Schubert.
Seven automobile manufacturing companies have agreed to stop certain advertising methods complained of by the Federal Trade Commission, it was announced today.
Red Lucas settled down after a shaky start today and, with the aid of home runs by Arky Vaughan and Al Todd, the Pirates took the final game of the three-game series from the Phils, 4-3.

Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer yesterday announced its plans for London production to meet the requirements of the British quota laws. Louis B. Mayer will leave here for England in mid-August, joining Michael Balcon (MGM's British production head), Ben Goetz and Robert Ritchie.

Maria Adelaide Dana, daughter of Mrs. John Swift Dana of Pasadena, Calif., and the late Mr. Dana, was married last night to James Gilbert Parker, son of James C. Parker of Schenectady, N. Y. The wedding took place at the home of the bride's aunt, Mrs. Waller C. Hardy of Lewisburg, W. Va., the Rev. Lloyd V. Courtney officiating.

Britain's new Prime Minister, Neville Chamberlain, will carry on a twocenturies' family tradition tomorrow when he becomes a Cordwainer of the City of London, member of a benevolent order that began as a trade guild nearly 900 years ago.
The current news reveals a paternity center in this city where prospective fathers are taught how to meet the duties

In a sleek and shiny little brown outboard that through painstaking adjusting and tinkering during the past week had been tuned, geared and pampered into extraordinary new speeds, Robert C. Rowland of Norfolk, Va., who has just finished his sophomore year at William and Mary, not only retained the Class B championship today but three times in succession raised the American intercollegiate speed record until tonight it stands at 46.512 miles an hour.
Threatening weather lowered the attendance at the final day of the three-day festival of the Plattdeutsche Volksfest Verein in Plattdeutsche Volksfest Park here today.

There is only one way to face a crisis, and that is to face it with faith and the determination to conquer it, Rabbi Morris Lichtenstein told the Society of Jewish Science at its meeting yesterday morning at 150 West Eighty-fifth Street.

Something like an informal world economic conference will begin here tomorrow when 1,600 delegates representing forty of the most important countries, excepting Russia, will assemble in the German OperaHouse for the formal opening of the ninth general congress of the International Chamber of Commerce, which is to discuss ways to improve world trade as one approach toward world peace.

More than 100 members of the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America who have been doing repair work on the fireboat George B. McClellan at the Brewer Dry Dock, Mariners Harbor, Staten Island, will joint the strike there at 5 P. M. today, according to Herman Solomon. secretary of Local 12.

Warning against pride in personal achievements and opinions, the Rev. Phillips Packer Elliott, preaching at the First Presbyterian Church, Henry Street near Clark Street, Brooklyn, yesterday morning, placed equal emphasis on the danger of a rise of cowardice and indifference among Christians.

Miss Norma La Mond of this place and Donald Kenny of Maplewood, N. J., son of Mr. and William Kenny of Bevins, N. J., and St. Petersburg, Fla., will be married July 17 at the home of her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Norman E. La Mond of Haddonfield Road. The Rev. Dr. Nelson Butz, pastor of Prospect Presbyterian Church, Maplewood, will perform the ceremony.
Reported by the American News Company, Bloomingdale's, Brentano's, Doubleday, Doran Bookshops, Gimbel's, Macy's, Scribner's, Wanamaker's and Womrath's:

When heads were counted tonight in the twenty-one tented mess halls of the Boy Scouts city that has arisen on the shores of the Potomac it was revealed that 11,945 scouts from all over the United States had arrived for their Jamboree, scheduled to start on Wednesday.

A telegraphed request by Mayor Andrew Rooney of East Chicago, Ind., for troops to aid in preventing bloodshed when the strike-closed Chicago district steel plants reopen, was met late today by Governor M. Clifford Townsend of Indiana with refusal and predictions of a stop gap agreement within twenty-four hours.

More than $2,000,000,000, or 38.5 per cent of the $5,374,884,762 principal amount of foreign dollar bonds outstanding on Dec. 31, 1936, was in default either as to interest, sinking fund payment or principal, according to the third annual report of the Foreign Bondholders Protective Council, Inc., which will be issued today.

Adolf Wagner, Bavarian Minister of the Interior, announced today a progressive reduction of the public funds that are paid under existing treaties to both the Catholic and Protestant Churches in Bavaria.
Looking about for a vehicle for next season, Walter Hampden has selected, tentatively, a revival of Jerome K. Jerome's "The Passing of the Third Floor Back."
Dr. Ralph W. Sockman of New York delivered the baccalaureate sermon to the 123 members of the graduating class and their guests at the Hill School today.

It is a happy fortuity for America that with changes of Ministries and the coming and going of French Ambassadors, there is here a locum tenens in the person of M. JULES HENRY who is able to perform with distinction the high duties of the ambassadorial office whenever occasion arises.

The Frankli Delano Roosevelt Stadium,a WPA project, was opened this afternoon with a fife,drum and bugle corps contest for forty organizations from New Jersery, New York, Pennsylvania, Connecticut and Massachusetts. It was arranged by the local Elks Lodge, which awarded cash prizes and certificates.

Holton V. Noyes, State Agriculture Commissioner, urged the State's two-billion-dollar milk industry today to eliminate "selfishness" and "namecalling" and give the Rogers-Allen price-fixing law a fair test.

Miss Eleanor Van Dyke Beckwith and John G. E. Taylor, son of Mrs. Emerson G. Taylor and the late Colonel Taylor, were married here yesterday afternoon in the chapel of Trinity College by the Rev. Dr. Remsen B. Ogilby, president of the college.

National Youth Administration headquarters here announced today that thirty-five specially trained young men and women of the Onondaga Indian tribe will act as special counselors this Summer at camps for children in this State and in New Hampshire, Vermont, Connecticut, New Jersey and Michigan.

The cotton market here last week was only moderately active. Prices were somewhat erratic. The labor troubles in the steel and other industries influenced the market, particularly early in the week, but the main factor was the weather and crop news.

Late yesterday afternoon a sturdy Diesel electric engine, pulling a string of flat cars, rolled slowly southward on the New York Central tracks on Eleventh Avenue, hauling to storage the little green shanties that served for many years as shelters for flagmen stationed at points where "Death Avenue" intersected city streets between Forty-second and Sixty-first Streets.

A motorist was electrocuted here today when his car crashed into a streetlight standard that broke and fell on the machine. The victim was James F. Ryan, 34, of Albany, who, the coroner's physician, Dr. John A. Phelan, said, died of electric shock. John E. Mahoney, 24, of Brooklyn,

A flying fashion parade, a novel method of displaying the characteristics and performances of a dozen new-type airplanes, was held today at the Aviation Country Club here, before 150 sportsmen pilots and their guests.

"Pig-pen philosophy," which he characterized as "this getting and glutting with both feet in the trough," is all too prevalent throughout America, the Rev. Dr. William Ward Ayer, pastor of Calvary Baptist Church, 123 West Fifty-seventh Street, declared in his sermon last evening.

The outflow of capital from France, for which speculators are only slightly responsible, has been reaching such proportions lately that it is believed that the gold reserve equalization fund has been completely exhausted.
