Pope Plus today expressed hopes for the return of peace to Spain. In giving formal approval for the canonization of Salvador da Orta, Spanish lay professor of the Franciscan Brotherhood, the Pontiff said:
Stocks lower in the slowest trading for any week since that ended on March 30, 1935; turnover 2,925,830 shares. United States Government and corporate issues lower;

A proposal to convert the abandoned Center Street bridge of the Hudson Manhattan Railroad into an automobile span will be the subject of a conference here of officials of Hudson and Essex Counties and the railroad Thursday morning.

Governor Martin L. Davey issued tonight a statement which he said was intended to clarify phases of reports on a conference with C. I. O. representatives and an apparent misunderstanding with Labor Secretary Perkins concerning the steel strike.
There are no steel helmets, 14inch guns or munition factories around the Southport and Ainsdale golf course, but the "international situation" nevertheless is tense.

While firemen fought a blaze yesterday in the Sacred Heart altar of Our Lady of Lourdes Church, Springfield and Winchester Boulevards, Queens Village, the curate of the parish was baptizing two boys and a girl at the baptismal font, a short distance away.

Scoring the deciding tally in the eighth inning after registering three runs in the fifth to tie the count at 3-all, the New York Athletic Club baseball team downed the Penn A. C., 4 to 3, at Travers Island yesterday.

Tourists returning to this country will face the possibility of being searched and liable to a fine of $500 for bringing in merchandise under certain conditions if Congress passes, in its present form, a measure introduced at the request of the Treasury Department, according to a brief filed with the Committee on Ways and Means by the Merchants Association of New York.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Marx M. Levy of Shreveport, La., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jane Levy, to Dr. John J. Shaw of East Orange, N. J., son of Mr. and Mrs. Isaac M. Shaw of Newark, N. J.

Waldo Fraser, veteran parachute jumper and,an expert in packing parachutes for jumpers, was killed when his parachute failed to open at Westchester Airport here this afternoon. Some 3,000 persons saw the fatal leap of 1,500 feet.

Richard C. du Pont said tonight he would leave tomorrow on an attempt to soar to Wilmington, Del., in a glider to attend the wedding of his cousin, Ethel du Pont, to Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr., Wednesday.

If the first half of the year produced adverse factors in abundance and financial activity has been thereby reduced to an abonormally low level, it seems safe to predict a decided turn of the tide in the second half of 1937. The chief complaint from which the markets have been suffering has been overspeculatin.

For the purpose of "broadening" the Wagner Labor Relations Act and protecting the rights of all groups involved, Senator Vanderberg announced today that he would introduce three amendments to the act this week "to produce more effective industrial peace and prosperity for labor and every one else."

How the kmerican drivers will attempt to match their skill against the greater speed of the foreign cars in the Vanderbilt Cup auto race on Saturday was demonstrated at the Roosevelt Raceway today by Billy Winn, Detroit star in his four-cylinder Miller Special.

Widespread evictions have been avoided in enforcing the provisions of the Multiple Dwelling Law, according to Langdon W. Post, Tenement House Commissioner, who announced yesterday that owners of 1,284 buildings had agreed to comply with the law and to vacate 534 structures under the terms of the Murray Act, which grants exemption from prosecution for a period of six months when such agreements are signed.
The Devon Yacht Club's reception and tea and the first dinner dance opened the social season here yesterday. Many large parties were given at the clubhouse overlooking Gardiner's Bay.
The league-leading Newark Bears won a pair of extra-inning games from the Baltimore Orioles today, taking the nightcap in nine frames, 5 to 4, after bagging the opener by 8 to 7 in the twelfth.

Blaming what he characterized as the backward attitude of courts on the right of labor to organize and the anti-union policies of employers for the prevailing industrial unrest, Justice Ferdinand Pecora of the New York Supreme Court, in an address here today at the concluding session of the Tamiment Social and Economic Institute,

Several American ship lines have notified the Department of Commerce that they will be unable to complete renovations of their ships to conform to Federal safety regulations which become effective next Thursday, it was learned yesterday.
Buford H. Jones has been elected president of Dunn McCarthy, Inc., manufacturers of Enna Jettick Shoes. Other newly elected officers are William M. Enerson, vice president; Fred L. Emerson,

Stirred by a taunt from their leaders that they were losing their nerve, steel strikers here opened picketing on a "twenty-four-hour" basis tonight at the Cambria plant of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, where the back-to-work movement is expected to reach a peak tomorrow morning.

Mrs. Harris Fahnestock had her first luncheon party of the season today at Eastover, Lenox. The guests included Mr. and Mrs. David T. Dana, Mr. and Mrs. R. Jay Flock, Mrs. E. R. Reed, Mrs. Reed Howard, Mr. and Mrs. Frederic F. De Rham, Greenville Lindall Winthrop and Giraud Foster.

The 475-mile ocean race from Sarah's Ledge, off New London Harbor, to Gibson Island in Chesapeake Bay, held under the auspices of the Gibson Island Yacht Squadron, was started on time this afternoon in a light southerly wind and drizzling rain.

Members of two American Federation of Labor theatrical unions authorized their executive committees yesterday to take any steps they considered necessary to halt dismissals on the WPA Federal Theatre Project.

Graham Youngs, a special partner in the New York Stock Exchange firm of Stokes, Hoyt Co., 39 Broadway, died suddenly early yesterday on board the liner Franconia, according to word received here by one of his partners. Mr.
Ecuador is becoming one of the most promising producers of bananas in Latin America as a result of the United Fruit Company's offer of a market to local planters.

Rochester Teutonia Liedertafel today was declared the championship chorus of the thirteenth State saengerfest, which concluded its sessions here today. The runner-up and winner of the Max Scholer Trophy was the Buffalo Harugari-Froshinn Chorus.

Steadily and in increasing numbers Russian aeronautical engineers and mechanics, sent to this country by the Soviet government, are being taken into key plants of the United States aviation industry. This fact is beginning to cause concern in the minds of high government officials closely identified with military and commercial aviation.

In the last year the Municipal Civil Service Commission centered its attention on three objectives: extension of the competitive system, with greater opportunities for promotion; improvement of examining technique, and increased efficiency and morale in the public service, the commission said yesterday in its annual report for 1936.

The first anniversary of the new family law prohibiting operations to prevent births except for therapeutic reasons was marked today by the publication of figures showing a stattling increase in the birth rate. There is worry among the population over what is to be done with all the babies now arriving.
Putting in service 320 motor trucks, a record number for transportation of New York National Guard units from the metropolitan area, 3,300 Guardsmen were moved in and out of Camp Smith here today.

The Chiefs swept a double header with the Jersey City Giants before 5,000 today, gaining a 2 to 1 decision in the opener despite Rollie Stiles's four-hit hurling, and landing on three pitchers for fourteen hits to take the second game, 9 to 1.

WHEN a big-league ball player begins to slow up he has to look for another job. Sometimes he finds it in baseball. He becomes a coach, a scout or a manager. But there aren't enough of those jobs to go all the way around. The departing heroes have to go further afield.

Adding another important link to her short but brilliant string of competitive achievements, the American-bred wire-haired foxterrier bitch Penwick's Snowflake yesterday took the premier honors at the Staten Island Kennel Club's second annual all-breed exhibition held on the grounds of the Cavalry Brigade Armory . in West New Brighton.

Miss Mary Evelyn Ashley, daughter of Mrs. Charles Otis Ashley of this city and Long Branch, N. J., and the late Mr. Ashley, was married to Henry de Segur Lauve, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Leroy Lauve of Baltimore, here Saturday afternoon in the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Ascension by the Rev. Frederick Cooper, the assistant rector.

Temporary headquarters established in Stony Brook by State, county and township officials for investigation of the disappearance of Mrs. William H. Parsons will be closed tomorrow, it was announced today.

While rate forms for residential electrical service have made material progress toward simplification and uniformity in the last year, one of the most conspicuous features of the rates in effect in cities is their wide variation, "the range from the lowest to the highest bill for a similar quantity of electrical energy often exceeding 100 per cent and occasionally over 200 per cent," the Federal Power Commission reported today.

A lone marauder broke into Hilholme, the country estate of Percy S. Straus, president of R. H. Macy Co., in Rye, just outside the boundary of Port Chester, early this morning and escaped with jewelry valued at $50,000 and a small sum in cash.

Behind the problem of industrial unrest which now engages the interest of the country looms another and older problem on which an event this week will focus fresh attention. This is the problem of national finance.

The return-to-work movement in Ohio is important because it suggests a movement in local sentiment, quickly reflected in the policy of Governor DAVEY, which leaders on both sides of the labor struggle will be wise to take into account.

George Gabner Schreiber of this place has announced the engagement of his daughter, Miss Caroline Auguste Schreiber, to Milan Raynard Bump of New York and Wilmington, Del., son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Milan Raynard Bump. The announcement was made today at a buffet luncheon at the Schreiber home.
A mixed reception was given to the Stage Society's presentation at the Westminster Theatre tonight of "Tsar Lenin," Francois Porche's play, adapted in English by Ossia Trilling and Emanuel Wax.

The navy relaxed tonight. Final figures on the attendance at the Jefferson Islands Club for the three-day Democratic picnic were not available, but they ran in the neighborhood of 340 men, and tonight the navy was saying, as its officers and men said after the war:
The rise in quotations of French renters is probably attributable to the compulsory repurchases by short sellers, and perhaps also to the fact that some persons are more confident than before.

The cereal grain crops in the' southern part of the Western Canadian Provinces have collapsed in the last two weeks as the result of hot and dry weather. The collapse came with the same dramatic suddenness witnessed in the Northwest in the United States in the forepart of June, 1936, when an excellent crop promise was eliminated almost overnight by hot winds and a lack of subsoil moisture.

Caught beneath the falls when he was swept over a power dam here today, Morris Smith, 11 years old, was rescued 1 hour and 45 minutes later. The boy was taken to Potsdam Hospital, where it was said that he had suffered from cold but would recover.
Mr. and Mrs. Kuo C. Li of Thompson Park gave a luncheon today at the Piping Rock Club, Locust Valley, in honor of Dr. H. H. Kung, Vice President and Minister of Finance of the Republic of China.

Attacks on the church are always preceded by revilementt" of the clergy, the Rev. Clement Neubauer declared in a sermon yesterday morning at the Church of Our Lady Queen of Angels, 226 East 113th Street, where the pastor, the Rev. Sebastian Schaff celebrated his silver jubilee as a Capuchin priest by saying the high mass.

With "The Right Boy in the Right Job" as its slogan, a two-week conference on vocational careers and college education will start here tomorrow, attended by boys from forty-three public high schools and nineteen private preparatory schools. The conference was arranged by Stevens Institute.
Seventy-eight men and women cadets of the Salvation Army will receive commissions as probationary lieutenants at exercises this evening at Mecca Temple on West Fifty-fifth Street.

Religious groups in the United States gained in membership, as a whole, during 1936 and continued to draw ahead in the steady increase in population, according to the annual statistical report made public yesterday by The Christian Herald.

Eighty thousand men and a handful of women who more than a score of years ago were part of the rank and file of the British Army in France today formed ranks again to march past King George VI in Hyde Park.

Tom Yawkey's gold-plated Red Sox swept both ends of a double-header from the Browns today, completing the most successful home stand in years with eleven victories out of thirteen games against Western invaders.

Although there are some signs of a Summer lull in steel buying, the mills are continuing production at a high rate to meet the needs of consumers and little progress is being made in reducing backlogs, according to the magazine Steel.

The engagement of Mrs. Mary P. Hay and the Right Rev. Benjamin Brewster, Bishop of the Maine Episcopal Diocese, who this month completed fifty years in the ministry, was announced here today. They will be married late in August.

Mrs. Madeleine la Ferriere, known also as Miss Magda de Fontanges, who shot and wounded Count Charles de Chambrun as he was boarding a train here on March 17, was declared mentally responsible in a report today by alienists who have had her under observation.

Miss Carolyn Lydia Beyer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Beyer of Merion, was married this afternoon to the Rev. Allan MacLachlan Frew, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Robert Allan Frew of Glasgow, Scotland, and rector of the Ardmore Presbyterian Church.
Louis Arthur Johnson of Clarksburg, W. Va., former national commander of the American Legion, took office today as Assistant Secretary of War, a post which had been vacant for almost a year.

James Francis Fargo, financier and originator of the modern express travelers' check system, who died on June 18, in his eightieth year, in the Harkness Pavilion, left an estate of less than $500. This was learned yesterday when his will was filed for probate in Surrogates' Court.

Charles L. Bradley and John P. Murphy, president and secretary of the Alleghany Corporation, announced today that they had bought the Higbee Company, operator of a department store here, from the George A. and Frances Ball Foundation, which had retained the Higbee Company and other Cleveland interests of the Van Sweringens recently while selling the Van Sweringen railroad properties.

The Society of British Aircraft Constructors today held at Hatfield Airdrome a "private" showing of technical progress in manufacture in the past year before an invited list of 5,000 guests from fifty countries. But the newest and most interesting planes were withheld from the display.

Two mysterious telephone calls, both made from public phone booths in New London, Conn., by a woman who said she was the missing Mrs. William H. Parsons tonight sent police of two States on a fruitless search for the caller.
The Lincoln National Life Insurance Company opened its 1937 Eastern regional convention in the Hotel Traymore today. A. L. Dern of Fort Wayne, Ind., vice president and director

ADAMS--Mary E.. of 355 West 19th St., on June 28, 1937. Services at Universal Chapel, 597 Lexington Ave., on Wednesday, at 2:30 P. M. AGATSTEIN-Ruth (nee Seidenstein), beloved wife of Nathan, darling daughter of Nathan and Mollie, dear sister of Dr. Jacob J., Ida Chartoff, Anna Nassberg, Dr. Louis and Saul. Services Tuesday,

A new campaign by the Police Department against violators of the Sabbath Law, which forbids the opening of delicatessen and grocery stores between 10 A. M. and 4 P. M., brought thirty-five storekeepers into West Side Court yesterday before Magistrate Earl A. Smith.

Steps for the rehabilitation of East Harlem by extensive rezoning and rehousing were recommended yesterday in a planning report published by the Mayor's Committee on City Planning, the second in its series of community studies in the city.

Hedging pressure caused a fair recession in the wheat market early today but the selling was absorbed quickly and later sensational reports of black rust damage from parts of Northeastern Kansas, Southeastern Nebraska and parts of Illinois and Missouri, combined with continued dry weather in the Canadian Northwest, sent the market soaring.

When Judge Carroll C. Hincks of the United States District Court here today approved a petition filed by Harry R. Trainer of Brookline, Mass., asking that the New York, Westchester Boston Railroad be placed in equity receivership because of its evident failure to reorganize under Section 77 of the Bankruptcy Act the last obstacle apparent to liquidation of the affairs of that line was removed.

In the last year, the gross income of the $24,000,000 Series C-2 mortgage certificate issue of the New York Title and Mortgage Company was $2,097,932 and the net income $701,249, the trustees appointed by Supreme Court Justice Frankenthaler reported yesterday. The net for the first full year under their control, the trustees said, was almost twelve times the net for the three previous years combined.

Governor Cross of Connecticut urged members of the graduating class of the Hill School today to "live actively in the present, look to the future but also look to the past in order to obtain hope for the future."

Nellie Gutowski, alias Norma Parker, the 20-year-old so-called Broadway gun girl, and three other women inmates of the Westfield State Farm here escaped shortly before dark tonight as they were being returned from the reformatory mess hall to their screened-in cottages on the grounds.

Without the help of their aviation the Nationalists [Rebels] have been slowed somewhat in their advance west of Bilbao toward Santander, but because there is much less resistance the bad weather is not impeding the progress as much as it retarded the march on Bilbao.

Detailed replies to recent criticism of the proposed contract for private operation of the Staten Island Foreign Trade Zone were forwarded yesterday by Louis K. Comstock, chairman of the Mayor's advisory committee on foreign trade zone, to Mayor Fiorella H. La Guardia.

Steel operations in the United States this week are scheduled at 75 per cent of ingot capacity, compared with 75.9 per cent last week, a decrease of nine-tenths of 1 point, or 1.2 per cent, and a new low level for the year, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. A month ago the rate was 77.4 per cent.

Frank L. Miller, representing the Austin Silver Mining Company before the Securities and Exchange Commission, yesterday obtained a continuance of the hearings on the company's case until Aug. 2. Counsel for the respondents argued that they had been served with supplementary notice of matters to be considered as recently as June 24 and would need additional time for preparation. Pierce Bradley,

The second member of the younger generation of the Oyster Bay Roosevelt family to make her debut this season was introduced to society tonight when Mr. and Mrs. John Kean Roosevelt of Yellowbanks gave a supper dance at the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club on Centre Island for their

Mrs. Russell Hillard Loines of New York announced the marriage today of her daughter, Miss Margot Loines, to Dwight Whitney Morrow Jr., son of Mrs. Dwight W. Morrow of Englewood, N. J., and Deacon Brown's Point, North Haven, Me., and the late Ambassador to Mexico.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today dated June 25: REAR ADMIRAL Bakenhus, R. E., Civil Engr. Corps, Third Naval District, New York, N. Y., on Aug. 1 ordered home, relieved from all active duty.

Former Deputy Controller Frank J. Prial will announce his candidacy for the Democratic nomination for either Mayor or Controller later this week, it was indicated last night. Mr. Prial, while willing to confer with the city leaders of the party, and gain his place on the city-wide ticket in that manner, is also prepared to enter the primaries and fight for the nomination.

Dr. Richard F. Flint of the Department of Geology of Yale; Dr. Henry Oosting, Professor of Botany at Duke, and Dr. Flint's assistant, Albert L. Washburn, left Helsingfors today via Lapland for Tromsoe, Norway, where they will start immediately on a six weeks' geological exploration of Greenland.

The first Nassau County Police Department patrol boat, a 38-foot cabin cruiser, was launched into Woodcleft Bay today after young Joan Skidmore, granddaughter of Chief of Police Abram Skidmore, had broken a bottle of champagne over the bow and named it The Chief.
John Holzderber Jr., secretary of the Hastings Building Savings and Loan Association, died yesterday in St. John's Riverside Hospital, Yonkers, at the age of 54.

The estate of Alfred I. du Pont had paid $14,873,119 in Federal and State taxes, $11,233,661.19 to the Federal Government and $3,639,457.81 to the State, according to the annual report of the executors filed today in the office of County Judge Ollie Edmunds.

The marriage of Miss Marion Beatrice Ritter, daughter of Mr. Mrs. Frederick W. Ritter of Douglas Manor, L. I., to John Wilson Peelle, son of Mrs. Charles W. Peelle, also of Douglas Manor, and the late Mr. Peelle, took place last night in the Community Church, Douglaston.

A suggested "model law" prohibiting the retailing of merchandise at less than the invoice cost price has been completed by the National Food and Grocery Conference Committee and will be submitted to the industry for its approval within the next few weeks, it was learned here yesterday. The committee,
Sir William Charles Robertson, former Governor of Barbados, died here yesterday and was buried today. His age was 70.

William McAndrew, one of America's best-known educators, died at his home here at 12 o'clock noon yesterday. He was 73 years old. Mr. McAndrew, who attracted national attention when he was ousted from the superintendency of the Chicago public schools in 1927 by Mayor William Hale Thompson,

Louis H. Pink, State Superintendent of Insurance, announced yesterday that checks for a 3 per cent liquidation dividend were being mailed to 5,737 policyholder creditors of the Lloyds Insurance Company of America, which the Insurance Department is liquidating.
Addition of five new members to the board of trustees of the Twentieth Century Fund, Inc., was announced last night by Edward A. Filene, president.

The President Pierce of the Dollar Line arrived last night at Jersey City and landed forty members of the crew of the British freighter Sandgate Castle, which was burned at sea on Saturday. Captain H. C.

Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Allen Fairchild of Noroton, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Priscilla Sears Fairchild, to Dr. Arthur John Smyth, son of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Arthur Worsley Smyth of Cambridge, England.

America needs to expand rather than merely to restore production if economic progress is to continue, said Owen D. Young of New York, chairman of the board of the General Electric Company, in an address tonight at the Purdue University Institute on American Policy and Technology.
The second accident of the national soaring contest came late this afternoon, when Leslie Barton of Newark, N. J., flying for altitude, crashed on a ridge within sight of Harris Hill.
Premier Paul Van Zeeland of Belgium revealed in two addresses here yesterday that he had a "mission" in the United States in addition to receiving an honorary degree last week at Princeton.
Mrs. J. Borden Harriman arrived in Norway today to take up her new duties as United States Minister. She preserved a diplomatic silence. The United States Consul at Bergen saw to that.

The "Blue Danube" will flow through the Austrian section of the New York Exposition of 1939, with views of Austrian Alpine scenery and a scenic railroad on its banks, Baron Guido von Fuchs, member of the Austrian committee for the exposition, has announced in Vienna, the Department of Commerce reported today.

A single-handed piece of investigation by a young detective, John J. Whalen, led to the discovery of Robert Irwin's cached luggage and in it vital evidence that two months ago in the minds of the police definitely identified him as the Gedeon murderer, it was revealed yesterday by Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine.

The biggest international economic conference of recent years got under way here today when the ninth Congress of the International Chamber of Commerce was opened at a ceremonious session in the gayly decorated German Opera House.

Northern Ave, 20, s w c 178th St, 6-story apartment, 105x135 ft; Joseph B. Miller, trustee. against 20 Northern Ave. Corp.; due, $328,734; to plaintiff for $1,000. By I. LINCOLN SEIDE 24th St, 49-51 West, 11-story loft building, 45x98.9 feet: Aaron Rabinowitz et al., trustees, against Car-Meen Corp.; due, $241.631: to plaintiff for $1,000.

Thirty-six more Russians have been shot on charges of espionage and sabotage in the Far Eastern section of the Transsiberian Railway, according to the June 20 issue of The Pacific Ocean Star, official newspaper at Khabarovsk, where the trial was held.

The wedding of Miss Elsie Marion Bomhoff, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry J. Bomhoff of this place, to William Ezra Cornell, son of Professor and Mrs. William G. Cornell, also of Montclair, took place this afternoon in Grace Presbyterian Church here. The Rev. Willard G. Purdy of Wilmington, Del.,

Dr. Bayard T. Horton of the Mayo Clinic sounded a warning today to swimmers who are hypersensitive to cold. It is such a condition, he said in a clinical report, that causes many drownings. Here is Dr. Horton's advice to bathers:

With new trials in the Scottsboro case scheduled to begin here July 6, Attorney General A. A. Carmichael was absent from his office in Montgomery today, and there were rumors he was away in connection with a compromise settlement for eight of the nine Negroes accused of attacking two white women aboard a freight train in March, 1931.

The Ford company began planning today a fight against the National Labor Relations Board's charges of unfair labor practices and "brutal" treatment of union organizers. In a statement today Louis J. Colombo, a Ford company attorney, termed "absolutely untrue" every charge made by the board in a complaint Saturday.

Although Frank Sarro, the captain of the Lawrence High School golf team, scored a 78, 76--154 today over the red course at Bethpage State Park, which was four strokes better than his winning play in this same tournament last year, he is no longer the holder of the Long Island Golf Association's caddie championship.
Ira W. Hirshfield, New York lawyer, has purchased the six-acre country home of William K. Lowry on East Hunting Ridge Road, Stamford, Conn. Kenneth Ives Co. acted as brokers in the sale.

Professor Adolf Erman, widely known for his books on Egypt and Egyptology, died today at the age of 83. Professor Erman directed the compilation of a complete dictionary of Egyptian hieroglyphics, a herculean task which consumed more than twenty years. In July,

Arlington Park opened its rich thirty-day racing meeting today in a driving rainstorm, with Fraidy Cat, owned by Hal Price Headley of Lexington, Ky., splashing to victory in the $5,000 added Inaugural Handicap in a photo finish.
The Public Service Commission announced today that three more municipally owned electric plants had been advised to lower their rates immediately to forestall legal proceedings. The communities,

It has been the general belief here that Lieut. Gen. Sir Arthur Grenfell Wauchope would continue in office as High Commissioner for the remainder of his five-year appointment, which started at the end of last year.
The Great Lakes Transit Corporation has announced it will seek the Interstate Commerce Commission's authority to restore full freight service to Chicago and other ports on lower Lake Michigan.

The bodies of three little girls, kidnapped Saturday by a supposed degenerate, were found late today by Boy Scouts, aided by an aviator, in a gully in the Baldwin Hills, four miles north of this Los Angeles suburb.
Lieutenant A. B. Smith's pursuit plane struck telephone wires and crashed when landing with eleven other United States Army planes at Sabanas Airfield this morning.

Holland Ave (16-4597), w s, 100 n of Burke Ave, 100x100; Charles Krupnick to 3,215 Holland Avenue Realty Corp., 3,328 Rochambeau Ave; mtg $134,750. Ogden Ave, 994 (9-2511); Michael Dermody to Katherine Clancy, 1,026 Nelson Ave; mtg $10,000.

Governor Davey in Columbus today asserted that he intended keeping the National Guard in the Mahoning Valley steel districts until all danger of violence had passed, in response to protests from C. I. O. leaders that the troops were aiding a campaign of "terrorism" against strikers, and demands for their removal.

Four life guards in a surf boat today rescued Captain Hans Alberts of Wilmington, Del., from the ocean four miles off Stone Harbor after a fire and explosion had wrecked the 55-foot motor yacht Almar belonging to Alfred V. du Pont of Wilmington. Alberts,

President Roosevelt today sent to the Senate for ratification the international agreement on regulation of sugar production and marketing, signed at London May 6 by the United States and other sugarproducing countries and designed to come into force on Sept. 1.
W. S. Alexander, Federal Alcohol Administrator, told the liquor industry today that advertisements were "misleading" if they described distilled spirits as "cool or refreshing" when imbibed alone.

Rain caused the curtailment of most of the program of the fifth annual Eastern invitation boarding schools tennis tourney today at the Manursing Island Club. Six matches were played when conditions permitted.

Announcing that the three-centsa-day plan for hospital care now had more than 400,000 members, Frank Van Dyk, executive director of the Associated Hospital Service of New York, said yesterday that beginning today subscription payments could be made through Western Union offices.

Governor Murphy, in New York, reveals legislation just passed by the Michigan Legislature which puts drastic restrictions on picketing and provides sweeping authority for the use of police powers in strikes.

William R. Williams, assistant general manager of the metropolitan division of the Western Union Telegraph Company, died suddenly of a heart attack early yesterday at his home, 74-00 Kessel Street, Forest Hills, Queens. His age was 45.

Tazio Nuvolari, daring little Italian automobile driver who captured the first Vanderbilt Cup race last year, arrived in New Yorkyesterday, as did six other European stars who will match speed and skill against the Americans in the second 300-mile contest at the Roosevelt Raceway, Westbury, L. I., Saturday.

The Senate passed legislation today providing a special tax to finance the 1937 Railroad Retirement Act. The bill, which now goes to the White House, proposes to levy equal taxes on the railroads and their employes, through graduated imposts on payrolls. The total tax would amount to 5 1/2 per cent for three years and increase to 7 1/2 per cent by 1949.

Owners of waterfront property whose titles are clouded by covenant clauses extending back to the Revolution may clear their titles under a simple procedure outlined yesterday by Corporation Counsel Paul Windels.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The TIMES'S editorial comment of June 13 on my letter concerning the ever-normal granary plan contains some interesting observations and will no doubt help to stimulate thought on this important subject.

Leases of space for expansion of several well-known business groups were reported yesterday by Manhattan brokers. The Western Union Telegraph Company and the Postal Telegraph and Cable Company took space for new branch offices in 9 Rockefeller Plaza, new unit of Rockefeller Center.

From information that the authorities have been receiving here in the last forty-eight hours it appears more than probable that Germany and Italy have instituted what amounts to an unofficial submarine blockade of the Loyalist Spanish coast.

With a shrill cry of "Moo-osh" and a shriller "Gee-ee," contrasting weirdly with the traffic rumble of busy Lafayette Street, Patrick Carroll swung his dog team into the wide entrance of the Speyer Hospital for Animals, at 350 Lafayette Street, yesterday,

With the American Legion and the Veterans of Foreign Wars as the nucleus, a great army of volunteer "strikebreakers" is being recruited and organized in Michigan as Henry Ford and John L. Lewis prepare for a struggle which may mark a turning point in American labor history.

Mr. and Mrs. Malcolm Du Boise Hunter were hosts tonight at a large dinner dance at Glen Lo Farm, their Glen Cove place, in honor of Mrs. Hunter's twin debutante daughters, the Misses Althea Gibb and Mary A. Eldredge.

Miss Grace D. Kirkpatrick, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Archibald S. Kirkpatrick of Chandler Road, was married this evening to Paul Rheinhardt Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Rheinhardt of New York, in the Ogden Memorial Presbyterian Church here.

YOU may very well argue that it wouldn't come to pass. Much too hypothetical. This is America, not Europe, and in America such things don't happen. We're a kindly, law-abiding people. A bloody general strike in New York City? Unlikely. Largely imagination. Storybook stuff.

Using the old-fashioned football "flying wedge" to break undermanned picket lines, about half of the 1,000 employes of three Beaver Falls steel plants joined a back-towork movement today without the aid of the police.

A homicidal maniac who believes that he can discuss crimes with police and still outwit them but who loses in the end is the central figure of the new play, "Wanted for Murder," which opened at the Q Theatre tonight.
Disturbed by a White House announcement today that President Roosevelt planned to ask for passage of the ever-normal granary farm relief plan at this session of Congress,

Running along seasonal lines, business failures have dropped to the lowest level since late last November. Dun Bradstreet yesterday reported a total of 148 for the week ended June 24, against 166 in the previous week and 165 in the corresponding week last ear.

The following members of the department having been tried before Francis X. Giaccone, Deputy Fire Commissioner, on date specified, for violation of rules and regulations, the following decisions are rendered by the fire chief and commissioner: Aug. 4, 1936: Lieutenant Lawrence V. Fagan, Engine Co. 243, now H. L. 18. Charge: Neglect of duty (neglected to properly direct chauffeur of company apparatus). Complaint dismissed.

Despite the handicap of inclement weather, attendance at the New York Furniture Exchange, Inc., where Fall furniture lines are on display, reached 315 yesterday. The registration equalled that of the record opening last year and is considered exceptional for the second week of a furniture trade event.

On the ground of "public policy" the House of Lords decided today that if a man promises to marry a woman as soon as his pending divorce from his wife becomes absolute the contract is binding. Accordingly Sir Anthony Mildmay, baronet, will have to pay Miss Emily Fender, a nurse, [Pound]2,000 for breach of promise.

"Prosperity Dwells Where Harmony Reigns," is the keynote of a cooperative advertising campaign being prepared by the National Association of Manufacturers for use by business and civic groups in industrial centers threatened with labor troubles, it was learned here yesterday.
Thirteen Federal agencies awarded 126 supply contracts in the week ended on June 24 under restrictions of the Public Contracts Act, the Department of Labor announces in its weekly summary.
Colonel Clarence J. Manly, Medical Corps, U. S. A., retired, died yesterday. He formerly was surgeon general of of the Ninth Corps Area here.

The line-up for the Scotch foursomes which will open the Ryder Cup golf play tomorrow follows: Ed Dudley and Byron Nelson, United States, vs. Alf Padgham and Henry Cotton, Britain; Ralph Guldahl and Tony Manero, United States, vs. Arthur Lacey and W. J. Cox, Britain; Gene Sarazen and Denny Shute, United States, vs.

Colonel Louis Arthur Watres, a former Lieutenant Governor and twice a State Senator, whose long career had included the practice of law, publishing a newspaper and organizing banks and utility companies, died tonight after a brief illness. He was 86 years old.

Trading was fair on practically all classes of traefa meats. Lamb prices were steady and other classes strong to higher. Early trading In kosher meats indicated beef prices to be higher and other kosher meats steady with last Friday's close as reported by the U. S. Department of Agriculture.

More than 100 American and Canadian Boy Scouts on their way to the national jamboree in Washington were received yesterday at City Hall by Mayor La Guardia. Scoutmaster Albert Smith, in charge of the boys, told the Mayor that a letter to him from the Mayor of Verdun, Que., had been lost in the Empire State Building.
A syndicate headed by the Bankers Trust Company purchased yesterday a new issue of $4,000,000 of short-term notes of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts at 0.64 per cent plus a premium of $57.

Donald Budge, with an impressive straight-set victory over Vivian McGrath of Australia, and Frankie Parker, whose overeagerness to finish the match made him take five sets instead of three to defeat Heinrich Henkel of Germany, today entered the semi-finals of the men's singles at Wimbledon.

Girl Guides from thirty-one nations who will attend the Girl Scout Silver Jubilee encampment- at Briarcliff Manor in August are by a special courtesy of Congress to be exempted with their official chaperones from payment of visa, head tax and other entrance fees, including customs duties.

The Feld-Crawford Price Maintenance Act will be the subject of a debate at a luncheon and executive conference of the International Association of Sales Executives at the Hotel Astor tomorrow, with Senator A. Spencer Feld defending it and Q. Forrest Walker, economist for R. H. Macy Co., Inc., opposing it.

Charging breach of agreement and asking for "an appropriate remedy and penalty," the Midtown Realty Owners Association and the Penn Zone Association jointly filed a complaint yesterday against the Building Service Employes International Union, Local 32-B.

Liquidation among the railroad bonds caused sharp declines in this section yesterday in trading on the New York Stock Exchange. Losses of more than 4 points were recorded by the liens of some of the carriers. The selling in the rails was the heaviest the market has experienced in several months and was attributed principally to the decline in net operating income for May, compared with the same month in 1936.

A new minimum wage law for women and minors, substituting a "fair" wage for a blanket $16 a week minimum, became effective today with the signature of Governor R. C. Stanford. The old law was held unconstitutional in 1925 by the United States Supreme Court.

Price changes were divided almost evenly between gains and losses on local commodity futures markets yesterday, hides being strong, rubber weak and most of the other staples reflecting only slight changes. On the cash markets the grains, flour, lard, eggs and cocoa advanced, while cotton, printcloth, rubber, hides, silk and tin declined.
Frank E. Haley, a Republican justice of the peace, drove eight miles from his office here today to deliver a marriage license and collect $3 from Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr.

Harry Frankel, secretary-treasurer of Local 167 of the Chicken Drivers Union, was sentenced to from one to three years in the penitentiary yesterday by Justices William R. Bayes, Max Solomon and Bernard A. Kozicke of the Court of Special Sessions, who found him guilty last week of usury.
The Inland Steel Company and the Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company announced a temporary delay today in plans to reopen their strikebound plants in the Chicago area tomorrow morning.

An address by Professor Julian Coolidge, master of Lowell College at Harvard, and awarding of diplomas to seventy-eight seniors were features of commencement exercises at the Hotchkiss School this morning.
The Securities and Exchange Commission resumed today its investigation of investment trusts with an examination of the growth of the Atlas Corporation, one of the largest companies in that field.

On the stock market, the volume of business improved slightly today, and most sections were better. Gilt-edge issues were strong, and among foreign loans, German issues advanced after early dullness. The transatlantic list was firm at the outset, but became uncertain after United States Steel fell off.

Canadian made with the United States continues to expand-partly because of the reciprocal trade agreement between the two countries and partly because of the general improvement in economic conditions in both and the rise in prices.
The Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company has been appointed trustee of the Phelps Dodge Corporation convertible 3 1/2 per cent debentures, due June 15, 1952, authorized issue of $20,285,000.
If the President accepted all the presents that the Scouts have brought for him, a secret'service officer told Scout leaders today, he would -almost have to move out of the White House.

Seventeen young women, members of the class of 1937 at Stoneleigh College, were graduated this morning at the annual commencement exercises. The commencement address was delivered by Senator Moore of New Jersey, who flew from Washington for the exercises.

On own application: To take effect 12 midnight, June 30: CAPTAIN-William H. Amann, Traffic Precinct J, at $2,750 per annum. Appointed Oct. 1, 1896. PATROLMEN-To take effect 12 midnight, June 26: Francis J. Sherry, 112th Precinct, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed June 7, 1907. To take effect 12 midnight, June 30: William W. Ruege, 106th Precinct, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed June 11, 1912.

The task of negotiating a compromise on President Roosevelt's judiciary reorganization bill was renewed in earnest by administration leaders in the Senate today under what they regarded as more favorable circumstances following the Democratic harmony picnics on Jefferson Islands.

Five defendants, including three labor union officials, a lawyer and the son of one of the fugitives in the Drukman case, went on trial before a special term of the Court of Special Sessions yesterday, charged with conspiracy to put out of business any cake or pastry manufacturer who failed to abide by their orders.

Miss Florence Allen Branigan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Irwin Branigan of this place, was married tonight to Dr. Edward Campbell Berger, son of Dr. Grace Berger of New York and the late Dr. Theodore Berger. The ceremony was performed at the home of the bride by the Rev. Donald McAdie, rector of St. John's Episcopal Church.
Mrs. Julia Hamilton Briscoe, eldest daughter of former Governor William T. Hamilton of Maryland and widow of James T. Briscoe, died early today at the Hamilton homestead here, where she was born.

A demand for an investigation by the Department of Justice into charges that representatives of the Democratic National Committee are "hijacking business men and governmental contractors in Tennessee into buying at outrageous prices the Democratic Campaign Book, autographed by the President,"

Pacing a field of 146 players over the rain-soaked Woodway Country Club course today, Tony Kosinski of Greenfield Hills, State amateur champion in 1934, won the qualifying round in the thirty-eighth annual meeting of the Connecticut Golf Association with a par 71.

In the expectation that this city will be the Mecca during the next two months for a record-breaking number of tourists, leading stores here are planning promotional publicity to capitalize on the visitor's interest in the city's retail establishments. The copy,
The seventy-first annual commencement of the Peddie School was held here this morning in the First Baptist Church. The class day program was held in the Greek Theatre earlier in the day.

The system of obtaining materials for WPA projects is so enmeshed in "super-bureaucracy and red tape" that it would prove "outright ruinous" for any private business organization, Ralph M. Easley, chairman of the executive council of the National Civic Federation, charged yesterday in the fourth of a series of letters to President Roosevelt on alleged defects in the Federal work relief program.

Jules Bouy, an interior decorator, who was among the first to make use of modern art in this country, died Sunday of heart disease in the Andrew Freedman Home, 1,125 Grand Concourse, the Bronx, where he had been living for eighteen months. He was 66 years old.

All the warehouses of McKesson Robbins, Inc., wholesale drugs, except that at 3,674 Third Avenue, the Bronx, where the company began a lockout last Friday "to prevent the C. I. O. from compelling it to breach a contract with an A. F. of L. local," were reported in operation yesterday by Frederic Wingersky, vice president of the company.

When the seven Democratic Senators-whose names, with those of three Republicans, appear on the majority report of the Judiciary Committee disapproving the President's Supreme Court Bill-had affixed their signatures to that document, they felt and displayed pardonable pride.
The list of the Cunard White Star liner Aquitania, due today from Southampton via Cherbourg, includes Sir Percy Bates, chairman of the Cunard White Star Line; Frederick Watson,
Captain William O. Chichester, retired master mariner of the Clyde Line, died today in the Southside Hospital at Bay Shore. He was 77 years old.

Supreme Court Justice Benjamin N. Cardozo has sold his four-story private home at 16 West Seventy-fifth Street, which he purchased about 1920, to the 16 West Seventy-fifth Street Corporation, A. Abelson, president, of 61 Broadway.

A compromise by which Herbert and Morton Minsky may be able to reopen their Oriental Theatre at Broadway and Fifty-second Street with motion pictures and vaudeville instead of burlesque is being considered by License Commissioner Paul Moss.

Automobile production showed a contra-seasonal increase last week, and the adjusted index spurted to 127.3 from 115.0. This compares with 100.6 for the week ended June 27, 1936. Output for the week was estimated by Ward's Reports, Inc., at 121,032 units, compared with 111,620 for the previous week.

The two-family house at 2,845 West Thirty-fifth Street, Brooklyn, has been sold by the Godfrey Investing Corporation to Anne Feiner. The Model Products Corporation, manufacturing plumbing supplies, has leased the three-story building at the northwest corner of Concord Street and Hudson Avenue through Baffa Dixon, brokers.

John H. Regan, ship news reporter for the City News Association in New York, died here today at the age of 52, having returned to his former home here six months ago. Funeral services will be held here tomorrow.

Mr. and Mrs. Herman Duval of this place gave a dinner dance tonight at the Westchester Country Club, Rye, at which they announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marion Duval, to John Shober Burrows Jr., son of John Shober Burrows, also of Scarsdale, and the late Mrs. Elizabeth Corner Burrows.

Recovering after a poor start, New Zealand hit 282 runs for nine wickets today in reply to England's first-innings total of 424 and now has fair prospects of forcing a draw in the opening cricket test match between the two countries.

Beginning on Thursday employes of the Hospitals Department will be placed on an eight-hour day as rapidly as the enlistment of additional personnel will permit, Hospitals Commissioner S. S. Goldwater announced yesterday.

Strict neutrality by this country and international cooperation to prevent war are favored by a large majority of youths answering a peace ballot of the World Youth Congress, the first results of which were announced yesterday.

A Committee for Industrial Organization union was victorious by a margin of 244 votes today in an election conducted by the National Labor Board for employes of the American Car and Foundry Company. The balloting,

Amelia Earhart took off today on another lap in her flight around the world, heading presumably for Lae, New Guinea. She lifted her plane into the air at 6:49 A. M. [5:19 P. M. Monday, New York time] without formally announcing her destination. She had said earlier, however, that Lae was her next goal.
An Air France passenger liner was machine-gunned today by a Spanish Government plane a few miles south of Alicante. No one was injured.

Paragraph 19, Special Orders 144, dated June 23, 1937, relating to Second Lieutenant Pablo Gonzalez, Inf.-Res., is revolted. Second Lieutenant Pablo Gonzalez, Inf.Res., P. O. Box 4, Station 1, New York, N. Y., 77th Division, is ordered to active duty for six months, effective June 28, at Camp Dix, N. J., for assignment and duty with CCC Co. 3212, Camp SCS-3, in connection with CCC activities. Lieutenant Gonzalez will rank from June 14, 1937.

Dr. James Rowland Angell, retiring president of Yale University, who has accepted a position as educational counselor of the National Broadcasting Company, will receive a salary of $25,000 a year, L. R. Lohr, president of the N. B. C. announced yesterday.

The marriage of Miss Laura Werner, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hymen Werner of 20 East Seventysixth Street, to Leon Wallerstein Jr., son of Leon Wallerstein of Richmond, Va., and the late Mrs. Wallerstein, took place yesterday afternoon in the Gold Room of Sherry's.

Gilbert J. Easton of South Orange, N. J., was in Miami tonight without the ring finger on his right hand, but he did not mind so much, because he lost it today near Bimini bringing to gaff a 608-pound blue marlin, a near-record catch for this type of sea fighter.

Miss Phyllis A. De Guard of Jackson Heights, Queens, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Anthony De Guard, was married to Rudolph Bensch of this city, son of Mr. and Mrs. Wilhelm Bensch of Stuttgart, Germany,

Continuing with slightly more emphasis the upward trend of interest rates in recent weeks on 273-day Treasury bills, the average annual rate on the $50,000,000 issue sold today was 0.619 per cent on a bank discount basis, compared to 0.578 per cent on the issue sold a week ago. The issue two weeks ago brought a rate of 0.572.

Determination of the validity of Puerto Rico's $6 weekly minimum wage law for women, which the needle trades are testing, may take weeks. Judges Berga, De Jesus and Llauger will continue the hearing tomorrow.

Originally intended to last only through the Winter of 1931, the State Temporary Emergency Relief Administration will go out of existence tomorrow after having disbursed $738,930,000, or thirtyseven times the amount first allotted it by the Legislature.
A suit to recover $15,984 from the National Conference on Legalizing Lotteries, Inc., headed by Mrs. Oliver W. Harriman, was filed in Supreme Court yesterday by the Contest Service Corporation.

A corner apartment house on upper Broadway, several Harlem properties and West Side residences were included in the Manhattan realty transactions reported yesterday. The details of deals of Seventh and Amsterdam Avenues also were disclosed.
The appearance of two new islands in Japan's Kurile archipelago as the result of violent submarine eruptions was reported today in a wireless message from a Japanese fishing boat in those waters.

Displaying a far keener interest in the event than he did when he rode in high command three years ago, Bill Terry, manager of the Giants, yesterday announced his selections for the National League team which he will lead against the American League in the all-star game in Washington on July 7.

William Weinstein, 49 years old, of 1,108 Grand Avenue, the Bronx, who in ten years defrauded the New York Life Insurance Company of $60,000 on a disability policy by simulating a form of paralysis known as Parkinson's disease, was freed on a suspended sentence in General Sessions yesterday. Judge Wallace at the same time placed him on probation for five years.
A hearing has been called by the Securities and Exchange Commission for July 7 to determine whether the Class A and Class B no-par common stock of the Rainbow Luminous Products, Inc.,

The new Radio Corporation of America sign, the loftiest in the world, 900 feet above Rockefeller Plaza, was lighted last night by Grover Whalen, president of the New York World's Fair. Its huge letters, twenty-four feet tall, could be seen for miles around Radio City.

Miss Phyllis Charbneau of the Barbizon-Plaza, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jules Charbneau of Seattle, Wash., was married to Keith Torrey Middleton, also of New York, yesterday morning in the Church of the Transfiguration by the Rev. Harold F. Lemoine.

Back in the friendly environs of the Polo Grounds after a disastrous tour of the heat-scorched West, the Giants will attempt to regain lost ground in the spirited National League pennant race during a three-game series with the seventhplace Phillies opening today.
As its first production for the Summer season, the Berkshire Playhouse offered Helen Ford in "Mariette," which opened among the mountain laurel and rain clouds this evening.

Sales of hardware retailers in May exceeded those of May, 1936, by 10 per cent, in terms of dollar volume, according to the National Retail Hardware Association. The physical volume was about the same.
Classday exercises of Phillips Exeter Academy were held here today as the final event before the commencement program tomorrow, marking the school's 156th anniversary.

Residential properties formed the bulk of the demand in New Jersey realty transactions announced by brokers yesterday. The three-story brick dwelling at 118 Bloomfield Street, Hoboken, has been sold by William F. Fraser to Solomon Reinheimer, who will operate the building as a rooming house.

The Rev. Joseph P. Desmedt, chancellor of Xavier University for the last seventeen years, died today at Good Samaritan Hospital after a long illness. He was 77 years old. Father Desmedt came to Cincinnati in 1910 to serve as assistant pastor of Xavier Church.

Success once more crowned the efforts of Samuel Reshevsky of New York, chess champion of the United States, in the international masters tournament at the Kurhaus today, when the eleventh round was contested.

Without calling Postmaster General Farley as a witness, the Senate Committee on Postoffices and Post Roads today ended its investigation of the Postoffice Department's refusal to deliver parcel post food packages to non-striking employes of Republic Steel Corporation atNiles and Warren, Ohio.

President and Mrs. Roosevelt will be members of a family luncheon party on Wednesday at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene du Pont near Greenville, Del., preceding the marriage of Miss Ethel du Pont to Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr., Mrs. Roosevelt said today.
The trials of Protestant pastors before emergency courts will start this week. They will be tried separately on charges of deliberately disobeying the Interior Minister's ordinances.

The Independent Grocers Alliance of America has set a goal of a $10,000 volume of business monthly for each of the 10,000 affiliated stores of the organization, J. Frank Grimes, president, said today to delegates to the annual convention here.

Fluctuations on the Cotton Exchange here had a 15-point range yesterday and prices ended unchanged to 8 points lower than Saturday, the latter in the July. Trading, although limited, reflected 3 the absence of contracts.

Several large steel mills are on vacation schedules this week, the arrangements being that about onehalf of the force takes its vacation at one time and the mills operate on a sharply reduced basis until all have had their rest. It so happens that this coincides with the resumption of work at several mills that were strike-bound, or the operating rate would have fallen much lower than the 75 per cent shown.

President Roosevelt returned from the Jefferson Islands Club outing early this morning and started two busy days in preparation for leaving Wednesday to attend his son's wedding and then go on to Hyde Park.

Edwin L. Lobdell Co., dealers in investment securities here for almost half a century, announced today their withdrawal from the securities business. A joint statement by Charles W. Lobdell, son of the late founder, and Harold Pynchon, a partner, said conditions made continuation undesirable.

The shipping industry faces ruin at the hands of labor leaders and can be saved only by regulation of the labor groups to protect shipping operators in the performance of contracts and keep ships moving, according to a statement issued yesterday by the Maritime Association.

On the eve of the meeting of the International Non-Intervention Committee, at which the crisis brought about by the withdrawal of Italy and Germany from the naval control off Spain will be discussed, the problem does not appear to Rome to be any nearer a solution.

The first American Federation of Labor strike in the WPA Federal Theatre Project became a virtual certainty yesterday when three powerful theatrical unions empowered their executive committees to take strike action if other methods of halting a 30 per cent cut in project personnel proved ineffective.

Movements of livestock on the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts, 16,000, including 6,500 direct. Uneven, good and choice hogs 180 lb., down fully steady; others weak to 10c lower than Friday's average;

Smashing victories were turned in today by Middlesex and Derbyshire in English first-class cricket matches concluded a day ahead of schedule. Middlesex vanquished Kent by an Innings and 37 runs, while the champion county turned back Gloucestershire by an innings and 133.

Unless some one whisks a show into town ahead of him, A. H. Woods will have the honor of launching next season's first Broadway play; for it is learned that he has roped off the evening of Aug. 28, at the Forty-eighth Street Theatre, for the debut of "Rhyme Without Reason," James Gow's and Edmund North's play.

Mayor Henry S. Wheeler today appointed Colonel Frederick H. Allen as chairman of the local committee to arrange for exercises to be held here on Sept. 17 in observance of the 150th anniversary of the United States Constitution.

The marriage of Claire Bernice Burley, daughter of Mrs. George L. Burley of Toronto and the late Mr. Burley, to Nathan J. Stern of New York took place today at the Chelsea Registry office. Laurence Steinhard, former United States Minister to Sweden, was a witness at the ceremony.

The national resources of coal, oil and gas, without which our highly mechanized civilization could not survive, are dwindling so rapidly that industry may begin to feel "the cramping hand" of a shortage of some fuels within a decade or two, Dr. Arno C. Fieldner, chief of the technologic branch of the United States Bureau of Mines, warned yesterday.

Twenty-one appointments and promotions on the scientific staff of the Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research were announced yesterday by the board of scientific directors of the institute, to take effect on or after July 1.

The "purge" now going on in high places in Soviet Russia, Ambassador Alexander A. Troyanovsky explained today by implication rather than direct statement, is due to the government's will to protect the liberties of the people and to foster their creative spirit.

West End Ave, n w cor 79th St, 102.2x100; Excelsior Savings Bank to 405 West End Ave, Inc, 36 W. 44th St, care of William C. Crane ($431). 118th St, 12 W, 18x101; trustees will of Mary E Fitts to Millicent Realty Corp, 213 W. 139th St, care of Lucile E. Chance; consideration, $6,000.

A charge that CCC authorities "permit ex-convicts to mix with youngsters of clean records" was made yesterday by County Judge Franklin Taylor in Prooklyn while sentencing two young men on charges of unlawful entry.

Edward J. Neary of Westbury, L. I., Assistant District Attorney of Nassau County, was nominated to succeed Martin W. Littleton at a meeting here tonight of the Republican Nassau County Executive Committee in the County Court House. Mr. Neary is a former State commander of the American Legion.

The Pennsylvania Company for Insurances on Lives and Granting Annuities made application today to Federal Judge John P. Nields for a restraining order against the Seaford Power and Light Company to keep it from exercising its franchise for the construction and operation of a power plant in Seaford.

Stockholders of the Northern Oklahoma Gas Company have been called to act on July 9 on an increase in number of common shares from 70,000 to 210,000 to make possible a three-for-one split-up of the present shares. The conversion right of preferred shares is to be increased proportionately if the change is approved.

CHIEF OF LIBRARY SERVICE DIVISION, $5,600 a year; SPECIALIST IN PUBLIC LIBRARIES, $3,800 a year; SPECIALIST IN SCHOOL LIBRARIES, $3,800 a year; Office of Education, Department of the Interior. Applications must be on file not later than the following dates: (a) July 26, 1937, if received from States other than those named in (b) below; (b) July 29, 1937, if received from the following States: Arizona, California, Colorado, Idaho, Montana, Nevada, New Mexico, Oregon,

On the basis of such evidence as has been presented thus far, it is neither fair nor wise to charge, as Mr. MURRAY of the C. I. O. did yesterday, that "Ohio National Guardsmen are being " used as company police in an effort to " break the steel strike."
Mrs. Jennie Hirschmann, prominent for years in Jewish religious and philanthropic activities, died here last night at her home, 1,708 Eutaw Place, at the age of 65.

Miss Margaret Davison, daughter of C. Herbert Davison of Edgerstoune, and the late Mrs. Davison, was married this morning to John Paul Chubet 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard A. Chubet of Boston. The Rev. Walter S. Davison of Auburn Theological Seminary, uncle of the bride, performed the ceremony, which took place at the home of her father.

Western marksmen captured the top places in a field of forty-two contenders in the national telegraphic skeet championship, according to results announced today at the headquarters of the Great Eastern skeet championship meet, which concluded a three-day stand yesterday at Lordship.

Published at a moment when union labor has forced the closing of steel mills throughout the country, throwing out of work thousands of laborers who desire to continue working, Wednesday's report of the Labor Department on factory employment in May comes with a touch of irony.

ARLOTTA, CATHERINE L.(April 3, 1935). Gross assets, $15,600; net, $10,083. To husband, Gaetano Arlotta, one-third of residuary estate; daughter, Nicolina A. Filasto, two-thirds of residuary estate. Chief asset, real estate, $15,600. I. Irving Colnick, attorney, 16 Court St.
T. O. M. Sopwith, British challenger for the America's Cup, and Mrs. Sopwith will leave tomorrow for Block Island aboard Mr. Sopwith's yacht Philante.

No successor to Colonel C. O. Sherrill as president of the American Retail Federation was named yesterday at the meeting of the executive committee in the Hotel Pennsylvania. Colonel Sherrill's resignation was accepted with regret and best wishes extended for his success as City Manager of Cincinnati.

A group of residents of the upper West Side, under the leadership of Rabbi Herbert S. Goldstein, has purchased St. Andrew's Methodist Episcopal Church, 120 West Seventy-sixth Street. and will convert it into a synagogue and community house in September, it was revealed yesterday.

A six-year search for a man who saved large electricity consumers thousands of dollars by turning their meters back resulted yesterday in the holding of Walter Laurence Jr., 31 years old, of 245 West Seventy-fourth Street, in $5,000 bail in Yorkville Court.

The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that it had issued an order declaring effective a posteffective amendment filed by Bainbridge Colby, Ernest Minor Patterson and Lindsay Rogers as the committee representing 5 per cent secured debentures of the Kreuger Toll Company, now in bankruptcy. Accordingly, the commission made known that further proceedings against the registrant would be discontinued.
The Permanent Court of International Justice gave its judgment today in a dispute between the Netherlands and Belgium concerning the waters of the River Meuse.

August T. Gausebeck of this city has been named Bolivian Consul for the State of New Jersey, according to an official notification sent to Mayor Charles H. Martens here by Guillermo Alborta, consul general for Bolivia.
Premier Camille Chautemps will go before Parliament this afternoon asking for what the Senate refused last week to Leon Blum-full powers to deal with the financial situation.

No I change in the United States silver agreement with China will follow the visit to this city of Dr. H. H. Kung, Chinese Finance Minister, Secretary Morgenthau indicated at his press conference this afternoon.

Wisconsin, where people consume an average of 23.2 gallons of beer annually, leads all other States of the Union in per capital beer drinking, a statistical analysis of beer sales in the country since repeal disclosed yesterday. The analysis,

BRADY, JOHN (June 3). Estate, $12,000. To Bridget Brady, widow, executrix, 15 W. 94th St. CONLON, MARY (April 17). Estate, less than $5,000. To Mary Walsh, niece, and Redmond Walsh, nephew. 229 E. 28th St., residue in trust; John J. Conlon, Cloonvullana, Elphin P. O., County Roscommon, Ireland; Bridget Kearns, Crummilon, Elphin P. O., Roscommon, Ireland, and Margaret Walsch, executrix, 229 E. 28th St.. $1.000 each.

America's college golfers today found it simpler to decipher ancient Latin orations and mathematical puzzlers than to figure out Oakmont's stiff par that hid behind greens which roll and dip and furrowed sand beaches that fringe the fairways.

Early settlement of negotiations between the Philippine Government and a committee for holders of 4 per cent bonds of the Philippine Railway, looking toward payment of the bonds, was forecast yesterday by the committee, of which William P. Buckner is chairman.

The War Department released the following orders today dated June 26: COLONELS Davis, J. R., F. A., National Guard Bureau, 7 days' leave, June 29. with permission to visit foreign countries. Miller, E. S., Inf., 4 months and 3 days' leave. June 28. Peek, E. D., Engrs., 1 month and three days' leave, July 1. Miller, E. S., Inf., Hawaiian Dept., to retirement. Oct. 31. on own application.
In a setting calculated to inspire young America, the section between the Washington Monument and westward to the Lincoln Memorial, about 15,000 Boy Scouts were encamped tonight. Tomorrow,
"Just for a handful of silver he left us, Just for a ribbon to stick in his coat." So wrote the indignant ROBERT BROWNING about his

Larry Kelley, Yale's famous AllAmerica end and all-around athlete, has agreed to play with a team of Eastern college all-stars against the New York Football Giants at the Polo Grounds, Sept. 8, for the benefit of The New York Herald Tribune's fresh air fund for children.

German official quarters professed tonight to be without an inkling as to how Great Britain and France envisage the resumption of the international Spanish control after the GermanItalian secession from the fourpower consultations.

The newly created New York State Labor Board announced yesterday that it hoped to assume jurisdiction over the most urgent cases about July 20. The board outlined its plans in a statement issued after a conference with Governor Lehman at his residence, 820 Park Avenue.

Mrs. Suzanne Carroll Hill of Baltimore was married to former Senator Hiram Bingham of Connecticut at noon today at Broadalbin House, home of Mrs. Robert W. Chambers, widow of the novelist. Among the guests were persons well known in political and social circles.

A new anthracite boiler, designed for use in heating medium-sized homes by steam, vapor or hot water, and developed in the laboratories of Anthracite Industries, Inc., is being manufactured by the Burnham Boiler Corporation of Irvington, N. Y., and the Fitzgibbons Boiler Company of New York, Anthracite Industries, Inc., cooperative promotional agency for the industry, announced yesterday.

The white and straw colors of Cleveland Putnam, young Arizona sportsman, occupied three positions of prominence on today's program of the Delaware Steeplechase and Race Association. Running over a muddy, holding track, Reddy Teddy, Nautch and White Sand gave owner Putnam a turf triple for the afternoon.

The dogs specially trained to guide blind men and women will be permitted, under a bill passed by the Senate today, to accompany their masters on all American railroad trains, either in day coaches or in Pullmans.
Despite a teeming rainstorm that lasted almost the duration of play, 108 metropolitan women golfers started the annual two-day Scotch foursome event at the Century Country Club this morning.

The Department of Commerce made public today an analysis showing that the trade of the Unitd States with Southern North America-Mexico, Cuba, Central America and the West Indies-had increased during the first four months this year considerably abovee that in the corresponding period of 1936.

Edward J. Ford, formerly a partner in the firm of word Smith in Newark, makers and distributors of Pease pianos for forty years, died yesterday in Orange Memorial Hospital at the age of 65. The firm discontinued business last year.
Hotelkeepers throughout France posted notices tonight informing guests that all hotels, cafes and restaurants would close July 3 in protest against the forty-hour-week law.
Like the Engineer McAndrew of KIPLING'S "McAndrew's Hymn," WILLIAM MCANDREW, the teacher, could, without fear of what the judgment might be, exclaim at the end of the voyage of life:

Luis Munoz Marin, former Puerto Rican Senator, who recently was read out of the Liberal party by its president, Antonio R. Barcelo, for alleged attempts to wreck the organization through radical measures advocated at Washington, contended today that he had captured the party and had been elected its president.

Lawrence E. Sherwood Jr. and William Goldbeck, from Lawrence Farms, topped a small field in the amateur-pro tournament sponsored by the Westchester P. G. A. today at the Gedney Farm, their 35, 3267 being a stroke better than the best ball of three other pairs.

Net income of the Gamewell Company, signal equipment manufacturer, for the fiscal year ended on May 31, was $250,835, Vincent C. Stanley, president, stated in a letter sent yesterday to stockholders. The figures, which are subject to auditors' adjustments, are in contrast to a loss of $125,385 in the company's preceding year.

The foreign delegates to Goettingen University's bicentennial celebration heard Education Minister Bernhard Rust deliver today a denunciation of individual liberty that spared neither the sensibilities nor the convictions of those who came from democratic countries.

The business building at 8 Atlantic Avenue, Lynbrook, L. I., adjoining the W. T. Grant store, has been purchased by a client of Isidore Mates, lawyer, from the Firstone Realty Corporation, of which Dr. J. Alfred D'Onofrio is president.
Federal Judge William Clark today appointed Walter Kidde of Montclair, a consulting engineer, and Hudson J. Bordwell of Jersey City, former general manager of the road, trustees of the New York,

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are June 28, unless specified: At Naval Operating Base, Norfolk, Acushnet, June 26; Texas, June 27. At Chefoo, Alden, June 27; J. D. Edwards, June 25. At Guantanamo Bay, June 27, Badger, Decatur, Dickerson, Herbert, Leary, Tattnall, Tillman.

The black bass season, with certain exceptions, opens in this State on Thursday. Officials of the Conservation Department assert that their investigations reveal conditions have been favorable for natural spawning in the waters suited to bass. Then, too, the bass hatchery at South Otselic is adding to its production program each year and the State is widely distributing fry to streams, augmenting the natural propagation.

Fifty manufacturers of $4.75 dresses met yesterday at the offices of the Popular Price Dress Manufacturers Group and took under advisement the proposal of the National Association of Women's Apparel Chains for a change in the price line from $4.75 to $5.25.

A fingerprint was the only clue which Port Chester and New York State police had today in their investigation of a $50,000 jewel theft at the estate of Percy S. Straus, president of R. H. Macy Co., in Rye township, early yesterday.

Frederick Collamore Hitchcock, engineer and contractor, who built the Moffat Tunnel in Colorado, died yesterday of a heart attack at his apartment in the Midston House, 22 East Thirty-eighth Street. He was in his seventy-third year. He was head of Hitchcock Tinkler of 295 Park Avenue.

The marriage of Miss Edith McKnight, daughter of Mrs. C. Reinold Noyes of 53 East Sixty-sixth Street, and of Sumner T. McKnight of Minneapolis, to William H. Moore 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Moore of 825 Fifth Avenue and Hollow Hill Farm, Convent, N. J., took place yesterday afternoon in St. James Protestant Episcopal Church.

Samuel Hurwitz has sold for a client of the Chemical Bank Trust Co a first mortgage of $12,000 on the 3-story tenement at 636 Vermont St, Brooklyn, assessed at $16,000, and for Joseph Stynes a first mortgage of $6,000 on 79 Flatbush Ave Extension, Brooklyn, running through to 60 Duffield St.

Conferees considering the $1,500,000,000 Relief Bill for the fiscal year 1938 reached an agreement on differences between the House and Senate and worked late into the night to compile their report in time for both houses to act upon it tomorrow.

"Beyond Sing the Woods," by Trygye Gulbranssen, leads the Baker Taylor best seller list of fiction for the period May 14 to June 14. This list is made on actual count of sales by this firm of book wholesalers.

Miss Frances Olmsted and Miss Janet Smith, in 214 E 62d St, from Mrs. Constance Sloane; Edward Lagrom, in 440 E 52d St, from Gresham Realty Co; Potter, Hamilton Co, brokers. Dr. M. Wilson, in 1,160 Fifth Ave; Dr. S. Atkins, in 315 Central Park West; F. Ann Kutner, broker.
A small but impressive line of German warships that only a few days ago were cruising in the Mediterranean were sighted tonight going through the Straits of Dover homeward bound.

As far as the Bethlehem Steel Corporation is concerned, the steel strike here ended at 7 o'clock this morning, by which time the back-towork movement had progressed to such an extent that the management announced that the Cambria plant was operating on a normal basis.

The three-story brick residence at 902 East Ninth Street, Brooklyn, known as the "show" place of the Midwood section of Flatbush, has been sold by Mrs. Milton Jones to a New York manufacturer of textile fabrics whose name was not revealed. Gaston Koch acted as broker in the deal.

Illness following a heart attack resulted in the death last night of Mrs. A. H. Griswold of New York, wife of Colonel A. H. Griswold, executive vice president of the Postal Telegraph and Cable Corporation.
Charles P. Taft 2d, chairman of the Federal Steel Mediation Board, is expected to be in Washington tomorrow to see President Roosevelt and Secretary Perkins.

Mrs. Walter Gibb, who has returned from a trip around the world, is honorary chairman for the entertainment to aid the community chest, which will be given on Friday and Saturday evenings at the Cove Theatre.
Legislation to permit construction of flood walls, levees and drainage structures in the lower Ohio River Valley won approval of the House Flood Control Committee today.

Marshal Werner von Blomberg, German War Minister, arrived here today to return the visit of General William Roeder, Hungarian War Minister, to Berlin several months ago. He conferred with Cabinet Ministers today and will be received by Admiral Nicholas Horthy, the Regent, Wednesday.

Seven individuals, including Andrew W. Mellon, former Secretary of the Treasury, and two groups of trustees own or control 58 per cent of the 1,472,625 outstanding common shares of the Aluminum Company of America, according to a chart which Robert H. Jackson, Assistant United States Attorney General, showed yesterday to Federal Judge Vincent L. Leibell.
Thirty-seven sophomores of the Union County Junior College received diplomas this evening at the fourth annual commencement of the institution at the Abraham Clark High School.

The grist of news from Germany yesterday makes perplexing but highly suggestive reading. At their rally at Kassel the German war veterans cheered to the echo when two British officers made a fervid appeal for understanding between England and Germany.
Stocks. continued to sag and closed lower in slightly more active trading; turnover, 733,830 shares. United States Government and corporate bonds lower, other issues steady; transactions, $8,657,900.

A Senate economy wave receded rapidly today. Champions of reduced spending sat silent while the chamber, without debate, agreed to restore a $60,000,000 cut made last month in a $500,000,000 appropriation for the conservation service.

Twenty-nine of fifty-five defendants indicted last week on charges of conspiracy and smuggling diamonds valued at $13,000,000 into this port during the last six years pleaded not guilty yesterday and were held in bail ranging from $1,000 to $5,000 each when they were arraigned before Federal Judge John W. Clancy,

LONDON-The Non-Intervention Committee will meet today under stiff pressure to end the impasse over the patrol of Spain. Britain is expected to ask control of the Mediterranean coast, but Germany and Italy may ask that the task be given to Yugoslavia and Greece. Page 1.
Harry W. Marsh, First Deputy Commissioner of Public Welfare since 1934, was guest at a dinner given by 200 employes of the Department of Public Welfare at the Hotel Commodore last night. Mr.

Stanley Ogilvy's Star yacht Jay continued its threat to capture the fiveday racing series for the John Taylor Arms Trophy over the Noroton Yacht Club course, placing third in today's event, in which thirty-three competed.
