The sudden appearance of a 100-piece brass band composed of Scouts from Ohio, Kentucky and West Virginia sent all the camera fans at the Boy Scout Jamboree scurrying today to photograph the musicians framed against the spire of the Washington Monument.

Chief of Police Gillen announced tonight the "smashing of a dynamite ring" through the arrest and the confession of three C. I. O. strikers. The confessions, he said, solved a series of dynamitings in the vicinity of the Republic Steel Company mill here.

It was not clear today who had won the shoe strike which tied up factories here and at Auburn for ninety-six days. C. I. O. leaders who called the strike in March ended it when the NLRB ordered "consent" elections for collective bargaining and sent their members back to work.
The government's general headquarters reported tonight that 184 Insurgent war planes had been shot down in the eight months between Oct. 13 and June 14.

Francis B. Sayre, Assistant Secretary of State and Mrs. Elizabeth Graves were married here today. The bride is the daughter of Mrs. William Taylor Evans and the late Colonel Evans, U. S. A., and widow of Ralph Graves of the National Geographic Society.

Annual award of the M. Samuel Stern memorial prizes at the office of Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Board of Education, 9:30 A. M. Luncheon conference of the National Committee for Religion and Welfare Recovery, Lawyers Club, 115 Broadway, 12:30 P. M. Speakers: Justice William R. Bayes, Dr. Charles S. Macfarland, Alfred J. Talley, Alexander U. Zinke.

The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended June 23: An increase of $74,000,000 in loans to brokers and dealers in securities; a decrease of $182,000,

The yawl Valiant, owned by W. T. Aldrich, took the trophy in the Racing Class when she. crossed the finish line here at 5:48:28 tonight in the Eastern Yacht Club's annual race around Cape Cod from New London.

The Securities and Exchange Commission has approved applications by the Middlewest Corporation and its subsidiary, the Kentucky Utilities Company, for acquisition of certain securities to be issued by the Arkansas-Missouri Power Corporation in the course of the reorganization of the Arkansas-Missouri Power Company under Section 77B of the Federal Bankruptcy Act.

Continuing his testimony for the defense in a $20,000,000 stockholders' suit against present and former officials of the Long Island Lighting Company, Ellis L. Phillips, president of the company, defended yesterday the actions of directors in acquiring the stock of the Kings County Lighting Company and in making appropriations for reserves.

Echoes of the labor warfare in this area penetrated the academic calm of half a dozen sessions of the National Education Convention today. Before a large and approving audience this afternoon, William J. Cameron of the Ford Motor Company accused teachers of giving students a "false view of industry" and told them that every advance in social justice was due not to labor leaders but to "altruistic industrialists."

President Roosevelt returned from the Jefferson Islands Club outing; signed the bill continuing the Civilian Conservation Corps until June 30, 1940; asked Congress for $350,000,000 to finance the CCC for the 1938 fiscal year;

A big collection of animals, snakes and birds arrived here from Africa yesterday, and with it the solution of how it grew from "an animal or two" to the largest shipment of animals to reach here from Africa at one time. The group arrived in Brooklyn in the afternoon, aboard the Atlantic of the American South Africa line.

May sales of reporting wholesale firms in this district averaged 15 per cent higher than in the corresponding period in 1936, a larger increase than in the previous month, according to the monthly review issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve agent here.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Margaret Lillian Scholle, daughter of Mrs. Clinton B. F. Brill of 333 East Sixty-eighth Street and of Hardinge Scholle, director of the Museum of the City of New York, to Lindley Bronson of Waterbury, Conn.

A spokesman for the C. I. O. affiliate, whose members have been conducting a sit-down strike in the plant of the American Smelting and Refining Company here since Wednesday, declared today that the strikers would not accede to the company's request that its property be evacuated.
Four soldiers attached to the East Surrey Regiment reached an altitude of 23,500 feet before having to abandon their effort to climb Mount Kamet, 25,413 feet high, in the Himalayas.

Mr. and Mrs. Francis L. Whitmarsh, Miss Anne Whitmarsh and Francis L. Whitmarsh Jr. will sail tomorrow on the Normandie to pass the Summer abroad. Major Gen. and Mrs. William Crozier have come from Washington to the St. Regis.

Frank W. Smith presented his resignation as president of the Brooklyn Edison Company, Inc., at a meeting of the directors yesterday, having reached the retirement age of seventy years on June 22. On March 17, at his request, he was not reelected president of the Consolidated Edison Company, a position which he had held since July 1. 1935.

Retail display advertising during the week ended June 19 approached within 1.2 per cent of equaling the record volume of the corresponding week of 1936, when soldier-bonus promotions were heavy, according to The Advertising Age figures.
The Garden City Golf Club, where Johnny Fischer captured the national amateur crown last year, was the scene of the twenty-second annual Father and Son Golf Association tournament today.

Jim Barnes, former British open champion, and Bob McCollom of Timber Point captured the honors in the professional-amateur bestball tournament of the Long Island Golf Association today with a score of 32, 35-67. The tourney,

The threat of a strike on the B. M. T. lines by the Transport Workers Union, a C. I. O. affiliate, was averted temporarily yesterday when the company, at a conference at City Hall, consented to holding an election to determine a collective bargaining agency within the next two weeks.

The United States Court of Appeals held today that 100,000 cotton producers were entitled to more than $3,500,000 in refunds for cotton tax exemption certificates they bought under the repealed Bankhead Act.

Deaths by motor vehicle accidents increased last week and week-end despite a decline in the number of accidents, figures made public yesterday by First Deputy Police Commissioner Harold Fowler showed.

For the first time since the American Federation of Labor and the Committee for Industrial Oganization became rivals the National Labor Relations Board intervened today to order an election in the case of a company which had an exclusive t bargaining contract with one side, in this instance the A. F. of L.
HOLLYWOOD --Marla Shelton, Walter Wanger's discovery, who played a minor role in "52d Street," was cast today in the second lead in "Stand-in" in the ro1e of the star.

Returning from Easter Island, Chilean possession in the Southern Pacific, an official investigator declared this morning that the Chilean Government would commence a campaign to combat leprosy by modern methods. The disease is now killing many inhabitants.
A definite hope became manifest in some Congressional quarters today that President Roosevelt would soon define his labor policies publicly in light of the present strike situation,

The American Federation of Textile Operators announced today that resolutions passed at the annual convention favored the Wagner act, the administration Labor Bill, an $18 minimum wage and a thirty-hour work-week.

Seeking to prevent any decisions by the British Government that might jeopardize the future of Jewish development in Palestine, Dr. Chaim Weizmann, president of the Jewish agency for Palestine, and its chairman, David Ben Gurion, in a cable message from London urged yesterday that Dr. Stephen S. Wise and other leading American Zionists come to England.

Johnny Fischer of Cincinnati, national amateur golf champion, today matched the two rounds of Harold (Jug) McSpaden of Winchester, the defending titleholder, in the 72-hole Massachusetts open tourney and shared the half-way lead with the capable professional.

Dr. Benjamin E. Helprin of 1,026 St. John's Place, Brooklyn, died yesterday in the Jewish Hospital, Brooklyn, at the age of 57. A native of Wheeling, W. Va., he was graduated from Bethany College in 1899, from the Long Island College Hospital in 1903.

The Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., has filed a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering 92,134 shares of $5 cumulative preferred stock, no par value, to be exchanged for preferred stock of the New York Steam Corporation, a subsidiary.
President Roosevelt sent to the Senate today the nomination of Hugh R. Wilson, a career diplomat who is now Minister to Switzerland, to be Assistant Secretary of State.

More than 100 members of the Workers Alliance, the labor organization that staged a "sit-in" for nearly a week in the Assembly last year, started a new demonstration tonight when the Legislature postDoned action on relief funds.

The formation of the Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation "for the promotion and encouragement of art and education in art and the enlightenment of the public especially in the field of art," was announced here yesterday at the offices of Stanchfield Levy, attorneys, 1 South William Street.

Shorts in the French franc who must make delivery today of the exchange they had previously sold were squeezed yesterday as the arrival of the new Finance Minister, Georges Bonnet, in France, failed to bring the immediate devaluation of the franc that rumor had predicted. While spot francs,
Mr. and Mrs. James N. Andrews of Somerset, Va., and Aiken, S. C., announced here today the engagement of their daughter, Miss Anne Ridgeley Andrews, to John Sharpless McIntyre, son of Mr. and Mrs.

The fly in the amber for many an amateur gardener hereabouts belongs to the vegetable rather than the animal kingdom. Poison ivy, that ubiquitous member of the sumac genus, technically known as Rhus toxicodendron or radicans, creeps in on any woodland border where more welcome growths-even the charming Virginia Creeper, which, despite its five leaves, often is mistaken for the three-leaved poison ivy-are temperamental and transitory.
President Roosevelt sent to the Senate today the nomination of Hugh R. Wilson, a career diplomat who is now Minister to Switzerland, to be Assistant Secretary of State.

J. Reuben Clark Jr., president of the Foreign Bondholders Protective Council, Inc., came here today by airplane from New York to confer briefly with officials of the State Department. He made no comment on his visit.

Mr. and Mrs. Ivor B. Clark celebrated the twenty-first anniversary of their marriage by giving a dinner last night in the Pierre Roof. Their guests included Mr. and Mrs. William L. DeBost, Mr. and Mrs.

The pace of reordering of Summer merchandise slowed up in the wholesale apparel and accessory markets here yesterday. Some further fill-in business from retailers is anticipated, but the consensus is that the season has passed its peak.
Customs Inspector Arthur Hansen, looking over the luggage of passengers debarking from the Normandie yesterday at Pier 88, North River, saw three suitcases that aroused his suspicion.

Miss Mary Lowe Gaddis, daughter of Mrs. Avery Gaddis of Milton, Mass., and Houston Lowe Gaddis of Marshall, Va., became the bride of Kermit Roosevelt Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Kermit Roosevelt of Oyster Bay, L. I., here today.

Enlargement of Britain's exchange equalization fund from [pound]350,000,000 to [pound]550,000,000 was approved by the House of Commons tonight. In the debate on the resolution authorizing the increase Sir John Simon, Chancellor of the Exchequer, lifted for the first time part of the veil that has hidden the fund's resources.

Nonchalant and at time apparently bored, Robert Irwin moved yesterday through the legal processes bringing him closer to punishment for the three Gedeon murders which he admits he committed last Easter Day.

Mrs. Louise Thaden, winner of the Bendix Trophy for transcontinental air racing in 1936, left North Beach Airport yesterday at 10:30 A. M. to invite the Governors of seven States to attend the Vanderbilt Cup automobile race on Saturday.
Robert Victor Anderson, formerly with the Semet-Solvay Company, has joined the field staff of Anthracite Industries, Inc.
The debts of 57,943 farmers have been reduced by $46,442,919 in the Senator twenty-one months ending May 21, the Resettlement Administration stated today.

The Mead Corporation earned a net income of $606,854 for the twelve weeks to June 12, after deductions for expenses, depreciation, Interest and taxes on funded debt, Federal and State income taxes, minority interest and other charges.
Nine lay brothers of the Order of Alexis were sentenced to terms of from six to sixteen months in prison today on immorality charges at Bonn, the official German news agency reported.

The New York Curb Exchange will admit to dealings at the start of wtrading today Cosden Petroleum Corporation $1 par common stock and $50 par 5 per cent convertible preferred stock, simultaneously suspending dealings in common and preferred stocks of the Cosden Oil Corporation.

The M. Samuel Stern Memorial prizes of $200 each, awarded annually to physically handicapped or underprivileged public school pupils, were presented by Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, to a boy and two girls yesterday in Dr. Campbell's office.
THE UNHOLY CITY, by Charles G. Finney. (Vanguard, $2.) A new novel by the author of "The Circus of Dr. Lao."
Supreme Court Justice Gilbert V. Schenck ruled today that William J. Sheils, surrogate of Westchester County by appointment of the Governor, had the right to determine the title to his office.

Because the Communist party failed to poll 50,000 votes in the 1936 Gubernatorial election its designees will not appear on the ballots on Sept. 16, Justice Gilbert V. Schenck of the Supreme Court ruled today in an opinion.

The scheduled sale today of a new issue of $1,160,000 of bonds of Jersey City, N. J., consisting of $980,000 of hospital bonds and $180,000 of general-improvement bonds, has been indefinitely postponed, Raymond M. Greer, City Controller, announced late yesterday. Bidders had been asked to name a rate of interest not exceeding 4 per cent.
William Toland Bryans, vice-president of Best Company, Fifth Avenue and Thirty-fifth Street, New York, died at his home here today of tuberculosis after a long illness.

Miss Elizabeth Pryce Yallalee, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles H. P. Yallalee of this place, was married this afternoon to Bayard Dominick 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gayer G. Dominick of New Canaan, Conn., and New York.

Morgan, Corpus Christi, Texas, oil man, today bought the racing stable of the Three D's Stock Farm from Paul and Guy Waggoner of Fort Worth. Among the horses that are campaigning at Rockingham Park was Heelfly, 3-year-old that finish sixth in ,this year's Kentucky Derby.

A knotty problem of whether a man ought to be allowed to sit on his own private chair on the beach at Coney Island was threshed out in court there yesterday, with the answer appearing to be in the negative.
Dorsey St, 2,424, dwelling, 25x100; Home Owners Loan Corp against Caroline De Biase; due, $6,365; taxes, , $443; TO plaintiff for $500.

Colonel E. D. Peek, War Department engineer for the North Atlantic division, has submitted an unfavorable report to the Board of Engineers for Rivers and Harbors on the proposal to improve a deep waterway linking St. Francis on

Total vegetable packs will be smaller than had been expected at the beginning of the season, with the result that, while current selling by canners is still slack, they are disposing of the remnants of the 1936 packs and show no disposition to hurry in sales of new packs, according to a study by the American Institute Food Distribution made public yesterday.

The Chamber of Deputies voted, 380 to 228, to grant full power over fiscal affairs to the Chautemps Cabinet. The measure now goes to the Senate. The government decided to unpeg the franc from gold and let it find its own level. Page 1.

The greatest display of speed by a racing automobile in this country was put on at Roosevelt Raceway today when the German stars brought out their rear-motor Auto Union cars and fairly burned up the course over which the second Vanderbilt Cup contest will be run Saturday .

Speyer Co., American fiscal agents for the Kingdom of Hungary 71/2, per cent State loan of 1924, stated yesterday in connection with the terms of the new offer of the Hungarian Government of future service of this loan at the rate of 4 1/2 per cent annually in dollars that this represents an increase over the rate of 3 3/4 per cent paid since February, 1934, down to date.

President Roosevelt was asked at his press conference today whether he would accept a nomination for a third term. His first reply was that the weather was hot, and a second later he told the inquirer to put on his dunce cap, go into the corner and turn his back on the rest of the boys.

William Craig, who was seriously wounded in France in the World War while fighting as a private in Company E, 108th Infantry, Twenty-seventh Division, died yesterday in the Veterans Hospital, Kingsbridge Road, the Bronx, at the age of 43.

Seventeen maritime labor leaders of Atlantic and Pacific ports were invited yesterday by John L. Lewis to a conference to be held in Washington on July 7 to discuss plans for the complete organization of the shipping industry and "work out policies for the cooperation of all interested groups with the Committee for Industrial Organization."
Poor base running by the Reds gave Pittsburgh a 2-to-1 victory in the first game of a double-header today and the Pirates enjoyed a batters' feast to win the second game also, 13-6.
Luncheon, Progressive City Committee, the Town Hall Club, 12:30 P. M. Speakers: Dr. John Bauer, Mildred Richardson Kelly, James I. Metcalf, George Slaff, Percival Robert Moses, Maurice P. Davidson.

Three members of a C. I. O. affiliate were arrested on charges of disorderly conduct during the rush hour last night while picketing newsstands in and near the Rialto Building, Seventh Avenue and Forty-second Street. Two of the men were arrested for picketing in an arcade, and disposition of their cases is expected to determine whether an arcade to stores is private property and closed to pickets.

Two faculty members of the Graduate School of Banking at Rutgers University assumed the roles of John L. Lewis and Tom M. Girdler today to explain to the 600 banking students attending the school the divergence of views between the C. I. O. leader and the president of the Republic Steel Corportion and to pave the way for a summary in which the necessity for a "middle road" attitude was outlined.

The golf enthusiasts of the New York Stock Exchange held their forty-first annual tournament at the Fresh Meadow Golf Club in Flushing yesterday, with 175 players taking part in the handicap event which started at 8:30 in the morning and was not completed until 8:30 at night.
President Roosevelt agreed today to participate in a radio broadcast opening the annual drive of the Community Mobilization for Human Needs.

The French Government served formal notice on the Treasury today that It might be obliged, by the pressure of internal events, to withdraw from the tripartite monetary agreement negotiated last Sept. 25 between the United States, France and Great Britain.

R. Henry Norweb, United States Minister to Bolivia, Mrs. Norweb and members of their family are at the Biltmore before going to Cleveland. Mr. and Mrs. C. van CourtlandMoon have returned to the WaldorfAstoria after a visit with Mr. and Mrs. Herbert L. Satterlee at Dover House, Greenwich. They will leave later this week for Murray Bay, P. Q., and will sail for England late in July.
Admirers of Mickey Cochrane, manager of the Detroit Tigers, who has been in hospitals since being hit by a
Harold (Jug) McSpaden of Winchester today retained his .Massachusetts open championship by totaling 288 for 72 holes of title play on Oyster Harbors' seaside course.

Under the sponsorship of the Swanhurst School of Arts of Newport the new amphitheatre garden at Gray Craig, home of Mr. and Mrs. Michael M. van Beuren, will be formally opened on the afternoon of July 23 with a Russian ballet festival.

Dr. Daniel Brophy, assistant professor in the Public Speaking Department of City College, was named to succeed Arthur Frank Payne as head of the college's personnel bureau last night at a meeting of the Board of Higher Education in the college's School of Business and Civic Administration,
Miss Jane Tyler Cave, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward A. Cave of this place, was married here this morning to Lyndon Arnold Smith Wilson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ashley Fly Wilson of Montclair, N. J.,

President Roosevelt expressed regret in a message to the Senate today that the Congress, when it passed the Independent Offices Appropriation Bill, had included a provision requiring the Presidential appointment, and confirmation by the Senate, of all Social Security Board attorneys and experts whose annual salaries are $5,000 or more.
On Police Surgeon's certificate: To take effect 12 midnight, June 30: PATROLMAN--Peter Dove, Motorcycle Precinct 1, at $2,250 per annum. Appointed Jan. 5, 1921.

The Treasury Department announced today that bids would be received on an offering of $50,000,000 of discount bills of 273 days' maturity, at the Federal Reserve Banks or their branches, until 2 P. M. Eastern Standard Time on July 2. The bills will be dated July 7 and will mature on April 6, 1938.

Roosevelt said the general opinion of the country on the strike situation was: "A plague on both your houses." Page 1. Johnstown Mayor called on Roosevelt to remove C. I. O. forces, after dynamite smashed water mains and closed Cambria steel plant. Page 1.

The committee on stock list of the New York Stock Exchange has authorized the listing, on official notice of issuance and pursuant to the terms of an option agreement, 10,000 additional common shares of the Certain-teed Products Corporation of $1 par value.

A group of nine houses which several years ago were converted into garden apartments, at 315-21 West Fifty-seventh Street, and 316-24 West Fifty-eighth Street, have been sold by the 315 West Fifty-seventh Street Corporation to the Scherman Development Corporation, Isaac Scherman, president.
Samuel Eugene Kuen, an attorney long active here in title insurance work, died at his home in Cynwyd last night. His age was 72.

A capsule of radium weighing less than an ounce can give added safety and efficiency to battleships and bridges weighing thousands of tons by revealing hidden defects in steel construction, E. V. Lange, physicist of the Radium Chemical Company, told members of the American Socity for Testing Materials yesterday.

Statistics tending to show that the use of electricity in the country had increased proportionately with a decline in rates were submitted today by David E. Lilienthal, a director of the Tennessee Valley Authority, to a Senate sub-committee holding hearings on the Norris bill to divide the country into seven regional conservation districts for the correlated development of navigation, flood control and power.

The five Democratic county leaders in New York City have reached an agreement on Senator Robert F. Wagner as the Mayoralty candidate, if he will consent to run, but have split on the nomination for Controller.
Sir Percy Bates, chairman of the Cunard White Star Line, arrived yesterday on the Aquitania on his way to Canada for three weeks of fishing. He was accompanied by Lady Bates.

Having completed a half century of service in the Department of Justice, John Van Buren Merritt, chief clerk of the United States Attorney's office, took time out yesterday afternoon to receive tributes from several hundred government employes and friends. He also received a gold watch and chain, a golden key and a rise in salary.
Although not within several miles of the Polo Grounds yesterday, they had Colonel Bill Terry nearly out as well as down..

The marriage of Miss Louise Townsend, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Edward Townsend, to Elmer Dean Coulter of this city took place yesterday afternoon at the home of the bride's brother and sister-in-law, Mr. and Mrs. Edward Perry Towsend, 580 Park Avenue. The Rev. Dr. W. Russell Bowie, rector of Grace Church, performed the ceremony.
Contracts for approximately 5,000,000 yards of cotton cloth for the army were awarded at the Quartermaster Depot here today under Invitation 364.

Asserting that the policy of price maintenance on some books and not on others has "no justification in sound business methods or in the spirit of fair trade," the D. Appleton-Century Company, Inc., yesterday announced that it has placed all of the regular trade books it has published or will publish in the future "under the price protection of the Feld-Crawford Fair Trade Act" in this State.

Frank A. Vanderlip, former Assistant Secretary of the Treasury, who was president of the National City Bank from 1909 to 1919, died yesterday afternoon in New York Hospital, where he had been a patient for the last two weeks. He was 72 years old.
Patrick Gillen, 45 years old, of 307 East Sixtieth Street, was freed yesterday of a charge of homicide by Magistrate Frank Giorgio in Felony Court, Ridgewood, Queens.
President Roosevelt's steel peace board disbanded today after its mediation efforts failed, but Secretary Perkins said the Federal Government was keeping an eye on the strike.

The Railroad Credit Corporation applied to the Interstate Commerce Commission today for permission to intervene in the reorganization proceedings of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad and the Chicago,

The White Sox increased their margin in the tussle for second place in the American League to two full games today by whipping the Tigers, 3 to 2, behind Monty Stratton's brilliant three-hit pitching. Detroit dropped to fourth place, back of Boston.
Helen Lowell, veteran character actress, was found dead in her hotel room today. She came here to appear in films after having played in twentynine Broadway shows.

Mrs. Mary Buckner Royall of Fieldston Old House, Riverdale, this city, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas A. Buckner of Riverdale, was married to Loring Washburn of Greenwich yesterday afternoon at the York Club, 4 East Sixtysecond Street.

Postal Inspector D. H. Stephens filed complaints today against three men charged with "obstructing and delaying" the mails during picketing at the plant of the Dilworth Porter division of the Republic Steel Corporation.
St Nichals yve, 1,090, 6-story apartment on irregular plot 113x123.7; Franklin Savings Ban;. against Menline -Realty Corp; due, $169,603; taxes , $4,945; to plaintiff for $140,000.

Miss Mary Cowham Senior, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Lawson Senior of 10 Gracie Square and Belleair, Fla., was married to Morton Fearey, son of Mr. and Mrs. Morton L. Fearey of Garden City, yesterday afternoon in the Church of the Heavenly Rest.
One of the largest parties of the "little season" on the North Shore took place tonight at the Piping Rock Club when Mr. and Mrs. Robert C. Winmill of Mill Neck and Mr. and Mrs. L. Martin Richmond

Indictments charging violations of the gambling laws against two officials of the Nassau Kennel Club, operators of the dog track at the Fairgrounds here, were handed up tonight by the Nassau County grand jury.
A record entry of 101 golfers, none of whom is under 50 years of age, teed off today in quest of the Westchester senior championship over the Westchester Hills course.

The City Industrial Relations Board, which passes out of existence as such tomorrow, will continue to function for a short time as an agent of the newly created State Labor Board to handle the referendum to be held for employes of the B. M. T. system, it was disclosed yesterday.

Supreme Court Justice Paul Bonynge of the second department died this morning of a cerebral hemorrhage, which he had suffered on June 20, at his home here, Ballintober Farm, which he had named for the farm in the North of Ireland where his father was born. He was 61 years old.

In her second trial in General Sessions in a month Mrs. Florence Majestic, 40 years old, who described herself as a minister of the Spiritualist Church of America at 1,477 Lexington Avenue, was convicted by a jury yesterday of defrauding a woman of $190 in a fake hospital investment scheme.

Representatives of the twenty-seven nations taking part in Spanish non-intervention agreed today at a meeting of the chairman's subcommittee of the Non-Intervention Committee to refer to their governments the Anglo-French proposal for filling the gap in the sea control scheme left by the Italo-German withdrawal from it.

New York City recorded its tribute to Lillian D. Wald in enduring form yesterday by dedicating to her a playground in the heart of the district served by the Henry Street Settlement, where she founded forty-four years ago the first visiting nurse service in the country.

Engagement of $4,023,000 gold in England for shipment here was reported yesterday to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. This brought the total of gold obtained in England since the first of the year
Miss Grace Joy Adams, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Fairchild Adams of Newtonville, near here, and Henry Mallinckrodt, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Mallinckrodt Jr. of St. Louis,

Having completed his schedule through the eleventh round, Samuel Reshevsky of New York, the United States chess champion, leader in the international tournament at the Kurhaus, rested today, but his commanding position in the race was not challenged by any of his rivals.

Al Roth of the Bronx defeated Willie Davis of Mexico in the feature bout of 10 rounds at the Queensboro arena, Long Island City, last night. A crowd of 2,500 saw Roth establish a clean edge. His rival, however, waged a game fight. Roth weighed 136 3/4 pounds and Davis 132.

Mrs. Libby P. Marcus, wife of Bernard K. Marcus, president of the defunct Bank of United States, has agreed to pay $40,256 in full settlement of a $255,455 judgment obtained against her by the State Banking Department, it was disclosed yesterday. The agreement was approved by Supreme Court Justice Charles B. McLaughlin.

Harold Brown, 145 1/2, Chicago, gained the decision over Vincent Pimpinella, 148, Brooklyn, in the feature eight-round bout at the New York Coliseum in the Bronx last night before 5,000. Brown was the aggressor all the way.

The General Motors Corporation has given notice that it will not renew negotiations with the United Automobile be Workers of America until the union ca agrees to definite penalties for insttors of unauthorized strikes.
Arthur B. Yeates Jr. of Norfolk, Va., and William J. Tate Jr. of Baltimore were renamed captain and manager, respectively, of the Navy crew today.
Congratulations went to New Zealand's youthful cricketers today for waging a gallant fight against England in their opening test match at Lord's.
GEORGES BONNET, the new French Finance Minister, may be pardoned when he says that he will not stay in office unless Parliament grants him the "full powers" he asks.

BENEDICT, HARRIET S. (May 27). Estate, more than $10,000. To Charles E. Benedict, Tudor Hall Apts., Booth Ave. and Engle St., Englewood, N. J., $30,000 and specific jewelry; Harriet Case Phelps, Hyde Park, specific jewelry; Isabel H. Benedict, daughter, 260 W. 72d St., jewelry, personalty and one-half residue; Jeanette B. Case, daughter, 110 Livingston St., Poughkeepsie, N. Y., jewelry, personalty and one-half residue. William Wallace Sturges, brother, executor, 4 W. 43d St.

Miss Elsie Anna Marie Hoffmann, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Hoffmann of Scarsdale, was married here tonight to Edward Delano Bangs, son of Mrs. Edward Clayton Bangs of New London, Conn., and the late Mr. Bangs, in Trinity Lutheran Church.

Commonwealth Ave, 1,326 (15-3875); Newregime Corp to Isador Tankus, 222 W 83d St, installments, 6 per cent, $10,500. 175th St (11-2953), n e s, 240 ft s * of Prospect Ave, 150x194; Blo Associates, Inc, to Kingsboro Mortgage Corp. 26 Court St, Brooklyn. due Dec 28. 1937, 6 per cent, building loan: 3:O,.tu.

The six-story apartment house known as the Pelham Biltmore, overlooking the Pelham Country Club grounds Pelham Manor, one of the well-known multi-family buildings of Westchester County, has been sold by the Manhattan Savings Institution to David S. Meister.
By an important agreement concluded today which awaits only signing, the motorization of the entire Rumanian Army was entrusted to Czechoslovak armament concerns, headed by Skoda.

Traffic on the Illinois Central Railroad reflects a slackening in business generally, L. A. Downs, president, said yesterday. The company's revenues, which in the first five months of the year ran 6.7 per cent ahead of last year's levels, ran about even this month. Mr. Downs added that passenger traffic was making better comparative showing than freight, and that he expected the largest holiday travel in years over this week-end.
Signs of activity by anti-Semitic terrorist organizations are provided by the increasing number of bomb outrages against Jewish-owned property in Bulgaria.

The mama pig and the four little pigs which delighted the crew of the Greek freighter Eugenie S. Enbiricos are dead at the point of a mess boy's knife, victims of the Federal. quarantine on animals from Argentina.

Mayor La Guardia, replying to critics of his financial policies, who have expressed fears that the city's credit would again be weakened by spending, declared last night that it was his ambition to leave New York "in a better financial condition than I found it."
Drastic changes in Albany newspapers were announced tonight in the last edition of The Knickerbocker Press, owned by Frank E. Gannett, setting at rest rumors which flew thick and fast during the day.

The first public financing by E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. since early in 1928 will be undertaken today with the offering to the public of 500,000 shares of $4.50 cumulative preferred stock by a syndicate headed by Morgan Stanley Co., Inc.
Explosive protests by the Cubs were mingled with hits and runs today as the fighting Bruins whipped the Cardinals, 11 to 9, and kept their National League lead.

Bainbridge Colby, chairman of the independent committee representing Kreuger Toll Company 6 per cent debentures, commenting yesterday on an announcement by the Securities and Exchange Commission in Washington on Monday in connection with making effective a post-election amendment filed by the committee, said:

Owen D. Young and Gerard Swope, chairman and president of the General Electric Company, each received a salary of $106,500 and $40,000 under bonus and profit-sharing provisions of the company in 1936.

Organized labor offers a fruitful field for development of new athletic talent, Jeremiah T. Mahoney, president of the national A. A. U. and an honorary chairman of the second annual World Labor Athletic Carnival, to be held at Randalls Island July 11, said at a luncheon for the meet committee and the press at the New York Athletic Club yesterday.

Daily average gross production of crude oil in the United States last week amounted to 3,529,600 barrels, compared with 3,510,950 in the preceding week, an increase of 18,650, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday. Gains of 13,050 and of 6,800 barrels, respectively, in the daily averages of Texas and Louisiana were important changes.
Richmond Borough President Joseph A. Palma will formally open to the public at 2:30 P. M. on Saturday the new $2,000,000 Franklin D. Roosevelt Boardwalk in Staten Island.

Turpentine firm, 33 3/4c; sales 170 barrels; receipts 738 barrels; shipments 1,343 barrels; stock 26,711 barrels. Resin firm; sales 1,068 barrels; receipts 3,464 barrels; shipments 8,606 barrels; stock 54,410 barrels. Quote, B, D, E, F, G, H, I, K, M, N, $8; WG, $8.05; WW, X, $8.85.

Dr. Clyde Fisher, veteran observer of the sidereal world, returned yesterday on the Grace liner Santa Clara with enthusiastic reports of the success of the Hayden Planetarium Grace Expedition which studied the total eclipse of the sun on June 8.
The French Government furthered its vast program of nationalization of defense industries today by taking over the munitions plant of the Schneider Arms Works here.

Mrs. Florence G. Cropsey, widow of Supreme Court Justice James C. Cropsey, and the 12-year-old son of a Brooklyn clergyman are named as principal beneficiaries under the will of the jurist, which was filed yesterday in the Kings County Surrogate's Court. Justice Cropsey died on June 16 in Brooklyn Hospital after a short illness. He had no children.

Charges of price discrimination in the sale of cosmetics products by Bourjois, Inc., to certain of its customers in violation of the Robinson-Patman act were reviewed yesterday at a hearing of the Federal Trade Commission before John W. Addison, trial examiner, in the hearing rooms of the commission at 45 Broadway.

Predicting an appreciable change for the better in credit advertising methods before the Fall season is well advanced, J. Anton Hagios, manager of the credit management division of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, said yesterday that a committee of representative retailers will shortly contact appliance manufacturers, finance companies and others to join in the work of raising credit publicity standards.

Three of the thirty-five boats that started the ocean race from New London at noon on Sunday were beating up Chesapeake Bay tonight still a hundred miles or so from this anchorage on their contest of about 475 nautical miles.

At 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon thirty detectives and attaches of the District Attorney's office raided nine radio stores between Cortlandt Street and Harlem in a drive on what Assistant District Attorney Eugene B. McAuliffe described as a "counterfeit midget radio racket" in which buyers were being defrauded of $50,000,000 annually throughout the country.
Senator Josh Lee advised fifty-three graduates of the Hershey Industrial School last night to "make a success of a peanut stand before you look around to run somebody's factory."

Four women inmates of the Westfield State Farm, who escaped last night by climbing a seven-foot fence topped with barbed wire, were captured at 1:40 this afternoon in a woods three miles from the prison.

Advance interest in "Salome," opera by Strauss to be given at the Lewisohn Stadium tonight and tomorrow night, indicates that packed houses will attend both performances. As the opera-in one act-is short, and as it does not grow dark until quite late, the curtain will go up at 9 P. M. Instead of the usual 8:30.

Offices of the Motor Vehicle Bureau at the State Building in Manhattan and at 320 Schermerhorn Street, Brooklyn, and the County Clerks' offices in the Bronx, Queens and Richmond were busy yesterday issuing chauffeurs' licenses to replace those which expire at midnight tonight. Applications for renewal and original licenses may also be obtained at the police stations.

Lord Craigmyle, who was one of Great Britain's most noted lawyers and jurists, died in Glasgow yesterday at the age of 87. As Lord of Appeal in Ordinary, he held the title of Lord Shaw of Dunfermline in the life peerage until he resigned from the bench in 1929.

In spite of widespread business uncertainty caused by serious labor troubles and worries over the administration actions and plans, the sales prospect for the third quarter is excellent, Peter B. B. Andrews, economist of Hemphill, Noyes Co., writes in the current issue of Sales Management.

The Eastern Yacht Club race committee today officially declared Charles F. Havemeyer's Apache the winner of the third annual New London to Marblehead ocean race, and the New York Yacht Club 32footer thereby became the first winner of the Gerard Barnes Lambert trophy.

Trading was fair. Steer hinds and ribs were slightly stronger and other classes steady. Early trading in kosher meats indicated beef prices to be slightly lower, other classes steady, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.

The marriage of Mrs. Florence L. S. Morse of 117 East Seventy-seventh Street, widow of Edwin Wilson Morse, writer and editor, to Harry R. Hillard of this city, a retired importer, took place yesterday afternoon in St. James Protestant Episcopal Church.

Wide distribution of prizes for the two-day Scotch foursome tournament of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association took place at the Century Country Club today, with Miss Charlotte Glutting and Miss Louise Iselin collecting the chief trophy for a combined low gross score of 83, 84--167.

Again the tide has turned from the farms toward villages, towns and cities. The United States Department of Agriculture reports that about 80,000 fewer persons lived on farms at the beginning of 1937 than a year earlier-the first net loss since 1929.

President Roosevelt said today that except for four items, representing the sterilized gold, two of the Social Security reserves and the Veterans Insurance Fund, involving the bonus payment, the national debt had stood still since Dec. 22, 1936.

Five hundred pickets tried to battle their way through police lines last night as 126 WPA "stand up" strikers were being ejected from the labor relations office of the WPA educational division and taken to the West Twentieth Street police station for booking on disorderly conduct charges preferred by the Federal relief agency.

AS the Spanish civil war drags on, books pleading the one cause or the other increase in number. It seems that most of them are Loyalist in tone, but today we have an unqualified defense of the Rebel cause: F. Theo Rogers's "Spain: A Tragic Journey" (Macaulay, $2.50).
Columbia Pictures will release sixty-two feature productions, 126 short subjects and four serials on its 1937-38 program, it was announced yesterday.
Prime Minister William Lyon Mackenzie King of Canada was received by Chancellor Adolf Hitler today. They conferred for more than an hour.
The resignation of Louis T. Strauss as a director of the Jewish Hospital of Brooklyn because of his sympathy with the strikers of the Hospital Employes Union was disclosed yesterday.

East Side properties reported yesterday to have passed into new ownership included an old-law tene- W. ment, which was sold for remodeling to comply with the Multiple Dwelling Law, and a five-story building which will be demolished by the new owner.

The Bergen Center Holding Corporation, A Glickman, president, has signed a long lease with Bergen Center Amusements, Inc., said to represent a large metropolitan theatrical syndicate, for a theatre which the holding firm will construct at 777-87 Bergen Avenue, on the southwest corner of Glenwood Avenue, Jersey City.

Within forty-five minutes a grand jury heard the testimony of seven witnesses and returned three firstdegree murder indictments yesterday against Robert Irwin, the 29-year-old sculptor, who appears to enjoy the notoriety he has received since he surrendered in Chicago on Saturday.

Miss Edith Converse Colt, daughter of Mrs. LeBaron Carleton Colt aRd the late Mr. Colt of Bristol, R. I., was married this afternoon to Horace White Peters of Washington, son of Mrs. Joseph Hyde Pratt of
A hearing has been called for July 16 by the Securities and Exchange Commission on a declaration by the Oklahoma Power and Water Company, Sands Springs, Okla.,

Police Chief B. J. Gillen signed a warrant here today charging Gus Hall, the Warren-Niles C. I. O. strike leader, with having been the "brains" of a wholesale scheme to dynamite bridges, railroad tracks, steel mills and the light and power company, and to blow up the homes of non-strikers with high explosives.

The National Labor Relations Board has been swamped with cases since the Supreme Court validated the Wagner act. The board reported today that it had handled 3,852 cases in the first twenty months of its existence up to June 1.

Three of the youngsters who have been chosen for the junior Davis Cup squad came through their matches last night before in the fifth annual Eastern pri- the aggressor all vate schools tennis tourney without any trouble today on the courts of the Manursing Island Club. .
British officials opened today the longest and cheapest air-mail service in the world when an Imperial Airways liner took off from Southampton for South Africa with 112,000 letters.
Winthrop W. Aldrich, chairman of the Chase National Bank, was re-elected chairman of the New York Community Trust at a meeting of the trustees' committee at the Broad Street Club yesterday.

The Essex County Symphony Society brought to a close its second season of Summer concerts with the presentation in City Schools Stadium here tonight of Beethoven's Ninth symphony before an audience of about 15,000.

" Smyth With a Y," a comedy directed by Maurice L. Simmons, was presented this evening at the Valley Road playhouse on Vernon Valley Road by the Players Theatre Group of Manhattan as the opening attraction of a ten weeks' engagement here.
The seven-story loft building at 36 West Twenty-second Street has been leased by the Consolidated Druggist Realty Company to the New York Merchandise Company for a long term.

Stanley Singer, U. C. L. A., defeated John M. Schmidt, C. C. N. Y., 11-9, 10-8; Don McNeill, Kenyon, defeated Roger Bartlett, Drew, 6-0. 6-1; Antonio Dizon, Iowa State, defeated Paul L. Ferber, Yale, 6-4, 6-3; Joe Abrams, Tulane, defeated Irving Storch, N. Y. U., 7-5, 6-1: A. T. Doyle, North Carolina, won from Herbert Sobel, Cornell, by default.

A co-conspirator with the five men on trial in the bakery racket case caused a strike in a bakery because it undersold the price list fixed by the United Cake, Pastry and Pie Bakers Association, according to testimony yesterday in the Court of Special Sessions.
Chancellor Adolf Hitler further cemented Italo-German friendship today by conferring the Grand Cross of the Order of the German Eagle on Marshal Pietro Badoglio and five other Italians.
Teachers were warned against leaders of both sides of the current conflict between capital and labor from platforms of the National Education Association convention today.

Lenox Ave, 666-74; 60.9x28.5; for I-story gas station: Grand Lodge of Knights of Pythias, State of N. Y., 101 E 112th St, owner; R. C. Browe, architect; cost, $6,000. 60th St, 109 W; to 5-story tenement; Ursula Soule, premises, owner' J. J. Gloster, architect; cost, $5,000. 2d Ave, 1,979; to 5-story tenement and store; Spotswood D. and Marjorie S. Bowers, trustees, 40 Wall St, owner; G. T. Hirsch, architect; cost, $3.000.
John D. Rockefeller Jr. has written The Associated Press the following letter, expressing appreciation to the American press for its news coverage on the death of his father, John D. Rockefeller Sr.:

The liberal administration of Premier Angus L. Macdonald was swept back into power in the Nova Scotia elections today, adding three more seats to the twenty-two it held in the last House. There are thirty seats in the Legislature.

Battling against an unfamiliar wind and at times jostled by a great crowd that in its excitement overran a cordon of 500 patient stewards, the United States Ryder Cup team of professional golfers today scored 2 1/2 points to Great Britain's 1 1/2 in the Scotch foursome matches.

Ellis H. Parker Sr., chief of Burlington County detectives, and his son, Ellis Parker Jr., who were convicted last week by a Federal court jury on charges of conspiracy in the kidnapping of Paul H. Wendel, will be sentenced here at 10 o'clock tomorrow morning by Judge William Clark.

Steel ingot output declined less than seasonally last week, and the adjusted index advanced to 110.0 from 108.6. It was 105.4 for the week ended June 27, 1936. The week's production was estimated by THE NEW YORK TIMES at 75 per cent of capacity, compared with 76 per cent for the previous week and 72 per cent for the corresponding week last year.
John Patrick Doherty, president and managing director of the Tree Line Navigation Company, Ltd., died here last night following an attack of acute indigestion. His age was 48.

Miss Priscilla Steers, daughter of Mrs. Peter Greig of this place and Henry Coster Steers of New York, was married this afternoon to John Tolar Henry, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Henry of Brooklyn in Christs
Dominic De Martino, 26 years old, of 1,626 Seventy-sixth Street, Brooklyn, who three weeks ago was found guilty by a jury in Kings County Court on a charge of firstdegree robbery,
Mr. and Mrs. Morris Woodruff Kellogg of this city and Fieldston Farm, Roslyn, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Beatrice Winthrop Kellogg, to Harvey Childs McClintock Jr.
The French financial crisis forecasting a new devaluation of the franc threw a cloud over the congress of the International Chamber of Commerce today.

A spokesman for the Investment Bankers Association urged the Senate Banking and Currency Committee today to modify the Barkley Trust Indenture Bill, designed to protect investors through more stringent regulation of bondissue indentures.

Another garnishee racketeer hastily paid a $250 fine in Special Sessions yesterday, imposed for engaging in the money-lending business without a State license, after Justices Hackenburg, McInerney and Perlman had suspended a thirtyday workhouse term on him.
Fifty-three boys and one girl began play here today in the National Marbles Tournament. The tournament will continue until the finals are played Friday.

The Interstate Commerce Commission was requested yesterday by spokesmen of twenty-two trade groups in the New York and New Jersey district to reopen the case involving the designation of a metropolitan New'York area under the Federal Motor Carriers Act.

Here and there: Fisherman from England-Anthony Balding of Melton Mowbray, whose brothers are well known international polo players, tried salt water fishing in American waters for the first time while a guest of Earl Potter recently on the yacht Tarpon out of Bayshore.

Announcement was made today of the election of the Rev. Frederick M. Adams, rector of the Church of the Messiah and Incarnation, Brooklyn, as dean of Trinity Episcopal Catheral here, to succeed the late Right Rev. Ralph E. Urban.

The wedding of Miss Barbara Elizabeth Hawley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George S. Hawley of this city, to Harcourt Frederick Schutz of Hartford took place this afternoon at the residence of the bride's parents on the Ridge Road. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Watson L. Phillips, pastoremeritus of the Church of the Redeemer of this city.

Mayor La Guardia stole a march yesterday on the Board of Aldermen by recommending a $2,400,000 cut in water rates on the eve of a public hearing called for today by the Aldermen to ask a 50 per cent cut in the rates.
The Steel Workers Organizing Committee of the C. I. O. won an election at the American Car and Foundry Company plant at Berwick yesterday.

Jackson E. Reynolds, who retired on Jan. 1 as president of the First National Bank, was called back yesterday to become the bank's chairman, a post made vacant by the death a month ago of George F. Baker.

GOVERNORS ISLAND Each of the following Field Artillery Reserve officers is ordered to active duty, effective July 4, at Pine Camp, N. Y., for training. These officers are assigned or attached to the 307th Field Artillery. Each will revert to inactive status July 17.

For the third time, the directors of United States Steel yesterday broke precedents to pay something on account of preferred dividend arrears, since from time immemorial it had been the custom to declare dividends only on the final Tuesday of the month following the end of the quarter.
Copy has been broken in local newspapers by the National City |Bank of New York, representing the first time a bank of that size has used substantial space to advertise small loans.

Floyd B. Odium, president of the Atlas Corporation, told the Securities and Exchange Commission today that he built up one of the largest investment trusts in the world by taking advantage of depression opportunities.

Evidence that Alfred P. Sloan Jr., president of General Motors Corporation, and Mrs. Irene Jackson Sloan, his wife, avoided payment of $1,921,587 in income taxes during the last three years by reporting their income through personal holding companies was presented by Treasury experts today to the Joint Congressional Investigating Committee.
Alfred E. Smith, former Governor of New York, who arrived in Dublin last night, saw the Ireland of his dreams today in the June sunshine.
Chancellor Adolf Hitler assured Thomas J. Watson of New York today that "there will not be any war."

Governor Earle signed legislation today merging the State police and the State highway patrol and appointed Rear Admiral Percy W. Foote, retired, as commissioner of the combined forces, to be, known as the Pennsylvania Motor Police.

Following is the text of the joint communique issued by President Roosevelt and Premier Paul Van Zeeland of Belgium at the conclusion of their conferences today, as well as a separate statement made by the President alone:
Editors, publishers and other members of the New York Associated Dailies concluded today a two-day conference at Briarcliff Lodge here.

" The Singing Marine," with Dick Powell as the devil-dog mentioned in the title, will go on view this morning at the Strand. Among the supporting players are Doris Weston, Lee Dixon, Hugh Herbert, Jane Darwell, Allen Jenkins, George (Doc) Rockwell, Guinn Williams and Marcia Ralston.

Eugene J. Busher Co, Inc, have arranged a first mortgage of $145,000 for ten years on the recently completed apartment at 2,786-88 Bainbridge Ave, the Bronx, for the Halbridge Building Corp, with the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank. A first mortgage of $36,000 for five years has been placed on the two one-story taxpayers at 2,960 3d Ave and 651 Bergen Ave, the Bronx, for the 2,960 3d Ave Corp by Walter Samuels, Inc.
William J. Brede, formerly assistant secretary of the City Title Insurance Company, has been named title research director of the New York Title Insurance Company.
Miss Dorothy Fosdick, 24, daughter of the Rev. Dr. Harry Fosdick of New York, rescued a Southport Harbor lobsterman from his burning boat today.

The marriage of Miss Margaret M. Allen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Carlton B. Allen of this city, to Edwin R. Jung of Cleveland took place this evening in the North Avenue Presbyterian Church here. The Rev. Robert Gardner McGregor.

The New York State Athletic Commission yesterday took official cognizance of Joe Louis's recent ring encounter with James J. Braddock and voted to recognize the "Heavyweight champion of the world," after the Brown Bomber's name.
The year-old Robinson-Patman act has served the constructive purpose of eliminating unfair discounts and allowances, and thereby placed all buyers on an equal basis. Paul S.

The membrs of the Workers Alliance, who in protest against the management of relief in New Jersey took possession of the galleries of the Assembly Chamber in the State House last night, abandoned their sit-in siege late this afternoon when Governor Hoffman, as chairman of the State Financial Assistance Commission, agreed to give their organization a hearing on July 8.
The bicentennial ceremonies of the University of Goettingen closed today with another National Socialist party demonstration in the afternoon and a garden party in the evening. Bernhard Rust,

Lead weights of three floating mines have been found by Spanish fishermen outside the port of Almeria, and the National Defense Ministry warned the British Charge d'Affaires here today to advise naval officials about them.
The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated June 28:

Dividend Shares, Inc., Jersey City, an investment trust, has filed under the Securities Act of 1933 a registration statement covering 10,000,000 twenty-five-cent par value capital shares to be sold at the market for an estimated amount of $19,800,000. Proceeds would be used for investment. Calvin Bullock was named as underwriter.

Mrs. Mina du M. Bernard Monroe of this place and New York, widow of Colonel Robert Grier Monroe, was married here this afternoon to Robert C. Rand, son of Mrs. William Rand of New York and the late Colonel Rand. The Rev. John Cross of St. Patrick's Church, Cove, performed the ceremony, which took place at the bride's home in Pound Hollow here. The couple dispensed with attendants.
The text of the resolution adopted by representatives of eleven large newspaper associations today was as follows:

In an opinion handed down yesterday, Judge Clarence G. Galston in the Federal court, Brooklyn, dismissed a suit brought by the General Electric Company charging infringement of a patent by the Wabash Appliance Corporation, Abe Adler and Abe Parker.

Federal Judge William Clark vacated today a libel for $10,000 against the General A. W. Greely, a ship scheduled to leave here soon on an Arctic expedition headed by C. J. MacGregor. The libel was filed in Admiralty Court by Miss Florence Rouse, who charged she was injured when she fell into the water last April 14 as she was stepping from a dock to the boat.

Only because of American aid have hundreds of thousands of European Jews been able to survive increasingly critical conditions, according to the report for 1936 of the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee made public yesterday.

To take effect at 9 A. M., July 1: Fireman 1st grade William Meystrik, Engine Co. 262, to the Fire College. Change of Detail To take effect at 9 A. M., July 1: Fireman 1st grade William A. Dorritie, Rescue Co. 1, from the Fire College to the Probationary Firemen's School.
The weather here today was at the freezing point, 32 degrees Fahrenheit. The ceiling was overcast and visibility from three to six miles.

The marriage of Miss Ruth E. Hurlburt, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. H. C. Hurlburt of Hinsdale, N. Y., to Nelson H. Budd of New York, son of Mrs. George S. Budd of Gatlinburg, Tenn., and the late Rev. Budd,

THAT ear-splitting racket arising over Long Island is the roar of the "infernal combustion" chariots warming up for the Saturday speed carnival over the Roosevelt Raceway. Last year Signor Tazio Nuvolari rolled home in front without trouble, but a good tall fellow said yesterday that it's going to be different this year.

Continued sensational reports of damage by black rust in late maturing fields of Winter wheat, especially the soft variety, and almost unparalleled drought in the Canadian Northwest sent the wheat market soaring again today.
What the Governor of North Carolina said to the Governor of South Carolina will no doubt remain a subject of perennial interest.

Directors of the Nashua Manufacturing Company yesterday declared operative the plan of recapitalization which was approved on June 23 by holders of more than 80 per cent of the outstanding preferred and common stock.
The Export-Import Bank of Washington has agreed to participate in the financing of the sale of twenty locomotives and equipment valued at about $1,500,000 to China, Jesse H. Jones,
Visiting buyers registered in the market during the week ended yesterday were less than in the preceding week and well below the same period last year, according to the lists published in THE TIMES.

Miss Elizabeth Shelby Sinclair, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Sinclair, was married yesterday afternoon at the home of her mother, 277 Park Avenue, to Louis Wood Hoyle, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis L. Hoyle of Pasadena, Calif. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Lynde E. May Jr. of St. Bartholomew's Church.

Miss Patricia Henry of Los Angeles, women's national intercollegiate champion, led the advance of favorites into the third round of the women's Middle States tennis championships today by defeating Mrs. Sidney Miss Henry drew a bye in the first round.

With a moderate northeastern sweeping down Buzzard's Bay, the second day of the interscholastic yacht racing championship for the Mallory Cup produced five well sailed races but was marred by many protests in both the senior and junior divisions.

The All-American Bus Lines, Inc., of Chicago has taken the ground floor, basement and a portion of the fifth floor in 244-48 West Fortysecond Street, with the abutting vacant property at 241-43 West Forty-first Street, for terminal facilities for its own lines and for several affiliated companies.

A funeral service for Charles A. Flanagan, retired circulation manager of THE NEW YORK TIMES, who died on Saturday, was held yesterday morning in the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola, Park Avenue and Eighty-fourth Street.

A tentative regulation of the Securities and Exchange Commission concerning "pegging, fixing and stabilizing" is the subject of conferences now being conducted among representatives of brokers and other interested groups, including the governors of the New York Stock Exchange.
Frederic A. Juilliard, textile manufacturer and patron of music, died suddenly at his home here this morning of a cerebral hemorrhage, which occurred at 9:30 as he finished his breakfast.
Frederick J. Peper, former Assistant United States Attorney for the Eastern District of New York, died on Monday of a heart attack in his office, 189 Montague Street, Brooklyn.

Miss Loretta McCarthy, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Dennis McCarthy, was married to Assemblyman William J. A. Glancy of Washington Heights, New York, son of Mrs. John Glancy of Yonkers, today in St. Mary's Church here.
Stephen Ogilvy, New Rochelle, N. Y., reached the quarter-finals of the fifth annual Mountain Lakes Club tennis tournament today by defeating Donald Wheaton, Pelham Manor, N. Y., 6--4, 6--4.
This is the third of a series of articles on conditions in the centers where the Committee for Industrial Organization is waging its battle with industry to effect mass unionization.

The New York Racing Commission made public the following statement at Aqueduct yesterday: "After a thorough investigation, the New York State Racing Commission took action in the case of Jungle Chase, a 3-year-old colt in the stable of Alvin Untermyer, which was tampered with on June 19, by suspending William Goltz, stable foreman, for a period of thirty days to July 27., inclusive.

Miss Barbara Batchelder, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Hollis Goodell Batchelder of Dedham, Mass., will be married to John Marshall Lockwood, son of Justice and Mrs. Charles Clapp Lockwood of Brooklyn, on July 6 by the Rev. Thomas Huntington Chappell in St. Paul's Church, Dedham. A reception will be held at the Dedham Country and Polo Club.

After an ownership of only a few days, Loomis J. Grossman has re-sold the six-story apartment house at 107 Christopher Street, in Greenwich Village, to Matteo Perrotty, an investing client of J. J. Goodman, broker in the deal.

It took a youngster reared in professional environment--smiling Willie Turnesa of Holy Cross--to finally master Oakmont' stiffly guarded par and win the national intercollegiate golf championship's 36-hole qualifying round medal with a 146.

Charles Rosenthal, in 180 E 79th St, through Miss Frances Tilghman; Joseph W. Rumbough. twelve rooms in 885 Park Ave, through Ladd Nichols; Isadore S. Schweitzer, in 1,125 Park Ave, through Brown, Wheelock,. Harris, Stevens, Inc; leases made for Tishman Realty and Construction Co.

John C. Lynch, retired electrical engineer and former assistant vice president of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, died of coronary thrombosis this afternoon at Fairview Hospital, Great Barrington. He was 62 years old.

Sales of goods by maunfacturers and wholesalers showed substantial gains in May over May, 1936, the Commerce Department said today on the basis of a joint survey with the National Association of Credit Men.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Emily North King, daughter of Edwin B. King, headmaster of the Stuyvesant School here, and Mrs. King, to Melville Church 2d of Washington. Miss King, through her father, is descended from Dr. John Neilson of New York, Colonel Nicholas Fish of Revolutionary War times, and Peter Stuyvesant, early Dutch Governor of New Amsterdam.

The tall, graceful spire of little Christ Church at Christiana Hundred is sheltered by the swaying heads of huge and ancient elm trees. There is a patch of smooth, green lawn in front and a small circular driveway.

Representatives of the American Federation of Labor and the Committee for Industrial Organization protested to Governor Graves today against what they termed "outrages" against unionists by "constituted authorities" at Gadsden, Ala.
George F. Merritt, president of a New York printing company bearing his name, died here yesterday at his home.

Directors of the United States Steel Corporation declared yesterday a dividend of $2 a share on the 7 per cent $100-par preferred stock, applying against accumulated arrears, payable on July 30 to stock of record of July 9.

Arthur A. Boklan is with Amott, Baker Co., Inc. Harriman Keech have opened a branch office for the Summer at Bar Harbor, Me., with John J. Kearns as manager, and one at Oak Bluffs, Mass., under the management of Harold Paull.

Miss Ruth Evelyn Heidkamp, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Rudolph W. Heldkamp of Orchard Hill, Elmsford, N. Y., was married yesterday afternoon to Arthur Philip Moebius Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur P. Moebius of Tarrytown.

All the negotiators in London and Washington may not know it, but the outlook for a reciprocal trade agreement between the United States and Great Britain has suffered a sinking-spell in its American sector.

The Group Theatre, which tried it once before with two one-acters by Clifford Odets, is planning another evening of short plays. They won't form the Group's opener for the season, but are to be done later on.

Representatives of eleven large newspaper associations adopted a resolution today stating their "unalterable opposition to the closed shop for those who prepare and edit news copy and pictures for newspapers."

Newark increased its astounding lead in the International League tonight by defeating Baltimore twice. Vito Tamulis pitched a 5-0 shut-out in a twilight game and then Joe Beggs checked the Birds, 6-2. It was the ninth straight time the Bears had beaten the Orioles.

James Leslie Donaly, originator and manufacturer of bait-casting plugs, died at his name here today at the age of 67 after a two-months' Illness of a heart malady. In Jersey waters Donaly baits were popular with bass and pickerel fishermen.

The Senate ratified today, without debate and without a record vote, two treaties, five conventions and one protocol negotiated and signed by the representatives of the twentyone American republics participating in the Inter-American Conference for the Maintenance of Peace, held at Buenos Aires last December.

Officers of the Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation were chosen yesterday at the first meeting of the board of trustees at 120 Broadway. Solomon R. Guggenheim, who has created and endowed the foundation to promote art,

Fire which started in a huge paint tub raged for almost two hours through the Canton plant of the International Harvester Company today, causing damage which, according to W. J. La Croix, Chicago works manager, might exceed $200,000.
Mrs. Christina Horsburgh Alison of Bridgeport, widow of the Rev. Dr. Alexander Alison Sr., died today at a Hartford hospital after a long illness. Her age was 84.

Death sentences were pronounced today upon Robert J. Suhay and Glen J. Applegate, convicted murderers of Wimberly W. Baker, Federal agent. Judge Richard J. Hopkins denied their motion for a new trial.

Richard C. du Pont, determined to soar to the wedding of his cousin, Ethel, and Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr., spent this afternoon in the air over Harris Hill trying to find a current that would give him sufficient altitude to attempt the glider hop.

Theodore Dreiser, author, was ordered yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Salvatore A. Cotillo to pay the Liveright Publishing Corporation, his former publishers, a total of $12,789. A counter-claim made by the writer for $67,500 was dismissed by the court.
Leaders of Camp Fire Girls' groups from eight States will attend a training course to be held at the organization's camp near Arden, N. Y., from tomorrow to Sunday.

The text of the bill providing for the delegation of full financial powers to the French Cabinet contains one article introduced by a preamble explaining the reasons why the government is obliged to resort to emergency measures. The text follows:

MANHATTAN BAAR, JESSE (April 9, 1936). Gross assets, $521,107; net, $455,027. To Laura Baar, mother, half residue; Stella Baar, widow, $5,000 and half residue; Jewish Hospital of Brooklyn and Brooklyn Hebrew Orphan Asylum, $2,505 each; Union Temple of Brooklyn, $2,500; Brooklyn Hebrew Orphan Asylum, $1,954. Chief assets, mortgages, notes, cash and insurance, $319,053. Herman Goldman, attorne. 120 Broadway.

Paul Van Zeeland, Premier of Belgium, and Mrs. Van Zeeland, Prince Eugene de Ligne, Counselor of the Belgian Embassy; Cardinal Dougherty, Lady Astor, the Duchess of Leeds, Paul D. Cravath and former Governor Charles S. Whitman are among those sailing on the French liner Normandie today.

Receipts, 17,000, including 4,000 direct. Market generally 10-15c lower than yesterday's average; packing sows fully 15c lower, excepting best lightweight sows; top $11.90; bulk good and choice 200-300 pound, averages $11.50-$11.85; most 150-190 pound. $11.25-$11.80; good packing sows 350-500 pound, $9.80-$10.40; few lightweights $10.50$10.60.
The embargo on foreign loans, formally effective for several years, but which in practice has been gradually dropped, now apparently will be still further modified.

Mr. and Mrs. William M. Byrnes of Scarsdale, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Catherine Marie Byrnes, to Robert Francis Flood of Chicago, son of Mr. and Mrs. Maurice S. Flood of New Rochelle, N. Y.

The American Institute of Steel Construction, at a dinner in the Engineers Club, 32 West Fortieth Street, last night announced its annual awards for the most beautiful steel bridges constructed in the United States during the previous year.

The American Federation of Labor's application for affiliation with the International Federation of Trade Unions will be one of the most controversial issues at the annual session of the general council of the latter federation, beginning in Warsaw tomorrow.

Governor Lehman gave the "commencement" address at Sing Sing prison here today to the first 240 graduates of the Wallkill Central Guard School, established recently by the Division of Education, State Correction Department, to train men for work as prison guards.

A couple of horses rated last year as great 3-year-old prospects, only to be laid low for one reason or another, fought it out in the featured Baychester Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday in company considerably below the grade their 2-year-old form indicated.

Basque refugee children will be the beneficiaries of a concert tomorrow evening at the Mecca Temple. Arnold Eidus, twelve-year-old violinist, will be heard in Lalo's "Symphonie Espagnole," assisted by a symphony orchestra under the direction of Max Goberman.

The marriage of Miss Janet Inglis Miller, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Ernest Miller of East Orange, to Henry Barton Off, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry J. Off of Germantown, Pa., took place today at the Central Brick Presbyterian Church here. The ceremony was performed by the pastor, the Rev. Harold E. Nicely.
John Robinton of 3,969 Saxon Avenue, the Bronx, an organizer of the Jewish War Veterans of the United States, died yesterday in Mount Sinai Hospital after a short illness. He was 65 years old.

Governor Frank Murphy's views on labor relations and his comments on the new Michigan labor legislation were read here today in labor and government circles and considerable concurrence was expressed with parts of the report published in today's NEW YORK TIMES.
Walter Hagen, hero of many an American victory on the windswept British golf courses, was the hero of still another today, although he never struck a shot.

The Senate confirmed Arthur A. Quinn of New Jersey today as Controller of Customs at New York. When the Senate confirmed Arthur A. Quinn as Controller of Customs for the Port of New York yesterday it confirmed him for a second four-year term.
Pope Pius, for the first time in his pontificate, failed today to pray at the tomb of St. Peter on the day dedicated to him whom Catholic tradition regards as the first of all Popes.

Wet fields caused postponement of the five Meadow Brook Club Cup polo matches scheduled today, but with some of the practice fields rapidly drying matches were played on the No. 4 field at Meadow Brook, at neighboring Mitchel Field and on two fields at the J. S. Phipps estate in Old Westbury.

Mrs. Carl S. Petrasch, R. W. Cluett estate on McLane St, Mount Kisco, Westchester; Holbrook B. Cushman, broker. C W. Gilmer, the Robert Calvert residence at 28 Rugby Road, Scarsdale; Dr. T. Wallis Davis, the Amelia B. Crim dwelling at 231 Nelson Road, Scarsdale; 1. Harby, the Alfred L. Hellwith home at 69 WLlworth Ave, Scarsdale; William Bateman, in 29 Lawrence Road, Scarsdale; Prince Ripley, Inc, broker.

With 2,094 births reported in the city last week, bringing the total for the twenty-five weeks since the first of the year to 50,596, indications are that births in 1937 will exceed 100,000, as compared with 98,507 last year, Dr. John L. Rice,

Fractious at the post but thoroughly businesslike when the racing began, Wild Turkey of the Tranquility Farm scored an easy victory in the Dover Purse, outstanding event on today's program of the Delaware Steeplechase and Race Association at Delaware Park.
Amelia Earhart landed her silver monoplane at Lae, New Guinea, at 1:46 P. M. today [12:46 A. M. New York time]. She had flown across the Arafura Sea from Port Darwin, on the North Australian coast.

Miss Helen Jacobs's dreams of annexing two Wimbledon titles in a row were dashed today when Miss Dorothy Round of England, the 1934 champion, played the most beautiful tennis of her career to defeat the American girl in straight sets, 6-4, 6-2.

A firmer tone developed yesterday in bond trading on the New York Stock Exchange, and the volume diminished slightly as the liquidation of railroad issues which set in on Monday appeared to have been checked to some extent.
The War Office has been browbeaten into paying for thousands of Guardsmen's scarlet tunics ruined by the downpour that ended the coronation procession last month.

Representative Donald L. O'Toole of Brooklyn said today that the Federal Reserve Board had agreed to eliminate from employment application blanks a question which he contended "opens the door to racial and religious prejudice."

It was Colonel Theodore Roosevelt, who, as Secretary of the United States Navy in 1922,. so vigorously condemned the perpetrators of the Herrin Massacre, Premier Mitchell Hepburn admitted here tonight.

Mrs. Harry L. Rollins and Leighton Rollins will give a dinner on Thursday for young people, who are arriving to join the Studio of Acting, under the direction of Mr. Rollins. The group will stay at Greycroft, one of Mrs. Lorenzo E.
The a $135,000,000 Farm Tenancy Bill, described as a means of providing a "laboratory" for study of the problem, was passed today by the House and sent to the Senate. The rollcall vote was 307 to 25.

The Yankees beat the Athletics, 3 to 2, today before 6,000 excited fans in Shibe Park amid a flutter of torn papers, knotted programs, flying cushions, one pop bottle and a metal tray thrown from the stands.

Avenue B, 102, 24.6x64.6; Miriam King to Emigrant Bank; mtg $15,600, held by bank. 74th St, n s, 25.6 e of Amsterdam Ave, 19x37xirreg; Malroe Corp to Joseph E. Gilbert, Inc: mtg $35,000 ($1). Same property, Joseph E. Gilbert, Inc, to 1,042 Madison Ave. Inc, 2 Rector St ($20.50). First Ave, 2,021, 25x75; Bowery Savings Bank to Gaetano Grimaldi, 178 E 110th St (52).
Clarence Munroe Clark, banker and sportsman, died today at his estate, Cedron, in Germantown, after an illness of seven months. He was in his seventy-eighth year.

The Social Security Act in the United States may sound the death knell of private initiative in philanthropy, said Merle E. Frampton, principal of the New York Institute for the Education of the Blind, addressing the convention of workers for the blind today.
The Senate Committee on Pensions was asked today to approve a bill providing a pension of $5,000 annually for Mrs. Benjamin Harrison, 79year-old widow of President Harrison.

Julius Heldman, University of California at Los Angeles, who is the national junior tennis champion, won two matches yesterday to reach the third round of the Eastern intercollegiate championship at the Richmond County Country Club, Dongan Hills, Staten Island.

Supreme Court Justice George E. Brower in Brooklyn rejected yesterday in its entirety a plan submitted for the readjustment, modification or reorganization of the rights of holders of participation certificates in a mortgage of $700,000 on the Hotel Bossert, at Montague and Hicks Streets, Brooklyn.
With financial markets in France closed and a general moratorium on all gold and foreign exchange payments in effect in that country, dealings in the franc here yesterday were only nominal.

The restored and rehabilitated Fort Greene Park in Brooklyn, which in the last few years had become so scarred by vandals and unkempt from lack of proper maintenance as to present a dilapidated appearance, was opened officially to the public yesterday at exercises in the park presided over by Park Commissioner Moses.

A rehearsal of the wedding of Miss Ethel du Pont and Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr., which will take place at 5 o'clock tomorrow afternoon, was held late this afternoon in the little quaint stone church at Greenville.

Two publishers have announced for coming publication hitherto suppressed material from the original manuscript of T. E. Lawrence's "Seven Pillars of Wisdom." The Viking Press has made known that it would publish a chapter in the Fall.

At the half-way mark in the thirty six-hole race for medal honors in the twenty-sixth annual Eastern interscholastic golf championship on the Greenwich Country Club course Eddie Foy, a student at Kingsley School in New Jersey, was leading the juvenile parade with a threeover par 73.
Only the retail group showed an increase over last year in the weekly compilation of commercial and industrial failures issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet.

Leonard Hartman of New York, the first seeded player, slashed his way to three quick victories today to lead the field into the quarter-final round of the annual New Jersey be State men's tennis championship at the Montclair Athletic Club. Hartman defeated D. V. G. Corwin of Jersey City, Richard J. Hanwell of Montclair and Stephen B. Brunbas of Union City with little rest between matches.
