Loan disbursements by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation in May amounted to $11,271,373, while repayments on previous loans aggregated $14,878,529, according to a report sent to Congress by the agency today.

After dynamite had ripped open two water mains feeding the reopened Cambria plant of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation here early today, Mayor Daniel J. Shields called an emergency meeting of the City Council tonight, at which James Mark and C. J. Jones, leaders of the strikers of Bethlehem steel and railroad workers, were warned that they remained in town at their own risk.
The new sculpture section of the Tate Gallery, Lord Duveen's gift to the nation, was described by King George as "the world's finest sculpture galleries," as he declared them open today.
Stocks improved fractionally and closed steady and mixed; turnover, 553,040 shares. United States Government issues dull and slightly higher, other bonds irregular; transactions, $7,558,700.
The Senate overrode today an economy appeal by President Roosevelt approving legislation to extend the 3 1/2 per cent interest rate on Federal Land Bank loans another year.

Mrs. Roy Chapman Andrews, wife of the director of the American Museum of Natural History, has purchased Seven Hills Farm at Colebrook, Conn., comprising 120 acres, with a large residence and a three-acre lake.
The Frans Hals exhibition commemorating the seventy-fifth anniversary of the founding of the Frans Hals Museum here will open tomorrow.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated June 28: LIEUTENANT COLONELS Watrous, L., Adjutant General's Dept., three months' lease, July 1, on acocunt of sickness. Fleming, P. B., Eng'rs., twenty days' leave, July 1.

Speaking at the official opening of the Mott Haven Health Center, 349 East 140th Street, the Bronx, Health Commissioner John L. Rice yesterday described it as an institution "for friendship, unity of endeavor and service."
The Mayor's Committee on City Planning is wisely prefacing its detailed suggestions for New York City's future with systematic studies of the city's present.
Pairings for the United StatesGreat Britain Ryder Cup singles matches to be played over Southport and Ainsdale tomorrow: Ralph Guldahl, U. S., vs. Alf Padgham.

Premier Hepburn has announced a Provincial Tourist Bureau estimate that between May and September nearly 10,000,000 persons will come from the United States to Ontario in more than 3,000,000 automobiles and will spend about $150,000,000.
Darkness ended a battle between the Senators and Red Sox in the twelfth inning today, with the teams in a 2-to-2 tie.

Cutting a tape, Postmaster Albert Goldman opened yesterday the new quarters of the Inwood postal station at Vermilyea Avenue and 204th Street. The building, which cost $106,000, occupies a site 100 feet square and is one and a half stories high.

The Adjutant General released the following orders today: COMMISSIONS Foley, Capt. Frank M., assigned to 14th Infantry for further assignment to Company I. Gaige, 2d Lt. Charles H., assigned to 10th Infantry for further assignment to Company E.

On the eve of the canning season Alaska packers in this district have arranged to stamp out fish piracy. They have chartered planes with two-way radios and magnesium flares, and patrol boats, and will attach flood lights to 100 traps in this district.

Mrs. Margaret McCabe of 3,006 Decatur Avenue, the Bronx, and Miss Josephine McCabe, her daughter, were killed this afternoon when their automobile, a small coupe, was hit by a truck loaded with brick in front of the Pinehurst Inn. Miss Anna McCabe, another daughter, and George McCabe, son, who drove the car, were severely Injured.

A steering committee for the underwear and negligee industries voted yesterday to establish offices and employ necessary clerical help in a program for setting up fair trade practice rules for those industries.

Public criticism of the arrangement between E. L. Phillips Co. and the Long Island Lighting Company led to its abandonment in 1933, Ellis L. Phillips, head of both organizations, testified yesterday in Supreme Court. Mr. Phillips added that he believed continuation of the arrangement would have proved better for stockholders and consumers of Long Island Lighting.
Mr. and Mrs. John Edgar Gomery of Overbrook have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ruth A. Gomery, to John M. Mackie of Englewood, N. J., son of Mrs. David Ives Mackie of New

A single by Lou Fette that scored Elby Fletcher broke up a twelve-inning pitching duel between the Boston hurler and Max Butcher and gave the Bees the victory over the Dodgers, 1-0, in the series opener at National League Park today.

In Yugoslav political circles there is much talk about the constant political tension in Albania. It is reported here that the Minister of War and army leader, General Aranitas, has been sent on a five-month compulsory leave and will not be allowed to return to his post because of suspicions that he was aware of Ethem Toto's preparations for the recent revolt but did nothing to hinder them.

The former Kelvinator Building consisting of a two-story factory and warehouse with 50,000 square feet of space and a siding connected with the Long Island Railroad, at Fiftieth Avenue and Twenty-first Street, Long Island City, has been leased for Max Aronson to the General Fire Extinguisher Company as a distribution warehouse in conjunction with its main plant at Providence, R. I.

Major W. Wolcott Marks, a veteran of the Spanish-American War and in former years active in the cable industry, died on Monday in a Brooklyn hospital at the age of 84. Major Marks won his commission with the Ninth C. A. C.

The marriage of Miss Beatrice Nehrbas, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles J. Hehrbas of Bayside, L. I., to Robert Wallace Strayer, son of Mrs. Arthur S. Strayer of Niagara Falls, N. Y., and the late Mr. Strayer, took place yesterday afternoon at St. Kevin's Church, auburndale, L I. the Rev. Dr. Peter Baker performed the ceremony.

Price advances of 7 to 10 per cent will be announced tomorrow by a number of machine tool builders whose plants are now booked to capacity well into the Winter months. The increases will apply on all types of tools built by the companies but will be effective only on new orders.

The closing of the Paris Bourse and the subsequent decision to suspend dealings in francs here until further notice disturbed all sections of the stock market here today, business virtually coming to a standstill and prices, where changed, finishing lower.
Mayor La Guardia signed a local law yesterday which lightens the cost of a pumping station and sewage treatment plant for property owners in the Sheepshead Bay section of Brooklyn.
No man in American public life has packed a more intimate experience with a wide variety of labor problems into a shorter space of time than Governor MURPHY of Michigan.

The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that it had issued an order suspending the effectiveness of a registration statement filed under the Securities Act of 1933 by Income Estates of America, Inc., on Aug. 30, 1935, covering trustee Income Estates certificates, series C, of an aggregate offering price of $5,000,000.

The American Bar Association, through an office in Washington, is actively engaged in putting pressure on the ten United States Senators whose votes will be needed to defeat a compromise plan affecting the United States Supreme Court, it was revealed last night by former Senator George Wharton Pepper of Pennsylvania.

SENIOR BOMBSIGHT MECHANIC, $2,000 a year; Air Corps: Patterson Field, Fairfield, Ohio. Applications must be on file with the secretary, Board of U. S. Civil Service Examiners, Wright Field-Fairfield Air Depot, Wright Field, Dayton. Ohio, not later than July 15.

Howe Ave (14-3509). w s, 275 ft s of Lacombe Ave, 50x108; Cas-Hil Development Corp to Della O'Mahoney, 389 Sackett St, Brooklyn. Williamsbridge Rd, 3,055 (16-4547); Glovania Russell to Ralph Rubins, 174 E 85th St.

RUBIN BIRNBACH, real estate, 1,464 Bryant Ave.-Liabilities, $30,000, mainly contingent on mortgage bonds; no assets except insurance. MEYER GUTERMAN, dentist, 1,775 Broadway-Liabilities, $10,680; assets, $2,000, exclusive of insurance.

The Inland Steel Company announced tonight that its two plants in East Chicago, Ind., would be reopened at 8 o'clock Thursday morning. It is regarded as certain that the Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company will reopen its East Chicago plant at the same time.

The marriage of Miss Amanda Grace Hayward, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Heller Hayward of this place, to Standish Salisbury Rowe of Cedar Grove, son of the late William Lewis Rowe of Baltimore and the late Mrs. George Le

Mayor La Guardia signed the Carroll bill yesterday giving any city employee re-employed from preferred lists sinee Jan. 1, 1933, his full salary, but he warned the Board of Aldermen that he would tolerate no abuse of its provisions.
A. F. Kammer Sr. of Baltusrol and his son, Lowry, today won the New Jersey State father-son golf championship over the Montclair Golf Club course with a score of 77, 81-158.

President Roosevelt, because of his personal interest in the development of the waterfront of New York City, made available WPA funds for the Grand to Twelfth Street section of the East River Drive, which was formally opened yesterday, it was disclosed by Mayor Ia Guardia.

Great Britain must honor her obligation to the Jews in Palestine and "America has the right to expect her to do so," United States Senator Robert F. Wagner told more than 2,000 Zionists in Carnegie Hall last night at a public meeting closing the fortieth anniversary convention of the Zionist Organization of America.
The first Little Entente stamps ever to be placed on sale will be offered in all Czechoslovak postoffices July 1, the denominations being 2 crowns and 2.50 crowns.
A Carlist patrol forming part of the troops commanded by Colonel Alonso Vega today entered Valmaseda, fifteen miles southwest of Bilbao.
The usual quiet of this little Oxfordshire town was shattered today as the preparations for the annual Royal Henley Regatta, starting tomorrow, reached their climax.

A White House aide informed Acme Newspictures, Inc., and The Associated Press News Photo Service today that, because of their Jefferson Islands picture "scoops," they "probably will not make any more pictures of the President for some time to come."

Malcolm Muir, who recently became president of News-Week, Inc., at the invitation of Vincent Astor and Averill Harriman, said yesterday he had no immediate plans for the creation of a string of business papers, but indicated he will devote his attention to "developing the maximum possibilities of News-Week."

Eighty-two promotions were made yesterday in the higher ranks of the Fire Department by Fire Commissioner John J. McElligott. Deputy Chief James W. Heffernan of the Eleventh Division was placed in charge of Brooklyn and Queens. Six captains became battalion chiefs; eighteen lieutenants were promoted to captaincies; and fifty-seven first grade firemen became lieutenants.

More than 200 elementary school children from the lower East Side put on a demonstration at City Hall yesterday morning against their impending transfer to a school somewhat distant from the one they now attend.
Stoneridge Direct, brown gelding owned by the Biery Farms of Butler, Pa., captured the feature event of tonight's Grand Circuit program at Fort Miami track.

Leonard B. Boudin in his letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES argues that the refusal of the steel companies to enter into written contracts with the C. I. O. constitutes prima facie evidence of their bad faith.

Along both sides of the Potomac, in the shadow of the Washington Monument and Lincoln Memorial, and under the slopes of Arlington National Cemetery in Virginia, more than 24,000 Boy Scouts from every State in the Union and from twenty-four foreign countries were bivouacked tonight in anticipation of the opening ceremony tomorrow morning which will start their tenday National Jamboree.

Anthony Caffaro, 59 years old, of 546 Eastern Parkway, Brooklyn, was booked in the Bergen Street Station, Brooklyn, yesterday on a homicide charge in connection with the fatal stabbing of Joseph Zerba, 52, of 1,136 Seventy-second Street, Brooklyn, last Saturday.
General METAXAS is not much more than a freshman in dictatorship; but he is coming on. Dictators, always gnawed by suspicion, must be on guard all the time and meddle with everything.
Movements of vessels follow, all dates are June 28 unless specified: Kiel, Germany, to Funchal, Madeira, June 29: Arkansas, New York, Wyoming.

Irregular fluctuations over an unusually wide range continued yesterday to feature trading on the Cotton Exchange and the list ended with losses of 4 to 6 points. After a lower opening on circulation of more notices than were issued on
The Maritime Commission announced today that it had retained as managing agents for six months the former operators of six government-owned steamship lines.

The three Soviet fliers, Valery Chkaloff, Georgi Baidukoff and Alexander Beliakoff, who flew over the North Pole from Moscow to Vancouver, Wash., are scheduled to arrive here today from Washington, where they were received by President Roosevelt.

Premier Paul Van Zeeland of Belgium returned to New York by plane late yesterday afternoon with Mrs. Van Zeeland and they were guests of the Belgian League of Honor in the United States at a reception at the Ambassador Hotel. More than 300 persons attended.
William A. Taylor, 75-year-old retired dry goods commission merchant, fell to his death about 10:30 o'clock last night from his eleventhfloor apartment at 988 Fifth Avenue.
The Rev. Dr. Thomas Johnstone, former Moderator of the Presbyterian Church of Ireland, figured in a remarkable scene in the Ulster High Court at Belfast today.

Sammy Hale's home run led a 13-hit attack on Elon Hogsett and Jack Knott today to bring the Indians from behind and defeat the Browns in the first of a three-game series, 7 to 5. Second baseman Hale smashed a ho one of Hogsett's offerings at the height of a six-inning rally, which netted the Tribe four runs.
The Japanese Embassy announced tonight agreement with Russia to withdraw armed forces from the Bolshoi and Sennufa islands in the Amur River, boundary between Siberia and Northeastern Manchukuo.

The one-story taxpayer and adjoining dwelling at 14 and 16 West 183d Street, just west of Jerome Avenue, in the Bronx, have been acquired by Joseph L. Ennis Co., operators, from Virginia M. Ahern. The plot measures 37.6 by 100 feet. J. J. Goodman was the broker.

Miss Evelyn Barbara Spears, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Spears of Hillandale Farm here, was married this afternoon in the Presbyterian church to Dr. John Walter Martin Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. John Martin of Cleveland. The Rev. John A. Hayes officiated.
In two large rooms and an upstairs hall at Owl's Nest white-draped tables held tonight the thousands of gifts to Mr. and Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr.

The Attorney General's Department approved today the "agreement of consolidation and merger" of the New York Cuba Mail Steamship Company and the Agwi Navigation Company of Eliot into a single corporation to be known as the New York Cuba Mail Steamship Company of Eliot.
East Broadway. e s, 46.2 ft w of Montgomery St, 23x95; John Horn to Two Fifty-five East Broadway Corp, c/o Parker Dawson, 30 Rockefeller Plaza; consideration $11,000, over mtg for $10,200.

A arning to workers not to "sign away their rights" was sounded today in an article in the Ford Company's Almanac, which declared that the "true meaning" of the drive to unionize them is an effort on the part of financiers to set up "wage dictatorships."

Miss Mary Victoria Stevens, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Horace N. Stevens of this place, was married this evening to Dr. Merton L. Griswold Jr. of Plainfield, son of Mr. and Mrs. Merton L. Griswold of Uxbridge, Mass. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Alson H. Robinson in All Souls Unitarian Church. A reception followed at the home of the bride's parents.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Edith Moore, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Moore of this place, to Arthur R. Crawford, son of Mrs. Ann Crawford of Douglas Manor, L. I., and the late Arthur L. Crawford.

The Rev. M. J. Divine, worshiped as "God" by thousands of Negroes and some whites, and his Peace Mission Movement are not beyond the bounds of the law, Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook declared yesterday in giving the Harlem cult leader two courses to escape the appointment of receivers for all the order's temporal possessions.

Mr. and Mrs. E. de Forest Simmons are with Mr. and Mrs. Ledlie Hees at their country home in Sacandaga, N. Y., for the holiday. Breckinridge Long, former United States Ambassador to Italy, Mrs. Long and Miss Christine Long, who were at the Ambassador, sailed yesterday on the Kungsholm for the North Cape cruise.

The all-American college lacrosse team whipped the Oldham ten, 13 to 5, today in the first match of its British tour. Kid Norris led the San American attack with five goals. Oldham's coach, Herman Epstein, Ban aid the long sticks used by the Americans seemed to bewilder the players.
Contract awards for 577,000 yards of textiles were announced by the Treasury Procurement Division today as follows:

The popular belief that the largest share of the millions of pounds spent here during the coronation for the highest priced seats, for hotel reservations and in the general spending boom came from the pockets of American tourists was exploded today when figures were published on the number of visitors from abroad who were here during May.

Alexander A. Troyanovsky, Soviet Ambassador to Washington, denounced "unfounded gossip" about Soviet Russia and "the calumnies of our enemies," in a speech last night at a dinner in the WaldorfAstoria Hotel in honor of the three heroes of the Russian trans-polar flight.

The Consolidated Retail Stores, Inc., yesterday declared a dividend 4 of $30 a share on its preferred 1 stock. The distribution will clear . up $28 a share accumulations on the preferred stock and the regular quarterly dividend of $2 a share due today. J. C. Berkson, president, said he believed it was not advisable to initiate any dividend on the common stock at this time.

The June financing operations of the United States Treasury and the turnover of funds incident to the quarterly tax period provided the first test of the money market since member-bank reserve requirements were increased and member-bank excess reserves were reduced on May 1, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York comments in its monthly review, issued yesterday. This test, the bank indicates, was passed without difficulty.

In the soft glow of candle light and looking like a slim princess in gossamer white, Miss Ethel du Pont, a member of one of America's greatest industrial families, was married this afternoon at 5 o'clock to Franklin Delano Roosevelt Jr., third son of the President, in the Christ Protestant Episcopal Church in Christiana Hundred.
The Communications Commission today awarded the broadcasting facilities of Stations WARD and WLTH, both of Brookly, to Sation WBBC, operated by the Brooklyn Boradcasting Corporation of Brooklyn.

The marriage of Miss Louella Florence Clow, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James A. Clow of Brockville, Ont., to Robert William Lippoth of this city, took place here yesterday afternoon in the Church of the Transfiguration. The Rev. Harold Lemoine performed the ceremony.
It was Dick Bartell Day at the Polo Grounds yesterday, and even if the Phillies were only mildly aware of it at the outset, they had occasion to become fully cognizant of the fact before it was over.
" I don't know whether to be happy or sad," Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt said in her weekly radio broadcast tonight following the wedding of her son, Franklin, Jr., to Ethel du Pont.

Negotiations between the Trans- The fo port Workers Union, a C. I. O. Charles ( affiliate, and the New York City and E. J. Omnibus Corporation over the' Among union's demands for higher wages plant sin, and improved working conditions on May Ifor the company's 1,800 employes with the will begin this afternoon at the section company's offices, 125 West 146th G d Street.

Monopolistic and discriminatory practices in violation of the Federal Trade Commission and Robinson-Patman acts are charged in a complaint issued by the commission today against the Golf Ball Manufacturers Association, the Professional Golfers Association of America, their officers and various members of each group.

Announcement has been made by Dr. Graeme M. Hammond of 145 East Fifty-second Street of the engagement and approaching marriage of his granddaughter, Miss Claire Noel Kendall, to Jose Ossorio, son of Miguel Ossorio of Leed's Point, Greenwich, Conn., and Mrs. Ossorio of Manila. P. I.
New securities offered in the local market in June showed a marked increase over the totals for recent months, with bond offerings the largest since January and stock offerings the best since April.
The Chiefs ended its home stand tonight, scoring a double victory over Jersey City, 4-3 and 9-3, before a record-breaking night crowd of 10,000.

Washington defeated Boston, 6 to 4, today behind the pitching and hitting of Wesley Ferrell, who was opposed on the mound by Buck Newsom in the first meeting of the two right-handers since they traded uniforms three weeks ago.
A sit-down strike of 400 employes of the Lavalle Shoe Company, 632 Broadway, was called yesterday by the United Shoe Workers Union, C. I. O. affiliate, with offices at 750 Broadway.

The General A. W. Greely, a trim three-masted schooner, is scheduled to head out of Port Newark this afternoon for a long stay in the Arctic regions to study meteorological conditions and perhaps pay a call on the Russians at their North Pole observation station.

Bowling across the finish line off Baltimore Light at the edge of a squall, Walter N. Rothschild's Avanti from the western end of Long Island Sound looked like the winner in Class A of the ocean race from New London to this port tonight.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your editorial "The Housing Crisis" was timely. If our executives in Washington were more socially than politically minded they would hasten the passage of the Wagner-Steagall bill as a long-range rehousing plan and not advocate temporary grants.

Today is moving day for the visit to the R Mayor, and he plans to leave for if opportunity his Summer City Hall in the Chis- Lieut. Comm holm Mansion, College Point, at bach, who was 9:15 o'clock this morning after at- and Wilkins e: tending a 6 o'clock breakfast of the both the ship Association of Hospital and Medical Professionals at the Tavern-on- SUBWAY LiP the-Green in Central Park.

The eight seeded players in the Eastern intercollegiate tennis championship came through their thirdround tests at the Richmond County Country Club, Dongan Hills, S. I., yesterday, but several encountered strenuous opposition on the way.

Admiral William D. Leahy, chief of naval operations, has apologized in a letter to Secretary Hull for remarks concerning Russia that he made to the graduating class of the Army Industrial College on June 22, and has expressed regret if they had been regarded as a slighting reference to the Soviet Government or had caused offense. Secretary Hull announced receipt of the letter today but did not make it public.

Municipal DIRECTOR, BROOKLYN CANCER INSTITUTE. Salary: $4.500 per annum; penson; fair sick leave. Ages: Preferred 35 through 50, on July 16, 1937. Candidates not more than 55 may be admitted to this examination if they present qualifications sufficiently outstanding to warrant exception as to age. Vacancies: One, in the Department of Hospitals. Applications: Received 9 A. M., Thursday, July 1, to 4 P. M., Friday, July 16. Room 1400, Municipal Building, Manhattan.

Robert Low oF Choate continued his successful march in the Eastern private schools' tennis tourney at the Manursing Island Club today when he won his fourth-round engagement from Robert Terry of Groton, 6-1, 6-4.

Congress, when it established the United States Maritime Commission, set this midnight as the expiration of the period in which to arrange, as substitutes for mail contracts with twenty-eight shipping lines, new differential operating subsidies based on cost and other disparities between this country and competitors with merchant marines.

The presence of the President of the United States and the economic and political chasm between him the du Pont family made the wedding of Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. and Miss Ethel du Pont something of a spectacle rather than the mere social event it might have been.

Shrill, gleeful shouts echoed through Pennsylvania and Grand Central Stations last evening and resounded at bus terminals, boat piers and other points of exit from the city as hundreds of children, released from school, started for camps throughout the country.

All but two of the quarter-final brackets were filled in the New Jersey men's tennis championship at the Montclair Athletic Club today as favorites progressed unhampered. All places in the round of eight in the women's Eastern clay court championship were filled.

The closing of schools yesterday brought a ten-week holiday to nearly 1,250,000 children and 38,000 teachers and supervisors. Many of the pupils will attend Summer play schools, tutorial high schools and classes coached by WPA teachers.
In a session replete with political gibes and counter-thrusts, the Board of Estimate voted yesterday to restore about $9,480,000 that had been taken from 90,000 city employes in salary cuts.

A custom of hundreds of years' standing that the British royal family never engages in controversies was shattered by the Duke of Windsor today in an interview by telephone with a London newspaper characterizing as a "rotten story" remarks by Sir Gerald Wollaston, Garter King of Arms, that as King Edward VIII he had hurried arrangements for his father's funeral.
Dr. Forbes Robert McCreery of 123 East Fortieth Street, New York, retired physician, died yesterday at his Summer home here at the age of 72.
Reservations have been made by Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. and his bride on the liner Empress of Britain, sailing from Quebec for Liverpool, July 10. This was learned here today.
Russo-Japanese relations are again in a state of dangerous tension. Soon after Maxim Litvinoff, the Soviet Foreign Commissar, had promised Mamoru Shigemitsu, the Japanese Ambassador to Moscow,

The marriage of Miss Margaret Louise Bacon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Dewey Bacon, and Frank Dean Russell 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. F. Dean Russell of Seneca Parkway, took place this evening in St. Paul's Episcopal Church. Dr. George E. Norton officiated.

Senator Sil- vio Longhi, magistrate and author of a number of books on jurisprudence, died here today. He was 72 years old. Senator Longhi, a former president and procurator general at the Court of Cassation ir Rome, was regarded as the Italian Government's spokesman on legal changes in the kingdom.

Tommy Bridges's five-hit pitching, backed up by Hank Greenberg's seventeenth home run of the season and a timely triple by Billy Rogell, gave the Detroit Tigers a 4-1 victory over the Chicago White Sox today and ended the home club's winning streak at seven games.

Duty collections at the Port of New York gained. 21 per cent for the fiscal year ended yesterday compared with the preceding year, according to figures released yesterday by Harry M. During, Collector of Customs.

Miss Frances Elizabeth (Betty) Morris, daughter of Lewis Gouverneur Morris of this city and Newport and a descendant of Lewis Morris, signer of the Declaration of Independence, was married to Harold Whitfield Carhart Jr. yesterday afternoon in St. Ann's Church of Morrisania at 140th Street and St. Ann's Avenue.

Peering into the dusty darkness of the 205th Street station of the city's Eighth Avenue subway, fifty persons witnessed Bronx transportation history in the making when Charles H. Halley Jr., Transportation Commissioner, pressed yesterday afternoon a button which officially opened the first subway escalator in the "Borough of the Universities."

Richard T. Wharton of 155 East Seventy-seventh Street and Islip, L. I., has announced the engagement of his sister, Miss Marion Wharton, to Gerard Hallock 3d of Brooklyn, son of Mrs. Gerard Hallock and the late Mr. Hallock.
Miss Edwina Atwell was introduced to society tonight at a large outdoor supper dance given by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. George J. Atwell, at Greenridge, their Summer home in the Greenvale colony.
Trading on the New York Stock Exchange in June resulted in the smallest turnover for any month since March, 1935, when only 15,849,017 shares changed hands.

The work of Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, for international peace was honored to-day when a portrait plaque was unveiled on the wall of Dartmoutl House, the headquarters of the English-Speaking Union,

Louis Beitcher, confessed collector for racketeers shaking down restaurant operators, received a suspended sentence from Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook yesterday in return for the cooperation he gave Special Prosecutor Thomas E. Dewey in obtaining convictions of the principals in the extortion scheme.

Mis. Josephine Drake Smith, wife of Dr. John Vernon Smith, lied here yesterday at their resiience after an illness of several months. She was born in Newburgh, N. Y., a daughter of former Supreme Court Justice John H. Drake and Phoebe Belden Titus Drake, and a descendant, through her mother,

Manhattan Lexington Ave, 586 to 594, and 52d St, 130 ??; 100.5x90; for 1-story motion picture theatre and store; City Bank Farmers Trust Co., trustee. 22 William St., owner; Walker Gillette, architects; cost, $80,000. Broadway, 4,390; 47.5x92.9; for 7-story storage and store; the T. J. F. Holding Co., 4,396 Broadway, owner; Frederick O. Lewis, architect; cost, $85,000.

The Heckscher camp for children, founded by August Heckscher at Adams Corners, five miles north of this village, will open tomorrow for the eighth successive year. The first contingent arriving in camp will be 110 pre-school group children. On Friday the boy and girl camps will open with the arrival of 250 boys and 225 girls.

More than 200 persons from various walks of life are daily thronging the headquarters of the Northern Sea Route in Moscow asking to be sent to work at Arctic posts, according to Tass, the Soviet news agency. All have jobs, but are anxious to help conquer the Arctic.

Francis E. Frothingham, vice president of Coffin Burr, Inc., of Boston, has been selected by the board of governors of the Investment will Bankers Association of America as president for the year 1937-38.

Floyd B. Odlum, president of the Atlas Corporation, one of the nation's largest investment trusts, testiflying today at a Securities and Exchange Commission inquiry into investment trusts, said he favored regulation of investment - trusts "only to the extent that the public interest is involved."

Mrs. Margaret Eastman Sortor, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lucius Root Eastman of Axonwold. this place, formerly of Montclair, N. J., was married this afternoon at the home of her parents to Paul Cornell French of Amherst, Mass., son of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Howard Dean French.
Prices moved upward in bond trading on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday as buyers entered the market in larger numbers than in recent sessions.

Reports by 142 Class I railways to the Interstate Commerce Commission showed an aggregate net income of $2,666,735 in April, compared with a net loss of $2,192,586 in April, 1936. For the first four months the net was $16,802,485, comparing with a net loss of $29,768,076 in the same period last year.

Most of Mexico's cotton production, which is now developed on communal farms, has been put under State control and the government has informed cotton brokers they must give half of their profit on sales at world market prices to the government.

Less than twenty-four hours after he had been warned that he remained in the city at his own risk, James Mark, director of the strike against the Bethlehem Corporation here, announced at 7:30 o'clock to-night that the long-threatened massing of Central Pennsylvania's miners in sympathy with the strikers would be held at 2 P. M. Sunday in Faith's Grove, on the edge of Johnstown.

Speaking yesterday before the New York Financial Advertisers Association at its last monthly luncheon of the season, Allen E. Throop, general counsel of the Securities and Exchange Commission, made a strong plea for greater use of newspaper advertising in the marketing of new issues.

Stephen T. Early, secretary to the President, reaffirmed in a formal statement today that Acme News Pictures, Inc., and the Associated Press News Photo Service "temporarily" should not make pictures of President Roosevelt.

Miss Mary Virginia Barnes, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Wade Hampton Barnes of this city, was married this evening to Andrew Augustus Smith 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Andrew A. Smith Jr. of New York, in the Independent Presbyterian Church. The Rev. Dr. Henry M.

The retail price of milk will be increased 1 cent a quart, effective today, by the Sheffield Farms Company, the Borden Company and other distributors in the metropolitan area. The increase came coincidentally with an average increase of 1 cent a quart to be paid to the farmers under the agreement reached last week between prodoucer and distributor groups, the companies said.

Recommendations that brokerage commissions in the future be based directly on the dollar volume of the deal, rather than on the number of shares bought or sold, are expected to be presented to the governing committee of the New York Stock Exchange at a special meeting scheduled for this morning.

Adding 77s to yesterday's 76s, F. Bramwell Geddes and Alfred M. Morris, Scarsdale club-mates, finished in a tie for the Westchester senior golf championship -today at Westchester Hills, each with a thirty-six-hole gross score of 153.

Ernest Sutter of Tulane, national intercollegiate tennis champion, had a fight on his hands in the very first round of the Nassau Country Club invitation tournament today as the turf court fixture started with a strong field of thirtyfour players headed by Gregory S. Mangin.

Miss Catherine Elizabeth Igoe, daughter of Mrs. Andrew Joseph Igoe of Brooklyn and the late Mr. Igoe, was married yesterday in Holy Innocents Catholic Church, Brooklyn, to Dr. James Emerson Dailey, son of Mr. and Mrs. James Matthew Dailey of Olean, N. Y.
Agitation created by the promulgation of the amnesty law forgiving pro-Germans arrested during the World War is beginning to arouse deep concern in political and parliamentary circles.

Amparo Iturbi, Spanish pianist, sister of Jos6 Iturbi, will make her local concert d6but Wednesday evrening at the Lewisohn Stadium, playing with her brother the Mozart E flat concerto for two pianos and orchestra and three Spanish dances by Infante. Alexander Smallens will conduct the PhilharmonicSymphony Orchestra.

The joint Congressional committee investigating income tax avoidance and evasion was told by Treasury experts today that prominent persons had incorporated yachts, farms, racing stables, residences and personal talents, and by deducting individual losses on operation saved substantial taxes otherwise due to the government.

Timothy M. Spelman, composer, who several years ago acquired the former Brady property in Sterling Ridge, Rye, Westchester, has purchased thirteen acres on Woodlands and Sterling Road, and a contract is pending for the purchase of six additional acres in the same locality. The former Madden property in Sterling Ridge also has been purchased by Mr. Spelman. Cornelius Van Buren was the broker in the deals.

Establishing a new record for the event, Wilson Flohr of Canoe Brook, a Dartmouth freshmen, today scored a 69, one under par, to win the qualifying medal in the New Jersey State junior golf championship on the Montclair Golf Club course.

Power generated by the electric light and power industry in the United States during April was 13.1 per cent ahead of the same month in 1936, according to research statistics of the Edison Electric Institute.

The general election in Ireland tomorrow is attracting less attention and interest in Great' Britain than any of the other major events scheduled for that day. It is taken-for granted that President Eamon de Valera will be returned to power. He has gained prestige in the past three years.
Movements of livestock on the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow:

J. I. Kislak, Inc, has arranged a Vrzttortgage loan of $40,000 at 5 per cent ior ten years on 623 Bergenline Ave. West New York, for the 623 Bergenline Avenue Corp The property is a two-story brick business building adjoining the corner of Sixteenth St and Bergenine Ave...

In one of the most impressive events ever staged in the capital, more than 25,000 Boy Scouts, representing every State in the Union and twenty-five foreign countries, grouped over six acres near the base of the Washington Monument tonight to form the greatest campfire assemblage in the history of America.

Mrs. Sarah P. Duke, widow of Benjamin N. Duke, power and tobacco financier, left a net estate of $11,830,758 when she died on Sept. 2, 1936, at the age of 80, according to a transfer tax appraisal filed yesterday. Despite the size of the estate, it is not sufficient to pay all bequests in full after Federal and State taxes amounting to $5,696,757 are paid.

Miss Margaret Preston, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Veryl Preston of this city, was married in Grace Church yesterday afternoon to George Wellington Dillingham Symonds, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Hale Symonds of Warehouse Point, Conn. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. E. Felix Kloman.

The marriage of Mrs. Frances Peters Holmes of this city and Glen Head, L. I., to Harry Cooke Cushing of New York and Oxon Hill, Oyster Bay, took place yesterday afternoon in the bride's apartment at the Pierre. The Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman performed the ceremony in the presence of members of the two families.

The New England Telephone and Telegraph Company during the first five months of this year recorded a net gain of 36,575 telephone in service, as compared with a gain of 27,275 instruments in the similar 1936 period, according to an announcement yesterday by J. J. Robinson, president.

One of the most momentous yet most orderly election campaigns in the Irish Free State closed tonight and tomorrow the citizens will go to the polls not only to elect a new government, but also to approve a new constitution. When the campaign opened a fortnight ago few would care to forecast the result with any degree of certainty.

A new team record was established in the Eastern interscholastic golf championship today as Hill and Lawrenceville each notched 622 for four-man totals for thirty-six holes over the Greenwich Country Club course, 'where the amateur champions of tomorrow are competing for. honors.

Completing eleven of the seventeen rounds of the international chessmasters' tournament at the Kurhaus, the competitors, with the exception of those figuring in adjourned games, devoted their time today to sightseeing and resting in preparation for the twelfth round, scheduled for tomorrow, when Samuel Reshevsky, United States champion, the leader, will meet Salo Flohr of Czechoslovakia.

The French financial crisis continued to dominate the congress of the International Chamber of Commerce today, causing something like a snag to obstruct its work when differences of opinion developed between delegations over the resolution originally drafted to endorse a return to the gold standard.

Premier Benito Mussolini made two conciliatory gestures to Italian Jews today. He refused to accept the resignation of their governing body, the Council of the Union of Israelitic Communities in Italy, and ordered elaborate funeral services held for a Jewish lieutenant killed by Spanish Government airplanes.

Four hundred mothers and children from various parts of the city will be taken to Hoffman Island for outings every day through the Summer, beginning next Tuesday, as the result of a modification of Mayor La Guardia's original plan to establish a Summer camp for children there.
Following is the text of President Roosevelt's message to the Boy Scouts at their national jamboree: Fellow Scouts: Welcome to Washington.
A hundred Japanese geisha went on a "liedown" strike today, demanding an increase in fees for entertaining. Mediators are seeking to bring an agreement.

Daly's Theatre, where "No Sleep for the Wicked," by Delano L. Ames, cousin of President Roosevelt, opened tonight, is to become a London shopwindoww" cinema for Warner Brothers soon after the play ends its run.

Dr. Walter B. Pitkin, Columbia University professor and author, predicted here that 10,000,000 Americans who are socially and economically "almost at a Chinese coolie level of progress and culture" eventually would multiply and occupy stations similar to those of the coolies.
Frank Parker outplayed anu out generaled Donald Budge in the first set of their semi-finals today, allowing the mainstay of the American Davis Cup tennis team only two games.

The House moved into the breach caused by the Senate holiday and the absence of President Roosevelt today by passing a "stop-gap" resolution providing for the War and Interior Departments and other agencies whose appropriation bills were still pending as the end of the fiscal year approached at midnight tonight.

The Westchester Lighting Company, Mount Vernon, N. Y., wholly owned by the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., has filed a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering issuance of $25,000,000 of general mortgage bonds, 31/2 per cent series, due in 1967, which are guaranteed as to principal and interest by the parent company.

The Securities and Exchange Commission today called a hearing for July 27 on an application by the Chalmers Oil and Gas Company, Baltimore, for permission to withdraw from registration on the Baltimore Stock Exchange its $8 cumulative preferred stock, $5 par value.

A downtown investment deal was revealed yesterday when Charles F. Noyes announced that he had purchased the six-story basement and sub-basement building at 134-140 Grand Street, northeast corner of Crosby Street, from William D. and Samuel Kilpatrick. He immediately leased it to J. Rabinovich, furniture dealer, for warehouse purposes.

In another long game with plenty of hits and many pitchers, the Chicago Cubs defeated the St. Louis Cardinals again today, 9 to 4, to retain first place in the National League against a New York Giant threat.

By good generalship and ramming down putts when their golfing lives depended on it, the American team of golf professionals won the Ryder Cup today, 8 points to 4. Starting this blustering, soaking day with a lead of 23' to 1X, gained in the Scotch foursomes yesterday, they won five of the eight singles matches, halved another and lost two.

Dwight (Doc) Newport, who before his retirement in 1931 had served as trainer for the athletic teams at Amherst College for forty-eight years, died at his home here today of a heart ailment induced by a long siege with pneumonia. His age was 77.

The marriage of Miss Harriet Jenkins Richardson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Herbert Richardson of St. Paul, to Dr. Edward Sumner Brewster, son of Major Sidney Webber Brewster, U. S. Marine Corps (retired), and Mrs. Brewster of 180 East Seventyninth Street, took place last night in the Church of the Transfiguration. The rector, the Rev. Dr.
Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Marie Hamilton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James J. Hamilton of Albany, to John W. Cullen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph A. Cullen, also of Albany.

Miss Sarah Elizabeth Price, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Smith Price of this place, was married here tonight in the Rutherford Baptist Church to Dr. William James Lutton; also of Rutherford, son of Dr. and Mrs. William Bowie Lutton of Roselle. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Lester H. Clee of Newark, assisted by the pastor, the Rev. Paul H. Conrad.
Roy B. White, president of the Western Union Telegraph Company, said yesterday that his company's plant and equipment were in better condition now than they ever had been.
Copperweld Steel The Copperweld Steel Company declared yesterday a quarterly dividend of 50 cents a share, against 30 cents paid on March 1 and May 31.
Stocks closed higher, leading shares up 1 to 6 points; turnover, 688,570 shares. United States Government and corporate bonds higher, foreign loans irregular; transactions, $8.271.000.
Paulie Walker, welterweight boxer from Toronto, will square off against Teddy Loder of Yorkville in the Madison Square Garden ring tonight in the feature attraction, scheduled for eight rounds.

A truce was reached in the Inland steel strike when the C. I. O. agreed to a formula devised by Governor Townsend of Indiana. Youngstown also signs. Page 1. Mass call of 40,000 miners to Johnstown Sunday and union pleas for renewed martial law met that city's warning to strike leaders to leave town. Page 2.
United States sailors and Coast Guardsmen set watch tonight along one of the loneliest stretches of the earth's surface to guide Amelia Earhart on the longest, most hazardous flight of her career.
Harry T. Eggert, through A. V. Amy Co, in 1,212 Fifth Ave; Alan H. Bonito, in 277 Par}k Ave; William L. Desloge, in 111 E 60th St; Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc, broker.
Mrs. Markle Bannard entertained with a luncheon yesterday at the Weylin for Mr. and Mrs. Wallace Lincoln Pierce, Miss Eleanor Swift, Miss Elizabeth Bannard and Harold McL. Turner Jr.

William Lyon Mackenzie King, the Canadian Prime Minister, left Berlin tonight after a short visit which, he said, was "exceedingly enjoyable, profitable and, above all, most reassuring." In a prepared statement Mr. King said:
Mayor La Guardia will step aboard the first subway train to run direct between downtown Brooklyn and Queens today at 12:30 P. M., in the Queens Plaza station of the city's Independent Subway system.

A six weeks' exploring trip into the Canadian Arctic for research into the energy-releasing mechanism of Arctic mammals will start about Aug. 1, Dr. D. P. Quiring of the Western Reserve University Biology Department said today.

Luncheon, Rotary Club of New York, .Hotel Commodore, 12:15 P. M. Address by "General" Jacob S. Coxey. Luncheon, New York Young Republican Club, Lawyers Club, 115 Broadway, 12:45 P. M. "Problems of Criminal Investigation," J. Edward Lumbard Jr.

Electric power production showed a larger increase last week than allowed for by seasonal and longterm factors, and the adjusted index advanced to 106.6 from 106.4. It was 101.9 for the week ended June 27, 1936.

Ellis Parker Sr., chief of Burlington County detectives for forty-four years, was sentenced today to six years in Federal prison and his son, Ellis Parker Jr., to three years, for conspiracy to kidnap Paul H. Wendel. The sentences were pronounced by Federal Judge William Clark this morning.

A high wind and an overcast sky today kept the crowds that gathered along this picturesque stretch of the Thames to witness the opening of the Royal Henley regatta at a mere fraction of the numbers that attended last year.
Mrs. Anne Fish Hoyt obtained a divorce here today from Walter S. Hoyt of New York and Stamford, Conn., on charges of cruelty. An agreement for custody of their three children was filed.

A debate on resale price maintenance under State "fair-trade" laws, was a feature yesterday at a luncheon session of the International Association of Sales Executives at the Hotel Astor. Q. Forrest Walker, economist for R. H. Macy Co., Inc., argued against the laws, and State Senator A. Spencer Feld, co-author of the Feld-Crawford act, presented views in favor of price maintenance.

Aldermanic President William F. Brunner attacked Mayor La Guardia yesterday for having failed to carry out his campaign pledge to repeal the 50 per cent increase in water rates, when he spoke on a resolution to that effect before the General Welfare Committee of the Board of Aldermen.
The stock market here was dull today and most sections lost ground. Giltedge issues declined, and among the foreign bonds German loans, which had been fairly steady yesterday, declined.

Another contingent of the Medical Bureau to Aid Spanish Democracy sailed yesterday on board the Aquitania of the Cunard White Star Line, under the leadership of Dr. Samuel N. Franklin of Milwaukee There were thirteen doctors, nurses and ambulance drivers in the unit.

Despite unwanted rainfall in eastern sections of the Cotton Belt and a sharp recovery in the stock markets, prices on the Cotton Exchange here lost 5 to 12 points yesterday after receipt of private estimates of the highest end-of-June condition in several years.

Miss Betty Ritchie Kerr, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Chichester Charles Kerr of Llewellyn Park, was married this afternoon in Grace Episcopal Church, Orange, to Alastair Douglas Robertson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth Douglas Robertson of Hewlett, L. I. The ceremony was performed by the rector, the Rev. Dr. Charles T. Walkley, assisted by the Rev. Dr. Samuel S. Drury, headmaster of St. Paul's School, Concord, N. H.

A painting by Honor6 Daumier called "Children Under a Tree," has been acquired by the Toledo (Ohio) Museum of Art from M. Knoedler Co., Inc., as a gift from the founder of the museum, the late Edward Drummond Libbey.

Beginning tomorrow the American Merchant Marine, after nine years of operating under ocean mail "disguised" subsidies costing $20,000,000 to $30,000,000 annually, will switch to direct government subsides.

Plans of Anglo-Continentale Treuhand A. G. and Mondiale Handels und Verwaltungs A. G. for reorganization of the St. Louis Southwestern Railway (the Cotton Belt) were made public here yesterday by Harry Hoffman of New York, of counsel for the German intervenors. A brief of their proposals is expected to be filed today with the Interestate Commerce Commission.

Nikolaj Velimirovitch, Bishop of Ochrida, called down anathema on the heads of all Orthodox Christians supporting the concordat with the Vatican which the government is reported to be trying to force Parliament to ratify.

While most of Broadway was sitting- around yesterday afternoon waiting for something to happen, a mild flurry started in West Fortyfifth Street on the emanation of a rumor from the Music Box. It was to the effect that the new George S. Kaufman-Moss Hart musical comedvy. which will have George M.

An extension of ninety days in the limit of time allowed to shipping come panies to comply with the new safety at sea regulations promulgated by the Bureau of Marine Inspection and Navigation was voted today in the House. A similar measure is expected to pass the Senate tomorrow or the next day. The law was to have gone into effect tomorrow.

A one-day strike of seamen employed by the New England Steamship Company which tied up seven ships in three services, was settled last night at a conference of shipline officials and representatives of the crews in New Bedford.

Women workers in the pig iron department of the big Fukuoka Iron Works, dismissed on the grounds that their husbands were employed in the same plant, announced today they would get divorces in order to regain their jobs.

Frauds of certain types have increased decidedly in recent months, it is asserted in the report of the Better Business Bureau of New York City, covering the operations of the investors' section of the bureau for the year ended on May 1.

The leasehold on the Rialto Theatre property at the northwest corner of Broadway and Forty-second Street has changed hands in one of the largest realty transactions of recent years in the Times Square district.

Miss Evelyn Marie McCausland, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank M. McCausland of Brooklyn, was married at noon yesterday in the Lady Chapel of St. Patrick's Cathedral to Kenneth Albert Johnson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Johnson, also of Brooklyn. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Walter P. Kellenberg.

The Guaranty Trust Company has been appointed registrar for the nopar common stock of the Ohio Oil Company. John P. Dalton, formerly president of the First National Bank of Paterson, N. J., is with Van Deventer, Spear Co.

Asserting that the fiscal year closed today with an accumulated State deficit of about $20,000,000 and a bonded debt of $500,000,000, Senator Thomas C. Desmond of Newburgh said in a statement today that the State's financial policies need revision.
Receipts of gold at New York in June, as reported by the Federal Reserve Bank, were the largest for any month since June, 1936. Great Britain led in shipments of the metal.

Contracts for engineering construction awarded during June totaled $274,399,000, the highest for the month since 1930 and 49 per cent above the June, 1936, total of $183,917,000, according to The Engineering News-Record. The cumulative total for the first six months of the year, $1,245,428,000, represents a gain of 15 per cent over the same period of last year, when the figure was $1,121,375,000.
William Park, president and treasurer of the Riverside Woolen Mills and William Park Sons, died at his home last night, after an illness of several months, at the age of 76.

Each of the following Dental Corps Reserve officers is ordered to active duty, effective July 8, at Camp Dix, N. J., for training: 1st Lt. Milton Fishman, 439th Engr. Bn. (Sep.), 1,475 Grand Concourse, Bronx, N. Y. 1st Lt. Joseph Miller, 154th Station Hosp. (R.A.I.), 1,540 E. 29th St., Brooklyn, N. Y.

About 1,000 persons attended the annual fair at St. Johnland this afternoon on the grounds and in the buildings of the institution for the benefit of the aged and children supported by the society. The dedication of the new St. Johnland baby shelter and an auction sale conducted by John M. Mitchell of Greenwich, Conn., were features of the entertainment which included a continuous program from 1 P. M. until 9:30.

Undivided profits of the United States Trust Company of New York rose from $2,510,824 to $2,715,276 in the first half of 1937, according to figures made public today. -Deposits rose from $77,606,506 at the beginning of the year to $85,591,791 on July 1. Resources climbed from $110,114,765 to $118,253,844.
More than forty telegraph wire circuits set up in a press field tent, with fifty operators, provided quick outlets for fifty reporters' copy on the .Roosevelt-du Pont wedding.

Miss Charlotte Lambert Clark, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas H. Clark of Springfield, N. J., was married today to Lee K. Waring Jr., son of Mrs. Lee K. Waring of Elizabeth, N. J., and the late Mr. Waring,

Governor Lehman tonight issued a statement on the dissolution of the State Temporary Emergency Relief Administration, which is to be taken over tomorrow by the State Department of Social Welfare, and paid tribute to those who had labored in the public interest.

Pensioned ON THEIR OWN APPLICATIONS To take effect 12 midnight, June 30: SERGEANT-James F. Boylan, 120th Preinct, at $1,750 per annum. Appointed fan. 24, 1912. PATROLMEN-George Werner, Traffic Precinct C, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed lune 18, 1912. Patrick J. Quinn, 18th Division, M. O. D. D., at $1,500 per annum. Appointed Feb. 28. 1907.

Paul van Zeeland, Premier of Belgium, sailed for home yesterday on the French liner Normandie. He was strictly noncommittal about the results of his informal talks with President Roosevelt, but expressed the highest admiration for the President and said he found him "a most extraordinary personality."
Heywood Broun, president of the American Newspaper Guild, issued the following statement yesterday: "The publishers should have brought a copy reader with them to the convention in Chicago.

Matthew Woll, vice president of the American Federation of Labor, arrived here this afternoon and attended a meeting of the general council of the International Federation, of Trade Unions as a fraternal delegate.
Many manufacturing concerns were numbered among the principals in the lists of business leases reported yesterday. Several other contracts for space involved various labor organizations.

Attended by an admiring crowd of middle-aged women, Robert Irwin, the egocentric young sculptor who has. admitted the murder of Veronica Gedeon, her mother and a roomer in their home, followed the maze of official red tape yesterday to a formal plea of not guilty in General Sessions.

The War Department released the following orders today, dated June 29: COLONELS McDonald, D. . (F. A.), Bureau of Insular Affairs, seven days' leave, June 7. Cotton, R. C., Inf. Stillwater, Okla., to 18th Inf., Ft. Wadsworth, N. Y.

Alfred P. Sloan Jr., chairman of the General Motors Corporation, issued a statement yesterday revealing that he and his wife received income during 1936 totaling $2,876,310. Of this he said they paid Federal and State income taxes of $1,725,790 and split the remaining $1,150,520 evenly between charity and themselves.

Trading in lamb was slow, and some cuts were lower. Demand for other classes was fair and prices little changed. Early trading in kosher meats indicated beef to be slightly stronger in spots, veal steady to firm, lamb weak, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.
Miss Flora MacDonald, society editor of The Washington Times, and John W. Joslin were married this afternoon at the New York Avenue Presbyterian Church. The Rev. Albert Evans officiated.

Some of the gowns in Miss Ethel du Pont's trousseau were described to the press a few hours before the ceremony. The du Pont family gave out details of the costumes of the bride and her attendants. The bride desired to observe the tradition that her finery should be kept a secret until she came down the aisle of the church with her attendants.

More than $8,500,000 worth of orders for Fall furniture have been placed by the 4,300 buyers visiting the New York Furniture Exchange in the nine business days of the annual Fall trade opening, according to unofficial estimates by producers, officials of the Exchange and others yesterday. The buying has centered chiefly on goods for immediate delivery and on sample lots of merchandise for early Fall shipment.

Close of play scores in English first-class cricket matches started today follow: Worcestershire, 163 (Goddard, 7 for 84): Gloucestershire, 41 for 5 wickets, at Dudley. Kent, 209 (Davies, 89; Smith, 5 for 95); Leicestershire, 127 for 6 wickets, at Tunbridge Wellis.

The aggregate of dividends declared in June was less than the total for May, but substantially larger than the total for June, 1936. Payments of $375,851,284 were voted by 1,503 companies in June, against $524,198,349 by 993 companies in May and $294,880,158 by 1,345 companies in June, 1936.

A new issue of $375,000 of bonds of Miami Beach, Fla., for construction of a golf course was awarded yesterday to a syndicate composed of John Nuveen Co., the Wells-Dickey Company, Childress Co., Inc., and the Miami Beach First National Bank on a bid of 98.32 for 3.32s.

Few manufacturers in the "handmade" industries are carrying on operations in Puerto Rico at present, it was indicated here yesterday, pending the outcome of injunction proceedings filed by manufacturers against Commissioner of Labor Rivera Martinez against enforcement of the $1 a day Minimum Wage Law of 1919.

THE field-working anthropologists are perhaps the nearest modern kin to the seaman explorers of Elizabeth's day who brought back the strange lore from the maps' white spots that went into Hakluyt's reports of voyages and Shakespeare's plays. While stay-at-home philosophers filled the world with mind-born monsters, the adventuring seamen found out facts.

Warning that business progress and employment were being seriously disturbed by continued fomenting of violence in employment relations, the nation's organized manufacturers appealed today for the cooperation of "responsible labor organizations" in eliminating all conduct that causes "irritation, resentment and disorder."

For the second time within nine months the gold value of the franc is to sink, this time because the French unit of currency has been cut adrift from the gold content limitations imposed Oct. 1, 1936.

Copper prices again were slightly easier yesterday in the foreign market. Sales were made between 13.75 and 13.85 cents a pound, c.i.f., European base ports, compared with 13.80 to 13.85 cents on Tuesday. The domestic price was unchanged at 14 cents.

Several important new provisions in Banking Law will become effective today. In the case of both national and State banks, the double liability on their capital shares will cease today for those institutions which have given at least six months' prior notice of their inten tion to terminate the liability. Practically all important banks have published the required notice.

Confronted by pictures of the Memorial Day riot showing a fleeing crowd of steel strikers near the Republic Steel plant, high officials of the Chicago Police Department told the La Follette subcommittee today that seven men killed by bullets in the back were shot in self-defense by policemen. Three died of wounds in the side.

Hugh F. McElroy Jr. gave a large reception with music this afternoon in the new Merry-Go-Round Room of the Seven Ponds Inn. Among those invited were Mr. and Mrs. Goodhue Livingston, Mr. and Mrs. Josiah Copley Thaw, Mrs. Eliot Betts Hoadley, Mr. and Mrs. Robert Malcolm Littlejohn, Mr.

Throughout today wires between London, Paris, Rome and Berlin have been buzzing--between Rome and Berlin especially-in an effort to salvage something out of what appeared last, night to be the wreck of the nonintervention agreement.

Memorial services presided over by Supreme Court Justice Thomas J. Cuff were held here today in Part 1 of the Supreme Court for Supreme Court Justice Paul Bonynge, who died yesterday at his home in Locust Valley.

The contract for the $58,000,000 PWA financed East River Tunnel to Queens was formally awarded at 11 o'clock last night to the Walsh Construction Company of New York in the offices of Arthur S. Tuttle, State Director of the Federal Public Works Administration, 2 Lafayette Street.

To reproduce at the New Yorlk World's Fair the tradition, spirit and atmosphere of Vienna, a project to be called "Vienna, City of Song," will include reproductions of famous theatres, cabarets, shops, restaurants and cafes against a background of miniature Alps, it was announced yesterday by the Committee for the Presentation of Austrian Art, Science and Culture at the New York World's Fair.

Britain recaptured the heavier-than-air altitude record from Italy today when Lieutenant M. J. Adam of the Royal Air Force ascended 53,937 feet in an official test under the auspices of the Air Ministry.

The instability of fame was demonstrated yesterday when an investigation of the knocking down of a statue in Riverside Park at 104th Street opened difficulties in identifying the subject of the memorial.
National League Philadelphia at New York-Walters vs. Melton. Brooklyn at Boston-Hoyt vs. MacFayen. Chicago at St. Louis-Lee vs. Dean.

Imports of merchandise into Colombia from the United States during the eleven months which have elapsed since the effective date of the, reciprocal trade agreement between the two countries--June, 1936, to April, 1937-were valued at approximately $32,246,950,
The steel strike has been followed here in the Mahoning River valley, center of operations for Republic Steel and Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company, by bitter hostility toward the C. I. O.

Several persons were injured, women's dresses were ripped and one man was arrested today in a clash between A. F. L. and C. I. O. garment workers at the plant of the Stone Knitting Mills Company here.

The marriage of Miss Barbara Parker, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Richard Parker of Greenwich, Conn., to Clifford Jewett Swift Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Clifford J. Swift of Columbus, took place here this afternoon at Green Island Ranch, the home of Mr. and Mrs. R. Curtis Jordan. The Rev. H. G. Walker performed the ceremony.
King George and Ambassador Robert W. Bingham of the United States were honored with high Masonic degrees tonight at a special meeting of the United Grand Lodge of England in Royal Albert Hall.

The following table shows the names of the 190 employes whose salaries were increased by the Board of Estimate over the amounts recommended by Budget Director Leo J. McDermott with both the recommended salaries and those voted yesterday by the Board of Estimate..

The qualifying round pace - setters, topped by Medalist Willie Turnesa of Holy Cross, developed slices, hooks and putting jitters in the national intercollegiate golf championship's opening match play competition today and wound up on Oakmont's sidelines.

Leading stocks rallied 1 to 3 points yesterday, and a few issues showed gains on the day that were better than that. The volume of business gained moderately, with the turnover on the Stock Exchange amounting to 688,000 shares, against 553,000 the day before.

A letter from President Roosevelt felicitating the delegates to the fortieth anniversary convention of the Zionist Organization of America was received yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Stephen S. Wise, president of the group. The President congratulated Dr. Wise on his re-election as president of the organization on Tuesday.

Group C, comprising manufacturers of millinery wholesaling from $10.50 to $15, has now been organized, it was announced yesterday by Maxwell E. Lopin, counsel for the Eastern Women's Headwear Association.

Louis Paul, whose first short story, "No More Trouble for Jedwick," won the 0. Henry Memorial Prize in 1934, has completed a novel that will be published late in July by Doubleday, Doran. It is the story of a woman who started a business career with a hole-in-thewall coffee shop and developed as the owner of a chain of restaurants. The title is "Emma."

Two persons were injured yesterday afternoon when a service elevator in a twenty-story loft building at 150 West Thirtieth Street, which was carrying twenty-six passengers, including the operator, dropped from the sixteenth floor to the basement.
Stocks of domestic and foreign crude petroleum in the United States on June 19 amounted to 307,465,000 barrels, the Bureau of Mines reported to-day.

FRANK A. VANDERLIP was one of those " self-made " Americans who, according to the ideology now fashionable, can no longer exist. To help support his family as a boy he gave up school and got a job in a machine shop for 75 cents a day.

Asserting there had been partisanship shown in selecting the names of alleged income tax evaders, Representative Fish of New York offered today to appear before the Joint Tax Evasion Committee with evidence he said would show that President Roosevelt and members of his Cabinet were using loopholes in the laws to avoid taxes.
Censure of Yale University for its dismissal of Professor Jerome Davis was voted by the National Education Association today by unanimous adoption of the report of its committee on tenure.

The annual mother and daughter tournament of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association was won by the accurate short game of Mrs. Frank Adel and her well-known golfing daughter, Mrs. Ruth Adel Torgerson at the Women's National Club today.

A new issue of $750,000 Macon Gas Company (Macon, Ga.) first mortgage 4 1/2 per cent bonds, dated June 1, 1937, and due on June 1, 1952, will be placed on the market today by Chandler Co., Inc., and G. L. Ohrstrom Co., Inc. The bonds will be priced at 92, to yield about 5.27 per cent.

Wilbert Sheridan Beaumont, former varsity football player at the University of Pennsylvania, died of a heart attack today at his home in Margate. He was graduated from the Wharton School of Finance and Commerce in 1930, having gone to Pennsylvania from the Atlantic City High School.

Terence A. Brady and The Yorkers Record Corporation, a publishing concern of which he is president, were fined $2,000 and were ordered to suspend publication of an "obscene and lewd" newspaper I today by Supreme Court Justice Lee Parsons Davis.

The amount of bonds called for redemption before maturity was larger in June than in May, but the volume was the smallest for that month in three years. The aggregate for all groups in June was $181,989,000, compared with $134,925,000 in the preceding month and $304,088,000 in June, 1936.

At 11 o'clock last night a hostile naval demonstration occurred off the port of La Mola on the island of Minorca, according to a message the Ministry of National Defense received today from the commander of the Port Mahon naval base.

A jury before Federal Judge John W. Clancy brought in a verdict of guilty yesterday against Ralph A. Freundlich, doll manufacturer of 801 Broadway, who was accused in a four-count indictment of having committed perjury in 1934 during his testimony before a special master in a copyright infringement suit.

Richard G. Cullivan, serving his fourth year as this city's Mayor, died in Oswego Hospital last night after an illness of eight weeks. Mayor Cullivan is the first chief executive to die in office here.
The Amur River border between Siberia and Manchukuo has been under almost constant dispute from the time the Manchurian adventure of Japan led to the creation of Manchukuo.

Confronted by the insatiable steel demands of the government's rearmament L program and an acute shortage of raw materials, the British steel industry has been driven to imitate Germany and Italy in turning to barns and lumber-rooms for scrap iron.

The General Electric Company signed a contract yesterday for 68,339 square feet of space on the New York World's Fair site and will erect a large building designed to show the achievements of electricity.
Rather than submit his pet Jers6y cows, Molly and Sylvia, to tests by the State for the eradication of bovine tuberculosis, Robert Gibson, lawyer, ordered them shot.

A prediction that England would recognize General Franco, leader of the Fascist Rebels in Spain, to maintain the peace of Europe was made here tonight by Dr. Robert McElroy, Harmsworth Professor of American History at Oxford University. He spoke at the Southern meeting of the National Conference of Jews, Catholics and Protestants. The five-day session is being held at the University of North Carolina.
Financing of the housing project for the site of the Marshall Field residence at 3-5 East Sixtyninth Street and 4-8 East Seventieth Street was announced yesterday by Lawrence, Blake Jewell, Inc.,

Years before the Wagner Labor Relations Act was first thought of, the American press began dealing collectively, and successfully, with nationally organized trades unions. At all times during the long history of these negotiations the trade unions have been represented by spokesmen of their own choosing.

Funeral services for Frank A. Vande-lip, international financier, who died yesterday in New York, will be held at 11 A. M. tomorrow at Beechwood, his estate here. The home had been closed during his illness but was reopened by the family today.

Two houses in the Riverdale section of the Bronx changed hands while under construction and were completed according to specifications of the buyers. Joseph and Meyer Goldstein sold to Mrs. Bessie Druckman the house at 405 West 259th Street and to the 2,322 University Corporation, James J. Carroll, president, the adjoining house at 401. Lester A. Kent, attorney, represented the sellers, and Max Miller acted for Mrs. Druckman.

The staff of the regional office of the National Labor Relations Board has been almost doubled with the opening of the new headquarters in the Woolworth Building, and cases can now be handled with less delay, Mrs. Elinore M. Herrick, regional director, announced yesterday.

Hanns Kerrl, the Minister for Church Affairs, issued today two decrees calculated to silence all agitation against the government's policy toward the Protestant Church and to place control of the church's finances completely in his hands.

The Pope has appointed the new Nuncio, Mgr. Cortesi, to act as canon of the Wawel Cathedral at Krakow for the duration of the visit of King Carol of Rumania. Customarily Archbishop Sapieha acts as canon on such occasions.

Applications for final allowances for services as receivers in equity and trustees in reorganization proceedings for the Bush Terminal Company and its subsidiary corporations were filed yesterday in the Federal court in Brooklyn by C. Walter Randall and James C. Van Siclen.

Four golfers who were recovering from a severe electrical shock today told this story: A thunderstorm caught them as they played the seventh hole. Huddled under an umbrella, each grasped its handle by one hand. Each held a steel-shafted golf club in his other hand, with the club head resting on the ground.

W. E. Hamilton, a construction P engineer, testified yesterday in Su- lP preme Court that he had appraised n the equipment of E. L. Phillips b Co. at $307,000 a short time before f( it was sold to the Long Island o' Lighting Company for $200,000. The rf fi equipment had been valued by Phil- if lips Co. at $600,000 a short while a before that. he said. o.

Harry G. Marquis, former manager of the now defunct Maytown Club, Inc., operator of a social club in Fifty-seventh Street, was accused yesterday in a Federal indictment of having failed to pay the tax on dues of $27,792 collected between May and December 1934.

Captain George J. Gallagher, in charge of the Brooklyn homicide squad, announced yesterday that he had issued about twenty subpoenas to strike guards of a private detective agency, strikers and the two owners, Irving and Hyman Fein, of the Fine Tin Can Company, 284 Furman Street, Brooklyn, when a striker was killed last week.
Officials at the Republic Steel Corporation's South Buffalo mill hauled out the "No more help wanted" sign today after they said they had received applications from 800 men in two days.

The Boy Scouts of America has a permanent charter, granted by an act of Congress in June of 1916. It was already on the march, but it then received official recognition as a "body "corporate and politic of the District "of Columbia, where its domicile shall "be."

In anticipation of the emergency, predicted by some experts, when the nation will be confronted with a dwindling reserve of certain fuels, particularly oil and gas, the United States Bureau of Mines has established an experimental station at Pittsburgh to search for a commercially practical technique to obtain oil and other more concentrated fuels from coal,

The visit of Paul van Zeeland, Premier of Belgium, is only one of a series that probably will take place in coming months between United States and foreign officials in an effort to facilitate international economic cooperation and thus lay the basis for enduring peace, according to Secretary of State Cordell Hull.
David Phillips, Boy Scout, of Fort Worth, reported today that a protracted "swap" netted him a Florida alligator and 50 cents to boot.

The possibility that Cuba will enact legislation that will attempt more equally to distribute sugar industry profits was seen last night when Colonel Fulgencio Batista, the army chief of staff, asserted he and Secretary of Agriculture Amadeo Lopez had put the finishing touches to "a law which will coordinate all factors of sugar production."

Passenger flying within a year or two from coast to coast and across the Atlantic in twelve hours or less, at a height of six miles where storms are practically unknown and the sun shines 90 per cent of the time, is the goal of experiments in the stratosphere, carried on quietly this year by the Army Air Corps in California.

Charges that the government had failed to halt a "labor despotism" in the United States were made in the House today by Representative Cox of Georgia, who asserted that the South would not tolerate the "lawless plan of organization of the Committee for Industrial Organization and John L. Lewis."
A sweeping, reorganization of the Manchukuoan Government was announced today with the formation of a new Cabinet, headed by General Chang Chinghui as Premier.

RKO's "New Faces of 1937," the first of a series of annual musicals, presenting Joe Penner, Milton Berle; Parkyakarkus, Harriet Hilliard, Thelma Leeds, Bill Brady and the comedy dance team of Lowe, White and Stanley, opens at noon today at the Radio City Music Hall.

Miss Frances Claire De Vogel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Mathew De Vogel of this place, and Leonard J. Baker, son of Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas Baker, also of Clifton, were married tonight at the First Holland Reformed Church of Passaic. The Rev. Lawence J. Borst officiated.

THEY were two regulars from the race track and they agreed that there had been three "grand coups" in betting circles in recent times. The one in California was the smartest. The one involving the Australian horse was the softest.
Two benefits are conferred on this community by the creation of the Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation to promote interest in the school of painting which is called abstract or non-objective.

Mayor La Guardia, Borough President James J. Lyons of the Bronx, the Most Rev. James E. Kearney, Bishop of Salt Lake were among the guests who paid tribute last night to Joseph F. Lamb, newly elected state deputy of the Knights of Columbus.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated June 28: CAPTAINS Johnson, R. H.. Newport, R. I., to Norfolk Navy Yard, Portsmouth, Va., in September. Leutze, T. W., Norfolk Navy Yard to Naval Supply Depot, Norfolk, Va., as officer In charge.

The marriage of Mrs. Catherine Root Browne of this city to Alexander Wells Peck of Litchfield, Conn., took place yesterday morning at the Central Presbyterian Church. The pastor, the Rev. Dr. Theodore C. Speers, officiated, in the presence of the near relatives and a few friends.
Unfortunately, when people say "A plague on both your houses" it means that they wash their hands of the
Mrs. Anne Robertson, whose discharge from the Fisher Body Company plant here caused a three-day sitdown strike that put 1,500 men out of work two weeks ago, went back to her job today.

One pitch at Shibe Park today robbed Lefty Gomez of a no-hit, no-run game. Pitching his southpaw hooks and slants with bewildering perfection, Gomez gave up one hit in what was easily one of the season's masterful pitching performances.

Thirty-seven school teachers, nine of them women, were arrested at 1 o'clock this morning and charged with a Federal offense after they had broken into and upset, according to the police, the administration offices of the Recreational Unit of the WPA, 167 West Sixty-fourth Street.

United States Senator A. Harry Moore formally announced tonight his candidacy for the Democratic Gubernatorial nomination and, as on three previous occasions when he became a candidate for a major office, he made the announcement at the annual bazaar of St. James's Roman Catholic Church in the Parish Hall at 142 Jefferson Street, here.
