The Empire City race meeting will begin today at the Yonkers course with John Hay Whitney's three-time stake winner, Inhale, pitted against Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt's unbeaten Balking, who equalled a world record in California. Theese two help make up the field of eight named for the $5,000 Demoiselle Stakes, a juvenile test at the short six-furlong distance which will feature the program.

Benny Friedman and his football staff have been reappointed for next Fall, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Frederick B. Robinson, president of C. C. N. Y. Friedman, named for the fourth successive season as a member of the instruction staff, and his three assistants, Paul Riblett, Eugene Berkowitz and Adolph Cooper, will serve for one year more.

The authority of the Federal District Court in Massachusetts to grant injunctions against holding of hearings by the National Labor Relations Board was assailed in a petition filed today with the Supreme Court by the board.

The Daily Bulletin says today that the Philippine Government soon will force an involuntary insolvency upon the Philippine Railway Company, which has not been able to pay the principal on it 4 per cent first-mortgage bonds, due today.

WASHINGTON, June 30.-The Securities and Exchange Commission heard testimony today in connection with an application by the New York Stock Exchange for permission to strike from registration and listing on that Exchange the common stock of the Pierce Petroleum Corporation. It took the case under advisement.
The British Government has sent friendly but emphatic advice to the French Government in the last few days to overhaul its budgetary methods and bring them into conformity with British practice.

A much higher cost of living and a period of rising commodity prices were forecast tonight by Dr. Edwin W. Kemmerer, Walker Professor of International Finance at Princeton University, in an address here at the Graduate School of BanKing, conducted jointly by the American Bankers Association and Rutgers University.
President Roosevelt. approved today a bill providing for the acceptance by the Secretary of the Interior of a site in New York City for a memorial to the Gold Star Mothers of the World War.

Friends of the President who have been hoping for months that he would speak out clearly on the labor situation will be disappointed by the statement he has now made. His only remark is that he believes the country as a whole is saving of the strike:"

ALEXANDER-Bernat, beloved husband of the late Hilda, dear father of Helen Gross and Edna, darling grandfather of Wilmur and Eugene. Services at Park West Memorial Chapel, 115 West 79th St.. Friday, July 2, at 10 A. M. Kindly omit flowers.
Queen Wilhelmina of the Netherlands has conferred upon Hendrik Willem van Loon the order of Orange Nassau with the rank of officer, it was announced yesterday by the National Broadcasting Company.

The month of June brought a moderate decline in industrial activity, attributed in part to seasonal influences, but chiefly to the strikes in the steel, automobile and other industries, says the National City Bank in its current monthly bulletin, published yesterday.
Police forcibly expelled forty American Federation of Labor sit-down strikers from the Freihofer Baking Company plant here late tonight, while 160 C. I. O. members continued to work.

The rise in the city's birth rate, indicating that there will be an increase in the rate this year, the first time since 1928, was attributed yesterday by Thomas J. Duffield, Registrar of Deeds of the Health Department, largely to vast Federal, State and local relief expenditures and to the recent general improvement in business and industry.
A collection of ancient locks and keys recently brought from abroad by Charles Courtney of 630 Fifth Avenue has been sold by him to the Yale Towne Manufacturing Company, it was announced yesterday.
Four brand-new fathers left the alloy mills of Republic Steel Corporation today. They had never seen their children. The four are Victor Snyder, Charles Oakley, John R. Wilson and E. J. Allred.

The marriage of Miss Alice Rose Kelly, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael E. Kelly of Brooklyn, to Harry J. McLaughlin, son of Mrs. Joseph McLaughlin of Great Neck, L. I., and the late Mr. McLaughlin, took place yesterday at St. Saviour's Roman Catholic Church, Brooklyn. Mgr. William Conklin officiated.

Additional steel mills opened tonight after a hard-won "back-to-work" thrust here. Eight persons were injured and seventy-five pickets arrested in a rock-throwing melee as National Guardsmen began evacuation of 2,000 non-strikers interned in the Canton plant of Republic Steel since May 25 and guarded other workmen moving in to take their places.
King George and Queen Elizabeth will hold their last Buckingham Palace court of the season tomorrow, when fourteen American women and many others will be presented to the monarchs.
The House passed today and sent to the Senate a resolution by Representative Merritt of New York authorizing a $3,000,000 appropriation for Federal participation in the 1939 World's Fair in New York.

Ethel du Pont, now Mrs. Franklin Delano Roosevelt Jr., is 21 years old, slender, with a delicate oval face, blue eyes and light brown hair. She dresses very simply, mostly in sports clothes, for she is a sports enthusiast.

Movements of vessels follow; all dates are June 29 unless specified: Puget Sound Yard to San Francisco: Fox, Oklahoma. At Coco Solo: Nokomis, S-1, 30. Acushnet, Naval Operating Base, Norfolk to Annapolis, June 30. Bobolink. Mare Island Yard to San Pedro, June 30.

The marriage of Miss Dorothy Knox Goodyear, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edmund Pendleton Rogers of New York and East Aurora, and Clinton Randolph Wyckoff Jr. of this city took place here this afternoon in Westminster Presbyterian Church. The Rev. Dr. Albert C. Putzer officiated.

President Roosevelt signed the $1,500,000,000 Relief Bill today. It provides $1,325,000,000 for the WPA, $100,000,000 for the Resettlement Administration and $75,000,000 for the National Youth Administration for use in the fiscal year beginning tomorrow.

Movements of vessels follow; all dates are June 29 unless specified: Puget Sound Yard to San Francisco: Fox, Oklahoma. At Coco Solo: Nokomis, S-1, 30. Acushnet, Naval Operating Base, Norfolk to Annapolis, June 30. Bobolink. Mare Island Yard to San Pedro, June 30.

The marriage of Miss Dorothy Knox Goodyear, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edmund Pendleton Rogers of New York and East Aurora, and Clinton Randolph Wyckoff Jr. of this city took place here this afternoon in Westminster Presbyterian Church. The Rev. Dr. Albert C. Putzer officiated.

President Roosevelt signed the $1,500,000,000 Relief Bill today. It provides $1,325,000,000 for the WPA, $100,000,000 for the Resettlement Administration and $75,000,000 for the National Youth Administration for use in the fiscal year beginning tomorrow.
Declining steel business and vacation shut-downs for certain plants have brought a sharp drop in ingot production in the Pittsburgh and Wheeling areas, according to Iron Age.

After seven years of service as "Wall Street's policeman," or chairman of the New York Stock Exchange's business conduct committee, Allen L. Lindley of Shields Co. has resigned. He will continue to serve the committee as vice chairman and he is being sucneeded by Howland S. Davis, former vice chairman.

Charles P. Taft 2d, chairman of the Federal Steel Mediation Board, sailed yesterday for England on the Cunard White Star liner Aquitania to attend the World Conference on Church, State and Community, to be held at Oxford from July 2 to July 28.

No more applications for allotments for non-Federal projects will be accepted by the Public Works Administration, under a staff order issued today by Secretary Ickes in accordance with Section 206 of the 1937 act authorizing PWA to continue in operation until July 1, 1939.

George L. Plant has been named personnel administrator and assistant to James L. Schoff, vice president and general manager of L. Bamberger Co., Newark, N. J., it was announced yesterday. Mr. Plant has resigned as manager of the bureau of employee relations and of the store managers' division of the National Retail Dry Goods Association. Channing E. Sweitzer, managing director of the association, said yesterday no announcement was ready as to a successor.

Terming their present rent schedules "inadequate," the Emergency Relief Bureau presented a preliminary report yesterday to the Board of Estimate covering housing conditions of 81,000 of the city's 150,000 relief recipients in an appeal for a $300.000 contingency fund.
The House passed today and sent to the Senate a resolution by Representative Merritt of New York authorizing a $3,000,000 appropriation for Federal participation in the 1939 World's Fair in New York.

Ethel du Pont, now Mrs. Franklin Delano Roosevelt Jr., is 21 years old, slender, with a delicate oval face, blue eyes and light brown hair. She dresses very simply, mostly in sports clothes, for she is a sports enthusiast.

The report of the Consolidated Gas, Electric Light and Power Company of Baltimore and its wholly owned subsidiaries for the twelve months ended May 31, issued yesterday, shows a consolidated net income, after interest, depreciation, amortization.

The Marine Midland Trust Company has been appointed successor trustee under the trust agreement of the Mortgage Bank of Colombia, securing $1,551,000 of twenty-year 7 per cent sinking fund goad bonds of 1927 and $1,985,000 of twentyyear 6 1/2 per cent sinking fund gold bonds.

Woodycrest Ave (9-2510); e s. 143 ft s of 168th St, 100x100; Richnorma Holding Corp to Lawrence S. La Rosa, 910 Summit Ave; mtg, $11,250. Duncan St (16-4636), n s, 50 ft w of Paulding Ave. 50x100; Bronx County Trust Co, executor, to Caroline Gleeson, 985 Duncan St.
A motion picture division is being created under the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce in the Department of Commerce, Secretary Roper said today.

In an application for listing of securities submitted to the New York Stock Exchange, the Liquid Carbonic Corporation, Delaware, and its subsidiaries reported yesterday a revised net profit of $275,030 for the six months ended on March 31.

The Massachusetts Institute of Technology is to make a detailed survey of the progress of its graduates in one ten-year period. Dr. Karl T. Compton, president of the institute, told of the plan in speaking before the general session of the Society for Promotion of Engineering Education meeting here.

The marriage of Miss Julia Willard Salter, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Lowe Salter Jr., to Charlton Cheney Ferris, son of Mrs. Cheney Ferris of New Haven, Conn., and of Walter Ferris of Beverly Hills, Calif., took place here tonight at the Salter home. The Rev. Dr. John D. Skilton of Cheshire, Conn., performed the ceremony.
Six steel strikers arrested last week on Federal charges of obstructing the mail pleaded innocent today before Commissioner W. J. Laub.

The Union Dime Savings Bank extended to May 1, 1942, at 4 1/2 per cent, a mortgage for $10,000 held from William C. Jacobson on his residence at 40 W 69th St. Adelaide Kip Rhinelander Thomas gave to the North River Mortgage Co.. Jersey City, a new mortgage for $2,500, due June 23, 1938, at 6 per cent,
The decision of the five Democratic county leaders to press for the nomination of Senator Robert F. Wagner for Mayor failed yesterday to clarify the tangled local political picture.

Signs of a favorable break in the labor situation were hailed in advertising circles yesterday, following the intimation of President Roosevelt that the public is tired of extremists on both sides of the controversy. It is an open secret that advertisers have been waiting for a turn in the course of events, believing that adverse developments have followed so thick and fast that a change which would result in a less pessimistic psychology was overdue.
Mary Elizabeth Bennett, the writer, who recently moved to Hollywood, has sold her home at Manhasset, L. I., to Al Donahue through the Harvey Craw Company.
Miss Katherine Forman, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Radcliffe Forman of this place, was married this morning to Dr. George Alexander Scheller, son of Mrs. George A. Scheller of Newark. The Rev.
There is neither balm nor a base hit solution in Boston for Burleigh Grimes and his Dodgers.
Eugene Buckley, former chairman of the Massachusetts Boxing Commission, died at his home last night after a heart attack at the age of 81.

The Treasury will defer its decision on the present status of the AngloFrench-American agreement on exchange stabilization until it has learned what ultimate gold value will be placed on the franc by the Chautemps government under the powers voted to it by the French Parliament.

President Roosevelt attended the wedding of his son, Franklin Jr., to Miss Ethel du Pont. The Senate was in recess. The La Follette subcommittee inquiring into subversive activities in labor disputes questioned Chicago police officers regarding the Memorial Day riots at the plant of the Republic Steel Corporation in South Chicago.

MANHATTAN BLANK. RAY D. (June 28). Estate, more than $10,000. To Andrew B. Davies, brother. 2,907 Kingsbtidge Ter., Bronx, $1,500; Sarah D. Green, 114 Park St., Woodmere. L. I., specific jewelry; Raymond XV. Blank, son, executor, 6660 est End Ave., residue. BYRON, RALPH (June 29). Estate, more than $10,000. To Gertrude F. Byron, widow. 433 E. 51st St.
NORTHWEST PASSAGE, by Kenneth Roberts. (Doubleday, Doran, $2.75.) A historical novel by the author of "Rabble in Arms." VICTORIA 4:30, by Cecil Roberts. (Macmillan, $2.50.) A novel of London.
Cy Blanton pitched seven-hit ball and his fourth shut-out of the season tonight as the Pirates knocked Lee Grissom from the mound and defeated the Reds, 6 to 0, before a crowd of 15,568.

The United States Circuit Court of Appeals denied yesterday a motion made last June 3 by the National Labor Relations Board for a temporary - injunction to restrain Remington Rand, Inc., from refusing to comply with the board's order concerning discharged employes and collective bargaining.

William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, today blamed the C. I. O. for acts that led to passage of the new Michigan labor legisolation and called its picketing provisions extremely restrictive.
The owls of North Tarrytown are demonstrating that they are not so wise as they look and getting themselves killed in the process.
President Roosevelt and Eugene du Pont, two smiling parents, exchanged hearty greetings tonight when they met following the wedding of Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. and Ethel du Pont.

Dick Powell, whom this irascible old corner publicly gave up for Lent last season, returns to a certain measure of grace, and therefore forgiveness, in the Strand's new musical comedy, "The Singing Marine."

A song entitled "You Are the Reason for My Love Song," composed in honor of Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. and his bride, was sung at the reception by William Horne, a student at the Curtis Institute of Music, and played by Meyer Davis and his orchestra. The music was written by Mr. Davis's wife, and the lyrics by Miss Sally Gibbs of Philadelphia.
Two home runs by Hal Trosky, his ninth and tenth of the season, paced the Cleveland Indians to a 10-3 victory over the St. Louis Browns today.
Thomas W. Lamont, partner of J. P. Morgan Co., accompanied by his wife, two children and four grandchildren, were among the passengers on the Cunard White Star liner Aquitania yesterday.

The Rev. Dr. Endicott Peabody, the 80-year-old but vigorous headmaster of Groton School, who officiated at the wedding after the rector of the church, the Rev. Frederick T. Ashton, had begun the marriage ceremony, married the bridegroom's parents, the President and Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, in 1905.

Predictions as to favorable results for the railroads this year were sustained yesterday by reports made public by the Interstate Commerce Commission which showed that in the first four months of the year 142 Class I railways earned an aggregate net income of $16,802,485, against a net loss of $29,768,076 in the same period last year.

The wheat market made a firm start and a tame finish today, with prices in Winnipeg advancing as much as 4'.4 cents a bushel in the early trading to a new high mark for the current movement and 23%7 to 247, cents above the low point of June 21.
Except for a small reduction in open-market discounts on bankers' acceptance, the second such cut in two months, there were no changes in money market quotations last month.

The two-story business building being erected by Benjamin Winter at 32-36 East Fifty-third Street is nearing completion, and the second floor is now being occupied by the F. J. Newcomb Company, manufacturers of furniture, under a tenyear lease with rentals totaling more than $70,000.

Ianek Pazner, 52 years old, scion of an aristocratic Russian family impoverished by the revolution, was sentenced by General Sessions Judge Collins yesterday to a Sing Sing term of two and a half to five years for defrauding a physician and a woman of $63,000 in a fake counterfeiting scheme.

Mr. and Mrs. Philip Huntington were hosts tonight at a dinner at the Brookville Country Club and later at a garden supper dance in celebration of the twenty-first birthday of their twin children, Miss Helen E. Huntington and Fred M. Huntington, and their house guests.

The task of assigning all social security account numbers was taken over from the Postoffice Department yesterday by the Social Security Board, here as well as throughout the country. Albert Goldman, New York Postmaster, visited the Social Security Board's field office at 45 Broadway

The International Chamber of Commerce's congress today became the forum for an impassioned British appeal to Germany to give adequate guarantees of "peace and peaceful evolution in Europe" in return for a gold loan to be granted by a redistribution of British and American gold holdings.

The board of governors of West Virginia University named Marshall (Little Sleepy) Glenn today as head football coach to succeed Charles C. Tallman. Glenn also will continue to coach basketball. He now is a student at the Rush Medical School in Chicago.
Miss Florence Brill of Green Hill Farms, Overbrook, has announced the engagement of her niece, Miss Jane Powell Patchett, to Frank Hartley Shearer, son of Dr. and Mrs. Leander H. Shearer of New York.

Canada's celebration today of the seventieth anniversary of her confederation was confined largely to the air, but was nonetheless memorable for that since the radio carried for the first time in the Dominion's history an exchange of greetings between her titular head, Lord Tweedsmuir, the Governor General, and the President of the United States.

Harry E. Cole, who was Secretary to State Controller Alfred C. Chapin, and also served in a similar capacity to Controller Edward Wemple and Controller Frank Campbell, died today at his home in Salem, Washington County, at the age of 76.

The marriage of Miss Margaret Russell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Chester Battin Russell of this city, to James Dawes Van Arsdale, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Dawes Van Arsdale, also of East Orange, took place today in Grace Episcopal Church, Orange. The ceremony was performed by the rector, the Rev. Dr. Charles T. Walkley.

Endeavour II, the newer of the two English yachts sent here, will be the challenger for the America's Cup. T. O. M. Sopwith so stated today after returning from Block Island, where he went on his large motor yacht Philante. The two racing sloops also making the trip.

William F. Campion, an Albany contractor, today became executive officer of the Saratoga Springs Commission, now a division of the Conservation Department, and is to act as liaison officer. He will place himself at the disposal of Chairman Noyes and Superintendent Elmore of the commission.

The crop of Memorial Coin Bills in Congress still flourishes, despite a recent plea by President Roosevelt for curtailed production. Mr. Roosevelt complained that 737,464 coins were struck in 1936 and said that because of the "multiplicity of their designs" they jeopardize "the integrity of our coinage system."

For the second time within the last two years, Myron Mittleman, 18-year-old amateur herpetologist, of 650 Ocean Avenue, Brooklyn, was in a hospital yesterday recovering from the bite of a poisonous reptile.
President Roosevelt arrived here early this morning to spend the rest of the week and the week-end with a family party at the house of his mother, Mrs. James Roosevelt.

A resplendent Empire City, improved and furbished to be worthy of comparison with any track in the country, began its Summer meeting yesterday with a consecutive double for John Hay Whitney, member of the Racing Commission and of the Jockey Club and one of the important turfmen who will race horses at the Yonkers course.

Lumber production increased more than seasonally last week, and the adjusted index moved up to 96.9 from 96.6. It was 83.1 for the week ended June 27, 1936. Shipments and orders also increased, according to the reports wired specially to THE NEW YORK TIMES by the various regional associations.

The volume of business in the Pittsburgh district decreased a little more last week, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh. In the week ended June 26, the bureau's adjusted index stood at 117.9 per cent of the 1923-25 average. It was 118.4 per cent in the preceding week, and 101.4 per cent in the week ended June 27, 1936.

A Catholic priest named Biehl was sentenced here today to four years in the penitentiary, charged with having swindled church funds and having obtained money by false pretenses, mostly from poor men and women, according to the official report of the trial.

The Colonial residence of eight rooms and three baths at the northwest corner of State and 150th Streets, Flushing, Queens, formerly owned by Ernest Fieux, has been purchased by Dr. Benjamin Rosenfeld as an investment.

Always striving to maintain that dignified poise demanded of them by old Colonel Terry himself, the Giants made a noble effort to outwit the Phillies in the series finale at the Polo Grounds yesterday, but, incredible as it may seem, it proved too much for them.

Reflecting a further rise in prices on the London Metal Exchange, sales of copper abroad were negotiated yesterday at 14 cents a pound c.i.f. the European base ports. This compares with 13.75 to 13.85 cents on Wednesday.

Ernest Hayden Hull, vocational guidance expert, civil engineer and naval architect, with an office at 113 West Fifty-seventh Street, died Wednesday of a heart attack at his home, 101 West Fifty-fifth Street. His age was 54.

When any group tries to put through legislation in a hurry, by unusual means and without full opportunity for the opponents to bring forward their arguments, the public has a right to be suspicious. It happens that this is just the fashion in which the plan to drive a power and irrigation tunnel under the Continental Divide and through the Rocky Mountain National Park has been handled in Congress both this year and last.
More than 600 workers, all members of locals of the International Hod Carriers, Builders and Common Laborers Union, walked out on forty construction jobs in this town today.
The Rev. John McMahon of St. Patrick's Cathedral died today after several months' illness at the age of 77. He was retired pastor of St. Leo's Church at Hilton, a village near here.

Behind the three-hit pitching of Hy Vandenberg and a good ninth inning relief job by Pete Sivess, the Orioles handed the Jersey City Giants a 3-to-O shutout in the opening game of the series tonight. Puccinelli hit the only homer of the game.

Business in a listless wool goods market during the last week was confined largely to women's wear fabrics, the New York Wool Top Exchange Service reported yesterday, adding that while shipments of men's wear fabrics were heavy, new business was "virtually nonexistent."

Miss Mary Frederica Poor, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Wharton Poor of Flushing, L. I., and this place, was married here to Ashbel Tingley Wall 3d this afternoon in the Church of St. Peter's-by-the-Sea. The bride, who was given in marriage by her father, wore a gown of old lace and a tulle veil.

Some 400 persons were on hand to wave good-bye to the General A. W. Greely, a three-masted schooner, as it headed out of Port Newark at 8 o'clock tonight for a long stay in the Arctic regions to study meteorological conditions.

The Rev. Martin Niemoeller; who has been the backbone of the Protestant resistance to the National Socialist regime, was arrested today and will be brought for trial before a criminal court or the People's Tribunal.

Another daring hold-up of a woman by a gang of armed men who accosted her as she drove up to 27 Beekman Place in an automobile at 2:10 o'clock this morning had police in the city guarding all bridges. The gang was reported to have taken at least $10,000 worth of jewelry.

Government officials suggested today to farm representatives from the wheat areas that some limitation be clamped down on the acreage that they plant for harvest next year. H. R. Tolley, AAA administrator; Secretary Wallace, and economists of the Department of Agriculture made the suggestion.

William G. Fullen, chairman of the New York Transit Commission, has taken under advisement an application of the Fifth Avenue Coach Company for authority to acquire 13,028 shares of the New York City Omnibus Corporation stock.

Federal Judge Caffey postponed confirmation yesterday of a twentyyear film-rental franchise between the Roxy Theatres Corporation, which is being reorganized under Section 77b of the Bankruptcy Law, and the Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation because of objections filed by Harold P. Seligson, attorney for a group of bondholders.

With the first set and, perhaps, victory in her grasp, Miss Alice Marble, American champion, started playing too carefully today and bowed before the powerful drives of Miss Jadwiga Jedrzejowska of Poland, 8-6, 6-2. This victory left the Polish girl, who thus attained the all-England tennis final for the first time, to contest the singles championship with Miss Dorothy Round of England, 1934 titleholder, on Saturday.

The American delegation of skiers, who will participate in the international contests here, arrived today and made arrangements to begin training without delay. The squad includes Fraser Edward Hunter Jr., Wells Commells, John Litchfield and Howard Chivers.

The marriage of Miss Hazel Blackwell Sadler, daughter of Mrs. Archibald Fleming McLiesh of this city, and the late Houstoun McIntosh Sadler, to John Hodges, son of Mrs. Edwin Hodges of Los Angeles and the late Mr. Hodges, took place yesterday afternoon in the chapel of the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church.

The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that a hearing would be held either in Chicago or in Madison, Wis., to determine whether the registration of William J. Haacke, Inc., of Madison as a broker or dealer in the over-thecounter market should be suspended or revoked.

The New York Stock Exchange has authorized the listing by the Certain-Teed Products Corporation of 10,000 additional shares of common stock; by the Liquid Carbonic Corporation 500,000additional shares of common stock, and by Roan Antelope Copper Mines, Ltd., 106,125 additional "American shares."

Howard V. Stephens of Yale was the lone Easterner to remain in the round of eight when yesterday's, play in the Eastern intercollegiate tennis championships at the Richmond County Country Club, Dongan Hills, S. I., ended.

For the first time since repeal, American whiskies will be advertised extensively next Fall in foreign markets by agents for the Schenley Distillers Corporation. The program calls for promotional copy throughout the British Isles, in South America, Japan and a number of Continental nations.

A total of 2,762 youthful enrollees will leave their homes in New York State, New Jersey and Delaware today for the first of this Summer's citizens' military training camps in the Second Corps Area, United States Army. They will train for thirty days.
Governor Lehman tonight announced the appointment of three members of the Board of Standards and Appeals which was created by the Howard bill, effective today. The members are:

Charles E. Falconer, for many years president of the Falconer Company, manufacturing commercial stationery, and prominent in Baltimore business and civic interests, died today at his Summer home on Gibson Island at the age of 77.

Azel F. Hatch, investment banker, received a decree of divorce from Mrs. Dorothy Hatch from Supreme Court Justice Aron Steuer yesterday. A separation suit brought by Mrs. Hatch charging cruelty was dismissed.

Fritz Reiner will return today from London, where he participated in the coronation season of opera at Covent Garden. He will conduct concert and opera at the Lewisohn Stadium for almost three weeks, beginning next Friday evening.

A building loan of $200,000 has been placed by Nehring Bros. with the Kingsboro Mortgage Corp. on the garden apartments being erected on the north side of E. 175th St., 240 ft. east of Prospect Av., by the B. I. O. Associates, Inc.

All picketing at the Cambria plant of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation ended here today, while the strike leadership concentrated on assembling at least 40,000 miners at the Faith's Grove rally on Sunday.

Frederick Muller and Abraham Himmelstein, two of the eighteen college students selected by Mayor La Guardia for Summer Scholarships in city government, began their duties yesterday in the Mayor's Summer City Hall at College Point, Queens.

The Aluminum Company of America has arranged through the Mellon Securities Corporation of Pittsburgh for $30,000,000 of new financing to provide for the retirement of about $19,000,000 of 5 per cent sinking fund debentures due in 1952 and for other corporate purposes.
George H. Weidner, real estate dealer here, died suddenly today at Mather Memorial Hospital, Port Jefferson, after a brief illness. He was 69 years old.
World employment statistics for the second quarter of 1937, published here today by the International Labor Organization, disclosed that ten countries now have more workers employed than in 1929.
Floyd B. Odlum, president of the Atlas Corporation, told the Securities and Exchange Commission today that Atlas had provided
Fourteen American women made the traditional double curtsey before King George VI and Queen Elizabeth tonight at the third royal court of the coronation season.

Postmaster General Farley charged the Republic Steel Corporation today with seeking to provoke "civil disorder and strife" and with attempting to necessitate use of armed Federal forces at struck plants in Warren and Niles. Ohio.

Anthony (Tough Tony) Garlaus and two of the three men convicted with him for the slaying of a patron during a hold-up in a Brooklyn tavern Nov. 8, 1936, were put to death in the electric chair at Sing Sing tonight.

Mrs. Hamilton Fish has arrived from Washington and is at the Commodore. Mr. and Mrs. T. Wallace Orr of the Pierre are sailing tomorrow on the Conte di Savoia to pass the rest of the Summer in the south of France.

The report of the special New York Stock Exchange committee on commissions places heavy emphasis upon the fact, often whispered but seldom shouted, that brokerage houses have scant interest in investors.
There is no indication tonight, on the eve of what may prove a crucial meeting of the non-intervention powers, that any solution to the Spanish deadlock has been found.

By a singular coincidence, yesterday's newspapers published accounts of two aviation exploits of historic importance. From London came the news that Lieutenant M. J. ADAM of the Royal Air Force had achieved the recordbreaking altitude of 53,937 feet;

Miss Ruth P. Smith, daughter of Mrs. John Smith of Jersey City, N. J., was married yesterday morning in St. Aedan's Roman Catholic Church, Jersey City, to Emil P. Camson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Camson of Brooklyn. The Rev. Patrick Maloney officiated.

One of the most startling upsets of the current metropolitan tennis season occurred today when Chauncey Depew Steele Jr., unseeded New Yorker, virtually blasted Leonard Hartman, first-ranked player, off the court in their quarter-final encounter in the New Jersey State men's singles championship at the Montclair Athletic Club.

Directors of the Syracuse Lighting Company, Inc., the Utica Gas and Electric Company, Northern New York Utilities, Inc., and nine other operating utility companies in the Niagara-Hudson Corporation system included in the plan of consolidation recently approved by the Public Service Commission, have sent letters to shareholders recommending the consolidation.
The death list rose to four today in the wreck of a Norfolk Western freight train. James Ball, brakeman, died in a hospital a few hours after the body of 23-year-old Clark Maxey was found in the

Completion of two strategically important railways in northern Manchukuo, pointing toward the troubled Manchukuoan - Siberian frontier, was announced today. Construction had been rushed and was finished far ahead of schedule.

Exports of raw sugar from Cuba from Jan. I to June 13 of this year totaled 1,402,707 long tons, against 1,451,927 in the corresponding period of 1936, according to a report to the Department of Commerce from Walter J. Donnelly, commercial attache at Havana.

The all-American collegiate lacrosse team won the second game of its English tour over the Mellor team, English champion, today, 15 to 3. Stieber was the American ten's outstanding player. He scored five goals and helped the invaders run up a 12-0 lead at half-time.
Funeral services were held today for Frank A. Vanderlip, former president of the National City Bank of New York, in the library of the main dwelling at Beechwood, his estate here.

A Brooklyn bakery owner testified yesterday in the cake racket trial that two pickets were placed in front of his bakery and remained there for two months because he had sold coffee rings at five cents a dozen less than the price established by the United Cake, Pastry and Pie Bakers Association.

Theodore Meighen of Montreal, son of the former Canadian Prime Minister, Arthur Meighen, yesterday married Miss Margaret de Lancey Robinson of Montreal. Archdeacon Gower-Rees performed the ceremony in St. George's Anglican Church.

A plan of consolidation of the Sierra Pacific Electric Company and the Sierra Pacific Power Company has been formulated, and, according to an announcement by the directors of the former company yesterday, a special meeting will be held on July 23 to act on the proposed consolidation.

Miss Ruth Abel, daughter of Mrs. Henry Abel of this place and the late Mr. Abel, was married this morning to Edward J. O'Byrne, son of Edward J. O'Byrne of Paterson and the late Mrs. O'Byrne. The ceremony was performed at St. Nicholas's Catholic Church, Passaic, by the Rev.
Playing under protest, Syracuse dropped a 7-to-3 decision to the Bears tonight in the first game of a series. The triumph increased Newark's International League lead to seventeen games.

About 1,200 persons attended a memorial meeting and concert given by the Julius Rosenthal Committee last night at the Mecca Temple for the benefit of Basque refugee children. The event was under auspices of the International Coordinating Committee for Aid to Republican Spain, whose headquarters are in Paris.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Violet Ernette Lanneau of this city, daughter of Mrs. Ernest Edward Lanneau of Minneapolis and the late Mr. Lanneau, to Joseph Carleton Borden Jr. of South Norwalk, Conn., son of Joseph C. Borden of South Orange, N. J., and of Mrs. J. Roderick Buchanan of Darien, Conn.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Nearly two years ago the Federal Writers' Project was set up, largely at the solicitation of the Authors League of America, in behalf of its members and other established writers caught in the undertow of the depression. Comfortable offices were secured; competent executives were installed;

A judgment involving $1,032,000 obtained in Supreme Court by the Interborough Rapid Transit Company against the city was ordered vacated by the Appellate Division in a unanimous decision yesterday. The complaint on which the claim was based was also ordered dismissed.

The Senate completed Congressional action on the bill carrying funds for the CCC and for rail retirement pensions and the tax inquiry; approved the conference report of the War Department Appropriation Bill;

Tomorrow's center court program in the all-England tennis championships follow. Play starts at 2 P. M. (8 A. M., Eastern standard time): Men's Singles Final-Don Budge, United States, vs. Gottfried von Cramm, Germany.

It will not be long before the British Government attempts to end the JewishArab unrest in Palestine by a partition scheme as drastic as the separation of the North and South of Ireland fifteen years ago.

Detectives Henry Hansen and Frank Mullady of the Brooklyn Headquarters Squad, received yesterday afternoon checks for $1,875 each, given by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company as a reward for their arrest of three men Aug. 31, 1936, who shot and killed Jacob Hoffman, an agent of the company during a hold-up at 105 Monroe Street.
At the finish of the first round in the Eastern eliminations of the national model yacht races in the Mill Pond tonight, the Redskin, owned by Billy Bithell of Boston, led with 38 points.

Finding manufacture of carbon blacks from napthalene too expensive owing to its scarcity and the heavy demand for it in other industries, Germany has turned to anthracene, also a coal-tar derivative, as "a raw material" from which to make the blacks, according to a report from Consul Sydney B. Redecker at Frankfort-on-Main made public today by the Chemical Division of the Department of Commerce.

Mayor La Guardia opened his Summer City Hall in the old Chisholm mansion in College Point Park, Queens, at 10:20 o'clock yesterday morning, after a reception by twenty-four Queens civic organizations. A crowd of 1,500 persons,

About 1,000 persons held a mass demonstration late yesterday afternoon in front of the Italian Consul General's office at 626 Fifth Avenue, at the corner of Fiftieth Street, in protest against the Italian military forces in Spain.

Operations yesterday in the bond market on the New York Stock Exchange reflected a consolidation of Wednesday's gains, and, with renewed public interest apparent in trading, prices went generally ahead.

A long list of names of new lessees of apartment units submitted yesterday by renting agents and brokers indicated the mounting demand for quarters in the city. A number of brokers reported a lively interest in apartments for Fall occupancy. The list follows:

Details of plans for refinancing and refunding of debts of more than a score of counties, school districts and cities in Florida were announced yesterday by R. E. Crummer Co., Inc., who for three years have been the sponsors of readjustment programs for more than 100 separate taxing units in the Southern State.

Miss Ellen Marie Walsh, former teacher in Public School 151, died suddenly last night at her home, Hudson View Gardens, 183d Street and Pinehurst Avenue. A graduate of Hunter College, Miss Walsh was a member of the Hunter College Alumnae, the American Women's Association and the Foreign Policy Association. She retired in 1936.

Ray Ratajczak, Dartmouth shortstop, was the best player in the Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League last season, so far as the coaches are concerned. This was revealed today when the seven mentors named their first and second all-league teams, The Associated Press reported.
It is not difficult to understand wny the Democratic county leaders are eager to "draft" Senator WAGNER as a candidate for Mayor. The Democratic party in this city is torn by factional strife,

Miss Meave Hamill, daughter of former Representative and Mrs. James A. Hamill of this city, was married here this morning to Michael F. Reilly, Newark lawyer, son of William B. Reilly, also of Jersey City, and the late Mrs. Reilly, in St. Bridget's Church.

The Mayor's Crime Commission, in a final report of forty-two pages, today accused District Attorney Charles F. Kelly of "whitewashing evidence of corruption" in the city and reiterated its charges of protected vice and crime and maladministration of the magistrate and criminal courts.

The reorganization plan of the Propper-McCallum Hosiery Company of Northampton was confirmed today by Judge Hugh D. McLellan in United States District Court. It calls for payment of 75 cents on the dollar to creditors with claims which amount to almost $800,000.

Today will be a memorable date in parliamentary history. For the first time Neville Chamberlain as Prime Minister led the procession of members of Parliament, which, accompanied by the Speaker, went to the House of Lords to hear the royal assent given to "acts which have been agreed upon by both houses."

RUNNING COUPLED (AFTER KIPLING) Elmer ran on the Texas plain And gave the folks a thrill, But Delmer sped half as fast again And made it seem downhill. Haste-haste! No time to waste As they sprint from town to town-- Oh, fast and clean is the strife between Elmer and Delmer Brown.

William G. Irvine, sales manager for the tree surgery firm of Wahl Ferguson of this town, died today at the Summer home of his parents, Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Irvine, in East Northfield, Mass., according to word received here today. He was a World War veteran.

A further drop of $43,000,000 in the total of their loans and investments, following upon one of $93,000,000 in the previous week, was reported for the week ended on Wednesday by member banks of the Federal Reserve System in this city, in their condition statement issued yesterday. The decline was made up of a fall of $6,000,000 in loans and one of $37,000,000 in investments.
With the arrival at noon today of 110 pre-school age children at the Heckscher Camp at Adams Corners, near here, the camp was opened formally for the annual eight-week Summer period.

The Senate, in one of its busiest days of the present session, adopted and sent to the House the conference report on the $130,000,000 Department of the Interior Appropriation Bill, passed the $416,000,000 Army Bill, and then sent to conference the War Department's non-military bill carrying an appropriation, mainly for flood control and rivers and harbors, amounting to about $200,000,000.

Classroomteacher insurgents in the ranks of the National Education Association today won their three-year fight to break the hold of the old guard, composed largely of school superintendents and other education officials, over the policies of the organization.

Senator Ellender of Louisiana told the Senate today that he visioned in the possible success of the C. I. O. movement the crumbling of the American form of government and "the destruction of the sacred rights of free government that our forefathers fought for."

Brooklyn and Queens were brought closer together yesterday afternoon with the formal opening of the new crosstown subway line on the city's independent system between downtown Brooklyn and Long Island City, Queens. Mayor La Guardia joined with borough officials and civic leaders in opening the route, which cost the city $35,000,000.
Morrill G. Goddard, long editor of Hearst's American Weekly, died of heart disease at his Summer home here today at the age of 70. He had been ill only two days.
Walter Hagen and his victorious Ryder Cup team arrived today to join Charlie Lacey, Bobby Cruickshank and Joe Kirkwood in practice for the British open championship.

Statistics covering odd-lot trading on the New York Stock Exchange for the week ended on June 26, made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission, showed a continuance of the trend in which the number of customers' orders to buy, the total shares bought and their aggregate value exceeded similar figures for odd-lot selling.
Marie Antoinette's famous diamond necklace today went into the jewel collection of the wealthy Maharajah of Darbhanga, Sir Kameshwar Singh. He bought it at an auction at Sotheby's for [Pound]15,000.

Milton Speiser and two other attorneys recently sent to jail by the court of Special Sessions for ambulance chasing were disbarred yesterday by the Appellate Division on application of the Association of the Bar. Speiser's conviction was upheld by the court last week.

Almost thirty months of labor culminated yesterday when the New York Stock Exchange's special committee on commissions, headed by E. A. Pierce, turned in a report to the governing committee recommending sweeping changes in the manner of calculating brokerage fees. The report,

Dr. Glenn Frank, former president of the University of Wisconsin, asserted in an address at a National Press luncheon today that the right to vote in this country was in danger of becoming the same formality it is now in Germany.
Properties in Cliffside Park, N. J., having an aggregate valuation of about $200,000, figured in an exchange deal announced yesterday by J. I. Kislak, Inc., broker.
Captain Durval de Barros, who took an important part in the revolt of the Third Regiment in the Leftist uprising in November, 1935, has escaped from prison, where he was serving a twelve-year term.

For the third straight time the Cubs defeated the Cardinals today to keep their slim first-place margin in the National League over the Giants. Bill Lee's effective pitching and Ripper Collins's big bat combined to sweep the final game of the series, 6 to 3, as the Cardinals, fighting mad in defeat, wrangled in their characteristic manner with the umpires.

EXCITEMENT, adventure, love (all-conquering and all-consuming), French and-Indians, tomahawks, scalps drying in the sun, the greenclad Rogers's Rangers, eighteenth century London coffee-houses, debtors rotting in the Fleet prison, Jeffery Amherst, Benjamin Franklin, John Singleton Copley, William Hogarth,

On behalf of the government and people of the United States, it gives .me sincere gratification to extend a word of greeting to our Canadian friends and to congratulate them on the seventieth anniversary of Canadian confederation.

The report of the Engineers Public Service Company and subsidiaries for the year ended on May 31, issued for publication today, shows a net income of $3,215,572, after interest, depreciation, amortization, Federal income taxes and other expenses and charges, compared with a net of $2,330,674 in the preceding year, or an increase of $884,898.

Merchandise which is ordered here but delivered from plants outside the city is exempt from the New York City 2 per cent sales tax, the Appellate Division ruled yesterday in two four-to-one decisions reversing determinations previously made by Controller Frank J. Taylor.

Ralph Beck, a reporter for The Chicago Daily News, eyewitness of the Memoral Day shooting near the Republic Steel Corporation plant in South Chicago where ten men were slain, told a vivid story to the La Follette subcommittee today, describing what he saw and contradicting in every major particular the narrative of Chicago police who had previously put the entire blame for the shooting on the strikers.

Mr. and Mrs. David Chester Noyes of 19 East Seventy-fifth Street, New York, and Netherwood, Cold Spring Harbor, gave a large supper dance tonight to introduce to society their daughter, Miss Frances Noyes.

H. Rider Haggard's "King Solomon's Mines" will begin an engagement this morning at the Roxy. The film was made in England by Gaumont-British and features Sir Cedric Hardwicke, Roland Young, Paul Robeson, Anna Lee and John Loder. .... The Criterion's new

Samuel Reshevsky of New York, champion of the United States, and Salo Flohr of Czechoslovakia, the only undefeated competitor, met today in the twelfth round of the international chess masters' tournament at the Kurhaus.

Photography and chemistry were used by Secret Service agents in a sixteenmonth investigation which ended today with the arrest of Morton D. Wainwright, 72 years old, of Winthrop, on a charge of writing threatening letters to President Roosevelt.

The semifinal round berths in the Eastern private schools tennis tourney were filled today on the courts of the Manursing Island Club. Robert Low of Choate, one of the favored players, had a close call in his match with Emmett Steele of Scarborough. After a long session Low won 4-6. 7-5. 6-0.

The Rubber Manufacturers Association estimated yesterday shipments of pneumatic casings in April at 5,560,453 units. This represented a decrease of 3.9 per cent from March, but a 13.4 per cent rise above April, 1936.

Miss Jane Polachek, known in the musical world as Jarna Paull, was married to Dr. Siegmund H. May yesterday afternoon at the home of her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Victor H. Polachek, 471 Park Avenue. The Rev. Dr. Jonah B. Wise performed the ceremony.

The Koppers Company and its affiliate, the Eastern Gas and Fuel Associates, have control of 40 per cent of the Virginian Railway Company, it was disclosed yesterday in a statement by H. Lee, president of Eastern Gas and Fuel. The price paid in the transaction was $7,870,600.
Wholesale prices reversed their slow downward trend in the week ended on June 26 and rose to the same general level as in the week ended on June 12, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today.

Pete Scalzo, 123, West Side, knocked out Henry Hook, 122, Indiana, in 2:15 of the third session of their eight-round main bout last night at the Fort Hamilton Army Reservation in Brooklyn. The semifinal of six was won by Sten Suvio, 146, Finland, who outpointed Bobby Cummings, 144, Harlem.

The Association of the Bar of the City of New York made public yesterday its list of standing and special committees for the year 193738. The committees were appointed by Henry L. Stimson, president of the association.

The retail price of milk in the metropolitan area was increased 1 cent a quart yesterday. At the same time the retail price of cream was increased 1 cent a half pint. For Grade B milk consumers paid 12 cents a quart delivered to the home.

The open season for conferring college degrees honors cause is ended once more, and once more it is notable that an administration which has drawn so heavily from the academic ranks has received such slight recognition of this kind.

With the Irish Free State Minister to Spain, L. H. Kerney, your correspondent visited Countess Zubiria in Las Arenas today to obtain details of the murder by anarchists on June 16 of Miss Bridget Boland, 56-yearold Irish governess who had been in the Countess's employ for thirtv-seven years.
Wilbur Shaw, who won the recent 500mile race at Indianapolis in a close finish, today injected himself prominently into the second Vanderbilt Cup grind to be run over the Roosevelt Raceway Saturday.

The Southern Pacific Co. filed today with the Interstate Commerce Commission a new "plan" for the reorganization of the St. Louis Southwestern Railway Co., or Cotton Belt, in which it holds a controlling stock interest.

James H. Rand Jr., president of Remington Rand, Inc., in announcing yesterday the annual meeting date of July 13, stated in his letter to stockholders that the net profit of the company for the six months ended on May 31 approximated $3,295,000.

Thomas P. Booth, chief accounting officer of the Long Island Lighting Company, testified yesterday in the Supreme Court that all bills submitted by E. L. Phillips Co. were carefully checked and audited before being paid. He denied that the accounting methods of the company were loose.

Attorneys for the Inland Steel Company, which is charged with violating the Wagner Labor Act, quoted from The Congressional Record today statements made by Senatorial backers of the act, holding that it does not compel employers to sign contracts with labor unions.

The excess reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve System rose $60,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday to a total of $870,000,000, according to the weekly statements of the system, published yesterday. This gain was equal to the one reported last week and made a net recovery for the two weeks of two-thirds of the $180,000,000 drop which occurred over the June 15 financing period.

The New York Stock Exchange's committee on admissions announced yesterday the transfer of the membership of Crawford Burton to Milton Steinbach of Wertheim Co. and that of Alexander B. Johnson to Alexander M. Main of Frazier, Jelke Co.

The 1937 edition of Automobile Facts and Figures compiled by the Automobile Manufacturers Association places at $3,959,248,656 the wholesale value of motor vehicles, parts and tires sold in the United States and Canada last year.

To pave the way for the reopening of its plants in Staten Island and Brooklyn, which have been tied up for two weeks together with about fifteen other shipyards, in the New York-New Jersey area by the strike of the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipyard Workers, United Shipyards, Inc., yesterday sent out ballots to its 4,000 employes asking them to express their attitude in the strike situation.

Francis X. Bastible, newspaper reporter, died last night of a heart attack at his Summer home in Haines Falls, Greene County, N. Y. He had gone there yesterday morning to spend several days with his family and was apparently in good health. He was 50 years old.

Announcement of the organization of the Tea Bureau of the United States, which plans to spend $1,000,000 in the next twelve months in promoting consumption of black tea in this country was made yesterday at a reception held by the organization at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

The world's wheat market turned strongly upward today as the result of general speculative buying and short covering based on uneasiness over the strained political relations between Russia and Japan, a flood of reports of black rust from the Red River Valley section in the northwestern Spring wheat belt, increasing indications of heavy losses from rust in parts of the Winter wheat belt and continued dry weather over the greater part of the Canadian Northwest.

George F. Armstrong, former president of the Armstrong Rubber Company of Garfield and a former manager of the Adams Hotel, New York, died last night of a heart ailment at his Summer home at Lake Hopatcong. He was 67 years old.

The Sheffield Farms and Borden companies and other distributors announced an increase effective yesterday of 1 cent a quart in the price of milk in this city. Though some authorities have been arguing that with the seasonal shortage of milk supplies in Jury and August,

The usual fate of a medalist overtook John Virgil Scott, upstanding young Texan who is captain of the Hill School team, in the second round of the annual Eastern interscholastic golf championship on the Greenwich Country Club course today.
Transatlantic air service will get under way tomorrow morning when Pan American Airways of the United States and Imperial Airways, Ltd., of London start their first flights.
Pending renewal of attempts to carry its unionization campaign to the Ford Motor Company gates, the United Automobile Workers of America plans to use the mails to reach Ford employes.

Mrs. W. Rockwood Gibbs opened Rich Ridge Farms, Richmond, tonight for the first of a series of community suppers for the benefit of the Congregational Church. A party of thirty arranged by Mr. and Mrs. Darwin Spurr Morse attended the supper and later the benefit performance of "Mariette," with Helen Ford as star, at the Berkshire Playhouse, Stockbridge.

Nominations for office in next Fall's election were made tonight at the Nassau County Republican convention in the police auditorium here. The convention was attended by 600 delegates, with George R. Brennan, chairman of the county committee, presiding.

The Bankers Trust Company, as trustee for Interborough Rapid Transit Company ten-year secured convertible 7 per cent notes, which became due on Sept. 1, 1932, has notified holders that it has been authorized by court order to distribute interest on bonds pledged as security for the notes.
It was about a year ago that James T. Farrell warned would-be dramatizers of his "Studs Lonigan" trilogy to desist. And the reason, it now appears, was that he intended to adapt it himself.
Burleigh Grimes took his Dodgers away from here tonight bruised and battered by the worst series of defeats the Flatbush representatives have suffered in many a moon.

Miss Jeanne de Rehling-Quistgaard, daughter of the portrait painter, J. W. de Rehling-Quistgaard, died on June 23, the day after an automobile accident at Fort Morgan, Colo., in which two other persons lost their lives, it was learned here yesterday.
Tommy Farr, the Welsh heavyweight who defeated Max Baer two months ago, likely will be the next ring opponent for Joe Louis in this country. Mike Jacobs,

Making public a report from the special Federal Mediation Board, which criticized the stand of independent steel companies in the present strike, Secretary Perkins asserted today that she had observed nothing to prove that the Committee for Industrial Organization was in the hands of irresponsible leaders.

The cornerstone of the permanent "Tower of Light" being erected here to the memory of Thomas A. Edison, was laid this afternoon in the presence of 300 persons, including Charles Edison, son of the inventor and Assistant Secretary of the Navy, and Governor Hoffman.

The two-story building with a store and two apartments at 1,909 Avenue U, Brooklyn, has been sold by E. Brummel to an investing client of J. A. O'Sullivan, Inc. An investing client of Henry P. Cain, broker, bought the two-family residence at 1,761 Bergen Street from John E. Warner.
Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed total gold holdings for the system as a whole to be at the lowest point of the year to date.
Frank J. Murray, State Controller, reported today to Governor Hoffman that at the close of the fiscal year yesterday the State had a cash balance of $7,376,016 in the general fund.

The sixth volume of the "Men of Good Will" series by Jules Romains will be published in September by Knopf under the title "The Depths and the Heights." In this volume the author concentrates most of his attention upon two men, a frustrated novelist and a research scientist.

The Wednesday Culture Club That Meets on Friday, an organization of writers, publishers and miscellaneous literary lights, almost encircled Manhattan Island by rail yesterday, aboard a three-car special train supplied by the New York Central Railroad.

In the lexicon of the schools, the "city's educational authorities hope," there will be "eventually" no such word as "failure." This elimination is to be achieved through individualization of instruction and the development of the child up to his capacity.

Gains were the rule yesterday in the local commodities futures markets, but the advances were moderate as a rule, with rubber, sugar, coffee and hides strong leaders in the recovery. In the cash markets, wheat declined as new wheat became the base, and other grains, flour, cotton, lard, eggs, silk, rubber, cocoa and tin were stronger for the day.

Leighton Rollins, director of the Studio of Acting of Guild Hall, and his mother, Mrs. Harry L. Rollins, gave a dinner at Greycroft tonight in honor of the group of forty-five young men and women who arrived today to study drama this Summer with Mr. Rollins.

Cut loose to find its own level, the French franc yesterday plunged to 3.83 cents, the cheapest price for France's currency unit since December, 1926, when the Exchange was struggling up from its post-war decline toward the level of 3.92 cents at which Premier Poincare finally stabilized it in 1928.

Mrs. Josephine Austin, known on the stage as Irene Delroy, obtained a divorce today from William L. Austin Jr. Mrs. Austin, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Roy Sanders of Bloomington, Ill., made her first stage appearance as a ballet dancer with the Chicago Opera Company.
The forthcoming "three day holiday" will afford opportunities for many metropolitan anglers who wish to devote some time to fishing while taking part in a safe and sane observance of the Fourth.

Prosecutor Howard Eastwood of Burlington County today notified Ellis H. Parker, chief of the Burington County detectives for the last forty-four years, that he was under suspension pending the outcome of his appeal on his conspiracy conviction in the Wendel case.

Guided by their 16-year-old coxswain, the youngsters representing Tabor Academy of Marion, Mass., brought their shell over the finish line three lengths ahead of their rivals, the Twickenham Rowing Club, today in the second round of this four-day Royal Henley regatta. Their time over the one and five-sixteenth miles course was 7:47.

Two distinct trends are noticeable here in the complicated labor situation which has grown up out of the family fight in the ranks of labor. One is an attitude of conciliation on the part of industrialists of the Pittsburgh area toward the Committee for Industrial Organization.

The Garden City Hotel, at Garden City, L. I., is now under the management of the Knott Management Corporation. C. M. Doyle, who has been resident manager for several years, will continue in that post.

Wilson Flohr of Canoe Brook, winner of the qualifying medal with a record 69, today swept through the first two rounds of the New Jersey State junior golf championship over the Montclair Country Club course to reach the semi-final round.
Spokesmen of organized banking termed "unfair" today a proposed twoyear extension of the right of States and political subdivisions to draw interest on demand deposits.

The White Sox celebrated Manager Jim Dykes's 1937 debut at third base today by shelling four Detroit pitchers for twenty hits and a15-8 victory. The 41-year-old Dykes, whose previous participation in his twentieth big league season had been limited to two futile pinch-hitting appearances, led the attack with a double, three singles and a walk for a perfect day.

William Woodward's American-owned Flares today won the Princess of Wales Stakes over 1 1/2 miles, defeating Sir Abe Bailey's Valerian by a short head. The Duke of Marlborough's Monument, three lengths back, was third in the field of six.

Total offerings of new Canadian bond issues in the first six months of 1937 amounted to $364,501,000, compared with $499,856,599 in the corresponding period in 1936, according to Dominion Securities Corporation. The volume was substantially larger than in any of the three years preceding 1936.
A seven-ridged leatherback turtle, said to be the largest of its species on record, is now on exhibition at the Seaside Heights Casino here, the wonder of all who see it.

A demand for dwellings on the West Side was indicated in realty deals reported in Manhattan yesterday. After being in the same family since 1861, the four-story brick residence at 405 West Forty-sixth Street was sold by Oscar H. Vaupel through J. Arthur Fischer. Inc., broker.

The House passed and sent to the Senate today the 1938 Rivers and Harbors Bill authorizing projects totaking $32,275,300. Among the authorized projects are seven for New York, including $2,481,000 for improvements to New York Harbor.

The Adams Express Company has extended to July 31 its offer to exchange its ten-year 4 1/4 per cent debentures for equal principal amounts of 4 per cent collateral-trust bonds, due in 1947 and 1948, which are in the hands of the public.

Announcement was made here today of the engagement and approaching marriages of Miss Lois Hanlin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Fred A. Hanlin of Steubenville, Ohio, to Lloyd Stanley Blinco of this place, son of Mr. and Mrs. Percy Blinco of Grand Mere, P. Q. The marriage will take place in Steubenville on Aug. 28.

An unexpected development yesterday in the murder charges against Robert Irwin led to a report that his lawyer, Samuel S. Leibowitz, not alone is confident of Irwin's acquittal, but expects even to save him from being sent to the State Hospital for the Criminal Insane.

Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin W. Greer Jr. of Meadowbrook have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Josephine Ely Greer, to Claude Arnold Phipps, son of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Phipps of Willow Grove. The wedding will take place July 31.

George Selkirk, one of the mainstays in the Yankee drive on another pennant, was assisted off the field at Shibe Park this afternoon, a casualty in a strange game in which the champions swamped the hapless Athletics, 12 to 7.
Rabbi Herbert S. Goldstein of the Institutional Synagogue, New York, was elected president of the Rabbinical Council of America at the final session of its third annual convention here last night.

Elimination of section five of the proposed wage and hour bill is proposed by Arthur Besse, president of the National Association of Wool Manufacturers, in a suggested simplification of the bill drafted at the request of Senator Hugo L. Black, chairman of the Senate Labor Committee, and forwarded to the Senator yesterday.
The Grocery Store Products Company of Union City, N. J., has filed a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering 79,930 shares of 25-cent par value capital stock. Of this amount,

The pick of the country's track and field athletes awaited tonight the call for the national A. A. U. championships which will get under way in all their panoply and splendor in the Marquette University stadium tomorrow with the staging of the junior games, forerunner to the allimportant senior meet on Saturday.

Clarence M. Burdick, former Deputy County Clerk of Queens and former Republican leader of Far Rockaway, died yesterday at his home, 1,254 John Street, Far Rockaway, of a cerebral hemorrhage. He was 53 years old.

British opinion, already tense over the acrid press war between Germany and Britain, is likely to be further incensed by the publication of a virulent cartoon in the Schwarze Korps, organ of the Hitler Elite Guards.
The longexpected administration compromise bill to reorganize the Federal judiciary will be introduced in the Senate tomorrow, it was announced today by Senator Robinson, majority leader.
The House of Representatives passed today and sent to the Senate a bill putting the interstate shipment and sale of natural gas under regulation by the Federal Power Commission.
The State Department of Health banned today the sale of grade A and grade B raw milk in cities and villages having populations of 10,000 to 15,000.
Mrs. James H. Robbins of the home club captured low gross honors with an 82 today in the Westchester-Fairfield Women's Golf Association one-day medal tourney at the Lawrence Farms Club. Mrs.

Rapid adjustment was the rule on the Bourse today when it reopened to reflect the liberation of the franc from gold and the prospect of inflation. All the departments rose following a decline during the day of the franc from 22.42 per United States dollar last Monday to 26.06.

Discharged WPA employes made three assaults yesterday on two project offices and in one attempted to seize the government records. They were fought off by WPA guards and the police, and ejected by force from offices at 881 Broadway and 101 West Thirty-first Street.

Rested after their labors of establishing camp and from the spectacular opening campfire ceremony last night, 26,223 Boy Scouts, including about 500 from twenty-five foreign countries, turned today to play and sight-seeing about the capital.

Funeral services for Supreme Court Justice Paul Bonynge, who died Tuesday at his home, Balintober Farm, Locust Valley, N. Y., were held yesterday afternoon at the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Ascension, Fifth Avenue and Tenth Street. Justice Bonynge was 61 years old.

Belmont Hill and St. Mark's tied for first place today in the eighth interscholastic yachting championship for possession of the Mallory Cup. The winner will be decided tomorrow, when the two crews will fight it out. St. Paul's finished third, Choate fourth, Morristown fifth and Tabor last.

The marriage of Miss Winifred Dana Gould, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Aubrey Van Wyck Gould of the Red Brook Colony, to Clifford Coddington, son of Mr. and Mrs. C. Morgan Coddington of New York and Harwichport, Mass., took place this afternoon in All Saints Episcopal Church. The rector,

William Koch of 180 Weirfield Street, Brooklyn, was sworn in yesterday by Mayor La Guardia as a Municipal Court justice to fill the vacancy in the Seventh District caused by the death of Justice Charles H. Haubert.

Domestic manufacturers of cotton bedspreads have appealed to the joint committee of American and Japanese cotton textile industries to negotiate a quota to cover exports of such goods from Japan to the United States, it was learned yesterday.
Gus Hall, Warren-Niles district C. I. O. union organizer, surrendered to police today on a charge of unlawful possession of explosive devices in connection with disorders in the steel strike.

The Dixie Securities Corporation on June 10 last owned 52.338 percent of the Class A and 20.582 percent of the common shares of the Dixie-Vortex Company, according to a report to the Securities and Exchange Commission, which was made public yesterday. The Chicago corporation owned 6.8 per cent of the former and 15.6 per cent of the latter.

The Prudential Life Insurance Company figured in a large West Bronx transaction when it sold the two six-story elevator apartment houses at 2,899 and 2,907 Kingsbridge Terrace, assessed at $520,000. The buildings were bought by Max Rosenfeld, operator, through A. Robinson Co., Inc., brokers.

Mgr. Cornelius F. Crowley, president of the College of New Rochelle, died last night in the Neurological Institute of New York, Fort Washington Avenue and West 168th Street, where he had been a patient for several weeks. He was 67 years old.

In the Senate Monday Mr. CLARK, continuing his curious aversion to Government propaganda, took up the case of Mr. JOHN COLLIER, Commissioner of Indian Affairs. In his discharge of one of the prime duties and pleasures of Federal officeholders,

Postmaster Albert Goldman announced yesterday that, because of an increase of business amounting to $8,748,833 during the fiscal year ended Wednesday, the New York postoffice would take on 400 additional regular clerks and fifty-two letter carriers.

It was announced yesterday that the Brooklyn Union Gas Company will refund to general customers approximately $925,000 under an agreement with the Public Service Commission whereby the State agency will terminate proceedings under way against the gas company during the last two years.

Increased freight rates on cargoes moving between the Atlantic seaboard and ports of South Africa became effective yesterday on all lines in the service, marking the end of a rate war that had lasted more than two years.

The Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., received last night the sanction of the Public Service Commission to exchange 92,134 shares of its $5 preferred stock for the 6 per cent and 7 per cent preferred stocks of its affiliate, the New York Steam Corporation.
FIORELLO H. LA GUARDIA of Fifth Avenue at 109th Street and City Hall Park has taken up his official residence for the

Paul P. Rao, attorney, in 155 E 44th St; Philip Cohen and Max Sachs, ladies' wearing apparel, in 347 W 39th St; Graphart Photo Engraving Corp, in 150 W 22d St; Dudley G. Eldridge, Inc, in 202 E 44th St., through Butler Baldwin; the Cross Brown Co, brokers.

The outdoor terrace of the Round Hill Club was the scene of the third in a series of weekly dances this evening. Among those who entertained for dinner were Mr. and Mrs. Richard G. Croft and Mr. and Mrs. Arthur F. Lafrentz.

Trim navy air cruisers droned northward tonight for the fleet's greatest manoeuvres in the Arctic skies. Six patrol squadrons, newest sky weapons of the fleet, were under orders for the extensive manoeuvres over Alaska and the Aleutians.

Thousands of jubilant workers returned to the mills of the Inland Steel Company in Indiana Harbor, steel-making end of the city of East Chicago, Ind., today under a truce arranged late last night by Governor Townsend of that State.
The Justice Ministry has admitted the one defendant in the trial of the Buendische Jugend leaders at Essen had hanged himself in prison. No details were given.
Frank Parkhurst Russell, retired investment broker and manufacturer, died yesterday at his home here after a long illness at the age of 60.

After an early decline, following a sharp break in Liverpool and predictions of clearing weather in eastern sections of the Cotton Belt, prices on the Cotton Exchange here rallied nearly $1 a bale yesterday to end with net gains of 4 to 8 points.

To prevent the serious injuries and loss of life that inevitably occur on or about each 4th of July, Chief Inspector John J. Seery issued orders yesterday that without permits from the Fire Department the use and discharge of fireworks within the city limits is banned.

Dr. and Mrs. Leland Eggleston Cofer gave a dinner tonight at Leelands for Mrs. Robert Weeks Kelley, who has joined them for a visit. Mrs. Frederick Brooks arrived today to pass the holiday week-end with Mr. and Mrs. T. Morrison Carnegie, who are occupying Sunnyside after an absence of several seasons.

Acting favorably on a petition signed by 660 members, the governing committee of the New York Stock Exchange voted yesterday to close tomorrow, to enable financial district employes to take advantage of the long Independence Day week-end.

James M. Landis, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, was re-elected today to that post for an indefinite period, thus probably deferring the selection of his successor at least until Sept. 1, when he will leave the commission to become dean of the Harvard Law School.
Deployment of State troops in the Mahoning Valley violated the Wagner Labor Act, the Committee for Industrial Organization contended in Federal court today.
It became illegal today for any German resident in Southwest Africa who has not become a naturalized British subject to take any part in local politics.

The twenty-story Hotel Drake at the corner of Fifty-sixth Street and Park Avenue will be offered at auction on July 20 in the Vesey Street salesrooms, together with the furniture and furnishings of all the public rooms, Alfred J. Talley, referee, announced yesterday.

Brazil is the first South American country to accept officially an invitation to participate in the New York World's Fair in 1939, according to an announcement yesterday by Grover Whalen, president of the Fair Corporation.
Reports here and in Washington indicated yesterday that Senator Robert F. Wagner is weakening in his refusal to allow himself to be drafted to run for Mayor of New York City.

The formal transfer of home relief administration from the Temporary Emergency Relief Administration to the State Department of Social Welfare was marked yesterday by a radio program in which Frederick I. Daniels, TERA head, and David C. Adie, State Welfare Commissioner, made speeches.
The Music Hall, where some of the strangest things have been happening recently, presented yesterday a rambling catch-all revue which RKO-Radio has been pleased to call "New Faces of 1937."
Frank Clifford Smith, a member of The Montreal Star's staff for forty years, died tonight at the age of 72. His writing career had an unusual start.

A challenge to American aviation to retrace the flight he and his two comrades had made across the top of the world from Moscow to Vancover, Wash., was made last night by Valery Chkaloff, chief pilot of the Soviet polar plane.

The Brazilian Government made official yesterday the recommendations of delegates from coffee-producing States and ordained that 70 per cent of the new coffee crop, estimated at 25,462,000 bags, would be bought and destroyed, leaving 30 per cent free for export, according to a cable dispatch received by the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange.

The marriage of Miss Margaret Seymour Richardson, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Henry Barber Richardson of Darien and New York, to John Lawrence Angel, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Angel of New York, took place here at noon today in the chapel of the Choate School.

Mayor La Guardia was 12 1/2 minutes ahead of time yesterday for a 6 A. M. breakfast in Central Park, where 160 nurses of hospitals operated by the city gathered to celebrate the consecutive eight-hour day, which went into effect yesterday.

The City Bank Farmers Trust Company has been appointed registrar for 200,000 common shares of the Rome Cable Corporation. Henry Kenneth Astwood and William Samuel Baren have formed Astwood Baren to conduct a general securities business at 70 Pine Street.

A woman, her two small children and a nephew were killed instantly this evening when their automobile was struck by a southbound Pennsylvania Railroad express train of the Long Branch division at the Silverside Avenue grade crossing near here.

By an overwhelming majority the Transport Workers Union, a C. I. O. affiliate, won yesterday in the collective bargaining referendum among the chauffeurs and maintenance employes of the Atlas, Liberty and Sunshine-Radio taxicab fleets.

The budget for the coming fiscal year presented to Congress today figures government revenue at 5,585,000 cordobas and expenditures at 6,200,000 cordobas, leaving an annual deficit of 662,000 cordobas.

Louisiana's lanky aces, Paul Leslie and Fred Haas, strode into the semi-finals of the national intercollegiate golf championship today along with Michigan's Bill Barclay and Tulane's Vincent d'Antoni.

Yorkshire followed its firstinnings victory over Nottinghamshire of two days ago with a brilliant innings and 208-run triumph over Essex today in the English county cricket championship. The result sent the Yorkshiremen into a commanding lead over Sussex, runner-up.
King Carol and Crown Prince Michael of Rumania left Krakow today, returning to Bucharest after a fiveday visit. President Ignaz Moscicki and Marshal Edward Smigly-Rydz bade them farewell.

The old days when factional fights were numerous on polling day in the Irish general elections have passed. More than 1,500,000 voters went to the polls today and reports from all over the Free State indicate that this was one of the most quiet polling days on record. Complete returns are not expected until Saturday.

The Federal Communications Commission today authorized William B. Dunn of New York to be secretary of thirty-four affiliates of the Postal Telegraph System and Claude H. Strickland of New York to be director and controller of the same companies.

Paulie Walker, veteran Trenton welterweight, scored another victory in his comeback campaign when he defeated Teddy Loder of Yorkville in the feature bout of eight rounds at Madison Square Garden last night.
The Rev. David Oscar Kendall of Dobbs Ferry, N. Y., and Miss Ann Rives Barker of Durham and Oklahoma City were married in Duke Memorial Methodist Church here today.
