Miss Constance Marion Dudley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Howard Dudley of Hanover, N. H., was married to Representative Joseph Edward Casey of Washington, D. C., and Clinton, Mass., yesterday in the Lady Chapel of St. Patrick's Cathedral. The Rev. William J. Kenealy performed the ceremony.

The Senators defeated the Red Sox, 3 to 2, today behind the effective pitching of Jimmy DeShong. Cecil Travis started the winning rally in the sixth, when he doubled to left and scored on a single by Rick Ferrell.
The Federal Government today started a new fiscal year which holds the prospect of the smallest deficit since the budget lost its balance in 1931.

The Soviet Government has offered to withdraw troops and naval cutters today from the islands in the Amur River, where clashes between Soviet and Japanese-Manchukuoan forces have produced new tension in the Far East, on condition that the Japanese-Manchukuoan authorities agree to withdraw their forces.

The crowded tenements in the city's poorest sections gave up 1,000 tenants for a day yesterday as the Floating Hospital of St. John's Guild sailed from the foot of East Twenty-second Street on the first voyage of its sixty-second season.

Grover A. Whalen, president of the New York World's Fair, denied yesterday that the project "Vienna, City of Songs," sponsored by the Committee for the Presentation of Austrian Art, Science and Culture at the New York World's Fair had been accepted by the World's Fair Corporation. He said:

Professor Malcolm Gilmore Wright of Drexel Hills, Pa., instructor of modern languages in Girard College, Philadelphia, died here today at the age of 39. A Vermont native, he had come here to spend the Summer.
The Marine Parkway Bridge over Rockaway Inlet, built at a cost of $6,000,000 in less than a year, will be opened tomorrow morning with elaborate ceremony.

During the week ended June 30 member bank reserve balances increased $46,000,000. Additions to member bank reserves arose from decreases of $58,000,000 in Treasury deposits with Federal Reserve Banks, and $42,000,000 in non-member deposits and other Federal Reserve accounts, offset in part by an increase of $54,000,000 in money in circulation.
Ernest Sutter of Tulane, national intercollegiate tennis champion, was eliminated from the invitation turf court tournament of the Nassau Country Club today.

Frank Tweedy, former topographic engineer in the United States Geological Survey, who spent forty-three years in the service of the government, died on Monday in Washington, D. C., according to word received here yesterday. His age was 83.

For the second time since it got under way two weeks ago, the Congressional investigation of income tax avoidance and evasion today back-fired in a storm of criticism of Treasury officials whose daily recitation of tax-avoidance methods was intended to form a basis for plugging the loopholes in the present revenue laws.

The six-story hotel at 2,100 Third Avenue, southwest corner of 115th Street, was sold by Adolph Reisenberg and the estates of Erduin Von Der Horst Goch and William T. Koch to the R. M. Hotels Corporation. Porter Co. negotiated the sale, the first of the property since 1915.

A new name will be engraved this year on the Bedford Challenge Cup, one of the leading trophies offered at the fourteenth annual horse show of the Fairfield County Hunt Club, which opened this morning on the club's grounds and will continue through Saturday

Hugh S. Gibson, Ambassador to Brazil, was appointed Ambassador to Belgium today. Jefferson Caffery, Ambassador to Cuba, will succeed him in Rio de Janeiro, and J. Butler Wright, Minister to Czechoslovakia, was named Ambassador to Cuba. The nominations were sent to the Senate by President Roosevelt.

At Ver-sur-Mer, the peaceful Normandie fishing village on which the attention of the world was suddenly centered ten years ago by the forced landing of the Byrd transatlantic flight expeedition, ceremonies were held today to. commemorate that event and to inaugurate a permanent internsational foundation for the benefit of aviators of all nations.

The Cunard White Star liner Berengaria, arriving today from Southampton and Cherbourg, has among her passengers Fritz Reiner, conductor, returning from a season in London to conduct at the Lewisohn Stadium; George M. Cohan, actor; Mr. and Mrs. C. W. Bowring Jr.,
Police Lieutenant Robert F. McCarthy of the Thirteenth Inspection Division, Brooklyn, died yesterday in Brooklyn Hospital after an illness of two months. His age was 59.

The New York Curb Exchange announced yesterday that members would be permitted, until further notice, to reduce salaries of customers' men in accordance with similar action recently announced by the New York Stock Exchange.

Mrs. Eva Raft, the mother of George Raft, motion picture actor, died on Wednesday night of asthma at her home, 610 West 174th Street, after a long illness. Mr. Raft was at her bedside. Her age was 62.
Legislation which would impose a tax of nearly $65,000,000 annually on sugar consumed in the United States received the approval today of the House Agriculture Committee.

Miss Cecilia Borg Stein, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Fred M. Stein of this city, was married yesterday afternoon at the Plaza to William Arthur Cullman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph F. Cullman Jr. of Stamford, Conn., by the Rev. Dr. Jonah B. Wise.

Although short-term interest rates, including those on borrowings by the Federal Government, have advanced since the end of 1936, New York City will be able to carry on its short-term tax-anticipation borrowing in the last half of 1937 at the same rates which have obtained in the first half, it was decided yesterday.

Bank clearings for the week ended on Wednesday amounted to $5,815,932,000 for twenty-two leading cities in the United States, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc. The total is 3.5 per cent lower than the $6,027,895,000 reported for the corresponding week of 1936. In the year-to-year comparison for the preceding week there was an increase of 11.4 per cent, which was the first rise over 1936 in four weeks.
New Yorkers began to move out of the city yesterday for the threeday Fourth of July week-end in a steadily growing stream that threatened to tax to the limit the facilities of air and bus lines.

The Mining Development Corporation of 52 Vanderbilt Avenue, of which August Heckscher is chairman of the board of directors, and Floyd de L. Brown, treasurer and director, filed yesterday in Federal Court a petition for permission to reorganize under Section 77B of the bankruptcy law.

Americans today for the first time since the dollar devaluation in 1933 had the privilege of purchasing francs here at rates that gave their money a purchasing power in France equivalent to the value of the dollar at home.
A further relaxation of Japanese pressure on China is seen here as one of the immediate effects of the new Russo-Japanese tension since the Amur River clash.

After conferences that lasted until early this morning, Henry Morgenthau Jr., Secretary of the Treasury, announced today that an understanding had been reached with France and Great Britain for continuation of the tripartite agreement entered into Sept. 25 last to stabilize international currencies.

With the determination to make a substantial contribution to the promotion of industrial peace in New York, the State Labor Relations Board, headed by the Rev. John P. Boland, began functioning yesterday at its temporary offices, 342 Madison Avenue.
The mid-year reports of local banks and trust companies which began to appear yesterday showed substantial increases in loans and discounts for the second quarter of the year.

Thomas J. Watson, president of the International Business Machines Corporation of New York and the new president of the International Chamber of Commerce, has achieved the distinction of being the first American whom Chancellor Adolf Hitler has decorated with the new order of merit of the German Eagle,

The 10 per cent average increase in wages gained by the 35,000 cloak makers in this city in the new collective agreement will add fully 5 per cent to selling prices for the Fall season, it was agreed yesterday by David Dubinsky, president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, and Samuel Klein, executive director of the Industrial Council of Cloak, Suit and Skirt Manufacturers, Inc.

An uncommonly spirited and interesting performance of Richard Strauss's "Salome" was given last night in the Lewisohn Stadium by the forces above listed. In some respects this was the most difficult and ambitious operatic production thus far attempted in that open-air auditorium. It may be said that,
Hai Pric Headleu's Whopper and Mrs. Emill Denemark;s Finance raced pto a dead heat in the seventh event at one mile at Arlingtom park today.

The New York and Cuba Mail Steamship Company removed two radio operators from the Siboney yesterday afternoon to avert a possible strike of her crew. The operators were said by. seamen to have been deliberately antagonistic during a recent voyage, and when the ship was preparing to sail the crew asked the National Maritime Union to file a complaint with the line.

The Federal Trade Commission announced today it has ordered James Clark Distilling Corporation and D. and B. Products Corporation, Jersey City, N. J., to cease "representing that they are distillers of alcoholic beverages, when such is not a fact."
John Wuest Hunt, follower of Father Divine, was under conviction today on Mann Act charges of transporting Delight Jewett, 17, from her Denver home to Beverly Hills, Calif.

The marriage of Miss Mary Jane Moore, daughter of Mrs. A. Howard Shaw of Darien, Conn., and the late Joseph A. Moore, to Daniel Hill Sangster, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert D. Sangster of Los Angeles, Calif., took place yesterday afternoon at her home, 300 Park Avenue.

Thomas I. Parkinson, president of the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States, announced yesterday that the company has registered its best record in group insurance production in the first six months of any year in the period ended June 30, this year.

Walter N. Rothschild's yawl Avanti from Mamaroneck took the J. Ruion Miller Jr. Trophy for being first on corrected time in the fleet and also was confirmed as the Class A winner tonight, as all but three of the thirty-five yachts that raced here from New London were either in or accounted for.

Virtually all the former royal prerogatives were conferred on Admiral Nicholas Horthy, Hungary's Regent, and the question of his successor was regulated in a bill adopted unanimously without debate by the Chamber of Deputies today. The Socialists abstained from voting.

Philadelphia, Pa. An issue of $5,000,000 city of Philadelphia general 3 1/4 per cent bonds was awarded yesterday to the city's sinking fund, which bid 100.25. A group headed by Dougherty Corkran Co., the only syndicate to enter a proposal, bid 100.05. The bonds are dated July 1, 1937, and will mature on July 1, 1987.

Carl Meyers, assistant general district manager for Republic Steel Corporation, announced tonight that the corporation's two Massillon units would reopen at 7 A. M. tomorrow under the protection of Ohio National Guardsmen. Captain F. W. Forsythe led 500 troopers into Massillon tonight from the Youngstown strike sector.

The arrival of Paul Siple, Eagle Scout from Erie, Pa., in various sectional camps of the National Boy Scout Jamboree today brought admiring youngsters tumbling out of their tents with cameras and autograph books in hand.

Exceptional pay rises granted to four- employes of the Corporation Counsel's office by the Board of Estimate were assailed yesterday by Paul Windels, Corporation Counsel, as political favoritism that would undermine the morale of his staff.

Rising quotations on wheat, corn, pork and some of the dairy and garden items toward the close of June lifted yesterday Dun's index number of wholesale commodity prices to $202.413. While this was an increase of only $0.897, or 0.4 per cent, over the $201.516 on June 1, it was the first advance to be recorded in three months.

Two parcels of land comprising forty-seven acres in Mount Pleasant, between Briarcliff and Pleasantville, have been sold by the Briarclif Realty Company to Richard M. Lederer, president of the Standard National Corporation, increasing his estate known as Hardscrabble Farm to about 200 acres.

Mrs. Norma Gatto, 26 years old, of 96 Columbia Avenue, Huntington Station, L. I., was sentenced yesterday by Queens County Judge Charles S. Colden to serve from two and a half to five years in prison and pay a $1,000 fine, or spend a day in jail for each unpaid dollar.

Trading in pre-holiday specialties was disappointing to some extent. The lamb market was lower, cow and bull beef weak to lower, steer, veal and fresh pork strong to higher. Early trading in kosher meats indicated beef prices to be sharply higher. Veal steady, lamb uneven but mostly steady as reported by the United-States Department of Agriculture.
Three British battleships, the Royal Oak, Warspite and Malaya, will soon join the British Mediterranean squadron. The Malaya is already en route to Gibraltar.

The Transamerica Corporation declared a semi-annual dividend of 25 cents a share, payable on July 31 to stock of record July 1, placing the stock on a 50-cent annual basis, against 40 cents annually previously.

An investigation to determine whether the increase of 1 cent a quart in the retail price of milk in the metropolitan area, effective last Thursday, involved monopolistico practices" was started yesterday by John F. X. McGohey, Assistant State Attorney General.

Mrs. Mabel Thompson Filor, widow of Walter H. Filor, was married this afternoon at Greyridge, her country place here, to Samuel Garner Wilson of Phoenix, Ariz. The Rev. Paul Giffin performed the ceremony. The bride was escorted by her son, James Reick Filor.

" Broncho Charlie" Miller, the last of the pony express riders, was en route today to his beloved Middle West-on a railroad train. The 87-year-old former plainsman, self-styled "hell-raisin' hombre," said he would visit the "Buffalo Bill" Ranch at Cody, Wyo., and hunt buffalo.

With not more than a length separating them, six horses raced home today in a sensational finish at Delaware Park. Calling upon the camera to aid them, the judges finally decided that No Nane, running in the interests of the Tranquility Farm, was the winner of the grueling six-furlong test.
The eve of the three-day recess for the Independence Day week-end in no way dampened the impetus of the forward movement of bond prices yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange.

The preferential shop, pay rises ranging from 10 per cent to 121/2 per cent, paid vacations and other betterments in working conditions are provided in a contract between the Third Avenue Railway System and the Transport Workers of America, C. I. O. affiliate, made public yesterday.

Fifty persons were injured tonight when the second section of the Ashland Limited of the Chicago North Western Railway crashed into the rear of the first section near Davis Street Station in Evanston.
The Pan American Clipper, a 45,500-pound Sikorsky S-42 B flying boat, was groomed and ready here tonight to start air service over the North Atlantic.

A private funeral service will be held at 10 A. M. tomorrow for Morrill Goddard, editor of The American Weekly, Hearst newspaper Sunday supplement, at his home, 48 East Seventy-third Street. Mr. Goddard died of a heart attack on Thursday at his Summer home at Naskeag, Me., at the age of 70. The body will be cremated.

Among clergymen from the United States and Canada who will attend the second World Conference on Church, State and Community at Oxford, England, July 12 to 26, will be the Rev. Dr. Elmore McNeill McKee, rector of St. George's Protestant Episcopal Church, Stuyvesant Square. He sailed Tuesday as an associate delegate.

Mr. and Mrs. Philip B. Weld of 113 East Seventy-ninth Street and Wareham, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Rose Weld, to Ian Baldwin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Clark Baldwin Jr. of Mt. Kisco.

Materially increasing crop prospects in the Edmonton district and throughout most of Alberta north of Red Deer; light rains fell over the central and northern parts of the Province last night. Rain continued here for two and one-half hours, one-fifth of an inch of moisture being recorded.
Princess Alessandro Torlonia, daughter of the former King Alfonso and Queen Victoria of Spain, gave birth to a son early this morning.

The second performance in Lewisohn Stadium of Richard Strauss's "Salome," given last night with Alexander Smallens conducting the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, attracted an audience of some 5,500 people. The cast was the same as that of the first production.

Japanese interests in the past two years have been extremely active in raising the iron ore output of Malaya, according to a report received from Consul General Monnett B. Davis at Singapore, and made public today by the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce.

With the arrest of Dr. MARTIN NIEMOELLER in Berlin on Thursday the last of the members of the Council of the Confessional Synod is now in custody. Why this militant leader of the opposition group within the German Protestant Church has been spared so long is due not so much to his brilliant war record as to the enormous popularity he has built up by defying the regime.

The first of the Devon Yacht Club's series of Friday dinner dances took place tonight. Among those bringing guests were Mr. and Mrs. Edward M. K. Klapp, Mr. and Mrs. Wallace Reid, Mr. and Mrs. Harkness Edwards, Mr. and Mrs. Victor Harris, Major Richard A. Swartwout, Mr. and Mrs. Jorges Zalles, Mr. and Mrs. Philip Ruxton, Mrs. Edward Fielding Elkins, Mrs. Kent Costikyan, Mrs. Morris H. Smith and Donald P. Carse.

British and United States paper money held by the Bank of Canada decreased more than $10,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the bank's weekly statement revealed today. For several weeks holdings of sterling and United States dollars had been moving upward.
Representatives of fourteen "non-operating" railway labor organizations in the United States today authorized a strike vote among their 800,000 members.
President Roosevelt signed today two major appropriations bills, the army's and one for special purposes, permitting the spending of $864,930,000 during the fiscal year that started yesterday.

Unless otherwise stated, the results of operations of the following companies, announced yesterday, are after deductions for operating expenses, normal Federal income taxes, depreciation, and other charges, but before provisions for Federal surtax on undistributed earnings. Figures, in many cases, are subject to final adjustment.

Seven local newspapers had a combined gain in advertising of 867,074 lines in June, while two others had a loss of 134,972 lines, leaving a net increase for the month of 732,102 lines in comparison with the same month a year ago, according to statistical analvsis yesterdau.

Mrs. Gisella Lang Berger, long active in Jewish charitable affairs, died on Thursday at her home, 525 West End Avenue, after a long illness. Mrs. Berger was the wife of Isidor Berger, general manager of the Greater New York Taxpayers Mutual Insurance Association, an insurance company, and of the Greater New York Taxpayers Association, a property owners' organization.

George M. Cohan, actor and playwright, arrived yesterday from Southampton on the Cunard White Star line Berengaria, after spending two months in England, France, Holland and Belgium. He said he had brought back with him "some little play which I fooled around with in France."

A national chain of citizens' committees to defend the right of loyal workers to continue at their jobs under the protection of elected officials in spite of strikes is being organized from this city with the financial backing of a group of industrialists under the guidance of a nationally known publicity and fund-raising firm.

Jewels valued at $48,000 were stolen from Mrs. Josephine Ogden Forrestal, wife of James V. Forrestal, a vice president of Dillon, Read Co., private bankers, in front of her home at 27 Beekman Place at 2:10 o'clock yesterday morning.

Crocky Rawding of Bloomfield, N. J., defeated Jimmy Gibb, Los Angeles, in the feature two-lap race on the card of motor cycle races at the Yankee Stadium last night. The victor crossed the finish line a few inches ahead of his rival in 404-5 seconds.

The compromise court reorganization bill introduced today by the Senate Democratic leaders reads as follows: Amendment proposed by Mr. Logan (for himself), Mr. Hatch and Mr. Ashurst to the bill (S. 1392) to reorganize the judicial branch of the government, viz:

Wilbur J. Carr, the veteran administrative chief of the State Department, who is often referred to as the "father" of the Foreign Service, was replaced today as Assistant Secretary of State and appointed Minister to Czechoslovakia, a post left open by the designation of J. Butler Wright as Ambassador to Cuba.

Miss Amelia Earhart's monoplane, although a land ship without special flotation apparatus, has good buoyancy for that type of craft, it was pointed out last night. The buoyancy is obtained especially from the wing tanks and the general constructlion of the wings.

Entrance of Bendix Aviation Corporation to the home appliance field on a small scale was announced today with the disclosure of formation of Bendix Home Appliances, Inc., in which Bendix Aviation has a 25 per cent interest.
Great Britain tonight named H. W. (Bunny) Austin, Charles Hare, George Patrick Hughes and C. R. D. Tuckey on her 1937 Davis Cup tennis team.

Quietly confident of their ability to uphold the prestige of England on the cinder path and, what is more, in the jumping pits and weight ring, the combined Oxford and Cambridge track and field squad of twenty-two athletes arrived in New York yesterday aboard the Cunard White Star liner Berengaria.

Miss Caroline Goree Faison, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John W. Faison of 43 Remsen Street, Brooklyn, was married yesterday afternoon at the home of her parents to Joseph Dana Allen Jr., son of Dr. Joseph Dana Allen, headmaster of Polytechnic Preparatory Country Day School, and Mrs. Allen of 200 Hicks Street, Brooklyn.
Miss Althea Pardee, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Harold E. B. Pardee of 770 Park Avenue, New York, and Lauderdale here, was introduced to society at a dinner dance at the Lawrence Beach Club.

Former U. S. Senator and Mrs. Thomas F. Bayard announced today the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ellen Lee Bayard, to Reginald Kennelly, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Edwin Kennelly of Cambridge. Mass.

Broadway, 1,555, 23.101 front; also 205-15 W 46th St, 139 front, surrounding n w cor, Laura Denvaret to 1,555 Broadway. Inc, 1,555 Broadway. 64th St, 116 W, 19x100.5; George Waters to Henry A. Mulcahy, 142 W 64th St; mtg, $12.500.

Witnesses before the La Follette Civil Liberties Committee today dovetailed their testimony into the riot scenes of the Memorial Day shooting near the Republic Steel Corporation plant in Chicago, where ten persons were mortally wounded and several score injured.
Mrs. Thomas Fortune Ryan, 78, widow of the financier who died in 1928, died late tonight at her home, Oak Ridge, in Nelson County. Her death was attributed to a heart attack.

Many large suites in East Side apartments were taken by tenants listed in brokers' reports yesterday. Among those leasing new quarters were Jorge Natamoras, Minister of Costa Rica to El Salvador; Norman Bel Geddes, stage and industrial designer; Ivy L. Lee Jr., publicity man. and Hulda Lashanska, singer.

From all sections of the United States the Society of DesignerCraftsmen, 115 East Fortieth Street, has gathered an exhibition of craft work by leading American craftsmen and has shipped it to Paris for installation in the American Pavilion at the Paris Exposition.

Loans on securities to member firms of the New York Stock Ex change increased $34,114,593 in June, according to an announcement yesterday by the Exchange. The total at the end of the month was $1,186,327,581, compared with $1,152,212,988 at the end of May.

Police Inspector Donald H. MacDougall said tonight that Miss Margaret Elliott, 33, and Miss Ruth Lucille Stewart, 36, both of Montclair, N. J., nurses at the Hotchkiss School at Lakeville, Conn., told him they had attempted suicide in a Portland hotel because they "didn't want to live any more."

From this vantage point it would appear that Jean Giradoux will be represented on Broadway by two plays next season. There Is "Amphitryon 38," in which the Lunts are to appear for the Theatre Guild. There is, further, "Trojan War," in which the MerivalesPhilip and Gladys Cooper-may appear on behalf of some party or parties unknown.
The situation regarding Senator WAGNER and the Democratic nomination for Mayor may perhaps be best summed up by saying that

Final trial racing to select the defender of the America's Cup against T. O. M. Sopwith's Endeavour II will start here tomorrow. The tests will determine the defender, as the privilege in the conditions of the international match agreed upon between the challenging Royal Yacht Squadron and the New York Yacht Club will be waived.

A ninthinning home run, with one on base, by Augie Galan, the Cubs' fourth round-tripper of the game, enabled the Chicagoans to defeat the Pirates, 8 to 7, today and cling to their slender half-game National League lead.

Miss Marie Keisler, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David G. Keisler of South Orange, was married to Herbert W. McDavit, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert M. McDavit of Andover, N. J., this evening in the Second Reformed Church, Irvington. The Rev. George W. Moore, the pastor, officiated.

The Appellate Division in Brooklyn reversed unanimously yesterday the three convictions in the Drukman conspiracy trial, dismissing the indictment as to one defendant and ordering new trials for the two others.

Foreign capital continued to move into the United States in the first quarter of this year at about the same rate as in the last quarter of 1936, the net capital inflow for the first quarter of 1937 aggregating $323,024,000, compared with $325,099,000 in the last quarter of 1936, according to an analysis made by the Treasury Department and revealed today.

Estate, more than $10,000. To Louis G. Arnold. Louise M. Harriet P. Arnold, and emma A. Arnold, executrix, sisters, all of 854 E. 226th St., residue equally. GROSSMAN, LIZZIE (April 28). Estate, $8,000. To Harry Grossman, son, 725 Southern Boulevard, $1,470; Benjamin Grossman, 4,165 Bedford Ave., Brooklyn, and Samuel Grossman, 725 Southern Blvd., sons, executors, $1,120 each.

The wedding of Miss Virginia Lee Townsend, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Homer B. Townsend of this place, to Warren W. Grabyne, also of East Orange, son of Dr. and Mrs. Paul Grabyne of Germany, took place this evening in the Episcopal Church of the Incarnation here.

Eight former varsity oarsmen attending the Rutgers University Graduate School of Banking have been rowing on Lake Carnegie, Princeton, for two weeks. This was revealed last night when Nelson Young of New York, only member of the crew who was graduated tonight, received an oar as a gift from his fellow crewmen.
Wheat prices in the leading world's markets SEE soared today to new high levels on the current movement, with the deferred deliveries in North America in new ground for the season.
The Red Sox celebrated their return to their Fenway stamping grounds today, thanks to homers by Ben Chapman and Buster Mills, with an 8-4 triumph over the Athletics.
William Kloss, 13 years old, of Greater Canton, Ohio, was crowned national marbles champion today after winning a play-off with Andrew Tanana, 13, of Throop, Pa., here.

Mr. and Mrs. Herbert W. Ballantine of this community gave a supper dance tonight at the Woman's National Golf and Tennis Club at Glen Head to present their elder daughter, Miss Marguerite Ballantine, to society. A dinner at the house for about thirty of the younger set preceded the dance.
Ward's Reports, Inc., estimated today that automobile factory output for the current week would be 122,890 cars and trucks, compared with 121,032 last week and 102,833 in the comparable week of 1936.

Roscoe Alan Seaver died last night at his home here. He was connected with the Importers and Traders National Bank of New York, and with the Equitable Trust Company and the Chase National Bank. Mr. Seaver was graduated from the College of the City of New York.

President Roosevelt today issued a statement asking public cooperation to prevent an annual loss of $51,000,000 a year through forest fires, nine of ten of which, he said, are caused by "man's carelessness or indifference."
William Hahn, former superintendent of the Sunday school of Epworth Methodist Episcopal Church here, died yesterday at the home of his son, Percy E. Hahn at Cranberry Lake.

The crew of the Furness Bermuda liner Monarch of Bermuda walked off the ship yesterday morning after submitting demands for wage increases and improved living conditions. Several hours later officials of the line signed an agreement with the crew's spokesmen and the men returned to work.

The Rev. Terence E. Gilmartin, for fifteen years pastor of the Roman Catholic Church of St. Peter and St. Paul, 159th Street and St. Ann's Avenue, the Bronx, died of a heart attack yesterday morning in the rectory at 833 St. Ann's Avenue. His age was 65.

A jury today convicted Harry French, 30 years old, of first-degree murder for the slaying of Claude L. McCracken, 46, in a "newspaper feud." A death sentence will be mandatory. unless a jury later finds French insane. McCracken was shot five times as he ate dinner in the kitchen of his home March 25.

Ellis H. Parker, who was suspended yesterday as chief of Burlington County detectives on an order by Prosecutor Howard Eastwood, reported for duty as usual this morning and announced he did not recognize the legality of his suspension.
The following table shows the ten most active stocks traded on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday; also the new highs and lows for the past three days:

Plans for remodeling three fourstory houses in the Greenwich Village section were announced yesterday in connection with the sale of 90, 92 and 94 Macdougal Street by the Church of the Incarnation, which has held them since 1924.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated June 30: Cooper, Lieut. J. F., orders June 9 revoked, to continue duty in the Ramapo. Fulton, J. R., Med. Corp, orders of June 26 corrected to read: To duty in connection fitting out the Brooklyn and on board when commissioned.
Atley Donald, Newark right-hander, registered his twelfth consecutive victory of the season tonight, limiting Syracuse to four hits while his league-leading mates pounded out a 5-to-3 verdict.

Those buzzing Bees of Boston quite flushed with their recent achievement in having polished off the Dodgers in four straight games and boasting a winning streak of six, barged into the Polo Grounds yesterday and immediately became the object of much curiosity on the part of a ladies' day throng that numbered 12,000.

Mr. and Mrs. William Robertson Coe and their son, Robert D. Coe, who is here from India on leave from the diplomatic service, have gone to their place in Cody, Wyo. The Hon. Dudley Ward of London, who arrived on the Berengaria, is at the Ritz-Carlton.

Amelia Earhart and her navigator, Fred J. Noonan, left Lae, New Guinea, at 10 p. M. Thursday (New York daylight time) on the most perilous leg of their projected flight around the world-a 2,556-mile jump to Howland Island, tiny dot of land rising only a few feet above the sea, two miles long and half a mile wide.

Surrounded by savage Kukuanas and a trained volcano which erupts to order and is careful to spill its lava on the right (by which we mean the wrong people), the Gaumont-British expedition for "King Solomon's Mines" at the Roxy comes through with a whole, if. slightly singed skin, and leaves the beholder with the definite impression that Africa for the Africans is still a good slogan.

Temporarily balked in an effort to reveal the names of additional persons accused of income tax avoidance and evasion, the Treasury Department rested its case today before the Joint Congressional Investigating Committee to which it has been appealing for amendments to strengthen the present revenue laws.

The Rev. John F. Naab, who had been pastor. for twenty-two years of- St. Mary's Catholic Church, Seventieth Street, Winfield, died early yesterday at the rectory after a brief illness. His age was 63.

IT'S all a bit confusing, that big auto race, and the noise that goes with the "infernal combustion" contraptions as they roar down the straightaway is no help to an onlooker trying to think things out in a quiet way. With the qualifiers blazing by, a mechanic with oil-spotted overalls said that it was a contest of cars and the foreign chariots would buzz off and leave the U. S. productions well to the rear.

W. H. Croft, vice president of the National Lead Company, last year received $146,763, according to a report to the Securities and Exchange Commission and made public yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange. Fred M. Carter, president, got $42,000 and W. C. Beschorman, vice president, $36,760.
Works Progress Administration laborers heaved aside a decrepit floor board in the century-old United States Hotel today and uncovered some enlightening early Americana.
In its statement for June 30 the Clinton Trust Company reported deposits of $7,763,355, compared with $7,603,431 on March 31, and total assets of $9,099,234, against $8.974,646 three months earlier.

Automobile sales in Pennsylvania were placed under a two-year "little NRA" set-up by the 1937 Legislature. Governor Earle signed last night the regulations of the fiveman commission which will direct trade in new and used cars.
Mrs. Stephen Brubans, West New York, today was eliminated in the second round of the Mountain Lakes Club tennis tournament by Miss Anita Este, New York, 6-3, 10-8.

Contrary to usual pre-holiday markets, stocks closed near the best levels of the week in slightly increased trading. Many of the leading issues made net gains of 1 to 3 1/3 points yesterday and a few stocks showed wider gains than that.

The war Department released the following orders today, dated July 1: MAJOR GENERAL Sunderland, A. H., Chief of Coast Artillery, 5 days' leave, July 3. COLONELS Peek, E. D., Eng'rs, appointed as Brigadier General; relieved from duty at New York, N. Y., and ordered to command the Fourth Brigade, Ft. Francis E. Warren, Wyo.; to sail about Aug. 4 for San Francisco.

Mrs. Ansel Phelps gave a luncheon yesterday in the Japanese Garden of the Ritz-Carlton for Mrs. Allen M. Thomas, Mrs. H. Edward Manville, Mrs. Philip A. S. Franklin, Mrs. Frederic R. Coudert, Mrs. Herman D. Kountze, Mrs. Edward R. Stettinius and Mrs. Lewis Gawtry.

With Great Britain facing difficulty in meeting the demand for iron and steel for rearmament, the government tonight announced reduction of ad valorem duties on a long list of iron and steel products to 12 1/2 per cent. The existing rate is approximately 20 Per cent.

General business activity in New England durIng May stood at 109.5 per cent In comparison with 110.6 per cent in April and 109.4 per cent in March, according to the New England Council's index of business activity. The corresponding figures for 1936 are: May, 94.8; April, 92.5; March, 90.4.

Alexander H. Garnjost, who represented the Fourth Assembly District of Westchester for twelve terms, and a member of an old and prominent Yonkers family, died today in St. John's Riverside Hospital. He was 43 years old.

Supporters and opponents of the C. I. O. labor movement staged the bitterest debate of the session in the House today and suggestions were made that fist fights would result unless "these insulting remarks" were discontinued.

The government ended the fiscal year on June 30 with a net deficit of $2,707,000,000 and a gross public debt of $36,425,000,000, according to final figures made public today by Secretary Morgenthau. The deficit was about $150,000,000 more than estimated by President Roosevelt on April 20.

Mayor Daniel J. Shields was unruffled by the assertion of strike leaders here today that 40,000 would be the minimum number of mine, steel and railroad workers at the Faith's Grove Rally called by the S. W. O. C. for Sunday.

The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow: "The movement of wool from Boston is absolutely prevented by the strike of woolhandlers, who have been granted all their demands except the closed shop, on which the wool trade refuses to arbitrate as a matter of principle.

New financing scheduled for next week by 121 municipalities totals only $9,460,126, as compared with the revised total of $15,841,659 for the past week, according to The Daily Bond Buyer. The weekly average of new offerings for the year to date now stands at $32,099,664.
Teamsters here today tied up delivery of early editions of The Seattle Star by calling a strike in an effort to force branch managers to drop their membership in the American Newspaper Guild.

Accused of having used the mails to defraud, three former officials and two employes of C. J. Morley Co., an investment firm, were found guilty today after a Federal court jury had deliberated all night.

Arguments on the proposal by the Johnson committee to have the Interborough Rapid Transit Company buy from the Bankers Trust Company the I. R. T. 5 per cent first-mortgage bonds necessary to meet annual sinking-fund requirements was adjourned yesterday until Aug. 24 by Federal Judge Julian W. Mack.
In accordance with apparent cooperation among Central American dictators, Rafael Medina Raudales, a lawyer and Honduran political exile, has been expelled from Nicaragua.

The old Consumers Brewery site in Sutton Place between F i ft y-f o ur t h and Fifty-fifth Streets was sold at auction yesterday to Frank L. Well and other trustees for holders of Series C-2 certificates of the New York Title and Mortgage Company.

Deposit receipts for Wheeling Steel Corporation 6 per cent preferred stock, $100 par value; Central Railroad and Banking Company of Georgia 5 per cent collateral trust bonds extended to 1942; Phelps Dodge Corporation convertible 3 1/2 per cent debentures due in 1952 and Southern Bell Telephone and Telegraph Company twenty-five-year 3 1/4 per cent debentures due in 1962 were admitted to the New York Stock Exchange list yesterday.

It is possible that the four employes of the Corporation Counsel's office whose pay increases were cited this week by Corporation Counsel WINDELS himself as evidence of political favoritism are worth every cent that the city ever has or ever will pay them.
The sale of a number of residential properties in Brooklyn was announced yesterday by brokers. Several of the parcels changing hands will be occupied by the new owners.

The State Banking Department announced today its approval of a certificate of reduction of capital stock of the Guaranty Safe Deposit Company of New York from $400,000, consisting of 4,000 shares of a par value of $100 each, to $250,000, to consist of 2,500 shares of the same par value.
At the end of competition today in the invitation turf court tennis tournament at the Nassau Country Club, all four of the top-seeded favorites found themselves out of the running.

DAY before yesterday was July 1. Here are notes on books published since March 1 that this reviewer remembers with especial satisfaction. The order of listing is haphazard. Otto Eisenschiml's "Why Was Lincoln Murdered?" (Little, Brown).

Creston Ave. (11-3162), n e cor 181st St, 150x91; Gerf Construction Corp to Morris Morgenstern, 286 Ft Washington Ave, due Feb 1, 1938, 6 per cent; building loan; $235,000. Broadway (13-3423P), s w cor 262d St. 51x202; Chester View, Inc, to Arthur E. Muth, receiver, two years, 4 per cent; $12,000.

The Senate passed the Farm Tenancy Bill and sent it to conference; received the Logan-Ashurst-Hatch compromise Courts Reorganization Bill; received the nomination of Wilbur Carr to be Minister to Czechoslovakia and George Messersmith to be Assistant Secretary of State; confirmed the nomination of Hugh R. Wilson to be Assistant Secretary of State and adjourned at 2:30 P. M. until noon Tuesday.

Mr. ROOSEVELT'S congratulations to Canada on the seventieth anniversary of confederation are in his happiest manner. They express the sincere goodwill of the American people to another democratic nation working on substantially the same problems, subject to much the same stresses, divisions of region and interest as themselves.

Seventy-eight yachts competed in the Summer's seventh championship regatta of the Long Island Sound Yacht Racing Association under the auspices of the Horse Shoe Harbor Yacht Club today. The racing started a series of Fourth of July week-end events on the Sound.

The Securities and Exchange Commission heard Floyd B. Odlum, president of Atlas Corporation, approve today a proposal for governmental supervision of mergers, reorganizations and exchanges of securities between investment corporations.
The Reichsbank's statement as of July 1 shows the following changes from the preceding week, in thousands of marks:

Below are given nominal comparative quotations on standard constructions of gray printcloths, sheetings and pajama checks in this market, as supplied yesterday by the Textile Brokers Association, Inc.:

Teamsters' council called a "holiday" for 25,000 drivers, halting the movement of food, freight, merchandise and newspapers in Philadelphia. Page 1. Republic Steel mills at Massillon, Ohio, were reopened under protection of National Guardsmen. Page 6.

The name of Max Silverman, fugitive from two investigations and associate of the murdered Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer's henchmen, was brought into the cake racket trial yesterday as the man who ordered the dissolution of a price-fixing bakery owners association.

A large sign, reading "This plant is closed for the duration of the strike," confronted pickets yesterday of the Metal Novelty Union, a C. I. O. affiliate, at the plant of the Astorloid Manufacturing Company, 2 Hopkins Street, Brooklyn.

A passenger who is forced to stand from Albany to New York has good ground for a damage suit against the New York Central Railroad, the Appellate Term of the Supreme Court ruled unanimously yesterday, reversing a Municipal Court decision which held that possession of a ticket did not entitle a rider to a seat.

A prominent Viennese psychologist, Dr. Marie Lazarsfeld, former wife of Dr. Paul Lazarsfeld, a professor at the University of Pittsburgh, was sentenced today to three months' rigorous imprisonment after she had pleaded guilty to aiding Socialists and to possessing Socialist literature.

Judge Allen in General Sessions yesterday dismissed a second-degree grand larceny indictment returned about a year ago against Mrs. Hannah G. Medoff, 33 years old, a former resident of the Tudor Hotel in East Forty-second Street.

Curtailment of activity in the various lines of the glass industry has been setting in for weeks and the present month from all indications is certain to reach the year's low, according to the issue appearing today of The American Glass Review.
Two groups of young persons will leave within a week to attend interdenominational and international religious conferences at Oxford, england.

Price movements of commodity futures held to a narrow range yesterday in a typical pre-holiday trading session, although most of the staples were steady. Rubber and world sugar contracts, however, fell.
Turpentine firm, 341/4c; sales, 107 barrels; receipts, 575 barrels; shipments, 80 barrels; stock. 27,890 barrels. Resin, firm; sales, 1,087: receipts, 2,000; no shipments: stock, 59,661.

In an opinion that may have far-reaching consequences in the battle now in progress between Stock Exchanges and the over-the-counter market, the Securities and Exchange Commission today ordered that the 7 per cent convertible preferred stock of $100-par value and the no-par value common stock of the American District Telegraph Company be removed from unlisted trading on the New York Curb Exchange at the close of business on July 10.

The Moredall Realty Corporation, owner of the Capitol Theatre, must render an accounting to Edward Sheldon and Margaret Ayer Barnes, authors of the play "Dishonored Lady," for eighty-four exhibitions of the motion picture "Letty Lynton" given in the theatre between April 29 and May 12, 1932, Federal Judge Robert P. Patterson ruled yesterday.
The report of the Board of Transportation on the proposed In-. dependent Subway spur to the World's Fair grounds in Queens was submitted to the Board of Estimate yesterday.

The shutout disease, from which the Dodgers suffered so excruciatingly in Boston, must be contagious and the Phillies, a group of low-resistance athletes, promptly contracted it from their visitors today.

John Edward Mullins of New York and Paris, whose grandfather founded the John Mullins Son furniture company here, died of heart disease at sea on Wednesday on the Italian liner Rex, on which he had sailed on his wedding trip last Saturday, according to a radio message received at the Italian Line offices here.
All equities of certificate holders in a $140,000 first mortgage on the Green Meadow Country Club at Harrison, N. Y., were wiped out today when the property was sold at auction.

Coast Guard headquarters was advised tonight that Amelia Earhart was believed to have alighted on the Pacific Ocean near Howland Island shortly after 5 P. M. Eastern daylight time today. A message from the cutter Itasca, stationed in the vicinity of the island in the mid-Pacific, said:

A new testing machine with which it is possible "to cause a battleship to shiver like a man with the ague" was described yesterday by C. H. Gibbons, technical adviser to the Baldwin Southwork Corporation, at the closing session of the fortieth annual meeting of the American Society for Testing Materials.
The New York Savings Bank sold the flat at 165 E. 116th St for $16,500 to the Sal-Cap Realty Corp, Salvatore Caputo, president, taking back a purchase-money mortgage for $13.200.

With guests beginning to arrive for the holiday week-end, the entertaining for the Fourth of July got under way tonight. Among the dinner hosts were Mr. and Mrs. Roger W. Cutler, who entertained at their Bellevue Avenue home; Mr. and Mrs. H. B. H. Ripley, at Beachbound; Mr. and Mrs. Snowden A. Fahnestock, at Ker Arvor, and Count and Countess Alfonso P. Villa. at Fairholme.

American Light and Traction Company and Subsidiaries - Twelve months ended May 31: Net income after interest, depreciation, amortization, Federal income taxes and other expenses and charges, $5,995,567, equal, after preferred dividend charges, to $1.88 a common share, comparing with a net of $4,815,454, or $1.45 a common share, in the twelve months ended May 31, 1936.

Of eight persons arraigned yesterday before Magistrate Pinto in the Flatbush court, Brooklyn, for selling fireworks illegally, six were fined $10 each and two $5 each. One of the latter group, Andrew O'Donnell, 20 years old, was arrested for selling fireworks in his apartment at 136 Fifth Avenue, Brooklyn.

American domination of world tennis was re-established today when Donald Budge overwhelmed Baron Gottfried von Cramm of Germany to take the singles championship in the all-England tournament and then, with the aid of Gene Mako, won a thrilling five-set victory over von Cramm and Heinrich Henkel to enter the final of doubles.
Steel furnaces turned the night skies red along the strike front tonight. Here in East Chicago, 5,500 day-shift workers fattened their paychecks with a second day of work at Inland Steel's plant.

Two Confessional Synod leaders, Pastor Niesel and Mr. von Arnim-Lutzow, were fined 600 marks each today by the regular criminal court here, but their co-defendants, Pastor Gerhard Jakobi of the Kaiser Wilhelm Memorial Church in Berlin and Dr. Ehlers, were acquitted.

Eugene V. Connett, a retired hat manufacturer of the firm of E. V. Connett Co. of Manhattan, died suddenly last night of a heart attack at his Summer home here. He was 75 years old and was a native of South Orange, N. J. He and Mrs. Connett arrived on June 16.
For the second time in as many days a No. 1 favorite was ousted by an unseeded player in tennis tournaments running concurrently at the Montclair Athletic Club.

Mrs. Veronica M. Kohler, widow of Charles Kohler, piano manufacturer and owner of racing stables here and abroad, died yesterday at her home, Ramapo Farm, after a six-month illness. She was 66 years old.

The annual influx of visiting clergymen will begin tomorrow when many of the city's pulpits will be filled by preachers from other cities and from foreign countries. Many pastors who have not yet gone on vacation will preach on liberty, patriotism and similar themes bearing on the celebration of Independence Day.

It will be remembered that in 1934 the Administration canceled wholesale the contracts of air mail operators in the United States. This action was taken upon the charge, formulated by the Black committee, of "fraud and collusion," based especially upon an alleged collusive conference held in Washington at the call of the then Postmaster General, WALTER BROWN.

The fifth session of the Grand Circuit's inaugural week was halted tonight when a heavy rain drenched the Fort Miami track after Arleton, bay colt by Peter Volo, and Halley's Comet had won the first heats in the Peninsula Farm stake and twenty-class pace.
Dorothea Brande and her husband, Seward Collins, have sailed for Europe, where they will stay four months. Miss Brande is the author of "Wake Up and Live."

Martin (Buggsy) Goldstein and his alleged bodyguard, Seymour Magoon, who were convicted in the Court of Special Sessions in Queens last November on charges of conspiracy and coercion in intimidating union painters, will receive a new trial under a decision of the Appellate Division in Brooklyn yesterday.

The New York Sun yesterday announced that Oscar Thompson had been appointed music critic, William G. King, music editor, and Irving Kolodin, associate critic. They have been with The Sun for several years.
The first returns in the Free State general election received tonight in dicate that the De Valera party the Fianna Fail, is running ahead in many constituencies and the Cosgrave party faring badly.

Presaging even more superb performances in the all-important senior games tomorrow, the lesser lights of the foot-racing fraternity launched a wholesale assault on meet records this afternoon and evening as the National A. A. U. championships opened with the junior title games in the Marquette University Stadium.

Crowded terminals and highways, heavily laden porters and shouting children vacation-bound were the outward signs that one of the greatest holiday outpourings in years was reaching its peak last night. All conveyances by land, sea and air were filled to capacity.
Jim Walkup turned in a 6-hit pitching job for the seventh-place Browns today and played a major part in his team's 4-to-2 victory over the White Sox.

Max Baer returned here yesterday after a two-month stay in England. The former heavyweight boxing champion of the world, accompanied by his brother Buddy, arrived aboard the Berengaria of the Cunard White Star Line.

John G. Chesney, J. S. Diston 3d and Howard B. Edwards were granted amateur rider certificates at a meeting of the license committee of the National Steeplechase and Hunt Association at its offices yesterday. A. C. Bostwick, John Strawbridge and F. S. von Stade of the committee were present.

The charge of "Violation of Section 114, Par. 11, R. R., 1926," on which Fireman 1st Grade Joseph A. Lane, H. L. 127, was tried before Francis X. Giaccone, Deputy Fire Commissioner, on June 23. 1936, found guilty and sentence suspended, is dismissed.

Cotton-mill activity declined last week, when the seasonal trend was steady, and the adjusted index receded to 142.9 from 147.3 revised). It was 125.6 for the week ended June 27, 1936. Sales of gray goods this week were light,

The Board of Examiners reports that there have been placed in the eligible list of holders of license for service as teacher of Italian in junior high schools, as of June 30, 1937, the names of the following applicants, who have been granted said license:

Foreign petroleum companies henceforth will be forced to pay royalties on all lands under lease from Mexico and work them without interruption, according to a uniform article which is published on the front pages of all newspapers here and which is obviously officially inspired.

It was in London, following the March financial crisis in Paris, that a well-known English economist counseled this correspondent to watch Georges Bonnet. "Next time, unless I miss my guess," he predicted, "an S O S call will be sent to Washington for Bonnet.

Brooklyn police were accused of brutality and unwarranted assault upon striking pickets at the Fein Tin Can Company plant, 284 Furman Street, Brooklyn, by several strikers who gave testimony yesterday before Inspector Harry Lobdell of the Eleventh Inspection District.

Theatre matters: The New Amsterdam Theatre, Forty-second Street west of Broadway, will start tonight on a new career as a seeond-run motion picture house with the Warners film version of "A Midsummer Night's Dream." . . .

The Mechanics' Trust Co., in iquidation, by Carl K. Withers, Commissioner of Banking and Insurance, has sold the former bank building at 734-736 Broadway on the northeast corner of East Thirtythird Stree+, in Bayonne, assessed at $27,655, to Mary N. Kay, for a stated consideration of $3.600.
The Franklin Society announces the payment for the current quarter of a 212 per cent dividend on installment and income shares and 2 per cent on ordinary savings and club accounts.

Unedited editions of Paramount's newsreel pictures of the Memorial Day riot before the Republic Steel Corporation plant in South Chicago in which ten men were slain were released yesterday by Paramount Pictures, Inc., for general showing throughout the country.

Losing first innings points to Lancashire today, Sussex lost ground in the English county cricket championship. Although retraining second place the Southern county dropped further behind Yorkshire, which emerged victor by an innings and 208 runs over rick Essex yesterday.

Speed horses from several sections of the country will clash in the $5,000 added Fleetwing Handicap, feature this afternoon at Empire City, Marshall Field's Tintagel, erstwhile winner of the Futurity and other races will run, being coupled in the betting with Mrs. W. Plunket Stewart's Mower, and the two are expected to rule favorite.
Non-intervention in Spain did not, as some had expected, come to its death in the meeting of the chairman's subcommittee of the principal powers today.

Asserting that business recovery has reached a point where it is necessary "to drive with a tighter rein" in regard to further expansion of credit; Lewis E. Pierson, chairman of the board of the Irving Trust Company of New York, recommended here tonight that the Federal Reserve Board and the Treasury continue their steps to prevent unsound expansion.

That Latvia, playing host to leading European and American chess masters, will receive a considerable share of the honors and prizes in the international tournament at the Kurhaus was more clearly indicated today when V, Petrow of Riga moved into second place below Samuel Reshevsky, the United States champion, by adding 1 1/2 points to this total.

Veteran employes of the Corporation Counsel's office whose salaries were raised above the figures recommended by Budget Director Leo J. McDermott were not the only political and semi-political figures to benefit by the generosity of the Board of Estimate, a check of the list of 190 individuals so favored disclosed yesterday.

Deliberations of the Ninth Congress of the International Chamber of Commerce closed tonight with the adoption by various committees of numerous draft resolutions to be submitted to the final plenary session tomorrow.

The volume of new bond financing was slightly lower this week, the total being $98,337,000 in eight individual issues, compared with an aggregate of $101,843,000 last week. A year ago in the current comparable period a total of $80,996,000 in new loans was publicly offered.
The threat of a nation-wide shutdown of hotels, restaurants and cafes was averted early today when employers and workers signed an agreement on working conditions.
J. F. Weaver and Herbert Thiele, both formerly of the Runkel Company, have been appointed district sales managers of the bulk division of Walter Baker Co., Inc., it was announced yesterday.

DON BUDGE, the Red Terror of the courts, seems on the verge of ruining tennis. The game has usually been considered a two-sided affair which gave opportunities for graceful strokes, lone rallies and crafty tactics.

Now that the mothers of some 20,000,000 children are without the cooperation of the teachers and so have full-time responsibility themselves for the care of those whom they have brought into the world, they should know that the Children's Bureau in the United States Department of Labor has ready for distribution a booklet of a hundred pages entitled " Child Management" which may be of help to them in their perplexities and anxieties.

The Police Honor Legion, it was disclosed yesterday, has temporarily discontinued the placing of bronze markers over the graves of police heroes because a number of the plaques have recently been stolen.

Melo Almada of the Senators conducted a noisy one-man uprising against the Yankees before a ladies' day gathering of some 15,000 today. Almada battered Irving (Bump) Hadley for a double and a single and picked on Pat Malone for two more singles, all of which figured in scoring rallies of the home club.

Under bayonet protection, more strikelocked steel mills opened here today. The back-to-work movement was carried out without violence. Gates of Republic Steel's central steel division swung open, under protection of steel-helmeted National Guardsmen, for the first time since the strike started May 27.
Clendenin J. Ryan Jr., one of Mayor La Guardia's secretaries, stopped a runaway horse in College Point yesterday morning as he was driving to the Summer City Hall in College Point Park, Queens.

The London NonIntervention Committee's rejection of the counter-proposals submitted by Count Dino Grandi, Italian Ambassador, and Joachim von Ribbentrop, German Envoy, caused intense disappointment here and is considered to have greatly aggravated the crisis brought about by Italy's and Germany's withdrawal from the international control of Spanish frontiers.

Baroness de Sibert, the former Miss Dorothy Knight Colford, was married here this afternoon to E. Maitland Armstrong, socially prominent resident of Newport and New York. The wedding was performed about two hours after her divorce from Baron Pierre C. de Sibert of Paris.

Struggling through gas and smoke to aid a party of miners trapped a mile underground in the Brymbo colliery in Staffordshire today, a rescue group of eighteen was wiped out by a second explosion. Altogether twenty-seven lost their lives and many were injured.

Coming up to New England with a one-horse stable, Mrs. Laning Harvey Jr. of Midkiff's Farm of Kingston, Pa., made an early and definite impression in hunter circles at the fourteenth annual exhibition of the Fairfield County Hunt Club.

The Commissariat of Defense issued an order early today for the withdrawal of Soviet armed patrols and naval cutters from Amur River islands, the ownership of which is in dispute between the Soviet Union and Japanese-controlled Manchukun.

The Union Electric Company of Missouri has called the following general mortgage bonds for redemption on Aug. 2: 5 per cent Series A, due 1954, at 105; 5 per cent Series B, due 1967, at 103 3/4, and 4 1/2 per cent series, due 1957, at 103 3/4, all plus accrued interest.

76th St., 300 E`.; to 5-story tenement and stores; Morris Kurtzman, 1,454 2d Ave., owner; Philip Markowitz, architect; cost, .$7,000. Madison Ave., 1,142: to 6-story tenement and offices; Enfants Realty Corp., premises, owner; H. P. Jaenike, architect; cost, $4,000.

The question of affiliation of the American Federation of Labor with the International Federation of Trade Unions provoked heated debate at today's session of the general council of the I. F. T. U. The vote was put off till tomorrow in the hope that a formula could be found for agreement.

The one-story industrial building at 42-26 Thirteenth Street, Long Island City, has been sold by the Myralo Corporation to an investing client of Allan D. Emil, attorney, through the Herbert Callman Company, broker.

Depositors and general creditors of the Harriman National Bank and Trust Company, which closed its doors in 1933 and passed out of existence, will receive 100 per cent on their claims, according to Frederick V. Goess, receiver, who was authorized yesterday by Federal Judge Vincent L. Leibell to accept $900,008 as a settlement of claims against sixteen former directors of the bank and the estate of another director.

Ground - breaking ceremonies, marking the beginning of construction of Manhattan College's new Cardinal Hayes library building, were observed yesterday on the site of the new building on the eastern part of the campus adjoining Spuyten Duyvil Parkway near the junction of 242d Street and Broadway.
The appointment of M. D. Howell of New York as vice president of the Carnegie-Illinois Steel Corporation was announced today by the company's president, Benjamin F. Fairless.

Mrs. Charles Morgan of 36 East Seventy-second Street and Islip, L. I., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Nancy Morgan, to James Hopkins Smith Jr., son of Mrs. Dwight F. Davis of New York and Washington and of James Hopkins Smith.

Cardinal Hayes will preside at the funeral mass for Mgr. Cornelius F. Crowley on Monday morning, it was announced today. Mgr. Crowley, president of the College of New Rochelle and dean of the Catholic clergy in Westchester County, died in a New York hospital last evening.

The New London-Gibson Island yacht race committee announced today that the yawl Avanti was the official winner of the coastal cruise. The committee said that six more craft crossed the finish line today.

The Federal Trade Commission today ordered the Uptown Cooperative Press, Inc., of New York and seventeen individuals to stop using the name "I. S. U. Pilot," or operating a newspaper of that name, holding that the name was used without permission of the International Seamen's Union.

Miss Evelyn Willoughby Sharp, daughter of the late Rev. and Mrs. Henry Talbot Sharp, was married to Dr. Samuel McLanahan, son of Mrs. Samuel McLanahan and the late Rev. Mr. McLanahan and grandson of the late Bishop Latane, this evening in Christ Protestant Episcopal Church.
Today will be a holiday in the major securities markets of the world. Following the action

Tabor Academy, the only American entry left in the Royal Henley Regatta, moved nearer the coveted Thames Challenge Cup today by eliminating the Reading Rowing Club. Never pressed, the Massachusetts school crew crossed the finish line in 7 minutes 38 seconds, with three lengths to spare.

Many dinners were given tonight at various estates for guests who have arrived for the Independence Day week-end. Mr. and Mrs. Goodhue Livingston gave a dinner at Old Trees for members of their holiday house party, Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Gifford Grace of Bethlehem, Pa., and Aiken, S. C., and Mrs. George Brewster and A. Hamilton S. Post of Baltimore.

Joseph T. Brown, former Assistant Corporation Counsel of New Rochelle, N. Y., died Thursday night in the Mount Morris Park Hospital after a two-week illness. He was 67 years old and lived at 17 The Circle, Rochelle Park.
The New York Telephone Company reported yesterday a net gain of 4,085 telephones in service in June, contrasted with a net loss of 1,745 stations in June, 1936, and a loss of 5,534 in June, 1935.

Two rulings of interest to operators in commodities have been published recently by the Commissioner of Internal Revenue. The rulings were made in response to inquiries of counsel for the Commodity Exchange, Inc., and are contained in letters of the commissioner in answer to the queries.

Thirty of the greatest race drivers in the world, including eight European stars, will send their highpowered racing machines roaring away from the starting line at Roosevelt Raceway at 2:15 tomorrow for the second holding of the renewed Vanderbilt Cup grind.

Trading in round lots by members for their own account on the New York Stock Exchange in the week ended on June 5 dropped to 19.98 per cent of total volume, falling below 20 per cent for the first time since February, according to a summary issued today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Gross assets, $773,554; net, $644,835. To wife, Leonora V. Clarke (deceased), household furnishings, clothing, jewelry, automobiles, specific realty, $10,000 and life income from 33 1-3 per cent of residuary estate in trust, principal to issue: son, Desmonde Clarke, $5,000 and life income from 24 2-3 per cent of residuary

The Public Service Commission directed yesterday that the temporary rates now charged by the Kings County Lighting Company for gas be continued for an additional one-year period or until changed by law.

The brewing industry's expediture for domestic farm products this year will be nearly $130,000,000, it was estimated yesterday by the United Brewers Industrial Foundation on the basis of current quotations for raw materials, and the anticipated production of beer.

Miss Maureen Orcutt, veteran golf star, broke the course record for women at the White Beeches Golf and Country Club today in winning first place in a women's New Jersey Golf Association one-day tourney. She shot a 76 from the men's tees over the par 72 links.

Weekly cotton statistics are as follows: British stocks, 901,000 bales, against 886,000 a week ago, 913,000 two weeks ago, 909,000 three weeks ago and 716,000 a year ago; of which American 340,000 bales, against 352,000 a week ago, 360,000 two weeks ago, 380,000 three weeks ago and 295,000 a year ago.

W. Stebbins Smith, the first president of the Bar Association of Bronx County and the oldest member of the Bronx. County bar, died here suddenly yesterday at the home of a friend, Dr. James Bolton, whom he was visiting. His age was 91.

Frank A. Duggan has been elected a member of the board of directors and executive vice president in charge of hotel operations of Hotels Statler Company, Inc., Mrs. E. M. Statler, chairman of the board, announced yesterday.

Married women in the employ of the Federal Land Bank of Springfield have been notified that their employment will terminate after Jan. 1, the allowance for readjustment including also one additional month for each full year of employment.

Following three consecutive postponements due to unfavorable weather, the play in the annual Meadow Brook Club Cups polo tournaments was resumed today, with three matches in the brook league being contested.

The City Amateur Symphony Orchestra, directed by Municipal Court Justice Leopold Prince, will be heard in concert tonight at 8:30 o'clock on the Mall in Central Park. Avram Weiss, violinist, will be soloist. Tomorrow afternoon at 3 o'clock the orchestra will play in the Music Grove of Prospect Park, Brooklyn.

In the first rebuff given to a foreign nation in the half century of its existence; the Amateur Athletic Union of the United States tonight declined to permit a track and field team to compete in Germany this Summer.

In the most thrilling finish ever witnessed in the eight years that the interscholastic yachting championships have been held, the Belmont Hill crew, with Bill Claffin Jr. at the helm, took possession of the Mallory Trophy by sailing home six seconds ahead of St. Mark's today.

Mrs. Roswell Miller, daughter of Mrs. Andrew Carnegie and the late Mr. Carnegie, is sailing today on the Cunard White Star liner Berengaria to visit her mother at Skibo Castle, accompanied by her son, Roswell Miller 3d, and daughter, Margaret.

As the Manursing Island Club's invitation tournament for Eastern preparatory school tennis players narrowed down today from the original field of 110 to the final two, the logical contenders for the title remained in the running.

Louisiana's Paul Leslie and Freddie Haas meet tomorrow for the national intercollegiate golf championship. Today Leslie got the jump on Bill Barclay of Michigan, nursed his lead carefully and finally won, 3 and 2.

The American Federation of Labor said today that price increases in the last three years had nearly wiped out labor's gains from higher pay. Government figures, the federation said in its monthly business survey, show that the average worker's annual pay has increased $162 since 1933, but that increased living costs have offset all but $17 of that amount.

A requirement that the union provide surety against breach of contract was contained in an agreement signed today to settle the fourweeks' strike at the Albert O. Trostel Sons tannery here. It is believed to be one of the first labor settlements insuring the employer against loss by strikes within the contract period.

In an erort to get action on his Retail Price Maintenance bill, hitherto blocked it this session of Congress by the iirect intervention of President 1oosevelt, Senator Tydings succeedid today in persuading the Senate Committee on the District of Coumbia to attach his measure as a 'rider" to the local tax bill it has inder consideration.

Two giant pandas, among the rarest of animals, trapped by Chinese woodcutters in the hills northwest of Chengtu, were brought here today. The only other known to be in captivity is the baby panda captured in China last year by Mrs. William H. Harkness Jr., who took it to the United States.

The International Congress of World Union for Progressive Judaism opened here today. Delegates from the United States, Great Britain, France and Germany met to devise new religious rules and general lines of conduct for liberal Jewry.

The Bankhead Farm Tenancy Bill, which, after two years, would appropriate $50,000,000 annually to aid tenant farmers to acquire homes and lands of their own, was passed today by the Senate. The vote was not of record and was unanimous.

A rescue by Mrs. Osa Johnson, explorer, of two friends lost in the African jungle thirty miles southwest of Nairobi, Kenya Colony, after a forced landing of their airplane was reported yesterday in a cablegram to friends in New York.

Cloak Operators Union, floor; Dress Pressers Unionq Local No. 60, floor, through Michael E. Lipset Co, in 242 W 36th St; Schuster, Fine Mayleas, Inc. broker. J. Matzinger, optical goods, in 30 E 20th ISt: Lo Curcio Nadelman, ladies' wear, in 27 W 24th St: Bonny Babywear, Inc. in 15 W 26th St; renewals by Bastine Co, Inc. agent.
Joseph A. Maynard, Collector of Customs here, said today that imports landed at Boston during the last fiscal year were valued at $212,419,364, an increase of $77,106,907 over the previous year.
A relatively large drop in interest rate on the $50,000,000 issue of 273-day Treasury bills sold today was announced by Wayne Taylor, Acting Secretary of the Treasury.

The marriage of Miss Jessie Elizabeth Ashworth, daughter of Mrs. Frederick P. Ashworth of Brooklyn and the late Mr. Ashworth, to Victor Myndert Reusch, son of Charles Reusch of Brooklyn and the late Mrs. Reusch, took place yesterday afternoon at the Sixth Avenue Baptist Church, Brooklyn.

After thirty patrolmen, including members of two emergency squads, had worked for two hours in an attempt to revive her, Elizabeth Hall, 13 years old, died of gas poisoning yesterday morning in her home at 4,719 Sixth Avenue, Brooklyn.
Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on June 26 amounted to 773,733 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.

The marriage of Miss Elizabeth Bright, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. G. Howard Bright, to Rodman Morgan, son of Mr. and Mrs. S. Rowland Morgan of Chestnut Hill, Pa.,took place here this afternoon in the garden of her parents home on Cleveland Lane, which was at one time the residence of the late President Woodrow Wilson.

Of the originally outstanding $59,911,100 of ten-year 6 per cent convertible secured notes due in 1944 of the New York Central Railroad, $58,699,300 had been converted on Wednesday, when conversion rights expired, the company announced yesterday. The remaining $1,211,

The one-story commercial building on a lot 20 by 84 feet at 344 East Forty-seventh Street was sold by the 621 Columbus Corporation, Leo T. Silver, president, to the New Era Glass Corporation for occupancy It was sold through Thomas J. O'Reilly, broker, the buyer being represented by S. Friedland and the seller by J. Howard Katz.

The proposal made in the House of Commons in London that Palestine be partitioned in order to prevent conflict between Jews and Arabs was protested in the Senate today by Senator Copeland of New York.

Richard Woodrow Meany, son of Postmaster and Mrs. William S. Meany, and brother of Helen Meany, former Olympic diving champion, of Old Church Road, died at the Greenwich Hospital early today, following a long illness. His age was 22.

A copy of the report made by the special committee on commissions of the New York Stock Exchange to the Exchange's governing committee, recommending changes in commission rates, has been received by the Securities and Exchange Commission but no comment was available today.
Two children and three women are dead from injuries caused by the explosion of a fireworks display in a drug store yesterday. Mrs. T. C.
Owen O'Connor, former Mayor of Fairview, died today in Holy Name Hospital here of an intestinal disorder at the age of 65. He was born in Ireland and came to this country thirty-eight years ago.

Vice President Garner, vacationing at his home here, jokingly chided the stamp-collecting hobbies of President Roosevelt and Postmaster General Farley today, and voiced a preference for other recreations.

Strapping Tommy Pierce of Rutland, 19 years old and a graduate of Clark School up in the Dartmouth environs at Hanover, today annexed the Eastern interscholastic golf crown at the Greenwich Country Club, where the schoolboys gather annually for their championship.

Federal agents have filed tax liens of $76,040 against Mayor Daniel J. Shields and thirteen other persons in Johnstown. The case, which dates from 1924, was prepared in Washington by the tax and penalty division of the Department of Justice. The liens were not filed until this week.

Monroe Hamilton Sweet, son of Dr. and Mrs. Charles C. Sweet of Ossining, N. Y., and Miss Challis Helvie of Ontario, Calif., were married here today at the Sweet Summer home. The bridegroom's father is a psychiatrist.

A request often made by the late John D. Rockefeller to have Bedford Road moved away from the edge of his Pocantico Hills estate may be granted soon, it was learned today when County Engineer Charles H. Sells called a meeting of engineers for next Tuesday to study the proposal.

The Interstate Commerce Commission today permitted fourteen insurance companies holding $57,863,100 of securities of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad Company to intervene in the road's reorganization proceedings.
A determination whether the Holly Sugar Corporation could pay an additional 25-cent dividend on its 500,000 shares of common stock was requested yesterday of Supreme Court Justice Valente.

A substitute court bill, providing an addition of one justice a year to the Supreme Court to supplement those passing 75 years of age and refusing to retire, was introduced in the Senate today by Senate leaders, formally abandoning the President's original program.

The French franc reflected a new-found stability yesterday at around the low level to which it had plunged on Thursday. The exchange continued to be in demand from private sources and the official control again sold whenever the opportunity afforded.

Retail trade here eased further during the week, with the early departure of holiday-seekers and vacationists serving to cut down sales volume. The consumer demand for both Summer apparel and home items was only fair, and substantially behind the active pace of the first half of June.

With no rain of importance in the Cotton Belt, and reports that the crop was progressing favorably in most sections, prices of cotton moved lower here yesterday and the list ended with losses of 12 to 19 points.

The marriage of Miss Eleanor Miller, daughter of former Governor Nathan L. Miller and Mrs. Miller of 2 East Sixty-first Street, New York, and Norwich House, East Norwich, and Francis T. Carmody, son of Mr. and Mrs. Terence F. Carmody of Watertown, N. Y., took place at 12:30 today in St. Dominic's Roman Catholic Church of Oyster Bay. Mgr. Charles J. Canivan performed the ceremony and was the celebrant of the nuptial mass that followed.

Almost every day now, it seems, New York City gets a new section of express highway, a new park, a new or rejuvenated beach or a new bridge. Today's event, aptly timed for the holiday week-end, is the opening of the Marine Parkway Bridge, which gives direct access from the Brooklyn shore to the newly opened Jacob Riis Park and to the Rockaways.
In opening the Canadian pavilion at the International Exhibition here today, Prime Minister Mackenzie King said that no country was more fortunate in its relations with other countries than Canada.
The Manufacturers Trust Company is registrar for 112,500 no-par common shares and 20,026 no-par preference shares of the A. C. Gilbert Company, New Haven, Conn.

The government of Premier Camille Chautemps won another important point today in its preparations for the financial restoration of the country when it obtained the consent of the Senate to a bill authorizing the government to alter tariff rates by decree.

Shaun Kelley Jr. and Miss Jeanne Millet, who are to be married tomorrow afternoon in Stockbridge, were the honored guests at a dinner party given here tonight by Mr. and Mrs. Shaun Kelley at the Berkshire Hunt and Country Club. Mr. and Mrs.

H. J. Ltvine, in 35-15 171st St, Flushing; A. C. Marquardt. in 33-50 159th St, Flushing; H. Albert Johntra, broker. Mrs. A. H. Lummus, Sagitkos Manor. the Robert Gardiner house between Bayshore and Babylon, L. I.; Alexander J. Bruen, the Compton dwelling at Millbrook, N. Y.; Mrs. Peyton Van Rensselaer, broker.

More than 26,000 Boy Scouts, here from all parts of the world for their tenday jamboree, devoted themselves today to frolic and sight-seeing while the national council of the organization met in executive session and re-elected all present officers, including President Roosevelt as honorary president and Herbert Hoover as an honorary vice president, and Walter W. Head of St. Louis as president.

Nikolaus Basseches, dean of foreign correspondents in Moscow, 'received an expulsion order from the Commissariat of Internal Affairs tonight on the eve of the fifteenth anniversary of his arrival in Russia.
