Mr. Basseches, an Austrian, is correspondent for the Neue Freie Presse of Vienna and other foreign newspapers.

Miss Doris F. Latimer of this place, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. William F. Latimer of East Orange, was married this evening in the Ridgewood Methodist Episcopal Church to Victor Duncan O'Brien, son of Dr. and Mrs. Paul O'Brien of East Rutherford. The Rev. Arthur H. Brown, brother-in-law of the bride, officiated.

Elmer F. Andrews, State Industrial Commissioner, announced yesterday the appointment of Paul Sifton as Deputy Industrial Commissioner to succeed William J. Picard, recently appointed by Governor Lehman as chairman of the Board of Standards and Appeals in the Department of Labor. Mr.

Under an agreement with Mayor La Guardia and Aldermanic President William F. Brunner, made public yesterday, the Green Bus Lines, Inc., will extend its Rockaway line over the Marine Parkway Bridge to the junction of Flatbush and Nostrand Avenues in Brooklyn.

Permission to sponsor a contest on "Labor and the Constitution" in the junior and senior high schools of this city is being sought by several trade unions and individuals interested in the labor movement, Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools, disclosed yesterday.

The family party over which President Roosevelt has been presiding at his mother's house here broke up today and the Roosevelts scattered widely, leaving the President to spend a quiet week-end at his mother's home.
The newspaper Asahi objected today to Thursday's editorial in THE NEW YORK TIMES on the recent clash between Soviet and Japanese-Manchukuoan forces on the Amur River. The Asahi says:
With her parents beaming in approval, Lucy Conti, 13 years old, was married this evening to Michael Sanzita, 33, in the Commissioners' Room at City Hall.

The detection and "liquidation" of two large groups of alleged spies-one of seventy members, said to be in the service of Estonia, and the other of fifty to seventy members, said to be in the service of Poland-were disclosed today by Leonid Zakovsky, chief of the Leningrad district of the Commissariat of Internal Affairs [the secret police department].

188th St (11-3081), s w cor Belmont Ave, 87x158; David Rosing to Minnie Rosing, 1,127 Oak St, Far Rockaway, N. Y. Kingsbridge Ave (13-3404A), n e cor Naples Terrace, 105x100; Havemeyer Realty Corp to Lawberne Estates, Inc, 2,721 Wallace Ave; mtg 114,950.

John Corigliano, assistant concert-master of the PhilharmonicSymphony Orchestra, will be the soloist at tonight's concert at Lewisohn's Stadium. He will be heard in the violin concerto in G minor by Bruch originally scheduled for the concert canceled because of tonight's performance of Strauss's "Salome."
No longer are tall stories, horned toads, neokerchief slides, cameras or autographs the main topic of conversation of the National Scout Jamboree. The radio has moved in,

The raucous pealing of a burglaralarm bell, set off when a thief tried to break into a tailor's shop at 190 West 135th Street, brought the owner of the store a summons from the police for "-'aking an unnecessary noise," it was revealed in Washington Heights Court yesterday.

John T. Underwood, retired chairman of the Underwood Elliott Fisher Company, and founder of the Underwood typewriter business, died early this morning at his Summer home, Wianno, Cape Cod, Mass., after a short illness. He was 80 years old.
The Associated General Utilities Company reported yesterday for the year ended on May 31 a total income of $1,84,239, against $862,962 the year before, and a net income of $527,686, against $300,999.

Fireworks, literally speaking, may not be exactly the thing to expect in the comparative confinements of a night club, but plenty of the figurative kind are certain to' be touched off this week-end by the hopeful bonifaces.

A primary fight for the Democratic nomination for Controller was indicated yesterday when former Deputy Controller Frank J. Prial announced his candidacy for that office and Controller Frank J. Taylor declared that he would be a candidate for re-election on his record.
The "Glen Cove Capers of 1937," a revue in aid of the Glen Cove community chest, opened tonight in the Cove Theatre with a cast of local talent in a program of singing and dancing.

Wilson Flohr of Canoe Brook, 19-year-old Dartmouth sophomore, made a clean sweep of the New Jersey State junior golf honors today when he defeated Billy Rohrey, 15year-old Swimming River representative, 2 up, in the final at the Montclair Golf Club. Flohr won the qualifying medal Wednesday with a record card of 69.

Miss Daisy Nicoll, who retired last year as vice principal of the Maple Avenue school here after thirty-eight years of service in the Newark school system, died last night in Presbyterian Hospital after a short illness.

Approval by Governor Lehman of the findings of a general court-martial in the case of Major Charles R. Morrison of the 245th Coast Artillery was announced today by Walter G. Robinson, adjutant general.

The United Automobile Workers of America disciplined three organizers today "because of unauthorized sit-downs" in the Flint, Mich., area, as its Lansing local engaged in a controversy with Governor Frank Murphy.
The Maritime Commission today opened bids on the purchase of six steel cargo vessels of its laid-up fleet for conversion into tankers.

With the week-end holiday focusing attention on vacation necessities, retail distribution was the only branch for which headway of consequence was recorded this week, according to the review issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.

The French financial situation continued to occupy interest on the stock market today. Business was small in volume and was influenced by the end of the account. Most prices were slightly lower at the close.

The Temporary Emergency Relief Administration is within its legal rights in withholding relief from war veterans who have not explained satisfactorily the disposition of their bonuses, Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler ruled yesterday in a test case affecting about 5,000 former soldiers.

The Agricultural Adjustment Administration announced today that representatives from thirty-one wheat States had turned down a proposal that a definite limitation be established on wheat acreage under the Federal farm benefit program for next year.

Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. and his bride, the former Miss Ethel du Pont, who were married in Wilmington, Del., on Wednesday afternoon, left New York yesterday afternoon for Boston after having passed the day at the St. Regis Hotel.

Betty Ann Laxton, 32 months old, rated 25 points above a genius in intelligence today. Dr. M. O. Wilson, Professor of Psychology at the University of Oklahoma, said that tests he gave the child showed her "I. Q." as 145. A score of 120 points for a child her age, he said, would be that of a genius.

Baron Ernle, long known as Rowland Prothero, War Minister of Agriculture and later one of Britain's most distinguished literary peers, died at his home, Gingen Manor, in Berkshire, at the age of 86 yesterday.

The newly created State Labor Relations Board received yesterday at its temporary headquarters, 342 Madison Avenue, the first petition filed with it by a labor organization. Local 302 of the Cafeteria Workers Union asked for an election to determine whether the local, comprising employes of fortyfour Horn Hardart Company cafeterias, should represent these employes as the sole collective-bargaining agency.

The East's last representative in the Eastern intercollegiate tennis championships at the Richmond County Country Club, Dongan Hills, S. I., was defeated yesterday in the quarter-finals as Julius Heldman, brilliant southpaw from U. C. L. A., defeated Howard V. Stephens, Yale, 6-2, 6-1.

The Southern Pacific Company, as owner of 97 per cent of the preferred stock and 77 per cent of the common stock of the St. Louis Southwestern Railway Company, was assailed in a brief filed today with the Interstate Commerce Commission as responsible for the railroad's reorganization.
It probably would have been more appropriate to have made the catch on July 4, just by way of celebrating, but when one lands a broadbill swordfish such a matter readily can be overlooked.
The personnel of the committees and commissions continued or created by the Legislature were announced tonight by Senator Dunnigan and Speaker Heck.

The French financial situation continued to occupy interest on the stock market today. Business was small in volume and was influenced by the end of the account. Most prices were slightly lower at the close.

The Temporary Emergency Relief Administration is within its legal rights in withholding relief from war veterans who have not explained satisfactorily the disposition of their bonuses, Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler ruled yesterday in a test case affecting about 5,000 former soldiers.

The Agricultural Adjustment Administration announced today that representatives from thirty-one wheat States had turned down a proposal that a definite limitation be established on wheat acreage under the Federal farm benefit program for next year.

Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. and his bride, the former Miss Ethel du Pont, who were married in Wilmington, Del., on Wednesday afternoon, left New York yesterday afternoon for Boston after having passed the day at the St. Regis Hotel.

Betty Ann Laxton, 32 months old, rated 25 points above a genius in intelligence today. Dr. M. O. Wilson, Professor of Psychology at the University of Oklahoma, said that tests he gave the child showed her "I. Q." as 145. A score of 120 points for a child her age, he said, would be that of a genius.

Flush Cornell, the cocker spaniel who was one of the modern stage's best known troupers, died yesterday morning after a brief illness. He was but 7 years old, yet into those years he had crowded a success and fame that most Broadway actors never attain.

Miss Emily Benedict McAlpin, daughter of Mrs. Edwin A. McAlpin of this place and the late Rev. Dr. McAlpin, was married here this afternoon to John quincy Adams, son of Mr. and Mrs. Le Roy Adams of Holyoke, Mass., in the Madison Presbyterian Church, which was decorated with white flowers and cybotium ferns. The Rev. John W. Parks performed the ceremony.
THE radio showmen hope July will blow them out of the doldrums in which their etheral show boats have been wallowing since early June. New programs are expected to stir up the waves.

Professor Heinrich Focke has produced here a heliocopter which, it is asserted, has broken all records for this type of machine. It has, ascended to a height of 2,500 meters [about 8,123 feet], has traveled 16,400 kilometers [about 10,184 miles] and has shown an average speed over a twenty-kilometer stretch of 122.2 kilometers [about seventy-six miles] an hour.

The marriage of Miss Geraldine Lee, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Wideman Lee Jr. of New York and this place, to Marcello Girosi, son of Mrs. Eduardo Girosi of Naples, Italy, and the late Rear Admiral Girosi, took place today at the Summer home of her parents here. The Rev. Dr. John Henry of Rye performed the ceremony.

Miss Helen M. Math, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Earle R. Math of this city, was married here today afternoon in Calvary Church to Irving K. Christensen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Knud Christensen of Wood Ridge, by the pastor, the Rev. Dr. Lloyd E. Foster.

Establishment of an advisory committee on music for the 1939 New York World's Fair, with the aim of signalizing and enhancing the position of New York City as the musical center of the world, was announced yesterday by Grover A. Whalen, president of the fair corporation.
President Lazaro Cardenas created today a bank of foreign trade to develop Mexican exports

Hundreds of police will be on duty tomorrow all the way from Kentish Town, North London, to Trafalgar Square, to keep order when Sir Oswald Mosley's British Union of Fascists holds its first march since the passage of the Public Order Act.

Whether the "Summer home" is to be a log cabin in the north woods, a cottage by the sea, or a farmhouse in the country, the housekeeper is likely to want flowers to decorate rooms and porches. A sufficient supply of cut flowers for this purpose is not often to be had or the cost over an extended period is prohibitive.
LAKE HOPATCONG, N. J.-The sailing season will open this morning with the club's fleet of knockabouts, stars and sloops competing for the season's point trophy.

Worn out with the exhaustion that only youngsters could endure, more than 26,000 Boy Scouts from all parts of the world went to sleep in tents tonight, bodies freshly bathed and clean linen for Sunday school ready at their cot-sides.
Mr. and Mrs. Walter T. Stern of 812 Park Avenue, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jean Stern to A. Richard Stern of Danbury, Conn.
A C. I. O. "purge" began today, as the union's axe fell on Gus Hall and two other strike captains in the Mahoning Valley steel sector.

Four Catholic priests and six laymen were sentenced to the penitentiary: here today for periods ranging from one to three years on charges of leading an attack by Catholic Youth on police who halted a Corpus Christi procession. The Catholic Youth had appeared in uniform clothing signifying their membership in the Catholic Youth organization.

The names of three members of the temporary State commission to make a study and survey of the prevalence of cancer and facilities for its treatment were announced by Governor Lehman today. The Senate and Assembly appointments to the commission have been announced.
The American Farm Realty Agency, for many years at 254 Fourth Avenue, this city, has moved into new quarters in the National City Bank Building, 17 East Fortysecond Street, corner of Madison Avenue.
George Whitney of Westbury, L. I., banker, applied today to the Interstate Commerce Commission for authority to be a director of the West Shore Railroad Company, to which he was elected in April,

The Austrian official news agency issued tonight a sharp denial of the official German news bureau report broadcast from German radio stations yesterday that Nazi prisoners in Garsten jail have started a hunger strike,

Ice skating parties were organized here by members of the Summer colony for the ice mardi gras which opened the mid-Summer ice season in Olympic Arena tonight. Tomorrow members of the colony will witness horse races sponsored by the Lake Placid Driving Club.

CANADA'S vast Arctic regions have become so important in the past few years that this Summer for the first time a Governor General of the Dominion will tour the greater part of the area by boat and airplane. Lord Tweedsmuir begins a trip of the Far North on July 22- to visit the old fur posts and the newest mines.

An increasing demand for desirable gasoline station sites in Westchester County has been noted recently, according to Prince Ripley, Inc. The realty firm also points out that there is no lack of funds for investment in such properties where the tenant is one of the large oil companies.

The Southside Garden Club of Long Island held its annual flower show Thursday at St. Mark's Parish House in Islip. Among Sayville and Bayport exhibitors who won awards were Mrs. Elmer T. Zabriskie, Mrs. Martin T. Manton,

About one half of the $25,000 appropriated by the Bergen County Board of Freeholders to finance the investigation of the murder of R. Norman Redwood, Teaneck sandhog union leader, has been spent in the 134 days that have elapsed snice the murder on Feb. 19.
Mrs. Louis Edwin Thompson of Brooklyn has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Diana Campbell, to Robert Morris Exner, son of Dr. and Mrs. Max Joseph Exner of New York.
Every once in a while some British purist or ancient sounds a warning against the ravages of American slang in the inviolate island.

The Foreign Exchange Control Board of the Ministry of Finance today recommended that remittances to the United States by American and other foreign concerns and individuals doing business in Japan be limited to 1,000 yen (about $290) monthly. The present limit is 30,000 yen ($8,700).

The marriage of Miss Kathryn Virginia Philburn, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Valentine F. Philburn of this city, to James F. McNally of Newark, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. William McNally of New York City, took place this morning in Holy Name Church here.

IF buildings in trembling parts of the earth are ever to be quakeproof, the engineer must know about earthquakes. Since he cannot wait for earthquakes to occur, he has to make little ones in the laboratory and study the effect of these on miniature structures.

As a means of reducing accidents in industry, a city-wide survey of the safety practices in the vocational high schools here will be undertaken this week, Mrs. Betty A. Hawley, executive secretary of the Advisory Board on Industrial Education, announced yesterday.

Charging that a "vicious, wild dangerous ostrich" stamped on him at the San Simeon ranch of William Randolph Hearst, Jesse Zelda has filed a $40,000 damage suit against the publisher and the Sunical Land and Packing Company.

The gangster-style murder of Washington Irvin, former Harlan County deputy sheriff, June 23 may result in additional light upon relations between coal mine operators and public officers prior to the Senate civil liberties investigation, but at present there is no evidence that Irvin was killed to prevent his talking.

The Choate School tennis forces made a clean sweep of the fifth annual Eastern preparatory school invitation tournament, concluded at the Manursing Island Club today. Robert Low, the team's No. 1 player, won his final singles assignment from William Gillespie of Scarborough School, 8-6, 2-6, 6-3, 6-2, then, with Henry Daniels, defeated William Thorne and James Reilly of Kent, 6-3, 6-2, 6-4, in the doubles.

Although conditions in the foreign exchange market here were fairly quiet today, the French franc more than maintained yesterday's improvement in spot and forward rates and finished strong at 128 5/8 to the pound.
Lefty Fritz Ostermueller of the Red Sox was given a five-run send-off by his hard-hitting team-mates today and gained his first victory in five starts at the expense of the Athletics, 8--3.
WHY is it that those brave young Englishmen who are always faring forth on dangerous missions of various sorts never think to arm themselves with anything more lethal than a pocket flask?

Miss Katharine W. Kindleberger, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. E. Crosby Kindleberger of Flushing, L. I., and June Cottage, Jamestown, was married today to William Henry Wetherill 2d of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert J. Wetherill of Jamestown and Philadelphia.
President Roosevelt, his family scattered for the Summer, spent a busy day on his mail and on the reports of government departments, covering the fiscal year 1936-37 just ended.

After fifty-two years' teaching, Eldon Van Dusen, head of the commercial department of Far Rockaway High School, will retire Sept. 1. Mr. Van Dusen actually went into retirement, however, when he started on his vacation last week.

Close of play scores in first-class English cricket matches started today were: Yorkshire, 398 (Sutcliffe 138, Verity 76, Hutton 67); Surrey, no runs for no wickets; at Bradford. Warwickshire, 334 for three wickets (Wyatt 155, not out: Dollery 86, not out; Croom 72). vs. Derbyshire; at Birmingham.
When the freighter Delilian sailed today for England a minister from Kingston, Ont., was aboard as a cattleman. The Rev.
Reports from many of the suburban centers of New Jersey show that in the majority of cases home sales during June attained a higher volume than was the case for that month one year ago.
ERMANNO WOLF-FERRARI'S last opera, "II Campiello," recently received its first Berlin presentation at the German Opera House, where it was enthusiastically welcomed by both the public and the press.

STATION UPOL at the Soviet camp at the North Pole is a new tuning goal for all-wave set owners. The transmitter on top of the world is reported to be seeking to establish communication with amateurs on the 20 and 40 meter wave bands.
In the last race of the Royal Henley Regatta, the crew of Tabor Academy of Marion, Mass., defeated the London Rowing Club eight by one length today, thereby retaining the Thames Challenge Cup.

Investment buying in the Jackson Heights area of Queens during the last few weeks has been attracting more than usual interest not only in Queens realty circles but among Manhattan operators and brokers.

More than 100,000 girls will spend their vacations at Girl Scout camps this Summer with many of the units throughout the United States already enrolled to capacity, according to Mrs. Lewis A. DeBlois, executive secretary of the national program division.

With house parties at nearly every estate in the Summer colony, various entertainments were held throughout the day for holiday guests. Mrs. Eliot Betts Hoadley gave a dinner tonight at the Mallows for Mr. and Mrs. Sidney J. Smith, who are passing Independence Day with Miss Ethel Wickham at Bonnie Bourne.

A FEW weeks ago the Bureau of Air Commerce let it be known that many of the country's leading air terminals would be inadequate for the forthcoming big ships of the four-engined Boeing and Douglas types.

JOHN NEAL was the pertinacious son of a Quaker schoolmaster of Portland, Me. He began life as a merchant's clerk and an itinerant penmanship teacher, and was so successful that he was soon able to set himself up in business with John Pierrepont as partner.

AFTER a low production start, coach trailer manufacturers are- doing much better this year than in 1936, according to a survey of the industry's operations. In the first six months of 1937 more coach trailers were built than in the entire twelve months of last year.
This year's grain crop, the harvesting of which is now well under way in the Southern regions, is the brighest feature in the present checkered Soviet picture. Nature has been bountiful.

THE wireless man's dream of an automatic S 0 S alarm has come true. Two instances of emergency were reported during the past week in which the robot S 0 S, developed to meet the Safety of Life at Sea Convention recently ratified by the United States, performed to perfection.
A RECENT decision handed down by Swiss courts decrees that the Rhone Glacier, one of the country's beauty spots, is private property.

Exports from and imports into the United States in May increased materially over those in May, 1936, according to a statement issued today by the Division of Foreign Trade Statistics of the Department of Commerce.

Chances for the rescue of Amelia Earhart and her navigator, Fred Noonan, diminished today when storms turned a big naval flying boat away from the search, leaving only the Coast Guard cutter Itasca in the immediate vicinity of Howland Island in the South Pacific to resume its discouraging quest.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Geraldine Storm, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond W. Storm of Pelham Manor and New York, to Joseph O. Kremer, son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Brainerd Kremer of Montclair, N. J. The engagement was made known last night at a dinner given by Mr. and Mrs. Storm.

A plot of professional assassins to kill leaders of the Communist International, with especially elaborate plans for the death of Georgi Dimitroff, was described today by Leonid Zakovsky, chief of the secret police in Leningrad, in a continuation of his allegations of foreign espionage within the Soviet Union.
Democratic gains, principally in the industrial districts, were revealed in the first day of permanent registration in Allegheny County boroughs and townships, with one-eighth of the vote registered.

Ratification by the State of New Hampshire this week of two interstate flood control compacts has provided a new means of cooperation between the New England States and a method of mutual discussion and solution of regional problems related to New England's greatest natural resource, water power, and control of its streams.
TIENTSIN, China. -The smuggling situation here, which has already ruined many Chinese and foreign firms, but is making Japanese and Koreans rich, has now assumed the aspects of a tragi-comedy.

The Far Eastern friction between Japan and Russia flared into the 185th border "incident" between the two nations last week, and the brief thunder of the guns above the Amur echoed-for a time--in the Kremlin and the Tokyo War Office.
The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated July 1: COMMANDER Bennett, J. T., Med. Corps, the Arkansas, to Naval Hospital, Annapolis, Md.
The leagueleading Cubs fell on Joe Bowman for five runs in the first inning today and continued to a 10-to-5 victory over the Pirates, their fifth triumph in succession.
Dr. Hugh Parshall of Urbana, Ohio, moved back into the Grand Circuit racing picture at Fort Miami today when he won the feature race of the closing program.

THAT long neglected stepchild of the motion-picture industry, the 16 mm. film, seems destined to become an important addition to the documentary shelves of the film libraries of amateur movie enthusiasts.

ADES-Mr. and Mrs. Sam Ades (nee Adele Keilson) of Brooklyn, N. Y., announce with joy the arrival of a son, Richard Louis, on June 27 at Madison Park Hospital, Brooklyn. ARENS-Margo Marilyn. arrived June 28, 1937, at Methodist Episcopal Hospital, Brooklyn.

Business movements in general continued fairly steady last week, with the most encouraging reports coming from agricultural sections of the country, where large amounts of cash released through the sale of bumper crops stimulated all lines of trade.

The Fishers Island Yacht Club will hold a special regatta tomorrow, with trophies, donated by the club, for the winners in the three classes of regular yachts, 11-23 footers, L-16 footers and bullseye. There will be an extra race for yawls, schooners and auxiliaries.

THE Radio Script Exchange, organized last October as a joint effort of the Federal Radio Education Committee and the Office of Education, expects to double if not triple its activities in broadcasting during the next school term, according to Commissioner of Education, John W. Studebaker.
A fire raging in her hold, the Greek freighter Themoni, loaded with coal, grounded on Cachorro Beach on this island today.

Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Mathesius of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elisabeth Mathesius, to Dallas Blair-Smith of New York, son of Mrs. Daniel E. Pomeroy of Englewood, N. J., and the late Hugh Blair-Smith.

The police broadcast an eight-State alarm tonight for Bella McCarthy, 3-year-old daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin McCarthy of 207 Willow Avenue, who disappeared mysteriously late this afternoon while playing in the Church Square Park playground, about two blocks from her home.

June 1-Left Miami, Fla., at 6:47 A. M., Eastern daylight time, for San Juan, P. R., where she landed 8 hours 17 minutes later. June 2-Landed at Caripito, Venezuela, at 11:18 A. M., E. D. T., after four-hour flight from San Juan.

Geraniums are among the simple subjects for the home gardener to deal with. They represent but a slight initial investment. Geraniums with strong woods, such as is produced by the salmon and scarlet varieties (Beaute Poitevine and Alphonse Riccard) almost always can be depended on to develop a floriferous top.

Mel Porter of the Millrose A. A., national marathon champion, won the thirteen-mile modified marathon yesterday, the feature attraction of the sports carnival presented at the celebration marking the completion of the new Franklin D. Roosevelt Boardwalk at South Beach, Staten Island.

Both the first and second seeded men were upset victims in the semifinal round of the Eastern intercollegiate tennis championships at the Richmond County Country Club, Dongan Hills, Staten Island, yesterday.

Hundreds of members of the Christian Endeavor Society, representing many communities in. the State, marched through Syracuse this afternoon in a mile-long parade, the climax of their golden jubilee convention.

100 Meters-Perrin -Walker, unattached, College Park, Ga. 200 Meters-Jack Weierhauser, Olympic Club. 400 Meters-Ray Malott, Olympic Club. 800 Meters-John Woodruff, Pitt. *1,500 Meters-Glenn Cunningham. N. Y. Curb Exchange.
William Grayson, 72 years old, bought fireworks today for his 10year-old grandson, Edward Earl, but decided that the boy was too young to handle them.

Middle-Western farmers are enjoying the relatively novel experience of harvesting the best wheat crop they have grown in six years and sending it to town to be sold on a rising market, a market which is paying right around that agricultural ideal which is called parity.

Governor Earle today cleared his desk of legislation passed by the General Assembly by signing 120 bills, including the Frey measure limiting employment after Dec. 1 to forty-four hours a week. He vetoed seventeen bills.

GALLERY: King George and Queen Elizabeth opened last week the new sculpture section of the Tate Gallery. The King commented: "We now have in London a home where the work of British and foreign modern sculptors can worthily be shown.

Designers of trunks, bags, valises and portmanteaus, although they have noted the long ocean-liner passenger lists, swelled by students and teachers released from school and college, are aware that swarms of people are taking their vacations by motor and have given these special attention. Ingenious pieces of baggage have been contrived for the limited space available in automobiles.

ON a March evening in 1917 people were crowding into the City Auditorium at Lincoln, Neb. Seats filled, hundreds were forced to stand, and still other hundreds were turned away. Tension gripped all in that auditorium.
The Staten Island C. C., defeated by the visiting Brooklyn C. C. eleven at Walker Park, Livingston, was eliminated yesterday from the annual cup competition of the United States Cricket Association.

After thirty-five years of service to the State as botanist at the Agricultural Experiment Station, Dr. George Perkins Clinton has ended his administrative duties. He will remain at the station, however, to continue scientific research in plant diseases and to give advice in a new capacity of consulting botanist.

Two Blue Point oysters demonstrated the versatility of a golf ball on the bottom of Great River adjoining the twelfth green of the Timber Point course, here, according to Nicholas Vignate of East Main Street, Patchogue.

With the agreement of the Russian Government to withdraw its river naval forces from the islands in the Amur, possession of which is in dispute between the U.S.S.R. and Manchukuo, the strained situation between Moscow and Tokyo seems, at least for the time being, to have been distinctly relieved.

Mayor La Guardia called public attention yesterday to the city ordinance prohibiting the sale and use of fireworks and asked parents to keep fireworks out of the hands of their children over the Fourth of July holiday.

A STOPPEROVER in Gotham this week is Edmund Lowe, on his way from. England and a screen version of Edgar Wallace's "The Squeaker" for Alexander Korda to Hollywood and a probable appearance in the next Mae West picture, when, as,
With forty-one seats yet to be filled, President Eamon de Valera early today needed to win only twenty of them to gain an absolute parliamentary majority in the Free Stae's election.
The freighter Thorpehall, flying a British flag, was held tonight for a court ruling on the ownership of its cargo of money and jewels from Insurgent-captured Bilbao, Spain.

Four youths were under arrest at Newark Police Headquarters tonight in connection with the systematic theft of about $25,000 worth of jewelry delivered by New York and Boston firms at the Newark Airport for shipment to cities in the West by express.

Savings, building and loan associations throughout the country made during May loans on homes totaling $123,129,600, according to an estimate by the United States Building and Loan League, which declares that the loans went to about 51,480 families.

Mr. and Mrs. John Perry Spiker of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Virginia Louise Spiker, to Gordon Foster Wing of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Sewall Wing of Newton Center, Mass.

Miss Dorothy Lindsey, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Fred R. Lindsey, was married today at the home of her parents here to John Osterheld Deming, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Willard Deming of 121 Madison Avenue, New York.

A large representation of socially prominent women of Rumson, Red Bank, Middletown, Deal, Elberon, Shrewsbury and this city took part in the tag day held today throughout Monmouth County to raise funds for Monmouth Memorial Hospital.
IN spite of exceptionally good business in both new and used cars the automobile dealers in this area have found plenty of troubles to harass them in the half year which closed last week.
James Graham, 4 years old, of 117 Corbin Avenue, Jersey City, was killed yesterday afternoon by a bus on Hudson Boulevard, Journal Square, Jersey City.

The decision of the Interstate Commerce Commission fixing the metropolitan area of New York for purposes of exemptions under the Motor Carrier Act "has almost cut the New York district in two," a petition filed today by the Port of New York Authority asserted. It asked the commission to reconsider the decision.

With battle lines sharply drawn and a three-day armistice declared in their own turbulent pennant campaigns, the pick of the American and National Leagues, led by Managers Joe McCarthy and Bill Terry, will converge this week on Washington, where on Wednesday professional baseball will stage its fifth annual midsummer classicthe All-Star game.
T. Reid Fell, former general agent here for the Massachusetts Mutual Life Insurance Company, died yesterday in his home at 375 Park in Avenue after an illness of several weeks. He was 72 years old.

As a result of the experience gained in real estate management policies during the last few years by many institutions which, owing to the depression, were compelled to take over large realty holdings, a marked improvement is now being seen in the managerial methods of such organizations, points out Clement E. Merowit, apartment house owner and manager.
During the month of July dog show activities are completely suspended throughout the Eastern section of the United States and in all the country only half a dozen events have been scheduled.

The summary of transactions by officers, directors and principal stockholders in equity securities for May, which included also some delayed reports for earlier months, made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission, showed several gifts, including one of 4,530 common shares of General Motors with a current market value of about $225,000, made by William S. Knudsen of Detroit, president of the corporation.

AFTER "Poppea" the second most important novelty of the festival was the third series (first time anywhere) of "Choruses of Michelangelo Buonarotti the Younger" by Luigi Dallapiccola, a leading exponent of the young Italian school.

Miss Rose Cecilia Kelly, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Patrick Henry Kelly of Rockville Centre, L. I., was married yesterday morning in St. Agnes Roman Catholic Church, Rockville Centre, to Eugene Vincent Lawson, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Lawson, also of Rockville Centre. The ceremony was performed by Mgr. Peter Quealy.

PROGRAMS at the Stadium this week will feature the People's Chorus directed by Lorenzo Camilieri tonight, Amparo and Jose Iturbi as piano soloists Wednesday and Fritz Reiner's first appearance at the Lewisohn Stadium on Friday.

Germany and Italy further cemented their friendship today by agreeing to close cooperation on socio-political questions and the promotion of regular exchange of workers for "furtherance of good relations of all nations"

Two strike-bound liners carrying 378 passengers, cargoes and United States mails sailed eight hours late yesterday after day-long negotiations between officials of the Atlantic, Gulf and West Indies Lines and maritime labor leaders.

PARIS has been overhauling its street names again. The latest of these recurrent overhauls has had two results-(a) there is now a Rue Pushkin, named for the great Russian writer whose centenary was observed a few weeks ago;

When the President of the French Chamber of Deputies puts his silk hat on the table, the session is called to order. When he puts his hat on his head, the session is suspended. In one day last week Edouard Herriot, President of the Chamber, removed and replaced his hat three times-so heated had become the parliamentary debate over the future of the franc.

With all but two of its components higher, THE NEW YORK TIMES weekly index of business activity for the week ended June 26 has advanced to 107.5, which compares with 107.1 (revised) for the previous week and 99.6 for the corresponding week last year.

The enclosed roof terrace of the main grandstand became the rendezvous for many of the box holders and their guests when the rain drove them from the uncovered sections before the scheduled start of the second running of the Vanderbilt Cup race at the Roosevelt Raceway today.

Six thousand Catholics arrived in the capital today from the State of Queretaro, northeast of this city, to ask the reopening of five churches including the Cathedral in the capital of the State, also named Queretaro. Nearly 2,000 made the 200mile trip on foot.

Dr. and Mrs. Hugh James Lenahan of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Catherine Francis Lenahan, to John J. O'Donnell of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles M. O'Donnell of Wilkes-Barre, Pa.

SINCLAIR LEWIS has been arguing that since people do not read as much as they used to, writers will have to write for the air and the screen. That is, if they want to keep on writing at all. But that will not help very much, either.

Miss Aubrey, speedy bay filly owned by Uzal H. Martz, Pottsville, Pa., captured the 3-year-old trot today. The favorite, Arlene Hanover, broke a bone in her ankle while leading late in the second heat and was withdrawn.

A society whose engineers are interested only in mechanisms and disregard social implications is doomed, Professor Thomas N. Whitehead of Harvard University declared in an address yesterday before 1,500 members of the Society for the Promotion of Engineering Education. The meeting was held at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
Rain caused the postponement of the three polo matches scheduled for today at the Meadow Brook Club in the Meadow League division of the Meadow Brook Club Cups tourney for twenty-goal teams.

Possible changes in the design of school buildings in New York were discussed last Tuesday at a meeting of the Architectural Commission, composed of architects and engineers from this and other cities and not connected in any way with the New York school system.

With its work confined to marksmanship tests in rifle, automatic rifle, machine-gun and Howitzer firing, the Manhattan and Brooklyn Guardsmen of the Ninety-third Infantry Brigade, composed of the 165th Infantry, commanded by Colonel Alexander E. Anderson, and the Fourteenth Infantry, commanded by Colonel William R. Jackson, ended their first week of training here at Camp Smith today.
The appointment of Newbold T. Lawrence as general manager of the United States Lines Company was announced yesterday by John M. Franklin, president.

George Seewagen and Percy L. Kynaston, seeded fifth and eighth, respectively, were among those to advance yesterday in the annual Queens County tennis tourney at the Seminole Club, Forest Hills, L. I. Seewagen gained the third round by beating George Schaeffer, 6-3, 6-4. The veteran Kynaston defeated Richard Dowson, 6-4, 6-0, to enter the second round.

The twenty-ninth semi-annual survey of real estate conditions throughout the country by the National Association of Real Estate Boards shows that realty prices are higher in 84 per cent of the leading cities than was the case one year ago.
Miss Dorothy Marie Despard, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Edward Despard of East Orange, was married this afternoon to Philip Henry Conner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Conner of Wilmington, Del.

A PART from the fact that both are New Yorker contributors, Mr. Moffat and Richard Lockridge share many traits in common. Like "Mr. and Mrs. North," which preceded it only recently, "The Mott Family in France"

MY WAR WITH THE UNITED STATES. By Ludwig Bemelnians. 12mo. New York: The Viking Press. $2.50. The diary of a German who enlisted in the United States Army. AN EVENING WITH A. E. HOUSMAN. By Cyril Clemens. 12mo. International Mark Twain Society, Webster Groves. Mo. $1.50.

A series of psychological experiments now under way at Teachers College, Columbia University, indicates that highly intelligent children maintain their intellectual superiority through life. The child who showed signs of superior intelligence at an early age can be expected to fulfill the promise of childhood in his later years.
WHEN Kenneth Roberts really lays himself out to tell a story in his own chosen field of early American history, the reader may be pretty sure that there will be no adulterants in the entertainment.

POLAND presents a new type in recent coinage, for instead of using the head of Marshal Joseph Pilsudski or other personage on the obverse, a three-masted vessel of ancient vintage is shown in relief. The 2-zlote and 5-zlotych silver pieces just received are of the same design.

SHOW business appears to have turned more active in book circles lately than at other times. Nor is this an illusion due to the normal seasonal relaxing of tension along the auction front and elsewhere in the trade.

Seven football stars who were graduated from metropolitan New York colleges last month have accepted Coach Andy Kerr's invitation to play on the Eastern All-Star football team which will meet the New York Giants at the Polo Grounds Sept. 8 under the auspices of The New York Herald-Tribune.

Misinterpretation of steps taken by Paul V. McNutt, United States High Commissioner to the Philippine Commonwealth, to assure correct procedure at formal functions created the "toasting" incident of Manila, Wayne Coy, administrative assistant to Mr. McNutt, writes in the current issue of the weekly Hoosier Sentinel, Indiana Democratic party organ.

Warning that the estimated $9,000,000,000 credit sales total this year threatens a setback to American business and to the welfare of consumer-employes who have mortgaged their future income, Herbert N. Fell, executive secretary of the Thrift and Security Foundation, said it is vital for employers to take immediate steps to promote thrift among their employes.
Swinburne Hale, retired New York lawyer, formerly prominent in various liberal groups, died here today in the Westport Sanitarium at the age of 53 after an illness of several years.

Miss Mary Louise Johnson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Johnson of Glen Ridge, will be married to John Shroyer Bailey, son of Mr. and Mrs. W. J. Bailey of East Orange, on July 13. The ceremony will be performed at Arlington Avenue Presbyterian Church, East Orange, by the Rev. L. Ward McCreary.

King George VI, Queen Elizabeth and their two daughters will leave London tomorrow night on a State visit to Scotland. They will drive through. Edinburgh Monday morning with streets lined with thousands of spectators and troops.
Nine alleged Communists, all Venezuelans exiled by government, were deported to Mexico by the Government of Panama on the steamship Virginia last night.

Miss Mona Jean MacMillan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert E. MacMillan of Johnstown, Col., was married here to Hoch Reid, son of Mr. and Mrs. James Winfred Reid of New York, yesterday in the Chapel of Christ Methodist Episcopal Church by the Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman, the pastor.

Charles V. Bossert, son of Louis Bossert, who amassed a fortune in the lumber business in Williamsburg and who built the Hotel Bossert at Montague and Hicks Streets, Brooklyn Heights, filed a petition in bankruptcy yesterday in Federal Court in Brooklyn..

Miss Louise Henderson Carter, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Dewey J. Carter of Glenbrook, was married to Howand Henry Tyler, son of Mrs. John Tyler of Noroton, tonight in the Union Memorial Church, Glenbrook, by the Rev. Samuel J. Evers. The bride wore her mother's wedding gown and carried a white prayer book with a spray of lilies of the valley.
LEE PATTISON sailed eight days ago for a trip through Europe, with the festivals at Munich, Salzburg and Bayreuth figuring conspicuously on the itinerary.

ON a Summer Sunday evening of last year the inhabitants of Somerset were startled by the sight, low over head, of the Hindenburg back from New York. It flew low: one could read the name and see the swastika without any difficulty; it was a superb sight,
The War Department released the following orders today, dated July 2. COLONEL McCabe, E. R. W. (F. A.). General Staff Corps, to duty as Assistant Chief of Staff, G-2.

Atop the Music Hall in Rockefeller Center the first skyscraper roof sports garden has been opened. Facilities for handball, volley ball and paddle tennis are supplied. Playing space is bordered by two panels in which grow yews, hawthorns, cherry and cork-bark trees. Ivy masks the parapets.

The Vixen III, a 58-foot sloop owned and sailed by J. D. Archbold, Bar Harbor, Me., today finished first in the sailing race from Gibson Island to Annapolis. The Sewanna, entered and sailed by James Roosevelt, son of the President, was third.

A new chapter in the development of the commercial and industrial facilities of the West Side of Manhattan was written last week when the New York Central's Diesel-electric locomotive No. 528 drew a train of cars along the new tracks in the deep cut between Tenth and Eleventh Avenues from Sixtieth Street down to Thirty-fifth Street.
Miss Harriet Mae Terhune, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry E. Terhune of this place, was married this afternoon to Henry Lee Baker Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry L. Baker, also of Nutley.

While retail trade figures for the last two weeks did not maintain the fast pace of the first half of June, nevertheless they do not compare unfavorably with the figures of a year ago, which were swollen by the spending of soldier bonus payments. Gains for last month are anticipated in populous sections of the country, the exception being those hit by actual labor disturbances or by loss of confidence due to labor unrest.

BASS fishermen are abroad now, casting flies for small-mouth on wilderness lakes in the North, hurling ganghooked plugs oer lagoons in the Everglades in quest of giant large-mouth, or bait-fishing with killies or earthworms near the shores of Kensico Reservoir or any of the numerous other angling waters in the New York City outskirts.

Miss Helen H. Cannon, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Walter B. Cannon, became the bride of Douglas D. Bond at the home of her parents here this afternoon. Mr. Bond is the son of Dr. and Mrs. Earl D. Bond of Bryn Mawr, Pa.

Total resources of the Brooklyn Trust Company on June 30 amounted to $128,817,411, compared with $137,095,724 on March 31. Deposits were $112,770,628, against $121,215,468, and surplus was $50,000 higher at $4,250,000.

Mr. and Mrs. Robert Boissevain are at their cottage in the neighboring village of Lewis. Sea Miss, L. Howland Brown's yacht, has arrived for lake cruises. Mr. Brown has leased The Elms cottage for the season.

Miss Alison Harrison of Philadelphia who yesterday eliminated the favorite, Miss Patricia Henry of Los Angeles, today won the women's Middle States tennis championship, beating 17-year-old Miss Hope Knowles, Philadelphia, 1-6, 6--3 6--4.

James Dorment and Robert L. Goetz, builders of the six-story Kenilworth apartment house on Kenilworth Place, between Farragut and Glenwood Roads, Brooklyn, announce that 80 per cent of the suites are rented, although the structure will not be fully completed until the end of the present month.

Discontinued as an official unit of the WPA Federal Art Project, the Design Laboratory has become affiliated with the School of the Federation of Architects, Engineers, Chemists and Technicians, It was announced yesterday.

It is really putting out to sea when a New Yorker starts a vacation cruise to Martha's Vineyard and Nantucket. They are out in the open Atlantic and some waggish townsman at Siasconset, on the eastern shore of Nantucket, has erected a signboard pointing eastward to Portugal as the next landing place.

CONSIDERABLE interest attaches to the announcement made last week that the Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation has been established "for the promotion and encouragement of art and education in art and the enlightenment of the public especially in the field of art."
Several entertainments have been arranged in connection with the seventh annual Country Club Horse Show to be held from Friday through Sunday on the grounds of the Westchester Country Club here.

The reindeer herds of Alaska now contain more than 600,000 animals, owned by about 3,500 persons, according to a recent estimate of the Department of Interior. The Federal Government, through its reindeer service staffed by seven employes, supervises these herds over a vast area, from Bristol Bay to Point Barrow, on the mainland, and also on several islands.
The Federal Communications Commission gave the first indication today that it would approve operation of additional radio broadcasting stations by daily newspapers.

Residential builders are giving more value in today's homes than they did in 1929, despite rising material and labor costs, declares Joseph B. Mason, Eastern editor of The American Builder. A new house, in his opinion, is still one of the best investments.

Playing about as well as he did the day he defeated Sidney Wood in the national championship a few years back, Frank Bowden gained the final round of the invitation turf court tennis tournament of the Nassau Country Club this afternoon with a crushing 6-3, 6-2 victory over Paul Newton of the University of California.

Throughout Europe and in many parts of the British commonwealth it was hoped that Neville Chamberlain's first speech in the House of Commons as Prime Minister would answer the various questions as to whether the British Government really has a well thought out policy or whether it is merely striving to stave off European disaster and hoping the Spanish conflict will not extend beyond Spain.

THE Federal Government is the largest non-paying sponsor on the nation's networks and radio stations, it was emphasized recently as the Byrd committee on government reorganization disclosed that at least $150,000 a year is being spent just to prepare programs.
The Dodgers dropped back to earth with a dull thud today, beaten by the close confines of this hat-box ball park and the very good pitching of Claude Passeau.

David Cronheim, Newark broker, reports that his organization during the first six months of the present year has sold 349 properties in North Jersey areas for various financial institutions and building and loan associations for a total of $4.898.250.
WHILE the Nobel and Pulitzer Prizes may be the biggest plums in the literary orchard, they are not in all respects the most interesting of the awards open to the competition of men of letters.

The prospects of an early break in the Nanking-Tokyo diplomatic deadlock are gloomy, according to the Japanese Ambassador,- Shigeru Kawagoe, who returned today to his post in Nanking after two months of conferences in Tokyo, although he stressed that both governments were working for a better understanding.
The struggle over proposals for reorganization of the judiciary has developed into a straight-out political fight with the control of the Democratic party at stake, Senator Logan asserted today.

The Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America warned the Robins Dry Dock and Repair Company yesterday that it would not allow any strike breakers to be taken into the yard which the union understands is to be reopened next week.

Miss Sanchia Doorly of Weyford Terrace, has completed plans for her marriage to Charles J. Lundgren Jr., also of Garden City. The ceremony which will take place on Saturday in the Cathedral of the Incarnation, will be performed by Dean Arthur B. Kinsolving 2d. A reception will be held at the Garden City Hotel.

Sixteen of the twenty-one American republics were represented at the second international conference on American history which opened here today for a ten-day session. Only Costa Rica, Cuba, Haiti, Honduras and El Salvador were not represented.

EKTINCTION threatens several of the most historic life-saving stations on the Cape Cod's Great Beach, and Provincetown, Truro and other haunts of sea-lovers are up in arms against what they regard as a mistaken idea of economy on the part of the Federal Government.
Walter Cary, vice president of the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company, died yesterday after a heart attack at his home, 510 Park Avenue. He was 66 years old.
Miss Ruth Eleanor Fellows, daughter of Lester Fellows of East Orange and the late Mrs. Fellows, and George Lennart Palmgren of Hawthorne, son of Mr. and Mrs. Franz O. Palmgren of Lowell, Mass.,
Although final results of the Irish election are not available at this time, it is apparent that President Eamon de Valera has been returned by a large vote for another term of office.

Two left-behind mates of the roundthe-world fliers lost in the Pacific passed part of the afternoon trying to bolster each other's sinking hopes as the hours brought no certain word from Amelia Earhart or her navigator, Frederick J. Noonan.

The following Foreign Service changes since June 26 were announced today by the State Department: James B. Young of Philadelphia, Counselor of the Legation and Consul General at Vienna, assigned to Lisbon, as Consul General.

THE news that John Grierson, head of the postoffice film unit and the man who has done most to establish the prestige of British documentary films, is resigning his post in order to employ his talents in a wider sphere, draws attention to the immense field which this type of film now covers.

Indications that the records for volume exports established last year by electrical, commercial and household refrigerators and by radio sets and tubes will be broken this year are seen by appliance manufacturers in the exceptional foreign demand for electrical goods so far this year.

The WPA education program has reduced illiteracy in the United States by onesixth, according to an estimate recently made for the House Appropriations Committee by Administrator Hopkins. During the past three years WPA instructors have taught 700,000 men and women how to read newspapers and write letters.
Operations were resumed today in the South Chicago plant of the Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company, closed since a strike began on May 26.

The second championship regatta of the Barnegat Bay Yacht Racing Association was held today with the Mantoloking Yacht Club host to the seven other clubs on the bay. A total of 106 craft sailed in ten classes.
WASHINGTON.-In the new library at Howard University, PWA funds will help to bring under a single roof one of the world's most important collections of anti-slavery material.

Like a hawk coasting and wheeling, this Rhonsperber sailplane scuds along the sky above Elmira, N. Y. It is one of the fleet of motorless aircraft assembled there for the Eighth Annual National Soaring Contest, which began June 26 and will continue until July 11.

THE St. Louis Opera Company will begin its fifth season Nov. 22 in the opera house of the Municipal Auditorium, St. Louis, Mo., with a performance of "Rigoletto," in which Erna Sack, colorature soprano of European renown, will appear as Gilda.
Government highway experts said today that the United States was now the greatest road builder in all history, yet only a start had been made toward improving its 3,000,000 miles of roads.

AN aftermath of the bombing of the German battleship Deutsch land off Spain is hailed in British flying circles as proving the practicability of operation by plane over an "all-red route" between England and the Far East, with stops only on British territory.

ATAXIDERMIST, popularly conceived to be a person who "stuffs" the skins of animals, fish and birds, is really a combination modeler, anatomist, naturalist, interior decorator, blacksmith, carpenter, artist in oils and chemist.
The problem of the blockade of the Loyal Spanish coast became vital this week when a submarine, believed to be Italian, sank the freighter Cabo Palos off Alicante.

William Cabell Bruce, former United States Senator and for many years one of the most prominent lawyers in Maryland, has retired from practice at the age of 77 to devote his entire time to writing a life of Thomas Jefferson.

John J. Lenehan, Assistant Prosecutor of Hudson County and a native of this town, died early today in St. Michael's Hospital, Newark, at the age of 42. He was taken ill in the Prosecutor's office in the court house at Jersey City on April 29 and underwent several operations for stomach ulcers.

Mexico will march to the polls tomorrow for the first time in three years and in all probability give President Lazaro Cardenas and his policies for the nationalization of industry and the division of landed estates an overwhelming vote of approval.

Miss Martha Wilhelmina Bray, daughter of Frank Chapin Bray of this city and the late Mrs. Bray, was married yesterday at noon to John Fairbairn Jenkisson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alvan W. Jenkisson of Chicago, in the chapel of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church.

Real estate conditions in the Bronx are continuing to show healthy improvement, states Elmer C. Gates, president of the Real Estate Board of the Bronx, in a recent review of the realty status in the borough.

Extension of the waterfront truce between A. F. of L. and C. I. O. unions to cover the lumber workers of the Brooklyn waterfront is being sought, it was announced yesterday by Mervyn Rathborne, president of the American Radio Telegraphists Association and chairman of the local council of the National Maritime Union, affiliate of the C. I. O.

Franklin D. Roosevelt, Jr. and his bride, the former Ethel, du Pont, arrived here early tonight. Captain Franklin Calder, caretaker of President Roosevelt's Summer home on the island, announced they had arrived, but refused to give any further information.

For the first time since he lost in the eighth round to Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of Paris, Samuel Reshevsky, United States champion, lost a game today in the international chess masters tournament in progress at the Kurhaus. It was the thirteenthround adjourned match from yesterday in which he was paired with the German representative, L. Rellstab of Berlin.

Six Massachusetts C. I. O. aides, jailed during the recent LewistonAuburn shoe strike for contempt of court, were released in $2,000 bail each today by order of Supreme Court Justice Sidney St. Felix Thaxter.

Against a background of current national industrial and social turbulence, New York State now has in effect two new major instrumentalities designed to promote peace, harmony and equity between employers and employes-a State Labor Relations Board and a State Board of Mediation.

The holiday week-end finds many of the Summer residents in their homes here for the season, among them Mr. and Mrs. Edwin P. Maynard of the Hotel Bossert, Brooklyn, who have arrived at their house on Quiogue. Mr. and Mrs. Norvin Greene and their two children are occupying their home on the dunes for the season.

While a light breeze played tricks all around the compass and the clouds loosed a heavy but brief rain squall today, 134 boats sailed in the New Rochelle Yacht Club's regatta, eighth in the Yacht Racing Association's championship series.

The ninth congress of the International Chamber of Commerce ended today with a session at which under Thomas J. Watson's chairmanship twentyfive resolutions were adopted embodying the results of the week's deliberations by a record number of businessmen from all parts of the world.

Max Franklin Millikan, son of Dr. Robert A. Millikan, noted scientist, and Miss Jeanne MacBeth Thomson filed here today intentions to wed. The son of the executive head of California Institute of Technology will seek a Doctor's degree in economics at Yale University next Fall.

WE are come again to that distressing time of the year when the drama's Mr. Atkinson picks up his robes and scampers to Prink Hill to write "No Sunday Article"; and when this conscientious corner picks up its card index and scurries to its desk to write "Semi-Annual Report."
THE first half of the current year ended last Wednesday, and philatelists, taking stock, are predicting that 1937 will take high rank among the years of the past decade.

PENNSYLVANIA'S "Dream Highway" is about to come true. Construction of a superartery of traffic, stretching 164 1/2 miles,, half-way across the State between points near Carlisle and Pittsburgh, has been authorized by the State Legislature in an act signed by Governor George H. Earle.

THE tourist who this Summer finds his way over the Mount Vernon Memorial Highway to the stately red-roofed mansion of George Washington will discover a Mount Vernon resembling more closely than ever before Washington's home as he himself knew it.
The Archbishop of Canterbury, in an address to a diocesan conference this week said his office during recent months had been "incredible, indefensible and inevitable."
With excellent weather throughout the South and reports that the monsoon in India continued favorable, prices on the Cotton Exchange moved lower again yesterday.
Brooklyn at New York-Mungo vs. Castleman. Boston at Philadelphia (2)-Fette and Bush vs. La Master and Walters. St. Louis at Cincinnati (2)--1. Dean and Warneke vs. Grissom and Davis.

Joe Foley of Chicago, co-promoter of the Louis-Braddock heavyweight title fight, said today he was considering matching Champion Joe Louis and the former holder of the crown, Max Baer, in Chicago in the Fall.

Miss Catherine Hopkins, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Walton H. Hopkins of this city, was married here to Ensign Leslie Martin Slack, United States Navy, this afternoon in St. Anne's Church, by the rector, the Rev. Edward Darlington Johnson.

Miss Jean McMillen, daughter of Captain Fred E. McMillen, Supply Corps, U. S. N., and Mrs. McMillen, was married here this afternoon in Memorial Church to Hugh R. Jones, son of Mrs. Hugh R. Jones of New Hartford and the late Mr. Jones. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. W. C. Prout of this place and the Rev. Charles D. White of Utica.

A group of about fifty widely known guest lecturers will participate in the Summer session of New York University which will reach its peak of registration Tuesday with the opening of five additional educational units.
An answer to an important point in the Wagner Labor Act-Do craft unions have the right to bargain for minority groups in plants where an industrial union has a majority?
THE exhibition is carrying on the theatrical season into months which are usually dead, and we have had two important new productions in the last few weeks.

Last night's concert of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, under Vladimir Golschmann, at the Lewisohn Stadium attracted an audience of 3,000 persons. John Corigliano, assistant concertmaster of the orchestra, was the soloist. His vehicle was the violin concerto in G minor of Bruch, a masterpiece which never fails of its effect when adequately performed.

STROUDSBURG, Pa.-The largest number of guests in many years has arrived in the Poconos for the Fourth of July weekend, and everywhere special arrangements have been made for their entertainment. Practically every resort in the entire area is filled to capacity.

Mr. and Mrs. John D. Rockefeller are expected to arrive this week at their home, the Eyrie, in Seal Harbor. Other members of the Rockefeller family who are expected to occupy their homes on the Rockefeller estate at the same time are Mr. and Mrs. John D. Rockefeller 3d and Mr. and Mrs. Nelson Rockefeller.

Miss Margaret Merker, 20 years old, of 610 Concord Avenue, the Bronx, died of a fractured skull tonight in Mount Vernon Hospital, the result of a fall from a horse on a bridle path adjacent to Split Rock Road in the Bronx, yesterday.

The marriage of Miss Viola C. Carpenter, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter E. Carpenter of this city, to A. Stanley Ammerman Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. A. S. Ammerman of Lexington, Ky., took place this evening at the rectory of the Central Christian Church of East Orange. The pastor, the Rev. Vere E. Gillespie, performed the ceremony.

Japanese military observers believe the Far Eastern Red Army, whose strength, morale and equipment have been the subject of much Soviet boasting in recent years, is not in good condition. This conviction is part of the background of the Amur affair, which only now is beginning to show.

A store room became today the new home of studious William A. Mellon, cousin of Andrew W. Mellon. The huge room, 150 feet long, will offer refuge for his work even amid the rush and traffic din of downtown business. Mr. Mellon is a student of genetics.

Many of the early Spring flowering plants of border and rock garden can readily be propagated at this time to supply additional stock for another year. This is particularly true of creeping and spreading types such as Phlox subulata and most of the sedums.
TECHNOLOGY, which has revolutionized the manufacture of many household furnishings used extensively by modern decorators, is making new contributions even to the prehistoric art of pottery,

Admitting that when the moratorium on mortgage foreclosures came into existence it was generally helpful, Joseph F. Mittelman, loan broker, points out that at present many home owners who are in a position to make amortization payments on their mortgages are taking advantage of the extension of time.
The veteran outfielders, Chick Hafey and Kiki Cuyler, today batted the Reds to their first victory of the season over the Cardinals, a 3-to-2 triumph in ten innings.
AS may be expected of a story adapted from a radio serial into novel form, "Wilderness Road" is sustained chiefly by action and conversation.

One of the largest privately financed housing projects undertaken in Manhattan in several years was announced yesterday when builders purchased a block front on Riverside Drive between Eighty-sixth and Eighty-seventh Streets for a nineteen-story apartment house.

Few tender pot plants give the all round Winter and Summer satisfaction that is to be had from members of the Lantana family. The sturdy bushes, covered with gay-colored verbena-like flower heads in orange, yellow cream and violet, are a joy alike in the greenhouse, the window garden and the Summer flower border.
A discharged pump-runner of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation's Cambria plant here was under arrest tonight in connection .with an attempt to dynamite a freight train.

THE novelty and pleasure of motoring these hot days through walls of snow three times higher than an automobile is offered to the tourist in Switzerland this Summer, thanks to a new type of snowplow invented this Spring.

THE land of the Blarney Stone will this season play host to the largest tourist crowd, probably, in its history. Names familiar to all lovers of Irish verses-Killarney, Kilkenny, Limerick, Tipperary, and all the rest-are on the lists of travelers headed for Erin's green shores.

The function of financing small business in its seasonal operations has been taken over in large measure from the banks by large manufacturers, mostly through extension of merchandise credits, and men dealing in trade credits have thereby assumed a much wider responsibility than heretofore, credit men have found.
The National Labor Relations Board hearing of charges against the Inland Steel Company broke up dramatically today when the three attorneys for the company walked out of the session.

Members of the cast of the charity revue, "Glen Cove Capers of 1937," which closed tonight at the Cove Theatre, attended the Country Club ball and carnival planned for them by the patronesses of the benefit as an additional aid to the funds.

Henry S. Halahan, Richard I. Nevin, Burrell G. White and Cecil C. Sargent have been added to the sales force of the Alexander Summer organization, of Teaneck, N. J. An auction sale of acreage at Copake Lake, N. Y., will be held on Aug. 14 by J. Edward Breuer.
Is John L. Lewis through? Has the movement headed by his Committee for Industrial Organization reached its apex and is it now going down grade?

Questions arising from administration of the reciprocal trade treaties negotiated by the United States, and points involving NRA and AAA levies, furnished the United States Customs Court with a near-record total of protests during the fiscal year ended June 30, it was announced yesterday.

ADAMS-On July 3, 1937, Grace Chapman, widow of John P. Adams of Newburyport, Mass., and Brooklyn, N. Y., and beloved mother of John P. Adams Jr., at the home of her son at Greenwich, Conn. Funeral private. Please omit flowers.

NEWPORT, R. I. -After the flare of entertaining incident to the Fourth of July, members of the Summer colony will begin to settle down Monday for a few days' rest prior to the coming of another lively week-end.

Picking up the baton from the spot where the Amateur Athletic Union snatched it from Germany's hands last night, Sweden today cabled Daniel J. Ferris, secretary-treasurer of the A. A. U., that it would go ahead with the European tour in even more elaborate style than had been originally intended.

Again the automotive labor spotlight is turned squarely on the Ford Motor Company as the United Automobile Workers of America renews its vigorous campaign to unionize the motor industry's largest individual company.
Lieut. Col. Jacob Schick, retired army officer and inventor of the Schick Dry Shaver, died at 4 A. M. yesterday in the Presbyterian Hospital after an illness of six months at the age of 59.

The finest of all national championships finished in blinding sunshine and brilliant performances in Marquette University Stadium today as records, teeming drama and upsets of all sorts, marked the fiftieth title games of the Amateur Athletic Union.

Prince Charming II, veteran of many a championship competition, came through to another title when he gained first honors in the hunter division at the fourteenth annual horse show of the Fairfield County Hunt Club, which came to a successful conclusion this afternoon.

Tall and handsome Freddie Haas of Louisiana State wound up three spectacular years of university competition today by conquering his teammate, Paul Leslie, for the national intercollegiate golf championship. The score was 5 and 3.

The volume of bonds called last week for redemption prior to maturity was substantially larger than in the preceding week. Refundings of public utility, industrial and foreign issues featured the announcements.

Three hundred and ninety-four Reserve officers of the Military Police, Cavalry, Corps of Engineers, Field Artillery, Infantry and Ordnance Department will leave today for two weeks of active duty training at five regular army posts in New York, New Jersey and Delaware, and one at Fort Knox, Ky. All are from this, the Second Corps Area.

MR. FERGUSSON'S novel flows like a Spoon River through the history of a Southwestern town. The hitching posts have given way to shiny gas pumps and over lands the cattle rustlers invaded the realtor reigns.

Mrs. Mary E. Hafner of 85-04 Eighty-eighth Street, Woodhaven, Queens, former Republican State Committeewoman of the Sixth A. D., Queens, died Friday in Lutheran Hospital, Brooklyn. A widow for some years, she operated a jewelry store at 408 Jay Street, Brooklyn.

The Count of Covadonga, eldest son of former King Alfonso of Spain, was married tonight to Sefiorita Marta Rocafort y Altuzarra Vedado at the residence of Don Manuel Zamora, Spanish millionaire and friend of the Count.

Hailing the Tammany celebration of the Fourth of July to be held tomorrow at the northwest corner of Union Square, President Roosevelt, in a letter just made public, stressed the necessity for emphasizing in Independence Day festivities the battle for preservation of democracy.

There has been a sharp decline this year in the number of certiorari proceedings to review real property assessments, according to 0. S. Cox, Assistant Corporation Counsel in Charge of Taxes, who estimates the writs issued this year at 40 per cent less than in 1936.

Miss Nan K. Hepburn, active in West Virginia club circles, died Thursday of pneumonia. She taught school forty years, organized Piedmont's Women's Clubs, for many years was secretary of West Virginia Tuberculosis Association
Bus service in eighteen cities and towns was tied up today as a result of a strike of employes of the Lovell Bus Company.
The Oakland Tribune said George Palmer Putnam disclosed today that his wife, Amelia Earhart, planned to give up record-breaking flights after satisfying a "life dream" of a round-the-world flight.

Members of the Oyster Bay, L. I., Fire Department, making a natty appearance in light blue sweaters with "Teddy's Boys" inscribed thereon in white, demonstrated their prowess today when they won first prize in the ladder-raising contest that was a feature of the New Jersey firemen's field day at the Fair Grounds here.

Summer schools are opening in their biggest and best year as New York City welcomes more than 33,000 students this week. Teachers, graduates and undergraduates are signing up in record registrations all over the country.

The Federal Housing Administration closed the third year of its activities last week. It was on June 27, 1934, that the National Housing Act was passed by Congress. Reporting some of the achievements during the three-year period, Administrator Stewart McDonald anounces that up to June 19, the last date for which figures were available, the FHA had accepted for insurance 206,794 residential mortgages showing a value of $835,417,627.

A FISHING ground of few regrets may be found at the mouth of California's Klamath River, 360 miles north of San Francisco, where from early August to late October there are perhaps more anglers concentrated within one square mile of stream and shoreline than anywhere else along either coast. And one rarely returns empty-handed.
In a speech before the American Club yesterday, Stefan Osusky, Czechoslovak Minister to France, referring to his experiences as a student in the United States, paid tribute to American democracy.

A LADY of superb and unshakable poise, Marjorie Gateson violates one of the basic canons of Hollywood by coolly admitting-by even volunteering the information-that she was in the first revival of "Mlle. Modiste," and is proud of it.

Employes of the editorial, circulation and advertising departments of The Seattle Star, a Scripps league afternoon newspaper, went on strike today, after an early edition of the newspaper had reached the street.

The Department of Agriculture announced today that Secretary Wallace has ordered a reduction in charges in the New York-Jersey City live-poultry markets for furnishing coops and for loading and trucking live poultry.

Miss Helen Sinclair Bruno, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Jerome Bruno of this place, was married to Merritt A. Clegg. son of Mr. and Mrs. John H. Clegg of Suffern, N. Y., today at the home of the bride's parents. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Frank J. Bruno of Washington University, St. Louis, an uncle of the bride.
Alice heard the persistent rattle of the newspaper and knew her attention was being solicited.

The Treasury this afternoon mailed checks aggregating $2,458,208 to 42,000 railroad-pension beneficiaries. The checks went out when William A. Julian, United States Treasurer, informed the disbursement division that $10,000,000 had been credited to the account of the Railroad Retirement Board's pension fund.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt visited the city's new steamship terminal on the Hudson from Forty-eighth to Fifty-second Street yesterday and witnessed gay and turbulent indications that prosperity had returned to the waterfront. The President's wife went to the Italian liner Conte di Savoia to say good-bye to her son John and to the President's mother, who sailed for Italy and other European countries.
A calm, squall, rain and sunshine marked the first of a three-day yacht-racing program of the local yacht club today. Because of lack of wind, the start was postponed fifteen minutes.

ANNOUNCEMENT is made by the Whitney Museum of American Art in connection with the book which it is preparing on the American artist Winslow Homer (1836-1910), the centenary of whose birth was celebrated by a number of exhibitions last season, that Carmine Dalesio of the E. C. Babcock Art Galleries and Robert W. Macbeth of William Macbeth, Inc., have generously agreed to make available to the museum the results of their own work on Homer.
Following is the answer of the Ford Motor Company to the complaint made against the company by the National Labor Relations Board:

Miss Catherine Dolores Willi, daughter of Mrs. Francis Willi of Astoria, L. I., and the late Mr. Willi, was married yesterday morning in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola, New York, to William Gerard Ryan, son of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Ryan of Brightwaters, L. I.

Georgia's Prison Commission took a long step yesterday toward abolition of the chain gang for convicted felons. The State that day accepted title to the new prison in Tatnall County, built for Georgia by the Federal Public Works Administration. As rapidly as administrative problems permit, the commission will begin moving convicts from all parts of the State into this modern $1,300,000 structure.

TWO American plays have been the theatre's principal business during the past week, and "Victoria Regina," which seems almost to have become American by adoption, is to make its appearance on the 21st.

Miss Louise Symington Levering, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin W. Levering Jr. was married here tonight to Dr. Edward Thomas Newell Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. E. T. Newell of Chattanooga, Tenn., in Brown Memorial Presbyterian Church. The ceremony was followed by a reception at the Levering home in Ruxton, near Baltimore.

Miss Jeanne Millet, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John Parsons Millet of 770 Park Avenue, New York, was married to Shaun Kelly Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Shaun Kelly of Glen Crannie Farm, Richmond, at St. Paul's Episcopal Church this afternoon.

Establishment of new qualifications for membership under which applicants must prove they operate under fair wage and hour schedules and comply with other modern ideas of industrial policy is being undertaken by the Associated Grocery Manufacturers of America, Inc., it was learned yesterday.

A cultural renaissance is taking place in rural America, and in hundreds of farm communities creative talent in the arts is finding encouragement, a survey sponsored by Columbia University reported yesterday.
