Government educational reports do not ordinarily have an intimate bearing on the news of the day, but an exception is-provided by one issued here this week upon certain aspects of the. new physical education system in Germany.

Team shooting featured the events at the Jamaica Bay traps of the Bergen Beach Gun Club yesterday, and the five led by Lynn Hunt was the winner, defeating G. C. Schwalb's aggregation by 254 to 248. A doubles event, decided on the B. J. Field system, was taken by F. A. Cauchois, who had 19 out of 24 targets.

MUSCOVITES joyfully welcomed home their five violinists who had won five out of the six prizes offered by the Ysaye contest in Brussels. They had been away for two months playing in most of the European capitals and the people were impatient for their return.

Culver, Hollyday Co., located at 38 East Fifty-seventh Street for several years, now is occupying the entire thirty-third floor in the Squibb Building, thirty-five-story office structure at the corner of Fifth Avenue and Fifty-eighth Street. The firm has just been appointed agent for this building.

ADMITTING that the future development of television may bring a good many problems with it, The Listener, journal of the British Broadcasting Corporation, boasts that "Great Britain is still the only country that enjoys a public television service which may be received by listeners in their homes."

Many of the yacht and beach clubs in Westchester County started their Independence Day celebrations this evening with dinner dances. One of the largest took place tonight at the Beach House of the Anawamis Cluh here.

Governor Davey announced troops would be sent to Cleveland to keep order at reopening of four Republic mills. Page 1. The Ford Motor Company challenged the authority of the National Labor Relations Board, upholding its men in the May fighting at River Rouge plant. Page 4.
A special engineering section has been established by Colonel C. S. Ridley, Governor of the Panama Canal Zone, for the purpose of preparing plans and estimates for building a third set of locks.
Three persons were killed and another was severely burned today in the crash of an airplane at a private landing field near Morris, twelve miles from here.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, West Va.-Tonight this resort will inugurate its moonlight barbecues and already more than seventy-five guests of the Greenbrier have signed up to participate in the picnic, which will be repeated every week-end throughout the Summer.

On Wednesday the Treasury closed its books on another chapter of red ink. In the twelve months just ended it had spent $8,105,000,000 and taken in $5,294,000,000, leaving it with an excess of expenditures over income of $2,811,000,000, the seventh consecutive deficit.

The survey of the East Riverfrom the New York Navy Yard, in Brooklyn, to Throgs Neck-begun last year, to determine the advisability of deepening and straightening the channel, will not be completed until Autumn, army engineers said yesterday.

The Commonwealth of Kentucky on Wednesday completed its first fiscal year with a balanced budget since the corresponding period which ended on June 30, 1908-and the State government here thus is in a condition of jubilation. According to Governor A. B. Chandler, the result is not a "layman's balance," but a state in which revenues actually covered expenditures.

Pleading guilty to a charge of abandoning a minor in the case of 6-year-old Charles W. Ditmars of Rahway, N. J., who was left in a theatre last Wednesday, Mrs. Edna Gladys Jenson, 40, of Elizabeth, N. J., was held in $2,000 bail today for sentence on Tuesday.

WASHINGTON'S "curb market" of philately operates on the first and second days of the issuance of new stamps at the Benjamin Franklin postal station in the new Postoffice Department Building, corner of Pennsylvania Avenue and Twelfth Street.
Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Alta Sue Doe of this place, daughter of Frank A. Doe of China, Me., and the late Mrs. Doe, to Harry S. Maher, also of Montclair.

BROADCASTERS here and abroad are recognizing the fact that "since the life of almost every one is now touched by one phase or another by broadcasting, the radio set becomes an increasingly important adjunct to education."

A sum approximating $105,000,000 will have been paid by the end of this month by the savings, building and loan associations of the country in semi-annual dividends to their 7,000,000 members, reports the United States Building and Loan League. The sum represents earnings for the first six months of the year on the home-mortgage business of the associations.
Dr. Jose Carlos de Macedo Soares, Minister of Justice, told the Justices of the Appellate Court that the government would undertake a sweeping revision of the penal and police systems.
Two flying boats were groomed tonight to span the North Atlantic and link the Old World with the new on Monday by commercial air transport.

The Madrid front is in an effervescent state these days, with skirmishes and local engagements occurring all the way from the Jarama River to the Guadalajara sector. The Loyalists captured a few more streets and houses in Carabanchel this morning, but otherwise apparently no ground changed hands.

Government statisticians will go into executive session next Thursday and Friday to prepare this season's most important cotton, wheat, corn, rye and other feed-crop reports. Venetian blinds will be sealed behind shadowless windows, telephones disconnected and an armed guard stationed at the door. The statisticians will study figures from reporters throughout the country.

After long hesitation education seems at last to be entering the machine age. Teaching about machines and teaching by machines were emphasized as never before on the program of the National Education Association convention just closed at Detroit.

Two. young women who were arrested with seven men in a disturbance in front of the studios of Max Fleischer, animated cartoons, 1,600 Broadway, at Forty-eighth Street, early Friday evening, obtained adjournment of their cases in magistrates' courts yesterday.
Movements of vessels follow, all dates are July 2, unless specified: Windward Passage to New Haven: Badger, Tattnall, Tillman. San Francisco to Eureka: Borie, Trevor, Wasmuth, Zane.

If any one had been able to foresee in July, 1936, the developments of the Spanish civil war, it is doubtful whether Italy would have rushed so lightheartedly into the adventure, the end of which still is not in sight.

The crippled Tigers won the opener of a three-game series with the Indians, 9 to 5, today. Rudy York hit a home run with the bases full at the height of a pass parade which netted the Tigers six runs in the second inning.
This Massachusetts South Shore town, incorporated seventeen years after the landing of the Pilgrims at near-by Plymouth, today opened a three-day celebration of its 300th anniversary.

The congress of the International Chamber of Commerce, which met at Berlin this week, considered many ways of expanding international trade as a means of promoting the peace and prosperity of nations, but completely forgot to touch on one of the biggest international industries of the day,

In its first fifty weeks of operation the Triborough Bridge has been used by 9,500,000 automobiles, as against the estimate of 9,000,000 cars for its first complete year of service, Arthur S. Tuttle, State Director of the Public Works Administration, announced yesterday in making public a report submitted by him to Harold L. Ickes, PWA Administrator.

The marriage of Miss Margaret Jane Walker, daughter of Mrs. L. Clark Walker of East Orange and the late Mr. Walker, to John Howard Anderson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Anderson of Hawthorne, took place this afternoon at the home of the bride's mother.

Miss Louise Fallon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin J. Fallon of 334 Mansfield Place, Brooklyn, was married yesterday morning in Our Lady of Refuge Church, Brooklyn, to Thomas J. de Lellis of New York. The ceremony was performed by Mgr. Francis P. Connelly.

Mr. and Mrs. Robert Gause Bellah of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Dorothy Clark Bellah, to Henry Orlando Marcy 3d, son of Mrs. Henry Orlando Marcy Jr. of Newton, Mass., and the late Dr. Marcy.

The affiliation of the American Federation of Labor with the International Federation of Trade Unions was unanimously accepted today by the latter's general council after a stormy debate in a private session in which delegates of several countries strongly criticized the A. F. L.'s attitude toward the Committee for Industrial Organization.
THE death of James Matthew Barrie at a ripe old age removed one of the last of the late Victorians who interested the English-speaking world at the turn of the century.

FEW sections of the country last week were able to report large trade gains over last year despite the fact that the pre-Fourth week is usually a period of high volume. Weather conditions were blamed in some areas, while in others it was a case of the 1936 "veterans' bonus" figures proving too high. The South and Southwest were about the only exceptions.
THE dulcet bray of Lionel Stander, who has his own technique for rendering likable the most egregious toughmuggery of the screen, has brought him to a four-figure-a-week salary in Hollywood.

AN investigation was undertaken in baseball circles to discover whether or not the uprisings against umpires this season were caused by, consequent upon or related to the general economic upheaval, the spirit of social unrest, the C. I. O. conflict in this country, the clash between fascism and communism in Spain and the war clouds hovering over Mitteleuropa as well as the big-league diamonds.

Three factors are contributing materially to a healthier condition in the observance of sound building principles in the construction industry, points out Harold Knapp, vice president in charge of sales of the Celotex Company.

The City Amateur Symphony Orchestra, Justice Leopold Prince conducting, last night gave the fourth of a series of eleven Summer outdoor concerts in Central Park. The concert, which was broadcast by WNYC, attracted about 2,000 listeners. It opened with Verdi's overture "Sicilian Vespers" and closed with Strauss's "Tales from the Vienna Woods."

LONDON.-What Stanley Baldwin called "the intolerable burdens" of the Premiership are made worse for Neville Chamberlain in his first months in office by the discomforts of the old house at 10 Downing Street, the historic home of Britain's Prime Ministers.

Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Walker, Louis E. Walker and Bayard Walker gave a large supper-dance tonight at Muttontown Meadow, the home of Mr. and Mrs. Elisha Walker in Muttontown in honor of Miss Adele Walker and Elisha Walker Jr., whose engagements were announced recently.

Arriving at Sugar Hill, where she has taken the home of Mrs. John R. Winterbotham of Chicago, was Lady Lindsay, wife of Sir Roland Lindsay, British Ambassador to the United States. Mrs. Umberto Cugia, wife of the naval attache at the Italian Embassy, returned today to her cottage at Sugar Hill.
An astonishing record of achievement is revealed by the report of the highways committee of the Automobile Manufacturers Association on world highway progress.

A downpour that not only made track conditions hazardous but drenched a large part of the crowd of 35,000 spectators today caused the officials of the Roosevelt Raceway to postpone the second Vanderbilt Cup automobile race until Monday.

There is no kind of doubt that Carnoustie possesses a very fine and exacting golf course. It has been made more exacting than ever for the open championship play, which begins Monday and can, I am told, be now stretched to theto my mind-almost ridiculous length of over 7,200 yards.

Debits to individual accounts, as reported by banks in leading cities, for the week ended June 30 aggregated $9,450,000,000, or 6 per cent above the total reported for the preceding week and 11 per cent below the total for the corresponding week last year.

Jockey Ray Hightshoe rode Cary Grayson's Third Party into the winner's circle in the $5,000 added Boston American Pink Final Juvenile Handicap, five-and-one-half-furlong feature, before 18,000 fans at Rockingham Park today. The victor returned $31.70 for $2.

Miss Beatrice Berry of Madison will be married to Andrew S. Hegeman on Saturday by the Rev. John W. Parks at Webb Memorial Chapel, Madison. Mrs. Kenneth MacDougall of Madison will be her sister's only attendant.
KINGSTON. - Vacationists in Ulster County this week-end will celebrate on the lakes, in theatre, on golf courses and tennis courts, at night spots and in the mountains and woodlands.

George W. Gliebe, a construction engineer employed by the Fairbanks Morse Company and a resident of San Francisco, died yesterday morning at City Hospital from injuries received in a fall from his fourth-floor room in the Hotel Bristol, 129 West Forty-eighth Street. Gliebe, who was 43 years old, lived at 560 Forty-fifth Street, San Francisco.

Nikolaus Basseches, correspondent of the Neue Freie Presse of Vienna and other foreign newspapers,, who was "invited" by the Commissariat of Internal Affairs last night to leave the Soviet Union within forty-eight hours, departed from Moscow tonight for Vienna via the Polish border, accompanied by his Russian-born wife and stepdaughter.

To come from Los Angeles to San Francisco is not merely to change cities but in a certain sense to change worlds. Except in Europe, where one crosses a border and immediately hears a new language, there are perhaps no other two cities so close together where a change in the atmosphere and life of the community is so readily apparent to the visitor.
Ruth Elder, another woman flier whose plane was forced down at sea, said today "I feel in my heart that Amelia Earhart will be rescued."

THE announcement that the New Amsterdam Theatre has been sold for a "grind" house is another indication that the old order has indeed changed. For the New Amsterdam was once the citadel of show business, aloof, aristocratic and rich.

The opening dinner dance of the Maidstone Club's season took place tonight, attended by several hundred from East Hampton and Southampton. Among them were Dr. and Mrs. John F. Erdmann, Mr. and Mrs. Julian Myrick, Mr. and Mrs. A. Wallace Chauncey, Mr. and Mrs. Dickson Bayard Potter,

With steel production in a number of plants reduced by strikes, the question is being asked whether strikes slow down recovery. Statistics show conclusively that they retard recovery temporarily, but experts differ on whether, in the long run, they have any serious effect.

The flying fists of fifteen of the best boxers in the Police Athletic League's ninth unit, members of which have been in training for the Long Island City championship bouts July 12, feinted and lashed out with new vigor and dexterity yesterday morning under the tutelage of Jack Dempsey.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Though far removed from my erstwhile country, I have never lost contact with it. I know pretty much what is going on in the States, by no means only through the American press. And I also know what your paper has been writing of the events in Spain.

Miss Jean Newell McGraw, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James A. McGraw of Montclair, N. J., and this place, has completed plans for her marriage to Ezra Kendall Gillett Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Ezra K. Gillett of Pelham Manor, N. Y. The wedding will take place July 17 in the Church of Christ, Norfolk.

Brother William, co-director of the New York Catholic Protectory, died last Friday evening. His age was 78. His family name was Humphreys, and -he was a brother of the late Joe Humphreys, veteran sports announcer.

THE story of early New England can be told in words, but more eloquent than words are the surviving souvenirs of the actual life and spirit of those days. Churches and town halls are one part; furniture another; kitchen implements still another.
When some unknown savage in an unrecorded time first placed a fallen tree across a stream that he might pass to the other side without wetting himself he had an idea that other men found good.

Fire starting in an ice-cream stand in the center of the amusement section of Rockaway Beach swept through two blocks of concessions along the boardwalk and several adjoining bungalows yesterday with an estimated loss of $200,000 to $300,000.

It is reported in political circles this evening that the Cabinet will probably undergo changes early next week as a result of efforts to bring opposition parties in with the addition of more Radical members.

A little band of pioneers marched up a Northern Vermont trail 150 years ago and founded the town of St. Johnsbury. The town is celebrating the anniversary today, tomorrow and Monday with pageantry, parades, music and oratory.

The most striking characteristic of the markets in the week just completed was the show of optimism, however cautious, after many weeks of extreme pessimism. This was particularly true of the securities markets, since commodities frequently had shown independent strength and activity at times over a period of weeks.

Mr. and Mrs. Charles Shipman Payson gave a costume supper dance tonight at their home to mark the thirteenth anniversary of their wedding. Mr. and Mrs. Payson were married in Christ Church, Manhasset, on July 3, 1924. Mrs. Payson was Miss Joan Whitney, daughter of Mrs. Payne Whitney.

CAN a novel delve into social problems honestly and forcefully without plunging into the ugly morass of photographic realism? Can it forge persuasive symbols of economic conflict without descending to the flimsy melodrama and thin factualism so common in topical novels?

A nation wearied with the prolonged strife in steel saw hope of a compromise last week; brick-throwing and clubbing showed signs of going out of fashion as union tactics, and the united company front against negotiations gave way.

Dry goods Jobbers throughout the country will begin taking inventory when they reopen after the holiday tomorrow and will continue this through the week. More than usual interest is being shown by primary dry goods sellers in the outcome of the inventory taking, since it will give a key to the amount of repeat buying that will be done for the Fall.

In the Assembly Room of Independence Hall, where the Declaration of Independence was drawn up and signed, a collection of notable documents relating to the Declaration, owned by Dr. A. S. W. Rosenbach and valued at about $2,000,000, will be placed on public view tomorrow.
ON THE RURAL CIRCUIT--These are the attractions, both new and revived, which will be seen this week in the Summer theatres. Unless specified, first performances will be given tomorrow evening:

Independence Day here will be celebrated with a number of social and other events, featured by the thirteenth annual Cowal Games, of the United States, on Monday, at the estate of Charles Arthur Moore in Round Hill.
MANHATTAN AARON, Lillie (June 22). Estate, $11,500. To Renna Bergman, sister, executrix, 1,090 St. Nicolas Ave. Rebecca Oberndorfer and Dora Haack, sisters, 547 W. 157th St., one-third residue each.

The sitdown strike was condemned -today by Frances Perkins, Secretary of Labor, in the first clear public pronouncement on the subject by a high administration official since the issue was raised in Michigan several months ago.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J.-Swimming, sunning, fishing, boating, golf, tennis, cycling, horseback riding and boardwalk strolling are competing for the interest of the visitors during their days in Atlantic City.

Payrolls have risen 37.9 per cent since May, 1936, and are now 2.4 per cent above the average level in 1929 in manufacturing industries covered by the regular monthly survey of the National Industrial Conference Board.

In a thrilling photo finish, Marica, 4 Year-old daughter of Epinard-Canberra, owned by Thomas D. Taggart of French Lick Springs, Ind., won the renewal of the Arlington Matron Handicap by a nose today.

The $60,000,000 battleship to be built at the navy yard in Brooklyn will be the North Carolina, navy yard officials announced yesterday. Her sister ship, the Washington, will be constructed in the Navy Yard at Philadelphia.
The "Coronation Bisley" opens Monday, promising to be the most interest and successful empire military marksmanship meet since the war.

A 28year-old Butte attorney named Burton Kendall Wheeler made his debut in Montana politics in 1910 by getting elected to the State Legislature. Since then he has been an active and dramatic figure in progressive politics in the nation's third largest State. Thus Montana watches with keen interest the effect on Wheeler's popularity of his leadership of the opposition to the President's Supreme Court reform plan.

THE recent formal opening of the reorganized Berkshire Museum at Pittsfield, Mass., was a notable event in the art world not only because of interest in the occasion itself but also because it draws attention anew to the growth, progress and modernizing of museums and similar institutions throughout New England in the last few years.

The floating population in search of work, while smaller than in the worst depression times, appears to be greater than during the Nineteen Twenties, Secretary Perkins reported to the Senate today in response to a demand for a study of worker migration.

General John J. Pershing's biggest peace-time job will be finished in October when the last of ninteen chapels and monuments erected in Europe by the American Battle Monuments Commission he heads will be dedicated.

World peace rests "in the lap of God" and only a militant and united world church can prevent It, Dr. Henry Smith Leiper, executive secretary of the American Section of the Universal Christian Council, said yesterday as he boarded the French liner Champlain to attend the World Conference on Church, State and Community, to be held at Oxford, England, from July 12-26.

A theory that Amelia Earhart might have brought her plane down safely on a small coral atoll south of Howland Island was advanced today by her technical adviser, Paul Mantz, in a telephone conversation with George Palmer Putnam, husband of the aviatrix, who said he conferred with Mr. Mantz at Burbank, Calif.
Diametrically opposed views on the question of labor unions' "responsibility under the law" are expressed in the subjoined letters to THE TIMES.
This capital city of British Columbia is bewildered. The government's health insurance chicken has come home to roost, and nobody seems to have any idea what to do with it.

Miss Dorothy Calcagno had guests at the dinner dance at the Garden City Country Club tonight. In her party were Miss Helen Durand, Miss Marcelle Figueroa, Miss Jean Summersgill, Miss Betty Wooster, Miss Patricia Chalfant, Adrian Scheiss Jr., Edward Dannemiller, John McDermott, Kenneth Friedler and Walter Leigh.

By train, automobile and on foot, 1,700 picked young men, between the ages of 17 and 29, representing thirty-nine counties in New York State and eight counties in New Jersey, have assembled at Plattsburg Barracks to embark on a full month's military training course and vacation at the expense of Uncle Sam.

Raymond L. Buell of New York, president of the Foreign Policy Association, today told delegates to the American youth "model congress" that "in no other liberal country in the world is the future of democracy more threatened than in the United States."

CONTEMPORARY music has been played so often in Paris during the last ten years that the public has grown accustomed to the modern idiom, and rarely manifests hostility to a new work! In fact, during the past season indifference has characterized the reception of certain premieres which formerly would have occasioned jeers and hisses.

Miss Katherine E. Flynn, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Andrew Flynn of this city, was married to Richard Allan Hyer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Montgomery W. Hyer of Fanwood, this morning in St. Bernard's Church. The Rev. C. A. Heavey, pastor, performed the ceremony.

The "labor holiday" of American Federation of Labor truck drivers, by which they tied up deliveries in this area of merchandise, including milk and other food, was ordered ended at dawn today under a truce forced by Mayor S. Davis Wilson.

Miss Phyliss Eleanor Matthews, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry V. Matthews of this place, will be married to Lieutenant Milton Harvey Clark, U.S.A., in the First Presbyterian Church here Saturday. The Rev. Dr. George H. Talbott, pastor of the church, will perform the ceremony.

A two-day program commemorating the 136th anniversary of the birth of David Glasgow Farragut of Hastings, first admiral of the United States Navy, will begin at 2:30 P. M. tomorrow when a flagpole and bronze tablet will be dedicated to his memory at Mount Hope Cemetery on Saw Mill River Road.
Mrs. Leo Sulzberger of this city has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Beatrice Sulzberger, to Dr. Leonard Jay Trilling, son of Mrs. Betty Trilling of Paterson. N. J.

Gaining in popularity each year, the motor cruiser race from Execution Light to Block Island, which will be conducted Saturday by the Yachting Department of the New York A. C., has attracted the largest number of competing skippers of any year since the predicted log system of scoring was instituted.

The Newark Bears, the International League leaders, cracked down on two pitchers for fifteen hits, four of them home runs, to score a 10 to 0 victory over the Syracuse Chiefs today, much to the delight of more than 2,000 members of the "Knot-Hole Gang," who were guests of the clubs.

LAKE PLACID. -Largest and most novel of parties throughout the Adirondack region this first week of July will be the ice gymkhana to be given Wednesday night in the Olympic Arena by members of the Lake Placid Club.

Statistics issued today show that 12,094 Jews left Berlin last year for Palestine. Great Britain and the Americas. Those bound for the United States were relatively few, 523, but 1,126 went to South and Central America.
The Baltimore Orioles defeated Jersey City, 15 to 6, today in a free-hitting contest featured by Ab Wright's three homers for the victors.

Daffodils to the number of 7,600 are listed by names in the current issue of the British Royal Horticultural Society "Classified List of Daffodil Names." The name of the raiser and the year of the variety's development are given. Avoidance of duplications was obviously a chore.

The construction industry, according to Myron L. Matthews of the Dow Service, will soon be asked for an expression of opinion regarding the contemplated bureau of rating and structural value of the construction industry being advocated by the vigilance committee for better building.
Boy Scout contingents from four foreign countries banded together today as a unit for the duration of the National Jamboree in a session which stressed a movement for international peace.

When Karl de Schweinitz changed his title this week from executive director of the State Emergency Relief Board to State Secretary of Assistance, Pennsylvania put into effect a unified system of relief and pension administration without precedent in the country.

Under the direction of the Minister of Public Works, Peru's contribution to the Pan-American Exhibition at Dallas, Texas, may be classified as in two divisions, archaeological and historical and industrial and commercial.
BY one way of measuring history the United States is 161 years old today, for it is just that long ago that our ancestors stopped pretending that they were loyal subjects of the British Crown.

BRITAIN expects railroad history to be made tomorrow, when the new Coronation Express, latest and most luxurious of her streamlined trains, begins the first six-hour service between London and Edinburgh.
Close associates of the former King and Queen of Spain said tonight that although the couple had met last night at the crib of a new grandson they still were far from a reconciliation.

A three-day Summer festival was opened yesterday at the Carroll Vacation Club in Pawling to initiate the Summer season. More than 100 girls will participate in the events, which include a water pageant, swimming exhibition, stunts and competitions.

The All-Star American college lacrosse team gained the third victory of its English tour today by defeating a picked North-England team, 12 to 2. The English side was selected from thirty-four North England teams, with sixteen of them actually represented on the field.

The business done by the Federal Housing Administration in insured mortgages in the New York City district for the first five months of 1937 was 130 per cent ahead of the same period last year, according to Thomas G. Grace, State director of the FHA.
Recent home sales in various parts of Long Island are reported by William R. Behrens, sales manager for Realty Associates, as follows: Susan Lloyd purchased 4 West Hudson Street, Bay Park;
NO one knows, with absolute certainty, where or when John James Audubon was born or who his parents were. A glamorous veil of mystery hangs and will probably always hang over his origin.

Miss Johannah Louise Bumstead, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Ellsworth Bumstead of this place. was married to William Conover, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Childs Conover of New Rochelle, this afternoon in the Methodist Church here. The Rev. John R. Henry, the pastor, performed the ceremony which was followed by a reception at the Bumstead home.

An educational program in which the expenditure of $50,000 over the coming five years has been planned will be launched in the next few weeks by the National Association of Purchasing Agents. The program, including textbooks on buying, commodity markets, purchasing office organization and a number of other subjects, is for the benefit of members of the association.

Several specially qualified French observers who recently returned from the United States endeavored Thursday to explain the "Roosevelt experiment" to a group of French intellectuals assembled under the auspices of the Congress of American Nations in cooperation with the FranceAmerica Committee and the Sorbonne.

J. W. Parrish, Bluegrass turfman, accounted for another feature triumph and his third victory here today when Knee Deep captured the Cincinnati Trophy for juvenile colts and geldings. Piloted by Jockey J. Cowley, the winner paid 7-10.
Members of the Senate Labor Committee reported today a tentative agreement to strip from the Wage and Hour Bill much of the discretionary power given to a proposed laborstandards board.
Courses in arts and crafts will be conducted at the Westchester Workshop of the Westchester County Recreation Commission in the County Center, here, from Tuesday to Aug. 27, it was announced today.

A survey covering more than 120 coat and suit firms, conducted last week, showed an "overwhelming preference" for price advances over "cheapening of quality" as a means of reflecting the increase in labor costs in the industry, Samuel Klein, executive director of the Industrial Council of Cloak, Suit and Skirt Manufacturers, Inc., and chairman of the fair trade practice committee of the National Coat and Suit Industry Recovery Board, announced yesterday.

Mr. and Mrs. Robbins Gilman of Minneapolis announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Catherine Cooke Gilman, to Clement William Welsh, son of Mr. and Mrs. James Winfield Welsh of Forest Hills, L. I., tonight at a dinner at Arden Forest, their Summer home here.

A blazing finish to an exciting threeset match gave Miss Eunice Dean of San Antonio, Texas, the women's Eastern clay court tennis championship today. Miss Dean, trailing Miss Helen Germaine at 5-2 in the deciding set of the final round, swept to victory at 1-6, 6--2, 7--5.

THERE are very few duplicate games running at local bridge clubs; no tournament play is in sight until the Southern New England championships begin at New London, Conn., July 15, and many of those who frequent the bridge clubs are out of town.

Bequeathing virtually his entire estate to members of his family, William A. Taylor, retired dry goods merchant, declared in his will that "heavy taxes" and uncertain economic conditions caused him to forego bequests to charities.
Representative William B. Barry of New York sought support today for his child labor amendment, which he describes- as "a new approach to the child labor problem."

The home owner who is so fortunate as to possess a place which borders on water or that contains a brook or a pool or pond of fair size will find unusual possibilities for the creation of pleasing landscape effects. Such places, however, almost always present out-of-the-ordinary problems.

Problems of marriage and the family will be discussed by specialists at the third annual Conference on the Conservation of Marriage and the Family, to be held from Monday through Friday at the University of North Carolina.

A series of entertainment and sports programs for the holiday week-end was begun today at the Atlantic Beach Club here. Children's swimming races in the pool this morning were followed by the finals of the mixed doubles tennis tournament.
Soaring planes were shot into the air at three-minute intervals soon after noon today and at least four distance flights were made. Several thousand spectators watched the start.

The engagement of Miss Ruth Dresser, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank E. Dresser of this place, to William K. Metcalfe of New York, son of Mrs. Ada K. Crouch of Denver and the late Thomas W. Metcalfe, has been announced by her parents.
Increasing confidence that Senator Robert F. Wagner would consent to take the Democratic nomination for Mayor was expressed yesterday by party leaders.

While the approaching long week-end for observance of Independence Day materially restricted speculative operations in the wheat market today, prices showed a distinctly firm undertone, and rallied sharply after nearly breaking.

The twoscore scheduled airlines operating in continental United States carried 98,035 passengers and flew 5,783,643 miles and 42,019,428passenger-miles in May, the Bureau of Air Commerce reported today.

In more conservative buying mood than a year ago but optimistic on prospects for Fall retail trade, thousands of buyers from retail stores throughout the country will begin to arrive in the wholesale markets here after the holiday tomorrow.
The marriage of Miss Harriette Fenwick Jackson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Winthrop Alsop Jackson of Ipswich. Mass., to John Davis White, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert D. White of Milton,

WHEN the 300th anniversary of the beginning of chemical industry in this country was celebrated, in 1935, the record of achievement was so gratifying that it was decided to give it permanent place in a book.
Jean Dupuy won the Spreckels Trophy for outboard motor boats today by defeating nine rivals, among whom were three from the United States, in a hotly contested race on the Seine River.
Mr. and Mrs. Walker Breckinridge Armstrong gave a buffet supper tonight for Russell Dunkin of Tucson, Ariz., before the dance at the Ballast Reef Club, near here.

DURING the week Metro-Gold wyn-Mayer formulated plans for film production in London to comply with the newly revised English quota laws, which govern the showing of American-made features throughout the British Empire.

WHITE MOUNTAINS, N.H.-The annual registered trap-shooting tournament of the Maplewood Club, which started on Wednesday, will continue today and tomorrow, with a special holiday shoot for Independence Day, prizes for which will be given by the club president, Colonel William F. Dunspaugh of Tarrytown, N. Y. Sportsmen from New York and surrounding towns are in attendance.

Colonel and Mrs. C. Wickliffe Throckmorton and Mrs. Throckmorton's daughter, Miss Katherine H. W. Swift, will pass the remainder of the Summer at Bay Shore, L. I. Mrs. David H. Kincheloe, wife of Judge Kincheloe, will return today to 115 East Eighty-sixth Street from a visit to her mother in Kentuckv.

The peculiar and unfailing ability of the farm problem to upset the most carefully laid legislative plans was demonstrated again this week. The upset came with a sudden revival of interest in the "ever-normalgranary" plan which, after having been consigned to the legislative bone-heap, was catapulted back on the "desirable" list-it used to be called "must" list-by the White House.

Stamp collectors, who pay much of the expense of pioneering airplane flights, have a $25,000 stake in the around-the-world flight of Amelia Earhart. When her first attempt was halted by a minor accident at Honolulu March 20, says The Associated Press, her plane was carrying 5,500 letters that collectors had addressed to themselves.

LOVERS of wild life have long been perturbed lest the mighty California condor become extinct. But the State where this largest of American birds of flight makes its habitat has come to its rescue, and now there is word that the condor has come back and that its numbers are increasing.
Hundreds of shoe shine boys who circulate about the streets in this city raised their price from a nickel to a dime today.

John Ross Hopkin, 57 years old, contractor, former real estate dealer, and in 1900 national amateur featherweight boxing champion, committed suicide today by shooting himself with a 30-30 rifle in the living room of his home on Orchard Hill Road.

Paul Shields sailed Rebel home first over the twelve-mile Gold Cup course off the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club today in the first of the three-day six-meter Seawanhaka Cup races. A. E. Luders finished second in Totem, with G. U. Vetlessen in Vema fiftythree seconds behind in third place.

MEXICO, D. F.-Two apparently unrelated occurrences of the recent past bear upon the measure of success of the United States "good neighbor" policy as it applies to Mexico, a key Latin-American nation.

Del Baker, acting manager of the Tigers, said tonight that Gerald Walker, heavy-hitting right fielder, will be unable to play in the all-star game at Washington Wednesday. He made the announcement after Trainer Denny Carroll completed an examination of Walker's injured leg.
The United States Ambassador and Mrs. Bingham will be at home to Americans in London at 14 Prince's Gate, on Monday, in observance of Independence Day. The efforts of Dr.
Left a bachelor for two weeks, Vice President Garner pulled down his old cane fishing pole today and headed for the deep holes. For the first time in more than twenty-five years,

Texture weaves will dominate in all types of rugs and carpets displayed here Tuesday at the carpet industry's annual Fall opening, both rug manufacturers and buyers agreed yesterday. The popularity of the texture weave has carried over from the previous year and mill executives expect it to remain an outstanding favorite for the balance of this year.
FOUR substantial and welcome additions to the chamber music library, drawn from later Mozart and comparatively early Brahms, form the backbone of this month's lists.

Declaring that only a radical solution can cope with the Palestine situation and that palliatives will not go to the root of the problem, the Royal Commission report, which is to be made public next Thursday, recommends the establishment of two separate States, Jewish and Arab, and the division of the country accordingly, it is learned on reliable authority.
Bringing off an incomparable triple tennis triumph, Donald Budge, American singles champion, completed his conquest of Wimbledon today by taking over the all-England men's and mixed doubles titles.

After the Heidelberg celebrations, last week's jubilations at Goettingen seemed tame enough. To be sure, there was some saluting with upraised arm-the Hitler Gruss-on the part of at least two American university professors, but very few ranking universities sent delegates.
A holiday dance was held at the Bellport Country Club tonight. Mrs. Percy Gray is chairman of a series of eight bridge parties, to begin on July 12 at the club. Members of her committee include Mrs.

Chissie, a 3-months-old black and white kitten, invaded Mayor La Guardia's Summer City Hall in the Chisholm mansion in College Point so successfully on Friday that it was immediately made a member of the Mayor's official family.

IN a government laboratory at Washington a man wearing ear muffs and mittens is studying a brick of ice cream; in another a man is pushing a plunger through the skin of a pear; in another a food expert is spinning tomatoes in color tests; in still another a man is squashing individual peas and kernels of corn to paste.

The problems created by the arrival of thousands of Basque refugee children in England and France have not disappeared but are gradually being solved. They are being solved both by the children themselves and by the devoted work of charitable organizations in both countries.

Manufacturers in the wholesale market here were preparing last week for the influx of buyers scheduled to arrive this week. It is probable that advance purchasing will be more conservative than has been previously anticipated, according to a special report prepared for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., resident buyers.

THE Salzburg Festival opens Saturday, July 24, with a performance of "Fidelio," under the direction of Arturo Toscanini. The cast includes Lotte Lehmann as Leonore, Harriet Henders as Marcellina, Alfred Jerger as Don Pizzaro, Alexander Kipnis as Rocco, Carl Bisutti as Don Fernando and Hermann Gallos as Jacauino.

THIS week-end sees the annual hot-weather migration from New York City to Long Island's ocean-cooled play-grounds rising to full volume. The tide of seekers after rest and pleasure flows over highways made smoother and faster.

Miss Patricia Cumming of Westfield, seeded first, and sister of the girl for whom the event is named, will defend her crown in the final of the Anne Cumming Memorial tournament, New Jersey girls' championship at the Westfield Tennis Club tomorrow. She will meet Miss Josephine San Filippo of Brooklyn, seeded second.

Covering a thirty-mile triangle, with close haul work, in the fastest time on record, Harold S. Vanderbilt's powerful yacht Ranger administered an overwhelming defeat today to Gerard B. Lambert's Yankee.

The American open champion, Ralph Guldahl, reveling in another miraculous putting streak, and Henry Cotton tonight were established joint favorites for the British open golf tournament, starting Monday.

HAROLD BAUER will play with the Philadelphia Orchestra, under Alfred Wallenstein, July 15 and 16 at Robin Hood Dell. The Thursday program includes Wagner's overture to "Rienzi" and Siegfried's Rhine Journey from "Goetterdaemmerung," the Beethoven "Emperor" concerto, with Mr. Bauer as soloist;
ALMOST simultaneously with the shivers and palpitations of "Lulu," Switzerland experienced another operatic world premiere, this one at the Basle Stadttheater.

Don Heffner's single gave the Yankees a victory over the Senators at Griffith Stadium today amid riotous scenes, and enabled the champions to maintain their four-game lead in the American League race. The score was 5 to 4, to the undisguised chagrin of some 10,000 Washington fans.
The last two of the thirty-five entries in the New London-Gibson Island race docked here today, ending any anxiety felt because they were long overdue.

Esposa, a 5-year-old mare who had not showed much in the way of winning form for nearly a year, ran one of her good races today in carrying William Ziegler Jr.'s silks to victory in the $7,500 added Brandywine Handicap at Delaware Park.

Mrs. Marguerite Ives of Forest Hills, Queens, has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Frances McKee Ives, to Merritt Judson Dannatt Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Merritt J. Dannatt, also of Forest Hills.
FAR and away the dominant feature of the festival weeks just ended was Artur Rod zinski's concert with the Philharmonic.
The Italians do not conceal their great concern over the gravity of the international situation arising from the disagreement in which yesterday's session of a non-intervention subcommittee ended.

Two large sales of Southern esstates have been announced by the National Real Estate Clearing House, one being in Maryland and the other in South Carolina, the purchaser of the latter being Miss Helen Harman of Plainfield, N. J.

THE curtain rises on the great annual disappearing act of the American people, commonly known as the vacation exodus. Around New York City this mass movement of early Summer exceeds, it is believed, any population dispersion recorded in history. Fewer people vanished, so far as can be learned, when ancient Carthage was deleted, while the Trojans and the Mayas seem to have been only a couple of drops in the bucket.

Asserting that proposed reductions in the United States sugar quota for Puerto Rico would lower the island's purchasing power, twenty-three organizations cabled to Washington officials today urging that the rights of American citizens be not curtailed by such legislation.

Herman Aspegren, Swedish Vice Consul here, and Mrs. Aspegren have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marta Aspegren, to Dr. Ralph Chandler Parker Jr. of Batavia, N. Y., and Boston, son of Captain Ralph Chandler Parker, U. S. N., and Mrs. Parker of California. The wedding will take place this Summer.
Motorists from Brooklyn rolled over Rockaway Inlet to Jacob Riis Park in Queens at noon yesterday for the first time, following in the wake of Mayor La Guardia, who opened the Marine Farkway Bridge.
Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Edith A. Bernard, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis W. Bernard of Brooklyn, to Evans D. Cohen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Julius I. Cohen, also of Brooklyn.

Philip W. Kniskern, president of the First Mortgage Corporation of Philadelphia, states that the proposals to extend the amortization period and to reduce the interest rate on HOLC mortgages are economically unsound and unnecessary.

Two volumes of letters written by Senator Charles Pinckney of South Carolina and published in Philadelphia nearly 140 years ago are among the twenty rare books that have been transferred to the Princeton University Library from the residence of the late Colonel James Barnes of Princeton.
MME. DU DEFFAND was famous for founding the first literary salon in the eighteenth century. M. Gaston Rageot gives us a psychological portrait of that remarkable woman ("Mme. du Deffand,"

The marriage of Miss Elizabeth Morton Draper, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Edward Draper of this city and Norfolk, Conn., to William Emanuel Muntz, son of Dr. Emanuel Muntz of Buffalo and the late Mrs. Muntz, took place yesterday afternoon in the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Church. The Rev. Lynde E. May officiated.

Officers and members of the Lenox Garden Club have set aside Wednesday as a special visiting day, during which their gardens will be on exhibition between specified hours of the morning and afternoon, as a benefit for the club's special reserve fund.
Storm clouds blackened the skies of both Europe and Asia last week. Thunder rumbled menacingly in the East and in the West, but in neither region did the storm break.

The marriage of Miss Katherine Amelia Neyhart, daughter of Mrs. Bertram Franklin Weiper of Jackson Heights, L. I., and the late Elias Neyhart, to Robert A. Bullock, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Bullock of this city, took place here today in Pine Street Methodist Episcopal Church, with Dr. J. Howard Ake, pastor, officiating.

TOMORROW morning a big flying boat of Imperial Airways, the Short Caledonia, will take off from the sheltered harbor of Foynes, Ireland, for Newfoundland, on the first of the exploratory flights preliminary to transatlantic mail and passenger service.

With 4,500 applications for home relief already received from dismissed WPA workers, officials of the Emergency Relief Bureau estimated yesterday that nearly 50 per cent of the 11,800 persons dropped from the Federal relief rolls last Wednesday would qualify for ERB aid.
THE 25,000 Boy Scouts gathered in the national jamboree at Washington will be reviewed this week by their honorary president, who is also President of the United States.

More than 1,050 undergraduate students at City College earned $22,000 during the Spring semester beginning in February and ending in June, according to the eighteenth semi-annual report of the college employment bureau to the faculty committee on student employment of which Professor Edmund Burke is chairman.
The flying heels of Don Lash, Indiana University distance runner, were temporarily slowed today when the athlete underwent an appendectomy in the Sanders Hospital.

This department is designed to assist in the location of complete versions of poems and their sources, the names of authors, , which cannot be found through the usual channels of anthologies and books of reference.

Sir James Barrie's birthplace at Kirriemuir, Scotland, with its "Window in Thrums," has been purchased for the nation by Duncan Elliot Alves, wealthy New Zealander, who has already made many presentations to British universities and academies.
OVER the Oriental seas, recently plied only by leisurely junks, hulking freighters and sleek ocean liners, new wings are flashing today.

Is Congress losing its sense of humor? There is a lot of foreboding on this subject during Washington's current political season, and not a little concrete evidence that more unpleasantness is impending. Some of the principal evidences are:
The President of the Basque Republic, Jose Antonio Aguirre, driven from his homeland, declared today that "our territory has been conquered, but not the spirit of the Basque people."

Ray Radcliff paced the slugging White Sox with five for five today as Chicago defeated St. Louis, 10 to 5. Rain fell virtually throughout the game and made the rubber on the pitcher's mound so slick that Bill Dietrich of the Sox slipped and fell while starting a pitch to Harlond Clift in the third and the umpires ruled it a balk.

Those old times when housewives trudged many a weary mile in the course of each day's housework have been condemned by the Federal Housing Administration. FHA officials have declared that they will not risk government money on houses that are poorly planned and inconveniently arranged. Houses must be "designed for living," they say.

The President, in the matter of labor strikes, is against those workers who want and employ violence and those employers who refuse to negotiate. He implied this at a press conference this week by quoting what Mercutio said of the Capulets and the Montagues when he was mortally wounded by Tybalt: "A plague on [o'] both your houses!"

Announcement has been made of the marriage of Miss Ruie Rideout, daughter of F. W. C. Rideout of this place, to Raymond S. Morgan, son of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Walter E. Morgan of Chicago, which took place on June 26 in the Presbyterian Church in Englewood.

The marriage of Miss Patricia McCready Sykes, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. McCready Sykes of this city, to Jean-Louis Terry of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Hopkins Terry of Paris, took place this evening in the home of the bride's parents. The ceremony was performed by Mayor DeWitt D. Barlow of Plainfield.

Mr. and Mrs. Frederic W. Rhinelander of Newport, R. I., are expected this week at their Twilight Park cottage. Baron and Baroness Heinrich Adrian Walterius von Lockhorst have taken the cottage on Mr. and Mrs. Francis Stewart's place near here for the season. Mr. and Mrs. Frank Hubby of 17 East Ninety-first Street recently opened their house here.
E. Mulford Crutchfield, general agent here for the Equitable Life Assurance Society, was slain late this afternoon at his home, Reveille, just outside the city line.
THE first of six uniform guidebooks to the New England States, each prepared under the auspices of the Federal Government and sponsored by its own State government,

The four-story building at 430-4 Seventh Avenue, in the block north of Pennsylvania Station and opposite Macy's, has been leased to the operator of a chain of restaurants, including the Exchange Bar and Grill in Cortlandt Street, it was announced yesterday.
SINCE the radio curtain has dropped on the first half of 1937, globe-girdling events in broadcasting and new developments in radio science now skyrocket in review, for this is the Fourth of July.
The long awaited substitute for President ROOSEVELT'S court-reorganization plan has now been introduced with the support of the majority leader of the Senate.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Jessamine Hale, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John C. Hale of Bound Brook, N. J., to H. Stewart Mensing, son of Mr. and Mrs. Carl E. Mensing of Somerville. N. J.

The marriage of Miss Marion Louise Fisher, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles J. Fisher of this city, to John Shortridge Vansant, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen S. Vansant of New Rochelle, took place at noon today in the North Avenue Presbyterian Church in New Rochelle.

The franc continued to move narrowly yesterday in a quiet foreign exchange market. The range for the spot franc was between 3.84 7/8 and 3.84 1/2 cents, with a final price of 3.843/4 cents, representing a net gain of 3/8 point for the short business day. At this level, the net decline on the week was 62 1/4 points.

Five men who arrived here last week from Milwaukee in a sixtytwo-foot schooner via the Great Lakes, State Barge Canal and Hudson River, will set out from City Island this week on the next leg of a proposed trip around the world.

The forty-sixth annual session of the Catholic Summer School of America will open today at Cliff Haven, on Lake Champlain. Mgr. Michael J. Lavelle, rector of St. Patrick's Cathedral, will have charge of studies.

Aspects of the race problem in various parts of the world will be discussed by economists, social workers, religious leaders and others at the Institute of Race Relations which opens tomorrow at the Cheyney State Teachers College, Cheyney, Pa. They institute will continue through July 24.

Lord Macaulay a century ago replaced the Sanskrit and Persian learning of Indian schools with the English language and Western culture. The Indian generations since Macaulay's time have been brought up in schools and colleges modeled on English patterns.

FIVE new exhibitions were added to the current attractions last week and changes and notable additions were made in at least three other exhibitions. The Brooklyn Museum opened its "Art and Technique of Ceramics," prepared by the Rockefeller Internes of the Museum.

The Ann, owned by Francis S. Page, was the winner in the Atlantic class races at the Indian Harbor Yacht Club today, with John M. Lovejoy's Snapper finishing one minute and forty-five seconds behind in second place.

Mr. and Mrs. Richard N. L. Church of Kings Point gave their annual Fourth of July garden supper tonight at their estate overlooking Manhasset Bay. More than 200 persons, including the neighbors of the countryside and their holiday house guests, danced and witnessed the display of fireworks.

Moe Schultz, 29 years old, of 351 Hinsdale Street, Brooklyn, returned yesterday on the President Roosevelt from Palestine, where he said he had driven a truck for three years between the towns of Haifa and Tel-Aviv, a distance of ninety miles, and had many thrilling escapes from Arab snipers.

The board of trustees of the American Medical Association as vested with a tremendous responsibility when it was authorized to cooperate with the Federal Government "in developing the best possible care of the indigent sick, within the principles fundamental to good medical service previously established,"

Hot weather often used to hasten adjournment of Congress, but this year the cold might do it. House members are complaining more and more that their airconditioned chamber is too frigid. Many of them refer to it as the "icebox" and spend as much time as possible in the warmer lobbies and cloakrooms.
LONDON-Foreign Secretary Eden warned that Britain was determined "to maintain the territorial integrity of Spain" because of the traditional attitude toward the Mediterranean -route to the East.
The British Wightman Cup tennis team which will play the United States at Forest Hills, L. I., Aug. 20-21, was announced today and failed to include the new all-England singles champion.

Overcoming early interference and then standing a drive gamely, Jay Jay won the $6,950 Fleetwing Handicap before a record crowd of 15,000 at Empire City yesterday. Despite the increased facilities afforded by recent improvement, fans were actually clinging to the backs of others to see the drive through the stretch whereby Howard Bruce's colorbearer triumphed by a length and a half over Mrs. Marian Cassidy's Bill Farnsworth.

The Pennsylvania Turnpike Commission, created by the Legislature to build a $65,000,000 "super highway" from Carlisle to Pittsburgh through existing tunnels in the Allegheny Mountains, expects to offer bonds for the project early next January.
Henri Cuenot, 75-year-old mountain climber and skier, disappeared today during a mountain excursion and it is feared he met a serious accident.

THE rafters of the Paramount sound stages shook this week with the stress of some pretty elegant acting. Hollywood's conception of dramatic emphasis as typified by the repeated phrase, "I tell you I won't. I won't." or "You've got to go. You've got to,"
GENEVA.-The Swiss are debating a scheme for a vehicular tunnel which will far and away outclass the Holland tubes if it ever materializes.

A series of campaigns concentrated on individual industries is seen by foreign traders as the new strategy of organizations pushing "Buy American" movements in this country. The foreign traders believe that such groups as the Made-inAmerica Club, Inc., and the Madein-America League, Inc., propose to concentrate on various industries until major lines of production in the United States have been covered.

A party of seventy-five students and musicians, members of the Keller Travel Club, will sail on the Queen Mary Wednesday. The club's president, Dr. E. G. Keller, reported yesterday a gain of 91 per cent in student tour bookings above those of last year.
ANNIVERSARY SPEAKER: Twenty-four foreign professors, representing sixty-six foreign universities, were at Goettingen, Germany,

Track and field activity, focused for the last few days on the national championships in Milwaukee, will swing back to the East where a series of important events await followers of foot-racing in the next fortnight.
Opposition of the United States to the barter treaty between Germany and Brazil has caused charges here that Washington has been bringing undue pressure to bear on this country.

Thomas G. Grace, New York State FHA director, issues a warning to persons seeking governmental home aid of any character against the employment of persons calling themselves Federal Housing Administration representatives.
Always with that qualifying note, "weather permitting," the Fourth of July should go down as one of the big fishing days of the year in this section of the East.

FHA Insurance commitments on New Jersey home loans during the first six months of 1937 totaled more than $12,700,000, consisting of 1,225 mortgages totaling $6,558,700 on new construction and 1,372 totaling $6,163,400 for refinancing, according to a report issued yesterday by Thomas E. Colleton, New Jersey Director of the FHA.

The French Government as well as the American colony in Paris will observe the Fourth according to the traditions of former years, except that the day's most important ceremony will be the opening, in the afternoon, of the United States Pavilion at the Exposition.

Rearrangement" of the service of the States Steamship Company from Portland to the Orient will depend upon the Maritime Commission's "generosity" to the line, according to Charles E. Dant, a stockholder.
NIGHT-LIFE in Manhattan never attracted us, but here we've gone for it--spades, doubled. You can't escape it. We've taken up, for example, the habit of Brown Derby diners.

Plans for establishing a museum of the industrial arts and sciences which will seek not only to show the significant applications of science and engineering, but to interpret the social implications in the advancement of science,

New York markets will have on hand this week a plentiful supply of vegetables from New Jersey, Long Island and up-State farms. And with few exceptions the produce from these near-by truck gardens is expected to be of excellent quality.

The announcement yesterday that the armed forces of both sides had been or were being withdrawn from the disputed area shows that the counsels of moderation have won, temporarily at least, in both Moscow and Tokyo, and--what is just as vital-in the Russian and Japanese general staffs in the field.

Fireworks displays in several parts of the Summer colony here tonight featured holiday dinner parties. There will be more tomorrow and still more on Monday night, all in celebration of the Fourth of July.

The administration compromise measure on reorganization of the Judiciary can be beaten in the Senate, if at all, only by a filibuster. That is now conceded by the opponents of any Supreme Court changes.

Rev. Dr. Henry Darlington, rector of the Church of the Heavenly Rest, New York City, is expected to join his family at the rectory here this week. During the season Dr. Darlington occupies the pulpit at Wilderness Chapel at Saranac Inn.

Brick and red sandstone taken from the hoisting house of the Morris Canal at Rockaway, N. J., have been used in constructing the new telephone building at Lake Mohawk near Sparta. The structure will be the Lake Mohawk Exchange of the Sussex Telephone Company of Newton, N. J.

Built to seat 6,500 persons, Bing Crosby's million-dollar Del Mar racing plant made its bow today with an attendance of nearly 15,000, many of them from the film colony. The pari-mutuel handle for the day was $183,041. Crosby had hopefully estimated it would reach $150,000.

National and international problems will be the subject of intensive discussion during the two-week sessions of the annual Institute of Public Affairs, which will open tomorrow at the University of Virginia.

The decision of the Joint Congressional Tax Inquiry Committee, announced last Friday, not to make public any of the names of nonresident aliens and foreign corporations because they had not been guilty of improper income-tax practices may be construed as carrying allusions with regard to the conduct of resident individuals and domestic corporations previously named in the course of the inquiry.

SOUTHAMPTON. -- Marked by an unusually full program, the celebration of Independence Day, which traditionally is the date for the beginning of formal entertaining in Southampton, gives every indication that the season will be the liveliest this resort has experienced in several years.

Four pole vaulters broke the accepted world record by soaring 14 feet 7 5/8 inches m the National A. A. U. games at Milwaukee, Bill Sefton eventually taking the event. Other notable victories were gained by Jack Weierhauser, John Woodruff; Joe McCluskey and Allan Tolmich. The Olympic Club of San Francisco dethroned the New York A. C. as team champion.

Calling attention to a plan recently launched by many cooperative bankers in Massachusetts to safeguard the borrower's family by providing borrowing mortgage money insurance, the United States Building and Loan League, declaring that the plan is an "earnest experiment," states that the "insured borrower in the future may be the rule rather than the exception."

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Helen Irene Miller, daughter of Mrs. Irene Siebert Miller of this city and Walter H. Miller of New York and The Ranch, Nassau Point, L. I., to Clifford McAleenan, son of Mrs. Joseph McAleenan of New York and the late Mr. McAleenan.

The second concert of the Naumburg series will be given on the Mall in Central Park tonight at 8:15 o'clock. Lajos Shuk, conductor of the Buffalo Philharmonic Orchestra, will direct a program featuring selections by the American composers, Henry Hadley, George Gershwin and Victor Herbert, and including Dvorak's "New World" symphony.

The grave of Nathaniel Foster Jr., famous Adirondack trapper and guide declared by many to be the original Natty Bumppo of James Fenimore Cooper's "Leather Stocking Tales," was marked for posterity today at Ava, fifteen miles from Rome. The grave, virtually unmarked since Foster's death ninety-seven years ago, is located in an old Quaker cemetery atop a knoll.
ERNEST NEWMAN has had occasion, in the columns of The London Sunday Times, to discuss the art of orchestral interpretation as lately manifested in London and Toscanini affords the moral of his tale.

Corporations during June paid $32,094,772 in back income taxes, compared with $11,219,446 in June of last year, the Bureau of Internal Revenue reported this afternoon on the basis of late telegraphic reports.

ANY ONE who trots through Forty-fourth Street, meaning the Shubert office, must have noted that the accent next season will be on music. It happens, though, that the first show of any sort from that atelier will be a straight play-this the drama by Micaeia O'Harra that was made known last September at Matunuck, R. I., under the title of "Honor Bright."
Miss Doris Bell Johnson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. C. R. Johnson of this place, was married tonight to Samuel Callahan Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Callahan, also of Nutley.
General Francisco Franco is willing that volunteers in Spain be withdrawn, according to an article in the semi-official Diario de Burgos reaching here today.

A new reference volume has found its way to the book shelves on the bridge of many a yacht this Summer. It is Robert F. Duncan's "A Cruising Guide to the New England Coast," a unique 302-page tome that has been produced in an edition limited to 1,500 copies.

THIS year marks the twentieth anniversary of the overthrow of the Czarist regime in Russia. There had been many portents in the empire of Nicholas II that his crown was beginning to topple, and the furor which arose when a new series of stamps was issued by the Czarist government in 1913 may have been among them.

THE designing of monograms is a hobby that has a decided practical side. Here letters of all languages may be combined and thus "enigmas" formed; in other words, a rebus of the interlaced and cleverly combined initials of a person's name, or of the full name itself, may be wrought.

Travel - minded Europeans with "the time, the money and the curiosity-in fact, everything but the courage" could come to America and bring millions to American railroads, hotels and resorts if this country would only show "more hospitable interest" in encouraging them, according to Ferro C. Rota of Rome, internationally known hotel man.

Mrs. Mary Elizabeth Currier Noakes, wife of George Noakes, died today at her home here of a coronary thrombosis. She would have been 72 years old on Monday. She was married to Mr. Noakes, a restaurateur, fifty-one years ago.

Miss Marjorie Morse, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. William Reginald Morse of Lawrencetown, Nova Scotia, and Chengtu, West China, will be married to Allan B. Crunden Jr., son of Allan B. Crunden of Montclair, N. J., and the late Mrs. Crunden, next Saturday in London.

The back-to-work movement at the Cambria plant of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation here, slightly interrupted by the dynamiting of two water mains feeding the mills, unquestionably has progressed to such an extent that it is difficult to upset the company contention that operation is virtually normal again.

In the initial 7 1/2-mile race of the Rumson Country Club's season among seven of the new Arrow Class craft, sailed today over the South Shrewsbury River course, Bemus Pierce's Heron won by 20 seconds from William Dinsmore Bank's Circe.

As the British Government strives to keep the lid on the Spanish situation, attention again is centered upon its relations with Germany-partly because Premier Mussolini is regarded as a hopeless case and partly because Chancellor Hitler is recognized as his major partner in the Fascist entente.
BLOCK ISLAND, R. I.-With more extensive schedules facilitating travel from all directions, Block Island plans for the Summer are growing.

Many garden owners are prevented by business from enjoying the benefits of their gardens except over the week-ends and holidays. Seldom do they walk in the garden on a dark night, and there are many nights when the moon puts in a late appearance or fails to cast any light at all.

Harry Haenigsen, cartoonist, of this city, has purchased a farm of fifty-two acres at Buckmanville, Bucks County, Pa., from H. V. Marsh. About twenty-five acres are devoted to apple orchards. An old stone house having eleven rooms is on the property, in addition to a garage and other buildings.

A new State law effective Monday prohibits employment of deputy sheriffs by private individuals and corporations for duty at industrial plants, Ralph M. Bashore, Secretary of Labor and Industry, announced today.
Dustcovered securities bearing the figures "$450,000" in gold letters greeted James Willis, a Negro handyman, as he dismantled a shoe shine stand in a hotel here.

In what is believed to be the largest claim ever granted by the Atlantic County Circuit Court, a jury early today awarded to Raymond I. Adams of North Massachusetts Avenue and James Palmer of Pleasantville $66,464 in their suit against the Atlantic City Electric Company. Attorneys for the utility company said they would appeal.

The marriage of Miss Marjorie Virginia Monaghan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Monaghan of this city, to Julian Calvert Nichols, son of Dr. and Mrs. William Nichols of Lansdowne. Pa., took place this morning in the Church of St. Barnabas, Woodlawn, the Bronx. The Rev. Michael A. Reilly, the rector, performed the ceremony.
A Summer camp operated at Adams Corners, six miles from here, by the Heckscher Foundation for Children began its eighth season this week with 585 children enrolled.

The $2,000,000 Franklin D. Roosevelt Boardwalk and beach stretching a mile and one half along the south shore of Staten Island for one mile and a half, was opened yesterday by Mayor La Guardia at dedicatory exercises. Colonel Brehon B. Somervell, local WPA Administrator; Borough President Joseph A. Palma and other officials also took part in the exercises.
Almost all French internal troubles, beginning with the great Revolution, have come from an empty treasury, and the events of the past two weeks have offered no exception to that rule.

Irked no little by the fact that a winning streak of their own had been wrecked on Friday by the Giants after they so painstakingly had run it up to an imposing six games, the Bees went to work with a vengeance yesterday as they concluded their two-day stay at the Polo Grounds.
OF the many public characters in the short reign of the Queen of Scots only two are really inexplicable: Mary herself, and Bothwell.

Announcement was made here last night of the death yesterday in London, England, of Tracy Dows of Rhinebeck, N. Y., at the age of 64. He had been living in London for the last six months. His death came suddenly, and quite unexpectedly, from an internal ailment.
Daniel Edward Moran, expert on bridge foundation work and consulting engineer for some of the largest bridges in the world, died at his home here today after a brief illness. He was 73 years old.

GOVERNORS ISLAND 2d Lt. Robert A. Evans, Sig.-Res., 1,916 Whitney Ave.. Niagara Falls. N. Y., is ordered to active duty, effective July 10, at Fort Monmouth, New Jersey, for training. Lt. Evans will rank from June 26, 1937.

Home buyers, according to Porter D. Daniel, who has designed more than forty suburban dwellings at Wheatley Ridge, the former estate of Will Rogers at East Williston, L. I., are demanding authentic styles in architecture.
Frederick M. Alger Jr.'s Azucar took the $3,000 added Michigan Handicap in a thrilling photo finish at the State Fair Grounds today.

A feature of today's celebration of the Fourth at Buenos Aires was a patriotic entertainment at an Argentine grade school named the United States of America School in accordance with a Pan-American resolution of several years ago, by which schools in all American countries are named after other American republics.

ON a drifting ice floe near the North Pole four Russians are living in a small hut, making observation, which they hope win aid in establishing a transpolar airline. They are testing the upper air, taking weather observations on the surface, sounding the depths of the sea. Recently, high over the Arctic wastes, flew three Russian aviators on the way from Moscow to Vancouver.

HAVING had a few years' breathing spell, the Dutch are resuming work this Summer on the huge Zuider Zee reclamation scheme. It is the greatest scheme of its kind ever attempted, but, despite the hard times they have had to contend with, the Dutch are indissolubly married to it.

Miss Violet Ernette Lanneau, daughter of Mrs. Ernest Edward Lanneau of Minneapolis, was married yesterday morning in the marriage chapel of the Municipal Building to Joseph Carleton Borden Jr. of Darien, Conn.

Miss Erna Margaret Lueders, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Lueders of Essex Fells, was married here this morning in St. Luke's Church to John Wills Tuthill, son of Mrs. Oliver Bailey Tuthill of North Caldwell and the late Mr. Tuthill, by the Rev. Ernest Tuthill, uncle of the bridegroom.

Miss Eleanor Henry Griffin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Griffin of Overbrook, was married this morning to William Hopkins Zimmerman of Harrisburg, son of Mr. and Mrs. A. William Zimmerman of Baltimore.
The popular belief that the blind "possess some unusual way of knowing" is found apparently justified in experiments announced today at Duke University.
Mr. and Mrs, Arthur D. Woodward of this place have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Katherine Woodward, to Daniel B, Curtiss of Thomaston.
Social nudism has grown tremendously and will become even more widespread in the next few years, Dr. Elton R. Shaw of Lansing, Mich., president of the American Sun Bathing Association, said today.
Civil war in the gypsy nation may result from the election of a new king here tonight. The younger generations of gypsies are republican and do not want a self-appointed king.

The Louise Mining Company of British Columbia, controlled by Japanese interests, has acquired control of the Iron Duke property on Louise Island, one of the Queen Charlotte group. Surface examinations of the property have indicated large deposits of magnetite ore. A test program is to be carried out this Summer. The chief bar to development by the Jpanese interests is the embargo on the export of capital from Japan.

A field of forty distance runners headed by Defending Champion Pat Dengis of Baltimore will lope off in quest of the national A. A. U. thirty-kilometer title in the annual Schenectady-to-Albany run tomorrow.
THIS column on this holiday is devoted to a couple of quick ones, both extremely pleasant to take, pure and unadulterated, and guaranteed to case no harmful after effects. They are,

Funeral services for Waiter Cary, former vice president of the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company, will be held tomorrow at 3 P. M. in All Souls Unitarian Church, Lexington Avenue and Eightieth Street. Burial will take place in the family plot in Milwaukee.

Capturing the lead in the third period and holding it for the remainder of the contest, the Burnt Mills Polo Club won, 9 to 6, from Monmouth County at Schley Field today. Each team has now won one game in the series.
One-Man Junior-Won by Andy Kulakovich Yonkers; John Ryan, Wanda, second; John Schulz, Red Feather, third. Time-1:18 2/5.

The discussion of freedom belongs in the Christian Church and is not to be left to the flag-draped stands of Independence Day, the Rev. Phillips Packer Elliott, pastor of the First Presbyterian Church, Brooklyn, said in a sermon yesterday at the First Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Twelfth Street, where he was formerly associate minister.

An audience of 3,500 persons was present last night at the Lewisohn Stadium, where the holiday was celebrated with a concert given by the People's Chorus of New York with the assistance of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra. Lorenzo Camilieri, regular conductor of the chorus, directed.

The path out of the present international disturbances is a "decent respect" for men as men, the Rev. Francis J. McConnell, Bishop of the Methodist Epsicopal Church of New York, said in a sermon yesterday morning at the First Presbyterian Church, 124 Henry Street, iBrooklyn.

A sudden quarrel which flared up after a-night of drinking led to the death shortly before 3 o'clock yesterday morning of John Kirby, 24 years old, an ex-convict, who was shot through the heart in the street near 823 Greenwich 'Street.

Here and there: In behalf of the Westchester County Conservation Association, Dr. Raymond L. Ditmars has issued an appeal to motorists to exercise due care t avoid running over song and game birds and small animals.
Ted Horton, pitching star of the Yale University baseball forces for three years, has signed with the Toronto Maple Leafs of the International League, the Leafs announced today.

Speaking at Bordeaux today for the first time since he was compelled by a hostile Senate vote to resign the Premiership, Leon Blum spoke of the past and the future "not as a beaten man but as one full of confidence and hope."

Amos Frank Stauffer of 19 Arlington Avenue, who retired in 1933 as assistant superintendent of Jersey City public schools, died this morning in the Fairmount Hospital after an illness of several months.

Once more the dislike of Italy among large sections of the population was demonstrated on the Vienna football field this afternoon, when violent fighting and kicking wound up the Central European Soccer Cup match in the Stadium between the Genoa team and the Austrian Admira eleven.
Cereal crops are reported to have suffered some damage. Owing to official economy measures, consumption of wheat and rye has sharply declined, but the mills now depend mainly upon imported wheat.
Edson Ave, 4,414 (17-5094); Bised Realty Corp to Helen D. Cooper, 4,414 Edson Ave. Union Ave (10-2678), e s, 71 ft n of 163d St, 37x125; Pauline Klein to 946 Union Ave Realty Corp, 950 Prospect Ave.
An argument between Hungarian bridge players who three weeks ago faced Ely Culbertson and other Americans in world ch

It appears unlikely that at least until the Fall, additional moves of importance in the program dealing with functional segregation of broker-dealer activity on the Exchanges will be made by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

As a special holiday attraction, Fortune Gallo, director of the San Carlo Opera Company, presented the Fokine Ballet, a group of seventy dancers, here tonight on the mammoth water stage on Zach's Bay. An audience of 10,300 persons filled every available seat in the Jones Beach Stadium, located on the shores of the bay.
Taking advantage of a four-goal handicap, the Saxon Woods combination conquered the Ramapo Polo Club, 9-8, today in the first game of their hol?iday week-end series.
