"Prayer and the light of God are powers by which the horizons between heaven and earth can be brought together," the Rev. Carlos G. Fuller of the Featherbed Lane Presbyterian Church, the Bronx, declared yesterday morning in a union service sermon at the Calvary Methodist Episcopal Church, 1,885 University Avenue, the Bronx. The joint service was held with the congregations of the Featherbed Lane and University Heights Presbyterian Churches.
Scoring 625 points, Lew France of New York City today won the Class B division of the annual twoday outboard regatta on Canandaigua Lake.

"Regulating Wall Street" will be the subject of an address by Henry C. France, former executive of the United States Treasury Department and Professor of Economics at New York University, to be given on Wednesday at the Kiwanis Club.

Major Ernest W. Strong of the Officers Reserve Corps, attached to the 312th Infantry, died Saturday afternoon in the United States Veterans Hospital, Kingsbridge Road, Bronx, of a heart attack which occurred early that morning.
Although tomorrow is a legal holiday, exhibitors in the Summer furniture markets opening tomorrow at the Merchandise Mart and the American Furniture Mart expect a heavy attendance.

While hundreds of spectators lined the banks of the Seventy-second Street Lake in Central Park yesterday, the Yonkers Canoe Club successfully defended its metropolitan canoeing championship, amassing a total of 45 points to retain the laurels it won a year ago.

Much of the patriotism in America is subject to criticism according to Christian standards, the Rev. Cecil C. Hine said yesterday in a sermon at the Lutheran Church of Our Saviour's Atonement, Bennett Avenue at 189th Street.

Although we succeeded in abolishing Negro slavery, we now have industrial slavery that must be faced as courageously, said the Rev. E. Felix Kloman in a sermon yesterday at Grace Episcopal Church, Broadway and Tenth Street.

Faith in God and a belief in the future and the brotherhood of man were advocated by the Rev. John A. MacCallum of Philadelphia today as an "instrument of liberation" from the disastrous consequences now "everywhere apparent of personal greed, class interest and narrow nationalism."

Miss Lucy Caruso of the Ravenhall A. C. and Miss Helen Lohman, unattached, gained the. final round in the metropolitan women's handball singles championship tournament at the Ravenhall Bathing Park in Coney Island yesterday.
Former Governor Alfred E. Smith of New York, returning from his first trip abroad, today gave his fellowpassengers a Fourth of July warning to preserve the American form of government.

With only twenty-five seats out of 138 to be filled for the new Dail Eireann, Eamon de Valera's party has already won fifty-seven, while the standing of the other parties today are Cosgraveites, 37; Laborites, 11, and Independents. 8.

Freed of some of its worries, the stock market recovered substantially last week in moderately increased trading. But aside from the actual improvement in share prices, the main point to be remarked was the change for the better in market sentiment.

British retail trade sales in May were 13.2 per cent over May, 1936. Public holidays, including the coronation period, doubtless accounted for a large part of this expansion, but for the four-month period (February to May) there was a gain of 9.2 per cent over the 1936 period.

Miss Mary Ann Stuart, daughter of Mrs. Joseph Herman Yuhas of the Bronx, was married to William C. O'Brien yesterday afternoon in St. Francis of Assisi Monastery, 135 West Thirty-first Street, by the Rev. Donatus Walsh, F. O. M.

New York City celebrated yesterday its safest 'and quietest Fourth of July in many years. While millions of city dwellerss took advantage of the perfect weather and the double holiday week-end to visit the shore and country, fireworks accidents showed a marked downward trend.
Pedro Montanez, Puerto Rican lightweight, punched his way to victory over Frankie Wallace of Cleveland in ten rounds tonight. The bout started in a heavy rain before a capacity crowd.

Paul Keres of Estonia, V. Petrow of Latvia and Dr. Alexandre Alekhine of France, all winners in the fifteenth round, gained slightly on Samuel Reshevsky, the United States champion, in the international masters tournament at the Kurhaus today.

One or those Nortn sea gusts which, with the Barry Burn, will be among the biggest hazards of this British open golf championship which starts tomorrow, caught two large refreshment tents early today and sent them flying skyward with their poles. ropes and stakes.
Mr. and Mrs. Francis Gilbert of Woodmere, L. I., have announced the marriage of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Ruth Gilbert, to Samuel Belfer of Milwaukee, on Friday in Chicago.

Richmond police early today shot and killed Joe Deas, Negro chauffeur, when he fired upon them, wounding one officer, as they attempted to arrest him on a charge of slaying E. Mulford Crutchfield, general agent for Virginia of the Equitable Life Assurance Society.
Princess Dagmar, sister of King Christian X, was among 30,000 who gathered today at Rebild National Park in North Jutland to celebrate the Fourth of July.
Tremont Ave, 744 to 752 E (11-2951); Nicotri Realty Corp. to Mary V. Crocker, 284 E 206th St, extends mtgs to June 15, 1942, at 4 1/2 to 5 per cent; $80,000.
Repeating their polo victory of last week, the Shamrocks conquered the Knaves, 8-7, today to gain posession for one year of the Mrs. Gilbert Lawrence Haight trophy.

August P. Hilla, chief electrician at Newark Airport since it opened in 1929, was killed early this morning when a wrench he was holding came in contact with a high-tension wire in the switchboard control room of the Administration Building.
Senator Byrd today alleged that conditions approaching "a national scandal" were being created by the "sinful and absurd waste" in the Resettlement Administration's homestead projects.
A new ways and means subcommittee of which Representative Lamneck, Democrat of Ohio, is chairman, will hold its first meeting Tuesday to consider a bill to create a Federal lottery commission.

There was no holiday on recordbreaking swimming performances today. While a gala crowd looked on at the Castle Beach Club six American standards were shattered as some of the nation's leading mermaids and mermen competed in an A. A. U. meet.

In final returns just received In its semi-annual cost survey covering forty-seven cities throughout the country the Dow Service finds that the barometric items of basic building materials used in construction work are far more stable in comparison to New York prices than prevailing hourly wage rates.

Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Eleanor Vey Thibaut, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard E. Thibaut of Greenwich, to Charles Francis Smithers, son of Mrs. Oscar L. Gubelman and the late Charles Smithers.
French, Spanish and Far Eastern troubles had an unsettling and depressing reaction on the week's markets here.

Units of the Ninety-third Infantry Brigade of the Metropolitan area, the 165th Infantry, the "Fighting Irish" of Manhattan, and the old Fourteenth Regiment of Brooklyn, holding annual "visitors' day" here at Camp Smith, acted as host today to more than 10,000 persons, including Governor Herbert H. Lehman, who reviewed the guardsmen.
Candidates for the House of Representatives who were backed by President Lazaro Cardenas are leading in the first returns in the first general election in three years.
Exploded bombs were found today under two bridges on main highways into San Juan.

The official view of the future of non-intervention in Spain reflects a desire to prevent a complete breakdown of the control machinery. Press attacks on Great Britain and France also are considerably moderated.
Belgium is dealing with the problem of how to provide for Spanish refugee children from the Basque country very satisfactorily.
Apathy in the face of attacks on American institutions was condemned yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Benjamin. F. Farber, pastor of the Fourth Presbyterian Church, West End Avenue and Ninety-first Street.
The first husband of the Duchess of Windsor, Commander Earl Winfield Spencer, U.S.N., married Mrs. Norma Reese Johnson at her home here today.

The Communist party will support Mayor La Guardia for re-election if he is the Fusion candidate this Fall, Clarence Hathaway, member of the Central Committee of the Communist party and editor of The Daily Worker, said yesterday at the party's seventeenth annual Independence Day fair and carnival at Pleasant Bay Park, the Bronx.

The Delaware Hudson police team from Albany, N. Y., turned in a score of 1,312 to defeat the New York police today in the national small bore rifle and pistol championships at Camp Cascade. The New York unit had 1,259.
The votes by the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls in Congress last week are given in the following tabulation:
Two memorials to Frank Melville Jr. were dedicated here today by Suffragan Bishop J. I. Blair Larned of the Long Island Episcopal Diocese.
Western States, where dust storms tore crops from the ground in recent years, intensified a fight today against a new enemy threatening from the air-swarms of grasshoppers.
Led by its captain, George Ford, the Rochester Yacht Club today completed a sweep of its invitation regatta for 14-foot one-design international dinghies, held on the waters of Lake Ontario.

The Public Works Bond Commission, appointed by the Cuban Government to study means for the settlement of these defaulted obligations, will propose four possible solutions of the problem, with a strong recommendation that floating debts be included with the public works bonds in a new issue, according to the first draft report drawn up by the subcommittee in charge of this work, according to information from a reliable source today.
Reported by the American News Company, Bloomingdale's, Brentano's, Doubleday, Doran Book Shops, Gimbel's, Macy's, Scribner's, Wanamaker's, and Womrath's:

Samuel Adsit of Norfolk, Va., and Mrs. Elizabeth W. Gobay of Flushing, L. I., were married here yesterday by Justice of the Peace William S. M. Fiske. With the-couple were Mrs. Jean Ghent, daughter of the bride, and M. Dal Ghent,

Detective Lieutenant Leroy Sanderson said tonight that Albert Dyer, a WPA crossing guard employed in Centinela Park, Inglewood, to protect children, had confessed slaying three young Inglewood girls June 26.
Kisarazu's 100 geisha won their fiveday strike today, but the fruits of victory were only about half a cent an hour.

Despite increased taxes and the loss of the emergency freight surcharges which expired last Dec. 31, the railroads have shown substantially increased earnings in the first half of the year, according to current figures.
It was decided tonight that Ranger and Rainbow would race tomorrow in the second contest of the final trials to select the America's Cup defender.
The Securities and Exchange Commission has approved various proposed transactions in the reorganization of the St. Louis Gas and Coke Corporation.

Miss Elisabeth Howard, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence A. Howard of Farmington, will be married on July 24 to Henry Parker Jones of Beaufort, S. C. The Rev. Quincy Blakeley will perform the ceremony in the Congregational Church. A small reception will be held at the Howard residence.

Representatives of the New York Towboat Exchange and the marine division of the International Longshoremen's Association will resume negotiations tomorrow for a new wage agreement. Committees have been named to study the various types of towboat service operating from this port and wage schedules will be based on the nature of each service.

At the close of the second day of a three-day racing program sponscored by the Bay Shore Yacht Club, ties marked the competition in four classes. The top point scorers in the eight other divisions led rivals by narrow margins.

Surrounded by hundreds of policemen and thousands of anti-Fascists, about 3,000 British Fascists marched today from Kentish-Town in North London to Trafalgar Square in their first procession since. the passage of the Public Order Act in January.

The Red Sox today took two games from the Athletics for their fourteenth and fifteenth triumphs in the last seventeen home games. The double victory sent Boston into third place in the league race, five percentage points ahead of Detroit.

A carrier pigeon brought the Coast Guard to the aid of four persons in a disabled craft twenty miles southeast of Jones Inlet yesterday. The pigeon was freed by Captain Ray Eldred of the forty -foot fishing boat Betty Ann, who sighted the disabled boat.

Mrs. Isabel Weed Jones Morgan, daughter of Mrs. Louise Weed Jones of New York and the late John Morgan Jones, was married to Morton Good, son of the Rev. and Mrs. Thomas R. Good of Schenectady, N. Y., this afternoon on the lawn of the estate of the bride's great uncle and great aunt, Mr. and Mrs. Edward Franklin Weed of Contentment Island here.
The American Federation of Labor sent more squads of organizers into industrial areas today to battle John L. Lewis's Committee for Industrial Organization.
The Graduate Faculty of Political and Social Science (the University in Exile) will begin its third sixweek Summer session tomorrow at the New School for Social Research, 66 West Twelfth Street.

The Economist's Index of British commodity prices, at 84.3 on June 30, although showing a rise of 0.1 point from that of a fortnight earlier, continues at the lower level to which it dropped in June. The present figure, based on the average of 1927 as 100, compares with 86.2 a month ago and with the index of 60.4 on Sept. 19, 1931, just before the suspension of gold payments by Great Britain.

Monty Stratton and Ted Lyons limited the Browns to eight hits apiece today and the White Sox captured both games of a double-header, 4 to 2 and 9 to 5. The two triumphs gave the Chicagoans the series, three games to one.
Gerardo Butero, 42-year-old WPA worker, of 1,225 Greene Avenue, Brooklyn, was arrested last night on a charge of homicide after he admitted shooting his wife dead aocidentally.

To write the story of the 1939 Golden Gate International Exposition would be, in a fashion, the setting forth of a pocket edition of the history of Western America, of the nations along the mighty Pacific, and of San Francisco, picturesque and romantic, whose people have an unusual faculty for envisaging and achieving studendous projects.

Mr. and Mrs. Charies B. Sanford of this city have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss caroline Cope Ingram, to Lawrence Southwick, son of Mr. and Mrs. Nathan M. Southwiek of Leicester, Mass.

Youth swept to victory in a game usually reserved to veterans yesterday as the fourth annual United States open horseshoe pitching championship was held by the Emerald Club in Central Park, near 106th Street.
Miss Patricia Cumming successfully defended her. New Jersey State girls' tennis championship when she won the Anne Cumming Memorial tournament at the Westfield Tennis Club today.

Dr. Onslow A. Gordon, retired Brooklyn (N. Y.) surgeon, died today at his Summer home at Lake Keoka, near here, at the age of 84. He was a charter member of the American College of Surgeons and a former president and treasurer of the Brooklyn Medical Society.

Some important dividend meetings this week by companies listed on the New York Stock Exchange follow: Tomorrow Century Ribbon Mills, Inc. (pf.). Cerro de Pasco Copper Co. (com.). Homestake Mining Co. (com.). Maytag Co. (com.).
Bill Lohrman and Hy Vandenberg, allowing six and two hits, respectively, today gave Baltimore a double victory over Jersey City, 3 to 2 and 14 to 1, to sweep the fourgame series.
William Green president of the American Federation of' Labor, expressed approval today of Secretary Perkins's statement Saturday that sit-down strikes were unbecoming to America.

The week's stock market was inert, quotations at first being lower but, in consequence of the technical position, there was a recovery today. Average prices in the different groups declined only a little.

Mrs. Selby Zell Rowland, widow of C. Ransom Rowland, was married yesterday to Frank Sheppard Royster Jr. of Norfolk, Va., son of Mrs. F. S. Royster and the late Mr. Royster, at Vesper Hill, the country place of Mr. and Mrs. W. W. Abell, stepfather and mother of the bride.

A group of Newark bankers and industrialists are shunning trains in favor of a de luxe trailer in making daily trips between here and their Jersey shore homes. The trailer is owned by William B. Reilly, vice president of the Feigenspan Brewing Company.
The Cunard Line completed its ninety-seventh year of service yesterday. The line is merged with the White Star and creates the greatest British line in the Atlantic. It was founded by Samuel Cunard.
Complete evacuation of Soviet land and naval forces from disputed islands in the Amur River was reported in dispatches reaching Tokyo today,

The nude body of a man, his head crushed and covered by three rocks about the size of cobble stones, was found this evening in a brush field about 200 yards from Convent Road, two miles southwest of here.

Pop bottles rained again on the field at Griffith Stadium today along with fire-crackers in a dangerous manifestation of antipathy to Jake Powell by the minority in a crowd of about 23,000 otherwise peaceful fans.

The First Division polo team made it three victories in as many starts over its home rival, the Fort Hamilton Officers, yesterday at the Fort Hamilton Army Reservation, staging a last-period rally to triumph by 8 to 7.
Six persons were downed today when the motor boat Bab, with forty-two persons aboard, capsized in East Pass Channel between Choctawhatchee Bay and the Gulf of Mexico.

Fire believed to have been caused by an electric short circuit early today destroyed the attic and damaged the first and second floors of a wing occupied by the intermediate grade classrooms in the twoand-a-half story brick Hastings Public School building on Farragut Avenue.
Definite radio signals on a frequency assigned to Amelia Earhart's missing airplane were reported tonight by the Coast Guard after the aviatrix had been asked to answer broadcast instructions.
The holiday entertaining continued this afternoon and this evening and many other parties have been planned for tomorrow, including the annual Fourth of July bake of the Newport Clambake Club.

A. Felix du Pont Jr. is chairman of the regatta committee for the Long Island Aviation Country Club's seventh annual cruise. The forty-five members will arrive in eighteen seaplanes Thursday for a four-day

The New York Athletic Club tennis team triumphed over the Orienta Beach Club netmen of Larchmont, 8 to 3, in a match played at Travers Island yesterday. The victors took five of the six singles matches and three of the five doubles tests.

An unnamed manufacturing company, located in America and making instruments for the Soviet Union, was accused today by Leonid Zakovsky, chief of the secret service in Leningrad, of being closely connected with the German intelligence service.

If Jesus lived. today as he lived, in Palestine he would not be hailed as a prophet but locked up in an insane asylum or deported as.a dangerous Red,-. the Rev. Dr. Daniel Bliss of the Second Congregational Church, Greenwich,- Conn., declared in a sermon yesterday morning at the Broadway Tabernacle at-Fiftysixth Street.

On both sides of the Atlantic two huge flying boats, one representing the Imperial Airways and the other the Pan American Airways, were being tuned up yesterday ready for transatlantic survey flights scheduled to start early this afternoon.

Captain Wilson C. Price, organizer and former superintendent of the Pennsylvania highway patrol, died today at his home here after a long illness. His age was 57. Last week, little more than a year after Captain Price's retirement, the patrol was merged with the State police to form the Pennsylvania motor police.
Sir Sorabji Pochkhanawala, managing director of the Central Bank of India, died today. He was 55 years old.

Twenty-five students of the Sorbonne, some of them French and some American, spent all last night painting, sweeping and polishing under police guard to get the United States pavilion at the Paris International Exhibition ready for its official inauguration on this Fourth of July by Ambassador William C. Bullitt and Commissioners Thomas J. Watson and Frederick A. Sterling.

The Library of Congress "reading machine" factory at 475 Tenth Avenue, where 100 blind WPA workers helped build the intricate electric gramophones that make literature available to sightless persons unfamiliar with Braille, has been closed, it was learned last night.

Contracts have been awarded for additions to the Gadsden mills of the Republic Steel Corporation to cost approximately $2,000,000. L. E. Geohegan, general manager of the company's Gulf Steel division, said today that the sheet mill would be enlarged at a cost of about $1,000,000 and its capacity increased about 50 per cent.
The Rev. Martin Niemoeller, from his cell in Moabit prison, sent a message of good cheer today to his congregation in Dahlem. There were two mornings services, and the crowds,

After hudlingthe stands a full hour during a first-inning rainstorm, a capacity crowd of 36,744 was treated to six hours of spectacular baseball today as the league-leading Cubs bombed Cy Blanton from the mound to defeat Pittsburgh, 8 to 5, in the opener, but lost the second game, 7 to 6, when a ninth-inning rally fell short with the tying run on third base.
Fourteen Federal agencies awarded 124 supply contracts valued at $6,288,999 under terms of the Public Contracts Act during the week ending July 1, according to the Department of Labor.

Alleviation of the Dutch embargo on circulation of foreign security issues here means that the capital market again is open to all new issues of foreign companies or organizations, the previous issues of which already are quoted on the Amsterdam Bourse.

Mrs. Martha Bernhelm, in 64 E 86th St through Samuel A. Herzog. Curzon Taylor, in 180 E 79th St through Port Burke, Inc, Harold G. Villard, in 125 E 72d St through G. Vitagliano; Jarvis Williams Jr, in 983 Park Ave through Mrs. Edward Stout, Inc; Newell B. Whitcomb, in 1,125 Park Ave through Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc, brokers.

Charles Fuchs, 54 years old, a retired Department of Sanitation employee, was drowned late yesterday afternoon in a combination wash and bath tub in the kitchen of his top-floor apartment at 333 East Ninety-seventh Street.

Funeral serviced for John T. Underwood, retired chairman of the Underwood Elliott Fisher Company and founder of the Underwood typerwriter business, were held yesterday at the Lafayette Avenue Presbyterian Church, at South Oxford Street, Brooklyn, of which he had been a trustee. More than 350 persons attended.

Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Pierce Robinson of this city have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Louise Robinson, to Carl Raymond Brandt of Wilmington, Del., son of Mr. and Mrs. Carl V. Brandt of Great Neck. L. I.

Two were killed and three others injured today in an automobile collision on Route 29 near Vossler Avenue. The dead and injured were occupants of a car driven by Irving Hyman, 41 years old, of 2,525 Beverly Road, Brooklyn.

Henry Rostorff, 20 years old, of West Orange is in the Beach Boroughs Hospital in critical condition after being rescued tonight from the Manasquan River Inlet where he and a companion were attempting a long-distance swim.

The eyes of the world are turned toward America as. the great conservator of independence, according to the Rev. Dr. Samuel Henry Prince, Professor of Economics and Sociology at King's College, Halifax, in a Fourth of July sermon yesterday in St. Stephen's Protestant Episcopal Church, Sixtyninth Street near Broadway.

New capital is more difficult to obtain here because of the fall in security prices since the beginning of the year, but the depressed market for securities has not interrupted the industrial recovery in Great Britain and there seems to be no reason why it should be halted.

President Roosevelt today proclaimed the period of Sept. 17 of this year to April 30, 1939, for commemoration of the one hundred and fiftieth anniversary of the Constitution and of the inauguration of the first President thereunder.

The value of construction in the South in 1936 climbed to heights never reached before. Contracts awarded for new buildings, new industrial plants, road and bridge construction, engineering projects, and for many improvements and extensions to existing structures soared to a new high of $939,264,000. This was an increase of $18,
Thanks to CHARLES HAYDEN and the Museum of Natural History, we have our Planetarium, in whose skies the simulated stars can be seen in all kinds of weather and by day as well as by night.
There was a considerable demand for money after the turn of the month, and the banks believe that the strain occasioned by the Reich loan in May continues to be felt.

Mr. MAURY MAVERICK, a Texas Representative in Congress, is a statesman of wide--some folks think altogether too wide-effusion and diffusion. At Washingto-- he is the leader of a dauntless band of patriots whose numbers have been estimated at a dozen and a half.

Three classes of the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club fleet started their second-day races in the holiday three-day series for the Seawanhaka Cup this afternoon, but the Class S yachts alone finished.

If war comes, the pulpits will be commandeered, the Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman declared yesterday in his sermon at Christ Methodist Episcopal Church, Park Avenue at Sixtieth -Street. Appealing for the safeguarding of freedom of speech, action and worship as a -means of guarding liberty, he said "democracy seems more in danger throughout the world than ever before."
The South Shore Polo Club erased a one-goal handicap in topping the Ox Ridge team from Darien, Conn., in an exciting contest today at Hazard Field, 6 to 5.

In last week's news were two local items, printed in adjoining columns, that stood out like a signpost: This is New York. First there was the story of the head found rolling down the slopes of Riverside Drive, fortunately a head in bronze which had been knocked off its pedestal by a crowd of raffish boys.

Frederick Benedict bought a plot at the corner of Country Club Drive and East High Road, Flower Hill, L. I., from Carlos W. Munson for improvement with a dwelling. L'Ecluse, Washburn Co. and Ernest G. Blaich Company were the brokers. Mr. Munson also sold at Flower Hill to George F. Scudder, builder, two one-acre plots on Knolls Lane. L'Ecluse, Washburn Co. were the brokers.

Costs of food declined slightly in the month ended on June 15, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today. The food cost index for June 15 was 86.3 per cent of the 1923-25 average. A month earlier it was 86.5 per cent, and in the middle of April it was 85.6 per cent.

An augury of what may be expected during Larchmont Race Week two weeks hence was given today when 120 boats, the biggest fleet in the memory of the oldest salt for a Sunday special, turned out for the Larchmont Yacht Club's regatta.
Governor Earle told a Johnstown steel strikers' rally that "you don't need violence when you have Roosevelt, a liberal Congress and a Governor like me." A crowd of 10,000 to 15,000 attended. Page 1.

In his statement Saturday to his constituents in Warwickshire, Mr. Eden did his part in sweeping aside the camouflage which has kept in being for seven unhappy months the desperate pretense of the Spanish Non-Intervention Committee.

John Colt of Red Bank, N. J., and Mrs. Colt of 829 Park Avenue have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Eleanor Herr Colt, to C. Alan Hudson Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. C. Alan Hudson of this city, Rumson, N. J., and Miami Beach Fla.

The Coast and Geodetic Survey ships Oceanographer and Lydonia, which with two small tenders. are based at the Navy Yard in Brooklyn; during their work of surveying the ocean bottomoff the Barnegat Lightship, have discovered unusual streaks of alternating warm andcold water under the ocean's surface off the New Jersey Coast, it was revealed yesterday.
Following are outstanding parts of the address given by foreign Minister Carlos Saavedra Lamas at last night's Fourth of July dinner of the American Society of the River Plate.
A "fair trial" was urged for the Rogers-Allen Law, permitting collective. bargaining for milk' prices, at a gathering of 1,000 up-State

An 11-year-old boy was wounded seriously by a stray bullet yesterday afternoon while playing in the water near his Gerrittsen Beach home. He was rescued and taken to Coney Island Hospital, where an X-ray photograph disclosed a bullet in the right side of his head.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The letter signed by four members of the Twentieth Century Fund committee which appeared in your issue of June 20 is so courteous in its reference to the criticisms of "Facing the Tax

Carl W. Ackerman, dean of the Graduate School of Journalism of Columbia University, underwent a successful operation for appendicitis last night at the British-American Hospital at Bellavista, near Lima.

(Figures in parentheses indicate par) Brookville (72)--Second round for President's Trophy: F. B. Bowne defeated Mark Ryan, 1 up (19 holes). Best-ball competition: Dr. T. J. Evers and Dr. J. Connolly, 9-13-66; Dr. M. Dunne and C. Parr. 78--10--68. Quadrangular round robbin; Huntington, 51; Brookville, 50; Crescent, 24 1/2; Northport, 12 1/2.

Speculation resulting from the current tax evasion hearings on the possibility of the Federal Government fundamentally altering its method of imposing and collecting individual income taxes was scouted today by Representative Doughton of North Carolina, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee.
Palestine-both Arabs and Jews-is impatiently awaiting the royal inquiry commission's report and recommendations for a solution of the nationalities problem.

Although the official observance of Independence Day is tomorrow, the almost total absence of fireworks accidents here and in other New Jersey communities today indicated that the Bischoff anti-fireworks law, passed at the last session of the Legislature, would prove effective in discouraging the use of pyrotechnics.
A committee of Indiana Harbor clergymen today telegraphed an appeal to Governor M. Clifford Townsend to send troops into this steel area, declaring that "the situation is entirely out of control."

Ham and eggs for breakfast-that was the way we started celebrating the Fourth of July with an American transport unit outside Madrid. It was a great day even if the war stirck with us throughout and pretty well spelled matters for the Abraham Lincoln and George Washington Battalions, who had sterner business on their minds. But it ended well for Madrid's American colony with a feast at the embassy and a dance afterward.

Coming up with the rush of a rocket that burst with a gorgeous pyrotechnic display, the Giants brought down the forlorn Dodgers and their fireball ace, Van Lingle Mungo, at the Polo Grounds yesterday, 6 to 5, to give a crowd of 21,743 a rare one-day tournament.
Prices of cotton futures, which had advanced in the previous week, ended last week 24 to 29 points lower than on the previous Saturday, although they were about 20 points above the recent low levels.

Constitutional government in this country has "abdicated to the lawless forces of John L. Lewis and his communistic co-workers," the Rev. Dr. William Ward Ayer charged in his sermon yesterday as pastor of Calvary Baptist Church, 123 West Fifty-seventh Street.
Frank Disston, vice president of Henry Disston Sons, saw manufacturers, died this morning at his home in St. David's after a month's illness. His age was 57.

Furniture from a home in which the late John D. Rockefeller lived forty years ago will be placed on display in the new textile division of the Brooklyn Museum under a plan formulated by Philip N. Youtz, director, to have the institution serve as an aid for American designers and manufacturers, it was learned yesterday.

Thirty-three American track and field stars earned Summer trips to Europe and Japan in the fiftieth annual championship meet- of the Amateur Athletic Union yesterday, as well as winning the right to compete in the Pan American athletic games at Dallas next month.

Analyzing international trade trends, the official Trade Research Institute says trade was impeded until recently by the increased selling opportunities at home but has now entered a new stage of expansion.

The half year ended with the usual large turnover of money in Lombard Street, but there was a complete absence of pressure except on the last day of June, when loans from the Bank of England were required on a small scale.

The and thirty greatest race drivers in the world, representing Europe and America, are poised for the start tomorrow of the second 300-mile. Vanderbilt Cup automobile race which was postponed yesterday as the result of rain.
Five Woonsocket spinning mills are preparing a test as the result of an arbitration board award in a labor dispute to determine over a three months' period whether men or women do the better work.

Victories by Old Westbury and the Foxhunters were among the features of today's six-game program in the Meadow Brook Club Cups tourney as more than 10,000 polo enthusiasts watched the action on the fields at the Meadow Brook Club or near-by Bostwick Field.

The impression left on financial London by the rapid development and temporary solution of the French crisis has not been unfavorable. It is recognized, however, that the situation still is so delicately poised that anything in the nature of prophecy concerning the immediate future is impossible.

The Rev. H. Norman Sibley, Pastor of the Wyoming Presbyterian Church here for the last eight years, told his congregation today that he had decided to accept a call to the pulpit of the University Heights Presbyterian Church in the Bronx, New York City.

The moral health of society depends upon the Christians who are the "salt of the earth," the Rev. Jule Ayers declared yesterday at the Central Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue and Sixty-fourth Street.

There was a round of entertainment throughout the day for holiday guests at estates in the Summer colony. One of the largest parties was a buffet supper with dancing given by Mr. and Mrs. William De Wilder Atkinson at Ballyshear,

Sammy West, veteran outfielder of the Browns, today was selected to fill the vacancy in the American League team which will face the National League in the all-star game at Griffith Stadium on Wednesday.
Last Tuesday the Senate set what is said to be an all-time record for prompt and favorable action on a group of related international agreements.

Professor Irving Fisher's index number of average commodity prices last week, based on 100 as the average for 1926, was 92.5, which compares with 92 the week before, 91.9 two weeks before, 92 three weeks before and 92.6 four weeks before.

Two small stained-glass windows, both executed by Charles J. Connick of Boston, have been presented to the Princeton University Chapel by Mrs. Mary Ludington McKeen of Omaha, Neb., in memory of her brother, Dr. Paul H. Ludington, '94, of Omaha and Princeton, it was announced today by president Harold W. Dodds.
Lena Luftig gave to Edna M. Hurt a purchase money mortgage for $7,500, due in five years at 4 1/2 to 5 per cent, on 346 E 4th St. The price was $10,000.

Janet Gaynor, the object of bidding since her re-establishment in "A Star Is Born," has signed a term contract with Selznick International for one picture a year. Her first will be :Angel on Broadway," by Russel J. Birdwell, for which Ben Hecht will write the screen play.

Holland is not perturbed by the new devaluation in France, which for several months has been anticipated here. It is considered highly fortunate that since September, 1936, all direct monetary connections between the Netherlands and France have been broken, except indirectly through the tripartite agreement.

James H. Jourdan, chief officer of the Brooklyn Union Gas Company for twenty-three years, has retired as chairman of the board. No successor has been selected. Mr. Jourdan will remain a director of the company. Clifford E. Paige,

Owen Anderson of U. C. L. A. scored his fourth consecutive victory over a seeded rival, and won the Eastern intercollegiate tennis title for himself and the 1937 team trophy for his college when he defeated Gardnar Mulloy of Miami, the defending champion, 2-6, 6-4, 6-2, 3-6, 7-5, at the Richmond County Country Club, Dongan Hills, S. I., yesterday.
Winners of the scholarships offered by the Manhattan, Bronx and Richmond divisions of the Fite Department Holy Name Society were announced yesterday. Lawrence J.

Mrs. Kathlyn Kochman, 49 years old, a widow, of 106-08 Twenty-seventh Avenue, East Elmhurst, died in the Flushing Hospital yesterday after being removed from the Cedar Grove Cemetery, Flushing, where she was found slumped over the wheel of an automobile.

A gray squirrel scampered across the street here tbday, and thereby hangs a tale. A cat saw and promptly. pursued the squirrel. Chased and chaser crossed the path of Dan, a fox terrier. Dan accepted the challenge.

George Mitchell, former Premier of Southern Rhodesia, died here today at the age of 70. A native of Ayrshire, Scotland, George Mitchell went to South Africa in 1889 as an employee of the Bank of Africa, Ltd., and six years later opened the first branch of the bank in Matabeleland.

10th St, 419-421 E, 40.1x92.2, trustee of will of Thomas F. Manville to 419 E 10th St Corp, 415 E 5th St, Brooklyn, consideration $35,000. 4th St, 346 E, 28.1 1/2x96, Edna M. Hurt to Lena Luftig, Greystone Hotel, 91st St and Broadway ($10).
The National Labor Relations Board ended 103 cases involving strikes, covering 17,869 workers, during May, the board said in a report made public at the White House offices today.

SOUTHERN DISTRICT. Petitions Filed--By ABRAHAM A. GREENE, salesman 106 Ft. Washington Ave.--Liabilities $3,400; no assets. MAX SILBERMAN, sales (unemployed), 1,230 Leland Ave.--Liabilities $2,245; no assets.

Richard Bennett, national intercollegiate doubles champion from the University of California, followed his partner, Paul Newton, out of the invitation turf court tennis tournament of the Nassau Country Club today.
The French Foreign Ministry announced today that the Spanish Rebel cruiser Almirante Cervera had seized the French steamer Tregastel today off Santander.

In a contest marked by the superb defensive work of both quartets, Governors Island conquered the West Point Officers, 5-2, at Memorial Fieid yesterday in the first contest in the metropolitan area this season for the invaders.

THE custom is to have the major league teams let go with both barrels on the glorious Fourth, but, like Bob Feller's proposed rise to baseball stardom, it was postponed this year. The heavy firing was postponed only one day. For how long the Feller postponement holds deponent sayeth not. As it is now, it has been too long and too bad.

Business men and public officials attended funeral services here today for lexander Hamilton Garnjost, former New York State Assemblyman, who died Friday. The services were held in the Havey Funeral Home, with the Rev. Oliver Shaw Newell, rector of St. John's Episcopal Church, Yonkers, officiating.

An attempt to assassinate Dr. Antonio de Oliveira Salazar, Premier and virtual dictator of Portugal, was made here this morning. Accompanied by his secretary, Leal Marques, the Premier arrived just before 10:30 o'clock outside the private chapel where he usually attends mass.
Donald Hawley of East Orange outlasted Gerard Podesta in a gruelling five-set final today to win the New Jersey State men's tennis championship at the Montclair Athletic Club. The scores were 4-6,

Back from an inspection of the United States Naval Academy and a trip to Washington, midshipmen on the Argentine Naval Training Ship Presidente Sarmiento prepared today to take part in Independence Day ceremonies.

The Holy Redeemer Roman Catholic Church on South Ocean Avenue, here, was filled to capacity this morning when solemn high military mass was sung by the pastor, the Rev. John J. Mahon. He was assisted by the Rev. John J. Maddenn, assistant pastor and deacon, who also presented the eulogy of the flag;

A large decrease in exports of live cattle from Canada this year, compared with 1936, is shown in figures for the first six months, issued today by the Department of Agriculture. Scarcity of good-quality beef cattle and high prices offered for domestic consumption are believed to be responsible for the slump in exports, according to officials.

How Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh paddled a collapsible rubber boat at midnight to St. Gildas Island, a quarter of a mile off the coast of France, was described in a dispatch to The London Daily Mail today.
The Long Island women's team halted the California quartet by 7-6 and Rumson conquered Shrewsbury by 5 to 4 in a polo doubleheader today.

As this page goes to press there is still hope tat AMELIA EAR HART will be rescued from the fate of one whose name was given to the sea into which he fell in his flight--his "scattered plumage dancing upon the wave" while "sorrowing Nereids" decked the site.

Delegates from all parts of the United States and from Canada, Alaska, Cuba, Puerto Rico and the Panama Canal Zone will open tomorrow the seventeenth biennial supreme convention of the Catholic Daughters of America.

Speaking to more than 3,500 Catholic Boy Scouts and to thousands of other persons who attended the pontifical mass at the base of the Washington Monument this morning, the Most Rev. Francis J. L. Beckman, Archbishop of Dubuque, assailed religious intolerance in Mexico, Spain, Russia and Germany, and warned the Scouts that they "must be prepared for the fury of the storm when it shall break" in the United States.

Herman Davis, store In 1,956 3d Ave; Benjamin Deutsch. store In 65 2d Ave.; Oscar Schleifer, store in 782 8th Ave.; Albert Pfeifer Management Corp., Esther Osman, Ruth Fox, Leo McLaughlin, Thomas A. McMahon, Frank H. Mackintosh, Franklin H. Keese, Mosher Co., Inc., John A. Toepfer,
Stocks improved and closed with the widest average gain of any week since week ended on May 22; turnover, 3,484,115 shares.

Mr. and Mrs. Hobart C. Chatfield-Taylor will return on the Queen Mary today, and will be at the Pierre. Mr. and Mrs. John Harsen Rhoades of the Westbury have taken a cottage at Watch Hill, R. I., for the season.

Governor Lehman announced today the appointment of three members of the temporary State commission to cooperate with the Federal Government in observance of the 300th anniversary of the settlement of the Delaware by the Swedes. The Governor's selections are:

State and municipal, financing for June aggregated $107,358,546, compared with $118,092,250 in June, 1936, according to Daily Bond Buyer. The total for the first six months of this year was $618,904,915, compared with $634,748,325 in the same period last year.

Evergreen Farms continued its victorious pace in the Eastern Polo League today by outscoring the Blind Brook Esquires of Port Chester, N. Y., 8 to 6. Clarence (Buddy) Combs, Cornell University captain, led the Evergreen attack and chalked up five goals. Milton F.
Lieut. Col. Ralph Isham, noted manuscript collector, is returning today from Europe on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary, accompanied by Mrs. Isham.
William Umstaeder and Merritt Cutler paced the field into the fourth round as play in the annual Queens County tennis tournament continued at the Seminole Club in Forest Hills yesterday.

The eleven-day sit-down strike at the local plant of the American Smelting and Refining Company ended today with the strikers leaving the plant at noon, soon after the signing of a settlement between the management and the C. I. O. union, the International Union of Mine, Mill and Smelter Workers.
When Grande Beaute and Valombrosa finished neck and neck in the last race today, judges waited until the official photograph was developed and then declared Grande Beaute the winner.

The financial markets generally have been overshadowed by the French crisis, although investment sentiment has brightened a little through the knowledge that a determined effort is being made to tackle the French monetary problem.

At the request of THE NEW YORK TIMES Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University and of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, prepared the following statement on the present international situation as he has observed it during several weeks in Europe.

An atmosphere of unreality surrounds the issue of non interverition in Spain. The meeting last Friday did not produce the expected break-up in the agreement of the twenty-seven nations to abstain from intervening in the Spanish civil war.
The Federal Trade Commission announced today that it had issued an order against the Rieser Company, Inc., of 119 West Fortieth Street, New York, prohibiting what it maintained were certain unfair
The Race-Second annual George Vanderbilt Cup competition. Time--1 P. M. Place-Roosevelt Raceway, Westbury, L. I. Distance-300 miles (ninety laps around three - and - one-third-mile course).

The aggregate of home loans negotiated in may by savings, building and loan associations was 16 per cent more than a year ago, 94 per cent more than two years ago and the best for the month since 1929, according to the United States Building and Loan League.

Catholic clergy of the archdiocese of New York participated at the Church of the Blessed Sacrament on Centre Avenue tonight in a service of divine office for Mgr. Cornelius F. Crowley, pastor of the church, president of the College of New Rochelle and dean of the catholic clergy of Westchester County, who died last Thursday.

Miss Helen Bruno, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert J. Bruno of this place, was married to Merritt A. Clegg, son of Mr. and Mrs. John H. Clegg of Suffern, N. Y., yesterday at the home of the bride's parents. The ceremony was performed by the bride's uncle, the Rev. Frank J. Bruno.

The Wagner Labor Act, as every one must now know, is officially entitled " an act to diminish the causes of labor disputes." As every one, including its author, now admits, it has not achieved this aim.

A flagpole and a bronze tablet, gifts of the Mount Hope Cemetery Association, were dedicated at the cemetery today to the memory of David Glasgow Farragut of this village, first Admiral of the United States Navy. The ceremony opened a two-day program marking the 136th anniversary of Admiral Farragut's birthday, July 5, 1801.

Encroachment upon the rights of individuals by the State, a condition "steadily on the increase" both here and abroad, was attacked yesterday morning by the Rev. Dr. Paul Scherer at Holy Trinity Lutheran Church, Central Park West at Sixty-fifth Street.

Frank Koch, retired flooring manufacturer, died on Saturday in his apartment at the Union League Club after a long illness. He was 76 years old. Mr. Koch was born in New York and attended City College.

Bella McCarthy, 3-year-old daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin McCarthy of 207 Willow Avenue, Hoboken, who was abducted yesterday afternoon from a playground in Church Square, Hoboken, was surrendered to Jersy City police tonight by Mrs. Loretta Grabowski.

The 130th anniversary of the birth of Giuseppe Garibaldi, the Italian liberator, was observed yesterday afternoon with an open-air meeting at Washington Place and Washington Square East, at which speakers urged support of the Garibaldi Brigade fighting with the Loyalists in Spain.
"We speak too much of the wisdom of our ancestors, when we should speak of their courage," the Rev. William H. Garth said yesterday in a sermon at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.
If dogs are to be driven out of city apartments in accordance with modern notions of sanitation and misanthropy, the crusade should be conducted in an orderly fashion.

Resumption of production by independent steel companies whose plants were closed by labor difficulties is proceeding as rapidly as circumstances will permit and the situation is clearing, according to the magazine Steel.

Announcement has been made of the marriage of Mrs. Marjorie Crane Paddock Krapf, daughter of Mrs. William Le Roy Paddock of Sky Meadows, Dalton, Mass., to William Rogers Bragaw, son of Mr. and Mrs. Allen C. Bragaw of Orange, N. J., last Monday in Miami, Fla.

A fairly large oats crop is expected to be harvested this year, as weather conditions of late have been favorable for the maturity of that grain. Experts here last week forecast a yield of 1,185,000,000 bushels, or almost 400,000,000 in excess of the exceedingly small crop last year, and the current prospect is for about a normal quantity.

Improvement of the Federal Constitution, so that it may in the language of its framers, "promote the general welfare and secure the blessings of liberty to ourselves and our posterity," should be an important concern of the American citizen of today, Governor Lehman declares in a letter to be read in Tammany Hall this morning.

Few of the African aniinals and birds that were brought to Brooklyn on the freighter Atlantic last week spent their first Sunday here in their new homes in Central and Prospect Park zoos. Most were in New Jersey in quarantine, and will not be exhibited for another week or ten days.
Bob Feller, American League strike-out star, ran his season's record to two starts and two defeats today as the Tigers defeated the Indians, 3 to 2, in a game cut short by rain after seven innings.
Puzzled newspaper readers, studying reproductions of the abstract or non-objective art which SOLOMON GUGGENHEIM has

Like the country at large, Broadway continued today to celebrate the Fourth of July. Or rather, Broadway catches up with the celebration, this afternoon, for the theatre's idea of a holiday takes the form of special matinees.

The United Aircraft Welders of America, a union affiliated with the United Automobile Workers of America, has asked that the Wages and Hours Bill pending in Congress specify a 25-hour week for welders engaged in work on government aircraft contracts.

President Roosevelt today took the reporters who are "covering" him on his visit here for a personally conducted tour of the 560 acres which he owns here and which he operates commercially for its timber crop.
The navy's giant aircraft carrier Lexington, convoyed by four destroyers, sped from San Diego Harbor today to aid in the search for Amelia Earhart.

Governor Harold G. Hoffman of New Jersey, his wife, their two youngest daughters and sixteen other persons suffered a harrowing fifteen minutes here today when their 52-foot motor boat, after an explosion, burned half a mile out from the Convention. Hall pier.

Six hundred and eighty-two candidates for the second half of the ninth enrollment period of the Civilian Conservation Corps in the Second Corps Area, embracing New Norm York, New Jersey and Delaware, will be examined tomorrow at the army recruiting office, 39 Whitehall Street. The-group includes 582 white youths and 100 Negroes.

The Bees made it nine victories in their last ten starts when they swept both ends of a double-header with the Phillies today. The scores were 14-9 in the first game and 4-2 in the second, which went ten innings.
Arch R. Nutter, 33-year-old Clarksburg airplane pilot, spun to his death today at the Harrisoin County airport before a holiday crowd of 1,000 watching a Fourth of July air festival. Trooper J. R.

Critics of our form of government were advised to observe conditions existing under dictatorships by the Rev. William P. Kenealy of Washington University, who preached yesterday at the high mass at St. Patrick's Cathedral.

Hugh J. Logan, former copy editor of The New York World, died Saturday night at Equinunk, Pa., it was reported here yesturday. The veteran newspaper man, who had served on many newspapers before his quarter of a century with the World, was 63 years old.

Dr. Cornelia Frances Robertson of New York, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis R. Robertson of Lakeview, Ore., was married yesterday afternoon to Dr. Seymour Fiske, also of New York, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. William Fiske of Philadelphia.

Arrow II of the Corinthian Y. C., Philadelphia, made it three in a row when she led the Barnegat Bay fleet of International Star Class sloops in their elimination race today off the Seaside Park Yacht Club.
A private funeral service for Morrill Goddard, editor of The American Weekly, was held yesterday morning at his home, 48 East Seventy-third Street.

Rapidly fading prospects for the new Canadian wheat crop because of drought and prospective damage to the Winter and Spring wheat crops on this side of the international line because of Black rust have caused a material change in sentiment in the last two weeks regarding the ultimate level of prices for the yield of the coming harvest.

Flashing their best teamwork of the season, the Blind Brook Knights routed a Monmouth County Country Club quartet, 11 to 6, today in a non-league clash. The game originally was scheduled to be in the Eastern Polo League but the Eatontown (N. J.) squad was unable to muster its full strength for the holiday clash, so the circuit encounter was postponed until Wednesday.

Frederick J. Maywald, an explosives expert formerly in the service of the City of New York, died last night at his home here after an illness of a few days. Mr. Maywald was born in New York, but lived for years in Elizabeth, N. J.

The United States taught Great Britain the principles of democratic freedom and tolerance toward colonies in the Revolutionary War and eventually made the British Empire an almost wholly self-governing British Commonwealth of Nations, the Rev. Frederick W. Norwood, br formerly minister of the City Temple Church of London, said in his sermon yesterday at Riverside Church, Riverside Drive and 122d Street.
The Cardinals defeated the Reds twice today, taking a six-inning, rainswept nightcap, 5 to 2, after Dizzy Dean hurled a 1 to 0 victory in the opener for his twelfth triumph of the season.

The Continental Congress of 1776 lived again in Philadelphia today and once more the Liberty Bell fang out its proclamation of freedom as Philadelphia formally opened its tow-day celebration of July 4--the anniversary of the nation's Birth.

Mrs. Mazie Nodine Hunt of 125 East Eightieth Street, New York, widow of Joseph Howland Hunt, architect, died here today at her country home, The Columns, on East Putnam Avenue, of a heart attack which occurred three days ago. Her age was 66.
Light winds and poor thermal currents grounded most of the glider pilots at the National Soaring Contests today as only two got away for distance flights.
Jim Maloney, hard-hitting first baseman, was the batting star as the New York Fire Department baseball team defeated the New York Athletic Club, 11 to 3, at Travers Island yesterday.

Charges of intimidation and coercion flew from both camps today as C. I. O. and A. F. of L. unions prepared for the voting that is to decide which is to represent employes in Philadelphia baking companies.

The police reopened yesterday their investigation of the cause of death of Samuel Silverman, 37 years old, a furrier, whose body was found hanging Friday morning from a steam pipe in his office at 231 West Twenty-ninth Street.

Obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $3,851,419,600. They consist of Treasury bonds, notes and non-interestbearing discount bills. The list follows:

A strong plea for the Monroe Doctrine as the best means of defending the American republics against new forms of government that recently have Sprung up in Europe Was made by Foreign Minister Carlos Saavedra Lamas at last night's Fourth of July dinner of the American community here.
The Cardinals defeated the Reds twice today, taking a six-inning, rainswept nightcap, 5 to 2, after Dizzy Dean hurled a 1 to 0 victory in the opener for his twelfth triumph of the season.

The Continental Congress of 1776 lived again in Philadelphia today and once more the Liberty Bell fang out its proclamation of freedom as Philadelphia formally opened its tow-day celebration of July 4--the anniversary of the nation's Birth.

Mrs. Mazie Nodine Hunt of 125 East Eightieth Street, New York, widow of Joseph Howland Hunt, architect, died here today at her country home, The Columns, on East Putnam Avenue, of a heart attack which occurred three days ago. Her age was 66.
Light winds and poor thermal currents grounded most of the glider pilots at the National Soaring Contests today as only two got away for distance flights.
Jim Maloney, hard-hitting first baseman, was the batting star as the New York Fire Department baseball team defeated the New York Athletic Club, 11 to 3, at Travers Island yesterday.

Charges of intimidation and coercion flew from both camps today as C. I. O. and A. F. of L. unions prepared for the voting that is to decide which is to represent employes in Philadelphia baking companies.

The police reopened yesterday their investigation of the cause of death of Samuel Silverman, 37 years old, a furrier, whose body was found hanging Friday morning from a steam pipe in his office at 231 West Twenty-ninth Street.

Nationwide production of steel ingots last week was estimated here at 75 per cent of capacity, unchanged from the preceding four weeks. Numerous changes, however, developed in the five-week period in district operations and in individual mills.
Ted Broadribb, manager of the British Empire heavyweight champion, Tommy Farr, today signed articles for a world championship match between Farr and Joe Louis to be held in New York in September.

About 1,000 persons, mostly children, gathered about the steps of the Soldiers and Sailors Monument, at Riverside Drive and Eightyninth Street, last night to witness the Fourth of July celebration of the University Forum of America.

Leonard Hartman, first seeded player, and George Seewagen, No. 5, gained the fourth round of the Queens County singles tourney yesterday as a result of victories on the courts of the Seminole Club in Forest Hills.

Twenty-five members of the State Theatre at Sofia, Bulgaria, arrived yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary to make a tour of the chief cities of the United States, as there are large colonies of their countrymen here.

Luncheon of the Lions Club of New York, Hotel Astor, 12:30 P. M. "The Declaration of Independence and Americanism," Peter T. Campon. Luncheon of the Sales Executives Club of New York, Hotel Roosevelt, 12:30 P. M. "A Solution to the Labor Management. Dispute," Samuel P. Gilman.

There was an amused smile on the face of that long-limbed golfing tiger, Horton Smith, as he led in the low-scoring American contingent with a record card of 69 on Carnoustie's championship course in the first qualifying medal round of the British open golf tournament today.
H. F. Whiton brought his six-meter yacht Light Scout across the line first today in the second race of the Seawanhaka Corinthian Club's cup series.

Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd, when asked to outline the plans of the Byrd Foundation Committee, which laid the cornerstone of a monument at Ver-sur-Mer, France, Thursday, commemorating the tenth anniversary of his transatlantic flight expedition, explained here that the foundation had been established by French notables with its main object to carry on a campaign for peace in Europe.

America's largest city was one of the "safest" in the country yesterday, judging by hospital reports of firecracker and fireworks injuries, as New Yorkers for the second straight year celebrated Independence Day in diminuendo.

MORE in sorrow than in anger it must be set down that Mr. Clark Griffith, president of the Washington ball club, has been no help at all to His Britannic Majesty's Government in a diplomatic affair, and Downing Street would be justified--oh, quite!--in becoming waxy about it.

Unexpectedly heavy registrations ushered in the major semi-annual furniture show today at the American Furniture Mart. Up to 5 P. M., the official count showed that 2,400 buyers had checked in, exceeding the 2,380 registrations for the same period last January, when the event started on a regular business day.
A gain in automobile production last week when the seasonal trend called for a decline has moved the adjusted index to 136.3, the highest level since the last week in June of 1929.

Weirdly dressed fantasticcs" painted faces streaked by rain, roved the streets today "booing" passers-by in a Halloweenized celebration of Independence Day. Dawn brought out scores of the masqueraders for the odd demonstration.

The Cuban sales Government's commission studying possible settlement of the defaulted public works obligations will invite representatives of holders of the bonds and other obligations to appear before it to discuss the proposals which it will recommend to the government, an official statement by the commission said this afternoon.

The Pan American Clipper III of Pan American Airways landed on the River Shannon in Ireland at 5:50 A. M., New York time, today. At 6:06 A. M., the British flying boat Caledonia landed in Newfoundland.

Mitzi Green, in Essex House, 160 Central Park South; Mrs. Alice Martin. in 55 Central Park W; Irving C. Franklin, in 320 Central Park W: A. J. Miranda Jr., in 305 West End Ave; H. G. Griffin, in 244 W 72d St; John M. Grace. in 5 Prospect Pl; Apartment Renting Co., Inc., broker.

The organization of a National Association of Marine Draftsmen, in which about 5,000 men employed by shipyards and ship designers would be eligible for membership, has been started by a group of men employed in the New York port district, it was learned yesterday.

Shipped to Empire City from Delaware especially to take advantage of the feather impost of 106 pounds, Mrs. Louise Viau's Rex Flag yesterday won the $14,425 Empire City Handicap before a record crowd estimated at 18,000 persons. Postmaster General James A. Farley and United States Senator Robert F. Wagner were among those at the Yonkers course.

Confusion in London over Merle Oberon's activities has caused Samuel Goldwyn to alter production plans here. Alexander Korda has delayed production of "Red Shoes," due to start today, because of script difficulties,

Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Nash Beadleston of this place entertained at a dinner party at their home last night. Those in the group included Mr. and Mrs. J. Hartley Mellick Jr., Mr. and Mrs. Upshur Moorhead, Mr. and Mrs. Bayard Stout, Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Balding,
Emma Signal, driven by John Dill, trotted to a straight-heat victory in the 2:17 Class event on the closing day program of the Penn-Jersey harness horse circuit today.
Government agents operating out of Camden today arrested Willie Daye, 29 years old, of Jacksonville, Fla., and Robert M. Parrish, 26, of Philadelphia, both Negroes,
The Coast Guard made public today a report from the cutter Itasca, telling of its efforts to help Amelia Earhart locate Howland Island last Friday just before she was forced down.
Surrounded by the white markers of the graves of 45,000 war dead, 5,000 Boy Scouts participated in a memorial service in Arlington National Cemetery today.

The Rev. Robert Anderson Jardine, who emerged from a working class English parish to international notice when he performed the marriage ceremony for the Duke of Windsor and Mrs. Wallis Warfield, arrived in New York yesterday on the Cunard liner Queen Mary to begin a lecture tour and a series of radio addresses.

Tom Leslie of Salt Lake City plays a "ducky" game of golf. On a 120yard hole, with tee and green separated by a lake, Leslie topped an iron shot. The ball headed for the water, but bounced off a duck's back and onto the green.

The two two-story apartment houses with stores at 122-26 and 122-28 Nellis Street, St. Albans, L. I., were sold by Matin Realty Inc. to a client of the Lydan Realty Corporation, broker in the transaction. Sale of the properties,

President Roosevelt told a shirtsleeved gathering at a church fair in the village of Mount Marion, about twenty miles from here, today that "the American form of government" was being preserved against dictatorial and militaristic trends in the world.

John P. Flynn of 1,976 Hughes Avenue, Bronx, who was captain of the New York University baseball team in -1923, died early yesterday in the Park East Hospital, 112 East Eighty-third Street, a week after returning from his wedding trip to Bermuda.

William M. Eichleay, 22, of Dormont, Pa., flying a Carnegie Institute of Technology all-steel tubing soaring plane, crashed on the American Airlines airport while making a test flight for his glider license at the national soaring contest here today.

Kahla Peter, bay mare driven by Miss Frances Post, finished the' third mile of the featured 2:15 handicap trot and pace in a dead heat with Clarinda Hanover, driven by Mrs. Robert McKim, at the Fair Grounds today.

Mr. Watt, 3-year-old trotter owned by the Newbrook Stable of Short Hills, IN. J., trotted to a new world record at the harness racing matinee of the Road Horse Association of New Jersey in Weequahic Park today.

John Woodruff of Pittsburgh, world's premier half-miler, will make his debut in big-time mile competition in the World Labor Athletic Carnival at Randalls Island next Sunday, when he opposes Glenn Cunningham, Archie San Romani, Gene Venzke and Lou
The apartment house at 17-23 Post Avenue, in the Dyckman section of Manhattan, has been sold by Morris Luskin Son to an investing client of the Arnold B. Bashein Company.

Miss Evelyn Gardner, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Gardner of this place, will be married to George Reitze Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. George Reitze of Oradell, on July 17 in Grace Episcopal Church here. The Rev. Karl G. Krumm of the a Church of St. Mary Magdalene, A Newark, will officiate.
For the greater part of a very long afternoon the Giants celebrated their independence today with great fervor and a grand flourish.

The entire roof of the world-famous Bridge of Sighs-two tons of lead-was discovered today to have been stolen. The theft was revealed when rain began to leak through the structure, which has been visited by literally millions of Americans.

Senator Ricardo Dolz y Arango died tonight of a heart attack at his home after a short illness at the age of 76. Senator Dolz was an eminent jurist, a member of the World Court at The Hague and a former rector at Havana University.

Three Americans who have been in business in Trujillo City, Dominican Republic, for years, have been honored by President Trujillo with a presentation of the medal of the Order of Merit "Juan Pablo Duarte," it was announced here yesterday by the Dominican Chamber of Commerce.

New Jersey had one of the quietest Fourth of July celebrations on record. With the sale of fireworks banned, North Jersey communities reported comparatively few accidents. There was, however, one fatality. Russell Morley, 15 years old, of Burlington, was mortally wounded with an automatic pistol last night while celebrating with two companions.

More than threescore persons had been served by tonight with subpoenas to testify in the National Labor Relations Board hearings, beginning tomorrow, into charges that the Ford Motor Company has violated the Wagner Labor Act.
Opening his talk to the gathering at the little Dutch Reformed Church here today, President Roosevelt spoke of the letter by Mrs. Warren D. Myer, which invited him to the church fair.
Fifteen thousand spectators looked on today at the Cowal Games, held under the auspices of the Round Hill Scottish Games Association at the Charles A. Moore estate. The attendance set a record.
President Manuel Quezon of the Philippine Commonwealth, arriving here today, announced he planned to travel in Germany before returning home.
The Japanese Army declared today it had defeated a sizable detachment of Russian troops in a day-long battle on the Eastern frontier of Manchukuo and Siberia.

Harvard Observatory announced today the discovery by Dr. P. Finsler, Professor of Mathematics at the University of Zurich, of a new comet of the seventh magnitude. The observatory said the discovery was made yesterday. The comet's position was given as right
The police disclosed tonight that elaborate preparations had been made for yesterday's unsuccessful attempt to bomb Premier Antonio de Oliveira Salazar.
The magnificent Temple of Humanity was sold under the auctioneer's hammer today to furnish scrap iron for warships of Japan's increasing navy.

Colonel Frank Knox, Republican candidate for the Vice Presidency in the last election and owner of The Chicago Daily News, returned yesterday on the North German Lloyd liner Europa after spending two months in Europe studying labor movements and social security programs.

The marriage of Miss Elizabeth MacGregor Bailey, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William N. Bailey of Brooklyn, to John Harold Jacobs Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. John Harold Jacobs, also of Brooklyn, will take place on Saturday afternoon in the Prospect Heights Presbyterian Church. The ceremony, which will be performed by the Rev. Dr. Donald MacColl, will be followed by a reception at the St. George.
It is hardly correct to say that ex-Senator WILLIAM CABELL BRUCE of Maryland gives up the law at the age of 77

ADLER--Louis. Goldfaden Independent So city requests all members to attend funeral of the beloved husband of Anna and the devoted father of Dorothy Wilson. Services Park Memorial Chapel, 4,511 Fort Hamilton Parkway, Brooklyn, today at 11 A. M.

"Terrific" was Broadway's word for the holiday matinee attendance yesterday. Well, very good, anyhow. Of the nine shows that gave afternoon performances, four appear to have sold out, three of them playing to standees.

Martial law will be declared in Palestine at the first sign of disturbances over the report of the Royal Commission, which will recommend the partition of that land into Jewish and Arab States and a British mandate.

With interest quickened by the current barrage of citations and stipulations by the Federal Trade Commission, advertising circles are watching closely the progress of the Lea bill in Congressional channels.
Dr. Joseph M. Caley, former medical director and chief of staff of Hahnemann Hospital, died at the hospital today after an illness of two weeks. His age was 77.

New York and Brooklyn students are represented among 142 applicants who have received tentative scholarships for admission to the Yale freshman class 'of 1941, the university announced today. University regional scholarships, with stipends of $850 or less, according to individual needs, were granted to eighteen students.

Business and industry must present a solid front unless they want to find themselves "overshadowed and outdistanced in the race for control of their enterprises," Louis K. Comstock, president of the Merchants Association, declared in his annual report, made public yesterday.

Governor Lehman today named seven members of a temporary State commission created by the Legislature to "examine, report upon and recommend measures to improve facilities for care of hard of hearing and deaf children and children liable to become deaf."

Dr. Timothy Prescott Frost, Methodist Episcopal clergyman and author of several theological works, died today at his home here. He was 87 years old. Dr; Frost occupied pulpits in Brooklyn, Newark, N. J., Evanston, Ill., and Baltimore at the turn

Exceptional bowling on the part of F. Garcia and W. S. Tunley, coupled with energetic batting of E. A. Batt, P. Blair, G. Engels and Tunley, enabled the Veteran St. George Cricket Club to defeat Union County in the annual championship series of the New York and Metropolitan District Cricket Association at Warinanco Park today. St.

Limited-price variety chains last year had the largest sales in their history, the volume exceeding that in 1935 by 9.5 per cent and running substantially ahead of 1929, the previous peak year, according to the report issued here today by the bureau of business research of the Harvard Business School.

The all-star American lacrosse team marked up another victory, its fourth straight in England, today by defeating Cheshire, 17 to 5, in an exciting game. Trailing through most of the first quarter, the Americans evened the count, then put on a real show in the second half.

Acting on a telephone tip that a man sought in connection with the slaying early Sunday in Greenwich Village of John Kirby, an ex-convict, could be found in a parked automobile at Gansevoort and Washington Streets, detectives yesterday went there and arrested Leslie Bell, 26 years old, a loader, of 535 West 160th Street. He was charged with homicide and will be arraigned today in homicide court.

A notable gathering of society, celebrities in the amateur sports world, and distinguished statesmen and diplomats viewed the second holding of the Vanderbilt Cup race from the boxes in the main grand stand and its skyway clubhouse at the Roosevelt Raceway today.

Reform Judaism's prospects in America are exceedingly favorable, Rabbi Joseph Rauch of Louisville, Ky., concluded today in a paper he read before the Fourth Congress of the World Union for Progressive Judaism, which is in session here.

Senator Robert F. Wagner, whom the Democratic leaders of the city hope to draft for the party nomination for Mayor, declared yesterday that "Tammany Hall may justly claim the title of the cradle of modern liberalism in America."

Mr. and Mrs. Clinton Stephen Lutkins of Wavertree, this place, and 1,120 Fifth Avenue, New York, have announced the engagement of Mr. Lutkins's daughter, Miss Louise Lutkins, to Robert Le Brecht, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Marston Le Brecht of New York, formerly of Hingham, Mass.

Lord Beauchamp of London and his daughter, Lady Dorothy Lygon, who arrived on the Berengaria, are at the Waldorf-Astoria. They will leave soon for Virginia. Mr. and Mrs. Ralph M. Johnson of the Savoy-Plaza will depart for home today on the Ile de France.
The Newark Bears shaded the Jersey City Giants by the same score, 3 to 2, in both ends of a double bill at Roosevelt Stadium today and stretched the Jerseys' losing streak to eleven straight.
Among the excellent nonpartisan appointments which Mayor LA GUARDIA mace early in his term was that of GEORGE V. MCLAUGHLIN to the Triborough Bridge Authority.

The marriage of Miss Aileen Clair, daughter of Mrs. N. Clair Ryan of Wilkes-Barre, Pa., and the late Martin Clair, to James P. O'Don??ell of New York, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Cornelius J. O'Donnell, took place yesterday morning in Corpus Christi Church, West 121st Street. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. George B. Ford, Catholic Counselor at Columbia University.

Vico Cpmmodore Edward C. Fiedler, with Richard Moeller as his sailing mate, piloted his Nischasch to victory today in the first official race for points on the season championship trophy over the Rumson Country Club course on the South Shrewsbury River.
To the Editor of The New York Times: The so-called compromise bill proposed by Senator Logan for himself and Senators Hatch and Ashurst (S. 1392) is no compromise.
Captain Alfred Cyr of the sloop George A., Block Island, was injured in the chest today by a swordfish which charged the small boat he was in and ran its sword through the frail craft.
Iroquois Indian chieftains, gathered at their first conclave since before the Revolution, were told today that a successful world peace plan could be patterned after their ancient confederacy.

The twentieth Summer session of the Fordham University Graduate School and Teachers College will open tomorrow with a registration of more than 1,300 students, the Rev. Robert I. Gannon, S. J., president of the university, announced yesterday.
Metropolitan scullers won four races in the annual Peoples Day regatta on the Schuylkill today before a crowd of 7,000 rowing followers. Rain fell through most of the afternoon.

There was a definite word of admonition in Governor Blanton Winship's brief and pointed Fourth of July speech today following a review of the island's biggest celebration, and Rafael Martinez Nadal, President of the Senate and of the majority coalition, was equally emphatic in expressing the statehood aims of the island majority.
Mrs. Loretta Grabowski, 20 years old, of 57 Wayne Street, Jersey City, will be arraigned tomorrow morning in police court here on a charge of kidnapping.

Completing fifteen rounds of the seventeen scheduled, the competitors in the international chess masters' tournament at the Kurhaus today gave their attention to six adjourned games and all were played off. Samuel Reshevsky and Reuben Fine of New York celebrated the American holiday appropriately by turning in a victory apiece.

The marriage of Miss Mary Green Harrison, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Davis Harrison, to Dr. Donald Houghton Hooker, son of Dr. and Mrs. Donald Russell Hooker, took place this afternoon in Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church, Towson, near Baltimore. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. William O. Smith, rector of the Church of the Good Shepherd. He was assisted by the Rev. Henry B. Lee, rector of Trinity Church.
Five men are in a copper-walled room on the San Francisco beach, alert for any word from Amelia Earhart. Four are Coast Guard operators. The fifth is Lieutenant Frank Johnson, communication officer.

Stewart N. Clarkson, at 64 Greendale Rd, Scarsdale, from Adelia K. Shwedo; the Robert E. Farley Organization, broker. Dr. Ralph O. Clock, at 20 Ridgecrest West, Scarsdale, from Elia F. McAfee; Dr. Vincent A. Gallo, at 126 South Broadway, White Plains. from George C. Thompson; Prince Ripley, Inc., broker.

Patrick D'Errico, a Brooklyn truck driver who was on parole from the New York County Penitentiary, was found slain here today beside a parking area at Echo Lake, adjoining Saw Mill River Road. He had been shot once in the abdomen with a .38-calibre bullet. D'Errico was 29 years old and lived at 212 Gold Street, Brooklyn.

The second of the official trial races of the America Cup sloops attracted many yachting parties today. General and Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt had guests on the Winchester, Mr. and Mrs. T. O. M. Sopwith entertained on the Philante, Frederick H. Prince was out on the Lone Star and Mrs. W. A. W. Stewart had guests on the Queen Mab.

Leaders of the House public power group stated today that upon President Roosevelt's return from Hyde Park they would protest to him the proposed sale of Tennessee Valley Authority power to a private company for resale.
Arthur Wood Kennard, president of Hodgson, Kennard Co., Boston jewelers, died today at the Phillips House following a short illness. He was in his sixty-seventh year.

Municipal officials, analyzing the attempted show of strength of steel strikers at the Faith's Grove rally yesterday, are of the general opinion that the C. I. O. has played its trump card against the Bethlehem Steel Corporation and that for the present at least it was not good enough.
