The new American president of the International Chamber of Commerce, Thomas J. Watson, who recently received the Order of the German Eagle from Chancellor Adolf Hitler, sent him personal and official telegrams of gratitude for the reception the chamber received in Berlin.
Now that it is all over, everybody concerned must have given thanks that the heavens opened up on Saturday to cause the postponement of the George Vanderbilt Cup Race until today.

In a serene setting where the waters of the Niagara River mingle with those of Lake Ontario, 625 young men, admitted to the Citizens Military Training Camp here, took the oath of allegiance today before an audience of officials and leading citizens of Niagara and Erie Counties.

Glenn Edward Hewitt, 21 years old, of Syracuse, N. Y., was found dead today in a small laboratory in the Duke University Biology Building. Three gas jets in the room were open and containers of anesthetic were on a table.
Huge flocks of turkeys were drafted today in a five-State war on an army of new-winged grasshoppers.

Crisply hitting the ball on a long gallop from almost midfield to record the winning tally, Peter Grace, former Yale star, today gave the Santa Barbara side a 7-to-6 triumph over Long Island in a special high-goal exhibition polo match at the Meadow Brook Club.

The earlier surprises of the general election in the Irish Free State are now overshadowed by an unexpected and greater surprise. On the basis of the first twenty constituencies it was taken for granted that President Eamon de Valera had swept the country.
Gilbert Hunt of Washington, D. C., added his name today to the distinguished list of winners of the Nassau Bowl.

With heads bared and right hands upraised, 1,500 young men between the ages of 17 and 29, including 700 from the metropolitan area, took the oath of allegiance this morning on the Plattsburg parade ground and were inducted into the Citizens Military Training Camp for a month of instruction.

Pouring into Ontario at four points, nearly 200,000 automobiles brought in more than 500,000 Americans to spend their Independence Day holiday on Canadian soil. New traffic records were set as augmented customs and immigration staffs worked overtime to handle the crowds.
Westchester County experienced one of the quietest Fourth of July celebrations on record with comparatively few accidents from fireworks. In most of the county sale of fireworks was illegal.

An issue of $1,400,000 State of Tennessee 3 1/2 per cent and 3 1/4 per cent consolidated bonds is to be offered today by a group composed of the Chase National Bank, Blyth Co., Inc., Equitable Securities Corporation, Commerce Union Bank of Nashville and the RobinsonHumphrey Company of Atlanta.
The Coast Guard cutter Itasca, searching 281 miles north of Howland Island for Amelia Earhart, reported early today it had sighted flares. The Itasca sent out a radio message to Miss Earhart:

Senator Elmer Thomas of Oklahoma said today he did not expect Congress to adopt at this session his bill providing for stabilization of the dollar at a "fair" value, but predicted that within the next few years "we'll have some kind of a law."
The keys of this ancient capital of Scotland were presented to its new sovereign today as King George VI and Queen Elizabeth arrived for a post-coronation trip through their northern realm.

State and city officials, social and civic organizations of the State and of the Mohawk Valley will be represented at the opening of the third annual Mohawk Drama Festival in the outdoor theatre on Union College campus tomorrow night.

Emanuel Co., stock brokers, in RitzCarlton Hotel, Madison Avenue and 46th St; Douglas L. Elliman Co., Inc., brokers. Swedish American Tercentenary Association, in International Building, Rockeleffer Center.

The armaments race "imposed" upon Great Britain and the United States is one the democracies must inevitably win, Robert W. Bingham, the United States Ambassador, told 300 American and British guests at the American Society's Independence Day dinner tonight.

Hampton Ewing, New York attorney, has made a request for police protection from a band of marauding squirrels, which, it was explained at his home today, are ruining the garden of his house at 35 Belmont Avenue.
Local leaders in the steel strike telegraphed President Roosevelt tonight accusing him of "playing the fiddle while Rome burns," and asking him to call a national conference to end the strike.

Miss Suzanne B. Moreau of Baltimore, formerly of Paris, and George J. Finney, son of Mr. and Mrs. William W. Finney of Overhill Road, Guilford, were married today at Greenwood, the Finney country estate at Churchville, Md.

The escape this week-end from the Rockland State Hospital of three mental patients served to increase further the growing alarm of Rockland County residents over what they consider to be the menacing invasion of a new and formidable population of undesirable outsiders from New York City.
Richard Duncan, a student of Memphis, Tenn., was instantly killed this afternoon near Nafbach while cycling from Nuremberg to Schwabach.
Fire believed to have been caused by the explosion of a still destroyed a barn owned by Ernest Bockoven on Mendham Mountain Road here early today. Louis Prete, 21 years old,
Audry and Waveney Carten's "Destination Unknown," which opened at the Q Theatre tonight, apparently was intended to convey a large philosophical message.

Junior Single Shells, First Heat-Won by John Herold, Nautilus B. C.; R. B. Cutler. unattached, second: Patrick McNally, Union B. C., Brooklyn, third. Time8:15 1-5. Junior Single Shells, Second Heat-Won by Daniel Matthews, Union B. C., Brooklyn; William G. Marr, Princeton R. A.. second; Warren Schroder, Active B. C., Edgewater, N. J., third. Time-8:25 4-5.
Under the heading "A Man Hungry for Power," the Angriff publishes a front page article. about John L. Lewis. The American labor leader is described as the "champion of Moscow ideals."
A message to Coast Guard headquarters today said that the interception of "ragged" radio signals "indicate possibility Earhart plane still afloat 281 miles north of Howland Island."
The wind took a holiday, too. That was the result of the attempt today to sail the second of the final trial races to select the defender of the America's Cup.

While cruising in Long Island Sound aboard his yacht, Moana, William B. Leeds, sportsman, went to the assistance shortly after noon on Sunday of the naval patrol boat YP-9, which had been slightly damaged by a small explosion and fire
Interest in Fall merchandise increased in the wholesale market here last week, although rush orders arrived on Summer goods for pre-holiday selling and on midseason apparel.

Increased appropriations by the Board of Estimate will enable the American Museum of Natural History, beginning today, to open all its halls to the public every day, it was announced last night by F. Trubee Davison, president.

Garden club representatives are arriving in Berkshire for the Lenox garden club visiting day on Wednesday. Mrs. Carl A. de Gersdorff has in her house party on Prospect Hill, Stockbridge, Mrs. Robert H. Fife, president of the Garden Club of America; Mrs. Jonathan Bulkley,
Mrs. Josephine Pettingill Everett, philanthropist, who helped found the Hollywood Bowl symphonies, died yesterday after a long illness. Her age was 71. She lived here for twenty years.

The present declared plan of Senate opponents of Federal judiciary legislation to talk the Robinson compromise to death at this session of Congress will meet its fate behind the scenes, not on the floor. If the administration adheres to its announced intention to press the FourJustice Bill, and the opposition proceeds with a serious filibuster, public opinion -turning on a Democratic party axiswill select the victor.
Seven artists who have been members of the Civilian Conservation Corps have been invited to submit designs for mural decorations in postoffice buildings.
Mrs. William R. Maloney will preaide tomorrow afternoon at a meeting of the Ladies Village Improvement Society to be held in the Thomas Moran Gallery, Guild Hall. Officers will be elected.

Now Then, a long shot racing in the. sky-blue silks of F. J. Buchanan, won the first running of the $5,000 added Christiana Stakes for 2-yearolds today as a crowd estimated at 25,000 tested the capacity of Delaware Park.
Misfortune which has followed the showboat Dixiana again overtook the craft this afternoon when the United States training ship Hawk rammed it at its pier here.
Dr. L. S. Rowe, director general of the Pan American Union, congratulated the Republic of Venezuela today on the anniversary of the signing of the Venezuelan declaration of independence.

Marcel Steinbrugge, 54 years old, retired stock broker, of 49 East Sixty-third Street, died late Sunday night at Flower Hospital, where he had been taken Saturday after a fall on a stairway in his home.
Mrs. Florence Lowden, wife of Frank Oren Lowden, former Governor of Illinois, died unexpectedly today at their Sinnissippi Farm, near here. She was 68 years old.
Military planes have been ordered to search for four Mexican railroad engineers lost in the desert in Southern California since Wednesday.

Edwin Gibson, aged 26, of Binghamton, died this evening in a Watertown hospital from a- gunshot wound in the head accidentally inflicted this morning at the Saunders farm near Cape Vincent. Mr. Gibson and his fiancee, Miss Margaret Dewey, also of Binghamton, drove to the farm Sunday for the holiday.
The New York Athletic Club baseball team scored a 10-to-6 victory over the Columbus K. of C. nine yesterday at Travers Island before a large holiday crowd.
Winant Van Winkle of Rutherford, State Senator from Bergen County, made the dedication address at the opening of the new municipal park on Route 4 at Belle Avenue here this afternoon.

Independence Day brought much entertaining in the White Mountain resorts by members of hotel and cottage colonies. At the Mount Crescent House in Randolph members of the Randolph Mountain Club gave a tea. Mr. and Mrs. Soreno Lund were hosts at a large tea at the Waumbeck in Jefferson.

Narrow margins separated the leaders in the three-day point invitation regatta that closed off the Bay Shore Yacht Club today. The extra 3/4 point accredited to the winner of each race helped in several instances in determining the series victors.

Immediately on his arrival in England from the United States, where he discussed with President Roosevelt the possibilities of lowering trade barriers and stabilizing international currencies, Premier Paul van Zeeland of Belgium held tonight long private talks on his mission with Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain and Foreign Secretary Anthony Eden.
The government published tonight a twenty-one page decree giving government employes the right to organize unions, make collective contracts and strike.

Funeral services for Mgr. Cornelius F. Crowley, president of the College of New Rochelle and dean of the Catholic clergy in Westchester County, were held this morning at the Church of the Blessed Sacrament on Center Avenue. Mgr. Crowley had held the pastorate of that church from 1913 until his death last Thursday.

Eugene Fernan, 11 years old, of 93 Dictum Court, Gerrittsen Beach, Brooklyn, who was seriously wounded by a stray bullet Sunday afternoon while playing in the water near his home, remained in a critical condition at Coney Island Hospital yesterday.
Robert G. Menzies, Commonwealth Treasurer, announced today a budget surplus of [pound]1,276,637 for the year ended on June 30, compared with the estimated surplus of [pound]40,000.

Net assets of the National Investors Corporation on June 30 amounted to $25,295,449, including $1,109,136 cash and $24,844,188 worth of common stocks based on market value, and recorded at a Federal income tax cost of $20,493,497 on the books.

The government's National Revolutionary party appeared assured tonight of an overwhelming majority in the Chamber of Deputies for another three years as the result of yesterday's nationwide elections.

After a day marked by electioneering by telephone, telegraph and personal solicitation, employes of two baking companies began casting ballots tonight in an election to determine whether the Committee for Industrial Organization is to abandon its drive in the bakery field in Philadelphia.

The shooting as spies of twenty-two more employes of the Far Eastern section of the Transiberian Railroad was reported in an official notice in the June 27 issue of the Khabarovsk newspaper, Pacific Star, reaching Moscow today.
Forst mortgages totaling $430,000 have been placed by the Kingsboro Mortgage Corp. of Brooklyn on three six-story apartment houses under construction in the Bronx and Long Island City.

Harry S. Carlisle, 54 years old, of 2,044 North Twentyninth Street, Philadelphia, was killed and his wife and four children were injured this morning in an automobile accident on Route 49 at Dias Creek, near here.
The well-dressed golfer in 1938 will continue to wear cool slacks, short socks and polo shirts even more colorful than those now to be seen on the links.

Thomas P. Revelle, a minister who turned to law and as United States Attorney became a leading legal figure of the Pacific Northwest's prohibition era, died yesterday of heart disease and pneumonia. His age was 69.
Federal and State taxes on alcoholic beverages, totaled $864,927,355 in 1936, according to figures published today by the Distilled Spirits Institute, Inc.
The climax of the busy holiday yachting week-end brought the biggest fleet of the season and the worst wind conditions to the fiftysixth annual regatta of the Larchmont Yacht Club today.
Harvey Wiley Corbett, architect, will open a series of lectures on architecture and art at the Columbia University Summer sessions starting on Monday, July 12.
Last night's Lewisohn Stadium concert by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra under Victor Golschmann can hardly be said to have taken place under ideal circumstances.

Exceptionally close racing in a moderate easterly breeze was provided by well filled entry lists in all classes as the Island Heights Yacht Club played host today to the seven member clubs of the Barnegat Bay Yacht Racing Association.

The financial statement of Brown Brothers Harriman Co., private bankers, for June 30 shows total resources of $103,135,529, the highest figure since the firm began publishing statements in 1934, compared with $93,665,936 on March 31.

Martin Simmons of East Hampton won the championship cup for the greatest number of points scored in the gymkhana held this afternoon at the Southampton Riding and Hunt Club. He also won a leg on the Spectator Challenge Cup donated by Allan Howard. Mrs. Rufus L. Paterson awarded the trophies and ribbons. John D. Beals Jr. headed the gymkhana committee.

Mr. and Mrs. C. Henry Mellon Jr., who are visiting his parents, Mr. and Mrs. Charles Henry Mellon, at The Shutters, their home in Little Plains Road, gave a luncheon there today for members of their holiday house party, Miss Susan Stackpole, Charles H. Thieriot Jr. and David Tiffany.

Although intermittent drizzles of rain marred the second half of the Independence Day week-end yesterday, nevertheless huge crowds of merrymakers thronged the near-by beach and amusement resorts and taxed the transportation facilities of the city and its environs to the limit when they returned last night.

Strikes, the Spanish civil war, apparent government prejudice against speculation, uncertainties in France and the international gold situation combined to force security markets downward in the first half of 1937. Volume fell with prices.
An American newspaper man saved the life of an Austrian girl who attempted to commit suicide today by leaping into the Seine River.

Prices of beets, cabbage, celery and peas are holding to last week's levels, while string beans, carrots and tomatoes are slightly cheaper, it was reported yesterday by the Food Guide of the Department of Public Markets, Weights and Measures.
General strikes have been declared among workers in foodstuffs industries in this region, and 2,000 employes are sitting down in various plants.

Lieut. Col. Ralph Isham, collector of papers of James Boswell, biographer of Dr. Samuel Johnson, returned from England yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary with his bride, the former Viscountess Churchill, to whom he was married on June 12 at the Paddington Registry.

The Toronto share market staged a right-about face in the last hour today and advanced in active trading after four hours of dullness and small sales. The final spurt was made chiefly by the secondary and junior gold securities with the base metal shares showing a much improved tone also.

Securities generally were quiet and steady today as the new account opened in the Stock Market. Gilt-edge issues were a shade firmer, with a rally in Japanese obligations a feature in the foreign-loan section.
Jesse Grant Chapline, president and founder of the La Salle Extension University, died last Saturday in the Wesley Memorial Hospital, it was learned today. He was 67 years old.

The Federal Trade Commission has ordered the Crystaltone Radio Corporation of 44 West Eighteenth Street, New York City, to stop "misleading uses" of certain well-known trade names in the sale of radio sets and appliances.

In connection with its ninth annual convention, which began here yesterday and will end tomorrow, the National Association of Dunning Teachers will present Hans Barth, pianist, in a lecture-recital this morning at the Barbizon-Plaza Hotel, headquarters of the convention. Mr. Barth will play and discuss little-known piano music.

The trembling hand of a youthful thief discharged the weapon he pointed last night at Ralph Ferro, 52 years old, in the latter's drug store at 107 Court Street, Brooklyn, wounding the storekeeper seriously.

Possibility of a break between John L. Lewis and the Roosevelt administration was discussed here today when it was disclosed in C. I. O. circles that a belief was gaining momentum that the administration "has become scared and has turned tail."
The determination of a despairing mother to blot out the lives of herself and her two children reached ran ironic climax yesterday with the mother still alive and both children dead.
Ohio National Guard trucks, loaded with armed troops, rolled in Cleveland today to enforce peace when four strike-bound steel mills reopen tomorrow.
As many as 218,340 fans saw sixteen major league baseball games yesterday, as compared with the 208,328 who saw the Independence Day double-headers a year ago.

A 12-year-old orphan girl was seized. from the sidewalk in front of her home today, Police Chief Charles Monks said, and driven off in an automobile bearing Connecticut registration plates. He said the girl, Mary Carmon, lived with Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Hoski and had been the ward of Hoski's parents until two years ago.

Miss Blair Hawes, daughter of the late Harry Hammond Hawes and the late Mrs. Louise Griswold Hawes, was married this evening to Hugh Davies Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Hugh Davies of Teaneck, N. J., in St. Peter's Church here. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. George F. Bratt, rector of St. Paul's Church, Ossining, who was assisted by the Rev. William Rehfeld, curate of St. Peter's.

The United States Steel Company, the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company and the Young Men's Christian Association were added yesterday to the list of corporations and groups which have contracted for space-at the 1939 World's Fair, it was announced yesterday by Grover A. Whalen, president of the fair corporation.

The German-American Bund, official Nazi organization in the United States, held its fifth annual convention at a closed meeting yesterday at the Biltmore Hotel, at the end of which a statement was issued declaring that "our battle is the battle of all the hundred million Aryan (white gentile) citizens of these United States," and that this battle "can and will be won."
A horde of Mormon crickets covered buildings and streets here today. They began arriving Friday and today had reached virtually every corner of this town of 500 persons.
Hitting at extremists in the labor-industrial conflict, Secretary Roper asserted tonight that the public would not long "patiently forbear unnecessary strife and disturbance."
Mel Porter of New York trotted over a sun-scorched Schenectady-Albany highway today to his second national distance running championship of the year, the A. A. U. 30kilometer event.
Pickets of the American Newspaper Guild blocked all entry to The Seattle Star building today and the newspaper, a Scripps league afternoon daily, failed to publish.

Colonel and Mrs. Henry Brooks Ward gave a dinner last night in the roof garden of the Astor. Their guests included Captain and Mrs. Lester J. Andrews, Captain Harrison L. Dodd, Lieutenant and Mrs. Lewis G. Powell, Mr. and Mrs. George D. de Winter and Miss Lois K. Parkes.

Asserting that he would never support a candidate for office endorsed by the Communist party, former Alderman Lambert Fairchild struck at Mayor La Guardia without naming him at the sunrise flag-raising service of the Patriotic Society of Van Cortlandt Park

There assembled yesterday for the first time since pre-Revolutionary days the Grand Council of the Six Nations that together bore the name Iroquois. When CHATEAUBRIAND visited the Mohawk Valley he found that they called themselves the " Men of Always."
(Figures in parentheses indicate par.) Arrowbrook (70) -- Independence Day tournament: Mark Smith, 80; Harry Parker, 81; R. Stevenson, 88; Jack Goodman, 88; D.C. Goldman, 88.

The rust scourge now threatens crops in Manitoba, particularly in the southwestern corner of the Province which has had six successive crop failures because of drought and grasshoppers, a report from the Dominion's rust research laboratory here indicated today.

Detective Isaac Jacobs and Patrolman Edwin Stiehle of the Glendale (Queens) police station, on special duty at Mount Carmel Cemetery, investigating the sound of hammering in the cemetery late Sunday night, found Charles Ford, 67 years old and homeless, trying "to make a few dollars" by chiseling bronze letters off mausoleums.

Corinto, one of the trio of horses running as an entry for Mrs. Emil Denemark of Chicago, captured the $10,000 added Stars and Stripes Handicap before a holiday crowd of more than 40,000 at Arlington Park today.

A grave warning that the outbreak of war abroad would strike at the welfare of the United States and bring world-wide disaster and suffering was given by President Roosevelt in a letter read tonight at the opening of the annual Institute of Public Affairs at the University of Virginia.

At 1:30 A. M. (G. M. T.) today we fixed our position as 665 miles out from Botwood, Newfoundlandafter four hours and twenty minutes of flying-exactly one-third the way to Foynes, Ireland, the European terminus of our projected transatlantic airplane service.

While expressing concern for the safety of Miss Amelia Earhart and her navigator, Fred J. Noonan, down in mid-Pacific, Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd declared today that there were good chances of their rescue.
Governor M. Clifford Townsend will "reply tomorrow" to a request of a group of Indiana Harbor clergymen that he send National Guard troops to Lake County's steel strike area.

Sigmund Romberg's operetta "Maytime," a Shubert production, a melodic work at one time popular, was offered on the water stage on Zach's Bay tonight by Fortune Gallo before an audience of more than 5,000.

The War Department announced tonight the death of Major Gen. Edmund Wittenmyer, retired, in Walter Reed Hospital. His age was 75. General Wittenmyer was retired at his own request in 1923 after forty years of service. He served in Cuba during the war with Spain, and with the China Relief Expedition in 1900.

Courses designed to prepare young people for marriage will soon be offered in almost every college in the country and eventually they will be given in the high schools, Dr. Ernest R. Groves, sociologist of the University of North Carolina, predicted at the opening session today of the Conference on Conservation of Marriage and the Family being held at the university.

Prosecutors demanded the life of Alfred Dyer, who admitted the killing of three small girls tonight. His wife protested his innocence. District Attorney Fitts said he would ask the grand jury tomorrow to indict the WPA worker on the strength of his confession that he lured the girls from an Inglewood park playground, led them one by one into a ravine and strangled them.

A campaign to raise $2,000,000 for improvements to the Tufts Medical School, planned by President John A. Cousens just before his sudden death of heart disease on Friday, was announced today by the Tufts Medical Alumni Association.

It took them 6 hours 23 minutes of actual playing time to do it, but the Cubs finally won a double-header from the Cardinals, 13 to 12, in fourteen innings, and 9 to 7 today, to extend to two full games their league lead over the Giants.

The National Lumber Manufacturers Association made known today that lumber production for the week ended on June 26 increased slightly over the preceding period to almost the highest level of the year.
David E. Lilienthal, Tennessee Valley Authority director, said today that management has completely lost contact with the human beings who make the machine go.

Mrs. Kate Huyler, Bergen County's oldest native, celebrated her 101st birthday today. As usual she arose early did a little housework and held steadfast to her policy of evading all queries as to how one lives to a ripe old age.

Administration leaders, confident of the outcome after a last-minute count of noses, plan to bring their Supreme Court compromise bill to the Senate floor tomorrow and keep it there until the fight is won or lost.

The Athletics lost one game and played to an eleven-inning tie in a double-header with the Senators today. The Mackmen lost the first game, 5 to 3, and tied the second game at 2-2, which was called on account of rain and darkness.

Seventy yachts were moored tonight in Lake Montauk, off the Montauk Yacht Club. Among them were Julian Bishop's Eugenie II, Mr. and Mrs. Bertram Work's Parrot, Thomas L. Chadbourne's house boat Sea Play, Preston L. Sutphen's Elco Angler, Z. G. Simmon's Genzan and Graham Thompson's Liber 2d.

From two friendly sources the C. I. O. heard words of advice over the weekend on the question of strike tactics. Speaking at Johnstown Governor EARLE told the steel strikers that he thinks their cause is just, but he also warned them against the use of violence, against breaking contracts and against accepting the support of Communists who are always on the spot and always ready to turn a labor controversy to their own advantage.

Lady Clifford sailed for New York on the Munargo today to visit at her home in Cleveland. Her husband, Sir Bede E. H. Clifford, will leave in two weeks for the Island of Mauritius, of which he recently was appointed Governor.
An expedition of Massachusetts Institute of Technology meteorologists left today to resume the hurricane research work started in Cuba last Summer.

Water Service Companies, Inc., has called all outstanding collateraltrust 5 per cent bonds, series of 1942, for redemption on Sept. 1 at 102 and accrued interest, and has made arrangements whereby holders may obtain immediate payment upon surrender of the bonds at the principal office of the Bankers Trust Company, New York.

Dr. H. H. Rung, Chinese Minister of Finance, who is on a short visit to this country, was honored last night by Chinese of New York City at a dinner at the Hotel Astor arranged by the Chinese Consolidated Benevolent Association, central organization for nearly fifty local Chinese groups. Dr. C. T. Wang,
A postcard bearing the stamped slogan of the postoffice, "Post early," has just been delivered here after taking more than thirty-five years to travel from a town just seventy miles away.

Tryax, black flier owned by F. D. Fulton of Chicago and cleverly driven by little Charley Mabrey, swept to a straight-heat victory in the $1,000 Edwards pace that featured the opening card of the Grand Circuit's second week of racing at the North Randall track today.

French and Spanish Insurgent authorities agreed today to form an international commission to settle a border incident at La Rhune, where Spanish Rebel soldiers replaced French markers with the red and gold flag of the former monarchy. The French delegation.
Foreign officials said tonight they expected prompt release. of the French freighter Tregastel, captured. by Spanish Insurgents off the northern coast of Spain yesterday.

Charges of racketeering in the distribution and conduct of WPA supervisory posts were sent to President Roosevelt yesterday by Ralph M. Easley, chairman of the executive council of the National Civic Federation, in the fifth of a series of letters on alleged abuses in the Federal relief program.
While hundreds of thousands were returning to the city yesterday, at. least one happy angler was among them.

Ten thousand horse race followers who had remained at the new Delaware Park track until the last winner sloshed home this evening were marooned for several hours when the single exit, a small tunnel, became filled with swirling water.
An appeal for this country to "eschew entangling alliances with foreign nations" was made today by the Most Rev. William J. Hafey, Catholic bishop of Raleigh, N. C.

Miss Mary R. Newlands, formerly for more than twenty years -postmistress at the United States Military Academy at West Point, N. Y., died yesterday morning in St. Luke's Home for Aged Women, 2,914 Broadway, in her ninetieth year.

Earl Johnson, chairman of the award committee of the National Headliners Club, announced today the names of winners of eleven prizes for outstanding journalistic achievements during the last year. The awards, in the form of gold plaques, will be made Saturday night at the club's annual dinner at the Hotel Traymore here.

Division staff officers of the New York National Guard announced today that Major Joseph W. Becker of Buffalo had been commissioned by Governor Lehman as colonel of the 174th Infantry Regiment of Buffalo, which is to begin its field training in Camp Smith, Peekskill, Aug. 22.
The Rev. Martin Niemoeller's parishioners have learned it is a crime to petition the Minister of Justice in his favor.

The eleven Summer tutoring high schools organized by the Board of Education for pupils who have had difficulties in the regular session will open today and continue through Aug. 13, with four periods a day from 9 A. M. to 1 P. M.

The Principality of Monaco elected today a new National Council headed by Louis Aureglia, Mayor of Monaco and President of the National Liberal Union. Most of the new council of twenty-one were in the old one.

Dr. Jean Piccard, stratosphere explorer, said today that he was ready to test his strange craft of eighty small rubber balloons. Weather permitting, he will take off within ten days to learn how the four-foot balloons, filled with hydrogen, behave in the air.

The Russian and Italian Armies are the military question marks of Europe. The Russian moujik, patient, plodding; the Don Cossack, spectacular, showy; the trotting Bersaglieri of Italy, jogging tirelessly for mile on endless mile, their black-dyed plumes blowing in the wind; the giant horsemen of the Royal Guard, breastplates gleaming, sabers flashing silver against the crumbling walls of ancient Rome.
Six of the Browns' pitchers were unable to stem the vicious slugging of the Indians today and Cleveland took both ends of a doubleheader, 14 to 4 and 15 to 4.

High above the "trail of '98," over which pioneers plodded to the Yukon four decades ago, a huge monoplane winged its way today from Edmonton to Whitehorse to join the Yukon to Edmonton and the rest of Canada by air.
The French feminist movement will carry on the fight for suffrage in the Paris Exposition this Summer.

Clarence A. de Goll of Elizabeth, who has driven about 1,000,000 miles without causing an accident to any other car, closely rivals the safe driving record of recently acclaimed champion Harry B. Haines, owner of The Paterson News, it was announced today by the New Jersey Safe Drivers' Committee.
The appointment of Dr. Robert Hutchins, president of the University of Chicago, as a member of the board of visitors and governors of St. John's College at Annapolis was announced today.
Formation of a sweeping alliance between the government-controlled labor organizations of Italy and Germany was announced today.
Sir Philip Gibbs has written a book about the Duke of Windsor. It is called "Ordeal in England," and will be published by Doubleday, Doran on Aug. 20.

Your correspondent is allowed to transmit the following communique issued by the Madrid general staff at 11:30 tonight: "This morning we initiated an offensive against Sesena [about 28 1/2 miles almost due south of Madrid] and succeeded in attaining our objectives.

Bernd Rosemeyer, German champion, who drove an Auto Union, captured the second Vanderbilt Cup race at Westbury, L. I., beating Richard Seaman, Englishman, representing the MercedesBenz team, by 51.03 seconds. Rex Mays, American, who was at the wheel of an Alfa Romeo, crossed the line third in the spectacular grind that thrilled 75,000 spectators with its close finish. The winner averaged 82.564 m. p. h. for the 300 miles and earned about $24,000.

Dr. Seyss Inquart, who has just been appointed Nationalist conciliator of the Fatherland Front, with the object of bringing about reconciliation between extreme Nazis and the government, arrived here unexpectedly from Berlin Saturday night.
The explosive noise like the rattle of musket fire that echoed over the Bronx bank of the Harlem yesterday was merely the Yankees' way of celebrating Independence Day with Tom Yawkey's Red Sox.

The Reds lost both games of a holiday double-header to the Pirates today, 3-1 and 5-1, before an official attendance of 21,999 fans. It was the fourth double setback the Reds had suffered in nine days.
Juan Carlos Zabala, Argentine marathon runner, gave up his attempt to win the "dragoer run" today when he sprained his left foot early in the race.
George C. Johnston of 90-10 Elmhurst Avenue, Jackson Heights, Queens, died yesterday in the Memorial Hospital, Manhattan, at the age of 75, after an illness of two months.
The first six months of 1937 were a period of contradictory developments in the field of banking and credit. Although the total
All wheat futures made new seasonal high prices on the Grain Exchange here today. Later in the session, however, prices eased to levels around the close on Saturday.

The Westchester Playhouse of this place presented "Petticoat Fever," the Mark Reed comedy, tonight before a capacity audience of 360 persons. Harry Ellerbe took the leading role, and others in the cast

Conde Nast, the publisher; Maurice Leon, international lawyer; Mylton W. King, lawyer; Walter A. Teipel, Charles Chanderlin and Mr. and Mrs. Charles Boutellier are among the passengers due today from Europe on the French liner Ile de France.

A heat wave seared Southern Saskatchewan today after a blistering week-end, and crop prospects dwindled still lower. In mid-afternoon the temperature in this city soared to 110 degrees in the shade, making this the hottest place in the Canadian West.

A spirit of reciprocity prevailed at Ebbets Field yesterday for the holiday double-header that brought out 13,319 fans. Burleigh Grimes's Dodgers, being in a hospitable mood toward everybody but Waite Hoyt, permitted the Phils to take the first game, 3-1, collecting only four hits off the veteran Sylvester Johnson.

The California Packing Corporation and its subsidiary, the Alaska, Packers Association, have been ordered by the Federal Trade Commission to "cease and desist" from practices tending to create monopolies and suppress competition, the commission announced today.
The Tigers took both morning and afternoon games from the White Sox today, winning the first, 8 to 4, and the second i. ten innings, 7 to 4.

H. C. Faden has been appointed to the newly created post of assistant to A. D. Byler, vice president and general manager of the Edison General Electric Company, Chicago. I. A. Rose has been named director of purchases and production, with A. H. Behnke serving as assistant.

Various organizations and Legion posts throughout Suffolk County participated in the parade held here today under the auspices of the Malcolm R. White Post of the American Legion. A feature of the parade was the appearance of a contingent of Shinnecock Indians in the full regalia of their tribe from the reservation in the Shinnecock hills. They received a special award from the judges.

Several multi-family houses and other residential properties were ineluded in the list of realty sales reported from New Jersey. The three-story apartment house at 237 Fowler Avenue, Jersey City, has been sold by the Fifteenth Street Corporation' to an investing client of J. I. Kislak, Inc. The house contains nine suites.
The increase in private residential construction in recent years has been marked by a rise in the building of low-priced houses, thereby tapping a building market that was inactive in former years,
In a special holiday cup polo match played today on Herbert Memorial Field at the Rumson Country Club. Rumson defeated the Elephants, 11 to 6.

In what was probably the most spectacular automobile marathon ever witnessed in this country, Bernd Rosemeyer, German champion, driving his rear-motor Auto Union, captured the second Vanderbilt Cup race over the Roosevelt Raceway today.

Coroner Grover A. Silliman of Sayville announced today that carbon-monoxide poisoning had caused the death yesterday of Mrs. Hattie Cohen, who was found in the bathroom of her home on Chichester Avenue, here, with a bullet wound in her chest.
The deadlock over non-intervention in Spain remained complete today. Talk of a compromise was in the air, but no basis for such a settlement had emerged by nightfall.

Eight Negroes will be arraigned in Circuit Court tomorrow to begin a new episode in the six-year-old Scottsboro case. An announcement by the prosecutor that the State was prepared to try all the defendants followed a denial of reports of' a compromise.

Sussex and Kent turned in victories today in English County cricket matches, concluding a day ahead of schedule. Sussex trimmed Somerset by 275 runs and the hop county proved far too strong for Worcestershire, winning by an inning and 110 runs.

Working with smooth audacity while hundreds of holiday strollers passed outside, four armed thugs held up the M. and C. Chair Operating Company, Kensington Walk and the Boardwalk, Coney Island, at 8 A. M. yesterday and escaped with $3,100 in cash.

Mrs. Ellen A. Burke Reidy, wife of Michael J. Reidy, retired Queens Assistant Superintendent of Buildings, died on Sunday of a heart ailment at their home, 18-22 Twenty-fifth Avenue, Astoria, Queens, after a year's illness. Her age was 78.
In the hearings before the Joint Congressional Tax Inquiry Committee, the Treasury experts have admitted that legal changes alone are powerless to prevent all the possible forms of "tax avoidance";

In the shadow of Independence Hall several hundred persons heard appeals today for the preservation of the democracy which came into being at the spot where they stood. Former Representative Clare G. Fenerty urged his hearers to remember this "in our unthinking times":

Trinidad's month-old oil field strikes were at an end tonight, but police were still carrying on an intense search for J. Uriah Butler, alleged agitator of the walkouts that spread into other industries throughout the colony.
Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh's week-end visit to Brittany was spent in conference with Dr. Alexis Carrel over their scientific researches, it was revealed today.
Royce Brier, Western newspaper man and author of the Civil War novel, "Boy in Blue," recently published by Appleton-Century, has arrived here with Mrs. Brier after a tour of the Levant.
Johnny Vander Meer, the 22-year-old strikeout king of the minor leagues last year, went to Syracuse of the international League today under a 24-hour recall. The Reds,
President Roosevelt expressed concern today for the safety of Miss Amelia Earhart, flier missing in the Pacific Ocean.

The Pittsfield Riding and Polo Club is to hold its first picnic ride of the season to Washington Mountain tomorrow night and the club is to play West Point officers on the polo grounds at Holmesdale Sunday afternoon.

Nearly two years after Batisto Salvo, former Bronx policy banker, was kidnapped the involved aftermath was brought to a close yesterday in the Bronx County Court when three men charged with the crime pleaded guilty to lesser charges and received ten to twenty year sentences from Judge James M. Barrett.

Mystery surrounded the identity of several witnesses. whom District Attorney Dodge questioned yesterday in preparation for the trial of Robert Irwin, sculptor and former theological student, in the triple slaying of Mrs. Mary Gedeon; her daughter, Veronica, and Frank Byrnes, a boarder, in their home at 316 East Fiftieth Street.

John Ecstella, about 12 years old, whose address was given only as Bethune Street, was drowned about 5 P. M. yesterday while swimming in the Central Park Lake at Seventy-seventh Street and the West Drive.

The Fourth of July speech of United States Ambassador Robert W. Bingham in London was sharply criticized by the Deutsche Allgemeine Zeitung today as "agitational." The Berlin newspaper minces no words in denouncing the diplomat, concluding:

Mayor La Guardia expressed the hope that this country would soon have a national art theatre yesterday when he welcomed thirty-two members of the Bulgarian National Theatre at his Summer City Hall in Chisholm Mansion, College Point, Queens.

The touring American lacrosse team continued its victorious progress today, defeating Lancashire, 9 to 4, for its fifth successive victory. Only an outstanding performance by the Lancashire goal keeper, who made thirty-five difficult stops, kept the score from mounting higher.

The International Seamen's Union, affiliate of the American Federation of Labor, has rejected an invitation to sign a peace agreement with other maritime unions to remain effective until the National Labor Relations Board has completed an election among the crews of eighty-eight Atlantic and Gulf ship lines:

Klamath County, Ore., will enter the market on July 19 with an issue of $205,000 Union High School District No. 2 bonds, dated July 1 and due July 1, 1938 to 1948. Bidders are asked to name a rate of interest not exceeding 6 per cent.
Funeral services were held at his home today for Professor Albert C. Phelps of the College of Architecture faculty at Cornell, who died Sunday. He was 64 years old.
A special permit enabled the Rumson Country Club to celebrate July 4 in the usual manner with a display of fireworks last night. It was preceded by dinner and followed by dancing.

EDEN, WILHELMINA J. (Oct. 27, 1936). Gross assets, $42,555; net, $37,392. To nephew, Henry J. Rover. Chief assets, real estate, $20,126; stocks and bonds, $5,026; mortgages, notes, cash and insurance, $17,352. Frederick B. Merkle, attorney. 9-15 Park Pl., Manhattan.

The Court of Appeals, in holding the $1,000,000 State Office Building bond issue constitutional and not subject to a referendum, ruled today for the first time on the legality of the Legislature's creating a debt, with interest due in the year of the legislative meeting, without making provision in the budget for paying the interest charges.

With the time for filing designations for party nominations a month away, a delegation of Republicans, including some of the most prominent party members in the city, will call upon Mayor La Guardia at the Summer City Hall at College Point tomorrow and ask him to run for the Republican nomination for Mayor.

From all directions athletes have begun to converge on New York for the second annual World Labor Athletic Carnival at Randalls Island Stadium Sunday. A sizable delegation of out-of-towners, including several national champions, already is on hand and more are arriving from time to time for this city's biggest outdoor track extravaganza since the final Olympic tryouts.
Bullish sentiment ran high in the wheat market today and a rally which followed an opening decline sent prices for the deferred deliveries into new high ground for the season.
The virtually clue-less search for Amelia Earhart swung into the isle-dotted seas south and east of tiny Howland Island tonight after another disappointing day of rumor-checking
Funeral services were held here today for Russ Hall, secretary of the Professional Baseball Players of America. Mr. Hall died last Thursday.

Yesterday found the long proposed transatlantic airline, via the Great Circle course between New York and London, an accomplished fact with the most difficult leg of the flight proved practical. Two great modern airliners rested at each end of the over-ocean run after demonstrating that they could fly the course under both favorable and unfavorable conditions.

Bob Burke, a former Columbia University student, was indicted with 200 other persons today by a grand jury which investigated steel strike violence. Both Burke and John Stevens, alias Stevenson, were dismissed last week as organizers for the Steel Workers Organizing Committee.

Members of the Board of Aldermen's baseball team will have their last opportunity to avenge eleven straight defeats by the City Hall Reporters Association when the teams meet again at the New York Athletic Club on Travers Island on Thursday, July 15.

Tom Kerrigan, professional at the Siwanoy Country Club and his amateur clubmate, S. E. Ward Jr.,turned in a fine 65, five under par, to take first honors in the weekly pro-amateur best-ball tournament at the Old Oaks Golf Club today.
THE ROMANTIC DECATUR, by Charles Lee Lewis. (University of Pennsylvania Press, $3.) A new biography of the naval leader.

That sophistication and high living are not confined to the human race and its cities seemed evident yesterday with the arrival at a Jersey City pier of a cargo of "animals extraordinary" from the wilds of Brazil.

Former Justice Willis Van Devanter, in his first public utterance on President Roosevelt's proposal to enlarge the Supreme Court, declared today: "The Supreme Court has weathered storms before, and I am sure it will weather the present one."

Mr. and Mrs. E. Victor Loew of Tuxedo Park gave a farewell dinner last night in the Viennese Roof Garden of the St. Regis for Mrs. Loew's daughter, Miss Catherine Rogers, who sailed later on the Europa to pass several weeks in Europe with Mr. and Mrs. Joseph E. Davis and their daughter. Miss Virginia Davis.

Alleging that Max Grossman of Galen Hall, Atlantic City, ran up a $2,523 laundry bill at a hotel in Atlantic City in two years and failed to pay it, John E. McGuirk applied in Supreme Court yesterday for an attachment against Mr. Grossman's property here. Mr. McGuirk said the claim had been assigned to him by the Atlantic City Ambassador Hotel Corporation.

Marvin Kantrowitz of New York and the University of Texas provided the feature of today's opening play in the Agawam Hunt singles by upsetting Albert Horton 3d of Providence, second on the seeded list, in a three-set second-round thriller. 6-8, 7-5. 6-2.

The Kings County Lighting Company has been directed by the Public Service Commission to extend for one year the temporary rates now charged to customers in its territory. The rates were originally ordered reduced in 1933, and have saved customers about $800,000 in the four years they have been in effect.

Miss Barbara Batchelder, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Hollis G. Batchelder of this place, became the bride this afternoon of John Marshall Lockwood, son of Justice and Mrs. Charles C. Lockwood of Brooklyn, N. Y., in St. Paul's Church here. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Thomas Huntington Chappell.
When Mrs. Della Weeks was inproduced to Mrs. Della Weeks here, the two began comparing facts about themselves.

The general staff issued at 4 o'clock this afternoon the following communique: "An offensive action, in which part of the central front forces participated, began at dawn in accordance with plans. As a prologue to this action our aviation attacked the enemy's rear-guard and front lines.

The Rev. Dr. William E. P. Haas, retired Methodist Episcopal minister who had served as superintendent of the West district of the Philadelphia Conference, died yesterday at the home, in Lima, of his son, the Rev. William E. P. Haas Jr. He was 64.

Johnny Rohrig, Clifton, N. J., 132 1/4, and Eddie Alzek of Brooklyn, 134, met in the feature bout of eight rounds at the New York Coliseum last night and boxed to a draw before 5,000 spectators. The fight, which started slowly, picked up momentum with each succeeding round.

ANTONTIADES, NICHOLAS P. (Feb. 7, 1935). Estate, less than $1,000. To Mary Antontiades, widow, and Helen Gertsou, daughter, Ploutarchon 3, Athens, Greece; two specific and five contingent bequests. Theodose J. Mitrou, 50 Riverside Dr., executor.
The city's produce supply was threatened tonight and hundreds of carloads of perishable fruits and vegetables stood neglected on railroad sidings as laborers, handlers and draymen voted to strike.

A preliminary report made public today of the metals and minerals division of the Department of Commerce indicates that all post-war records for the export of semi-finished and finished iron and steel products were broken in May.

Business failures in the second quarter of this year totaled 2,291, the smallest number for any similar period since 1920, according to a report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc. In the same period last year the total was 2,435.

Heartened by the most prosperous Fourth-of-July week-end in many years, but disgusted at "dead heads" who visit this resort without spending, Mayor Charles D. White said today the 'time has come when Atlantic City must consider charging visitors an entrance fee."
Thirteen persons arrested on riot charges during the strike last year at' the Camden plant of the Radio Corporation of America were acquitted in Camden Criminal Court today on a directed verdict.

A stoppage involving 35,000 workers in more than 1,500 shops in the coat and suit industry in the metropolitan area was ordered yesterday, effective tomorrow morning, by-the joint board of the Cloakmakers Unioni an affiliate of the International Ladies Garment Workers, after a special meeting of the joint board at union headquarters, 3 West Sixteenth Street.

The stock market here was more cheerful today, although business continued quiet. Gilt-edged issues were firm and among the foreign loans German bonds improved. Transatlantic issues attracted considerable support and United States Steel and International Nickel shares went ahead.

Use of a "black wagon" and the practice of "giving them a union" were the two methods upon which the United Cake, Pastry and Pie Bakers- Association relied to enforce its price scale upon unruly boss bakers among its membership, according to testimony in the Court of Special Sessions yesterday.

Lord Baden-Powell, Chief Scout of the World and founder of the Boy Scouts, spoke from England tonight and admonished 26,000 youths assembled at their Jamboree here "to carry on and develop friendship among themselves," so that they might help to bring about an era of "peace and good-will among men."

Frogmore Cottage in Windsor Great Park is being renovated so Queen Mary will have her own country house near the King and Queen. The "cottage" is a large Georgian mansion half a mile from Windsor Castle and three miles from the Royal Lodge where the King and Queen go for complete privacy.

Building plans filed yesterday included projects for altering many structures in Manhattan and Brooklyn. In the Bronx, specifications were submitted for a group of dwellings on Seminole Avenue. The list follows:

Dr. Stewart Lee Jeffrey of New York and Coconut Grove, Fla., observed his birthday today at the Mount Washington Hotel. Mrs. Jeffrey gave a party in his honor, at which guests included Mrs. Frank B. Reynold and R. Foster Reynold. Later they all attended the cinema at the Hall in the Pines.

Partial returns in the poll being conducted by the United Shipyards, Inc., among its 1,700 striking employes at Mariners Harbor, Staten Island, where a strike has been in progress for three weeks, disclosed yesterday that 678 of 757 employes voting have expressed their desire that the strike be called off and to return to work whether or not the walkout is terminated.
The one-family dwelling at 50-25 244th Street, Douglaston, L. I., has been sold by Edward Necarsulmer to Frederic W. Wilson Jr. The house is on a plot 50x118 feet and is assessed for $9,000.

Felony warrants were issued against the Ford company and fourteen employes in connection with the alleged beating of union officials. Labor Board began hearing. Page 1. Youngstown indicted 200 steel workers, including Bob Burke, as a result of recent strike riots. Page 6.

The office of the Controller of the Currency and the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System have issued calls for statements showing the condition of banks under their jurisdiction as of June 30.

The Federal Trade Commission today ordered the ten rayon yarn corporations which manufacture practically all the rayon yarn in the United States to cease and desist from cartrying out "an agreement, combination, understanding. and conspiracy among themselves" to eliminate the price competition. The commission,

Mr. and Mrs. Henry Ettinger of Yonkers, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Harriette Rose Ettinger, to Dr. Carl L. Wilson, son of Mr. and Mrs. S. D. Wilson of Brookline, Mass., formerly of Yonkers.

Sir Walford Selby, British Minister to Vienna, who became a close friend of the Duke of Windsor during the former monarch's stay at Enzesfeld, has been appointed Ambassador to Lisbon, it was announced tonight.
Maxie Berger, 136, of New York, defeated Midget Wolgast, 136, Philadelphia, in an eight-round bout before 3,000 fans at the Coney Island Velodrome last night, according to The Associated Press.

The Securities and Exchange Commission has issued an order calling upon the Marlin-Rockwell Corporation to show cause why its $1 par value common capital stock should not be suspended or withdrawn from registration and listing on the New York Stock Exchange because the company failed in its annual report on Form 10-K for 1936 to include the amount of sales and cost of goods sold as required.

Although some 500 buyers, including representatives of most of the large department stores in the East, were in attendance, opening of floor covering lines here yesterday was marked by a considerable degree of concern on the part of manufacturers as to whether the 5 to 10 per cent price advances, which became general with the opening, would result in resistance on the part of retailers who feared public reluctance to pay the higher prices.
We, the people of the State of New York, had at least two opportunities to think well of ourselves on Independence Day.
Chissie, the three-month-old black and white kitten that installed herself in Mayor La Guardia's Summer City Hall last Thursday, was missing temporarily from the building yesterday.
The United States Bureau of Air Commerce started today installing new markers on air lines radiating to the south, west and north of Newark Airport.

Irving Capell, 22, of 270 South Ninth Street, Brooklyn, and his brother, Bernard, 24, of 1419 Gerard Street, Washington, escaped death early today when the car in which they were riding plunged 35 feet to the bottom of a railroad cut and was demolished when struck by two fast-moving passenger trains. The accident happened at 4 A. M.

James Whitehouse, employed for twenty-three years as a pressman by THE NEW YORK TIMES, died yesterday at his home, 32-54 Eightysecond Street, Jackson Heights, Queens, following a brief illness. He was 48 years old.

Declaring that every strike can be ended in an intelligent way, Governor Frank Murphy of Michigan writes on the strike situation in the Amerikai Magyarsag (The American Hungarian), a new semimonthly newspaper published in New York under the editorship of Tibor Bartok.

Another half-dozen matches were contested today in the Meadow Brook Club cups polo tourney with the pace setters in the two divisions of the competition--Old Westbury and the Foxhunters--continuing along the unbeaten path by recording impressive triumphs.

Expressing the belief that America can obtain greater benefits from study of Oriental culture than from war-fearing and intolerant Europe, Dr. Gregg M. Sinclair, director of the Oriental Institute of the University of Hawaii, outlined here yesterday his university's plans for a conference of Eastern and Western philosophers in Honolulu, possibly in 1939.

Steel operations in the United States this week are scheduled at 67.3 per cent of capacity, a decline of 7.7 points, or 10.3 per cent from last week, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
Eastern States Veterinary Conference begins at the Hotel New Yorker this morning at 10 o'clock and continues Thursday and Friday. Speakers, opening session: Mayor La Guardia, Dr. R. S. MacKellar Sr.
Joseph Jozwiak, a 42-year-old picket, was killed today at the plant of the Lloyd Manufacturing Company when non-strikers attempted to enter the factory grounds.

An apple tree which grows in a glasshouse out in an orchard at Cornell University outdoes the ants in industry. It works a thirty-five-hour week-a five-hour day for seven days-at top speed while scientists seek the solution to many problems of fruit growers.

Without fanfare and with a matterof-factness which is deeply impressive, Captain HAROLD E. GRAY of Pan American Airways and Captain A. S. WILCOCKSON of Imperial Airways landed their flying boats respectively at Foynes, in the Irish Free State, and at Botwood, Nfld., yesterday morning.

Louis (Lepke) Buchalter and Jacob (Gurrah) Shapiro, alleged racketeers, who are said to have extorted more than $1,000,000 a year from industry, failed to appear for trial yesterday on a Sherman AntiTrust Law indictment and Federal Judge Sidney C. Mize, issuing warrants for their arrest, ordered their bonds of $3,000 each forfeited.
The Public Service Commission announced yesterday that it had ordered the Queensboro Gas and Electric Company to reduce its electric rates, effective Aug. 1, to save consumers about $220,000 a year.

Collaborating perfectly most of the way, Ray G. Maxwell and his 24year-old son, Lloyd R., posted a fine 37, 40-77 to annex the Westchester father-and-son golf championship today as they set the pace for sixteen other combinations over the Sunningdale course.

The powerful engines of the naval aircraft carrier Lexington, knifing through Pacific swells at thirty-three knots on her Amelia Earhart rescue mission, make her a speedier vessel than the North Atlantic's fleetest liners, available records here last night indicated.

The anthracite industry of the T United States is opposed to the iNorris bill to divide virtually the entire country between "seven TVA's" for the purpose of flood control, land reclamation, abatement of unemployment and other purposes, Louis C. Madeira 3d, executive director of the Anthracite Institute, said {yesterday.

Governor Lehman reported today, in a statement summarizing the State's finances for the fiscal year which ended June 30, that the cumulative deficit, which "reached nearly a hundred millions four years ago," had been reduced to $10,198,451.76.

The Steiger Hotel Operating Company, Inc., Walter L. Steiger president, has leased from the Equitable Life Assurance Society the seventeen-story San Carlos Hotel at 150-54 East Fiftieth Street, and the sixstory hotel annex at 148 East Fiftieth Street.

The United States Circuit Court of Appeals today upheld a ruling by District Judge John W. Holland in Miami ordering foreclosure sale of the estate of Mrs. Richard Croker, widow of the former Tammany leader.

It is probably a reasonable estimate that as many as two million persons go out of New York City or visit pleasure resorts on the fringes of the city during one of our great Summer holidays. Possibly a quarter as many come into town, though the numbers of those who live outside and think it fun to come in when they have a free day are harder to figure.
The United States imported in May, last, about five times the amount of foodstuffs exported, judging by the dollar value of the goods, according to a Commerce Department statement today,

Assistant District Attorney Sigismund Trapani and two policemen in Flatbush Court, Brooklyn, paid a $1 fine yesterday for Ralph Mastrogiovanni, 17 years old, of 1,281 St. Mark's Avenue, Brooklyn, who had been penalized by Magistrate Pinto for shining shoes at Utica Avenue and Eastern Parkway, Brooklyn, where such activity is prohibited.

A clash between pickets and workers at 1 Main Street, Brooklyn, where a C. I. 0. strike is in progress, followed by a union demonstration before the Poplar Street police station, resulted yesterday in the arrest of sixty-eight persons, ten of them women.
King George VI paid tribute to his Scottish Queen tonight by holding in Holyrood House the first royal evening court Scotland has seen in more than thirty years.
The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated July 2: COMMANDER Wiley, H. V., the Sirius, to Naval Academy.

While the Norris bill dividing the map of the United States into seven parts for the purpose of flood control, navigation, reclamation and other aims was introduced in the Senate on June 3 and hearings were begun on June 21, only one appearance has been made before the Senate subcommittee in the last two weeks by private corporations or trade associations.

Many Inks in 1936 engaged in speculave investing, a practice which ends to undermine "the soundness of the financial structure of the enre country," the Federal Deposit asurance Corporation said in its inual report, made public today.

The American Federation of Labor defeated the Committee for Industrial Organization in a collective bargaining election today.' The result raises the bars against the C. I. O. in the baking industry in Philadelphia.

Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora approved yesterday a motion by Jacob J. Rosenblum, one of the chief assistants of Thomas E. Dewey, special prosecutor of rackets, for the drawing of a special panel of 300 veniremen for the poultry racket trial.
The five-story business building at 379 Fifth Avenue, between Thirty-fifth and Thirty-sixth Streets, has been purchased by Frederick Brown from a client of Brown, Wheelock, Harris, Stevens, Inc.

An agreement between the International Fur Workers Union and A. Hollander Son extending recognition to the union and granting wage increases, the 35-hour week and improved working conditions was announced yesterday.
Some repercussions of the glorious Fourth and fifth: Beach Haven-Catches of goodsized bluefish brought in by the offshore fleet proved to be the outstanding news of the fishing holidays.

One of the Free State's most surprising general elections ended tonight with a stalemate decision. When the last Deputy was elected for Cork West the final line-up in the new Dail Eireann gave the Fianna Fail 69, the party of William T. Cosgrave, former President, 48; Labor, 13, and Independents 8.

Lord Tweedsmuir and three members of his touring party walked through this city's principal streets today almost unrecognized. In a shop His Excellency bought six twenty-cent books to take on his Northern voyage down the Mackenzie River. The books are:
Following is .the text of the message broadcast from London to the Boy Scout Jamboree this evening by Lord Baden-Powell:

Premier Camille Chautemps's government drafted decrees tonight to replenish France's depleted treasury with 10,000,000,000 francs (about $386,500,000). The step was taken after the treasury lowered the Bank of France's discount rate from 6 to 5 per cent.

Funeral services for Major Gen. Edmund Wittenmyer, U.S.A. (retired), who died here Saturday, will be held in Fort Myer Chapel at 10 A. M. tomorrow. Chaplain Ora J. Cohee will officiate. Burial will take place in Arlington National Cemetery.

American women were chided yesterday by Miss Gordon Holmes, joint managing director of the National Securities Corporation Ltd. of London, for not taking the lead in the woman's movement as seriously as they might.

The voice of Theodore Roosevelt, whose years as President passed before the development of radio, is to be broadcast for what is believed to be the first time at 6:45 P. M. tomorrow, radio station WOR announced yesterday.

The belated enthusiasm of holiday celebrants using up their supply of bootleg fireworks late Monday night and yesterday brought the total number of reported fireworks injuries in the city since Saturday night to 1,180, but left the daily rate of injuries well below the figure for a year ago.

Harry Bonsignore of 127 Cherry Street and Columbus Christopher of 30 St. Edward Street, Brooklyn, who pleaded guilty last month to violation of the Anti-Trust Law in the city's $1,000,000a year artichoke trade, received prison sentences of six months each when they appeared yesterday before Federal Judge John C. Knox.
Mrs. Florence Kendall, who won honors in France driving her own ambulance over that shell-torn country during the World War, observed her- eighty-seventh birthday anniversary at her home here today.

Sensational stories of continued purges in the Far Eastern Red Army, with great unrest and confusion in its ranks, are reported in the Japanese press. These reports are based on rumors passing around in Manchukuo.
Stocks advanced 1 to 6 points and closed higher in heaviest trading since May 13; turnover, 1,412,300 shares. All groups of bonds higher in more active trading; transactions, $9,096,400.

Charles Maurras, Royalist leader who was sent to prison for inciting violence against members of Parliament and in connection with the attack on Leon Blum last year, was released from Sante Prison today.
The Montreal Royals tightened their grip on second place by making it two out of three over the Bisons with a 9-to-4 victory tonight.
Rains over the holidays and strength in outside markets brought about a further recovery in prices on the Cotton Exchange yesterday The list ended with a loss of 1 point to a gain of 7 points.

Because his aim was too good assault charges were made today against Prosecutor Virgolino of the Security Tribunal by Representative Vieira, counsel for Governor Lima Cavalcanti of the State of Pernambuco, who is on trial on charges of aiding the Leftist uprising in November, 1935.

Following the death of President Cousens, the trustees of Tufts College today appointed Professor George S. Miller, assistant to the president since 1916, to carry on the administrative functions of the college. Dr. Miller,
Movements of livestock on the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow:

The new films listed to open today are "Easy Living," a comedy by Preston Sturges, featuring Jean Arthur, Edward Arnold, Ray Milland, Luis Alberni and Mary Nash, at the Paramount, and "Fools' Comedy," an Italian importation, with the DeFilippo Brothers, at the Broadway Cine Roma Theatre.

August Edmund Widli of 4 Oxford Road, a partner in the investment brokerage firm of Lord Widli, died here last night in St. Agnes Hospital at the age of 46. He underwent an operation for appendicitis one week ago.

Youthful enthusiasts joined with gray-headed adults yesterday to register for the Summer modelbuilding class of the New York Museum of Science and Industry in Rockefeller Center, the first venture of the kind sponsored by the museum.

Mrs. Catherine Hall, 40 years old, whose attempt to commit suicide last Friday in her apartment at 4,719 Sixth Avenue, Brooklyn, resulted in the death of her two children, died early yesterday morning in Kings County Hospital from gas poisoning.
Arrested Saturday in connection with jewelry thefts at Newark Airport, four men were arraigned here today before Police Judge Seymour Klein of the Third Precinct Court and held for the grand jury.

The Navy Department said today it was unable to estimate whether any additional cost, beyond normal operating expenses, was involved in the search by naval vessels for the missing aviator Amelia Earhart.

A tempest in a tespot, or, to be more exact, in a be more exact, in a beer stein, simmered and cooled yesterday as the liner Yucatan of the New York and Cuba Mail Line arrived from Mexico with 148 passengers.

Enzo Fiermonte, the Italianborn automobile racer husband of Mrs. Madeline Force Astor Dick Fiermonte, was sentenced to five days in prison yesterday by Magistrate Gustav Wieboldt in Queens traffic court following his arrest on a three-year-old warrant charging him with speeding.

It has been evident from the start that Democratic support of the President's Supreme Court plan has been reluctant and half-hearted. The plan was submitted suddenly to Congress, without public warning and after consultation only with a small group of intimate advisers.

Mr. and Mrs. Hobart C. ChatfieldTaylor, who have been at the Pierre, will leave today for Santa Barbara, Calif. Mrs. James Barlow Cullum and Miss Mollie Cullum of Sewickley, Pa., are at the Plaza. Mr. and Mrs. T. Wallace Orr, who sailed Saturday on the Conte di Savoia, will return Oct. 1 to the Waldorf-Astoria.

Under an agreement with the Columbia Broadcasting System, Inc., William S. Paley, its president, draws an annual salary of $40,000, plus 2 1/2 per cent of the consolidated net profits of the company and its subsidiaries up to $600,000, according to a report to the Securities and Exchange Commission made public yesterday.

President Roosevelt said today that he would send letters in the next day or two to the chairmen of the Senate and House Agriculture Committees asking passage of general farm legislation at this session of Congress.
Abraham Cahan, author, editorin-chief of the Jewish Daily Forward, and old-time Socialist, will celebrate' his seventy-seventh birthday today at his desk as usual, at 175 East Broadway.
The Franklin D. Roosevelts Jr. will leave here Friday, taking train for Quebec, where they embark Saturday on the liner Empress of Britain for Europe.
Two men are believed to have been drowned in the most destructive wind and rain storm Delaware has experienced in forty years. About 100 families were driven from their homes.

The net profit of the Raytheon Manufacturing Company and subsidiaries for the fiscal year ended on May 31, last, was reported yesterday as $151,277 after depreciation, amortization of patents, research and development expenses, Federal income taxes and other deductions, including $157,375 provision for disputed royalties.

Movements of vessels, all dates, are July 3, unless specified: At Aberdeen: Barry, Gilmer, Childs. San Clemente to LaHaina Roads, July 4: Cushing, Drayton, Lamson, Lexington. Annapolis to Dahlgren, July 6: Claxton, Erie, Fairfax, Jacob Jones, Manley, Roper.
The South Shore Polo Club defeated the Ox Ridge team on Hazard Field today when Richard Floyd, No. 3, shot a goal in the last chukker to give the squad a 6-to-5 edge.

Proposed increases in passenger fares filed by twelve bus companies and corportions operating lines between New York City and points in Northern New Jersey which were to have gone into effect yesterday have been suspended until Oct. 3 by the Interstate Commerce Commission.

Horton Smith, who was not thought to be playing well enough to represent the United States in the Ryder Cup matches last week, led a field of 141 qualifiers to win the medal in the British open golf championship with his second crashing round of 69 today.
Prince Charles, nephew of King Gustaf of Sweden, was married in Quillinge Church today to Countess Elsa von Rosen, a daughter of King Gustaf's Grand Master of Ceremonies.

Creation, "in the near future," of an inter-American court of justice was predicted today by Dr. Pedro Martinez Fraga, Cuban Ambassador to the United States, in an address delivered before the Institute of Public Affairs at the University of Virginia.

Daring the opposition to begin a filibuster, administration forces in the Senate fired the first salvo today in their campaign to drive through a compromise version of President Roosevelt's plan for reorganizing the judiciary.

Mrs. C. Suydam Cutting, with her husband, explorer and trustee of the American Museum of Natural History, will sail today on the Queen Mary to begin the long journey to Lhasa, in Tibet, by way of India.

Running counter to the usual trend following a three-day holiday, the prices of all bonds moved upward yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. Although activity did not expand to any degree over that of last week, the upturn inaugurated last Wednesday continued and the scarcity of offerings resulted in bidding more spirited than usual.

Two additional deaths from automobile accidents over the Fourth of July week-end were reported here today. Mrs. Florence Woodward, 40 years old, wife of Walter B. Woodward, president of the Westville Republican Club in Camden County, died this morning in the Underwood Hospital, Woodbury.
Theatregoers here again received a setback when the Red Bank Players failed tonight for the second time to open the Summer season with the scheduled "Candlelight."
Donald E. Frederick, co-founder of Frederick Nelson, Seattle's largest department store, died today of pneumonia at his home in the Highlands after an illness of a week. His age was 77.

Government and commercial radiotelephone service between the continental United States and Alaska will be formally opened at 2 o'clock, Eastern standard time, tomorrow afternoon, with conversations between government and American Telephone and Telegraph Company officials here and at Juneau.

For several reasons the building industry ought now to be enjoying a period of great activity. With the extremely low level of new construction, a shortage of housing accumulated during the depression. Since 1929 the country's population has increased by about 7,000,000, while in those eight years many houses have been rendered unfit for habitation by decay.
The county grand jury tonight indicted Albert Dyer, former WPA school crossing guard, on charges of murdering three small Inglewood girls.

President Manuel Qyezon of the Philippines arrived here today for a three-day visit. Although traveling unofficially, he was met at the station by three Foreign Office representatives and three members of the United States Embassy, headed by First Secretary Ferdinand L. Mayer.
Forty seven directors of the Continental Illinois Bank and Trust Company were named today defendants in a suit for accounting involving more than $6,000,000.

" Caught" between newly found freedom and a desire for continuance of the many courtesies shown them by the "adoring male," many women today resort to unsportsmanlike methods of obtaining the best in both the new and the old regimes, Dr. M. A. Griffin, co-director of the Appalachian Hall, a sanatorium for the treatment of nervous diseases at Asheville, N. C., said here today.

The city's Independent Subway System has cut deeply into the Long Island Railroad's traffic and somewhat less into the B. M. T. service in the Jamaica area since the city's line opened to its 169th Street terminal in April, according to figures made public yesterday at the Board of Transportation.

Daniel Edward (Ned) Sawyer, twenty years ago one of America's outstanding amateur golfers, died today. He was stricken on his return last Wednesday from an Eastern business trip and did not regain consciousness.

The marriage of Miss Adelaide Jost, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Theodore A. Jost of Mount Vernon, N. Y., to Dr. Wilbur J. Prezzano, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward P. Prezzano, also of Mount Vernon, took place last night at St. Ursula's Catholic Church in Mount Vernon. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Francis M. O'Reilly.

Seven weeks on the bench, listening to policy racketeers, wife-beaters or pickets plead their cases have not spoiled Magistrate Edgar Bromberger's ear for music. Instead, the recently appointed magistrate now has a keener sense of appreciation for the well-played violin and finds that it relaxes him after a long day in court.

For the first time since the opening of the international chess congress at the Kurhaus, three weeks ago, not a single tournament game was on today's program and the eighteen competitors were given a full day for rest and recreation, of which all took the fullest advantage.
Amelia Earhart's disappearance resuited today in an official suggestion that amateur radio stations be linked into a giant network for use in future emergencies.

Hoffman Island, best known as a quarantine station for parrots, became a municipal picnic ground yesterday when 297 under-privileged children and 40 parents were taken on the first of daily outings arranged by Mayor La Guardia with the cooperation of Federal authorities, the WPA and the, Departments of Health and Plant and Structures.
Jorge Brescia of Argentina won a twelve-round decision tonight over Bob Tow of Washington. Brescia Weighed 203 1/2 pounds and Tow 205.

Automobile accidents in the city during the July 4 week-end this year caused one more death than in 1936, but there were fewer crashes and injuries, the weekly report of the Police Department showed yesterday.
SOUTHERN DISTRICT Petitions Filed--Against M. G. LEATHER GOODS CO., INC., 55 Greene St., by Crown Fastener Corp., for $294; Robert Scholze Tannery, $6,200; Samuel Lipschitz, $124. Petitions Filed--By
Charles E. Lipscomb, member of the New York publishing firm of Parke, Austin Lipscomb, died here yesterday at the age of 66.

For the third time Harold S. Vanderbilt, big-boat skipper and bridge player extraordinary, stands in the position of head man in the defense of the America's Cup, but this time there is one important difference. Not only has he the destiny of the new defender in his hands, but he is her sole owner as well.

County Judge Peter J. Brancato in Brooklyn swore in the July grand jury yesterday with a brief address containing remarks believed to be directed at Special Prosecutor Hiram C. Todd and the extraordinary grand jury investigating the Samuel Drukman murder case.

Grenville T. Emmet of New York, Minister to the Netherlands, was nominated by President Roosevelt today to be Minister to Austria, a post left vacant by the recent appointment of George S. Messersmith as Assistant SecretarY of State.

Steel mills in another major salient in the seven-State strike opened here today. An estimated 3,000 workers returned to their posts at three Republic Steel Corporation plants after forty-one days of idleness.

The Colorado Supreme Court today temporarily suspended from practice Erl H. Ellis, a Denver attorney, who acknowledged confederatingg" with others to conceal microphones in Governor Teller Ammons's private offices.
