The Mason Brown Ice and Coal Company of Huntsville, Ala., asserted before the Board of Tax Appeals today that competition by the TVA should be considered in income tax computations.

118th St, 305 W, 25x101: Merlet, Inc., to trustee will of Adolphus Ottenberg; same property, trustee said will to Cherep Realty, Inc., 1,950 7th Ave, consideration $11,000. 1st Ave, s w cor 104th St, 25x100; Maurice J. Smith to trustee for Celestine Helbert Goldsmith, 755 Park Ave, consideration $15,000, foreclosure.

More than 300 persons yesterday afternoon attended a funeral service for Walter Cary, vice president of the Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company, in All Souls Unitarian Church, Lexington Avenue and Eightieth Street. Mr.

The Theatre of the Four Seasons offered tonight George Bernard Shaw's comedy "Pygmalion," under the direction of Charles Hopkins and with the same cast that played last week in "No More Peace," the Ernst Toller anti-war satire.

The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended June 30: An increase of $23,000,000 in commercial, industrial and agricultural loans and a decrease of $44,000,000 in loans to banks;

A charge by 700 dismissed WPA workers that recent disorders on relief projects here were provoked by newly hired WPA guards brought from Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, local Works Progress Administrator, yesterday the retort that not only had no new guards been hired but that some of the old guards were being laid off in the general process of WPA curtailment.
After their applications had been accepted at the Army Building in New York City, 440 young men selected for enrollment in the Civilian Conservation Corps arrived here today.

Experts now estimate that Germany's coming grain harvest will be even worse than the inadequate crops of last year and that even larger purchases abroad will be required next Spring than in the past season.

Although the government would like to deport him as an undesirable alien, Max Erblick, former supervisor of kosher food on the Cunard White Star liner Aquitania, was released from Ellis Island yesterday because the immigration department cannot persuade a foreign country to accept him.

A more careful analysis and understanding of the aims of labor and management, intelligent and more conservative leadership for labor unions and greater union responsibility were advocated as a "solution for the present labor unrest" by Samuel P. Gilman,

A kidnap rumor that drew crowds in the West Flatbush section of Brooklyn last night ended shortly after 9 P. M. with the finding of the body of a missing 2-year-old boy in the rear of an apartment building next to one in which he had been visiting.

With more than 15,000 troops on the spot, prepared for any emergency, the British Government was ready tonight to announce the most momentous change of policy toward Palestine since the establishment of the mandate.

The Rev. R. Anderson Jardine, who became a celebrity overnight when he married the Duke and Duchess of Windsor, said yesterday afternoon on top of the Empire State Building that he would not marry any couples in this country.

Leaders of the strike against the Cambria plant of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation abandoned picketing indefinitely here today and laid plans to win votes in an election that they are confident that the National Labor Relations Board will order.
The House bill appropriating $3,000,000 to finance Federal participation in the New York World's Fair of 1939 was passed by the Senate today, in exactly the form it came from the House.

The nation's capital will be the baseball center of the country tomorrow when the fifth annual All-Star game will be played. But Washington is not feeling any pressure so far as hotel accommodations are concerned.

Testifying before the National Labor Relations Board yesterday Floyd L. Carlisle, chairman of the board of the Consolidated Edison Company, disputed charges that the company acted illegally in extending recognition to the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers and signing contracts with this A. F. of L. affiliate.
Irish Billy Beauhuld of Jersey City won another victory in the pro ranks tonight, conquering Johnny BeIlus of New Haven, Conn., over the eight-round distance.

Denouncing the "evils of a system which keeps millions in practical slavery," the Very Rev. Francis P. Lyons, spiritual director and co-organizer of the National Convert League, called tonight for a reconstruction of the social order.

Leo J. McDermott, director of the city budget, issued certificates yesterday reducing the salaries of three employes of the Corporation Counsel's staff for whom exceptional pay increases had been voted by the Board of Estimate, it was announced by William C. Chanler, First Assistant Corporation Counsel.

Baxter Pickering, Advertising, in RCA Building, Rockefeller Center. Sieburg's Liberty Tower Restaurant Co., renewal, in 56 Nassau St; Horn Hardart Co., renewal, in 44-60 E 23d St; Bond Clothing Stores, in 57 Church St. New Haven, Conn.; State Department of Social Welfare, two floors in 112 State St, Albany; Charles F. Noyes Co., Inc., broker.
German automobile racing fans are jubilant over the capture of first and second prizes by German-made cars in the Vanderbilt Cup race yesterday.

Triumphing by three wickets over Surrey, Yorkshire today recorded its ninth victory in the English county cricket championship. The victors remained at the head of the table with a good margin over Sussex and two matches in hand.

A brother and a sister were reunited here yesterday after a separation of thirty-three years. Fifty-three years ago P. E. Hanson, now of su Detroit, came to the United States from Skoene, a small hamlet in Sweden. A year later his sister,
ON THEIR OWN APPLICATIONS PATROLMEN-Andrew Bornkessel, 40th Precinct, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed July 6, 1912. Alfred J. Huestis, 52d Precinct, at $1,500 per annum. Appointed March 12, 1910.

Because of the difficulties of transferring money, thousands of Jewish families have been unable to leave Germany. Now, however, Germany's standstill creditors have consented to the use of "haavaramarken" (Jewish transfer marks) for relief drafts and remittances to persons of Jewish origin and to Jewish organizations in Germany.

Miss Candace Baird Alig, daughter of Mrs. Otto Fidele Alig of New York and Des Moines and the late Mr. Alig, and Kelvin Cox Vanderlip, son of Mrs. Frank A. Vanderlip of this city and Scarboroughon-Hudson and the late Mr. Vanderlip, obtained a marriage license at the Municipal Building yesterday.

When a dark smudge appeared through the misty curtain, thirty miles through, the first break in a gray horizon that held unchanging since the sun disappeared behind low-hanging cloud banks off the Newfoundland coast last night, First Officer William de Lima, sharing the bridge watch with me, turned slightly, nodded his head and said, "There she is."

The automobile industry has already traversed 58 per cent of the way toward its goal of 5,000,000 units for 1937, according to Automotive Industries, which says that more than 2,900,000 cars and trucks were built in the first half of the year.
By WALTER M. JACOBSON Park Ave, 28, 5-story dwelling, 3Ox100; Windholme Realty Corp. against Ella F. Guthrie; due, $97,952: taxes, c., $2,100; to plaintiff for $50,000.

Laurence O. Anderson of the Northern National Bank of Duluth, Minn., after a month's holiday in the Belgian Congo, will sail for the United States tomorrow on the Normandle with what probably are the first amateur motion pictures in color of native and animal life in Africa.
Two pictures of children at the i Heckscher Camp, Adams Corner, N. Y., which appeared in THE NEW YORK TIMES of July 4, were incorrectly captioned as "youngsters of the East Side."

Vernon Sylvaine's new farce, "A Spot of Bother," was presented at the Strand Theatre tonight. Its humor depends not on dialogue or character but on the spectacle of one man chasing another with an axe.
Deliberator, racing in the colors of the Everglade Stable, unloosed a burst of speed in the stretch today to win the featured Evanston Purse, a six-furlong event, at Arlington Park.

Both from within France and from across the Pyrenees strong pressure is being put on the French Government to take action to end the deadlock on the Spanish non-intervention control issue and permit the shipping of guns and ammunition, especially ammunition.

Sheriff Oliver Metcalf of Tioga County said today that he and his deputies had used tear gas this morning to rout more than 200 pickets who stoned 22 automobiles taking Elkland Leather Company employes to work.

In seeking to evaluate the importance of the fact--set down by Mr. Stark in yesterday's TIMES--that C. I. O. circles are discussing a break between the President and John L. Lewis, it is useful to bear several things in mind. One is that the author of the dispatch is generally regarded as the best-informed labor reporter in the United States. Another is that Mr.

More than 150 members of the International Clothing Designers Association were welcomed here today by Mayor Charles Stanton in an opening session of their fifty-sev enth semi-annual convention in the Sagamore Hotel.

Atley Donald, Newark's freshman sensation, stretched his winning streak to thirteen today when he pitched the Bears to a clean sweep of their three-game series with the Jersey City Giants. The score was 5 to 2.

Following up the recent German and Italian demands that belligerent rights be given to the Insurgents, General Francisco. Franco has addressed a note to foreign governments, reiterating his recent warnings in the Salamanca press that nations favoring the Valencia government "should not be surprised if our international and economic policy closed our doors to those who showed their enmity to us in our need."
According to Admiralty figures issued today, the German Navy will consist of the following units by June, 1941:

Due to the holiday on Monday visiting buyers registered in the market during the week ended yesterday were well below the preceding week and the corresponding week a year ago, according to the lists published in THE TIME.

Albert M. Fisher, a veteran of fifty-six years' service with the Western Union Telegraph Company, died Monday, after a brief illness, at his home, 1,015 Summit Avenue, the Bronx, at the age of 69. Since 1910 he had been chief clerk in the office of the vice president in charge of traffic, this city.
A letter from Philip De Ronde, who was named by the Treasury as a tax avoider, has been received by Chairman Doughton of the Joint Committee on Tax Evasion and Avoidance.

Mrs. Julia M. Pennell Schauffler, widow of Alfred T. Schauffler, died yesterday at her home here after an illness of three weeks. She was 84 years old. Her husband, who was a District Superintendent of Schools in New York, died fifteen years ago.

Miss Alice Callahan, 19 years old, is in a critical condition in Burlington County Hospital, Mount Holly, and her mother, Mrs. Nora Callahan, is recovering today from a beating both suffered last midnight at the hands of a man, believed to have been a Negro, who accosted them while they were walking in Route 38 to their home west of here.

Two unexpected reversals took place yesterday in the Queens County tennis tourney at the Seminole Club, Forest Hills, as Leonard Hartman, first-seeded player, and George Seewagen, No. 5, were eliminated by unranked entrants in fourth-round encounters.

City Island Ave (18-5641), s e cor of Schofield St, 74x92; John J. Brady, referee, to MIortgage Commission Realty Corp, trustee. Buchanan PI,. 15 (11-3196); Marine Midland Trust Co of N Y, trustee, to St. Paul's Church, Newburgh, N. Y.

A suggestion that infusion of the Supreme Court with "new blood" might aid the government in tax collections through liberalization of decisions affecting revenue statutes was made today by Representative Lewis of Maryland in a House speech.

Trading In lamb was slow but prices were about 50 cents higher. Steel and fresh pork cuts were strong to $1 higher and veal about steady. Early trading in kosher meats indicated beef prices to be strong to $1 higher. Veal weak, lamb steady,

A saving of $400,000,000 in Federal expenditures during this fiscal year was forecast by President Roosevelt today on his return from Hyde Park. The economy would result, he explained, from voluntary abstention from spending on the part of Cabinet officers and heads of independent agencies.

Charles (Gabby) Street, who piloted the St. Louis Cardinals to two pennants and one World Series title, resigned today as manager of the St. Paul American Association club he led to second place last season.

After "postponing" - amid much hue and cry-"The Cradle Will Rock" the Federal Government has finally made up its mind about Marc Blitzstein's storm-tossed opera. The government has decided to have nothing more to do with it, a formal order to that effect having been received yesterday from Mrs. Hallie Flanagan, national theatre director.
It is a maxim of the turf that when a 3-year-old can give weight to an older horse and still win the young thoroughbred must be a good one.
The Chrysler Corporation's Dodge Truck division reopened after a four-hour shutdown today when the night shift reported to work.
A contract for 210 pursuit monoplanes and spare parts was awarded by the War Department today to the Curtiss airplane division of the Curtiss Wright Corporation of Buffalo, at a cost of $4,113,550.

Dr. H. H. Kung, Vice President of the Executive Yuan (Vice Premier) and Finance Minister of China, urged American capital to help modernize his country and guaranteed full protection by his government for foreign investors, in an address last night at a dinner in his honor.

Passengers sailing today for Europe on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary include the Maharajah, Rajsaheb of Wankener, the Maharanee Saheba of Wankener and Maharajah Kumar Shin, Raiskumar Sinji of Wankener.

Federal Judge Samuel Mandelbaum dismissed yesterday a suit brought by I. N. Phelps Stokes, president of the Municipal Art Commission and director of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, to recover $4,259 on income tax paid for the year 1929.
Leonard Del Genio, Harlem battler, outpointed Mickey Duca of Paulsboro, N. J., in the main bout of ten rounds at the Queensboro Arena last night. Duca,
Mrs. Mary A. O'Brien, widow of Charles J. O'Brien who founded the printing firm in Lafayette Street bearing his name, died on Monday at her home, 2 Montague Terrace, Brooklyn. Her age was 77.

Building activity in Queens during the first half of this year showed an increase of 275 per cent over that recorded for the first half of 1936, Borough President George U. Harvey announced yesterday.

Featured by higher prices, a strong trend toward "romantic" style treatments, and with manufacturers predicting a substantial volume of early business from retailers, the Fall season in women's apparel got off to a good start here yesterday.

Unlicensed remittances sent abroad by Americans and other foreign residents for goods imported to Japan will be limited to 1,000 yen instead of 30,000 yen, beginning Aug. 1, officials announced today.

The conclusion of the extended holiday plus the season's last appearance at Lewisohn Stadium of Vladimir Golschmann restored to last night's Philharmonic-Symphony concert the attendance customary at the weekday programs, that is, about 3,500. Other audience inducements were clear skies and two works by Beethoven.

President Roosevelt will prepare for publication next Spring a selection of public documents dealing with his administrations as Governor of New York and as President, it was announced at the White House today.

Mrs. Francis Clark is to give a dinner at Wrentham House on Saturday night in honor of her son-in-law and daughter, Mr. and Mrs. Robert R. Hitt, who will arrive on Friday with their daughter, Miss Diana Hitt.
Sixty new airports, almost all of them for military purposes, are under construction by 25,000 workmen in Italy, an official announcement disclosed today.

President Robert M. Hutchins of the University of Chicago announced yesterday, through The Associated Press, that he had accepted appointment to the board of governors of St. John's College in Maryland to assist in "a revival of the ancient purposes of education."

Some 400 employes of the Lily Tulip Cup Corporation of College Point, Queens, voted last night at Eskotter's Hotel, College Point, to forsake the American Federation of Labor for the Committee for Industrial Organization.
Fordham Rd, (11-3184), s e cor of Walton Ave., 74x131; William H. C. Pletz to Teachers Insurance and Annuity Association, 522 Fifth Ave., extends mortgages to July 1, 1942, at 4 per cent: $172,800.
Seventy-seven New Jersey business and professional men, all commissioned Army Reserve officers of the 312th Infantry, will leave their homes Thursday to begin a fourteen-day tour of active duty here.
Mrs. Tokuko Nakano, former champion of Japan, was among the winners as the Philadelphia and District women's grass court tennis championship opened at the Germantown Cricket Club today.
A thousand animal doctors are expected to gather at the Hotel New Yorker this morning for a threeday meeting of the Eastern States Veterinary Conference.

Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. stated today that approval of the State Industrial Board was necessary to incorporation of all workers' organizations formed for "mutual benefit, protection and advancement or for regulation of hours of labor, working conditions and wages."
Captain Paul J. Dashiell, U.S.N. (retired), one of the leading figures in the early days of American college football, died here today at the age of 69.
Nine men were arrested yesterday on charges of obtaining money under false pretenses after a raid on a house at 1,141 Brooklyn Avenue, Brooklyn. According to the police,

Reorganization of the $2,150,000 certificated mortgage on the sixteen-story apartment building, with stores, on the northeast corner of Second Avenue and Sixty-eighth Street has been completed, it was announced yesterday by Sidney Rossman, attorney for the certificate holders committee.

The Nassau County grand jury handed up an indictment today charging second degree burglary on two counts to Joseph Sroczynski, 53 years old, a butcher, of Jamaica, Queens. He was arrested last Friday in Hoboken as he was preparing to sail for Poland on the liner Batory.
W. Elliott's Cournt Tetrarch, gelded son of Reigh Count, today won the Shadow Lake claiming purse, mile and a sixteenth feature at Rockingham Park. He paid $15.50 for a $2 mutuel ticket.
REMEMBERING always that the weather and Dizzy Dean are subject to change without notice, everything else is set and in place for the big baseball festivities in Washington today.
The difficult transatlantic flight safely navigated, Captain A. S. Wilcockson and the crew of the Imperial Airways flying boat Caledonia rested in this outlying Newfoundland town tonight.

In response to calls for statements of condition as of June 30 issued by the Controller of the Currency and the board of governors of the Federal Reserve System, additional banks and trust companies made public yesterday their reports as of the end of the halfyear.

The Netherlands was the, largest purchaser of arms, ammunition and implements of war from the United States during June, according to the monthly report on export licenses issued by the State Department today.

Many members of the Summer colony and their guests attended the first in a series of bridge tournaments for this season which was held tonight at the Shinnecock Hills Golf Club. Mrs. Goodhue Livingston gave a dinner at the clubhouse, her party later entering the tournament.
The property occupied by the two five-story buildings at 53-55 East Fifty-ninth Street has been leased by the Nielmo Realty Corporation, the owner of the Hotel Delmonico, from Gustave S. Boehm.
Lieutenant Bronius Oskinis of the Aero Club of Lithuania partially wrecked his "Kaunas" soaring plane in a forced landing today on Elmira Reformatory property five miles from Harris Hill.

With both the thermometer and the general enthusiasm rising rapidly to what may develop into a new high, Washington tonight took on a world series atmosphere as a horde of men, all talking baseball, descended on the capital to take high command for the next twenty-four hours.

Mr. and Mrs. Ronald Eliot Curtis of 400 East Fifty-eighth Street have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Madeleine Curtis, to James W. Walsh Jr. of this city and Lawrence, L. I., son of the late Mr. and Mrs. J. W. Walsh.

President Roosevelt parried questions' today concerning his attitude toward John L. Lewis and sit-down strikes. Asked at -his press conference about the report that he and Mr. Lewis had broken off relations, the President said such reports did not need comment.
Mrs. Helen Pierson Curtis, who with her husband, the Rev. Frederick S. Curtis, was engaged in missionary work in Japan and Korea for forty years, died yesterday at her home here. Her age was 74.

Mach of the following Reserve officers is ordered to active duty for a period of six months, effective July 6. Each officer will proceed to the Presidio of San Francisco, Calif., for assignment and duty in connection with CCC activities:

On instructions from the National Labor Relations Board in Washington, Charles A. Wood, the board's trial examiner, ordered today that a transcript be taken of off-the-record arguments and discussions in the board's case against the Inland Steel Company.
The Maritime Commission announced today the sale of four steel cargo vessels now in the government's laid-up fleet to the National Bulk Carriers, Inc., of New York, for $745,000.
A new series of trials in the six-yearold Scottsboro case was ordered today when two of eight Negro defendants pleaded innocent to rape charges in arraignment before Judge W., W. Callahan.

Dr. Ernst F. S. Hanfstaengl, former confidant of Chancellor Adolf Hitler and for a long time head of foreign press affairs for the German National Socialist party, has no intention of returning to Germany, it was stated authoritatively today.

Federal Judge Francis G. Caffey approved yesterday a twentyyear film-rental franchise between the Roxy Theatres Corporation and the- Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation, in line with a previously approved reorganization plan under which the latter company will operate the Roxy concern.

The first International trotting race bringing together Greyhound, champion of America, and Muscletone, ranking Italian performer, in a home-and-abroad series, moved a step nearer yesterday with the announcement that the invader would land in this country about Aug. 1, The Associated Press reported.

In a radio talk yesterday from Paris, where he is attending as United States delegate the International Congress of Music Educators, Dr. Walter Damrosch, conductor, and music counsel for the National Broadcasting Company, praised new methods of musical training of children.

Sir Hubert Wilkins, who is making preparations at Aalesund, Norway, for an expedition to Antartica, informed the press today that he would charter the Norwegian ship Wyatt Earp for his expedition ship because she has proved herself suitable for Polar cruises.

Marion T. Ross, nationally known cartoonist, art instructor and interior decorator, died today at his home in Oakland, after an illness of three weeks. A heart attack was the cause of death. He was 56 years old.
After three days of idleness owing to rain and lack of a breeze, the first round of the championships for the National Model

Two contracts for the construction of new educational buildings have been awarded to the William L. Crow Construction Company. On Pelham Parkway, just north of the intersection of Pelham Parkway and the Boston Post Road, Bronx, the builders will erect a two-story structure for the New York Institute for the Education of the Blind.

Unison Realty Company, Patrick J. Carroll, president, sold to the First Jersey Corporation the threestory brick store building at 625 Bergenline Avenue, on the southwest corner of Sixteenth Street, West New York, N. J., for $13,500 over a first mortgage of $60,000 held by the Weehawken Trust Company.
Pairings and starting of the American qualifiers in the British open golf championship for the first two rounds of the tournament proper tomorrow and Thursday:
A strike of employes of the Pan American Airways Mexican subsidiary, the Compania Mexicana de Aviacion, has been called for July 15, it was announced today.
Thirteen entries have been signed for the annual international lifeboat races to be held Sept. 11 off the Bay Ridge shore, it was announced yesterday.

Hampered by floods, unfavorable weather and -the epidemic of strikes, newspaper advertising did not register as large gains in the first half of the year as had been expected, a check-up yesterday revealed.
Prince Theodore, nephew of the late Czar of Russia, said today that he recognized the "utter futility" of the hopes of the Romanoffs for returning to the land they once ruled.

The biggest field in the history of model aviation, more than 500 entrants, will compete in thirteen events of the tenth annual national championship model aircraft meet, opening here tomorrow, according to Thomas B. Colby, chairman of the contest committee.
The Rev. Henry J. Mahoney, pastor of All Saints Roman Catholic Church here, died at the St. Francis Hospital last night after a brief illness. He was 55 years old.

Judge Carroll C. Hincks in the United States District Court here made possible today the early termination of proceedings in the attempt of the New York, Westchester Boston Railway Company to reorganize under Section 77B of the bankruptcy laws when he accepted the "final" report and accounting of Clinton S. Bardo, trustee for the Westchester system. No objections were made to the report.

Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain has accepted the position of honorary president of the League of Nations Union on condition that its members refrain from attacking his government, as they did Stanley Baldwin's for its obvious lack of enthusiasm over the League's usefulness as a means of keeping the peace.
Mid-South cotton growers and classers saw a demonstration today of a robot cotton-classing instrument developed by Dr. K. L. Hertel, Professor of Physics at the University of Tennessee.

The Bethlehem Steel Corporation obtained a contract for a building in Detroit for the Chrysler Corporation involving 4,000 tons of structural steel; in addition to 3,700 tons for two schools here, one in Brooklvn and one in the Bronx.

More than six hundred alumni, faculty members and other' educators attended funeral services for Dr. John A. Cousens, president of Tufts College for nineteen years, in Goddard Chapel on the college campus here today. Dr. Cousens died last Friday.

The medical profession faces the anomalous situation of having created a demand for more psychiatric treatment than there are physicians qualified to handle, Dr. Leland E. Hinsie, assistant director of the New York State Psychiatric Institute and Hospital, declared in a study of psychotherapy published today by the Columbia University Press.

Ranger, Harold S. Vanderbilt's new sloop, tonight was selected to defend the America's Cup against T. 0. M. Sopwith's Endeawour II. They will meet off here on July 31 in the first race of the international match, the sixteenth one for the old silver mug brought here from England eighty-six years ago by the historic schooner yacht America.

In a second accounting to the administration of the Jersey Mortgage and Title Guaranty Company, in trusteeship, Carl K. Withers, Commissioner of Banking and Insurance of the State of New Jersey, reported yesterday that on April 30, 1937, combined assets of the company and of its real estate subsidiary, Raeburn, Inc., exceeded combined liabilities by $1,660,735.

If the National Broadcasting Company tent could have held them, 25,000 Boy Scouts would have forced their way into the temporary studio here at the National Jamboree grounds to see and hear Lowell Thomas, news commentator, in his regular broadcast over a national network.

Many of the striking employes of the American Smelting and Refining Company plant here returned to work today, but not until the furnaces have been heated during the next few days will the majority of the 1,440 employes return to their posts. However,

Steel ingot production increased last week when the seasonal movement was still downward and the adjusted index advanced to 113.2 from 110.0 in the previous week. For the week ended July 4, 1936, the index was 111.3.
The Interstate Commerce Commission announced today the postponement to Sept. 1 of hearings on the reorganization plan of the Chicago, Indianapolis Louisville Railroad, originally set for July 27.

Traffic through the Panama Canal decreased in June. A total of 472 commercial vessels passed through the waterway last month and paid tolls of $2,070,337.89, as compared with 544 vessels and tolls of $2,376,706.36 in May.
The strength and moderately improved activity in the securities markets in the last few days have completely changed the attitude of the financial community.

Col. Gen. Hermann Goering, German Air Minister, is believed to be planning to revive medieval kings' hunting sports in the Reich. Two German experts have arrived here to buy Icelandic hunting falcons.

A Cabinet decree constituting the Department for General Affairs was issued today. The department will be under the direct authority of the Premier, who in the future as a rule will not hold other portfolios, thus enabling him to devote his full attention to coordinaion of the government's policy and such questions as require special consideration.
A first mortgage of $85,000 has been arranged by Schimmer, Kerner Feder with the Metropolitan Life Insurance Co on the 5-story apartment house at 593-601 E 141st
Mrs. Elizabeth O'Shea, mother of ten actors and actresses and reputed to have been the benefactress of Charles Chaplin in his youth, died today after a long illness at Brighton. Her age was 93.
Joe Louis will very likely make the first defense of his recently won world heavyweight championship in this city within the next two months.

Through monumental windows of stained glass, Uncertain morning sunlight wanly steals; Kaleidoscopes all comers as they pass: Each dowager in splendor as she kneels On padded satin knees, confessing all; Devout young matrons on whose pious breasts

Hundreds of investors victimized in stock swindles have had a total of $525,768.70 in cash and securities restored to them in the first six months of 1937 through the New York City Bureau of Securities, of which Ambrose V. McCall, Assistant Attorney General, is in charge.
The War Depat ment released the following orders today dated July 3: LIEUTENANT COLONELS Baade, P. W. (Inf.), General Staff Corps, one month leave, July 15.

Edwin N. Clark of Robb, Clark Bennitt was elected yesterday a director and chairman of the executive committee of Condor Pictures, Inc. This followed the resignation of George A. Hirliman as president of the company, a position which remains vacant.

William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, called upon the organized labor of Seattle today to support the Teamsters Union in its fight for recognition as the bargaining agency for employes on The Seattle Star.

Ralph Strafaci of the golfing Strafacis won the one-day tournament of the Metropolitan Golf Association at the Plandome Club today by returning a card of 37, 35-72, which bettered the two second-place scores by three strokes.
Miss Hattie Hood, said to have been one of the first women department store buyers in New York, died yesterday at the home of a nephew here in her seventy-first year.

Submitting for the second time the only bid meeting all requirements, the Weaver Manufacturing Company of Springfield, Ill., proposed today to furnish automobile testing equipment to the State for $188,077. This figure is about $10,000 higher than the previous bid and was attributed by the company to cost advances in the equipment and installation now specified.
French and United States art authorities met today for the first international exchange of scientific methods to detect fraud in paintings.

More than the religious issue is involved in the arrest on Monday of Professor BACHNIN, chairman of the council in Dr. NIEMOELLER'S parish in Dahlem. With nearly fifty other pastors of the Confessional opposition, Pastor NIEMOELLER was jailed because he preached stubbornly against the suppression of religious liberty in Germany. But his chief vestryman,
Bernd Rosemeyer accepted a check for $22,100 yesterday just as nonchalantly as he had steered his high-powered Auto Union racer around Roosevelt Raceway to win the second Vanderbilt Cup race.

A youth who identified himself as Maurice John Taylor of 30-69 Hobart Street, Long Island City, Queens, was arrested and charged with burglary and possession of burglars' tools early last night when he was found in a secondfloor apartment of a rooming house at 51 East Sixty-fifth Street. The building is adjacent to President Roosevelt's town house at 49.

Creameries of America, Inc., Los Angeles, has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission under the Securities Act of 1933 a registration statement covering 506,647 shares of common stock of $1 par value, through voting trust certificates.
A Maine cat that struck the fancy of William Zorach, New York sculptor, a few years ago will become familiar to posterity in the Metropolitan Museum of Art.
Miss Anne Depew Paulding, Louis S. Higgins, Mrs. Herman F. Scharman, Miss Edith V. Sanford, Mrs. James P. Linahan, in Hampshire House, 150 Central Park South; Douglas L. Elliman Co., Inc., broker.

Frank Handren, recently elected president of the Park Tilford Import Corporation, will sail on the Queen Mary today to visit the various wine and liquor concerns abroad which the company represents here.

A temporary order restraining 196 defendants, including national offi-I cers of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, from interfering with the business of the Donnelly Garment Company here was issued by Federal Judge Merrill E. Otis.

The French naval base planned for the Bay of Cam Ranh, in Indo-China, remains only a plan. No appropriation has yet been made for this project, and there is nothing definite beyond the probability that the base will be established if and when Great Britain asks France to construct the base as a mutual help against "the yellow peril."
Al Roth, 136 1/2, Bronx, gained the decision over Pete Mascia, 140 1/4, Williamsburg, in the feature eightround bout at the Canarsie Stadium before a crowd of 3,000 last night.

The Associated Gas and Electric Company, in the last of a series of proposed mergers of the system's subsidiaries operating in Pennsylvania, has filed with the State Public Utility Commission an application to merge the Metropolitan Edison Company with the Pennsylvania Edison Company.
The squirrels here that have been "making pests of themselves" defied today the efforts of John Butler, agent of the Society for Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, to capture them.

Earl's Mr. Will, making the first start of his career, swept to a straight-heat victory today in the $1,500 Rainy Day Sweepstakes, feature of the second day of Grand Circuit racing at the North Randall track.

Mrs. Edna Gladys Jenson, 40, of Elizabeth, N. J., who pleaded guilty on Saturday of abandoning six-yearold Charles W. Ditmars of Rahway, N. J., in a Providence theatre last Wednesday, was placed on probation by District Judge Maurice Robinson today.
THE local-color interest in American literature goes back at least 100 years to Timothy Flint, James Hall and other writers who found their material on what was then the MiddleWestern frontier.

The German press this evening devotes considerable space to a Bilbao report that the Valencia government will soon make use of poison gas. Preparations for this, it is charged in a report put out by the official agency here, have been under way for some months under the direction of a Soviet chemist working under Moscow's orders.

Governor Lehman announced today the appointment of three members, completing formation of -the Temporary State Commission to make a survey of the scenic, historical and commercial assets of the Hudson River valley and to draft a comprehensive plan for the preservation of the natural beauty, improvement and development of the valley.
Rammed accidentally yesterday by the United States Naval Reserve boat Hawk, the showboat Dixiana, tied up at Michigan City, Ind., today became a showboat without a show.

Employers, making their first move to break a three-week-old strike which has crippled the wool market here, reopened their warehouses today and invited "former employes to return to work without discrimination."
Miss Isabelle Hallin said today that the town school board would have a fight on its hands if its members expected her to accept an "invitation" to resign as a teacher in the high school.

Plans for the eleventh annual convention of the New York Society of Physiotherapists, to be held here on July 24, were discussed last night at the society's eleventh annual business meeting in Masonic Hall, 71 West Twenty-third Street.

Representative Mitchell, Illinois Democrat, only Negro member of Congress, said today that he would go to the Naval Academy tomorrow to investigate the resignation of George J. Triver, Negro youth whom he appointed several weeks ago.

Stockholders of the Middle West Corporation held their annual meeting here today, electing three new directors, approving a change in the meeting date and asking the questions expected at an assembly of dividendless stockholders.

Colonel Alton S. Miller, a vice president of the Koppers Coke Company, testified yesterday in Supreme Court that E. L. Phillips Co. had undercharged the Long Island Lighting Company by $190,000 in the ten-year period ended with 1932.

Henry Howson, a patent attorney, died at his Summer home in Glenmoore yesterday in his seventy-ninth year. He was vice president of the Franklin Institute and since 1898 a member of its board of managers.

Former President Carlos E. Restrepo died at Medellin today at the age of 70. He was considered the "grand old man of Colombian politics" and was largely responsible for the election of the late Olaya Herrera and the return of the Liberal party to power after almost a half century of Conservative rule.

Weak support and occasional wildness cost Tony Kaufmann, veteran Rochester right-hander, a four-hit ball game tonight as Toronto took advantage of both to register a 7-to-3 victory over the Red Wings.
Good pitching enabled Syracuse and Baltimore to divide their International League double header today, the Chiefs taking the first, 8 to 0, and the Orioles the second, 2 to 1.

Negotiations for reopening the Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company's plant at Indiana Harbor apparently had reached a deadlock tonight when Governor Townsend announced after a conference with Sheet and Tube officials that they had refused to agree to a plan for settling employer-worker differences after reopening.

Announcement was made by the War Department today of the death of Colonel Thomas J. Flynn of the Army Medical Corps at Jefferson Barracks, Mo., on Sunday at the age of 56. He had been stationed in St. Louis.
James J. Judge and Brigham K. Watson have become associated with Soucy, Swartswelter Co., the former as manager of the trading department and the latter on the staff of the investment department.

Large blocks of gray Indiana limestone, measuring about four by seven by six feet, will be used in the exterior construction on the unusual two-story and basement building in New Rochelle to be occupied by Arnold Constable Co. as its Westchester County store, according to plans just filed by Kenneth Franzheim, New York architect, with the New Rochelle Department of Buildings.

A total of 5,878 students attending the twenty-three vocational high schools of this city were placed in jobs during the last school term, Morris E. Siegel, director of the continuation and evening schools, announced yesterday.

State and municipal financing for June amounted to $107,358,546, compared with $118,092,250 in the same month of 1936, according to The Daily Bond Buyer of New York. For the first six months of this year, such financing aggregated $618,904,915, against $634,748,325 for the same period last year.

Accused of having capitalized on her reputed powers of witchcraft, Mrs. Florence Fiacco, 25 years old, of 1,065 Sixty-first Street, Brooklyn, was locked up in the Fort Hamilton police station at 4 A. M. yesterday on a charge of grand larceny.
Delegates to the annual meeting of the International Association of Clothing Designers put their heads together today and decided that American manhood is growing up.

Unless the wholly unexpected happens in the final round, scheduled for tomorrow afternoon and evening, Samuel Reshevsky of New York, United States chess champion, now leading by half a point, is expected to carry off the first prize in the international masters' tournament at the Kurhaus.

Princess Erik, the former Lois Frances Booth, daughter of an Ottawa lumber merchant, plans to marry her young Danish secretary, Thorkild Juelsberg, in Paris within the next few days, it was learned tonight.

HARVEY FERGUSSON'S new novel concerns the gay caballero of a Southwestern town. It shows what might happen to a virile man. of action in a settled community. Had Morgan Riley, hero of "The Life of Riley" (Knopf, $2), truly sought complete personal fulfillment, he probably would promptly have been mugged and fingerprinted and put away on a prison farm.

Rene Belbenoit, 38-year-old former French journalist and famous fugitive from Devil's Island, the French penal colony off the coast of Guiana, from which he escaped five times, walked into the New York offices of the North American Newspaper Alliance yesterday and revealed that he had made his way undetected into the United States.

John Curtis of Ithaca, virtually unknown in metropolitan tennis, sprang the biggest upset thus far in the Queens County singles championship at the Seminole Club in Forest Hills when he eliminated Frank Bowden, second-rated contestant from New York, in one of the three fourth-round matches yesterday.

The price of bar gold in London rose yesterday to a premium over the price of the metal in the United States for the first time in months. At the same time, paradoxically, it dropped to a new low mark for this year, in terms of sterling.

It was announced last night at a mass meeting of employes of the Childs Company that more than 50 per cent of the employes had joined or signed to join the Childs unit of the Hotel, Restaurant and Cafeteria Employes Organization Committee.

About eighty internes, representing 500 in city hospitals, appeared before the committee on local laws of the Board-of Estimate yesterday on behalf of a bill passed by the Board of Aldermen that would give them annual compensation of $1,000 instead of the present 50 cents a day.

Hugh McLaughlin Courtney, a member of the real estate and insurance firm of Courtney Donnelly in Brooklyn and a grandson of the late Hugh McLaughlin, Democratic leader of Brooklyn, died on Monday at his home, 591 Ocean Avenue, at the age of 38.

Trading was fair on most classes of traefa meats. Steer beef was strong to higher and some fresh pork cuts were higher. Other classes showed little change. Early trading in kosher meats was slow, with beef lower and other classes about steady, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture.

A three-day registration period for enrollment in Columbia University's thirty-eighth Summer session begins today on Morningside Heights. On the strength of increased Summer registration figures at other institutions, Registrar Edward J. Grant predicted yesterday that Columbia's current Summer enrollment would exceed that of last year by about 10 per cent.

The marriage of Miss Flora Fergusson, daughter of Mrs. Arthur R. Fergusson of Bryn Mawr to Henry Dawson Furniss Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. H. Dawson Furniss of New York will take place on Oct. 9 in the First Unitarian Church, Philadelphia.

Death Announced Retired Fireman Stephen A. Gandolfi, formerly a member of Engine 253, residing at 1,015 Seventy-first Street, Brooklyn, died July 4. Pensioned Fireman first grade Edward J. Kennedy (2), of Engine 80, is retired own application for physical disability, on an annual pension of $2,250.

Time has caught up with the girls who regarded the World War as a grand adventure and a sacred cause, one of them admitted yesterday. Nineteen years removed from rolling drums and blaring bugles, she asserted, hundreds of women veterans who were wounded, gassed or shell-shocked live out their days in the dreary monotony of hospital wards, jettisoned by the nation they served, and helpless to improve their state.

Loew's, Inc., had a net income of $11,714,722 after expenses, depreciation, subsidiaries' preferred dividends and other charges, according to the statement covering the forty weeks ended on June 3- announced today by David Bernstein, vice president and treasurer.
James Allardice, former Jersey City Alderman and member of the Hudson County Tax Board, died today in Orange Memorial Hospital in his seventy - sixth year following a mastoid operation.

R. I. STATE MEN'S SINGLES Third Round Gardnar Mulloy, U. of Miami, defeated David Burt, Harvard, 7--5, 6--3; Howard Stephens, Yale, defeated Robert Decker, Longwood, 6--4, 4--6, 6--3; Robert Low, Choate School, defeated McLeod Stephens, Yale, 6--3, 6--3: Joseph Abrams,

While the unexpected stoppage of production in the coat and suit industry, beginning today, injected an uncertain element into the Fall merchandising situation, buyers now arriving in the wholesale markets here in large numbers were reassured by indications that no long strike is in prospect.

With one death from diphtheria in Brooklyn and one in Queens last week, the total of such deaths for the first half of this year reached forty, as compared with only thirtyfive for the entire year of 1936, according to statistics made public yesterday by Dr. John L. Rice, Health Commissioner.

A waterproof velvet wrap for a bride was shown at the fashion revue staged by the Velvet Guild in the grand ballroom of the Hotel Astor last night, at which American fabrics and designs were presented.

The marriage of Miss Katharine Hellman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edgar A. Hellman of 311 West Seventy-first Street, to Philip deYoung, son of Samuel deYoung, took place yesterday afternoon at the home of the bride's parents. The ceremony was performed by Magistrate Anthony F. Burke.

Mrs. Marion Turpie of Plandome, metropolitan champion, took low gross honors today in the one-day medal play of the Women's Long Island Golf Association tournament at the Sands Point Golf Club. Mrs. Turpie scored a

The Transport Workers Union, C. I. O. affiliate, renewed yesterday its drive for a collective bargaining referendum and a closed shop on the city's Independent Subway System, where it claims to have enrolled a substantial majority of the 4,500 employes.

George B. Graves, who was the only assistant to the Governor that New York State ever had, a position which was created for him during the term of former Governor Alfred E. Smith, died today at the age of 61. He had served the State in various capacities and rose from a $12-aweek page boy in the State Department of Education to one that paid $12.000 a year.

The Court of Errors and Appeals, New Jersey's highest tribunal, upheld the State Supreme Court today in dismissing service of complaints on four companies named as co-defendants in Governor Hoffman's $100,000 slander suit against Boake Carter, radio commentator, for statements on the Governor's activities in the Hauptmann case.

Miss Dorothy Shaver, first vice president of Lord Taylor, sailed yesterday on the Queen Mary for Europe. She will attend the couturier openings in Paris to select models for Lord Taylor and will also visit London, Vienna and Flonrnce.

The United States Circuit Court of Appeals heard argument and reserved decision yesterday on a motion by Isidor J. Kresel, representing a committee of stockholders in the bankruptcy of Orpheum Circult, Inc., for the right to appeal from an order of Federal Judge Robert P. Patterson directing the sale of Orpheum to the Stadium

Mound Bayou, a bustling, allNegro community founded by former slaves, is getting dressed up for its fiftieth birthday party. Mayor Green, a lawyer, Harvard graduate and son of one of the founders, will deliver the memorial address.
The Earl of Moray broke precedent to light a cigarette and threw the House of Lords into turmoil tonight by his remarks on insanity as a cause for divorce. He was escorted from the chamber.
Dr. Karl Ritter, chief of the economic section of the Foreign Office, has been appointed Ambassador to Brazil. He will leave for his new post in the early Autumn.

The mysterious conditions under which the Spanish tanker Campoanor left Port Verdon last midnight without the formality of clearing have given rise to rumors that the vessel might have been seized by an Insurgent crew and taken to Bilbao.

Colonel Herbert S. Wilgus, reserve officer of the United States Army, whose home was in Albany, N. Y., died of a heart attack at the Fort du Pont Hospital last night. His age was 63. He arrived Sunday for two weeks of active duty. His name was erroneously given as William J. Wilgus in a report of his death last night.

There has been "informal discussion" in the Department of Justice as to whether evidence might be given to a Brooklyn (N. Y.) Federal grand jury charging Ellis Parker and Ellis Parker Jr. with violation of the Lindbergh kidnapping law,

A warning that America cannot hope to escape unscathed in a world situation replete with menace of international war was sounded today before the University of Virginia's Institute of Public Affairs by Sumner Welles, Under-Secretary of State, Dr. Francisco Castello Najera, Ambassador from Mexico, and Frederic N. Coudert of New York, former special assistant attorney general.

Miss Peggy Morris, daughter of Mrs. Dudley Mixer Morris of this city, has chosen Sept. 10 for her marriage to Russell Sherman Cate, son of Mrs. Russell D. Cate, also of Bridgeport. An informal home ceremony has been planned, with a small reception to follow.

John Cecil E. Dorman, a rewrite man with the New York City News Association, died yesterday in the Broad Street Hospital, where he was taken on Tuesday after he had collapsed at his office, 2 Lafayette Street. He was 37 years old and lived at 42 Horatio Street.

A threat to "wipe out" Chinese troops unless they agreed to disarm immediately terminated at 10 o'clock this morning a sanguinary five-hour clash between the Chinese and a Japanese force on the outskirts of Peiping.
Dismantling of the monoplane in which three Russians made their transpolar flight from Moscow here two weeks ago, was begun today by V. Berndnix, who arrived yesterday from Moscow.
Germany's Davis cup tennis stars, Baron Gottfried Von Cramm and Heinrich Henkel, and the ranking woman ace, Miss Marie Louise Horn, will start a world tour after the German championships in August.

In a smoky southwest by west breeze of from eleven to twelve and one-half miles an hour strength, Chandler Hovey's Rainbow and Gerard B. Lambert's Yankee went to sea today to help tune up the America's Cup defender Ranger. Harold S.

The disappearance of Jacob Doletzky, chief director of Tass, the Soviet official news agency, whose arrest has been rumored for some weeks, was explained today in the July 3 issue of the Ural Worker, published at Sverdlovsk.

Officials of the New York Curb Exchange moved yesterday to set in motion an investigation to allow higher commissions on its transactions. The secretary was instructed to prepare statistical data to guide the committee on commissions in its decision whether to follow the possible lead of the New York Stock Exchange or to go its own way.

Kid Chocolate moved further along the comeback trail last night by outpointing rugged Charlie Gomer in the eight-round feature bout at Dyckman Oval before a crowd of 3,500. The former world featherweight champion came on strongly in the last few rounds to gain the verdict.
Fist fights broke out and two automobiles were overturned today as several hundred pickets blocked attempts to - reopen the Industria Rayon Corporation's plant, strike bound for fourteen weeks.

The Truck Sales Corporation, distributors of Studebaker trucks, leased from the Edgar S. Appleby estate and the Four Plus Corporation the garage and service station at 649 West Fifty-seventh Street. Huberth Huberth were the brokers.
The Senate made the President's Federal Court Reorganization Bill its unfinished business because the administration had the votes for that purpose.

An important deal has just been closed in the Borough Hall section of Brooklyn, whereby Samson Rosenblatt and Herman Wacht, acting through the 1,925 Holding Corporation, have taken a lease for a further term of twenty-one years, running to May 1, 1960, on the store property taking in the triangular block bounded by Fulton, Willoughby and Pearl Streets.
The Board of Tax Appeals settled for $415,861 today ten tax cases heard recently in New York City involving deficiencies aggregating $674,690 assessed by the Bureau of Internal Revenue.

Dr. Russell E. Blaisdell, superintendent of the Rockland State Hospital, issued a statement today denying there was an increase in the number of mental patients escaping from the institution and saying those who did escape were mostly of the "quiet types."

Criticism of some features of the Wagner-Steagall Housing Bill, now before Congress, and counter proposals for meeting the slum problem, were presented by Clarke G. Dailey, president of the Real Estate Board of New York, in a radio talk yesterday over Station WNYC.

Harry C. France, financial counselor and lecturer on finance at New York University, advocated yesterday a wider study of investment finance to prevent a return of the "bullish" condition that prevailed in the stock market from 1927 to 1929. He spoke on this

Bismark, a German shepherd dog, once again has escaped the death penalty for biting children and is under parole, pending good behavior, in the custody of his master, Robert E. Cook of 239 New Main Street, Yonkers.

King Carol today will start a fiveweek tour of foreign countries incognito which will include a long stay in Scotland with one of the leaders of the pro-German group in Great Britain, the Marquess of Londonderry.

The building on the north.west corner of Roosevelt Avenue and Seventy-ninth Street, Jackson Heights, Queens, containing four apartments and five stores, has been sold by the United States Life Insurance Company to a corporation controlled by Henry Mansfield, attorney. Arthur L. Dryfos,

The report of the British Royal Commission did not come as a surprise to the Palestine public. That the country would be divided every one had felt certain, but how and under what conditions were subjects of conjecture.

Mrs. Thomas Jefferson Mumford heads the committee to receive on Friday afternoon at the reception and tea which will open Guild Hall's activities for the Summer. That evening, Mrs. Charles De Kay will be heard in the John Drew Memorial Theatre, Guild Hall, in a series of original sketches, memories of New York in the Eighteen Nineties.

The produce workers' strike was settled late tonight. The unloading of cars began and resumption of regular deliveries was planned early today. All pickets were immediately withdrawn from the Pennsylvania Railroad produce and fruit terminal sidings. Terms of the settlement were not divulged.

Proofs of claims aggregating several million dollars against the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad as a result of its disaffirmance of a lease with the Old Colony Railroad Company were presented today to Judge Carroll C. Hincks in United States District Court here by Robert D. Dodge, counsel for the trustees of the Old Colony. Judge Hincks adjourned

The working committee of the All India Congress [Nationalist] party today voted to accept office after three months of unsuccessful attempt to obtain from the British Government specific assurances that Provincial Governors would not use their "special powers" to nullify the party program.

Copper exports from the United States were valued at $9,880,966 in May, compared with $7,811,651 in April and $3,625,679 in May, 1936, according to a report published today by the metals and minerals division of the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce. A large proportion of the foreign shipments in the month was made up of copper which had been imported for refining and re-export.

President Roosevelt cheered in high good humor along with 32,000 other baseball fans as the American League All Stars made life miserable for the pitchers of the National League today. Postmaster General Farley,
Mrs. Harry B. Spaulding of this city has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Lucile A. Forman, to Chauncey Jerome Hamlin Jr., son of Chauncey J. Hamlin, also of Buffalo.
Mrs. Alice M. Fahnestock obtained a divorce on June 28 at Carson City, Nev., from Harris Fahnestock Jr., it was learned here today. She charged cruelty. The suit was not contested.

Dunbar W. Bostwick, former Yale poloist and millionaire sportsman from Old Westbury, L. I., today captured the first Grand Circuit race of his amateur driving career on the third day's program at North Randall.

Eight more of America's outstanding athletes arrived in New York, the nation's temporary track and field capital, yesterday and promptly tested the cinders at Randalls Island Stadium, where they will compete Sunday in the World Labor Athletic Carnival. They found it very much to their liking, groomed to perfect shape.

In a series of unanimous decisions which disappointed Democratic leaders and caused jubilation among Republicans, the State Supreme Court today declared unconstitutional all except one of the recently enacted Ripper laws affecting Philadelphia.

District headquarters of the Works Progress Administration here will be eliminated for reasons of economy about Aug. 1, according to word received today by District Director Thomas L. Cotton from regional headquarters in Albany.

George Frost retired on July 1 as a partner in J. W. Bowen Co., members of the New York Stock Exchange. Worthington Pump and Machinery Corporation Class A 7 per cent cumulative preferred stock, $100 par value, "stamped," and Class B
Close of play scores in first-class English cricket matches started today: Yorkshire, 238 (Turner 77, Wood 58, OwenSmith five for 74); Middlesex, 54 for two wickets; at Sheffield.

Amid a blazing hot setting which included in its cast President Roosevelt and a sweltering, shirt-sleeve crowd of 32,000 that jammed every available inch of Griffith Stadium, the might of the American League returned to power today as the carefullychosen forces of Joseph V. McCarthy crushed Bill Terry's handpicked National League array in major league baseball's fifth annual all-star game.

Joseph Clark Baldwin 3d, Estate at Katonah, N. Y., known as Happy Valley, from Robert L. Fowler Jr., through the Kenneth H. Clapp Co. Thomas Bartold, bungalow at Saugerties, N. Y., from C. I. Schoentag; Albertl Romano, brokers.

Funeral services for Frank P. Strack, co-founder of the old clothing firm of Spielman, Strack Co., in Newark, and member of an old Newark family, will be held here tomorrow at the home of his brother.
An appeal from a $10,000,000 municipal personal property tax assessment was filed today by the Public Service Corporation of New Jersey with the Essex Tax Board.

Dr. Giuseppe Farina, who finished fifth in the Vanderbilt Cup race at Roosevelt Raceway Monday, accompanied by Tazio Nuvolari, ace of the Italian racing team, who failed to finish the contest, sailed for home on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary yesterday.

The Cafe de la Paix and three of the largest cafes on the Champs-Elysees were closed today by a,strike of waiters and other employes dissatisfied with the compromise reached with the government over the threatened hotel cafe lockout last week.

The committee on stock list of the New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that it had authorized the listing of 10,000 additional convertible preference shares, $3 series, and 20.000 additional common shares of McKesson Robbins, Inc.

Under proportional representation Free State elections are usually close. When in 1933 Mr. DE VALERA, who had got no majority in the Dail the year before and was weary of depending on his Labor allies, sprang a general election in the most favorable circumstances, he won 77 out of 153 seats.

Mrs. Russell Bennett sailed Tuesday .on the Excalibur for Naples, where she will join friends for a Mediterranean cruise to Egypt. Her daughter, Miss Florence Harris, will visit her father, Rear Admiral Frederic R. Harris, U. S. N. (retired) at the Atlantic Beach Club before going to Maine.

Enzo Fiermonte, former boxer, automobile racer and husband of Mrs. Madeline Force Astor Dick Fiermonte, was transferred yesterday from the Queens City Prison to the penitentiary at Rikers Island to finish his five-day sentence imposed in Queens Traffic Court on Tuesday.
Mercer County will receive only the regular fee of 50 cents although two clerks spent a day canceling a $160,000,000 mortgage.
Although the Greek censorship prevents all news of the present constitutional crisis from being sent abroad, messages here from Corfu suggest that the situation is grave. It is so serious
" They Came by Night," produced at the Globe Theatre tonight, has the same characteristics that distinguished Barre Lyndon's earlier successful essay in criminology, "The Amazing Dr. .Clltterhouse."

The L. H. Gilmer Company, Philadelphia, filed today a registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 covering 42,000 shares of $5 par value common stock to be offered first to stockholders at $11 a share and thereafter any unsubscribed shares publicly through Walter Lyons Co., Inc., underwriter, at the same price.

Plans for the modernization and expansion of the- nation's airways safeguards, to cost $7,000,000 over the next two years, were announced today by Secretary Roper. Work is already going forward at more than sixty localities on the airlines,

Dr. Louis Robert Eichberg, store physician for Saks Fifth Avenue and Saks Thirty-fourth Street, died Tuesday, his sixty-seventh birthday, at his home, 782 West End Avenue. A native of Champaign, Ill.,

Governor General Blanton Winship left for Washington today, satisfied that Puerto Rico had set a trade record of $215,000,000 in exports and imports for the year ended June 30 that had been exceeded only in one post-war year when sugar sold as high as 23 cents a pound. Imports exceeded $100,000,000 and exports were more than $113,000,000.
The play-by-play description of the allstar game at Griffith Stadium today follows: FIRST INNING NATIONAL--The first pitch to Waner was low and outside.
The annual exhibition of contemporary American paintings and sculpture will open at the Art Association on Saturday afternoon with a private view for members of the association and guests.

More than 1,800 youths from New York, Delaware and New Jersey will arrive at the Citizens Military Training Camp here, Friday morning, it was announced today by Colonel R. E. Beebe, Eighteenth Infantry, commander of the camp. The youths will receive a month's training. An induction ceremony will be held Monday.

The decline of the "commercial horse" as a familiar item in New York's street scenes was lamented yesterday by William Ryan, animal lover by profession and avocation, on the occasion of his twenty-fifth anniversary with the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals.

Mayor La Guardia conferred yesterday with Dock Commissioner John McKenzie at the Summer City Hall on the plans he intends to press before the Board of Estimate a week from tomorrow for acquisition and development of the North Beach Airport in Queens.
Edward Johnson of this place has announced the engagement of his daughter, Miss Eunice Johnson, to Kermit Parker, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry E. Parker, also of New Britain.

Word has been received by relatives here of the marriage on Saturday in Paris of Miss M. Jacqueline Livingston, daughter of Mrs. Robert L. Livingston of Paris and the late Mr. Livingston, to Edward S. J. McVickar 2d of New York, son of Mrs. Dorothea Crouse McVickar of Paris and John A. McVickar of this city.

With a total of 100 for the week ended July 1, retail failures showed an increase over the figures for the previous week and the corresponding period last year, according to the report issued yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc. Declines were shown by both the manufacturing and wholesale groups.

The American Institute of Accountants announced yesterday it will award a prize of $500 in its fiftieth anniversary celebration to be staged Oct. 18 to 22 for the best essay on the subject "To what extent can the practice of accounting be reduced to rules and standards?"

A motion asking President Federico Laredo Bru to inform Congress if the United States Embassy here is exerting pressure on the Cuban Government Commission that now is studying the possibility of effecting a settlement of the defaulted Public Works obligations was presented this afternoon at a secret session of the House of Representatives by Congressman Francisco Lorie Bertot, Liberal, of Oriente Province.

United States SENIOR CABINETMAKER, $1,860 a year; senior carpenter, $1,860; senior electrician, $1,860; senior painter, $1,860; for appointment in Washington, D. C., and immediate vicinity only. Applications must be on file not later than July 20, if received from States other than those named below; July 23, if received from the following States: Arizona, California, Colorado, Idaho,
Leon Trotsky dropped for the moment his war of words with Joseph Stalin and. left this city today for an extensive fishing and hunting trip. Accompanied by only
Nebraska farmers girded today for a last ditch fight against grasshopper hordes which O. S. Bare, entomologist of Nebraska Agricultural College, called the worst State-wide infestation in the nation.

William F. Carey Jr., 24-year-old son of the Commissioner of Sanitation, of 1 Beekman Place, whose automobile was alleged by the police to have struck and injured Dennis Murphy, 31, of 54 West Eighty-second Street, on June 5 at Columbus Avenue and Eighty-second Street, was continued in $200 bail yesterday by Chief Magistrate Jacob Gould Schurman Jr. in Homicide Court on charges of driving while intoxicated and assault.

The sturdiness of the statistical record for the first half of 1937, despite the automotive strikes early in the year and the steel strikes late in the period, has led numerous commentators to the conclusion that, barring unforeseen developments, the record for the second semester should be at least as good as that for the first.

The business property, 50 by 149 feet, at 48-50 Park Avenue, Rutherford, N. J., was sold by the Rutherford Mutual Loan and Building Association to the Hurwitz Realty Company, a subsidiary of the M. Z. Hurwitz Company, Max Z. Hurwitz, president.

Playing unruffled golf over a course strewn with the wreckage of those American hopes that stood so high yesterday, Ed Dudley of Philadelphia returned a 70 today to lead the field in the first round of the British open championship.

Luncheon of the Rotary Club of New York, Hotel Commodore, 12:15 P. M. "Meeting the Nations' Needsa Peace Plan," Elizabeth R. Pendry. Metropolitan Museum of Art, 4 P. M. "Three Centuries of American Furnishings," Ethelwyn Bradish, 4 P. M.
Most of the members of Parliament were agreed tonight that the report of the Royal Commission on Palestine would ranks as one of the great State papers of the century.

F. E. Moranzy's 2-year-old Fairflax, who has been looking better with every start, equaled the track record for five and a half furlongs in winning the top event of a featureless card today. This provided the second

Plans were announced yesterday for a new passenger and freight service between New York and South America, to be operated with Swedish-flag ships, starting in November. L. N. Stockard of Eckert Stockard Inc. returned on Tuesday from Europe, where he completed arrangements for the use of two 3,700-ton ships now under construction in Stockholm.

A concerted attempt to break the strike that has paralyzed a score of shipyards in the New York-New Jersey area for more than three weeks will be made this morning, when three of the biggest plants involved will attempt to resume operations.

Residents of old Shawneetown packed lock, stock and barrel today for a mass migration. The oldest town in Illinois and its 1,400 citizens are going to move to a new site three miles to the west and 400 feet above sea level, out of the path of Ohio River floods, which twice inundated the community in the last twenty-five years.

Laurence A. Steinhardt, newly appointed United States Ambassador to Peru, and former Governor Alfred E. Smith will arrive today from Europe on the Manhattan of the United States Lines. In the Smith party are Mrs. Smith, Justice and Mrs. Edward J. McGoldrick, Mr. and Mrs.- Daniel J. Mooney and Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Cary.

Who that was ever in Edinburgh was not there on Monday when the new young King with his Scottish Queen passed through Princes Street on the way to Holyrood. Even those at the Scottish games in Greenwich must have sent their thoughts across to the ancient and famous City of the North, whose situation, as ROBERT LOUIS

A club and gun fight between strikers and the police in which twenty-one men were wounded, two fatally, caused National Guardsmen to mount guard today with machine guns, riot guns and tear gas over the plant here of the Aluminum Company of America.

The weekly report of the United States Weather Bureau follows: The week was cool in the Eastern Cotton Belt and warmer than normal in the West. Substantial rains occurred in most places east of the Mississippi Valley, while in the western half of the belt, except locally in some northern sections, the week was practically rainless.

Led by a 3-year-old boy, 1,500 youngsters from the "gas house district" marched down Broadway and Columbus and Ninth Avenues yesterday in the periodic S. O. S. (Stay on Sidewalk) parade conducted by Uncle Robert, child welfare leader.

A former naval radio operator, who drifted for nine days in a wrecked airplane in the Pacific Ocean. before being picked up by a submarine, expressed the belief today that Amelia Earhart and her navigator, Fred Noonan, had a greater chance for rescue.

Boykin Wright, counsel for the reorganization committee for the United Cigar Stores Company of America, announced yesterday that Louis K. Comstock, president of the Merchants Association of New York, had consented to serve as a director of the new company under a reorganization plan approved last June 10 by Federal Judge Alfred C. Coxe.
President Manuel Quezon of the Philippines visited Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, Minister of Economics and President of the Reichsbank, today. Officially,
Stocks closed higher; turnover, 1,408,870 shares. Corporate bonds advanced, United States Government and foreign issues irregular; transactions, $9,361,000.

In her first Long Island tournament appearance of the season, Miss Maureen Orcutt today teamed with her brother, Sinclair Orcutt, to win the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's annual brotherand-sister championship fixture.

The Monmouth County Country Club's powerful quartet from Eatontown, N. J., continued its unbeaten pace in the Eastern Polo League by taking a hard-earned 9-7 decision from the hitherto undefeated Blind Brook Knights today at the Blind Book Turf and Polo Club. The victory was the fourth straight for the winners while the setback marked the first in three tourney starts for the home combination.

Thirty-seven polo ponies to be used by the Argentine players in the forthcoming national open championship at Meadow Brook next September arrived from Buenos Aires yesterday aboard the Lamport Holt freighter Nasmyth at Hoboken, N. J. Eleven gauchos also arrived.

Funeral services for Mrs. Florence Pullman Lowden, wife of former Governor Frank O. Lowden of Illinois, were held today at Sinnissippi Farms, the Lowden estate near here. The Rev. Dr. Frederick Shannon of the Central Church of Chicago officiated.

Executives of leading producers of viscose process rayon said yesterday that the order of the Federal Trade Commission to "cease and desist" from carrying out an "agreement, combination, understanding and conspiracy among themselves" to eliminate price competition, would neither be appealed nor have any effect upon present price policies.

Marlene Dietrich and Robert Donat will be featured in Alexander Korda's screen adaptation of James Hilton's novel, "Knight Without Armor," which opens this morning at Radio City Music Hall. A new issue of "The March of Time" containing a subject on Rockefeller Center also is on the program.

One of the most colorful figures for years in horse racing, hockey and other sports, William Vincent Dwyer, known familiarly as Bill Dwyer, experienced an unusual thrill yesterday at Empire City. The horse he bred at his Montalvo Stud in New Jersey, and who was named for him, scampered home first, giving Dwyer as much satisfaction as if he had won a Kentucky Derby.
The plan for reorganization of the Lawyers Mortgage Company submitted by James A. Martin as special referee was approved yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Alfred Frankenthaler.

Putting with the touch of a veteran campaigner, Eddie Foy, stocky blonde-haired entrant from Green Meadow enjoyed outstanding success over the sunbaked Sunningdale Country Club course today to enter the semi-final round of the Westchester County Golf Association junior championship tourney.

After an absence of a year from the real estate business, George J. Miller again has becomee associated with Pease Elliman, with whom he was connected previously for 20 years. Mr. Miller said he noted a "complete change" in the market, especially in the Plaza district, with properties bringing better rents and few vacancies to be found.

Public offering will be made today, by means of a prospectus, of 8,769 shares of common stock of the Greenwich Gas Company by F. L. Putnam Co., Inc.; R. H. Johnson Co. and Amott, Baker Co., Inc. The stock will be priced at

Governor Lehman announced today a list of appointments to various State institutions and commissions. Roger B. Prescott of Keesville was reappointed a member of the White Face Mountain Highway Commission.

Barely thirty hours are now left before the full Non-Intervention Committee, representing the twenty-seven nations concerned with the dangers arising from the conflict in Spain, will meet to find some way out of the present deadlock. No way has been

While industrial production was maintrained in April and May at 118 per cent of the 1923-25 average, compared with 115 per cent in the last quarter of 1936 and 119 for 1929, preliminary reports indicate a dedine in June, reflecting a sharp reduction in steel output, largely as a result of labor disturbances, the board of governors of the Federal Reserve System said today in its bulletin for July.

The marriage of Miss Marion Goodrich, daughter of Mrs. John Butler Goodrich of this city, to Edgar N. Sanford, son of Mrs. Robert G. Sanford of Somerville, N. J., took place this afternoon in the Dwight Memorial Chapel at Yale University. The Rev. Theodore Evans of Trinity Episcopal Church officiated.

Senator Robert F. Wagner indicated definitely to friends in Washington yesterday that he had made up his mind to stay in the United States Senate, and not yield to the movement to draft him for the Democratic nomination for Mayor.

Parmely W. Herrick, financier and son of the late Myron T. Herrick, former Governor of Ohio and Ambassador to France, died yesterday afternoon at Doctors Hospital, East End Avenue and Eighty-seventh Street, at the age of 55. He had been a patient at the hospital for ten weeks. His wife and son,

The executive committee of the open market committee of the Federal Reserve System met this morning with Secretary Morgenthau of the Treasury and later held a separate meeting at the offices of the board of goverors of the system.
Mrs. Brice W. Turner gave a luncheon yesterday in the Japanese Garden of the Ritz-Carlton for Mrs. Harry W. Lowe, Mrs. Harold M. Roberts, Mrs. Walter P. Fearon and Mrs. George S. Burr.

There are students of the Palestine problem who sincerely believe that any "solution" that promises to be effectively carried out for a considerable period of years by the Mandatory Power will represent a vast improvement over present conditions.

The full membership of the Central Executive Committee of the Soviet Government convened in the great Kremlin palace this evening preparatory to adopting in the next day or so detailed rules for the secret elections to the Soviet Supreme Council as provided in the new Constitution.

Miss Sylvia Worts advanced to the quarter-final round of the girls' junior center tennis championship yesterday with a triumph over Miss Betty Greene at the Amackassin Tennis Club in Yonkers. The scores were 4--6, 6--3, 6--2.

Beating the National League's All-Stars today for the fourth time in the annual midseason baseball classic was a palatable dish for the American League's team, but more enjoyable still was the cuffing to which the junior circuit hitters subjected Dizzy Dean.
The War Department released the following orders today, dated July 6: BRIGADIER GENERALS Pratt, H. C., one month and seventeen days leave, July 15. Darrah; T. W., Brooklyn, N. Y., to retirement.
The postman stopped at 906 Creed Road, Oakland, today and, as a result, the occupant of the house, her face lined with fatigue and worry, smiled for the first time in days.

United States Minister Alvin Mansfield Owsley, on his departure from Dublin tonight for his new ministerial post in Denmark, received a popular ovation. On his drive from the legation In Phoenix Park to his ship the Minister was met in the center of the city, at the Capel Street Bridge, by a large crowd, headed by Lord Mayor Alfred Byrne in full Mayoral regalia, accompanied by members of the Dublin Corporation.

Robert Jackson of Washington, with his daughters, Mrs. W. Forbes Morgan and Mrs. Francis P. Garvin Jr., arrived at the Mount Washington Hotel today. Mr. Jackson, a native of New Hampshire, formerly was chairman of the Democratic National Committee. Others here are Mr. and Mrs. C. A. Parliament of Swampscot, Mass., and Mr. and Mrs. A. J. Heffernan of Bound Brook, N. J.

The Public Service Commission today called upon seven more communities operating municipally owned electric plants to file reduced rates Immediately.
