These villages are in addition to nearly thirty of which the commission already had requested lowered rate schedules, alleging that they were making an excessive profit.

A drive to organize the 300,000 maritime workers in the United States into a "national maritime federation" to be affiliated with the Committee for Industrial Organization was announced today by John L. Lewis.
Echoes have reached here of the almost simultaneous publication in New York, London and Paris of alarming accounts of the present state of Austro-German relations.

President Roosevelt conferred with Senator Wagner; entertained Dr. H. H. Kung, the Chinese Finance Minister, and Dr. Cheng-Ting Wang, the Chinese Ambassador, at luncheon; attended the All-Star baseball game, and visited the Boy Scout encampment.

Ernst F. S. Hanfstaengl, once the intimate of Chancellor Adolf Hitler of Germany but recently a resident of London, won today a settlement of [Pound]250 and costs in a libel action against The Cavalcade Weekly News Magazine.

Debutantes of this and recent seasons, as well as several young matrons in the Summer colony, have entered the competition for the Fox and Babcock trophies in the local tennis tournament at the Meadow Club. The draw has been posted
Following is the text of the British Government decision on the Royal Commission's report on Palestine:

Fritz Reiner's opening program with the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra tomorrow night at Lewisohn Stadium has been revised and stands as follows: Toccata and Fugue in C, by Bach-Weiner; the Brahms Fourth symphony in E minor, selections from Stravinsky's "Petrouchka," and the overture to Wagner's "Die Meistersinger."

This way to baseball's planetarium, the All-Star show with a diamond setting. Every move a picture--some of them slightly blurred. Gomez vs. J. H. Dean at the start. Ol' Dizz finally made up his mind to pitch. Or Sam Breadon made it up for him.

Marking the first time that a major cigarette manufacturer has taken such action, Philip Morris Co., Ltd., moved yesterday to put Philip Morris cigarettes and Bond Street tobacco under the price-maintenance provisions of the Feld-Crawford act in this State.

Dr. Gera Cehak of the Reich Academy's Biological Institute contends that women are quicker than men in gestures, speech and movement generally. In his research with what he calls a psychomotor of tempo Dr. Cehak made thousands of tests on 1,546 persons of both sexes and of several races.
Judge Ake Wilhelm Hammarskjold of the World Court died this afternoon at the age of 44. He was the court's registrar since its foundation and was appointed judge a few months ago.

Worries over the recently introduced Black-Connery Hour-WageBill and its possible effects in raising prices to the consumer occupied visitors today at the semi-annual furniture show in the American Furniture Mart.

The State Supreme Court ruled today that the State Milk Control Board not only had the power to revoke a dealer's license for selling at less than the established price, but also that sales to the Federal Government were subject to the prices fixed by the State.

American flag ship lines will lose a large share of the parcel post and printed matter that they have carried for about eight years to foreign ports, under a ruling announced yesterday by the Postoffice Department.

The bond market continued its advance yesterday and, led by railroad and convertible issues, prices made gains comparable with Tuesday's session in trading on the New York Stock Exchange. High-grade corporation bonds again maintrained a firmness in -tone, with Republic Steel 5 1/2s of 1954 gaining more than 3 points.
Arturo Toscanini's performance in the forthcoming Salzburg festival will have to be carried out without the German singers who were to have appeared.
The Senate Labor Committee completed today a drastic revision of the Black-Connery Wage and Hour Bill, but deferred a final vote on the measure until tomorrow.

Twelve teams participating in the league contests of the Meadow Brook Club Cups polo tournament will see action this afternoon at 5 o'clock. The Old Westbury-Aiken Knights match will decide Meadow League laurels. Both are undefeated with
Members of the American Newspaper Guild who are on strike against the Seattle Star tonight rejected unanimously a compromise proposal offered by the management.

Seven California collegians reached the fourth round of the Middle States men's tennis championship at the Germantown Cricket Club today. Robert Harman, Modeste Alloo, Richard Bennett and Paul Newton of the University of California;
The Fourth of July speeches in London continue to evoke indignant press comment here, Ambassador Robert W. Bingham being severely criticized for his utterances.

The Lockheed Aircraft Company's vice president, C. B. Squier, identified tonight a rubber tire and landing gear found in the Andaman Sea off the coast of Burma as part of the airplane equipment of Air Commander Sir Charles KingsfordSmith, who was lost on a flight from London to Australia on Nov. 8, 1935.

Valentine Ave, 2,965 (12-3306); Valford Building Corp to Seamen's Bank for Savings; extends mtg to May 19, 1947, at 4 1/2 per cent: $87,500. Goodridge Ave (13-3415G), e s, 135 ft n of 250th St, 130x142; Freeman C. Lynch to Elizabeth B. Ware, 5,020 Goodridge Ave; 5 years, 4 1/2 per cent: $26,500.
The Bethlehem Steel Company opened the largest college training class in the history of the company yesterday, with 111 graduates from many sections of the country reporting for work.

The medical profession will be confronted with the problem of socialized medicine "within a short time" and, consequently, should prepare itself 'to get a fair bargain" out of the new social program, Dr. C. P. Zepp, president of
Prices on the Cotton Exchange continued yesterday to rise under a light volume of business, and the list ended with gains of 3 to 6 points.

The two flying boats of Imperial Airways and Pan American Airways, moored since their conquest of the North Atlantic Monday night, will resume their journeys to the terminals of the proposed ocean line this morning.

John North Willys, former Ambassador to Poland, who started in the automobile business with $7,500 of borrowed capital, left a net estate of $2,205,419, according to a transfer tax appraisal filed yesterday by Commissioner Jacob I. Manicoff. Not included as part of the estate was a settlement, reported to be for $7,650,000, made with Mr. Willys's first wife at the time of their divorce in 1934.

The British Government is on the point of signing bilateral agreements with Germany and Russia to which they will be bound by the 1936 London Naval Treaty, according to Rector C. Bywater, the naval correspondent of The Daily Telegraph.

The Tennessee Valley Authority announced today it has contracted to furnish the Aluminum Company of America electric power at its Alcoa plant in quantities estimated to yield the authority $1,500,000 annually.

Smiling and waving almost continuously for more than an hour and a half, President Roosevelt drove slowly this afternoon through 10.8 miles of highways of the great 350-acre camp where 26,000 Boy Scouts from all parts of the world are nearing the end of their ten-day jamboree.

Announcement was made here last night of the death yesterday in the American Hospital, Paris, of Joseph Ferris Simmons of 28 West Fifty-second Street, who retired in 1916 after twenty years as treasurer of the Trow Directory Printing and Bookbinding Company.
A coin collector's treasure, sixty-five old American gold coins, was poured this morning from a small iron bank dug out of the sand on the shore of the Manasquan Inlet, near Point Pleasant.

Plans and specifications for new buildings filed in June with the Manhattan Department of Buildings called for the erection of ten structures at an estimated cost of $914,350, as compared with fortysix buildings costing $10,632,850 in June a year ago, Commissioner Samuel Fassler announced yesterday.
The National Defense Ministry issued the following communique at 4 o'clock this afternoon: "The occupation of Villanueva de la Canada by our troops occurred at 10 o'clock last night.
Raymond Uhler Bunker of New York and Walpole, a mechanical engineer long associated with the beet sugar industry, died yesterday in the Elliot Memorial Hospital at Keene at the age of 53.

F. George Forrow has been appointed manager of the loss department of the Atlantic Mutual Insurance Company to succeed the late Walter J. Falb. He was assistant head of the cargo claims department of Marsh McLennan for nine years.

With announcement copy in trade magazines and newspapers running as high as 50 per cent over a year ago and well above that for the Spring opening, floor coverings mills in opening their Fall lines intend to expand their advertising budgets considerably, reports here yesterday indicated.

The anti-trust division of the Department of Justice has decided to recommend to Attorney General Cummings that the Western Union and Postal Telegraph companies be prosecuted for alleged violation of the anti-trust laws by practices tending to lessen competition between the companies.

Wool moved out of Boston in freight cars today as warehouse men loaded the cars, which were shunted about under the eyes of a picket line. The dealers did not attempt to move wool from congested docks.

Jacob Emil Leitner, Inc, have arranged a first mortgage of $125,000 on the recently completed apartment on the west side of Decatur Ave, 150 feet north of Mosholu Parkway, the Bronx, for Morris Bogdanoff.

Mark Hyman of New York City has purchased a tract of twentyone acres with a lake in Tarrytown, Westchester, from the Gracemere Holding Corporation. The property formerly was a part of the estate of the late Henry K. Browning. Mr. Hyman plans to improve the site soon with a residence. George Howe, Inc., was the broker.

The former residence of Alla Nazimova, actress, on King Street, Port Chester, N .Y., has been sold for the Port Chester Savings Bank by Blakeman Quintard Meyer, broker, to C. Woody Feurt, of Henri Bendel, Inc.

An issue of $700,000 Series C refunding bonds of Bridgeport, Conn., Will be offered to the highest bidder on July 12. The bonds, dated July 15, will mature serially on July 15, 1939 to 1947. Bidders are asked to name a rate of interest not exceeding 3 per cent.
One death was attributed to the heat and several persons were prostrated yesterday as the mercury climbed to a new high for the year, 91.4 degrees, one degree less than the record for the date.

Charles Swanson, Pawtucket product of the public parks, upset Donald Hawley of Orange, N. J., fourth-seeded player, to provide the feature of the second day of the thirtieth annual Agawam Hunt singles as the field was pared to quarter-finalists today.

Movements of livestock on the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts, 13,000 including 2,000 directs; good and choice hogs, 250 pounds, down steady to shade lower: heavy butchers and

Funeral services were held this afternoon for William H. Bennett, retired school principal who was honorary president of an association of 171 of his former boy pupils. His age was 76. Mr. Bennett died Saturday.

Citing the government's recognition of a 27 1/2 per cent depreciation item in income taxes paid on earnings of oil wells and other mineral properties, Rogers Marchetti, Los Angeles attorney, announced here yesterday that he would go to Washington to seek a "sympathetic hearing" on his proposal that movie stars receive a similar reduction for "depreciation" of their drawing power through the passage of time and the "fickleness of the public."

Three planes catapulted from the battleship Colorado launched the navy's aerial search for Amelia Earhart's round-theworld plane tonight but returned after two hours to report no trace sighted of the missing flier and her navigator, Frederick J. Noonan.

Shareholders of the United Specialty Company are to meet in Detroit July 19 to consider amendments to the certificate of incorporation which will permit it to acquire the Alco Valve Company for $500,000, according to an announcement made yesterday by Christian Girl, president.

Amparo Iturbi, Spanish pianist, the sister of Jose Iturbi, made her local debut at Lewisohn Stadium last night, where she was heard with her brother in two-piano numbers with the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, under Alexander Smallens. An audience of 12,000

Five Ford Motor Company employes were identified today by witnesses at a National Labor Relations Board hearing as participants in the beating of organizers and officials of the United Automobile Workers of America supervising the distribution of handbills at the River Rouge plant on May 26.

Admitting that Arab and Zionist aspirations are "irreconcilable" and that the present mandate has been unworkable, the British Government tonight proposed a threefold partition of Palestine, including the creation there of the first independent Jewish State since the days of Emperor Titus.

Some idea of the travel last weekend to Long Island fishing centers is contained in the statistics compiled by the Long Island Railroad. According to their data, 829 anglers boarded the Fishermen's Special for Canoe Place and Montauk on Sunday and 239 made the trip on Monday. Of course, there

Sensational reports of damage to the wheat crop in the Canadian Northwest and continued dry weather in the Spring wheat area on both sides of the international line were effective in advancing North American markets in the early trading today,

Activities of the Catholic Daughters of America in attempts to stamp out communistic teachings were praised this afternoon by the Rt. Rev. Eugene McGuinness of Chicago, vice president of the Catholic Extension Society. He also lauded the teaching of youth to array themselves against divorce, mixed marriages and birth control.

The 1,397 bond issues listed on the New York Stock Exchange, aggregating $47,321,130,777 par value as of July 1, had a total market value of $44,001,162,031, according to a compilation by the Exchange issued yesterday. As of June 1, there were 1,395 issues, aggregating $47,045,129,044 par value, which had a total market value of $44,170,837,675.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States States last week was 3,525,650 barrels, compared with 3,529,600 in the preceding week, a decline of 3,950, according to the American Petroleum Institute. A decline of 12,450

Gordon Murphy of Garden City, L. I., today sailed Chance to victory in the H-23-foot class of the Fishers Island Yacht Club regatta, scoring by 77 seconds over William H. Hubbard's Fairway. This was Chance's third victory in as many starts. She scored twice previously while sailed by Arthur E. Whitney, also of Garden City.

Mrs. Otto F. Hahn and her daughter, E. Adelaide Hahn, of 640 Riverside Drive, New York City, won first and second prizes, $10 and $5, respectively in the annual prize spelling match at the Amphitheater tonight.

Shareholders of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., at a special meeting yesterday afternoon in the company's auditorium authorized by a vote of more than 70 per cent of the outstanding stock the proposal to permit the company to engage directly in the steam business throughout New York City and also to guarantee a $25,000,000 issue of 3 1/2 per cent bonds of the Westchester Lighting Company, an affiliate.

Mrs. Owen Johnson gave a large garden party this afternoon at Ingleside, Stockbridge, for visitors who were in the Berkshires as guests of the Lenox Garden Club. Mrs. Robert H. Fife, president of the Garden Club of America, assisted the hostess in receiving in the library.

The stock markets here were more active than recently today and most of the sections improved. Gilt-edge ?? were firm and, among the Foreign loans, German securities advanced. International shares were ?? briskly and prices moved upward.

The Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Company has acquired the A. B. See Elevator Company, Inc., in exchange for 10,000 shares of the former's common stock, of which 4,186 were held in the company's treasury and 5,814 shares were authorized but unissued, it was disclosed yesterday.
Plans to make a gigantic health exhibit of the New York World's Fair were outlined yesterday by Dr. Victor G. Heiser, physician and author of "An American Doctor's Odyssey."

Dodd, Mead announce a new Red Badge mystery and detective novel competition, with a prize of $1,000 offered for the best manuscript submitted before Dec. 31 by an author who has not previously had a book published with the Red Badge imprint.

Building operations for the aviation center to be constructed for the Bendix Aviation Corporation here will commence immediately, Vincent Bendix, company president, announced here today. Speaking at a luncheon given by the Bergen County Chamber of Commerce to his executives at the Bendix Golf Club, near Bendix Airport, he told of the award of construction contracts.

Clarence E. S. Bellows, vice president and director of Bellows Co., wine and liquor importers, 67 East Fifty-second Street, Manhattan, died late this evening at his home, 644 Hillcrest Road, after a month's illness.

The first congress of German historians under the National Socialist regime, which opened at Erfurt yesterday with an address by Dr. Walther Frank, head of the Institute for History of the Third Reich, got down to grips with the Jewish question today.

Following is the text of the official "Summary of the Report of the Palestine Royal Commission": The members of the Palestine Royal Commission were. Rt. Hon. EARL PEEL, G. C. S. I., G. B. E., Chairman. Rt. Hon. Sir HORACE RUMBOLD,

Fourteen men, identified by the management as sit-down L??ikers who were evicted yesterday from the Enterprise Garnetting Company plant here, pleaded innocent before Justice Donald C. McLean today to charges of "unlawful intrusion of real property."
A $105,000,000 flood control program appeared likely today to win congressional approval, but there was talk that it might be vetoed by President Roosevelt.

THE HERO: A STUDY IN TRADITION, MYTH AND DRAMA, by Lord Raglan. (Oxford, $3.50.) A survey of traditional narrative. CHILD OF LIGHT, by Mrs. J. L. Garvin. (Longmans, Green, $2.) The Catholic Book Club selection for this month. A novel.

Plans for an election tomorrow for the designation of a collective bargaining agent for 8,500 employes of the Philadelphia Rapid Transit Company were protested today by representatives of three of the four competing unions.

The New York Curb Exchange has approved listing applications for 100,000 shares of Dobeckmun Company common stock, $1, with authority to add 10,000 shares on official notice of issuance; 189,250 shares of Rome Cable Corporation common capital stock, $5 par value, with authority to add 10,750 shares; and 215,000 shares of Silex Company common stock, no par value.

Colonel Jacob Schick, retired United States Army officer and inventor, who died in New York last Saturday, was buried here today at Mount Royal Cemetery. Colonel Schick, inventor of the razor which bore his name and president of the Schick Dry Razor, Inc., became a naturalized Canadian citizen in 1935 and lived in Montreal.

TRANSFERS AND ASSIGNMENTS Patrolmen Gustave Friedman from 3d Division to 10th Precinct, assignment to duty in plain clothes discontinued. Francis M. Marley, 61st to 9th Precinct. TEMPORARY ASSIGNMENTS Sergeant Thomas J. McLaughlin, from 6Sth Precinct to 18th Division, duty in D. A. Office, Queens County, for 1 day. Patrolmen George M. DelGaudio, from 46th Precinct to 19th Division, Raided Premises Squad, for 8 days.

Miss Patty Henry, national intercollegiate champion from Los Angeles, took a three-set match from Miss Olga Kallos of New York at the Germantown Cricket Club today to advance to the quarter-final round of the Women's Philadelphia District grass courts tennis singles championship.

The Commission on Marriage and Divorce of the Protestant Episcopal Church, which six years ago caused the General Convention to ease the traditional ban of the church against remarriage of divorced persons, proposed yesterday a further liberalization of Canon 41--the "divorce canon."

The sale by the Randolph Realty Corporation of the fifteen-story apartment house at 36 Central Park South, between Fifth and Sixth Avenues, was announced yesterday. The building, which occupies a plot 50 by 100 feet and contains fifty-one apartments, was bought by Vanderbilt Estates, Inc., Louis Schleifer, president.
To snatch just two human lives from the Pacific wastes the three chief sea powers have mobilized their battleships and their

Production of steel ingots in the United States declined sharply last month because of strike conditions and failed to equal the May output by nearly 1,000,000 gross tons, although exceeding June, 1936, figures by over 200,000 tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reports.

A State Senator's charge that Harvard University gave financial aid to the Spanish Loyalist government brought a terse denial today from Harvard and a demand for "evidence" from Massachusetts' Secretary of State.

Preliminary to issuing a certificate of occupancy, Borough President Samuel Levy and Building Commissioner Samuel Fassler inspected yesterday the rehabilitated Postal Telegraph Building at 253 Broadway, corner of Murray Street.

Announcement has been made of the marriage of Miss Emilie Dietrich, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Herman Dietrich, formerly of Hamburg, Germany, and White Plains, N. Y., to Rayford W. Alley, lawyer of this city and Syosset, L. I. The wedding took place on June 5 in the First Presbyterian Church, Oyster Bay, and the ceremony was performed by the Rev. Alfred J. Penney. The couple dispensed with attendants.

Intensive study will be given by the State Department to the report of the British Royal Commission of Inquiry on Palestine and the declaration of policy by the British Government for partitioning the mandated territory before any decision is reached as to whether the United States should intervene on the basis of its convention of 1924 with Great Britain.
EASY LIVING, from a screen play by Preston Sturges based on a story by Vera Caspary; directed by Mitchell Leisen; produced for Paramount by Arthur Hornblow Jr. At the Paramount.

Radio meteorographs-robot weather observers which broadcast finds from miniature balloons high above the earth-will begin taking upper air readings at Union Air Terminal, Burbank, Sept. 1, the Department of Agriculture announced here today.

Administration spokesmen in the Senate moved today to put support of the compromise Judiciary Reorganization Bill on the basis of loyalty to President Roosevelt, warning Democratic opponents that the blame for any split in the party, which resulted in the defeat of the bill would rest on their shoulders.
George Palmer Putnam, husband of Amelia Earhart, said today that If his wife was dead she had died in the way she would have chosen.
The United States Circuit Court of Appeals halted today until Fall the inquiry by the Federal Power Commission into the six subsidiaries of the Associated Gas and Electric Company in this State.

Contrary to the expectations of manufacturers, buying at the second day of the Fall floor covering opening market here yesterday failed to develop into any appreciable volume, and it was evident that retailers are exercising more than usual caution in making commitments for their Fall merchandising program.
The Middletown Purse, feature race at Delaware Park, held 8,000 spectators in suspense today until a photo decided that Drudgery had won from Golden Era by a nose.
Henry Downing Jacobs, a lexicographer and member of the editorial staff of the John C. Winston Company, publishers, died at Triangle, Va., on Monday from injuries received in an automobile accident.

The wedding of Miss Muriel Gallagher, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. J. Walter Gallagher of New Haven, Conn., and Charles Goodspeed Lord, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Murdock Lord, took place this afternoon at St. John's Protestant Episcopal Church in the Worthington Valley.
Two navy fliers were killed today when a pursuit plane and an observation plane crashed while nearly a mile aloft, burst into flames and fell to earth.
The United States Treasury Department has leased, for the WPA Cartographic and Map Making Project, three floors containing 33,000 square feet in the building at 154 West Fourteenth Street.
Mae West, screen actress, admitted for the first time today that on April 11, 1911, she was married to Frank Wallace, former New York vaudeville performer.
Dr. Joseph W. Mauck, former president of Hillsdale College and of the University of South Dakota, died at his home here this morning after a long illness. His age was 84.

A fresh dispute involving different interpretations of last week's agreement has risen regarding the Amur islands. Yesterday the Soviet complained that Japanese troops had been landed on Sennufa and Bolshoi Islands and requested an explanation of the proceeding, which it said violated

The fortnightly statement of the Central Bank of Argentina for June 30 showed the ratio of gold reserve to notes in circulation as 134.57 per cent, compared with 134.95 per cent on June 15. The reserve ratio of gold to notes and sight liabilities was 90.74 per cent, compared with 91.03 on June 15.

Jimmy Thomson, long-driving professional.from Shawnee-on-Delaware, Pa., won the $1,000 open driving contest staged today in conjunction with the General Brock golf tournament, with ten drives for a total yardage of 3,407.

Seven trial transatlantic flights on an entirely non-commercial basis will take place between England and New York via Montreal between now and September, according to Captain J. H. Shaw, officer in charge of airlines for Asiatic Petroleum Corporation, who is here awaiting the arrival of the Imperial Airways flying boat, Caledonia, tomorrow.

Last minute efforts by representatives of the employers and employes to avert the threatened stoppage of 35,000 cloakmakers in more than 1,500 shops in the metropolitan area failed last night and the stoppage will go into effect, as scheduled, this morning.

Henry Armstrong, sensational California lightweight, will meet Alf Blatch, the 135-pound ruler of Australia, in the feature ten-rounder at Madison Square Garden's fourth Summer boxing show tonight. The hard hitting Coast youngster rules as a 2-1 favorite.

Turpentine firm, 34c; sales, 244 barrels; receipts, 965 barrels; shipments, 7 barrels; stock, 29,393 barrels. Resin. steady; sales, 906; receipts, 3,409; shipments, 990; stock, 64,239. Quote: B, D, E, $7.85; F to N, $7.85-90; WG, $7.85-95; WW, X, $8.75-80.

The General American Investors Company, Inc., reported yesterday that its net assets on June 30 were $34,416,141 after allowing $2,115,800 for taxes on unrealized appreciation of $10,526,501. This was equivalent

The special promotions and clearance events of local stores thus far this month have evoked good consumer response in several leading local stores, reports here yesterday indicated. Retailers cut prices quite sharply on many items of seasonal merchandise on which they were overstocked.

Supreme Court Justice Bergan today dismissed a complaint of Rockland County property owners who sought the removal from office of the appraisal commissioners of the Palisades Interstate Commission and also to enjoin condemnation proceedings for the acquisition of park lands.

Clarence M. McLeveine, 57 years old, a former seaman, received yesterday the maximum sentence from Magistrate Bromberger in Yorkville Court on a charge of defrauding the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel of $51.50.

In view of the greatly overcrowded calendar, which will not possibly allow time for adequate consideration of the far-reaching measures already before Congress, the Administration's decision to press for passage of general farm legislation at the present session is unfortunate. It would be regrettable,

The honor of presenting the Abbey Theatre Company here and on tour next season has fallen to the Shubert office, it was learned yesterday. A visit of at least fifteen weeks will open in October, the old and well-known plays showing in repertory with one or two new ones.
Republic Steel officials reported the ranks of returned workers swelled today, while charges and denials of police and National Guard violence echoed through the Mahoning Valley.

Germany won the first round today in the re-hearing of the case involving war-time damages to owners and underwriters of the Black Tom Terminal and the Kingsland, N. J., munitions factories which were destroyed by explosions and fire in 1916. The German-American Mixed

Despite pleas for leniency received from many persons, including James M. Curley, former Governor of Massachusetts, Federal Judge John C. Knox imposed a prison sentence of two years yesterday upon Frank M. Maloney, Salt Lake City mining promoter, who was convicted last month of mail fraud growing out of his sale of stock of the National Merger Gold Mine Company.

Alfred C. Dent of 108 East Thirtyeighth Street, special representative of the Chemical Bank and Trust Company, who had held various positions with banks and security houses here and in the Middle West, died Tuesday night in the Post-Graduate Hospital at the age of 48.

Counsel for the Steel Workers Organizing Committee accused the Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company tonight of collusion with the police and Ohio National Guard officers in an attempt to break the steel strike.

The entire square bounded by the Grand Concourse, East 162d Street, East 163d Street and Sheridan Avenue, in the Bronx, has been purchased by Samuel Derfner and his son from Elizabeth, A. Diller, through William A. White Sons, broker.

Six star tennis players of Harvard and Yale Universities have been selected to meet Oxford and Cambridge of England in the international college tournament on the Newport Casino courts on July 22, 23 and 24 for the Prentice Cup. Harvard and Yale won the cup in England two year ago.

Six star tennis players of Harvard and Yale Universities have been selected to meet Oxford and Cambridge of England in the international college tournament on the Newport Casino courts on July 22, 23 and 24 for the Prentice Cup. Harvard and Yale won the cup in England two year ago.

A 75-foot plot on Caldwell Avenue, in Stamford, Conn., has been purchased by Lena Dooley through H. A. Lockwood Co. The same brokers sold a plot on Van Buskirk Avenue, in Stamford, to William Moorhouse, who has started construction of a residence there.
Labor Department statistics disclosed today that the number of strikes beginning in April was about 25 per cent lower than in March, when there were the most strikes of any month in twenty years.

A sharp warning that the city's unencumbered debt margin with pending commitments has dwindled to $62;284,087 as of April 1 was issued yesterday by Controller Frank J. Taylor in a report to the members of the Board of Estimate, Since Jan. 1, when the unencumbered debt margin was $235,886,532, there has been a net decrease of $173,602.445. he reported.
No fatted calf was slaughtered in the Russo home at 15 Tribune Street, Elmont, L. I., yesterday when the Russos' prodigal son, Vito, 22, came home.

The Vanderburg Apartments, a twenty-family building at the northwest corner of Chatsworth and Vanderburgh Avenues, Larshmont, N.Y., has been sold by William C. Watt to Irving 0. Freedman, New York operator. Eadie Hart, Inc.,

A proposal for revision of the rules for grading butter, drafted by the Bureau of Agricultural Economics, met consistent opposition from representatives of independent and chain retail grocers, New York commission merchants,

Charles C. Pettijohn Jr., slim 18-year-old representative of the Westchester C. C., retained his Westchester County Golf Association junior crown for a second year today as he turned back the bid of Arthur Conaty from Gedney Farm in a match that ended on the sixteenth hole.

Eastbound service on the Long Island Railroad between Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn, and the East New York station, was tied up from 5:44 to 6:40 P. M. yesterday, owing to expansion of the third rail caused by the heat.
Sorting the mail: A Brooklyn fisherman, J. H. Nichols, recites his experiences on two trips to Ocean City, Md. They are described, in part, as follows:

Queen Elizabeth made her first public speech of the new reign today when she was enrolled as an honorary Doctor of Laws at Edinburgh University. "As a Scotswoman," she said, "I know the high value my countrymen set upon education and the importance of a university to the national life. I am glad to

With a smaller acreage shown by the Department of Agriculture than the cotton trade had expected, the market became active yesterday, and prices on the Cotton Exchange advanced $1.50 a bale under the largest volume of business in several weeks.

Gene J. Fuerst, furniture, in 432 Fourth Ave; Clyde Shirt Co, Inc, in 1,140 Broadway; Dorothy Noyes and Albert E. Sproul Jr, advertising; in 155 E 44th St; Finger Brotman, tailor, through Webb Knapp, Inc, in 681 Fifth Ave; The Cross Brown Co, broker.

Federal Judge Edwin S. Thomas enjoined the General Shaver Corporation of Bridgeport today from manufacturing its Remington electric shaver. A preliminary injunction, issued in connection with a patent suit brought by the Lektro Shave Corporation of New Jersey,

The Music Hall broke its fast, and ours, yesterday by serving up a solidly entertaining romance, "Knight Without Armor," which stems-as you probably already have heard-from the James Hilton novel known, more simply, as "Without Armor."
Despite a boycott by three "outside" unions, employes of the Philadelphia Rapid Transit Company began casting ballots today for the choice of a collective bargaining agency.

Miss Virginia M. Smith, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clarence P. Smith of Ocean City, Md., was married yesterday morning in the Marble Collegiate Church Chapel, Twenty-ninth Street and Fifth Avenue, to Philip Walter Seipp Jr., son of Mrs. Philip W. Seipp of this city and the late Mr. Seipp.

The 1936-7 Honor Roll of 169 undergraduates of Fordham University was made public by the university yesterday. Of these thirtynine will receive gold and silver medals for the highest averages over 90 per cent for the school year.

Mrs. Nannie Inman Brokaw of this city and Glen Cove, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. John Hamilton Inman and former wife of Clifford Vail Brokaw, was married to Milton D. Brown yesterday at noon in the chapel of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church.

By HENRY BRADY 71st St, 332 E, 5-story brick tenement, 25x 100.5; Edith B. Lloyd against Beniamino De Stasio; due, $15,709; to plaintiff for $10,000. 81st St, 310 E, 3-story stone dwelling, 16x102.2; Guaranty Trust Co of N. Y., trustee, against Annie Sutton; due, $11,455; to plaintiff for $8,250.

Sgt. Byrne, one of the few horses owned by John Simonetti of Jamaica, rewarded faithful backers at Empire City yesterday when he came home first in the featured four-horse Whitestone Handicap, where many supposed he had little chance. At the end he was first
Three thousand of Father Divine's most righteous followers had their first glimpse today of the latest addition to the Negro evangelist's promised land, four miles from here at Greenkill Park.
The completed manuscript of "To Have and Have Not," by Ernest Hemingway, went to press yesterday. This novel, the first by Mr. Hemingway in eight years, will be published by Scribner in October.

The French franc, after having been buoyed about a week by shortcovering, again turned weak yesterday. The official control, which had been in the happy position of being able to sell its own currency to repress the rise and thereby to acquire new supplies of gold and foreign exchange, found it necessary once more to come to the support of the franc.

One explanation of the origin of the word "Hoosier" is that when in the pioneer period a knock was heard by night at a cabin door the " settler" before opening the door called out " Who's h'yer? " and then showed frontier hospitality. Purdue University in the
President Roosevelt went into direct discussion with the heads of twentyeight Federal agencies today on his order that they save, during the current fiscal year, 10 per cent of appropriations.

The musical group, "Dopolavoro" of the motor-ship Vulcania, will give a concert tonight at 8 30 o'clock in the auditorium of the Palazzo D'Italia under the auspices of the Dante Alighieri Society for the benefit of the society's free Italian school. The program consists of vocal solos and choral and orchestral numbers.
The New York Stock Exchange membership of George L. Maxwell has been transferred to Eliphalet N. Potter at DeCoppet Doremus; that of William C. Cooke, to Dale Parker.

Three grandsons of Lydia E. Pinkham today won a victory in Massachusetts Supreme Court in their battle of thirty-seven years with women relatives for control of the $3,000,000 patent medicine business founded by the Quaker schoolteacher over sixty years ago.
ARCHIBALD HENDERSON is the head of the mathematics department at the University of North Carolina, but people

Dr. and Mrs. Lawrence Kirby Lunt of Valleyhead, Concord, Mass., have announced here the engagement of Mrs. Lunt's daughter, Miss Anne Faith Donaldson, to Russell Grace D'Oench, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Albert F. D'Oench of Manhasset, L. I.

To the Editor of The New York Times: From a milk producer's standpoint I do not see much promise of benefit to the producer by the Rogers-Allen law. It was fathered by the big distributors. The cooperatives are in the hands of the distributors.

Louis Oliver Vaughan, promising young Negro artist who disappeared from his home at 59 West Ninety-eighth Street last Friday, was found to have been drowned when his body was identified yesterday at the morgue.

Announcement has been made of the marriage on May 5 in Grenock, Scotland, of Charles A. Powell Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles A. Powell of Osceola Farm, this city, and Miss Christina MacKenzie MacAllister, daughter of Mrs. Margaret Whyte MacAllister and the late Alexander MacAllister of Grenock.
Fierce opposition is rising in the Yugoslav Parliament to a new measure designed to give the police enormously increased powers to punish political offenders summarily.
Five hours of play today in the seventeenth and final round of the international chess masters' tournament at the Kurhaus failed to bring the event to a finish.

Laurence A. Steinhardt, former United States Minister to Sweden, who has been appointed Ambassador to Peru, returned yesterday with Mrs. Steinhardt to report in Washington before leaving for his new post. Arriving on the United

Irene Rich, in 24 W 55th St; C. Lamont Post, in 150 E 73d St; Mrs. Grace E. Gray, in 55 E 72d St; Miss Gertrude Delahunt, in 245 E 72d St; Jean Skelton and Gertrude Woolley, in 140 E 81st St; Kendrick Luther, in 983 Park Ave; Douglas Gibbons Co, Inc, broker.
Mike Jacobs, head of the Twentieth Century Sporting Club, plans to stage the proposed heavyweight championship bout between Joe Louis and Tommy Farr of England at the Yankee Stadium on Aug. 26.
Dr. Louis William Atlee, member of a prominent family of medical men, died at his Summer home in Horsham township yesterday at the age of 77. He retired from active practice in May.

In the first six months of this year, 9,927 new stock corporations were formed in this State, the division of corporations of the Department of State revealed today. This was an increase of thirty-five over the same period in 1936. In June, 1,509
During the week ended July 7 member bank reserve balances decreased $73,000,000. The reduction in
Mrs. Ivor O'Connor Morgan, formerly of New York, died here suddenly on Tuesday. Funeral services will be held in Paris on Saturday.

New offices, showrooms and warehouse facilities occupying 9,000 feet on the main and lower floors of the building at 231 Varick Street have been opened by the Schrafft's Sales Corporation, wholesale distributors in the metropolitan area for Schrafft's and Wallace Co. candies.

Under a sun that sent the temperature soaring to the high 90s, Miss Millicent Hirsh, 20-year-old New Yorker, reached the semi-final round of the Philadelphia and district women's tennis championship at the Germantown Cricket Club today.

Mayor Wilson today announced the creation of a commission of prominent citizens, headed by Dr. Thomas S. Gates, president of the University of Pennsylvania, to prepare a comprehensive plan for modernizing and financing municipal operations.

The United Press Association, a news-gathering agency, objected at a public hearing yesterday afternoon before a trial examiner of the National Labor Relations Board, to the inclusion of its bureau managers in a nation-wide poll of its editorial employes to determine whether they want to be represented by the American Newspaper Guild in collective bargaining.

The will of Graham Youngs, president-elect of the Bath and Tennis Club, who died June 27, sets up a series of trust funds. The widow, Mrs. Laura H. Youngs, receives all tangible personal property except personal jewelry bequeathed to Mortimer A. Seabury Jr., husband of Mr. Youngs's step-daughter.

Plans for a transatlantic air line which will compete with the joint project of Pan American Airways and Imperial Airways have been developed quietly in the last few weeks by the American Export Line, it was revealed today. Surveys have been
The Caledonia, Imperial Airways transat??antic flying boat, landed safely in Montreal Harbor at 4 o'clock this afternoon amid roars of cheering and the din of sirens and foghorns.

Donald McNeill, Kenyon College star, and S. Ellsworth Davenport 3d, the only seeded players remaining in the Queens County tennis singles championship, moved into the semi-final bracket yesterday at the Seminole Club in Forest Hills.

Representative Fish, Republican, of New York proposed today to prove by the personal admission of President Roosevelt that he had taken advantage of a "loophole" in the-revenue laws to reduce his income taxes to the Federal Government.

Steel-strike violence brought indictments against eight accused as Warren bombers today. The indictments, which followed similar grand jury action at nearby Youngstown, grew out of bomb blasts which shook this steel city two weeks ago.

THE night before the all-star ball game in Washington Chuck Dressen was wandering around the lobby of the Shoreham Hotel looking under chairs and behind potted palms for National League nominees. His march was
Mrs. Lilith M. Wilson, for three terms member of the Pennsylvania State Assembly from Reading, died here tonight, aged 50 years.

Lumber production dropped much more sharply last week than was to be expected seasonally and the adjusted index has declined to 80.7 from 96.9 in the preceding week. The number was 93.1 for the week ended July 4, 1936.

The Chaddsford Purse, feature at Delaware Park today, furnished the biggest upset for the 8,000 spectators when J. B. Belk's Wise Sister, a 21-1 shot, defeated Bootless by a neck. Corundum took third money.

An attempt of the Municipal Civil Service Commission to emulate British methods of selecting city employes was spiked yesterday when Supreme Court Justice Louis A. Valente ruled that it lacked power to exclude persons past 25 years old from competing for positions in the entering clerical grades.

While commitments for women's wear fabrics increased, wool goods markets generally were quiet this week, according to the report issued yesterday by the New York Wool Top Exchange Service. Unfilled orders for women's wear lines are

An emergency court at Frankenthal, Bavaria, sentenced a Catholic priest, the Rev. Karl Kilinkhammer, to eight months' imprisonment today on a charge of misusing his pulpit to agitate against the National Socialist regime.

Henry Huddleston Rogers Jr., 32, son of the late Standard Oi1 leader, has filed a divorce suit against his wife, the former Virginia Lincoln of Cleveland, charging desertion. Circuit Judge Worth W. Trammell has appointed James A. Dunn of Miami as special master to take the testimony.
Last week the ratio was 23.00 per cent; two weeks ago, 29.50. The highest ratio of the year to date was 42 per cent, on Jan, 21;

The steel companies have been getting back gradually to near-normal operation, and only the Indiana Harbor plant of the Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company remains completely idle, according to Iron Age. A blast furnace of this

A recommendation that Harry Sherman, former president of Local 306 of the Moving Picture Operators Union, be required to return $150,961 to the union's treasury has been made by George Brokaw Compton, a special referee, it was disclosed yesterday in Supreme Court.
The office of Senator Norris, Nebraska. independent, announced today that the 75-year-old Senator would leave Washington for the rest of this session of Congress.

The Arab High Committee today decided to publish a manifesto to Palestine's Arabs protesting against the proposed establishment of a Jewish State "in the most fertile part of the country" and "leaving the Arabs the hilly regions,"

A Bronx bakery was put out of business by a strike fomented among its employes at the instigation of rival bakery owners after it had failed to live up to the price schedules fixed by the United Cake, Pastry and Pie Bakers Association, of which they were all members, according to testimony yesterday in the Court of Special Sessions.

Adoption of curfew laws for minors by State, city and town governments as a means of combating youthful disrespect for law was urged today by the Rev. John J. Brophy of Concord. N. H. He spoke at the Biennial Convention of the Catholic Daughters of America.

The Reconstruction Finance Corporation today received bids on an offering of fifty-nine issues of securities of States, counties, municipalities and school districts taken over from the Public Works Administration for resale.

Temporary Assignments LIEUTENANTS-Peter J. McGowan, Traffic J, assigned in command, from 8 A. M., July 9. Martin T. Johnson, Traffic Precinct P, assigned in command, from 8 A. M., July 9, during absence of captain on sick report.
George T. Keech, for fifty years publisher of The Stanhope Eagle, a weekly newspaper, died at his home here last night after an illness of several months. His age was 85.
The jingling bells of newsboys resounded through the city before 8 A. M. today telling the citizens that peace had been restored in North China.

The National Labor Relations Board took under advisement today a charge by a Committee for Industrial Organization shipbuilders' union that the Electric Boat Company of Groton, Conn., was guilty of unfair labor practices and dominated its workers through a company union.
Six distance flights were made today at the national soaring contest, Peter Riedel of Germany making the longest hop, to Port Jervis, N. Y., 128 miles in five hours.

British hopes for European peace and especially for European peace and for an equitable adjustment of the problems arising out of the conflict in Spain were expressed by Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain tonight on the eve of a meeting of the Non-Intervention Committee in a speech to 7,000 supporters of his government gathered from all parts of the country in Albert Hall.

Death Announced Retired Fireman Arthur Carroll, formerly a member of Engine 67, residing at 276 Leonia, Ave., Leonia, N. J., died June 30. Excused The following firemen shall be excused for one day, from 9 A. M., Saturday, July 10, 1937, and shall be directed to report to Fireman Frank B. Cartwright, at Station WNYC, Municipal Building, Borough of Manhattan, at 10 A. M. on that date:
William H. (Duke) Deshon, fifty years a newspaper man, died at his home here today. He was born in Whitesboro and was graduated from Hamilton College in 1870.
Movements of livestock in the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts, 11,000, including 3,000 directs.

Chocolate Storm Troopers are not wanted in Germany. The official Gazette disclosed today that the manufacture or sale of molds designed for making confectionery figures of the Brownshirts had been prohibited.
The Foxhunters captured the title in the Brook League half of the annual Meadow Brook Club Cups polo tournament today by winning from the Narragansett riders on a forfeit.

The feature of last night's concert at Lewisohn Stadium was Dmitri Shostakovich's First Symphony, Op. 10, played by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra under Alexander Smallens. It was introduced locally about nine years ago by Leopold Stokowski and the Philadelphia Orchestra, but last night's hearing was the first at the stadium.

Alfred E. Smith came home from his first European visit yesterday a changed man. It was an infinitesimal alteration as changes go in this world, but a score of interviewers who clustered about the former Governor on the liner Manhattan's simmering upper, deck felt that, somehow, this Mr. Smith who had traveled through Italy, interviewed Mussolini, met the Pope and visited his ancestral Ireland, had come back a different man.
Steel, rail, copper and baking stocks higher; others irregular; turnover, 1,028,870 shares. United States Government loans higher; other bonds firm; transactions, $9,271,700.

The feature of this week's report on bank clearings was the decline in the total for the outside cities from a year ago, the first such decrease reported since the week of Sept. 9, 1936. The aggregate for
Construction contracts totaling $733,924, awarded by the Bureau of Yards and Docks of the Navy Department today, included the following:

Chairmen, and in some cases other officers, of the joint investigating committees and commissions of the State Legislature were selected yesterday at meetings in the Bar Association Building. The personnel of the bodies was announced last week.

The senate of the National University of Ireland, at a special session to confer honorary degrees, held in Dublin today, paid tribute to three Americans, on whom degrees of Doctor of Literature were bestowed.
Bobbie Harman, University of California, and Paul Haber of New York, by Virtue of Victories today, will meet tomorrow in the quarterfinals of the Middle Atlantic lawn tennis tournament.

Reginald A. Whitcombe, youngest of three famous golfing brothers, has displaced Ed Dudley of the United States from the lead in the British open championship. His total is 142, a three-under-par 70 today putting him on top.

The Bureau of Navigation released the following orders today, dated July 6: CAPTAIN Hickey, A. S., Washington, D. C., to command Destroyer Squadron 3. COMMANDER Haigler, F. H., Med. Corps, orders of June 3 revoked; to continue duty at the Naval Hospital, Portsmouth, N. H.
Violence flared up for the first time in the shipyard strike yesterday as two big plants of the score affected here attempted to resume operations but with only partial success.

Supreme Court Justice Samuel J. Harris ruled yesterday that the buildings erected in Knickerbocker Village were exempt from real estate taxes under the State Housing Law. His decision was declared immediately by Darwin R. James, chairman of the State Housing Board, an incentive to future investments in limited dividend housing projects.

Several patrolmen of the West Sixty-eighth Street Police Station and two thugs staged a running pistol battle yesterday morning on upper Broadway, and at the end of the fray the thugs were in Bellevue Hospital, one in a serious condition, and both charged with assault and robbery.
Miss Dorothy Teele Foale, daughter of Mrs. Myrtle Teele Foale of this city, and Kenneth B. Tuttle, son of Mr. and Mrs. Fred Tuttle of Darien, will be married July 16 in St. John's Episcopal Church.
Johnstown's Citizen Committee, an outgrowth of the 27-day-old steel strike, charted today the course of a national chain of committees "to defend the- right of local self-government."

Anna Sten, who has been absent from local screens since 1935, will return this morning in the Englishmade "Two Who Dared," opening at the Roxy. Henry Wilcoxon has the lead male role and the supporting company includes John Garrick, Viola Keats, Guy Middleton and Romilly Lunge.... German films opening today are "Eine VonUns," at the Eighty-sixth Street Casino Theatre, and "Ein Seltsamer Gast," at the Eighty-sixth Street Garden Theatre.

David M. Hooks, swimming coach of De Witt Clinton High School in New York for twenty-five years, during which he developed many scholastic swimming stars, died at his home, 297 Ogden Avenue, West Englewood, N. J., this morning after a short illness. He was 54 years old.

A new bone-setting formula which is expected to save the lives of thousands of dogs and other animals that would hitherto have had to be destroyed was described yesterday by Dr. Otto Stader at the second day meeting of the Eastern State Veterinary Conference at the Hotel New Yorker.
The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:

A move to arbitrate differences between strikers and management of the Alcoa plant of the Aluminum Company of America, where two men were killed and twenty-eight wounded in rioting yesterday, apparently collapsed tonight.
H. Townsend Blodget, architectural and interior decorator, died yesterday morning in the New York Hospital after a brief illness. He was 81 years old and lived at 90 Barrow Street.

Frederick J. Weber, inventor of the modern grain elevator and former president of the Steel Storage and Elevator Construction Company of Buffalo, died here tonight. His age was 77. He had been ill since Feb. 1.

Howard Hammell, 26 years old, of 2,021 Mill Avenue, Brooklyn, an engineer at the Borden Company's plant at 90 Third Avenue, at Bergen Street, Brooklyn, hoisted himself from a traveling crane to his death early yesterday morning, according to the police.

Mrs. Henry E. Coe gave a reception this afternoon at the Appletrees, her place here. The hostess, in costume, presented recitations with musical accompaniment of old songs and ballads that were popular during the period of 1851, and quaint poems from old birthday books published at that time.
Sussex kept in step behind Yorkshire at the top of the English county cricket championship table today, trouncing Worcestershire by nine wickets. The match was completed in two days.

The National Football League will make the earliest start in its history during the coming season, according to the schedule released today by Joe F. Carr, president of the organization. The official opening is listed for Sept. 5, with Philadelphia traveling to Pittsburgh for the league inaugural.

Joseph P. Ryan, president of the International Longshoremen's Association, an affiliate of the American Federation of Labor, accused John L. Lewis of bad faith yesterday following the announcement of Lewis's plan to organize all maritime workers of the nation under the Committee for Industrial Organization.
The text of the petition presented to Mayor La Guardia follows: Republican Committee for the Renomination of Mayor La Guardia. New York City, June 1, 1937.

Beginning on Monday the Treasury will offer a new series of $50,000,000 bill issues maturing around Dec. 15, when a quarterly installment of Federal taxes will be due, Secretary Morgenthau announced today.

Gross assets, $6,942; net, $5,431. To friend, Elizabeth Lyons. Chief assets, stocks and bonds, $1,870; mortgages, notes, cash and insurance, $5,071. Joseph E. Keenan, attorney, 32 Court St. HALLORAN, MARY E. (Feb. 29, 1936).

There is considered to be little more than purely local interest in "Women of Property" presented at the Queesn Theatre tonight in the translation by Frank Davision from the Finnish of Hella Wuolijoki.

John Kick, 20 years old, of 179 Marcy Avenue, Brooklyn, who pleaded guilty of second-degree murder last week, was sentenced yesterday by Kings County Judge George W. Martin to serve from twenty years to life in Sing Sing.

James J. Hoey, Collector of Internal Revenue, announced yesterday the distribution of two forms which must be filed with his office before July 31, in connection with the records of payments under the Social Security Act.

A bullish construction was placed today by the European and North American grain trade on the crop report issued late yesterday by the Searle Grain Company of Winnipeg estimating the condition of the wheat crop in the three Canadian Provinces at 40 per cent of normal, compared with 70 per cent at this season in 1936.

The marriage of Miss Janet Emerson McMullen, daughter of Mrs. Thomas McMullen of Brooklyn and the late Mr. McMullen, to Carl Edward Rugen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis C. Rugen of Plainfield, N. J., took place last night in the Memorial Presbyterian Church, Brooklyn. The ceremony was performed

Guests at luncheon today at the Greenbrier Golf and Tennis Club of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas A. Northrup were Mr. and Mrs. O. E. Grow, Mrs. Charles A. Ludley, the Misses Patricia and Suzanne Ludley and Donald Northrup. Mrs.

Adoption of a $3.25 wholesale dress price line for Fall replacing the $2.87 1/2 range was formally voted yesterday at a meeting of $2.87 1/2 dress manufacturers held at the offices of the Popular Price Dress Manufacturers' Group, 1,440 Broadway. The action will affect about

Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Allen Fairchild of Noroton, Conn., announced the marriage of their daughter, Miss Priscilla Sears Fairchild, to Dr. Arthur John Smyth, son of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Arthur Worsley Smyth of Cambridge, England, which took place on Tuesday in the Church of the Transfiguration, this city. The Rev. Harold F.

Although Borough President LEVY first assumed his present office during the troublous times of Tammany rule, when strange things were happening in the city government, he has been able to catch the spirit of a newer and better day. In private life a successful

The War Department released the following, orders today, dated July 7: MAJOR GENERAL Gibbins, H., the Quartermaster General, one month leave, July 15. COLONELS Bryden, W. (F. A.), General Staff Corps, seven days leave, July 9.

Supreme Court Justice Albert Conway in Brooklyn granted a permanent injunction yesterday restraining the New York and Queens Electric Light and Power Company and the Consolidated Edison Company from amending the charter of the former to permit the preferred stock of the concern to be subject to call and retirement.

A sharp upturn in livestock and meats, gains in milk, butter and eggs and higher prices for bituminous coal, tin, silk and rubber sent The Annalist weekly index of wholesale commodity prices considerably higher last week.
A sentence of one to three years in State prison was imposed today on Irving M. Weissman, a disbarred lawyer of 215 Spring Street, Passaic, by Judge J. Wallace Layden in Special Sessions Court.
The prepared address of Joseph H. Choate Jr. in behalf of a Republican group urging the Mayor to run again follows: Mayor La Guardia: I have been
Aluminium, Ltd., has declared a dividend of $4 on account of arrears and the regular quarterly dividend of $1.50, on the 6 per cent cumulative preferred stock. Three months
Fifty chairmen of State, county and town committees of the Berkshire Music Festival met this afternoon at Tanglewood, Stockbridge, where the festival is to be held in August.
It was by a counsel of strategy in the Court Bill fight that Republicans in Congress and many outside party leaders were persuaded to remain silent while the Democrats assailed one another.

The marriage of Miss Arlene Hill Zerega, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John P. Zerega of Brooklyn and this place, to William Joseph Kent Jr. of Brooklyn and South Norwalk, Conn., took place this morning in the Church of Our Lady of the Snow, Blue Point. The ceremony,

Several witnesses appeared today before the House Interstate and Foreign Commerce Committee to urge passage of the Martin bill providing that the Federal Trade Commission be given jurisdiction to enforce regulations for the identification of fabrics.

Governor Lehman named an unofficial committee of forty-two citizens today to pave the way for the constitutional convention opening here in April, by collecting data which will be of service to that gathering.

For the first time in more than a year the Federal Theatre Project next Monday evening will have no show playing in the Broadway district. Three of the WPA's offerings are scheduled to close tomorrow night, leaving only Harlem's Lafayette Theatre to offer under government auspices the full-length drama to Manhattan.

Common sense seems to have triumphed in breaking the constitutional deadlock in India. Following the provincial elections during February-the first held under the new Constitutionthe All-India Congress party won absolute majorities in six of the eleven provinces of British India.

Marvin Kantrowitz of New York provided his second upset of a seeded player by defeating his University of Texas room-mate, Melvin Lapman, also of New York, 6-1, 6-1, in a quarter-final match of the Agawam Hunt singles today.
Planes from the battleship Colorado, seeking trace of Amelia Earhart, returned without clues tonight after their second day of flight over the area where she vanished.
A campaign to discourage the "no down payment" and "four years to pay" policy followed by some house appliance establishments was recommended today by the National Retail Furniture Association.

A survey covering fourteen of the largest cities in this country indicates that a rise in real estate tax rates for 1937 has been general and that to meet this additional charge and the growing cost of operation increases in rentals in the coming season should be expected, according to Eli T. Watson Co., Inc., who made the survey.
The five houses at 350-358 East Seventy-ninth Street, near the southwest corner of First Avenue, have been sold by the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company to the Lewine Realty Corporation.

An application by the Cleveland Stock Exchange to strike from its listing and registration 50,000 Class A shares of no par value of the North American Securities Company has been granted by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

The marriage of Miss Theresa Fish of Norwalk, teacher in the Center Junior High School, to Dr. Thomas Cody of New Canaan, former interne at St. Vincent's Hospital, was announced here today. The couple were married in Brooklyn, N. Y., in January.
It is very uncertain that Pedro Montahez will meet Lou Ambers in New York for the world lightweight championship, Pedro's manager, Lou Burston, said before departing for New York late today.

Papers were filed here today in the Essex County Clerk's office for the incorporation of the Braddock Holding Company, with James J. Braddock, former world's heavyweight boxing champion, as holder of 98 per cent of the capital stock of 2,500 shares with no-par value.

Bids totaling $1,021,135.97 for twentyeight vessels of its laid-up fleet were opened today at the Maritime Commission. A few weeks ago the commission rejected a bid of $350,000 for this same group offered for sale for scrap purposes.
The Wheeling Steel Corporation reported yesterday for the five months ended on May 31 a net profit of $2,693,521 after depreciation, depletion, Federal income taxes and other charges.

Luis Manuel Debayle, Foreign Minister of Nicaragua, began today a series of conferences with Federal officials here looking toward reorganization of Nicaragua's financial systern and the clarification of several collateral economic problems.

Wholesale prices continued their current upward trend during the week ended on July 3, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today. The index, based on the 1926 average as 100, rose to 87.2 from 86.7 the preceding week, and compared with 79.5 a year ago.
Alterations formed the bulk of building projects submitted by architects yesterday. Changes will be made in several structures in Manhattan and Brooklyn.

BENDA, JOHN (May 1). Estate, less than $1,000. To Charles Benda, son, 404 E. 73d St, and William Benda, son, executor, 432 E. 72d St, one-half residue each; one other bequest. HIRSCH, MIRIAN G. (July 2). Estate, less than $10,000. To Emelie H. Reiter,

Premier Benito Mussolini today removed one of the British Government's many anxieties over Palestine by announcing that he had forbidden any further anti-British broadcasts in Arabic or other attempts by Italy to stir up Arab hostility against the British Empire.

Displaying the vivacity which fitted them for their work of keeping "the boy in the iron lung" cheerful, the seven Chinese nurses who attended Frederick Snite Jr., infantile paralysis victim, on his 12,000-mile trip from China to Chicago, arrived in New York yesterday for a week of sightseeing and inspection of local hospitals.
Lady Clifford, wife of the Hon. Sir Bede E. H. Clifford, Governor of the Bahamas, is at the Ritz-Carlton. Mr. and Mrs. Van Lear Black Jr. of Baltimore are at the Weylin.
President Roosevelt discussed administrative economies with the heads of twenty-eight independent agencies and "reviewed" the Boy Scouts attending the jamboree.

In excess of 4,000 branded items have been placed under the provisions of the Feld-Crawford Fair Trade Act by more than eighty-five manufacturers of nationally advertised drug and cosmetic products, it was reported yesterday at a meeting of the fair trade committee of the New York.State Pharmaceutical Association in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

William L. Cheney, editor of Collier's Magazine, was elected president of the Pelham Board of Education at its annual meeting tonight. Joseph V. Connolly, in charge of Hearst Features and News Services, and Fred B. Wright, Eastern general sales manager of the Western Electric Company, were installed as new members of the board.

About forty physicians in New York County are to be haled before the State Medical Grievance Committee for disciplinary action in irregularities in connection with fraudulent accident indemnity claims during recent years, it was announced yesterday at a luncheon conference of the committee, held in the Academy of Medicine.

It was revealed today that the Spanish oil tanker Campoamor which left here under mysterious circumstances Tuesday midnight without clearing was able to get off because the Loyalist members of the crew had gone ashore to attend a dance.

The combined net earnings after taxes of the Marine Midland Corporation and its constituent banks, trust companies and other affiliates for the quarter ended on June 30 amounted, after adjustment to minority interests, to $1,050,768. This was equal to 18 cents a share on the outstanding stock.

A few weeks ago the American Federation of Labor seemed to be losing on all fronts to the Committee for Industrial Organization. Its comparative losses were not surprising. The C. I. O. was organizing workers that the A. F. of L. had never seriously attempted to organize. The C. I. O. was

The Manufacturers Trust Company is trustee for $9,771,000 tenyear 4 1/4 per cent debentures, due Aug. 1, 1946, of the Adams Express Company. Joseph P. Smith is in the sales organization of Van Alstyne, Noel Co.

Forty-one policemen today ordered pickets of the American Newspaper Guild away from the neighborhood of The Seattle Star plant when the newspaper, closed four days by a strike, announced it would reopen tomorrow morning under police guard.

William Green declared the steel strike was a failure and that John L. Lewis and the C. I. O. had hurt labor's cause. Page 1. Republic Steel reopened its last struck plant at Cleveland and declared 3,800 men were at work there. Page 2.
Nova Scotia's first tuna of the 1937 season was taken at Lobster Bay late yesterday by Herman Gray, a Florida guide.

Mrs. William Andros Barron gave a luncheon today at the Crawford House in honor of members of the White Mountain Garden Club, of which she is a charter member. After the luncheon the Boston Symphony Orchestra ensemble gave a musical program.

Electric power production eased slightly last week when an increase was called for by seasonal and longterm trends, and the adjusted index has declined to 105.3 from 106.6 in the previous week. The number was 103.6 for the week ended July 4, 1936.

Assertions that the Ford Motor Company workers who attacked officers of the United Automobile Workers Union on May 26 when they tried to supervise the distribution of union leaflets at the River Rouge plant were "typical hoodlums" were made by witnesses today before John T. Lindsay, trial examiner,

The serious clash between Chinese and Japanese troops on the outskirts of Peiping calls attention to the extraordinary situation that makes possible Japanese army manoeuvres in the capital of North China.

The possibilities of American neutrality in the "next war" were argued tonight before the Institute of Public Affairs of the University of Virginia by Representative H. Jerry Voorhis of California and Dr. Clark M. Eichelberger, director of the League of Nations Association.

Samuel Kronsky Co has arranged a first mortgage building loan for $135,000 on the apartment building under construction on the west side of Morris Ave, 208.10 feet south of E 167th St, the Bronx, for the Ten Twenty Four Walton Corp.

Orders received by the General Electric Company in the first six months of this year amounted to $217,265,619, an increase of 59 per cent over the $136,968,597 received in the same period last year, according to an announcement yesterday by Gerard Swope, president. The record first half-year

The Rev. Dr. Nathan E. Wood, former president of the Newton Theological Seminary, an author and Baptist pastor, died today at the home of his son, the Rev. Dr. Nathan R. Wood, president of Gordon College of Theology and Missions. His age was 88.

Gerard Ave, (9-2474) s e cor of 161st St, 111x91; Anne Mink to East River Savings Bank; extends mtgs to May 1, 1942, at 4 1/2 per cent; $160,000. Carpenter Ave, 4,116-4,118 (17-4832) Resco Holding Corp to Metropolitan Life Insurance Co, 1 Madison Ave; extends mtg to
Roger Taylor Gregory, former member of the Virginia State Legislature and prominent attorney, died tonight at his home in New Kent County. He was 71 years old.

Renewal of interest in United States Government obligations was responsible for some sizable gains in the Federal list yesterday, and while the trading pace was maintained in other sections the advances in bonds traded in on the New York Stock Exchange were not so pronounced as in three previous sessions.
As the thermometer mounted so did the scores of the competitors in the Women's Westchester-Fairfield Golf Association one-day event at the Silver Spring Country Club this morning.

Facing a crowd of 1,000 cheering Republicans on the green sloping lawn of the Chisholm Mansion in College Point, Mayor La Guardia formally accepted yesterday their petition asking him to run for reelection and asked for the election of a united Board of Estimate.
Mickey Cochrane, struck on the head six weeks ago by a pitched ball in New York, has left the Henry Ford Hospital to continue his convalescence at home. Dizzy spells which
Bernie (Schoolboy) Friedkin, Brownsville featherweight, fought a ten-round draw with Johnny Pena, South Brooklyn, in the main bout at the Fort Hamilton Army Reservation in Brooklyn last night.

Despite that the week ended yesterday was a short week due to the Fourth of July holiday, engineering construction awards reached a total of $66,998,000, and exceeded the total for the same week of last year by 10 per cent, the figure then being $60,847,000, according to the Engineering News-Record. Awards for private work dropped

Some 8,000,000,000 francs was added to the burden of the French taxpayer today when Finance Minister Georges Bonnet got Cabinet approval for plans he had drafted since his return here from Washington for getting the budget balanced and restoring order to French finance.

The Cuban Government's Public Works Bonds Commission, which is studying a settlement of these defaulted obligations, made public today its proposal for payment of the $40,000,000 of bonds in the hands of American and Cuban investors, but made no mention of obligations of other types which are involved.

Miss Anne Bramhall Miles, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George H. Miles of Rumson and New York, has set the date for her marriage to Robert Shippee, son of Mr. and Mrs. Carl Shippee of Fair Haven, as Saturday, July 24, at noon.

On the strength of a succession of birdies on the out nine, Bob Gray, Windsor, Ont., pro, posted a two-underpar 68 over the Fonthill Country Club layout today to top the field of seventy-seven in the first round of the $4,000 General Brock open golf tournament.

The Salisbury Times, a daily, and The Wicomico News, a weekly, appeared today under new ownership. Alfred T. Truitt and Charles J. Truitt, publishers of the newspapers, announced the sale of the papers to the Brush-Moore Newspapers, Inc.,. of Canton, Ohio. Gale was effective today.
The 1937 Wateler Peace Prize, amounting to [Pound]2,100, has been awarded to Lord BadenPowell, founder of the Boy Scouts, for his work in promoting peace among the youth of all nations.
Decision of Assemblyman William E. Morris of Waterford not to seek re-election and an intraparty contest for nomination as District Attorney enlivened Saratoga County Republican politics today.

The Coast Guard announced today the following changes for the week ended July 7: WARRANT OFFICERS Aviation Chief Machinist's Mate W. D. Pinkston, office inspector, Hall Aluminum Aircraft Company, Bristol, Pa., tendered acting appointment as machinist by Department letter June 23; executed oath June 29.
The following Marine Corps changes for the week ended July 8 were announced today:
There was no change in the level of business activity in the Pittsburgh district last week, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh. The adjusted index

Early resumption of normal operation of the cloak industry was foreseen last night as representatives of the joint board of the Cloakmakers Union and employers moved toward an agreement expected to terminate the work stoppage of 35,000 employes in more than 1,500 shops, begun yesterday morning.
When Katherine G. Koenig sold to Salvatore Monteleone the flats at 406-408 E 13th St for $6,500 she took back a purchase money mortgage for $5,150, at 5 1/2 per cent.
The following table shows the ten most active stocks traded on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday; also the new highs and lows for the past three days:

NORTH OF THE RIME-RINGED SUN: AN ALASKAN JOURNEY, by Isobel W. Hutchison. (Hillman-Curl, $2.50.) A woman's adventures in Alaska. NO MORE REMAINS, by Leonard O. Mosley. (Doubleday, Doran, $2.) A new book by the author of "So I Killed Her."

GOVERNORS ISLAND Second Lieut. George A. Reynolds, Ord.Res., 468 13th St., Niagara Falls, N. Y., 502d Ordnance Company, is ordered to active duty July 4 at Raritan Arsenal, N. J., for training. Lieutenant Reynolds will rank from July 4, 1937. He will be relieved from active duty July 17.

Preliminary estimates set Australia's favorable trade balance for the year ended on June 30 at [Pound]35,580,000, compared with [Pound]22,597,000 for the 1935-6 fiscal period. Imports were [Pound]92,499,000, including [Pound]2,072,000 gold from New Guinea for re-export, compared with [Pound]82,250,000.

William Heilmann, former Essex County Freeholder and a funeral director in Newark for many years, died last night at his home here, 73 West End Avenue, after a month's illness of a heart ailment. He was 80 years old.

Cecil P. Stewart, chairman of the Bondholders Committee of the Postal Telegraph Cable Corporation, yesterday made a statement with reference to a report in THE NEW YORK TIMES that the Attorney General is looking into the possibility of proceeding under the Anti-Trust Laws against the Postal and Western Union Telegraph Companies. The statement follows in part:
Newark's Bears exploded 21 hits all over Oriole Park tonight to trounce Baltimore, 17 to 3.

Republic Steel Corporation reopened the last of its strike-closed plants today. Steel Tubes, Inc., employing normally about 500 men and the smallest of Republic's four Cleveland units, was opened to workers while police and Ohio National Guardsmen formed a protective circle at the mill.

Harvard University astronomers predicted today that the large comet discovered a few days ago by Dr. P. Finsler, a Swiss astronomer, would swing steadily nearer the earth until early in August, becoming visible to the unaided eye late this month.

Activity in Long Island real estate reported yesterday mainly involved industrial properties. The six-story reinforced concrete loft building at 40-09 Twenty-first Street, adjoining the Bridge Plaza, in Long Island City, has been sold by the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank to Bernard L. Touroff through Roman-Caswell Company, Inc., brokers.
More than 7,000 political prisoners have passed through the hands of the police since the Leftist uprising in November, 1935. according to figures divulged today by Chief of Police Filinto Muller.

The Alleghany Corporation, largest and best known of the holding companies set up by the late O. P. and M. J. Van Sweringen to control a $3,000,000,000 system of railroads, real estate, coal companies and other enterprises, is to be dissolved, it was announced yesterday by Robert R. Young, Allan P. Kirby and Frank F. Kolbe, new owners of the structure.

Two hundred and eighty Croats from the United States and Canada arrived here today, led by President Butkovich of the Pittsburgh Fraternal Croat Union. They were received at the station by enthusiastic crowds and then paraded through the streets, which were lined by thousands.

Mrs. Mary Belcher Trapnell, daughter of Frank J. Belcher Jr. of San Francisco and San Diego, Calif., was married at noon yesterday to Major Walter Greatsinger Farrell, United States Marine Corps, at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Edgar G. Crossman, 1,148 Fifth Avenue. The Rev. George C.

Exports and imports of the United States by classified groups of merchandise in May, as announced by the Department of Commerce. are compared below with those of the preceding month and with May, 1936. Exports as given cover only
Becalmed on Passamaquoddy Bay, the Franklin D. Roosevelts Jr. had to send for a tow today when the wind failed their sailboat.

The shooting as spies for Japan of sixty-four more executives and employes of the Soviet Far Eastern railway system was reported today by Japanese consular officials in the Far East to the Japanese Embassy in Moscow.
Edward Francis Hart of South Norwalk, Conn., president of the National Engraving Company, here, for twenty years, died on Wednesday in St. Luke's Hospital after a long illness. He was 55 years old.

The stock market was quiet and firm today, with most sections closing slightly higher. Gilt-edge issues were in good demand, with German obligations going ahead. Transatlantics. reflecting yesterday's late profittaking in Wall Street, had to absorb offerings with the result the list sagged generally.
