Mrs. Jacob Hekma entertained at her home for luncheon here today in honor of her daughter-in-law, Mrs. Nicholas Barry Hekma, the former Miss Colleen Cooper of Chicago, daughter of Mrs. Harry Noel Leist of that city and the late Charles Leonard Cooper.

Representative Mitchell of Illinois said today that George J. Trivers, Negro midshipman, had resigned from the Naval Academy because he found he could not do a midshipman's work. Mr. Mitchell, the only Negro member of Congress, appointed Trivers to the academy.

-The Jersey City Giants finally snapped out of their twelve-game losing streak today by shelling a trio of Syracuse pitchers for eighteen hits and a decisive 12-to-0 triumph in the opener of a six-game series.

Hanus Resek, a director of the Anglo-Czechoslovak and Prague Credit Bank, was elected yesterday to membership in the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. Mr. Resek is manager of the sugar department of the Exchange.

Proposals will be considered by the State Treasurer of Maryland at Annapolis on Aug. 10 for the sale of $3,408,000 State of Maryland 2 3/4 per cent general-construction bonds. A block of $900,000 of the bonds will be dated June 15, 1937, and the remainder Aug. 15, 1937.

The bitterest Senate session in recent years took place today before packed galleries as administration leaders invoked seldom-used rules to hinder a threatened filibuster against the compromise Court Bill and protect their debaters from the cross-fire of the opposition.

An ingenious lawyer announces that he is going to Washington to get a "sympathetic hearing" for a proposal that movie stars should be allowed a deduction on their income tax for the annual "depreciation" of their drawing power because of the passage of time and the fickleness of the public.

Movements of vessels follow, all dates are July 7, unless specified: At Mare Island Yard: MacDonough, Aylwin, Arctic. At Tsingtao, July 8: Bittern, Chaumont. At Portland: Cincinnati, King, Lawrence, Sands. At Savannah,. Ga., July 8: Decatur, Dickerson.

Henry Armstrong, the hard-hitting Los Angeles boxer, who is recognized in many quarters as the world featherweight champion, added another knockout victory to his list last night when he stopped Alf Blatch, Australian lightweight champion, at Madison Square Garden.

Ambassador Alexander Troyanovsky of Soviet Russia will sail today on the French liner Ile de France. Others listed for Plymouth and Havre include Jean Appert, financial adviser of the French Embassy; Emil Ludwig, author, with Mrs. Ludwig; Isaac F. Marcosson,

The port authorities at Constanza prevented today the departure of the Swedish steamer Kolia with a cargo of thirty-two carloads of ammunition reported to have been shipped from Poland consigned to Greece. The Rumanian authorities,

A summons charging third-degree assault on John Drennan, a newspaper photographer, was served yesterday on Enzo Fiermonte in the Rikers Island penitentiary, where Mr. Fiermonte is serving a five-day sentence for speeding three years ago. Mr. Fiermonte is accused of
Unfilled orders of the American Car and Foundry Company on July 1 amounted to $27,338,000, against

The Award of the International Youth's Distinguished Service Citation was made tonight to Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd, retired, by the International Society of Christian Endeavor and the World's Christian Endeavor Union, which opened a week's convention here today -with many thousands in attendance.

Municipal SENIOR ARCHITECT (HOSPITALS), GRADE 4--Salary: $4,800 per annum; pension; fair sick leave. Vacancies: One in the Department of Hospitals at $4,800 per annum; new title. Ages: Through 55, on July 22. Candidates beyond this age may be adnitted to the examination if they present qualifications sufficiently outstanding to warrant exception as to age. Applications:
Just under another speed-eclipsing performance, the record-breaking Ranger of Harold S. Vanderbilt took the second race for the George Nichols Cup today in tuning up for her America's Cup defense.

The Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company has launched a contest for the naming of a new monthly magazine which it will distribute through its 15,000 retail outlets throughout the country. The contest closes on Aug. 20. While details of the new venture were meager yesterday, the magazine will accept advertising, it is understood.

In what is believed to be the first action of its kind by any out-oftown publishing company, the J. B. Lippincott Company, Philadelphia, yesterday placed all of its regular trade books under the provisions of the Feld-Crawford Fair Trade Act in this State. Joseph W. Lippincott,

In one respect the so-called " compromise " court plan now before the Senate is an even worse measure than the President's original proposal. Under the original bill additional appointments to the Supreme. Court would have been mandatory. Under the new bill they
The Senate Committee on Education and Labor reversed the formula for fixing maximum hours and minimum wages in the Black-Connery Bill and then gave it a favorable report today.
The Soviet Government threatened Japan with open warfare today if Japanese troops do not keep out of Siberia.

Bronx Blvd (17-4820), n e cor of 224th St, 114x105; John T. Javasile to Derby Realty Corp, 119 W 40th St. Bronx Blvd (16-4653), e s, 330 ft s of 222dSt, 132x105; same to same. Clay Ave, 1,354 (11-2887); Shirley Kahn, referee, to North Side Savings Bank, 3,230 3d Ave.
The American all-star lacrosse team won its sixth consecutive victory today when it defeated an allEngland team, 12 to 8.

Elevator service in the Chrysler Building was interrupted for about ten minutes at the height of the lunch-hour rush yesterday when a delegation of ten women representing trade unions, church groups and peace organizations sought to register a protest with Republic Steel Corporation officials against the company's "un-American". attitude toward labor.

Stocks of domestic slab zinc at the end of June amounted to 14,081 tons, compared with 13,774 at the end of May and 84,855 on June 30, last year, according to the American Zinc Institute. Shipments in June amounted to 50,219 tons, against 55,201 in May, while production last month was 50,526 tons, compared with 55,012 in May.
William P. Gannon, former Corporation Counsel of Syracuse and lawyer for many large corporations in cases in this city, died tonight in his home at 119 South Avenue. He would have been 76 on July 17.

Retail package deliveries in the metropolitan and suburban areas showed no change, in comparison with a year ago, for the week ended July 3, it was reported yesterday by the United Parcel Service. In the previous week, that of June 26,

Circuit Judge Sherman D. Callendar awarded Mrs. Laura Miller Boyer $1,000,000 in cash and securities today from the estate of her father-in-law, Joseph A. Boyer, chairman of the board of the Burroughs Adding Machine Company, who died in 1931.

Continued contraction in the outstanding credit of reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve in this city was reported for the week ended on Wednesday, covered by their condition statement issued yesterday. The total of the banks'

Miss Helen Bernhard and Miss Patricia Cumming will meet in the final of the junior girls' center tennis championship tournament at the Amackassin Tennis Club in Yonkers, N. Y., this morning at 11 o'clock. Both scored triumphs in

The Rev. William C. Kidd, principal of the Lakewood High School and volunteer pastor of the Hope Presbyterian Church, committed suicide last night, according to a report today by County Coroner Raymond A. Taylor. Mr. Kidd was 48 years

Blistering heat baked more than half of the country yesterday as temperatures mounted to new highs for the year at various points from the Rocky Mountains eastward to the Atlantic Coast. Temporary but slight relief was forecast for the city today.

The acute shortage of rayon yarn persists, with producers' stocks negligible as of June 30, although deliveries to domestic mills were slightly lower last month, compared with May, according to a report

There were 16,578 licensed pilots and 7,914 license aircraft in this country on July 1, the Bureau of Air Commerce reported today, as compared with 15,204 pilots and 7,403 licensed planes on the same date last year.

The seventh annual invitation cruise of privately owned seaplanes, amphibians and flying boats got under way here this afternoon as nineteen aircraft roared away toward Montauk Point. The cruise will last four days.

Arthur J. Davis, an employee of the Consolidated Edison Co. in New York, was killed instantly here this afternoon when the automobile he was driving crashed into a tree at the side of the Middle Country Road near Southern Boulevard.

Polish Jewry received the Palestine report with mixed feelings. The Jews rejoice that the necessity for creating an independent Jewish State at last has been admitted by Great Britain, but they oppose the Royal Commission's findings because, it is contended, the Jews are robbed of the major part of Palestine.

The rental schedule for Fairfield Court, $884,000 PWA Housing Project, facing Fairfield Avenue, in Stamford, Conn., was made public yesterday by PWA Administrator Ickes through the PWA Housing Division offices here.

Public health experts, medical specialists and members of Congress testified today before a Joint Committee of Congress in support of legislation which, the nation's leading cancer experts assert, will mark the longest step forward ever taken in the battle to control cancer.

4:00-4:15 P. M.-"The Needs of Spain's Children," Bishop Francis J. McConnell of New York-WOR. 4:30-5:00 P. M.-An Evaluation of the American Youth Congress: Homer Rainey, Chairman American Youth Commission of the American Council of Education; Senator Claude Pepper of Florida-WOR.

Further delay in holding a collective-bargaining referendum on the B. M. T. rapid transit, street car and bus lines, or any attempt to deprive any of the company's 12,500 employes of an opportunity to take part in such an election, is "an invitation to strike," the Transport Workers Union notified the City Industrial Relations Board yesterday.

Mrs. Walter O. Ford gave a dinner last night in the Viennese Roof Garden of the St. Regis for Mrs. Edwin C. McCullough. The party was in celebration of the birthday of both the hostess and her guest of honor. Other guests included

Captain Donald MacPhee, who came to this country from England as navigating officer of the T. O. M. Sopwith America's Cup challenging yacht Endeavour II, died this afternoon in the Newport Hospital, where he had been under treatment for gastric ulcers. His age was 56.
Cargo traffic through the Panama Canal from the Atlantic to the Pacific Oceans set a record during the fiscal year 1937, exceeding the former high mark made in 1929.
The report of the Bank of Canada for the week ended yesterday shows that the ratio of net reserve to notes and deposit liabilities was 60.55 per cent, compared with 59.79 per cent the week before.

The American Museum of Natural History sold to the Shafecraus Realty Corporation, organized and represented by Morris A. Crausman, attorney, the six-story walkup apartment house at 1,271 Merriam Avenue, the Bronx.

The Communications Department was advised today, that the bodies of four members of a railroad surveying party, missing eight days in the deserts of the State of Sonora, had been sighted from the air.

The Burlington Transportation Corporation, a motor-carrier subsidiary of the Chicago, Burlington Quincy Railroad, operating buses and trucks on routes extending to San Francisco from Chicago and into the Northwest, applied today to the Interstate Commerce Commission for authority to buy control of one motor carrier and control of two others through leaseholds.

Bill Sefton, the national pole vault champion, arrived in New York last night simultaneously with his entry for the World Labor Athletic Carnival at Randalls Island Stadium on Sunday and man's first fifteen-foot vault immediately became a possibility.

A slayer who narrowly escaped capture shortly afterward as a hitand-run driver trapped John Pizzo, 43 years old, proprietor of the Porter Cloak and Suit Company, in the hallway of the factory building at 117 Gratten Street, Brooklyn, housing his concern, and shot him five times in the back and neck at 7:40 o'clock last night.
A paradoxical change in the reserve position of member banks of the Federal Reserve System in the first week of this month was shown in the weekly statistics of the system, published yesterday.
Borough President Samuel Levy and former Deputy Controller Frank J. Prial joined forces yesterday, to fight in the Democratic primaries for the nominations for Mayor and Controller, respectively.
The Chase National Bank has leased space for two more branches to be opened this Fall in Rockefeller Center. The new units will

Governor and Mrs. Lehman will be among the spectators at the seventh annual Country Club Horse Show, which will start this morning to continue through Sunday afternoon, with two sessions each day. They will visit the exhibition

A net asset value of $40.18 a share was shown for the 2,081,580 capital shares of the Lehman Corporation resulting from the recent three-for-one split-up as of June 30, according to Robert Lehman, president, in his report for the fiscal year ended on that date.

Announcement has been made of the marriage of Miss Kathleen Alicia Clark, daughter of Frank J. Clark of Brooklyn and the late Mrs. Clark, to Chester J. Maxson Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Chester J. Maxson of Buffalo.

Two new buildings for the New York World's Fair, to cost a total of $575,000, were announced yesterday by Grover A. Whalen, president of the Fair Corporation, at a luncheon to the fair's architects, designers and artists.

Mrs. Edna Christian, 38 years old, and her son, Charles, 7, sailed tonight on the liner Rangitata to claim a small farm and native house on Pitcairn Island, inherited from Fletcher Christian, one of the original mutineers of the ship Bounty.
The Gordon-O'Neill Company, liquor dealers, purchased the fourstory factory building at 120 Sherman Avenue, Jersey City, N. J., through J. I. Kislak, Inc., and Riker Co., Inc., co-brokers.

Although materially below the estimate of private forecasters, the trade accepted generally the report yesterday of the Department of Agriculture placing the area planted to cotton this year at 34,192,000 acres. The reports brought out a
Professor Anna G. Pease, early educator in the Middle West and widow of Dr. Jerome F. Pease, died on Tuesday in the Roosevelt Hospital after a short illness. She was 83 years old.

Six patrolmen in three radio cars from the Bath Beach precinct, Brooklyn, raced to the private garage of Mrs. Anna Treumann of 2,156 Seventy-sixth Street, Brooklyn, at 11:15 A. M. yesterday and there bravely dispatched a six-inch garter snake.

Full military honors accompanied the funeral this afternoon of Captain Paul J. Dashiell, U.S.N. (retired), connected with the Naval Academy Department of Physics and Chemistry for nearly forty years and first chairman of the Intercollegiate Football Rules Committee.

With the completion of the roof of the new Reichsbank building--the largest building in Berlin--Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, the bank's president, to-day compared the slow but solid construction of this edifice with the building up of the National Socialist party.

President Manuel Quezon of the Philippines left tonight for Paris after having luncheon with Hans G. V. von Mackensen, Foreign Office UnderSecretary, and about fifty representatives of the government and the German Far Eastern trade.

Contract for construction of the New Jersey approach to the Lincoln Tunnel has been awarded by the Port of New York Authority to George M. Brewster Son, Inc., of Bogota, N. J., for $2,257,205, the lowest bid of several recently received.

Down Constitution Avenue from the Capitol to Twenty-third Street, N. W., and then northward for two blocks alongside the Naval Hospital, President and Mrs. Roosevelt rode slowly today to "pass in review" before more than 26,000 wildly cheering Boy Scouts and about 3,000 older Scouters, leaders and Scoutmasters making a line about two miles long.

Building of a model community to house 40,000 persons on a comparatively unimproved tract of 350 acres in Forest Hills, Queens, without sacrifice of playground space or property values, is proposed in a report made public yesterday by a group of residents.

Expressions of disappointment were general here yesterday among persons interested in the future of Palestine on reading the British Royal Commission's proposal for the division of the Holy Land into three States.

The Ministry of National Defense issued the following communique at 11 o'clock tonight regarding the great offensive now under way: "South of Tagus River troops of the Seventh Army Corps started an offensive at daybreak and have taken the Sierra Suarez and the village of Rena.

Premier Benito Mussolini's second son, Bruno, wrote his name this morning among the holders of world aviation records by flying, together with his father's flying instructor, Lieut. Col. Attillo Biseo, and a mechanic, a distance of 1,000 kilometers with a load of two metric tons at a speed of 263.223 miles an hour.

Schnapps, brown colt, owned by W. N. Reynolds of Winston-Salem, N. C., sprang a surprise at the North Randall Grand Circuit races today when he beat the Hambletonian favorite, Twilight Song, in the $6,065 championship stallion stake for trotters.
Tumbling from a falling pony in a polo match at the Meadow Brook Club, today, Howell Howard of Dayton, Ohio, suffered a fractured skull and possibly a broken neck.

The steady decline in the percentage gained by Princeton athletic teams, which has prevailed since 1934, when it stood at an all-time high of .656, culminated during the past college year with an average of .496, a survey released today by the university athletic association reveals.

At least 25,789 had asked for application blanks with a view to renting apartments in the new $13,500,000 PWA-financed Williamsburg Houses when the time for registering applications was closed officially at midnight Wednesday, the PWA Housing Division announced yesterday.

Six patrolmen in three radio cars from the Bath Beach precinct, Brooklyn, raced to the private garage of Mrs. Anna Treumann of 2,156 Seventy-sixth Street, Brooklyn, at 11:15 A. M. yesterday and there bravely dispatched a six-inch garter snake.

Full military honors accompanied the funeral this afternoon of Captain Paul J. Dashiell, U.S.N. (retired), connected with the Naval Academy Department of Physics and Chemistry for nearly forty years and first chairman of the Intercollegiate Football Rules Committee.

With the completion of the roof of the new Reichsbank building--the largest building in Berlin--Dr. Hjalmar Schacht, the bank's president, to-day compared the slow but solid construction of this edifice with the building up of the National Socialist party.

President Manuel Quezon of the Philippines left tonight for Paris after having luncheon with Hans G. V. von Mackensen, Foreign Office UnderSecretary, and about fifty representatives of the government and the German Far Eastern trade.

Contract for construction of the New Jersey approach to the Lincoln Tunnel has been awarded by the Port of New York Authority to George M. Brewster Son, Inc., of Bogota, N. J., for $2,257,205, the lowest bid of several recently received.

Under the influence of the most aggressive buying operations since the advance in the market last March, prices on the Cotton Exchange rose $1 a bale yesterday and ended with gains of 14 to 22 points.

Argentina celebrated today the 121st anniversary of its Declaration of Independence with the largest military display in its history. President Augustin P. Justo, accompanied by the Ministers of War and the Navy, reviewed a parade of 17,500 troops in the Avenida Alvear, including 3,500 from the navy.

Homer Martin, president of the United Automobile Workers, said last night that Lansing's recent labor holiday was a "mistake." Mr. Martin spoke before 800 union members and sympathizers, many of whom were leaders in the oneday holiday that paralyzed Lansing industries June 7.

DURING the past few days there has been at the bottom of this page a little advertisement suggesting that you ask about something called "My War With the United States." Whom you are to ask, or why, is not specified, but the implications are clear enough: you are supposed to go to a bookstore and say, "What is all this about some one having a war with the United States?"
An 8-weeks-old boy, "with three dark hairs," was adopted today by former Mayor Jaines J. Walker of New York and Mrs. Walker, the former Betty Compt6n.
Success of our World's Fair architecturally is already assured, provided the first two specimens in the papers are a fair sample.

Paul Blanshard, Commissioner of Accounts, in accordance with a recent decision of the Corporation Counsel, transferred yesterday to other and lower paying budget lines three Tammany-appointed members of his staff of examiners whose salaries were raised recently by the Board of Estimate above the figures recommended by the Budget Director.

Leon Blum, Edouard Herriot, Viscount Cecil of Chelwood and other international leaders today declaimed a pledge to world conciliaton in dedicating the Peace Pavilion of the League of Nations at the Paris Exposition.

Fred W. Steele of New Bedford, Mass., legislative chairman of the National Association of Cotton Manufacturers, said today that "carelessly drafted and hastily enacted labor legislation" was "one contributing factor to the present disgraceful industrial mess."

A cramatized March of Time radio program broadcast yesterday from New York, which featured the disappearance of Amelia Earhart and her navigator, Fred Noonan, resulted in an erroneous report here that Miss Earhart had been in two-way communication with naval vessels.

The Transport Workers Union, C. I. O. affiliate, won another victory in the taxicab field last night when a majority of the 1,000 employes of the Bell Transportation System, in a referendum supervised by the City Industrial Relations Board, designated it as their agent for collective bargaining.
Miss Emma A. Johnson, retired principal of the Model Training School for Teachers, New York, died here yesterday after a long illness. She was 80 years old and lived at 21 Trinity Place, this town.
The fourth broadbill of the season was brought to the dock of the Montauk Yacht Club today when C. D. Quaw, fishing on Captain Harry Conklin's Duchess, came in with a 344-pnounder.

More than 1,500 delegates of three locals of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, Chauffeurs, Stablemen and Helpers of America, representing 6,144 employes of the Borden Farm Products Company, ratified unanimously a two-year contract with their employers yesterday at a meeting held in Mecca Temple. 130 West Fifty-sixth Street.

BONGORD, MARTIN (March 25, 1935). Gross assets, $141,920: net, $133,538. To Washington County Museum of Fine Arts, Hagerstown, Md., books and books on art and $15,000 in trust; Salmagundi Club, $2,000; Riverside Community Hospital, Riverside, Calif., $1,000;

Federal Judge Frederick H. Bryant approved today settlement for $335,000 of a $1,250,000 claim of the Rochester Gas and Electric Company against Benjamin L. Tilton, trustee of New York State Railways. The order of settlement.

Newsreel pictures of the Memorial Day riot before the Republic Steel Corporation plant in South Chicago in which ten men were slain were characterized yesterday by Police Commissioner Lewis J. Valentine as "a pictorial indictment of law enforcement agencies."
Both Jews and Arabs, although disagreeing among themselves, plunged tonight into the work of organizing opposition to Great Britain's plan to partition Palestine.

Paul A. Tramuta, 34, lost part of the suit his former fiancee brought against him, but he can have her trousseau, when he pays for it. This was the ruling of Judge Walter L. Gleason who awarded to Miss Amelia Bagala, 25, the $780.43 which the young woman said she had paid for her unused troussean.
The Board of Estimate branch of the Municipal Assembly voted yesterday to override the veto of Mayor La Guardian on the Lyons Residence Bill. The bill,

A. Manuel Fox, New York economist, was nominated by President Roosevelt today to be a member of the Tariff Commission for the remainder of the term of Robert Lincoin O'Brien of Massachusetts, who resigned recently.

Mrs. Marls Warrington, who said she is an art collector known as Lady Howard, living at 91 Van Ness Avenue, Rutherford, N. J., appeared as complainant in the Felony Court yesterday when Gustav Nassauer, 65 years old, of 66 East Eighty-seventh Street, was arraigned on a grand larceny charge. He pleaded not guilty.
Wheat production in Greece this year has been estimated at 37,000,000 bushels, according to a Department of Commerce report. This is a new record for wheat growing in Greece.

In another light turnover of stocks, member trading in round lots for own account on the New York Stock Exchange was at a somewhat lower level in the week ended on June 12, representing 19.31 per cent of total volume, compared with 19.98 per cent in the week ended on June 5, according to the weekly analysis made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Boy Scouts from all over the world, happy but fatigued with the excitement and pageants of their ten-day jamboree, "broke camp" today. Tonight special trains or coaches were carrying more than 12,000 of the boys homeward.

The P. R. T. Employes Association, assailed as a "company union" by three opposing groups, won an overwhelming victory today in Mayor Wilson's collective bargaining election for Philadelphia Rapid Transit Company workers.

Miss Eleanor Trowbridge Adams, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald A. Adams of this city, was married to Ulrich Bonnell Phillips, son of Mrs. Ulrich B. Phillips and the late Professor Phillips of Yale University, this afternoon in the Dwight Memorial Chapel at Yale. Professor George Dalil of the Yale Divinity School officiated.
Slightly declining wheat prices and a return to an export basis were predicted by agricultural officials today as the government's Crop Reporting Board estimated the 1937 crop at 882,287,000 bushels.
Government employes have no right to strike, and their right to collective bargaining is severely restricted by the fact that Congress establishes their wages, President Roosevelt said today.

Miss Priscilla Jacobus, daughter of Mrs. Edmund Jacobus of this place, was married in the Park Methodist Episcopal Church here tonight to George Christiansen of Glen Ridge by the pastor, the Rev. Dr. William B. Kelly.

Because his love of history was greater than his patience, Isidore Zanger, 16 years old, of 1,607 Bathgate Avenue, the Bronx, yesterday received a suspended sentence in Bronx Special Sessions for malicious mischief.

The Dunbar National Bank in its statement of condition for June 30 reported total assets of $3,930,439, an increase of $205,000 in the six months. Deposits amounted to $3,010,518, an increase of $198,949.

The suit of the Standard Oil Company of Indiana to enjoin Esso, Incorporated, a subsidiary of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, from using the trade name "Esso" was decided in favor of the Indiana Company in an opinion handed down today by Federal Judge Moore.

Peter Heenan, Ontario Minister of Lands and Forests, said in a speech here last night that the next three years would see the expenditure in Ontario of $44,000,000 on capital account in construction of new pulp and paper mills and extension of existing mills.
The price of bar gold in London rose again yesterday to a premium over its New York shipping parity,. making it unprofitable, for the time being, to send gold here from that market.

For "bread and peace," a generation ago, the Russian soldiers deserted the armies and supported the revolution. There remains a vital connection between arms and the man, the battle line and the bread line.

From our Commissioner of Health come some encouraging statistics as to the effect of hot weather on human beings. Deaths in New York City due directly to sunstroke, Dr. RICE points out, have declined steadily from the astounding figure of 724 in 1901 to the low mark of 34 in 1936.
Churches on Morningside Heights will hold special religious services daily, starting tomorrow morning, throughout the six-week period of the Summer session at Columbia University. The Rev. Raymond C.

Comfort, colors and more "dressing up" will be the high lights of men's fashions this Fall, style trends outlined today at the convention of the International Association of Clothing Designers indicated.

While no signatures have yet been affixed to a contract, it now appears more than likely that Hannah Williams (Mrs. Jack Dempsey) will return to the stage next season in one or another of the Shuberts' musical shows-probably, it Is believed, the Ed Wynn vehicle, "Hurray for What." Miss Williams's last Broadway appearance was made some seven years ago in "Sweet and Low," during the run of which she was succeeded by her sister, Dorothy.

A more hopeful view of the Soviet industrial situation is taken today in Za Industrializatsiu, the organ of heavy industry, which has been one of the leaders in the current exposlures of industrial breakdowns.

Three persons were killed and a score injured when an ammunition depot holding 1,500 shells on the Island of Skansebanken, outside of Helsingfors, blew up this morning. The explosion followed a fire of undetermined origin in a laboratory where thirty workers were fixing detonators on shells.

The Black Diamond Steamship Lines and the Lloyd Maritime Belge won a second verdict over Arnold Bernstein, German steamship operator, in a decision rendered yesterday by the second highest court in Belgium, denying an appeal of Bernstein from an earlier decision by a board of arbitration.
For the second time in his career Henry Cotton today won the British open golf championship with an aggregate score of 290.

Seabiscuit, rated the top-notch handicap performer now in training, will face in this afternoon's renewal of the $20,000 added Butler Handicap at Empire City, thoroughbreds shipped in from other sections of the country especially to meet him. In effect the Butler,

The Seattle Star published four of its customary five editions today and planned to continue publication tomorrow under protection or police, who yesterday- disbanded an American Newspaper Guild picket line. The paper had been suspended since July 3.

Chafing under inactivity and the realization that the Senate may battle all Summer on the Judiciary Reorganization Bill, House members set up a cry of "hot weather" today and obtained a promise from the leaders of a two-week vacation starting soon, with a light legislative program when they meet sporadically.
The British plan for the partition of Palestine focuses attention on a problem much larger than the conflict between Arabs and Jews in the Holy Land.

Passengers sailing for Europe today on the Cunard White Star motor ship Georgic include L. D. Gilbert, Frank Baldwin, Miss Harriet Brigham, Dr. and Mrs. William E. Gardner, Dr. and Mrs. Ellis Jones, the Very Rev. Joseph Fenelon, Mrs. E. L. Jamison, Mrs. Walter Brown Parker and Bertram Bucknall.
Myron C. Taylor declared today he wished people "would stop" saying he was planning to retire as chairman of the board of United States Steel on Dec. 31.
A series of seven small fires last night in Bronx apartments, caused by Sabbath candles, were attributed to the heat wave by the Fire Department.

The demonstration in 1,000 cities and towns this month of small homes costing $5,000 or less was marked today when leaders in the housing movement spoke simultaneously over a coast-to-coast radio network.
Mentally deranged by the heat, Anna Dienst, 43 years old, mortally wounded her mother with a revolver at their farm here this morning and then turned the weapon upon herself.
A municipal court judge fined the city's "bad boy" Mayor, Andrew J. (Bossy) Gillis, $50 today, after convicting him of non-payment of wages to a city employee.

The Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Arthur B. Kinsolving of Baltimore have announced here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Lucinda Lee Kinsolving, to Egbert G. Leigh 3d, son of Mrs. Egbert Leigh of Richmond and Orange County, Va., and the late Mr. Leigh.

All details necessary for a new collective agreement in the coat and suit industry probably will be worked out at conferences of representatives of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union and employer groups in the industry, it was forecast last night by Samuel Klein, executive director of the Industrial Council of Cloak, Suit and Skirt Manufacturers, Inc.

Democratic opponents of the compromise Judiciary Reorganization Bill struck back today at the administration leaders in the Senate on the charges hurled at them for three days that they were attempting to wreck the Political fortunes of President Roosevelt by deserting him on this important issue.

Sweltering heat caused eleven deaths and prostrated at least thirty-five persons yesterday as the temperature in the city, shattering the season's record for the third successive day, rose to 95.3 degrees at 4:15 o'clock in the afternoon.

What is believed to be the first attempt to catch fish through the lure of ultra-violet rays at great depth will be made in Bermudian waters by two New York City lighting engineers who are scheduled to sail for the islands today on the Monarch of Bermuda with the newest available scientific devices for under-water illumination.

Miss Natalja Willard, whose engagement to Captain James C. White, U. S. A., Twelfth Infantry, was announced yesterday by her sister, Mrs. Robert Goelet, will be married in Trinity Church here probably during the first week in August.

James W. Fosburgh, in 150 E. 61st St: Mrs. Edward Roche, through Trans-Borough Corp, in 420 E. 86th St; Potter, Hamilton Co, broker. Raubi S. Goldstein, through Samuel Herzog, in 140 W. 79th St; Warren L. Marks, Daniel Brener, Inc, broker.

A vast cloud of cosmic dust near the North Pole Star, obscuring and reddening heavenly bodies in this area, and requiring astronomers to make complex corrections for established star values in the polar regions, was reported today by Dr. Harlow Shapley of Harvard Observatory.

The union of hotel, cafe and restaurant workers, overriding an appeal for labor peace by Premier Camille Chautemps, early today called a strike in their industry in Paris. Leaders said they expected the movement to spread to other cities.

Representative Cox of Georgia demanded today in a House speech that if John L. Lewis and his associates in the Committee for Industrial Organization had "unloosed a movement which they cannot control, every power of government and of law should be invoked to bring that irresponsible movement into immediate submission to the orderly processes of government."

Bids totaling $1,010,131 for the purchase of twenty-seven of the twenty-eight ships in the government's laid-up merchant fleet were accepted today by the Maritime Commission, most of them going to foreign purchasers.

Captain Max Moeller, retired marine superintendent of the North German Lloyd Line, with which he was associated for fifty-three years, died here last night at the home of his daughter, The Associated Press reported. His age was 82.
A merger of the Federal Housing Administration and the Federal Home Loan Bank Board would result in an annual saving of $3,500,000, according to Charles O. Hardy of the Brookings Institution.
Julius Heldman, national junior titleholder from the University of California, defeated Richard Bennett, another Californian,
The Alleghany Corporation reported yesterday a net loss of $65,990 in the first six months of the year, against a loss of $79,203 in the same period last year. The statement follows:

One of three WPA guards accused of roughly handling three cripples while ejecting them from the WPA office at 70 Columbus Avenue, was discharged in West Side Court yesterday by Magistrate Anthony F. Burke, when three complainants failed to identify him.

New financing scheduled for next week by two States and forty-five municipalities aggregates $12,007,807, as compared with the revised total of $11,040,601 for the past week, according to The Daily Bond Buyer of New York.

Charges made in New York on Wednesday by Miss Dorothy Frooks, National Commander of the Women World War Veterans, that women war veterans were housed in hospitals "indiscriminately" among men, white and Negro, were denied today by officials of the Veterans Administration.

A plea for temperance education and legislation, Christian unity and the preservation of American liberties was made tonight by the Rev. Dr. Daniel A. Poling, president of the International Christian Endeavor Society, in an address to 5,000 delegates to the convention here.
Vic Fleming, veteran Syracuse (N. Y.) reinsman, equaled today a 35-yearold Cleveland Grand Circuit record when he captured four races over the North Randall track.
The Federal Trade Commission today issued an order vacating and setting aside an order to cease and desist issued July 8, 1936, against Raritan Distillers Corporation of Perth Amboy, N. J.

Contracts for construction steel in the Far West showed a greater demand for structural shapes in the first half of this year than had been seen since 1933, according to Don Partridge, associate editor of Steel.

Frederic E. Craigie, publisher of The Examiner, a weekly newspaper in Catskill, N. Y., from 1890 to 1930, when he retired, died today in Oak Park, Ill. He was 79 years old. He was born in Rochester, N. Y., where he was formerly foreman of the E. R. Andrews Printing Company.

With the temperature ranging from 105 to 110 degrees for the last three days, uninterrupted field training for 2,100 metropolitan Guardsmen was concluded at Camp Smith here today with only several minor heat prostration cases having been cared for at the post hospital.

Mrs. May Brewer Connett, widow of Eugene V. Connett, retired New York hat manufacturer, died yesterday at her Summer home here after a long illness. She was 73 years old and lived at 40 Fifth Avenue, Manhattan.

The Board of Estimate will hold a public hearing in City Hall on Friday to permit expressions of opinion on the procedure to be folloved in applying its $500,000 revolving fund to bring old-law tenements into compliance with the Multip Dwellings Law.

As the site for a building to contain a motion-picture theatre and stores, the plot 100 by 100 feet at the southeast corner of Parsons Boulevard and Eighty-fourth Road, Jamaica, L. I., has been bought by Rosewood Realties, Inc., from Dr. A. A. Goldstein.
Signing of a non-agression treaty between Iran, Afghanistan, Iraq and Turkey by the Foreign Minsisters of those four countries was announced here today.

George Lansbury, former British Laborite leader, had a conversation this evening with Premier Benito Mussolini, to whom he expounded his plan for securing international peace and bringing about disarmament.
Joseph Abbott Griffin, for many years a civic leader in Syracuse and Central New York and a conspicuous figure in the city's business world, died here today. He was 75 years old.

Miss Helen Rose Greene of Floral Park, L. I., daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Alonson Greene of Syracuse, was married yesterday in St. Thomas Episcopal Church, Bellerose, L. I., to Arthur J. Busch, son of Mrs. Frederick J. Busch of Stewart Manor, L. I., and the late Mr. Busch.
Harold H. Robertson, a social worker, estimated today that 70,000 homeless persons were wandering in the San Joaquin Valley.
Deposits in the savings banks in New York State amounted on June 30 to $5,275,057,605, a decline of $3,383,410 in the quarteryear. The number of depositors was 6,078,877, a reduction of 2,614.

Henderson Brothers, investment managers, of Boston, Mass., have sent a letter to stockholders of Wheeling Steel Corporation opposing the proposed reorganization plan of that company as "unfair" to common stockholders.

The British Government has asked Sir Henry Chilton, its Ambassador to Spain, now at Hendaye, France, to report on conditions in Bilbao with a view to the possible repatriation of 4,000 Basque children now being cared for in England.

Weekly cotton statistics are as follows: British stocks, 860,000 bales, against 901,000 a week ago, 886,000 two weeks ago, 913,000 three weeks ago and 720,000 a year ago, of which American 325,000 bales, against 340,000 a week ago, 352,000 two weeks ago, 360,000 three weeks ago and 289,000 a year ago.

With the boom that big game fishing received in Nova Scotia last year, following the Michael Lerner expedition and the success of many of our anglers in those waters, the forthcoming international tuna angling cup matches are receiving considerable attention.

The sharp barking of dogs mingled with the mooing of cows and the neighing of horses yesterday in the ballroom of the Hotel New Yorker, usually the setting for dance orchestras or after dinner speakers. Four horses, five dogs,

Among the many items that add to the appeal of the World Labor Athletic Carnival at Randalls Island Stadium tomorrow are the great number of return matches involving beaten stars at the national championships last week-end who are gunning for their conquerors.

While details of the newest Packard Elektro Shaver advertising campaign will not be completed until the middle of August, the budget will be substantially increased over the previous one, Arnold Van Leer of Cowan Van Leer, which handles the account, said yesterday.

Price movements of commodity futures on the exchanges here were mixed in moderate trading activity yesterday. Scattered profit-taking and hedge selling appeared in cocoa, copper, rubber and pepper futures. Silk, hide and world sugar futures advanced. On the cash market cotton. silk, hides and oats advanced, but wheat, corn, rye, cocoa, tins, lard and rubber fell.
The construction index for railroads in the United States during 1936, with the 1910-14 activity as 100, was 143, the Bureau of Valuation of the Interstate Commerce Commission reported today.

The Catholic Daughters of America concluded their biennial convention here today with a parade of nations, emphasing the extent of the membership and the wide range of the work, as the high point of the day.

SMARTFIT SILK STOCKING CO., INC., 444 4th Ave.-By Bert F. Crawford on a claim forever $1,000. Petitions Filed-By ABRAMOWITZ JEBALTOSKY, painting and decorating, formerly 3,039 Wallace Ave.-Liabilities, $709; no assets. The members of the firm are Max Abramowitz and Philip Jebaltosky.
Bob Feller, Cleveland's young pitcher who lasted only four innings the last time he faced Detroit, is scheduled to hurl against the Tigers Sunday when the Indians close their fourgame series here.

Mrs. Edward Jacobs, national president of Hadassah, will head a delegation of eighteen women who will represent the organization at the World Zionist Congress in Zurich, Switzerland, Aug. 3, it was announced yesterday.

Figures originally withheld from complete disclosure by companies reporting to the Securities and Exchange Commission were made publio yesterday by that body "in the public interest" or because the companies had withdrawn their objections to publication.
Playing the first London game of their English tour, America's all-star lacrosse players defeated the All-England ten for the second time, 10 to 5, at White City Stadium.

The Manufacturers Trust Company is exchange agent to effect the exchange of Adams Express Company ten-year 41/4 per cent debentures for equal principal amounts of collateral trust 4 per cent distribution bonds due in 1947 and collateral trust fifty-year 4 per cent bonds due in 1948.

Bermudans are recounting another fish story. It appears that Pilot Augustus Minors, attached to the government pilot station, while awaiting a launch to take him to the station lit his last cigarette and then threw the container into St. George's Harbor.

Cuba will make settlement of its long-defaulted public works obligations through a single bond issue, it was reliably learned today as the government commission began discussions with representatives of holders of the bonds and other types of obligations.

The House approved today an appropriation of $105,000,000 for flood-control work this fiscal year. The sum was authorized in the War Department's non-military appropriation bill, aggregating $194,000,000, but the House stipulated that $52,500,000 of the flood money should come from the $1,500,000,000 work-relier fund.

Testimony that gangsters, prizefighters and a dismissed policeman were used by the Ford Motor Company to beat up and prevent agents of the United Automobile Workers of America from passing out union leaflets at the company's gates was offered today at the National Labor Relations Board hearing on a complaint charging the automobile manufacturer with violating the Wagner act.

The Securities and Exchange Commission has called a hearing for July 26 on an application by the St. Louis Gas Company, St. Louis, a subsidiary of the North American Company, for exemption from the necessity of making a declaration concurrent with the issuance of 5,000 shares of $100-par capital, stock.
" Heaven" was too hot today for energetic sports-so Father Divine's Celestial Olympics in the 1,000-acre Greenkill promised land evolved into an imitation of a sit-down strike.
A successor to the late Dr. Charles Norris, Chief Medical Examiner of the city, will be named as the outcome of a competitive examination

Several dinners were given tonight for guests who arrived today to pass the week-end at various estates in the Summer colony. Mr. and Mrs. Reginald Fincke entertained with one at their place on the ocean for Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Choate and Mr. and Mrs. Reginald Fincke Jr.

Every underdog has his day and yesterday at Ebbets Field the Dodgers had theirs. They must have gone a trifle mad, too, because when Colonel Bill Terry took his hot and dusty Giants off the field after two hours and fifteen minutes of baseball torture the Grimes clan had given the proud pennant contenders their worst beating of the year.
Edward C. Malone, a Brooklyn baseball fan for more than sixtyfive years, died on Thursday at his home, 260 Washington Avenue, Brooklyn. He was 81 years old and a native of Brooklyn.

A Japanese pearling mother ship sank with 300 tons of pearl shell valued at ?42,000 off the mouth, of the Liverpool River, and the purser and one diver were drowned. The ship, a large steel vessel, was constructed at great cost to serve a fleet of thirty luggers operating off the coast.

Dozens of Bronx children, tired of hearing complaints of the heat, started out yesterday morning to do something about it. And, much to the chagrin of employes of the Department of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity and the radio police of the Bathgate Avenue station, they succeeded.

Borough President Samuel Levy of Manhattan, a Democratio candidate for the Mayoralty nomination, challenged the right of Mayor La Guardia's commissioners to make salary increases and decreases yesterday, and on his motion the Board of Estimate voted to call for a complete list of increases granted in exempt jobs since the Mayor took office.

Governor Lehman announced today that he would not immediately fill vacancies in the Supreme Court, Second District, caused by the deaths of Justices James C. Cropsey of Brooklyn and Paul Bonynge of Locust Valley.
The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow: "The wool handlers' union has decided to end the strike and go back to work, content to let the closed shop issue drop. Meanwhile,

Bob Gray Jr., lanky Windsor (Ont.) pro, maintained his lead over a trio of invading challengers from the United States and three of Canada's best golfers in the second round of the $4,000 General Brock open golf tournament today.
A restrike call by the Steel Workers Organizing Committee for employes of Republic Steel plants here apparently failed today. Republic Steel officials said: "Not a man left the plant." Tom White,

Leaders supporting and opposing the steel strike mustered their forces tonight for a spirited electioneering campaign among 15,000 Cambria works employes in anticipation of a possible collective bargaining vote being ordered by the National Labor Relations Board.

Mrs. Catherine O'Brien, 27 years old; employed as a domestic at the home of Mrs. Alfred Turman, 2,222 East Twelfth Street, Brooklyn, gave birth to a son at 6:10 A. M. yesterday on the Avenue U station of the B. M. T. subway at East Fifteenth Street in Brooklyn.
Through a series of recent diplomatic nominations, the last of which was confirmed on Thursday, President ROOSEVELT and Secretary HULL have achieved two important purposes.

William Phillips, United States Ambassador, left tonight for Naples to meet President Roosevelt's mother, Mrs. James Roosevelt, and his son, John Roosevelt, who will arrive tomorrow from New York on the Conte di Savoia.

The significance of the development of administrative agencies as law-enforcing bodies was the topic of an address given tonight by James M. Landis, chairman of the Federal Securities and Exchange Commission, at the annual convention of the Indiana State Bar Association in the Golfmore Hotel in Grand Beach. More than 500 lawyers were present.
The American volunteers again have written a fine page in the military history of the civil war, but at least three have been killed and forty wounded as the result of present operations.

One of the largest single mortgage loans placed on an apartment property in the Bronx in several years has been negotiated by Jacob and Emil Leitner for P. and A. D. Rubin on the mutli-family building being erected at the southeast corner of the Grand Concourse and 161st Street, opposite the new Bronx County Building.
Ivan P. Akuloff, Secretary of the Central Executive Committee and second in rank to President Michael Kalinin. resigned today.

The Tigers pounded Willis Hudlin and Whitlow Wyatt for nine hits in the first three innings to account for all their runs in a 10-to-8 victory over the Indians today. The contest opened a four-game series.

Movements of livestock in the Chicago markets today, as reported by the United States Department of Agriculture, follow: HOGS Receipts, 7,000 head,. including 2,500 dlrect;- market 10c-25c lower than Thursday's average:
On the fifth day of the government's offensive General Jose Miaja issued this stirring appeal to his battling troops:

With high temperatures and clearance events stimulating the demand for all types of hot weather merchandise, retail trade this week was the most active since early Spring in many of the leading centers of distribution, the increases over last week ranging from 3 to 8 per cent,
The first half of 1937 saw an increase of 108,881 carloadings in Canada, or 9.7 per cent over the first half of last year, the Dominion Bureau of Statistics reported today.

A 2-month-old baby was killed and nine persons were injured, six seriously, at 2:30 P. M. yesterday when two automobiles collided at Sunrise Highway and Seventyeighth Street, Ozone Park, Queens, according to the police.

Premier Milan Stoyadinovitch has explained to a parliamentary cornmittee the concordat to be coneluded with the Vatican. The Premier answered opposition criticisms that it would put the Orthodox sides Church in a secondary position in comparison with the Roman Catholic Church.

Maritime labor leaders of the Atlantic and Pacific were divided yesterday in their reaction to the proposal of John L. Lewis that all workers in the shipping industry throughout the nation be organized into a single federation under the Committee for Industrial Organization.

The five Democratic county leaders, meeting for the second time in a general conference yesterday, again failed to produce a candidate for Mayor who would be satisfacfor Mayor who would be satisfactory to all factions in the party.

In connection with its study of investment companies, the Securities and Exchange Commission today called a hearing for July 15 on the TriContinental Corporation and its affiliated companies, the Broad Street Investing Company, Inc., and the Capital Administration Company, Ltd.
Syracuse and Jersey City divided a double-header today, the Chiefs coming back to take the second game, 2 to 1, after the homesters had taken the first by 1 to 0.

American democracy was compared to Soviet democracy to the distinct advantage of the latter in a session of the Central Executive Committee of the government, now meeting in the Kremlin for the adoption of regulations for the secret ballot under the new Constitution.
Charlie McCarthy, the overbred brat of the radio, is so insufferably satisfied with himself that it is risky to praise him in public. He is already in danger of bursting with vainglory.

Fire Department specifications for gasoline, fuel oil, platform trucks, explosive trucks and airport tenders, with all amendments to date, in Pamphlet form, are now on sale at the Office of the City Record, Room 2213 Municipal Building, Borough of Manhattan.
Cotton mill activity last week dropped rather sharply when the seasonal trend was unchanged. The adjusted index declined to 135.5 from 142.9 and compared with 119.7 for the week ended July 4, 1936.

The long-awaited crucial meeting of the Non-intervention Committee ended tonight with the twenty-seven nations represented in it extending a unanimous invitation to the Earl of Plymouth, representing the British Government, to make a personal effort by private negotiations to end the deadlock that has blocked its continuance.
Seven German minesweepers arrived at the Hook of Holland today and will steam up the Rhine to visit several German towns that cannot be reached by German waterways.

The judgmentagainst twenty-two Poles of German origin by a court at Chojnice has aroused bitter resentment in the Berlin press. The sentences, ranging from five months to two years, are regarded as extremely severe.

The Caledonia, four-engined flying boat of Imperial Airways, Captain Arthur Sydney Wilcockson commanding, made a perfect landing on Manhasset Bay here this afternoon at 3:40 o'clock, completing the first transatlantic westward survey flight looking to regular twenty-four hour service between New York and London.

President Roosevelt explained today that he hoped to effect the saving of $400,000,000 in operating expenses of the government during the current fiscal year by slowing down the whole Federal program rather than by discarding any part of it.

Miss Mina Kellner of 145 East Seventy-fourth Street, daughter of Mrs. Elmer R. Kellner of Chicago and San Antonio, Texas, and the late Mr. Kellner, was married to Herbert Sheldon Spencer of this city and Springfield, Mass., son of the Rev. and Mrs. John E. Spencer of Buhl, Idaho, last night in the chapel of the Brick Presbyterian Church.

The entry of Sears, Roebuck Co., into the farm tractor field and the company's award of a contract for the construction of a new Sears retail unit in Detroit to the Patterson Engineering Company of Detroit, were announced today by General R. E. Wood, president. The new tractor,

Representative Hamilton Fish, appearing before the Congressional committee investigating income tax avoidance and evasion, declared today that Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, in connection with her radio broadcasts, had been able "to avail herself of special loopholes" in the tax laws.
Richard C. du Pont of Wilmington, Del., sent his soaring plane into the thunderheads in succession today and rode them successfully for the first time in the history of the annual contests here.
Arthur Peterson, Arthur Billingham and Fred Wright Jr. were early winners today in the quarter-final matches of the State amateur championship golf tournament.
With good consumer response noted to clearance events and special promotions of seasonal merchandise, retail trade here made a better comparative showing this week than last.

United States Ambassador William C. Bullitt and Miss Ann Madison Washington attended the inauguration today of the George Washington exhibition arranged by the French National Library in commemoration of the 150th anniversary of the United States Constitution.

The Port of New York Authority announced yesterday the award of a contract for the construction of the approach to the new Lincoln Tunnel on the New Jersey side of Hudson River to George M. Brewster Son, Inc., of Bogota, N. J.
The opening day of the seventh annual Westchester Country Club Horse Show on the club grounds here today attracted a large gathering.
The Loyalist defenders of Madrid, transformed into an offensive force in the last four days, today captured Quijorna, eighteen miles west of the capital.
A few days ago word came from Eastern Colorado and Western Kansas that millions of grasshoppers were on the march, "trekking across the plains."

The Literary Guild already has selected its October book, a novel called "Famine." This is a novel of Ireland by Liam O'Flaherty, the first he has written since the prizewinning motion-picture version of his "The Informer" was released, It will be published by Random House on Sept. 28.

The War Department released the following orders to; day, dated July 8: COLONELS Householders, E. R., Adjutant General's Department, one day leave, July 10. Poillon, A., Cav., Harrisburg, Pa., to Camp Dix, N. J.
Lester W. Herzog, up-State WPA Administrator, said in a statement today that there was "no intention at the present time to make any drastic cuts in WPA relief working forces."

A scale model of an outrigger canoe was presented to President Roosevelt today by two Hawaiian Boy Scouts who have been attending the Jamboree here. The boat was constructed of koa wood, embellished with a sail of tapa cloth, and was said to be complete in every detail.

The marriage of Miss June Elizabeth Smith, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert George Smith of West Orange, to Theodore Hart Perry of Neenah, Wis., son of Mrs. Leslie L. Perry of Chicago and the late Mr. Perry, took place this evening at the home of the bride's parents.

Maybe it was the heat, or the humidity, or a little of both. Whatever it was, the Yankees just couldn't shake off their Washington habits yesterday at the Stadium, where they opened a weekend series against Bucky Harris's Senators.

To the Editor of The New York Timea: Since the workingman is being protected by legislation in every sphere of economic activity, why not extend adequate protection to him after he joins a union and also insure his children against the day when unions that now welcome him with open arms will close their books against newcomers?
The four-story apartment building at 354 Seventy-fifth Street, Brooklyn, containing twenty-six suites, has been sold by the Franklin Savings Bank to a client of Henry D. Agar, Inc. The house,

Edward I. Aaron, former employee of THE NEW YORE TIMES, died last night in St. Luke's Hospital of an infection following an operation. Mr. Aaron, whose home was at 201 West 108th street , was 60 years old.

Arkane, Inc., Elsie Crane Porter, vice president, gave a second mortgage to Albert C. Bristol for $9,000, due May 1, 1942, at 6 per cent, the plot on the south side of 30th St., 125 feet west of 11th Ave., 150x100, subject to a first for $35,000.
Germany's tennis aces, Baron Gottfried von Cramm and Heinrich Henkel, virtually clinched a berth in the Davis Cup interzone final against the TTnited States today.

George Steinweg's nose was broken in an automobile accident a year ago and since then he had been so confused he neglected his foreign exchange business, he explained in General Sessions yesterday when he pleaded guilty to the theft of $1,000 from a patron.
This correspondent learns that close connections are being made between Konrad Henlein's Sudeten German Nazi party in Czechoslovakia and the Austrian Nazis and Pronounced Nationals.
Nicholas John Tynan, baritone soloist for eighteen years at St. Patrick's Cathedral in Newark, died at his home here yesterday after a two-week illness. He was in his fifty-second year.

Net outstanding advances of the Federal Home Loan Bank of New York reached a new high level of $19,084,080 on June 30, according to George L. Bliss, president. This compared with $16,113,360 a year previously.
Miss Emily E. England, for fifteen years secretary to the late Florenz Ziegfeld and his wife, Billie Burke, died in the Mount Vernon Hospital today after a week's illness. Her age was 65.
The story of how a new delivery truck was "burned to the ground" was told before Justices Bayes, Salomon and Kozicke in Special
Mr. and Mrs. William W. Coleman, who are passing July at Marthas Vineyard, Mass., will motor through Canada before their return to New York. They plan to stop at Lake George on the return trip.
The total number of unemployed throughout the United States was reduced between April and May more than 600,000, it was reported yesterday by the National Industrial Conference Board.
The House Interstate Commerce Committee sent to the floor today legisnation that would broaden powers of the Federal Trade Commission to deal with unfair and- deceptiv trade practices.
